column2: The appointment of Mr. JAMES H. BLOUNT of Georgia as Minister to Hawaii is a natural sequence to the extremely satisfactory performance of his duties as Special Commissioner. He has shown great good sense, prudence, and a rare capacity to attend to the business of the Government and to none other since his arrival in Honolulu.

The British fleet sailed yesterday morning for Bermuda, and as the vessels steamed down the river they were saluted by the men-of-war and by the heartiest cheers from the sailors of all the nations represented, including the American men-of-war's men.
The railway mortgage market was moderately active and irregular. The features were Northern Pacific 5s. Rock Island 5s, and Erie seconds. The principal changes were:

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 1O. -- Ex-Mayor Gleason is full of wrath. For nearly two years Long Island City has used two of his buildings for school purposes, one in the First Ward, the other, a high school, in the Fourth Ward, and he has not had a cent of rent from the city for them in that time.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The cotton crop report to the Department of Agriculture for May relates to the progress of cotton planting and contemplated acreage. The proportion of the proposed breadth already planted on the 1st of May was 85.3 per cent. which approaches very closely the area usually planted at that date, which is estimated at 86 per cent.

It is announced in Paris that the little Gallican flock, whereof Hyacinthe Loyson was the sole pastor, has passed under the jurisdiction of the Oud Katholicke Kerke -- the Old Catholic Church of the Netherlands.

-- W.J. Andrews has shipped his string of thirteen horses to Belmont Park, Philadelphia. It will undoubtedly be the strongest stable out during the Spring, as it includes Mascot. George Sherman. 2:24 1/4; Annie Wilkes, 2:21 1/2; Globard, 2:24; Warwitch, 2:22 3/4; Electrician, 2:24 1/4; Nellie Aldine, and others. Andrews says they are ready to race now, but he will remain at Belmont until June 1, when he will go to Pimlico Park, Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The State Department expresses perfect security in the care that Minister Blount will exercise over United States interests in Hawaii. As long as Minister Stevens was in power, there seemed, to be reason to believe that the revolution which, the United States made successful would be perpetuated only by the active interference of this Government.

As the shades of night were falling over Jamaica Bay yesterday, a band of New-York baseball enthusiasts might have been seen filing out of the gate f Eastern Park, with heavy hearts and light pockets. They had witnessed the slangher or their innocents for the third successive time, and lost all the money that the Brooklyn sports had the nerve to cover.

Relief from the difficulties which befell Wall Street through the order of Chancellor McGill of New-Jersey closing the transfer books of the National Cordage Company was secured yesterday. After looking into the matter a little more, the Chancellor granted another order permitting the consolidation of existing certificates into larger blocks or the splitting up of certificates into smaller lots, but not allowing a change in the names of holders on the company's books.

RICHMOND, Va., May 10. -- Gov. McKinney of this State has been devoting considerable attention to the tax laws of New-York. The Virginia Executive believes that a large part of the personal property escapes taxation. He will recommend the Legislature which meets this Winter to appoint a State Board of Assessors.
Mr. J. Rogers Maxwell's steel schooner Emerald was successfully launched at the yard of Samuel Moore Sons Company at Elizabeth port yesterday afternoon.

Some weeks ago we put in a plea for raising the medical service of the navy to a higher plane of efficiency by appointing to its head as the successor of Surgeon General BROWN, who went upon the retired list yesterday, one of the medical officers who are still in the prime of life and vigor, and who would have at least a full term to serve before retirement for age.

By superior all-around play the Staten Island Athletic team defeated the Yale Law School players yesterday. The game was played at Staten Island and was witnessed by many ladies. Sharpe and Bowers, who pitched for Yale, were hit hard and were given poor support. The score:

Alfred Bishop Mason, a Director of the Cottonseed Oil Trust, will probably look after the business affairs of Mrs. Harriet Hubbard Ayer, who was recently declared insane on the application of her divorced husband.

President Morris K. Jesup of the Board of Trustees of the American Museum of Natural History sent a communication to the Park Commissioners, which was read at their meeting yesterday afternoon, in which he enclosed a resolution adopted by the Trustees, in which they declared that the best interests of the museum would be subserved by refraining from building a lecture hall at this time.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The President to-day made the following appointments:

The Single Tax League of Kings County held a public meeting in the Art Association's rooms on Montague Street, Brooklyn, last night. There were about forty persons present, but every one of them was hot for municipal reform.

James R. Smith, an actor who played the role of Sorrowful Smith in the play, the "Cadi," is suing Stuart Robson for $1,220. Mr. Robson brought out the "Cadi" at the Union Square Theatre, and engaged Smith for thirty weeks at a salary of $55 per week.

Preparations for receiving the special investigating commission appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to look into the workings of the Customs Service at this port were begun at the Custom House yesterday. An office near the quarters of the Civil Service Examining Boards, usually occupied by one of the Deputy Collectors, has been set apart for the commission's use.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The May returns of the Department of Agriculture on the condition of Winter wheat show a reduction of 2.1 points from the April average, being 75.3 against 77.4 last, month and 84 in May. 1892. The averages of the principal Winter wheat States are: Ohio, 88; Michigan, 71; Indiana, 79; Illinois, 62; Missouri, 72; Kaneas, 51.

Some five or six hundred German folks, a large proportion of whom were women and children, gathered in the gymnasium of the Bloomingdale Turn Verein, 305 West Fifty-fourth Street, last night to witness the second benefit entertainment of the season given by the score or more of members who are to represent the society at Milwaukee, next July.

At 184 Fifth Avenue the store of Messrs. C. G. Gunther's Sons may be seen for a few days to come, prior to its removal to Chicago for the World's Fair, one of the most magnificent exhibitions of costly fur wraps, robes, and cloaks that has ever gladdened woman's eye and made her feel that it was indeed good to be alive.

It was brought out in the Court of General Sessions yesterday that Mr. Edward S. Stokes. who served a term in Sing Sing, from Oct. 29, 1873, to Oct. 28, 1876. for the killing of James Fisk. had been restored to citizenship.
The following bid and asked prices for unlisted and investment securities were reported by Messrs. Tobey Kirk, 8 Broad Street:
The White Star steamship Majestic arrived yesterday after a fairly rapid passage of 6 days 3 hours and 28 minutes. There was rough weather on only one day, last Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Pension Department believes that it has unearthed stupendous pension frauds.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., May 10. -- The Brown-Yale game here to-day was the most exciting contest ever witnessed on Lincoln Field. Not a run was scored by either side until the eleventh inning, this being due to Carter's splendid pitching for Yale and the great support given Sexton. Carter struck out fourteen of the Brown men, and until the concluding inning they were unable to do anything with his delivery.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Jesse Johnson, representing the Republican organization of Kings County; Almet F. Jenks, Corporation Counsel of Brooklyn, and John B. Meyenborg, counsel for the Kings County Board of Supervisors, were before Judge Peckham of the Court of Appeals to-day to have formally issued the order of the court which arises from the decision, written by Judge Peckham, providing for a reapportionment of Assembly districts in Kings County.
NEW-YORK. -- Thomas L. Manson, Jr., takes the place of Francis L. Eames as Chairman of the Clearing House Committee of the Stock Exchange.

There is a peculiar interest to more than 75,000 Irishmen in the forty-fourth annual convention of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, in affiliation with the Board of Erin, now being held in Tammany Hall.

The beggars have flocked to Chicago. This welcome news comes from the eleventh annual report of the Charity Organization Society. The Secretary finds that there has been a marked decrease in the number of vagrants and homeless people during the last six months, and most of them have swarmed to the World's Fair.

The remarkable circumstances attending the escape from Sing Sing of the condemned murderers Roehl and Pallister have kindled in the minds of the detectives of this city some reminiscences of prison escapes, many or which almost rival the recent escape in adroitness and daring.

CHICAGO, May 10. -- To-day was the first warm, ennshiny day the World's Fair has seen, and it made the most of it. Not until to-day was a real idea of the exposition, when it gets in full blast possible. The attendance was large, and Midway Plaisance secured most of the popular interest and held it against the larger attractions of the main grounds.
Just before the British fleet sailed yesterday, officers in that fleet are reported to have stated that 180 seamen had deserted from the four British ships during their stay in this port.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 10. -- William R. Hennig, a, diamond importer of 101 West Fourteenth Street, New-York, had a brief but rather costly wrestle with Long Island City justice this morning. He was given the choice of paying a fine of $25 or going to jail for twenty-five days. He chose the pecnniary alternative. He also had his handsome bowie knife confiscated.

Yesterday's proceedings in the trial of Plan Clerk James H. Pigott, one of the indicted Brooklyn Columbians, was full of interest. The indictment charges him with defrauding the City of Brooklyn by presenting false bills for the construction of stands from which the Aldermen and their friends viewed the parade of last October.

The sale of G.W. Crawford's saddle and harness horses at Tattersall's repository was concluded yesterday. Thirty head realized $5,280, an average of $176 per head. The attendance was slim, very few of the society people -- who pay good prices for anything they fancy -- being present. The seventy-four head sold during the two days brought $15,305, a very fair average of $208.

There have been few more Impressive funeral services in New-York than those which were held yesterday morning in St. Bartholomew's Church, in Madison Avenue, over the body of Mrs. Elise Hegeman Depew, wife of Chaunoey M. Depew.
ALBANY, May 10. -- Gov. Flower signed a number of bills to-day, the more important of which were the following:
The new Herald Building presented a very rare and, in some respects, a uniqne architectural opportunity, of which, upon the whole, Mr. Bennett's architect has taken admirable advantage.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 10. -- The Saratoga Gon Club was blessed with magnificent Spring weather to-day, and the attendance was even heavier than yesterday. The grounds are situated near the Saratoga race track in an exposed position, and to-day the shooting was extremely hard, owing to a strong rear wind, which caused the light kingbirds to describe some peculiar motions.

LONDON, May 10. -- The British Imperial Institute was opened to-day with brilliant ceremony by Queen Victoria. The sun shone brightly. It was what the British call "Queen's weather," and the occasion was, therefore, most propitious for the homage of her Majesty's subjects upon this, which, it is said, will be her last public appearance.

When little Mercedes Crimmins, the sevenyear-old daughter of John D. Crimmins, with cheeks as pink as her cap, twisted a nickelplated wheel in the big basement of the building on the northwest corner of Broadway and Houston Street at 5:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon she set hundreds of tons of ponderous machinery in motion, and in an instant the traction cables were running from Fiftieth Street to the Battery.

When a person of depraved nature and criminal conduct is put to death by authority of the State as a penalty for taking human life and as a deterrent to others for the protection, of society, there is apt to be an outcry against the barbarity of the act from, sentimentalists who are guided rather by feeling than judgment.

BOSTON, May 10. -- Walter Emerson, the cornet player, was to-day granted a divorce from his wife, Midora M., by Justice Richardson. The charge made by Mr. Emerson was that his wife, who is said to be in London, has been unfaithful.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 10. -- The revenue cutter McLane, Capt. Littlefield commanding, which, was telegraphed for by order of the Secretary of the Treasury to return to this port immediately, on account of the demonstrations of the Cuban filibusters here and reports of an expedition being fitted out to sail for Cuba, arrived here at 7 P.M. to-day.

While Thomas McGuinness, well known to clubmen and athletes in Jersey City, was in Madison Avenue, on Jersey City Heights, yesterday morning, a woman of stalwart frame walked up to him. The moment she got within arm's reach she struck out with her right hand and hit him squarely between the eyes. A moment later her left was planted behind his jaw as he turned to retreat.

CINCINNATI, May 10. -- One of the largest meetings of stockholders of the Big Four -- the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railway Company -- met here to-day to vote upon one of the largest financial transactions within its history. More than 200,000 shares of common stock and 75,OOO of preferred stock were represented, which makes up three-fourths of the issue.

SING SING, May 10. -- It was on April 20, when Mr. Brown was the Warden of Sing Sing Prison, that Frank W. Roehl and Thomas Pallister, murderers awaiting execution, escaped from the death house and left the two keepers whose duty it was to watch them looked up in the cells which they had occupied.

From the time when the rulers of Japan, discovered the true nature of the treaties signed in ignorance of the obligations to which, they bound themselves, their most strenuous efforts have been devoted to procuring the abrogation of these agreements and regaining the independence they unwittingly surrendered.

American visitors to the famous old royal nursery or fruit trees at Herrenhaussen, near Hanover, Germany, will find that its gloriea have departed. On the 1st of April last it was closed by the Government, which desired the location for other purposes.

The citizens of the town of New-Utrecht, which is a southern suburb of Brooklyn, have taken vigorous steps to rid themselves of the gas octopus which Supervisor and Shore Inspector Cornelius Furgueson and his friends have sought to fasten on them for all time.

A.T. KIECKHOEFER, a well-known retired banker of Baltimore. Md.. is dead, aged eighty-eight years. Mr. Kieckhoefer was born in Hamburg. Germany, in 1804. He passed his youth in England, France, and Brazil in commercial enterprises. He came to this city in 1832, and was associated with the firm of Brown Brothers Co., bankers. Upon the dissolution of the banking firm of Corcoran Riggs in Washington.

George Gould and Robert M. Galioway, with ex-Judge John F. Dilion and Julien T. Davies as counsel, met the Rapid-Transit Commissioners yersterday afternoon at Mr. Steinway's house for a conference upon the pending proositions for elevated railroad extensions. They went over the subject in detail, spending several hour upon it and indicating pretty well how the two sides regard the matter.
The Prospect Heights Tennis Club of Brooklyn began its Spring tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Union Street, near Eighth Avenue. The result of the afternoon's play was as follows:
S. T. K. Prime of Dwight, Ill, whose weekly reports on the crops and statistics on industrial topics have been published widely, is in this city after a visit of several weeks in California.

The department of music of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences gave its eleventh concert of the season last night at Plymouth Church. There were few vacant seats when the conductor, Mr. W. H. Neidlinger, took up his baton.

The story of the differences between the two orders of Hibernians, as told exclusively in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES, came with all the force of a great surprise to the 500 delegates who assembled in Tammany Hall yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The American Hunt and Pony Racing Association to-day opened a three days' meeting at the Bennings course. The tract was fast, but the attendance small.

The unfounded report from Washington circulated yesterday that Secretary Gresham had received from Russia the draft of the extradition treaty which bears the Czar's signature and had turned it over to President Cleveland, who had at once signed the duplicate, caused a feeling or sadness among Russians in this city.

BOSTON, May 11 -- There are now in process of construction at toe shop of Alvan Clark Sons, Cambridgeport, two huge telescopic instruments which are soon destined to interest greatly the general public as well as astronomical students. These machines are the enormous forty-inch-lens telescope, which la almost completed, for the Kenwood Observatory of the University of Chicago, and the Bruce photographic telescope, which is being made for the Astronomical Observatory of Harvard College.

Charles N. Gyllenhammer married Augusta Hanson, a servant girl, on Sept. 8, 1881. She had her life insured lor $5,000 in his favor on Nov. 15, 1891, and on Feb. 12, 1692, three months later, she died.

GRAND HAVEN, Mich., May 11. -- Half of the village of Spring Lake, a short distance from here, was destroyed by fire to-day. The steamer Barrett, in passing up the river at 7 o'clock this morning. set fire to a sawdust pile by sparks from her smokestack. A stiff gale was blowing and in an hour the greater part of the residence portion of the town was burning.

Plans are now being made for an Industrial art exhibition, to be held at the Madison Square Garden next October, upon a scale of high quality and elaboration of detail much larger than any ever before attempted in this country, not excepting the exhibit of that nature at Chicago. Mr. Stanford White is expected back from Europe within a few days, and immediately upon his return work upon the details of the show will begin.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Two weeks ago a revolution broke out in Nicaragua. To-day, according to the latest account received at the State Department, the Government that was in power a fortnight ago has been overthrown, and there seems to be small probability that the revolution will be reversed.
Ellis Island was in a ferment yesterday. More than 4,000 immigrants bad to be looked after, and 947 by the Majestic had to be registered and inspected under the new immigration law.

The jewelry seized last week at 92 Berry Street, Williamsburg, estimated at the time of the seizure to be worth $100,000, has been appraised by experts at less than one-third of that sum. The report of the appraisal filed yesterday contained the following inventory:

Julius Ruff, forty-eight years, of 1,676 Avenue A, and John Murphy, a stripling, who lived with his parents at 314 West Forty-ninth Street, were launched to death from a scaffold yesterday afternoon at 14 West Sixty-fifth Street, and Otto Boelsen, a painter, of 5 Grand Circle, was arrested for criminal carelessness. He gave ball.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 11. -- The announcement of the failure of R.R. Robinson Co., bankers and brokers of this city, to-day created a profound sensation, although rumors of the probable failure of the firm have been on the street for several days. The Sheriff has seized all the property of the bankrupt concern.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 11. -- The trainhouse and powerhouse of the Grand View Beach Electric Road, which runs along the lake shore for several miles, were burned to the ground this morning. Thirteen out of fourteen cars, 300 tons of coal stored for the Summer traffic, and all the tools and appliances were destroyed. The loss is $60,000, but is covered by insurance.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- Cornell University outplayed the University of Pennsylvania in an interesting game here to-day.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 11. -- A certificate of the consolidation of the New-York, New-Jersey and Eastern Railroad Company and the New-York and New-Jersey Underground Railway Company, to form the Brooklyn, New-York and Jersey City Terminal Railroad Company, was filed in the office of the Secretary of State today.

At a meeting of Good Government Club B, held last evening in Lyceum Hall, 225 West Ninety-ninth Street, Mr. George H. Baker presiding, reports were presented from several branches of the City Reform Club on the progress made in the work of organization.
ALBANY, May 11. -- Gov. Flower has vetoed the following bills:

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 11. -- If the New-York Central officials wanted a record for their new engine. No. 999, preparatory to exhibiting her at the World's Fair, they have got one now that beats the world. It Is 112 1/2 miles an hour.

Judge Ingraham, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday sentenced Dr. R.F. Jones Atwell, a well-known Hoboken physician, to two years and five months in State prison, after going carefully over the facts in the bigamy charge to which the doctor pleaded guilty.
Did Carlyle W. Harris leave a wife?

LONDON, May 11. -- Hallett Co., navy agents and bankers, have suspended. Their suspension has caused a sensation in military and naval circles at the West End, as many officers are depositors with the company, but commercially the failure is of slight Importance.
Dr. Charles Carroll Lee, President of the Medical Society of the County of New-York, died on Wednesday night at his residence, 79 Madison Avenue, of heart failure following an attack of pleurisy.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 11. -- Two weeks ago Jeff Barthel, an Italian, who owns a small farm at Centre Bridge, in Conway County, near Morrillton, suddenly became insane, and jumped into a well and drowned himself. Barthel had a wife and several children and two brothers. John and Alexander, who lived on the farm with him.

NEWARK, May 11. -- Frederick L. Flohn, a real estate agent. whose name has been frequently compromised in connection with money scandals, was arraigned in the Court ol Sessions today on three indictments charging him with embezzlement.

LONDON, May 11. -- In the House of Commons to-day, in committee on the Home Rule Bill, William Redmond, Parnellite, moved as an amendment to the bill that the two branches of the Irish Legislature should be designated the Senate and the House of Commons.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., May 11. -- Little Flora Sterling, the interesting five-year-old daughter of Dr. Sterling of Sag Harbor, L. I., alarmed her parents greatly yesterday and missed losing her life by the narrowest margin.

BERLIN, May 11. -- The preparations for the elections of June 15 are being vigorously pushed by the various parties. Herr Eugen Richter, the leader of the stronger section of the Freisinnige, now known as the Freisinnige Volkapartel, or Radical People's Party, addressed an enthusiastic meeting of the , party in behalf of the candidacy of Prof. Rudolf Virchow, who has been put forward for the Reichstag.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 11. -- An important suit for infringement and damages, it is said, to the amount of $500,000, has been brought against the Winchester Avenue and West Haven Electric Road of this city and the Westinghouse parent corporation in Pittsburg and New-York. The suit is one to restrain these concerns from using the trolley.

There must be some special virtue to April and May in the minds of Academicians and members of the Society of American Artists, otherwise they would not hold the annual shows of the greatest importance at this season, when everybody is tired from the rush of Winter work and play and many among those who can so arrange it have already left for Europe or the country.

President Van Horne of the Canadian Pacific Railway has again been getting himself interviewed in the Montreal papers -- the Daily Witness and the Gazette. In these interviews he sweepingly denies the articles which have been printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES recently, charging him with gross mismanagement of the railroad or which he is President, but does not deign to go into details.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 11. -- Wright Brody is one of Georgia's prominent statesmen. As Representative from Sumter County for several terms he has won more than ordinary renown. But Mr. Brody's legislative renown pales into insignificance beside his matrimonial renown. Three years ago the Board of Directors of the Georgia Experimental Farm, of which Brody is a member, passed resolutions condoling with that gentleman over the death of his wife.

The second case this season of the detention of a vessel at Quarantine occurred yesterday, when the North German Lloyd liner Lahn arrived from Bremen with three oases of smallpox on board. The patients were George Bullinger, aged twenty-five; Johanna Matthias, aged twenty, and Adam Sutterer, aged twenty.

From various sources Wall Street heard yesterday that the uncertainty it had been experiencing about the National Cordage Company's finances was fully equaled by the tangle of affairs connected with the commercial operation of the trust.

A number of public men discussed the office seekers in Washington yesterday afternoon, and all who had anything to say with reference to the recent order of President Cleveland declared that it was a good thing.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2@5 cent. The last loan was made at 2 1/2 cent.

The Irish Independent Parliamentary Party met last night at the Dublin Club, 103 East Thirty-second Street, for the purpose of selling the boxes for their concert to be held at the Academy of Music on Sunday evening next.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., May 11. -- Within the last ton days there have boon nine burglaries, two of which were or Post Offices, in this neighborhood; three at Hagerman's Mills, three at Fultonville, and three at Fort Hunter. The store of Findlay Cole, at Fort Hunter, was broken Into and robbed last night.

The Columbia College Tennis Club will hold an interscholastic tennis tournament for the schools of New-York and vicinity, at the Columbia Oval, William's Bridge. The preliminary matches will bagin Tuesday, May 16, at 3:30 P.M. This chance is to enable the contestants to take part without interfering with their school work. Entries have been received from Howard School, Cutler. Berkeley, Wilson, and others.
PATCHOGUE, L. L, May 11. -- The first convention of the Epworth League Societies of Long Island assembled in the Methodist Episcopal Church here this morning. Five hundred delegates were present.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 11. -- The steamer Danube, which arrived here several days ago with 612 Chinamen aboard, left last night for Victoria with 410 of the Celestials, having succeeded In landing only 2O2. The Tacora is expected here to-day with another cargo of Chinamen.

MADRID, May 11. -- The Republicans and Carlists are making a persistent and strong fight against the Government bill providing for a postponement of the municipal elections until November. Both groups have followed a course of unremitting obstruction in the Cortes. The Deputies have set Tor thirtj- hours without intermission, and the Opposition show no signs of wavering.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The extradition treaty with Russia has not yet reached the State Department, but is expected here by the next European mail. Reports as to its receipt here are said by confidential officials at the White House and at the State Department to be destitute of truth.

Commissioner of Street Improvements of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards Louis F. Haffen yesterday appointed Joseph P. Hennessy Secretary of his department at $3,OOO per year, to succeed William H. Ten Eyok, Republican, removed. Mr. Ten Eyok is the Republican leader in the Twenty-third Ward. His successor, Mr. Hennessy, thirty-seven years of age, is a member of the law firm of Spellissy Hennessy.

The national fencing championships were decided last night at the Berkeley Lyceum. They were held under the direction of the Amateur Fencers' League of America and the Amateur Athletic Union. The preliminary bouts were decided a few weeks ago and the finals last night resulted in some very lively contests.

The name of the new dramatic school recently organized by Mr. Nelson Wheatcroft has been changed from "Empire Theatre Dramatic Collage" to "Empire Theatre Dramatic School," for reasons explained in the following interesting letter from Mr. Melvil Dewey, Secretary of the University of the State of New-York and Director of the State, Library, to Mr. Wheatcroft:

Creedmoor was occupied yesterday by a battalion of the Seventh Regiment, composed of Companies A and D. under the command of Major Kipp, and numbering 181 officers and men, inclusive of some of the field, staff, and non-commissioned staff and stragglers from other companies. Capt. W.H. Palmer, Regimental Inspector of Rifle Practice, was in charge of the shooting.

PARIS, May 11. -- The Hon. James B. Eustia, American Ambassador, was present to-day at the session of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration. Sir Charles Russell resumed his argument, which was largely devoted to the technical features of the controversy.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Headers of the Century Magazine will be very much interested in the exhibit made by the Century Company in the northwest corner of the Liberal Arts Building. A reception was given there to-day by William W. Ellsworth, Secretary of the company, to New-York people and distinguished personages from other States.

BOSTON, May 11 -- General Electric recovered about all of yesterday's decline to-day. The preferred sold up to 103, against 90 yesterday, on small transactions. Arbitragers were very active in all New-York stocks in the morning, but trading quieted down in the afternoon. Bell Telephone declined to 181 and rose later to 184.

William Givens, who has been on trial in Judge Lippineott's court, Jersey City Heights. for several days for the shooting and murder of Patrick Ward at Bayonne last September, was convicted of manslaughter yesterday and sentenced to ten years' imprisonment.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 11. -- Things In general have been decidedly lively in Republican league circles since the delegates returned from the Kentucky Derby on Wednesday. The League and the National Committee went with all Louisville to see that famous race. Politics were forgotten for the time, and candidates for the Presidency and Secretaryship ot tho league declared a truce and became true Kentuckians until the Derby was run.
CHICAGO, May 11. -- The Columbia National Bank, capital $1,000,000, suspended to-day and is in the hands of the Bank Examiner by order of the Controller of the Currency.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11. -- At last the Giants have found a club that they can beat. They came here to-day and iron an old-fashioned game from the Philadelphias after a contest marked by the heaviest kind of batting on both sides. The visitors made 20 and the local players 16 hits, including home runs, Triples, and doubles.

CANARSIE, L. I., May 11. -- The trial of the case of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals against Joseph Reyner came off in Justice Matthews's court at Canarsie Village this afternoon. It went against the defendant.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day Calumet Canal sold at 59@58. Diamond Match at 120, Lake Street Elevated at 24. North Chicago broke 2 3/4 points, to 256 for the account, and then to 255. West Chicago opened 41/4 points off, at 174, and sold to 170, reacting to 175. Strawboard sold at 64.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- A novel case has come up for the decision of the Treasury Department in its enforcement of the customs laws. It involves the question of the character of natural gas, whether It comes under the tariil laws as a mineral product or in any other way.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- The committee of the National Commission, which has been investigating the music row, made its report to-day, and in it said that the usefulness of Theodore Thomas at the head of the Bureau of Music was so impaired that in their judgment his services should be further dispensed with, and recommended that the Director General be Instructed to request his resignation.

On the membership rolls of the Deutscher Verein, better known as the German Club, which occupies one of the handsomest clubhouses in this city, at 112 West Fifty-ninth Street, can be found the names of the most exclusive German residents of this city.

SING SING, May 11. -- Another body of a man was seen floating in the Hudson River to-day, and there are many persons in Sing Sing who believe that it was the body of Thomas Pallister, the second of the two murderers who escaped from the death cell chamber at the prison on the night of April 20.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 11. -- The Capital National Bank of this city suspended this morning. The statement is made that the closing of the bank's doors was made necessary by the failure of the Chemical National Bank of Chicago last week, which institution owed the Capital $100,000. The bank also carried a large amount of Premier Steel Works paper.

Arrangements were completed yesterday at a meeting of the National league for Good Roads, at 45 Broadway, by Gen. Roy Stone, August Belmont, Chauncey B. Ripley, ex-Gov. George P. Wetmore, Augustus T. Gillender, and other members of the league, to make an exhibit of a roadway 50 feet wide and 1,000 feet In length at the World's Fair in Chicago.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club, the central body of kindred, organizations flourishing in all but three of the wards of the City of Churches, with an enrolled membership of 18,000 voters, evidently does not cease to exist when a campaign ends.

PANAMA, via Galveaton, May 11. -- Newspapers receive from Costa Rica say that the fight between the Government and the revolutionists in Nicaragua is centring at Masaya, and bids fair to be a long and stubborn one. The country around Masaya others line strategic positions to the armies. Most of those positions are in the hands of the revolutionists.

Commissioner Brennan of the Street-Cleaning Department had a strike on his hands yesterday. About 120 cart drivers in his department "went out" because, as they claimed, they were compelled to haul too many loads of garbage and ashes per day. They said that it was too much to ask a cartman to haul from eight to ten loads a day.

NEWARK, N.J., May 11. -- A man who described himself as A.F. Smith, a New-York lawyer, thirty years old, was arrested here to-night for attempting to shoot a woman known only as Miss Johnson, who for several weeks has boarded at the Women's Christian Home at 104 Court Street.

The thousands who lined Fifth Avenue and Broadway yesterday afternoon witnessed a sight which they will not soon forget. It was the columns of handsomely-uniformed Knights Templars, forming a brilliant pageant, and marching to historic St. Paul's Church to celebrate Ascension Day.

The tara and marines of the cruiser Baltimore were at none to their friends yesterday from noon till 5 o'clock. Their guests were the sailors from the other ships, thirty from each manof-war in the river.
DETROIT. Mich., May 11. -- At to-day's session of the National League of Musicians, Baltimore was selected as the place, and May 1. 1894, the time for holding the next National Convention.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 11. -- When the French schooner Rosa left St. Pierre on May 2 for North Sydney under command of Capt. Dufresne she was manned by a crew of six Frenchmen, but when she reached Sydney she was in charge of a prize crew from Neil's Harbor. The men stated that the vessel had been abandoned on Friday last and that they were entitled to salvage for bringing her into port.

The current number of the Dry Goods Economist contains interviews with a number of merchants in this city. Boston, Philadelphia, and Chicago regarding the present prospects of trade as shown by their experience and observation. Several things are made plain by the expressions of these gentlemen. One, and perhaps the most important with reference to the immediate future, is that the dry goods business throughout the country has, on the whole, been conducted prudently.

Hiram Stone, who is twenty-nine years old and flue-looking, was placed on trial before Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with assaulting Miss Daisy Schmid of Bridgeport, Conn., in a houso in East Fifteenth Street, on Sept. 15, 1892.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., May 11. -- John Monks, senior member of the firm of John Monks Son, wharf builders, of Water Street, New-York, met with a peculiar and distressing accident while on his way to Southampton, L. L., from New-York yesterday.

LONDON, May 11. -- William Townsend, the man arrested on the charge of having discharged a pistol in Downing Street, and also suspected of having designed to kill Prime Minister Gladstone, was brought up in the Bow Street Police Court to-day, and again arraigned on the firstmentioned charge. Townsend was also charged to-day with having sent a, menacing letter to Mr. Gladstone, which was read in court.

The sixty-first annual convention of the Alpha Delpha Phi Fraternity was begun yesterday morning in the lodgeroom of the Masonic Temple, at Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue. Clarence A. Seward of this city, President of the fraternity, presided, and Robert S. Rudd of Hamilton College was the Secretary.
The pigeon shooters of the Larchmont Yacht Club were cut in full force yesterday to witness the final matches of the year. All the contests were handicaps, and some very good shooting was witnessed.

The Feast of the Ascension was, celebrated yesterday with appropriate ceremonies in the Protestant Episcopal and the Roman Catholic churches of this city. In the Catholic Church the day was observed as a holiday of obligation.

-- The shareholders of the Canadian Pacific Railroad Company at their annual meeting in Montreal last Wednesday authorized the issue of $8.000.000 preferred stock it 4 per cent. In addition to the ordinary stock of the company now outstanding. The company has deposited $4.000.000 In the Bank of Montreal to meet any deficiency at any time in maintaining dividends at 5 per cent on ordinary stock.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The political situation in Erie County, N. Y., will be the subject of a conference between Mr. Cleveland and a delegation of home-rule Democrats from Buffalo Friday. The delegation is composed of George Bleistein, proprietor of the Buffalo Courier; Herbert P. Bissell, the law partner of Postmaster General Bissell; Mayor Charles F. Bishop, John McManus, and M. Rozan.

The interesting fact has been reported in our news columns that the President of the Cordage Trust, Mr. J. M. WATERBURY, has contributed large sums to the campaign funds of the Republican Party. It is natural that this should excite some curiosity as to the effect of that party's tariff legislation upon the industry which Mr. WATERBURY'S combination sought to control.

LONDON, May 11 -- An easier feeling prevailed on the Stock Exchange to-day. As the day advanced, and it was found that money was forthcoming for good collaterals, prices recovered some of the declines registered at the opening, and the closing was firm at the highest prices of the day. The advance of the bank rate to 3 1/2 was considered favorable, and the statement was not bad.

The demonstration by fashionable society in honor of her Royal Highness Infanta Eulalie of Spain will take place on the evening of Monday, May 22, according to the present arrangements. A ball of the most exclusive character is to be given.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Mrs. Cleveland is just now busily engaged in superintending the furnishing of the Summer residence on the Woodley Lane Road which Mr. Cleveland recently leased for a term of years. This task will soon be completed and then the President and his family will go from the White House to one of the most attractive of country seats.

There has been a notion in the public mind that the Manhattan Railway Company was seeking at the hands of the Rapid-Transit Commission the privilege of extending its lines and occupying all the available ground to the exclusion of other means for meeting the requirements of the city for rapid transit, and that such a privilege would be of great value to it.

It is announced from Richmond that the Governors of Virginia and other Southern States have received propositions from immigration agents in the Northwest to deliver foreign settlers to the South if the agents are suitably rewarded for that service.
CITY ISLAND, May 12. -- The following yachts passed here to-day:

By superior batting and fielding the Brooklyns won from the Bostons at Eastern Park yesterday. It was a one-sided game, and warrants but little description. In the first half of the second inning the Bostons scored 3 runs, and took the lead, but the Brooklyns soon passed them, and gained an advantage hard to overcome.

The fifteenth field meeting of the Interscholastic Athletic Association will be held this afternoon on the Berkeley Oval at 2. These games are as much to the boys attending the private schools of the city as the intercollegiate games are to the undergraduates.

RONKONKOMA. L. L., May 12. -- All yesterday afternoon, last night, and to-day a great forest fire has been raging in this vicinity. Last night it threatened to annihilate the little hamlet of Lake Grove.

The United States Rubber Company's Directors yesterday elected officers and made Joseph Banigan President. He represents the Woonsocket Rubber Company, which, with the Marvel Rubber Company and the Lawrence Felting Company, has been added to the combination in the last few days.

The Jolm Good Company will begin on Monday to extend Its cordage plant to such an extent that It will be fully capable, as far as room is concerned, of fulfilling Mr. Good's facetiouslymade offer to take the National Cordage Company Into his told.
"Baumert's got his badge." This announcement was received yesterday with great Joy by the Aldermen who were around the City Hall.

"I see that City Chamberlain Joseph J. O'Donohue has subscribed for a box at the home-rule concert to be given under the auspices of the Irish Independent Parliamentary Party," said Joseph P. Ryan, Assistant Secretary of the Irish National Federation of America, to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

ALBANY, May 12. -- Gov. Flower to-day granted a respite in the case of John Fitzhum until May 29. Fitzhum was convicted of murder in Erie County, and was to have boon executed in Auburn Prison this week.
Creedmoor rifle range was occupied yesterday by a battalion of the Seventh Regiment, composed of Companies I and K, under command of Capt. Harper, and numbering in all 183 officers and men.

At half an hour after the setting of the sun last evening, the members of the Tammany Society or Columbian Order met in the Wigwam on Fourteenth Street and installed the Sachems and officers chosen at the April meeting. The feature of the evening was the installation as a Sachem of ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., May 12. -- A fire which started in the Mansion House, Charies A. Sohilling, proprietor, at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, destroyed that hotel and other property near it, causing a loss of about $55,OOO. The local Fire Department, composed of hose companies, was practically powerless. It responded promptly to the alarm, but its streams were feeble and almost ineffective.

The weather at the Gravesend and Sheepshead Bay race tracks yesterday was all that could be deaired by the trainers. A large crowd of visitors was at both tracks to catch a glimpse of the Brooklyn Handicap horses at their work.
Francis H. Weeks, bankrupt since May 1, has disappeared. With him, it is charged, have vanished securities representing nearly $1,000,000 owned by estates and placed in his hands in trust.

-- The Bayonne Yacht Club members have elected the following officers for the season: Commodore -- W. E. Ellsworth; Vice Commodore -- T. Hopkins; Secretary -- Phil J. Mooney; Treasurer -- F. H. Ellsworth; Measurer -- Phil E. Van Buskirk. New-York Yacht Racing Association Committee -- Capt. Joe Ellsworth, John O'Neil, and Edward H, Bennett.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Secretary Lamont to-day gave further evidence at his policy heretofore credited to his administration of having as few officers absent from their regiments oil possible. He proposes that, gradually, army Officers on detached duty shall return to their companies and perform the work now devolving unjustly upon others.
MONTREAL, Quebee, May 12. -- The St. Lawrence River la not likely to prove a favorite route for ocean communication with the World's Fair at Chicago.

Policeman Kineagh of the East Twentyseoond Street Station was standing on the southeast corner of First Avenue and Fourteenth Street early yesterday morning. Across the way he noticed a disheveled-looking man making hideous faces, at the same time waving a cornet in one hand and Its case In the other. A woman came past, and he struck at her with, the instrument. It missed her, and the woman ran away screaming.

STAMFORD, N.Y., May 12. -- The action of the people in the towns of Stamford, in Delaware County; Shandaken, in Ulster County, and Hamptenburg and Montgomery, in Orange County, in voting no license at the recent Spring election and putting in Excise Commissioners opposed to selling liquor has caused some anxiety among the hotel proprietors in these towns.

Since the finding of the body of Murderer Frank W. Roshl in the Hudson River with a fractured skull and a bullet hole in the head, Lawyer Ambrose H. Purdy, who defended Thomas Palliater, the murderer who escaped from the Sing Sing deathhouse with Rochl on the night of April 2O, has formed a remarkable theory as to the manner in which, the murderera escaped and the manner in which Roehl met with death.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 13. -- In October last Mrs. Niven, the wife of Thornton A. Niven of Monticello, N.Y., conceived the idea of organizing a ladies' association for the purpose of erecting a monument in memory of the One Hundred and Forty-third Regiment. New-York Volunteers, and other soldiers who went out from Sullivan County during the war of the rebellion.

The detaching of the Atlanta from the naval review fleet, under hurried orders to Greytown, and the dispatch of the Alliance southward from San Francisco under sealed orders, probably for Nicaragua, were sufficient indications that the revolution in that country was considered very serious. Since then, the report has come that the insurgents have been victorious, and that President SACAZA is already overthrown.

SHERMAN, Texas, May 12. -- John Z. Carlisle and Charles Luttrell were hanged in the jail yard here at 2:06 P. M. to-day Tor the murder of W. T. Sherman. Both died instantly, their necks being: Droken.

Charles B. Thurston, one of the confidential chiefs of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. said yesterday that the filing of certificates for the consolidation of the New-York, New-Jersey and Eastern Railroad Company and the NewYork and New-Jersey Underground Railway Company into the Brooklyn. New-York and Jersey City Terminal Company reveals a great scheme which the Pennsylvania Railroad Company has had in contemplation for the last two years.

ST. PAUL, Mlnn., May 12. -- There was a great deal of disappointment in milling circles this evening when it was learned that the PillsburyWashburn Flour Mill Company at Minneapolis, the majority of the stock in which is held by London capitalists, had passed its annual dividend.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12. -- Rippey, the old man who is being tried for attempting to murder John W. Mackay, went on the stand yesterday afternoon and very clearly related the story of his life, but disclaimed any recollection of the shooting of Mackay. This morning Dr. Resthers of the Insanity Commission testified that in his opinion Rippey had exhibited epileptic symptoms prior to the shooting.
The wholesale merchants of New-York have formulated a novel scheme, which is expected to revolutionize some of the present methods of doing business.

-- C. H. Ellis, Secretary of the Cricket Department of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, has just issued the club's schedule for the year, the largest list of matches which has ever been arranged by the club. In all 47 games will be played, 30 by the first eleven and 17 by the second. The latter has entered for The second section pennant of the Metropolitan District Cricket League.

Dressed in the attractive garb or an Oriental, with blue stockings, red pantaloons, and on his head a fez, F.R. Roberson of Omaha talked about the people, customs, and scenery of India last night to the members of the department of geography of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in the large hall of the Young Men's Christian Association Building in that city.
ALBANY, May 12. -- Gov. Flower has vetoed the following bills:

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- In the absence of additional information at the State Department from Nicaragua, the interest in the recent revolution was expressed to-day in discussion of the probable reasons for it and of the difficulty of the Navy Department in getting the Atlanta on the way to Greytown.

The annual distribution of prizes for the year's work in the Department of Schools of the National Academy of Design was made last night in the lecture room of the academy. Twenty-third Street and Fourth Avenue. The distribution was made by the President of the academy, T.W. Wood.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 12. -- Icnatius Donnelly, President or the Minnesota Alliance, announces that the alliance will make an immediate demand on Gov. Nelson that he call an extra session of the Legislature. The trouble has arisen over a decision by Attorney General Childs that will prevent tho building of the farmers' State elevator at Duluth.

KOKOMO, Ind., May 12. -- The Commercial State Bank of Russiaville and the Farmers' Bank at Greentown, both under one management, closed their doors this morning with deposits of $60,000. They were caught in the Columbia Bank failure of Chicago, after having been recently crippled by a large milling company's failure.

RICHMOND, Va., May 12. -- Burke N. Smith, a well-known business man of Detroit, Mich., and Miss Hester Clifford Tallin, who claims to be a native of Orange County, this State, have just returned West after a short and fruitless search for a fortune Which the woman claimed In Virginia.

Simultaneously with the budding of the trees, the unfolding of the tulips, and the steady climbing of the mercury in the thermometer, preparations are already well under way for what is expected to be an unusually busy and prosperous season at the Manhattan Beach and Oriental Hotels. The former will open June 15 and the latter a week afterward.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 12. -- The war between the two factions of the Minnesota Farmers' Alliance reached a climax this evening when Dr. Everett W. Fish, editor of the Great West, brought suit against Ignatius Donnelly for $25,000 for defamation of character and against George L. Stoughton, editor of the Representative, for criminal libel.

SARATOGA, N. Y., May 12. -- The closing day of the Saratoga Gun Club shoot was fully as successful as any of the preceding ones, there being from twentytwo to twenty-seven entries In the various events. The sun shone clear and hot all day. but a cool breeze which came down from the mountains kept the shooters and visitors comfortable.

The officers of the American fleet in the harbor were very much stirred up yesterday by the dispatch in THE NEW-YORK TIMES that the Navy Department considered Commander Higginson or the Atlanta dilatory in obeying the orders issued to him to set sail at once for Nicaragua.

The Children's Aid Society is desirous of obtaining several lots of ground below Fortieth Street free of rent to be used as a Vacation Society playground for the poor children of the neighborhood during the Summer months. A competent person will be placed in charge to direct the children in play and instruction.
There are times when the friction between the Naval Office and the Surveyor's Department serves to amuse the Custom House. One of these occasions came about yesterday afternoon.

The announcement, made yesterday in the Herald, calling for proposals for a steel office building twelve or tifteen stories high, on the site of the present Herald Building, at Broadway and Ann Street, was received with much Interest among real estate men.

PARIS, May 12. -- The Incident yesterday which Seemed to threaten the success of the arbitration was based upon a difference of opinion between the American and British representatives as to the liability of the United States for seizures made In Bering Sea In the event of a decision against the United States on the question of Jurisdiction.

A notable addition to Mr. Frank Work's small but choice stable of trottors arrived recently from Frankfort, Ky. It is the bay mare Charter. 2:24 at four years old, which Mr. Work recently purchased from Col. R. P. Pepper. She stands 15.2, and is a lengthy, powerfully-bails mare, with a shapelier head and more smoothly turned than the Onwards usually are.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday signed orders appointing Charles H. Pearson and James P. Stearns, both of Brookline, Mass., receivers for the Standard Cordage Company, the Boston Cordage Company, the Sewall Day Cordage Company, and the Chelsea Cordage Company, all Massachusetts concerns, which were involved in the business of the National Cordage Company.

NEWARK, May 12. -- A.F. McNicoll, a NewYork lawyer, is the man who figured in the attempt to shoot a woman last night at the Women's Christian Association, the story of which appeared in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Sunday, May 21, the World's Fair Will be thrown open to the public, and thereafter every Sunday visitors will be permitted to enjoy the park, which was laid out for them and at their expense.

LONDON, May 12. -- The House of Commons, Sitting as a Committee of the Whole on the Home-Rule bill, to-day resumed the debate on the motion made yesterday by Mr. George Bartley (Conservative) to strike out the first clanse of the measure, a motion which practically means to reject the whole bill.
LONDON, May 12. -- There was a much steadier feeling on the Stock Exchange today, and money was in fair supply.

-- A dispatch from Pittsburg says: "Capt. Proffer of the Louisville Ball Club stated that the Louisville Club had first claim on Mark Baldwin and he must pitch for that club. Baldwin, however, emphatically stated that he preferred to retire from baseball rather than play In Louisville, and he won't go there."

The nature of the Western business man has not been so remarkably exemplified in anything connected with the World's Fair as in the Department of Music. The limit seemed to have been reached in the treatment by the press of Chicago of Mr. PADEREWSKI'S proposition to give two concerts for nothing.

BUFFALO. N.Y., May 12. -- Engine No. 999, the Central's world record beater, was sent down to Syracuse early this morning, and it wa rumored that a farther test of her capacity was to be made, as well as an attempt to break Wednesday's record. She returned here early this afternoon drawing a special train, on which was Superintendent of Motive Power Buchanan and several other officials.

MADRID, May 12. -- The counter-motion of the Republicans in the Cortes against leaving the Government free hands in the matter of the municipal election was rejected soon after 8 o'clock this evening, by a vote of 126 to 21.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- The greatest superficial effect, the most brilliancy, and probably the greatest interest which will be aroused in inquiring minds will be that created by the department of electricity. This is because the electrical exhibit of 1893 has rounded the period in which the greatest progress has been made in this wonderful agency.

The Grand Duke Alexander, the Admiral of the Russian squadron, and the officers of the vessels were entetained last evening at Sherry's by Consul General A. E. Olarovsky and Mrs. Olarovsky of Russia. The reception was small in comparison with several such entertainments given in honor of the Russian naval visitors, but the occasion was one of informality.

A NEW STOCK COMPANY. -- The management of the Grand Opera House in Boston is organizing a stock company for that theatre. Annie Clark, is to be the nuclear. The company is to produce such plays as "Rosedale," "The Ticket-of-Leave Man" and "The Octoroon." It is to travel on The NewEngland circuit fifteen or twenty weeks each year.

QUEENSTOWN, May 12. -- The new Cunard Line steamship Campania, Capt. Hains, which sailed from New-York for Liverpool on May 6, arrived at Queenstown at 9:3O o'clock this morning, having made the passage from Sandy Hook to Qneenstown in 5 days 17 hours and 42 minutes, the quickest passage eastward yet made by any steamer.

On four or the delusive mirrors In the Crystal Maze, at Broadway and Thirty-eighth Street are long semi-circular scratches, about onetenth of an Inch apart. These disfigure the mirrors to the extent of $400, so the managers of the Maze say, and. they propose to make things lively for the soratcher.

It is very probable that the matter of the revision of the creed of the Presbyterian Church may come up before the General Assembly of that church in Washington next week in a way unexpected by many prominent ministers of the denomination, who consider that the question of revision has been practically shelved by recent actions of various Presbyteries, and notably by the Presbytery of New-York.

For several weeks reports have been circulatod to the effect that President Hunter of the Normal College has been exercising undue severity by refusing to permit the girls to dance at all because one girl fainted a few weeks ago while dancing in the oalistheneam. President Hunter was seen yesterday afternoon at the college and made the following statement:
The gunboat Bancroft was ordered yesterday to proceed from the North River to the Brooklyn Navy Yard. There she will be fitted out for foreign service.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Representative women from all over the world are here as guests of the National Council of Women of the United States. This morning Miss Susan B. Anthony, Mrs. May Wright Sewall, and Mrs. Rachel Foster Avery came to the city, and work was begun in earnest on the preliminaries for the Congress of Representative Women, to be held in the Art Palace next Monday.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2@3 1/2 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.
The Directors of the World's Fair have very wisely and very sensibly decided to admit visitors on Sunday.

The unsettled question of rates on the fast trains between New-York and Chicago during the World's Fair was discussed yesterday by the Presidents of the railroads in the Trunk Line Association. The figures recommended to the joint committee a few days ago by Commissionera Walker, Goddard, and Blanchard formed the basis of the discussion.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 12. -- Informations were made this morning by James W. Jack against Robert McClure, agent for the Law and Order Society, and Alderman Michael Rohe and Constable Louis Kaercher, charging them with conspiracy to cheat and defraud the Guardians of the Poor of Allegheny County in failing to turn over or to account for the sum of $365 collected for violations of the liquor laws.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 12. -- The firm stand taken by Judge J.B. Chrisman with reference to the White Caps at Brookhaven, Miss., and the part he played in the triumph of law and order, attracted the attention and won the admiration of the New-Orleans Cotton Exchange, and a fund for a testimonial was raised in a few minutes.

Ex-Secretary Fairchild's decision not to serve on the Customs Service Investigating Commission is likely to result in a postponement of the beginning of the commission's work. It had been expected that the investigation would be opened next Monday, but yesterday the belief prevailed that there would be some delay.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 12. -- Mr. T. Edward Hambleton, a well-known banker and broker of this city and President of the Traction Company, and Mr. W. Irvine Cross, a prominent railroad lawyer, had a personal encounter to-day in the dining room of the Merchants' Club.

The revolution which is being carried on in Nicaragua has been laid at the door of NewYork capitalists by Dr. Guzman, the Nioaraguan Minister at Washington. He has said that the uprising was instigated by New-York capitalists who are directly interested in Nicaraguan affairs. He knew their names, but did not deem it advisable to disclose them at the present time.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- Secretary Lamont to-day created the predicted stir in the War Department outlined in THE NEWYORK TIMES of this morning.

O.C. MOORE, Representative from the Second District of New-Hampshire to the Fifty-first Congress, and from 1864 to the time of his death editor and manager of the Daily and Weekly Telegraph, died Friday, aged fifty-four. He was born in New Hampton, and during his active life was a leading editor, politician, and orator in the Republican Party. He had held important official positions and stood high in the councils of that party.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- There was a marked recovery of confidence in business circles to-day. Every one connected with the Chicago banks agreed that there is no probability of any further trouble in the way of important bank failures, although there is something like a panic among small concerns in the country.

AMHERST, Mass., May 12. -- Amheret, with a substitute pitcher in the box, defeated Wesleyan In a closely-contested game on Pratt Field. Froat's pitching suited the Amherst batters exactly and he was hit hard throughout the game, but food fielding by Wesleyan kept the score down. Wesleyan hit Grocery hard, but he had beautiful support.

From the Buffalo Courier, (Dem.,) May 12. Speaking of the Sheehanizing work going on in the Police Department, THE NEW-YORK TIMES says: "The people seem to be powerless to resist this outrage, which the Legislature and the Governor empowered Sheehan to perpetrate, but one of these days they will have a chance to vote either to support the machine which is run over them in this ruthiess fashion or to smash it to pieces.

The Larchmont Yacht Club house is nearly ready for the opening next Saturday, and is beginning to look spick and span. The heavy gale of two weeks ago, that did so mach damage everywhere, did not leave Larchmont, out. At one time it looked as though the yachtsmen would be without a home and that the clubhouse would be washed away. Old-timers Bay that it was the worst gale ever experienced in that region.

" We believe in scaling the fraudulent pension lists so that only those who are really deserving or aid from the Government shall receive it for service in the rebellion," said Commander John J. Finn of Noah L. Farnham Post to a NEWYORK TIMES reporter yesterday, " and we shall stand by our resolutions to that effect, even if we have to ask the courts to protect us."

The New-York Guaranty and Indemnity Company and Messrs. Brown Brothers Co. offer for subscription and recommended as a very desirable investment $2,600,000 first mortgage 4 cent. 100year gold bonds of the Monawk and Malone Railway Company. payment of principal and interest guaranteed by the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, such guarantee being indorsed on each bond.

BUFFALO, May 12. -- A letter from Florida announces the death at Homosassa, that State, of Alfred B. Bidwell, a former Buffalonian, who eight years ago was sentenced to death for the murder of Harrison Riley at Sara Sota, Fla. which murder was ordered by a society of which Mr. Bidwell had been a member.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 12. -- A decided sensation was created here to-night. A little over a year ago the new Methodist Church in Scranton, erected at a cost of over $175,000, was destroyed by fire. A watchman named Peter Humbach was in charge of the building at the time.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 12. -- The failure of the Capital National Bank yesterday has had no perceptible effect upon business to-day.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12. -- Advices from Honolulu up to May 4 are as follows: The Hawaiian Republic proposition has not been materially promoted during the past week. The projectors say they have concluded it is best to wait and see what the United States intends to do. The Spreckels boom for a republic has also, apparently, come to a standstill.

Four horses drew Broadway cable car No. 2 out of the station at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street when the clocks struck the hour of 2 yesterday morning, and started southward on the new track. In due time they hauled the car around the curve at Bowling Green and thence back to the station.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 12. -- The Southern Baptist Convention met in this city to-day. Several thousand persons are in attendance, representing fifteen States. The Hon. Jonathan Haroldson, Chief Justice of Alabama, was reelected President of the convention. The following were elected Vice Presidents: Gov. W.J. Northen of Georgia, Joshua Levering of Maryland, S.H. Ford of Missouri, and W.H. Whitsett of Kentucky.

PORTLAND, Me., May 12. -- The smuggling case of Samuel J. Watson was concluded to-day and the jury returned a verdict of guilty. Watson was charged with smuggling potatoes from New-Brunswick into the New-England States, thereby defrauding the United States revenue of many thousands of dollars yearly.

It has been said in various quarters since Mr. Frederic May came back to this city on April 11 and gave himself up for the assault upon Policeman Daniel McGowan in June, 1888, that he would not be sent to prison.

Ever since the Guttenberg race meeting opened on Saturday last, the weather Has been lair and it seemed to most racegoers, who recalled the miserable weather which prevailed during the Elizabeth meeting, that the Guttenberg officials must have made some sort of a deal with the gods to secure good weather for their seven days meeting. Should it be clear to-day racegoers will be sure that such a deal was consummated.

As was announced in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES, the Thomson-Houston Company has brought suit in New-Haven, Conn., to restrain the Winchester Avenue and West Haven Electric Road of that city and the Westinghouse Electric Company of New-York and Pittsburg from operating an electric trolley railroad.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., May 12. -- The announcement this evening that Francis Henry Weeks, the President of the Land and River Improvement Company, had absconded with several hundred thousand dollars caused little surprise or comment here.

Inspector Timothy Donohue of the Custom House was very indignant yesterday in consequence of a story circulated to the effect that, because of the way in which he treated Congressman Cockran, he had been removed from the docks of the passenger steamships on the North River to the docks on the East River, where few besides the crews of vessels trading with this port are landed.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- When the history of the World's Fair is written by an unbiased observer, the part which the National Commission and its officers nave played will fill an exceedingly small and ridiculous part.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The second day's races at Bennings under the rules of the American Hunt and Pony-Racing Association attracted a email attendance to-day, although the conditions made it a perfect racing day. The select set was largely represented again and the music of the band of the Third Artillery aided to give the occasion the features of a social function.

NEW-YORK. -- Water Register Reilly's report of receipt from Croton water since the year 1842, when the first aqueduct was opened, shows that the city has received $62,890,793.06 from that Source since then.
WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Lighthouse Board will soon take up the plans for the immense light on the treacherous Outer Diamond Shoal, off Cape Hatteras.

PHILADELPHlA, May 12. -- The Pennsylvania Legislature has before it a bill affecting the most autocratic body which ever handled any public affairs of any kind in Philadelphia. The bill is designed to abolish the commission for the erection of the public buildings of this city.

This afternoon the third annual joint tract athletic meeting between Yale and Harvard Universities takes place on the latter's grounds at Cambridge. The meeting promises to be much closer than either of the previous two, though last year's championship went to Harvard by only 10 points. At these meetings the experienced follower of the cinder path will look for the usual number of "upseta."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 12. -- Charles P. McClelland of Dobbs Ferry has addressed an open letter to Sheriff John Daffy of Westchester County concerning the split In the Democratic County Committee caused by the withdrawal of Sheriff Daffy and his friends and supporters from the meeting on May 3 and their subsequent organization as a County Committee.

At a dinner of the alumni of the School of Mines of Columbia College at the Hotel Waldorf Thursday night, President Seth Low made a statement which settles a question over which there has been some doubt in the minds of those who have had charge of spending the money of the college.
ST. LOUIS, May 12. -- Charles Turner, a real estate agent and money lender of 914 Olive Street, committed suicide to-day with prussic acid. He proves to have been a defaulter and a forger as well.

We invite the attention of the State Board of Health to the proceedings of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals against the owner of a herd of cattle in Canarsie. The competent veterinary surgeon employed by this society inspected these cattle a few days ago and discovered that they were in a most deplorable condition.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The Treasury situation shows decided improvement, the receipts being larger than for last year at this time, while the expenditures, though large, are not so heavy as was anticipated. Most of the heavy disbursement for the month have already been made, including $8,000,000 for pensions and other heavy payments that become due about the first of the month.

A little rumpus took place at the Press Club Fair last night which was not known of outside of a small circle. A.B. De Frece of the Mail and Express, who is engineering matters since the retirement of Charles O'Connor Hennessy, precipitated the row by tearing down the flower booth presided over by Mrs. John A. Cockerill and putting in its place a cheap counter.

James H. Pilot's trial was ended at 3:30 O'clock yesterday afternoon, as far as the testimony and summing up of the opposing counsel were concerned. At that hour Judge-Moore adjourned court until 9 o'clock this morning, when he will make his charge to the Jury.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- The new Memorial Art Palace of the Lake Front was thrown open to the members of the Art Institute this afternoon. While the building is by no means complete, the interior of the main floor is receiving the finishing touches, and workmen are busy putting the plaster casts, busts, and models of the Art Institute in position.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 12. -- The Rev. Alexander Barren, pastor of the Presbyterian Church, Highland Falls, and Miss Emma Wyant of Cornwall were married at the First Presbyterian Church, Cornwall-on-the-Hudson, last evening. The olliciating ciergyman was the Rev. Hugh Rusael Fraser, pastor of the church, and he was assisted by the Rev. Lyman Abbott of Brooklyn.
Dennis Ward, the ambulance driver of the Health Department, who was recently removed to North Brother Island suffering from typhus, was reported to be slightly better yesterday.

James Carpenter, the five-year-old son of a stonemason, went to his home at 227 Greene Street crying Thursday evening. His left hand was inflamed. He could not articulate distinctly, and it was supposed that he bad been Knocked down and hurt.
The Rev. Father Corrigan of Hoboken, whose guest Ablegate Satolli is to be to-morrow and Monday, refuses to say whether Bishop Wigger will be present to greet the Ablegate or not.

No one can have much to do with collecting information in Wall Street nowadays without frequently and continually coming upon the traces of varied, elaborate, and systematic misrepresentation. The only uniform quality of this misrepresentation is that it is obviously intended to breed distrust and to depress values, and that quality is so persistent as to indicate to a trained observer the existence of a common source.

-- The Columbia Cycle club has been reorganized, and the following officers have been elected: President -- J.J. Woods; Vice President -- A.K. Fox; Secretary -- H.E. Hatzel; Treasurer -- J. Foster, Jr.; Captain -- T.A. Ritchie; Lieutenant -- A.R.R. Fox. The membership limit has been fixed at thirty, and a committee is looking for a clubhouse between Thirty-fourth and Fifty-ninth Streets.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 12. -- Hyman, Paller Co., the consignees of the cotton that was seized on the steamboat Natchez the other day, have deposited with Collector Warmoth $3,000 to cover the amount demanded by the Government for the release of the cotton. The consignees have obtained possession of the cotton and are now preparing an appeal to the Secretary of the Treasury for a ruling on the matter.
The Colorado River Irrigation Company has Just been incorporated under the laws of Colorado with an authorized capital of $7,500,000.

BERLIN, May 13. -- The first week of the electoral struggle ends without any of the parties knowing where they stand, and without any of them having anything like reliable data from which to forecast the result of the contest for members of the Reichstag.

The whereabouts of Lawyer Francis H. Weeks is shrouded in as much mystery as ever. Yesterday being Saturday, the majority of the lawyers and business men who are interested in his affairs were absent from their offices. Assignee R.W.G. Welling declined to be seen upon the subject. He is said to have stated on the day after Mr. Weeks executed the assignment that there could be no possible question of Mr. Weeks's honesty of purpose.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 13. -- The Mechanical Rubber Company, which has absorbed most of the large rubber manufactories in the United States in a single combination, has mortgaged the whole outfit for $2,500,000. A copy of the mortgage, covering the two Cleveland factories as well as those of other concerns abroad, was filed in Recorder Salls's office yesterday.

A writer in the Boston Journal is inclined to think that the paragraphers who are ambitiously trying to make young women believe that authorship is conducive to single blessedness in the case of women, are a trifle erroneous in their information.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Secretary Gresham has attached one scalp to his belt that will attract the appreciative and approving comments of many persons in this country, and perhaps some in Europe.

-- Sales at the Academy segregate more than $10,500, with offers in for other pictures held for $5,000 at the catalogue prices. The pictures sold from the corridor are "Violets," by Annie T. Burt; "Reverie," by Sarah NobleIves; "The God of Silence," by Alfred Z. Baker; "The Puritan's Trust," by Robert F. Bloodgood, and "Church Lane," by William B. Whittemore.

BALTIMORE, May 13. -- Major J. G. Pangborn, United States Honorary Commissioner and Exposition Executive of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, left Baltimore this evening in General Manager Odell's car, carrying to Chicago the most valuable and interesting collection of early historical railway relics ever gathered together.

The more information comes in regarding the amazing concerns under the general control of DWIGGINS STARBUCK of Chicago, the plainer it becomes that the presence of a lawyer in the Controller's office in Washington may be a very good thing for the national bank system and for the country.

The visit of the Cherokee Commissioners to Washington, in order to get the money immediately payable to them, should advance the opening of their lands to settlement. Their people acted sensibly in accepting the amendments made by Congress to the agreement for purchasing their tract of 6,000,000 acres. The original compact provided that unless its terms were ratified without change it should be null and void.
The business of the rumor mongers in Wall Street is in a fair way to receive a decided check.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 13. -- The United States Grand Jury to-day finished its investigation of the affairs of the First National Bank and returned indictments against H. G. Allis. President of the bank, and Creed T. Walker, its Cashier in 189O.

Mrs. Sparling, better known as May Morris, the English art embroiderer, gets by inheritance the marvelous designing skill and execution which makes the needle in her hand the peer of the brash or pencil. She is the daughter of the well-known designer William Morris, whose beautiful wife was also, under her husband's guidance, a skilled worker at needle painting.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, May 13 -- P.M. There was renewed activity in the stock market to-day, but it was at the expense of values. The selling came from all quarters. London, the West, and local operators apparently vying with one another in their eagerness to liquidate.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 13. -- The Spring meet held by the Cornell Athletic Club to-day on Percy Field was a great success. Six Cornell records were broken. Many of the men had been in hard training under Capt. Shaw, but the result was even better than expected, giving considerable encouragement for next Friday's contest with the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 23 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.
Society is in a curious muddle over the proposed ball to the Infanta Eulalie and suite, which is planned to take place at the Madison Square Garden on May 22.

In this convenient little volume Mr. Crawford gives us, simply enough, a frank statement of what a novel, to his mind, is That is, he tries to do so, for his art as a novelist is so much more subtle than his analysis of the novel that we cannot but think he finds himself in difficulties. He has, however, gone to work with much conscientiousness, and has divided his book into good little chapters.

If the young men of Columbia College are as proficient in their other studies as they are in the modern art of burlesque, they will surely illuminate the twentieth century.
