There is as yet no chair of modern burlesque in any of the colleges, but the students of Columbia have splendid facilities near at hand for studying the art.

The suggestion made by THE TIMES yesterday morning that the invention and spreading of falsehoods affecting the credit of individuals or institutions constituted a case for investigation by the District Attorney has been received with great favor by bank officers and others having financial interests to protect.

The arrival of Mgr. Satolli at Jersey City yesterday and his immediate transportation to the Passionists Monastery on West Hoboken Heights have led to fears that Father Corrigan's preparations for an imposing reception at the Church of Our Lady of Grace, in Hoboken, has not turned out well. Two separate programmes for the Delegate's entertainment have been arranged, and it will be impossible for Mgr. Satolli to out the prearranged figure in both.

MILWAUKEE. Wis., May 13. -- A special train arrived in the city, at 11 o'clock this morning from Chicago, bearing $77.000 in gold for the Plankinton Bank. It was a cash balance due and was sent by the Continental Bank of Chicago. The run of eighty-five miles was made in considerably less than two hours.
LONDON, May 13. -- Markets generally opened steady to-day and remained dull until the close, which was dull at fractions below the opening.

Among the novelties in preparation, but as yet unannounced, for the coming theatrical season is an adaptation of "Le Prince d'Aurec." the most successful of M. Henri Lavedan's comedies. It will be played with the full strength of a competent stock company -- NewYork hasn't so many such as to leave a broad field for conjecture.
Dr. Otto John Miller of 340 East Thirteenth Street has obtained a writ of habeas corpus from Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court for the production in court of his six-year-old daughter, Lucy.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- The first legal steps in the World's Fair Sunday-closing question was made this afternoon. Charles W. Clingman, who represents that he is a stockholder in the Columbian Exposition personally and by proxy to the extent of $100.000, filed a bill in the Superior Court praying for an injunction restraining the Directors of the exposition and the South Park Commissioners from closing the gates of the fair on Sunday.

The Rev. Wilbur F. Crafts, Chairman of the new National Committee on Sunday Closing of the World's Fair, recently organized at Columbus by officers of the American Sabbath Union, Woman's Christian Temperance Union, the Christian Endeavor Societies, five State Sabbath associations, and other bodies, was in NewYork yesterday arranging by telegraph for resistance during the coming week to the proposed Sunday opening of the World's Fair on May 21.

Mr. Stille's volume on John Dickinson of Pennsylvania and his part in the making of a free America aroused interest a few years ago for several causes, but mainly because it was a sketch of a man for whom the present generation has not retained the esteem, and knowledge winch were Dickinson's due.
Roundsman Cahill of the Barge Office was visited yesterday by a dark-complexioned, buxom bride of forty-five years who had been abandoned by her young husband, and had lost her jewelry besides.

The financial troubles of Erastus Wiman, which began with his retirement from his connection with R.G. Dun Co., and the loss of the large income which he derived therefrom, have culminated in the appointment of Albert B. Boardman of New-Brighton, S.I., as receiver of the Electric Power Company of Staten Island, and the determination of Mr. Wiman to make a general assignment for the benefit of his creditors.

The Government patrol fleet in Bering Sea during the coming Summer will consist of five war ships and two revenue cutters. This is a slightly larger force than that of last year, though, owing to the absence of the Yorktown, there is no vessel in this year's fleet which, in point of speed, can approach the flagship's work of last year.

AN inspection made yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard of the new practice cruiser Bancroft disclosed that her propeller is badly injured. It will require over a mouth to put her in condition for sea. Up to within a few days ago the naval authorities at the United States Naval Academy had toped to be able to use the Bancroft for practice work with the naval cadets during the Summer.

" I have come to the conclusion." remarked a man the other day, "that the shibboleth of most Americans is the children. Parents strain every nerve, deny themselves, alter their mode of life that the children may have every advantage of an age of opportunities.
CHICAGO, May 13. -- Developments of the past twenty-four hours have made President Dwiggins of the defunet Columbia Bank an interesting figure in the banking world.

On the line of the New-York and Northern Railway, near Elmsford, Westchester County, about ten miles beyond the limits of New-York City, is a fine estate of 184 acres, valued alike for its beauty and healthfulnes a of situation. Of 114 acres of this tract, St. Luke's Retreat obtained a lease for 999 yeurs in pursuance of a provision by the late Robert B. Minturn for securing sites for buildings to several church charities.

Mr. LAMONT is carrying sound business methods into the War Department, and, besides obviously improving and strengthening the service of his own department, he is demonstrating the practical advantage of principles of administration which are of the very essence of civil service reform, not only in the classified service under the rules, but throughout the whole service.

THE LEGITIMATE DRAMA. -- During the Commonwealth, the legitimate stage succumbed before the Puritan, but the variety entertainment, with the "turns" long since out of date, and with, that scattering of its component parts which would be intolerable to the modern man, defied the preacher, as it had already challenged the artist, to do his worst.

BOSTON, May 13. -- To-night marked the closing of the dramatic season at three theatres. One was the Hollis Street, where the attraction for the past three weeks has been Bronson Howard's "Aristocracy." Another was the Columbia, where Thomas Q. Seabrooke finished a run in "The Isle of Champagne." Both of these houses will remain closed all summer.
The railway mortgage market was dull and irregular. The principal changes were:

NEWPORT, R.I., May 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Vanderbilt are here on the steam yacht Conqueror. They spent the day making calls and arranging for the opening or their cottage Saturday next. They will leave on their steam yacht to-morrow for New-York, and meantime "Rough Point" will be got ready for occupancy.
The weekly bank statement issued to-day showed an increase in reserve of $4,959,850. The banks now hold $17,795,025 in excess of the legal requirements.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 13. -- The delightful warm weather of the last week has worked a wonderful transformation in this city by the sea. Around the cliffs and along Bellevue Avenue the lawns and flower beds are looking their prettiest, while the splendid foilage, for which Newport's famous drive is noted, is bursting into full leaf.

In that comedy or tragedy which, the greatest of all modern romancers wrote, the Parisian journalist was a factor who could not be overlooked. Balzac draws him as he knew him in a period prior to 1830, and the portrait is not flattering. If he is precise as to silhouettes, he designates, too, the character of the work.

The series of questions propounded to Mayor David A. Boody through the columns of THE NEW-YORK TIMES last Sunday have created a decided sensation among the Brooklyn politicians and have set those worthy gentlemen by the ears. These questions of the Young Men's Democratic Club were chiefly noticeable for the plain truths they told, and that they were truths is admitted by the absolute silence of Mayor Boody.

The passing of the 1st of May has brought prominently to notice the work of the destroyers of buildings, as well as the builders. In all parts of the city the evidences are patent as to the amount of building, of which the next twelve months will show the results. In certain places these evidences are more noteworthy than in others, as indicating the development of localities.

The latest newspaper aspirant to seek popular favor in the metropolis is Daily America, a morning journal devoted almost exclusively to sports and politics -- a combination which seems to be very much in vogue at the present time, as the twin vocations of Mr. Crokor and other public men fittest.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The meeting or the American Hunt and Pony Racing Association closed thisafternoon. There were six events on the card. Owing to a shower the attendance was not very large. The match race between P. S. P. Randolph's Jilt and F. Gebhard's Rosarium, at three-eighths of a mile, was won by Rosarium, easily, in 0:37 1/2. The summaries:

From the Lewiston (Mc.) Journal, May 5. The Maine Historical Society paid its respects to Dr. Fordyce Barker, the great New-York surgeon, a native of Kennebec County, Me., at its Spring meeting in Portland on Thursday, his former classmate, the Hon. George F. Talbot reading reminiscences. He said that probably the class in Bowdoin, second in importance to 25 was that which contained Gov. Andrew and Dr. Fordyce Barker -- the class of '33.

From the Boston Transcript. Prof. Barton of the Institute of Technology save a half-hour talk before the students of the Chauney Hall School the other morning on "Drumlins." It is only within a few years that any extended research has been made into the history of drumlins. The investigations in this State have been conducted largely by Prof. Barton himself.

-- Thomas Stacker, fifty years old, was arrested yesterday and arraigned before Justice Hendrickson, at Huntingdon, L. I., charged with murderous assault upon James Mahew, who lies at his home, on Crow Hill, dying from a stab wound which it is charged was inflicted by Stacker. Both men are negroes. The quarrel was the result of Jealousy of a young colored woman with whom Blacker was living.

The poolroom keepers expect to be prepared to do business to-morrow on the big Brooklyn Handicap and other races. New-York City will not be the scene of their operations. They will sell tickets and cash them near the ferryboat landing in Weehawken.

The foreign exchange market was steady. The posted, rates for sterling were unchanged at $4.86 for 60-day bills and $4.90 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.85 $4.85 1/4 for 60-day bills, $4.89$4.89 1/4 for demand, $4.90$1.9O 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.84$4.84 1/4 for commercial.

BOSTON, Mass., May 13. -- Following is the full text of the famous agreement of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad Company with the Boston and Maine Railroad Company for the division of New-England territory. It was made public to-day:

HAMILTON, Washington, May 13 -- One morning in January, as I sat by a brightly-burning fire of resinous fir sticks to smoke an after-breakfast pipe of Havana tobacco and to read the telegraphic accounts, as published in Seattle newspapers, of arcticlike storms racing along the Atlantic seaboard and of blizzards coursing over the great plains, I rejoiced that I lived in a land where blizzards are unknown.

PARIS, May 1 -- Just as the Japanese go about at this season of the year looking for cherry trees before which to pose for the benefit of English poets and American actresses, so the Parisians, whether young, old, or undated, devote themselves for several weeks every Spring to a worship of the lilac.

It is idle to hope that the time will ever come when the recurrence of Spring will not tempt the poet from his sanctuary. The learned Mr. Tony Weller once remarked to his son, in one of those bursts of paternal instruction whose source was the fund of information and experience gathered throughout a long and varied career: "Vidth, Sammy, vidth and visdom grows together."

NORWALK, Conn., May 13. -- During the past few days the residents of this town and of a few adjoining towns have not lost any sleep on account of the high price of beef. Their diet has been fish -- fish, too, that has been gunned for as persistently and more successfully than quail or partridge, and the sportsmen have returned home loaded down.

THE NAVAL VISITORS. -- Last week society continued to exhibit its respect for the visiting naval officials by snowing them many courtesies. The Grand Duke Alexander of Russia had the lion's share of attention, and it may have been noticed that the Grand Duke and several other minor officials had "swell times" ashore, while the Admiral had to bunk aboard the Dimitri Donskoi.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Under the former Commissioner, Raum, the Pension Office business fell into disrepute with those who knew what the meaning of the "completed files" order was, because it was generally understood that the order was contrived for the benefit of a few enterprising pension agents rather than for the speedy relief of the pension applicants.

COLLEGE POINT, May 13. -- The mystery of the disappearance of Frank Schlessingor on April 14 from his home in College Point was partly cleared to-day when his body was found in Flushing Bay bearing evidence that he had been robbed and murdered.

The official sanitary report of Registrar John T. Nagle for the week beginning at noon May 6 gave these vital statistics: Births, 802; marriages, 195, and deaths, 940. The death rate was 26.05 in a population of 1,882,741. The week before the rate was 26.32, and the average rate for the preceding five years for the period corresponding to last week was 25.44.

-- George M. Pullman and Gen. Horace Porter, President and Vice President of the Pullman Palace Car Company, had a conference with Joseph S. Harris and John Lowber Welsh in Philadelphia last Friday relative to the payment of the $5.000,000 of Reading equipment notes held by the Pullman Company. A proposition was made to Mr. Pullman, and he will return an answer next Tuesday or Wednesday.
An amateur theatrical performance for the benefit of Calvary Company No. 3, Knights of Temperance, will be given at the Berkeley Lyceum, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, on Thursday evening, May 18.

De Wolf Hopper and his merry band of comedians and singers are entertaining crowded audiences nightly at the Broadway Theatre in their new oilapodrids "Panjandrum." Manager Stevens, with a modesty characteristic of himself and his star, declines to call "Panjandrum" a comic opera, but it is quite as much entitled to the name as scores of other entertainments that pass for comic opera.

Mrs. Fannie L. Oakley of 665 Lexington Avenue captured an alleged, pocketbook thief in a Sixth Avenue store Friday afternoon. She was standing at the dress-goods counter when she missed her pocketbook, containing $7.50, from a bag suspended at her side.

Chicago yachtsmen are booming things this year. The latest addition to the fleet is a steam yacht called the Catherine C. She is 120 feet in length, 17 feet beam, and has a guaranteed speed of 17 knots. She will be schooner rigged. The engines are of the triple-expansion type, that will develop 700 horse power. She has a Roberts boiler. Her owner is Michael Cudahy.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 13. -- Gen. Haven, Acting Warden at the State prison, to-day suspended Mrs. Hall, the prison matron, and installed Miss Florence Doming of Wethersfield in her place. He also suspended Hallman Hathaway.

"You American girls are spoiled -- utterly spoiled." said an English matron. "You frequently reject a young man for no other reason than that he is the first who has done you the honor to offer you his hand."
NEWARK, May 13. -- David A. Paullin, father of Phcebe Pauilin, whose unavenged murder in the Orange Mountains created a sensation several years ago, was stricken with paralysis last night.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., May 13. -- The recent rains have transformed the Round Lake region from a dreary ice bed to a garden of flowers. The verdure and the bloom were never before so luxuriant at this season of the year.

There is a joke current in Morrisania that the local laundresses never hang out clothes to dry on any day thare is racing at Fleetwood. Yesterday was in keeping with this tradition, but in spite of the wet and contrary to custom, the card was put through, with the exception of the 2:30 class for professional drivers.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- Augustin Daly's stock company will begin an engagement at Hooley's next week. Daring its three weeks' stay six of the most important productions and revivals of its New-York season will be given. The repertory for the first week will be: Monday and Tuesday evenings and Wednesday matinee, "The Last Word"; Wednesday and Thursday evenings, "Belie's Stratagem"; Friday and Saturday evenings and Saturday matinee, "The Hunchback."

After a successful meeting of seven days. Guttenberg race track closed its gates yesterday afternoon. The rain of yesterday did not mar the racing to any extent, nor did it make the going heavy, although the spectators were obliged to keep within the grand stand after the second race had been run.

TRENTON, May 13 -- The people of New-Jersey have the choice of a large number of religious bodies, embracing every known doctrine and creed. There are in the State organizations of the Mormons. Dunkards. Seventh-Day Adventists, the Christodelphians, and Christians. Dr. H.K. Carroll has been collecting for the Census Department facts about religious bodies in the State, and his bulletins present some interesting facts concerning the minor religious denominations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 13. -- In the second annual track athletic games between Harvard and Yale held here this afternoon. Harvard won by a score of 67 to 45 points. In 1891 Harvard won by a score of 85 to 27. Last year in New-Haven she was victori one by a score of 61 to 51.

The champion Bostons played in the style yesterday at Eastern Park which earned for them their remarkable success of last season. They batted hard and timely, fielded well, and ran bases with a dash and judgment which they have not shown in some time. The whole team seemed to be imbued with a winning spirit, and they won the game with ease.

The committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the New-York Custom House will have its first meeting and determine on a method of procedure at the Custom House to-morrow morning. Unless instructions from the Secretary of the Treasury to the contrary are received by Commissioners Dunn and Magone, the commission will proceed to business before a member is named in place of Mr. Fairchild.
WASHINGTON, May 13. -- The statement of the United States Treasurer, showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day, is as follows:
Although the auction sales of real estate announced for the present week include many which are by order of the courts, there are several others to which attention may well be directed.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 13. -- In the first five innings of the Lehigh-Cornell game here this afternoon, Lehigh made 4 runs. Johnston was hit for a home run, a three bagger, two doubles, and two singles. The visitors got three men scross the plate early in the game.

PARIS, May 1. -- A capital programme at the Theatre Libre, and at least one play quite possible for any Parisian stage. "Valet de Coeur," a three-act comedy from the pen of M. Maurice Vaucaire, the author of "Lidoire," a one-act military farce, already given at this same theatre with great success, is an unequal attempt, and the impression given is not tiresome, certainly, but colorless.

A significant feature of the musical life of the metropolis is the annual advent in the late Spring or early Summer of some company which performs grand opera at what are described as popular prices. These companies would cease to appear if there were no solid support for them. Some one must be making a few dollars out of these ventures or they would be abandoned.
From the Louisville Courier-Journal. At the installation Monday night of the officers or Curran Pope Camp, Sons at Veterans, the following letter of Gen. Sherman was read:
"I had an experience to-day," said Mrs. John as she broke off a bit of her soup bread last night and began daintily to sip her cream of asparagus.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., May 13. -- Phillip Weiler, a hardware merchant of this place, was killed to-day, being thrown out of his wagon. His neck was broken.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Fine records were made in nearly all the events at the first annual open Spring games of the University of Pennsylvania here to-day. The mile relay race between Pennsylvania and Princeton was won by the latter by about 8 yards in the fast time of 3:34 1-5.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- All but two of the 586 Commissioners who will compose the one hundred and fifth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church have communicated with the Committee on Entertainment, and quarters have been assigned to more than 500. Most of them will be entertained at hotels, but 200 will be the guests of members of the New-York Avenue Church, where the Assembly will hold its sessions.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 13. -- One more bank failure was announced to-day as a result of the collapse of the Columbia National Bank of Chicago. Auditor of State Henderson was notified by telegraph at noon that the Citizens' State Bank of Monroeville, Alien County, had suspended this morning. The concern was one of the Dwiggins chain of banks in Indiana, and had a capital stock of $30,000.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie. were $12,310,548, of which amount $2,1OO,211 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $39,768, and the exports of specie were $899,455.

"Woodcock's Little Game" was presented by the young ladies or the Misses Ely's school, at Riverside Drive and Eighty-sixth, Street, last night, to augment the fund of the Working Girls' Vacation Committee. The audience was made up of the young women of the school and their friends and relatives of their own sex, together with four or five quiet old gentlemen, whom the management had deemed it not imprudent to admit.

The severity of the losses inflicted by the late panic is demonstrated by the continuance of liquidation, which during the past week has been most conspicuous in the railroad shares. In the industrials, Distillers and Cordage have gone lower, but the others are about steady. It is in the railroad shares that the selling has been most persistent, and yesterday's prices for many of these were the lowest seen since the Baring crisis.

It was generally thought about town yesterday that Fred May is not likely to be severely punished for his assault upon Policeman McGowan five years ago, and the apparent disposition to let him off easily was for various reasons received with expressions of approval. His voluntary return to give himself up and plead guilty without any attempt at defense was spoken of as to his credit.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 13. -- The Spanish loyalist newspapers of all the principal cities of Cuba are proclaiming the surrender of the insurgents, and are doing everything they can to impress the world with the idea that the recent uprising of Cubans in the several provinces has been thoroughly suppressed.

BOSTON, May 13. -- Arbitrage dealing was active in all New-York stocks, and prices weakened from 1 to 3 points. Bell Telephone declined to 180. Westinghouse Electric to 28, do preferred to 45. General Electric preferred to 98, and Tamarack Copper to 145. Trading in other local stocks was fairly active at about yesterday's closing prices.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the Board of Directors of the Brooklyn Library, just submitted, makes a most satisfactory showing as to the library's work in the year to which it refers. The work was done under favoring conditions, the particular help to good results being the freedom, from annoyance caused by the extensive repairs of two years ago and the recent rearrangement of the library and reading room.

From the New- York Herald of Yesterday. We appreciate the graceful compliment paid us by THE TIMES in printing a handsome illustration of the Herald's new up-town building, with a full and interesting description of it.

Had it not been for the payment of land damages by the City of New-York, the Protestant Episcopal Church Missionary Society for Seamen would have been seriously embarrassed during the last year. Such is the statement made by the Board of Managers in their forty-ninth annual report.

Henry T. Finck is the most extreme Wagnerite in the United States, and he is glad of it. He became a Wagnerite in the beginning, when the Wagner movement was without form and void, when to be an admirer of the grand genius of Baireuth was to be covered with scorn and ridicule, to be abused, and even directly insulted.

MAJOR A.R. HALE of New-London, Conn., a widely-known hotel man, died yesterday aged seventy. He went into the hotel business in Bridgeport, Conn., as manager of the Atlantic Hotel, which house he conducted until 1872. Since then he conducted the Watch Hill House at Watch Hill, R.I. He also managed Winter resorts in Florida, at Green Cove Springs, St. Augustine, and Sanford.

The fur-manufacturing firm of Barenkopf Blourock of 47 Bond Street was robbed on May 3 of about $1,500 worth of stone marten, mink, and skunk skins. The police worked on the case for several days without success.

BOSTON, May 13. -- At Lawley'a, at City Point, the riveting of the Paine Cup defender is well along, and the decks are being laid. The centreboard boxes are in place and the skylights and deck fittings are ready to go on board as soon as the boat is ready for them. The work on the tin is progressing, and it will be ready to put in place when needed.

The Comedie Francaise is soon to lose another of its most eminent societaires, and again, as in the case of Laroche, an actor still in the possession of all his powers has determined to retire. This time it is Frederic Febvre, without whom Alexandre Dumas thinks it is impossible properly to present one of his plays, and who is deservedly loved as well as admired by the Parisian public.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- The National Executive Committee of the Prohibition Party held a meeting at the Sherman House to-day. The party Intends to begin work for the nest Presidential campaign at once and this meeting was called for the purpose of devising and perfecting a plan of State work which will, when completed, be submitted to the State Central Committee for its approval.

-- L. B. Potter, the authority on good roads, who handles the League of American Wheelmen work in that direction is going abroad the first part of July to be gone until September. He will spend fifty days on his wheel in France. Switzerland. Germany, and Holland for the purpose of studying the roads of those countries.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- There is at least a possibility that the Infanta Eulalie of Spain will not visit the United States and attend the World's Fair. She was expected to arrive here May 19, and has proceeded as far on her way as Havana, but that she will continue thereon in accordance with the programme originally prepared is not yet decided.
The trial of James H. Pigot, the Brooklyn Columbian, is over. It ended last night at 6 o'clock in a disagreement of the jury after that body had deliberated for more than eight hours.

The Psi Upsilon banquet at Springfield, Mass., on Friday evening next promises to be the moat successful college event of the season. Mr. Asa W. Tonney, President of the fraternity, has succeeded in providing an attractive and notable list of speakers for this interesting meeting. Conspicuous among the gentlemen who will respond to toasts are ex-Gov. Alexander H. Rice of Massachusetts.

A communication asking the co-operation of the railroads in the work of the National League for Good Roads was received by L. P. Farmer, Commissioner of the Passenger Department of the Trunk Line Association, two or three days ago, and Mr. Farmer has sent copies of it to the members of the Passenger Committee in order that the matter may be considered at the next meeting of that committee.

-- Manager T. Henry French announces that his new American Theatre in Eighth Avenue will positively open next Thursday evening with the first production in America of the great English melodrama. "The Prodigal Daughter." Mr. French has engaged a strong cast for this production, the closing of the regular season at many houses giving him the choice among the beat of American artists.

The General was sixteen years old. She was a maid of all work, one of the unfortunate tribe specified as general servants, and her home was in a Bloomsbury lodging house, in a shabby-genteel street which abutted on a large square. Not much room for romance or interest here, you think; possibly not, except the every-day kind of romance inseparable from any human life lived honestly and bravely.

Bertha Dorn, a Long Island maiden, who lives on her father's farm in the hamlet of Plain View, near Hicksville, is suffering from a wounded heart. To-morrow, in the City Court, before Judge McGowan, she will try to convince a jury that $10,000 would heal the wound.

Mrs. Catherine Raynes, a young and pretty widow, who was spending the Summer at "Safford Inn," tucked her two little children into the pony cart one afternoon, arranged reins and whip with the precision of a Jehu, and drove away.

Ex-Minister Robert T. Lincoln and Ambassador Bayard were yesterday the principals in an exchange of courtesies between the old Republican and the new Democratic Administrations which was unique and interesting.

CHICAGO, May 13. -- The Agricultural Building of the World's Fair appears to the casual vistor too much like a country fair or a Western Fall exposition to be as interesting to those who do not follow the peaceful and bucolic pursuit of tilling the soil as some of the other exhibits. It is one of the largest structures of the exposition.

The Academy of Music was crowded to its full capacity last evening by more than 4,000 enthusiastic sympathizers with the cause of Irish home rule. The occasion was a concert under he auspices of the Irish Independent Parliamentary Fund Association, its object being the raising of funds to aid the Parnellities of Ireland in their Parliamentary struggle.

The American Institute, which has had quarters in the old rink at Sixty-third Street and Third Avenue for many years, has decided to demolish the aggregation of old sheds which now forms what is known as the American Institute Hall, and replace it with a handsome administration and exhibition building, to cost at the lowest estimate $500,000.

A fine programme at the third Sunday night Press Club Fair concert last night draw a large audience to the Grand Central Palace. The attractions included Innes and his Thirteenth Regiment Band, Miss Ida Gray Scott, soprano; Miss Agnes Florian, contralto; Miss Dora Valesea Becker, violiniste; M. Dethurens, baritone; Senor Jose Pons y Serrs, tenor, and Mrs. Marguerite Steenoken, soprano.

At the recent session of the Minnesota Legislature it was decided that the State should go into the business of storing and soiling wheat for farmers. An act was passed providing for the erection at Duluth of a State elevator of the capacity of 2,500,000 bushels, to be managed and operated by State officers, who were empowered to buy and ship grain to any j market where the price should be exceptionally attractive.

Two trade journals that are noted for their wheat reports and statistics publish interesting comments upon the condition of growing wheat as shown by the latest Government report and the official reports of several States. The Cincinnati Price Current says:
The band of Republicans who went on the excursion of the National League to Louisville last week have returned, bowed down with many sorrows.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- "The Woman's Congress this week will be one of the most notable ever held by women," said Mrs. Susan B. Anthony to-day. "Every department in which she has secured recognition and gained reputation for her sex will be represented. I have looked forward to this occasion with a great deal of pleasure.

The Rev. S.A. Eliot, a son of the President of Harvard University, preached his first sermon yesterday as pastor of the Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn. He was recently called from Denver, Col.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 14. -- The days that intervene before the Yale crew will take up its a quarters at New-London can almost be counted on the fingers. At this time last year "Bob" Cook had visited New-Haven, worked with the men, and made his final choice. And then on to the race it only remained for the individual oars to become thoroughly accustomed to each other and their stroke.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 14. -- The Republicans elected a Senator in North Smithfield yesterday, which gives them, with the Lieutenant Governor, fifty-five votes in the next General Assembly. This constitutes a majority in Grand Committee and will enable them to elect Republican State officers unless further complications arise by the unseating of Republicans by the Democratic House.

George Durynik, a middle-aged Bohemian, who for more than a year has been held in the Ward's Island Lunatic Asylum, is likely to be released this week, it is thought, in consequence of the hearing of testimony before J.J. Nealis, whom Judge Patterson appointed referee in the case.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 14. -- A well-dressed young man registered at the Lazerno Hotel here as Arthur Coleman of Montreal, on May 5. At first he said he was traveling for his health, but the third day he told the clerk that he was looking after the interests of Dunham, Buckley Co., dry goods, of New-York. He appeared to have lots of money, and soon made the acquaintance of the young men about town.

REVOLUTIONARY PATRIOTS. -- "Descendant": Is there a record in the War Department at Washington or in any of the department offices of New-York State of the commissions and services of officers and soldiers in the Continental Army of the Revolution.

Ex-Alderman and ex-Excise Commissioner John J. Morris was a prisoner yesterday morning in the Yorkville Police Court, having been arrested by an officer of the Central Park Police on a technical charge of disorderly conduct. Mr. Morris, who lives at the Hotel Beresford at Eighty-first street and Central Park West, is a member of Dr. Paxton's church, in West Forty-second Street.

Samuel Peyor is a blind man who can be seen almost any day along Eighth or Ninth Avenues, between Thirty-fourth and Forty-second Streets, playing an accordion, with a little dog standing near. Peyor is large and broad shouldered, and, when intoxicated, is a hard man to handle. It is said that his income from his begging is large.

ORANGE, N.J., May 14. -- One of the most notable society events which has ever taken place in the Oranges will be the open-air performance of "As You Like It," to be given on the lawn of Oliver S. Carter's beautiful residence, "Mountainside," on Monday afternoon, May 29, for the benefit of the House of the Good Shepherd.

The crowds or people riding, driving, and on foot which thronged Riverside Park and promenade, from early morning to twilight yesterday, were treated to an animated scene which renewed the recent memories of the great naval parade. The magnificent Russian, General Admiral, under the command of Capt Berolbrasoff, weighed anchor at 3:30 and steamed up river, preparatory to swinging around and departing for France.
In the Autumn a third volume of William Winter's "Shadows of the Stage" will be issued by Macmillan Co. It will be devoted to Edwin Booth.

NEW-YORK. MONDAY, May 15 -- A.M. Liquidation was a feature of the stock market throughout the week, and as a result of it Wall Street now views the general situation more calmly than it did a week ago. There was some uneasiness on Monday morning, but it was followed by a substantial rally in prices and subsequently trading became narrow.

OMAHA, Neb., May 14. -- There stood on a side track under the Eleventh Street viaduct last night an interesting relic of old-time railroading. It was the private car in which President Lincoln traveled about the country back in the sixties.

It is a rather difficult task nowadays to make sketches of travel interesting to the general reader. Everybody who goes to Europe comes back with a story to tell, and it is generally the same old story. The charm of this little book by Miss Wiggin is the more delightful because it is uncommon.

President Powers of the Eastern League has issued the following bulletin: Contracts, Approved: With Albany, William Calihan; Binghamton, Frank Lang; Buffalo, William Schellerman; Erie, John Healy; Providence, James Sullivan, Charles E. Bassett, M.J. Madden; Troy, James H. Devlin, E.L. Breckenridge, R.W. Miller, T.J. Scheffier; Wilkesbarre, John Irwin, H.F. Goodall, George Staltz. Released: By Buffalo, H.F. Mace; Providence, J. V. Martin, James Hanivan; Springfield, George A. Wilson.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 14. -- It has been rumored that Prof. Barbour intended to leave Rutgers next year to go to Princeton as Professor of Elocution to take the place of Prof. Raymond, who has resigned. Princeton did extend an invitation to Prof. Barbour, but he declined, as he prefers to stay here for the present.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: One of the assertions made by protected manufacturers in the American Economist of April 21, 1893, is that the lowering of duties would decrease the wages fund.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 14. -- The handsome new Congregational Church of Patchogue, just completed at a cost of $50,000, was formally dedicated this morning in the presence of a great audience, composed of members of the denomination from New-York and Brooklyn, who came on special trains.

When one who thinks he knows all about horses and horse races sits down with the list of starters for to-day's Brooklyn Handicap race in front of him, he cannot help saying that the race looks for all the world like a walk-over for Lamplighter, and that all the contest there will be in the race is the contest for the second and third money.

According to the information thus far received, Messrs. H.B. HOLLINS Co. will have a pretty clear case against the news agency that sent out over its "tickers" the statement that that firm had announced its suspension. The circulation of such a statement is a clear damage to the victims of it, and it was started in this case by the gross misconduct of an employe of the agency.

The Kings County Tennis Club announces Tuesday, May 30, as the opening day for its regular Spring tournament. The tournament will be held on the club grounds, Dean Street and Kingston Avenue, and will be open to the members only. The events contested will probably be the same as last year, men's singles, men's doubles, mixed doubles, and women's singles.

It looks as if the New-York Presbytery might have been counting without its host in the proposition that the Presbyterian Home Board give to mission work among the Jews in this city "its special attention at this time," and that the subject might, after all, be referred for instructions to the General Assembly, which will meet this week in Washington.
The port of Suvanillo, in the Province of New-Granada, United States of Colombia, South America, has only just escaped an attack or, at any rate, a belligerent visit from a United States man-of-war.

The navy appropriations of the coming fiscal year contain the sum of $200,000 for the construction of a submarine torpedo boat and experiments therewith. Designs have accordingly been invited, either with or without bids, and at least one plan, that of Mr. HOLLAND, well known in this form of boat construction, has been received.

In inviting Controller Myers and the Elevated Railroad Extensions Committee to meet them in conference at Mr. Steinway's to-day, the Rapid-Transit Commissioners hare outlined programme for a lively meeting. The invitation amounts to a request that the city authorities and the Manhattan Company, who have been at odds in print and in the courts over the value or elevated franchises come together now and fight it out.

-- Orrin A. Hickok will have the best of the Palo Alto trotters this year. Among them are Azote, Advace, Eider, Avens, Allivo, Sweet Rose, and Expressive. They are all strongly infused with thoroughbred blood. Azote is half thoroughbread, Lady Amanda, the dam of Advance, is thoroughbread, and Palo Alto, the sire of Avena, is half thoroughbred, while the dams of Allivo and Expressive were thoroughbred mares.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The crew of the University of Pennsylvania now row in their shell, with occasional returns to the pair oar. They are rowing every day in the following order: Barnes, '94, Law, stroke; Waters, '94, Dental. No. 7; Wilson, '94. Medical, No. 6; O. Wagonhurst, '96. College, No. 5; Marshall, '94, Veterinary, Captain. No. 4; J.H. Wagonhurst, '94, College, No. 3; Beck, '95. Medical, No. 2, and Hollingshed, '94, Medical, bow.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 14. -- Gen. Aureliano Rivera, one of the bravest and most celebrated officers of the Mexican Army, has done more during the past live months toward suppressing the typhus fever epidemic in Mexico than all the physicians of the country combined.

TRENTON, N.J., May 14. -- Although the election of the next United States Senator to represent, this State is nearly two years distant, the contest is close enough at hand to engage the attention of those who hope to out conspicuous figures in it.

The London cable from Harold Frederic in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES announcing that the exodus of Jews from Poland had actually Begun, and that the refugees were already arriving in America, was almost as ranch of a surprise to the Jews of New-York as the exclusive news in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of the previous Sunday to the effect that edicts which would result in an exodus had been promulgated by the Czar.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- Another Puritanical Sabbath was observed inside the fair ground gates to-day. From 10 o'clock in the morning until 5 in the evening there was an almost continuous stream of wanderers passing down Stony Island Avenue along the whole western side of the grounds.

CHICAGO, May 14. -- New-York is going to turn loose nearly half a million honey bees right in the midst of the World's Fair within a few days. This announcement is made by Oreil L. Hersheiser of Big Tree, near Buffalo, Superintendent of the New-York State exhibit of bees and honey in the Agricultural Building, and until the idea becomes familiar it is going to carry consternation in its train.

-- In regard to the comments caused by the alleged lethargy of the New York Athletic Club in athletics the club journal says: "Our club is to-day as actively engaged in athletics as at any time during its existence. The indoor games held this season contain more than the average number of New York Athletic Club entries, and at the Twelfth Regiment a first and second prize were won by wearers of the winged foot.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The United States Supreme Court cleared its docket pretty well the past week and got its business into good shape for its annual Summer recess by passing upon some twenty-seven cases, most of which were of interest only to the parties directly affected and which depended upon special statements of facts.

NEW-HAVEN, May 14. -- It is the gala time at Yale, with the Spring regatta Saturday, a ball game Monday, the presentation Monday evening in the Hyperion of the musical extravaganza "Robin Hood. Jr." The latter will be quite a social event. There is a great demand for tickets. The New-York Yale alumni will attend in force, several parties from that city having chartered special cars.

The most imposing ecclesiastical demonstration that has ever been witnessed in Hoboken took place yesterday at St. Michael's Monastery and at the Church of Our Lady of Grace, of which the Rev. Father Corrigan is rector, on the occasion of the visit of Archbishop Satolli, the Papal Delegate to this country.

The sophomore class held a meeting last Thursday at which the following students were appointed to serve as editors on the Violet board for next year: J.O. Boyd, G.L. Weekes, B.L. Stern, R. Seggie, and J. Smith. The above students represent their respective fraternities. H.B. Singer and J.L. Neuman were apponted to represent the neutral students.

The Brooklyn Jockey Club begins its fourteen days' meeting at the Gravesend track at 2:30 this afternoon with a splendid card, aside from the great feature of the day, the Brooklyn Handicap, which is the fourth race, and the chances of which are fully discussed in another column. The entries to the races, aside from the Handicap, are as follows:

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, May 14. -- There is great suffering and destitution among the lower classes in the Altar mining district, this State, owing to the severe drought that has prevailed there for the past four years. All of the mountain streams, springs, and wells are dry, and water must be hauled from the village of San Antonio, a distance of twenty-five miles.

The Democrats of the Twenty-fourth Ward, Brooklyn, are jubilant William H. Lyon, Jr., who was considered for years one of the stanchest and most influential Republicans in Brooklyn, has applied for membership in the organization known as the Twenty-fourth Ward Democrats.

A petition to be forwarded to the President, the Secretary of State, and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the United States Senate has been drawn up and signed by prominent gentlemen regarding the proposed treaty of extradition with Russia.

A statement in the newspapers that the Assessors of Lowell, Mass., and Paris, France, had expressed their intention of placing a tax on bicycles is creating considerable talk among wheelmen. It is agreed that a tax on bicycles would be a burden placed directly upon thousands of mechanics, to whom the bicycle has become a necessity in traveling from their homes to work.

A special service was held yesterday afternoon at the Gustavus Adolphus Evangelical Lutheran Church, Twenty-second Street and Third Avenue, in honor of the Swedish Lutheran Bishop K.H.G. von Soheele, who has come to this country as a delegate appointed by King Oscar from the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Sweden to be present at the jubilee in honor of the three hundredth anniversary of the Swedish Reformation, to be held at Book Island. Ill.

Theodore Weld Farmele, Who died at His home, 325 West Fifty-sixth Street, yesterday moraine, was born in New-York City in June, 1833. At the breaking out of the war he was a private in the Seventh Regiment, and went to Washington with, it When the command returned to this city he became Major at the Thirty-seventh New-York Volunteers.

The Central Labor Federation is making strenuous efforts to raise money to help the Socialists in Germany to carry on their campaign for the approaching parliamentary elections. The reports from the various unions at yesterday's meeting, however, were not very encouraging, as only $45 had been raised, and at least 200 times that amount is needed.
NEWARK, N.J., May 14. -- The municipal ring displayed some more of its "fine work" at a meeting of the Street and Water Board last evening.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 14. -- While Manhattan Island and Long Island were wrapped in slumber at 2 o'clock this morning ex-Mayor Gleason was performing one of those prodigies of audacity which originally boosted him into fame and kept him there, in spite of an army of bitter foes.

Lawyer James W. MoLaughlin, who with E. Townsend Goldberg defended Murderer Frank W. Roehl, will leave this forenoon for Sing Sing. When he gets there, he will ask Warden Durston of the prison to exhume the body of the man picked up in the Hudson River with a bullet hole in his head and identified as that of Roehl.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- The medical department of the University of Pennsylvania held its one hundred and nineteenth, and the dental department its fifteenth annual commencement at the Academy of Music May 10. The graduates number 210, and represent nearly every State in the Union, besides eleven foreign countries. The valedictory address was delivered by Dr. William F. Norris.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 14. -- That Mr. Royal Phelps Carroll has gone in for comfort as well as speed in his eighty-four-footer Navahoe is apparent from a look through the yacht below decks. Whatever there may be outside, there is nothing of the racer here, but all is comfort, elegance, and convenience.

The Western Society of New-York, organized about a month ago, has secured permanent headquarters at 19 West Twenty-fourth Street, and is in such, a condition as to justify its projectors in predicting for it a brilliant future. Men who have resided west of the Allegheny Mountains for five years or more are eligible to membership.
Following are some of the opinions expressed at the race tracks yesterday as to the probable winner of the Brooklyn Handicap:

About 300 bidders were present in the paddock of the Hudson County Racing Association Saturday morning when William Easton sold twenty-two race horses, the property of James H. McCormick and others, at auction. The bidding was spirited and the top price was paid for Indigo, a full brother to Sallie McClelland.

At Association Hall, East Twenty-third Street, yesterday morning, the Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., delivered his fourth lermon on "The Gates of Hell in Modern Babylon," before a large and attentive congregation. The subject was "The Saloon in the City." and in analyzing the conditions of to-day he said:
Yesterday was not what one might call an ideal day for this time of the year, but the sunshine at noon induced many thousands of pleasure seekers to journey to Coney Island.

Noah L. Farnham Post of the Grand Army of the Republic will stand by the position it has taken on the pension question. To a man the sentiment in the pout is in favor or scaling the pension list so that those alone who deserve aid from the Government shall receive it for war service.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14. -- In spite of the fact that the Harvard baseball nine has lost two college games this season, one to Georgetown University and the other to the University of Pennsylvania, the Harvard men feel that they have a pretty strong team. At Harvard, John Clarkson trained the pitchers for several years, but this Spring he went to Yale and Timothy Keefe took his place.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 14. -- "A popular error." said a preacher of national fame the other day, "ascribes to the Presbyterian Church a conservatism which it does not possess in fact. On the contrary. Its men or letters have been, since the days of Calvin, the most restless of all philosophers. They have been speculative to a remarkable degree.

The Rev. Gilbert Read, who has been for more than ten years a missionary in China, preached yesterday morning in the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, on "The Injustice of the Chinese Exclusion Bill." He referred at considerable length to the political side of the question. In concluding he said:

Capt. Devery of the Eldridge Street Police and his detectives were busy yesterday collecting evidence to combat the story of William Flannelly, the young truck driver, who is accused of having shot and killed Mary Sexton in the tenement house 222 Chrystle Street, early on Saturday morning. Flannelly now declares that the girl shot herself because he had informed her that he intended to leave her.

A press association dispatch, sent from Berlin on Saturday asserts, in contradiction of the recent dispatches of our London correspondent, that there is no movement for the expulsion of Jews from Poland. A few persons suspected of being engaged in smuggling, it is said in this dispatch, have been dislodged from places along the frontier, but will he permitted to settle in the interior. This is all, we are told.

The annual banquet of the Parisian students always rants among the most interesting of that city's Spring events. It has long been their onstom to invite somebody of note, literary or otherwise, to preside, and the speech he makes becomes the object of wide attention.

The trial of PIGOT, the clerk in the Department of Public Works in Brooklyn, closed on Saturday night with, what was substantially a failure of justice. The jury disagreed, seven of them, it is reported, being for conviction and five for acquittal. Judge MOORE discharged the jury after eight hours.

The second annual athletic games between Columbia and Princeton next Saturday are engrossing the attention of the majority of the students at the two colleges, and also the college athletes from Yale and Harvard, who will be enabled to gauge the respective strength of the two teams for the intercollegiate games the following Saturday.

TRENTON, N.J., May 14. -- Neither Bishop O'Farrell of the Diocess of Trenton nor Vicar General McFaul will attend the banquet to be given to-morrow at Hoboken in Honor of the visit of Mgr. Satolli. While no particular reason is assigned for their absence, some prominent Catholics venture the statement that the Bishop will not do anything that might add to the discomfiture of Bishop Wigger.

President E.P. Cragin of the Columbian Sunday Association of Chicago, also a member of the national committee of five on the Sunday closing of the World's Fair, and J.H. Knowles, Secretary of the American Sabbath Union, had a conference in this city yesterday as to the nature of the campaign to be carried on this week to keep the gates to the World's Fair closed next Sunday.

The accounts from Chicago fully confirm the predictions of those who maintained when the questions of Sunday opening was before Congress, that if the visitors at chicago did not visit the fair on Sunday they would do worse. The opponents of the opening seemed to assume that the questions was between the fair and the churches, which indicates not only an "austere" but a bucolic way of looking at the subject.

The National Federation of America, which is the title borne by that body of Irishmen and Irish sympathizers who are friendly to the McCarthy wing of the Parliamentary party and to Mr. Gladstone, is inclined to smile broadly at the meeting or concert held Sunday evening in the Academy of Music.

When young Mr. Salvini makes his entr'actes shorter, gets his hand in time and tune, and trains some of his actors to pitch their voices so as to fill the vast auditorium of the Manhattan Opera House, perhaps his new bill will be popular. It ought to be if for no other reason than the desire to get away from the dreary old round of melodrama and farce that its selection indicates.

THE TIMES yesterday morning in reviewing the possibilities of the handicap said: "It is certain that some horse will be subjected to them [interferences] in this race. It is as likely to be Lamplighter as any other horse."

For no apparent reason, except that which might be inferred from a remark made Sunday night, William Koch, the proprietor of the buffet saloon at 1,235 Broadway, committed suicide yesterday by severing the main artery of his left arm with a penknife.

The Executive Committee of the American Sabbath Union met at 201 Broadway yesterday morning to discuss what pressure could be brought to boar to prevent the Chicago Fair Directors from opening the gates of the fair next Sunday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 15. -- The Farmers and Merchants' State Bank suspended payment this afternoon, the following notice being posted:

NEW-ORLEANS, May 15. -- A remarkable suicide on Sunday was that of Aristide Mary, the most wealthy and one or the best-known colored men of Louisianna. He was a native of this city, bat was, educated in Paris. He first oame into notice by being appointed an Alderman of the city by Gen. P.H. Sheridan when he displaced the Monroe Council in 1867.

Two-thirds of the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States have joined in the decision sustaining the validity of the Geary act for the exclusion of Chinese laborers from this country. We feared that it would be a difficult matter for the court to find, any tangible ground upon which the hasty and unjust action of Congress could be set aside.

The auction sales for to-day include two especially attractive offerings by Peter F. Meyer. These are thirty-four lots at 163d and 164th Sts. and Morris Av., which should prove tempting to investors, and also ten lots, four of which are at the southwest corner of West End Av. and 106th St.

- Next Saturday the postponed tournament of the Oval Club will be played off at the Berkeley Oval The tournament is an invitation one. open to women only. The first matches were played last Saturday. Miss Lulu Mowery of the Englewood Field Club defeating Miss Morre of the Hohokus Valley Tennis Club in the singles. Miss Homans and Miss Burdetie of the Englewood Field club won from the Misses Ervingof Rye.

BIDDEFORD, Me., May 15. -- Max L. Lizotte, a one-armed lawyer of this place, to-day swore out a warrant for the arrest of John L. Sullivan, ex-champion heavy weight pugilist of the world, who assaulted him on a sleeping car last night. The lawyer reached in front of Sullivan to shake hands with John Sheehan, a member of Sullivan's party.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The board of naval officers charged with examining Pay Inspector Stevenson with a view to determining his fitness for promotion will probably conclude its hearings on Wednesday next. Saturday was spent in reading the record of the inquiry into charges against Mr. Stevenson while he was stationed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Within 10O yards at the spot where Jim Fisk was shot and killed, Henry Gebhardt was murdered yesterday morning by August Wanner, whom he had discharged from the employ of his firm Saturday evening. Then Wanner shot himself.

THE CRYSTAL MAZE. -- Since the Maze was opened, at Broadway and Thirty-eighth Street. negotiations hare been entered into for building mazes at Philadelphia, Boston, Montreal, Cincinnati, Buffalo, Chicago, San Francisco, Kansas City, Atlantic City, and Coney Island. Herr von Prutwitz Palm, the inventor and patentee, who receives a royalty on all of the mazes erected, expects to return to Hungary, his native country, within the next two years a veritable Croesus.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 15. -- Ex-Mayor Patrick J. Gleason of Long Island City, who on Sunday morning stole a march on the Brooklyn City Railway and the officials of Newtown and took possession of a street at the dead hour of night for the purpose of extending his electric railway on alleged forbidden ground, was at work again to-day with a hundred or more men gridironing a thoroughfare known as the New-town Road.

LONDON, May 15. -- In the House of Commons to-day, Sir J. Blundell Maple, Conservative, asked the Prime Minister whether the value of the Post Office property in Ireland, which the Imperial Government proposed to give, free of cost or compensation, to the new Irish Government to be created by the Home Rule bill, amounted to the total of u4,000,000.

Yachtsmen are taking advantage of the fine weather, and work on fitting out the yachts for the season is being rushed along. One of the busiest places near here is Tebo's yard, at the foot of Twenty-third Street, South Brooklyn. All the big steamers are at this yard, and many of them are nearly ready to go in commission.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Over twelve months of labor, involving correspondence with every portion of the civilized globe, culminated this morning in one of the most truly representative and brilliant gatherings of women that has ever assembled.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 15. -- R.S. Osborne. Secretary of State, was this afternoon bound over to the District Court to stand trial for criminal libel, the preliminary examination establishing the probability of his guilt. Mr. Osborno had charged Cyrus Leland with practically stealing State coal from the penitentiary mine and selling it to his county officials.

NEW-YORK. MONDAY, May 15 -- P.M. There was a much better feeling in the Street to-day. It is true that there was weakness in the early trading as a consequence of soiling orders from London, but by noon most of the losses had been recovered. A slight depression followed shortly after 12 o, clock, but later on stocks were quite buoyant.

There was a wild scene in the County Court House yesterday morning during the examination as to the mental condition of Philip McDowell, the proprietor of the "Fan Horn," a well-known resort at Twenty-third Street and Ninth Avenue. McDowell, it is alleged, has been insane for six weeks. Recently, he has been confined in Bloomingdale Asylum.
Collector Hendricks was busy at his desk yesterday morning wHen a well-dressed woman entered his office.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- Robert A. Fales, the boy murderer who is confined in the Essex County Jail, made an attempt to escape last night. In the course of the day he had asked permission to scrub the floor in the bathroom. The Wardens became auspicious at this request, and, after Fales had gone back to his cell, the floor of the bathroom was examined.

Mr. Russell Sago, who hag hitherto not been talking very confidently, is now advising friends to show courage and buy stocks. Mr. Sage is credited with having bought many thousand shares of conspicuous stocks during the last week.

All four of the big English cutters have now been launched, and the Britannia and Calluna have had very satisfactory trial trips. A description of the Britannia has been printed, in THE TIMES. The following accounts of the Calluna, Valkyrie, and Satanita are taken from the latest number of the London field:

-- Carter of Yale up to date has struck out 122 men in the few games he hag pitched this season. He has held some of the strongest college nines in the country down wonderfully, his greatest performance being to retire the Brown University Club with but a single hit. His ability has found signal recognition in an offer from the Boston League nine, which is in need of another pitcher.
"What are the prospects of putting cable cars on the road?" asked a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday of Superintendent Newell of the Broadway and Seventh Avenue Railroad.

John Mee and Edward Desjardins, leaders of the Alliance waiters, called yesterday forenoon at the coffee and luncheon rooms of Naething Brothers at 118 Fulton Street and asked Charles F. Naething to increase the wages of the waiters there. The men work three and a half hours, and get 50 cents and two meals. They wanted 75 cents, but not a third meal.

CONCORD, N.H., May 15. -- George H. Abbott, alias Frank L. Almy, will before noon to-day be hanged for the brutal murder at Hanover, N. H., on July 17, 1891, of Christle Warden. Ten out of fifteen of the last years of his life have been spent in prison. His father, overcome by shame, killed himself years ago.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- Bonds will be issued by the Whisky Trust to carry out the plan proposed by it of reaching consumers without the intervention of middlemen. The question, a solution of which the financial world has waited for two weeks, President Greenhut says, was settled at a meeting of the Board of Directors to-day.
Senator John Sherman and ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt were within hailing distance of each other yesterday, but did not speak to each other.

NEW-YORK. -- Detectives raided 4O New Street, an alleged "bucket shop." yesterday and seized three phonographs and $814, and arrested four men, George W. Rumble, Charles Matthews, Monroe Williams, and Frank Cole. Rumble, the proprietor of the place, and Matthews, the cashier, were held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for violating the gambling law.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- A disappointingly small decrease in the visible supply of wheat, financial disturbance at Minneapolis, and toward the close reported rains in France worked against the bulls to-day in wheat. The market closed with a loss for the day of 7/8c. Corn was firm, and gained 1/8c for July and 1/4c for September. The provision market was dull and narrow without any striking changes in values at the close.

Some of our contemporaries have rather severely criticised Justice PATTERSON of the Supreme Court for his action in sealing papers in a, certain case recently brought before him, and in refusing to reveal the contents of the papers or even the nature of the action. These criticisms have been based upon the perfectly just and sound principle that justice should be administered with open doors.

About 150 members of the Alumni Club of Union Theological Seminary met last night in the beautiful now dining room of the St. Denis Hotel on the occasion of the club's annual dinner. The Rev. Dr. Henry M. Booth, President of the club, sat at the head of the table, with the venerable Dr. Charles Butler. President of the seminary's Board of Directors, at his right and President Hastings at his left.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Mr. George Kennan, tie well-known writer on Russia, to-day sent to President Cleveland several protests against the Russian extradition treaty. Mr. Kennan will said Wednesday, from New-York, for Enrope.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 15. -- The fierce fight here over the Post Office appointments, which has attracted much attention, brought oat a decision from the Postmaster General to-day, and the result is the Republican clerks and carriers, who thought they were protected by oivil service rules, are about ready to throw up the sponge to-night.

The Rev. William Henry Augustus Bissell, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Vermont, died Sunday. He had rallied from the wellnigh fatal attack of last December, but unfavorable symptoms set in last Friday. He was born in Randolph, Vt., Nov. 10, 1814. He was graduated from the University of Vermont in the class of '36.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The first race meeting of the Chevy Chase Hunt Club began this afternoon at the Ivy City race track under the rules of the American Hunt and Pony Racing Association. There was a good crowd in attendance. The track was in excellent condition.

DENVER, Col., May 15. -- William B. Mygatt, a well-known banker and business man, made an assignment to-day to James F. Hopkins. He places his assets at $591,860 and his liabilities at $507,889.35. Mr. Mygatt was a member of the old banking firm of McIntosh. Mygatt, this city, of which the National Bank of Commerce was an outgrowth.

William Bliss, President of the Boston and Albany Railroad, and A.J. Cassatt, a Director of the Pennsylvania Railroad, are the arbitrators to whom was referred the Question of increased fares on the very fast trains between New-York and Chicago.

BOSTON, May 15. -- Once more the Giants were forced to accept defeat. They opened the season here with the champions in the presence of 8,000 persons, and although they batted Nichols hard and often the Boston fielders saved the game by remarkably pretty work. Gov. Russell and other State and municipal dignitaries graced the occasion with their presence.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- No orders had been issued at the Treasury Department at the close of business to-day as to the deporting of Chinese under the Geary act. The instructions under which Collectors of Internal Revenue and United States Marshals are now operating direct them to make no arrests of unregistered Chinamen until further orders.

CHICAGO, May 15. -- As a result of the attempt on the part or the World's Fair Executive to exclude Government officers from the grounds except on the pay mentor admission fee, the arrest of two World's Fair officers was made this afternoon. Capt. W.L. Deremer, chief of gate inspectors, and Gatekeeper H. Shuenenman were taken into custody at the World's Fair grounds by Deputy Marshal Strahan and brought before United States Commissioner Hoyne.

Mr. Stuart Reason has wisely gone book to "The Henrietta." His revival of "She Stoops to Conquer," exceedingly fine in a pictorial sense, and not objectionable to the multitude because the text of the old play was changed, was quite off the key in the performance. It did not draw.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 15. -- The North-Western Guaranty Loan Company is embarrassed, owing to the financial stringency. The company is about thirty years old. and its capital stock is 31,250,000. It owns the two-million-dollar building in which its offices are, and holds as collateral and in fee simple a large amount of real property here, in Chicago, and elsewhere.

Our esteemed contemporary, the Herald expresses its pleasure that a spirit of unusual friendliness prevails at present among all the newspapers of this city. The Herald had occasion on Sunday to publish an illustrated article concerning New-York newspapers and those who make them, and it yesterday expressed the opinion that nothing pertaining to the newspaper press is "more significant than the fact that peace and good-will prevail among them all." The Herald continues:
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2@3 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.

"The luck of Italians" in the higher criminal courts has come to be proverbial. Fewer convictions are obtained at trials of prisoners who are Italians than at those of members of any other nationality under similar circumstances.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 15. -- A commission arrived in this city to-day for the purpose of examining into the workings of the prohibitory law. The commission, sent by the Canadian Government, is composed of Judge Herbert S. McDonald of Brockville, Ontario; the Rev. Frederick McLeod of Frodericton, N.B.; G.A. Gigault, the Minister of Agriculture of Quebec, and Albert Horton.
LONDON, May 15. -- To-day was Scotch Term and the day of final strain for the Australian banks, as well as the last day of grace given to defaulters on the Stock Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Isaac L. Rice, who, under the regime of Mr. McLeod, was the foreign representative of the Reading Railroad Company, with offices in London, and who, after the appointment of the receivers for the road, made an examination of the company's books in the interests of the bondholders, to-night made public the resale of his examination of the Boston and Maine, and New-York and New-England stock transactions.

Diablo, son of Bolus and Grace Darling, under the brilliant pilotage of Fred Taral, won the great Brooklyn Handicap on the Gravesend track yesterday. Nearly 30,000 people saw the race won, and of that creat multitude there were few indeed who had any reason to rejoice, either over the winnine of wagers or over the belief that the rich prize had been won by the best horse.

The Rev. Father Corrigan entertained Delegate Satolli to-day at a public banquet in the school hall of St. Mary's Parish, Hoboken. About 120 persons sat down to the dinner. The hall was draped handsomely with, evergreens and the national colors. Dr. Corrigan presided. Delegate Satolli sat at his right and Gov. Werts at his left.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the erection of the following new buildings were filed:
A very handsome collection of vehicles is on exhibition at the repositories of Messrs. Flandrau Co., 372 Broome Street, and Fifty-first Street and Broadway.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- There is an unpleasant experience in store for Capt. Francis J. Higginson of the United States cruiser Atlanta. The Atlanta is now on her way to Greytown, Nicaragua. Soon after she reaches that port Capt. Higginson will receive an official document from the Navy Department, the contents of which are summarized in the following entry made in the order book of the department to-day:

Members at the firm of H.B. Hollins Co. were busy yesterday conferring with their counsel and prosecuting their investigation of the rumors about their house which led to Mr. Hollins's formal letter to the President of the Stock Exchange on Saturday. They had communication, too, with the District Attorney in reference to a searching legal inquiry into the case.

Recent assassinations and felonious assaults committed by so-called Italians in or near this city indicate that the stern lesson read to the Mafia and Camorra by hot-headed citizens of New-Orleans on March 14, 1891, when they broke down the gates or the Parish Prison and shot to death a dozen wretches, the offscourings of Calabria and Sicily, has exercised no permanent effect in this latitude.

The Weehawken poolrooms did a big business yesterday. Three of them were in full blast. The little boat Midland, which piles between Forty-second Street and Weehawken, was crowded with passengers all day. The early boats took over the bookmakers and their assistants. By noontime the New-York ferryhouse was jammed, and the three poolrooms and two saloons on the other side were soon filled to overflowing.

Upon the basis afforded by crop reports recenty lissued by the Department of Agriculture and by several States, it has been estimated by some authorities that the entire wheat crop this year may not exceed 440,000,000 bushels. This would be larger, however, than the average annual crop for the six years immediately preceding the great crop year of 1891.

This afternoon the younger tennis players of New-York city and vicinity will meet on the Columbia Oval, William's Bridge. The tournament will be held under the auspices of Colombia College, and no one who la not a schoolboy will be allowed to compete. The winner will then face the champions of the Yale. Harvard, and Princeton sections at Newport for the interacholastte championship of America.
"My and Gen. Di Cesnola's Explorations in Cyprus" was the title of Dr. Max Ohnefalsch-Richter's lecture last night at Chickering Hall.

John S. Hulin of 373 Broadway, a member of Noah L. Farnham Post, which is under suspension for its expressions regarding the pension abuses, yesterday resigned his appointment as aide de camp to the Grand Marshal, George M. Barry, for the Decoration Day parade.

The principal auction sale of real estate yesterday in point of attendance was that of Mr. James L. Wells, who offered 174 lots on King's Bridge Heights at the salesroom in the Trinity Building. The property has been improved by macadamized roads, sewers, water, and gas. Bidding was slow, and the prices obtained were not as good as the owners expected.

By long odds the prettiest game of ball played in this vicinity this season was the contest at Eastern Park yesterday between the Brooklyn and Baltimore Clubs. From start to finish the game was replete with pretty fielding plays, clover hits, and daring base running, and all but one of the runs scored were earned. The game, too, was close, and not until the last man was retired ware the Brooklyns confident of victory.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15. -- The most exciting game of baseball on the Harvard home grounds this season was played this afternoon between Harvard and Brown. When, at the end of the tenth inning, the game was called on account of the darkness the score was tied -- 2 to 2.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 15. -- The mystery of Richard V. Hall's disappearance has been cleared up. The body of the missing man was found floating in the river over Main Street dock this morning. Hall was a well-to-do farmer, about sixty years of age, who lived in the town of Bookman. On the night of April 6 the Liquor Dealers' Association held a ball at Kirchner Hall and Hall attended it.

Not everybody is aware that there la an order of juveniles in this country embracing a membership of 215,000. Despite its romantic name, its aims are eminently practical, and girls and boys are equally eligible to be enrolled on its books and to fill its offices.

The examination papers of four candidates for the position of Customs Inspector have been cancelled by the examining board, the men being charged with assisting one another, or with using private memoranda to assist them in answering the questions.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Gov. Flower looted fatigued this evening. This was the combined result of the warm weather and the steady work the Governor has put in on the acts left in his hands at the close of the Legislature. Of the 403 bills left there are but 43 remaining. The time for approval expires Saturday, bat it is probable that the Governor will close out the rest in a day or two.

Creedmoor was occupied yesterday by the First Battalion, fourteenth Regiment, composed of Companies A, E.F.H, and I, together with some of the field staff and non-commissioned staff, numbering in all about 175 men. The battalion was under command of Capt. Crane. Capt. Dixon, the Regimental Inspector of Rifle Practice, had charge or the shooting, under the supervision of Gen. B.M. Whitlock, the head of the Department of Rifle Practice of the State.

Why one element of the Italian population of this city and its environs should for many years have brought undeserved obloquy upon the industrious and law-abiding majority of the race is partly explained by the fact that nine Italian immigrants, who are said to have served varying terms in prison at home for felonious crimes, were detected among the Bolivia's steerage passengers yesterday and detained at Ellis Island.

It has often been shown that the gullibility of Irish-Americans in respect to Irish affairs is inexhaustible, and that an Irish adventurer of very moderate cleverness can at any time derive his living from it without difficulty. The latest illustration of this truth is the effort now making here to provide a fund for the support of the members of Parliament who call themselves Parnellites.

Three races in which Kingston, Rainbow, and Chateau had been in tarn the winners had been ran without much attention being paid to them from the vast crowd that fretted and fumed and fussed about the stands, the ground, and the betting ring. That vast multitude was there for one purpose, and that was to see the decision of the seventh running of the Brooklyn Handicap.
Society's leading question at present is: Will there be a gala ball in honor of the Infanta Eulalle

Capt. Krogh of the Norwegian steamer Antonio Zambrano, which returned on Sunday from Savanillo, New-Granada, with the cargo that she took out for Baranquilla in December last, said yesterday that he did not go with the steamer, as he had gone to spend Christmas in Norway. Capt. Boe, the first officer, was in command.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- Lieut. Henry Lemly of the Third Cavalry has succeeded in convincing Secretary Lamont that his case is an exceptional one and should not be classed with those of officers who are absent on extended leave, whom Col. Lament has decided to send back to their regiments.

SEYMOUR, Ind., May 16. -- Lou Trenck, who murdered Henry Faedler a week ago last Sunday, was hanged at Brownstown at 1:2O A.M. by a mob from this place. The lynching party was composed of the same men who hanged Turley at Bedford yesterday morning.

PARIS, May 16. -- Sir Charles Russell resumed his argument to-day in behalf of the British case before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration. He argued mat the seizures made of British vessels in Bering Sea were not justifiable, and he reviewed at length the origin and nature of the rights transferred by Russia to the United States in 1867.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., May 16. -- The Exchange Bank of Normal, a suburb of this city, closed its doors to-day. It was a private institution, conducted by W.H.
