Schureman, and the cause of failure was doing business without adequate capital. The crash had been expected for some time. The deposits averaged $90,000, and the capital stock was supposed to be $25,000.
British naval advices report the following movements of ships of Vice Admiral Hopkins's North American squadron:

The synopsis of Isaac L. Rice's report relating to A.A. McLeod's peculiar financiering while President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, which was printed in THE TIMES yesterday morning, was engerly perused in Wail Street. The figures given by Mr. Rice confirmed many impressions that nave prevailed in railroad and financial circles in this city since the Reading property was so abruptly thrown into the hands of a receiver.
Messrs, H.B. Hollins Co. are still diligent in their campaign against the manufacturers and circulators of malicious rumors in Wall Street.

The affairs of Francis H. Weeks, who disappeared Mar 1. leaving his accounts in a badly-tangled condition, assumed a new phase yesterday because of an action taken by the Atlantic Trust Company in the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- Directors of the Whisky Trust did not take action to-day on the question of the amount of bonds to be issued by the trust. They met at 10 o'clock and took up the matter, but for the reason that the full board was not present postponed further action until to-morrow morning. The remainder of the day was devoted to routine matters.

-- The members of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club are enjoying most thoroughly the comforts of its conntry house. Sunday over fifty members sat down to dinner in the parlor of the house, and a constant stream of wheelmen dropped in in the afternoon. It is very probable that the games of the Wheelmen's Bowling League, scheduled with this club next Winter, will be rolled off at the out-of-town house.
Plenty of business was transacted yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

REYNO SO, Mexico, May 16. -- The Rio Grande River is out of its banks at this point and is doing great damage to the country, both in Mexico and Texas. Thousands of acres of bottom lands are inundated, and the losses of cattle and horses are already very heavy.

BOSTON, May 16. -- The following telegram was sent to-day by General Secretary Baer of the Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor: Mr. H.N. Higinbotham, President World's Columbian Exposition, Chicago, ill.:

Nathan B. Blum, a railroad ticket broker at 457 Broadway, was tried in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday on a charge of forgery in the third degree, preferred against him by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. The jury was out over six hours, and came in a few minutes before midnight with the report that they could not agree.
The money market continued easy. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2@3 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.

There was an exciting scene at the meeting of the Richmond County Supervisors yesterday afternoon. The report had been circulated that the board would remove from office the County Engineer of Roads, William S. Bacot, who was appointed three years ago when the building of macadam roads, under the special law passed for the county, was begun.

GARDEN CITY, May 16. -- The twenty-seventh annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of Long Island began in Garden City at 11 o'clock this morning and will continue until to-morrow evening. Bishop A.N. Littlejohn presiding.

Joshua M. Spencer, a resident of Indiana, has brought suit in tie United States Circuit Court in this city against John Ewing Rlsley, recently appointed Minister to Denmark, for an accounting of fees alleged to be due to plaintiff an assignee of certain interests of the late Senator Joseph E. McDonald.

One outcome of the visit to this country of the Duke de Veragua was made public yesterday in the announcement of the purchase by a member of his party of some property in this city for investment. The purchaser is Donna Anita Nolletali. She bought, through Messrs. Ames Co., the Venice apartment house at 408 West 57th St. The terms are kept private.

At their meeting yesterday afternoon the Police Commissioners received from Mayor Gilroy a communication relating to a protest of the Road Horse Association against police interference with fast pleasure-driving on Seventh Avenue, above One Hundred and Tenth Street. The association complained to the Mayor that a "senseless, Puritanical ordinance" had been revived, and was being enforced.
The second annual tract, athletic games between Princeton and Columbia will be held next Saturday at the Columbia athletic field at William's Bridge. The entries are as follows:

At the Grolier Club house, in the silver-white light which Flameng's painting of Grolier in the workshop of Aldus reflects, they are almost beautiful, these quaint, old, naive examples of English art of bookmaking which Beverly Chew, Bierstadt, and Marshall Lefferts know so intimately. Their awkward grace is enchanting, and the Byzantine niceties with which grave book lovers discuss their relative importance in very serious, tedious phrases seem natural, amusing, irresistible.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article which appeared in your issue of the 7th inst., commenting on Brooklyn's misgovernment in general and certain actions relative thereto on the part of the Young Men's Democratic Club in particular, contained among other things an allusion to one of its members, Mr. John Baker of the firm of Murray, Mather Baker, lawyers at 115 Broadway.
This is to certify that Mr. Lloyd Aspinwall is not, in a fit mental or physical condition to attend any examination as to his affairs at toe present time. G.H. WYNKOOP, M.D.

Mgr. Satolli, the Pope's Ablegate, ended his visit to New-Jersey yesterday and went off in a special car on the Congressional Limited that left the Pennsylvania Railroad station at 3:23 P.M. for Washington. The Rev. Dr. O'Gorman accompanied him. He had spent Monday night in Father Corrigan's rectory in Hoboken.

LONDON, May 16. -- The central part of the episcopal palace at Bishop's Court, near Douglas, Isle of Man, the seat of the Anglican Bishop of Eodor and Man, has been destroyed by fire. Bishop's Court is a handsome structure, much, resorted to by visitors to the island.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The New-York educational exhibit is one which will attract the attention of educators, teachers, and students, but it is not destined to attain much popularity among the masses. This is not because it is not a good exhibit, for it is, conceding to no State, unless it may be Massachusetts, superiority in any avenue of educational endeavor.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- A thousand or more people assembled at Third and Market Street last night to celebrate the delivery of the antiChinese decision. The chief addresses were by the anti-Chinese agitators, Dr. C.C. O'Donnell and Denis Kearney, but neither succeeded in arousing a high degree of enthusiasm. It was decided to hold a procession next Saturday night.

The sailors aboard the French man-of-war Arethuse were depressed yesterday by the death of one of their number named Raoul. He had been suffering from peritonitis. He will be buried to-day. One of the officers called on the French Consul General to make arrangements for the funeral, and the Consul General will look after the burial of the sailor.

The members of the New-York Riding Club who were the guests recently of the Detroit Riding Club have presented their Western friends with a handsome silver loving cup. Accompanying the gift was a letter of which the following is a portion:

MASPETH, L.I., May 16. -- A remarkable statement was made by a prisoner in a little courtroom in Middle Village, L.I., this evening that will be the reverse of quieting to the nerves of Superintendent Byrnes and his New-York policemen.

Just at dusk last evening George Phillips, who was taken from the little restaurant at 29 Green-point Avenue, Greenpoint, on Saturday evening, mortally wounded by a shot from the revolver of Edward K. Hoerner, or as he then called himself. Joseph Hall, died in St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn. Who he really was or where he came from he never told.

There is some evidence in to-day's dispatches that the London market is seriously affected by the unexpected continuance of the Australian crisis, and by the demands made upon London to sustain banks supposed a fortnight since to be entirely strong. How far the effect may extend, it is difficult to say.

The controversy between Mayor Wanser and the ring in Jersey City over the organization of the local boards came to an impotent conclusion at Trenton yesterday. When Finance Commissioners Edelstein and Peterson began their quo warranto proceeding against Messrs. Frazer and Detwiler. whom the Mayor had appointed to succeed them, they applied to Judge Lippincott for all order staying the new appointees from acting.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The State Department has not had any communication from the Chinese Minister since the Supreme Court decision on the Geary act. While there is some concern manifested as to how the law is to be carried into effect without an appropriation to enable the Government to enforce it, there seems to be little or no anxiety about possible retaliation by violence.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 16. -- Mr. William A. Campbell was married this evening in St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Miss Marion Hartridge Dunbar. The Rev. Chauneey C. Williams performed the ceremony and the church was crowded. The groom stood with his brother, Mr. Douglass Campbell, who acted as best man. The bride was escorted to the altar by her brother, Mr. Steiner Dunbar.
Alderman Cornelius Flynn, the giant from the First Assembly District, was the feature of yesterday's meeting of the Board of Aldermen.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 16. -- The State today opened an intelligence office and will seek to supply employers with, help at 5 cents for each situation, or, rather, for placing employer and employe in communication with each other. Labor Commissioner Todd, who was known at the Utah silver convention as "Congressman" Todd, originated the plan and presented it to Gov. Lewelling, who indorsed it and told him to go ahead.

SING SING, N.Y., May 15. -- Thomas Pallister, the murderer, is dead. Two fishermen found the body in the Hudson River this morning with a bullet wound under the left eye. The autopsy showed that death was caused by shooting, and not by drowning.
"Theresa, ran out and get me some rhubard tea," were the last words that wealthy Philip Samuels of 191 Henry Street spoke to his wife.
ALBANY, May 16. -- When Gov. Flower concluded his day's labors at the Executive Chamber this evening by handing out copies of his veto message on the Western Union Tax-Refunding bill, he said:
A pitiful story of neglect and inhumanity was told to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter by Mr. Louis Windmuller in this office, 20 Reade Street, yesterday morning.

The first regular meeting of the New-York Merchants' Discount Company was held yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Hotel. Henry W. Sohloss, President of the company, called the forty merchants present to order, and then invited Senator Jacob A. Cantor to take the chair.

-- The annual meeting of the Jackson (Mich.) Canoe Club was held lane week, and the following officers elected: Comanodoro -- S,B. mettler: Vice Commodore -- (K.G. Case: secretary and Treasurer -- F.M. Yerrick: Measurer -- E.L. Smith; Directors -- W.W. Todd, F.C. Mead. C.A, Blair, F.H. Helmer, C.E. Markham, S.B. Mettler, G.G. Caso, F.M. Yerrick. E.L. Smith; Regatta Committee -- Clyde Brown, C.A. Blair, Frank Smith.

LONDON, May 16. -- The House of Commons resumed the consideration of the Irish Home Rule bill in committee to-day. The Hon. Sir John Brodriok, formerly Financial Under Secretary to the War Office under Laid Salisbury's administration, moved to amend the second clause of the Home Rule bill so as to empower the Crown, in response to an address by the Imperial Parliament, to diminish and restrain the powers granted to the Irish Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- A court of Inquiry will be granted Capt. Francis J. Higginson of the Atlanta to investigate his tardiness in sailing from New-York for Greytown, Nicaragua, to protect American interests there. The court will be granted at the written request of Capt. Higginson.
"Boy, two months old, white, No. 62," is the record in Matron Travers's book of the finding of a pretty blue-eyed wait in the hallway of the tenement house 181 Greenwich Street Monday night.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- The delegates to the Women's Congress started in bright and early this morning for a hard day's work. The programme for the week comprises a four-hour morning session each day, a visit, to the World's Fair each afternoon, and a three-hour session in the evening.

THE WHITING-CLAGETT WEDDING. -- This evening the marriage of Augustus Whiting of this city and Miss May Allen Clagett of Washington will take place at the home of the bride's mother in Washington. Owing to the recent death of Mr. Clagett, the wedding will be very quiet, and only relatives and close family connections will be present. Bishop Keane, rector of the Catholic University, will officiate.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- There seemed less anxiety regarding the financial outlook on Change here today and the weather was not all that conld be wished for the growth of the wheat plant. The result was to more than overcome the effects of the stormy weather in England and France. July wheat is 3/4c higher than last night. Corn was firm and closed at 1/8c improvement.

John Chinaman is not given to worriment or nervousness. So far as the more than 4,000 sons of the Flowery Kingdom to be found in and about this city are concerned, they have not been thrown into a panic by the Geary law, now supported by decision of the Supreme Court of the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Maxwell will supply a large number of New-York State Post Offices with anti-machine Democratic Postmasters to-morrow. The list has not yet been officially announced, but THE NEW-YORK TIMES is enabled to present it in spite of this fact.

Three at least of to-day's auction sales of real estate promise to command attention. One of these by Mr. Peter F. Merer will include 225 lots in the 26th Ward of Brooklyn, besides valuable farm property at Hicksville, L.L., lots at Bayswater, and a Saratoga residence and grounds. The second is Mr. James L. Wells'a sale of 98 lots, by order of the Supremo Court in partition.

Mrs. Juli Boswald. wife of Charles Boswald, the leader of a band in this city, was found some months ago at her home, 136 Alien Street, suf fering from the effects of an overdose of laudanum, taKen with suicidal intent. In reply to questions as to her motive, she only moaned: "I am disgraced; I am disgraced."

By the decision of the Supreme Court, announced on Monday, the controversy concerning the duty on hat trimmings is finally settled, and settled against the Government. Owing to the decisions heretofore made in cases involving the same question, we do not see how any other result could have been expected.
LONG ISLAND CITY, May 16. -- Policeman Conroy of Long Island City rubbed his eyes at 3:30 o'clock this morning and stared at two figures that passed him on Borden Avenue.

From various sources and from the statements of some of the officers of the Health Department of the City of New-York, it has been learned that at the Bellevne Hospital, at the foot of East Twenty-sixth Street, there has been a laxity of management and an absence of most of the extraordinary and many of the ordinary precautions against the spreading of epidemic diseases which are expected to be rigidly enforced at all such institutions.

In a drenching downpour of rain yesterday afternoon the Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, pastor of the old First Presbyterian Church, at Eleventh Street and Fifth Avenue, laid the cornerstone of the new chapel building, which is to adjoin the main structure at the south side. The violence of the storm was so great that the out-of-door ceremonies were reduced to a minimum, and practically the whole service of the day was conducted wlthin the church.

Erastus Wiman's looted-for general assignment was made yesterday, the papers being filed with the Clerk of Richmond County. The assignee is David Bennett King, who was made trustee under the deed of Staten Island real estate, for the benefit of creditors, filed some time ago by Mr. Wiman and his wife.

-- The Kings County Club or Brooklyn expects to have an unusually prosperous tennis season this year. The club grounds have been in use for several weeks. Decoration Day has been fixed upon for the opening day of the regular Spring tournament. A tournament will also be held in the Fall. The membership now numbers over a hundred.
Her Royal Highness Infanta Eulalie of Spain is on her way to this city and the much-talked-of ball is now assured.

The affairs of Lazarus Wolff, a retired clothier, and his family are being brought before the public in an unpleasant light, and are resulting in charges and counter charges of a serious nature between father and son.

The startling report of Accountant RICE will prepare the public for the close of the public career of ARCHIBALD A. MCLEOD, whom JOHN WANAMAKER and THOMAS DOLAN placed at the head of the unlawful combination devised by them and their associates for the enrichment of a few persons by means of a large increase in the price of one of the necessaries of life.

Van Tassell Kearney sold at East Thirteenth Street yesterday fifteen head of trotting stock consigned by John H. Shults from Parkville Farm. There was a fair attendance, and prices for what were practically weed-outs were certainly good, the amount realized being $3,692, an average of $246 per head.

The landing of Leif, the son of Eirick, or of some other Norseman, on the shores of Vinland the good has been taken by Mr. John Rogers, the sculptor, for the subject of his latest group. A boat built with overlapping boards, like the galleys found in Scandinavian poat bogs, and having a dragon's head, like certain ships of the Viking men, has been run ashore and three discoverers have stopped from the prow.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 16. -- In view of the renewed complications that are likely to attend the Gubernatorial inauguration on the 30th inst., the necessity for a change in the complicated elective system of this State becomes all the more imperative. At the annnal election, held April 5, David S. Baker. Jr., the Democratic candidate for Governor, ran 283 votes ahead, of his Republican competitor, Gov. D. Russell Brown.

Myer S. Isaacs, Chairman of the Trustees of the Baron Hirsch Fund for the aid of Russian Jews in this country, said yesterday that his associates and himself had not considered the question of an influx of Polish Jews into the United States, for the reason that they did not look for any abnormal immigration of that character.

George Kennan, the Russian traveler, said yesterday that he had not only read the articles in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, with reference to the Russian edicts against the Jews, with more than ordinary interest, but that he believed the disclosures made in the London correspondence were well founded.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 16. -- The levee at Grand Lake, Ark., broke last night and the break was 400 feet wide and 15 feet deep at noon to-day. This point is eight miles above the Louisiana line, and the break will do much toward inundating parishes in Northeast Louisiana.

In some respects the little State of Rhode Island is a sufficiently lively Commonwealth. In business it is enterprising and active, and has accumulated much wealth. But in respect of its political institutions it is strangely behindhand, and shows little disposition to catch up. Until 1842 it was content to live under the old royal charter of the Providence and Rhode Island Plantations, and its first Constitution, then adopted, retained antiquated features of colonial government.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 16. -- When the State Commissioners in Lunacy finished their investigation of the Hudson River State Asylum for the Insane at Poughkeepsle a week or so ago, the Trustees were so astonished by the revelations that they apparently abandoned the idea of further defense of their administration of that Institution.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 16. -- The State of Illinois is to take a hand in the fierce legal conflict that is now being waged to open the World's Columbian Exposition on Sunday. Senator Salomon of Coot has prepared the following resolution, which he will to-morrow introduce in the State Senate:

NEW-YORK. TUESDAY, May 16 -- P.M. The better feeling in Stock Exchange circles which was appreciable yesterday was more pronounced to-day, and for the first time in many weeks the tone of the news which came into the Street was as a rule encouraging.

A piece of property 200 feet by 350 feet, and including twenty-two city lots, at the corner of First Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, changed ownership twice yesterday, and both times it brought an extraordinary price. Early in the day the New-Jersey and New York Abattoir Company sold it to F.J. Sheehan for $760,000, and later on the United States Dressed Beef Company purchased it from Mr. Sheehan for $1,500,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16. -- The Chinese in San Francisco are doing nothing, saying little, and thinking are great deal about the Supreme Court's decision on the Geary law. All reports of threatened mob violence, either on the part of Chinese or whites, are rot. San Francisco is as orderly as New-York, although O'Donnell and Kearney worked off some superfluous steam last night by haranguing small street crowds.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16. -- The armored cruiser New-York has started on her official trial trip. With the rain falling in torrents, she left the Cramps' shipyard at 11 o'clock to-day. So methodically was the start planned that the distinguished Russians on the battle ship Indiana were in ecstacies of delight.

Senator HILL, though he has now had the advantage of two years in the Senate, seems to be as ignorant as he ever was of the duties of his office, of the privileges or obligations created by law or by custom, for a member of that body, and of the general behavior expected of respectable persons in the office he holds.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- With a boldness characteristic of Chicago, the local Board of Directors of the World's Columbian Exposition to-day voted almost unanimously to return to the United States Government its appropriation of $1,929,120, made Aug. 5, 1892, in aid of the enterprise, if it should demand it, thus freeing the Directory from the obligation imposed by the act, and enabling it to open the grounds and buildings on Sunday.
It isn't often that quite such a repulsive family skeleton is dragged into the open as was the case yesterday during the trial of Weed vs. Weed in the Supreme Court, before Judge Truax.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- For some weeks past rumors have been in circulation in the Interior Department which have brought into serious question the official conduct of W.E. Simonds, late Commissioner of Patents.

BIDDEFORD, Me., May 16. -- John L. Sullivan, the Boston pugilist, against whom the Grand Jury of the York County Supreme Court at Alfred this afternoon reported an indictment for assault and battary. went before Jail Commissioner Charles S. Hamilton here to-night and gave bond in the sum of $500 for his appearance for trial during the term.

Anthony Comstock of the New-York Society for the Suppression of Vice returned to this city last night after one of the most successful raids into the camp of his mortal enemies, the bunko steerers, that he ever made.

The dinner given to Archbishop SATOLLI, the Papal Delegate, on Monday was an event of very great significance in several respects. In the first place it was a dinner given by an Irish-American priest who had incurred the disfavor of his Bishop by the Americanism of his Catholicity. It might be more accurate to say that the Bishop had incurred the priest's disfavor by his opposition to American ideas.

-- A Cincinnati exchange says: "It is known that the New-York officials will trade Mike Kelly to the Cincinnati Club for Tony Mullane. The Cincinnati should grab at the deal before the New-Yorkers change their mind. Mike Kelly would be of more service to the Beds than a dozen Mullanes. If the trade is made every real lover of the came in this city will throw up his hat and give three cheers.

LONDON, May 16. -- The American market was steady to-day, and the fluctuations were only fractional, but in spite of a limited amount of business the tone was good, even when the long-expected failure of the City of Melbourne Bank was announced, as well as that of an unimportant broker.
The Waiters' Alliance yesterday ordered a strike at Glogan's restaurant at 356 Canal Street because the proprietor refused to give his waiters an advance of 25 cents a day. Nine men went out.

BALTIMORE, May 16. -- Within the shadow of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, in a neat three-story brick house, live two sisters of a highly respectable family. One of the sisters is Mrs. Maggie Hooper. The other is Miss Mamie Maxwell. The latter is a teacher in a public school. At the in stance of Mary Moulton, the colored domestic of the sisters, the police have arrested Mary Harvey and her husband.

The admirable collection of books illustrating in a bibliographical sense the history of the art of typography, formed by George Edward Sears, has passed at private sale for $25,000 into the possession of William Evarts Benjamin.

Gerard Emline, a manufacturer of Philadelphia, came to New-York Tuesday evening. He is forty-eight years old, but he took a drink in a saloon at Eleventh Avenue and Fifty-seventn Street. He did not remember anything after that until he found himself walking in the street in his shirt sleeves about 2 o'clock Wednesday morning.

The trial of the new cruiser New-York promises to be the most interesting test of power in the history of the new navy of the United States. The New-York is the largest cruising ship of war ever built by an American ship plant. The vessel, furthermore, has been equipped with steam power to an extent little short of that accorded to the greyhounds Paris and NewYork of the American Line.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- First mortgage bonds to the amount of $8,000,000 will be issued, on the plant of the Whisky Trust. Every distillery owned will be included in the trust deed. The Directors of the trust decided upon this step at their meeting today. They decided, also, to reduce the output of their plant to a point which will inaugurate the most extensive shut-down ordered by the trust since it was formed.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 17. -- The Citizens' Bunk suspended payment this morning. A notice on the door says that depositors will be paid in full. The officials declare that the bank is perfectly solvent, and that the suspension is due simply to its inability to realize promptly on its securities.

Vice Admiral Kaznakoff of the Russian fleet, Capt. Zelenoy of the Dimitrl Donskol, and the other Russian officers who went to Philadelphia to see the cruiser New York before she started on her trial trip, returned to their vessels yesterday afternoon.

Richard W.G. Welling, assignee of Francis H. Weeks, filed a provisional bond of $75,000 yesterday. Included in the property covered in the assignment are the yacht Mohawk, worth perhaps $7,500; cash to the amount of $1,496. and promissory notes of the West Superior Iron and Steel Company for $223,387.

Land adjoining the Southern Boulevard. when condemned a few years ago to make part of Bronx Park, was paid for at the rate of but little over $200 per lot. Similar property, belonging to the Lydig estate, put up at auction sale yesterday in the Trinity Building, brought an average of more than three times as much, and the purchases were by many regarded as bargains.

At the annual meeting of the New-York Civil Service Reform Association held last night in the Academy of Medicine, the report of the Executive Committee reviewing the work of the year was read and officers elected. The report said in part:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 17. -- Until the opening of the championship games it is felt at Yale that the baseball season has never been begun. The first championship contest of the season of 1893 will take place at the Yale field Saturday afternoon with the Princetons as the opposing team. Both clubs have disposed of their usual list of practice games, and with about the usual result.

The latest news from, the Hawaiian Islands confirms the report that CLAUS SPRECKELS is working against annexation, "fearing the labor question." The original inspiring cause of the "revolution" at Honolulu appears to have been the desire of the sugar planters to get the benefit of the bounty on the production of sugar, since they had lost the advantage of the reciprocity treaty which had enabled them to make enormous profits for some years.

LOUISVILLE, May 17. -- The 5,000 persons who went out to Churchill Downs to-day to see the Clark States run witnessed a very tame contest for a stake worth $2,500. Only three horses contested for the prize. Boundless and Buck McCann and De Capod, who was added to the list this morning. Lookout, the Derby winner, was withdrawn. The results:

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- The trotting season in the East opened to-day with spirited racing at the Point Breeze course. Yesterday's heavy rain had left the track in bad condition, and the time made was consequently nothing sensational. In the 2:45 race Big Four won with, the utmost ease, showing ability to trot more than ten seconds faster when called upon.
James H. Love, whom Mayor Wanser named to succeed John D. Gorman (ring Democrat) in the Jersey City Tax Board, made a demand upon German yesterday for the possession of his office.

That Health Officer William T. Jenkins has not been able to secure old Fort Lafayette as a place of detention for well or apparently well passengers from cholera infected ships seems to be due to Col. Looinis L. Langdon of the First Artillery, commanding the post of Fort Hamilton and incidentally exercising jurisdiction, of Fort Lafayette.

THE GENERAL COURT-MARTIAL in session at Jefferson Barracks, Mo., has been dissolved and a new one appointed. The latter court consists or Capt. John B. Kerr. Sixth Cavalry; Lieuts. Franklin O. Johnson, Third Cavalry; John A. Johnston, Eighth Cavalry; Percy E. Trippe. Tenth Cavalry; Stephen L. Slocum. Eighth Cavalry; Roger B. Bryan, Second Cavalry; Richard B. Paddock, Sixth Cavalry, and Robert D. Walsh, Fourth Cavalry, Judge Advocate.

NEW-YORK. -- A committee from the Woman's Hospital called on Mayor Gilroy yesterday to ask him why he had asked the Governor to veto the bill requiring the city to pay the hospital $25 for each obstetrics case treated free there. The Mayor said he had made no such request of the Governor, although he was opposed to all legislation compelling appropriations of this sort.

SUMMER AT THE BIG GARDEn. -- The sale of seats for the grand combination entertainment to begin at the Madison Square Garden May 29 will open next Monday. Three hundred people are to take part in the performance, which is to be after the style of the Folies Bergeres, Paris, and the Alhambra, London. From 8:30 to 9 P.M. the minstrels will hold the stage.

A houseful of bright-faced young people were assembled last evening at the Church of the Pilgrims, corner of Henry and Remsen Streets, where the fourth annual convention of the Brooklyn Christian Endeavor Union was opened.
Among the securities sold at auction to-day at 111 Broadway by Adrian H. Muller Son were the following lots:

By a grand rally at the bat in the eighth and ninth innings the Baltimores won from Brooklyn at Eastern Part yesterday. For seven innings the local players looked like winners, but they could not check the heavy batting of the Orioles. As a matter of fact, only the stupidest kind of base running prevented the visitors from taking the lead at an earlier stage of the contest.

Some interesting developments are promised at the meeting of the Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad to-day. Mr. Henry Villard, it is said, has concluded to retire from the Chairmanship of the board and will make known his determination at this meeting. There was a report in Wall Street yesterday that Mr. Villard's written resignation had been in the hands of President Oakes for several days.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- There is a great game of see-saw going on between the local Directory and the National Commission. To-day the resolutions adopted yesterday by the Directory, providing for the refunding on demand of the Governmental appropriation and the opening of the fair on Sunday, were presented to the commission and referred by that body to the Judiciary Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 17. -- Representative Geary is considerably disgusted by the reports that the Administration is hostile to his Chinese law and does not intend to enforce it. He said to THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S correspondent today:

According to Miss Bertha Dora, it's woman's first love that lasts the longest. Miss Dorn received a verdict for $2,000 yesterday afternoon for injuries inflicted on her own first love. Miss Dorn is a farmer's daughter. She was wooed, and us far as she was concerned, won, at Hicksville, L. I., by a fickle butcher rejoicing in the name of George C. Seyforth.

The La Due street sweeping machine was exhibited yesterday afternoon on Lexington Avenue, between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets, in the presence of some gentlemen interested in the street-cleaning problem. Among those who saw the new sweeper at work were Mayor Rankin, Street Cleaning Commissioner N. K. Thompson, and Councilman Eagan, Smith, and O'Donnell of Elizabeth, N. J., and Thomas E. Crimmins of this city.

The Administration at Washington is likely to "go very slow" in putting the penal provisions of the Geary act into effect, if for no other reason, because it has no appropriation available for the expense of deporting Chinese from the country. But there are plenty of other reasons for making no haste.

The big immigrant station on Ellis Island was visited yesterday by the Senate committee which is examining into its workings. The party which called on Dr. Joseph Senner, Superintendent of Immigration for this port, about 9:30 o'clock, consisted of Senator David B. Hill, the Chairman of the committee, and Senators Chandler of New-Hampshire, Proctor of Vermont, Du Bois of Washington, and Faulkner of West Virginia, the other Commissioners Senator Faulkner had a friend with him.

The probable fate of the American missions and missionaries to China, in case the attempt is made to enforce the Chinese Exclusion act, is a subject over which the missionary bodies of the various Protestant Churches are greatly alarmed.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- There was a costly surprise in the shape of a bad break in prices the last hour to-day on 'Change. Wheat tumbled to 74 1/2c for July and left off rather weak at 74 5/8c, or 2c under last night's closing price. Corn quit with a loss of 1 1/4c. Provisions show declines of 30c in pork, 25c in lard and from 20c to 22 1/2c in ribs.

After ten years of lawless freedom, William Cox, alias John Fletcher, an escaped convict, was recaptured in Jersey City yesterday. Cox broke into a house on Henderson Street in 1881, and was sent to the penitentiary at Snake Hill for a year. He managed to escape after a few months confinement by sawing his prison bars and dropping from the corridor window.

Important events were sharply contested yesterday at the annual field day at Stevens Institute, Hobeken. There was a good attendance. The class ot '94 made most of the arrangements, and ran things pretty much to suit itself, but giving other classes a chance. The '95 man won the day with 36-3 points; '94 men had 35 1-6; '96 made 24 1-6, and the seniors 20 points.

The Actors' Amateur Athletic Association of America, known best as the Five A's, has come to the conclusion that, however famous its members may be and however ornamental their presence in the clubhouse, it takes cold, hard cash to do business among actors as well as among more natural people.
Judge Lacombe signed a decree yesterday which will probably bring about the sale of a quantity of securities once the property of the City Railway Improvement Company.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, May 17 -- P.M. This was another day of general all-round improvement. London prices came much lower than our closing, and for a time selling orders from that centre were numerous. But all offerings were well taken, and in less than half an hour prices resumed their upward movement.
SAN FRANCISCO, Mar 17. -- The steamer Oceanio arrived from Hongkong and Yokohama via Honolulu this morning. She brings the latest advices from the Hawaiian Islands, dated Honolulu, May 10, saying:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 17. -- The schooner Lamartine of Deer Island. Me., Capt. Eben Eaton, with a crew of three men, for New-York, with cut stone, went down off Cape Cod at 7 o'clock this morning. Two of the crew were picked up by the schooner Edith McInnis. The drowned man was Hiram Powers of Deer Island.

Recorder Smyth was much provoked yesterday because of the successive delays in the case of Dr. Robert W. Buchanan, convicted of wife poisoning, who has not yet been sentenced. The Recorder was in the Court of General Sessions yesterday prepared to hear the motion for a new trial.
PRAGUE, May 17. -- The Bohemian Diet was the scene to-day of a display of violence and disorder unparalleled in the bitter struggle for supremacy between the Czech and German elements.
PARIS, May 17. -- Sir Charles Russell continued his arguments before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration to-day in behalf of the British case.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Capt. Francis J. Higginson has been relieved from the command of the Atlanta by the Secretary of the Navy, probably under a misunderstanding of facts. For some days the newspaper correspondents from Washington have been making attacks on Capt. Higginson, some one evidently supplying them with detailed information in which "trifles light as air" are strained to make it appear that Capt. Higginson was neglecting his duty.
A striking example of canine intelligence and fidelity was displayed last Tuesday at the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn.

The Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway Company has declared a semi-annual dividend of 2 1/2 per cent, on its preferred stock, payable July 1. The transfer books will be closed as noon June 10 and reopened July 3.

-- Stock and bond holders of the Pittsburgh Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad Company held their annual meeting in Pittsburg yesterday. The President's report shows that many improvements have been made on the Fort Wayne during the past year. The income for the yoar was $12,760,222.85; expenses of operating and maintaining, $9,195,093.93.

The New-Netherlands Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, is so nearly ready to open its doors that Gen. Earle, the proprietor, announced yesterday that the register would be placed, on the desk and all departments be prepared to attend to guests at 10 o'clock on the morning of June 1. From the engines in the basement to the laundry, seventeen stories higher up, the building will be declared op on at that time.

RALEIGH, N. C., May 17. -- L. Moore, an emigrant agent, was charged before the Criminal Court of New-Hanovar for doing business as an emigrant agent without having first obtained a license. Judge Meares has decided the law under which the case was brought to be unconstitutional, because the Legislature has not the power to prevent a man from exercising his freedom and privilege by going to another State under contract to work.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The preparation for the initial session of the one hundred and fifth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States, at the, New-York Avenue Church to-morrow morning, are practically complete. Dr. Roberts, the Stated Clerk, reached the city this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The Grand Duke Alexander of Russia arrived here this afternoon with his secretary, Mr. Sharpels, and Lieuts. Boutakoff and Chiehkine. They drove at once to the Russian location, where they will be the guests of the Minister until Sunday morning, when they will return to New-York.

Policeman Patrick J. Muldoon of the Twentythird Precinet was tried yesterday by Commissioner McClave for roughly treating Ferdinand P. Earle, son of the proprietor of the Hotel Normandie. On April 28 the boy rode a bicycle on the sidewalk at Fifth Avenue and Fiftyeighth Street, and he was in the roadway when Muldoon arrested him.

HANOVER, N. H., May 17. -- The Yale Law School nine played Dartmouth's Varsity team here to-day a game characterized by the poor playing of the home nine. Thornburg was in the box for Dartmouth month and pitched what should have been a winning game if he had had ordinary support.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Not a cloud could be seen in the sky to-day, but the wind blew strong and cold. From force of habit many people brought waterproofs and umbrellas, besides Winter wraps, to celebrate the dedication of the Norwegian Building, and to commemorate the separation of the Norwegian kingdom from that of Denmark.

There is a fine and characteristic commingling of commercial shrewdness and public spirit in the action of the Chicago Directors of the World's Fair "with respect to Sunday opening. They magnanimously waive the question whether, since the Government violated the conditions on "which public money was to be given to the fair, it did not give the money unconditionally.

Just before Henry Winthrop Gray was appointed a Fire Commissioner he was elected Vice President of the Park Board, an office without salary created by the last Legislature. The vacancy left in that place by his resignation was filled at yesterday's meeting of the Park Commissioners by the election of Paul Dana as Vice President.

LONDON, May 17. -- The reception of the Prince of Wales at the Imperial Institute to-day was attended by Mr. Gladstone as the Prince's guest. A hostile demonstration was made by some of the ultra Tories when he appeared.

The Brooklyn Yacht club is a progressive organization. It is one of the oldest yacht clubs in this country, bat for several years has been just existing. Now the members have decided to posh it to the front. It is to have a town house in Brooklyn and stations on the bay and Sound.

The annual session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church was opened last night by a service in the First Church, at 123 West Twelfth Street. The sermon was preached by the Rev. David McKinney of Cincinnati, the retiring Moderator.
LONDON, May 17. -- Markets opened steady, with a much better feeling, the general view being that the crisis is past and that an upward reaction is due.

-- The revised schedule of the Harvard 'Varsity team has been given out by Manager Hill. The important, feature of the schedule as it now stands is the addition of three names with Brown University. This makes five names in all this Spring between Harvard aud Brown. These games are sure to be close, and they will doubtless add a great deal to the success of the remainder of the Spring season.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 17. -- The bicycle tournament on Broadway to-night was the greatest thing of its kind ever held in Baltimore. Broadway is the main avenue of East Baltimore, and the carnival was held to celebrate the securing of its new asphalt pavement. There were between 2,00O and 3,000 wheelmen in line. It was long after 9 o'clock when the column moved, and the distributing of prizes and lestivities lasted until midnight.

A peculiar trait of a Norwegian's character is the intense love he bears toward the mother country, and this was manifest in New-York yesterday in the celebration of the Norway independence day. If a Norwegian is asked: "Who discovered America?" he will tell you that Columbus didn't; that this great continent was found by Norsemen.

The passenger traffic arrangement that has existed for some time between the West Shore Roadl and the Chicago and Grand Trunk Road will be discontinued on Monday next. Hereafter the West Shore's solid vestibuled trains to Chicago, except the Grafton special, will be run over the Nickel Plate line. The route from Hamilton, Ontario, to Port Huron, and thence to Chicago via the Chicago and Grand Trunk Road, will be abandoned.

BOSTON, May 17. -- It was with fear and trembling that Capt. Nash put Staley in the box to-day against New-York. Staley had not won a game this season, and was considered an easy mark for all the batsmen that he faced from early in the Spring. But King was put in the box for New-York, and that alone prevented the Giants from winning.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 17. -- The commencement exercises of the Yale Theological School were begun in Battell Chapel this morning. President Dwight presided. The following essays were delivered by members selected from the graduating class:
PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 17. -- At to-day's session of the convention of the New-York State Congregational Association the report of the Committee on Moral Instruction created a sensation.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- A small crayon picture of a gallant, with an Elizabethan ruffle about his neck, stands against the wall in the yet unfurnished room in the New-York Building occupied by State Executive Officer McNaughton.

ALBANY, May 17. -- Capitol Hill was not very active to-day. Now that the acts of the Legislature in the Governor's hands are about cleaned up, the number of callers at the Executive Chamber is comparatively small. To-night but eight bills remained undisposed of, and none of these is of any great importance.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 17. -- Shortly after noon to-day Capt. Stanley Flannigan and Michael Le Blonde of this city were going down the river in a rowboat which they used for peddling milk alone the docks. When near the mouth of the raging stream one of Le Blonde's oars broke, and the two men were left at the mercy of the waters.

HENDRICK -- SCUDDER. At noon yesterday Miss Cornella Soudder, daughter of the late Townsend Seudder of this city, was married to James Burnside Hendrick, son of Col. James Hendrick of Albany. The quaint Church of the Transfiguration in East Twenty-ninth Street was the scene of the wedding, and the rector, the Rev. Dr. G.H. Houghton, officiated.

Louis Cluett, a thirteen-year-old inmate of the New-York Juvenile Asylum, concluded that he would, see something of the outside world, and made his escape by tying several sheets together and letting himself down from the ward on the third floor, in which he slept. One of the matrons who occupied an adjoining room heard him, but before she could enter the ward Louis had disappeared.

In the small enclosed space known as the "detention pen" on Ellis Island there are at present, awaiting the decision of Commissioner Senner on their cases, nine Italians who arrived in the steerages of the vessels Bolivia and India and who were discovered to be ex-convicts.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- The third day of the World's Congress of Women shows no diminution of interest in this remarkable gathering, or rather series of gatherings. The audiences in the fifteen or eighteen convention halls this morning were the largest of the week.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- For several weeks there have been upon a sofa in Secretary Lamont's second office a cartload of papers, being the accumulated applications and recommendations of persons who desired to be appointed to the position of Major and Paymaster in the army. For the present they are of no further use.

CONNEAUT, Ohio, May 17. -- The tug Walter Richardson and the dredge Continental were anchored in the harbor last night. At 1 o'clock this morning the dredge and the tug were swept out into the lake by the flood in the river. In cutting away the dredge the wheel of the tug was disabled, and the boat was washed ashore, the crew being saved.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17. -- "The case of Roehl and Pallister," said Superintendent of Police Linden this afternoon, "is an unparalleled one I do not think the closest research in the criminal annals of the world through many years past would reveal one so remarkable. While this is the case, however, I am sure that an entirely plausible explanation of the whole matter is possible.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., May 17. -- The Western New-York and Pennsylvania tracks above Hydetown are under water. The lower end of this city is flooded, and all the factories have stopped. Trains are stalled and business has been suspended. Mechanic, Washington, Franklin, Perry, and Monroe Streets are all flooded in certain sections, and on Seneca and Water Streets the people have moved into the second stories of their houses.

MASPETH, L.I., May 17. -- This pretty village of Maspeth is much better acquainted with its little colony of Anarchists to-day, because of the confession of Otto Eckholdt published in this morning's NEW-YORK TIMES.

As M. H. Grice, the choirmaster of Christ Episcopal Church, was about to make his way into the building on Claremont Avenue in the Greenville section of Jersey City Tuesday Evening, he almost fell ever a bundle that lay on the steps. With a lad named Scott, who reached the steps a moment later, he lifted it, and by the light of a near-by lamppost saw that it was tied tightly around with cords.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 17. -- The inquiry as to the death of Mrs. Elizabeth Dibble in a farmhouse in the town of Beekman on Sunday occurred to-day. She was found lying on her back dead, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Her right and left sides were badly bruised, her face was almost black, her eyes bulged out, and her pupils were dilated.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 17. -- The large three-masted schooner White Cloud, from Philadelphia for Gloucester, with coal, Fred Robinson, master, was in collision with the Old Colony steamer Providence between 5 and 6 o'clock this morning.

SING SING, May 17. -- Coroner Sutton concluded his inquest this afternoon as to the death of Thomas Pallistor, who, with Frank W. Roehl, escaped from the condemned-cell house in Sing Sing Prison on the night of Thursday, April 20, and whose body, with a bullet in the head, was found in the Hudson River on Tuesday morning by two shad fishermen.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 17. -- At to-day's session of the Long Island Diocesan Convention at Garden City, L. I., it was voted to increase the annual salary of Bishop Littejohn by $1,200. The vote was 55 to 36.

It was fully 8:30 o'clock when Col. L.D. Brue began selling the annual consignment of thorough bred yearlings, the produce of Woodburn Farn Spring Station, Woodford County, Ky. At that time the main hall of the American Horse Exchange Fiftieth Street and Broadway. was thronge with a good representative crowd of racin men.

The committee to investigate the New-York Custom House, composed of Daniel Magone of Ogdenburg, Poindexter Dunn of Arkansas, and Charles S. Fairchild of this city, did not organize yesterday, as it was expected to do.

John Malone, the actor, delivered an exceedingly sound and interesting lecture on Shakespeare's life and work at the Lyceum Theatre yesterday afternoon. Mr. Malone has an honest and wholesome contempt for the greater part of Shakespearean literature. So have all the ablest and wisest of Shakespeare editors and critics.

There was much talk yesterday among real estate men about the deed recorded on Tuesday in which it was stated that the United States Dressed Beef Company had paid F. J. Sheehan $1,500,000 for the twenty-two city lots at the corner of East Forty-fourth Street and First Avenue, and the buildings and improvements thereon.

LEWES, Del., May 17. -- Coming down from Philadelphia yesterday the great cruiser NewYork made a speed of about 14 knots, which was maintained until she anchored off Petty's Island. There she lay for three hours waiting for higher water to cross the shoals.

The report which Isaac L. Rice has just made public in Philadelphia covering port or Mr. McLeod's management of the Reading Railroad has called forth, a reply from Mr. McLeod and the matter has become a live topic of public discussion.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners decided yesterday to stand substantially by the propositions for elevated railroad extensions transmitted to the Manhattan Company April 12. A letter to this effect was drawn up to be sent to George Gould, with an intimation that an answer would be acceptable by next Tuesday.

Mr. Simon Hess, a brother of Mr. "Jake" Hess, announces that he intends to leave the Republican Party. One of the reasons which he gives for this change in political faith is the blackballing by the Union League Club of Jesse Seligman's son.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- This was the second and last day of the Chevy Chase Hunt Club meeting at the Ivy City Course. The day was cold and Kept the attendance down to rather small proportions. The track was good.
The attendance at the Press Club Fair last evening was larger than usual and all the booths did a thriving business.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 17. -- The news from the overflowed districts in Arkansas and Louisiana are of the most discouraging character. Dispatches from points on the west side of the river, below Memphis, report a distressing condition of affairs. The water which has been flowing around the head of the levee system above Osceola, Ark., has inundated the St. Francis basin, and the farmers are compelled to abandon all hope of raising a cotton crop.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 17. -- This little State is seething with politics nowadays. In every county and town the politicians are bestirring themselves from dawn to midnight with only one object in view -- the control of the Grand Committee on May 30. To any one unacquainted with the idiosyncrasies of Rhode Island the situation is incomprehensible.

The Union Club is acknowledged to be one of the moat exclusive if not the first social organization in this country, and its members are chosen from the most notable people of New-York as well as of other cities.

LONDON, May 17 -- The second clause of the Irish Home Rule bill, conferring authority on the Irish Legislature to enact laws, was passed to-day in committee of the House of Commons as amended by the adoption of Sir Henry James's amendment, to the effect that the supreme power of the Imperial Parliament should remain undiminished by any proviso of the Home Rule bill.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon the conflict with the Board of Estimate and Apportionment over an extra appropriation for the maintenance or the Nautical School occupied most of the time. The Question of a transfer of $46,000 which had been laid before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to make good a deficiency in the allowance for teachers' salaries was also discussed.
The Sun's Washington dispatches yesterday contained a report of changes in the civil service methods contemplated by the President. Among other things, it was said:

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 18. -- The body of Thomas Pallister, the murderer, rests in "consecrated" earth in Calvary Cemetery, but it is not certain that it will be undisturbed. It was the intention of Vicar General Mooney that the body should be excluded from all Catholic cemeteries over which he has supervision, and he actually sent a messenger to Calvary Cemetery forbidding its burial there.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Theodore Thomas's resignation was asked for by Director General Davis to-day, in accordance with the orders or the National Commission. He has not sent in the resignation yet, nor has he made any statement of his position. He said to-night that he would make a statement in a short time.

MRS. ANDREWS'S COACHING PARTY. -- An interesting incident in local social life yesterday was Mrs. George P. Andrews's coaching party to the Berkeley Oval Club. The coach which was tooled by J. Lee Taller, left the Central Park Plaza about 10 o'clock in the morning. The cool, clear weather made the ride thoroughly enjoyable, and good appetites were ready for the line luncheon at the clubhouse.

Miss Matilda Murray, of twenty-five brief Summers, met Mr. William A. Stamm in the bleak Fall of 1890. She loved him and he lovod her; at least, he told her he did and she believed him. In the following Summer, standing on the gleaming wave-washed sands of Coney Island, they plighted their troth.

After being thrashed in Brooklyn, beaten la hollow style in Philadelphia, and whipped inglorionsly in Boston, the New-Yorks returned home yesterday and got sweet revenge on James Demosthenes O'Rourke's Senators. The latter were like so many amateura in the hands of the Giants, and the spectators wondered how New-York ever lost a game in Washington.

Mrs. Sydney Rosenfeld, wife of the composer of comic operas, was seen yesterday afternoon by a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter at her home. Cedar Glen, a romantic retreat overlooking the Hudson River at Ludlow Station. She was engaged in gardening, and was attired in a jaunty outdoor costume. She said:
The Russian Admiralty is preparing to send to the United States during the next ten days three of Russia's finest battle ships. Their names are now announced for the first time.

ERIE, Penn., May 18. -- Erie within the last two days has had 6.14 inches of rain. One million dollars will not restore the streets, bridges, thoroughfares, manufacturing plants, homes, gardens, and grounds which have fallen under the flood within the last forty-eight hours.

Valentine Muller, who has been in Ludlow Street Jail for some months for contempt of court, made an unsuccessful effort in the Supreme Court yesterday to secure his release. Muller may be kept in prison for an indefinite time, during his entire life in fact, by the terms of the order under which he was committed unless he purges himself of contempt by paying $858, which he has failed to account for as receiver.

-- The 24.036 shares of Boston and Maine Railroad stock recently hold in Boston for the account of the Philadelphia and Heading Road, is said to hare been taken by a syndicate of Philadelphia and New-York capitalists.

BERLIN, May 18. -- Baron Bacheracht, one of the Secretaries of the Russian Embassy, has married Baroness Kolemine, the divorced wife of the late Grand Duke Louis IV. of Hesse. Baron Bacheracht will, it is said, be transferred to the Russian Embassy at Lisbon.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., May 18. -- From what has appeared in the series of articles published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES from this State during the last week it is apparent that the political system of Rhode Island is radically wrong. Two thoughts naturally follow: Who is to blame and what is the remedy?

TUSKEGEE, Ala., May 17. -- To-day completed the twelfth, year in the history of the Tuskegee School. Twelve years ago the school had thirty pupils and one teacher, without a foot of ground, or a single building, and its only income was an annual appropriation of $2,000 from the State.

BOSTON, May 18. -- Mr. Robert Hillard, who is playing the leading role in "Led Astray" at the Globe Theatre, and Mr. Wilton Lackaye, until recently leading man in "Aristocracy" at the Hollis Street Theatre, had a fierce encounter Tuesday in the latter's room in the Langham Hotel, and as a result Lackaye is occupying his room and nursing some very severe contusions.

The National Board of Fire Underwriters held an annual meeting in this city yesterday and there was the usual note of complaint as to the peculiar hardships of the business of fire insurance. For various reasons, not always clearly made out, that has for some years been an unprofitable business, if we are to believe those engaged in it.
The twenty-seventh annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters was held yesterday in the rooms or the New-York board in the Mutual Life Building.

It looks as if Mr. Richard Croker had picked up a rare good horse when he bought Dobbins at the sale of Frank Ehret's horse last Fall. The colt seemed to show himself a good one when he won his race on Tuesday last over a very muddy track and in very fast time.
Dr. H.M. Biggs read a paper before the New-York Academy of Medicine last night on the organization and equipment of the division of disinfection in the New-York Health Department.

Meyer Caudle, a Russian, forty-five years old, of 111 Delanoey Street, attended a wedding at the Tiffereth Israel Synagogue, in Allen Street, Tuesday night. He took a seat next to Morris Levy, a glass dealer of 225 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, an uncle of the bride. Caudle, it is charged, took Levy's gold watch, valued at $80, and tried to pick the pocket of a woman sitting beside him.

Owing to the resistance of Messrs. STARIN and BUSHE at the meeting of Wednesday, the Rapid-Transit Commissioners made only a very moderate concession to the Manhattan Company in modifying the terms of the franchise for extendinglits elevated railroad lines which were presented in the resolutions of April 12.

Ex-President Harrison would not have felt very highly complimented if he could nave heard the speech made by Gen. George A. Sheridan at last night's meeting of the Republican County Committee in Grand Opera House Hall.

Col. David C. Houston, an officer with a distinguished record in the United States Engineer Corps, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital, whither he had been removed last Friday from the Everett House. While his death is ascribed to Bright's disease and liver disorder, there seems to be little doubt that his ailments were aggravated by recent indulgence in stimulants.

LONDON, May 18. -- The Russian cruiser Vitiaz is a total loss on the coast of Corea. This information has been received from imperial naval circles at Vladivostok. The same report states that all hands were saved.

There was a good attendance at Fleetwood yesterday to see a bit of trotting. Henry Elder, the oldest roadite now Capt. Jacob Vanderbilt is gone; David Bonner, F.T. Steinway, Gen. Jacob Baiz, Col. L. Kip, and many other well-known lovers of good trotting events were present.

BOSTON, May 18. -- Sugar and Burlington were the active arbitrage stocks to-day. The local market was generally strong, further recoveries from the recent depression being made. West End Railroad rose to 59, Bell Telephone to 186, New-York and New-England preferred to 70, Mexican Central 4s to 59 1/4, Westinghouse to 26, the preferred to 44, and Wisconsin Central incomes to 24 1/2.

Twice a year the different Societies of Christian Endeavor, which are banded together as the Local Union of New-York City and vicinity, meet in conference, and this Spring they decided to meet in the Madison Avenue Reformed Church, at the corner of Fifty-seventh Street. The first session of the conference was held there last evening, and the second and last will meet in the same place to-night.

TRENTON, N.J., May 18. -- The Mercer County Grand Jury has found an indictment for murder against Mrs. Shann, now in the county jail accused of poisoning her nineteen-year-old son to obtain his insurance money.

The Church of the Pilgrims, at Henry and Remsen Streets, was crowded yesterday afternoon and evening with members of the Brooklyn Christian Endeavor Union. It was the closing day of the fourth annual convention.

-- At the fiftieth games of the New-York Athletic Club, to take place on Saturday, June 8, at 3 P.M., at Travers Island, the following events will be contested: One-mile run, 44O yard run, one-mile walk, and two-mlle bicycle race -- all handicap Scratch events -- Half-mile bicycle race, 100-yard run, 880-yard run, 120-yard hurdle, obstacle race, running high and broad jumps, throwing 16 and 58-pound hammer, and putting 16-pound shot.

The recent difficulties between the Chicago Directory and the National Commission touching the conduct of the World's Fair indicate that the National Commission is rapidly becoming a national nuisance. It is to be borne in mind that everything that has been done to promote the success of the fair has been done by the representatives of Chicago.
BOSTON, Mass., May 18. -- At the annual meeting to-day of the General Association of the Congregational Churches of Massachusetts, the following resolutions ware adopted:

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 18. -- At the annual meeting of the Texas Bankers' Association here to-day a resolution was unanimously adopted favoring the repeal of the Sherman act and declaring against irce and unlimited coinage of silver.

The session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church was continued yesterday morning and afternoon at the First Church in Twelfth Street. The Rev. David McKinney of Cincinnati, the retiring Moderator, opened the session with prayer.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Mr. Daniel Magone will leave Washington to-morrow morning by an early train for New-York. He has finished his talk with the Secertary of the Treasury in relation to the inquiry into the Custom House and thoroughly understands the scope and purpose had in view by Mr. Carlisle.

The steamship Reina Maria Christina, having on board the Infanta Marie-Eulalie Francoise d'Assise-Marguerito-Roberte-Isabelle-Francoise de Paule-Christine-Marie de la Piete, , of Spain, her husband the Infante Antonio Maria de Orleans, and her suite arrived at the Bar yesterday evening from Havana, anchoring off the Scotland Liightship precisely at 7:47 P.M.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., May 18. -- The heavy rain has caused the canal and creek to rise four feet above normal level, and boats are unable to run from here to Pendleton. The tugs are unable to move the boats which have been lying at the pier in the canal, the current being too strong. All the low lands in this vicinity are turned into lakes.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- There was activity in the Transportation Building this morning as a result of the vigorous protest entered by Chief Willard Smith, the French Commissioner, against the neglect to provide workmen and light for the purpose of installing exhibits which have been on the ground for several weeks.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 18. -- The Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers are still rising, but the water will hardly reach the danger line, (twenty-four feet.) and no serious damage is apprehended here. The lowlands of Allegheny and the South Side are partly submerged. | Sharpsburg is under several feet of water and the residents have moved to the upper floors.
The editor of Harper's Magazine in a letter to the editor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES concerning a recently-published cablegram, says:
If the debt of the Brooklyn Tabernacle be not lifted this week the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmage will announce his resignation on Sunday morning from the pulpit.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Washington, for the second time in its history, and the first time in forty-one years, is entertaining the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States. The body that convened in Its one hundred, and fifth annual session in NewYork Avenue Church was a strikingly different one from that which met in the Fourth Presbyterian Church in 1852.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 18. -- The City Council to-night threw out the vote for Chief Engineer on the ground that bribery and intimidation had been freely practiced at the firemen's election. A new election was ordered to be held on May 30 at the City Hall.

Miss Lotta Crahtree and Mrs. Crabtree, her mother, were seen in their apartments in the Plaza Hotel. Miss Lotta was dressed in a costume of light material, and with her golden curls clustering about her head presented a charming picture. Mrs. Crabtree, her mother, wore conventional black.

OLEVELAND, Ohio. May 18. -- The rain, which had been falling with hardly a moment's cessation since Sunday night, stopped shortly after midnight, and citizens of Cleveland, upon rising this morning, were delighted to see the sun shinins brightly.

ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- A deplorable tragedy, directly traceable to sensational literature, occurred here this afternoon. Seven boys were playing ball at the corner of Cook Avenue and Perry Street. A quarrel arose, and Emmet Fitzwilliams, son of J.J. Fitzwilliams, cashier of the Star Sayings Publishing Company, shot Thomas Ahern through the heart.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 18. -- The arrangements for the fifth annual Indianapolis May musical festival are on the verge of collapse to-night, and the indications are that the festival will have to be abandoned.

Sorosis held its last business meeting for the club year on Monday, and although the sun shone without and the birds sang and nature smiled, there was in the clubroom at Sherry's only storm and discord and frowns.

--This is a description given in the West of a, wellknown pitcher: "Mr. Gastright is a tall young man, with a primrose dream of a face. He has a smile that goes back, to the time of Rameses II. He rolls an eye like a poet in a frenzied spasm, but that arm! That arm ! It swoops around in a way that makes the anticipation of the Ferris machine on Midway Plaisance a pinwheel."
The money market continued easy. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2@ 2 1/2 P cent. The last loan was made at 2 P cent.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 18. -- Otto Eckholdt, the indicted ex-Anarchist whose statement published in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES about the plot to blow up New-York policemen at the Union Square labor meeting on May 2, 1892, created a sensation, was furious to-day when a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter showed him the statement of Herr Most and Emma Goldman, denying his accusation.

BOSTON, May 18. -- Brooklyn's club paid its first visit of the season here to-day, and marked the event by carrylne off a well-contested game from the champions. It was well earned, too, the visitors excelling both at the bat and in the field.

The handsome schooner yacht Loyal made her maiden dip into the water yesterday morning. As she began to slide down the ways, Flossie Sutton, the four-year old daughter at Commodore B. Frank Sutton, for whom the boat was built, smashed a bottle of champagne on her bows and gave the yacht the name Loyal.

A meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held last night at the clubhouse, 67 Madison Avenue. In the absence of Commodore E.D. Morgan, Vice Commander W. Sutler Duncan, Jr., occupied the chair. There were about 100 members present. They got through their work quickly, and adjourned soon after 10 o'clock.

At the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, in the Trinity Building, Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold, in partition, the three lots 325, 327, and 329 East 33d St. for $26,750, to A. Stiehl's Sons. Two of the lots are each 25 by 98.9, and the intermediate one is 24.9 by 98.9. The 3 inches intervening are not claimed by any one.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 18. -- Startling news regarding the death of Albert V. Du Pont, millionaire and philanthropist, was disclosed to-day. Instead of dying of heart disease at Central Park, the home of his brother, it is now alleged that he expired in a disorderly house, and there are rumors that he was murdered.

Local manufacturers of pearl buttons are lamenting the decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals sustaining Judge Lacombe of the lower court in cases brought by importers against the Government.

The annual meeting of the Inter Club Tennis Association of Kings County resulted in the election of the following officers: Carroll J. Post, Jr., Crescent Athletic Club, President; Dr. W.N. Frazer. Kings County Tennis Club, Vice President; Jay S. Jones, Altiora Tennis Club, Secretary; Dr. W.A. Griffith, Brooklyn Tennis Club, Treasurer, and Clarence McMahon, Brooklyn Tennis Club; E.H. Lott.

BOSTON, May 18. -- The cruiser New-York reached an anchorage off Nantasket just before noon to-day. The run from Cape May Light, 434 miles, was made in 23 hours and 50 minutes. On the way up the vessel was run out of her course for an hour and a half to avoid a fog.

Edward R. Jones, who says he is a clerk by occupation, but an author and playwright by choice, is the occupant of a cell in the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters. He is designated by the detectives as a "free-lunch flend." He is only twenty-three years old.

In honor of the birthday of the Czarowitch the Russian war vessels in the river were illuminated last night and it was a gala day aboard the Dimitri Donskoi and Rynda. It was a double holiday, being also the Russian Ascension Day, and religious services were held on the Dimitri Donskoi.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 18. -- This little village had an exciting scene yesterday, when Mrs. Stall Post, a young and pretty matron, publicly horsewhipped two citizens of Mineola, L.I., who had come to an East Williston horse sale.

HAVERHILL, Mass., May 18. -- The body of Alexander James, who died in Brooklyn last week, was brought here yesterday in charge of the local lodge I.O.O.F., of which James was a member. Through some misunderstanding between the authorities of the Catholic Church and the Odd Fellows, there was no priest present at the church at the hour appointed for the funeral, and the body was buried without the usual services.

ALBANY, May 18. -- The Session Laws of 1893 are completed. The last act of the Legislature to receive the Governor's approval was the Supply bill, which was signed about noon to-day. Items in it to the amount of $530,000 were out out, leaving $2,399,000 intact.

At 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon Miss Irene Phoebe Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Brown of 357 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, was married to Frederick Pereival Tuthill of Brooklyn. Mr. Brown is auditor of the New-York Life Insurance Company.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- So wedged in the hallways of the Art Institute was the crowd of women to-day at the congress that at one time a panic was imminent. It was at the entrance of the hall in which Susan B. Anthony was speaking. In a hysterical voice a woman called on the Chairman to postpone the programme and send for the police.

The entry list of the Irvington-Milburn road race closed yesterday with 140 entries. The list last year ran up to 128. Three special time prizes will be awarded as follows: First, a silver cup; second, diamond medal; third, a high-grade bicycle.

A complaint made by a Mrs. Gough to the Hudson County health authorities against the manner of the burial of the dead in the Catholic cemetery on West Side Avenue, Jersey City, has led to the discovery that in a stable on the grounds and in the receiving vault there are close upon fifty unburied corpses.

Policeman Fitzgerald of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station arraigned Michael McManus, twenty-three years old, of 434 West Fifty-seventh Street, and John A. Ward, twenty-five years old, of 518 West Fifty-second Street, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct made by James Hughes, fifty-five years old, of 609 West Forty-ninth Street, a sweeper in the Street-Cleaning Department.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Lieut Virgil J. Brumback of the army is at last out of the service. He has given the authorities no end of trouble during the past few months, and there was a feeling of relief when to-day Secretary Lamont accepted the resignation of the officer.

Operators Looking for a Reaction Which They Believe to be Due in View of the Four Days' Steady Advance -- Richmond Terminal's Coming Reorganization -- Providing for Northern Pacific's Floating Debt -- Advance in Bank of England Rate -- Gold Shipments -- Railway Earnings.
CHICAGO, May 18. -- The Illinois Building was dedicated to-day in the presence of 60,000 people. The structure is not yet quite completed, and painters and decorators were at work.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The petition for an investigation of the charges of official wrong-doing made against W.E. Simonds, late Commissioner of Patents, has met with prompt action. To-day Commissioner of Patents Seymour issued a rule upon Messrs. Foster Freeman, the attorneys of the Bell Telephone Company, and the ex-Commissioner, requiring them to show cause why they should not be debarred from practice before the Patent Office.

There were freer dealings in breadstuffs on the Produce Exchange, but at easier prices. Wheat went off 5/8@7/8 c on lower foreign markets and selling orders. Flour was taken up liberally for the United Kingdom at a slight decline in prices. Corn was sold off 1/4@8/8 c, with increasing supplies West and at the seaboard.

The bills that have been hanging over since the Columbian celebration in October were audited yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, which met in secret session in the Mayor's private office for that purpose.
WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The President made the following appointments to-day:

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- An important and interesting test will take place at New-Haven, Conn., to-morrow night. The plan proposed by Capt. A.T. Mahan of the Army Corps of Engineers and the Engineer Secretary of the Light-House Board for a systematic arrangement of the lights along the coast will be put to a practical trial.

Marbles from Italy have long been a drag in the market, but rarely does one find a modern Greek represented hero in sculpture. Four statuettes carved in the purest Pentelican are to be seen at Tiffany Co.'s, where their owner has placed them temporarily before removing them to his house.
NEW-YORK. -- Max Judd Consul General to Vienna, and his wife, sailed yesterday for Southampton by the Hamburg-American steamer Augusta Victoria.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 18. -- Reports published here to-day of a threatened war between factions of Chinese over the Geary act are not believed to have much foundation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 18. -- Congressman M. D. Harter of Mansfield addressed the Thurman Club Wednesday night Mr. Harter predicted that before Christmas eight out of ten intelligent American citizens would incline to his views.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- His Imperial Highness the Grand Duke Alexander of Russia was entertained to-night at a dinner, followed by a ball, given in his honor by Senator and Mrs. Calvin S. Brice. The chief decoration of the dinner table was an immense oval plat of ferns studded with long-stemmed American Beauty roses.

The letter from the Rapid-Transit Commissioners to the Manhattan Company stating the notion taken by the Commissioners at Wednesday's meeting reached George Gould yesterday. He did not call together his Directors or the Committee on Extensions. All of these gentlemen knew from the morning papers what the Commissioners had done, however, and some of them were inclined to be a little resentful because the Commissioners had not come to the Manhattan's terms.

-- Mr. J.D. Wing's schooner Coronet is at Pollion's yard. She has had a new bowspirt, new spinnaker boom, and new topmasts. She will be taken to Tebo's in about two weeks and go on the dry dock. She is to have a new suit of sails.

Hugh McGowan, one of the men employed in fitting the iron beams in the twelve-story building which the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company is putting up at Broadway and Murray Street, fell from the top of the structure to the sub-cellar yesterday and sustained injuries from which he died an hour after his removal to the Chambers Street Hospital.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- To day's fine weather, lower cables, and a lingering feeling of uneasiness regarding the financial situation gave the bears a renewal of their iease of the grain market.
