July wheat closed to lower than on the day before. Corn was weak also. July shows a loss for the day of 8 ac. Hog products received some oilque support and closed higher.

CADETS APPOINTED. -- Appointment of cadets to West Point, N.Y., have been made as follows: Rufus E. Longan. Sedalia. Mo., Seventh District; R. Perry Spencer, Fayette, Mo., alternate, Seventh District; Harry M. Dickmann, Oshkosh. Wia., Sixth District; Emerson M. Johnson, Franklin, Ind., Fifth District; Harold B. Fiske, Portland, Oregon. Second District; E.N. Johnston, Portland.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, was consecrated yesterday morning by Bishop Potter. The occasion was the twenty-fifth anniversary of the church. It had not been consecrated before because it was burdened with debt.

Alfred Kayne, who is rated down town as a man of fashion, is in trouble with the customs authorities over three horses that he brought across the Canada line near Rouse's Point a few days ago. He reported the value of the animals at Rouse's Point as $145 each. This enabled him to eater them for $30 apiece, the tariff upon horses valued at under $150.

The foreign exchange market continued firm. The advance on discount in London caused renewed strength in short sterling and ease in long. The posted rates for sterling were $4.85 1/2 for 60-day bills and $4.90 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.84 1/2@$4.84 3/4 for 60-day bills, $4.89 1/4@$4.90 1/4 for demand, $4.90 1/4@$4.90 1/2 for cable transfers, and $4.83 1/2 @$4.84 for commercial.

The funeral of George Phillips, alias Tony Martin, the green-goods man who was shot and killed last week by Edward J. Hoerner, one of his victims, in Greenpoint, took place yesterday afternoon from 329 West Thlrty-fifth Street Anthony Comstock was on hand with four assistants prepared with warrants to arrest the accomplices of Martin.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 18. -- The railroads tied up by breaks and wash-outs yesterday are slowly resuming traffic.

The difficulties between Theodore Thomas and the World's Fair Directorate apparently leave questions of art and music alone and descend to the commonplace commercial disputes with which an artist of repute should not be troubled.

A new concern, the purpose of which is to help on the completion of the Nicaragua Canal by undertaking the work on the western section or the cut, has been incorporated in San Francisco under the title of the International Construction Company, with a capital of $10,000,000, only a little of which is subscribed.

LONDON, May 18. -- From opening to close a confident feeling prevailed on the Stock Exchange to-day, and a large volume of business was done at advancing prices. Amsterdam, Paris, and Frankfort sent buying orders for Americans, and local buyers eagerly bid for Australian Government bonds and shares of the surviving banks.

The plan providing for an issue of $15,000,000 of collateral trust notes for the purpose of taking up the floating debt and meeting other exigencies was approved by the Northern Pacific Railroad Directors yesterday. An immediate issue of $12,000,000 of these collateral trust notes was authorized, and the officers of the company express confidence that they will have no difficulty in obtaining subscriptions for that amount of the new obligations.

Joseph Rossiter, thirty-three years old, of 345 East Thirty-ninth Street, was committed in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for trial in the Court of Special Sessions on a charge of beating his wife.

A special meeting of the Board of Managers of the American Protective Tariff League was held at the headquarters, 135 West Twenty-third Street, yesterday, at which the league congratulated itself that its financial condition was more favorable than it had ever been before.

-- A Baltimore cycler suggests that the space between centre rails of double-track street railways be paved with sheet asphalt and given up to bicy, clists, as it is of little use to drivers. This would add to the appearance of a street, be a sanitury improvement, and afford a splendid roadway for bicycles. The importance of the bicycle is manifesting itself every day.

Now that ex-Commissioner SIMONDS and the attorneys of the Bell Telephone Company in Washington have been required to show cause why they should not be debarred from practicing before the Patent Office, there will be a thorough inquiry as to the charge that the ex-Commissioner was guilty of misconduct in permitting certain papers in the Patent Office to be copied for the benefit of the Bell Company, in violation, it is alleged, of the rules.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- In-and-out racing was the order of the day at the Point Breeze trotting meeting this afternoon. With the weather cold and cloudy there were many vacant chairs on the grand stand, and the sport lacked the interest it would have carried had the day and track been fine.

The annual report of the City Superintendent of Schools, John Jaspar, to the Board of Education for the year ending Dec. 31, 1892, shows that the total number of schools, including grammar, primary, corporate, industrial, evening, reformatories, orphan asylums, and the nautical school on board of the St. Mary's, is 313.

Friends and admirers of William Sexton, at one time the nerviest of Gotham's billiardists, gathered last night at Maurice Daly's up-town rooms on Broadway, near Thirty-third Street. The occasion was the first of a series of benefits which Sexton's friends are giving in this country and in Paris, France.
The Rev. Samuel A. Eliot, son of President Eliot of Harvard College, was installed last night as pastor of the Unitarian Church of the Saviour, Brooklyn, with appropriate ceremonies.

William Rosenstein of 373 Washington Street, who committed suicide in Machpelah Cemetery, at Cypress Hills, was virtually the head of the C. Rosenstein Company, importer of fanoy matches, bird seed, , being the Treasurer and general manager, while his wife Clara was the President.
The civil suit or John G. Bull, formerly a ticket taker in Madison Square Garden, against Edward G. Gimore. Manager of the Academy of Music, has been settled out of court.

Mr. Louis Windmuller of 20 Reads Street was quoted in Wednesday's NEW-YORK TIMES as saying that he had been informed that Dr. H. A. Haubold of 225 East Seventy-second Street was guilty of negligence in the case of C.O. Pausch, who died of erysipelas at Ward's Island May 10.

TRENTON, N.J., May 18. -- Ex-Senator George Pfeiffer of Camden has not yet given up his offices of United States Marshal, Fish Commissioner, and aide de camp on the Governor's staff, as has been reported.

When the project of the Mulberry Bend Park was first started the Board of Street Opening and Improvement placed 30 per cent, of the cost upon the property holders and 7O per cent. on the city. Last Fall the property owners went before the Board of Street Opening and Improvement and got their assessment reduced to 15 per cent., leaving 85 per cent of the cost of the improvement upon the city.

Evidence in the suit or Lawyer William C. De Witt against County Treasurer Henry H. Adams to recover the sum of $20,000 was heard yesterday by the commission consisting of Asa W. Tenney, Gen. James Jourdan, and David Barnett, to whom it was referred.

It is rather surprising that the press of Philadelphia should have so little to say editorially of Mr. RICE'S revelations concerning Reading's finances, with which the news columns of the papers have been filled. Two of the papers regard the facts shown in Mr. RICE'S report as a vindication of Mr. McLEOD, and his reply thereto as an able and convincing refutation of every possible insinuation!

regard both to attendance and character of racing, closed to-day. The Kentucky Handicap, worth $2,900, brought together the best field of the meeting, including Poet Scout, Ida Pickwick, Galinda, Ferrier, and Rudolph. Ida Pickwick and Poet Scout were anchored with weight, carrying 127 and 128 pounds, respectively.

The order of Secretary or the Navy Herbert directing that in future no leaves of absence will be granted to officers for the purpose of engaging in private business is regarded in naval circles as the forerunner of a long list of regulations which are calculated to completely change the present condition of the personnel of the navy.

Santos Mamai, the good-natured Peruvian giant, lately on exhibition at the Press Club Fair, is dead, and probably the Potter's Field will receive his body if it escapes the dissecting room of Bellevue College. Santos died in the Bellevue Hospital at 8:15 A.M. yesterday. He was admitted to the hospital Thursday, having been taken there from the Press Club Fair building; where he had been quartered.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- According to information received here, the Nicaragua revolution has taken an unexpected turn. Unofficial advices have been received at the State Department that an agreement for an armistice has been reached by the Government and the revolutionary factions in Nicaragua. No further informatian than this is obtainable at the department.

The discord which was precipitated in Sorosis last Monday, and which was exclusively reported in yesterday's NEWYORK TIMES, was the sole topic of conversation yesterday among people of the stage, members of the society, and those who have a taste for literature.

NEW-YORK. -- Jacob Birch, aged seventeen months, was run over and killed yesterday afternoon by a truck as he was playing in front of his home, 139 Suffolk Street. The body was taken to the Thirteenth Precinct Station and the Coroner notified. Simon Simionovitch, the driver of the truck, was arrested and locked up.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- There are to be four retirements among Captains of the line of the army for incapacity. One is the retirement of Capt. Lewis Merriam, Fourth Infantry, who is on sick leave at Seattle, Washington; another that of Capt. J.P. Thompson, Third Infantry; the third that of Capt. G.F. Stiles, Tenth Infantry, and the fourth that of Capt E.C. Knowles, Third Artillery.

Michael J. Kelly, the ball player, actor, philosopher, and all-round sporting man, better known, perhaps, as the "King" and the "Ten-ThonsandDollar Beauty." will be seen in a New-York uniform in a few days. Manager Ward yesterday received a telegram from the player, who accepted the terms offered, and said that he would report for duty on Monday.

LAWRENCE, Mass., May 19. -- Patrick J. Kernan, a young man belonging to a respectable family in this city when called to answer two complaints for larceny, stated that since the sale of liquors bad been forbidden in Lawrence by the no-license law, he had procured largo quantities of alcohol from paint stores, which he drank raw, sometimes three pints in one day, when he could procure money to purchase it.

An alarm of fire at 11:45 last night, followed within, fifteen minutes by three other alarms, called a large section, of the fire department to the seven-ctory brownstone building at 487 and 489 Fifth Avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets.

There is promise of a lively fight against the management of the North American Company, for some of the stockholders have begun efforts to secure a new Board of Directors at the annual meeting of the company, which will be held on June 15.

The Brooklyn Handicap is to be run over before the Board of Control on Tuesday next. A special meeting of the Board of Control has been called for that especial purpose at the request of H.D. Mclntyre, Secretary of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, who has asked for an investigation of all the rumors about the running of the race, under the direction of Philip J. Dwyer, President of the Brooklyn Jookey club.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 19. -- The forecast of another storm, with heavy rains and a cyclonic tendency, causes no little concern among railroad officials, as they have not yet completely recovered from the recent floods.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 19. -- The Star gang of desperadoes has terrorized many of the smaller towns near the border of the Indian Territory in the counties of Cowley, Montgomery, and Chautauqua. In several of these towns armed guards are kept out day and night, and yet members of the gang are permitted to appear on the streets unmolested, although recognized by the inhabitants.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in a case bearing pointedly upon the question of the legality of dealings in options has just been made public. The case was that of B.S. Bibb, plaintiff in error, against Richard H. Allen Co., on appeal from the Middle District of Alabama.

The cowboy race which is to be started from Chadron, Neb., for the World's Fair on June 13 will be the longest race ever tried in this country. Gov. Crounse has been invited to fire the pistol to start the contestants.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- It would appear from to-day's 1/2c advance in the price of wheat that the operators are beginning to shift their gaze from the visible supply to the outlook for next year's supply. Corn and oats were firmer, partly on account of what is being revealed of the requirements of Europe. Provisions were extremely limited, but very firm, with grain.

NEWARK, N.J. May 19. -- The Fidelity Title and Deposit Company has received from Mrs. George N. Watson an itemized list of her husband's pilferings from the company's treasury prior to his disappearance on Tuesday. Watson had been in charge of one of the departments, and his flight on the eve of the discovery of a deficiency of $5,000 in his accounts was noted in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of this morning.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- An evidence of what favoritism and law will do for an officer is afforded at the War Department. Among the officers who will be promoted on account of the advancement of Col. Carlin is Lieut. Merrlam of the Fourth Infantry, who becomes a Captain of that regiment.

HULL, May 19. -- The mediators in the union flock laborers' strike succeeded to-day in effecting a resumption of the conference between the representatives of the Shipping Federation and of the unionists, and after further discussion terms for ending the strike were agreed upon, subject to ratification by the body of the strikers.

Every year the value of the power given to the Governor of this State to veto separate items in appropriation bills is demonstrated anew. Gov. FLOWER has stricken over half a million dollars from the Supply bill and had previously cut about an equal amount from other appropriation bills, and in general he has used his discretion fairly and in the interest of the public welfare.
BOSTON, Mass., May 19. -- Dr. Smith, Secretary of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, says:
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the construction of the following new buildings were filed:
Mr. George W. Childs of the Philadelphia Public Ledger was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Mr. Childs came to New-York with his friend and business partner, Mr. Anthony J. Drexel, the banker.

In the easiest possible manner the New-Yorks won a game from the Washingtons on the Polo Grounds yesterday. They outbatted and outfielded the Senators, and after the fifth inning the result was never in doubt.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, May 19 -- P.M. Speculation to-day was extremely dull, but prices were firm. Those who have been looking for a reaction suffered disappointment, for notwithstanding the dullness the undertone was strong. The final prices were, as a rule, the highest of the day.

Previous to the races at the Gravesend track yesterday Col. S.D. Brace sold at auction the produce of the Ellerslie Stud of Col. R.J. Hancock. Eleven of the get of Eolus sold for a total of $14,750, an average of $1,340, and five of the get of Charaxus for $5,275, an average of $1,055. Details of the sale are as follows:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 19. -- The Little Rock and Memphis Railroad has been notified by the Iron Mountain Route that on and after June 5 it will not be allowed to enter the Union Station in this city. The station is the property of the Iron Mountain Road and the only railroad station here.

-- Today will be a busy one with the local cricket clubs, no less than five games being played on the local grounds in this vicinity. The most important came will take place at Livingston, where the first contest for the championship of the Metropolitan League will be played by the Staten Island and Brooklyn Cricket Clubs.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- Jealousy and personal enmity among some of the women prominent in the congress in session in the Art Institute to-day threatened for a time to disrupt the organization. An amicable settlement was reached after some manoeuvring, but it leaves Mrs. Helen M. Gougar and Mrs. May Wright Sewall in the light of personal enemies.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- There has been some talk of sending a few troops to Chicago. Col. Comly, who has charge of the War Department exhibit, has asked that two companies be sent to act as guards in the Government Building, but the officials who have the consideration of such matters have not found out whether the department possesses the requisite funds.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 19. -- Civil Service Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt spent four hours in this city to-day. Investigating the Terre Hauto Post Office muddle. Ho took the noon train for Washington. He employed a stenographer and took the evidence of about a dozen prominent men, of both parties, bearing on the trouble.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- Secretary Carlisle said this morning, speaking of the failure of so many national banks, that the banks were evidently in bad condition and failed of their own weight, without any connection whatever with the general financial condition of the country.

It is very curious to find intelligent citizens of Rhode Island presenting serious arguments in defense of the requirement of a majority vote for the election of public officers and popular representatives, as if there were some important principle at stake and an innovation were proposed of uncertain effect.

Mr. and Mrs. Wilmott Johnson, Jr., who have for some time figured in the fashionable social registers of New-York, made public yesterday before Judge O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, their domestic infelicities. Mr. Johnson is a prominent member of the Union, the St. Nicholas, the Fencers', the St. Anthony, and the City Club.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The navy may have two composite ships out of the three 1,200-ton gunboats for which plans have been prepared at the Navy Department. This, at least, is the recommendation of the Board of Bureau Chiefs. One of the ships will be of steel, and the Secretary's technical advisers believe it would be advantageous to the service to construct the other two with steel framing and wooden hulls.

-- The Lake Champlain Yacht Club has elected the following officers: Commodore -- W. Seward Webb; Vice Commodore -- Horatio Hickok; President -- E.C. Smith: First Vice President -- Elias Lyman; Second Vice President -- R. Le Grand Cannon; Secretary -- A.G. Wittemore; Treasurer -- Horatio Hickok; Measurer -- A.G. Tuttle; Executive Committee -- D. W. Robinson, C.B. Gray, G.S. Weed. F.H. Wells.

The first regular tournament of the Inter-State Manufacturers and Dealers' Association was commenced yesterday at Passaic, N. J., on the beautiful grounds of the Passaic Gun Club. The programme of the shooting consisted of ten regular events, preceding and following which were others to salt the shooters.

"I suppose we must expect retaliatory measures." said the Rev. Dr. S.L. Baldwin, Secretary of the Methodist Board of Foreign Missions, when the telegraph yestarday afternoon brought word from San Francisco that Congressman Geary had expressed the opinion that the Chinese Registration act would be immediately enforced.

ST. LOUIS, May 19. -- The Republic's Washington correspondent will say in to-morrow's paper that he is authorized to announce definitely at this time that the President and the Secretary of the Treasury have reached a positive conclusion in respect to financial matters.

The strongest public stable of light-harness racers in the East is by all odds that of John A. Goldsmith, at Jacob Rupport's Hudson River track, just out of Poughkeepsie. Nearly one-half of the twenty-four head that Goldsmith is training belong to the Guy Wilkes family. Some of them belong to their trainer, but the bulk of the big string is owned by William Corbitt and one or two others.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 19. -- The Government will pay all bills presented for the entertainment of the Duke of Veragua. This statement was made by Secretary Gresham this afternoon in answer to inquiries whether bills sent to the State Department for money expended in entertaining the Duke in Chicago would be allowed.

NEWARK, May 19. -- Justice Feldmann to-day held a Russian hosiery manufacturer named Lawitsky of 57 Bedford Street on a charge of bigamy. Last Fall the Justice had officiated at a little ceremony at which Jennie Rosenthal, a handsome brunette employed in his factory, became Mrs. Lewitzky.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The royal train arrived in Washington at 8:2O o'clock to-night. An immense crowd of people gathered in the vicinity of the Pennsylvania Railroad station more than an hour before the train arrived. The attaches of the Spanish Legation were there as early as 7 o'clock. They were the first official comers.

BOSTON, May 19. -- The cruiser New-York lay at anchor all day to-day off Boston. The new war ship is an object of great interest to Boston people. A number of excursion parties steamed around the vessel, only one coming on board, however, that of Capt. Kantz from the Charlestown Navy Yard.

-- The annual carnival of sports of the New-Jersey Athletic Club will be held at the club grounds. Bayonne City, N.J., on Decoration Day. The entries for the events will close Monday morning, with James E. Sullivan. Sporting Times office, 241 Broadway, and are as follows: 100-yard run, handicap; 220-yard hurdle, handicap; 440 yard run, handicap; 1-mile run, handicap; 3-mile run, handicap;

The Cutler and Berkeley Schools met at the Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon to decide the baseball championship. The two nines were well matched, and a closer game than the score would indicate resulted. Cutler won. 5 to 0. The 3 runs in the seventh inning virtually decided the struggle.

The discussion in critical circles given to over-nicety in theorizing about music as to whether Maseagni's first work, "Cavalleria Rustieana," is good or bad will undoubtedly go on for some time to come. The public, however, has calmly thrown critical discussion to the dogs and decided that the condensed musical tragedy is the sort of thing it wishes to hear.

Two million dollars in gold coin was withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury yesterday for shipment to Europe to-day. Lazard Fieres took $1,500,000 and Heidelbach, Ickelhelmer Co. $5OO,OOO. Greenbacks figured for $675,OOO in the payments for the gold, and Treasury notes for the remainder.

CANARSIE, L.I., May 19. -- John Redfern, who was aceused of feeding swill to cattle and selling diseased meat in the New-York and Brooklyn markets, was tried to-day before Justice Mathews and a jury at Canarsie Village and acquitted.

-- The Kings County Wheelman has an interesting contest going on among its membership for mileage medals. The men stand up to date as follows: Boerum, 1,015; Boerum, Jr., 488; McDonald, 469; Hawley, 452; Brown, 412; Bensinger, 381; Young, 377; Hart, 338; May, 338; Graham, 332; Bowdish, 331; Wilson, 309; Van De Wiele, 305; Sieves, 275; Kay, 269; Philllpa, 250; Buckley, 248;

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- After the devotional exercises opening the second day's session of the Presbyterian General Assembly, Permanent Clerk Moore requested that the brother who had exchanged overcoats with him come and get his own; also, that the person who had the Moderator's overcoat should return it.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The President to-day made the following appointments:

-- Mr. de Morgan continues to please the Egyptologists by his energetic work at Kom Ombos on the Nile, where he has excavated a large double temple, 500 by 250 feet in size, having a big court set with sixteen columns bearing the name of Tiberius in Egyptian hieroglyphs, and a hall with nineteen columns set about it, each column forty feet high.

A decision just handed down by Chief Justice Daly of the Court of Common Pleas will, if upheld on appeal, put a stop in this city to the practice of remodeling old buildings into hotels or of adding to hotel property by taKing in adjoining houses.

An amateur theatrical entertainment for the benefit of the University Settlement Society was given last night at the Berkeley Lyoeum. Two plays, "A Game of Cards" and "Withered Leaves," were presented by well-known, amateurs, the casts including Evert Janson Wendell, G. Gordon Cleather, Miss Mildred Eytinge, Harry Sargent Blake, and Miss Jean B. Webb.

LOUISVILLIE, Ky., May 19. -- Interest in the death of A. V. Dupont, the millionaire and philanthropist, which occurred under mysterious circumstances last Tuesday, grows instead of waning. The silence of the Louisville papers only tended to whet curiosity and furnish material for all kinds of sensational stories.

The Irishmen who follow the leadership of John Redmond met last night at Wendell's Assembly Rooms, 338 West Forty-fourth Street, and talked about home rule and raised $4OO in a very short time. The money will be used to relieve evicted tenants and for Parliamentary purposes.

LONDON, May 10. -- The leading features of yesterday's markets were repeated today, and a marked increase in business was evident in all departments. The vicinity of the Stock Exchange showed more animation than for many months, and outside buying was on a large scale.

The Infanta Eulalie, husband, and suite, hav. ing been duly welcomed to these shores, the Circulo Colon-Cervantes and the lady patronesses of the forthcoming ball are busy in arranging preliminaries for that most auspicious occasion.

Senator Squire of Washington was asked yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel if he apprehended any danger to the missionaries or other American residents in China as a result of the enforcement of the Chinese Exclusion act.

When the Ivy City race tract near Washington was started, Charles E. Meier, one of the leaders in the scheme, got Thomas Campbell, brother of Congressman Timothy J. Campbell, interested in it. It has caused Mr. Campbell lots of trouble. To invest in the enterprise, which proved unprofitable, Mr. Campbell gave Mr. Meier a bill of sale of his restaurant privileges in West Washington Market.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 19. -- John Walsh, a ten-year-old newsboy of this city, is to receive $2,000 as the result of a lucky find. In the New-York and New-London papers a reward of that amount was this morning offered for the recovery of diamond earrings lost on May 1 by Mrs. Edwin C. Johnson, wife of a wealthy resident of Norwich.

The proposed annexation of Hawaii to the United States was the subject of a debate last evening by the members of the Goldey Literary Society at their meeting at 8 West Fourteenth. Street. Vice President Joseph Beitman presided.

Henry D. Southard, a well-known contractor and politician of Brooklyn, now under indictment for his connection with the Columbian celebration expenditures, was arraigned in the Adams Street Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning on a charge of intoxication and disorderly conduct and fined $10 by Justice Walsh.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 19. -- There are numerous theories for the awful plunge into the Mississippi made by Charles S. Rogers, President of the St. Paul Cordage Company, this afternoon.

CINCINNATI, May 19. -- James E. Murdoch, the veteran tragedian, died this morning at 5:30 o'clock. He had been ill from various ailments for two years. He was tenderly cared for to the end by his daughters. Miss Fanny and Miss Ida.
CHICAGO, May 19. -- After an absence of nearly two years, "Old Hutch" walked into the Grand Pacific this morning as unconcernedly as if he had just crossed over from the Board of Trade Building.
The money market continued easy. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2@ 2 1/2 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.

NEWARK, May 19. -- The suit now pending in chancery, in which Mrs. Harriet Ahlum is sued by her husband, A.F. Ahlum, for divorce, on the ground of desertion, presents some unique features. Mrs. Ahlum's answer, filed to-day, declares that her husband is of unsound mind.

The Toledo. St. Louis and Kansas City Railroad, which has been in financial straits for some time, was yesterday put in the hands of a receiver by order of the United States Circuit Court in Cleveland. Application for a receivership was made by Stout Cory of this city, who filed a judgment against the railroad company for $40,000.

The committee of one hundred citizens which looked after the Duke of Veragua met yesterday in the Governor's Room in the City Hall to arrange for the Infanta's entertainment. Mayor Gilroy presided. He explained that the city had spent only about $13,000 in entertaining the Duke of Veragua, and that there was left $37,0OO of the sum for entertaining distinguished guests.

The harbor of the greatest city of the greatest democratic Government in the universe served yesterday, curiously enough, as a noble stage setting for a scene every element of which was replete with the ideas and observances of Old World aristocracy.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- The wind-up of the trotting meeting at Point Breeze developed lively sport to-day. Five heats, which averaged below 2:20, were trotted in the 2:17 class, a feat without a precedent so early in the season.

In a corner of the Central Park Police Station in the Arsenal Building yesterday there stood a lilac bush eleven feet high. its stems rudely splintered and its blossoms withering. It was a mute witness to a particularly mean speciee of vandalism against which the gray-coated policemen have to exercise their utmost vigilance.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- President Cleveland and the members of his Cabinet have been surprised within the last two days to be questioned about an alleged new policy said to be contemplated by him for the radical reformation of the civil service.

The speculative trading at the Exchanges today was generally light, but in instances at stronger prices. Wheat advanced 3/4 @ 10 on crop reports from the Southwest, reacted 1/4 @ 3/8c on lower cables, prompting realizing, closing steady at a train of 3/8 @ 5/8c for the day. Corn was up 1/4 @ 1/2c, but had very little trading.

ST. Louis, Mo., May 19. -- The tidings from New-York that Miss Lotta Crabtree had been blackballed by Sorosis was shown to Miss Georgia Cayvan, one of Lotta's sponsors, who is here with the Lyceum Theatre Company.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The reception accorded by President and Mrs. Cleveland to the members of the Presbyterian General Assembly from 4 to 6 o'clock this afternoon was a happy climax to a day of pleasant happenings for the visitors. The perfect weather added to the enjoyment of the occasion in rendering the walk from the New-York Avenue Church, where the company assembled, to the White House a positive pleasure.

-- The fifth annual invitation regatta of the Marine and Field Club Caooe Department will be held on Saturday. Jane 24, on Gravesend Bay, off the grounds of the club. The programme is as follows: Morning, 10:30 o'clock -- 1. Senior sailing, 6 miles. 2. Cruising sailing, 6 miles. Afternoon, 2 o'clock -- 3. Club "Representative," one man from each club. 6 miles. 4.

TRENTON, N.J., May 19. -- Pennington Seminary has been in an excited condition for the past week, and last night there was a sensational crisis when Dr. Hanlon, the President, and Prof. John Hanlon, his son, ejected S.E. Smith, a student, from the grounds in a forcible manner.

A quiet but earnest canvass of the large holders of Reading securities is under way for the purpose of ascertaining just how many can be depended upon to support the reorganization plan proposed by J. Lowber Welsh and his associates. The committee of general mortgage bondholders in this city will probably meet next week to consider the matter.

Ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild has found a way to serve on the commission which President Cleveland appointed to investigate the administration of the New-York Custom House. Mr. Fairchild at first declined on the ground that his private business would not permit him to serve.

The public discussion of the sufficiency of the reasons for which candidates for membership in clubs are rejected has advantages as well as charms. One of the advantages of it is that it is interminable and insoluble. This is recognized in debating societies as an excellent credential for a "subject."

Mr. Charles O'Connor Hennessy, who was the Director of the Press Club Fair, but who resigned because of ill health, being succeeded by A. B. de Frece, returned from a sea trip on Tuesday, and was on Thursday night reappointed to his old place as Director.

The harmful effect of the falsehoods put in circulation by reckless speculators in Wall Street is by no means confined to the individuals or the houses immediately affected, but spreads through the financial community. In fact, this is the purpose of the rumor maker. He has no malicious intention to injure those whose credit he attacks. He wishes merely to depress values.

The Treasury Department under the direction of President HARRISON undertook to procure a new set of standard samples of the various kinds and grades of wool, to be used for the classification of imports and in applying the several rates of duty. The samples were obtained in Europe by a commission, and the impression has prevailed since the completion of the commission's work, owing to published reports, that scarcely any change had been made.
MONTREAL, May 19. -- A private cable to a member of the Quebec Cabinet from John T. Hall, Provincial Treasurer, states that the latter has been unable to effect a loan for the Province.

The muscular youths of Columbia and Princeton had their second annual field meeting on the Columbia oval at William's Bridge yesterday, and again the orange and black proved victorious. It was an easy victory, too.

Assistant District Attorney John F. McIntyre is one of the leading candidates in this city for appointment by President Cleveland as United States District Attorney, and his friends are saying that his chances can be regarded as very good. Mr. McIntyre's record in the office of the District Attorney in this county is one that warrants his friends in hoping for his promotion.

Probably this season's revolution in gown designs has aroused no stronger interest at any point than in regard to tailor-made dresses. The firm determination of every woman in the country to visit the World's Fair, and the desire to go with as little luggage as possible, gives special interest to the tailor gown as the most suitable all-around costume yet invented for women.

The session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church yesterday was a short one. The main discussion was upon the question how to effect some feasible method of securing the various funds of the Church. This matter has been brought forcibly before the present General Synod by the Church's bad luck last year in losing a considerable sum of money intrusted without bond to Hugh McCollum, Jr., of Cincinnati.

If Augustus, Count de Benyowsky, were not so perfectly untrustworthy, the volume of memoirs purporting to be written by him might contain some sparse information of a geographical kind, but it can hardly be questioned that the man was a confirmed and habitual story teller. Some small interest there maybe in Benyowsky, because Jokai and Janko -- the first the novelist, the other the geographer -- have been trying of late to reconstruct the man.
LONDON, May 20 -- Business was restricted to-day, owing to the holiday, but there was a further recovery in all departments, and the closing was strong at the highest prices in most cases.

The story of a horse that has been doing some high and lofty tumbling is delighting the sensation lovers of Hudson County. The animal, young and frisky, took fright at Palisade Avenue and Forest Street. Jersey City, and broke loose from the wagon, carrying the forward wheels with him.

By one of the most approved methods Miss Marie Meinell, a scarlet-fever patient in the Willard Parker Hospital, at the foot of East Sixteenth Street, managed to elude the vigilance of nurses and watchman shortly after midnight Thursday morning and to make her escape from a first-floor room.

The Rev. Ralph Williams, rector of St Simon's Church at Aberdsen, sat in his study with the apparatus for writing before him, but the pen was dry and the page unmarked. He was thinking, but not of his sermon. He was hesitating, but not over its exordium. For a man who had ever been prompt, certain, and inflexible, the tremors, the murmurs, the sighs, the groans, which now agitated him were most incongruous.

It is as easy and true as it is useless to say that the kind of amusement presented at Palmer's Theatre during the past week is not of a high order, that its humor is of an elementary sort, and that the piece shows hardly a touch of The dramatic either in its construction or in its presentation. These facts are self-evident.

The Directors of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences adopted, on Friday night the plans of McKim, Mead White for their new museum building. The jury which made the selection from numbered plans consisted of Prof. A. D.F. Hamlin of Columbia College, Mr. Robert S. Peabody, a well-known Boston architect, and George L. Morse, a prominent Brooklyn architect.

"Conjecture over what the Chinese Government may do on account of the Geary law does not interest me in the least," said George F. Soward yesterday. "The thing that should concern every citizen, however, is the course of unblushing and undisguised perfidy that has characterized the dealings of our own Government with China."
The Woman's First Dental Association of the United States will hold several sessions in Chicago this Summer at the time of the Dental Congress and as a part of it.

The Ladies' Oval Tennis Club continued its Spring tennis tournament yesterday afternoon at the Berkeley Oval The women's doubles were completed, first honors going to Miss Sherwood and Miss Mowry, both of the Englewood Tennis Club. Second place went to Miss Burdett and Miss Romaus of the New-York Tennis Club.

CORNWALL, N.Y., May 20 -- The fairest day we've seen this Spring." That was the verdict passed to-day by the members of the Storm King Club, whose house is built upon the very summit of Deer Hill, on the Storm King range of mountains near Cornwall-on-the-Hudson.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- The University of Pennsylvania-Cornell sports took place to-day on thE former's grounds. The Pennsylvania boys had much the better of their opponents at the finish. Summaries:

"Yes, we had lots of trouble here this morning with a chunky Jerseyman, who carried no baggage but a load of Bowery stimulants, and I must appear in the Tombs Police Court again to-morrow," said Cashier Cunneen of the Boss Tweed Restaurant. 140 Park Row, to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

Events which succeeded each other in necessary links, and with frightful logic, and thus became the history of Poland, are here admirably related by Prof. Mortill. It is a disenchanting history, with no heroic legends, and there are only two or three great men. But it is a valuable history, in every phase an object lesson in practical morality.

Because Anthony Trollope was order personified, and wrote just so many words per minute for exactly so many hours, and turned out his "copy" as precise and perfect as if it were printed, is that any reason to suppose that his work is not admirable? You never smell the oil in what he wrote or notice the mechanism.

An able critic remarked, some fifteen years ago, that "no painter has translated a play of Shakespeare into the language of the pencil as Mendelssohn has translated the 'Midsummer Night's Dream' into the language of music." He suggested that this failure was not to be accounted for by saying that "no painter who has arisen since Shakespeare has possessed a genius at all approaching that of the poet in sublimity and comprehensiveness."

-- Amalia Materna, one of the greatest dramatic sopranos at her generation and the foremost exponent of Wagnerian roles, will appear in this city for the first time in seven years next Wednesday evening at Music Hall. Mme. Materna, who is in remarkably good voice, will sing "Isolde's Liebestod," a fragment from the second act of "Parsifal," and the flnale from "Gotterdammerung."

AN INTERESTING OFFICE -- The business office of Howland Pell, who is now in Chicago with Mrs. Pell, is an interesting place. Mr. Pell's office is at 4 Warren street, which generations ago, was the city home of his grandparents. Hanging on the wall of the office is the following interesting invitation:

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday appointed Archer V. Pancoast and Alanson T. Enos receivers of the Archer and Pancoast Manufacturing Company, at 900 Broadway. The appointment was made on the petition of the Directors of the company, and both of the receivers are officers of the concern.

WILD PIGEONS, -- The largest nesting however visited was in 1878 or 1877. It began near Petosky and extended northeast past Crooked Lake for twenty-eight miles, averagizig three or four miles wide. The birds arrived in two separate bodies, one directly from the south by land, the other following the east coast of Wisconsin and crossing at Manitou Island.

PITTSBURG, May 20 -- At 3:50 o'clock this afternoon Pittsburg and vicinity were visited by the most violent hailstorm ever known here. The effect was most disastrous both to life and property. Heavy black clouds suddenly obscured the light of the sun, while the air became oppressively hot. Following a terrific electric flash came the crash and roar of thunder, shaking the very earth.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Secretary Carlisle to-day received a telegram from New-York, stating that ex-Secretary Fairchild had finally consented to serve as Chairman of the commission to investigate the New-York Custom House. The commission will therefore consist of Messrs. Fairchild, Magone, and Dunn, as first announced.

NEW-HAVEN, May 20 -- Yale and Princeton opened the baseball season here to-day in a game which was marked by brilliant battery work on both teams, the best that has been seen here this year. Carter and Drake, the opposing pitchers, were in great form, the former allowing only flve and the latter six singles. Both were effective at critical moments Not one of the runs made on either side was earned.

The decision of Troop A to parade on Decoration Day is deserving of more than passing notice. This action was taken at a meeting of the command held in the West Fifty-sixth Street Armory last Tuesday evening. "It was done," said one of the participants, "in the heartiest manner, and showed the sentiment of the troop regarding the day. I believe, so far, we are the only organization sure of parading."

SAGINAW, Mich., May 20 -- A little spark and a strong southwest gale this afternoon between 4 and 7 o'clock resulted in a destructive fire. In that time the work of years of toil was destroyed, and the fairest portion of Saginaw left a mass of smoldering ashes.

The fact that thimble riggers, or sharpers who work the "shell" game, have been carrying on business on the ferryboats that ply between East Thirty-fourth Street and Long Island City came to light yesterday.

ROME, May 20 -- The Cabinet crisis continues. King Humbert has received in consultation President Farini of the Senate and President Siancheni of the Chamber of Deputies. It is at present uncertain whether Signor Giolitti, head of the Cabinet which has just resigned, will or will not receive a mandate to form another Cabinet.

Seven big ocean steamships, with their cabins filled with passengers, sailed from New-York yesterday. They were the New-York of the American Line, the Aurania of the Cunard Line, La Champagne of the French Line, the Saale of the North German Lloyd, the Werkendam of the Netherlands-American Liue, tlie Dania of the Hamburg-American Line, and the Anchoria of the Anchor Line.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- At last the orders for the distribution of commands in the navy have been completed, and the anxiety that has been manifested among naval officers for many weeks will be removed.

Rear Admiral Gherardi said to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday that he thought the order of Secretary Herbert with reference to leaves of absence for officers of the navy engaged in private business enterprises was a wise one.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 20 -- "The Commercial Relations of Canada" is the title of a new blue book issued to-day by the Finance Department. Mr. Foster, the Minister of Finance, admits that the McKinley tariff has caused a large decrease in Canadian exports to the United States. In 1889 the exports were $36,449,228, and in 1892, $31,624,304. In respect to reciprocity, the Finance Minister says:

LONDON, May 20 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- It is highly typical of the existing state of affairs in Great Britain that we should see the foremost Liberal paper in London devoting a long leader to Mr. Pierce's life of Charles Sumner and picking out the Bully Brooks incident as one fit to serve a peculiar and opportune warning on the Englishmen of to-day.

"No escape this time!" said old Baron Dornenburg, glaring somewhat savagely at an open letter in his hand. It was a letter from an old schoolfellow, now the representative of Government in a distant province of Austria, and in it the Baron was warmly appealed to on behalf of that schoolfellow's son.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Mr. John Willis Baer of Boston, the Secretary of the United Society of Christian Endeavor, had an interview with Attorney General Olney this morning in regard to the points of law and the Government's relations to the World's Columbian Exposition.

William Brookfield, the Chairman of the Republican state Committee, walked into the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday noon, and for the first time in many months he said he was on a hunt for some politicians.
Infanta Eulalie did not take with her to Washington the military band of the Saragossa Regiment. Its eighty members remained in New-York, and will play in Central Park at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

-- The Hempstead Bay Yacht Club will open its clubhouse and sail its first regatta of the season on Decoration Day. The second regatta will be sailed July 1, and the third Aug. 14. The annual cruise will begin July 24.

Amateur photopraphy at the World's Fair. Chicago, is still a topic of great interest to those going there with hand cameras. Much disappointment is felt at the extortionate rate that is charged for the privilege of making a few snap shots and the limitations that are put on the picture taker after he is once on the grounds.

"Too cool weather! is yet the cry of the trout anglers. In Sullivan County they are biting fairly well, but the streams are still swollen. In Delaware County the fishing is not yet good. The season is the latest in years. Farmers in the Beaverkill region, however, say that the next two weeks must produce good fishing.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The Paine cup defender, the Mayflower, the Volunteer, and the Carmita, the first fin keel in the forty-six-foot class, make a notable quartet at Lawley's City Point yard, and attract more attention than all the other boats in the yard put together. The Paine boat is plated and riveted, and the workmen are now busy in cementing her and smoothing her up.
The money market continued easy. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2 cent, throughout the day.

SWARTHMORE, Penn., May 20 -- The Intercollegiate Athletic Association of Pennsylvania held its eighth annual field meeting hero to-day. The weather was fine, and three records were broken and two equaled. All of the seven colleges were represented.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A day perfect in every respect greeted the royal party this morning. The Princess enjoyed a good night's rest, and at 7:30 o'clock, according to the Spanish custom, before leaving her bed, had her cup of chocolate and biscuit. At 9:30 she got up and began to prepare for the official call upon the President and Mrs. Cleveland, untill which time she was not known, officially, to be to the city.

GEORGE B. CURTIS, Treasurer of the Meriden (Conn.) Britannia Company, died ye-terday aged sixty-seven years. Mr. Curtis had held many offices of honor and trust. He was an ex-Mayor of Meriden, a member of the Common Council, and until recently a Trustee of the Cheshire Military Academy. He was one of the executors on the estate of Lemuel J. Curtis, who bequeathed $800,000 to the Curtis Home for Old Ladies.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Infanta Eulalie expressed herself this afternoon, atter her reception by the President and the return call of Mrs. Cleveland, as delighted with her enthusiastic reception in Washington, and said she was very grateful for the courtesies extended her.

BERLIN, May 20 -- Though it would still be rash and premature to attempt to predict the fate of the diverse groups at the coming elections for members of the Reichstag, it can safely be said that if the Government will offer a slight concession in the Army bill regarding the two years' service with the colors it will get a majority in the next House to support the bill.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 20 -- An important fact in connection with local railroad circles leaked out yesterday. It was reported that the Texas and Pacific had sent in its resignation as a member of the New-Orleans Freight Traffic Association, and an investigation proved the truth of the story. General Freight Agent Sargent of the Texas and Pacific telegraphed the withdrawal to New-Orleans without giving any reason.

Several quite large sales or real estate are on the auction lists for the present week, although not all will be had. The Manhattan Athletic Club House, for example, the sale of which was adjourned to Wednesday, has not been readvertised for sale and will net be sold at auction. There is a chance also of some complications attending the sale under foreclosure of the noted Ardsley property, which is set down for Friday.

LENOX, Mass., May 20 -- New-Yorkers who own cottages in Lenox are turning their faces toward this beautiful hilltop. There is a fair-sized colony of them already here, and every day additions are made to their number. Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sloane, who have been spending some time abroad, have returned, and will be in Chicago for a few weeks.

Henter Harfan, an Austrian carpet manufacturer living at 25 West Sixteenth Street, and his clerk, H. Sertosean, also an Austrian, who lives in the same house, were arrested about 10:30 o'clock lastnight in West Seventeenth Street, at the instance of Lawyer Randolph Hurry of the firm of Gallup Hurry, 58 William Street, who lives at 30 West Seventeenth Street.

BOSTON, May 20 -- The cruiser New-York was to-day given a trial spin over the official course. The result was highly satisfactory to her builders, who are sanguine, however, of getting a still higher rate of speed out of the vessel when the official trial takes place on Monday.

That is the cry coming from the French theatres. Managers and playwrights alike complain of a steady decrease in their profits, and are mournfully studying a report of the year's business just made to the Socities des Auteurs Dramatiques. So discouraging are its figures that they have all started in to form theories to account for the public's growing inclination to seek amusement from other sources than the stage.

MALONE, N.Y., May 20 -- Through channels known to be trustworthy, THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S correspondent learned tonight that a boy named Fred Dezener, aged thirteen years, had been attacked by two golden eagles on Thursday, just before nightfall, in Bellmont, seven miles from this village.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 20 -- Telegrams received by the officers of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company in this city give the details of an attempt by the Starr gang of desperadoes to rob the north-bound express train in the Cherokee Strip last night.

A performance will be given at the Star Theatre this evening for the benefit of the sick relief fund of United Council, No. 1,035. American Legion of Honor. This is the largest council in the order, and as it is composed very largely of theatrical people its entertainments are always of a high standard, and result in swelling the sick relief fund very materially.

HAVANA, Cuba, May 20 -- The great insurrection of twenty-five or thirty disaffected persons in the eastern district of the island has been completely suppressed, and the state of siege proclaimed by the Captain General for the Santiago de Cuba Zone has been raised, all without the loss of a single life.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 20 -- Gen. Glynn announces that the programme for the removal of Jefferson Davis's remains to Richmond is about completed. All that he is now awaiting is final details as to the train which is to be furnished for the occasion, and which will be under the control of the Richmond Monumental Association.

NEW-YORK. SATURDAY, May 20 -- P.M. The stock market experienced a reaction to-day, but it was a very limited one. In view of the steady advance since last Monday the decline might have been twice as heavy as it was and still been within the limits of a reasonable reaction.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The greatest attendance of the week at the fair was on Tuesday, Norwegian day, when 62,000 persons passed through the gates. The smallest day was Thursday, when but 27,000 persons came to see the show. The average attendance since the fair opened has been about 33,000. If the turnstiles record on an average 90,000 per day for the entire period of the fair the bare running expenses will be met.

A unique affair planned and executed very recently by a Washington hostess to relieve the tedium of the waning Spring season is permitted a description in THE TIMES on condition that no names are mentioned.

Mr. James Demosthenes O'Rourke can easily find a climate more to his liking than that of NewYork. The orator who has undertaken the task of piloting the Washington Club to victory has played four games here, and on each occasion the New-Yorks won, twice by scores that caused every man on the team to have that tired feeling peculiar to badly-whipped ball players.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 20 -- The warm rays of the early Summer sun have at last banished Winter from the Catskills, and the picturesque hills and valleys, held prisoner so many months by Winter's unrelenting hand, are fragrant with bud and blossom. The ghost of Winter, however, as if loth to abandon the former place of his abode, still lurks in many shady glens, where snowdrifts are still found.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A disastrous accident today marred the close of the great congress of women. A section of flooring 20 by 30 feet in extent forming an entrance to Washington Hall in the Art Institute suddenly gave way and fell to the ground, a distance of twelve feet. Seventy-five panic-stricken women fell in a mass of struggling humanity, and the cries of thousands of women already assembled contributed to the excitement that followed.

Both the auction and the private sales of real estate in this city during the past week snow a fairly good tone in the market. No good property has been sacrificed recently, although poor and speculative realty has been rather a drug. Here and there a bargain has been obtained, just enough to keep keen the scent for such things, but in general property has brought about its real value.

Two De Kalb Avenue trolley cars smashed into each other at the corner of Washington and Concord Streets, in Brooklyn, last night at 6:30 o'clock. One car was completely demolished, and four persons among the crowd with which it was tightly packed were severely hurt.

The sensible method employed by Prof. Gilman in writing his "Profit Sharing" insured its success, and the book remains today the one which best serves those who wish to understand, not theoretically alone, but practically, one of the most important of all modern industrial movements. The volume now under notice is of equal importance.

BOSTON, May 20 -- New bills at the theatres this week were few. At the Bowdoin Square James O'Neill began on Monday a three weeks' engagement, the first of which he has successfully filled with "Fontenelle," and the other two of which he will devote to "Monte Cristo." Then will come the George A. Baker Opera Company to stay live weeks and close the season.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 20 -- A leading family of New-York State has become involved in disgrace through an unworthy scion at Yale College. James S. Dwight, son of Prof. Dwight of Vassar, was arrested to-night on the charge of having defrauded his college mates by appropriating their property and securing money by getting a draft on a Chicago firm.

Twenty-eight lads, whose ages ran from fifteen to seventeen, were busy yesterday afternoon in the large schoolroom of Grammar School No. 46, St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, over examination papers, in which were a number of posers in arithmetic, United States history, geography, and grammar.

All the churches which have missionaries resident in China agree in deploring the effect, certainly upon the missions and probably upon the missionaries, of the enforcement of the Geary law. Even the arrival of the date when, by its terms, that law will go into operation, together with the affirmation by the Supreme Court of its validity, they fear will operate greatly to impair the usefulness of the Christian missionaries in China.

Phngsten, Whitsuntide, and Pentecost mark to-day among the Germans the opening of the season of Summer festivities. They signify that the dreary Winter and showery, windy Spring are at an end, and that it is time for the Teuton to take his wife and children or his best girl out into the green fields under the blue, sunny sky.

Martha Emily Adair, the aged woman who died in the Flatbash Insane Asylum on April 28, according to the evidence adduced at the inquest just held, was killed by the attendants or the patients of the institution.

The bodies of Col. David C. Houston, United States Army, who died in St. Vincent's Hospital Thursday of alcoholism, and Mrs. Minnie Porter, his companion at the Everett House, who died from the same cause in Bellevne Hospital Friday evening, were taken from the city yesterday for burial.

President GOULD of the Manhattan Railway Company, on behalf of the Directors, after an informal consultation with them has declined the proposition of the Rapid-Transit Commission, in its latest form, in regard to the extension of the elevated railroad system, and the high contracting parties are still at odds over the question of compensation, which is the thing the public cares least about.

Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn decided yesterday, in the suits of John Adamson against the Union Railway Company and the Nassau Electric Railroad Company, that the granting of the franchise by the Aldermen to the Union Railroad was fraudulent and in bad faith.

Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, is smoothly paved with asphalt from the Prospect Park Circle to Fifth Avenue, and has a slope of about 15 degrees. During the past few weeks small boys from all parts of the neighborhood have gathered on Lincoln Place with little four-wheeled carts, on which they have coasted down the middle of the street.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., May 20 -- The handsomest monument on this field will be unveiled July 3. It stands in the National Cemetery within a stone's throw of the beautiful statue of Major Gen. John F. Reynolds. It was erected by the State of New-York in memory of the 1,300 valiant sons who are clustered in soldiers' graves at its foot.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 -- The Princeton freshmen nine won its second game from the Harvard freshmen team this afternoon by a score of 11 to 2. For seven innings the game was very close, and the score stood 2 to 1.

Under a roof of flags of all nations on the main and quarter decks of the French man-of-war Arethuse, the officers of that vessel and of the French man-of-war Huseurd entertained yesterday afternoon and evening many of the society ladies of New-York and neighboring cities.

PARIS, May 3 -- A most curious and remarkable fact appears, luminous and undeniable, from the close inspection of the Salon of 1893 -- decidedly, from every point of view, the old Salon -- and this is, that French art has finally fallen in that same groove, apparently regulating her architecture, furniture, knickknacks, everything, in short, pertaining to French manufacture.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The dramatic menu for next week will contain an unusual number of tempting articles. Two more down-town theatres will enter upon their principal World's Fair attractions. Playgoers anticipate with pleasure the appearance at the Schiller of Charles Frohman's Empire Theatre Stock Company of New-York in "The Girl I Left Behind Me," by David Belasco and Franklin Fyles.

ALBANY, May 20 -- About $300,000 worth of paintings were brought here from Johnson's Fifth Avenue gallery and put up for sale at auction. Mr. Johnson had intended to have three evenings, but the light attendance and poor prices realized resulted in his closing the sale the second night. The offerings and sales were:
SING SING, N.Y., May 20 -- "How came Thomas Pallister and Frank W. Roehl to their death"

"I read THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S story of Mafite practices hereabout with very keen interest," Bald Lawyer John W. Goff yesterday, "because a few years ago my duties as Assistant District Attorney led me to make a searching inquiry into the history and methods of the society. Every temperate, earnest article of that sort helps to discourage the use of the stiletto or shotgun in settlement of quarrels or grudges.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Several weeks having elapsed since the opening of the fair, it is interesting to note what the impression concerning the exposition as an institution is based on the sensations experienced in that short time. The consensus of opinion is that, so tar as the exposition proper is concerned, it will be, in a few weeks more, thoroughly complete, comprehensive, and satisfactory, and there the high opinion of it stops.
"Russia proposes to outrepresent England at the port of New-York."

-- Prof. McMaster has made such progress with the fourth volume of his "History of the People of the United States" that he expects to see it in the printer's hands in the Autumn. It relates to the period between 1812 and 1830.

The Larchmont Yacht Club house is one of the prettiest yachting centres in the country, and the Larchmont yachtsmen are the most jovial and good natured of all yachtsmen. When they entertain, they do so royally. When they have a regatta, all enter with a vim, and the races are always well managed. One only has to breathe a challenge in the Larchmont precincts, and there are a dozen ready to take it up.

We notice that some of our Republican contemporaries are quoting with characteristic comments certain assertions made in a letter from Pittsburg recently published by the New-York Tribune, and apparently inspired by the officers of the Tin-Plate Association who reside in that city. One of the assertions to which our Republican friends point with manifestations of pleasurable emotion is as follows:
ALBANY, May 21 -- The following address has been issued in behalf of the Republican members of the State Legislature by the committee appointed for the purpose before the adjournment:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- The interclass tennis tournaments are taking place daily at the association courts en Bayard Avenne. With the exception of the senior class, the tournaments are very vigerously contested, and the result is some very fine playing. The winners of these tournaments will play de class champions who won the championships of their respective classes in their freshman years.

BUFFALO, May 21 -- Information reached the police last night that a well-dressed man was making a tour of the nouses on the east side and exhibiting great quantities of precious stones and fine jewelry which no offered to sell at low prices.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- There is one very important section of the World's Fair which, because of its inaccessibility and distance from the main buildings, is likely to be overlooked by nine out of every ten visitors. And yet there are grouped in this territory sights which would repay even the long and tedious tramp in sand ankle deep to get to them.

PARIS, May 10 -- Complaints of the policy of centralization that concentrates in the capital all the powers or government and0 nearly all cultivation of the arts and sciences are constantly coming from the Provinces. To this policy Paris owes its absolute supremacy over the rest of France, and to it is due the fact that in every political crisis the question is not, "What will France do?" but, "What will Paris do?"

BUFFALO, May 21 -- Mrs. John Downey, who lived on Ganson Street, was awakened early this morning by the noise made apparently by some one trying to open the side door of her room. She arose and lighted the lamp. A dog which was sleeping at the foot of the bed sprang toward the window, growling at the intruders. He struck the table, upsetting the lamp.

Interest in the efforts which members of the Roman Catholic Church are making to secure the reinstatement of the Rev. Dr. Richard L. Burtsell, the former pastor of the Church of the Epiphany, as stated in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, is not confined to members of that parish.

The last number of the London Economist contains some interesting figures as to the origin of the deposits in the suspended Australian banks, by which it appears that there was a sufficient proportion of colonial depositors to make the effect of the suspensions exceedingly grave, and in some cases crushing.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The first Sunday spent in Washington by her Royal Highness the Infanta Eulalie was a very quiet one. If the distinguished representative of the Spanish Government had been a private citizen, on a wholly informal visit to the city, instead of a royal guest being entertained by the Nation, her day could scarcely have been more uneventful.

The little exhibition at the Keppel Gallery of oils by George H. McCord, A.N.A., and the showing of oils, pastels, and etchings at the American Art Galleries are almost the only representatives of the shows which have been overlapping each other daring the past three months. But it will not be long before the Holbein Gallery, opposite the Windsor Hotel, opens a small Summer exhibition.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Possessing 1,600,000 cows, and therefore a larger number than any other State in the Union, and standing preeminently and unquestionably supreme as a dairy State, New-York's interest in the dairy exhibit at the World's Fair is naturally very great. The State is all the more conspicuous in the dairy exposition by reason of the fact that the Director of this important department is a New-York man -- W.H. Gilbert.

The steamship Roanoke of the Old Dominion Line arrived yesterday afternoon with smoke pouring from her afterhold. She reached Quarantine at 5:45 and got to Pier 26 North River, foot of Beach Street, three hours later.

BUFFALO, May 21-- Mayor Bishop will give his decision to-morrow in the trial of Controller Joseph E. Gavin, charged by Franklin D. Locke with malfeasance in office. Controller Gavin is the man in whom was Tested the power of appointing the Police Commissioners, which authority was taken from the Mayor by the nfamous bill whipped through the Legislators by Lieut. Gov. Sheehan on the night before adjournment.

A committee of ladies, among whom are Miss Laura J. Post. Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish, Miss Callender, Mrs. Neilson, Miss Hamilton, and Mrs. Pollock, have formed an association for the support of a much-needed day nursery on the west side, between Fourteenth and Thirty-fourth Streets. Mr. Morris Reno has offered to give the profits of two concerts, to be given by Mine.

PEORIA, Ill., May 21 -- It looks as if the Whisky Trust was doomed. Saturday night the officials of five of the principal working distilleries sent notice to the trust that they would take possession of their plants at once and work them in their own interests.

Gustav Hinrichs, manager and director at Hinrichs's Grand Opera Company, which is now nightly crowding the Grand Opera House, has issued an order that no notices of any members of his company shall be published in the newspapers unless such notices are stamped "O.K." by him.

CHICAGO, Mar 21 -- Eighteen ordained women ministers of the Gospel, representing thirteen different denominations, sat on the speaker's platform at the religious services held this morning in Washington Hall of the Memorial Art Palace by the World's Congress of Representative Women.

Every German in this city, unless perchance a dyspeptic or a misanthrope, was glad at heart when he saw yesterday morning's beaming sun and clear blue sky, giving invitation to a day's jollity in the open, on the green grass and under the green trees, with, his beer and his wife and children or his best girl by his side.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 -- The Harvard men are not at present feeling specially hopeful over the prospects of their crew, for though the material is fair, the men are not developing as well as had been expected. Good judges complain that there is considerable irregularity of body work and shooting of arms.

The grounds of the Clifton Lawn Tennis Club will be formally opened on Decoration Day. The courts have been in constant use for weeks past, but the regular matches between the club members are scheduled for Memorial Day. Later in the year the club will probably hold a handicap tournament with men's singles, men's doubles, and mixed doubles as the attractions.

The Young Men's Institute at 222 and 224 Bowery was crowded yesterday afternoon with a more than ordinarily miscellaneous audience. Those present had come to hear the ex-gambler and ex-convict John P. Quinn lecture on "The Race Track ana Social Gambling."

Lawyer Randolph Hurry was considerably disturbed yesterday over the stories printed in regard to the arrest of Henter Sarfan and H. Sertosean, who called at his house Saturday night, and whose arrest he caused, charging that they had annoyed his family. At the police station he decided not to make any charge and the men were discharged.

From the Westminster Gazette. The Mauritius is an interesting study for an economist. It was flourishing in a rather torpid way, with its old population of French and negroes. who were rather largely mixed, when British enterprise saw in it an opening for the unlimited cultivation of the sugar cane. Estates were bought up at fancy prices from the native proprietors, who generally migrated into the towns, to their own detriment.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21 -- The Appleton Prize in moral philosophy has been awarded to Frank Malvern.
The shooting tournament of the Inter-State Manufacturers and Dealers' Association was finished on Saturday at Passaic, N.J. The guns were kept hot all day, and good scores were made.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 21 -- The schedule for the final examinations is posted, and covers the week beginning June 5. Seniors are examined earlier, and enjoy a vacation from May 30 until commencement week. Commencement proper occurs Wednesday, June 14.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 21 -- The destruction of the great pine forests in Michigan and the upper lake region goes steadily forward in response to the constantly increasing demands of civilization and the pitiless exactions of modern industry. The day draws near when only waste and desolation will remain to mark and mar the broad stretches once clothed with majestic trees.

Richard Croker, Mayor Gilroy, ex-Mayor Grant, Corporation Counsel Clark, and a host of the leaser leaders of Tammany Hall and representatives of the City Government were among the tens of thousands of persons who spent a goodly part of yesterday in Central Park.

To the Editor of the New-YorK Times: In the admirable essay of your correspondent. * * *, which was printed under the caption, "The Wagos Fund Doctrine," in your issue of this date, the writer says that "the more favorable the national conditions and the greater the productive facilities, the greater also must be the joint product of land, labor, and capital.

NEW-HAVEN, May 21 -- The change, in some respects very abrnpt, of the Hartford Courani and the Post of the same city in favor of a plurality amendment of the State Constitution has had the effect of projecting the whole question of constitutional reform into the foreground of political discussion in this State.

Mr. JOHN WANAMAKER has been giving to the public some opinions concerning the financial situation, and of course he undertakes to hold Mr. CLEVELAND'S Administration and the Democratic Party responsible for everything of an unpleasant nature that has recently occurred. "The uncertainties of the policy of the Administration" have caused "distrust."

The Rev. Dr. John R. Paxton, pastor of the West Presbyterian Church, in West Forty-second Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, did not appear in his pulpit yesterday, his place being filled by the Rev. Dr. M.R. Vincent.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: One of the most unpleasant street sights in NewYork, and also a cause of sickness and dirt, is the antiquated ash barrel. It is high time that this eyesore, this relic of the primitive civilization of a frontier town, was banished from our thoroughfares. In no European capital would such a nuisance be tolerated now, and the time has certainly come for us to reform our present system.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed an increase in reserve of $6,627,150. The banks now hold $24,422,175 in excess of the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $3,306,400, an increase in specie of $428,200, an increase in legal tenders of $7,153,300, an increase in deposits of $3,817,400, and a decrease in circulation or $44,400.
"Shall the World's Fair be opened on Sunday?" was the question the Rev. A.C. Dixon of the Hanson Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, discussed in a prelude before his sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- "Stick close to a desk and never go to sea" may by and by become the motto of officers of the navy of the United States who hope to become Admirals, for there appears to be little advantage to be derived from service in deep water over that to be rendered safely on shore.

There is trouble on the Navahoe. Mr. Royal Phelps Carroll and Skipper "Charley" Barr signed a picked crew to take the boat to English waters and sail her in her races on the other side. Now, ten of the crew have deserted and the men say they will do their best to influence sailors not to sign with her. If they are successful their action will put Mr. Carroll in an embarrassing position.

Chairman James P. Archibald of the Paper Hangers' Union created much excitement at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union by declaring that several of the delegates present represented mythical organizations. "I refer," he said, "to the Newspaper Writers' Union, No. 4, and the organization represented by our Secretary, Mortimer O'Connell -- the Brotherhood of Surface Railway Employes.

The Hardware Club has secured quarters in the new building of the Postal Telegraph Company, at Broadway and Murray Street, where it will have the entire upper floor as soon as the building shall be ready for occupancy.
Cable cars have at last come into the procession of traffic on Broadway, and, though they are running slowly and cautiously, they have come to stay.
PORTLAND, Oregon, May 21 -- The Williamette River, in this city, is now 21 feet above the lowwater mark. A number of houses along the river front on the east side have been upset and wrecked.

It is announced to be the intention of the present administration of the Navy Department to hereafter order the annual cruises of the Annapolis naval cadets to be made in foreign waters. The Secretary of the Navy does not favor the idea of a Summer cruise to Newport. Such a cruise, it is declared, is made more in the interests of the officers than of the naval cadets.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The University of Pennsylvania crew is now rowing mostly for form, and consequently the speed la not as good as it has been in the past few weeks. But the form is certainly improving, the jerkiness so apparent in the early part of the season has almost entirely disappeared, and the crew is moon more even and steady in its work.

Thirty thousand overheated New-Yorkers and Brooklynites fled to Coney Island yesterday to escape the scorching which the sun had in store for them at home. All trains from Brooklyn to the wooden city by the sea were crowded to their utmost capacity, and the ferryboats were packed.

SCHENECTADY, May 31 -- The Williams - Union athletic meet held here yesterday was most exciting and closely contested. The day was almost perfect, but the track was poor and no records were broken. Williams won most of the points in the half-mile run and polo vault and obtained a good lead, but Union soon overtook her and from that time out the load see-sawed from one to the other.

A.C. McClurg Co. have published a translation of Arvede Barine's excellent volume on Bernardin de Saint-Pierre, with a preface by Augustin Birrell, who does not write a commentary such as might be interesting, but gives a brief rehearsal of opinions expressed in tones of rather magnanimous condescension.

The resignation of Mr. ISAAC L. RICE from all official connection with the Reading property and the letter setting forth his reasons for such action have brought into startling prominence the necessity for the enforcement of the strictest principles of business honesty in the management of the finances of great properties.
The money market was easy. Call loans were made at 2 @ 5 cent., the average being about 3 cent. On Saturday the rate was 2 cent.

NEW-YOKK, MONDAY, May 22 -- A.M. The week in the stock market was one of steady improvement in prices almost from the opening on Monday until the close on Saturday. There was a slight reaction on Saturday, due not to anything unfavorable in the situation, but to the taking of profits by those who had bought stocks early in the week.

TRENTON, May 21-- An explanation, put forth in the name of a friend, but apparently with his sanction, bearing on Senator John R. McPherson's relations to the Congressmen of the State in the matter of the apportionment of the Federal patronage, furnished the politicians and the newspapers of the State with food for gossip, speculation, and criticism all of last week.
