"Major" Ryan, who is well known to the officials on Governors Island and the officers on the dock at the Battery, has been playing one of his old games during the past few days by ordering large supplies for the island from dealers in this city, and then obtaining small loans by way of commission.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The new apparatus for operating lights in lighthouses will probably be the subject of experiments at New-Haven. Conn., where a visual range of seventy miles may be obtained if necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- Examinations are occupying the attention of the students at the University of Pennsylvania, and preparations for the closing exercises of the year are being made by the different classes and societies. Commencement week will begin on June 12 this year, and will be opened by the commencement of the Zelosophic Society on Monday evening.

The announcement yesterday of the contemplated marriage of Mrs. James G. Blaine, Jr., to Dr. William T. Bull was quite a surprise to society people, inasmuch as it was believed by her friends that Mrs. Blaine had forsworn any future matrimonial alliance.

"Consequent upon the dreadful necessity of being compelled by disaster to build three immense churches in the same city, this church had, two mouths ago, a floating debt of $110,000. Next Sabbath, morning, through contribution of friends and the generosity of those to whom we were indebted. I will preach a sermon commemorative of the payment at that entire floating debt.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The absorbing topic in church circles to-night is a sensational incident which occurred this morning in the First Presbyterian Church, the pastor of which is the Rev. Dr. Sunderland. The church was crowded to its utmost capacity, in the congregation being many Commissioners to the General Assembly.

Mr. Horton is one of the younger clergy of our day, an Oxford man, and actively at work in Hampstead, near London. He has published two volumes daring the past five years on "Inspiration and the Bible" and "Revelation and the Bible," both of which have been well received. The present is in the same line of study and research, and is full of spirit.

It is certain now that the outrages perpetrated upon the aged woman, Martha Emily Adalr, at the Kings County Insane Asylum at Flatbush, which resulted in her death, will cause a most thorough investigation.
The Farragut Association of Naval Veterans and their friends from other associations of veterans went to Woodlawn Cemetery yesterday to decorate the tomb of Admiral Farragut.
PARIS, May 21 -- Premier Dupuy, at a banquet in Toulouse this evening, made a long speech concerning the Government programme and the political situation in France.

The most notable of the auction sales of real estate to-day is that of Mr. James L. Wells, who will sell 211 lots directly opposite Morris Park, in the town of Weetchester. The property commends itself by its accessibility, and the surroundings are such as to make it promising as an investment.

It was supposed that the annual report of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, submitted to the shareholders at the annual meeting recently held in Montreal, would clear up some of the points to which reference has on several occasions been made in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, but the report contains little new information.

The New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor is about to resume its fresh-air work for the needy and distressed, and will welcome contributions to relieve the worthy poor during the coming Summer. It conducts two well-ordered fresh-air establishments, a People's Home, where ocean parties land, and the Eunice Free Home for Convalescent Children at Chapel Hill, N.J.

New-York insurance men were greatly interested yesterday in a published dispatch from Columbus, Ohio, stating that Attorney General John K. Richards of that State had instituted proceedings in the Ohio Supreme Court to prevent the Guarantee and Accident Lloyds Insurance Company of this city from doing business there.

Interest in the men-of-war anchored in the North River is on the wane. Judged from the small crowds which gathered at the landing places yesterday and the mere fringe of spectators on Riverside Drive. New-York's interest in the ships has considerably abated.

An auction sale of a very attractive list of books, including the carefully-selected library of Robert Hoe Lawrence, was begun yesterday afternoon by Bangs Co., 739 Broadway. The catalogue embraces standard works in English and French, besides many curious and scarce volumes and pamphlets.

Yesterday's session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church was characterized by the introduction of uncompromising resolutions touching the subject of abstinence from all manner of work upon Sunday, and deprecating the enforcement of the Geary Exclusion act, and also by a report upon "Signs of the Times," whose language was so extremely spirited as to evoke protests from various members of the Synod.

The Astor Place Bank has obtained two attachments against the Domestic Sewing Machine Company, corner of Broadway and Fourteenth Street, aggregating $27,343. The first attachment was for $2,976 on a note of Henry Bristow of Brooklyn, which was indorsed by the Domestic Sewing Machine Company and discounted by the Astor Place Bank for the company.

The attorney in the case of the alleged widow Anna Catherine Eichler and her children against Mary Eichler, widow and legatee of John Eichler, the wealthy brewer who died about a year ago, will attempt to-day to get a reconsideration of the case before the Supreme Court.

The Committee on Railroads of the Board of Aldermen gave a short hearing yesterday to the lawyers interested in the application of the Lexington Avenue and Pavonia Ferry Railroad Company for permission to extend its tracks from Lexington Avenue through Ninety-sixth Street to Avenue A to the Astoria Ferry.

PIEDRAS NEGRAS, Mexico, May 22 -- A telegram was received to-day at the general offices of the Mexican International Railway here, giving an account of a desperate encounter between Boon Baker, the American station agent at Gabriel, on the one hand, and Tomas Meirujo, a prominent ranchman and bandit, with his mozo, on the other.

Walter J. Chanler, the brother-in-law of Amelia Rives, left his apartments in the Everett House Sunday evening to gather information for a story on the lights and shadows of the Bowery. He succeeded beyond his most sanguine expectations.

Huyler Westervelt of Englewood, N.J., said to be the champion amateur pitcher of America, wants $5,000 damages from Arthur J. Moore, a Wall Street broker, because, he says, the latter punched his head and harled "malicious utterances" at him.
Keiran Kelly, a native of Ireland, fifty-two years old, a former Custom House Inspector, was take to Bellevue Hospital on Sunday night from the Old Slip Police Station suffering from insanity.
The twenty-third annual Corinthian race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club will be sailed on July 1 off Oyster Bay, on the Sound. The classification and list of prizes are as follows:
"That's what makes giants," said Dr. Charles L. Dana to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter last night, pointing to a growth at the base of a brain he had in a porcelain pan.
ALBANY, May 22 -- The Council of Administration of the New-York State Department of the Grand Army of the Republic has adopted the following:
The stiffness of the etiquette which is erpeoted to characterize the ball to the Infanta Eulalie on Friday has not been conducive to perfect peace among many of the patronesses.

As a result of its refusal to take back its recent public criticism of the United States Pension Office, Noah L. Farnham Post. No. 453, of the G.A.R. of tills city has been deprived of its charter by the Department Commander of the State, Joseph P. Cleary of Rochester. The post is now no longer in existence.

Johnny Walsh, the seven-year-old boy of NewLondon, Conn., who found the diamond earrings belonging to Mrs. Johnson of Norwich, Conn., yesterday received the reward of $2,000 offered for the recovery of the Jewels.

Judge Coze of the United States Circuit Court in a decision yesterday sustained the demurrer filed by the E. Howard Clock and Watch Company and other defendants in the action brought against them by the Dueber Watch Case Manufacturing Company.

Mayor Boody has announced his intention to take vigorous measures to protect the people of Brooklyn against the danger to life and limb caused by running elcotric trolley cars at a high rate of speed through the city's crowded streets.

Readers of the public prints are already aware of the surprising observations made on Sunday by the Rev. Dr. SUNDERLAND in the First Presbyterian Church of Washington. The sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. SMITH of New-York, and was devoted to a consideration of the decline of Christianity in general and of Presbyterianism in particular.

At the beginning of Summer, when the regular theatrical companies break up and actors by the score are at liberty, the man who thinks he has written a play, as distinguished from him who has really done so, only needs a little money, hard-earned or other, to acquire an unpleasant degree of certainty in regard to the fruit of his imaginings.

Tales told by travelers in the lands of the far East of the wonderful performances of the fakirs among the peoples there have given such a test to human credence that they would always have been greeted with laughter by the matter-of-fact peoples of the Western world had they not been so often repeated.

The range at Creedmoor was occupied yesterday by a detachment of the Forty-seventh Regiment composed of Companies A, D, I, and K, under command of Capt. Eddy, and numbering 150 officers and men. The shooting was undercharge of Capt. Le Count, the Regimental Inspector of Rifle Practice.

Mr. Lloyd Aspinwall, testifying under oath yesterday, said that he certainly did not have over 50 or 75 cents in bank, and that his assets were practically nothing. He also confirmed the story current for some time that he was separated from his wife, and he added that he was longer had a residence of his own.

-- A Phiadelphia paper says: "The local club lost many games last year from bad management, and evidently a similar weakness afflicts it this year. The game of Friday was lost for want of a little discretion at the right moment, and it was a particularly unfortunate game to lose. Rattle-headed shouting is not coaching, and more fatal errors can be committed that way than in play upon the field.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Having shown in the other departments or the fair what her resources are, New-York State very appropriately rounds out her exhibit of commercial greatness by demonstrating in the Transportation Building her rail and water facilities for handling the great volume of her own products and finding an outlet for those of other States to the seaboard.

PEORIA, Ill., May 22 -- A compromise has been made in the Whisky Trust's affair. At a meeting held to-day between the seceding distillers and the officers of the trust, it was agreed that the distilleries should remain in the hands of the men who withdrew from the trust until the points at issue in the controversy could be decided in a court of law.

KEKNE, N.H., May 22 -- A battery of five boilers at Beaver Mill exploded at 12:20 to-day, badly wrecking the building. Hubbard Houghton was killed. Robert Boulette is fatally injured. The workmen had nearly all left the building, but some had gathered in the boiler room to smoke and eat dinner.
The Directors of the National Bank of Deposit, whose quarters are in the Western Union Building, decided last night to put the bank in liquidation.

The auction sales of real estate announced for to-day are numerous, and include some very desirable improved and unimproved property. At the salesroom in the Trinity Building Mr. Peter F. Meyer will dispose of 39 lots on West 136th, 140th, 213th, and 214th Sts, the King's Bridge Road, and Hawthorne St. These include a whole block front on Amsterdam Av.

A band of Cherokee Indians, with C.J. Harris, the principal chief, at the head, is in this city to conduct, if possible, negotiations by which they may carry home about $6,640,000. They have with them documents showing that the Cherokees have sold to the Government 6,250,000 acres of land known as the Cherokee Outlet.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Princess Eulalie had her photograph taken this morning, and she was delighted with the experience, us old as it has grown to her.

Some nine or ten weeks ago that silvery tongued theatrical speculator and playwright, Mr. Steele Mackaye, while on a visit to this city induced Mr. Sigismund Bernstein, the musical agent for Seldl's Orchestra, to organize, under contract with the Columbian Celebration Company of Chicago, an orchestra of eighty first-class musicians, with Anton Seidl as leader.

-- By a few votes the Produce Exchange members yesterday defeated the proposition to close the Exchange on May 29. The coffee brokers are circulating a petition to the Managers to close their Exchange that day.

A cowardly attack in Williamsburg upon one of the sailors of the Reina Regente was brought to light in the Adams Street court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. James Lynch of 120 North Portland Avenue was charged with the assault, but there was not sufficient evidence to hold him.

The Ladies' Health Protective Association, which is about entering upon its ninth year of sanitary work, has just issued a report of work of the last year, showing very satisfactory progress. Within the year a national charter for sanitary work has been obtained, by which it is hoped to extend the scope of the association.

The action of the Legislature of this State at the last session was open to severe criticism, but the force of that which has been bestowed upon it by a committee of the minority of Senators and Assemblymen is greatly weakened by its partisan spirit. It is natural that criticism from such a source should be partisan, but the fact renders it none the less ineffective.

Rabbi Adolph Radin, Visiting Chaplain of the New-York Board of Jewish Missions, has just returned to this city from Tunkhannock, Penn., where he ministered to the only people of the Jewish faith ever executed for murder in this country.

Now that the naval celebration is over, many of the officers who hare gone, and many of those who still remain, are thinking of the days they spent in the city with a great deal of pleasure and regretting that they are gone.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- There will be an official inquiry affecting the officers of the Monongahela, which arrived last week at Gardiner's Bay, Long Island.

Flotow's pretty little opera "Martha" was brought forward at the Grand Opera House last evening to begin the second week of the Hinrich's Opera Company. "Martha" is genuine comic opera, and a very enjoyable specimen of that species, too. It always commands a fair share of popular approval, and when given by a respectable company at cheap prices will always draw large audiences.

First on reiterations of the Whisky Trust's disruption, and next on denials of it, the company's stock yesterday dropped to 13, and then advanced to 1658. It closed at 16, or 138 points below Saturday's latest quotation.

Some of the holders of the preferred stock of the Trow Directory, Printing and Bookbinding Company are disturbed over two circulars which the company has just issued proposing consents for the issue of a mortgage of $100,000 to secure the payment or loans, in order that current profits may be applied to the resumption of dividends.

ROME, May 22 -- At 11 o'clock this morning King Humbert was in consultation with Signor Giuseppe Zanardelli, a leading statesman and former Minister of Public Works and of the Interior. Signer Zanardelli urged that the King refuse to accept the resignations of the Ministry.

Unless some conciliatory action is taken at once by the Electrical Contractors' Association or the union to which its employes belong, there is likely to be a complete lock-out and tieup among the electrical workers of this city. The cause of all the trouble is the strike instituted against H. Ward Leonard Co. of 136 Liberty Street ten days ago.

MOBILE, Ala., May 22 -- Capt. Fredericksen of the steamer Haugesund, just returned from Bluefields, Nicaragua, reports that the revolutionists entered Rama, a town of 1,000 inhabitants, on May 6, and impressed the natives engaged in banana cultivation to serve in the army.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Fresh evidence has been offered that the row between the Campau and Dickinson factions of the Democratic Party of Michigan is far from a settlement. Mr. Campau has gone to New-York, but Mr. Dickinson has remained in Washington, and to-night his followers are very much elated.

BALTIMORE, May 22 -- Indeed the Giants are in poor luck, if such it can be termed. They lost a game here to-day in the ninth inning, after having the contest well in hand. Strange to say, the New-Yorks have won only two games away from home this season, and these were secured in Washington and Philadelphia.

"Where were the Aldermen?" In the crowd that drank in the sweet music of the Spanish band from the balcony of the City Hall yesterday afternoon there was not one single City Father, unless Col. George B. McClellan, the President of the board, can be called a City Father.

-- The fishing schooner Maggie Sullivan, designed by Thomas McManus of Boston, was given a trial trip on Saturday in Boston Harbor. She proved herself to be a fast and good boat. The Maggie Sullivan had a brush with Arthur Binney's new fisherman and easily held her own, although sailing under some disadvantages. They are now talking of a sweepstakes for fishermen in Boston.

There is good ground for the belief that negotiations for a cessation of hostilities between the Panama Railroad and the Pacific Mail Steamship Company have almost reached a mutually satisfactory termination. Influential persons connected with the Pacific Mail Company frankly admitted yesterday that the "difficulty" was practically settled.

Forty-nine head of thoroughbred yearlings, all but two the produce of the famous McGrathiana Stud, were sold at auction at Tattersalls last evening. Mr. Easton, as usual, disposed of the stock for a total of $69,800, an average of $1,460, a remarkably good showing. Mr. Easton was in good form, and kept things humming from the start, the sale lasting but a tritle over an hour and a half.
John C. Bressington, 19 years old, an agent for the Mosler Safe Company, of 787 Broadway, is lying in the Harlem Hospital suffering from hydrophobia.

C.P. Treat of Chicago, who built the ten-mile stretch of railroad in Nicaragua which is to he used in the construction of the canal, is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He said to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday that he had given especial attention to questions involving the feasibility of constructing the canal, and believed that there was no obstacle which could not easily he overcome when the money was raised.

If the Rapid-Transit Commissioners abandon all further negotiations with the Manhattan Railway Company for an extension of the present elevated railroad system and an increase of its facilities, and proceed to lay out an independent line on the west side, what is the practical result likely to be?

The Custom House Investigating Commission is to begin work bright and early this morning. Poindexter Duun was the only one of its members who visited the Custom House yesterday, and he did not stay there long.

The Reception Committee of Twenty of the Committee of One Hundred met yesterday in the Governor's Room at the City Hall to finish the arrangements for the entertainment of the Infanta Eulalie when she arrives in the city. Gen. Horace Porter presided.
Superintendent Byrnes was asked yesterday by a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES for his theory of the deaths of Pallister and Roehl, but he declined to talk about the matter.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- The Swiss exhibit in the great Manufactures and Liberal Arts Building is temporarily closed. James Perrenoud, the Swiss Commissioner, claims that his Government has been treated with indignity by the United States customs officers, and he ordered the Swiss section to be closed until the Minister of Switzerland at Washington, who has been notified, has obtained satisfaction.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, May 22 -- P.M. The principal interest in to-day's market centred in the speculation in Distilling and Cattle Feeding stock, which opened 2 3/8 points lower at 15, sold almost immediately at 13, and then recovered to 16 3/8, closing at 16, a net loss of 1 3/8 points.
NEWPORT, R.L. May 22 -- Assistant Secretary of the Navy McAdoo will officially inspect the Naval War College and the torpedo school and training station to-morrow.

Facts such as these have been pointed out time and again by civil-service reformers, but it seems that more radical measures are called for. All grades of the administrative public service, except the highest positions, ought to be brought within the range of appointment by competitive examinations. Of course the President must select his own Cabinet, and a few officials of the highest rank, to help him carry out his policy.

The American Theatre, at Eighth Avenue and Forty-second Street, was opened last night, and "The Prodigal Daughter," by Henry Pettitt and Augustus Harris, the most successful of the recent English melodramas, was performed there for the first time in this country.

The attitude of the President and Directors of the Manhattan Hallway Company does not encourage the belief that the Rapid-Transit Commission will succeed in making arrangements for an extension of the present system of elevated railroads in this city. The commission's latest proposition has been peremptorily declined by George J. Gould, who, while not owning a majority of the stock of the Manhattan Railway Company, practically controls the property.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Hot winds were said to prevail over two-thirds of Kansas yesterday, cooking the wheat, and the estimate of the statistician that the crop was reduced to 15,000,000 bushels caused something of a bull movement. There was considerable covering here to-day by shorts on the showing and Cudahy's brokers were active buyers for a time, so that during the first half hour there was an advance of 1/2c.

The Knickerbocker Tennis Club announces Saturday, June 10, as the opening day for its annual Spring tournament. The meeting will be for members only, and will be held on the club grounds. One Hundred and Fortieth Street and Brook Avenue, play beginning each afternoon at 3 o'clock.

NYACK, N.Y., May 22 -- At 1:30 o'clock this afternoon the people at Haverstraw who happened to be out of doors and looking toward the south saw a huge object blown high in the air, and the detonation which followed made the earth tremble. The conclusion was immediately reached that the Clinton Dynamite Works, two and a half miles below the village, had blown up.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 22 -- Jarnea Murphy one of the guards at Sing Sing Prison who was overpowered and disarmed by Pallister and Roehl when they escaped, is now working in this city. To a correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES today he said that the story printed that he had no revolver when attacked by the condemned men was absolutely false.

TRENTON, N.J., May 22 -- Supreme Court Justice Depue by a memorandum filed in the Supreme Court office to-day demoralized the crusade that Peter De Lacy conducted last month against the New-Jersey Jockey Club for violation of the lottery laws.

Previous to the racing at the Gravesend track yesterday, Col. S.D. Bruce sold the following yearlings in the paddock. Bidding was slow and the prices obtained indicated no particular fondness for the get of the sires represented. Details of the sale are as follows:

LONDON, May 22 -- The demonstration of the Irish National League of Great Britain in Hyde Park yesterday was a most enthusiastic affair. About 250,000 people were present, and delegates attended from all branches of the League in the United Kingdom.

The regular monthly meeting of the Trustees at the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine was held yesterday afternoon at the Dioeesan residence, 29 Lafayette Place. The Right Rev. Bishop Potter presided and the others present were the Rev. Drs. Cady, Hoffman, Huntington, and Rainsford, and Messrs. Vanderbilt, Babcock, and Miller.
The Methodist preachers at their regular meeting yesterday resolved to withdraw the Methodist exhibit from the World's Fair because of the proposed Sunday opening.

The steam yacht May, the new flagship of Commodore Edwin D. Morgan, arrived yesterday. She made the voyage from Gibraltar in the remarkably fast time of 12 days 11 hours. After passing Quarantine, the May anchored off Stapleton and her crew at once began to get her looking shipshape. Commodore Morgan will board her to-morrow and will then decide where she will be fitted out for the season.

BOSTON, May 22 -- An indignation meeting of the Boston Fruit and Produce Exchange has been called to take action against the failure of the New-Haven Railroad to keep its promises made at the legislative hearing recently. The decision of the investigation committee of the Legislature did the fruit men no good whatever, and a protest will be entered addressed to the Legislature an a whole.

BOSTON, May 22 -- The fighting qualities of the cruiser New-York are unknown, but if she cannot whip the opponent she may meet in a sea duel, there is at least some consolation in knowing that there are few war vessels afloat that can catch her should she have to run for it, and very few that can get away from her should the case be the other way.

TRENTON, N.J., May 22 -- An order was filed in the Supreme Court Clerk's office to-day by Justice Van Syckle confirming the report of Washington B. Williams on the appeal of the Clark Thread Company, the Clark Mile-End Spool Cotton Company, the Marshall Thread Company, and the Nairn Linoleum Company from the valuation placed upon their property at Harrison by the Hudson County Board for the Equalization of Taxes in 1892.

NEWARK, May 22 -- Selina Rice hobbled on crutches to the witness stand in Judge Childs's Circuit Court to-day to tell the story of an act of self-sacrificing heroism that had caused her injuries by one of the New-Jersey Traction Company's horse cars. She had sued the company for damages, and her story so impressed the jury that it awarded her a verdict of $3,000.

William T.A. Hart, the sexton of St. Patrick's Cathedral, was the subject of a weighty opin- ion handed down yesterday by Surrogate Ransom. Since 1887 Mr. Hart has bean executor of the estate of Archibald Johnston, well known in his day as an auctioneer of carriages and fine wagons at 105 and 107 East Thirteenth Street.

"About this time look out" for imposing statements of what is to be done by Congress with reference to the currency and taxation. There are several good reasons for expecting a considerable crop of this sort. People are very much interested in the subject. The dull season for news is upon us, and there is not much else likely to prove as interesting to talk about.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- John B. Riley of Plattsburg is in Washington for the purpose of advancing, if possible, his candidacy for the position of Consul General to Montreal. This place pays $4,000, and would be highly esteemed by Mr. Riley, whoso home is but a short distance from Montreal.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A garden party was given this afternoon by Senator and Mrs. Brice to the one hundred and fifth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church. The grounds were in perfect order. It was 4 o'clock before the quests began to assemble in any number, but after that time the arrivals followed in quick succession.

No feeling heart will withhold its mood of sympathy from the women of New-York society who have been for three or four days struggling with the mysteries of Spanish Court etiquotte, and whose struggles have straggled into the public prints. It is not known who is instructing them in these intricacies, which are many and various.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23 -- Again the wind has worked its will upon Louisville. Dwellings are ruined, streets are tilled with the wreckage of roofs, with broken and uprooted trees, and with remnants of walls and twisted wires. No lives are known to have been lost, and few of the injuries received were serious.

The office of Manager Rudolph Aronson at the Casino was besieged by chorus girls yesterday morning asking for an advance on the current week's pay for their work in the "Adonis" company. Mr. Aronson assumed charge of the company, which had been given up by Messrs. Burbank stimson, but did not assume their debts, which include many overdue salaries.

A very interesting letter from a correspondent at Chicago was published in Sunday's TIMES, entitled "Annoyances at the Fair." It is most valuable as an explanation of the state of things which has resulted partly from the very great falling off in the actual attendance from what seemed to be reasonable estimates, and partly from the proceedings that threaten to increase that falling off.

The commission created in 1888 for the purpose of improving the appliances at the Quarantine station and putting it in a more effective condition held a meeting yesterday, and proposes to go to work and spend the liberal appropriation of $175,000 and more allowed by the Legislature at the late session.
LONDON, May 23 -- The attendance at the Stock Exchange was thin to-day and the volume of business was small.

Chicago men who read in THE NEW-YORK TIMES Monday the story of the Columbus Monument which has been erected on the late front in the Windy City arose as one man and declared that the statue "looked like Columbus."

The Kings County Commissioners of Charities and Corrections yesterday began their investigation into the circumstances of the death of Mrs. Martha Adair, which occurred at the insane asylum at Flatbush on April 27. Mrs. Adair was eighty-nine years of age.

Another interesting and serious phase of the Chinese difficulty is the probable effect of the Geary law on missionary effort in the empire. A very large body of missionaries, approximating 500, is now at work in China. With commendable enterprise THE NEW-YORK TIMES has secured a complete list of the men and women who are laboring in the mission fields of China.

It was expected that the Rapid Transit Commissioners would meet yesterday and take action on the oft-repeated requests of the residents of the upper section of the city for better facilities for transportation. No meeting could be held, however, on account of the absence of Commissioner Spencer, who was ill.

James Reilly, aged fifty-one years, of 222 Richardson Street, Brooklyn, came to his death yesterday in a most dramatic manner. He lived with his three sons, aged from nineteen to twenty-three years, and his second wife, a pretty nineteen-year-old girl. The family was apparently a happy one.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The friendly mediation of the United States, exercised through Secretary Gresham, has averted a serious rupture between the Governments of Japan and Corea.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 23 -- The Union Electric Railway of New-York City yesterday completed a deal whereby it became the possessor of the entire lines or the Westchester Electric Company. The lines of the latter company, when completed, will operate from the Hudson River to Long Island Sound through the city, while the Union Road will extend its present system from Fordham, meeting and connecting with the newly-acquired line at Woodlawn.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 23 -- The case of Mrs. Martha Du Bois of Sea Cliff and her seventeen-year-old granddaughter, Lillian Treadwell, charged by Margaret Cooney, a former employe, with having given her poisoned coffee in July last, came up before Justice Noble, in the Long Island City Police Court to-day.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- The National Commission has withdrawn from its position of opposing the opening of the World's Fair on Sunday, and this afternoon, by a vote of 30 to 27, accepted the minority report of the Judiciary Committee, which favors Sunday opening.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Every one in the Navy Department to-day read THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S dispatch descriptive of the trial trip of the cruiser New-York, and there was rejoicing over the result. That result was not entirely unexpected, for the contractor's trial of some weeks ago prepared the officials for the remarkable speed developed oft the Massachusetts coast yesderday.

John C. Brassington, the yonng man who was found on the Harlem Bridge Monday afternoon, suffering from hydrophobia and was removed to the Harlem Hospital, was reported yesterday as some what improved, with an even chance for recovery. The lad's father, H.B. Brassington, salesman for the Mosier Safe Company at 787 Broadway, and his mother, were at the hospital all day.

As a result of the investigation by the Grand Jury into the false reports circulated a few days ago affecting the financial standing of H. B. Hollins Co., the following presentment was handed in yesterday to Recorder Smyth, sitting in Part I of the Court of General Sessions:

The physicians and ladies connected with the Post-Graduate Hospital at 226 East Twentieth Street have established at Englewood, N.J., a home called "Daisy Fields" for children undergoing treatment in the Orthopaedie Department of the hospital.

The investigation into the business methods prevailing in the New-York Custom House was informally started yesterday. The practical beginning, however, will be made to-day. All of the Commissioners were at the Custom House yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, the hour set for their formal organization. Ex-Congressman Poindexter Dunn put his latch key in the look of the Deputy Collector's room at 8:45 o'clock.

The auction sales of real estate yesterday included some parcels that were rather interesting in their way than valuable and others that came within the category of investments. Of the first kind were a number of lots on unopened streets near the extreme end of the island, close to the new speedway and the work on the Harlem Ship Canal.

For the last two or three days there has been a great deal of talk whether the stiff rules of Spanish etiquette should govern as to those who will be present at the ball of the Circulo Colon Cervantes on Friday night.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Dullness was the chief characteristic of the market to-day. The arbitrage specialties followed the New-York market closely. The local railway list was dull but strong, and Traction stocks were inactive and without material change. At the meeting of the Reading board no action was taken on the plan of rehabilitation.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The ceremonial of entertaining the Infanta Eulalie by a State banquet at the White House is at last an accomplished fact.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23 -- Information reaches the State officers here from the East to the effect that the Guarantee and Accident Lloyds of New-York, against which the Attorney General proposes to take action, will maintain its side of the fight with vigor. The company is managed by men who have had a variety of experiences with obstreperous public officers, and, if the reports are true, it is not to be easily terrified.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 23 -- A terrific windstorm struck this city at 9 o'clock this morning. A scaffold, blewn from its fastenings by the high wind. Injured four men employed by the Cleveland Gaslight and Coke Company.
John A. Taylor, well known as a publisher in this city and Toronto, Canada, has disappeared in a mysterious manner, leaving no clue as to where he has gone.
Francis H. Weeks, the defaulting lawyer, has been removed from the trusteeship of another estate of which he had charge.

The fifth bird shoot for the Coney Island Athletic Club's trophy was held at Dexter Park, Long Island, yesterday. Eight clubs started in the contest for the cup, and up to yesterday the New-Utrecht Club had a commanding lead. They still lead, but the Atlantic Club crawled up to second place yesterday, and are now only eight points behind the leaders.

PEORIA, Ill., May 23 -- The trouble in the Whisky Trust is increasing. Notice was served to-day on its officers of the withdrawal of another distillery. The blow was entirely unexpected, and it was a heavy one, because the new member of the opposing force is the largest distiller in the world.

BOSTON, Mass., May 23 -- There was just a quorum of ten of the seventeen Directors of the Boston and Maine Railroad present at the meeting to-day. They were Chairman Frank Jones and Messrs, Ricker, Sinclair, Sulloway, Hunneweli, Hart, White, Sewell, Blood, and Reed. Attorney-General Olney could not leave Washington.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Briggs case has monopolized most of the time of the Presbyterinn General Assembly to-day. It came up first in a sort of preliminary skirmish, soon after the opening of the morning session, when Dr. Young. Chairman of the Committee on Bills and Overtures, recommended the sending of certain overtures, indirectly bearing on the Briggs case, to the Judiciary Committee.

BOSTON, May 23 -- A letter was received yesterday from Commissioner Hovey, in charge of the Massachusetts Building at Chicago, stating that the steamship Cadet of Portland, Me., had been assigned moorings near the battle ship Illinois, which was very convenient to the fair grounds. This completes the arrangements for one of the most delightful parties to the World's Fair, composed of twenty-three students of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

During the recent stringency in the money market the New-York banks have been entirely unaffected. On Monday the first instance of weakness was developed. It was that of a small bank formed a few years ago, not a member of the Clearing House Association, with a limited line of local deposits and a still smaller business with banks out of the city, which it has apparently sought to extend.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 23 -- "I'll show her I'm a man! I'll show her I can do something brave," muttered a young boy as he walked, up the steps of the State Capitol this evening. The janitors, who were sitting outside and heard the words, thought nothing of it. A minute later the great door slammed and almost immediately there was a report of a pistol.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 23 -- After fourteen years of wandering. John W. Hillmon, the murderer of Frederick A. Walters, has been located and placed under surveillance so that he can be arrested at any time. The story of his discovery has already been told exclusively in THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The Municipal Council, Irish National League, met last night at Ledwith Hall, Forty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, with Daniel Riordan, the President, in the chair. The Secretary, Lawrence F. Fullam, read the following statement, put forth in behalf of the Irish Independent Parliamentary Party of New-York, whose headquarters are at 705 Eighth Avenue:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 23 -- A meeting of the now Democratic County Committee, chosen in January, was held yesterday in this city for the purpose of organizing. There was a very full attendance of members, and many of the active workers of the party also watched the proceedings with great interest.
Louis Lang was known for years in the artists' colony of this city as an eccentric. He resided at 13 Waverley Place, and died there early this year.

RICHMOND, Va., May 23 -- The programme of ceremonies attending the reinterment of Jefferson Davis's remains at Hollywood a week from to-morrow was made up to-night. The delay was occasioned by the inability of two of the ministers originally selected by Mrs. Davis to be present.

The buildings erected on the Mount Minturn estate by the Sheltering Arms and those closely allied societies, the Children's Fold and the Shepherd's Fold, for the housing and care of their objects of charity, were dedicated yesterday to their work by the Right Rev. H. C. Potter, Bishop of New-York.
If yesterday be a presage of what is to come, New-York's summer is destined to be as severe in its way as the Winter from which she has just emerged with one leap into palmleaf fans and perspiration.

George A. Whitman, the Treasurer and bookkeeper of the Spooner Box Manufacturing Company, 250 West Twenty-seventh Street, was arrested late on Monday night on charges of embezzlement, forgery, and falsification of accounts. Yesterday afternoon Whitman waived examination and was held for trial by Police Justice Martin in $3,500 bail.
Seldom have graver charges been presented against a minister of any denomination than those preferred last night agaist the Rev. Dr. D. C. Potter, pastor of the Tabernacle Baptist Church.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 23 -- At half past five to-night a storm, blowing sixty miles an hour, struck the city from the west and unroofed buildings all over the city, besides laying electric light and telegraph lines low.

WEST POINT, May 23 -- The officers here, with the annual examination and graduating ceremonies staring them in the face, are overwhelmed with social obligations. Yesterday Admiral Magnaghi brought his flagship Etna up here, and announced his arrival by firing the salute of twenty-one suus to the American colors as soon as he dropped anchor.

BRUSSELS, May 23 -- The two French miners, Basly and Lamaudin, delegates to the Miners' International Conference, have been expelled from Belgium on the ground that they had taken a leading part in expelling Belgian miners from Northern France in 1892. Both of the men deny the truth of the charge.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, May 23 -- P.M. While there was very little activity on the Stock Exchange to-day, there was more than the usual quantity of news. Over night the failure of the National Bank of Deposit had been announced, but, as it was in no scnse a Wall Street bank, and was, in fact, of very small consequence anyway, the closiug of its doors did not cause even a ripple of excitement.

-- Many stocks are still lending at a premium. The short interest has not been materially decreased, though bear speculators have been loud in their professions that it had been thoroughly extinguished.

The Board of Control, which has the management of racing affairs on all the big tracks in the East, had a three hours' session yesterday afternoon for the alleged purpose of investigating the talk about the foul running in the Brooklyn Handicap for the purpose of beating Lamplighter. The meeting was held with closed doors, and so far as could be ascertained there was no investigation.

William Hildreth Field, counsel for the Domestic Sewing Machine Company, said yesterday that the note discounted for that company by the Astor Place Bank for $2,976 would be paid at once, because it was due, but that the company would fight against taking up the additional paper, amounting to $24,367, for which the bank had demanded payment, because none of it had yet matured.
The will of Mrs. Channcey M. Depew was filed for probate yesterday. It was executed on July 1, 1886. The witnesses are William I. Van Arsdale, and H.C. Duval, Mr. Depew's private secretary.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 -- A windstorm passed over Indiana about 4 o'clock this morning and did much damage. In the eastern and southern portions of the State the wind blew with great force.

Ceremonies appropriate to the memory of Mr. Horace Waters were held last evening in the Trinity Baptist Church, on East Fifty-fifth Street, of which church he was for many years a member and Deacon. Many of his long-time friends and associates attended to pay tribute to his sterling character and his devotion to the advancement of the work of the church.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 23 -- Superintendent of Insurance Snyder to-day made an official ruling in relation to the non-resident agency law. He has followed closely the opinion of the Attorney General, and declares it to be his purpose to adhere strictly to this ruling, regardless of the action of any company or companies in withdrawing from the State.

E.W. Gould has just been elected Captain of the freshman crew. Since the freshmen won the class races a few of them have grown very careless. The climax was reached last week when three of the crew failed to appear at the boathonse one afternoon because it was raining. The Captain was one of these. Coach Bandler immediately deposed him, and Gould was elected in his place.

Honry Herman of the firm of Adler Herman of 155 Broadway was seen at his office yesterday afternoon by a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter in reference to the statement that he had purchased a controlling interest in the Canal Street Bank and would consolidate it with the Empire State Bank.

The great Type Trust, which was formed by parties interested in squeezing the printing trade, is not having as plain sailing as was anticipated. The few foundries who have persisted in remaining out of the trust have interfered materially with the prosperity of the combination and have again scored a signal victory over the combined foundries.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 23 -- Col. David Tisdale, Member of Parliament for South Norfolk, who brought the question of constructing a canal across the Essex peninsula before Parliament last session, is in the city discussing with Mr. Wyatt, a civil engineer of Duluth, the scheme just laid before the Government by that gentleman.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 23 -- A forest fire has been raging in the country surrounding Ronkonkoma, Lake Grove, and Hollbrook since early Monday morning. It was started in the iry brush by a spark from a locomotive.
BERLIN, May 23 -- The party of the Centre, concerning whose position so much doubt has been felt, has issued an electoral address.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 23 -- For the first time in many years, a strict party fight without a third ticket has taken place in Newport between Samuel R. Honey, Democrat, and John J. Carey, Republican. It was for Second General Assemblyman, to till a vacancy caused by the death of the late Henry Astor Carey.

The Russian ships and the remaining French men-of-war sailed down the river yesterday morning, and as they steamed out they were given three hearty cheers by the sailors of the American men-of-war lying in the North River. The cruisers made a pretty sight as they steamed slowly toward the bay. They went out in one-two-three order, their decks crowded with men who looked regretfully at the city they were leaving behind.

The Republican Club of Massachusetts is disseminating throughout that State an appeal to the voters of the party to take an active part in primary political action at the caucuses, as a means of securing the nomination of candidates known to be "of high character and without reproach," and thereby winning the support of independent voters.

In four of the six races that were run at the Gravesend track yesterday afternoon the favorites wers successful, and that sent the big crowd that was present home in very good humor. It was the sort of thing that the form players like, and they are in a large majority in these days, even though the season is not old enough to make form anything that can be relied on.

Depositors in the National Bank of Deposit, whose Directors voted on Monday night to go into liquidation, will have a meeting at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon in Room 212 at 203 Broadway, for the purpose of adopting a plan for winding up the affairs of the bank. If they can agree and appoint a committee to look after their interests, a receivership can be avoided.
A sudden downfall of rain marred the opening of the Casino roof garden last evening and sent away many who had gone there to enjoy the performance.

Benjamin F. Carver, a retired merchant, sixty-one years of age, committed suicide shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning by jumping from a fourth-story window of the Hotel Bristol, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, to the flagging of the Forty-second Street area. Hundreds of persons passing at the time saw the white-haired old man make his way out on the window sill and leap through nearly eighty feet of space to death on the stones below.

The art students of this city are enjoying a great laugh at the expense of the art students of Chicago, St. Louis, Philadelphis, and other cities from which the knights and ladies of the brush and crayon sent exhibits to the World's Fair. Even while the New-York students are laughing the students from the other cities are pointing the finger of shame and scorn at them.

Mr. JOHN BOYD THACHER has confided to a representative of the New-York Tribune a more lucid and comprehensive account of the system of awards adopted by the committee of which he is Chairman than has hitherto been vouchsafed to the public. After explaining that the fair was "divine" in anwser to a question from the representative of our esteemed contemporary, he went on to expound the system of awards.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- An addition of over 2,000,000 bushels to the amount of wheat on ocean passage was reported to-day. As a result of this and other decidedly bearish news, weakness was the leading feature in wheat and other grain markets. Rain continued in France and Germany and the English crop outlook was steadily improving. Cables were lower with the week's shipments from India, aggregating 700,000 bushels.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The trotting meeting at Belmont Park began with a big surprise to-day. Big Four was looked upon as a sure winner of the 2:45 class, but coming to the post sore and stiff and meeting a fast young mare in Nellie Aldine, the strongly-backed favorite went to the wall in straight heats. Nellie Aldine is a four-year-old. She had no record before to-day.

MADRID, May 23 -- Emilio Castelar, for some time Dictator of Spain and for nearly fifty years conspicuous among Spanish republicans, announced at a private breakfast Sunday that he had retired definitively from public life.

The Reading property is so vast and so intimately connected with the industries of the sections of the country which it serves that its growth and development are limited only by theirs. But the net profits to be derived from the operations of the Reading Road and of its satellite, the Coal and Iron Company, are dependent upon the honesty and efficiency of its management.

BALTIMORE, May 23 -- With Mark Baldwin in the box and "Jack" Doyle to handle his delivery, the New-Yorks felt confident of winning from the Orioles to-day, but again they were doomed to disappointment. The local players batted in good form, and won handily.

Anna Wetmore, who has been known in this city by a half-dozen different names, and to the District Attorneys of this and Kings County as an adventuress, has another victim in her toils. Marriage for the purpose of blackmail has been the agency she has used for her operations. The singular thing about the woman is that she is not handsome or educated.
COLLEGE POINT, L.I., May 23 -- Conductor Myers of the North Shore Branch of the Long Island Railroad experienced a lively ten minutes to-day while his train was between Whitestone and College Point.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Capt. Matthews was at the Navy Department to-day. He has just returned from the Mare Island Navy Yard, where he went as a member of a board detailed to examine into the conduct of that yard. The board was instructed to suggest any changes that might improve the administration of that distant station, so long the object of conflicting report.

The Press Club Fair is now in the height of its glory. Everything possible has been done to give the finishing touches to the arrangement and decorations of the booths, and symmetry and harmony prevail in all details. Its popularity, too, is undiminished, as the crowds of each evening testify.

The Directors or the Ives, Blakeslee Williams Company yesterday presented a petition praying for the dissolution of the company and the appointment of a receiver. For some years this concern has been toe largest manufacturer of toys in the country. The headquarters of the company is at 294 Broadway, and its main factory at Bridgeport, Conn.

At the last meeting of the Park Commissioners it was decided to request Col. W.C. Church of the committee in charge of the Ericsson Statue to appear at the meeting yesterday and explain why the date and place of Ericsson's birth had been placed on the pedestal of the statue in the Battery without the authorization of the Park Board.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- Two hard-fought races filled out the second afternoon of the Belmont Park trotting meeting. Favorites were overthrown in both events and every heat winner trotted the fastest mile of his life. Marguerite's gameness and stamina pave her the 2:33 race alter seven heats had been trotted. She fairly outclassed her rivals, some of whom were very tired toward the end.

Dr. Frank C. Buffun, the Pittsburg physician who was entrapped into marriage by the notorious adventuress one of whose numerous aliases is Anna Wotmore, was seen yesterday afternoon in the Astor House, where he is staying, by a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter.

The assent of the National Commission to the opening of the World's Fair on Sandays leaves the opponents of Sunday openings no recourse, except to the courts. The legal questions involved are interesting. That one which has been most conspicuously involved in the discussion is the question whether, when a grant of money is made upon specified conditions, and the grant is subsequently diminished by the grantor, the grantee is bound by the conditions.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 24 -- Lieut. Hugo Osterhous has been designated as Secretary of the Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy, subject to approval. Capt Phythian has invited Secretary of the Navy Herbert to deliver the diplomas to the graduates on June 2. and the Secretary has accepted.

GLEEN COVE, L.I., May 24 -- This has bean a great day for Glen Cove. It has celebrated with due pomp and ceremony the two hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of its foundation. There was an industrial parade in the morning, followed by the laying of the cornerstone of the new sehoolhouse. The land for this edifice, and one-half of the sum necessary to erect it, was contributed by the late Charles Pratt.
Typhus fever took a jump yesterday. There were four deaths from the disease at North Brother Island and five new cases reported at the Bureau of Contagious Diseases. Those who died were:

SPOKANE, Washington, May 24 -- The richest gold strike ever made in the Northwest was reported yesterday from the Grand Summit Mine on Palmer Mountains, in the Okanagon mining district, this State. An almost solid body of pure gold was found at a depth of 200 feet.

Yesterday was the tenth anniversary of the opening of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge to the public, and it has afforded a striking illustration of the growth of travel with the increase of facilities for it in this metropolitan community. Its use has steadily increased, and has far exceeded all the estimates and calculations of its projectors.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ga., May 24 -- A typical Georgia village of 1,500 inhabitants is Crawfordaville. Its few palatial homes stand far back from the streets in groves of giant oaks. The negroes, in a modest, quiet way, seem to have taken possession of everything.

The Domestic Sewing Machine Company yesterday settled the first attachment for $2,976 obtained by the Astor Place Bank by paying the amount due, but the Sheriff still remains in charge of the offices, at Broadway and Thirteenth Street, on the second attachment which the officers of the company claim they will fight. The officers were in consultation with their attorneys, Field Deshon, for several hours yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Naval Hydrographic Office and the army Corps of Engineers have clashed, with results largely in favor of the former.

Confusion filled the room of the Board of Trade at 203 Broadway yesterday afternoon, where had assembled 257 men, 2 women, and a three-year-old baby. All but the baby had presumably intrusted their money to the National Bank of Deposit of 55 Liberty Street, the Directors of which decided to go into liquidation on Monday night, and which was seized by the Bank Examiner on Monday.

Whatever may be the truth in regard to the current troubles of the Whisky Trust, there is no doubt that very many people believe that they are partly fictitious and that they have been arranged by insiders to affect the prices of stock on the Exchange. Any one inclined to take that view of the matter would have plenty of precedents to justify the probability of the inference.

The Press Club Fair was crowded last night. Every department had its share of the vistors. The restaurant did a thriving business, the room where a practical illustration of how papers are printed is given was crowded, and the women at the different booths were kept busy until the doors closed.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Plunging on a heavy scale was the feature on 'Change to-day. The volume of business was the greatest since the May delivery day. Compared with last night, however, the closing prices for grain are not greatly altered. Wheat is off 1/4 @3/8 c. Corn shows 1/8 c improvement. Provisions, unlike grain, slumped badly and failed to rally.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- After his conference with Attorney General Olney, District Attorney Milchrist stated that the object of his visit was to receive instructions regarding the prosecution of the World's Fair officials if they opened the fair on Sunday.

Zachariah V. Spinosa, a Cuban teacher of languages and a minister of the Gospel, was the complainant in the Court of General Sessions yesterday against Mrs. Julia E. Barringer, who was charged with grand larceny in the first degree.
The Rev. Thomas J. Ducey, rector of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, on East Twenty-eighth Street, has for years been a man whom the public has known for many reasons.

The Board of Health has decided to order that a number of unwholesome dwellings on the east side be vacated. This may involve the turning of some poor families into the streets, but it is the only practical way of dealing with this question of hopelessly unsanitary habitations. Not alone the well-being of the occupants, but the health of the public, is to be considered.

The long job of counting the money in the Sub-Treasury, made necessary by the change in Assistant Treasurers, was completed yesterday morning. Everything was found to be all right and the receipts given in such cases were promptly made out. That was the last formality attending the transfer of the office to the new Assistant Treasurer, Conrad N. Jordan.

The new ballroom at the Waldorf Hotel was filled yesterday afternoon with society women, Spanish officers, and a number of young men, who had fathered there to hear Mrs. C Van Etten Mack lecture on Isabella of Castile and to listen to the Saragassa Band.

The party of Spanish officers from the Infanta Ysabel who went to West Point yesterday in charge of Lieut. John J. Breretch of the Twenty-fourth Infantry had a royal time. General Passenger Agent Lambert of the West Shore Road placed a special car at their disposal.

The steam launch D. and H., designed and built by Seabury Co. for the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, was launched from their works yesterday. She is 35 feet long, 5 feet 9 inches beam, and 2 feet draught. This boat is or special design for canal service. She is of light draught, and the stern is arrangedise as to prevent the boat's causing waves while she is running.

One of the best pictures of yachting Mr. Julian O. Davidson has made is shown for to-day only at the Knoedler Gallery, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. To-morrow it goes to Chicago for exhibition at the fair.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 24 -- At the meeting of the stewards of the Grand Trotting Circuit here to-day dates for meetings were selected as follows:

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, May 24 -- P.M. Trading on the Stock Exchange was very limited to-day, the total transactions being considerably less than 200,000 shares. London prices came lower, a feeling of uneasiness existing at that centre over the coming fortnightly settlement, which begins on Monday next.

The Yale Law School team met the New-York Athletic Club players on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and iron in the easiest possible manner. By doing so they wiped out the defeat administered by the Athletic to the 'Varsity team a few weeks ago.

Farnhsm Post, No. 458, Grand Army of the Republic, will retract none of the sentiments which it expressed regarding the burdening of the pension rolls with the names of "coffee coolers, bounty jumpers, and bummers."

The residents of Staten Island are much exercised lest the ferry franchise of the Staten Island Rapid-Transit Company, which is to be sold at auction by the city authorities Friday morning in accordance with the statutes governing ferry franchises, should become the property of some person or company not at present equipped with transportation facilities equal to those they now enjoy.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 24 -- The Royal Society of Canada, founded by the Marquis of Lorne, is in session here. Many distinguished literary men and scientists, including Sir William Dawson of Montreal and Prof. Virchow of Berlin, Germany, are in attendance. The hall of the Normal School was crowded this evening to hear Dr. Bourinot deliver his Presidential address on "Our Intellectual Strength and Weakness."
The concluding session of the General Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church was held yesterday morning in the Twelfth Street Church.
For two hours last evening firemen waged a stubborn battle with the hottest fire that has taxed their resources for a long time.

Dr. Sara B. Chase, after having been locked up in the Tombs on Tuesday, night was taken to the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning, where her trial on the charge of manslaughter in the first degree was begun before Judge Martine. She is accused of causing the death of Margaret Manzoni by malpractice.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 24 -- James H. Eagan, a lawyer of New-York, came to this city to-day to see about attaching the property of C.A. Burbank and Stempson, to secure the salaries of members of the Dixey Opera Company. Mr. Eagan had a consultation with a legal representative of Mr. Burbank. They came to no settlement.

ORANGE, N.J., May 24 -- The first annual joint field day games of Stevens Institute and Rutgers College was held on the Orange Oval at Grove Street, East Orange, this afternoon, a good-sized crowd being present. Scarcely a record of either college was broken. After the decision of the events there was a scrub frame of lacroose between Stevens men and a few outsiders.

The exclusive official announcement in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES that the Infanta Eulalie had signified to her entertainers in this city that she would be guided entirely by American etiquette during her stay here, and that she did not desire any of the ceremony which attaches to Courts, brought relief to many minds.

In point of quantity of land to be disposed of the sales at the Real Estate Exchange announced for to-day lead. They include the offerings by Mr. R.V. Harnett of a plot, of sixty-five lots on Prescott Av and Emerson St and by Marlin F. Hatch of over 600 acres at Rockaway Beach. At the Trinity Building salesroom Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly offers some east side property and Mr. William Kennelly an Avenue A corner.

The House Committee of the American Yacht Club -- Messrs. W.H. Catlin, John R. Hegeman, Clement Gould, George W. Hall, W.H. Starbuck, and Edwin H. Weatherbee -- has sent out the following announcement about the opening of the club house at Milton Point on Tuesday, (Decoration Day,) May 30:

"Down with Boss Rule" was the caption of the tickets and posters for the "citizens' mass meeting" in Beethoven Hall, 210 to 214 Fifth Street, last night, in the Seventh Assembly District, which Otto Kempner represents in the Assembly. It was announced that Mr. Kempner would render an account to his constituents of the legislative session.

Yesterday was the tenth anniversary of the opening of the Brooklyn Bridge, and two wee flags were raised on the top of the piers in honor of the occasion. The train dispatchers' office at the Brooklyn terminus was decorated with star-spangled banners and crayon, lithographs of George Washington and Christopher Columbus.

In spite of the fact that yesterday was an off day -- that is, that no stakes were on for decision -- there was an exceptionally large crowd at the Gravesend track. The very pleasant weather had much to do with this, perhaps: possibly it was the fact that the races looked to be easy to beat. If the latter was the reason for the liberal attendance the racegoers must have been disappointed.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 24 -- There was lots of record breaking at the games of the New-England Intercollegiate Athletic Association here to-day. Dartmouth sent down a team of thirty-five athletes and carried off the championship honors, which for three years have been held by Amherst.

DENVER, May 24 -- Humors have been current for some days of weakness on the part of the People's Bank and the Savings Bank, which culminated this morning in a heavy run by the depositors upon both these institutions. The tellers have been kept busy all day, and to-night depositors are still in line pressing forward for their money.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The British Ambassador and Lady Pauncefote celebrated the seventy-fourth birthday of her Majesy Queen Victoria by a reception at 10 o'clock to-night, which was the most magnificent entertainment in the long line of brilliant ceremonials ever held within the walls of the embassy.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 24 -- The secret marriage of Sidney E. Clarke, a well-known lawyer of this city, with Miss Mary Robinson of Middletown, which took place at Christ Church last Friday, with only one witness, reached the public ear this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Saltonstall is the rector of the church where the marriage was performed, and the ceremony was witnessed by Capt. William H. Lockwood.

Trading on the Produce Exchange was generally Blow, both on export and speculative account. Wheat was Bold at a decline of 1/2 @ 5/8 c on lower foreign markets and good crop weather West, but rallied on a poor Kansas State crop report and a, statement of a decrease in the supplies east of the Rooky Mountains. Corn followed wheat in its fluctuations, without showing much activity.

A most extraordinary document was filed yesterday in the Clerk's office of the Superior Court by the attorneys of Douglas J. Neame, who was recently divorced by his wife, Lella Olyve Neame. At the time the divorce decree was granted, Mr. Neame gave notice of appeal. In the document filed yesterday through his lawyers.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Whether by accident or by design of the programme makers, to-day's session of the Congress of Press Women of the World was the most unique in its personality of the entire series, showing, as it did, that woman's work for the press is developing in lines heretofore supposed to be only within the province of men.

The annual exhibition of art work by the art students of Cooper Union was opened last evening with an informal reception which was attended by fully 2,000 persons. The building was brilliantly illuminated throughout and decorated with flags and bunting. Eben's band furnished music.

BALTIMORE, May 24 -- After playing in hardest kind of look for two days, the Giants finally carried off a game here tills afternoon. Capt. Ward now believes the spell is broken. Before starting for home to-night he said that he believed with Kelly on the team the Giants will rapidly force to the front. "King" Kelly will mate his first appearance in a New-York uniform when the club gets borne to-morrow.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- In anticipation of a crowd to hear the Briggs case, officers of the Assembly and of the Committee of Arrangements prepared to handle it equitably and satisfactorily.

A Chicago paper, in commenting upon, the fact that Mayor Gilroy did not arrive in Chicago this week, as had been expected, in the company of the party of well-known New-Yorkers who went out there to see the World's Fair, said that Mr. Gilroy, next to being the Chief Executive of New-York City, was best known as Chica- go's chief traducer.
The sale of the Manhattan Athletic Club house was yesterday postponed by Mr. Peter F. Meyer to June 21, at 111 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Mo., May 24 -- An express on the Missouri Pacific was robbed by unmasked robbers one mile and a half west of Pacific to-night.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The usually even-tempered men and women of the State of Maine were indignant to-day. Their granite State building was dedicated, and there were between 5,000 and 10,000 people at the exercises, which would have passed off most pleasantly but for an incident which ruffled the temper of the Commissioners and managers, and even of the Governor of Maine himself.

The commission to investigate the New-York Custom House established itself yesterday in the large room on the ground floor of the Barge Office, in Battery Park. There was a meeting lasting for several hours, but it was behind closed doors. At its end Mr. Wallace MacFarlane stated that the taking of testimony would probably not begin for several days.

The range at Creedmoor was occupied yesterday by a detachment of the Forty-seventh Regiment, composed or Companies B.E.F. and G, under command of Major Pettigrew, and numbering 135 officers and men, including representatives of the field, staff, and non-commissioned staff, and a few from other companies. The practice was in charge of Capt. Le Count of the regiment, under the supervision of Major Babcock of the Second Brigade.

One of those apparently inexplicable cases of a young woman of respectable parentage being detected in shoplifting came up in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning, when Miss Laura Little of 105 West Ninety-fourth Street was arraigned for having stolen from Stern Brothers' establishment on Twenty-third Street several articles of value.

Impresario Hinrich of the Grand Opera House is having a good deal of trouble with his prima donnas, Mmes. Natali and Tavary. Mme Natall appears to have aroused the jealousy of Mme. Tavary, and between them Mr. Hinrich's life is made miserable.

From the present outlook the intercollegiate games to be held at Manhattan Field on Saturday next ought to prove very interesting. All of the star performers are said to be in prime condition, and the Harvard men will have to do good work to retain the championship.

BOSTON, May 24 -- The racing season opened to-day at the beautiful grounds of the Country Club at Clyde Park. The weather was delightful and the attendance large. Eugene Thayer's four-in-hand drag was out. Among those in the grand stand were John Stetson, Louis Aldrich, E.S. Willard, and Gen Francis A. Walker. The Judges were E.B. Haven. John Duryea, and M.P. Lawrence.

The conservative members of the National Federation of America -- the men who do not approve of the methods of the dynamiters, but who look forward with hope to the efforts of Gladstone for home rule for Ireland -- have issued the following:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The absence of information from the Atlanta has caused much comment at the Navy Department. The ship was some days longer in reaching Kingston, Jamaica, than is usual in such cases, and the circumstance encouraged the suspicion that the trip had purposely been delayed in carrying out the alleged impression of inefficiency in the vessel's boilers.

Some grumbling was heard yesterday on the part of Richmond Terminal security holders relative to certain provisions of the Drexel Morgan reorganization plan. Certain provisions for the exchange of Richmond Terminal bonds, East Tennessee bonds, and Georgia Pacific bonds are not satisfactory to many of the holders of those securities.

There was printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday an exclusive story from Topeka, Kan., telling of the wanderings and present location of Joan W. Hillmon, the notorious Kansas Insurance swindler, upon whose life a claim for $25,000 against the Mutual Life Insurance Company of this city has been in the Kansas courts for years.

The house of the Atlantic Yacht Club at Bay Ridge will be opened to-day, and members can entertain as much as they want to from now on to the end of the season. Commodore David Bank has appointed Mr. George H. Church Fleet Captain. Mr. Church has officiated as Fleet Surgeon for several seasons. The appointment is a popular one.

Commissioner Brennan of the Street-Cleaning Department complains because the street railway companies put more sand between the tracks than is necessary. He will send the companies letters to-day asking them to use last sand.

BELFAST, May 24 -- The Conservatives of Belfast and neighboring towns made a great demonstration to-night in Ulster Hall in honor of the Marquis of Salisbury. The hall was literally crammed with people, and the proceedings were marked by intense enthusiasm. Fully 3,000 Ulterites, most of whom carried miniature union jacks, took part in the meeting.

There is every indication that the "withdrawal of the charter of the Noah L. Farnham Post of the Grand Army of the Republic will have an effect exactly opposite to that intended, as is so often the case with efforts to suppress manifestations of sentiment in favor of reforming flagrant abuses. Nobody takes the action of the department and National Commanders as merely a penalty for the technical violation of rules.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- At the morning session of the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day, Dr. Young's sessional report from the Committee on Bills and Overtures, as to the distribution of overtures among the several committees, went through without objection. Sixty overtures relating to new creeds and twenty proposing changes in the present Confession of Faith were sent to the Committee on Bills and Overtures for answer.

PEORIA, Ill., May 24 -- From all that can be learned the Direotors of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company, in session here to-day, kept the telegraph wires hot trying to bring to a focus a scheme to raise money to tide the trust over its present alleged financial embarrassment.

LONDON, May 24 -- The Iron and Steel Institute of Great Britain is holding its annual meeting. President Richards, in addressing the institute, said that the year 1892 had been one of the worst years ever known in the Iron and steel industries.

From the Home Journal. The assurance that under the new management THE NEW-YORK TIMES would undergo no chance of editorship or of policy has been borne out in a gratifying manner. For so many years it has been relied upon by the most intelligent and thoughtful people as a family newspaper that any radical change in the paper must have lost it the enviable position it has so honestly obtained.

Joseph H. Choale chuckled yesterday at the conclusion of a case which popped up unexpectedly before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, affecting a Chinaman who had been arrested under the Geary exclusion law for having no certificate of registration.

A congress of women, auxiliary to the one being held in Chicago, met at the home of Mrs. John McCullough, 317 West Eighty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon to discuss a few of the questions which are agitating the women in Chicago. Mrs. Moflat, President of the Phale Club, presided.

The General Electric Company gave notice yesterday that negotiations for the sale of its holdings in the stock of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of New-York, which had been pending for some time, had been, concluded.

A meeting of the Central Council of the Irish Independent Party which supports, the policy of William E. Redmond in the British House of Commons, was held last evening in the Dublin Club, 163 East Thirty-second Street, Edward O'Flaherty presiding.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24 -- Judge Cable of the City Court this morning handed in his decision in the case of the State against L.E. Meyers and others charged with gaming. Meyers is the legal representative of Mahoney Co. of New-York, pool sellers, and conducted a poolroom over Prokaski's care in this city. Judge Cable found the prisoners guilty and fined Meyers $100 and costs.

The residents of Columbia Heights in Brooklyn are greatly exercised over the efforts of the proprietor of the large boarding house known as the Wyndham, at Henry and Pineapple Streets, to establish a saloon in the building.
The commencement of the General Theological Seminary, Chelsea Square, Twentieth Street and Ninth Avenue, was observed yesterday with ceremony.

The tennis players in the neighborhood of the Rev. Dr. Talmage's church, Brooklyn, have organized a club which has just finished its first annual tournament. The tournament was a handicap affair, and included women's singles, men's singles, men's doubles, and women's doubles. Of the men, Percy G. Anderson, with a handicap of half thirty, bore off first prize in the singles, and Frederick G. Bates and David P. Caryll, receiving fifteen, won the doubles.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 24 -- Henry R. Parrott, head of numerous corporations, including the proposed New-York and Eastern Railroad, and who is a Republican of such prominence as to have his name mentioned for the Gubernatorial candidacy, has been made the defendant in a suit for $15,000, the plaintiffs charging fraud.

Justice Pratt, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, handed down a decision denying the motion of Mrs. Annie E. Palmer to open the judgment taken in the suit for absolute divorce brought against her by Warren C. Palmer. Mrs. Palmer did not defend the suit at the inquest on Dec. 7, and she wanted the judgment opened so that she could have another chance of defense.
Capt. Karl Hebich of the steamer Normannia was a witness for the defense yesterday in the suit brought by Judge Alfred B. Beers of Bridgeport for $10,000 against the Hamburg-American Packet Company.

The friends of Benjamin F. Carver, who was reported yesterday as having committed suicide by jumping from a window of his apartments in the Hotel Bristol, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-sooond Street, on Tuesday, are much incensed because of the statement that he killed himself. They declare that the tragedy was accidental, and they attribute it to a sudden attack of heart disease.

A man of medium stature, stoutly built, looking much careworn, opened the door of the apartments on the second floor of 162 Second Avenue yesterday afternoon, in response to the ring of a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter. His dark hair and mustache, slightly flecked with silvery gray, looted ragged and unkempt, as if he had spent a sleepless night.

CONCORD, N.H., May 24 -- In relation to the much-discussed question concerning alleged negotiation for a lease of the Concord and Montreal Railway to the Boston and Maine, ex-Gov. Frederick Smyth of Manchester, President of the former corporation, says:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 25. -- The cruiser New-York came up the river this morning from her night's anchorage off Brandywine Light, and at noon reached her landing at one of the wharves in Cramps' shipyard.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 25. -- Commander Davis, on board the special train conveying the Infanta Eulalie to New-York this morning, gave out the following authoritative statement:
