By the upsetting of an overcrowded rowboat in the East River yesterday afternoon seven boys were thrown into the water, and notwithstanding heroic efforts made to rescue them three of the number were drowned.

The clergymen of the African Methodist Episcopal Church of the New-York District are holding their annual conference in Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, 214 Sullivan Street. This is the seventy-third annual session. It was opened yesterday morning at 9:15 o'clock, the Right Rev. B.F. Tanner, D.D., presiding.

The examination of applicants for admission to the College of the City of New-York was begun yesterday In the college building. In East Twenty-third Street. l,370 boys, none of whom was under fourteen years of age, being present. This number is somewhat larger than that of last year. The number of applications sent from the public schools was 1,405 and President Webb expressed himself as well satisfied with the showing.

Judge THOMAS M. COOLEY, the highest authority on constitutional law in the United States, under the title "Grave Obstacles to Hawaiian Annexation," discusses in the June number of the Forum the coustitutional bearing of the exercise of the treaty-making powor of the Government for the "annexation," or acquisition, of independent nations remote from our national boundaries.

Mr. J. Thomas Stearns, who was removed by Commissioner Haffen from the office of Superintendent of Maintenance in the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards on May 11, yesterday served notice on Mr. Hoffen that his removal was illegal under the provisions of Chapter 577 of the Laws of 1892, on the ground that he was a member of the Volunteer Fire Department of Tremont at the time of its disbandment.
The Normal College of the City of New-York closed on Wednesday of last week to all but the members of the senior class, who have been and are yet at work on their examinations for diplomas.

The New-Haven Palladium, which is the representative Republican newspaper of at least the southern part of the State of Connecticut, comes out strongly in favor of a convention to revise the Constitution of that State, thus placing itself squarely in support of the demand of the Democratic Party.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- March, weather put a damper on tbe exposition to-day, but the crowds poured through the gates just the same. The strangers are in the city, and as they have come to see the fair they do not intend to be kept away by any freaks of the weather.

Another active Republican of Brooklyn has added his name to the list of converts to Democracy in that city. He is George N. Buchanan, who for several years has been one of the most successful Republican leaders in South Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- The record for speed from the 400 miles distance was broken to-day in the journey from High Point, N.C., to this city. The entry was Sonderling's Nelson and Moorestown, and Charles Mehler's Clipper, Devil, and Trainer. The start was at 6:30 o'clock.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY., May 25 -- P.M. There was a little more activity in the stock market to-day and prices generally were higher. General Electric, Richmond Terminal, and Cordage were heavy, but the general market moved in opposition to these specialties.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A report from the Judicial Committee was submitted this morning recommending that, the six complaints of J. J. McCook and others against the New-York Synod, growing out of the trial of Prof. Briggs, be referred to a judicial commission for trial. The question was asked whether or not the Synod of New-York had met since the charges were filed.

ST. Louis, Mo., May 25. -- The robbery of westbound Train No. 3 on tile Missouri Pacific Railroad, which was held up one mile west of the station at Pacific. Mo., at 9:40 P.M. last night, was one of the most daring train robberies on record.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 25. -- There is trouble among the members of the congregation of the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Bloomfield's most fashionable house of worship, and the cause of the trouble is an innocent action of the pastor, the Rev. George A. Paull.

NEWARK, May 25. -- Henri Bayard, a missing pension agent, whose sudden flight from this city has been attributed to a threatened pursuit of him by his abandoned wife, and who, when he went, is said to have left a number of collected pension claims unpaid, has been heard from at Washington, D.C.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 25. -- Miss H. Stanton and Miss J. Stanton, her sister, of 24 West Fifty-second Street, New-York, had a narrow escape to-day.
PEORIA, Ill., May 25. -- After holding an allday session, the Directors of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company gave a statement to the press in effect as follows:

CHICAGO, May 25. -- The German section of the Agricultural Building was thrown open this morning for the first time. The feature of the exhibition is a temple of solid chocolate by a Cologne house. The temple is built in the Renaissance style. It covers 10 square feet and has a height of 33 feet up to the crown. There are 30,000 pounds of chocolate in the pavilion.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 25. -- There is trouble brewing between the New-Orleans Freight Traffic Association and the Western Traffic Association. A conference was held here just after Mardi Gras and a peace was patched up, but it is evident from the action taken more recently by the local body that there is rate cutting somewhere, and the retaliation has been bold and rapid.

ALBANY, May 25. -- Governor Flower, accompanied by Superintendent of Public Works Hannan and State Engineer Schenck, this afternoon completed his inspection of the Erie Canal, having come down, to this city on a steam launch from Canajoharie since yesterday morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25. -- About twelve months ago an alluring prospectus was scattered broadcast in this State and also throughout the South and West asking subscriptions to stock for the Aldine Hotel Company of Chicago, to be paid on the installment plan, all subscriptions to mature in time for the World's Fair.
The park policemen were in their element yesterday. It was their day of days. They were on parade, the observed of all observers.

A funeral which was to have taken place yesterday morning in Brooklyn was ordered postponed by Coroner Kene and was not allowed to proceed until an autopsy had been performed upon the body. That was done at 1 P.M.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The President to-day made the following appointments: William E. Quinby of Detroit, Mich., to be Minister to the Netherlands.
The Trustees of St. Martha's Dispensary and Sanitarium, at the corner of Dean Street and Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn, are making efforts to provide for the care of epileptics.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 25.--Much gossip was indulged in here to-day when it became known that Betsy Dangler, daughter of Town Councilman J.H. Dangler of the village of West Long Branch, who mysteriously disappeared, on Oct. 23, 1892, had returned.

The new Commissioner of Pensions has revoked the "completed-files" order of Commissioner RAUM and thereby given notice that the Pension Bureau is not to be controlled by the ring of pension attorneys in Washington. The history and the effect of this order were fully disclosed during the recent Congressional investigation, and there was left no room for doubt as to the motives of the officer who issued it.

Frederick Hirdes, a German grocery clerk, twenty-one years old, committed suicide yesterday morning in his furnished room at the house of Mrs. Salomon, 132 West Sixty-third Street, by swallowing a cupful of carbolic acid. He was despondent because of ill health and inability to obtain remunerative employment.

It is no secret that the attendance upon the World's Fair has thus far been very much below the expectations of the managers of the enterprise. The expectations seemed reasonable enough, and they were shared by the men who purchased concessions of the right to sell nearly every thing, from photographs to popcorn, at prices which now seem very extravagant.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 25. -- Samuel W. Brooks, messenger to the Governor, is engaged in overhauling the State papers from the executive department which were removed to the cellars of the State House when the building was repaired in 1776. He sifts out especially valuable papers. To-day he handed to Gov. Brown a packet of five very interesting ones, four of great historic value.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 25. -- The Wesleyan nine shut out the Meriden professionals this afternoon. The visitors could not bunch their hits and were excelled in fielding and base running. Score by innings:

The Kings County Commissioners of Charities and Correction yesterday brought to a conclusion their investigation of the death of Mrs. Martha Emily Adair, which took, place at the Flatbush Insane Asylum on April 23. They directed their inquiries ostensibly to ascertaining how the deceased came to sustain the fracture of ten of her ribs and severe contusions upon various parts of her body.
SAN ANGELO, Texas, May 25. -- The westbound passenger train on the Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railroad was held up and the express car robbed by two highwaymen last night at Coleman, Texas.

Miss Beatrice Moroland and Miss Rose Coghlan are out. Formerly Miss Moreland played first female and other parts to Miss Coghlan's lead, but now the two ladies have not only drifted apart, but they have carried their troubles into court, or, at any rate. Miss Moreland has. She wants to recover from Miss Coghlan $1,145.35, which, she alleges, is due her for salary.

Great interest attaches to the forthcoming tests of Whitohead and Howell torpedoes which are to come off at Newport. It seems strange that our navy should be so backward in providing itself with these appliances of warfare, after having made a very rapid and creditable advance in other particulars.
The money market continued easy. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2@ 3 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.

Notwithstanding the presence of bona fide royalty in this city, the first time since the memorable visit of the Grand Duke Alexis in the early seventies, society has elected to go to the country during the week allotted for festivity and pass the time quietly instead of engaging in the pleasant task of welcoming the fair and gracious Spanish Princess who is the Nation's guest.

FORT MONROE, May 25. -- Hampton has this week celebrated her twenty-fifth anniversary. Commencement day is always the great day of the year, but to-day the flags which waved over the grounds were at half mast, and uppermost in the mind of every one was the thought of Gen. Armstrong, the founder of the school, who died two weeks ago.

It was reported yesterday that there was a conflict of authority between the Board of Health at Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the Department of Public Works in this city in consequence of the order issued by Commissioner Daly and Health Commissioner Edson during their tour of inspection to close up the drains which discharged into the tributaries of Croton Lake.

A corner on 5th AV just opposite the palatial quarters or too Union League Club has been sold which recalls an interesting phase or the old Tweed Ring. The property consists of the four-story brownstone high-stoop dwelling at the southeast corner or 39th St and 5th Av. The lot is 25 feet by 100, and back of it is a stable on a lot 25 by 50 feet.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 25. -- Insurance circles here are somewhat disturbed by the fact that Commission No. 1. at Cincinnati, has ordered Manager Allen of the Indianapolis Fire Insurance Compact, which includes every company represented in this city, to declare a rise in rates on mercantile risks and special hazards.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 25. -- The remainder of the great Russian exhibit for the World's Fair arrived here to-day in the British steamship Wivenhoe, Capt. B.D. Clark, which left Hamburg on April 26. The exhibit is packed in 231 cases and packages, and will be shipped to Chicago at once.

LONDON, May 25. -- There was a marked change of sentiment to-day. Prices in all departments opened strong, and, with the exception of Australian banks, which lost 1 per cent. on profit taking, and Greek bonds, which further declined, on probable non-payment of July coupons, the closing was at the best prices, after a buoyant day.

NORWALK, Conn., May 25.--Ex-Mayor William B. Reed of South Norwalk and Frederick Palmer or Stamford, who were appointed appraisers on the estate of William B. Weed, the Noroton miser and hermit who starved himself to death a short time ago, have completed their inventory of the estate, with the following results: In savings bank, $11,696,80; real estate, $7,500: stocks, bonds, and mortgages. $8,500; other property.

PARIS, May 25. -- Sir Charles Russell continued his argument in behalf of the British case today before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration. He argued against the United States forbidding foreigners to catch seals outside of territorial waters, and put emphasis on the statement that American law, even to-day, does not make sealing outside of Bering Sea illegal.

Grand Army men are much roused over the affairs of what was Farnham Post, and all day yesterday members of that body, and especially members of the committee who have immediate direction of matters, were the recipients of messages and congratulations for their stand in favor of pension reform from former comrades in other posts. That was as far, however, as sympathy seems yet to have gone.
For the first time yesterday the royal and dainty foot of the Infanta of Spain, now the guest of this city, pressed the soil, carefully carpeted though it was, of Manhattan Island.

The National Union Bank, which will open about June 1 in the Mutual Life Building, at 32 Nassau Street, in the offices formerly occupied by Kuhn, Loeb Co., will add materially to the financial institutions or New-York City.
RICHMOND, Va., May 25. -- Elections for local officers were held to-day in all of the counties in Virginia. In many cases the Democrats were elected without opposition.

Mrs. Eliza Blggart, mother of Margaret Manzoni, whoso death Dr. Sara B. Chase is charged with bringing about by means of a criminal operation, was again on the stand yesterday morning, in the Court of General Sessions, in the trial of Dr. Chase for manslaughter.

Thomas Breen, formerly an iron manufacturer of Chester, Ponn., and engaged lately as President and promoter of a transcontinental railway system, has devised a viaduct scheme for rapid transit which he intends to bring to the attention of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners.

There has been more or less talk about the new Reading reorganization scheme in the region of Wall Street within the past few days, and the suspicion that there was a serious hitch in the plan has grown in certain quarters.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25.--Justice Abbott and H.N. Barton, counsel for Mre. Mattle Shann, indicted for the murder of her son Join Shann by poison, had a breezy tilt in the Mercer Court to-day over the trial of the woman.

In a small, dingy back room on the top floor of one of the Cat Alley tenement houses just back of 19 Cherry Street, against which so many crimes are recorded, Antonio Blanco, a poor Italian tailor, shortly after 8 A.M. yesterday shot his wife Trusiana to death and wounded her lover, Gabriel Bertoilni, so that he died in the hospital.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 25, -- The Democrats won in the bye-election in South Kingstown today. This gives them 54 votes in the next Legislature the Republicans have 55.
CITY ISLAND, May 25. -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yacht Stella, Mr. James H. Breslin; sloop yacht Katrina, Mr. George Work.

The foreign exchange market was quiet. Sixtyday sterling was firm, but demand and cable transfers were somewhat easier. The posted rates for sterling were $4.86 for 60-day bills and $4.90 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.85 12@$4.85 34 for 60-day bills, $4.89@$4.89 14 for demand, $4.90 for cable transfers, and $4.84 12@ $4.84 34 for commercial.

Prof. Moses C. Farmar, who was one of the pioneers in the modern application of electricity to industrial uses, died yesterday of pneumonia in Chicago. Although Prof. Farmar was seventy-three years of age and had been for some time in delicate health, his death was unexpected by his friends, who knew it to be the ambition of his life to witness the triumphs of electrical science at the Colombian Exposition.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 174@173 12, North Chicago at 241 12, Diamond Match at 121, Lake Street Elevated at 22 12, Strawboard at 65. Money, 6@7 cent.; bank clearings, $14,612,584; New-York exchange, 60 c discount.

The test case under the Geary act which came before Judge LACOMBE on Wednesday was hardly less interesting than that which was carried to the United States Supreme Court two or three weeks ago. The latter was heralded with much public announcement and had for its purpose the determination of the constitutionality of the deportation provisions.
Under a decision rendered by Jndge Patterson yesterday, business men who refuse to enter trusts and combinations are entitled to relief when these trusts try to force them out of business.

ROCKLIN, Cal., May 25. -- This morning fire started in the kitchen of the Davis Hotel. The flames spread rapidly, destroying twenty-five buildings, including two-third of the business section of the town. The total loss is $75,000; insurance about one-third.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Although the trolley road which is being pushed to completion at Gettysburg has already caused great damage to the historic battlefield, steps are being taken by the War Department which may result in the partial preservation of the lines of battle, although the field can never again be restored to the condition, in which it was found by the trolley vandals.
Controller Frank Campbell announced last night that he is a candidate for renomination. He does not hesitate to say that he is proud of his record and that there is no opposition to him.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 25. -- The third meeting of the Connecticut Trapshooters' League was held at the grounds of the local club this afternoon and was well attended. The chief event of the day was the team race, in which the New-Haven and Bristol Clubs were tied for first place.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 25. -- Dispatches received, from several towns in Missouri and from one point in Kansas report the occurrence this afternoon of a severe storm of almost cyclonic proportions.

Though it is now much later in the Spring than it is usual for a musical season to continue in this city, there was no manifestation of an abatement or interest when Mendelssohn's "Elijah" was given at the Music Hall last night. The occasion was the second of the two concerts given for the purpose of enabling the music lovers of this city to renew their acquaintance with the famous dramatic soprano, Amelia Materna.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 25. -- George Martin and Angus Morrison, belonging to the Gloancestor fishing schooner Oliver Wendell Holmes, arrived at North Sydney yesterday and reported that on the 17th lust., while fishing off St. Paul's Island, in thick weather, they failed to find their buoy and lost their vessel, and after nine hours' experience on the dory made land near Niel's Harbor, Cape North.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The Nicaraguan Legation, through Minister Guzman, desires the formal statement to be made that all of the telegraphic information from Nicaragua which reaches the United States at present at subject to censorship.

Prospects of the best day's racing of the season brought, the largest crowd of the year except that of Brooklyn Handicap day to the Gravesend track yesterday. The racing was up to the highest standard, though not quite up to what the published list of entries had led people to expect. There were five scratches from the mile-and-a-sixteenth handicap, Leonawell, The Ironmaster, Melba, Sleipner, and Russell being kept in the stable during this race.

There was a subdued tremor of excitement in the neighborhood of the Hotel Savoy all the early part of the afternoon. The guests fluttered in and out, and nearly all received more visitors than they had received in a year.

HALIFAX, N.S., May 25. -- P.C. Pearaon of the West End Railway System is reported to be the head of n syndicate of Boston capitalists who have bought the blast furnaces and iron mines at Ferrona and the forge and steel works at New-Glasgow.
Many Democratic politicians of note from up the State were in the city yesterday, and much talk of the next campaign was heard in hotel corridors.

LONDON, May 25. -- The Prince of Wales's cutter Britannia defeated Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie to-day in the Royal Thames Club regatta. The Valkyrie carried away her topsail on the return course when a length behind the Britannia.

The big regatta of the Harlem Yacht Club will be sailed next Tuesday. This regatta is the most important event of the year with the Harlem yachtsmen, and Decoration Day is always a red-letter day with them. This year the fleet of yachts that will cross the line will be larger than ever.

Oppenheim Lentz, 45 years old, of 72 Elm Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital in an ambulance from Jefferson Market last evening. Surgeon C.F. Sanborn diagnosed the case as alcoholism and fractured ribs. The man had received his injuries by falling. He had wounds on the nose and over the left eye.

To the Editor or the New-York Times: A propos of your article this morning, as a "worried Staten Islander" I want to add my individual protest to those of other Staten Islanders against the ferry franchise being sold to any person or corporation with facilities for doing the business inferior to those of the company which now holds it.

Many of the parishioners of the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany in Second Avenue, are interested in a movement to secure the resstorationn of their former pastor, the Rev. Dr. Richard Lawler Burtsell.

Dr. J. Solis-Cohen of Philadelphia furnished a surprise to his fellow throat specialists at the annual meeting of the American Laryngological Association at the Academy of Medicine in this city last Tuesday, by exhibiting to them a man furnished by nature with, a speaking apparatus after his larynx had been entirely out out and his windpipe had grown together above the aperture in his throat through which he breathes.

The cadets of the Hamilton Institute, at 103 West Eighty-second Street, held their first annual reception drill at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon. The Principal, N. Archibald Shaw, Jr., was a proud man.

More trouble is in store for the Brooklyn Democratic ring contractors, and there is a probability that they will be compelled to drop one of the finest plums that grow on the tree of official patronage across the river.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 25. -- The Populists having made a complete failure in their attempt to establish the Industrial Legion have now organized a new society, which is to be known as the Workers' Union. It came into existence through the Alliance of Labette Township, Labette County. Like the Industrial Legion, the objects of this society are political, but unlike the Industrial Legion it is not a secret society.

The grain dealings were very light to-day. Wheat sold at 18@a 40 advance on firmer cables and reports of cold weather West. Corn advanced 12@ 1c. Exporters were quiet. In flour the business was small from shippers.

Mayor Gilroy does not believe in the schoolship St. Mary's as an educational institution. J. K. Hyatt recently made an inquiry of the Board of Education concerning payment made in behalf of a prospective pupil for the schoolship. Mr. Hyatt spent $30 for an outfit for the pupil, but owing to the deficiency in the appropriation for the schoolship, the pupil could not be accommodated.

The first steamship of a regular line to ply between New-York and South and East Africa will sail from the Empire Stores, Brooklyn, this morning. The vessel is the Worcester, of 2,908 tons, and she is loaded with a miscellaneous cargo of mining machinery, lumber, and different kinds of manufactured articles.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 25. -- The convention called to meet in Lincoln, Neb., in June, under the auspices of the Populists of Nebraska, has the hearty approval of the Populists of Kansas. The object in view is to build a railroad from Bismarck, N.D., to Galveston, Texas, or some other port on the Gulf of Mexico.

The suppression of the rebellion in Cuba a few weeks ago has not in the least discouraged the leaders of the Cuban revolutionary party in the United States. While they were willing to help in the movement when it started by Bending money to the revolutionists, they disclaim all responsibility for that movement, which they condemn as having been premature.

It was about 3 o'clock when the Ciroulo Colon-Cervantes, and representatives of the Spanish colony to the number of 300, assembled at Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street to march to the Hotel Savoy and serenade the Infanta. The Saragossa Band headed the procession and nearly all the participants in the parade carried torchlights.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 25. -- It may be "Mayor" Stein in Brooklyn, but in Baltimore, where almost every man has a title, he is a very plain "Mister." And it was all because of Pitcher McNabb and eight fielders that Stein's colors were dragged in the dust for the first time this season. Twelve base hits, including a three-bagger and three doubles, won the game for the Orioles.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- In order that there may be uniformity of action among Collectors of Customs and a thorough understanding on their part of the Secretary's construction of existing laws on the Chinese question, Secretary Carlisle has written a letter of instruction on the subject.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- The first shot in the Sunday opening fight has been fired. United States District Attorney Milchrist. following a conference with Attorney General Olney in Washington, has sent a lengthy telegram of instructions to Assistant District Attorney Hand in Chicago.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25. -- Judge Walter Olds of Columbia City, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Indiana, to-day announced the determination to tender his resignation to Gov. Matthews June 1. He is to move to Chicago to form a law partnership with ex-Secretary of State Charles F. Griffin.

The agitation over the opening of the World's Fair on Sunday, which has led to a threat of the withdrawal of the Methdist exhibit and protests from other religious quarters, has excited expressions of fear that this country is in danger of falling into the loose observance of Sunday that prevails in Europe. A reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES asked the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur of Calvary Baptist Church yesterday if that was his view.
The handicaps for the Milburn road race which will take place on Tuesday have been allotted.

J. Taylor Ellyson, Mayor of Richmond and President of the Jefferson Davis Monument Association, was in this city yesterday in consultation, with Mrs. Jefferson Davis as to the details of the programme to be observed in removing the remains of Jefferson Davis from New-Orleans to Richmond.

"We have had no request to give an exhibition of the skill of the Fire Department in the presence of the Infanta Eulalio,"said Chief Hugh Bouner yesterday, "and have made no preparations for such an exhibition."

GREENPORT, L.I., May 26 -- A straight line drawn across the bay from Greenport to Sag Harbor would pass directly through the centre of Shelter Island, which rises from the beautiful bay, an emerald gem surrounded by turquois. Nature has outdone herself in bestowing charms on this region, and that its beauties are known and loved by New-York and Brooklyn people is little wonder.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Protests against John Boyd Thaoher's patented system of judging exhibits continue to pour over his head into the Director General's mail box. The American exhibitors in the Manufacturers' Building have added their influence to the protest of the foreign Commissioners as a preliminary step, it is said, to withdrawing their displays from the contest for awards.

Mr. JOHN BOYD THACHER, the Chairman of the Committee on Awards at Chicago, has lately expressed the utmost confidence in the fairness and acceptability of the system of awards devised by the committee of which he is the Chairman. He calls it a "development" of the system adopted at the Philadelphia exhibition.

A series of accidents which occurred at the Brooklyn Jookey Club track yesterday marred very seriously what would nave otherwise been a pleasant day's sport. First of the lot was the leaving of Reckon at The post when the horses were started for the fifth race, a mistake which cost the public many thousands of dollars, and which probably lost to the Messrs.

The visit of Gov. Flower to Brooklyn yesterday possessed more interest for politicians than the semi-religions occasion which called him there. When the day was over it was considered by both the Governor and the Brooklyn politicians that a formal burial of the hatchet had taken place and that ill feeling toward the Governor on account, of his veto of the Columbian bills was a thing of the past.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 26 -- Alice Stone, a young girl who came here a year ago to study in the Waltham Training School for Nurses, has given up her studies to assume the position of adopted daughter of Mrs. Jane Thompson, who is reported to be a very wealthy and eccentric widow of New-York City.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., May 26 -- As a Summer Eden Cola Spring Harbor is very much in evidence. There are boats of New-Yorkers who regard with pitying wonder the pilgrim who finds lire enjoyable at any resort other than Cold Spring Harbor, and with the advent of the warm term betake themselves and their families to this their pet paradise, thanking their stars that they are alive and at Cold Spring Harbor.

Judge Lacombe or the United States Circuit Court, at the request of Maxwell Evarts, associate counsel with Joseph H. Choate in the Chinese cases, made a written decision yesterday of his order in the proceedings affecting the arrest of Ny Look, who was arraigned under the Geary act on Wednesday.

Isaac Buchen, seventeen years old, who came to this country from Galicia, Austria, aboard the steamer Danis on May 12, must go back to Europe. He was detained at Ellis Island because he was suffering from a loathsome and contagions scalp disease known as favus.

The pleasing game of battledore and shuttlecock between the Rapid-Transit Commissioners and the Manhattan Railway Company was resumed yesterday, when George J. Gould withdrew all propositions for elevated-railroad extensions and Mr. Starin returned the play with resolutions for new elevated lines.
Few new gowns were made for the ball. Ladles of fashion did not feel that, at this late day in the season, the occasion called for a brandnew dress.
BRENTWOOD, L.I., May 26 -- Long Island has its own Lakewood, with all the charms and advantages of that popular Jersey Mecoa, coupled with a number of its own, in Brentwood.

A momentary view of the carriage which bore the Infanta to the ball, as it rolled down Madison Avenue, and a long-distance glimpse of the glitter or the electric lights over the Twenty-sixth Street entrance to the Garden, was all that the more than 1,000 people who were near at hand saw of the festivities of last night.

The Rev. Dr. James W. Putnam, who resigned the office of associate pastor of the Baptist Tabernacie, gave out last evening a statement assuming the authorship and responsibility of the charges against the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter, pastor of the church. Dr. Putnam said that the Church Committee on Investigation of Charges would meet on Wednesday, but he could not tell where.

Gold shippers withdrew $2,550,000 in coin from the Sub-Treusury yesterday. Most of it will be sent out to-day. Lazard Freres took $2,000,000, Arbuckle Brothers, coffee dealers, $500,000, and the rest was for Canadian account. In payment for the gold $590,000 was turned in in Treasury notes. The balance was in greenbacks.

Early yesterday morning the ill-starred love affair of German couple in Brooklyn was brought to a tragic close. The lover Killed himself on the steps of his sweetheart's home, having despaired, of ever persuading her to disregard her father's wish that she should not marry him.

Gov. TILLMAN of South Carolina has been busy for some time past preparing for the liquor business upon which his State is to enter on the 1st of July. He was aronnd buying liquor a while ago, laying in stock for the "dispensaries," as the State grogshops are to be called, and boasting that he proposed to have good liquor and no common barroom stuff.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The Irish village was dedicated to-day. The benedictions of Archbishop Feehan of Chicago and Cardinal Logue of Armagh. Primate of Ireland, were read by the Rev. Father Muldoon. There was afterward a banquet in Donegal Castle, which stands in the centre of the village.
Senator George Z. Erwin, the Adonis of the State Legislature, from St. Lawrence County, is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- A formidable array of counsel, together with a largo number of persons interested in the Whisky Trust, was present in Chancellor Tuley's court this morning in anticipation of the opening of legal proceedings brought by the Attorney General, in the name of the people of Illinois, to compel the company to show by what warrant it assumes the powers and privileges which it exercises.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 26 -- Miss Winnie Davia and Mayor J. Taylor Ellison of Richmond will arrive in the morning, and in the afternoon the body of Jefferson Davis will be removed to the Memorial Hall and remain in state until the next evening. The veteran camps will furnish a guard of honor, which will keep constant vigil beside the bier.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., May 26 -- There may be more lovely retreats for Summer fugitives from the cities than Amityville, but they have not been discovered yet. If there ever was a native, or a visitor, who wasn't willing and anxious to sine its praises he is dead, for if one ask anybody about Amityville in Summer to-day he will be promptly informed that it is one of the most delightful places imaginable.
Ex-Secretary Foster's failure was by no means a surprise to those in Wall Street who had kept posted about his finances. His troubles are not likely to have any particular effect in New-York.

There were only forty-two boxes in Madison Square Garden, and great was the disappointment to Hundreds of persons who bad to be content as simple subscribers. The first chance was given to the patronesses, and as there were twice as many patronesses as boxes there was some clashing even there.

The Infanta spent yesterday morning in her apartments. Breakfast was served about 11:30. Afterward the Prince took a walk down the avenue alone. No one seemed to recognize him. He wore an ordinary business suit, with a straw hat with a wide brim.
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., May 26 -- The city man casting about for a place to spend the Summer who decides finally upon Far Rockaway will find his lines cast in pleasant places.
Commodore B. Frank Sutton of the Brooklyn Yacht Club has issued the following orders to the Fleet Captains for the Decoration Day ceremonies:

Tammany's tiger in his best coat went up to the Press Club Fair at the Grand Central Palace last night, and he and his family and friends crowded the building as it never has been crowded since it wus built.

A.J. Cassatt and President William Bliss of the Boston and Albany Railroad sat as arbistrators in the office of the Trunk Line Association yesterday and listened to statements relative to the extra fare to be charged by the New-York Central on its "exposition flior" -- the twenty-hour train to Chicago, which starts from here on its first trip to-morrow at 3 o'clock P.M.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., May 26 -- The beautiful villages clustering about old Southampton, including Quogue, Good Ground, the rest of the Hamptons, and the incomparable ShinnecocK Hillls combine to make as close an approach to Eden as can be found in a long journey. Exclusive -- in the best sense of the word -- society is here represented during the Summer by its choicest spirits.

Several private sales of real estate were reported yesterday which are or interest. Mr. George R. Read has sold for Henry W. Banks, to John Jacob Astor, the Banks Building on Pine, Depeystar, and Front Sts, on private terms. The dimensions of the plot on which, the building stands are 57 feet on Front St, east side. 89.8 1 2 on Pine St. 81.5 on Depeystor St. and 55 in the rear.
LONDON, May 27 -- The Daily Telegraph Says editorially this morning:

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The news of the failure in business of ex-Secretary Foster evoked many expressions of regret and surprise in Washington. The expressions of regret were brought out because of the fact that Mr. Foster, as a personality, was cheerful and companionable, and he had many friends.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 26 -- "Antigone," given by the Vassar students the evening, was a complete success. The Poughkeepsie Opera House was crowded, notwithstanding the storm. The audience was constantly surprised at the perfection of the acting and of the entire management of the presentation.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 26 -- There is danger of a meeting between two members of the House of Representatives as a result of the most exciting scene in the history of the body. The House bad under consideration what is known as the anti-strike law, the object of which is to prevent the unlawful practice of interfering with traffic and transportation.

The Ardsley Land and Improvement Company was yesterday placed in the bands of a receiver on the petition of Herbert L. Bridgman, a stockholder. For some time the company has been booming a plot of land in Westchester County, and among those figuring in its prospectus were dozens of men who are well known in the business world.

Chairman H.D. Howells of the Regatta Committee of the Atlantic Yacht Club has issued a circular containing details of the arrangements for the twenty-eighth annual regatta of the club, to be sailed Tuesday, June 13. Yachts enrolled, in the following clubs are invited to compete with the Atlantic Club yachts: New-York, American, Corinthian, Seawanhaka Corinthian, Larchmont, New-Rochelle, Marine and Field Club, Philadelphia, Corinthian of Philadelphia, Eastern, Riverside, Cedar Point, New-Haven, the Pequot Association, and New-Bedford.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The world's Fair will be open next Sunday. As least that is what Commissioner Hundley of the Judiciary Committee of the National Commission said to-day, and as he is one of the three members of the commission who valiantly opposed Sunday opening, his admission has doable force.

Never before had such decorations adorned the interior of the great Garden. In the hallways, stairways, on every wall and ceiling, and in every nook and corner there was a profusion of color; and yet there was no impresion that the decorations were overdone.

The Coaching Club will hold its annual Spring meet at 11:30 A.M. to-day. The coaches will line up on the short road leading past the Mall in Central Park. From there, starting as nearly as possible at that hour, eight turnouts, led by Col. William Jay, President, will parade north on the East Drive, pass McGown's Pass Tavern, around into the West Drive and from there circling the Park.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Secretary Lamont has decided against a Brooklyn bidder and awarded a three-and-a-half-million-dollar contract to the American Dredging Company of Philadelphia. In January bids were opened by the Engineer officer at Philadelphia for the removal of two Islands in the Philadelphia Harbor which are obstructions to navigation.
FOSTORIA, Ohio, May 26 -- The following statement was given to the public to-day by the ex-Secretary:

Louis Hohweisner, a handsome young German, was arraigned in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, upon a charge of arson preferred by his wife. Addle Hohweisner is the complainant's name. She is a sickly woman of twenty-six, and is living apart from her husband in consequence, she says, of his cruelty.

The body of little Katie McGlynn, who was run over and killed in the Boulevard, near Sixty-seventh Street, by Edward Kleinschmidt on his safety bicycle, will not be burled in Potter's Field. The sympathies of charitable citizens were aroused by the story of her death, and contributions to enable her poor parents to give her decent burial resulted.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 26 -- The Summer campaign will open in a burst or gayety tomorrow, the data of the opening regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. This event will bring all the Summer residents to the place, and a large percentage of them will remain for the season.

The Executive Committee or the Intercollegiate Athletic Association had a hard time at a meeting held in the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. They had to wrestle with a big batch of protests that had been filed by different colleges against athletes of other colleges competing in to-day's games. The members of the committee were P.H. Davis. Princeton, who presided; L.Thompson, Harvard; P.C. Pentz.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- The south half of the East and West Galleries of the Manufactures Building contains one of the most interesting exhibits of the World's Fair. Not one person out or fifty visits it, though it is now complete. This is because there is so much to see downstairs in the Manufactures Building that the majority of people do not get time to mount the flight of stairs leading to the gallery.

BABYLON, L.I., May 26 -- Babylon is shaking off its Winter's lethargy. It appreciates that within a few weeks its superb drives will be gay with equipages, from the cumbrous and dignified tally-no to the saucy village cart; that its friends will come in skirmish line and then in battalions before the fragance of the flowers of May has left the air, and that much must be done to adequately welcome the coming guest.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 26 -- The failure of ex-Secretary Foster was the one topic of conversation in business circles here today. Every one expressed sincere regret at the misfortune, and the people of Fostoria are especially sympathized with.

The original idea of separating the dining table or the Infanta from the remainder was abandoned and the Princess and the guests of honor simply supped at a table on a platform along the Twenty-sixth Street side of the banquet hall.

FOSTORIA, Ohio, May 26 -- The announcement this morning of the assignment of Charles Foster, Secretary of the Treasury under the Harrison Administration, was a Startling one for the people of Northwestern Ohio.

TRENTON, N.J., May 26 -- The State Board of Assessors has completed the table of the earnings and expenditures of the street railways in New-Jersey. These returns are made to the State board under an act of the Legislature, and they are not published until a resolution of the board authorizes it to be done, so that no advance information can be obtained for stock-speculating purposes.

Even with the addition of "King" Kelly the New-Yorks failed to win yesterday in their contest with the Philadelphias on the Polo Grounds. Poor pitching lost the contest. King started in with plenty of speed, but the Quakers hit the ball in all directions, and after the third inning, with the score 6 to 4 in favor of the visitors. Young Donohue was put in the box.

The second day of the conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church of the New-York District, which is in session in Betnel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Sullivan Street, was began promptly at 9 A.M. yesterday by the singing of the hymn "Oh for a Thousand Tongues."
LONDON, May 26 -- The Stock Exchange was inactive to-day and some of yesterday's advance was lost.

The thirty-fourth annual commencement of the Schools of Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art was celebrated in the large hall of the institute last night. The hall was crowded with friends and relatives of members of the graduating class. The platform was occupied by the class, twenty-two young men, their tutors, and the Trustees of the institute.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Miss Blanche W. Culbertson, heiress to $500,000, and accepted among her friends as the intended wife or a Captain in the British Army, left her home at 594 Division Street at midnight Wednesday in company with another lover, leaving behind her the mother of the British officer, who had come to this city to be present at the marriage of her son to the American heiress.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Soldiers of the United States Army will be armed, within a few months, with magazine rifles of the Krag-Jorgensen type. This decision was reached this afternoon by the Board of Ordnance and Fortification, in session at the Government Building in Jackson Park.

The first meeting of the Manhattan Tennis Association takes place this afternoon on the Lenox Club grounds. Instead of the customary way of giving the weaker players half-fifteen, fifteen, half-thirty, , and putting the cracks on scratch, all the entries will be divided into classes. The events will be men's singles, women's singles, women's doubles, men's doubles, and mixed doubles, of which, the men's doubles only will be played this afternoon.

Before Judge Martine, in the Court of General Sessions, the cross-examination of Dr. Joseph A. Saunders was continued yesterday in the case of Dr. Sara B. Chase, charged with causing the death of Margaret Manzoni by a criminal operation.

Eugene O'Connor, head of the auction house of George A. Leavitt Co., Broadway and Eleventh Street, was lodged in Ludlow Street Jail yesterday in default of $20,000 bail. He was arrested by a Deputy Sheriff on an order issued by Judge Andrews of the Supreme Court in a suit for about $65,000 brought by Harry Phillips, his partner.

With the thoughtful courtesy that marks our American people, Princess EULALIE is to be or already has been invited to witness a game of baseball at the Polo Grounds, so that she can compare it with the Spanish national pastime. Her Royal Highness may never have heard of King KEL or other monarchs of the diamond, yet she might detect a certain analogy between bull baiting and worrying the umpire.
Silver bullion, certificates were quoted at 32 1 2 @83 1 2.

The Iron Age publishes elaborate tables which, show the cost of producing pig iron at the works of the Thomas Iron Company in each year since 1855. We select the following figures as indicating some important changes which have taken place in the last twenty years:

PARIS, May 26 -- In his argument before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration to-day, Sir Charles Russell disputed the American contention that the Newfoundland fishery right, claimed under the treaty of 1783, sanctioned American claims to the exclusive right of seal catching in Bering Sea.

This afternoon on Manhattan Field, One Hundred md Fitty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue, the annual Intercollegiate athletic games for the Mott Haven Championship Cup will be held. From the present outlook the competition will be closer than ever before. Harvard looks like a winner, but Yale and Princeton may make it very lively for the Cambridge youths.

There seems to be no prospect of union between the factions of Irish Homo Rulers in New-York. The trouble, which was once confined to private expressions of opinion and comparatively mildly-uttered public statements, is now being conducted in a Hold where bitter invective, charges, and counter-charges are the main features.

If it were not for a Sheriff's seizure, xavier Gastinger would now be the proudest instead of the moat miserable man on Long Island, for an exhibit of his own, in which he feels he has put the best that is in him, would be on the war to the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- There is an unusual case before the War Department, upon which those two legal experts of the Government, the Attorney General and the Second Controller, differ in opinion. Some weeks ago President Cleveland nominated Lieut. Wrights P. Edgerton of the Second Artillery to the commission of Associate Instructor of Mathematics at the Military Academy at West Point, where Lieut. Edgerton has been on duty.

The members of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Club met in their handsome clubhouse, 435 Fifth Avenue, last night, to celebrate the eighth anniversary of the founding of this most successful college club. The rooms were crowded from 9 o'clock until the sun began to gild Fifth Avenue and remind the "Dekes" that all things must have an end.

KNOXVILLE, Tonn., May 26 -- The great tournament of the Knoxville Gun Club, which opened on Tuesday morning, was shot to a finish last night. The shoot was the biggest of Its kind held here since the Spring of 1891 and was perfectly managed. Over 30,000 blue targets wore thrown. The club gave $1,000 in added moneys for the various events and also gave $200 for averages.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The Belmont Park trotting meeting came to an end to-day with excellent apart in spite of unfavorable weather. Aline trotted the fastest mile of the year in the 2:15 class race. With fewer closing breaks she would nave won. bat Sadie M. out-acted the faster mare, and after live exciting heats, the last of which, was landed by less than a neck, the race belonged to the daughter of Prince Orloff.

William A. Carsey's face did not look handsome when he addressed the Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon, as Chairman of the so-called Citizens' Industrial Alliance, in behalf of elevated railroad improvements. One of his cheeks was puffed out far beyond the natural size. From just below the eye to the jaw was a chain of crimson marks.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, May 26 -- P.M. To-day's speculation was somewhat less active than that of yesterday, and prices were irregular. The general news was more or less depressing. It included another suspension in Melbourne, Australia, the closing of a small hank in Michigan, the assignment of the Minnesota Blast Furnace Company of Duluth.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The system of arranging lighthouse lights inventea by Capt. F.A. Mahan, which was tested recently off the NewHaven Harbor by the Board of Lighthouse Engineers, is destined to revolutionize the method. It has long been recognized that the present system has its disadvantages or its dangers in the uncertainty of the lights.

The Columbia College boys tried last night the rather perilous venture of presenting "Ivanhoe," their amusing burlesque, at the Academy of Music. In so immense a theatre the element of personality, upon which such performances must in great measure depend for success, suffered somewhat, and the auditors, too, while there were enough, of them to have crowded an ordinary house, could not help leaving a good many of the Academy's innumerable seats unoccupied.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Presbyterian General Assembly to-day decided to entertain the appeal in the Briggs case. The vote was 409 in favor, Prof. Briggs's supporters numbering only 144.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., May 26 -- Sea Cliff has sprung into being as a Summer resort with the vigor of a youns giant. Endowed by nature with charming features, they have been enhanced and given prominence by tea ingenious hand of man. Planted upon the pretty wooded bluffs of Hempstead Harbor, its scenery is a marvel to the visitor.

Arnaldo Menvielle was found dead in bed early yesterday morning in his room at 153 West Fourteenth Street, a private boarding house, kept by Dr. G.W. Elliots. The windows and doors were abut and the gas burner was turned full on.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 -- The Missouri and Mississippi Valleys were visited last night by a terrific thunderstorm. It extended as far west as Kansas City and as far north as Iowa. The averago rainfall reported by the Weather Bureau at 1 P.M. was 1.04 inch, and this evening the rain is still falling in torrents.
A jury in a lunacy proceeding before Judge McAdam, of the Superior Court, yesterday discharged Michael Pettit, a carman, despite the vigorous protest of the court.

The sixty-fourth anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union was celebrated yesterday by a parade of 60,000 children. In anticipation of the event, the City Hall, the County Court House, and all the other public buildings were gayly decorated with flags and bunting, and countless bright streamers floated from the houses along the lines of march.

No person of good taste can view without distrust the revival of the so-called Alpine hat. Last Fall a feeble attempt was made to bring this article of wearing apparel, which is properly described by the hatters as "natty headgear," into use, but it was confined to persons who habitually own more than one hat, and know, moreover, how to use a hat.
Mayor Gilroy is in full sympathy with the effort now making to stop the reckless riding of bicycles. He said yesterday afternoon:

Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn elevated eight young men to the priesthood of the Roman Catholic Church yesterday. The ceremony was performed in St. James's Pro-Cathedral on Jay Street, in the presence of a large number of clergymen and many friends of the candidates.
"Jane Annie; or the Good-Conduct Prize," is a comic opera in two acts, written by J.M. Barrie and Conan Doyle, the music composed by Ernest Ford. The libretto seems to puzzle London.

BOSTON, May 27. -- Arbitrage trading in Burlington, Sugar, and General Electric was fairly active to-day. The last named declined 5 points. Bell Telephone declined to 189, Boston and Albany to 211 3/4, Old Colony to 188, Fort Wayne Electric to 9 1/2, Tamarack Mining to 142, and Quincy Mining to 115. The local market was very dull.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Secretary Herbert today took a step that marks a radical change in the policy of the Navy Department in the matter or the construction of small cruisers. After mature consideration and full discussion with the Board of Bureau Chiefs he has directed that two of the three 1,200-ton gunboats authorized by Congress be constructed of the composite type.

NEW-HAVEN, May 27 -- The alarm in the editorial rooms of Connecticut Republican newspapers lest their party fail to do something at this legislative session toward satisfying the popular demand for constitutional revision grows. It is recognized that the Republican Party in Connecticut made the mistake of its life four years ago, when its legislative majority contemptuously rejected a constitutional amendment proposing plurality elections.

The bank statement for yesterday showed an increase in the reserve held of $526,100 and in the surplus reserve of $1,017,750. Legal tenders have increased $1,102,100 and specie has fallen off $574,000. Loans are $1,059,700 less and net deposits $1,958,000 less. The banks have continued the conservative policy of the last few weeks.

The Earl and Countess or Craven returned yesterday to New-York from their tridal journey, reaching Mr. Bradley-Martin's home about 6 o'clock. Both bride and bridegroom were in excellent health and spirits, notwithstanding the fact that they had spent a day or two in Boston and had attended a theatrical performance at the Tremont Theatre on Friday evening.

Chief Engineer Anonico G. Menocal of the Nicaragua Canal arrived in this city from London yesterday on the American Line steamship Paris. Immediately upon his arrival he telegraphed Secretary of the Navy Herbert at Washington that he would be at the Navy Department, ready for duty, as soon as he could reach Washington.

The management of Eldorado announces another grand sacred concert for this afternoon. The entertainment will be continuous from 3 until 11 P.M. At night the grounds will be beautifully illuminated by the aid of countless electric devices.

The associated canoe clubs of the passaic River began their annual meet yesterday on Dundee Lake, near Paterson. N.J. Canoes from more than fifty clubs are expected to be on band by Tuesday, on which day the races will be held. The programme for that day is as follows: Junior paddling. Junior sailing, tandem paddling, senior sailing, senior paddling, sailing upsets, paddling, (any canoe.) open canoea, single blades, paddling club fours, sailing and paddling.

Society yesterday -- that part that went coaching to Tuxedo, and that part that remained at home -- was busy discussing the ball of the night before. Society was a little tardy in coming to the front, but it went, was presented, danced and supped, and went away delighted.

The Kings County Commissioners of Charities and Correction have again gone through the formalities of an investigation of the Fiatbush Insane Asylum, and the public -- a portion of it at least -- is being led to believe that there has been a thorough inquiry on foot to learn the real circumstances of the death of old Mrs. Adair, for the purpose of placing the responsibility therefor where it belongs.
For the benefit of Summer cottagers, suburban residents, and city renovators a compilation of some suggestions on floor staining and painting from the Queen is timely and may be of value.

The present is in a marked degree an age of specialties. From the legal and medical professions the notion of concentrating one's energies upon some particular pursuit, knowing pretty much all there is to know about a single subject, while knowing also something of almost everything else, has spread to all other avocations.
BOSTON, May 27 -- To-night the one-hundred and thirteenth performance of "Shore Acres" was given at the Boston Museam, and the regular season at that house closed.

BOSTON, May 27. -- Daniel F. McCarthy and John II. Lynch, residents of Marlborough. Mass., had a stroke of luck while shooting on the shore on Great Bay, Portsmouth. N.H., yesterday afternoon. McCarthy. with gun cocked, looking for game, saw a huge eagle soaring with a maitese cat in its talons. The animal was struggling desperately to escape.

HAVASTA, May 27 -- Four days of continuous rain all over the Island of Cuba has dispelled the drought and given fresh courage to the planter and farmer, and great activity in planting and seeding prevails throughout the country. In the low rich lands of Guinea the rains have been excessive, and will cause the loss of a large part or the potato crop by rot.

The handsome clubhouse of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club wan formally opened for the season yesterday. Promptly at 1 o'clock Mrs. A.P. Montant, the wife of the fleet Captain, gave the signal and the club pennant was hoisted on the staff. As the signal was fired the oncida, with Commodore Robert Center and Vice Commodore E.C. Benedict on board, steamed into the harbor.

The Infanta did not go to West Point yesterday, as had been planned. Gen. Horace Porter called early and told her that the probabilities were that it would rain, and he thought the trip would better be postponed. To this the Infanta agreed rather gladly. She was very tired.

Central Office Detectives Mulry and Mulvey made an important capture Friday afternoon of two notorious criminals who for the past six months have been adding to records which have been for many years of an exceedingly dark shade.
Ten big transatlantic liners sailed yesterday, all carrying full passenger lists.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- "Phil" King, Princeton's Captain, lifted the ball over the fence in the tenth inning of the University of PennsylvaniaPrinceton game here to-day, and won the most closely-contested and exciting college game ever played in Philadelphia. All the scoring was done in the first three innings, after that the score remaining 4 to 4 until the tenth.

Those who took the trouble yesterday to figure out what the champion Paris and her rival, the Campania, had done on their trips that have Just ended, found that while both vessels had made a very creditable showing, neither had broken any record. An examination of their logs, however, will not have a tendency to diminish the interest felt by the nautical world in the performances of these two vessels.

WILLIAM'S BRIDGE, May 27 -- Patrick Cash, Chief of Police of William's Bridge, shot and killed James T. Cleary last night. The act was a cold-blooded murder. The officer was not engaged in making an arrest, he was not defending himself against assault, he was not under great provocation. He deliberately drew his revolver from his hip pocket and killed a man who had worsted him somewhat in a quarrel of words.

The Peekskill Electric Surface Railway Company will soon begin work on the construction of its road. During the past week, at a meeting of the Directors, hold in this city, the various bids for the work were opened. There were a half dozen or more, and all were found to be excessively high, and so declared to be by the company's consulting engineer, C.H. Ledlie of St. Louis.

FOSTORIA, Ohio, May 27 -- J.B. Gormley, assignee of ex-Secretary Foster, said to-day that further investigation showed affairs to be in even worse shape than had been at first thought, and that the liabilities would reach $800,000 and possibly $1,000,000, with assets of a much less amount.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Probably the most important pension decision ever sent from the office of the Secretary of the interior to the Commissioner of Pensions was filed to-day.

The centennial of the New-York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends of this city, of the southern and eastern parts of this State, and of adjacent counties in New-Jersey will be observed this week in the meeting houses on Rutherfurd Place.

The Riverside Yacht Club house will soon be one of the handsomest on the Sound. Through the liberality of Commodore Tyson the club has been enabled to make many improvements. The clubhouse has been moved further back, from the water, some additions have been made to the building, which has been redecorated, and the harbor in front of the house has been dredged, making a croud safe anchorage for the yachts.
When Harriet Martineau came to this country thirty years ago she found seven occupations open to women. To-day she would find 400.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- With the five principal New-York stock theatres closed and the leading traveling companies scattered over the land, the activity of the Chicago theatres at the beginning of the Summer season bears a marked contrast to the Eastern cities with which it mar claim comparison. Next week promises to bring forth more interesting things in the circle of the down-town playhouses than any preceding week of the World's Fair season.

The list of French books about Joan of Arc which Lord Ronald Grower has appended to his sympathetic history of her life and work is surprisingly brief, although it may be exhaustive. There are only 140 numbers and only four great names -- Voltaire, Henri Martin, Michelet, and Lamartine.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The expected bill for an injunction to prevent the Sunday opening of the World's Fair was filed to-day on behalf of the National Government, by United States District Attorney Milchrist, in the Federal Circuit Court. The District Attorney does not ask for a temporary injunction, and consequently the case will not be argued until next week.
Politicians were vastly interested yesterday in the following editorial article, which appeared in the Daily America, a paper in which Richard Croker is more or less interested:

Just as the crowd in Broadway was at its biggest, after the matinees, yesterday, there was a little excitement near Thirtyfourth Street that ended in William R. Hennig of 153 West Thirty-sixth Street being taken to the New-York Hospital to have a wound on the back of his head made by a paving stone patched up, and C.C. Anderson of Philadelphia lodging over night in the Nineteenth Precinct Police Station.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 -- Two Republicans were summarily ejected from the House of Delegates last night by Democrats who wanted control of that body. The two members unseated are W. C. Kelly and W.C. Marten, who were returned as elected to the House by handsome majorities. The Democrats, who got seats without ceremony, are John Ball and James Eagan, of the Twenty-sixth and Seventeenth Wards, respectively.

PARIS, May 10 -- The "Reine Juana "of M. Alexandra Parodi is a conscientious work, if not a brilliant one. It shows study, effort, and an ardent love for sublime heroism. The language is eloquent and communicative. If the drama is obscure, it is the subject and not its translation.

A hearing in the case of John Fitzhum, the Buffalo Murderer, who is in Auburn Prison under death sentence for the killing of John Roehrl, Jr., a young man of twenty, by stabbing him in a drunken row at 832, Sycamore Street, Buffalo, on April 7, 1892, was held yesterday morning by Gov. Flower in one of the parlors of the Windsor Hotel.

RONDOUT, N.Y., May 27 -- If the story told by Capt. Isaac Hotaling of the freight propeller Robert Rogers, now in this port from Sing Sing, be true, such a schooner as the Emma was at Sing Sing and discharged a cargo or cordwood there.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- The fourth week closed tonight in a blaze of electric glory and colored lights, human song and instrumental music. A great multitude of people came to see and hear. On no previous night have so many gathered within the gates. Sixty thousand is probably a low estimate of the number who dropped their tickets in the boxes at the turnstiles.
Great preparations have been made at the Madison Square Garden Amphitheatre for the production of a comprehensive programme of minstrelsy, vaudeville, opera, and ballet on Monday evening.

KINGSTON, N.Y., May 27 -- The warm weather of the last week has caused a great increase in travel up the Ulster and Delaware Railroad. Most of the early Summer travelers have gone to Hunter, Tannersville, Pine Hill, Margaretville, and Stamford. In these places nearly all the hotels and boarding houses are open for guests.
LENOX, Mass., May 27 -- Richard Watson Gilder of the Century Magazine has been in Lenox this week. He is making a driving tour of Berkshire County.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 27 -- A suit which promises to attract national interest was made public in this city to-day. An action is to be brought against the Russian Government by Congressman R.E. Deforest and Attorney J.B. Klein as counsel for Herman Kempiniskie, a Russian who has acquired citizenship in this country and who asks damages for the impairment of his eyesight, sustained in Russian prisons.

The Street has had three topics of interest the past week -- the Richmond Terminal plan, the performances in Distillers, and the break in General Electric. As a whole the market has been dull. The prospect is that it will continue so. Stagnation invariably follows sooner or later after a panic, usually accompanied by a sagging of prices and accumulation of money.
PITTSBURG, May 27 -- The brewery employes of Pittsburg and Allegheny went on a strike this morning because the Brewers' Association would not accede to the terms of their new scale.

William J. Gokey, the junior member of the firm of William Gokey Son, proprietors of the sectional dry docks at the Erie Basin, Brooklyn, was yesterday a very sick man. He has been growing steadily worse since last Sunday night, and Drs. John Harrigan and John Byrne, who are attending him, said yesterday that he had but one chance in ten of recovery.

Ten thousand or more people who were at the Gravesend race track yesterday afternoon left there fully impressed with the belief that they had Been the best two-year-old of the year at last, and that all doubts on that score were fully settled. The race that caused the forming of this opinion was that for the Great American Stakes, in which all but Halton of the tip-toppers of the year met.
Among the passengers on the steamship City of Rome, which sailed for Europe yesterday, were nine sturdy fire laddies from Kansas City, Mo.

LONDON, May 27. -- The disposition to-day on the Stock Exchange was to do as little business as possible, in view of the settlement beginning Monday. Rates are expected to be stiff, but it is thought there will be plenty of money for all purposes.

TRENTON, May 27 -- The Lawrenceville School, one of the oldest and best-known preparatory institutions in the country, begins to-morrow the decennial commemoration of the John C. Green foundation of the school. A number of prominent men will participate.

Few New-Yorkers who were shown over the big flagship Blake during her stay in this port by the swell little midshipmen of that vessel are aware that the embryo Admirals who so politely guided them about are subjected to an application of the birch rod whenever their Captain deems it necessary.

Copyrighted, 1893, by the New-York Times. LONDON, May 27 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent] -- From what source it came it is impossible to make sure, but there is an anecdote about Queen Victoria going the rounds of the political dinner tables in the West End which seems to belong to the history of current events.

-- A recent trial was made off Portsmouth, England, aboard the British gunboat Seagull, of a new device for preventing leakage in boiler tubes. Ferruling has enabled the engines of war ships to develop their maximum power, but the ferrules require renewing, and they have the further disadvantage of rendering the process of sweeping tubes a matter of difficulty.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 27 -- The shook to the financial world two weeks ago by the collapse or the Northwestern Guaranty Loan Company of Minneapolis was not much greater than the surprise occasioned to-night by the announcement that the company would in a short time resume business, paying dollar for dollar of its indebtedness.

It lay on the hall hat rack when Miss Johnson came in. She picked it up, read the name, replaced it, and went up stairs. Mrs. Millan glanced over it when she passed. Miss Taylor stuck it in a corner of the mirror. Mr. Jenkins grabbed it, read the name, and hastily replaced it, wrong side out.

A remarkably pretty game was played yesterday between the New-York and Philadelphia Clubs Both fielded finely and ran the bases with rare Judgment. but the New-Yorks won because of their superior batting.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., May 27 -- Peekskill is involved in litigation caused by a suit brought by T.M. Stewart, who is the owner of and resides in Boscobel, the former Summerplace of Henry Ward Beecher, the Kittridge, Beach, and other estates.

Yale has reason to feel proud of her athletes. They showed a clean pair of heels to all other competitors in the annual intercollegiate field games yesterday afternoon and are the undisputed champions for the coining year.

The residents of the Five Points assembled in Paradise Park yesterday afternoon. The Moderation Society had announced, by means of a brown-paper placard tacked on the railing of the music stand in the centre of the park, that flowers would be distributed at 3:30 o'clock.

A reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES called last evening at the home of John Mc-Glynn, the father of the little girl who was run over and killed on the Boulevard last Monday by Edward Kleinschmidt, who was riding a safety bicycle, and delivered to him a contribution of $5 which had been received by THE NEW-YORK TIMES to assist the parents in giving their daughter a decent burial.

It was easy to see, when we sat down to dinner last night, that Mrs. John was in a most comfortable frame of mind. The very way in which she opened her napkin betokened peace and serenity, and I was quite prepared for the expression of calm complacency in her eyes when, having finished her Little Necks, she leaned back in her chair and looked across at me.

The eighth volume of the Dryburgh edition of the Waverley Novels (Macmillan) contains "The Bride of Lammermoor." The illustrations are ten in number and were drawn by John Williamson. Among cheap editions this must be a favorite. At the price of $1.25 per volume we seldom get so much from England for the money.

The yachting season in Boston waters will open Memorial Day with the open race of the South Boston Yacht Club off City Point. Much sport is promised in this race for boats of 30 feet water line and under. The next big race will be that of the Massachusetts Yacht Club, June 17, off Nahant, and than will come the Eastern annual off Half-Way Rock, June 26, and the city's open regatta, July 14.

John C. New of Indiana, Consul General to London during the Harrison Administration, returned to this country yesterday on the Paris, accompanied by his family. He went to the Gilsey House, where he said he expected to stay for three or four days, after which he would go to Baltimore and Washington, and soon after to Indianapolis to become a private citizen.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., May 27 -- Among the cottagers at Richfield Springs for the coming Summer are the following well-known New-York people: Mrs. Robert Hoe and Miss Hoe, Mrs. Amos Morrill and family, Mrs. Charles Reuter, Mr. George Mosle, Mr. Theodore Drier, Dr. W.A. Knox, Mr. Purdon Robinson with his mother and sisters, Mrs. George H. Taylor, Mr. R.W. Taller, Mr. R.F. Westcott, and Mr. George Ticknor Curtis.

The ruin of a costly dress belonging to a society belle from Savannah and a mysterious and somewhat threatening message to her have disturbed the peace of mind of the society belle, her relatives, the employes of the hotel where she is staying, the firm that made the dress, and numerous friends of all concerned.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- A decrease of not over 500,000 bushels is expected Monday in the visible supply of wheat. This fact, coupled with the increasing receipts and the better weather, gave a bearish cast to the grain market to-day. Compared with last night, wheat is 1/2c off, corn 3/4@7/8c, and oats 1/2c. The clique permitted pork to drop back 55c; other hog products are unchanged.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 27 -- Action for divorce was brought to-day by Mrs. Jeannette Fortier against Alexander G. Fortier, Clerk of the Board of Health, President of the Democratic Veterans' Association, and permanent candidate for Pension Agent for this district to succeed Charles A. Orr. Miss Alice J. Brand, the co-respondent named in the suit, was until today the stenographer of the Board of Health.

The outlook in Europe with respect to cholera is decidedly more favorable than it was a month or two ago, notwithstanding the recent appearance of the disease in two small cities of Southern France, about 100 miles from Marseilles. It will be recalled that there was an outbreak of cholera in the last-named city about two months ago, and that it was easily controlled.

RUTLAND, Vt. May 27 -- There was a run on the Rutland Savings Bank of this city to-day, the first one in Vermont for many years. A few depositors, alarmed by the recent failures in the West, the failure yesterday of ex-Secretary Foster, and the Vermont Investment Company of Orwell, drew out their money.
The proceedings of the conference of the African Methodist Episcopal clergyman in session in Bethel Church, in Sullivan Street, were of an unusually lively character yesterday.

The record of the week just ended is uncommon. It is an unusual thing to find so much good music offered to the New-York public in the last week of May. At the Grand Opera House Mr. Hinrichs continued to present respectable performances of grand opera at cheap prices to the manifest delight of large numbers of persons.

CITY ISLAND, May 27 -- No tidings have yet been heard from ex-Supervisor Sherman T. Pell of the town of Pelham, in which this village is situated. He is wanted, as was stated in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES, by his successor in office, William McAllister, to whom he has failed to render an accounting of his stewardship as Supervisor.

Dealers In bicycles, and riders thereof, throughout the city are discussing with interest the outlook for cheaper bicycles of first-class manufacture. Last Thursday the Warwick Cycle Company of Springfield, Mass., announced that hereafter its highgrade bicycles of the 1893 stamp, which have previously sold for $150, would be sold for $85, and their 1892 machines for $65.

The closing exercises of the art schools of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the exhibition of students' work were held yesterday afternoon at the museum. Henry G. Marquand, President of the museum corporation, introduced Prof. William R. Ware, Chairman of the Committee on Art Schools, who presided.

The Prospect Park wicket was very heavy and slow yesterday, but this fact did not prevent the Brooklyn Cricket Club playing a good game against the Morris Parks, whom they managed to defeat by 1 runs. The latter team showed plainly the need of practice, although the fielding was a great improvement on that exhibited in the two previous games they have played.

Four cases of smallpox have occurred within a month in the tenement house at 1,294 First Avenue, and the health authorities knew nothing whatever about them until Friday, when a Yorkville physician wrote them that little Mary Volk, the oneyear-old daughter of a cigarmaker, had the disease.

Mrs. Sarah J. Monroe of 608, Lexington Avenue secured the arrest yesterday of Dr. John Shrady of 149 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, one of the best-known physicians in New-York, for breach of promise to marry. She wants $25,OOO damages.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 27 -- The boomers congratulated along the border of the Cherokee Strip held a mass meeting at Cale, in Cowley County, yesterday, and organized for mutual protection during the approaching opening. They prepared a petition asking the President to open these lands not later than July, in order that they might secure the hay and prepare themselves for next Winter.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 27 -- St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church, a beautiful new edifice which Mrs. Adrian Iselin and her family have just erected here, will be consecrated Sunday by Archbishop Corrigan. New-Rochelle has for generations been the country home of the Iselins, and this church has been built as a memorial to the deceased members of the family.

Bernhard H. Gueterbook, city editor of the New-Yorker Staate-Zeitung, and managing editor of that nawspaper's evening edition, was found dead in his bedroom at his home, 175 East Seventy-ninth Street, at 11 o'clock last night.

Despite the gloomy sky and chilling wind the streets leading to the Mall in Central Park were thronged yesterday morning by a well-dressed and expectant crowd, all anxious to see the parade of the Coaching Club.

RICHMOND, Va., May 27 -- The arrangements have finally been completed for the reinterment here next Wednesday, the 31st, of the remains of the ex-President of the Confederacy. One of the greatest demonstrations ever seen in this city is expected. There will be no formal oration, but simply the Episcopal burial services, at the grave.
NEWARK, May 27 -- The Ladies' Parsonage Association, of the Central Methodist Church last night closed a three nights' festival that has precipitated a church war.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 -- There is a clue to the lone highwayman who held up Passenger Train No. 3 on the Missouri Pacific the other night. An air of mystery pervaded the office of the Chief of Police this morning. Detectives dropped in and out; railroad men, officials, and employes did the same; consultations were the order of the day, but what occasioned all this bustle the Chief would not say.
