The fertility of the shore resorts in devices to engage public attention at about this time of year, by providing topics of diversion as a foil to Summer worry, bus left the exclusive sea serpent to the hidden depths this season and brought out in its place the Frankfurter sausage of the common people. Advance hints of this plan of campaign came simultaneously yesterday from Asbury Park and Coney Island.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The trial of Prof. Briggs by the Presbyterian General Assembly, upon the appeal from the Presbytery of New-York, which was expected to begin this morning, has been postponed until Monday.

"We are not spoiling for fist fights," said Martin J. Keyes yesterday when he read in THE NEW-YORK TIMES W.A. Carsey's story of the first blood that had been shed over the troubles of Farnham Post, "but if anybody thinks that the issue over bad pension laws had better be settled that way, I don't know but that we will be ready to meet all comers."

One morning Abel Burgess, the eminent Aberdeen attorney, was resuming the delights of legal pursuits after the lamentable interregnum or the night, when the door of his private office opened and his head clerk entered.
CITY OF MEXICO, May 27 -- One of the most prominent men of the Liberal Party said today:

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Secretary and Mrs. Lamont, after having nearly concluded arrangements for the lease of the Washington McLean house on Lafayette Square some weeks since, concluded to make a change in their plans and look elsewhere for a home. At present the preference is given to the graystone house on Farragut Square situated between the Russian Legation and Senator Stanford's residence.

Whatever disappointment Admiral GHERARDI may have felt at the inability of the Navy Department to grant his request to be allowed to continue in sea service until his retirement will be softened, if not removed, by the following remarkable letter of commendation from Secretary HERBERT:
The managers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad met in the company's ofice in Philadelphia yesterday afternoon and formally adopted the now plan to rehabilitate the corporation.

It is always a conflict -- this wrestling with duty. A young dressmaker, a member of the Salvation Army, received a letter from a would-be customer, asking, among other things, whether the material she was planning to bring -- plush -- would be suitable and look well to use in the big sleeves in vogue.

Just inside the main entrance to the Cemetery of the Evergreens, on the right side of the roadway which winds up the hill, is a handsome and spacious plot which has been devoted exclusively for the last forty years to the 'burial of sailors who die in this port. The ground rises in gentle ascent to the top of the hill and is most beautifully situated.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As a bona fide holder of 500 shares of the common stock of the General Electric Company I beg to call your attention to two points, especially with reference to the recent sale by the company of about $2,000,000 of the stock of the New-York Edison and the Boston Edison Illuminating Companies.

From time almost immemorial the police system of France has been held to be as nearly perfect as any system can be, especially in the matter of detecting crime. The student of criminal statistics has not, perhaps, held this view with the same confiding admiration as the devoted reader of French novels given up to the propaganda of the tradition; but the tradition has obtained, and has been very widely accepted.

James Van Blarcom, who is known as the "Bergen County Swearer," who was arrested in Jersey City a day or two ago for having, while driving recklessiy through Communipaw Avenue, run over a little boy, appeared before Justice O'Donnell yesterday for examination. A colored boy who was in the wagon with him at the time was in court as a witness.

PERRYMAN, Md., May 27 -- Julius Rellensman, an aged German who kept a small country store about two miles from here, was found dead in his back room this morning by a colored man who went there for supplies.

Playing the part of a millionaire seems to be a trying business to young John N. Luning. He was running an elevator in the Mills building three years ago, when he found himself, by the death of his father, in possession of a princely income.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- At last the computations by the naval engineers upon the results attained by the New-York upon her trial trip have been completed. The report itself has not yet reached the Navy Department, but late this afternoon Secretary Herbert received a telegram from Commodore Belknap as follows:

Col. Rockwell Tyler died at his home at White Sulpher Springs, N.Y., yesterday, aged sixty-eight years. He had been in falling health for some time and his death was not unexpected. At the outbreak of the war he went out with the Fifty-sixth Regiment. New-York Volunteers, under Col. Van Wyek. He was Quartermaster of his regiment and received promotions from time to time and returned home as Lieutenant Colonel.

Nothing so humiliating has ever happened to a nation which was acting as the host of other nations at a World's Fair as that which has now happened to the United States. The retirement of seventeen nations from the competition of the fair by reason of their dissatisfaction with the plan of awards adopted was such a blow as had never fallen upon a World's Fair before.

LONDON, May 27 -- The Royal Thames Yacht Club Regatta was finished to-day. Mr. Jameson's cutter, the Iverna, was declared winner of the chief race on a time allowance, the Prince of Wales's Britannia being second and Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie, which is to race for the America's Cup, third.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Treasury officials do not think there is anything alarming in the present financial condition of the country. Controller of the Currency Eckels said this afternoon he Thought the failure of ex-Secretary Foster would be entirely local in its effects. It had not affected any at the Ohio national banks, so far as he knew.

The mission of Mr. MUHAMMED ALEXANDER RUSSELL WEBB to convert the people of this country, beginning with the people of this city, to the faith of Islam has been received by the proposed converts with incredulous astonishment. It has even been doubted whether Mr. WEBB represented anybody but himself, or whether there was really any Mohammedan money at the back of his surprising venture.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, May 27-P.M. To-day's market was extremely dull until the final half hour, when, under a pressure to sell, prices declined rapidly. The bank statement did not show as large an increase in reserve as the traders expected, and they made use of the fact as an excuse for hammering the market. Rnmor mongers are becoming perniciously active again.
Work is active at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Ten war vessels of the United States and one foreign cruiser are being handled by the construction department.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 27 -- The Orioles to-day defeated the Bridegrooms for the third successive time. At no time were the visitors in it, and outside of the first two innings, when Schmidt pitched for the Baltimores, they failed to get a run. McNabb finished the game, and he was hit only twice. He pitched a brilliant game and was given good support. Brooklyn was in poor shape.

Mr. STARIN presented to the Rapid-Transit Commission at its last meeting some interesting ciphering in percentage, tending to show what the Manhattan Railway Company might do in the way of compensation to the city for its valuable franchise, and he thinks it ought really to do it for the privilege of making certain extensions of its system which the commission has proposed.

Another "race-track war" similar to that of 1891 at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's race course is to be inaugurated this week in all probability. On Tuesday next, which is the last day of the racing at the Brooklyn track, the Guttenberg people will resume racing at their track on the hill.

The first meeting of the Manhattan Tennis Association took place yesterday afternoon on the Lenox Club grounds. One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Some fifty competitors appeared for the event of the day, which was the men's singles. Contrary to the expectation of the committee, it was found impossible to finish the contests, so unusually large was the number of entries.

Albert Aronson, Treasurer of the Casino, appeared as complainant yesterday morning in the Tombs Police Court against Hyman Sohnitzer, a banker, who lives at 1.187 Lexington Avenue. He charged the prisoner with grand larceny.
The Infanta Eulalie attended high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Civil Service Commission yesterday transmitted to Postmaster General Bissell the report of Commissioner Roosevelt upon what is called by the commission "the Terre Haute Post Office scandal."

Thirty-three years ago the American Association for the Study and Cure of Inebriety was organized in New-York, its members being persons connected with inebriate asylums and others interested in the drink problem. In 1877 the Quarterly Journal of Inebriety was issued, and the volume under notice, compiled by Mr. T. D. Crothers, the Secretary of the association, contains selections gathered from over 5,000 pages of printed matter.

The Quaker Meeting House at Fifteenth Street and Rutherfurd Place is the home of that branch of Quakers known as Hicksites. It is a roomy building, but very unpretentious. The friends do not believe in ostentatious display. The Inside of the meeting house is fitted up with pine pews and the walls are painted in quiet tones of gray.

Prof. Felix Adler, President of the Ethical Culture Society of the City of New-York, spoke before the Russian-American Hebrew Association at the Hebrew Institute, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, last evening. The large hall was entirely filled, and Prof. Adler commanded close attention from his listeners throughout his address.

From present indications there is work ahead for the Transportation Committee of the League of American Wheelman. Word has been received that railroad lines west of Chicago have placed a tariff of 25 cents on the carrying of bicycled. An action of tills kind on the part of the Western roads will certainly lead to a similar action on the part of the railroads in this section of the country.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 28. -- The programme for commencement week is as follows:
The Central Later Federation yesterday adopted an amended constitution by which the constituent unions will go into politics and support the Socialistic ticket.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 28. -- On its noon trip from New-York to Long Island City to-day the Thirty-fourth Street ferryboat Manhattan Beach carried a big load of excursionists bound for Rockaway Beach and other popular Long Island resorts.

BALTIMORE, May 28. -- The agreement of the Baltimore and Ohio and Pennsylvania Railroad Companies to advance freight rates on Southern pig iron 35 cents a ton to Eastern points will go into effect next Thursday, and the result will be especially severe upon the furnaces of Virginia and West Virginia. The criticism upon the action is vigorous.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 28. -- For several weeks past Joseph Donoghue has been in care of Dr. Jova for trouble with his feet, resulting from tight lacing of his shoos during his skating matches and the training incident to them. He is to leave hore tomorrow to consult with specialists in New-York. It is feared that he will never again be in condition for speed contents.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 28. -- A Central Hudson train struck and killed an unknown man north of Cold Spring, this morning. He was apparently about fifty years of age and wore the Grand Army uniform. On his person, among other things found, were two cards on which were printed, "Mrs. R. Sharp, 429 E. 121st St., New-York City."

TRENTON, N.J., May 28. -- Mercer County is endeavoring to solve the tramp problem, and on Thursday the authorities will open a county farm and a workhouse, a new institution which will be used for tramps.

There was unveiled yesterday morning in the First Presbyterian Church, Filth Avenue and Twelth Street, a handsome window which the family or the late Prof. Richard Harrison Bull, Ph. D., has erected to his memory.

CRISFIELD, May 28. -- The troubles between Maryland and Virginia nave broken out again, and this time the contention is over the crab fishing. As usual, the seat of war is the Pocomoke Sound. The boundary line runs through the Sound and both States claim rights. The Maryland fishermen generally sailed over the line when they desired, but Virginia's navy began to object, and last Winter the difficulty became serious and the shots were many.

The decision just issued by the Secretary of the Interior in the case of the appeal of CHARLES T. BENNETT, late private Company F, Thirteenth Indiana Volunteers, throws a good deal of light on the way in which the Pension Bureau was run under RAUM, with the approval and assistance of Assistant Secretary BUSSEY.

The Rev. Pierce B. Tompkins, a colored clergyman from South Carolina, took a stroll in Central Park on Saturday. He was enjoying the pretty sights afforded by the many May parties of children, when he was rudely interrupted by Sergt. Mulholland of the Park Police, who arrested him an a charge of inciting some of the children to pick the flowers growing near the play grounds.

The mystery which surrounds the death of Bombard H. Gueterbock, city editor of the New-Yorker Staat-sZeitung and managing editor of its evening edition, who was shot at his house at 175 East Seventy-ninth Street on Saturday night, was not cleared up yesterday, although his friends on the Staats-Zeitung and Coroner Schultze feel confident that he committed suicide while in a state of nervous excitement and under the influence of liquor.

Though it was cool enough in the city yesterday to make light wraps and overcoats comfortable, thousands of pleasure seekers went down to Coney Island. Extra boats and trains were run by the various transportation lines in anticipation of a demand for them, and the traffic was about half as great as it is on the hot Sundays of the Summer season.

The Brooklyn Tennis Club expects to make a strong bid for the inteclub championships. Last year its representatives carried off first place in the men's doubles, and but for the illness of Merian might have taken first in the singles as well. W.R. Parker of the New York Tennis Club, and the Columbian interscholastic champion, is still a member of the Brooklyn organization, and will probably be its strongest champion against the local cracks.

The doors of the beautiful house of the Catholic Club, which fronts on Central Park at 120 West Fifty-ninth Street, were thrown wide open last night and the Infanta Eulalie of Spain and suite and about 3,000 gentlemen and ladies of this city passed through them.

William Hennig, who was knocked down by a paving atone which C.E. "Ashton." or "Anderson" threw athim Saturday afternoon, on Broadway, near Thirty-fourth Street, failed to appear when his assailant was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning.

Mr. JOHN C. NEW of Indiana, and more recently of the Consul General's office at Liverpool, has landed on his native shores with an elaborate diagnosis of the fatal malady which, struck his party under the Harrison Administration, and which had such a melancholy ending in November last.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- the chemical department of the University of Pennsylvania will soon be housed in the new building to be erected on the university ground. The structure will be 175 feet long, 110 feet wide, and 55 feet in height, and will be of red brick with terra-cotta trimmings. The architecture is plain but imposing, providing for a centre of three stories and wings of two stories in height.

According to the usual custom on the Sunday preceding Memorial Day, preliminary memorial services were held yesterday in Brooklyn at the Lincoln Monument, on the Prospect Park Plaza; at the Beecher Statue, in front of the City Hall, and at the tomb of the old Jersey prison ship martyrs at Washington Park, Fort Greene.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, May 29 -- A.M. Trading in the stock market last week was very dull and prices were irregular. While all the news was not as encouraging as could be wished for, much of it portained to progress in reconstruction of properties which have been in trouble.

Smoothly gliding out of the Grand Central Station yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, the New-York Central's noted "Exposition Filer" started on its first trip to Chicago. The compact train, drawn by a mammoth locomotive, skimmed over the track intent on making the fastest trip on record between this city and Chicago.

A dastardly attempt was made to burn a tenement in the heart of the Hebrew district early yesterday morning, but discovery of the fire prevented a conflagration which would have imperiled the lives of at least 130 persons.
The Rev. M.L. Gates, minister of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, Jersey City Heights, devoted the prelude to his sermon yesterday to the Geary act. He said in part:

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- The shipbuilding yards of the Cramps are now handling $20,522,000 worth of new war vessels for the United States Government. For this sum of money the Cramps have at present on their hands seven new cruisers and battle ships. The list includes the battle ships Iowa, Indiana, and Massachusetts, armored cruisers New-York and Brooklyn, and triple-screw cruisers Columbia and Minneapolis.

The committee representing the parishioners of the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, who seek the restoration of their former pastor, the Rev. Dr. R.L. Burtsell, started for Washington Saturday night to lay their prayer before Mgr. Satolli. An audience had been arranged with the delegate of the Holy See for 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Catholic University.

There has been trouble in the Young Men's Hebrew Association for some time, owing to a difference of opinion as to the management of a branch of its educational work. This difference of opinion was emphasized yesterday afternoon at the annnal meeting for the election of Directors and officers at 721 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Secretary Smith's pension decision, announced yesterday, reversing the ruling of ex-Commissioner Raum and ex-Assistant Secretary Bussey, by which the scope of the dependent pension law was greatly enlarged larged, has created considerable discussion here to-day. It is looked upon as the first important step in the direction of reforming the abuses that have grown up under the pension laws.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Referring to the proposed exaction of duty on natural gas, under the Collector's ruling that it was subject to duty as a raw or unmannufactured article at the rate of 10 per cent., it would seem that this duty is sought to be imposed because the article is "piped." and so imported, in the scnse of importation.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 28. -- The Republicans of Kansas are heaping anathemas upon the heads of those who attended the league meeting recently held in Louisville and there adopted a set of principles. The league meeting touched a sore spot for the politicians in this State in acting favorably upon the woman-suffrage resolution.

The decision of the Secretary of the Interior to adhere to the language of the act of 1890, thereby saving about $20,000,000 per annum to the Government. Is looked on with great satisfaction by the members of the recently-disbanded Farnham Post, and is regarded by them as being a vindication of their course in denouncing the abuses in the administration of the Pension Office.

The rivalry between the Campania and Paris is not more keen than that now existing between the Fall River steamboat Puritan and the Richard Peck of the New-Haven Line. The two boats have twice tried conclusions, and each time with a disputed result.

The light harness racers at Fleetwood are rapidly coming to their speed, Many a working mile below 2:30 was reeled off yesterday, the fastest for the season being the 2:18 1 2 made by Fowler's b.g. Charley Green, 2:24 1 4. He went to the half in 1:07, and was not all out at the win. The same trainer showed two steady miles with Andrew Miller's Tall Prince, 2:24 1 2.

The Methodists of Brooklyn are going to make an effort to raise $100,000 this week for the benefit of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, on Sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. They will try to secure a portion of this amount by giving a "grand lawn fete" on the grounds of the hospital on the afternoons and evenings of Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday of this week.

Senator George G. Vest of Missouri sat in the corridor of the St. James Hotel yesterday afternoon and for some time discussed the financial situation with ex-Gov. Samuel T. Hauser of Montana. He expressed his well-known ideas in favor of the free coinage of silver, and then the conversation turned on the number of national banks which have recently been embarrassed.

Charles Baumold, a young man twenty years old, a clerk for a firm of tailors at Broome Street and the Bowery, had an adventure on Saturday night which he will not soon forget. At 11 o'clock Mr. Baumold was passing through Twenty-first Street. Near Seventh Avenue he met four negro women who were walking abreast.

The Rev. Thomas J. Ducey of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twenty-eighth Street, lectured his congregation yesterday morning on their dilatoriness in wiping out the debt of the church, referred to the adulation which had been showered upon the Princess Eulalie, and concluded with a dissertation on the manner in which he had been misquoted by members of his congregation.

Harper Brothers have issued the second volume of the illustrated edition of John Richard Green's "Short History of the English People." The elegant, large octavo size of the pages, with the wide, indexed margins, the quality of the paper, the harmonious proportions of text and the engravings which Mrs. Green and Miss Kate Norgate have chosen, make of this work a masterpiece of typography.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28. -- Superintendent James F. Pierce of the State Insurance Department has received from the State Printer his annual report upon life and casualty insurance companies for the year 1892. After giving the statistics of the different companies of the State, Superintendent Pierce says:
Alice Lamb, nine years old, who was burned by igniting her dress from a candle in the cellar of her home at 468 Eleventh Avenue Saturday night, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital.
Gen. Joseph B. Foraker of Ohio, who is to deliver an oration at the tomb of Gen. Grant on Memorial Day, came to this city yesterday. He was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

TRENTON, May 28. -- The Essex County Republican Committee has begun its contest of the Redistricting act in earnest. Counsel has been engaged and committees are at work in the arrangement of the preliminaries.

The beautiful new Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel at New-Rochelle was consecrated yesterday by Archbishop Corrigan, in the presence of a large and distinguished congregation made up of people well known in New-York society, the occasion being the opening of the memorial given by Mrs. Adrian Iselin to the Catholics of New-Rochelle.

Charles Madden, a trackman, twenty-two years of age, whose residence is 228 West Twenty-ninth Street, was shot about 4:15 yesterday afternoon by James Donnelly, a bartender, employed by his cousin, Felix Donnelly, in the saloon at the corner of Eighth Avenue and Thirty-eignth Street.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 28. -- The fleet journey of the exposition, flier through this State has thus far been in the nature of a triumphal march. At almost every station enthusiastic crowds greeted the train, and hats, handkerchiefs, and flags wore waved vigorously as the flier passed.

If more evidence were needed of the great improvement in Gotham's road horses, vehicles, and their appointments, the annual ceaching parade of Saturday in Central Park would supply it. Compared with similar meets in Hyde Park or the Bois de Boulogue, New-York's parade would suffer only in point of numbers. Horses, harness, coaches, and the gentlemen who held the "ribbons" will bear comparison with any similar turnout anywhere.

The angling season is now fairly opened. The ice has gone out of the Adirondacks and the Maine lakes. Trout are biting in Canada, and Decoration Day the gamy black bass may be caught in this State and New-Jersey.

The auction sales of real estate to-day include offerings that appeal to many classes of persons. To those of Blender means who wish to build homos of their own there is much attractiveness in Mr. James L. Wells's selection of lots on tea Southern Boulevard and about the Crotona Parkway. Those who buy will do so with the certainty that their purchases will increase largely to value in a few years.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The report or the results of the survey for tie purpose of determining the practicability of laying a cable between California and the Hawaiian Islands, made by the Albatross, under an act of Congress, has been printed, and is a most elaborate compilation. It contains numerous Illustrations and drawings showing the different routes surveyed, the soundings taken, and the character of the ocean's bed.

The rooms for mission work built in the rear of the Mariners' Temple, at the corner of Oliver and Henry Streets, were formally opened yesterday, and the bronze drinking fountain, which will supply free ice water to the crowded tenement district through the Summer months, was unveiled.

The Harlem rowing regatta on Decoration Day premises to to the most successful of any of the long series. For the first time the entry fees leave a margin of profit. Nearly every rowing club in the neighborhood is represented in the entry list, and, granted fine weather and fair policing of the course, there will be a great day's sport.

Who would think that New-York contains more than one hundred men to whom the name of sculptor may be given? Excluding stonecutters and polishers, and considering those alone who model figures more or less artistic in clay, there are from one to two hundred persons here who consider themselves and are by others considered entitled to the name.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 28. -- The Cohoes Wheelmen held a successful race meet at Rensselaer Park. Lausingburgh, yesterday afternoon. Over 3,000 people were present. Good time was made in the cycle races, as the track was in fine condition. The summary or events follows:
The body of Katie McGlynn, the little girl who was Killed by a bicycle on the Boulevard last Wednesday, was buried yesterday afternoon in Calvary Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The trial of Prof. Charles A. Briggs of the Theological Seminary, New-York, upon the general charge of holding gross error in his teaching, will begin before the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church to-morrow morning. The case comes up on appeal from the judgment of the Presbytery of New-York, which acquitted the professor after a trial lasting several weeks last Fall and Winter.

Peace once again reigns in the councils of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks of the United States. The quarrel began in 1889 between New-York Lodge No. 1 and the Grand Lodge has been amicably adjusted.
ALBANY, May 28. -- Ex-commander in Chief John Palmer of the Grand Army of the Republic, says that the members of Farnham Post were wrong.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- There was a grand demonstration by the people in favor of Sunday opening at the World's Fair to-day. Nearly 200,000 men, women, and children paid to enter the gates. They began swarming into the grounds at early morning and kept the gatekeepers busy until nearly 9 o'clock in the evening.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Upon invitation of Ambassador Bayard, President Cleveland and Secretaries Gresham and Carlisle to-day took a trip down the Potomac in Mr. Hearst's yacht, the Vamoose, the craft that holds the fastest record in the world. The party reached the Seventh Street wharf, where the Vamoose has been lying for the past few days, about 1:30 o'clock.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 28. -- When the unloading or the animals at the Barnum Bailey show was in progress this morning a stampede of the thirty elephants connected with the circus took place, and for an hour the Winter quarters of the allow was the scene of much confusion.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 28. -- The Rev. Dr. Thomas Conrad, rector of St Mary's Memorial Church, at Wayne, died this morning after a brief illness. Last Tuesday he complained of pains in Ma heart, which, though not of a serious nature, caused his being confined to his house. On Wednesday he caught a cold which on Friday developed into pneumonia.

A pair of horses which had been toiling along with Car No. 110 of the Metropolitan Cross-Town Street Railway Company, found themselves suddenly freed from their burden about 9 o'clock yesterday morning at Old Slip, and so great was their joy that they plunged away, dragging the lines out of the hands of the driver, Thomas Harty.
The latest official reports show a great increase of the number of immigrants since the beginning of the year. The figures for February, March, and April are as follows:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An editorial in your eminent Journal this week spoke of the Art students' League and the Artist Artisan Institute as being the two art schools most recognized by the public for their "life and back-bone." And probaoly the rapid growth, and popularity of those two movements alone somewhat different lines and toward rather different alms does, indeed, fairly present the student feeling.

Friends of Richard M. Olcott, the broker at 56 New Street, who attached Millionaire John N. Lnning's schooner yacht Alert on an unsatisfied claim for $53,878, were indignant yesterday over the published statement of Luning's counsel, Robert L. Horrieon, to the effect that Olcott had pat forward a bogus claim in order to squeeze money bat of a foolish and confiding young man.

The Rev. Thomas De Witt Talmage yesterday wielded a scourge lashed with scorpions for those whom he claims are, and have been for a long time, defaming his beloved Brooklyn. His theme had been announced to be commemorative of the clearing of the big Tabernacle from its floating debt, and accordingly, when the hour for morning service arrived.

Secretary WHITNEY and Secretary TRACY each in turn came to the control of the Navy Department without ever having paid special attention to naval affairs. Great ability and assiduous study, however, soon made them masters of the work required of them, which included the very important task of supervising the reconstruction of the fleet.

Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Spaulding and Special Agent Tingle came to this city yesterday to attend the investigation of the Custom House by the commission of which, ex-Secretary Charles S. Fairchild is Chairman.

A call has been issued by the President of the Republican League of this State for a convention at Saratoga on the 27th of June next. It is well known that the League clubs are largely composed of the younger men of the party. We trust that all will send delegates to Saratoga, and that they will choose the best men they can find.

BERLIN, May 28. -- The Rhineland Clericals have published an election manifesto, which commends their Deputies for having voted against the Army bill, and declares that the growth or the army budget renders impossible any advance in the way of social reform. Nevertheless, the Rhineland Clericals profess willingness to grant as much of the Government demand as is indispensable to the security of the empire.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28. -- The great Bruce telescope is nearly ready for mounting in the Harvard Observatory. The fact is not generally known that the operation of this instrument is expected to mark one of the longest and most important advances in astronomical science. The plan of using such a telescope for photographing the Heavens originated with Prof. Edward C. Pickering, and he it was who designed most of the apparatus.

It is, to say the least, not delicate for the late Secretary of the Treasury at the present moment to undertake to lecture the present Administration as to its duty in the matter of finance. Mr. FOSTER is reported to have Bald, apropos of the stringency caused by doubts as to the future of the currency:

To the Editor of the New-York Times It seems to be about decided that we are to have a now City Hall, and that the old one -- by far the most correct and beautiful building of its kind ever erected in New-York -- must be removed. Let us hope that the old building will be re-erected without alteration in some place and for some object that will do it justice.

The Municipal Art Society having appointed From its membership a large committee to consider ways and moans for the accomplishment of the special object it has in mind, that committee has had a meeting and decided to attempt nothing until Autumn.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have read with amazement the article in your issue of to-day in which one McNaughton, Chief Executive Commissioner to the World's Fair for New-York, claimed to have discovered a portrait of Hemdrol Hudson, at the bottom of which appears the name of Count Pulaski.

VIENNA, May 29. -- While inspecting, to-day, the German Hussars, a crack Austrian regiment, on the parade ground of the main barracks, Col. Smzesanyi was angered by the clumsiness of a non-commissioned officer. He called the officer to him and, with an oath, gave him a box on the ear.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- New-York State Executive Officer Donald McNaughton was advised to-day by Gov. Flower, by wire, that the Governor, Mrs. Flower, Miss Flower, and others would leave Albany to-morrow night, reaching Chicago Wednesday night. The news was welcome to the Board of State Managers, as very little remains to be done to the New-York State Building to make it complete and ready for the entertainment of guests.

The third annual catalogue of the Metropolis Low School or this city has just heen issued. This school, designed especially for the advantage of young men whose daylight hours must be otherwise employed, was incorporated by the Regents of the University of this State in June, 1891, and it is established at Clinton Hall, in the Mercantile Library Building, in Astor Place.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 29. -- A report has just been made to the Government showing that during the past month there was exported from the State of Yucatan 28,500 bales of heniquen, with a total weight of 9,800,000 pounds. Of this amount 9,200,000 pounds was exported to the United States and the remainder to Europe.

Mr. Nathan Straus, who during the Winter months provided a poor man's coal yard, where coal could be bought in small quantities at the net cost price, has made arrangements to continue his praiseworthy service of his fellow-man during the hot weather.

LONDON, May 29. -- The carry-over which was looked forward to with much anxiety, was successfully accomplished to-day without the slightest difficulty. Two brokers, whose accounts had been previously closed out, announced their inability to pay balances due, but no serious failures are anticipated.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- "April Weather" was produced by Sol Smith Russell at the Grand Opera House to-night. In this Russell is still the same man that he is in "A Poor Relation," or "Peaceful Valley." The play is a comedy in three acts. Russell appears as a poor artist, Raphael Reed, who is "decorating" to make the pot boll.

Commenting on the criticism which the Rev. Thomas J. Ducey of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in East Twenty-eighth Street made from his pulpit yesterday morning on New-York society people, so called, for showering adulation upon the Princess Eulalie, the Rev. Madison C. Peters said yesterday:
NEWARK, May 29. -- Justice of the Peace Philip Sommor was sentenced by Judge Kirk-Patrick to-day to a year's imprisonment on several charges of extortion.

VICKSBURG, Miss., May 29. -- There are at least 10,000 homeless and hungry people in East Carroll, Moorehouse, West Carroll, and Madison Parishes, and the suffering and privations they are undergoing is appalling. With the exception of a few small elevations the whole of the northeastern portion of the State is under water.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- The meeting of the Western Passenger Association lines called to adjust World's Fair rates bad hardly been called to order this morning when it was announced, that the Santa Fe, Rock Island, and Burlington had made arrangements to settle their troubles and that the passenger officials of those roads were to hold a conference.

The funeral of Mrs. Catharine Sullivan, mother of Assemblyman Timothy D. Sullivan, took place yesterday at midday in the old cathedral, now called St. Patrick's Church, in Mott Street. A solemn requiem mass was celebrated by Father Murphy.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The President late this evening appointed Col. George M. Sternberg to be Surgeon General United States Army.

Gold to the amount of $1,140,000 was withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury yesterday, as per Saturday's engagements. Of the withdrawals, $1,000,000 will go to Europe to-day on the Aller and the $140,000 will fill out a two-hundred-thousand-dollar shipment to Canada. Arrangements were announced for the withdrawal of $2,500,000 for shipment to-morrow and Thursday.
The money market showed no marked change. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2 1/2@5 P cent. The last loan was made at 2 1/2 P cent.

In its issue of May 15, the Irish Daily Independent, the Dublin organ of the Parnellite Party, devoted several columns of its space to a denunciation of a statement, which, it alleged, was made in THE NEW-YORK TIMES by Joseph P. Ryan, Secretary of the Irish National Federation of America.

A number of well-known ladies and gentlemen connected with the New-York Kindergarten Association, which has its headquarters in the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, are interested in getting up a Park fund for the benefit of the children of the free kindergartens in this city.
"The World's Fair Directors are Anarchists, working for Anarchists' principles and for the disestablishment of the American Sabbath.

The Commercial Advertiser, the only newspaper now printed in New-York that is older than this century, published yesterday afternoon a special historical edition which, in its illustrations and typography, was one of the handsomest editions of a newspaper ever run off a press.
Coupons of the first mortgage bonds of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company maturing June 1 will be paid at the office of the company, 45 Wall Street, on and after that date.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 29. -- The Examiner this morning asserts that the Monterey's Scotch boilers are of such defective design that the only way to repair their faults is to take them out and virtually rebuild them.

The remarkable decline in Reading securities in the stock market yesterday following immediately upon the publication or the plan of rehabilitation has again brought this property prominently before the investing public.

George Burton, a roofer, leaned over the division wall between the roofs of the houses 46 and 48 West Thirty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon and saw the mutilated limb of a child protruding beneath a canvas.

John W. Mackay, the millionaire, who so nearly lost his life by the bullet from Rippey's pistol some weeks ago, is in New-York apparently as hale and hearty as he was before the attack upon his life was made. He left San Francisco about two weeks ago with Mrs. Mackay and their two sons. A short stay was made in Chicago and then the party came to this city.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 29. -- It has been the custom for banks to collect personal checks free of charge for their customers. They have lately commenced charging one-fourth of 1 per cent. for cashing them. Attorney General Little declares such united action and charges in the nature of a trust and in violation of the anticombine law, and that all banks which, are parties to such an agreement are liable to prosecution.

The prosecution in the trial of Mrs. Dr. Sarah B. Chase, charged with causing the death of Margaret Maozoni by a criminal operation, was concluded in the Court of General Sessions yesterday before Judge Martine.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 29. -- The great event in the opening-day races of the meeting of the Bay Slate Bicycle Club was the dofeat of Johnson, the Western crack, by Windle of the Bay State Club by a few feet in the mile open contest. Fast time was made. Nelson, the Springfield last rider, beat, both the experts in the half-mile open safety. Nelson also carried off the mile event for Massachusetts and Connecticut riders.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Wheat to-day sold at, with one exception, the lowest point in thirty years. The single exception was in 1887, during the reaction from the inflation caused by the running of a corner by Harper, the bank manager of Cincinnati. The great receipts, with little outlet for the wheat; the fine weather, weaker cables, financial tightness, and the heavy load of wheat carried here, all acted as depressing influences.
The Infanta's trip to West Point yesterday, judging by what she said about it, will be remembered by her as the most pleasant of the many pleasant excursions she has made in this country.

Senator William B. Allison of Iowa, the, Chairman of the American delegation at the International Monetary Conference, said yesterday, as the Brevoort House, that he expected the conference would arrive at some conclusions which would he of importance, at its session next Autumn.
Tennis courts of this city and vicinity will be crowded with players. Several of the clubs will celebrate the holiday by the formal opening of their grounds. Others will hold club tournaments.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Edward F. Cragin has returned to Chicago and is in the thick of the World's Fair Sunday-closing fight. Mr. Cragin is the acknowledged leader of the Sabbatarians, as, besides being a representative of religious elements in other ways, he gets about the country more than any other one Sunday-observance advocate.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A telegram has at last been received at the Navy Department announcing the arrival at Greytown, Nicaragua,, of the United States steamer Atlanta. Capt Higginson reports that he landed the marines attached to the vessel to look after American interests, but withdrew them Saturday evening at the suggestion of United States Consul Braida.

The attempt to prevent the dangerous pollution of the sources of public water supplies in Pennsylvania by legislation has come to nothing. The bill was carefully prepared by the State Board of Health and introduced soon after the beginning of the present session, and there was at first a general expectation that it would become a law.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 29. -- Eighteen miles north of Russellville, Ark., this morning, while a, United States Marshal and his posse were taking a prisoner from Newton County to Fort Smith, several volleys wore fired from ambush while they were passing through Bullfrog Valley.

MAJOR JOHN BROOKE, Surgeon, will be relieved from duty at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, by the Commanding General, Department of Missouri, and will repair to Philadelphia and enter upon temporary duty as attending surgeon and examiner of recruits in that city.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 29. -- Judge Bailey of the Twentieth Judicial District has, with Judge Bashare, decided that the new mortgage law applies to exchange mortgages. Both these Judges are Populists. In the other courts, presided over by Democratic and Republican Judges, the decisions have all been to the effect that existing mortgages are exempt from the operations of this law.

St. PAUL, Minn., May 29. -- It turns out that the investigation of the theft of $5,000,000 worth of pine land from the State of Minnesota must prove abortive, at least for the present. The trouble has arisen from the carelessness of members of the Legislature and State officials.

Summer gatherings for college students and others interested in education are growing more popular with each year. Among the most attractive for college students have been those held under the auspices of the International Young Men's Christian Association at Northfield, Mass.; Lake Geneva, Wis., and Knoxville, Tenn.

President Ransom of the National Bank of Deposit said yesterday that 100 additional consents to the appointment of Trustees for the management of the bank's affairs had been received. This gives the plan the approval of 500 of the 800 holders of open accounts and is regarded at the bank as a practical assurance that a receivership will be averted.

Ex-Judge John P. Rea of Minneapolis, formerly Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, was at the Sturtevant House last night. He will deliver an address at the memorial services at Haverstraw.

The trial of Alderman William McKee of Brooklyn, for alleged complicity in defrauding the city by excessive charges made in connection with the Columbian celebration last October, was begun yesterday in the Court of Sessions, Brooklyn, before Judge Moore.

To-day is Memorial Day, and, as usual, the old tailors and soldiers who fought to preserve the Union will parade in the morning. In the afternoon they will decorate the graves of their comrades who were killed during the bloody strife, or who died in their homes after the war, surrounded by their loved ones, and were buried with their comrades who had gone before.

HAMBURG, May 29. -- The Committee for the Prevention and Detection of Cholera, constituted by the Senate of Hamburg, declared officially to-day that a clerk, who was supposed to have been suffering, the previous week, from diarrhea, died on Saturday last from Asiatic cholera.

Some timely batting saved the Brooklyns from la defeat yesterday. They encountered the Louisvilles at Eastern Park, and the latter made matters very interesting for the Brooklyns by playing a remarkably strong game both at the bat and in the field.

The Jersey City Street and Water Board yesterday took action on two of the pending trolley applications. Those were those of the Jersey City, Hoboken and Rutherford Company and of the North Hudson County Road. The board passed the ordinances giving them the streetways they asked for at an annual consideration of $100 per mile.

The Rev. D.R. Lowrie, one of the most conspicuous members of the Newark Methodist Conference, who has been Presiding Elder in several of the districts within the conference jurisdiction, disparaged church fair lotteries in a sermon on gambling he preached Sunday evening from the pulpit of Emory Church, Jersey City Heights.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 29. -- When the train bearing the remains of Jefferson Davis pulled out of New-Orleans crowds appeared at every street corner. As soon as the train reached the open country the military escort laid aside arms and uniforms. At every station a crowd was assembled. Gray-headed veteran soldiers and women and children with flowers were prominent features.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 29. -- A number of the largest depositors in the Foster bank have issued a call for a meeting to be held in the Fostoria Opera House to-morrow evening, when a proposition, will be made to the depositors to settle at 50 cents on the dollar.

James Furman and George Waters, two negro convicts, escaped in a most extraordinary manner from the Kings County Penitentiary in Brooklyn yesterday morning between midnight and 5:30 o'clock. Both, men are desperate characters and have served terms in prison before. Furman was under sentence for felonious assault and Waters for petit larceny.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The work of reexamining the half-million of pensions that have been issued under the dependent pension act to see how many of them will stand the test of the construction of the law made by the decision announced from the Interior Department Saturday, will be commenced at once.

The salon of the Hotel Brunawick was crowded yesterday afternoon by the members of the Professional Woman's League, who hold their first installation of officers. The programme was diversified with musical and literary entertainments, and refreshments were served. Following is the list of officers:

The United States twin-screw cruiser Mablehead is due to arrive at this port to-day. The Marblehead left Boston on Sunday in tow for New-York. She comes direct from the shipyards of Harrison Loring of Boston. On arriving here the cruiser will be moored at the foot of East Twelfth Street.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the erection of the following new buildings and alterations were filed:
The Spanish colony of New-York gave a concert last night in honor of the Princess Eulalie and Prince Antonio at Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29. -- Rain spoiled the first day of commencement week at the Naval Academy. The Board of Visitors, or so much of it as was here in time, carried out part of the programme, in spite or a rainstorm that set in early and lasted until nearly sunset.
BOSTON, May 29. -- The Methodist clergy, representing this city and The suburbs, at a meeting to-day unanimously adopted the following:

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Over track torpedoes that sounded a rattling volley under the wheels, and greeted by cheering shouts and waving hands, the "Exposition Flier" of the New-York Central and Lake Shore Roads rolled into Chicago this morning and finally stopped in Van Buren Street Station at 9:57 o'clock -- three minutes ahead of time.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Judge Stein to-day issued a temporary injunction restraining the Exposition Directory from closing the World's Fair on Sundays. The decision was made in accordance with the prayer of a bill filed some weeks ago by Charles W. Clingman of Chicago, in behalf of himself as a stockholder in the Exposition Company and as a citizen.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A cold, cheerless rain that fell, sieadlly all day spread a wet blanket of depression over the proceedings of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church to-day, sitting as a high court for the trial of Prof. Charles A. Briggs upon the charges contained in the appeal of the prosecuting committee from the judgment or acquital entered by the New-York Presbytery.

If energy devoted to a good cause, combined with the support of all the Methodist churches at Brooklyn, can be taken as presaging success, the "grand lawn fete" to be given on the grounds of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital on Sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Brooklyn, to-day, to-morrow, and Thursday, will assuredly accomplish its object.

The official announcement that there was one death from Asiatic cholera in Hamburg on Saturday last should not cause alarm elsewhere. There were several fatal cases in that city last Winter. The fact that with the coming of warm weather there was no revival of last year's epidemic, and that for many weeks, up to last Saturday, no case appeared there, indicates that the sanitary condition of the city has been greatly improved.

According to Coroner Schultze and his jury the death of Bernhard H. Gueterbock, city editor of the New-Yorker Staats-Zeilung, in his home, at 175 East Seventy-ninth Street, Saturday evening, was brought about by himself. Some of Mr. Gueterbock's associates, however, believe that it was not.

Sheridan's first comedy, "The Rivals," is one of the old plays that seems to retain its freshness. Excepting the sentimental sub-plot involving exasperating Falkland and patient Julia, no portion of it has aged. Sir Anthony, and Jack, Bob, Widow Malaprop, and Lydia please the playgoers of this frivolous generation as much as they pleased their great-grandfathers.

THE LEGAL AND MORAL QUESTIONS. The experience of last Sunday vindicated the wisdom and policy of Sunday opening for the Columbian Exposition at Chicago, and it is fortunate that no legal obstacle was found for preventing the experiment. It justified what has been said in favor of Sunday opening and ought to go far toward disarming its opponents.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, May 29 -- P.M. For a day sandwiched between Sunday and a holiday, trading on the Stock Exchange was active, but most of to-day's excitement centred in Reading. Bear influences prevailed to the extent of causing a drop of almost 5 points in the stock. The reorganization plan was greeted with a medley of rumors as to its prospects of being carried out. and as to opposition from former security holders.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The newspapers here concur in declaring that the awards at the Chicago World's Fair will be worthless, since the Fair Committee has refused to give an international composition to the system of awards. The newspapers express regret that German exhibitors were enticed to the World's Fair.

LONDON, May 29. -- The sporting fraternity of England was treated to a surprise to-night, when Frank Slavin, the heavyweight pugilist, was whipped by "Jim" Hall, the middleweight. Both are Australians, lint the encoantec created no small amount of interest here. Previous to the contest Slavin was the favorite, and many ore inclined to look upon the fight with suspicion.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- An inquest was held to-day on the body of F.H. Milburn, the son of W. H. Milburn, the blind Chaplain of the United States House of Representatives, who killed himself yesterday at the Saratoga Hotel. The testimony brought out the fact very clearly that the young man committed suicide because he had despaired of being able to conquer his appetite for liquor, and had concluded to end the fight.
The investigation into the New-York Custom House was set agoing at the Barge Office yesterday at a lively rate.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 29. -- The Broadway Railroad Company of Brooklyn has filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of an extension of its route upon streets in Brooklyn as follows:

Seven steamships landed 4,566 immigrants on Ellis Island yesterday. Of this number nearly 3,000 were Italians. Eighteen of that nationality, who worked their passage on the Victoria, have been detained and will be held until the agents of the vessel pay the prescribed tine of $10 for each one of the number.

Friends of Gen. ARMSTRONG and of Hampton Institute will be glad to learn that the noble charity which he founded will hereafter be administered by the Rev. H.B. FRISSELL. It requires a peculiar call and special fitness to labor for one's lifetime amid negroes and Indians. Humanly speaking, "there's nothing in it," any more than in going missionary to China.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 29. -- The engine room-and boiler house of the Luckawanna steel Company north mill were destroyed by fire this morning. The flames originated in the engine room, where were situated ponderous engines of 22,000 and 18,000 horse power. The five quickly spread to other parts of the works, and the boiler house, 600 feet long, was more than half destroyed.

LONDON, May 29. -- The billiard match between Frank C. Ives, American champion, and John Roberts, Jr., English champion, began this evening at Huegler's Cirque. At the close of the play for the night Ives had scored 689 points. Roberts had scored 1,000 and was still playing. The hall was crowded. The frame is 12,000 points for $2,500 a side.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 29. -- Jerry Archer of New-York, a plasterer engaged on the new St. Mary's Church in this city, while at work on a scaffold about fifty feet high, lost his footing and fell, striking on his head and shoulder. His arm was broken in two places. He was picked up unconscious and placed in the Vassar Hospital ambulance, but died before he reached the hospital.

The principal auction sale of real estate yesterday was that of Mr. James L. Wells at the Trinity Building. He offered forty-one lots belonging to the Murphy estate, situated on the Southern Boulevard, Crotona Parkway. Penfold and Croton Avs. and 175th St. The attendance was quite large, but the bidding was not active and the prices were low.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 30 -- Fifteen thousand people saw Aeronaut Purcell Thomas killed by a fall to the flag walk in front of the Park Parade House this afternoon. Half the population of the east side had turned out to witness the finish of the Martin road race and the jump which Thomas and his wife were advertised to make from the pinnacle of the Parade House.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Besides the Briggs case there were two incidents of note in the day's proceedings of the Presbyterian General Assembly. The Committee on Bills and Overtures reported a form of deliverance, in explanation of the deliverance of the Portland Assembly on the inspiration of the Bible, as a substitute for the one submitted last Saturday.
The conductors, brakemen, and telegraphers who are employed on the Central Railroad of New-Jersey and other railroads in the vicinity want an increase of wages and a reduction in the hours of labor.

"And he gets a great deal more care than I do." That was the remark of a well-dressed, rosyfaced, rather stout, and altogether comfortable looking gentleman. It was made at Lenox Lyceum last evening, where was in progress the first annual bench show of dogs under the management of the American Pet Doff Club.

Though Noah L. Farnham Post, No. 458, is no longer recognized as an integral part of the Grand Army of the Republic, 150 of its 251 members observed Decoration Day in much the same manner as they had in years past.
The longer the Princess Eulalie remains in the City of New-York, and the more the people of the city know her and near of her doings, the stronger does the affection for her become.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30 -- To-night the cadets are very much interested in the statement that has been completed by Lieut Commander Harry Knox, the head of the department of mathematics. After careful consideration by the Academic Board of the standing of the graduating class, there are surprises for a few and disappointments for others.
The carriage factory and repair shops of the New-York Cab Company, formerly Ryerson Brown, in the rear of 21 and 23 East Twelfth Street, were badly damaged by fire last evening.

A large and deeply interested assembly of soulptors, architects, painters, and amateurs of soulpture met last night at the Fencers' Club, S7 West Twenty-second Street, to organize a society to promote good soulpture.

The annual parade of the police force, which will take place to-day, will, it is expected, exceed in interest all previous parades. There will be 2,50O policemen in line, and they will be divided into six battalions of ten companies each. The battalion commanders will be Inspectors Williams, Conlin, McAvoy, and McLaughlin, and Capts. Copeland and Washburn. Each battalion will be headed by a military band.
Decoration Day was celebrated in Brooklyn with considerable display. The feature of the celebration was the parade of the Grand Army posts and various military and civic organizations.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- The big crowd which visited the World's Fair to-day, because it was Decoration Day and a half holiday, proved too much for the foreign exhibitors in the Manufacturers' Building. Their cupidity got the best of them, and a number of arrests for selling articles on which duty has not been paid will follow.
PARIS, May 30. -- About 500 persons, largely Americans, were present to-day at the decoration of the tomb of the Marquis de Lafayette, in honor of his services to the cause of American independence.

Marie Nevins, who a few months ago secured a divorce from James Gillespie Blaine the younger, was married yesterday at noon to Dr. William Tillinghast Bull in the old South Reformed Church, Thirty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Roderick Terry, pastor of the church, who came up from Southampton, L.I., to perform the ceremony.
CHICAGO, May 30 -- The World's Conference of Eclectic Physicians and Surgeons opened at 9 o'clock in the Hall of Columbus, with music and drayer. Prof. J.M. Scudder of Cincinnati presided.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30 -- Fairer weather than that of to-day never shone during Commencement Week at the United States Naval Academy. When the sun rose this morning, it ascended a sky unobstructed by clouds, and, while the day remained cloudless, the sir was not hot. To those who had been here through the misty Sunday and the dripping Monday the contrast afforded was delightful.

RAHWAY, N.J., May 30 -- The fifth race meet of the Union County Roadsters was held on their new quarter-mile track in this city this afternoon. Twenty-five hundred enthusiasts were present. A arge number of visiting wheelmen were present from the Hudson County Wheelmen, the Tourist Cycling Club, the Atlanta Wheelmen, and a number of smaller clubs.

BALTIMORE, May 30 -- Good racing characterized the opening of the trotting meeting at Pimlico to-day. The weather and track were at their best, and a holiday crowd filled the grand stand and club-house balcony.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., May 30 -- Fifteen shipwrecked sailors of the Hamburg steamer Wandlahn arrived in this city to-day from Montreal and applied to the Custom House authorities for aid. They were sent from Montreal Monday, and were told they would be in New-York to-day. Since leaving Montreal they had had but a small quantity of dry bread to eat, having been given but little food to take on the cars.

After Washington Market was closed Monday night, Watchman Kelly heard some one prowling about the office on the second floor. He called to his aid Policeman Fern, and together they began to make an Investigation.

The Evening Post is moved, by the situation of affairs at Chicago, to remark that "the chief lesson of the World's Columbian Exposition ought to be that if we ever have another international fair in this country, there should be no National Commission connected with it." This is a plausible but hasty conclusion.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Montana's famous solid silver statue of "Justice" was unveiled in the Mines and Mining Building to-day. It is the statue for which Ada Rehan, the actress, sat as the model. The unveiling of the statue was the event of the day at the White City, and the great building in which the statue stands was thronged with people eager to see the magnificent work of art.

The prominent part taken by the Spanish colony in this city during the present festivities makes timely a sketch of the present and past personnel of the Consulate General of Spain in this city. The Consul General is his Excellency Arturo Baldasano y Topete. He was born in Madrid, the capital of Spain, and comes of a distinguished family.

ROME, N.Y., May 30 -- The fifth annual meet of he Rome cyclers was held in this city to-day. Clubs from Syracuse, Utica, Ilion, Watertown, and other places were represented. Brisk showers during the forenoon prevented many expected visitors from attending.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 30 -- Amateur athletes turned out in force at the New-Jersey Athletic Club games here this afternoon, the starters doing average work upon a rather slow track. Nearly 6,000 spectators were present, and found much of interest in the varied programme. There was a noticeable absence of much faultfinding, the spectators keeping in good humor and seeming to thoroughly enjoy themselves.
Gov. Flower, accompanied by Mrs. Flower and their daughter and son-in-law, started from this city for Chicago last evening. They expect to devote about two weeks to the World's Fair.

The auction sales of realty announced for today are all by order of the courts. Included among them are a series of brick houses in East 133d St, a residence in East 55th St, near Madison Av, and some tenement property. The property at 141 West 76th St, whose sale was announced for to-day by L.J. Phillips Co., has been withdrawn.

The pretty little clubhouse of the Corinthian Mosquito Fleet was opened yesterday. The house is a new one and stands on the shores of Echo Bay, opposite the New-Rochelle clubhouse. The situation is one of the prettiest on the sound. The house is built on the rocks and in front of it is the only sand beach in Echo Bay.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30 -- In a very exciting baseball game between Harvard and Princeton this afternoon Harvard won by a score of 9 to 8. The game was to have begun at 3 o'clock, but owing to a dispute over umpires it was delayed forty minutes. At the beginning of the season Princeton had chosen Murray to umpire for Harvard and Harvard had chosen Mullen to umpire for Princeton in the series between them.

The badge of the Grand Army of the Republic, hanging between fessoons of bunting over the centre of the stage in Music Hall last night, looked down upon a gathering assembled for memorial exercises that filled every part of the hall. Only the stage had been reserved for guests of the Memorial Committee.

Four of the children of William Votopken, who lives in a tenement at 1,5O4 Avenue A, were reported yesterday by a Health Inspector as having been sent to North Brother Island the night before suffering with smallpox. The Votopkens are Bohemians, and the afflicted children are William, four and a half years old; Carrie, fourteen; August, ten, and Rudolph, one and a half.

DEBUTANTES NOT ON THE BILL. -- Some of the 400 were startled Monday night by seeing others of the 400 on the stage of the American Theatre. Six or eight fashionable men of the town played small parts in "The Prodigal Daughter," and many in the fashionable audience recognized them and applauded their work. Their names were not in the printed cast and the parts they played were not speaking parts.

Central Park in the afternoon was crowded, and when the Infanta Eulalie drove through it on her way to the Grant tomb she was loudly cheered by the young couples, the mothers, and the children. The boys displayed their love of country and their respect for the memory of heroes by gathering in the tunnel, near the Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street end, and howling and shrieking like savages "to hear the echo."

The killing of a little child, by a reckless rider of a bicycle in the Boulevard has served, for the moment, to make these rubber-shod missiles of the highways more careful of their movements. But there is no hope that any real or lasting relief from the danger and annoyance to which wayfarers in the Boulevard are daily subjected will come through any change of heart in the bicycle riders.

The Kill von Kull Yacht Club of Staten Island held its annual Decoration Day open race yesterday over the club course in Newark bay. The clubhouse at Port Richmond was crowded with the members and their friends, a large proportion of whom were ladies, while the docks and shores that commanded a view of the whole course were filled with people.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 30 -- The city is in a state of intense excitement to-night, due to the discovery of an atrocious murder, rivaling in many respects those of Mr. and Mrs. Borden. The victim was Miss Bertha Manchester, aged twenty-two years, a former student in the high school and a descendant of one of the oldest families in this section of New-England.

The formal opening of the Atlantic Yacht Club house yesterday morning was the most imposing of the yachting ceremonies down the bay. Early in the morning Commodore David Bank's schooner Water Witch anchored in front of the clubhouse at Bay Ridge. The other yachts in the fleet then took up their positions in two lines behind the Water Witch.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 30 -- Little Rhode Island is more excited, politically, to-night han she has been at any time within her existence. Her checkered and eccentric history affords no parallel to the condition of affairs which govern her to-day. The new General Assembly met in the State House and adjourned till to-morrow without going into Grand Committee, thus leaving the executive officers of the State undetermined.

The Sabbatarians who propose to "boycott" the World's Fair by way of revenging themselves upon its managers for yielding to an overwhelming demand for its opening on Sunday do not occupy either a dignified or a promising attitude. Some weeks ago THE TIMES pointed out that nobody who objected to traveling on Sundays had gone the length of refusing to travel on week days by a road which ran Sunday trains.
The John T. McCall Association of the Twenty-second Assembly District went to Grand View Grove, on Long Island Sound, yesterday on the steamboat Pomona. This was its fifth annual excursion.

The absurdity of the Rhode Island majority and hold-over system could not be more conspicuously illustrated than in the case of HOXSEY of Westerley. HOXSEY has for many years been the Town Clerk of Westerley, and last year he was chosen a Representative of the First District of that town in the lower branch of the Legislature.

The formal opening of the "Grand Lawn Fete" which is being held on the grounds of the Methodist Episcopal Hospital on Sixth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Brooklyn, will take place this evening. The cold wind which blew over the grounds yesterday afternoon and evening, made the two great tents perfect "cases of the winds" and reddened the noses of the pretty "salesladies" in a way that was not becoming.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 30 -- Rumors of frequent groundings of steamships at the head of the Passes having been current quite recently, THE TIMES'S correspondent called upon Mr. M.J. Sanders, a loading shipping merchant, for information on the subject. Mr. Sanders said:

LONDON, May 30 -- Stocks were steady this morning, but soon fell away on persistent bear attacks against Reading securities, which were offered down in the dull, lifeless market, with the result of depressing prices, without much business being done.

The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessment worked all day yesterday upon the application for reductions on the assessed valuations of real and personal property. They had too much business on hand to take advantage of the holiday. The work will be completed to-day, and the books will be closed.

In this uncertain season the most objectionable public vehicle in New-York is the open street car. This car makes its appearance annually on the first warm day in April, and thereafter continues on its course, heedless of its baneful effect upon the health of the city, through all changes of weather, until the Autumnal equinox.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Up to the present time there is no Indication that the rumors that the Chinese Government proposes to retaliate upon citizens of the United States because of the recent decision of the Supreme Court bearing upon the constitutionality of the Geary law, and that the Chinese Minister will ask for his passport, are true.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 30 -- The bicycle races this afternoon were a disappointment to the 4,000 spectators. Windle, having beaten Johnson yesterday in the mile open, refused to start, and the riders loafed around the track, falling to come inside the 2:40 limit. Johnson came in first in 2:43. The judges ordered the race run over. The fliers all sulked, keeping in a bunch all the way around, allowing an outsider.

The multitude that went to Madison Square in the morning to see the review found that spot at its best. A forest of bunting had grown upon the neighboring roofs overnight, and gay colors brightened the house fronts, while Filth Avenue, down which the parade was to come, shone with cleanliness.
LONDON, May 30 -- In the House of Commons to-day T. Lea (Liberal Unionist) asked whether the Government had ordered the removal of Union Jacks from the hotels at Belfast.

The Staten Island Athletic Club made a great record in a game played against the Elizabeth Cricket Club. The latter went first to the bat and were all disposed of for 32 runs. The Athletic Club followed, and when they had obtained 154 for two wickets, they declared their inning closed and again got rid of the Jersey men for 40, winning the game by 82 runs, an inning, and eight wickets.

Decoration Day shares the honor with Fourth of July as the big baseball day of the Tear. On the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon just 23,142 persons paid to witness the game between the New-York and Cincinnati Clubs, and in the morning over 6,000 persons passed through the turnstiles, making in all nearly 30,000 for the two contests.

LONG ISLAND CITY, May 30 -- Richard Lavelle, who, with John O'Donnell, conducts a Wild West show at North Beach, was thrown from the back of a fiery mustang pony last night and was almost instantly killed, the fall breaking his neck.
Those that predicted and placed their money on the unknown man as the winner of the great Irvinging-Milburn twenty-five-mile handicap road race went home happy yesterday from the scene of the race.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, May 30 -- Ex-Gov. Foraker and his friends, with the audacity characteristic of the leader of the anti-Sherman forces, have brought the war for the control of the State organization right into the Senator's own personal bailiwick, and, so far as Senator Sherman is concerned, they are at liberty to work their will n this district.

The longest relay foot race ever held in this country took place yesterday, and seventy-six miles were covered by sixteen runners in the exceptionally good time of 9 hours 3 1/2 minutes. The race was under the management of the Young Men's Christian Associations of this city and Connecticut, and the relays were made up from members of the different associations.

The annual Spring handicap tournament of the Kings County Tennis Club began yesterday morning on the club courts, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street. The events were men's singles, men's doubles, women's singles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles. Of these the mixed doubles was the only event finished by yesterday's play. Dr. Frazer and Miss Moore capturing first place from E.M. Payne and Miss Brush.

The Manhattan Tennis Association continued its tournament yesterday afternoon on the Lenox Club Grounds. One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The men singles was the only event contested. Class A and B have a number of rounds to play before the prizes can be awarded. In Class C there are left undefeated A.C. Clark, Knickerbocker TC, and R.M. Cole of the Ariel TC, Arthur Keane is the champion of Class D.

BUFFALO, May 30 -- Since Gov. Flower sanctioned William T. Love's Bellamy scheme for the establishing of an industrial community by signing Assemblyman Ransom's Model City bill, the people of Niagara County have found confidence in it, and Mr. Love has had no difficulty of late in getting options on all the farm land that he will need in laying out his city.

The Brooklyn Yacht Club opened the season yesterday by a squadron sail down the bay. At 10 o'clock the yachts of the fleet were anchored off the clubhouse. Commodore B.F. Sutton's flagship Loyal was anchored outside the bar. At 10:30 o'clock a gun from the Loyal gave the signal for all yachts to weigh anchor and take position outside the bar.

ALTOONA, Penn., May 30 -- The most complete railroad wreck that has occurred in this section for many years took place this morning at a place known as McCann's Crossing, on the Tyrone and Clearfield Railway, about three miles from Tyrone, a station on the main line of the Pennsylvania Railroad, fourteen miles from Altoona.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- M. Nelson of the Columbia Wheelmen won the great Pullman road race to-day He ran over the seventeen miles of the course from Van Buren Street and Michigan Avenue in 55:44. Be won the race by a "scratch," as the saying goes, from Gunther of the Lincolns, who made a false turn out. Nelson is a good road rider, who has not been heard of much as a racer.

The charming and well-appointed grounds at Berkeley Oval, Morris Heights, were thronged yesterday by an eager crowd to witness the programme of athletic sports presented by the New-York Archdiocesan Union of Catholic Young Men's Societies.

The citizens of Harlem and the annexed district are in a state of indignation over the action of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners in refusing the offer of the Manhattan Elevated Road to extend its roads, and they will hold a mass meeting on Friday at 8 o'clock P.M. in Madison Hall, Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, and enter a vigorous protest against what they consider to be arbitrary action.

Capt. Reimkasten of the North German Lloyd steamship Ems, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, complained to Mr. Gustav Schwab, the agent of his line, that on Saturday last he met the Hamburg-American vessel, the Normannia, which had left this port two days before, steamig off the banks in the direct path of west-bound vessels.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- People evidently do not tire of the Briggs case, notwithstanding the technical and often wearisome features of the argument. The third day of the trial attracted an audience that left no spare room in the Church.

The statistics of the meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club prepared by Mr. L.N. Salmon, the clerk of the scales, show that eighty-eight races were run in which 299 different horses appeared. The club added to the stakes and over-night events the sum ol $124,700, including $14,400 added to the Brooklyn Handicap and $5,550 to the Fort Hamilton Handicap, to make up the guaranteed values.

The regular Democratic machine organization of Brooklyn is looking forward with the greatest interest to the trial of Alderman William McKee, which begins to-day before Judge Moore, in the Kings County Court of Sessions. The jury has been drawn and now comes the evidence.

In the morning the Princess spent four busy hours. She with the Marchioness of Arco-Hermosa, the Duke of Tamames, and Commander Davis left the Hotel Savoy a little after 9 and went to Moreno's, the photographer. Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. Her husband had gone there before her with his valet, and when the Princess reached the shop, Prince Antonio had already been photographed in three different positions.
PARIS, May 30 -- Sir Charles Russell continued to speak in behalf of the British case to-day before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration. He Will finish to-morrow.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., May 30 -- At the Lawrenceville School games yesterday all but four of the school records were broken. The class of '93 won in points with 53. Thompson and Smith captured half the prizes. Smith earning 18 points and Thompson 14.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- It is the opinion of Supervising Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service that the report of the presence of cholera in Hamburg is based on the single sporadic case which made its appearance yesterday. He takes it for granted that the authorities of Hamburg are taking all necessary precautions to prevent a recurrence of the epidemic.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 30 -- The American Home Missionary Society began its sixty-seventh annual session here to-night. Officers of the society and visitors are present from all parts of the country, including Texas, California, and Dakota.
NEWARK, N.J., May 30 -- Decoration Day was appropriately observed throughout New-Jersey.
As a monument to the value of newspaper advertising of a good article is the magnificent building just completed for Messrs, Scott Bowne, on New Chambers, Pearl, and Rose Streets.
