Charles H. Jones of St. Louis, until recently the editor of the St. Louis Republic, was at the Gilsey House yesterday. In discussing the financial situation, as it is regarded in the Southwest, he took the position that the Democratic Party has not been giving promise that it proposed to carry out the platform adopted in Chicago on the silver question.

The Philadelphia Cricket club gave a splendid exhibition of the game yesterday at Livingston, S.I., where their annual game against the Staten Island Cricket Club took place in the presence of a fair-sized gathering, which included many ladies. The game was close and well contested throughout, and at times proved exciting.

Richard Ryan of 177 East Broadway, Nicholas Remus of 1.055 Broadway, William Leary of 105 Cherry Street, George Melburn of 66 Oliver Street, and J. Campbell of 55 Oak Street took a trip out on the river yesterday afternoon in what is known as the "First Ward" rowboat.

Nobody seems to contend that Congress had any authority to require the Columbian Exposition Company to keep the World's Fair closed on Sunday. It is a matter over which the National Government had no jurisdiction. It was for this reason that the attempt was made to accomplish the object indirectly by making Sunday closing a condition of the grant of money.

From an interesting article on pensions, contributed to the Forum by the Hon. JOHN DE WITT WARNER, a well-known lawyer who represents one of the districts of this city in Congress, we take the following description of two cases of fraud:

Of the many services that were held during the day, none were more interesting than these at the tomb of Gen. Grant at Riverside Drive early in the afternoon. They were conducted by U.S. Grant Post under the leadership of their Commander, Enoch Rutzler. When Gen. Grant died a number of veterans were detailed as an escort to guard his body and to follow the body to its last resting place.

In the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, there is pending a suit for $20,000 damages, brought against a Roman Catholic priest, Father Philip J. Kinney, who was formerly attached to the Church of the Nativity on Classon Avenue, but is not at present connected with any church in Brooklyn, by Mrs. M.P.J. Thomas, a private detective, for alleged assault and battery.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 30 -- "Denver Ed "Smith, Peter Maher, "Joe" Medrath, and other pugilistic lights are here this week. Smith is talking around is champion of America. Yesterday he was asked what right he had to that title. He figures it out in this way:

NEWARK, N.J., May 30 -- The body of a young girl found floating in the river this morning was identified in the course of the day as that of fourteen-year-old Carrie Vogt, about whose disappearance the people of Newark had become considerably interested.

For some time customers of the Edison Illuminating Company have been complaining of the charges made for electricity supplied to run electric motors and for illuminating purposes. It is asserted that the motors used for registering the quantity of electricity used are worthless and that the company is obliged to resort to guess work.

From the upper North River at sunrise yesterday came the booming of cannon. A salute for the memories of those who fell that their country might not be divided was being fired by the few remaining war ships of the imposing Columbian fleet.

Commander Charles N. Davis of the United States Navy, who, as the representative of the President, has been in practical charge of the various entertainments given in behalf of the Infanta Eulalie, has been criticised in some quarters while complimented in others.

One thing seems to be very certain. If cholera should become epidemic at Hamburg or at any other European port, or at any place in communication with such a port, this Summer, we shall find ourselves in a much better condition for preventing its introduction into this country than we were in last year, when we succeeded in keeping it out.

Another one-run defeat was charged against the Giants yesterday, when they met the Clevelands_ They appear to be fated to lose the majority of their games by a single run, and Manager Ward is beginning to believe that there is a "Jonah" on the team.

TRENTON, N.J., May 31 -- Justice Abbett, sittins in the Mercer Ciroult Court, granted an order to-day requiring the State to tarnish a bill of particulars of the line of prosecution to be followed in the coming trial of Mrs. Shann, accused of poisoning her son.

The trial of Alderman William McKee the Brooklyn City Father who is under indictment for conspiracy and fraud in connection with the payment of the bill for constructing the city stands for the Columbian celebration last October, made little progress yesterday. Associate Justice Kelly was forced to leave the bench early because of sickness, and an adjournment was taken until 10 o'clock this morning.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 31 -- The Congregational Homo Missionary Society got through a great deal of business to-day. In the absence of the President, Gen. O. O. Howard. Mr. J. G. Merrill of Maine, one of the Vice Presidents, made the opening address, which was one of felicitation upon the prosperous year and promising outlook indicated by the statement presented by Secretary Choate.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 31 -- Postmaster General Bisseli was waited on to-day by a committee representing the Buffalo letter carriers, who wanted to consult with him regarding claims for overtime since the passage of the eight hour law for letter carriers in 1888.

Mrs. Sarah Blakslee Chase, on trial before Judge Martine in the Court of General Sessions under a charge of manslaughter in causing the death of Margaret Manzoni, was cross-examined yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Davis.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 31 -- The trotters went fast before a large and fashionable gathering at the Pimlico course this afternoon. It was a field day for favorites, all three of the events on the card going to the horses picked upon by the wise men of the turf.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31 -- Step by step, according to the official programme, graduation week approaches its close at the Naval Academy, and, as of old, the days are counted that intervene. Little note do the four-year men take of the presence of the Board of Visitors, except as official persons whose presence indicates the very last acts in the last scene of school life.

LONDON, May 31 -- This is Derby Day, the greatest day in the yearly annals of the British sporting world, when every Londoner and resident of the provinces who can possibly do so, makes his way to Epsom Downs, there to witness the short but always exciting race for the Derby Stakes. The day dawned dull, with occasional sunbursts. At times it was threatening, but on the whole the weather was fine.
HONOLULU, May 24 -- The situation here is at present more interesting than it has been for several months and the town is agog with excitement over late developments.

LONDON, May 31 -- Darkest Russia, a monthly publication, confirms the exclusive announcement of THE NEW-YORK TIMES that Russian persecution of the Jews is extending to Poland. It says that 480 families have been expelled from the Ronda-Gonzowski district alone. All the heads of families thus expelled were engaged in trade and possessed more or less real estate, which they were forced to abandon.

A pale-faced, delicate-looking thirteen-yearold Hebrew lad stood yesterday afternoon in the Superintendent's room of the Gerry Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. He had bruised hands and body and told a story of inhuman treatment to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter.

At noon yesterday two men went into the office of R.C. Washburn's brickyard, on Jersey Avenue, Jersey City, and asked Joseph Bridgart, the bookkeeper, it they could get a job about the yard. He told them that there were no vacancies.

PITTSBURG, May 31 -- A second Homestead, probably without lea record or bloodshed, seems to be the inevitable result of the forces working in the iron industry at Pittsburg said in the Mahoning and Shenango Valleys.

The resolution adopted yesterday by the Park Commissioners, authorizing a parade of the Seventh Regiment in the Park, was unwise, and is sure, if not revoked, to give the Commissioners much trouble hereafter. The objections are manifest to any display which tends to concentrate an enormous crowd in one quarter of the Park, and these objections have hitherto sufficed to prevent such displays.

That there is a feeling akin to jealousy in Great Britain toward American shipping, especially as regards the carrying of mails by steamers flying the American flag, is evident. The mails between this country and Great Britain were all carried under the British flag until the American Line steamers were put under the American flag.
An overhead wire of the Atlantic Avenue Trolley Railroad in Brooklyn slipped from its fastenings yesterday morning and struck an iron awning post in front of the grocery store at 292.
"But --" "Now, no buts. Boy just one." "Well, but I was --" "Never mind that. Buy just one. Remember it's for charity, and every penny'll come back to you."

THE CASINO HOOF -- For the popular concert upon the Casino roof Sunday evening Manager Aronson has prepared one of the best bills of the season. It will include Wood and Sheppard in their musical specialty, the Bland sisters in their clever act, Prof. Senac and son, Sadie MacDonald, the Saiambos, Mille. Naya, and the Casino roof orchestra, which will play some of the latest musical novelties now popular in Paris and Vienna.

The spaces between the horizontal lines in the above chart represent $25,000,000 each; those between the vertical lines represent twelve months each, but as every chance in direction of the irregular lines from left to right occurs at the beginning of a month the monthly fluctuations can readily be traced. It may be borne in mind that the line nearest the top shows the excess of reserve above the legal requirement.

LONDON, May 31 -- A dispatch from Borne yesterday stated that the Pope is about to publish a rescript on the school question with special application to the Church in the United States, and that the rescript was expected to show a considerable modification of the Pope's former views on the subject.

Three United States Senators had a threemillion-dollar house all to themselves last night, and in apartments equally as gorgeous and far more extensive than those which the Nation's Spanish guests have bean given. They passed what may be supposed to have been a comfortable night.

NEWARK, May 31 -- An air of mystery envelops the death of Lizzie Ritt, which took place at the City Hospital this morning. Eight days ago the police of the Second Precinet found, her lying unconscious upon the floor of her apartment in Boyden Street and took her away for treatment.

A real estate deal, said to be biggest which ever took place in New-York in which one person figured as the purchaser, was consummated yesterday. The purchase price was $2,400,000 cash. The vendors' profit was $2,350,000 beyond the amount originally paid for the property. For the last three months the St. Luke's Hospital corporation has been trying to negotiate the sale of its block of realty in Fifth Avenue.

The yelps and yowls of the aristocratic pet dogs -- they are very much like the yelps and yowls of the ordinary dogs whose ancestors are unknown -- on exhibition at the first annual bench show of the American Pet Dog Club, at Lenox Lyceum, continued unabated yesterday. The doss had nothing else to do. All the prizes had been awarded the day before and what earthly use was there in being dignified and austere?

CITY OF MEXICO, May 31 -- The machinery of the Government mint at San Luis Potosi, which was recently abandoned, has arrived here. There were until recently thirteen mints in this country under control of various private parties, who ranted from the Government.

SEATTLE, Washington, May 31 -- United States District Attorney Patrick Henry Winston has addressed a letter to President Cleveland, in which he says the reason for his removal was his prossecution of John M. Stone of Spokane for timber trespass. Stone cut ties for the Northern Pacific branch lines and Winston brought suit against the Northern Pacific for $80,000.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Secretary Herbert to-day made public the report of the naval board, of which Rear Admiral Belknap is President, which conducted the recent trial of the armored cruiser New-York.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Those who criticised the appointment of William H. Eckels of Illinois to be Controller of the Currency have received numerous evidences that their judgment was at fault. Mr. Eckels had been in office but a short time before he demonstrated the sagacity of the President in selecting him for this important position.

CAPE CHARLES, Va., May 81 -- President Cleveland and party arrived at Exmore at 2:36 this morning. They remained in their special car until 7:45 A.M., when they were driven to Willis Wharf, a distance of two miles, and boarded the steamer Sunshine, which left immediately for Broadwater, on Hog Island.

When the Park Commissioners met yesterday. William Coffey, L. Sanderson, and William Kretschmer, a oommittee from the various painters' unions, complained that Contractor Jacobson, who is painting the railing around Mount Morris Park, was employing "acab" labor and working his men more than eight hours a day.
The annual meeting of the Church Club of New-York was held last night in the new rooms of the club, 146 Fifth Avenue. Henry A. Oakley, First Vice President, was in the chair.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The task of counting the assets of the United States Treasurer's office will begin to-morrow morning. The committee which will ascertain whether the money, bonds, securities, , in the office equal the amount declared by the outgoing Treasurer consists of Mr. E.B. Daskam, appointed by Secretary Carlisle; Mr. A.T. Huntington, chosen by the outgoing Treasurer, Mr. Nebeker, and Mr. Charles H. Noble of Connectiout, representing the incom- Treasurer, Mr. Morgan.

Speaking of the new law which enables the Street Sprinkling Association to control the street sprinkling privileges of this city for the next ten years, and of which complaint has been made, Michael T. Daly, Commissioner of Public Works, said yesterday that he Knew nothing about the law until he advertised for bids under the old system of giving out contracts for forty-eight sprinkling routes.

Andrew Carnegle predicts in the June number of the North American Review, issued today, the union of all the parts of the Englishspeaking world, and sets forth the advantages that would follow an Anglo-American combination. Mr. Carnegle, writing of such a combination, says:

The Pittsburg Club played without an error of any description yesterday against Brooklyn, but in spite of that the Smoky City youths failed to win. This was due to the fact that the Brooklyn players found ample use for their bats in one inning, and in that short period knocked out enough runs to win the game.

PARIS, May 31 -- Sir Charles Russell concluded to-day his argument in behalf of the British case before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration. He said that this was the first occasion upon which a nation had claimed property in a free-swimming animal. The contention was untenable, and its advancement was derogatory to the principle of freedom of the seas.

The marriage of Miss Marion Phelps, daughter of W. W. Phelps, ex-Minister to Germany, to Dr. von Rottenburg, Secretary in the Department of the Interior, takes place at 11 o'clock this morning in Berlin.

The State of Texas owns a sugar plantation of 2,000 acres, upon which about 1,000,000 pounds of sugar was produced last year by the labor of 165 convicts. For the production of this sugar the State can collect from the National Treasury a bounty of about $20,000 per annum, but thus far no application for the money has been made, owing to the opposition of Gov. HOGG.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 31 -- The murderer of Miss Bertha Manchester has not yet been arrested, and the tragedy grows more mysterious. Contrary to a report given out yesterday, neighbors state this morning that they heard loud barking by the dogs on the Manchester place about 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon, but, "as the dogs are always barking," thought little of the circumstance.

When the curtain went up last night at the Broadway Theatre there was an audience in the seats and in the boxes such as probably had never been in the house before. The night was, according to the "official programme," the gala night at the theatre, in contradistinction to all the other nights that the Princess Eulalie has attended the theatre during her stay in the city.

A report was submitted at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Pacific Mall Steamship Company yesterday, showing the gross earnings from three steamship lines, $3,955,765; Central American and Mexican subsidies, interest, and miscellaneous, $162,708. Total, $4,419,000, against $4,409,262 in 1891-2. The expenses were $4.175,214, against $3,688,055 in 1891-2, showing a loss this year of $56,740, against a surplus in the previous year of $721,207.
The East River Bridge Commission met yesterday at the office of the company, 29 Broadway. There were present Adrian H. Joline, Samuel W. Milbank, and Thomas L. James, the full board.

The courts of the Kings County Tennis Club, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, were given up again to the competitors in the Spring handicap tournament yesterday afternoon. The tournament is advancing but slowly owing to the inability of many of the contestants to get away from business.
On their second day's cruise in the Appraiser's Department President Cleveland's Commissioners to investigate the New-York Custom House found themselves in muddy water.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 31 -- A terrible storm swept over Hempstead County last night. The worst damage was done at Guernsey and in its immediate vicinity. The town itself was almost completely destroyed, being struck by a terrible gale of wind about midnight, which was accompanied by a deluge of water.

CHICAGO, May 81 -- Wright covered about 1,000,000 bushels of wheat through Swartz Dupee on Monday and to-day, and Baldwin @ Farnum were also credited with heavy purchases of short wheat on his account. Largely as a result of this the tension in the wheat and corn markets, which made such an anxious time for the bulls Monday, was perceptibly relaxed to-day.
The money market was quiet. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2 @ 4, P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

aALBANY, N.Y., May 31 -- There was a hearing before the State Railroad Commission this afternoon upon the application of the Philadelphia, Honesdale and Albany Railroad. Company for the board's approval of the company's proposed construction of a road from Whitehaven, Penn., to this city, Seheneotady, and Rotterdam Junction.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday gave some space to persons who alleged grievances against an electric company on the ground of overcharges. A further investigation yesterday afternoon disclosed that the allegations against the company were without reasonable foundation.

The annual race of the Corinthian Yacht Club of New-York will be sailed on Saturday, June 17. The start will to made at noon. This year, instead of having a regatta for all classes of schooners and aloops, the race will be for schooners only.

PANAMA, May 31 -- Advices have been received that President Sacasa has abandoned the struggle with the revolutionists in Nicaragua. Last night the President signed a treaty of peace with his opponents.

According to the statements of Republicans who ought to know, a scheme is on foot among those in authority in their party to change the basis of representation in National Conventions of the Southern States possessing a large proportion of negro voters among the Republicans and a very small proportion of Republicans among the voters as a body.

New statues for the parks occupied considerable of the Park Commissioners' attention at their meeting yesterday. It was decided to place the statue of Roscoe Conkling, which is to be presented to the city by ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton, Clarence A. Seward, Cornelius N. Bliss, and other friends of Mr. Coukling, in the southeast corner of Madison Square.

PANAMA, May 24 -- Mall advices from Peru exhibit a state of affairs which must afford small consolation to the creditors of that country or to those who take any interest in its well being. Bad as is the commercial situation, with decreasing exports and paralyzed industries of all sorts, the political situation is still worse, and the country is fast drifting into civil war.

CONCORD, N. H. May 31 -- To-morrow is anniversary day at St. Panl's School, and the annual celebration commenced to-day with the first day's events in the eighteenth Spring meeting of the athletic association. The annual boat races were rowed on Lake Penacook yesterday, resulting in overwhelming victory to the Shattuck crews.

JAMAICA, L.I., May 31 -- In cutting one of the new highways through Dunton, a suburb of Jamaica, the workmen came upon the skeletons of two men to-day. They were found after cutting three feet into a small hillock. The skeletons were in good condition, the skulls being particularly well preserved.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 31 -- The Monterey came back this morning from her sea trial, and the word was passed around that everything was lovely.
Francis Lee Morrell of the stock brokerage firm of Francis L. Morrell Co. of 52 Broadway and 2 Exchange Place, met with a fatal accident while driving yesterday afternoon.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 31 -- There is no longer any question that the civilized tribes of Indians desire Statehood. They do not want to be attached to Oklahoma, but do want to have created a State taking in the live civilized tribes, who would thus be enabled to protect themselves, having control of the lawmaking body.

But whether the amount of money involved in the matter be large or small, the ruling was apparently a ruling which ought to be made, involving simply the principle that a law providing for the expenditure of public money must be construed according to the meaning apparent in its language, and not according to the liberal impulses of a disbursing officer.

It was feared last night that an over zealous desire to show distinguished consideration to the Princess Eulalie has led the Park Commissioners, the Mayor, the commanding officer of the Seventh Regiment, the committee of one hundred, and other persons interested in the entertainment of the royal visitor unwittingly to place her in the embarrassing position of seeming to desire a courtesy which there are serious objections to granting.

The proceeding by which the Democrats in the Rhode Island House of Representatives, under the efficient leadership of Col. HONEY of Newport, undertook on Tuesday to obtain control of the "Grand Committee" for the purpose of installing the candidates for State offices who received a plurality of the votes cast at the April election, was denounced by Republicans as "revolution."

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Memorial Day exercises at the Art Institute last night were rendered interesting by an exchange at opinions on the pension question between Gen. John C. Black, ex-United States Pension Commissioner, and Major William Warner of Kansas City,. Past Gran Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Ordnance Bureau of the army is preparing for important and interesting tests of small-calibre rapid-fire guns, for use in the army, at the Sandy Hook Proving Station. So far only American inventors have signified their intention of submitting guns for the trial, which will be the most thorough ever given any light army ordnance.

That there is nothing new under the sun is an assertion frequently made with a glib lack of reflection. Even in contemplating the latest developments in the construction of yachts, one is tempted to quote the old saw. At a first glance it does indeed seem that if anything under the sun could be radically new it is the fin-keel yacht.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Memorial Day exercises at the Art Institute last night were rendered interesting by an exchange at opinions on the pension question between Gen. John C. Black, ex-United States Pension Commissioner, and Major William Warner of Kansas City,. Past Gran Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic.

The "Exposition Flier," which rolled into the Grand Central Station yesterday forenoon, brought back from Chicago the party of specially invited guests who left here on the initial trip of the "flier" last Sunday afternoon. Each person was in a cheerful frame of mind and enthusiastic over the remarkable exploit in which he, had participated.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Presbyterlan General Assembly has voted to sustain the appeal against the verdict of the New-York Presbytery, sustaining Prof. Briggs. In other words, it has found him guilty of heretical teachings by a vote or 383 to 116.

NEWPORT, R.I, May 31 -- Royal Phelps Carroll's eighty-four-footor Navahoe has taken her last trial spin under her racing rig on this side of the water. To-morrow she will be taken to Bristol to have her cruising rig put in place and be fixed for her voyage to England.

CHICAGO, May 31 -- This was to have been the Wheelman Day at the Fair, but Architect Burnham, whose official title is Director of Works, although the construction part of the exposition is practically finished, has countermanded the permit issued to the wheelmen's clubs and leagues to have a cycling parade within the grounds. Mr. Burnham does not even deign to give any reason for his countermanding order.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 -- Ex-State Senator John J. MacFarlane, the defaulting President of the rained American Life Insurance Company, and a wrecker of the Bank of America, with which he was also connected, surrendered him- self to the authorities this morning, and in the Court of Quarter Sessions pleaded guilty to the indictments against him, and was sentenced by Judge Bare to four years' imprisonment in the Eastern Penitentiary.

To-day's stock market was narrow, but was very strong. General Electric was the feature, and it was apparent that those who have been bearing it from above par to below 70 have covered their short contracts. They did so between 65 and 70, and, of course, made very handsome profits.

A shovel with a leather thong attached to the handle and a brand new, untarnished stiletto arc in the office of the Bleecker Street horse car line waiting for a claimant. They wore left over from a little complication into which an Italian cart driver and the conductor of Car No. 116 got into in West Fourth Street, near Bank Street, yesterday afternoon.

The decline of the House of Commons from its once proud position as "the pleasantest club in London." has been progressive, and for the past few years an example of accelerated motion. It has not been more strikingly illustrated than by the refusal of that body to adjourn over Derby Day.

The Spring regatta of the Larehmont Yacht Club will be sailed on Saturday, June 10. The Regatta Committee of the club, Messrs. John E. Lovejoy, Otto Sarony, and Gsrard M. Barretto, has issued a circular containing the classification of the yachts and rules for the races.

The shipments of gold have been resumed in considerable volume, two and threequarter millions going out on the French steamer yesterday. The gold reserve of the Treasury, which was considerably below the $100,000,000 at the opening of the week will, it is estimated, be as low as $92,000,000 by the close.
Commander Charles Henry Davis, United States Navy, representing the President of the United States near the person of the Infanta Eulalie, spent a very busy day yesterday with his correspondence.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Trouble may grow out of the telegram which was received today at the Navy Department from Chief Engineer Joseph Trilley of the United States Ship Monterey. The officer is in charge of the engineer force and equipment of the coast defense ship, and on completion of the last official trial trip of the Monterey, which ended yesterday, sent a dispatch from Mare Island descriptive of the performance of the vessel's machinery.

A concealed case of smallpox was found late Wednesday afternoon in the tenement house 103 Park Street, which is inhabited exclusively by Italians. The patient is an Italian woman, Annie Preyce, thirty-three years old. She was found in one of the rooms on the top floor of the house.

The Infanta Eulalie, accompanied by her husband and her suite, visited Morris Park yesterday afternoon and saw a race. It had been iniended that the Princess should see several of the races, but she arrived late and left early.
OTTAWA, Ontario, June 1 -- Archbishop Duhamel and the French daily paper here, Le Canada, are involved in a quarrel which is growing acute.

The officers of the city banks are hearing more or less complaint of the course that some of the banks have felt obliged to adopt with reference to loans. In consequence of the stringent financial condition, applications for loans have lately been subjected to more than ordinary scrutiny, and much collateral that formerly would have been accepted without question by the banks has been turned back to applicants.

Not since the memorable day when a former Police Justice opened court with an axe, has Flatlanda, Kings County, been so pleasantly agitated as it was yesterday, when its new police force, composed of one doorman, six patrolmen, two Roundsmen, two Sergeants, one Captain, one Justice, and two Commissioners, assumed their various titles and began to sternly preserve the peace.

Great excitement was caused in the neighborhood of Pearl, Centre, and Chambers Streets yesterday by a small Scotch terrier belonging to Joseph Gross of 487 Pearl Street which, presumably, went mad, was chased through a number of streets, and, after biting two boys, was killed by a policeman.

The cheap milk depot established by Nathan Straus on the pier at the foot of East Third Street was opened yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, and the results of the first day's sales showed that the people appreciated Mr. Straus's desire to help them.

The third day of the show of the American Pet Dog Club at the Lenox Lyceum showed a large increase in the attendance at this interesting exhibition. The show is an excellent one, and the arrangements are such that half an hour or so can be agreeably spont in looking at the dogs.
The ringsters in Jersey City and Hudson County have suffered two or three serious setbacks within the last thirty-six hours.

The commission to investigate, the Custom House got out of sight of land yesterday, and encountered several squalls and a number of heavy cross seas of contradictions. Secretary Fairchild was not present. In their voyage of discovery for facts they learned that the President of the Board of General Appraisers had recommended Appraiser Cooper's removal.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Gov. Flower was the guest of honor at the opening of the Children's Building this afternoon. The Governor and party arrived after a third of the programme had been gone through with, but proceedings were suspended, while Mrs. Potter Palmer escorted the Governor and those accompanying him to the platform in the Assembly Hall where the exercises were held.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 1 -- The Plankinton Bunk closed its doors at 10:05 o'clock this morning. At that hour the following notice was tacked to the front door of the institution:

The New Netherlands Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, the second of the magnificent creations of this sort which William Waldorf Astor has completed within a year, was opened for business yesterday. It is seventeen stories high, of brown brick, and it has a beautiful location, many of its rooms commanding a view of Central Park.

LONDON, June 1 -- Tills was the third day of the Epsom Summer meeting. The meeting will end tomorrow. The principal eventon to-day's programme was the race for the Epsom Grand Prize of 2,000 sovereigns. It was won by Mr. R. Marsh's bay colt Tanderagee. The Duke of Portland's bay colet Raeburn, which ran third in the Derby yesterday, was second, and Mr. Douglas Baird's brown colt Harbinger third.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- On the Stock Exchange today West Chicago sold at 159 7 8, Calumet Canal at 55, Diamond Match at 114, Strawboard at 60, and Milwaukee Brewing at 23. Money, 6@ 7 cent Bank clearings, $20,596,722. NewYork exchange, 50 c discount.

The National Union Bank opened for business yesterday in the Mutual Life Building, at Nassau and Cedar Streets, in offices formerly occupied by Kuhn, Loeb Co. Down-town banking men paid the new-comer the compliment of a morning visit, admiring the handsome room in which business will be done and offering their best wishes for the success of the institution.

The sixth annual Dale of the Rancho Del Paso yearlings, the property of James B. Haggin of California, was opened yesterday morning in the paddock of the Morris Park race track. The catalogue numbered 146 youngsters, the get of such famous sires as Ben All, Fresno, Hidalgo, Sir Modred, St. Blaise, Tyrant, and the great salvator, and of this number thirty-nine were sold yesterday. The total amount realized was $67,900.

The Chamber of Commerce, on the motion of Mr. SIMMONS, seconded by Mr. WINDMULLER, has unanimously passed a resolution calling on Congress to repeal the Sherman law of 1890 at as early a date as possible. As the meeting of yesterday was the last until next October, this resolution is timely.
JAMESTOWN, N.D., June 1. -- State Auditor Porter said this evening that North Dakota would have a deficiency of from $100,000 to $150,000 before another Legislature could convene.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 -- Prices were steady at the opening, but were lower later on. Traction stocks were pressed for sale all day, and found, few buyers. Metropolitan sold at 104 7 8, Philadelphia at 104 1 2, and Baltimore at 22 1 4. Reading securities were somewhat firmer on a growing belief that the reorganization plan may go through. About $3,000,000 of the general 4s were deposited to-day.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 -- It is learned here that the flint-glass manufacturers of the country have formed a trust. Firms here who user a large amount of such goods have received letters setting forth terms, Meyer Brothers' Drug Company, said to be the largest company of the kind in the world, and the Samuel Clippies Waodenware Company have refused to be governed by the schedule.

The commencement exercises of the University Law School were held Wednesday evening in Music Hall. Chancellor MacCracken presented sixty-eight students, three of whom were women, with their degrees. The commencement address was delivered by Elihu Root. The valedictorian was Charles Preston Hallock.

WILLIAM'S BRIDGE, N. Y., June 1 -- Coroner Frederick Drews of Mount Vernon held his inquest this afternoon into the cause of death of James T. Cleary, who was shot last Friday night by Chief of Police Patrick Cash after a quarrel at a special election.

The Senate Committee on Immigration attempted yesterday to learn if the contract labor laws were violated in the Immigration to this country. Two sessions, which consumed the entire day, were held at the New-Netherlands Hotel.

The chief sufferers by the collapse of the Cordage Trust who were able to save themselves from assignments at the time that the company went into a receiver's hands, but who were crippled by the crash in the stock, have began to get their bearings, and yesterday they put out overtures for a settlement of their individual accounts with their creditors.

Chicago is soon to see in its most aristocratic quarter a bronze group which is just finished at the Henry-Bonnard Foundries, 432 West Sixteenth Street. It is by Carl Rohl-Smith, an American sculptor of Danish birth, and is the gift of Mr. George M. Pullman to the city by the windy shores of Lake Michigan.

Meagre as has been our information regarding the political or "revolutionary" disturbances in Nicaragua during the past few weeks, it has been manifest from the start that they could have but one termination. The so-called "insurrection" has been merely an outbreak of opposition against the Administration of President SACAZA, and it has been so general that it was sure to result in its overthrow.
When Philanthropist Oliver Sumner Teall's active brain gets to working on a particularly good idea, nature smiles.

RICHMOND, Va., June 1 -- The steamship El Cid for the Morgan Line was successfully launched Wednesday at Newport News. In the presence of 3,000 people Miss L. Young of Cainden, N. J., christened the ship. She is the daughter of a distinguished Philadelphia business man and a niece to Superintendent Smith, whose guest she has been for some time.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- The proceedings in the United States Circuit Court to determine whether or not the World's Fair may be legally opened on Sunday were continued to-day. That the public interest in the matter is unabated was evidenced by the throng that packed the courtroom and its approaches, many ministers of the Gospel being conspicuous by their occupancy of the from benches.

LONDON, June 1 -- William Townsend, the man arrested, on a charge of having discharged a pistol in Downing Street, but really on suspicion of intent to murder Mr. Gladstone, and who was subsequently charged with, having sent to Mr. Gladstone a letter threatening to take his life, was put on trial to-day at the Old Bailey. The defense was that Townsend is insane.
The money market was quiet. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2@3 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.
Schwab vs. Sohwab was on trial yesterday before Judge McAdam of the Superior Court, and before it had proceeded very far the Judge found himself in a sorely-perplexed frame of mind.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 1 -- There is an improved demand for foreign exchange, and merchants are malting heavier remittances abroad than for many months. There is an abundance of money in the country, importers having sent little abroad during a long period, in which large sums have been received for crops exported.
WEST POINT, June 1 -- For the coming week the cadet in the United States Military Academy here can well say, as the low comedian in the farce comedy does:

To one of two things can the victory gained by the Gianta yesterday be attributed -- they either had on a batting streak or John Clarkson's right hand has lost its cunning. At any rate the New-York batsmen kept the Cleveland fielders chasing the ball all day, and won in the easiest possible manner.

Detective Sergeants Heard and Price of Inspector McLaughlin's force made an important capture yesterday morning in the person of Frank Davis, otherwise known as Sinclair, a Chicago burglar who is responsible for a number of burglaries of which the wealthy residents of the upper part of the city have been the victims.

Nearly ten years ago Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," an ambitious, modern work, with many splendid passages, was introduced to New-York in the best possible circumstances. Nilsson, Sealchi, Fursch-Madi, Novara, Del Puente, and Stagno, had the principal roles. The opera was magnificently staged, and the scenic pictures satisfied the popular ideal of the romantic glory of the Venice under the rule of the Doges.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- When the joint conference of the Board of Reference and Control from the National Commission and the local Directory or the exposition met this afternoon to discuss the controversy over Thomas, there was a determination to settle the matter without further delay. This was done by the commission receding from its position, and withdrawing the order of May 19, 1893, asking for the resignation of the Musical Director.

NEWPORT, R.L, June 1 -- There will be no more State elections held in Rhode Island under the antiquated majority system. The Senate to-day recognized the House of Representatives sufficiently to forward to that body the resolution pending for the submission to the people of the proposition to amend the Constitution by creating plurality elections.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1 -- The Harvard baseball nine beat Georgetown University this afternoon by a score of 5 to 1. The game was of especial interest because during the Spring trip of the nine Georgetown was the only college to defeat Harvard. The score in the Spring game was 3 to 2.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the erection of the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1 -- Annapolis has been favored with another fair day, fairer in its closing hours than during the morning. The best drilled company of cadets are the proud possessors of the battalion flags won in a competitive drill.

The annual parade of the Brooklyn police yesterday was the most pronounced success which the blue-coated guardians of the peace in the City of Churches have yet scored. In point of numbers as well as in the discipline and military precision of their movements, the members of the department far excelled any similar demonstration of previous years.

In Ward 34 of Bellevue Hospital, the woman's ward as it is called, there eat yesterday afternoon a comely young woman of twenty years, whose life until a little over two years ago was unburdened by care or trouble, but which since that time has been one constant struggle for existence.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 1 -- In a decision in excise cases argued before him, Judge Alton B. Parker notes the power actually conferred by the Roesch law, finding that it cannot contravene a discretion legally exercised by the Excise Commissioners, and he also holds that the local option law no longer has an existence.

Fire early yesterday morning. in the secondhand furniture store of Bernard Webel at 17 A venue D, but for the prompt and courageous conduct of Patrolman FranK Donogan of the Union Market Police Station might have caused the loss of human lives.

SARATOGA, June 1 -- The Cougregationalists, after considering the problem of the country, dexterously faced right about and attacked that of the city. Secretary Clark stated that the eleventh census showed there were 353 American cities with a population of 10,000 and upward. In 272 of these the society has been carrying on a missionary work.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 1 -- A case was heard in the United States Court of Appeals in this city to-day, the outcome of which involves the existence of all the railway traffic associations in the country, somo sixty-eight in number. It is the case of the United States vs. the TransMissouri Freight Association and the fifteen roads constituting it.

On the stage now erected for vaudeville purposes at the eastern end of the Madison Square Garden Amphitheatre. Frank C. Bostook, business manager and representative of Wombwell's Menagerie and Circus, announced yesterday the perfomance of "the world-renowned Boxing Kangaroo, Big Frank, on the occasion of its debut in the New World."

Thomas Maguire, the Treasurer of the Fourteenth Street Theatre and the Bijon Opera House, is confined to his room at 125 West Thirteenth Street with a broken nose which is awathed in linen bandages. Mr. Maguire is the victim of an assault committed Saturday night in McKeever Brothers' saloon, Fourteenth Street and Sixth Avenue, by a man whose Identity, it is alleged, has not been established.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Gov. Flower, Mrs. Flower, the Governor's private secretary, Col. Williams; Mrs. Emma Keep Schley, a sister of Mrs. Flower, and Gen. and Mrs. F.R. Halsey drove in carriages from their hotel to the New-York State Building this afternoon and spent an hour in its inspection.
The Grand Jury handed the following presentment yesterday to Judge Cowing in the Court of General Sessions:

The action of the Park Board in granting permission for a review of the Seventh Regiment by the Infanta Eulalte in Central Park aroused widespread discussion yesterday. While some people said that the injury done to the Park would be insignificant and that the Infanta ought not to be made a party to the family jar, the strong weight of public opinion was against the use of Central Park for the review.

The sale of the St. Luke's Hospital property, reported in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, formed a fruitful topic of comment during the day among real estate men. The transaction was one which had been expected, because the property has been in the market for several months, and a number of brokers were interested in trying to find a purchaser or set of purchasers.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- When the Duke of Veragua returns to New-York he will be the guest of the Nation. There was some uncertainty about it until to-day, when an understanding was reached through a telegraphic correspondence between Commander Dickins, who was detailed by the President to attend the Duke, and Mayor Gilroy and Gen. Horace Porter.

The investigation into the escape of the two colored prisoners, Furman and Walters, from the Kings County Penitentiary last Monday morning is furnishing some surprises for the Commissioners of Charities. They began the investigation at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the parlors of the big gloomy-looking building on Nostrand Avenue from which the eacape was made.

BRISTOL, R. I., June 1 -- Tho Navahoe had to-day her last sail before she starts on her long trip across the ocean. She came up from Newport and now lies at anchor off the Herreshoff Works, with her sails unbent, in preparation for the placing of the cruising rig, in which she will tempt Atlantic weather.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted at 82 5 8 @ 83 1 2 c.
Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid entertained the Infanta and her husband last night.

The big iron foundry and machine shops of J.B. J.M. Cornell, occupying the entire block bounded by Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets and Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, were entirely destroyed by a fire that was discovered just after midnight last night.

The Pittsburg ball players did the Garrison act at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. With the score a "tie" in the last inning they made a strong finish, scored four times, and won a game from their Brooklyn rivals. It was an intersting contest throughout. Until the last inning the scores were remarkaby close, and the spectators were kept in an excitabe frame of mind.

The Republicans in the Rhode Island Legislature have practically decided to keep the present State officers in office through the present year as "hold-overs," regardless of the result of the last election. But this is a matter of minor importance, since the unjust election system of the State will be amended in accordance with the terms of a resolution adopted by both houses yesterday.

Mrs. Sara B. Chase, who is on trial in the Court of General Sessions, charged with manslaughter in causing the death of Margaret Manzoni by a criminal operation, continued her testimony under cross-examination yesterday.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, June 1 -- P. M. Speculation was less active than yesterday, but prices closed materially lower. All the news was of a depressing character. The suspension of the Plankington Bank in Milwaukee was announced early in the day and checked the advance which was then in progress.

Much business was transacted at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the Mayor's office. Attorney General Rosendale and State Controller Frank Campbell were present at the meeting in reference to the transfer by the State to the city of the State's interest in Ward's Island.

NEWARK, N. J., June 1 -- A bill was filed in the Court of Chancery yesterday morning by Vice President Blake of the Domestic Sewing Machine Company, praying for the appointment of a receiver for the company. An order to show cause was signed by Vice Chancellor Van Fleet, returnable on June 2 at the Chancery Chambers in this city at 10 A. M.
RICHMOND, Va., June 1 -- Mrs. Jefferson Davis, her daughters, Miss Winnie and Mrs. Hayes, and other members of the family, will return to New-York to-morrow night.

A prospectus has been issued for the NewYork and Peekskill Rapid-Transit Company, which certainly looks well on paper. It outlines a very great undertaking. The said company is preparing to organize for the purpose of constructing a line of railroad from the Battery, in this city, to Peekskill. The total cost of the proposed road is estimated at about $84,000,000.

The trial of Alderman William McKee of Brooklyn, who is under indictment for conspiracy and fraud in connection with the disbursement of money during the Columbian celebration last October, was not continued yesterday. Owing to the continued illnessof Judge Kelly, who was obliged to leave the bench on Wednesday, the case has been adjourned until Monday at 10:30 o'clock.

LONDON, June 1 -- In the international bllliard match at Hinley's Circus Ives did magnificent work this evening. He got the balls Jammed and scored 1,540 points in one run. His play throughout the evening, however, was neater and steadier than since the beginning of the match. The score now is: Ives, still playing, 4,001; Roberts, 3,484.

The ladies in charge of the Daisy Fields Fresh-Air Home for Crippled Children have opened their house at Englewood, N. J., and their Summer work is fairly under, way. Recent additions to the list of contributions are: George C. Rand....$20.00 Elbridge T. Gerry -$50.00 Mrs. A. P. Stokes..100.00 J.H. Aloxandre... 10.00 Mrs. W. E. Dodge. 25.00 Morris K. Jesup... 20.00

Members of the National Guard in Brooklyn are talking a good deal about the result of the election the Twenty-third Regiment held for a new Major last Monday night. Many go so far as to say that the result of the balloting may be considered as nothing loss than a rebuke to the commander of the regiment, Col. John N. Partridge, but the weight of opinion is against this view of the case.

Although it has been known for some time that our wheat crop this year would be much smaller than either of the last two crops, the price of wheat at leading markets has been falling for some weeks, and on Monday it was lower in Chicago than it had been for thirty years, a few days in 1887 excepted.

HALIFAX, June 2 -- Admiral Hopkins arrived this afternoon with the war ship Blake from Bermuda. Commander Bagley of the Blake said this evening to THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S correspondent that neither himself nor Admiral Hopkins would ever forget the noble reception and kind hospitality of the New-York people.

Before the second day's sale or the Rancho del Paso yearlings yesterday. Mr. J.B. Haggin made a statement to offset assertions that the sale was not wholly fair and that there was bye-bidding. He assured purchasers that he had no interest whatever in the stable of Marcus Daly or of any other owner, and that every sale would be bona fide and to the highest bidder, whether that was Marcus Daly or any one else.

Commenting upon our suggestion that, although the bill to prevent the pollution of public water supplies was rejected at Harrisburg, Philadelphia can purify its water by the construction and use of filter beds, the Inquirer of that city says:

In order to show their joy that the year at college is dead the sophomore class of Columbia held a wake last night over the Legendres that they had wrestled with during the last eight months. Invitations were sent out asking all the class members to be present on the campus at 7:30 P.M. to take part in the parade and also to participate in the orgies.

New-York Letter to the Philadelphia Press. The result of the trial of Dr. Briggs by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church is received in New-York by the liberal wing of the Church with profound regret, though it cannot be said that liberal Presbyterians are greatly surprised. I have just had a long talk with a very prominent supporter of the views held by Dr. Briggs.

"I have in my pocket a document which, shows the size of the corns on which a pension was granted by Assistant Secretary Bussey after the Pension Office physician had declared that they did not constitute disability."

Dr. Abraham Korn of 220 East Seventy-eighth Street appeared, through counsel, before Judge Patterson, in the Supreme Court yesterday, with a petition for a writ of habeas corpus, directing Mrs. Korn to bring into court his two children, Hortanse, nineteen months old, and Nathan A., six months old.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 2 -- The Rhode Island Legislature was to-day prorogued by Gov. Brown, in accordance with the plan of the Republican leaders. The Senate accepted the adjournment and retired, bat the Democratic House of Representatives threw the Governor's proclamation into the waste basket and went on with its business.

The latest advices from Honolulu indicate that the situation there a week ago was becoming decidedly "strained," and it seemed doubtful if the provisional Government could last much longer. Its evident lack of popular support is a sufficent justification of the waiting policy which the Administration at Washington has been calmly pursuing ever since it put a stop to the rash project for the immediate annexation of the Hawaiian Islands.
The Charities Commissioners of Kings County closed the investigation yesterday into the escape of James Furman and George Walters from the Kings County Penitentiary on May 29.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Corporal James Tanner of this city put on a look of disgust tonight when asked by the correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES if he had anything to say in reply to the charges of Farnham Post of NewYork that he and his ilk control the issue of pensions.

CONCORD, N.H., June 2 -- The thirty-seventh anniversary of St. Paul's School was observed yesterday with services in the school chapel, a lunch in the gymnasium, and athletic games on the cricket field. Services ware hold in the chapel at 11 o'clock, and were conducted by the Right Rev. W.W. Niles, Bishop of New-Hampshire, assisted by the Rev. Loren Webster, Rector of Holderness School.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Cheverton, Marton Co., bankers, at Ogden Avenue and Twelfth Street, closed their doors this evening and made a voluntary assignment in the County Court to Abraham Baldwin, assignee. Assets were scheduled at $100,000 and liabilities at $70,000. According to the statement made by M.S. Marton, the junior member of the firm, this evening, the failure was due to the unsettled condition of the money market.

Several steam yachts that are being built at Seabury's yard at Nyack are last approaching completion and will soon be turned over to their owners. The largest yacht is the Embla, building for Mr. J. H. Hanan. This boat was to have been finished last month, but the continuous wet weather greatly retarded the workmen. Now, however; she is about finished and will go overboard in a few days.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Edwin Pardridge, the well-known Board of Trade man, was arrested this afternoon on a warrant sworn out by Mrs. Korzinski, who accuses him of abducting her daughter, Sarah Korzinski, sixteen years old.
RED BANK, N.J., June 2 -- E. Voorhees Skillman, a traveling salesman who is boarding here, was to-day made a defendant in a suit for $10,000 allmony instituted by Mrs. Genevieve Slaughter.

Prince Antoine and his wife, the Infanta Eulalie, enjoyed a novel experience yesterday afternoon by slipping quietly away from the watchful care of Commander Davis and Superintendent Byrnes's detectives, and, arm in arm, strolling about the streets unattended.

Railroad men and financiers in Wall Street have heard with a great deal of interest within the past few days rumors of an impending change in the control and management of the New-York and New-England Railroad. The old and oft-repeated stories that the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford people have secured control of the New-England Road, have been revived.

LONDON, June 2 -- In the debate to-day on an amendment offered by Mr. E.W. Byrne, Conservative, the Irish members showed for the first time that they thought the Government was conceding too much without consulting them. Mr. Byrne's amendment was intended to prevent the Irish Legislature from enacting laws in respect to the use of arms by armed associations for drilling purposes.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 150 @ 141, Lake Street "L" at 20, Strawboard at 57 1/2, Diamond Match at 112. Money. 6 @ 7 P cent. Bank clearings, $19,314,232. New-York exchange, 80c discount.
The Senate Committee on Immigration resumed its session yesterday morning at the New Motherland Hotel. The inquiry chiefly related to the alleged violations of the contract labor law.

BUFFALO, June 2 -- After a stay in Buffalo of five days Postmaster General Bissell departed to-night for Washington. Just before boarding his train Mr. Bissell said to the correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2 -- The farewell ball given to-night by the class of '94 to the class of '93 was a brilliant success. It has given the cadets of the second class a great deal of anxiety, but it was nearly all repaid to-night.
CHICAGO, June 2 -- Senator Donald McNaughton acted as the escort of Gov. Flower and party when, they made their second day's exploration of the World's Fair grounds.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 2 -- The tin-plate liar is likely to have hard sledding in Ohio this year. Everything is against him. The collapse of the Youngstown Stamping Works, in which McKinley's friend Walker was interested, is still fresh in the public mind, and the two other tin-plate "factories" in Northern Ohio are not prospering.

Seibricht -- Titsworth. PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 2.--In the Seventh Day Baptist Church last evening, Miss Florence Titsworth, daughter of Mr. John D. Titswortn, a New-York druggist, who resides on Madison Avenue, this city, was married to Mr. Henry Seibricht of New-Roohelle, N. Y. The Rev. Dr. A. H. Lewis, the pastor, officiated.

NEWARK, N.J., June 2 -- Daniel Geraghty, barkeeper in the saloon known as Tammany Hall, was awakened early this morning by a crash of breaking glass in the room where he was sleeping. A window pane had been broken, and through this a woman's race was seen. The woman was Emma Woods, who had been living with Lewis Brown, proprietor of the saloon, and whose house was close by.
The Island of Manhattan is having a river wall of solid granite and concrete, thirty feet in thickness, built about it.

PAULDING, Ohio, Jane 2 -- Potters Bank, the oldest bank in Paulding County, and heretofore considered one of the safest, cloned its door this morning. The bank was established in 1874 and has always done a large banking business loaning money on land in this county. Information as to the cause of the assignment is hard to get.

Bookmakers at the Guttenberg race track and at the nest of poolrooms at Fort Lee just opened have found out that John A. Morris meant what he said to a TIMES reporter when he stated that the people who tried to make a book on the races run at Morris Park at those two places should not have the information that was necessary to them to carry on their business.
The Infanta Eulalie on Monday will start for Chicago, where she is to be the recipient of hospitalities from the society and civic leaders of that city.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 2 -- A wreck in which eleven persons were injured, occurred on the Northwestern Division of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railread, near Newsums Station, at 6:40 this morning. The rear coach of Passenger Train No. 54 from Memphis, due here at 7 o'clock, jumped the track and rolled down an embankment between 30 and 40 feet high.
Its Resolutions Against Fraudulent Pensions Approved in Part by Gen. Weissert.

A peculiar phase of the World's Fair travel out of this city will be considered at a meeting of trunk line managers and general passenger agents to-day. The official statement of the number of reduced-rate tickets to Chicago, sold in this city from the 1st to tho 27th of May, inclusive, shows that the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Road has had more of that business than all the other Eastern trunk lines combined.

What is asked for -- aye, demanded -- is that the pension list shall be minutely examined. No honest pensioner will resist that; he will not be considered honest if he does. Then let every dishonest case, if such be found, be wiped from the rolls. This is only fair and right to the people of the land, the people who pay taxes.

The investigation of the Appraiser's department of the New-York Custom House was virtually finished yesterday. Several importers remain to be heard, and a few papers are to be submitted, but the main evidence is complete.

Prof. Charles A. Briggs, whom the Presbyterian General Assembly has pronounced a heretic, has returned to his home in this city. A reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES who called at his house yesterday failed to find any signs of mourning about the premises. There was no crape on the door and the window shades were up.

At a meeting of the National Cycling Association held in the Filth Avenue Hotel yesterday the schedule for the season was adopted. All the delegates are sanguine that the new project will prove a grand success. Business methods will he adopted, and it is thought that the confidence of the public will be gained.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- It does not look now as if all the graduates at West Point this Summer would find commissions in the army. There are fifty-one cadets who will be graduated, including the foreigner, who may not be admitted.

The Electric Cricket Club of Newark suffered a ing defeat at the hands of the New-Jersey Athletic Club on the grounds of the latter yesterday afternoon. The New-Jerseys rolled up a high score, eight members of the team making double figures.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 2 -- The unvailing of the new monument to Gen. Francis Marion, to replace the old tomb shattered by the earthquake ten years ago, took place on Monday, May 22, at Belle Isle, an old plantation home, part of which once belonged to Marion, in St. Stephen's Parish, about forty-five miles from Charleston.

DEDHAM, Mass., June 2 -- This forenoon Mrs. Charles H. Colburn, daughter of Congressman William F. Draper of Hopedale, and wife of the senior member of the firm of Colburn, Fuller Co., 124 Summer Street, Boston, together with her two daughters. Helen and Alice, and their coachman, Frederick A. Skillen, left their Boston residence, 381 Commonwealth Avenue, to drive to Hopedale, where they were to make a short visit.

It was not known to the port authorities of the port of New-York until within the past two days that there are at present lying at the bottom of the North River, just off West Thirty-third Street, two large scows.
Police Justice Meade, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday liberated four young men who had been arrested for reckless bicycle riding on the Boulevard. One he fined $1, the others went scot free.

A report from New-Orleans yesterday stated that Jose Martinez, a prominent member of the Cuban revolutionary party in that city, had said that a movement was on foot among his countrymen to induce the United States to buy Cuba, and that the land owners and the business people of Cuba would be willing themselves to pay one-half of the cost of the purchase of the island.

Either Morris Park track wan as fast as lightning yesterday, or else the watches of the timekeepers were slow. In the opening race of the afternoon, a dash of five furlongs, Gold Dollar, the favorite in the betting and the winner of the dash, made a record of 0:57 1/2, which was within a half second of the record at the distance, made by Dr. Hashrouck last October.

Clement W. Scott, the well-known London dramatic critic and author, is in the city on his way home after a prolonged tour around the world. He has been in Chicago for the last two months, where he was specially engaged to write descriptive articles on the World's Fair or the London Daily Telegraph.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 2 -- It is practically assured that the undergraduate rule, which has caused such long, spirited debates at Yale the past six months, is a dead letter. As a compromise of the struggle, a committee consisting of the Captains of the athletic teams and representative members of all departments of the university was appointed to draw up a substitute rule three months ago.
Stephen W. Bassett, stenographer to Appraiser Cooper, was suspended yesterday on charges of absence from duty without leave. He has been in the Customs Service since 1877.
LONDON, June 2 -- The usual list of titles bestowed on fortunate commoners in honor of her Majesty's birthday shows that a phenomenal proportion has fallen to gentlemen connected with the press.
Clubs and clubmen will be interested in the decision of the Jekyl Island Club to admit women to full membership, with all the club rights and privileges accorded to men.

The decision of Mayor Gilroy, conveyed in a telegram to Commander Dickins, that upon the return visit of the Duke of Veragua to New-York he must come as a guest of the Nation and not as a guest of the city excited varied comment yesterday. When a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES saw the Mayor this afternoon, he said:

Wall Street interest in the National Cordage Company's reorganization was revived by the news published yesterday morning that some of the creditors of individuals and firms who lost heavily through the collapse of the trust had been settled with on a basis of 30 per cent. in cash and 70 per cent. in notes.
WEST POINT, June 2 -- The usual crowd that falls all over West Point during the first week of June has not materialized up to date and the delay is charged to the weather.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 2 -- The Rev. Newman Smythe of the Centre Church of this city has this to say in regard to the charges on which Prof. Briggs has been condemned: "The action of the Presbyterians in condemning Prof. Briggs is almost too ridiculous to grow indignant over. It is beat to treat it lightly and it is sure to be so regarded by the world of scholars.

TAHLEQUAH, Indian Territory, June 2 -- The failure to raise $6,500,000 on the Cherokee Strip bonds has caused a commercial crisis in the Territory. J. W. Staples Son, who have been the principal traders on the Strip fund, at once discontinued credit sales. Their action was followed immediately by nearly all the general merchants of the place, and now no goods are sold on the Strip money.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- There are two interesting cases before the Navy Department of officers who are up for examination for promotion. One is that of Commander George W. Wood, who is before the examining board. He is eligible for promotion to the grade of Captain, and there is some doubt whether he will be advanced.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted at 82 7/8 @ 83 1/2c.

Acting District Attorney Weeks was kept busy yesterday examining witnesses concerning the death, of Bernhard H. Gueterbock, city editor of the Staats-Zeitung, at his home, 175 East Seventy-ninth Street, last Saturday night.

The huge fitting shop of J.B. J.M. Cornell, the iron founders, which occupied the whole block bounded by Twenty-sixth and Twentyseventh Streets and Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, lay a vast and smoldering heap of ruins yesterday. The fire, which broke out in the building at midnight on Thursday, completely destroyed it, and so damaged its contents, which consisted of valuable stock, plant and machinery, as to cause nearly $400,000 loss.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Nine New-Yorkers went on record to-day as applicants for positions under the Secretary of the Treasury.

"On the 6th of December, 1648, Col. PRIDE, with two regiments, surrounded the Houses of Parliament and, seizing in the passage forty-one members of the Presbyterian party, sent them to a low room, then called HelL Above 160 other members were excluded and none admitted but the most furious of the Independents.

The wheat dealings were larger to-day, and especially on export account, with some large purchases, as well at the West, by shippers who have been encouraged by the low prices; after a firm opening there was a decline of 1 @ 1 1/4c, and the close is 3/8 @ 5/8c under yesterday. In corn there was more activity, with prices 1/8 @ 1/2c lower on increases supplies.

SHARON SPRINGS, N.Y., June 2 -- Evidence of the near arrival of the Summer guest is apparent on every hand. At the various hotels the carpenter, painter, and decorator hold full away, while the sound of the hammer, heard far into the night, and occasional glimpses of busy men in dimly-lighted rooms, attest the celerity with which work is being pushed to completion.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 2 -- The new Senatorial apportionment and the unconstitutionality of the law were the only subjects of discussion in political circles here to-day. There was a general feeling of indignation among the rank and file of the Democratic legislators that such an error as the omission of the entire town of Riverside should have been allowed to creep into the bill.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 2 -- Judge George B. Bradley of the Supreme Court sat in the court House library yesterday afternoon reading Judge Parker's decision upon the question of local option in this State. After a careful perusal of the article he stopped to a shelf and took down a copy of the session laws of 1892.

A consignment of highly-bred and good-looking, well-mannered saddle and driving horses, consigned by Grenside McGibbon from the Guelph Stables, Ontario, Canada, were yesterday sold by William Easton at Tattersalls. Seventh Avenue nod Fifty-fifth street. The bidding was brisk throughout, fair prices being realized, twenty-nine head selling for an average of over $250. Those that sold for $300 or over were:

"We hope to reach $3,000," said Mrs. Albion P. Strout, Chairman of the Brooklyn Methodist Hospital Fair, yesterday. "Our expenses have been about $500, and they have been fully cleared by our paper, the Hospital Journal. Of course it will be impossible to state definitely the amount we shall clear until all the accounts are settled up, but if it is much short of $3,000 I shall be surprised."

The debt statement for the month of May was issued yesterday. It shows a reduction of $657,175.50 in the debt of the Government and an increase of $82,250.49 in the cash in the Treasury, making a decrease in the net debt of $739,425.99. The gold reserve is reported at $95,048,640.

NEWARK, June 2 -- Mrs. Lucy H. Clark, as she calls herself, has made application to Vice Chancellor Van Fleet for an order compelling Joseph Ramsey Clark, whom she claims for a husband, to maintain her.

There may be a deal of truth in the oftrepeated assertion that mammon reigns in the minds of New-Yorkers and makes their lives seem to be tending always to the goal of the greatest accumulation, but it is just as true that in their hearts a shrine is kept for charity.

A heavily-built Italian entered the saloon of T.S. Manning at 238 Conover Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and offered a five-dollar bill in payment for a can of beer. The bill appeared to be good and was changed. The Italian's haste aroused the bartender's suspicions. He held the bill up to the light and at once detected the absence of the silk strands which appear in good money.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Argument in the case of the Government against the exposition authorities for an injunction against the opening of the gates on Sunday was concluded to-day. This morning-Attorney High, on behalf of the Government, made the closing address, reviewing the arguments already advanced and insisting upon the absolute character of the governmental control.

The indignation meeting which was to have been held last evening in Madison Hall. Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twentyfith Street, for the purpose of protesting against the action of the Rapid-Transit Commission in refusing the offer of the Manhattan Railway Company as to extending their road, was again postponed.
The Produce Exchange annual election will take place next Monday, and yesterday afternoon a caucus was held to put a ticket in the field.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Daniel G. Griffin or Watertown, member of the Democratic State Committee, and Thomas Spratt of Ogdensburg are at the Arlington.

NEWARK, June 2. -- Vice Chancellor Van Fleet to-day named Judge Kirkpatrick of the Essex County courts to act as receiver of the Domestic Sewing Machine Company. He accepted the appointment and has filed bonds in $150,000.
Good pitching by Ehret and clever playing by the Pittsburgs won a game from the Brooklyns yesterday. One of the features was the clever batting of Bierbaner. Shugart and Daly led in the field work.

The New-Yorks lost another game by one run yesterday, the Clevelands winning in ten innings by a score of 8 to 7, the same figures as in the defeat of Wednesday. The Giants nave lost three games this week -- two to Cleveland and one to Cincinnati -- by a single run and it mast be admitted that they are playing in poor luck.
Otherwise, Says Mr. Byrnes, He Wouldn't Have Made His Charge Against the Police.

In a private room at the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning, Police Justice Ryan and Detective John J. Claney of Trenton, N.J., were the causes of two very unexpected moves in the troubles which have arisen since the Barnegat Park (N.J.) Land and Improvement Company figured in the courts early in April.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., June 2 -- Thomas Moore was arraigned in Justice Ransom's court to-day charged with setting fire to his house in Kings Park last March. He says the insurance company has been misinformed and its suspicions aroused by his enemies.

The Supplement of the London Economist of May 20 gives in a summary form the statements, so far as they are accessible, of the banks of England and Wales, Scotland, Ireland, and of the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands, and also those of the colonial banks. It contains some very interesting facts.

As was exclusively published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, there were two tickets in the field at the annual election of the Church Club, on Wednesday night, at the clubhouse, 146 Fifth Avenue. There was a strong feeling of opposition to a part of the regular ticket and a members', or opposition, ticket won.

DANBURY, Conn., June 2 -- The unveiling and dedication of the Soldiers and Sailors' Memorial Window in the new Baptist Church here this afternoon was the occasion of an elaborate demonstration. Commander in Chief A.G. Weissert of the Grand Army of the Republic was present, arriving from his home. Milwaukee, at 11:30 A.M.

WHITE PLAINS, June 2 -- Surrogate Owen T. Coffin of Westchester County rendered his decision Thursday in one of the most extraordinary will contests ever known in Westchester County. The contest was over the will of Jane Nevins of Yonkers.

Foreign visitors to this city often comment on the absence of artistic statues of great men in our public places and about our municipal buildings. Knowing as they do that there are plenty of men whose memories could be fittingly honored by statues, they think it strange that there are not more erected in the metropolis of America.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The report of the Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy, as amply reported in THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S dispatch from Annapolis, provoked discussion in the department to-day, as a matter of course. Almost all of the recommendations made by the sub-committees, to be embodied in the final report, are approved.

The police of Jersey City Heights were informed yesterday that an old man was making a maddening racket in a building at 41 Paterson Street. An officer found Frederick Steger, sixty-seven years old, almost naked and hungry, imprisoned there. He was attacking the wall of one of the rooms with a crowbar in the hope of getting out. He was sent to Jail to await an inquiry as to his mental condition.

OSTRICH FARMING -- When ostrich farming was in its prime, some thirty years ago, they had been imported at vast expense from the North. Every eight months or so, as feathers matured, as many as could be circumvented were caught and plucked. Incessantly galloping for many miles over the veld in ever-lessening arcs we gradually drove them inward to the mouth of a funnel-shaped pen.

The germ of this volume was an address delivered three years ago by Dr. Peddle before the Harleian Society, and afterward reprinted in one of the Scotch medical journals. Friends have since suggested that it be expanded and issued as a small volume, which might take the place of a formal biography.

The Second Avenue Railroad is about to make a thorough test of the storage battery system of the Waddell-Entz Electric Company. A plant has been constructed in the car barns at One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Second Avenue, and to-morrow three cars will begin making regular trips between One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Ninety-sixth Street, and other cars will be added as rapidly as men can be instructed to operate them.

A guide to travel in the United States prepared by foreigners, primarily for the use of foreigners, is a novelty. There is no end of guides, "dictionaries," and "directories" of America of home manufacture, but no American seems yet to have mastered the art of making a perfect guide book.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 3 -- Runs are being made to-day, as yesterday, on all the banks in the city practically in a greater or less degree.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The statement of the United States Treasurer, showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day, is as follows:

Men still argue the question whether we are to believe that Jenner was a human benefactor or that inoculation, so far from being a cure, is prone to spread diseases that are worse than smallpox. Mr. William Tebb's volume is not to be compared with any ordinary work. It shows the utmost care in its preparation, and is the result of long study.

Nothing is now wanted but fair weather to make the open-air horse show, which begins to-morrow, an assured success. In comparison with the entries made last year those recorded for competition this year show an enormous increase, as there are actually more than 800 classified, so that in almost every department or breed double the number of exhibits will be made than were seen at the initial show.

Three weeks ago Maty Modrit, an immigrant from one of the provinces of Austria, reached this country. The same vessel that brought him brought also a letter to the Immigration Commissioner, signed by one Ivan Bradic, a fellow-townsman of Modrit.
The formal opening of the new home of Good Government Club A at 722 Lexington Avenue last evening was a great success.

HUDSON, N.Y., June 3 -- The case of the People ex rel. against the Board of State Canvassers of 1891 came up before Judge Edwards in Special Term to-day, on a motion to show cause why the board should not be punished for contempt of court for canvassing the Mylod certificates from the Fifteenth Senate District in 1891.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., June 3 -- For a month the beautiful Water Gap has been entertaining its first guests of the season, and rarely have its powers of entertainment been so advantageously set forth. The month has been perfect. The Gap has always been one of the first of the near-by resorts to open its gates, but there have rarely been so many early visitors as now.
