The official returns of the admissions and receipts at the Columbian Exhibition for the whole of the month of May ought to give a more trustworthy indication than we have had heretofore of the financial success of the fair. The total number of paid admissions for the month is given officially at 1,077,233, representing the receipt of $538,616.50.

The Rev. Joseph Silverman of the Temple Emanu-El, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, preached yesterday upon the topic, "Religious Liberty and the World's Fair," involving the question of Sunday closing.
OMAHA, Neb., June 3 -- In the midst of a heavy rainstorm, fire broke out in a block on Farnum Street, occupied by the Shiverick Furniture Company.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Next week will fail to pat forth any absolute novelties among the downtown theatres. The most interesting of the opening engagements will be at Hooley's, where Mr. E.S. Willard, the sterling English actor who has become a pronounced favorite in Chicago, will open for a long season.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- A ruling far-reaching in its importance and of interest to every Federal office holder in the country has been made by Justice Bradley of the District Circuit Court. It is to the effect that the courts have the right to inquire as to the sufficiency of the cause of removal in the cases of discharged Government employes holding office under the civil service laws and regulations.

LENOX, Mass., June 3 -- The early season in Lenox has fairly opened and many of the cottagers are here. Most of them will remain about two months before taking their annual outing at the seashore, and a number of them will visit the World's Fair in September and October. Many have come back from a pre- liminary visit to the fair, but expect to go again later, when there will be more to see.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 3 -- At noon to-day Miss Emma Lawrence Jacob, the daughter of Mr. Leonard Jacob, was married to Mr. George H.A. Elin of Leahoe, England, in St. Paul's Church, Glen Cove. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel Maxwell, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. L.M. Bakkelon of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The bride wore a simple, but elegant, wedding dress of white satin and crepe de chine.

OBELISKS OUT OF PLACE -- A few years ago the favorite drive of visitors in Alexandria was to see the obelisks known as "Cleopatra's Needles," but now both of them have gone; they stood before the palace or Sebasteum, whose site a stone mason's yard and Ramleh Station probably occupy, and the connection of them with the notorious Queen is now quite exploded.

CAPE CHARLES, Va., June 3 -- President Cleveland and party left Broadwater Clubhouse at 6 o'clock this morning to try their luck at fishing for the last time before taking their departure for home, and at 1 o'clock this afternoon the President walked into the clubhouse to prepare for the homeward trip.

FOOD OPPORTUNITIES WASTED -- A unique opportunity for eating an extinct monster was lost when the Siberian mammoth was discovered, incased in ice -- the first instance, we suppose, of frozen meat on record. But, in the matter of flesh, the proverb of "One man's meat is another man's poison" still holds good.
Two men detained for observation at Bellevue Hospital, suspected of having typhus fever, escaped from the hospital early yesterday morning and are still at large.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., June 3 -- Charles Landenburg of Far Rockaway is missing. So are the gold watch and chain and handsome engagement ring of Miss Jennie Kane. A wedding that was to have been celebrated last Sunday evening has been indefinitely postponed and a sea of troubles has beset several worthy people as the result of Mr. Landenburg's flight.

The past weak among real estate men has been rather eventful and the transactions have afforded much food for thought. The largest of the transactions called to public notice, namely, the sale of the St. Luke's Hospital property, has had a marked effect in recalling to the minds of many the fact that a demand exists for city property even when financial conditions are not of the best.

The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America will convene at Asbury Park, N.J., next Wednesday. One of the principal topics to come up for discussion will be the proposed union between the Reformed Church in America and the German Reformed Church.

THE TEMPLARS -- The Templars gradually bought up the lands of various ruined Barons, and became as powerful as did the Canons of the Holy Sepulchre and other great orders of ecclesiastics, whose lands -- widely spread over the best of the conquered districts -- were for the most part gifts of Kings or of pious nobles.
The wonder is that something did not tip up yesterday when the gangplanks of the outwardbound fleat were hanled in.

THE INCONCEIVABLE PROBLEM -- The volume occupied by this stupendous globe, [of ours] which includes within it all possible visible material, must be but a speck when compared with the space which contains it. Think of the water in the Atlantic Ocean, and think of the water in a single drop.

Ruskin's name having been mentioned in connection with the Laureateship, it is of interest to place on record his impressions of Southey and Wordsworth, both Poets-Laureate; Miss May Richardson, Ruskin's cousin and adopted sistor, writes in their journal:

The first meeting of the Interclub Association of Kings County took place yesterday afternoon at the Knickerbocker Field Club Courts, Eighteenth Street and Avenue A. Flatbush. The events of interest were the opening rounds of the women's singles and the women's doubles. Long before the players were ready to begin work the Knickerbocker Clubhouse and grounds adjacent were thronged with the followers of the game who had gathered to witness the matches.

Policeman James Spotton of the Twenty-fifth Precinct says that at 7 P.M. on May 30 Ambulance Surgeon Whittaker of the Presbyterian Hospital told him that Gottlieb Metzger, a young cooper of 334 East Fifty-fourth Street, who had been round with a bloody head at the foot of the rocks south of East Seventy-fourth Street, had two scalp wounds. Dr. Whittaker took Metzger away in an ambulance.

It would have been a most ungracious thing for the Judges before whom the application to restrain the Directors of the fair from opening it on Sunday was brought to issue a temporary injunction in advance of their decision upon the issue of a permanent injunction. A temporary injunction is proper when there is reasonable apprehension that somebody's rights will be invaded, or some waste or mischief done before the main question can be decided.

BEQUESTS OF BOOKS -- About the close of the fourteenth, century Londoners began to mention gifts of books in their wills, and Simon Bristowe, clerk, 1374, leaves his portifory with music lying in quires to the Church of St. Mary Aldermanbury. John de Kenyngton, rector of St. Dunstan's toward the Tower, left a book of the Epistles to that church, and also money to buy books.

The United States sloop-of-war Mohlcan, the flagship of the Bering Sea patrol fleet, is at Port Townsend in company with the revenue steamer Bear. All the vessels of the patrol fleet will be in Bering Sea waters, it is thought, by June 15.

Miss Ottille Stelter of 330 East Seventy-fifth Street, about twenty-six years old, went to the Grand Union Hotel yesterday afternoon about 5:30 and registered from 33 Duffield Street, Brooklyn. She was given Room 5, on the top floor.

NEWARK, June 3 -- A number of witnesses stepped to the front to-day to say for Emma Woods, who shot Saloon Keeper "Lew" Brown, at their home on Warren Street yesterday morning, that Brown had frequently beaten her. She had, they said, complained two or three times to the police, and on one occasion her face showed signs of ill-treatment.

The editor of this correspondence of Friedrich Froebel writes frankly of the troublesome character of his task. The letters have never been printed before, but an exact translation of them was hardly possible. The deciphering of many of them was difficult, and they could not be translated literally.

Two more cases of absolute need have come to the notice of the Charity Organization Society, and, in view of the readiness with which its appeal for the blind newsdealer and his wife, published recently in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, was answered, another request for aid is now made, and it is hoped that the responses will be as prompt and generous as they were in the former instance.

No good citizen can think of the services of the brave soldier boys and tolerate for a moment the idea that a single one of them should be deprived of his dues under the laws of the land which he helped to save. But, on the other hand, good citizens cannot tolerate the existence of fraud upon the Government.

The Seventh Regiment was reviewed yesterday afternoon by the Infanta Eulalie. Very early a crowd began to gather in the Plaza facing the Hotel Savoy, and hour by hour it grew and grew, until it taxed the resources of the police to keep it within bounds. It was estimated that 20,000 people were there.

Elizabeth G. Jordan contributes to a late Lippincoll's a trenchant paper on me of the requisites and characteristics of the newspaper woman. "If she be wise," says Miss Jordan, "self-confidence is the journalistic armor she will select first and wear on the outside. With self-confidence there are other qualifications which she must possess.

Those society stars, Belmont Tiffany, Howland Robbins, and the young coaching celebrity of Brooklyn, Frank Board, have been playing an engagement in," The Prodigal Daughter,'' now running at the American Theatre. They have acted as supes for two evenings amid great applause. Their roles confine them to standing on one of he coaches and cheering the steeplechase.
"We want our money. It's long overdue, and we can't get it."

ON THE EATING OF RABBITS -- The golden rule is to see that the rabbit is in condition. For rabbits prematurely arrive at that venerable age when they have something of the muskiness of the he goat or the alligator. Being so plentiful, there is neither object nor advantage in ''hanging" them -- beyond, of course, the reasonable time.

On one of the little farms near the border of Westchester County lives "Old George Root." Everybody in that part of the country seems to know him, and many of his friends object to his living alone. The old man will not be persuaded; he prefers to stay as he is.

DECATUR, Ill., June 3 -- Twenty-five men walked into this city of 22,000 people this morning and lynched a negro on the principal street without meeting any opposition. The victim was Samuel Bush, accused of assaulting two white women.
Four persons lost their lives in a fire that started in the Vanderbilt flats at 138 East Forty-third Street last night.

The royal visitors from Spain were astir early yesterday morning at the Hotel Savoy. At 10:40 Princess Eulalie, Prince Antoine, and Gen. Fitzgerald entered a carriage, and, followed in other carriages by Mayor Gilroy, the Duke and Marchioness d'Arco Hermosa, Editor Julio de Vargus, Admiral Vegas of the Infanta Isabel, and Commander Davis, started down Fifth Avenue.

Adolph Sodenburg, a wealthy retired merchant, who lives at 144 East Fifty-eighth Street, this city, was caught at an early hour yesterday morning trying to jump from the dock at the foot of Division Street, Brooklyn. He had removed his hat and coat and was on his knees praying loudly, when a watchman saw him.

The sailor hat is one of the perennial Jokes of millinery. The milliners perpetrate it afresh with every new season, and the women smile at it and appreciate it as though they never had seen it before. This season the sailor comes out enlarged and, well, yes, improved, on the whole, though some of the specimens are quite astonishing in size.

It was announced officially on May 14 that the Cities of Lorient and Quimper, on the coast of France, about 100 miles north of the mouth of the Loire, were free from cholera. For two or three months there had been an epidemic of the disease in Lorient, the presence of which was concealed from the outside world until a mortality report was published by the British postal authorities.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 3 -- Eugene and Frank D'Autreville, young men living in the Astoria section of Long Island City, boarded a horsecar on Flushing Avenue last evening in a hilarious condition. One of them hugged a pretty school teacher. She appealed to the conductor, who put the men off the car. A fusilade of stones followed the car, smashing the windows and creating general fright.

Francis Fackenberg was stricken with typhus fever at Bellevue Hospital yesterday and was removed to North Brother Island. Fackenberg was employed as librarian at the hospital and has lived there for some years.

"Do you think you could teach an old dog now tricks?" asked a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter of Prof. W. S. Shedman, who has been training dogs and exhibiting them for years, and whose dogs Jim Casaidy, Nulsance, Gypsy Swipes, and others amused the visitors to the pet dog show at the Lenox Lyceum last week.

Senator George Roesch was at the Tammany Club in his district last night when a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter dropped in to ask him his opinion of the construction put on the so-called "Roesch certiorari act" by Judge Alton B. Parker and Judge George B. Bradley of the Supreme Court, summaries of which have been printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

INCIDENTS AND GOSSIP OF LAST WEEK -- The exodus of fashionable people from town has fairly set in. Every day last week express wagons piled high with trunks and boxes taxed the patience of the baggage-masters at the railway stations and steamship piers, and many of these busy handlers of trunks and bags swore away what remained of their good dispositions.

It was an ideal day for racing yesterday, just as it was an ideal day for any outdoor sport. Morris Park as a result was the resort of more people than have been at the track any day this year, even though there was to be no Metropolitan Handicap decided. But the management had provided a programme that fairly bristled with good things, and there was such a crowd as the card deserved.

It was ladies' day at the beautiful grounds of the New York Athletic Club on Travers Island yesterday, and of the 4,000 or more who clustered round the clubhouse or the track more than one-half were young women.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., June 3 -- Lehigh lost the game of lacrosse with the University of Toronto here to-day by score of 9 to 3. The game was to decide the intercollegiate championship of America, as the University of Toronto held the championship of Canada and Lehigh that of the United States.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 3 -- The 3,000 coal miners of the Osage fields went out to-day, making over 10,000 miners now engaged in the strike in this State alone. M.L. Walters, President of the United Mine Workers' Association, Tenth District, will visit the four camps in Missouri, near the Kansas line, and call out the 4,000 miners at work there.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- With the dropping of the Treasury gold supply to a figure lower than it has yet been, there is as yet none of the alarm manifested just before it was decided to use gold included in the $100,000,000 reserved for resumption purposes.

John E. Risley, the United States Minister to Denmark, is at the Gilsey House somewhat ill. He had the grip a short time ago, and, as one of its after-effects, suffered from a heart trouble that was serious for a time, but he is now regaining his health, although the original trouble and the complications following have left him so weak that he is confined to his room most of the time.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Controller Eckels is determined that bank Directors shall know the obligations they assume when they become such, and with that object in view has had a circular printed containing the sections of the law defining the duties and obligations of bank Directors. When a new bank is established a copy of this circular will be forwarded to each Director.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- The entrance examinations for admission to the regular academy course, as well as to the John C. Green School of Science, will be held in Princeton June 15, 16, and 17. All candidates for examination must report at the Faculty room in the college offices the evening before the examination, or immediately on their arrival the following morning.

President Ransom of the National Bank of Deposit returned yesterday from Washington, where he had been conferring with the Controller of the Currency as to the winding up of the bank's affairs, and the work of securing signatures to the agreement of depositors to a liquidation was continued.

The educational work carried on by the Reform Club through public meetings last year is about to be resumed in New-Hampshire, where W.B. Estell, one of the speakers of the club, has gone upon invitation of some of the non-resident members of the club and their friends.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Herman Schaffner Co., private bankers, the largest private concern in this city or in the Northwest dealing exclusively in commercial paper, and about the oldest one of its kind in Chicago, made a complete assignment to-day.

BOSTON, June 3 -- The twice-postponed production, at the Park Theatre, of Fred Miller, Jr.'s, new comic opera -- or "ballet comedy," as he prefers to call it -- occurred on Monday evening, and it has drawn large audiences throughout the week. It contains many melodies that are tuneful and "catchy," and the dialogue -- Mr. Miller is also the librettist -- is breezy, sometimes bright, and often funny, and the action la spirited.

At a meeting of the Washington Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, last evening, a committee consisting of Frank Harvey Field, William D. Banoker, Willis Fletcher Johnson, William H. Allee, and Albert C. Hale presented a set of resolutions, which were unanimously adopted, upon the retirement of their pastor, the Rev. Edward Braislin, who resigned his charge to regain health and strength. The resolutions were as follows:

With to-night closes the brief vandeville season at the Madison Square Garden which started out with some hopes on the part of the management of making it a midsummer night's entertainment. The difficulty of entertaining an audience with song and dance in so large an auditorium was apparent, however, and a return to the former policy of the Garden was determined upon by the managers after the first few performances.

BERLIN, June 3 -- The electoral campaign is proceeding calmly, on the whole, but the activity of the several parties does not abate, and all the various factions are striving in every way to secure the election of their candidates. New candidates are appearing daily, and from platform and press the usual political froth is flowing in streams, more noticeable for their noise than for any great depth.

It is rather strange that, while the Republican members of a committee of the Connecticut Legislature have reported in favor of the adoption of the blanket ballot and the Australian system of voting, the Democrats prefer tinkering the present very imperfect law. Every step in ballot reform toward securing absolute secrecy and shutting off all chance of bribery has resulted for the benefit of the Democratic Party.

The filing of their report with Judge Lippin cott yesterday by Marens Beach and others, Commissioners appointed to condemn Pennsylvania Railroad property needed by the_Junction Railway Company at the Point of Rocks, in Jersey City, ends one phase of a bitterly-contested railroad litigation.

WEST POINT, June 3 -- The Board of Visitors avoided the intricate and difficult examinations in mathematics in the library to-day and devoted the morning to looking after the Commissary and Quartermaster's Departments of West Point, which are in charge of Capt. Spurgin Twenty-first Infantry, Cadet Quartermaster and Commissary, and of Capt. William H. Miller, Assistant Quartermaster United States Army, Quartermaster of the Military Academy and Post Quartermaster.
The Trustees of Columbia College have decided to proceed with their plans for building their new university on the site recently secured on Riverside Heights, overlooking the Hudson.

BOSTON, June 3 -- This was the last day of the Country Club's Spring meeting, and about 1,600 people, largely of the fashionable set in Boston and Brookline, were present at Clyde Park, Brookline. There were some exciting races, and this time there was no accident or unpleasant event of any sort to mar the sports. The cadet Band made the music. The steeplechase was the most interesting, that for the hunters being especially so.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- The World's Fair will be open at least one more Sabbath, despite the proceedings that have occupied the attention of the United States court during the present week. Judge Woods announced this morning that there were several law points involved in the arguments that required careful attention and consideration, and that in consequence the court had decided to take no immediate action.

Angling, or fishing for sport, is the art of capturing fish with either an artificial or natural bait placed on a hook. It is of great antiquity. We read of it in the Old Testament. In the records of ancient Egypt and Assyria, and in the polished literature of old Greece and Rome. The Greek post, Oppian, in his "Halientics," written in the second century, gave to the world the first systematic treatise on fishing.

The Paris, which sailed yesterday had, among her passengers the advance guard of Augustin Daly's forces for the opening of his new theatre in Leicester Square, London. Among her passengers were Ada Rehan, the leading lady of his company, and maid; Richard Dorney, business manager of the organization, and Henry Widmer, the musical director of Daly's.

There was a great commotion early yesterday morning in the tenement house at 104 Essex Street. It was caused by the advent and capture of a desperate burglar, who in his efforts to escape stabbed and slightly wounded two of his captors.

"Uncle" Anson won a fine up-hill game at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. The Brooklyns started off at a rapid pace, and soon had a lead of 4 runs. This did not appear to disconcert big "Anse" in the least. He kept pegging away with commendable gameness, and in the sixth inning managed to get within 2 runs of his opponents.

The musical commentator of London Truth describes Leoncavallo's "I Pagliacci" thus: "Mme. Melba is married to a husband in her own sphere, who, like her, is engaged in the Thespian profession. He is kind and indulgent and loves her very dearly, but will stand no nonsense, and in a half-earnest, half-ironical solo he marks very clearly the enormous difference between lovemaking on the stage and in private life.

One of the most important recommendations made by the Board of Visitors at Annapolis is that there shall be greater opportunity for practical work in the proposed six-year course. At first sight it seems as if this recommendation was not in need of any support, but the fact that successive boards have again and again called attention to the fact that the naval cadets needed more facilities for practical instruction proves that support is required.

Inspector McLaughlin said yesterday to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter that he did not believe the story told by the burglar Frank Davis, alias Sinclair, that he had attempted to commit suicide by swallowing his suspender buckles while in a cell at Police Headquarters.

Hans Peter Holst, teacher, novelist, dramatist, and poet, died in Copenhagen yesterday. He was born in Copenhagen Oct. 22, 1811. In 1836 he was professor of Danish and of logic; in 1837, the popular compiler of the "Dansk Laesebog"; in 1838, of the "Nytaarsgave"; in 1843, or the "Nye Romancer," collections of novels and poems of Danish authors made in an elevated tone of nationalism.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 3 -- Three thousand spectators saw the third annual bicycle tournament of the Ansonia Wheelmen's Club at the Derby Trotting Park this afternoon. It was the first appearance of J.S. Johnson, "the kite track fiend," in this part of the State, and interest centred in his work. He scooped two first prizes handily out of the three leading races of the day.

MONTREAL, June 3 -- The little passenger steamer Bon Esprit, with about fifty persons on board, had a narrow escape from being dashed to pieces in the Lachine Rapids, just above the City of Montreal, yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3 -- The market opened weak, but soon recovered and became steady. The closing was fractionally lower than the best of the day. Traction stocks, which broke so badly yesterday, were steady but dull. Metropolitan sold at par for small lots, and Philadelphia at 98 1/2 on limited sales. Baltimore was weak and neglected around 21.

The one hundred and twelfth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York will be opened next Tuesday afternoon at the Masonic Hall, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Representatives of over 700 subordinate lodges in the State will be present to review the events of the past year and to legislate for the coming year.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 3 -- Harvard 'Varsity nine defeated Yale Law School by one run to-day. The game was close and well played.

BOSTON, Mass., June 3 -- A.A. McLeod's resignation as a Director of the Boston and Maine Railroad was accepted at a meeting of the Directors yesterday. The board decided to defer the election of a President until a meeting to be held on the 27th inst. Following is the text of Mr. McLeod's resignation as President of the company:

Little cards have been distributed throughout the city recently, announcing that the Fort Lee Turf Commissioners were now ready for business on the Morris Park, Guttenberg, and Gloucester race tracks.

The willingness or the Park Board to surrender Central Park to the Seventh Regiment for the purpose of a review, although the project was abandened in the face of public protest, has aroused an uneasy feeling among the true lovers of the Park.
A woman writing in a weekly journal talks very sensibly of some matters touching the treatment of children, which are pertinent to all mothers. She Says:

It is hoped by some Brooklyn taxpayers still capable of hoping that when District Attorney Ridgway places Alderman Arthur J. Heaney and the other officials on trial for their part in the Columbian frauds, he will see to it that the jury is kept free from Secretaries of corporations which are every now and then asking for favors from the Common Council.

When M. EMILE ZOLA delivered his much-talked-of address at the banquet of "The General Association of Students" on the 18th of May he stuck very closely to the programme he had announced and to which we have already alluded. His text, practically, was "A man who works is always good," but his introduction was long and elaborate and constituted the body of the speech.

The boys of the Berkeley School had a regatta yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River, off Morris Dock. Five rowing races and one swimming race were hotly contested. A crowd of visitors congregated in the pretty little boathonse of the school, and they seemed to thoroughly enjoy the sport. The course was three-quarters of a mile in length. The water was smooth and the wind was very light.
The regular Summer season of Eldorado, the amusement resort on the Palisades, will open Saturday, June 17.

Alice Kirkland, thirty-four years old, of 424 West Forty-fifth Street, the daughter of James W. Kirkland, a piano manufacturer, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for writing threatening letters. The case was continued until June 14.

The air is full of dress reform. At the recent congress in Chicago the models which women are asked to follow were duly set forth and the advantages of short skirts, easy bodices, and lightened weight were attentively examined and discussed.

EVOLUTION OF BASEBALL -- Once a prehistoric man, in sport or anger, threw a cocoanut at a prehistoric friend. This had occurred before. But the method of the assailed had in it something of novelty in his dealing with the missile. He did not move aside out of its path.

HAVANA, June 3 -- Our local papers are giving their readers long accounts of the grand reception of the Spanish Princess by the Government and people of the United States, and all are watching these attentions with the most fervent expressions of regard.

"For six months I have been looking for positive evidence against this man, Alfred Adrin, who has been engaged in the infamous traffic of kidnapping young girls for disorderly houses, and I have succeeded at last," said Capt. Gallagher of the Eighteenth Precinct, in East Twenty-second Street, to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

LONDON, June 3 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Reassembling this week after the holidays the Commons leaves an extremely grim impression of Gladstone. For the first time he seems to acknowledge his age and to bow before the impending shears. The old man, always courtesy itself, seems to have taken on transfiguration garments.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Although it has been open to visitors since May 1, the battle ship Illinois, which epitomizes the United States Government's naval exhibit, held its first formal reception to-night. The ship has been illuminated by electricity for some time, but owing to the pressure of other matters the company which supplied the electric plant had not completed several minor details.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The visit of Gen. James Longstreet last week to the field of Gettysburg and the funeral ceremonies of Jefferson Davis have recalled many of the incidents of the war among the old soldiers of the First Corps of the Army of Northern Virginia. And not the least interesting of them is the quarrel of Gen. Longstreet with the President of the Southern Confederacy and its making up.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- The guests of the Hotel Metropole, Twenty-third Street and Michigan Avenue, were greatly shocked this morning when it became noised about the fashionable hostelry that Thomas G. McLaury, who had lived at the hotel with his wife and children for the past two years, had taken his own life by cutting his throat with a razor.

STRANGE NESTING PLACES -- Sparrows are proverbially audacious. Two recently reared their frail habitation in a railway signal box, unmindful of the various noises resulting from shunting the trains. A train used to make a daily run carrying a blackbird's nest and eggs among the woodwork underneath one of the carriages.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Two attachment suits were begun in the Superior Court to-day against the Grant Locomotive Works. The French Spring Company and the Otis Steel Company are the plaintiffs, the amounts involved being $2,646 and $20,000 respectively. The defendant in the suit is temporarily embarrassed financially.

The sales at auction of real estate announced to take place during the present week are notable for the variety in the property offered as well as for the choice character of much of it. In point of popular interest the sale by Mr. Peter F. Meyer on Tuesday of the Kemp estate leads all the others. This property begins on Sedgwick A venue, and extends to the eastward, comprising 272 lots.

After a remarkably pretty game, the New-Yorks won from the St. Louis Browns yesterday and are now seventh in the race. It was an easy victory for the Giants, as Baldwin confined the batting of the Browns to two hits. Breitenstein, the St. Louis pitcher, also put up a good game, but the New-Yorks managed to make five singles and a double.
NEWBURG, N.T., June 3 -- Judge Charles F. Brown, in the Montgomery excise cases, after argument this morning at the Supreme Court, Chambers, this city, rendered the following decision:
The antiquated and pernicious majority rule in Rhode Island has brought about a muddle that does not leave either party in the Legislature in a very dignified position.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 -- The feeling between Harvard and Princeton, which has not been of the most cordial sort since the squabble over football three years ago, was not improved by the baseball game here on Memorial Day. At Harvard the undergraduates in general, and the athletes in partioular, are much irritated over Princeton's attitude in regard to an umpire on that day.

John H. Vedder, a middle-aged machinist, came from Jersey City Saturday evening with his wife and child to 44 Thompson Street, the house of his brother Frank, whose daughter was to wed Charles Etienne, a truck driver. They were married at St. John's Church, in Varick Street, and then there were festivities at the house of the bride's father.

The educational work of the Reform Club in New-Hampshire, as outlined in our columns yesterday morning, is sure to yield good fruit. The club has in that State a speaker, Mr. ESTELL, who is not only well informed as to the tariff, but, having been a worker in the mines, is able to discuss the question from the workingman's point of view.

A conference will probably be held to-night at the headquarters of the Young Men's Democratic Club in Brooklyn, at which steps may be taken for the nomination of William J. Gaynor for Mayor. Among others who, it is expected, will be present are A.L. Sessions, President of the Young Men's Democratic Club; Frederick W. Hinrichs, ex-President of the club; C.C. Adams, and Henry M. Yonge.

The abuses that have arisen under the law classifying mail matter, resulting in delay in dispatch and delivery, especially of what is called the second class, are now attracting much attention, and legislation to remedy the evil is demanded.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, June 5 -- A.M. The tendency of prices on the Stock Exchange was downward during last week. The trading was not heavy, and most of it was done by the professional element. Outside of the large gold shipments, the news has been generally favorable. The plan for the reorganization of the Reading Company was announced.

WEST POINT, June 4. -- "The cadet of to-day enjoys more liberty than we did," said Gen. H. W. Slocum this afternoon on the piazza of Craney's Hotel. "We were not permitted to smoke, nor were we allowed to come to the hotel to see our friends."
The examinations in the department of arts and science were finished last Wednesday.

Every one interested in church, charities knows of the work conducted by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Gallaudet, General Manager of the Church Mission to Deaf-Mutes. In St. Ann's Church, in Eighteenth Street, of which Dr. Gallaudet is rector, a special service for deafmutes is held every Sunday afternoon. Some of the deaf-mutes also attend the regular daily morning service.

The correspondent who has discovered a clause in the Revised Statutes which authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to use the bonds or notes of the United States to purchase coin seems to have found an unusually large audience of interested citizens, with their mouths wide open, into which this information has dropped like a lark from the skies.

The Hudson River Yacht Club had a regatta yesterday. The coarse was laid off the clubhouse, at the foot of West Ninety-second street. It was a triangular one, starting from Ninety-second Street. The yachts went as far as Fort Lee, then to a stake-boat off Guttenberg, and back to the clubhouse. The big boats went over the coarse twice and the small boats once.

The deadly dumb-waiter shaft, characteristic of flat houses, which has been the cause of so many fatalities in connection with fires that were in themselves of little account, found easy victims in the five persons who lost their lives early yesterday morning at 138 East Forty-third Street.
In the North River, off the foot of West Fortysecond Street, there lies anchored a queer, oldfashioned looking war vessel with one smokestack and three towering square-rigged masts.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- An army officer has won a case against the Second Controller of the Treasury. The latter recently held that Capt. B.F. Stiles of the Tenth Infantry must refund to the Government the sums of money paid to an enlisted man who had acted as auctioneer in the sale of some Government property. It was decided that an enlisted man could not be paid out of the proceeds of the sale.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- There was no great outpouring of the wage-working class or any other class at the exposition to-day. The oppressive heat and heavy lightning, thunder, and rain in the middle of the afternoon account in part for the decreased attendance.

The ninth annual regatta of the Yorkville-Yacht Club was sailed yesterday. The start was made from off the clubhouse at Fort Morris at noon. Classes A, C, D, and H sailed as far as the Gangway Buoy and back, and the others went to Stepping Stones Light. The wind was from the southeast, and the yachts started out with the last of the ebb tide. Following is the table:

The Pastime Athletic Club had its second monthly competitions yesterday at the club grounds, Sixty-sixth Street and East River. A few days ago the Executive Committee secured a little extra space on the river side of the track, and on this they will put up a comfortable stand for the convenience of visitors.

The Wyanoke Boat Club threw open its new club-house yesterday for the inspection of its friends and neighboring crews on the Harlem River. There was a large number of visitors, for whom good cheer was provided by the members of the fortunate club, and a merry time was had till late at night.

The sugar planters of Louisiana may think that they are not directly interested in the condition of the grain market, but it is true, nevertheless, that the prevalence of low prices for wheat is a matter which they cannot afford to ignore in the preparation of their arguments against a repeal of the law that gives them a bounty on the products of their plantations.

Interest in last week's horse sales centred principally in the dispersal of several consignments of thoroughbred yearlings, conducted by William Easton of Tattersalls. Breeders and buyers alike find in to their interest to make this city their meeting ground, for although the bulk of this annual produce of "blue grass" farms was secured by local sportsmen, very many of them, including some most undoubted bargains, will go to all parts of the country.

To-day's sales of realty at auction, while few in number, are notable. The Sheriff is announced to do most of the selling, at the City Hall, his principal offerings being the property of Hawley Chapman of Rossmore Hotel fame. At the Trinity Salesroom Mr. William Kennelly's fine factory property in West Fortythird Street promises to show some good bidding. Mr. McQuillen will also sell a good corner.

Mrs. Elizabeth Chapin, a well-known teacher, and equally well known in missionary circles in this city and Brooklyn, has been obliged to leave her place as on instructor in the Wilson Industrial School for Girls, at 125 St. Mark's Place, this city, after ten years of service, because, it is said, she is a member of a Theosophical society in Brooklyn.

This will be a grand week for racing at the Morris Park track, and there is not a day on which something sensational in the way of sport may not be expected. To-day the two-year-old fillies will try conclusions in the race for the Debutante States, and the aged horses will be given a chance to show how good they are in the ran for the Hudson River Handicap.

Forty-two years ago "Lavengro" was written, and still, as Mr. Watts says, it is "among the most delightful of books." Never was there a man who came so near being a genius, and who failed by only a hair's breadth. The present volume is particularly interesting because it contains an introduction by Theodore Watts, who knew Borrow.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 4. -- At the municipal election in this city yesterday Dr. E.G. Shortlidge, Republican, for Mayor, received 4,312 votes, to 3,653 for William B. Norton, Democrat, a majority for the former of 659. The Republicans also elected their candidates for City Treasurer and City Solicitor and the President and six of the twelve members of the City Council, giving them control of that body by a vote of 7 to 6.
"The Bible is not the word of God," declared the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday.

The estimated value at the Realization Stakes to be run during the June meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club be $30,760. For this rich stake for three-year-olds there are still eligible Don Alonzo, Sir Francis, Sir Walter, Ramapo, St. Leonards, St. Domingo, Calhoun, Buck McCann, Lidgerwood, Uncle Jim, The Baron, Hammie, Comanche, Chiswicky, The Reaper, Young Arion, Long Dock, and Miles Standish.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Time out of mind, the shortcomings of the British Army have been laid to the Horse Guards, and of late years all the imperfections of our military establishment have been charged to the War Department. While the Horse Guards have been condemned as too conservative, our Department of War is accused of being too progressive.

Maggie Panda, a little girl five years old, of 210 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was killed by a trolley car on the Third Avenue and Fort Hamilton line of the Brooklyn City Railway, at the junction of Fifty-seventh Street and Third Avenue, about 6 o'clock last night.
ORANGE, N.J., June 4. -- Henry F. Clinton, who gives Fairmount, N.Y., as his place of residence, has been held here to answer a charge of land swindling.
JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., June 4. -- Yesterday the Carnegie Company and the Carnegie Iron Company made an assignment to J. W. Cure.
Complaints have lately been made about the cruel treatment of the Central Park goats by their drivers. A NEW-YORK TIMES reporter made a personal investigation yesterday.

During the last week the arrest of so distinguished a correspondent as Mr. Frederick Villiers of the English journal Black and White in the World's Fair Grounds, because he attempted to use his hand camera without a permit, was an illustration of the petty annoyances the hand camerist is put to in visiting the exposition.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 4. -- Jose Carreiro, suspected of the murder of Bertha May Manchester, is under arrest here. That he committed the murder there appears to be little doubt, in view of the developments of an investigation which, ended after 4 o'clock this morning.
The year took of the American Canoe Association is almost ready for publication. It contains all the information about the big canoe meet to be held on the St. Lawrence from Aug. 11 to 26.
EAGLE PASS, Texas, June 4. -- Great loss of life was caused last night in the Fuenta coal mines, in Mexico, about four miles from Eagle Pass, and operated by the Mexican National Railway Company.

It will be some time before a complete statement of she financial results of the Press Club Fair can be presented. From the reports now in the possession of the Treasurer, the club will be benefited by several thousand dollars, possibly $18,000. Many of the ladies in charge of the principal booths have not filed their reports, but will do so early this week.
"We are face to face this morning with the melancholy fact that since this parish was founded there has been a total loss to our Church of fourteen congregations below Fourteenth Street."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I had this experience the other morning with a bicycle rider. I was driving home through Central Park at a walk. The road had been watered and was slippery, especially at the sides, where it sloped. A bicycle rider came up behind me. His wheel slipped and went under my horse. Another rider followed over the first one, falling under the horse's head.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 4. -- Chautauqua, the seat of Dr. Vincent's educational university, had a double tragedy last evening. Mrs. Colton, an estimable lady, went to the office of Dr. Elderkin, presumably for consultation or treatment, about, 8 o'clock Saturday evening.

Now that the heat of contest is over and the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church has asserted its power and stamped upon alleged heresy within its dominion, the question has arisen whether it paid to try to convict Prof. Briggs.

Ex-Superintendent of Immigration Weber, while testifying before the Senate Committee on Immigration on Friday, in reply to a question as to which formed the most desirable immigrant class, the English-speaking races or the rest of those races which go to make up the population of this country, made the following statement:

BERLIN, June 4. -- William Walter Phelps, the retiring United States Minister, presented at the castle this noon his letter of recall. Immediately afterward Freiherr Marschall von Bieberstein, Minister of Foreign Affairs, introduced to the Emperor Theodore Runyon, the new United States Minister. Mr. Runyon wore the uniform of a General. He said:

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 4. -- United States District Judge Bellinger has served, an order on Capt. Myers of the steamship Danube, which brought 500 Chinese from Victoria, B.C., to this port, commanding him to bring into court on Monday a number of Chinese whose certificates had not been passed upon by the Collector of the Port.

Since the sculptor Randolph Rogers finished the bronze doors, with their many reliefs, for the Capitol at Washington, nothing of the sort has been seen to compare with the doors to be swung on their pivots to-day in the north and south entrances to Trinity Church.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Supervising Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service road the London cable letter in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of to-day with interest, and also with surprise. When he was asked to-night by a NEW-YORK TIMES correspondent to say what he thought about the reported shipment to this country from European cholera-infected districts of scores of thousands of tons of rags that were not disinfected, he said:

Prince Antoine, husband of the Infanta, has had little to say since his arrival in New-York. Columns have been printed in the newspapers about the Princess Eulalie, and what she has said, and what has been said to her, but very little notice has been taken of her husband, the Prince.
THE BRIGGS CASE. -- "G.W.J.": Will you give a short summary of the Briggs case from the beginning?

With a cool breeze blowing over the pleasant grounds at Clason-on-the-Sound yesterday, members of the Athletic Association of the Sacred Heart Academy ran off their games briskly and with energy. The Catholic Protectory Band furnished enlivening music. There was a large attendance and much interest manifested in the sports. In all twenty-five events were contested.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The last week completed the baseball season, as far as home cames are concerned, of the University of Pennsylvania nine. On the whole it has been very satisfactory, the nine playing good ball from the beginning to the end. The series with both Yale and Princeton were lost, but only by the closest scores, and after games which taxed the nerves of the spectators to the highest pitch.

The Revenue Marine authorities in Washington have decided to fill vacancies hereafter, in the Engineer Corps of the Revenue Marine Service, with graduates of schools of technology and universities having attached to the mechanical engineering departments. An order to this effect has been issued by the Secretary of the Treasury.

TRENTON, N.J., June 4. -- The fraternity of public jobbers was never so active in this State as it is to-day. In some places schemes are piled so high that the community condemned to bear them is fairly staggering under the load. One is omnipresent, and that is the traction aggression, to call it by no harsher name, which was exposed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of last Monday morning.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 4. -- The railroad men, as well as the buyers and producers of corn in the United States, will be interested in knowing just how much of that grain went into Mexico, and to what points, during the recent corn famine in that country. Gen. Warren T. Sutton, Consul General of the United States for Northern Mexico, has just completed his official report on the subject.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the administration of chloroform or ether to produce anaesthesia, a partial congestion of the lungs always takes place, because the normal supply of oxygen from the air is out off. The blood passes from one side of the heart into the lungs to get oxygen and become purified. It will novel leave the lungs until it obtains this oxygen.

Surrogate RANSOM has contributed to the North American Review a forcible and instructive article on "How to Check Testamentary Litigation." It is but fair to state that the most important reforms of which he speaks have been instituted by himself in the administration of the Surrogate's Court in this city and county.

If it be a fact, as it is said to be, that a boy was of late born in Ohio, on the iris of whose right eye the characters 1899 are plainly delineated, while on the iris of his left eye the characters 2003 are as plainly depicted, the phenomenon can hardly be looked upon in any other light than that of a portent.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The decision of the Supreme Court upon the Chinese Exclusion act recently delivered may possibly have a much wider scope and affect a greater variety of persons than was foreseen by the Associate Justices who joined with Mr. Gray in declaring it to be the law of the land.

An inexperienced "gripman" forgot to let go of the cable on the new Broadway road at Broadway and Thirty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon and lifted the wire rope off of the big wheel which is the turning point of its middle section, stopping travel for nearly an hour.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., June 4. -- William Moore, a woolen manufacturer of Cohoes, N.Y., has applied for a divorce from his wife Mary, but the chances are that he will have a robust fight before he gets his degree. Mrs. Moore has served a spirited answer.
The Banks Lose More Than $5,750,000 in Cash, a Heavy Decrease in Deposits, and a Loss in Surplus Reserve of $4,452,425 -- But the Surplus is Very Close to $21,000,000.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, June 5 -- A.M. London prices came higher than those at the close in this city on Saturday, and as a consequence the local market opened buoyant. The foreigners bought Louisville and Nashville and St. Paul and Atchison, but after the first buying movement had exhausted itself trading became very dull and prices sagged.
BENTONVILLE, Ark., June 5. -- The People's Bank was robbed this afternoon at 2:30 by a gang of six desperadoes, armed with rifles, who secured over $10,000.
The Trustees of Columbia College yesterday accepted the gift of $100,000 recently made by Mr. Joseph Pulltzer with a vote of thanks.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., June 5 -- After a struggle with a young horse last evening, Howard Denton, the nineteen-year-old son of the late Lewis Denton, was killed by the animal. The young man lived in Freeport, and hired the horse from a local livery stable to ride to Meadowbrook on a visit to his relatives.

The Columbian Liberty Bell, is which, almost from the moment of the inception of the idea of its creation, so much interest has been manifested in all sections of the United States, is to be cast at the Clinton H. Meneely Bell Foundry at Troy, N.Y., on Thursday, June 8. The bell must be completed and delivered to the Columbian Liberty Bell Committee before July 4.

There was a fairly good crowd at the Morris Park ck to see the racing yesterday. It would have en an enormous crowd if anybody had supposed at the race for the Hudson River Handicap would e resulted in such a magnificent contest as it d. His Highness and Racoland ran a dead heat in e liveliest kind of a finish, with Stockton beaten nly a head by the winners.

From the Botton Transcript, June 3. Back Bay came near having a decided sensation, without cause, yesterday, when for a time it was thought that a package containing $75,000 worth of diamonds had been stolen. Late in the afternoon, Mrs. C.H. Colburn, the daughter of the Hon. W.F. Draper, started to drive from her home at 124 Common wealth Avenue to Hopedale.

The Methodists will not boycott the World's Fair, just yet, at any rate. A good many clergymen of that denomination went to the Methodist Book Concern at Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street, primed for decisive action on the resolution which was choked off at the preachers' meeting a week ago denouncing the fair and calling on all true Methodists to boycott it.

CHARLESTON, West Va., June 5. -- There is just now a very interesting game of railroad chess being played by the companies operating the principal trunk lines or railroad in West Virginia. The object of each good is to dip the deepest into the coking-coal field in this State, and carry off the lion's share of the profits to be derived from its development, which is now but fairly begun.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- One by one the Commissioners from the sixteen foreign countries who agreed to withhold their exhibits from examination for award are yielding since the action of the Board of Control in modifying the rules, and the chances now are that, with one or two exceptions, all the countries will have their displays examined.

The Democrats in the Connecticut Legislature have framed a bill providing for a convention to revise the Constitution of the State. It has been unfavorably reported by a majority of the Judiciary Committee, which is controlled by Republicans. There is no doubt that it will be passed by the Democratic Senate, and it seems to be equally certain at present that it will be defeated in the Republican House.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 5. -- Smith M. Weed said to-day, regarding his recent reported utterances in a New-York paper: "I was misrepresented altogether. What I did say regarding Mr. Poucher of Oswego was that I hoped he would be appointed Collector of the Port of New-York, as he is my choice and a personal friend."

Farmer Dunn blamed the old familiar "General Humidity" for the great and damp personal inconvenience of yesterday. Whatever it was, it did its work well and made people more uncomfortable than on any previous day this season.

"There is nothing like leather," and there certainly is nothing like the leather which C.R. Yandell Co. of 140 Fifth Avenue are sending to Chicago for exhibition in the New-York State Building there. A NEW-YORK TIMES re- porter was given a view of the exhibit yester- day afternoon.

The appointment of Mr. DAYTON as Postmaster will be on all sides commended as an excellent one. We know of but one criticism that can be made, and that Mr. DAYTON makes himself when he says that whatever talent for postal affairs he has will have to be developed by study and experience.

It appears that the Wilson Industrial School for Girls, at Avenue A and St. Mark's Place, which is run under the suspices of many prominent church supporters, and from which Mrs. Elizabeth Chapin, who had been a teacher there for ten years, was forced to resign, because she was a professed Theosophist, proves to be a hotbed of believers in the teachings of the Blavatsky.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- It is generally agreed among Presbyterians prominently connected with the Briggs case that the expenses incurred during the entire progress of the case, from its initiatory stage until the General Assembly disposed of it last week, amount to a very large sum, but it is almost impossible to make an estimate of the total amount with accuracy.

The eighth annual games of the Hellenic Athletic Association, composed of the pupils of St. Austin's School, New-Brighton, S.I., was held yesterday afternoon on the grounds of the Staten Island Athletic Club. There were many starters in each event, and about 300 of the parents and friends of the schoolboys witnessed the sport. Nearly all of the events were well contested.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The President said this evening, in reply to a direct question, that he intended to call an extra session of Congress not earlier than the 1st nor later than the 15th of September, unless unexpected contingencies should necessitate an earlier meeting.

"Please, Sir, I want to give myself up. I want protection from my father." That was what Edwin Osbaldeston, Jr., ten years old, said at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday to Agent Barkley of the Gerry Society.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 5 -- The new gunboat Machias dropped anchor in the harbor at 2:15 this afternoon to remain until she starts on her trial trip over the forty-mile course on Long Island Sound, the same course upon which the Detroit was recently tested.

KANSAS CITY, June 5. -- The Kansas Grain Company, which claims to be the greatest buyer of grain from producers in the world, has failed. H.M. Kirkpatriek, Secretary and Treasurer of the company, notified the Secretary of the board this morning that the company was unable to meet its contracts. When the announcement of the suspension was made on the board it caused great excitement.

LONDON, June 5. -- The tone of all markets was good this morning, and, after a firm opening in Americans, prices advanced an average of half a point above parity and closed steady at some concessions from the highest.
The Infanta Rulalie and her party started for Chicago yesterday and are due there at noon to-day.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the erection of the following new buildings and alterations were filed:
The troubles of William H. Henriques, the banker, with Frank Ellison seem not to be ended.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Wild and unfounded rumors of impending financial disaster caused a senseless run on many of the banks in Chicago to-day. Those chiefly affected were the Prairie State National Bank, the State Bank of Commerce, the Hibernian Savings Bank, the Dime Savings Bank, the Union Trust Company's Bank, and the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 5. --The coal miners' strike bids fair to be the greatest ever recorded in the West, and unless a settlement be speedily reached it will involve, 30,000 miners. The immediate causes of this strike are two, a reduction in wages made to anticipate the screen law, which does not go into effect until September, and the refusal of some of the operators to recognize the miners' union.

LIVERPOOL, June 5 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef and pork in moderate demand. Hams in fair demand; short cut, about 14 to 16 lb, steady at 60s. Bacon in moderate demand; Cumberland out, about 28 to 30 lb, firm at 57s. Shoulders, about 12 to 18 lb, steady at 46s. Cheese in fair demand; American finest white and colored, easy at 49s for new. Tallow in poor demand.

To-day's auction sales of real estate will all be had at 111 Broadway. In popular estimation most interest will attach to the sale of the Kemp estate, comprising 272 lots, beginning on Sedgwick Avenue, in the Twenty-third Ward, and extending eastward. The property is near the new Macomb's Dam Bridge, and is close by the scene of large projected improvements which will enhance its value greatly in a short time.

A million dollars in gold was withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury yesterday for shipment to Europe to-day. Lazard Freres are the exporters. The withdrawal, according to figures from Washington, leaves the net gold in the Treasury at $89,334,320.

The efforts thus far looking to a sale of the Manhattan Athletic Clubhouse have come to naught, and it begins to look as though the judgment creditors will get nothing by way of repayment of their claims. The receiver, Mr. Andrew Freedman, has been very diligent in trying to make the property bring enough to pay the lions, and has been unwilling to allow it to be sacrificed.

Dr. Lyman Abbott's declaration that "the Bible is not the word of God," made in his sermon in Plymonth Church on Sunday and reported in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday from the official stenographer's notes, has aroused various comment among churchmen. Some of them were of the opinion that Dr. Abbott had recently said, also, that he did not believe in the divinity of Christ.
Three barbers will help to determine whether or not Russell Sage is to pay William R. Laidlaw $50,000 damages for being used as a human screen in the great dynamite drama of Dec. 4, 1891.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Arrangements are being made at the Pension Bureau for carrying into effect as speedily as possible the order of the Secretary or the Interior that an examination be made to determine how many pensions have been allowed under the disability pension clause of the act of 1890 in disregard of the terms of the act and in conflict with the recent ruling of the Secretary.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- On the theory that it is the only fit building on the grounds for the reception of the Infanta Eulalie, the New-York State Building was to-day tendered to the Ceremonies Committee by Lewis M. Howland of the Board of General Managers of New-York State. The committee took no final action on this, nor on some other matters which came before it in connection with the Infanta's entertainment.

Notwithstanding the many assertions that the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn has sailed for Rome in apocryphal steamers, it is said by some of his closest friends that he is in rotreat in the Trappist Monastery near Loxington, Ky., and that he will probably stay there in religious retreat all the Summer.
"I think it is the president's wish that an extra session of Congress should be held in September to take some action which may relieve the present financial situation."

The one hundred and twelfth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York will open at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the Masonic Hall, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Representatives of over 700 subordinate lodges in the State will be present. Grand Master James Ten Eyck of Albany will preside over the deliberations.

Mrs. Marie Volk, the Bohemian, woman, who on May 26 absconded with her one-year-old child, sick with smallpox, from the tenement house 1,294 First Avenue, has been found. She returned to her home with the child on Sunday night, and was captured by the Health Inspector on guard, and mother and child were taken to North Brother Island.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Owing to the absence from Washington of Secretary Carlisle, the warrant for the payment to the representatives of the Choetaws and Chickasaws of about $3,000,000 was not completed and issued, as was hoped by the agents of the tribes, who know that payment has been ordered and who are impatiently awaiting the opportunity to get hold of the money.

The new Postmaster of New-York, Charles Willoughby Dayton, was born in this city Oct. 3, 1846. His father was Abraham Child Dayton, a member of the New-York Stock Exchange, and a contributor to periodicals. His mother, Maria A. Tomlinson, was a daughter of Dr. David Tomlinson of Derby, Conn., a member of the State Legislature.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5. -- Despite the excessive humidity to-night about 8,500 men and boys of all ages crowded into Caledonian Park Hall and remained there four hours, watching the progress or the first pugilistic exhibition of the NewJersey Amusement Company. Four bouts were on the programme and all were fairly well contested.

Conlon -- Wilcox. A quiet but very interesting wedding ceremony was celebrated yesterday morning before the altar in the Church of St. Francis Xavier, Sixteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue. The bride was Miss Lulu Wilcox, the gifted Sister Calixtus of the Order of Mercy in Mount St. Joseph's Convent at Hartford, and the bridegroom was Dr. Thomas P. Conlon of Brockton, Mass.

There is trouble between the plot owners of the Union Cemetery, which is situated in the outskirts of Brooklyn, and the Trustees of the Methodist Protestant Episcopal Church of Williamsburg. The courts have been called upon to arbitrate the difficulty. The church Trustees, who control the cemetery, threaten to sell the ground and remove the bodies buried there.

The announcement of the names of the sucessful candidates for admission to the College of the City of New-York was made yesterday afternoon. Fourteen hundred and eight boys from the public and private schools of the city applied for admission to the college, and only 710 successfully passed the examination. The boys were examined on May 25, 26, and 27 in arithmetic, grammar, spelling, history, geography, geometry, and drawing.
President Cleveland yesterday appointed Charles W. Dayton to be Postmaster of New-York, to succeed Cornelius Van Cott. To a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES Mr. Dayton said:

The combination sale of thoroughbred yearlings at Tattersalls last night brought out some spirited bid- ding. Fifty-eight head were disposed of for a total of $53,025, an average of $913,88. The yearlings bought by William Lakeland were for the stable of J.R. F.P. Keene. The beat prices secured were as follows:

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 5. -- The second International Reciprocity Convention opened to-day. Between 300 and 400 were present. Attendance as delegates is limited to those who favor the extension of American commerce and of reciprocal trade relations between this country and Canada.

Chicago news was awaited with eagerness in Wall Street yesterday, although among bankers the belief prevailed that none of the failures and embarassments reported from that city would have any especial effect here.

Three test suits were brought in the United States Circuit Court yesterday by the Edison Electric Light Company and the Edison Electric Illuminating Company as a continuation, practically, of the fight against the Westinghouse Company.
Mr. Booth is dying in his rooms at The Players'. There is no longer any attempt to conceal the fact.

Immediately after the election of Mr. CLEVELAND some of our contemporaries urged that the new Congress should be called in special session at the beginning of the new Administration. We were of the opinion that it was act advisable for the President to take the action thus suggested.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 5. -- The Richmond and Danville and Raleigh and Gaston Railroad Companies recently erected a new union station in this city. The arrangement of the rooms contemplates the separation of the two races. This action of the railroad authorities has been resented by the colored people, and in a number of instances the police have been called in to elect the colored from the rooms assigned to the white people.

Chicago and Brooklyn played another good game at Eastern Park yesterday, and again the youths from Cook County, Ill., placed a victory to their credit. Mauck started in to pitch, and the Brooklyns took very kindly to his delivery. After they had knocked out 4 runs in the fifth inning, McGinnis was substituted, and he only allowed two hits to be made thereafter.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Cadet John Thomas Tompkins, who is under arrest on board the Constellation at Annapolis, as reported in th dispatches to THE NEW-YORK TIMES from Annapolis Friday night, seems to have owed his imprisonment to the persistent tendency of a part of the second, now the first, class to insubordination.
There was a typical Italian fight last night in the tenement house at 180 Hester Street, and as a result two of the participants are in the Chambers Street Hospital.

The Commissioners appointed last Winter by Mayor Boody to investigate the charges of in- efficiency in the Brooklyn Fire Department handed in their roport yesterday. The charges were brought by the Fire Insurance Trust. The committee appointed to conduct the investigation consisted of Alexander E. Orr, E.B. Bart- lett, and John O. Jenkins.

The effect upon the consumption of tin plates in this country of legislation which has made the price higher by 26 per cent. than the average monthly price for the period of five years ending with 1889 has not received the attention which it deserves.

Judge Edgar M. Cullen of the Supreme Court, it is said, was offered the Collectorship of the Port of New-York, but he declined to accept It. Judge Cullen's term on the bench runs to Dec. 31, 1896. When seen last night by a reports for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, he said:

The New-York committee which is to receive the Viking ship, now on its way to Newport, met at the residence of the Chairman, Prof. Hjalmar Hjorth Boyesen, 48 West Forty-fifth Street, last night, to attend to the details of the Norsemen's reception.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5. -- The Rev. Father Mulligan, pastor of the Sacred Heart Church, in his sermon yesterday discussed the school question. He said in part:

BERLIN, June 5. -- At a congress of the Military Unions of Baden the Grand Duke Frederic, who is also a Field Marshal in the German Army, spoke in recommendation of an agreement with the Government on the question of the Army bill. The Grand Duke said: "We must gather all our forces for the possibility of war in order to secure a quick victory."

The meeting at the Tammany Society called for last evening to hear reports from the com- mittees in charge of the arrangements for the celebration in Tammany Hall on the Fourth of July and to transact the regular business of the society was postponed to June 24, owing to the fact that a quorum wan not present. Mayor Gilroy and Mr. Croker were among those who were absent.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Another record was smashed today and prices reached 1 1/4c lower than heretofore for July, and have also shown a sharp decline in the deferred futures, but not to the same extent. The failure of Meadoweroft Brothers, private bankers, this morning gave the market quite a shock. Then came the failure of the Kansas City Grain Company, and prices took another dip downward.

We have already commented upon some indications of the success of the fair at Chicago that are furnished by the table of admissions and receipts for the month of May. Upon the whole, as we have said, these indications are that the fair will be able without difficulty to pay its operating expenses month by month, and thus to continue during the period that has been fixed for it.

Early Friday morning Policeman Knoll was called into 132 West Sixty-second Street by two frightened girls, and when he reached the second floor of the house he found Mrs. Mary Moore, forty-nine years old, in a pool of blood, and Richard T. Leach, a florist, tying up a badly lacerated hand.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 5. -- Notwithstanding Gov. Brown's act proroguing the Senate and General Assembly, the House of Representatives met here this morning according to adjournment. In the absence of the Speaker, J. B. Cottrell filled the office pro tem. The roll was called with no quorum, and the House adjourned till Wednesday at 11 o'clock.

A movement is on foot to amalgamate the International Hotel and Restaurant Employes Association with the Hotel and Restaurant Employes' National Alliance. The association was organized a couple of months ago by waiters who are employed in up-town fashionable hotels. They refused to identify themselves with the alliance because the latter was to a certain extent controlled by Socialists, who were constantly thrusting their doctrines down the throats of all their fellow-workmen.

ALBANY, June 5 -- Steps were taken to-night to punish Charles H. Armitage, the President of the Common Council, elected last Spring for two years, for treachery to the Democratic Party. He is one of the Hill State machine whose members acted with the Republicans in the organization of the board and in all matters since.

Among the passengers on the Anchor Line steamship Furnessia, which arrived here on Sunday, were twelve delegates to the conven- tion of Good Templars which is to be held at Dos Moines, Iowa, on June 10. The Furnessia left Glasgow on May 25, and dropped anchor off her pior here on Sunday evening at 7 o'clock, one hour too late to admit of her being docked.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 5 -- The Central Indiana Electric Railway Company, which has filed articles of association, contemplates an electric system on a larger scale than has as yet been attempted in this country. The capital stock is $4,500,000. The officers are J.T. Baker, President; W.B. Keep, First Vice President; Thomas Wilkinson, Second Vice President; N.D. Pontins, Secretary; R.T. Wilkinson, Treasurer, and Dr. T.A. Gesner, General Manager.

The Canal Street Bank, at Canal and Mulberry Streets, will suspend business and go into voluntary liquidation at once. Announcement of this intention was made late yesterday afternoon by the bank's President. Mr. Antonio Rasines. He also stated that all depositors would be paid in full, and that the only loss would be one of about $20,000 to the stockholders by shrinkage in the stock.
Annual elections were held yesterday on the Cotton and Produce Exchanges.

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Gov. Flower and those accompanying him continue industriously and systematically to "do" the fair. They started in again to-day after their Sunday rest and took in the Fine Arts Building, section by section, inspected the New-York State educational exhibit in the Liberal Arts section of the Manufactures Building, and visited the Dairy Building.

From the Springfield Republican, June 3. The crashing of a boy on Chestnut Street yesterday afternoon by a car of the electric railway company is the second accident of the kind within a week. These two deplorable deaths of children in the public highway, crowding so close the one upon the other and preceded by a considerable list of narrow escapes and fatalities, must not be allowed to escape the instant attention of the community.

Official announcement was made yesterday that Richard C. McMutrie and Joseph F. Sinnott had been selected as the additional voting Trustees of the Philadelphia and Reading Road. The full Board of Trustees now consists of Joseph S. Harris, E.T. Wilbur, Thomas McKean, R.C. McMutrie, and Joseph F. Sinnott. It is understood that in making up the voting list the representative of the syndicate insisted that Mr. Harris should be made the President of the board.

The reports as to the prevalence of cholera in the region at the head of the Persian Gulf may direct attention to the agencies and routes by which this scourge is carried westward from its home in India. A few days ago it was announced that the disease had appeared at Bassorah, a city near the mouth of the river formed by the union of the Tigris and the Euphrates.

LIVERPOOL, June 6 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef in poor demand. Pork in moderate demand. Hams and bacon in fair demand. Shoulders about 12 to 18 th, steady at 46s. Cheese in fair demand. Tallow in poor demand. Spirits of turpentine in poor demand; steady at 23s. Resin in poor demand, Lard -- Spot in poor demand; futures in no demand; crime Western, spot, dull at 49s.

The impressive ceremonies of the ancient order of Free and Accepted Masons were grandly illustrated at Masonic Hall yesterday, when representatives of 800 lodges met at the one hundred and twelfth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of this State. The thirty Masonic districts of this State were represented, and there were also present representatives from the four quarters of the globe.

Between 250 and 300 persons attended the sale of the Kemp estate lots, which were offered at auction by Mr. Peter F. Meyer, at 111 Broadway, yesterday. Among them were many ladies, some of whom took part in the bidding.
CHICAGO, June 6 -- The worst of the financial trouble in Chicago is over, it is believed.

The Produce Exchange dealings were general and liberal at advancing prices, with the money situation at the West improved. Exporters bought wheat freely, for which prices were put up 1 1/4@1 3/4c. There was a rise in prices of corn of 1/2@3/4c, under local covering. The shippers were neglecting flour beyond taking a large line, or 45,000 sacks, low-grade Spring.

The suit of Mrs. Lydia J. Roberts against the Stuyvesant Safe Deposit Company, which has been dragging through the courts for years, was decided again in favor of the plaintiff by Judge Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday. The amount of money involved in about $74,000, of which nearly $29,000 is interest.

The acting of Edwin Booth can be most satisfactorily considered if viewed in its relation to the man's personal peculiarities and temperament. No result of his labors lives after him, except in the memory. He played no new characters, he never prod need a new play, he did nothing whatever to encourage dramatic poets. Broadly speaking, his art was a beautiful composite of the boat in the work of his predecessors.

BENTONVILLE, Ark., June 6 -- This community is still excited over the Peoples' Bank robbery. Stone, the old man shot by the robbers, is dying to-night. After the Sheriff's posse had had three engagements with the robbers, the last one taking place twelve miles out of town, and in which the posse got badly worsted, losing about a dozen horses, they returned to Bentonville.
The money market was firm. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2 1/2@6 P cent. The last loan was made at 5 P cent.

A Coroner's inquest on an Italian organ grinder is fervently prayed for by the dwellers in the Columbia Heights district in Brooklyn. Nothing on earth would give them more, or as much, satisfaction as just such an inquest, and the man who is bold enough to provide the subject to be "sat on" will be looked upon by the people of Columbia Heights as a benefactor.

The Commissioners who are investigating the New-York Custom House did not hold their announced public session yesterday at the Barge Office. Appraiser Marvelle W. Cooper went there early and held a long secret conference with the Commissioners. He brought a big bundle of tables and papers, and went over them with the Commissioners, making explanations here and there as to his previous testimony.

Notwithstanding the heat last night the concert hall of the Madison Square Garden was filled to overflowing with people listening to the class-day exercises of the graduating class of the University of the City of New-York.

Junius Brutns Booth came to America in 1821, discouraged with the treatment he received in the English theatre. There is no doubt that this Booth was a great actor, greater in many parts than his rival, Edmund Kean. But the British public had, after years of neglect, made Kean its idol, and there was no room for Booth.

HONOLULU, via San Francisco, May 30. -- It may now be positively said that Minister Blount has come heartily to approve of the revolution, and probably that be justifies nearly all of the course of ex-Minister Stevens in it. He has never for an instant thought of restoring the ex Queen or of recommending that it be done, notwithstanding the diligent and persistent assertions of the royalists that he so intended.
Wall Street and the banking and business community showed yesterday the good results of President Cleveland's announcement of his intention to call an extra session of Congress in September.

Francis Falkenberg, the library keeper at Bellevue Hospital, who became a typhus-fever patient June 2, died on Monday on North Brother Island. Another death from this disease was that of Thomas Healey, an aged pauper, who was taken from the almshouse on Sunday.

The Gould pleasure party has returned from its three weeks' trip to the World's Fair and to the West and Southwest.
