Every member of the party speaks highly not only of the wonders and beauties of the fair, but also of the treatment accorded them by the citizens of the cities and towns which they visited.

The twelfth annual meeting of the Actors' Fund of America was held yesterday afternoon in Palmer's Theatre. Every seat on the main floor was occupied by subscribing members of the Fund and their friends, and nearly all the first balcony was filled. The boxes were occupied by persons prominent in the theatrical world.
The attendance of the fashionable people at the Open-Air Horse Show was not so good yesterday as on Monday, but the crowd on the grounds was almost as large as on the opening day.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 6. -- The trial of Lizze Borden for the murder of her father and stepmother was continued to-day. A few spectators were admitted the court chamber, but hundreds sought admission in vain. Today, as yesterday, when the trial opened, great crowds surrounded the Court House and gazed at the brick wall of the building, as though by so doing they might gain some slight information of the celebrated trial in progress within.

A thunderstorm of extraordinary violence visited New-York yesterday. The big guns of the war ships in the Hudson were as pop guns compared to the crashing and booming of the artillery of the sky, and before every thunderclap there was a flash of light like that which persons of uneasy conscience imagine belches forth from the nether region when Beelzebub opens the door for a quick peep without.

Superintendent Preston of the State Banking Department began yesterday the examination of the affairs of the Canal Street Bank, announcement of the decision by the Directors of which to go into voluntary liquidation was made in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES.
Edwin Booth, the well-known actor, died at the Players' this morning at 1:17 o'clock.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 6. -- The remarkable instance of a young man with a broken neck living and retaining all his faculties is exciting much interest among the medical men of this city.

"When the thoroughness and unstinted nature of the hospitality accorded by the City of New York to the Princess Eulalie is considered, the estimated total cost to the city is not likely to be considered large," said Controller Theodore W. Myers to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

The Broad way cable oars are very popular, and are much more patronized by the public than are the horse cars on that line. Most of the cable cars that ran yesterday were so crowded that there was hardly any standing room in them between Fourteenth Street and down town, while it was not difficult to secure seats in the horse cars.

Considerable comment was heard at Coney Island yesterday because of as occurrence at an entertainment given on Monday evening for the benefit of the Roman Catholic Church of the Guardian Angel, in the Sea Beach Palace.

Mr. James L. Wells's offerings of Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Ward property to-day, including as they do some valuable lots on the Southern Boulevard at Fordham, facing Bronx Park and adjoining the St. John's College grounds, should command attention. Mr. James S. McQuillen will also sell desirable improved North New-York property and a tenement in East Twenty-fifth Street.
The police are looking for Frank Ellison, clubman and man-about-town, who on Monday evening assaulted William H. Henriques, the wealthy broker of 94 Park Avenue.

The thirty-fifth annual commencement of the Gardner School, at 607 Fifth Avenue, took place on Monday evening at the Berkeley Lyceum. Notwithstanding the heat, the auditorium was filled with a large gathering of friends and relatives of the six young women who won diplomas by successfully-finished courses of study at this institution.

LONDON, June 6. -- The continued influx of gold and the decline of money rates are having an effect on prices. Since the forced selling ceased, prices have been good in all departments, Americans leading, and Greek bonds the only exception, being down 3. Rupee paper closed at 65 1/2. Three months bills were 1 3/4; six months, 2.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, June 6 -- P.M. The opening was fairly buoyant on the statement issued by President Cleveland that an extra session of Congress will be called for September. London bought stocks freely, but the purchases were offset by sales of stocks acquired yesterday by people who had advance information.

The stockholders of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company elected a new Board of Directors yesterday and voted unanimously to push the enterprise. The chief cause of delay is the failure of Congress at the last session to give the necessary authority of the National Government for bridging a navigable stream.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Russian treaty having been published in advance of its promulgation by the State Department, which seems to have entertained a traditional reinctance to part with it, it will be finally promulgated to-morrow.
The suit of William R. Laidlaw against Russell Sage for $50,000 damages, came to a sudden and most unexpected ending yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 6. -- Founder James A. Bradley has declared war against the band which bad given daily concerts on the beach for the past three seasons. The band is made up of Italians, a majority of whom were on the United States war ship Trenton when that vessel was wrecked at Samoa.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 6. -- Reparation, peounlary and by apology, has been asked of the Department of State by the British Ambassador at Washington for the action of the Captain of Night Inspectors in New-Orleans on May 2 in arresting First Mate R.E. Malle of the Steamship Nigretia and looking him up in a city jail.

CORTLAND, N.Y., June 6. -- The through night express to New-York on the Delaware, Laokawanna and Western Railroad, due here at 11:20 o'clock last night, collided with a runaway engine on the iron bridge three-quarters of a mile north of this station. The engine had been kept in the yard here, and was in charge of the night watchman, George Chaffee.

Mrs. Annie Devault Palmer, the wife of Frank W. Palmer, a broker doing business in Brooklyn and living at 647 Degraw Street in that city was found dead in bed at the United States Hotel yesterday morning in a room which she had occupied since the previous evening. Mrs. Palmer was a dipsomaniac. It is believed that her death was due to natural causes and that alcoholism was a contributing cause.
According to Vice President George W. Davis, the property of the Nicaragua Canal Company was not greatly disturbed by the recent revolution in Nicaragua.

Explorer Robert E. Peary, who is to start in about three weeks for a three years' expedition to the arctic regions, was in this city yesterday, making preparations for his trip. He is going to make an effort to reach the north pole, which he says is situated about 1,100 miles above the place which he made his headquarters on his expedition to Greenland.

RICHMOND, Va., June 6. -- The contest in Virginia this year for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination promises to be of more than ordinary interest. The fact that the election at which the Governor and other general officers are to be chosen will also elect a Legislature which is to name a United States Senator and five members of the Supreme Court intensifies this interest.

Mayor Gilroy has had an opportunity to buy for the city a rare curiosity in the shape of a note issued by the New-York Water Works in 1776, and because he has no funds at his disposal for such a purpose he must decline the offer.

The proceedings of any convention called at the suggestion of so pestilent a demagogue as IGNATIUS DONNELLY will inevitably be colored more or less by propositions and discussions calculated to make the judicious grieve. At the first session of the Anti-Trust Convention we find DONNELLY soberly proposing that the courts should encourage crime by declining to permit the prosecution or any person who has stolen property belonging to any Trust or similar combination.

The appointment of Charles W. Dayton to succeed Cornelius Van Cott as Postmaster of the City of New-York was a topic or general conversation among the business and professional men down town yesterday. The appointment was heartily commended, and even those of the opposite political faith admitted that President Cleveland's choice was one which afforded them no opportunity for criticism.

NEW-HAVEN, June 6. -- Play was commenced in the New-England tennis tournament this morning. During the forenoon's work the preliminary matches were disposed of and during the afternoon the first round and part of the second were played.

The suit of Mrs. Sophronia Twitchell for $250,000 damages, which she desires to collect from the Equitable Life Assurance Society, was begun in the Circuit Court, Brooklyn, yesterday before Judge Kellogg.

MANAGER BROOKS'S NEW ENTERPRISE. -- Manager Joseph Brook has signed contracts with J.H. McVicker to place in the latter's house in Chicago a strong stock company to produce American plays during the Summer months. The contract will go into affect next May and will be for five years. The first play to be produced will be by Augustus Thomas, and is now almost completed.
CHARLESTON, West Va., June 6. -- A cloudburst at Hinton and vicinity last night resulted in great destruction of property. The damage in Hinton is estimated at $200,000.

"Unconsidered trifles" in antiques, jewelry, watches, knicknacks, apparel, umbrellas, silverware, and burglar's tools, worth $1,500, and part of the booty of Frank Davis, the house thief of many pseudonyms, made a brave show in Inspector McLaughlin's sanctum last nignt.

Yacht Builder Elwood Abrams of Cold Spring Harbor will probably retain possession of the handsome schooner yacht Montank, owned by the missing lawyer, Francis H. Weekes, for debt. The yacht has been on the marine railway at Cold Spring undergoing repairs for several weeks and a general overhauling. Mr. Weekes owes the yacht builder several hundred dollars for the work, and the latter will hold the yacht until he is paid.

When Capt. George C. Wiltse, the commander of the Boston, connected with the flag incident in Honolulu, who recently died in this city, took charge of the training ship Minnesota some years ago, he found on board a middleaged Englishman, Julius Blanckensee, to whom he took a strong liking.

Prof. Charles A. Briggs of the Union Theological Seminary, who was suspended as a minister of the Presbyterian Church by the General Assembly in session at Washington recently, because of his views regarding the Bible, has a signed article in the New-York Evangelist of this week.

OSAGE CITY, Kan., June 6. -- The prospects for an early settlement of the trouble in the mining districts are unusually bright to-day. President Walters, who returned to this city from Scranton early this morning, received a telegram from T.M. Lacey, Secretary of the Miners' Union, to the effect that the operators would meet the Executive Committee and arbitrate the question on Wednesday.

ST. PAUL, June 6. -- The International Reciprocity Convention made a permanent organization to-day by electing James Fisher, M.P., of Winnipeg Chairman, P.M. Kelly of St. Paul Vice Chairman, Dr. J. Maginnis of Grand Forks Secretary, J.H. Beck of St. Paul, S.A. Thompson of Duluth, and C.N. Bell of Winnipeg Associate Secretaries.

The determination of the President to call an extraordinary session of Congress between the 1st and the 15th of September is received with hearty approval by all sensible men. It calls forth no criticism save of a purely partisan character, which interests no one but its authors, and which even they offer in a weary, half-hearted way, as if they had to "make believe very hard" to persuade themselves that they really disapprove of it.

At 11:45 last night a passer-by on Broadway opposite City Hall Park noticed smoke issuing from 240 Broadway. He notified Officer Brownell, who rang in an alarm. At the arrival of the first contingent a second alarm was sounded.
The three caravels, Santa Maria, Nina, and Pinta, left their moorings in the North River at 11:30 A.M. yesterday and started on their way to Chicago via the St. Lawrence.

Tuesday'a Western demand upon New-York for money was duplicated yesterday so far as amount was concerned, but its character was different. In place of heavy shipments, the bulk of which went to Chicago and Milwaukee, were smaller ones in greater number and with more soattered consignees.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, June 7 -- A few days ago some old and musty documents were found here, by which it was learned that treasure consisting of jewelry and gold coin amounting in value to $2,000,000 is buried at 6 Perpucta Street in this city. The documents bear official marks, and state that the wealth was secreted by orders of Emperor Maximilian.
LONG ISLAND CITY, June 7. -- Mrs. Mary Finn of 1,890 Second Avenue, New-York, went to Calvary Cemetery on May 17. A pickpocket robbed her of a pocketbook containing $22.93.

MONTREAL, June 7. -- A few days ago a telegram was received hero by the police asking the arrest of a man wanted in New-York for a murderous assault. The detectives located the man, but refused to arrest him until toe New-York or United States authorities sent in the cash to cover expenses.
Spirits of turpentine dull and easy at 28 1/2@29c. Resins quiet and steady at $1.25@$1.27 1/2 for common to good strained.

WEST POINT, June 7. -- The Board of Visitors saw to-day much to interest them and to prove the versatility of the cadet. The first class took the field in practical engineering. The scene of their operations was the old Revolutionary work, Fort Clinton, where so many fisticuff disputes between cadets have been adjusted. The entire Academic Board, the Board of Visitors, and many of the tactical officers turned out to see the sights.

The sales of North New-York property by Mr. James L. Wells yesterday drew many persons to the salesroom, in the Trinity Building. For the estate of John D. Fenn there were sold, in partition, four lots on the east side of Morris Avenue, beginning 100 feet north of Walnut Street. The neighborhood is known as Mount Hope.

PARIS, June 8 -- A death from a disease of a choleraic nature occurred to-day at Nisnes capital of the Department of the Gard, where a case of death from a similar disease was also reported on May 29.

The Aqueduct Commissioners took important action at their meeting yesterday in regard to the purchase of land and the construction of a storage reservoir within the city limits, north of the Harlem River.

The stable of Broker H. Victor Newcomb, at 108 West Fifty-fourth Street, was wrecked by fire early last evening. Three valuable horses perished in the flames, and three expensive vehicles were destroyed.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 7 -- Properly speaking, this was the first day of the Borden trial, for, while the two previous days had been occupied in the preparation of preliminaries, this day was marked by the rapid presentation of testimony. The progress made was marked, and was entirely in keeping with the course presaged by the prompt selection of the jury.

Having heard that the Democratic Board of Supervisors of Kings County was about to spring another gerrymander of Assembly districts, United States District Attorney Jesse Johnson and Benjamin F. Blair, by hurried appointment, conferred with the Redistrioting Committee of the Board of Supervisors, in behalf of the Republicans, last night, at the County Court House in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- The first nickel-steel gun is ready for assembling at the ordnance shops of the Washington Navy Yard. The forgings have been made ready for the jacketing, which on this occasion will be of more than usual interest, from the trial of a new assembling process invented by Mr. William Sellers of Philadelphia, who aided the Ordnance Bureau recently when the jacket of the thirteeninch gun stuck before it reached its seat.

John H. Starin and Samuel Spencer came to close quarters at yesterday's meeting of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners, and the Summer calm that has lately attended these proceedings gave place to a storm of words that came perilously close to the lie direct.

For the fourth time the sentencing of Dr. Robert W. Buchanan, convicted of poisoning his wife, was postponed in the Court of General Sessions yesterday. Recorder Smyth, at the request of Charles W. Brooke, counsel for the prisoner, put off hearing the motion for a new trial until to-morrow. Mr. Brooke said he had been delayed in procuring some important affidavits which will figure in his argument.

ST. PAUL, June 7. -- Never in the entire history of the Northwest has there been so great and successful a celebration as that begun in that city to-day in honor of James J. Hill, whose completion of the Great Northern Transcontinental Railway system, without aid from the Government, has given him high rank among the great financiers.

Ex-Alderman William Ficke, who is Chairman of the Tammany Hall District Committee of the Seventh Assembly District, was yesterday appointed by Mayor Gilroy as Sealer of Weights and Measures, to succeed Samuel R. Porter, Jr., who has been holding over for two years.
Matthew Strutt, a German tramp, was arrested on Tuesday night on the charge of attempting to kidnap and assault the seven-year-old daughter of James Murray of West Fams a few hours before.

On the recommendation of Chief of Battalion Cashman of the First District, James A. Gallagher, a first-grade fireman of Engine No. 57 was recorded yesterday on the roll of merit for rescuing Ernest Reich, who tried to drown himself near the New-Yorker on May 29.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Five naval cadets, two of the six-year class, and three of the four-year class, just graduated, have been found disqualified for service and will be honorably discharged. The six-year men are John G.F. Moale of California and Lucien G. Smith of Illinois. The four-year men are Peter C. Hains, Jr., District of Columbia; A.M. Proctor, Kentucky, and A.M. Cook, Kansas.

Deputy Coroner Weston ascertained yesterday that the death at the United States Hotel on Tuesday of Mrs. Annie D. Palmer was due to intemperance. Relatives have charge of the body and the interment will be in Evergreens Cemetery.

Miss Ray R. Smalley, cashier in a Brooklyn confectionery, joined the Mizpah Lodge of Knights and Ladies of Honor in 1889, and was insured for $3,000 in favor of her aunt, Angelina Vanderwerken, with whom the young woman lived. Miss Smalley married George H. Maynard, Secretary of the Mizpah Lodge, and obtained a new policy in her husband's favor, saying that the former one had been lost.

There were twenty-five classes on the programme, many of them contests between the turnouts of society people, at the Open-Air Horse Show yesterday, and the attendance was much larger than on any preceding day. Most of the boxes in the members' stand were fully occupied, and the grand stand, clubhouse, and promenade were well filled.

The Quebec Steamship Company has decided to send the steamship Trinidad of that line to England to have the vessel's length of 270 feet extended to 320 feet over all. The alteration will give the vessel greater stability and, as new machinery will be put in, higher speed is expected.

The White Star Liner Majestic yesterday arrived from Liverpool with every one of her numerous staterooms occupied. A correspondingly large number of persons were on the dock awaiting her arrival. Some of the more eager went down to Quarantine on the revenue cutter to meet the vessel at that point. Among them were ex-Mayor Grant and David Gideon. They were interested in the arrival of "Smillng" John Kelly.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 7 -- The third game of the series between the University of Pennsylvania and Princeton resulted in a victory for the visiting team, which won by a score of 4 to 2. Forsythe, substitute pitcher, was in the box for Princeton, and though the red and blue hit him hard and often, the phenomenal fielding of the home team held Pennsylvania down to a low score.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- The exercises preliminary to casting the Columbian Liberty Bell in Troy, N.Y., to-morrow, were held to-day in Common Council Chamber and for a time the place was filled with more patriotism than is shown in a whole year of ordinary Council work.

The first game of polo for the season at the Country Club's grounds at Westchester was played yesterday. It was between the Independence of the Morris County Country Club and the Meadowbrooks. Mr. August Belmont took the Meadowbrooks up on his steam yacht Ituna, and among his party were Mrs. A.W. Bird, Miss W. Eustis, and Miss May Bird.
At the meeting of the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday the Committee on Construction submitted the report of Chief Engineer Fteley on his work in the abatement of nuisances in the Croton Watershed.

The Theosophists have been brought prominently before the public again by the discharge of teachers from the Wilson Industrial School and Mission for Girls because they were believers in the doctrine of Karma and members of the society founded by Blavatsky.

QUINCY, Mass, June 7 -- On a commanding slope of "President's Hill" in this picturesque little city of granite and patriotic traditions stands the handsome residence of Dr. William Everett, the newly-elected member or Congress from the Seventh District. The spot is one that a man of refined and artistic taste would instinctively select for a habitat.
National Cordage stock fared badly in Wall Street trading yesterday. It was sold freely, and was carried down to 12, its close at 12 3/4 showing a drop of 3 points from Tuesday's last figures.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Confidence in the value of wheat tried hard to struggle to the top at the opening, but the atmosphere was still heavy with the borrowed troubles of savings bank depositors, and the more direct effect of rumored failures in the grain trade at Duluth and St. Louis, made known soon after the opening, quickly brought a return of despondeney, which caused a break of over le bushel in wheat.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The annual meeting of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Road was held to-day and the old officers and Directors, whose terms had expired, were re elected without a dissenting vote. The annual statement shows the gross earnings to have been $20,971,110, the operating expenses and taxes $15,083,688, leaving the net income $5,887,422, to which is added $60,000, the cash receipts from sales of land.

In the easiest manner imaginable the Brooklyns won a game yesterday from the St. Louis Browns at Eastern Park. Stein was in great form and pitched a clever game against the visitors. The latter tried three pitchers -- Hawley, Breitenstein, and Arthur Clarkson -- and all were hit hard.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, June 7 -- P.M.} Speculation to-day was very narrow and was almost wholly confined to the professional operators. The news from Chicago indicated a subsidence of the panic in that city, and the fact that the banks and financial institutions had withstood the strain so successfully was regarded as the best kind of evidence of their soundness.

Yesterday afternoon the Ariel Tennis Club began its regular Summer tournament on the club grounds, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and St. Ann's Avenue. The event of interest was the men's singles. The preliminary round and part of the first round were finished by the afternoon's play. Some very good matches were played, particularly the one between White of the Ariel Tennis Club and A.E. Kent of Berkeley School.

On Monday evening a respectable and estimable citizen, Mr. W.H. HENRIQUES, was attacked in a public street by a ruffian named ELLISON and so savagely beaten as to put his life in danger. The spectators told two policemen about the affray, of which the policemen had apparently not been witnesses, but had arrived to hear about the breach of the peace only after the breach of the peace had been committed.

Superintendent of Banking Preston said yesterday afternoon that the examination of the accounts of the Canal Street Bank, which was begun Tuesday morning, was not quite completed. No statement could therefore be given out yesterday. One may be given out to-day.

Isaac L. Rice, through his solicitor, Nathan Bijur, has just filed his answer in the suit brought by the Richmond Terminal Company to annul the purchase by the Directors of that company of Georgia Central Railroad stock, and to recover the $4,000,000 paid therefor.

The Police Commissioners yesterday awarded the contract for the construction of a new boat for the harbor police, to take the place of the Patrol, to the Maryland Steel Company. The company's bid, $52,000, was $10,000 less than the next highest bidder.

The Charities Commissioners of Kings County who undertook to investigate the death of aged Mrs. Adair in the Flatbush Insane Asylum, which was attended with certain suspicious circumstances and pronounced by a Coroner's jury to be due to violent treatment, gave out a report at the meeting yesterday morning. Dr. Sylvester, the Medical Superintendent of the asylum, is declared to be free from blame.
Bryan G. McSwyny, who was found late Tuesday night unconscious in his burning shoe store at 240 Broadway, died last night in Chambers Street Hospital.

DUBLIN, June 7 -- A.A. Zimmerman, the American champion bicyclist, was winner to-day in a mile invitation scratch race, participated in by bicyclists from various parts of Ireland. Zimmerman won easily by two laps in 2:47 2.5. O'Neill of Dublin was second and O'Callaghan of Cork was third.
The "People's Organization of Brooklyn," a new factor in municipal politics, was formally launched last night at 189 Seventh Avenue. Many of the best citizens of Brooklyn are in the movement.

Two of the members of the gang of flat thieves who have been robbing apartment houses all over the up-town district have fallen into the hands of the police. They were caught only after one of the hottest chases ever know in this city.

FARGO, N.D., June 7 -- About 3 o'clock this afternoon an alarm of fire was sounded and it was reported that some ashes, thrown from the Little Gem restaurant on Front Street, had started a fire in the rear of Herzman's store.

Joy -- Germond. Emanuel Baptist Church, at Lafayette Avenue and St. James's Place, Brooklyn, was the scene of a fashionable wedding yesterday afternoon. Miss Katharine Germond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Germond of 442 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, was the bride, and Francis Henry Joy of Brooklyn Heights was the bridegroom.

Frank Ellison, the assailant of W.H. Henriques, the broker, of 94 Park Avenue, was arrested at 6 o'clock on Tuesday evening by Detective Sergeants Hickey and McCluskey of Inspector McLaughlin's staff. He spent the night in a cell at Police Headquarters.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 7 -- Commonplace sport attended the postponed opening of the trotting meeting at the Gentlemen's Driving Park to-day. Two of the three races on the card were quite devoid of interest and of contest, favorited winning in straight heats without being headed from first to last.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 7 -- The State Commission in Lunacy this afternoon closed its investigation into the management of the affairs of the Hudson River state Hospital at Poughkeepsie. Senator Amasa J. Parker, who is President of the Board of Trustees of the hospital, was the only witness. A repetition of testimony heretofore brought out was mostly the result of a constant cross-fire which Commissioner Brown and the witness engaged in for over two hours.

A meeting of the stockholders or the Madison Square Garden Company will be held to-day to hear the report of the committee of five appointed at the meeting of stockholders on May 9 to find out at what price, if any, the property of the company could be sold.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Recently the Controller of the Currency made an assessment of 100 per cent, upon the shareholders of the Commercial National Bank of Nashville, Tenn., which failed some time ago. This large assessment has caused the shareholders to appoint a committee to wait upon the Controller, to protest against the assessment being made so soon after the failure of the bank.

There was much less activity to the grain dealings on export account, as following the recent extensive purchases, and only a fair degree of life to speculation, with prices unsettled, opening firm on crop reports from Kansas, but declining 3/4@1c under realizing orders from the West, closing at 5/8@7/8c under yesterday. The trading in corn was slow at 1/2@5/8c decline, through some raiding of the situation at the West.

A collection of French, American, Spanish, and Italian paintings is on exhibition at the art rooms of E.F. Bonaventure, 45 West Thirty-first Street. Some are in the rooms devoted to rare books and fine editions of modern volumes, but the overflow is found in certain halls belonging to the Hotel Imperial which are lighted by electricity.

BUFFALO, June 7. -- It is reported that Edward M. Field of New-York of the defunct firm of Field, Lindloy, Wiechers Co., who was remanded to the Buffalo State Hospital to determine the question of his sanity, enjoys a luxurious existence there entirely free from all restraint and that he is just as rational as he ever was.

A case or unusual interest to importers was referred to the Board of Managers of the Produce Exchange by the Complaint Committee of that institution yesterday. It turns on the power of the Exchange to exercise jurisdiction over transactions in which a member and a non-member are concerned.

The wave of excitement which swept over the City of Chicago during the last four days, and which caused a general and rather heavy run on the savings banks of that city, has apparently subsided. It appears to have been purely local and to have had no reasonable cause. The savings banks of the city were reputed strong, and they have shown that they were strong.

At the end of the eighth inning yesterday the score between the New-York and Pittsburg nines was even and every enthusiast looked for the Giants to make one of their Garrison finishes. But they didn't. On the contrary, the big Giants pulled up, so to speak, and allowed the youths from Allegheny to get the rail and win hands down.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Mrs. Cleveland is coming to Chicago soon. It bag been known for some time that the wife of the President was likely to visit the fair, but no definite time was mentioned for her trip. Now it is said that she will be here before July and will remain a week or longer.

RICHMOND, Va, June 7 -- The Virginia Populists are the most hopeful and buoyant politicians in the world. In spite of the fact that their Presidential ticket in this State last year polled only 12,275 votes out of a total of 292,252, the third-party leaders say that they will make a big fight in this campaign. They propose to nominate a full State ticket and to contest for members of the Legislature in every district.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 7. -- The Co-operative Exchange is the name of a new populist enterprise which is to be started in Topeka next week. The purpose of this exchange is to operate in connection with the Alliance Exchange store on East Sixth Street, and to make times better for the members of the Alliance by increasing the volume of circulation by issuing cheeks instead of money.
"The people have great confidence in the pure intentions and personal integrity of the President, and the slightest indication of independence on his part is hailed with joy."

Lord Dunraven's yacht, the Valkyrie, the latest challenger for the America's Cup, has now sailed in five races since she has been launched, and a fair idea can be had of her sailing abilities. In her first two races, sailed at the mouth of the Thames, she did not show up remarkably well, and those who expected that she was going to be a very fast yacht were somewhat disappointed.

Whatever else may be done in the course of the next session of Congress, it is very desirable that the smaller national banks throughout the country shall be allowed by law to give to the sections in which they are situated the accommodations that they can safely give and would be glad to give did not the law restrain them.

Several members of the Columbian Liberty Bell Committee arrived in this city from Philadelphia at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and an hour later left on the steamboat John Drew for Albany. They will go to Troy this afternoon to attend the casting of the bell.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Commodore Sampson, the Naval Chief of Ordnance, to-day submitted to the Secretary of the Navy his comment on the report of the board which examined the socalled dynamite guns of the Vesuvius. It is a non-committal report, which neither indorses the system nor condemns it except by inference.

FARGO, N.D., June 7 -- Attachments were served to-day upon all elevators and other property of the Northern Pacific Elevator Company in North Dakota. The suit is brought at the instance of banks in Montreal, Minneapolis, and Duluth. There are fifty elevators belonging to this company in North Dakota.

In every circle of life in New-York City yesterday, and for that matter througout the country, there was profound sorrow for the death of Edwin Booth, the tragedian, and everywhere there were heard expressions of the deepest sympathy for his daughter, Mrs. Edwins Booth Grossman.

LONDON, June 7 -- Business on the Exchange was moderate. Prices were firm, Greek and Argentine bonds advanced. Rupee paper rose to 67 1/4 and closed at 66 1/4; special allotments, conncil drafts, and transfers made up to 15 3-32d.

RICHMOND, Va., June 7. -- It looks as if the contest in Virginia for the Democratic nomination for Governor may end in bloodshed. At any rate, the epithets that are being hurled at each other by Congressman Charles T. O'Ferrall and Mr. W.R. Alexander are usually expected to terminate seriously.
Music Hall was crowded last evening to witness the commencement exercises of the NewYork Law School and the conferring of degrees on over 100 of the students.

The Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York met promptly in Masonic Hall yesterday, all the members being ready for the election of officers. Grand Master James Ten Eyck had announced his determination not to serve another term, and Frederick A. Burnham, the only nominee, was unanimously chosen as his successor.

By a vote that lacked only one of a tie the Brooklyn Board of Education has chosen Georgiana F. Putnam, an elderly colored woman, to be the head of a department in one of the city's largest schools. Miss Putnam, who is approaching in years the threescore mark, has been a school teacher in Brooklyn since the war.

With foreign exchange below the shipping point under the influence of grain bills offered, with gold ordered for export withdrawn, with money on the London market ranging as low as 1 1/2 per cent., the prospect for the immediate future is reassuring. There is for the present a definite turn for the better.

The trouble which has been brewing in the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn over the question of excluding women from the shore clubhouse at Bay Ridge on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, was practically settled last night by the pigeon-holing of a petition to the Board of Governors asking that they be excluded on those days.

The New-York Concert Company, Limited, which controls and runs the Casino, is deep in financial difficulties. In the Superior Court, at 10 o'clock this morning, it will, through its attorney, David Leventritt of 280 Broadway, present a petition for the appointment of a receiver.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 7. -- The great reunion of the Loyal Legion took place at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening. The exercises began with Sousa's "Loyal Legion March," followed by introductory remarks by Major Gen. Wealey Merritt. Archbishop Ireland delivered an address of welcome, and Gen. Nelson Cole, Junior Vice Commander in Chief, responded.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- That Russian extradition treaty was formally promulgated to-day, and the official copy of it makes It plain that the State Department was yesterday suffering from some chagrin at its appearance in an unauthorized form, for comes forth with the signatures of Bayard, Struve, and Rosen, as it was negotiated in 1887, and not with new signatures, as it was intimated that it would by State Department authorities last night.

In the interesting account of the preparation for the political canvass in Virginia which we printed yesterday there was a reference to a very significant phase of the contest for the nomination for Governor between the leading aspirants, Congressman O'FERRALL and Lieut. Gov. TYLER.

John Kelly, the smiling and genial, just back from his trip around the world, held an impromptu reception on the lawn in front of the Morris Park Clubhouse yesterday afternoon. Though somewhat tired after the trip across the ocean, which was rough enough to make all the passengers glad to be on land once more, he looked to be thoroughly benefited by his trip and said that his looks did not belle the facts.

The property owners on Madison Street, Brooklyn, do not intend to have trolley road run through that thoroughfare if they can help it. Madison Street is now a most desirable place of residence, owing to the fact that business has made little encroachment upon it, and elevated and surface roads are near at hand.

Crash! and a door of the three-room apartment of Gerald and Kate Creevy, on the second floor of 231 East Forty-fifth Street, was burst in at 5:30 P.M. yesterday by Detective Murphy of the Twentythird Precinct.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 8. -- This has been an anxious day for Lizzie Borden on trial here for murdering her father and stepmother. Two of the State's most important witnesses have testified and have furnished the evidence upon which reliance for a conviction is largely based by the prosecutors.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- As to-day's meeting of the General Managers of the Central Traffle Association lines it was decided to ran excursion trains from common points in Central Traffic territory for one fare for the round trip. The trains are to consist of coaches only, and will have no sleeping or chair cars, and tickets on the excursion trains will not be accepted on other trains.

FARGO, N.D., June 8 -- The sun rose this morning upon a city ball of which is in ashes. But few of the people aside from the women and children slept last night. The school houses, churches, and public buildings left standing were all utilized as places of shelter.

TROY, N.Y., June 8. -- The casting of the Columbian Liberty Bell, which was to take place this afternoon in this city, has been indefinitely postponed, owing to an unfortunate accident early this morning.

The new United States cruiser Marblehead will be given a steam dock trial in the course of the next ten days. The Marblehead is at present at the docks of the Morgan Iron Works, East River. She is in the hands of the builders of her engines, the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company of this city.

When Mayor Gilroy goes to the City Hall this morning, he will find awaiting him an envelope containing the resignations of Rapid-Transit Commissioners Steinway, Inman, Spencer, and Bushe. It would have been received by the Mayor yesterday had he been in the city. In his absence, Secretary Holly took it in charge.

APIA, Samoa, May 24, via San Francisco, per steamer Alameda -- It may be safely predicted that Samoan affairs are approaching a climax. Indeed, before this reaches America, Malietea and Mataafa may have tried conclusions, and the all-important question as to which is the stronger party may have been forever decided.

VIENNA, June 8 -- Archbishop Sembratowicz was mobbed by forty Polish students in Lemberg to-day on account of his visit to the Pope, which the Poles regard as treason to the Greek Catholic Church, of which he is a prelate.
There was an interesting coon hunt in the grounds of the Chapin Home, on Sixty-sixth Street, near Lexington Avenue, yesterday morning.

The Madison Square Garden property will not be sold, for the present at least. When the stockholders met a month ago the minority stockholders, who never had been paid a dividend, and whose stock had so greatly depreciated in value that they feared they would be wiped out entirely, demanded an investigation of the company's accounts.
Edward Dodson Speer is probably very sorry to-day that he committed his wrath against his wife to paper.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 8 -- The delegates to the Republican Convention found every business block gaily decorated with bunting. Stars and Stripes, and streamers different in color and design from anything they and ever seen. Some thought it was a new way of hailing the prospective renomination of McKinley, but they soon learned that the strange flags were the royal colors of Spain displayed as a compliment to the Duke of Veragua and his party.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The Federal Court, by a majority of two to one, decided this morning to grant the injunction prayed for by the District Attorney to restrain the local Directory from opening the World's Fair gates on Sunday. Judges Woods and Jenkins favored the closing of the gates, while Judge Grosscup held the contrary opinion.

DWIGHT, Ill., June 8. -- [Copyrighted by THE NEW-YORK TIMES.] -- There is a fairly encouraging crop outlook, with the exception of Winter wheat. Reports show the condition of Winter wheat, Spring wheat, corn, and oats in the States of Ohio. Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri, Kansas, Tennessee, Kentucky, Texas, and the Pacific slope.

WEST POINT, June 8 -- With the examinations concluded West Point is now awaiting the formal announcement at the standing of the first class, the first class is looking forward to Monday, when Col. Wilson will hand out the diplomas, and the third class is patiently biding the time when the green and tender plebe will make his advent.

The Ohio Republicans have begun early, as is their wont. In their convention yesterday they listened to a speech from Gen. GROSVENOR and a rather perfunctory letter from Senator SHERMAN, which were intended to give the keynote to the long canvass. Gen. GROSVENOR'S notion is that the party must insist on the splendid prosperity of the country on the 8th of November, 1892, and charge all departure from that point to the Democrats.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:
Yesterday was the blue-ribbon day at the open-air horse show in Manhattan Field. The stands, clubhouse, and promenade were crowded with visitors, and the programme was an interesting one.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- The various States having completed their exhibits and having them all now in a position to call for comparison, it is in order for each to put forth its claims to supremacy. Pennsylvania has started the controversy by claiming, through its chief executive officer, A.B. Farquhar, that its collective State exhibit is the beet on the grounds.

The objectionable features of the extradition treaty with Russia have been made familiar to the public by recent discussion, and the reasons why they are objectionable have been made sufficiently clear. It is not certain that the President would have been justified in withholding the treaty after it had been deliberately negotiated and duly ratified by both parties.

When the Board of Estimate of the County of Kings meets this morning it will find itself face to face with two pretty big requests for money, one from the City of Brooklyn for nearly $14,000,000, and the other for an additional $3,000,000 to keep the county afloat.

The Players, in Grameroy Park, the scene of Edwin Booth's death, was visited yesterday by nearly all the leading actors in the city. In the afternoon a few of the friends whom he had loved most were admitted to the room where the body reposed in a plain oak coffin.

Dr. John T. Nagle, Register of Records of the Health Department, yesterday requested Coroner Messemer to make an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the death of an infant child of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Langer of 540 West Fifty-fifth street. It is alleged that a forced death certificate was sent for record in the Bureau of Vital Statistics.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., June 8. -- The strike of the weavers at the lace works is still in progress. To-day the mills are being protected by a posse of deputies under Sheriff Darling.

There has now been spread upon the official records of the State Department a report as to the effect of one of the worst jobs in the McKinley tariff -- the imposition of a high duty on silver-lead fluxing ores -- and the report was written by one of Mr. HARRISON'S Consular officers.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 8. -- D.B. Loveman, one of the leading dry goods merchants in the South, filed a deed of trust with the County Registrar last evening for the benefit of certain preferred creditors. He named as assignees H. Clay Evans of Chattanooga, late First Assistant Postmaster General, and Lewis Black of Cleveland, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The question of reorganizing the Board of Pension Examining Surgeons throughout the country is just now under consideration by Secretary Hoke Smith, Commissioner Lochren, and Deputy Commissioner Murphy. There are 1,260 of these boards, each containing three members, and their work is a very important factor in the administration of the pension laws and in the adjudication of claims.

One of the most deserving charities in NewYork City is St. John's Guild, formed to aid helpless sick children, irrespective of creed, color, or nationality. Its twenty-seventh annual appeal to the charitable has just been issued, and the facts and statistics set forth cannot fall to gain the sympathies of the public.

The Kings County Tennis Club has almost finished its annual Spring handicap tournament at the club grounds, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn. The mixed doubles hag already been decided in favor of Dr. Frazer and Miss Moore. In the women's singles there are still left undefeated Miss Brush and Miss Helwig, Miss Brush having defeated the favorite, Miss Moore, for a place in the final round.
Deputy Coroner Conway viewed the body of Bryan G. McSwyny yesterday at the Chambers Street Hospital, and granted a permit for its removal for burial.

The fifteenth annual water excursion by John H. starin to the Union veteran soldiers and sailors and their families took place yesterday. There were about 7,000 men, women, and children on the steamers Laura M. Starin and Blackbird and the barges Neilson, Warren, Arthur, Sumner, Vanderbilt, and Carry. The objective point was Oakdale Park, on the Hudson near, Hastings.
A motion was made yesterday to place the Casino in the hands of a receiver, as was foreshadowed in the exclusive story published by THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Civil Justice Wauhope Lynn is quoted as having said in his speech at the Irish, amnesty meeting in Cooper Union Tuesday evening that, if England did not want peace, it was the duty of friends of Ireland to strike her -- from behind, if they pleased -- for England had not spared her Irish political prisoners.

CADETS APPOINTED. -- Timothy M. Coughlan of 698 Tenth Avenue. New-York City has been appointed alternate cadet at the Military Academy from the Thirteenth New-York District. Other appointments are: J.A. Buckler. El Paso, Texas, with W.R. Douglass of Abilene, Texas, alternate; H.S. Morgan, Valdosta, Ga., with M.L. McRas of Lumber City, Ga., alternate: J.E. Williams.

The resignation of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners appointed under the act of 1891, lacking the signature of Mr. STARIN, who was absent from the city, was sent to the Mayor yesterday afternoon. The resignation of the entire body and the immediate filling of the vacancies seemed to be the only way out of a hopeless dead-lock.
W.J. Coombs, member of Congress from the Fourth (Brooklyn) District, talking yesterday with a reporter of THE NEW-YORK Times about President Cleveland's call for an extra session of Congress, said:

An insane man made a lively time at Grant's Dock, Essex Street, Jersey City, yesterday. After wandering listlessly about for two hours he suddenly jumped into a rowboat and rowed vigorously toward the middle of the river.

It will be universally admitted, except possibly by himself, that Mr. RUSSELL SAGE is an exceptionally fortunate person. His good fortune largely consists in the dexterity and address with which, when what is called in politics and finance a "hole" yawns before him, he induces some other and less fortunate person to occupy it, while he himself remains outside, having arrested himself at the brink.

A reception to Charles W. Dayton, the newly-appointed Postmaster of this city, was given by the Harlem Democratic Club last evening at its house, 15 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. Several hundred well-known Democrats came to give their congratulations to Mr. Dayton. Many of them were Tammany men, prominent among whom were Mayor Gilroy, Col. John R. Fellows, and Judge Marline of the Court of General Sessions.

Chief Inspector Christopher C. James of the Post Office Department says that Daniel F. Beatty of Washington, N.J., whose advertisements of pianos and organs have so long been spread before the public on rocks, sidewalks, fences, and signboards, has gotten himself into a pretty tight place with Uncle Sam's authorities.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 8. -- The action of Commander in Chief A.G. Weissert and Department Commander Joseph F. Cleary of New-York in revoking the charter of Farnham Post, No. 458, G.A.R., has caused much comment in Grand Army circles in this State, where the question of pensions has been discussed freely.

The Summer work of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor is to be commended. It has been expanding its fresh-air enterprises year by year, and is desirous of building up a comprehensive work commensurate with the city's needs and coextensive with the city's bounds, and it asks the kind cooperation of the philanthropic public in carrying out its plans.

Frank Ellison, the assailant of William H. Henriques, the broker, is still in a prison cell at Jefferson Market Police Court. His lawyer, Charles W. Brooke, however, succeeded yesterday in getting a writ of habeas corpus for him signed by Judge Ingraham, returnable in Supreme Court, Chambers, at 10:30 o'clock this morning.
LONDON, June 8. -- The volume of business continues small, but prices hold good, and close generally at the best. Argentines were exceptionally weak on the resignation of the Romero Ministry.

Just when defeat seemed inevitable the Brooklyns won a game from the St. Louis Browns at Eastern Park yesterday. It was a hard came for the Browns to lose, inasmuch as they excelled their opponents at every point. To only one cause -- poor luck -- can the failure to win be attributed.
Unless the Canal Street Bank gets aid from some unexpected quarter, it will go into the hands of a receiver to-day.

An attempt was made early yesterday morning to burn the two-story frame house, 551 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street. The house is owned by Richard Fitzpatrick of 454 West Nineteenth Street, and is occupied by two families. George Hill lives on the first floor and the second floor is occupied by the family of Henry Richman.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, June 8 -- P.M. While speculation was narrow and professional, there was an undertone of strength to to-day's market which was decidedly encouraging. For many weeks prices have tended downward almost constantly, the sallies being feeble and short-lived.

Albert Guerin, who, with his wife and Mrs. Ida Texier, conducts a fashionable dressmaking establishment at 12 East Thirty-second Street, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on charges of illegal detention and assault.
The money martket was firm. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 4@15 cent. The last loan was made at 5 cent.

The thirty-second annual parade of the Sabbath School Association for the Eastern District of Brooklyn took place yesterday. As the children passed the reviewing stand at Morton Street and Bedford Avenue, they presented a fine appearance and were greeted with rounds of hearty applause.

The auction sales of real estate to-day are all in foreclosure proceedings and are to be held at 111 Broadway. Mr. William Kennelly offers a corner on Bradhurst Avenue, Mr. Walter two fiats up town, and Mr. Richard V. Harnett a one-sixth interest in the Rockingham apartment house and business and residence property. The details of the sales are as follows:
The Grand Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons, of the State of New-York finished its annual session yesterday.

The taxpayers or the Town of New-Utrecht, L.I., have formed an association to regulate the system of taxation, which of late bus been a great burden to them. The association met at Bensonhurst on Wednesday night, and it was resolved to bring suit against the members of the Town Board of Improvement, which is held responsible for the present oppressive rates.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Cataract Construction Company, the new organization of capitalists which has been formed to furnish electricity and electric power upon a scale of tremondous magnitude by employing the Falls of Niagara to generate the electric fluid, was held at 45 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, yesterday afternoon. The following Directors were elected:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 -- At baseball this afternoon Harvard beat Holy Cross by a score of 10 to 1. The name was of special interest, because about three weeks ago Holy Cross beat Harvard 2 to 0. J.A. Highlands, whom the Harvard Faculty put on probation near the beginning of the season, has recovered his standing in the class, and pitched for the first time to-day.

A letter was sent yesterday by Mayor Boody of Brooklyn to the members of the commission which recently investigated the efficiency of the Brooklyn Fire Department, thanking them for their work. In the course of the letter the Mayor said: "Your report contains valuable recommendations which will at once receive official attention."

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Secretary Herbert made his first move to-day in the interest or economy in the administration or the civil departments of navy yards. He directed the discharge of fourteen employes from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and has decided that the offices held by the displaced clerks shall not be refilled.

The Harlem Cricket Club journeyed to Bayonne, N.J., yesterday for a game with the New-Jersey Athletic Club, and received one of the severest drubbings ever given to a metropolitan club, being defeated by 197 runs. M.R. Cobb of the New-Jersey Athletic Club made the occasion a memorable one by scoring the largest individual total ever made by playing in this neighborhood.
Essex Market Police Court was crowded yesterday afternoon with union cloakmakers. Their leader, Joseph Barondess, had been arrested on a charge of assaulting an opponent.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 8 -- The first car of new Texas wheat arrived to-day. President Brown of the Galvoston Wharf Company, which owns the million-bashel elevator here, received advices to-day that William Cameron and D.D. McMillan of Fort Worth, had started 200 cars of panhandle wheat for Galveston, whence it will be exported to Europe.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 8 -- The Louisiana Cypress Lumber Company, which made an assignment yesterday in Chicago, through its President, Joseph Rathbone, has had a receiver appointed here. A suit was filed by William S. Hopstra of Muskegon, Mich., to recover from the company $11,431.42, alleged to be due on three notes now past due.

The syndicate having undertaken to provide the Government of Austria-Hungary with the gold needed to put its currency on a gold basis has completed its operations, and the Director of the Austrian Creditanstalt has published a full account of them, which is summarized by the Vienna correspondent of the London Economist.

"This confidence game has been going on for a long time," Senator John P. Jones of Nevada said yesterday to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter at the Grand Hotel as he was discussing the present financial situation.

BOSTON, June 8. -- Arbitrage business fell off considerably to-day owing to the dullness of the New-York market. The tone, however, was much better than yesterday. Bay State Gas was exceptionally weak. It sold down to 7, but afterward rallied to 7 3/4. Boston and Montana advanced to 21 1/4, and Mexican Central 4s to 57 1/4.

More of the good effects of the President's announcement of his intention to call an extra session of Congress in September were felt in Wall Street yesterday. On the Stock Exchange there is a better feeling, with an improvement in prices, while the foreign exchange declined, and the belief grew that the gold shipments had met a substantial check.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 8. -- William R. Merriam, President of the Merchants' National Bank of St. Paul and ex-Governor of Minnesota, speaking to-day of the financial crisis said:

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- As the time for State encampments draws near, the War Department is considering the details of officers who will act as inspectors of the citizen soldiery. A number of officers are already on duty with State militia. New-York has Lieut E.E. Hardin of the Seventh Infantry, and Gov. Flower has requested that Col. R.H. Hall of the Fourth Infantry act as inspector during this year's encampment.
Overlooking Morningside Park, near where the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is to be, the new home of the Teachers' College of NewYork is being built.

Bottome -- Tyng. The leading incident in local social affairs yesterday was the marriage of Miss Anna Griswold Tyng to the Rev. George H. Bottome, the popular assistant rector of Grace Church. The wedding took place at 3 o'clock in Grace Church.

Two of the sales of real estate at auction yesterday were interesting. The one involving the largest amount of property was by Richard V. Harnett at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway. Some months ago, Mr. Walden P. Anderson of this city undertook to build a row of elegantly-appointed residences on the south side of West Ninetieth Street, beginning 200 feet west of Central Park West.

In all probability the Madison Square Garden will be the scene of a second series of concerts to be given by the Imperial Infantry and Cavalry Band of Germany, now at the German Village in Chicago, during November prior to their departure for Berlin. The recent performances given in this city by this organization of soldier musicians met with great success, the larger part of the receipts being distributed by Henry Villard for charitable purposes.
There was to have been a meeting of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners at Mr. Steinway's house at 2 o'clock yesterday, but only Mr. Starin kept the appointment.

Charles W. Paul, who has been a clerk in the County Clerk's office for the past four or five years, was arrested yesterday by Central Office Detectives Jacobs and Dunn for a long series of forgeries, which brought him considerable sums of money.

W.R. Taylor, Secretary to the receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, furnished for publication yesterday an official statement relative to the finances of the company. The receivers find that on the 1st of July their resources will fall about $1,500,000 short of the amount necessary for current disbursements and for the rentals and interest which mature on that date.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The building which was the scene of the disaster to-day is known the country and the world over as the place where President Lincoln was assassinated by John Wilkes Booth on the night of April 14, 1865.

ALBANY, June 9. -- The new Dudley Observatory is fast nearing completion, and all its instruments will be set by November, when the dedication will take place. One of the most interesting accomplishments connected with its construction has been the setting of the massive piers which are to support the Olcott meridian circle.

Charles W. Dayton, the new Postmaster, called yesterday upon Cornelius Van Cott, whom he is to succeed, at the Federal Building. David F. Nelson, the colored messenger, had been on the alert for Mr. Dayton for two days and when he saw him yesterday he made a low bow and said:

The Dauntless Bowing Club of the Harlem River will take their annual long row of the season to-morrow. The barge will leave the boathouse at 10 o'olook, and the first stop will be made at Donnelly's College Point Grove, where a match game of ball will be played with the Atalanta Boat Club. After dinner the crew will row to Whitestone. Willet's Point, Larohmont, and Travers Island.

From the Boston Transcript. Do you know what atavism is? It is a strange and wonderful thing in nature, which governs most of our physical and mental resemblances. What it is will be illustrated by the true story which follows:

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, June 9 -- P.M. To-day's news was almost all good. There were few failures in the West, but with the exception of the savings bank at Hudson, Wis., the liabilities were small. The publication in THE TIMES this morning of the crop report prepared by Mr. Prime was read with interest and was considered satisfactory inasmuch as the showing is much more encouraging than it was a short time ago.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The dismissal by Secretary Carlisle of eighteen rag Inspectors in Europe and the turning over of the business of rag inspection to the Consuls was in pursuance of the provisions of the Quarantine act of February, 1893, and the regulations framed by the Treasury to carry that act into effect. It was found that the eighteen Inspectors just dismissed had been carried as representatives of the United States for many years.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- An appalling disaster, that has moved this city most profoundly, occurred this morning in the old Ford's Theatre Building, on Tenth Street, between E and F Streets.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas. June 9. -- This city was visited by a disastrous fire at an early hour this morning, and it resulted in a loss of about $95,000. The principal sufferers were the firm of Wanner Chalbot, whose wholesale crockery, hardware, and plumbing establishment was completely destroyed, entailing a lose of $70,000.

With the approach of Summer and the end of the Spring exhibition at the Academy of Design, some one remarks each year that it is a pity the Academy does not beep its galleries open during the hot months, for the benefit of the Summer residents and visitors, and the good of the artists. The suggestion is equivalent to making permanent salesrooms of the galleries.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 9. -- There is a lull in the export grain trade just now, but several steamers are expected during the month to load wheat and corn for English and European ports. The shipments since the opening of the season reach 1,034,074 bushels of wheat and 263,685 bushels of corn; there is at present in the elevators nearly 1,000,000 bushels.

"Not one person in a thousand takes proper care of a watch," said a watchmaker yesterday. "Good watches are ruined by the careless treatment they receive from their owners, and the makers are abused when they get out of order. The modern watch is a wonderfully intricate and most delicate piece of mechanism. It is composed of ninety-eight pieces, and over 2,000 operations are used in its manufacture.
The Architectural Society of Columbia College held its Spring meeting and dinner in the School of Mines Building Thursday night. Stockton Bookman Colt, the President, presided.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- There is a rumor afloat to-night that President Cleveland has finally decided upon a man for Collector of the Port of New-York. The person who started the report failed to give the name of Mr. Hendrick's successor.

TRENTON, N.J., June 9. -- The June examination of young men desirous of becoming attorneys at law was the largest class in ten years, twenty-six students being examined. The examiners were James McC. Morrow of Newark; C.C. Black of Jersey City; James Buchanan. Trenton; Thomas E. French, Camden, and Woodbury Holt, Trenton.

The range at Creedmoor was occupied yesterday by a detachment of the Twenty-second Regiment, composed of Companies C, D, and G, under command of Capt. Demarest, and numbering 142 officers and men. The weather was fair, with a light "4 o'clock" wind. Capt. M.E. Burnton, the Regimental Inspector of Rifle Practice, had charge of the shooting, under the general supervision of the Brigade Inspector, Major David Crocker.

In this country not much has been beard of late about either Dr. Brown-Sequard or his remarkable liquid. Several years ago the papers were full of the wonderful things that were to be accomplished by the subcutaneous use of this queer organic solution, and the whole world's incredulous attention was turned to the experiments of the Parisian doctor.

Mr. Samuel E. Morss was at the Plaza Hotel yesterday. He will sail to-day on the Umbria for Europe. After remaining a few days in London he will go to Paris, and on July 1, the beginning of the next fiscal year, he will begin his duties as Consul General there. Mrs. Morss and their little daughter are with him.

Fabius M. Clarke, a lawyer at 192 Broadway, and Henry T. Cutter, the President of the Hegeman Drug Corporation, were yesterday appointed receivers of the New-York Concert Company, which has been running the Casino. The appointment was made by Judge McAdam in the Superior Court.

The collapse of an old building in Washington, with a very extensive loss of life, is particularly disgraceful because the building was used as a public office and under the control of the Government. Almost all disasters of this kind are traceable to the reckless greed of private owners who are willing to incur the chance of destroying other people's lives rather than the certainty of spending their own money.

A foreclosure sale held by Mr. Richard V. Harnett in the Trinity Building Salesroom yesterday possessed some features of interest. The purchasers, for example, at this sale obtained only an undivided one-sixth interest in the real estate bought, and, as this is subject to a life interest, they cannot get possession of the property or of any of its income until the death of the life tenant.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- At the Paris Exposition of 1867 the electric telegraph had ceased to be an exhibitable novelty, but there were exhibited there a therme-electric battery of the late Prof. Moses G. Farmer, an exhibit of Day's kerite wire, and Ladd's dynamo, a composite machine built up of borrowed plates from Wilde's electro-magnetic machine with a second armature added, the dynamo principle which Siemens discovered a year previous being applied.

A dozen gentlemen who practice the pleasant game of fencing were at the Fencers Club yesterday afternoon to meet M. Albert Duret of Paris, a fencing master who has passed the Winter in Montreal and sails this morning on the Bourgogne for his native land.
William H. Henriques, the broker, who was brutally assaulted Monday evening by Frank Ellison, is in a very precarious condition.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 9. -- The women of the United States are preparing to march upon Kansas in a financial way and force equal suffrage upon this State. A fund of $50,000 is now being raised, according to the reports made by the officers of the State Association, which is to be used in the campaign for paying the expenses of speakers who will appear in every school house and church.

Some time between 9 and 12 o'clock on Thursday night, John Meyers, thirty-three years old, a prisoner in the Tombs since May 11, awaiting sentence for burglary, out his way to liberty through the three solid feet of masonry that formed the outer wall of his cell.
Isaac L. Rice sent to President Joseph S. Harris of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad yesterday the following review and criticism of the elaborate reorganization scheme:

The investigation of affairs at the Custom House, which has been in progress in this city for nearly two weeks, brought about yesterday an unexpected result in the form of the resignation of M.W. Cooper, United States Appraiser of the Port of New-York. The letter was sent to President Cleveland in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Mr. Alexander Von Landberg, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Twenty-first New-York District, whose resignation was recently asked for by Secretary Carlisle, may be able to hold office for another year at least. Mr. Von Landberg came to Washington yesterday and had an interview with the Secretary in which he asked that the request for his resignation be withdrawn.
Two small highway robbers, James and Thomas Shaw, ten and eight years old respectively, were committed temporarily in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to the care of the Gerry Society.

This afternoon the tennis courts of this city and vicinity will all be in use, and some hard struggles with rocket and ball are to be expected. Prominent Among the local clubs to hold tournaments will be the Knickerbocker Tennis Club, whose grounds are at One Hundred and Fortieth street and Brook Avenue. The events will be men's singles, men's doubles, women's singles, women's doubles, and mixed doables.
From the Boston Post. One of the most touching things I ever saw was at the anniversary celebration of the Young Men's Christian Union Wednesday evening.

"There is no real foundation for the suggestion that typhus fever is spreading in this city to an alarming extent," said Chief Inspector Doty of the Health Department to a NEWYORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

The Commissioners who are investigating the Custom House held a private consultation yesterday with Assistant Secretary Hamlin of the Treasury Department. Mr. Hamlin came directly from the Secretary of the Treasury and brought with him some papers and instructions from the Secretary.

WEST POINT, June 9. -- The agony for the first class men is over. The standing of the cadets has been promulgated in general orders and nothing is now left but the cadet ball in the gymnasium to-morrow night and the assignment to command.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 9. -- The facts concerning a heavy robbery which is alleged to have occurred on Wednesday in the store of exPostmaster General John Wanamater leaked out to-day, notwithstanding Mr. Wanamaker's efforts to keep them from the public.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 9. -- It is not often that a boycott is put in force by a secret, or semi-political, organization, and yet it is a matter of record that the Grand Army of the Republic, or many of its members, did once institute such a measure.

The Russian men-of-war Dimitri Donskol and Rhynda yesterday arrived in port and went to their old anchorage in the North River. Both vessels took part in the naval review. Upon the disbanding of the fleet they went to Philadelphia. It is quite probable that they will remain in this port until the arrival of the Russian squadron, which was ice-bound at the time of the assembling of the war ships in Hampton Roads.

The Railroad Committee of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met, with Chairman McGrath presiding, in the City Hall last night and listened to propositions for using streets from the Union Street Railroad Company and the Nassau Electric Railroad Company. The two concerns have met in struggles for franchises two or three times during the last few months.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Postmaster General Bissell stated to-day that, notwithstanding all rumors to the contrary, he had as yet made but one ruling with reference to Postmasters, to wit., that they would be required to devote their attention to the duties of their offices.

Mayor Wanser dealt the Street and Water Board branch of the Jersey City ring the severest blow yesterday he has given it since his election. The board, on May 29, passed an ordinance vacating Railroad Avenue from Fremont Street to the foot of the Heights, where it joins Academy Street, the distance of one block.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 9. -- Correspondence which is now going on between the Canadian and the United States Governments will decide whether or not the now extradition treaty between Canada, or rather Great Britain and the United States shall, in the near future, be a dead letter or not. Although the correspondence has been going on for some time, the public has not been aware of the fact.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9. -- The University crew leaves to-morrow for New-London, where training for the race with Yale will be completed. The boat is now made up as follows:

DENVER, Col., June 9. -- Senator Teller, in a letter which will appear in the Rocky Mountain News to-day, protests against President Cleveland's plea that an extra session of Congress is necessary to repeal the Sherman law. In the letter he says:

The three championship games of the first section of the Metropolitan League to-day will all be played in New-Jersey. The Morris Park team goes to Paterson, the Brooklyns play at Newark, and the Manhattans play the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Bergen Point. Three games of the second section will take place on the North Meadow, in Central Park, where the New-York Club plays Kings County St. George.

The third meeting of the East River Bridge Commission was held yesterday. The business before the meeting was to hear arguments for and against the approaches to the new bridge and the condemning of property therefor.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Gen. Flagler, the Army Chief of Ordnance, will in a few days award a contract for over $500,000 worth of steel forgings. The material is desired by the Army Ordnance Office for assembling into eight, ten, and twelve-inch guns for the coast defense system.

Ambrose and Alfred D. Snow, composing the firm of Snow Burgess, shipping and commission merchants at 66 South Street, made an assignment yesterday to James McWilliam, giving a preference to Edward Ellis O'Brien of Thomaston, Me., owner of the ship Baring Brothers, for $2,000, money received by the firm to pay the bills of the ship.

The Western demand for money was lighter yesterday than on the day before, and the shipments from this city were probably not much in excess of $600,000. Estimates of the amount sent out on Thursday were $1,000,000, and Wednesday's shipments were put at $1,500,000.

"There is no city in the United States in which the color line in the School is so thoroughly obliterated as it is in Brooklyn," declared School Committeeman C. Simis to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday, speaking with reference to the appointment of Miss Georgiana F. Putnam, a colored woman, by the Brooklyn Board of Education to the head of a department of one of that city's largest schools.

In the course of the next few weeks Edward Hannan, State Superintendent of Public Works, will undertake some experiments on the Erie Canal, probably in the neighborhood of Schenectady, with a view to testing the feasibility of the application of the trolley system to canal transportation. At the suggestion of Gov. Flower, made in his last annual message to the Legislature, $10,000 was appropriated to defray the expenses of the experiment.

As the Open Air Horse Show draws to a close, public approval or the enterprise increases. Yesterday the attendance was the largest of the week. Between 3 and 4 o'clock, all the private boxes, the immense grand stand, and the clubhouse were filled with well-dressed men and women, the gay apparel of the latter lending a most picturesque effect to the scene.

The House of Refuge on Randall's Island was the scene of festivities yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the celebration of the sixtyninth anniversary of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 9. -- Small fields, straight heats, and extremely one-sided racing was the order of events at the Gentlemen's Driving Park to-day. The three winners all earned now records, but apart from this the day's doing were devoid of interest or importance.

A prejudice exists in England against American dramatic art, and I am anxious to do all that is is my power to remove It. Had I not seen with my own eyes and heard with my own ears how steadily and surely you are advancing toward perfection, I might unconsciously myself have spread and encouraged that prejudice.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 9. -- At Abasalo, in the State of Guerraro, a hand of brigands led by Leandro Sanchez, a notorious out law, assaulted the residence of Saturnino Prudente. A desperate resistance was made by Mr. Prudente, assistad by his servants, and in the battle he received a wound which soon caused his death.
The Year Book of the Young Men's Christian Associations of North America for 1893 has just been issued.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- The New-York Board of Women Managers is the only one at the World's Fair which has a colored member. J. Imogen Howard, a school teacher is New-York City, is the sole representative of the Afro-American race. She has lately completed, in the Woman's Building, an exhibit of the work of the women among her people in the State of New-York.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Nearly 500 persons, mostly Government clerks, were at work in the Ford's Theatre Building when, at 9:35 o'clock, the floors suddenly fell to the cellar, causing a terrible result in loss of life and injury.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 9. -- The police of Fall River told their story of the Borden tragedy to-day. All the details of the affair were rehearsed with a painful exactness; all the scenes in and about that ill-fated house were presented in clear, and almost startling colors.
The annual meeting and reunion of the Alumni of the University of the City of NewYork was held last evening in the council room of the University Building, in Washington Square.
The Controller of the Currency telegraphed to this city yesterday afternoon that he had appointed David McClure, the well-known lawyer, receiver of the National Bank of Deposit.

LEMONT, Ill., June 9. -- As a result of the labor troubles that have existed in the stone quarries here and at Joliet and on the drainage canal for the past weak, a battle took place at noon to-day between the Will County Sheriff's posse and the strikers near the camps of E.D. Smith Co., that resulted in the loss of probably three lives and the serious injury of twenty men.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Between forty and fifty Directors of the World's Columbian Exposition sat in a cramped room of the Rand-McNaily Building, in the down-town portion of Chicago, for three hours this afternoon and waved palmleaf fans while they listened to Edwin Walker, Solicitor General of the Corporation, state the present status of the Sunday opening question and proffer legal advice.

The block on Columbus Avenue, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets, has been embellished with a drinking fountain intended solely for horses and other animals. There is a story connected with this fountain which is interesting from the fact that it has been twice removed from the spot designated by the donor in her deed of gift, and is now some six miles from the place where it was originally set up.
