The Board of Supervisor of the County of Kings yesterday, in accordance with the mandates of the Court of Appeals, adopted a plan for the reapportionment into Assembly districts of the territory under its supervision.

Hard, clevor, and timely hitting, sharp fielding, daring base running, food sacrifice hitting, and all the other elements necessary to win a game of ball were displayed by the Giants yesterday. As a result they defeated the Pittsburg Club after a highlyinteresting game.

CHICAGO, Jane 9. -- Joseph Higgins, owning a private bank at 84 Washington Street and three corresponding institutions in Illinois towns, has made an assignment to George W. Dixon. Assets are scheduled at $50,000. His liabilities are not estimated. Higgins operated banks at Mascoutah, Sorento, Gillespie, and St. Ann. The assignment covers all.

NEWARK, N.J., June 9. -- Edward Evans, a curly-haired gypsy who was encamped with Chief Chisodine's tribe in Glasby's Woods, between Newark and Elizabeth, has eloped with his dark-eyed sister-in-law, Marie Lovell.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Princess Eulalie and Chicago society met to-night. It would not become a Princess or any other priest of honor to express her opinion of Chicago society, but the unanimous opinion of Chicago's four hundred is that the Infanta is a charming woman, who does not make her royal rank conspicuous to embarrass or chill those around her.
Is the work of two years and a half under the Rapid-Transit act of 1891 to go for nothing? If so, whose fault is it? The history of that work has some peculiar and interesting features.
Wheat gained 1 1/3@1 3/4c for the day on reports of damage to the crop in France, an improved feeling financially, and pretty good buying on the part of the shorts and foreigners.

The trial of Matthew Strutt, the supposed "masked robber of Tremont," in the Morrisania Police Court was brought to a sudden close yesterday. Mrs. Lulu Hutchins, who claimed to have been his victim, broke down in the court room, and Justice Sims ordered the prisoner's discharge.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- There were a great many narrow escapes from death and many thrilling experiences.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Though officials connected with the building are not inclined so to state, and declare that they cannot understand the reason for the fall, there seems but little doubt that the primary cause was some excavating which was being done under the front wall.
The annual report of the Board of Managers of St. Mark's Hospital for the fiseal year ending March 1, 1893, has just been issued.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The examining board has completed its examination of Commander George W. Wood of the navy. This officer was up for promotion to the grade of Captain. He had not been to sea since July, 1875, and has seen no sea servise during his present commission. He represented to the board that it was through no fault of his that he was kept, on shore duty.

One effect of the decision to call Congress together in September has been to start a great number of suggestions as to what may and should be done when it meets. This is a good sign. It is true that many of the suggestions are very wild and some of them are dictated by personal or partisan interests.

KINGSTON, June 9. -- The old stone building in the City of Kingston, now owned by the State, in which was convened and organized the first Senate of the State of New-York in 1777, has within the last year, under the charge of its present custodian, been transformed into an interesting museum of relics, curios, old paintinge, and other things of historic interest.

Nothing appearing in the newspapers in a long time has attracted such general attention on the Produce Exchange as the summary of the grain crop conditions, prepared by S. Thornton K. Prime, the expert statistician of Dwight, Ill., and printed yesterday in THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 9. -- A military dinner was given at the Parker House here this afternoon by Gen. Richard A. Donnelly, Quartermaster General of the State, to Gov. George T. Werts and other distinguished visitors. Covers were laid for twenty-five guests. The dining rooms were handsomely decorated with flowers, potted plants, and the State colors prettily festooned.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 9. -- Judge Bartholomew of the Marion Superior Court to-day indicated his determination to fight the issue of jurisdiction between himself and Judge Baker of the Federal court to an end.
The National Cordage Company's receivers have sent notices to creditors to put in their claims on or before Aug. 31.

The funeral services of Edwin Booth, which were held yesterday morning at the Church of the Transfiguration, in Twentyninth street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, will pass into history as among the most remarkable ever held in NewYork City.

IN THE REALMS OF SOUND. -- Upon this cadence of speech depends the emotional effect, not of song merely, but of all intervals and progressions of artificial sounds. Many melodic devices are direct copies of human utterance; many more are indirectly suggestive of different peculiarities of intonation under special modes of emotion.

Discussing this question, the Rochester Democrat and chronicle says that in the Colorado Building at the World's Fair the efforts of some women of that State to establish co-operative housekeeping will be demonstrated. The plan is soon to be thoroughly tried in Denver.

SING SING, June 10. -- Everything is in readiness in Sing Sing Prison for the execution of John L. Osmond, who is to go to the electric chair some time during the week beginning Monday, for killing John C. Burchill in NewYork.

ORANGE, June 10. -- No more popular social affairs have been known in the Oranges this Spring than the series of archery and tennis teas being given on Llewellyn Park lawns by a number of young ladies from that locality. This afternoon the third or the series was held on the lawn at Beech Lodge, the residence of Mrs. C.D. Paul.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 10. -- The tide or Summer travel is now steadily flowing to the Catskills. To-day the trains of the Ulster and Delaware Railroad carried an unusually large crowd for this time of the season. The Tremper House at Phoenicia, the Palace Hotel at Shanlakeu, and the Cookburn House at Mount Pleasant were opened to-day.

The cornerstone of the new building to he occupied by the Fourth Presbyterian Church, one of the oldest religious societies in the city, was laid yesterday afternoon. Nearly 200 members of the church witnessed the ceremonies.

FLORENCE, May 21. -- The road leading toward the fine old Etruscan town of Fiesole is not now as popular as it was a month ago, Queen Victoria having in the meantime forsaken the Countess of Crawford's beautiful Villa Palmieri for the palace at Windsor, yet the country road is very beautiful, its hedges of flowers presenting unbroken lines of color under the blue May skies.
Wheat had a slow sale for the day, with exporters practically out of the market, while prices tended to an easier basis. Corn was also dull and offered at a decline of 1/8@1/2c.

Lower Rates to Chicago. -- Berths reserved sixty days ahead; all routes; buggage checked; write for information and rates. Lansing's Office, 397 Broadway. Special rates West and Pacific Coast. -- Adv.

C.Y. Wheeler, the President of the Sterling Stool Company of Pittsburg, which made the Steel projectiles which successfully stood the Government's "reception test" on Friday at the Sandy Hook Proving Grounds, went down again to the grounds yesterday and dug his two shells out of the sand, into which they had ploughed deeply.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, June 10 -- P.M. The improvement in sentiment which has been gradually growing all week was very apparent to-day in the covering of short contracts all along the line. On ordinary occasions a bank statement showing such a heavy loss in reserve as that of to-day would have been regarded as "unfavorable," but the bears have taken alarm, and they did not wait on the order of running.

NIAGARA FALLS, June 10. -- There is now well under way what promises to be the most prosperous season Niagara has ever known. It had not such a flourishing beginning as the enterprising landlords expected, for they opened their big hotels unusually early and expected that they would be filled at once. Next month, when the heavy travel to the World's Fair begins, the hotels will probably be taxed to their utmost capacity.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 10. -- This was the last day of the meeting at the Gentlemen's Driving Park, and marked the close of the Philadelphia and Baltimore Circuit. Two races were on the card and each were decided in straight heats and won by the favorites. Reality was the choice of the talent with firs race and was never extended in any heat, winning from start to finish.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 10. -- The Williams College baseball team defeated the Yale Law School here this afternoon by a score of 8 to 6. Williams put up an errorless game, while the boys from New-Haven were rather loose in fielding and not up to their usual standard in batter y work. Williams had a new pitcher, Clarke, '96, during the first half of the game. He did creitably, but showed lack of experience.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 10. -- The announcement here to-day that Secretary Carlisle had called for the resignation or G. Harrison Smith, Collector of Customs at Cape Vincent, caused considerable surprise among politicians, though it was known that Smith's official acts had made him liable to removal lone before Secretary Carlisle was pus at the head of the Treasury Department, and a report against him was supposed to be on file months ago.

The sales of real estate at auction during the present week are to be mainly on judcial order in foreclosure or partition suits. On Monday Mr. James L. Wells's sale of Twenty-third Ward improved and unimproved property and of lots by Messrs. Bryan L. and William Kennelly respectively will take place.

Gen. John B. Gordon, united States Senator from Georgia, has been asked to deliver a lecture in this city on the closing days of the Confederacy and he has promised to do so. The day is not yet selected.

BOSTON, June 10. -- Two more theatres closed to-night for the season -- the Grand Opera House and the Howard Athenaeum. In each case this closing seems to have been somewhat hastily decided upon, for in neither was it announced until the middle of the week. At the former the attraction was "Rosedale," which was produced in fine shape a week ago Monday and was intended to be ran indefinitely.

SOUTHAMPTON, June 10. -- The city to-day is a mass of flags, and everybody is in holiday dress in honor of the arrival of the American Line steamer Paris, bringing the first American Ambassador, Thomas F. Bayard, to England, Southampton has a gala appearance similar to the celebration which attended the arrival of the New-York as the pioneer of the new line.

A large crowd of Brooklyn tennis players gathered on the Kings County Club grounds, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, yesterday afternoon for the second meeting of the Interclub Tennis Association. The Kings County Club had carefully prepared the courts early in the morning, and when the contestants arrived, shortly before 3 o'clock, they were in the beat possible condition.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick Rogers Graves and the Rev. Dr. John MoKim will be consecrated as Protestant Episcopal Bishops of China and Japan respectively, in this city, on Wednesday, June 14. The impressive ceremonies attending the double consecration will he held in St. Thomas's Church, at Fifth Avonue and Fifty-third Street, at 11 o'clock in the morning.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 10. -- There was a lively struggle between two newspaper men and a green-goods operator at the railroad station in this city this morning. Before the operator was captured a bullet had entered his arm, and many of the passengers at the station had experienced the thrilling sensation of having bullets whiz by their ears.

Lloyd Aspinwall, the gay clubman who went to the New-York Hospital on Wednesday, was said yesterday to be greatly improved in condition. He was well enough to leave the hospital at any time, it was announced, but he would probably stay a few days longer.

Mr. Walter Phelps Dodge's crow not only flies, but raffles its plumage and occasionally pecks. A 'Varsity training, we are inclined to believe, accounts for occasional displays of temper. Otherwise, why should he not have felt some pity for that "thirdrate American, author" and his wife who presumed to live at Cannes, and were accordingly frozen out by the English or other persons dwelling there?

The platform or the chapel of Packer Institute in Brooklyn was filled with pretty faces yesterday afternoon when the class of '93 held its class-day exercises, and the auditorium was crowded. The President of the class, Miss Elizabeth Daniels, welcomed the guests.
The outgoing Atlantic fleet yesterday carried the largest number of passengers that has sailed on any day this year.

LIQUID AIR. -- The boiling points of oxygen and nitrogen are respectively 375.8 and 356 (Fahr.) below the freezing point of water, and therefore these are the highest temperatures at which they can be seen as liquids. The most remarkable liquefaction which has yet been accomplished, however, is that of air.

Mrs. Frank Leslie has secured an American divorce from William C. Kingsbury Wilde, brother of Oscar Wilde, and is free to marry again. Mr. Wilde is not. Mr. Wilde was Mrs. Leslie's fourth husband. Her previous husbands were David Charles Peacock. Ephraim George Squier, and Frank Leslie.

The range was occupied yesterday by a detachment of the Seventy-first Regiment composed of Companies B.F. and I, under command of Capt. Smith, and cambering 116 officers and men. Capt. Edwin Guild, the Regimental Inspector of Rifle Practice, supervised the shooting. The weather was fair, with a light "9 o'clock" wind.

PARIS, June 10. -- Cholera has shown itself at Narbonne, in the Department of Aude, on the railway from Bordeaux to Cette, and having communication with the Mediterranean through the Canal of Narbonne, which traverses the town. Doctor Mecle of the Narbonne Hospital, has died of a disease which is pronounced to be cholera.

The title of Chaplain of Ward's Island has been conferred upon the Rev. C.W. De Lyon Nichols by the Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction and the Episcopal City Mission. The Protestant services on Ward's Island Have heretofore been divided between two elergymen of the Episcopal City Mission.

THOUSAND ISLANDS, June 10. -- With the completion of their magnificent steamer, Empire State, the Thousand Island Steamboat Company will open the season, presenting the most perfect service that world-famed region has over enjoyed. The Empire State is beyond doubt more sumptuously fitted than any craft on the river.

"For every evil under the sun There is a remedy or there is none; If there is one, try and find it; If there isn't, never mind it." Scientists tell us that the common house fly is of great value as a scavenger. Perhaps it is. It certainly ought to hare some redeeming quality, for of all the minor evils that beset the cleanly housewife, few are a greater trial than this Summer pest.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- But eleven days remain for the holders of Reading stock and general mortgage bonds to make known their decision regarding, the rehabilitation plan. Up to o-day holders of $12,500,000 of the bonds and 100,000 shares of stock had assented to the plan, leaving 380,000 shares of stock and $27,500,000 of the bonds yet to be heard from.

A young and well-dressed man who shot himself on the pier at Eighteenth Street and the East River last night proved to be William Jones, a clerk for M.D. E. Mildeberger, real estate agents, 80 Carmine Street. He did not attract attention until he discharged a revolver at his right temple, and Thomas Ripler, master of a lighter of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, saw him fall.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 10. -- Harvard and Yale University crews will to-morrow spend their first Sunday on the picturesque banks of the Thames. For a week or more the quarters of both crews were being put in condition for their presence. The Board of Trade Race Committee has been active in its work of preparation, and there now only remains the flagging of the course, which will be attended to next week.

One of the finest strings of horses over exhibited in the Philadelphia and New-York shows is that of the Woodlawn Park Stock Farm, the Summer home of ex-Judge Henry Hilton at Saratoga Springs. It comprises hackney, trotting, pony, and draught stallions, fins coach and four-in-hand teams, bighstopping hansom horses, hunters, jumpers, and pairs of smaller horses for broughams.

The Home for Incurables at Fordham celebrated its twenty-seventh, anniversary yesterday afternoon. The exercises were held in the ivy-covered chapel, which was decorated with flowers and filled with friends of the institution. A number of the patients were also present, reclining in their wheel-chairs.

It was announced yesterday that Mr. John D. Rockefeller was the purchaser of the St. Luke's Hospital property. His same and that of Mr. Flagler of the Standard Oil Company have been repeatedly coupled with the purchase ever since it was made. No authority was given for the statement published yesterday, and Mr. Rockefeller himself was not in town.

Edwin Osbaldeston, the ten-year-old son of Prof. Edwin T. Osbaldeston, President of the New-York School of Training for Massage, who recently ran away from the parental roof, has returned. He had disobeyed me father and received punishment. He complained to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and was arraigned in court, but was turned over to his father when explanations were made.

There is something rather bewildering in the changes through which the World's Fair Sunday opening question goes. Yesterday Chief Justice FULLER granted a stay of the injunction, pending the appeal from the order of the Circuit Court, and the fair will be open to-day, whereat Chicago rejoices.

"I wish I were able to write all the go-tosleep stories that are told to the little folks all over the land every night," said a tender-hearted mother the other day. "It makes me positively sad to think of the small brains that are filled with distorted images, hobgobins, ogres, giants, and the like, just as reason is loosing its hold upon them for several hours.

The double service of the Fall River Line will become effective for the Summer season to-morrow, when the great steamboats, the Puritan, Pilgrim, Plymouth, and Providence, will be in commission and operated together, two boats being run is each direction dally. Steamers will leave New-York week days at 5:30 and 6:15 P.M., the latter touching at Newport at 5:45 A.M. Sundays they will leave New-York at 5:30 P.M., touching at Newport about 3:15 A.M.

An unfortunate woman, deserted by her husband and about to become a mother. Is weeping and bewailing her fate in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, to which place she says she was consigned by the manoenvres of her father.

The annual Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was sailed yesterday. It was hardly the success that the Larchmont yachtsmen expected. The wind was light and fluky and several of the boats entered failed to come to the line. One of these was Mr. J. Rogers Maxwell's new schooner Emerald. On Friday the Emerald ran aground off Bay Ridge and damaged her centreboard.

John P. Noonan, assistant cleric of the Hudson County (N.J.) Freeholders, went to see live Guttenberg races yesterday. He went into the Saloon under the grand stand just after the first race, and while there stopped on a rifle cartridge. The bullet plowed its way along his leg, cutting a gash three inches long. The empty cartridge core flew and hit a gentleman standing near, making a lump of considerable size behind his right car.
Mrs. J. Coleman Drayton arrived on the NewYork yesterday from Southampton, England. Mrs. Drayton was accompanied only by her maid, and no one was at the pier to meet them.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Following the turmoil and bloodshed of yesterday quiet has fallen on the town of Lemont. This morning added another to the list of dead. George Kiskia, who was shot through the right lung, died at 6 o'clock. On the ground beneath a huge oak tree, at Section 10, covered by a gray woolen blanket, lies the body of another victim of yesterday's trouble.
More trouble has overtaken Major William J. Powell of Brooklyn. He reported to Police Captain Eason of Brooklyn on Friday that his wife had run away.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 10. -- The evidence in the Borden trial to-day was chiefly corroborative of prior testimony and not of great value to either side. One witness, however, was badly confused on cross-examination, and others admitted several facts of some importance to the defense.

Machine Democrats freely express their delight over the recent reorganization of the Republican Party in Kings County. These manifestations of delight are caused by the belief that ex-Senator Jacob Worth has become "boss" of the Republican machine. Mr. Worth has been a warm friends of "Boss" McLaughlin since they were young men, and for years Mr. Worth has been known as a McLaughlin Republican.

The squabble for the position of Secretary of the National Republican League, which is soon to be settled by the Executive Committee at a meeting in Chicago, has involved some men of national prominence.

John Convenci, an Italian bootblack eleven years old, and two companions were playing on one of the Mail Street freight elevators of the Post Office last night at 11:15 o'clock, when the elevator started down.

The number of line naval cadets of this year's final graduating class is thirty-six. Of this number the naval retiring board at the Navy Department has authorized the rejection, physically, of two cadets. At the recent Naval Academy final physical examination five cadets were declared disqualified from being commissioned.
Two members of the Custom House Investigating Commission, Poindexter Dunn and Wallace Macfarlane, visited their quarters in the Barge Office yesterday morning. No public hearing was held, however.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 10. -- The annual Caledonian games took place this morning at the 'Varsity grounds. In these games the four classes contest for the Peace Cup, which is given to that class which wins the greatest number of points. It was hot and sultry, and, with one exception, no effort was made to break the record, but simply to win the points.

Says London Figaro: "Should the god be propitious, and should the divine Sarah hold to her expressed intention of paying us a visit again this year, it is interesting to note that in one season Londoners will have had the opportunity of seeing the four greatest actresses in the world, viz., Sarah Beruhardt, Eleonora Duse, Mrs. Bernard Beere, and Miss Ada Rehan.

When Mrs. Lilburne returned from the picnic and dismounted at her own garden gate from the three-horse brake which had carried the party, she assured Mr. Chessall that she had had a most enjoyable day, and she meant what she said. Mrs. Lilburne was fond of picnics, and this had been a very successful one.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Public interest in the disaster of yesterday continues to be very great in this city, and the newspapers that have less regard for calm judgment than they appear to feel for the indignation that is excited by sympathy have fallen into the error of anticipating the action of the Coroner's inquest and have already fixed the blame upon one or more persons.
Mayor Wanser yesterday dealt another severe Wow to the Jersey City Street and Water Commissioners.

The nucleus of the first auxiliary Greek-letter society was formed last night at the Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, where Alpha Delta Phi initiated thirteen professors and students of the Toronto University.

Two thousand little advocates of temperance romped on the grass in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and sang temperance songs and heard temperance speaking. It was the fifth annual rally of the Kings County Juvenile Temperance Union.

The superstition which Jules Lemaitre defined in the phrase, "Happiness is so fragile that one risks the loss of it by talking of it," is abolished by Dr. Brinton in this pleasantly-written book. He discusses many subjects bravely and effectively, and among them happiness as the aim of life, happiness as it depends on nature and fate, on ourselves, and on others, and the consolations of affliction.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 10. -- The financial affairs of ex-Supervisor Sherman T. Poel of the town of Felham, Westchester County, assumed a more serious and darker aspect to-day than they have heretofore, as an element of forgery has entered into them. Mr. Pell disappeared from his home about a month ago, and since then his whereabouts have been unknown to those who would very much like to see him.

LONDON, June 10. -- Another yacht race took place to-day, in which the Prince of Wales's cutter Britannia and Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie, which will be the English contestant for the America's Cup, took part. The course was from the Nore Lightship, which lies between the Maplin Sands and Sheppey Island, marking the entrance to the River Thames, to Dover, at the entrance of the Straits of Dover.

PARIS, May 20. -- The annual banquet of the Students' Association was held last night at the Hotel Moderns. Emile Zola presided and made a speech, which was received with frequent applause by the 150 members, active and honorary, who were present. His address, almost entire, follows:

"Stop him! Kill him! Lynch him!" yelled half a thousand men and women as Albert Schmidt ran past the Brooklyn City Hall yesterday morning and climbed the stairs to the roof of the Washington Building, on Court Street, three steps at a leap.

The annual club regatta of the Staten Island Athletic Club was held on the Kill von Kull yesterday afternoon, The races were witnessed by nearly 500 of the members of the club and gueats, among whom were many women. The course was three-quarters of a mile from a stake boat anchored off Port Richmond with the finish line at the club.

Kuhn, Doerflinger Co., importers of diamonds and precious stones at 18 Maiden Lane, failed yesterday. The house has been established thirty years. The members of the firm are George Doerflinger and Charles Kuhn, Jr. George Doerflinger filed an assignment on behalf of the firm to Frederick Beitz, lawyer, of 111 Broadway, who has been the attorney of the firm for many years.

BERLIN, June 10. -- At the general elections for members of the Reichstag to be hold on Thursday next and at the by-elections that are sure to be required 397 members of the House, the full complement, will be returned. The present weak closes with 1,550 candidates in the field. Not-only new aspirants for seats but new political factions appear daily, and as election day draws gradually nearer the confusion grows worse confounded.

There will be no interruption in the business of the Casino. Fablus M. Clarke and Henry T. Cutters, the receivers, yesterday obtained an order from Judge McAdam of the Superior Court permitting them to continue the business as it has been running.
My friend Smith and I visited the World's' Fair, not to see the sights of which we had read, but those of which we hadn't.

President Wilson and the other officers of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange have prepared their reports for the fiscal year ending May 23 last. They show that transactions in stocks on the Exchange in the year reached 61,084,560 shares, against 80.704,340 in 1891-2 and 75,806,990 in 1890-91. September was the busiest month, with a record of 6,564,720 shares, and July the dullest, with 4,060,900 shares.

Yesterday there was a bad bank statement. A bad statement had been expected. It came out about as calculated. Nevertheless the market advanced. It advanced in the face of the conviction that such a statement was coming, and it advanced still more after its publication. This is an encouraging sign. It means that the forces of recovery have begun to work.

For the present Miss Emma J. Waters will date her love letters from the County Jail, Albany. Miss Waters, otherwise Miss Jessie E. Rivers, is a most expert writer or tender missives, and for some years she has made a good income, thanks to this accomplishment. It was her wont to advertise her charms in the various matrimonial papers published throughout the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 10. -- President Charles Butler of New-York University, whose Summer residence is at Hartsdale Station on the Harlem Railroad, and who has for many years been noted for his beneficent gifts to that locality added another to the number yesterday by presenting to the towns of Scarsdaleland Greenburg a new macadamized roadway leading into Hartsdale Station and a handsome iron bridge across the Bronx River.

SARANAC LAKE, June 10. -- This beautiful spot, with its peaceful waters, gentle, undulating vales, emerald forests, and surrounding lofty, pine-clad mountains, was never lovelier than now. Already the invasion of "summerers" has not only begun, but has continued for several weeks, and the various resorts are rapidly assuming a businesslike air.

The trial of a handsome new vestibuled train of Pullman cars designed for Summer travel on the New-York. Ontario and Western Railroad was made the occasion of a pleasant excursion to Liberty, in Sullivan County, yesterday.

It is generally best to think twice before taking decisive action in any matter of importance, and the old maxim about counting a hundred before giving expression to angry feelings is not without merit. Mr. STARIN appeared anxious yesterday to have the Rapid-Transit Commissioners come together once more and try to agree, but his compromising temper came too late, if he really was in a compromising temper.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 10. -- There was a warm dispute at the morning session of the African Methodist Conference to-day when Presiding Elder W.T.M. Webster had concluded his report of the condition of the churches in the conference.

HIPPOLYTE TAINE. -- Perhaps the most striking thing in him was his modesty. It spoke even in his appearance. There was nothing about him to invite a second look. Somewhat below the middle height, with irregular features, and eyes which showed a slight cast behind their spectacles, his figure somewhat mean, especially in his youth, there was nothing to betray to a careless observer the man he was.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Fear of the Government crop report was the main cause of the reaction in the grain pits to-day from the recent big advance. Business in wheat was brisk. The close was 5/8c lower than on the day before. Corn wan dull, closing with a deline of 1/4c for the day. Provisions were never before speculated in on so small a scale. The nominal closing prices are a trifle lower than yesterday's.
"This is the most unkind thing ever laid at my door in my entire public career," said Congressman Poindexter Dunn of Arkansas to a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- The internal revenue officers seized the exhibit of the Old Times Distillery this morning and placed a guard, in charge of the place. The company had erected a building southeast of the Agricultural Hall and had built a still therein with the intention of manufacturing whisky on the grounds as a part of its exhibit.
Reserve accommodations for Richfield Springs on Past Mail, via New-York Central, leaving 9:10 A. M. on and after June 17. -- Adv.

Charles W. Brooke, counsel for Frank Ellison, who brutally assaulted William H. Henriques last Monday night, waived examination in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, and an adjournment was taken until next Saturday.

Since this volume was prepared for the press its author, who was Bishop of St. Andrews, has passed away. It embraces only eleven years of his life, as against the forty years that were covered by his former volume bearing the same title, from which we see that, after reaching his fortieth year, the activities of Dr. Wordsworth's life increased at a very rapid rate.

The 4,500 houses that comprised the town of Zante before the earthquake shocks began three months ago have now been reduced to 200, all the rest having been either quite demolished or rendered uninhabitable by the shocks, 1,600 of which have shaken the island since March 1. The vibrations of the earth have not yet ceased, three distinct quakes having been felt within a few weeks.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 10. -- A mile was made on a half-mile bicycle track at the meet here to-day by the Murphy brothers of New-York. W.A. Taxis of Philadelphia, and H.C. Wheeler, mounted on a quadricyole, in the fast time of 2:03.
WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The disaster here has called to the attention of officials the condition of other public buildings which, are said to be more or leas unsafe.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The notes interchanged in connection with the announcement of the appointment of Baron Fava as the first Ambassador from Italy to the United States express on both sides much gratification. President Cleveland, through Secretary Gresham, has conveyed to the Baron an expression of his personal gratification over the fact that he has been thus honored by his Government.

The police of the Oak Street Station and Inspector McLaughlin's detectives in the Central Office have a puzzle on hand. For a few days a gentleman's furnisning goods store in Nassas Street, near Beekman has been selling out a "bankrupt stock at 40 cents on the dollar" -- at least this announcement appears in monster letters of red on posters.

PARIS, June 1. -- The name of Gerard Hauptmann is not known in Paris. The German author of the new play of the Theatre Libre, the "Tisserands," is a native of Sllesia. His first play was given to the literary world in pamphlet form in 1889. He is only thirty years of age, and the very charitable possessor, as I am imformed, of a large fortune.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 10. -- Brooklyn's crack regiment, the Twenty-third, arrived in camp here this afternoon and immediately entered on the duties of a week in camp. The regiment, numbering 618 men all told, reached Roa Hook, just above Peekskill, at 2:30, having come from New-York on two special trains.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 10. -- Robert Dietz commenced an action this morning before Justice J.O. Dykman, in a Special Term of the Supreme Court, against Charles W. Gould, assignee of Edward M. Field, son of the late Cyrus W. Field, and who was adjudged insane in New-York a short time ago. The suit is to set aside the assignment on the ground of irregularities at the banking house of which Field was it member.

The construction of the coast-line battle ship Massachusetts was authorized by Congress in an act dated June 30, 1890. By this act the sum of $12,000.000 was appropriated for the construction of three const-line battle ships.

The success of "The Second Mrs. Tanqueray" at the St. James's Theatre, in London, seems to have exceeded expectation. Mr. Pinero finished this daring play more than a year ago, and Mr. George Alexander, who has had it in his possession ever since, had no idea until lately of putting it forward as the regular entertainment at his theatre.

It is high time that the farce of attempting to collect money in this country for the benefit and behoof of the "Parnellite" faction of Irishmen in Ireland should cease. It is something more and worse than a farce, and so far as it has any influence at all upon Irish affairs that influence must be mischievous.

The open letter addressed by Mr. RICE to the President of the Reading Railroad, published in our news columns yesterday, in answer to the recent public announcements of that company, is clear and unambiguous in its statements and devoid of personalities, so far as is consistent with criticism of the policy of the present officials of the property.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 10. -- The special train having on board the Duke of Veragua and party, in charge of Commander Dickins, arrived here at 8:50 o'clock this morning. The party took breakfast on the train, and at 9 o'clock were driven to a hotel. They were met by Mayor Butler, T.V. Welch, Superintendent of the State Reservation, and Peter A. Porter.

Miss Dickens, writing of her father, declares that in the Little Nell of "Old Curicsity Shop" is reproduced much of the character of her Aunt Mary, a sister of Mrs. Dickens, who died when little more than a child. Charles Dickens had a great affection for his young sister-in-law and keenly felt her death.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -- The second game of the intercollegiate championship series with Yale was played here this afternoon, resulting in a victory for Yale by the score 2 to 0. Both pitchers were in fine form and did effective work.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 10. -- The week has been a busy one at the Herreshuff works. Navahoe has been fitted with her cruising rig, Coisnia has her rigging put in place, and the Morgan boat has been smoothed and her lead keel put on.

LONDON, June 10. -- Despite the almost total absence of business, prices remained strong in most departments. Americans improved on good prices from New-York, with Illinois Central, Lake Shore, New-York Central and North Pacific preferred leading. The last name advanced to 37 on the report of the final funding of the floating debt.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10. -- On her trial trip to-day the new gunboat Machias, built by the Bath Iron Works Company, surpassed the expectations of her builders.

RAHWAY, N.J., June 10. -- The second club road race of the Union County Roadsters was held this afternoon at 6 o'clock. The distance, ten miles, was from the corner of St. George's Avenue and Grand Street to the railroad station at Westfield and return. There were fifteen entries. E. Gilbert, with one minute handicap, was the winner; W.S. Martin, one minute handicap, second, and William Chamberlain, Jr., third. Time of the winner, 29 minutes.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- The battle ship Massachusetts, grim and grand, was launched at 10 o'clock this moraine in the presence of a distinguished party, including representatives of the Navy Department and a great crowd of enthusiastic citizens.

ENGLISH LIVINGS. -- There are about 14,000 livings in England and Wales; of these nearly 7,500 are in the gift of the Crown, Prince of Wales. Lord Chancellor, Bishops, Chapters, Archdeacons, universisities, rectors, and vicars, (as such,) and trustees. About 2,000 others are in the patronage (as to 1,400) of peers and (as to the rest) of other titled persons.
Warden Fallon of the Tombs Prison is the angriest man in New-York. It is all because of the escape of Burglar Mayors from the institution over which he presides, on Thursday night.

The charges published laying blame upon the surgeons and authorities of the New-York Hospital for permitting the performance of an operation to ramove a goitre from the neck of Albert Louis, Jr., seem to have little substantiation. The young man died from the effects of the operation, but the facts in connection, with the case have apparently been grossly misstated, exaggerated, and distorted.

The census of patients and "suspects" on North Brother Island at 6 P.M. yesterday was as follows: Typhus fever. 25 patients and 4 "suspects"; smallpox. 24 patients; measles, (simple.) 15 patients: measles complicated with scarlet fever, 3 patients; scarlet fever, (simple,) 30 patients.

OAXACA, Mexico, June 10. -- Julia Blanchard, a young girl whose parents came to Mexico from France a few years ago and settled near here, where they have accumulated a fortune in the cultivation of coffee, has been arrested on the charge of murdering her sister by means of poison. She has confessed her guilt and says that she was led to commit the crime through her uncontrollable love for her sister's husband, Roberto Gavino.
A prophet is never honored in his own country, and the good things, the available things that lie close at hand are seldom valued at their true worth.

Copyrighted, 1893, by the New-York Times. LONDON, June 10. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Unhappily, there has been a large number of occasions during the past dozen years when people who have the Irish cause at heart have been entitled to groan with disgust and despair at the way in which that cause is mismanaged and jeopardized.

One foot in a russet shoe was cooked up on tiptoe. Her blue gingham was made with a fly-away jacket, the white blouse had a wide crimped frill around the throat and down each side of the front. The wind get under the frill and raised it about her head like a ruff. A tip in her hat nodded forward. She looked like a bird poised for fight.

Secretary HERBERT has taken another step toward preparing the naval militia for effective service by offering a week's cruise to the New-York and Massachusetts contingents on the North Atlantic squadron. Probably arrangements can also be made to give the battalions of other States a like tour of duty.

NEWPORT, R.I, June 10. -- A week of perfect Summer weather has witnessed the advent of scores of cottagers, and Bellevue Avenue presents an animated scene. To Mrs. Fred W. Vanderbilt belongs the credit of opening the season of 1893 with the first dinner party, which, though small, was none the less elaborate.
"Ah!" said the Outing Shirt to the Straw Hat, "I see you are out."

GOSSIP OF THE DAY. -- Society people having began to go to the country, very little happened in town last week worth the recording. During the warm days early in the week the elect fled from town before the torrid weather like cattle before a prairie fire, and the Open Air Horse and Cattle Show and the races at Morris Park were the only local attractions to exert any influence over society people.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10. -- All the Catholic churches of Trenton are beautifully decorated to-night in honor of the presence of Mgr. Satolli. The Pope's representative received a worthy welcome here. All the Catholic societies paraded, and escorted him from the Pennsylvania Railroad station to the Episcopal residence on North Warren Street.

ST. PAUL, June 10. -- The sensational fight for the possession of the St. Paul Daily Globe, the leading Democratic newspaper of Minnesota, whose editor is Lewis Baker, Minister to Nicaragua, was begun this morning before Judge Otis in the District Court, on the motion for a receiver by the St. Paul Trust Company, executor of the estate of the late Norman W. Kittson.

When it transpired some time ago that the erratic but gifted composer Camille SaintSaens was at work on an opera on the subject it Phryne, Paris at once became deeply interested. Phryne, it will be remembered, was, like Mr. Kipling's delectable young friend Lalun, "a member of the most ancient profession in the world," and her exceedingly great grandmother was Lilith.

FAST STEAMERS. -- A ship that can make a voyage to New-York and back in a fortnight will earn fifty-two freights in the year, instead of the twenty-six of the boats of twenty years ago. The crew costs no more, if the coal does, and the earnings are double. But there is yet another view of the matter.
CIMARRON, Kan., June 10. -- The California Express, No. 3, west-bound, on the Atcnison, Topeka and Santa Fe, was stopped near this place yesterday and the express car robbed of about $2,000.
"Well, boys, well have a nice quiet game this afternoon," said "Arlie" Latham of the Cincinnati Club as he strode on the grounds at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon.

Officials at the Navy Department are preparing to commission the new armored cruiser New-York early in July. The details to the New-York are practically complete. There remains only one line Lieutenant to be assigned to the new ship. The vacancy is owing to the recent assignment of Lieut. A.E. Culver to the Baltimore.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, June 12 -- A.M. There was a distinct improvement in the financial situation last week, due in large measure to the announcement made by President Cleveland that he would call an extra session of Congress for September to consider currency matters.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott delivered the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Packer Institute, Brooklyn, in the chapel of the institute last evening. The chapel was crowded with pupils, their friends and relatives.

The free storage warehouse of J.H. Hobby's Son, on the northeast corner of South and Clinton Streets, running through to Water Street, was gutted by fire yesterday, involving a loss of upward of $100,000. The warehouse, a three-story building, was erected fifty or sixty years ago.

Over 500 people were in the auditorium of the Casino last night to see a private entertainment given by Sandow, the "Strong Man." The invitations announced that a number of prominent physicians and surgeons would be present, and they probably were, but they were not conspicuous.
THE NEW-YORK TIMES, with the object of obtaining the opinions of the individual members of both houses of Congress, has telegraphed to each one the following message:

"I do not think it is necessary for me to announce that I favor the repeal of the Sherman law, as I have repeatedly stated that I favored its repeal, both in and out of Congress," said W. Bourke Cockran, (Dem.)

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Mariners are complaining to the Navy Department that no action has been taken to remove the floating wrecks in the North Atlantic. There are no less than twenty-two known derelicts at present, and they are a constant menace to navigation. They follow the currents and the directions of the winds, and are liable to appear in the path of a sailing vessel at any moment.

The Duke of Veragua and his party returned to New-York from Chicago last evening escorted by Commander Dickins. They reached the Grand Central Station at 8:50 o'clock, having come on the New-York and Chicago express train, and went to the Hotel Brunswick.

The first of these volumes is somewhat novel in design as well as execution. Mr. Harden avows himself a lawyer, and therefore "trained and accustomed to reasoning" beyond most people, particularly such as a Roman Catholic Bishop and other advocates of Christianity. Properly speaking, he is an old-fashioned deist, for he believes in a God of some sort, but not at all in the God whom Christians worship and adore.
BUFFALO, May 11. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I think the Sherman law should be repealed and a sufficient and stable currency provided by the United States.

DAMARISCOTTA, Me., June 11. -- Gen. James A. Hall of this place died suddenly of apoplexy on the train between Syracuse and Utica, N.Y., this morning. He was on his way home from Columbus Ohio, and was accompanied by his daughter and his grandson.
CHICAGO, June 12. -- It is rumored that the steamer Nyack, an excursion steamer from Buffalo to Chicago via Cleveland and Detroit, has foundered in Lake Erie.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 11. -- With the passage last Thursday by an almost unanimous vote of the plurality amendment to the Connecticut Constitution, the first step is taken toward the reform of that moldy organic law. It is a sentimental, rather than a practical, step, however, as the Democrats have not the slightest idea that the Republicans of the lower house voted for the amendment in sincerity.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The remains of the dead victims of the wreck of Ford's Theatre Friday have nearly all been disposed of, Washington was to-day a city of funerals, and all day long mourners have gone about the streets.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., June 11. -- The application of the Seawasset Oyster Company for a trace of ground under wrater in Long Island Sound, just outside the breakwater, has occasioned much discussion here. At that place last Fall a bed of oysters of natural growth, was discovered from which at least 60,000 bushele of seed oysters were taken.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., June 11. To the Editor of the New-York Times. I favor the repeal of the Sherman act only by a free-coinege silver law. The rate of interest in England is not and never was affected in the slightest degree by the Sherman act. Interest on loans in United States cannot be lowered by lessening volume of money.

If man really earned his bread by the sweat of his brow, then every man in this city yesterday who had to move around much should be able to open a bakery this morning with the wages of his perspiration.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- Dr. Patton has returned from Bermuda, where he had been spending the last six weeks endeavoring to regain his health. He feels much refreshed, and returns to engage in the active duties of college life. He delivered the baccalaureate sermon to-day.
CONCORD, N.H., June 11. -- A "campaign or education" with reference to the political action of the people, at a time when no election is ponding, is a decided novelty in the State of New-Hampshire.

Although the attempt to bring the American Derby candidates together for a race at Morris Park on Wednesday of this week has proved rather or a failure, there will still be good enough sport at the track to satisfy the lovers of racing. For the race that was proposed as a trial of the Derby candidates there have been but three entries, those three being Don Alonzo, G.W. Johnson, and Rainbow.

The President has indicated in his appointment of an Internal Revenue Collector for the district of Kansas that he has no sympathy with the fusion of Democrats and Populists. This is what was to be expected, for Mr. CLEVELAND'S Democracy is of a stalwart order. He is not given to compromising on party principles, and nothing could be further removed from the vagaries of the People's Party than his well-known convictions on public questions.

MENLO PARK. Cal, June 11. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am in favor of a currency of full legal tender for all debts, public and private, based upon perfect and imperishable security to meet all demands so far as the people desire to borrow upon such security, thus stopping for evermore paying interest abroad.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11. -- The Harvard University Cycling Association held its third annual Spring meeting yesterday. A dozen of the clubs, near and in Boston were represented by such men as W.W. Windle, P.J. Berle, P.J. McDuffee, E.A. McDuffee, H.C. Tyler, and G. F. Taylor, but no records were broken, and none of the races was specially exciting.
CHICAGO, June 11. -- A startling disclosure was made at the World's Fair grounds last evening when the priceless laces sent note by Queen Margherita of Italy were unpacked.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- This week closes the fear of '92,'98 at the University of Pennsylvania. Commencement Week opened to-day with the regular baccalaureate service by the Rev. Robert Ellis Thompson at the Tabernacle Presbyterian Church. It will be remembered that Dr. Thompson was the professor over whose forced resignation last year such a fight arose between the students and the authorities.

PARIS. June 11. -- The Grand Prix de Paris was run to-day. Baron A. do Schickler's b.c. Ragotsky came in first; Mr. Rose's b.c. Ravenabnry, second; A. Abeille's br. c. Callistrate, third. Ragotsky is by Perplexe, out of Czardas, and two weeks ago won the French Derby at Chantilly. Ravensbury, the favorite among the English horses that ran, is by Isonomy, out of Penitent.

PUEBLO, Mexico, June 11. -- The most disastrous storm that has ever visited this part of Mexico is reported from the town of Puachmetta, this State. The entire town was destroyed, every residence and building in the plane being swept away by the terrific wind.
"In the name of the Princess, I demand a room," said a well-dressed man at the clerk's desk in the Hotel Savoy yesterday afternoon.
The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott explained his conception of the true mission of the Bible yesterday to a large congregation at Plymouth Church, Brooklyn. He preached from St. John, V., 39:

TRENTON, N.J., June 11. -- One of the reasons why the people of New-Jersey cannot be aroused to a sense of responsibility in taxation is because of extravaganees under the system of raising all the expenses of the State Government by taxing corporations.
Eighty thousand hot, restless people from this and surrounding cities flocked to King McKane's wave-washed stand at Coney Island yesterday.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 11. -- Sunday in camp was observed by the Twenty-third Regiment in almost absolute quiet. There were no drills and no evolutions, except the customary guard mount at 8:30 in the morning and dress parade at sunset.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 11 -- Yale is hurrying toward Commencement Week. The seniors and juniors had their final recitation last Wednesday, the sophomores Friday, and the freshmen Saturday. The final examinations for the seniors and juniors began Friday, and will begin for the other classes this week. Examinations in both the academic and scientific departments will close on the 21st inst., when all, except the seniors, will be at liberty to go home.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Mrs. Cleveland may decide to open the Summer home at Buzzard's Bay within the next fortnight. Upon moving into the Woodier Road villa the President and Mrs. Cleveland had concluded to spend the entire Summer there, with the possible exception of August, when the cool breezes of the seaside home would hold greater attractions and afford the desired change before the resumption of the Winter's social duties.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 11. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I favor the repeal of the Sherman law.

HAVANA, June 11. -- Heavy rains prevailed during the past week, which have caused the loss of all the potato and onion crops in the low lands of Guines, and our markets are being supplied from New-Orleans and New-York.

"I was opposed to the Sherman sliver law from the beginning," said Senator Calvin S. Brice (Dem.) of Ohio yesterday. "I believed that the bill introduced in 1890 should not be passed, and stated my reasons in opposition to it at the time. I have thought ever since then that it should be repealed, and have no doubt now that Congress will repeal it.

TRENTON, N.J., June 11. -- The Apostolic Delegate, Mgr. Satolli, has been greatly honored in Trenton during the past twenty-four hours. He was escorted to the cathedral last night by 2,000 Catholics, representing the Catholic organizations of the city. Since that time he has had five services and half a dozen receptions. He is accompanied by Mgr. Gberratti, his private secretary, and Dr. O'Gorman of the Catholic University.
Navy Department officials announce that the historic old warship Hartford is to be placed in commission again next year.

Albert H. Schoudel, who lives at 272 Stuyvesant Avenue, Brooklyn, went into the country last Saturday night with his family, leaving a negro servant, Emma Crawley, in charge of his house. About midnight John Rogers, a private watchman, saw eight young men go to the basement door of the house and secure admittance.

We give this morning the results of a canvass of the members of the House and Senate who will meet in September to consider the financial situation. The request made by THE TIMES of each member was for information as to whether he favored a repeal of the Sherman law, and whether he favored any plan of currency issue.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- The Baccalaureate sermon for the graduating class of Princeton University was delivered this morning by Dr. Patton in Marquand Chapel. His text was "If therefore the light that is in thee be darkness how great is that darkness." He said in part:

NEWTOWN, L.I., June 11. -- The new Hebrew cemetery of the Mount Zion Association was dedicated this morning. The Rev. Dr. Drachman, rabbi of the Sixty-seventh Street Temple. New-York, was the officiating minister. The exercises were held in a temporary wooden building, which will be replaced by a handsome stone structure.

Mr. Frank Siefert, the father of Elizabeth Shultz, who is in the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn, having been committed by Justice Goetting last Saturday for vagrancy, said to a NEW-YOKK TIMES reporter yesterday:

SHELBVVILLE, Ind., June 11. -- Late yesterday afternoon "Babe" Hawkins, the desperado, with a gang of thirty men armed to the teeth, surprised the town by appearing on the streets for the purpose of avenging the death of his brother, Charles Hawkins, who was lynched a year ago for shooting the City Marshal. He met ex-Sheriff McDougall, whom he had said he would kill on sight.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- With the Harvard games at Cambridge, everything athletic at the University of Pennsylvania, with the single exception of the Cornell-Pennsylvania boat race, comes to a close. The past year has been the most successful, from an athletic point Pennsylvania ever had. In football second place was taken in the league at the expense of Princeton.
Lorenzo Narsorti was shot last night by Andrew Berucci at 529 Carroll Street, South Brooklyn, where Berucci lives.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11. -- The members of the class of '93 heard this morning the last sermon of their college course, the bacoalaureate by President Taylor. The day was pleasant and many guests came to the service in the college chapel. The floral decorations wore simple, "'93" hanging in small green-and-white letters before the altar, and the platform and aisles being tastily trimmed with ferns.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 11. -- The moat remarKable female forger in America, Annio Murphy, otherwise known as Annie M. Doolittle, was convicted at midnight last night of forgery in the first degree, and will to-morrow be sentenced to spend a long term in State prison.

Mr. Burr has made an outwardly attractive book. The type is large, the paper is of fine and heavy quality, the margins are broad, and the binding is good. But beyond this we cannot say that he has contributed very much to advance public knowledge of Anderson's life. Out of these 210 pages fewer than 70 are taken up with the biography.
The new school of St. Agnes's Pariah, 150 East Forty-fourth Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon by Archbishop Corrigan, assisted by a number of priests.
The Rev. G.K. Makely preached in opposition to the opening of the Chicago World's Fair on Sundays to a large congregation at the Cumberland Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, last night.

Miss Mary Cavanagh of 309 West One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street was standing upon the elevated platform at Bleecker Street, on the Sixth Avenue elevated road on Saturday night, with her pocketbook in her hand, when Charles Hallerbeck, a colored pickpocket, grabbed it and ran down stairs.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 11. -- The following story comes from Palvo, a small town in Presidio County, on the Mexican border, and situated in that section of Texas commonly called "The Bloody Peninsula": "In the last days of April Genobebo Lujan, an old Mexican, who was temporarily residing on the Mexican side of the river, called upon Jesus Ramos, said that he was hungry, and requested to be credited for a beef. This was refused.
"There is too much charity in New-York, and the more I study the subject the surer I am of what I say."

Wheat was sold in the Chicago market last Thursday for 63 cents a bushel. This is the lowest price for thirty years, and lower by about 5 cents than the lowest price that had been recorded in any previous year since the civil war.

LANDER, Wyoming, June 11. -- A man who has just arrived from the South Pass country gives some interesting details of the great gold find made by K.C. Burtlett, announcement of which was made in a dispatch from Choyenne printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES last Saturday morning.

The Central Labor Union yesterday declared that the Phoenix Protective Association of Surface Railroad Employes was dead, and had no longer any right to representation in the union unless it could prove that it has been n existence for the last six months.
PARIS, June 11. -- James Gordon Bennett is much better to-night and is resting easily. Dr. Robin is living temporarily at Mr. Bennett's hotel, so as to watch his patient.

There has been a good deal of congratulation among the politicians of Brooklyn lately over what they have been pleased to call the "favorable" report on the Fire Department of the Commission of investigation appointed by Mayor BOODY. It is favorable in the sense that it does not condemn everything in the management of the department, and for that the politicians have some reason to be thankful.

Two thousand friends and supporters of the New-York Turn Verein School looked with admiration upon the young men and boys and girls of the institution who took part in the annual festival and celebration at Washington Park. Sixty-ninth Street and East River, yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, June 11. -- Discount rates were weak during the week at 1 1/2 for three months and 1 for short bills. In spite of the temporary check of gold shipments from the United States, corn and cotton bills are now coming forward and the influx from all quarters has so strengthened the situation that the Bank of England's advances have been repaid, and the reserve at the next return will probably exceed u19,000,000.

There is no trick of dishonest partisanship quite so mean as that of distorting some chance remark of a public man or putting in his mouth words which he never used, ignoring all denials, and trying to injure the man's reputation and to damage his party by persistent reiteration of a petty slander.

The body of the astronomer Prof. Richard A. Proctor now lies in a neglected grave in Greenwood Cemetery, and Miss Mary Proctor, his daughter, it is said, is trying to raise funds to purchase a suitable lot and monument. She is the oldest daughter of Prof. Proctor and her home is in St. Joseph, Mo.

The auction sales of real estate announced for to-day are all to be held in the room in the Trinity Building. Mr. Wells offers improved and unimproved property across the Harlem River, Mr. B.L. Kennelly some lots in West Fiftythird Street, and Mr. William Kennelly a plot in West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street. Details of the sales follow:

The philanthropist who declares that there is too much charity in New-York probably does not mean too much of the spirit of charity or too much systematic aid to those who really need aid. But there is undoubtedly too much promiscuous assistance given to persons who do not try to help themselves, not only by individuals, but even by charitable organizations.

Four young men, who may be able to account for the unusual number of counterfeit bills with which Brooklyn has been troubled for a fort-night, were arrested in that city by Secret Service Officers Callahan and Hayes yesterday. They said that they were Frank Eder of Mott Street, this city, and Amman Antonio of Carroll Street, Joseph H.
The Brooklyn Lotus Circle, or Theoscphical Sunday School for Children, held its last-meeting for the season yesterday at the home of the Superintendent, Miss Lizzie Chapin, 464 Classon Avenue.

The Morris Park Cricket Club played their second league game at Paterson Saturday, where the local club defeated them by 22 runs. This victory was in a great measure due to the fine batting of Chief Officer Smith of the steamship Majestic. who is an honorary member of the club. F. Bullock also showed good form, while S. smith did the best bowling and took 4 wickets for 12 runs.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 10. To the Editor of the New-York Times: I favor repeal of Sherman law. National bank currency could be substituted. based upon security of State and municipal bonds.

"The favors and restrictions that are applied to Americans in China" was the title of a sermon preached by the Rev. Gilbert Reid in the Spring Street Presbyterian church yesterday morning. Mr. Reid, who is a Presbyterian missionary, is in this country on a furlough after ten years' work in China.

Lieut G.N. Whistler, the artillery expert connected with the experiments of the Brown segmental wire-wound gun, reports that in the late test of the five-inch gun at Birdsborough, Penn., an estimated pressure of 78,000 pounds per square inch was obtained.

SING SING, N.Y., June 12. -- For murdering his wife and his friend, because of a jealousy that made insanity the only defense for his crime, John Lewis Osmond was legally killed in the electrical chair in the State prison here to-day.

The Sales of real estate at auction announced for to-day are all at 111 Broadway and include some very good property. The Delaplaine estate. which Mr. Peter F. Meyer sells, has some Bowery and St. Mark's Place realty, besides a Seventh Avenue leasehold. Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly's offerings contain desirable east side property in Orchard and Norfolk Streets.

LONDON, June 12 -- The first in the series of meetings designed by the Unionists to rouse all London against home rule was held in the Royal Surrey Theatre this evening. The Marquis of Salisbury was the most notable speaker. He illustrated his opinion of Mr. Gladstone's action toward Ireland with an elaborate metaphor based on the account of the recent disaster in Washington.

Maurice Bouchor, the exquisite French poet, pupil of Theodore de Banville, author of the enchantingly naive mystery plays which he, Signoret, Ponohon, Klohepin, and the painter Georges Roohegrosse declaim behind the scenes where the marionettes play, in the little hall of the Boulevard dos Capuolnes, is in this city for one or two days.

Immigration Commissioner Joseph B. Senner was not very much disturbed yesterday by the alleged expose published in the American Israelite in Its issue of June 8. The article alleges that the Commissioner is masquerading under an assumed name, and that he left behind him a deserted wife and a history of much interest when he moved from the Fatherland.
A crate of wasted clams was the cause yesterday of a great fright among the Democratic machine politicians in Brooklyn.

At 5 o'clock last evening the Fire Department was stilll at work on the ruins of J.H. Hobby's Son's warehouse, corner of South and Clinton Streets. The Clinton Street wall had been pulled down early in the day and filled the street with a mass of half-burned debris, consisting of hogsheads of tobacco, bales of paper, rags, and straw-hat braid which had been stored in the warehouse.

WHEN THE INFANTA RETURNS. -- When the infanta Eulalie and Prince Antoine return from Chicago, society will be out of town. Ward McAllister Has received letters from the Duke of Tamames introducing Prince Antoine, but Mr. McAllister is not positive whether or not he will give a dinner in his honor. The lateness of the season is apt to interfere seriously with a successful stag dinner.

The Russian flagship Dimitri Donskol and the United States monitor Miantonomoh, lying in the North River off Forty-second Street, were run into early yesterday morning by canalboats coming down the river from Albany in the tow of several tugs.

The committee of the Harlem River Regatta Association held a meeting last night at the Grand Union Hotel to settle up the finances of the late regatta and to hand over the caps and plate to the winning clubs. The clubs represented by their delegates were Metropolitan, Union. Dauntless, Nonpareil, Atalantas, Nassau, Wyanoke, Friendship, and Lone Star.
Those best informed agreed yesterday that it looked as if the Rapid-Transit Commissioners would, shortly come together and agree upon some definite plan for elevated railroad extension.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Madison Hall was crowded to-day with delegates from all parts of the United States and Canada to the forty-first annual convention of the International Typographical Union. W.B. Prescott of Indianapolis, President of the organization, called the assembly to order, and Mayor Harrison welcomed the union to Chicago and tendered them the freedom of the city.
BALTIMORE, June 12. -- A civil suit has resulted from the encounter between Gen. John Carroll of The Caves and Capt. William C. Nicholas at Owing's Mills.

There was a pretty wedding at noon yesterday at Ascension Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, when, Miss Amy Bradish and Edward J. Sanford, Jr., were married. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Bradish of this city, and the bridegroom is the son of Judge Sanford of New-Haven. He is a graduate of Yale and has been practicing law in New-York.

The force at the Appraiser's Stores was in a state of mind yesterday, for it was convinced that it was under the surveillance of detectives. Accordingly its members looked with suspicion upon all strangers, especially such as chanced to show a disposition to loitor in the neighborhood.

The New-York and Brooklyn Bridge Trustees met in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. President Howells and Mayor Boody presented a plan for securing to the Brooklyn City Railroad Company a guarantee of payment for the land seized between Fulton, Sands, and High Streets and the entrance to the bridge for the extension of the Brooklyn terminus.

The Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur of Calvary Baptist Church was surprised yesterday afternoon when a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter called on him and showed him an anonymous letter, purporting to come from the Circulo-Colon-Cervantes, in which Dr. MacArthur is accused of belittling the character of Columbus and disparaging Spain and its people.

The decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of ex-Commissioner of Labor Statistics PECK brings that matter back to the basis of law and common sense from which it was whirled by political excitement and partisan bias last year, insomuch that an Albany court sustained a demurrer to the indictment against PECK.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 12. -- Capt. Joseph Shelby brought to this city and lodged in the county jail to-day Gonzalo Mono and Navato Pena, charged with violating the neutrality laws. The proper name of the former is Marco Sandoval, and he participated in the Retimal fight. Both men were arrested in the mountains of Peeos County by Capt. Shelby and Corp. Kerchner of Company D of Capt. Jones's rangers.
Augustus Baran, a waiter, of 151 East Houston Street, presented a sorry sight yesterday when he was arraigned in the Essex Market Police Court for assaulting Officer John Hodge.

Christian Wohlforth, a Brooklyn pork packer, is suing, before Judge McAdam in the Superior Court, for a divorce from his wife, Catherine Wohlforth, on statutory grounds. The case was heard yesterday, but decision was reserved.

Small electric fans for cooling rooms where a breeze or a draught of air is unknown on a hot Summer day are being used quite extensively this year, not only in business offices but in the household as well. They are found convenient for reducing the temperature of dining rooms situated near the kitchen, and they are even used in sleeping rooms, for they are so constructed that they revolve without noise.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 12. -- Alfred A. McCurdy, a deserter from the United States Army, has been arrested here. Oct. 20, 1888, McCurdy and another soldier named Lynch were prisoners in the guardhouse at Jefferson Barracks, St. Louis, from which they escaped by killing the guard. Before McCurdy became a soldier he was a noted professional bicycle rider and the winner of many long-distance races.

William Easton sold at Tattersalls, corner of Sventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday morning, fifty-seven head of registered and half-bred hackneys, consigned from the establishments of A. J. Cassatt, John A. Logan, Jr., and other well-known breeders. The attendance wag good, but the prices realized were only lair and bargains were plentiful. Mr. Cassatt's offerings showed a fair average, but the remainder were largely half-bred ponies.

There was a lively meeting of the West End Protective League at the Hotel Endlcott last night. The principal subject under discussion was the increase or saloons on the vest aide and the methods for stopping it.

The assignment of Edward H. Ammidown, wholesale dealer in dry goods, formerly at 68 Worth Street, who failed on Dec. 5, 1890, with liabilities of about $700,000, Has been set aside by Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court, Mr. Ammidown had assigned to his former partner, Albert D. Smith.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- A receiver was appointed this morning for the Harvey World's Fair Hotel and the Harvey Home Improvement Company. Walter Thomas Mills is the principal creditor. The assets of the Home Improvement Company are scheduled at $141,500 and the liabilities at $99,000, and the assets of the hotel company at $85,000, with $90,000 liabilities.

A peculiar litigation is going on before Lawyer Adolph L. Sanger, as referee, between Mrs. Mary Scott Rowland and the executors at the estate of the late Mrs. Mary H. White. Mrs. Rowland presented a claim for $250 to the executors last Winter for services rendered Mrs. White during her lifetime, but as she was unable to produce written evidence that it was just, they refused to pay it.

HAVANA, June 12 -- The Executive Committee of the Conservative Party has started an agitation against the proposals of the Spanish Minister of Colonies for administrative reforms in Cuba. The committee objacts especially to the plan to substitute one General Council for the several Provincial Councils.

DULUTH, Minn., June 12 -- The annual meeting of the Minnesota Iron Company and the Duluth and Iron Range Railway was held here this morning. Gov. Flower of New-York, Marshall Field and George M. Pullman of Chicago, Benjamin Brewster of Pennsylvania, and many other prominent men were here. The iron company elected as officers: H.H. Porter of Chicago. Chairman: D.H. Bacon of Tower.

BRISTOL, R.L., June 12. -- The Rogers cup defender Colonia was given her first trial trip this afternoon, but on account of the prevailing light wind it amounted to but little other than to give the sailmaker and those on board an opportunity to see how the new Sea Island cotton sails set. At an early hour this morning the work of bending the mainsail, which was uncompleted Saturday night, was finished.

ORANGE, N.J., June 12 -- The Riding Club of Orange to-day celebrated the completion of the subscription to a new clubhouse by a dinner in the Essex County Country Clubhouse. One hundred covers were laid.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Secretary Carlisle and Assistant Secretary Hamlin had a conference this evening in regard to the pending investigation of the New-York Custom House. At this conference Mr. Hamlin, as the result of his recent visit to New-York, acquainted Secretary Carlisle with the progress made and the gist of the evidence thus far given.

Within a year eleven persons have been killed by trolley cars in Brooklyn, two more owe their death directly to the trolley lines, and many have been seriously maimed. This record is all said to be duo to the continued carelessness of the motormen, and has been the subject of frequent complaints to Mayor Boody.

CINCINNATI, June 12. -- For three days this week Cincinnati will entertain members of the Order of the Mystic Shrine, the occasion being the mooting of the Imperial Council of North America of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Snrine. It is estimated that 5,000 Nobles, coming from all parts of the Union, will take part in the festivities.
Yesterday was class day at Columbia College for the class of '93. The exercises were held in the library, which was decorated with Columbia's flags and banners, and trophies won from other colleges.

PEORIA, Ill., June 12. -- There is an ominous quiet about the Whisky Trust office in this city; it is a calm before the storm. The suit of Attorney General Maloney will be heard in Chicago on the 23d. Some now and startling evidence has been discovered Dy him. He has secured a number of affidavits from distillers in Chicago and Peoria which he considers important.

Jacob Rosenblume of 156 Ludlow Street was charged in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday with the manslaughter of his wife. The complainant was Mrs. Ida Orminsky, a widow, of 56 Orchard Street, the mother-in-law of Rosenblume.

More than 95 per cent. of the Richmond Terminal securities have been deposited with Drexel, Morgan Co. under the terms of the reorganization plan. This almost unanimous action on the part of the security holders is regarded by the committee -- Messrs. Coster, Sherman, and Thomas -- as practically assuring the success of the plan.

We remarked a day or two ago that there were signs of the handiwork of ex-Controller LAWRENCE in that part of the Ohio Republican platform which relates to the duties on wool. We now learn from the local reports of the convention that the names of two of the members of the Platform Committee were as follows:

WOODSIDE, L.I., June 12. -- William Van Steinberg, the thirteen-year-old son of John A. Van Steinberg of 357 Fourth Avenue, New-York, was fatally shot here yesterday while at play. He had been taken by his mother to a picnic at Eberhard Dengler's Park, and began to play ball with some boy companions.

Although the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church has suspended the Rev. Dr. Briggs, the spirit of Briggsism seemed to be rampant as ever at the meeting of the New-York Presbytery yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Supervising Architect O'Rourke of the Treasury Department today made an inspection of the Bush Building, which is occupied by the Sixth Auditor's office, Treasury Department. This is the building which was declared unsafe several months ago by the clerks, and on examination it was decided to relieve the floors of the heavy cast-iron files, voluminous boots of record, and other weighty matter.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 12 -- The grounds of the Rochester Driving Association presented a picturesque appearance to-day when the thirty-fifth annual trap tournament of the New-York State Sportsmen's Association was opened. Four sots of expert traps were arranged in a semi-circle, with five traps in each. In the rear of the centre was a large marquee, furnished with eatables for the use of the gunners.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 12. -- The defense won a decided advantage to-day when the court excluded as evidence the testimony given by Lizzie Borden at the inquest held soon after her father and stepmother were murdered in Fall River.

There were two mysterious fires during last week at the residence of Dr. Albert H. Fridenberg, 60 East Sixty-first Street, and as the result of the investigation by Fire Marshal Mitchel and Detectives Lang and Weller of the East Sixty-seventh Street police, William Jones, the doctor's colored coachman, is under arrest on suspicion of having kindled both fires, an accusation which, however, he indignantly denies.

The New-York Tennis Club began its annual Summer tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts. One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The events contested were the men's singles and the men's doubles. In the singles J.F. Hobart showed up well. His match with S.L. Smith in the opening round was one of the features of the afternoon's play.
