COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 12. -- Favored by nature with the most romantic scenery on all Long Island, shady nooks and moonlight walks in plenty, Cold Spring Harbor is an Eden by day and a fairy land by night. It has its "lovers' lanes" by the score, and but little grass grows upon them.

Capt. Francis J. Higginson, United States Navy, reached tills city yesterday from Greytown, Nicaragua. Capt. Higginson Is the late Captain of the United States cruiser Atlanta who was relieved of his command recently by Capt J.R. Bartlett.

PIEDRAS NEGRAS, Mexico, June 12. -- The preliminary trial of George Spence, Superintendent of the Fuente Coal Mines, who was arrested upon the charge of murdering sixteen of the imprisoned miners who met their death in the mine a week ago, is progressing in the court here slowly. Meanwhile Mr. Spence continues to discharge his duties at the mines under the double security of a ten-thousand-dollar bond and a personal guard who attends him continually.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 12. -- The attempt of a love-sick youth to kill his sweetheart and himself created a sensation in the upper portion of the city this afternoon.

The Coroner's inquest into the cause of the death of the victims of the Ford's Theatre collapse in Washington will be followed by an investigation by a military court of inquiry, and between the two the facts in the case ought to be so clearly established that there will be no difficulty in fixing the responsibility for the disaster.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 12 -- This month is one of celebrations at the fair. One of the most Interesting days will be June 27, Brooklyn Day. The committee appointed by the citizens, which has Mirabeau L. Towns as Chairman, made arrangements with Secretary Gulp of the Ceremonies Committee of the fair to-day for the celebration.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Secretary Lamont has decided, as seated some weeks ago in these dispatches, that the contests for army prizes for small-arms firing will take place this year at Fort sheridan, near Chicago. The tests will be conducted by Capt. Frank Baldwin, Firth Infantry, an authority on the subject. The competitors will report at Fort Sheridan by Sept. 11.
The Duke of Vorague spent a quiet day at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday.

In the Emanuel Baptist Church of Brooklyn the class of '93 of Adelphi Academy received its diplomas last evening. The parchments, which were distributed by Charles M. Pratt, President of the board of Trustees, bore the names of:

The thirty-sixth or Columbian regatta of the Brooklyn, Yaoht club was Sailed yesterday, and the managers have to congratulate themselves on its success. It was the first open regatta that the club bas had in the remembrance of the oldest member. It marts a new era in the history at the Brooklyn Club, and the members say that now the club is going ahead and will soon be giving the leading clubs a close race.

In addition to the telegrams published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday from United States Senators and Representatives in Congress, giving their opinions as to the repeal of the Sherman act, some additional telegrams have been received which are given below. As stated yesterday, THE NEW-YORK TIMES sent to each member of each house of Congress the following message:

The department of architecture at Columbia College under Prof. Ware has an enviable reputation among those who are able to compare the various institutions of learning in which architecture is well supported. The number and size of the buildings in course of erection here make New-York a great centre for architects on the principle of the eagles that are gathered together.

A legal point of considerable importance was decided in the Borden case at New-Bedford yesterday. The prosecution desired to put in as evidence the statements of the accused made at the Coroner's inquest last August before she was placed under arrest charged with the murder. An agreed statement of facts was made up as a basis for argument and for the decision.

After a moat interesting game the Brooklyns won from the Cincinnati Club as Eastern Park yesterday. It was a heavy batting contest, tho Brooklyns, making 15 and the Cincinnatis 13 hits. Mullane started in to pitch for the visitors and he was pounded unmercifully in the second and eighth innings. After that Sullivan was pat in the box and he was also hit hard.

The total east-bound shipments from Chicago for the week were 61,647 tons, against 52,559 tone the week before and 53,736 tons the corresponding week last year. Lake Shore led with 12,030 tons. Other roads carried as follows: Michigan Central, 6,982; Wabash, 3,573; Fort Wayne, 9,054; Pan Handle, 7,114; Baltimore and Ohio, 2,792; Grand Trunk, 3,976; Nickel Plate, 5,783; Erie, 7,949; Big Four, 2,414.

The Charles P. Kollogg Clothing and Men's Furnishing Company of Chicago, whose assignment was announced in yesterday morning's NEW-YORK TIMES, had dealings with about twenty-five firms in this city, and some of these had traded with the company since its establishment twenty-five years ago.

WEST POINT, June 12 -- Once a year the cadet is hilarious in barracks -- the day of commencement, when the first class receives its diplomas and goes its several ways, the junior cadets are promoted to tie cadet officers, and the "plebs" become "yearlings."

William Heisen, thirty-five years old, of 155 East Fifty-second Street, was taken to the Presbyterian Hospital last night suffering from a broken arm, an injury to an artery in the arm, and prostration from loss of blood.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 12 -- An interesting lawsuit which will soon occupy the attention of the Civil District Court is the contest over one of the clauses of the will of Joseph Hernandoz, for a number of years one of the largest capitalists of New-Orleans and the President of the New-Orleans and Carrollton Railroad Company.

At the Jersey City Street and Water Board meeting yesterday Mayor Wanser may be credited with several victories over the board. The first was in relation to the proposed vacation of Washington Street south of the "Gap" for the benefit or the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

The first prices to-day were a little above Saturday's closing, bat the improvement did not hold. A decline set in early and continued until well on in the afternoon. There was au unimportant rally about 2 o'clock, but in the final hour the trade was only fairly steady. The close was very dull and in many instances the last prices were the lowest of the day.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- The opening Class-Day exercises of the class of '93. Princeton College, were held in the First Presbyterian Church this morning. Philip King of the District of Columbia acted as master of ceremonies and delivered the salutatory. The class oration was given by Alexander Marshall Thompson of Pennsylvania and the class poem by Charles Bertram Newton of Pennsylvania.

Trewey, the nimble-fingered gentleman with the mobile face, who was a part -- if not, indeed, the principal part -- of Prof. Herrmann's "transatlantic" variety show a row years ago, reappeared here last night in the Casino Roof Garden. He has acquired no new skill in the interval, and, indeed, once or twice in his interesting exhibition of jugglery last night he seemed to be "butter-fingered," which is a seasonable expression.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12 -- Constable McGrath of Summit escorted a badly pummelled prisoner to the Union County Jail at Elizabeth to-night. The Constable's charge was Dr. George H. Perrine, once the proprietor of Perrino's Mountain Home at Summit. He was charged with having allenated the affections of J.C. Kellington's wife.

VISALIA, Cal., June 12. -- John Sontag, one of the notorious train bandits, was brought to this city at 10:30 this morning. He is mortally wounded. It was he, and not Christopher Evans, his companion, who was wounded in last night's battle. Evans made his escape into the mountains.

The Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter scored another point against his detractors last night, when the committee appointed by himself to investigate charges of questionable conduct by him as pastor was continued under the appointment of the members of the Tabernacle Baptist Church. The meeting at which this happened had been called by the committee, and Dr. Potter's friends, mostly women, turned out to see that his interests were protected.

The death on Sunday of the bay filly, sister to Domino and Correction, which was to have been sold with the other yearlings or the Dixiana Stad, took much of the interest oat of the sale at Tattersalls last night. There were a number of youngsters by Himyar, the sire of Domino, put up in the ring, tout the prices were not up to expectations.

Col. Weber, formerly Superintendent, of Immigration, who was sent abroad in 1891 to study the character and habits of intending emigrants to the United States, was asked yesterday by a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES what he thought of the threatened exodus of Polish Jews. He replied:

JOHN BISSELL a retired lawypr, died yesterday morning at his residence, 241 Park Avenue, at general debility. Mr. Bissell was born in 1807 in Ulica, but his early years were passed at Litchfield Conn., where he prepared for the practice of the law. In 1831 he came to New-York City, and for many years he had an office at 11 Wall Street. He retired from the practice of his profession eighteen years ago.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Fraction reform will ocoupy the attention of the World's congress auxiliary during the present week. The proceedings are under the auspices of the International Congress of Charities, Corrections, and Philanthropy. The event has brought together a host of the world's moat devoted humanitarians, and an extraordinary list of names was inscribed on the register in the reception room of the Art Palace this morning.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 12 -- Those who opened the cases containing the laces loaned to the fair by Queen Margherita were dismayed on finding that a large portion of valuable textures promised from Italy was not in them. As the invoices tallied, and as the United States seals on the boxes were unbroken, the Government was relieved of all responsibility in the loss of the laces, it there was such losa.

An Important test of torpedo nets will be made in Newport Harbor early in August. The test will be in charge of the United States Naval Torpedo Board, the President or which is Commander G.A. Converse.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 12 -- Otto Praeger, a young newspaper reporter of this city, left here tills morning on a bicycle trip to Chicago. He goes via Fort Worth, Oklahoma, Kansas City, and St. Louis, and expects to reach Chicago in the early part of July.

In the easiest possible manner the New-Yorks iron from the Louisvilles yesterday. It was nothing more than a practice game Hemming, who pitched for the visitors, was bit hard and often by the Giants, who scored runs until they were tired. Baldwin was in the box for the New-Yorks and although ho kept down the batting, he was wild, giving no lean than seven men their bases on balls.

Walter Green, seven years old, son of John J. Green., a painter living at 1,988 Third Avenue, may die of meningitis, due, it is said, to a blow dealt him by Charles Peyser, a furrier of 1,986 Third Avenue. Peyser, who is in custody, admits that his temper got the better of him and that he slapped the boy's face.

The departure of the American sloop yacht Navahoe for England may be said to mark the beginning of a new era in international yachting. It is years since an American racing craft undertook the uncertain task of bearding the British lion in his deu. Our yachtsmeu have been contented to sit at home and nurse that dear and honored trophy, the America's Cup.

LONDON, June 13. -- The Right Hon. Henry Chaplin, President of the Board of Agriculture in the late Salisbury Government, asked in the House of Commons, to-day, what truth there was in the report that the Herschell Commission, appointed to consider and report upon the monetary troubles of India, had recommended that the coinage of silver for private account in India be stopped.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Chief Justice Bingham of the Supreme Court of the District issued an order this morning requiring the Acting Coroner to show cause, at 3 o'clock this afternoon, why Col. Ainsworth should not be allowed to be represented by counsel at the inquest.

Judging from the manner in which the New-Yorks are playing ball these days they have struck the long-looked-for gait. At any rate, their work during the past week would lead one to believe so, as they have proved winners in five successive games against the teams of Pittsburg and Louisville.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 13. -- Class day exercises were held at Cornell University tills morning. President Harlan Moore presiding. The first part of the programme was given in the armory, which was filled to the doors. The ivy planting, the ivy oration, the history, prophecy, and presentation of the classships occurred in the open air on the campus.
There was a collision early last evening in the East River off the foot of Grand Street, between the ferryboat Garden City of the Long Island Railroad Company and the tugboat William H. Walker.

The foreign exchange market was inactive but rather steadier in tone. The posted rates for sterling were $4.86 for 60-day bills and $4.88 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.85@$4.85 1/4 for 60-day bills, $4.87@$4.87 1/4 for demand, $4.87 1/4@$4.87 1/2 for cable transfers, and $4.83 1/2@$4.84 for commercial.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- The exercises of commencement week were continued this morning by the reading of theses by the graduating class of the John C. Green School of Science in Chemical Hall.
WESTCHESTER, N.Y., June 13. -- The Duke of Veragua disappointed His Grace Archbishop Corrigan and a large number of ladies and prominent gentlemen to-day.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The second day of the inquest into the causes of the Ford Theatre Building disaster was not marred, as was the first, by the development of a desire to turn it into a lynching, and Deputy Coroner Schaefler and the jury made some headway in the line of inquiry which they seem to have marked out to be pursued.
Dr. D.C. Potter and his accuser were both present when the committee of investigation appointed to make inquiries into the charges against him was called to order last night.

The Board of Park Commissioners will decide at its meeting to-day where the new monument to William Cullen Bryant, the American historian and poet, will be placed in Central Park. For several years the Metropolitan Museum of Art has had in its possession a bronze bust of the dead poet by Launt Thompson. This bust was executed by Mr. Thompson while Mr. Bryant was still alive, and submitted to him and his family for approval.

While at work at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday morning, the Marcus Daly candidate for the Suburban Handicap burst his hoof, and will not be able to start in the great race of next Tuesday. How serious the injury is is not certainly known, but it is feared that the horse will not be able to be trained again this season.

NEW-LONDON, June 13. -- The Viking ship arrived in New-London Harbor at 4 o'clock this afternoon, the first American port she has entered since leaving Bergen, Norway, April 30. All are well on board and the ship is in excellent condition.

There was rather more animation at the real estate auction salesroom in the Trinity Building yesterday than has been customary recently. The property offered included some of the kind which tempts the bargain hunter, and among the bidders were many whose faces are familiar at real estate sales.

At the combination sale of thoroughbred yearlings at Tattersalls last evening, Mr. Easton sold forty-three head for a total of $24,975 -- an average of $580. The beat prices obtained were for the following animals:

PARIS, June 13. -- At to-day's session of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration, Sir charles Russell of British counsel said that the United States proposed regulations of the seal fisheries that would leave British interests in a worse condition than they were under the Russian ukase issued in 1821 in regard to the sealing industry.

When Miss Aimie Wollcot, daughter of Mrs. Almie Wollcot of 307 West Thirtieth Street, woke up at 7:40 o'clock Tuesday morning, she saw a man putting things from her bureau into his pockets and holding under his arm her jewel box, containing $1,500 worth of diamonds.

To the Editor of the New York Times: I favor the repeal of the Sherman silver law and the enactment in lieu thereof by Congress of a law which would require the coinage of all silver bullion now owned or held by the Government, as well as all other silver bullion which may be presented for coinage. In regard to the maintainance of a parity of value, as near as can be established by legislation.

PARIS, June 13. -- Mr. James Gordon Bennett, who was injured by falling from a coach on Wednesday last, and who underwent a rather severe surgical operation in consequence, continues to make favorable progress toward recovery. It is expected, however, that he will be compelled to keep to his bed for several weeks.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 13. -- Ex-Mayor Gloason has given Long Island City a sew sensation. The big safe which he blandly surrendered to-day to the Sanfora administration, and which was supposed to contain the long-sought for books of the Board of Education and other important documents, was found to be practically empty and valueless to the city when it was opened at the City Hall this evening.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, June 13. -- The quiet life of the camp was broken this afternoon by two accidents which occurred at almost the same time, and which created a great deal of excitement among the companies of the Twenty-third Regiment

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, June 13 -- P.M. The fluctuations in to-day's market were meaningless. The transactions were only 164,585 shares all told, and if there are deducted from that amount the operations of the "scalpers" a very small share remains to be attributed to legitimate speculation on investment orders.

William H. Henriques, the broker who was assaulted by Frank Ellison, was so much, worse yesterday that his family and doctors became alarmed, and they do not now entertain very high hopes of his recovery.

The Brazilian war ships Aquidaban and Tiradentes will sail from this port to-day for Rio de Janeiro. They will go directly to Barbades, where coal will be taken on board. The voyage will then continue to Bahla, and then to Rio.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 13. -- The sun shone brightly this morning over the Rochester Driving Park when the members of the New-York State Sportsmen's Association began breaking king-bird targets Long before the time for opening the sport there was a big crowd on the grounds. The shooters had been arriving in town on the various night trains, and this morning there was the largest attendance ever seen at a State shoot.

It was not the fault of the Atlantic Yacht Club men that their regatta was a failure yesterday. The yachts were there all trim and taut. The yachtsmen were there to start them, and on the iron steamboat Cepheus there were lots of pretty girls to watch the amateur sailors handle their boats. The weather, however, was against all yacht racing. It was foggy, rainy, and there was hardly a breath of air stirring.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 13. -- Another unfortunate person, has probably sought relief in the waters of Niagara. Harry E. Holmes of Pittsburg, Penn., was last heard from in this city. He was the Treasurer of the Pittsburg Fuel Company, and had a wife and two daughters.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Judge McConnell has returned a decision against the American Preserver' Trust which may hare an important bearing. The decision was made by the court in a case brought by the Preservers' Association against Andrew D. Bishop of Evanston.

The sales of real estate at auction scheduled for to-day include a row of houses on East One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, two on East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, two residences on West Seventy-seventh Street, and a business building on Howard Street by William Konnelly; four flat houses by Richard V. Harnett, a store and tenement in Chrystle Street by Smyth Ryan. Details of all sales are subjoined:

The eighth annual regatta of the New-Rochelle Yacht Club will be sailed off New Rochelle on Saturday, July 1. It is open to yachts of the following clubs: American, Atlantic, Corinthian of Marblehead, Douglaston, Eastern Field and Marine, Jersey City. Knickerbocker, Larchmont, Massachusetts, New-Haven, New-Jersey, New-York, New-York Athletic Club, New-York Corinthian, Pavonia, Riverside, and Seawanhaks Corinthian.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin has instructed the Collector of Customs at New-York to refund the duties paid under the conditions involved in the suit of Blumieln Co. against the United States, which recently has been decided against the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Secretary Carlisle today gave some figures in regard to Treasury operations in silver. After showing that the total coinage of silver dollars under all acts since 1878 has bean $419,294,835, he says:

Emile Levassenr, the distinguished French scientist and statistician, held a conference last night in the President's room at Columbia College with a number of representatives of organized labor in America.

Dr. Robert Welsford Buohanan, who Will be put to death in the electrical chair for having poisoned his wife unless the conviction returned against him on April 28 can be overturned, was brought from the Tombs prison to the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning to have sentence pronounced upon him by Recorder Smyth.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13. -- This was Class Day at Vassar. At 3 o'clock the chapel was filled with guests, and soon the freshmen and sophomores marched in, ushered by Miss Mabel S. Jones, sophomore Marshal, and Miss Bertha Reed, freshman Marshal.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 13. -- There was intense excitement here this evening when the announcement that Company D, Third Infantry. United States troops, First Lieut. McCoy in charge, had taken a special train at 6:15 P.M. for Brainerd, whence it was to march with all possible speed to the Leech Lake Reservation, seventy-five miles away.

BOSTON, June 13. -- Mystic Park welcomed the harness racers this afternoon, when a programme began which is to continue for the rest of the week. A smooth, well-kept track awaited the fliers, and even in the slow classes the miles were rapid.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, June 13. -- The Government has shown great friendliness to a project for a large American hotel here and has extended the time required for commencing building. The hotel is to be built under the Lizardi concession, but it is announced that no similar privileges will be given in future.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Eulalie, the Spanish Princess, made her farewell visit to the World's Fair to-day, and it was quite as unostentatious as any of the visits she has yet made. She was attended by the same small party of men and women who have attended her on all excursions to the White City, and her presence attracted but little attention.
NEWARK, N.J., June 13. -- A strange incident in rejard to the Borden case has just been told to Police Captain Andrew McManus of this city by William W. De Vero, a barber at 32 Bridge Street.

Walter Green, the seven-year-old child of John J. Green of 1,988 Third Avenue, is lying ill with meningitis, the result of a blow on the left side of his head and face dealt to him in a moment of anger by Charles Peyser, who lives with his parents next door to the Green family.
Father Corrigan of Hoboken is authority for the statement that Mgr. Satolli will not attend the commencement exercises at Seton Hall College, Orange, to-day.

Answers to the telegrams sent to the members of the Fifty-third Congress by THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in which they were asked to state briefly as to whether they were in favor of the repeal of the Sherman law and as to what plan of currency issue they favored, are still coming in.

VISALIA, Cal., June 13. -- Chris Evans, Sontag's companion in crime, is at last a prisoner in the county jail here. One of his eyes is shot out, his right arm is broken in two places, and his left arm is shot through the fleshy part.
The Custom House investigators went to the Appraiser's Stores yesterday, and there they found out two interesting things.
One chapter of a romance which, began in Cairo, Egypt, with a lady of the English aristocracy and a wealthy English gentleman as the principals, was enacted at the Hotel Savoy recently.

OMAHA, Neb., June 13. -- There was a run today on every savings bank in the city, precipitated by the failure of the McCague Savings Bank yesterday, followed by the downfall this morning of the American National Bank, in which the McCagues are largely interested.

Four persons, two men and two women, were killed and eight others were seriously injured at a fire just alter 8 o'clock yesterday morning in the six-story brick building 10 and 12 Montgomery Street, the upper floors of which were occupied as tailor's shops by five different concerns.

It is too plain to be concealed that certain evil-disposed persons in the City of Washington are attempting to make use of the grief of the relatives and friends of the clerks who lost their lives in the Ford's Theatre disaster to excite a feeling of rage against Col F.C. AINSWORTH, Chief of the Record and Pension Bureau of the War Department.

It the weather is favorable, the New-York Society for Improving the Condition of the Poor will give its first "ocean parry" of the season to-day. About 500 beneficiaries, carefully selected from overcrowded tenement houses, will sail at 9 o'clock by an Iron steam-boat from Twenty-second Street and North River, and at 9:30 o'clock from Pier 1, for "The People's Seaside Home," at West Coney Island.

President Joseph S. Harris of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad issued a circular to the stockholders and the bondholders yesterday approving the plan of rehabilitation which has been so sharply criticised by Mr. Isaac L. Rice and others.

PATERSON, N.J., June 13. -- As early as 9 o'clock this morning pilgrims to the shrine of St. Anthony, at Butler, began to arrive in this city over the various railroads. They took the Susquehanna from here, and by noon the sleepy old town on the borders of Passaic and Morris Counties was swarming with them.

A proposition to make a halt-fare rate for special excursions to the World's Fair will be laid before the General Passenger Agents of the Truuk Line Association at their meeting in this city next Tuesday. The sentiment in favor of cheaper rates to enable persons of moderate means to see the great fair in Chicago is quite general among the Eastern railroad men.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 13. -- The grinning skull of Andrew J. Borden was exhibited in the CourtHouse at New-Bedford this afternoon. It was decided to keep this ghastly relic out of the case as long as possible, but to-day's events made it necessary that it should be produced.
In the chapel of Packer Institute, in Brooklyn, last evening forty-three young ladies, who compose the class of '93, graduated, and a host of their friends enjoyed the exercises.

Considering the la'eness of the season and the miscellaneous nature of the offerings, the second day of Tattersalls annual Spring Horse Show sale was a remarkably successful one. The crowd was a good one, and though the bidding dragged now and again, forty-three head were sold for an average of close to $300 each. The half dozen trotters from the estate of the late Capt. Vanderbilt sold unexpectedly low, loss than $1,000 for the lot.

The number of cases of cholera in towns of Southern France near Marseilles and the month of the Rhone is increasing, but no additional cases on the west coast are reported. The press dispatch of Monday afternoon which reported nine cases of "choleraic disease" at Calais, the port on the west coast which is only twenty-six miles from Dover, was misleading.

One of the most interesting features of the season of outdoor spoils always is the contest of the college baseball clubs. The young men play with all their hearts and all their strength for the glory of Alma Mater. Victory is a cause for loud paeans of triumph, and defeat is followed by silence and tears.
Charles M. Preston, State Bank Superintendent, announced yesterday that he had discovered a deficiency of $70,800 in the funds of the Irving Savings Institution, 9 Warren Street.

Wheat was under full attention from speculators, and had a fair export demand. The early prices were at 1/4@3/8c decline on free selling by the foreigners, from which there was an advance of 1 1/2@1 3/4c on reports of damage to the French crops and a decrease in the visible supply, while late cables were stronger. The close 18 strong at 3/4@7/8c over yesterday.

The Western demand for money continued yesterday, and again the New-York banks figured as large shippers to their correspondents in the interior. The amounts intrusted to the express companies aggregated about $1,250,000, according to the best estimates.

Two men of swarthy complexion, of medium size, with small black eyes, and hands and feet smaller than those of most men of their height and build, sat on the sofas of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

The New-York Southern Society at a special meeting in its house, 18 West Twenty-fifth Street, last night, decided to abandon the club features of its organization. It is now, therefore, what its name indicates, a society, pure and simple. The bar is to go and so is the restaurant.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, June 14 -- P.M. More than one-fifth of to-day's trading was on Atchison. The stock sold down from 24 to 22 7/8 closing at its lowest price. Some long stock came out as the result of the tactics of the bears. A report that the floating debt amounts to $5,000,000, and that a bond issue to care for it is contemplated, was used to depress the stock.
ROME, June 14 -- The newspaper organs of the Vatican are silent in regard to the alleged encyclical on the school question sent or to be sent to the American Bishops.

Mrs. Hattie Piser and her husband Joseph are running a hot race in the divorce courts to see which shall get a decree first Mr. Piser is the senior member of the firm of Piser Russell, printers, 212 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. He charges that his wife has been engineering a conspiracy to divorce him, in order to hide her own misdeeds with Henry H. Korn.

BRAINERD, Minn., June 14 -- Company D, Third Infantry, United States regulars, with Lieut McCoy in command, moved northward at 7:30 this morning. The weather is extremely sultry -- 94 in the shade -- and the march will be so slow that it will be impossible for the command to reach Leech Lake until some time to-morrow.

NEWARK, June 14 -- The Newark police are looking for August Hermann, Socialist and labor leader, who disappeared last Friday, taking tae money he had collected from agitators here for the purpose of sending to Socialists in Germany. He is believed to have collected $1,000, but the exact amount is not known. One man is said to have paid him $70.

The Clearing House Committee held a meeting yesterday afternoon at which a matter of great interest to the Wall Street public was discussed. It was the question of issuing Clearing House certificates, as has been done on several occasions. A meeting of the Clearing House Association is expected to be held to-day to take such action on the subject as it deems best.

When the Italian Government comes to put its hand in its pocket and pay the expenses incurred by its ships sent here, there is likely to be a very vigorous protest. The ships have had to be dry-dooked and a great many repairs made. These repairs must be paid for at American rate of wages. It is the difference in the price of labor to which the Italian Government is expected to object.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 14 -- The Exchange Banking Company of Weston closed its door this morning. The bank had a run, was unable to get help, and the Directors thought it best to close. The Directors have issued the following, which will be mailed to all depositors:

AURORA, June 14 -- The Wells College commencement concert occurred last evening in Music Hall, which was beautifully decorated for the occasion. A large audience listened to an entertaining programme. The concert opened with a piano solo by Miss Dunham. Miss Carolyn Abbort sang in a pleasing manner two soprano solos.
Mayor Gilroy yesterday issued an official statement defining his position regarding the Rapid-Transit Commission and the resignations of the four Commissioners. He said:

Dr. Wyncoop said at midnight last night, when he left the house of William H. Henriques, who is suffering from the assault made on him by Frank Ellison, that Mr. Henriques was slightly better. The fainting spells, he said, had ceased. The vertigo and pain in the head remained.

SING SING, N.Y., June 14 -- Frank Adams, a convict in Sing Sing Prison serving a second term, his right name being James Henry, as picked in India ink on his left forearm, escaped from that institution this morning while working outside the prison walls in the icehouse behind the old female prison. Adams asked permission to go to a closet near by.

Before the races at Morris Park were started yesterday afternoon, Mr. Easton of Tattersalls sold at auction eighteen thoroughbreds in training, all but one of which were the property of Messrs. Walcott Campbell. Spartecus, a full brother to Lamplighter, was offered, but no one cared to bid upon him. The average per head was $557, the total brought being $10,025.

-- Wall Street's bear contingent is making a good deal of noise, but not accomplishing much. A big short interest has been accumulated, the whole market being oversold, but quotations do not tumble under attack.

The Duke of Veragua went calling yesterday. After attending to some correspondence in the forenoon, he decided to pay his respects to some of the men who contributed to his entertainment, and he was driven to the homes of Cornelius N. Bliss, Gen. Horace Porter, and Mayor Gilroy.

Young pitched a good game of ball against the Brooklyns yesterday, but the support given him was of a poor character and accounts for the defeat. Stein, too, pitched in great shape, and his fielders gave him first-class support.

Representatives of the several railroads which constitute the Southern Railway and Steamship Association held two sessions in one of the parlors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Commissioner E.B. Stahlman presided, and the topic discussed was the formation of a new agreement for the current year. The work was not completed.

PRINCETON, N.J. June 14 -- The one hundred and forty-sixth commencement of Princeton University was held to-day. The procession of Trustees. Faculty, alumni, and students formed in front of the historic Nassau Hall at 10:15 and proceeded to the First Presbyterian Church, where the exercises were held for the last time, as the Alexander Commencement Hall will be available for these occasions hereafter.

The iron steamboat Cepheus left this city yesterday morning with about 500 passengers on board. She steamed to Col loge Point and took on a few more passengers there, among them being the judges and Regatta Committee of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club. The passengers had gone out to witness the races between the yachts of the Knickerbocker Club, it being annual regatta day.

Soon after Bernard F. Martin, the Tammany leader of the Eighth District, was appointed Police Justice a number of his friends started a subscription for a badge to be presented to him. Mr. Martin had so many friends that the fund almost reached $3,000.

The range was occupied yesterday by a detachment of the Thirteenth Regiment, composed of Companies C.D.E.H. and I. under command of Major Cochran, and numbering 144 officers and men. The weather was cloudy, with a light "12-to-1-o'clock" wind blowing-a fine shooting day.

QUEENSTOWN, June 14 -- The Cunard Line steamer Sarvia, Capt. Dutton, which sailed from New-York June 6 for Liverpool, arrived here to-day. She reports that on June 7 she ran down the American ship A. McCallum, Capt. O'Brien, from London April 23 for New-York. The McCallum was so badly damaged that she filled and sank a short time after the accident.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 14 -- Postmaster Charles B. Woolley, who was appointed three years ago to the Postmastership of Long Branch, disappeared suddenly last night. Assistant Inspector Parham of New-York has discovered a shortage of $2,080 in the money order department. Woolley's bondsmen are W. H. Woolley, W. R. Joline, William R. Maph, A. P. Cubberley, James Newbold, and Charles Valentine, who qualified for $10,000.

Two specimen bricks of the worst part of the police structure were dealt with at the Central Office yesterday. There were several charges against Policeman W.H. Burns of the Twentysecond Precinct, including an assault on his wife and the throwing of a brother officer on a stove, but the board decided to dismiss him from the force on a complaint that he was intoxicated while on duty.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The attendance at the xposition to-day was very large. There was nothing out of the routine ol sightseeing, but the fine weather brought in an army, and all enjoyed themselves looking at the exhibits and the buildings and listening to the music.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- "Good-bye, Mr. Harrison; I will always remember your kindness and the kindness of the people of Chicago." With these words the Infanta Eulalie of Spain bade adieu to the Mayor of Chicago, who acknowledged the compliment by gallantly kissing the gloved hand of the Princess for the last time.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14 -- The commencement exercises at Vassar opened this morning with an organ voluntary by Prof. Bowman and prayer by Dr. Taylor, Miss Frances Spaulding Belcher presented the first essay." Mediaeval and Modern Charity." This was followed by Miss Ethel Wilkinson on "Literature and Science," and Miss Elizabeth Kemper on "Spiritualization of Thought in France."

John Smidt of 40 Rose Street was held without bonds yesterday in the Essex Market Police Court on a Charge of stabbing Henry Lang of 392 East Houston Street Sunday night with a corkscrew. Lang is at his home, suffering from a deep and dangerous wound.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- Will the World's Fair be a financial success? More than one person has asked that question. It is a matter of interest, not less to those who have been conspicuous in promoting the great enterprise than to the obscure stockholders, the Government of the United States, and the people of the country.
The Sherman silver law was considered by the Board of Trade and Transportation at its meeting yesterday, the result being the adoption of the following, introduced by James S. Seymour:

Robert P. Porter, Superintendent of the Census, was at the fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He had just returned from Chicago, where he went as an expert to give advice on matters pertaining to the work of the Committee of Awards.

Ever since the introduction of the trolley cars in Brooklyn the people along the route of the lines upon which the trolley is used have been complaining of the intolerable ringing of the gongs by the motormen. It is bad enough, they say, to have the bells struck when the necessity arises, but to have it done by the motormen just because they like it is a nuisance that should not be tolerated.

The first "ocean party" of the season was given yesterday by the New-YorK Society for Improving the Condition of the Poor. Three hundred children and 150 adults, their mothers or guardians, were taken from the hot tenements on the steamboat Perseus and carried to Coney Island.

The feature of the racing at the Morris Park track yesterday was the trial for the American Derby to be run at Chicago on the 24th. between Don Alonzo and Rainbow. Other owners having horses eligible for the trial declined the issue, so that but the two named had their trial for the sixty-thousand-dollar-stake.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 14 -- The result of last week's examinations relative to the respective qualifications of the cadets was made known to-day. Three in the third and eight in the old fourth classes were found deficient and discharged. Eight were turned back to join the new fourth class.
At 8 o'clock last evening Miss Genevieve Thurston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs William C. Thurston of 253 Madison Street, Brooklyn, was married to John Rowland, Jr., of Brooklyn.

Wheat had a lively sale to-day on speculative account and a fair business for export; prices early advanced 34@78c on higher cables and liberal foreign buying, from which there was a decline of 58@34c on reports of financial trouble at the West, closing, however, firm at 12@58c better figures than yesterday on a report of a decrease in the world's supplies.

PARIS, June 14 -- Sir Richard Webster of counsel for Great Britain to-day combated, before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration, the American regulations for the seal fisheries. He devoted particular attention to the proposal made by the United States to forbid pelagic fishing east of the meridian of 180. Sir Richard declared that seals were found throughout Bering Sea from Alaska to Asia.

-- Gustave Emanuel Jansen, a native of Denmark, twenty-nine years old. who had been employed for one day as a dish washer in the restaurant at 257 Third Avenue, committed suicide early yesterday morning by stabbing himself in the left breast with a pocket knife. He had complained that he had been pursued by enemies, and several times pointed out imaginary foes in the street.

"There goes them flags up again," observed a tramp on a bench in the City Hall Park between 7 and 8 o'clock yesterday morning, as two United States flags and two of the State of New-York climbed jerkily up to the tops of poles on the City Hall. "What's up now. I wonder? Another Dook comin'? Well, I can't go lookin' for no work to-day.

A new flag 20 feet long and 12 feet wide will float hereafter from the roof of Grammar School No. 70, in East Seventy-fifth Street, of which George White is Principal. It was presented to the school yesterday morning. When all the School had assembled. Patrick McGrath, aged thirteen years, made the presentation of the flag as "the emblem of our individual liberty and collective greatness."
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 14 -- The question of interest in the Borden trial at present is whether prussic acid can be used, except scientifically and medicinally, for any but a deadly purpose.

Appraiser Marvelle W. Cooper has not been near his office in the Public Stores for two days, and the impression there is general that he has gone away for good. The Secretary of the Treasury has not yet accepted Mr. Cooper's resignation. Nothing was heard from Mr. Cooper yesterday at the Public Stores, and Assistant Appraiser Stevens was in charge.

The Kings County Board of Estimate yesterday continued, its examination of the county budget and Broooklyn's wants for next year. Supervisor Conly was to have explained a deficiency of $10.000 in the stationery account, but he did not appear, and Mayor Boody said that he did not think anybody could be compelled to attend if he would not out of courtesy.

CHADRON, Neb., June 14 -- Three thousand persons saw the start at 5:42 yesterday afternoon of the contestants in the cowboys' race to Chicago. The contestants left town on a jog trot. The riders and horses were Emmett Albright, Chadron. Outlaw and Joe Bush; James H. Stephens, Ness City. Kan., General Grant and Nick; George A. Jones, Whitewood, S.D. George and Romeo; Dr. Middleton, Chadron.

According to the Baltimore American, Chairman WILLIAM F. HARRITY of the National Democratic Committee is the greatest political tactician of his own or any other age. We extract from the Washington correspondence of the American the following hitherto unwritten chapter of the history of the State of Oregon:

RYE, N.Y., June 14 -- The marriage of Miss Mary Virginia Abbot to Joseph C. Seymour was the occasion for a very bright wedding in the picturesque Christ Church at this place this evening. The Rev. Channeay B. Brewater officiated, assisted by Archdeacon Kirkby.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jane 14 -- The first day of the Spring messing and fair of the Queens County Agricultural Society opened under pleasant auspices. The exhibits are larger, more varied, and extensive than on any previons meeting, and the attendance was very large. The racing brought out all of Queens County's best stock and was excellent. There were nine scheduled races and one special race for ponies. The following is the summary:

The Rev. Dr. Brann, pastor of St. Agnes's Roman Cathelie Church of this city, was one of the witnesses yesterday in the suit which Father Francis Dent is bringing in the Circuit Court, Brooklyn, for $50,000 on account of his expulsion from the Order of St. Francis, and to compel his reinstatement in that order.

Two new Missionary Bishops of the Protesttant Episcopal Church were consecrated yesterday in St. Thomas's Church, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, in the presence of a large congregation composed of laymen and clergy. The visiting clergymen, of whom there were more than fifty, sat in front seats reserved for them on the floor of the church, while the rest of the pews and galleries were crowded with interested laymen and women.

The Trustees of All Souls' Unitarian Church, at Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street, have refused an offer of $250,000 for the property. The lot measures 92 feet on the avenue by 126 on the street Real estate men understood that the church people were willing to sell if a fair offer were made. The present proposition was held for ten days.

The doors of the Irving Savings Institution, 96 Warren Street, had scarcely been thrown open yesterday morning before depositors surged up the steps, bank books in hand, bent upon withdrawing their money.

Sportsmen's Associations was not as well attended as the second, but still there were eighty gunners on the grounds. The weather was delightful, it being warm and clear, with a stiff breeze from the northeast, which kept everybody comfortable, although, it rendered the shooting a little more difficult.

Suits have been begun by the "Five A's" through A.D. Lind against J. Charles Davis, manager of Proctor's Opera House, and Actor Lee Harrison, formerly of Thomas Q. Seabrooke's company, for payment of back membership dues and grillroom debts. The claim against Mr. Davis is for $17.90, and that against Mr. Harrison is for $51.65.

Columbia College started more than three hundred young men and eight young women out to fight the battle of life last night, arming each one of them with a sheepskin as evidence of the learning they have aoquired.

The death, list by the fire at 10 and 12 Montgomery Street on Tuesday morning was added to yesterday by the death at Gonverneur Hospital of Morris Nathanson, the occupant of the sixth floor of the building. He was terribly burned all over the body before he was taken out of the building, and the burns and the inhalation of smoke and flame caused his death.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 14 -- There is a big commotion at Greencastle, the seat of Depew University, over the charge that Miss Jean Nelson has been detected at cheating in her examinations. The matter has been smouldering for several days, but the story comes out with the announcement that Miss Nelson will not be permitted to graduate.

George W. McKenzie, eighteen years old, was placed on trial in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, before Judge Fitzgerald, charged with killing a companion. Henry Quell, fifteen years old, by pushing him from the root of the bonded warehouse at 53 Washington Street on Feb. 10, 1892.
CHICAGO, June 14 -- The first serious accident since the opening of the fair occurred on Midway Plaisance at 6:30 this evening.

The contracts for the construction of the four-track steel viaduct through Park Avenue from One Hundred and Sixth Street to One Hunderd and Forty-ninth Street have been awarded. The work is to be divided into four sections. The contracts for Sections 1, 2, and 4 have been awarded to the Elmira Bridge Company of Elmira, N.Y., for $373,000, $344,000, and $424,000, respectively.

The United States cruiser Chicago, flagship of the European squadron, sails from New-York to-day for Galway, Ireland. She carries 410 officers and men, flies the pennant of Acting Rear Admiral Henry Erben, and is commanded by Capt. A.T. Mahan.
The firemen and boilermen in the sugar refinery of Havemeyers Elder, in Brooklyn -- the principal plant in the Sugar Trust, and the largest in this country -- went on a strike yesterday.

The canvass making by THE NEW-YORK TIMES for the purpose of discovering the individual preferences of the members of the Fifty-third Congress in regard to the advisability of repealing the Sherman silver law of 1890 and as to what plan of currency issue they favor is arousing considerable interest, as the answers received yesterday prove.

"The Russian laws enacted against the Jews, which have resulted in driving many of them out of the country, are necessary to protect the Russians," said Pierre Botkine, Secretary of the Russian Legation, to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter at the Victoria Hotel yesterday.

There was an unusually Interesting nuptial incident in St. Mary's Church, Manhattanville, last evening, in the form of a double wedding. Miss Katharine B. Rogers, eldest daughter of James Rogers, was married to John H. Pratt, and her sister, Miss Dollie Rogers, became Mrs. Dr. J. Darwin Nagel.

The statement issued by Secretary CARLISLE as to the workings of the present currency legislation of the United States is timely and ought to be conclusive. We recommend it to the attention of those members of Congress -- proportionately few, however -- who have not yet made up their minds on the merits of the silver law of 1890.

Eugene A. Marvin, who has a printing establishment at 482 Eighth Avenue, was on trial yesterday before Judge Martino in the Court of General Sessions, charged with printing green-goods circulars. His place was raided Dec. 16, 1892, by Anthony Comstock, who found 868,000 green-goods circulars in one of the rooms.

New-York syndicate headed by Commodore Morgan, and Mr. C.O. Iselin, and she was successfully launched at 7:35 this evening from the company's north shop. The name of the boat was not known until just before the launching, and so was a surprise.

Nothing is more irrational than the ordinary "run" on a savings bank, and it is liable to be started by any incident or rumor calculated to shake the confidence of ignorant people. There have been runs lately in Chicago and Omaha that were incited by local financial troubles in which savings were in no way involved.

The three Commissioners of the East River Bridge Company and the lawyers representing property owners on the line of the proposed elevated roads leading to the bridges met yesterday afternoon at the Desbrosses Street Ferry. Promptly at 2 o'clock they started in three landaus to drive over the line which has been laid out for the elevated road running to Bridge No. 1.

Mixed ale, singing, skylarking, and fighting on board a canalboat that was lying at the foot of Market Street on Wednesday evening led to the falling overboard of a man and a young woman and the drowning of the girl.

The Duke of Veragua has decided to remain in this country until July. He will stay in this city during the time Princess Eulalie is here on her return, and take part in whatever demonstration may be made in her honor.

A large proportion, of the depositors in savings banks who are so ready to join in a run at the least note of alarm do not appreciate the fact that for some years those institutions in this city have found difficulty in investing all their deposits to advantage under the restrictions of the law, and their officers are rather glad than otherwise to be relieved of some of their funds.

The annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Club used to be one of the most interesting of the yachting events of the season. As soon as the yachting season opened yacht owners looked forward to this regatta. Their boats were put in the best possible condition, and all the yachtsmen who could would enter and try to win a trophy, which was highly prized because it was won at the New-York Yacht Club regatta.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Attorney General Olney, who, with Speaker Crisp, was invited to deliver the "long talK" at Tammany Hall on July 4, has written a letter regretting his inability to do so.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Junev 15 -- The preliminary hearing in the Bertha Manchester murder case was called for this morning in the Second District Court, but was continued on request of the prisoner's counsel until Thursday, June 22.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- There was no snap to the markets to-day. The action of the New-York Clearing House Association in deciding to issue certificates, while designed to relieve matters, had temporarily a contrary effect on the Board of Trade here. Wheat broke over a cent and closed within 1/8c of the inside figures of the day. Corn, compared with last night, is 5/8c off.

Judge Ingraham of the Supreme Court rather startled the legal fraternity yesterday gathered before him in Chambers by his criticism of the methods employed by a great many attorneys to get all the money possible from their clients.

The credit of the Irving Savings Institution seems to have been fairly re-established in the minds of its customers. The run continued throughout the morning yesterday, but soon alter 2 o'clock the crowd had dwindled to a dozen persons, and at 3 o'clock not a depositor was waiting to withdraw money.

Capt. Adrian Constantine Anson and his band of ball tossers from Cook County, Ill., again were the guests of John Montgomery Ward and his fellow-Giants on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The guests played winning ball, while the play of the Giants savored of the minor league standard. The New-Yorks outbatted their opponents, but were prevented from winning by the costly errors of Mr. "Shorty" Fuller.

It will not be a matter for surprise it the judicious decide that Mr. Gustave Hinriohs is more distinguished for energy than discretion. It was he who eagerly produced Mascagnl's "Cavalleria Rustioana" in Philadelphia before any one else had an opportunity to do so, and now it is he who seizes upon the successor to Mascagni's work and hurries it on the stage with inadequate surroundings, a company of insufficient ability, and out of season.

NEW-LONDON, June 15 -- The Columbias had their first accident on the Thames this morning. They were out on their regular spin in their practice shell, and were coming down the river. When about opposite the navy yard, from some cause, a hole broke in the bow of the boat, and it at once filled with water, throwing the freshmen into the river.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 15 -- The closing day of the Queens County Suring meeting here was well attended and the races were mostly interesting.

The sidewheel steamer City of Richmond, bound from New-London, Conn., to the dry dock at Hoboken for repairs, ran on a reef directly in front of the Sands Point light, Long Island Sound, yesterday morning at 8:40 o'clock and was wrecked. The sun was shining brightly.

The foreign exchange market was demoralized by the high rates for money. The redaction of the rate of discount by the Bank of England, had no appreciable effect, as it had been fully anticipated. The posted rate for sterling was reduced to $4.85 for 60-day bills and $4.87 for demand. Actual business was done at $4,84 1/4 for 60-day bills, $4.85 3/4 for demand, $4,86 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.83 for commercial.
A decision was handed down in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday that tapioca flour is not dutiable as a starch preparation, but is free of duty.

Three genuine Hindoo jugglers, direct from Bombay, yesterday gave an exhibition of their cleverness at the Eden Musee. Their names are Seyid Jamal, Sheik Lall, and Sheik Jamal. There are two others in their party, Sultan Meyah and Mohamed Kahn, but they did not take part in yesterday's performance. These dusky Indians arrived in town direct from Poona, India, on the Anchoria last Monday in charge of the United States Consul to Calcutta, Henry Ballentine.

The Clearing House Committee has been authorized by a unanimous vote to issue Clearing House certificates at such times and in such amounts as may seem to them advantageous for the interests of the banks and their customers. These certificates are practically loans on interest by the Clearing House Association to such of its members as require them, on securities considered adequate by the committee.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 15 -- The case of the Government against Lizzle Borden was concluded this morning after the District Attorney had received a moat serious blow in the refusal of the Justices to allow the introduction of the prussic acid testimony.

Half a dozen houses were all but leveled With the earth, one man was fatally injured, and several other persons received severe hurts as the result of a dynamite explosion in West Hoboken at 6:30 o'clock last evening.

At one stage yesterday the Brooklyns were six runs behind, the Clevelands, and the most ardent admirer of the local team thought that Cleveland would win. But such was not the case. After a few innings they got the gauge ol Cuppy's delivery, and hit hard enough to win.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 15 -- There has been under discussion throughout the State the necessity of a revision of the corporation laws. There is now no question that they will be materially changed at the next session of the Legislature. No subject is receiving more attention among the people generally.

The expected passage at arms between W. Bourke Cockran and Electrician Jesse H. Bunnell because Mr. Cockran has fenced up a highway leading to Mr. Bunnell's place at Sands Point, L.I., did not take place at Port Washington yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15 -- The thirty-third anniversary commencement of St. Elizabeth's Convent was held to-day at Madison. Nine young women were graduated. Bishop Wigger presided, and Mgrs. Doane and Seton were also on hand, and about any priests. Before the hour for the exercises the visitors went to the artroom.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 15 -- Orders from outside banks for currency on balances have for two days been quite light, and there is a noticeable decrease in the applications for rediscounts. The demand from city customers shows very little change, for the reason that it is confined to actual needs. Stock and grain operators have not grown bold enough to ask for much accommodation, but some loans are made on wheat.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Advices received by Secretary Gresham from Samoa are to the effect that affairs there have reached a crisis, and it may be that the United States will again be obliged to intervene between the parties.

The New-York State League of Co-operative Savings and Loan Associations completed its labor yesterday. Papers were read by Judge Seymour Dexter of Elmira on "The Building and Loan Association Movement." Joan A. Barnhard of Rochester on "Gross Premiums as Present Profit." Edward Fitzgerald on "Prepaid Stock," Philip Joyce on "Association Account Keeping," and Edwin F. Howell on "State Organizations."

Without a dissenting vote the Clearing House Association decided yesterday to authorize the issue of certificates recommended by the Clearing House Committee as a result of its meeting on Wednesday afternoon. The story of that meeting was told yesterday in THE NEW-YORK Times.

GREENPORT, N.Y., June 15 -- Miss Leonora Ketchum, a bright and pretty girl of sixteen, was drowned this afternoon while bathing with two girl friends at Shelter Island Heights, near the residence of the Rev. J.L. Scudder, the well-known Brooklyn preacher.

Railroad Jack, one of Albany's two noted railroad dogs, is dead. After thirteen years of active life, in which he had earned an honorable reputation in all parts of the United States, he died suddenly.
"I have the honor to present to you George Blair, ft member ol our committee, who will deliver an address to-night upon the subject, 'Tammany Hall and Its Fidelity to Democracy.' "

BERLIN, June 16 -- At 2 o'clock this morning returns from seventy districts indicate that thirty-six have been carried by parties opposed to the Army bill, fifteen have been carried for the parties favoring the bill, and nineteen, are in doubt between the Government and the opposition parties, with the chances in the majority of them strongly in favor of the Government.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 15 -- This was the record day for the New-York State Sportsmen's Association, the attendance being the largest ever known at any similar affair, both as regards spectators and shooters. The day was hot, the mercury registering above 90 for several hours.

George McKenzie, the eighteen-year-old boy on trial in the Court of General Sessions for murder, will not go to the electric ohair. The prosecution ended its case yesterday and then Mr. Bradley, the Assistant District Attorney, asked Judge Fitzgerald to remove the charge of murder in the first degree from before the jury and substitute murder in the second degree. He said there was nothing to show premeditation.

BOSTON, June 15 -- Royal Phelps Carroll's yacht, the Navahoe, which sailed so gayly from Newport on Sunday on her mission to England to win back the American cups now held there, lies to-night at the Atlantic Work docks in this city, and is damaged so much that a week's work will be needed before she can proceed on her voyage.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 15 -- Princess Enislie and her party spent the afternoon visiting the whirlpool and making a trip under the Falls on the Maid of the Mist. The trip on the Canadian side of the river to the whirlpool was taken in carriages, the party stopping off at differant points in order to more thoroughly enjoy the scenery.

Kerosene-tainted smoke excited interest yesterday morning in the five-story tenement house 241 East Fifty-ninth Street, and it was at last decided that something was wrong in an apartment on the top floor, occupied by Peter Henry, a laborer, his wife Elizabeth, and their five children.
James O'Brien and his wife and two children, a boy six years old and a girl of four, had an experience in Jamaica Bay Wednesday night that they are not likely soon to forget.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- Harvard won another victory in baseball to-day, beating the University of Vermont 12 to 2. This score was made by, Harvard in spite of the fact that the base running was at times very reckless. In one inning all three outs were made on men trying to steal bases. Harvard also batted freely.

The City of New-York took a hand in the real estate market yesterday. It went out for customers and gathered them in at a great rate. The property it put on the market was of the usual three kinds -- good, bad, and indifferent -- but the prices attained belonged to the first of these. Up-town and down-town and out-of-town property were on the list.

NEW-YORK. THURSDAY, June 15 -- P.M. The Clearing House banks adopted the action foreshadowed in THE TIMES this morning and passed resolutions providing for the issuing of loan certificates to any of its members who may require them. There was much guessing during the morning as to what the effect of the action Would be, and certain traders sold stocks rather freely in anticipation of a decline.

WASHINGTON, Jane. 15 -- In accordance with the decision of Chief Justice Bingham yesterday, Dr. Patterson, the Coroner of the District, began a new inquest this morning in regard to the Ford's Theatre disaster. There was a smaller attendance than on previous days at Willard Hall, where the inquest was held, because most of Cel. Ainsworth's uninjured subordinates were at their desks in the new quarters secured for them.

Thirty-eight Senators and one hundred and eighty-six members of the House of Representatives have replied to the telegram sent by THE TIMES asking them to define their attitude toward the proposed repeal of the Sherman act. THE TIMES thanks them for the promptness and courtesy they have shown in attending to its request.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 15 -- The twenty-flfth commencement of Cornell University occurred to-day. The following orations were delivered: "The Functions of the Advocate," Andrew L. Olmstead; "Our Legacy to the Future," Charles M. Lillie; "The Classics in Education," Sarah A. McNulty; "Woman Suffrage," Thaddeus O. Henderson; "Portia in the Nineteenth Century," Mary E. Brown; "The Growth of Our Constitutional Liberty," Charles E. Murphy; "A Eulogy on Gladstone," Clarence B. Hadden.
It is generally understood in political circles that on July 1 Charles W. Dayton will begin his duties as Postmaster for the City of New-York. Postmaster Van Cott is of that opinion, too.

In the official report on the Machias, the board finds the vessel sufficiently strong to carry the armament, equipment, coal, stores, and machinery indicated in the plans. The hull fittings and machinery, including the engines, boilers, and appurtenances of the ship are strong and well built, and in conformity with the contract.

Twenty-eight hundred men are out of work as a result of the strike of firemen and boilermen in the Havemeyers Elder Sugar Refinery, Brooklyn, on Wednesday. Although the company claims to be able to supply the places of the strikers, it was necessary yesterday to borrow steam from the Brooklyn Sugar Refinery.
LONDON, June 15 -- The Ascot Cup was probably the cause of the thin attendance and the absence of business on the Exchange. Greeks recovered yesterday's decline and Argentines continued strong.

Elipbalot Stratton, eighty-three years of age, was arrested yesterday afternoon at his home, 124 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, charged with having tried to kill his wife by a slow process of abuse, starvation, and neglect.

Dr. Carlos F. MacDonald, State Commissioner of Lunacy, says that Edward M. Field, son of Cyrus W. Field, supposed to be confined in the State insane asylum at Buffalo under an order of the Supreme Court until it shall have been determined whether he is insane or merely shamming insanity, is undergoing practically no confinement, and, in fact, is permitted to go about the City of Buffalo without an attendant.

The "green-goods" man who was shot Saturday in Bridgeport, Conn., by a New-Havdn newspaper man, is not Robert Dalton. His name is "Bob" Crumley. and he is a well-known New-Yorker. His race is familiar to men about town and habitues of Sixth Avenue and Broadway. At one time he was a member of the Manhattan Athletic Club.

What is commonly called tin plate is made by rolling thin sheets of steel out of steel bars, and by dipping these sheets in melted tin. Only from 3 to 4 per cent. of the weight of finished tin plate is tin; the remainder, and the part which represents by far the greater amount of labor and cost, is the steel upon which the coating of tin is placed.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- There is now direct evidence, in quantities to suit the most exacting, that the Treasury of the United States has been robbed through the workings of the notorious Order No. 164 in the Pension Bureau.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 15 - The viking ship is high and dry up on the bar at the lower end or the torpedo station. The sailors there, together with the vessel's own crew, are scraping the entire vessel inside and out, all the stores and fixtures having been removed.

Patrolman Joseph Curran of the Nineteenth Precinct was at Seventh Avenue and Sixteenth Street at 3 o'clock yesterday morning when a man staggered by him along Seventh Avenue. The man was bleeding about the head. The policeman asked him what had happened to him. The man said he had been assaulted at 136 West Fifteenth Street, a furnished-room house kept by Mrs. Fannie A. Partridge.

PEEKSKILL, June 15 -- Seldom in the history of the State camp have troops drilled under a more torrid sun than that which blazed down on the Twenty-third during the early morning and forenoon exercises to-day. About midnight one of those fogs for which the Highlands are famous settled down over the camp.

Eugene A Marvin, the printer of 482 Eighth Avenue, tried in the Court of General Sessions charged withprinting a great quantity of greengoods circulars, was found guilty yesterday. The indictment charged a felony under Section 427 of the Penal Code, which is headed "Advertising Counterfeit Money."

CITY ISLAND, June 15 -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East-Steam yachts Condueror, Mr. F.W. Vanderbilt; Alicia, Mr. H.M. Flagler; Tillie, Mr. W.H. Starbuck; May, E.D. Morgan, and Emn. Mr. E. Duvivier. Schooner yacht Tioga, Mr. S.L. Husted, Jr., for Larchmont; sloop yachts Crocodile, Mr. William Osborn, for Larchmont, and Olivia, Mr. Otto Gerdau, from Old Point Comfort, Va., for Greenwich, Conn.; steam yacht Javelin, Mr. Charles R. Flint.
Thomas Burke, a steamboat fireman, twenty-seven years old, committed suicide last night at his home, 33 Hamilton Street, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15 -- The Newark Passenger Railway Company has been absorbed by the Consolidated Traction Company of New-Jersey. The following letter by President Barr of the Newark road announces the fact:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 15 -- The Democratic State Central Committee decided on the second ballot to hold the State Convention in Cincinnati, and at an adjourned session fixed upon the time as Aug. 9 and 10. The temporary organization will be Gilbert H. Bargar of Columbus, Chairman; Walter A. Thieme of Cleveland, Secretary, and Bernard W. Layton of Wapakoneta, Sergeant at Arms.
One false step was the cause of the loss of two young lives last evening.
The letter which Appraiser Cooper wrote to Secretary Carlisle of the Treasury on receipt of the latter's order to reinstate Stenographer Bassett was yesterday made public. It is as follows:

One of the most gratifying and encouraging features of the canvass of Congress on the Sherman bill made by THE TIMES is the candid and courteous tone of the replies received from Republican Representatives and Senators. It is evident that these gentlemen feel their responsibility to the whole country and are ready to do their duty without reference to the effect upon mere partisan interests.

"I never played the baby act and never will. I will not set up the defense of gambling and usury. For this case, however, I have no objection to my brother setting up such a defense, and I will give him all the necessary information concerning the debt."

With the advent of Spring, the bursting of the buds and the unfolding of the leaves, the children of the well-to-do and hotter classes begin to map out in their minds the enjoyments the approaching Summer has in store for them. But not so with the children of the poor. There is but little chance for the play of imagination on such subjects on their part.

-- Col. Killaen Van Rensselaer, President of the Grand Army Mission, will give an address to young men Sunday at 4, P.M. in the reception room of the Young Men's Institute. 222 Bowery. Grand Army men are specially invited. The subject of his address is, "Why Gettysburg or, God Defied."

The twenty-sixth annual regatta of the Columbian Yacht Club was sailed yesterday. Eleven sailing craft and tour naphthas raced over the course. The start was made at 11:30 o'clock, and the yachts raced to a stakeboat anchored off the Corinthian Clubhouse at Yonkers, and back to the starting line at Eighty-sixth Street, on the Hudson River.

Fault-finding, vigorous kicking, and innumerable protests by Capts. Ward and Anson wore the features of the game on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Eleven innings were played before Chicago scored the winning run, and big Adrian Anson, who had been as boisterous and as savage as a Fiji Islander for over two hours, left the held the picture of peace and contentment.

No disorder has been attempted by the striking firemen at the Havemeyor Sugar Refinery in Brooklyn, but a cordon of police still surrounds the works. The refinery was run yesterday under the same conditions as on Thursday. The mixers and other employes whose occupation is gone because of the lack of steam have been switched around into other departments and are so kept employed.

The Loan Committee of the Clearing House, which is to pass on applications from banks in the association tor Clearing House certificates, held its first meeting yesterday morning. As THE NEW-YORK TIMES has told, its membership is practically the same as that of the Clearing House Committee. President Frederick D. Tappen of the Gallatin National Bank is its Chairman.
The regular weekly meeting of the Commissioners of the East River Bridge was held yesterday afternoon.

District Attorney Nicoll, after consultation with Presiding Justice Van Brunt of the Supreme Court with a view to getting E.M. Field placed in custody again and trying the criminal charges on which he has been indicted, has written a letter to Superintendent Judson H. Andrews of the State Insane Asylum at Buffalo, asking for a report as to whether Mr. Field is sane or insane.

The special train of Pullman palace oars on which the Infanta Eulalie went to Chicago one week ago last Monday, rolled into the Grand Central Station at 8:15 o'clock last night, having the Infanta and suite on board. The train was not expected until 9:20 o'clock, but an entire hour was gained between Utica and NewYork.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 16. -- Col. Partridge has taken advantage of every opportunity presented to him to improve the standard of the Twenty-third Regiment in drilling and to derive every advantage for the organization which the tour ou duty in camp has given. In this he has bad the cheerful co-operation of his officers and men.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 16. -- Arthur Ellery, a son of William P. Ellery, stock broker, at 32 Broad street, New-York, and a member of the Oritani Field Club and The Hackensack Amateur Dramatic Association, was arrested a few days ago for not having a lamp on his bicycle after dark.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Gov. Russell of Massachusetts was the guest of Executive Commissioner Hovey at the Massachusetts Building last night, and at 8 o'clock this morning, while breakfasting, the Iowa State Band serenaded him.

-- The Societe Libre des Artistes Francais met as usual on the List of June at the Hotel Centrale, near the Louvre, under the nominal presidency of M. Bartholdi, but with M. Debon in the chair. It was supposed that many revolutionary motions would be advanced, but the roles of the meeting require that notice of motions must be given to the Secretary in advance.

TOPEKA, June 16 -- The State Board of Railroad Assessors have completed their inspection of the railroad property within the limits of Kansas. The members all declare that the rate of assessment is too high as compared with other property, but at the same time declare that the rate must be raised in deference to the wishes of their party.
The property owners of Brooklyn made a great public demonstration at the City Hall last night against the further encroachments of the trolley car on the choice resident streets of that city.

"Yes, but, your Honor, the company is so busy in the day time that it had to do that work at night," explained S. Stewart Whitehouse, the counsel of the Atlantic Avenue Railroad Company of Brooklyn, when he was called before Mayor Boody yesterday afternoon to tell why his client had gone on to Third Street at 10 o'clock the night before and put up iron poles and strung its feed wires on them.

The returns from the elections in Germany were read with keen, interest by many German-American citizens in this city, and a great deal of attention was centred upon the gains made by the Social Democratic Party, not-withstanding the fact that gains by that party were expected.

GREENPORT, L.I., June 16 -- The body of Miss Leonora Ketcham, whose tragic death by drowning yesterday was chronicled in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES, has not yet been recovered, and it is feared the body has been swept away by the strong tide beyond recovery.

One of the pitchers of the New-York Baseball Club, EDWARD CRANE, has uttered a complaint which calls attention to one of the peculiarities of the patrons of the national game. The pitcher says that he is discouraged by the cries of "Take him out!" every time a safe hit is made off his delivery.

A number of well-known ladies and gentlemen of this city, who believe that the extradition treaty recently entered into by the United States and Russia was signed because of misunderstanding and misrepresentation, met yesterday afternoon at the homo of Mrs. C.R. Lowell, 120 East Thirtieth Street.

ST. Louis, June 16. -- An application for a license in the marriage license office Wednesday brought out a romantic as wall as a pathetic story. Early in the morning Miss Minna Vallentine, a pretty young woman, accompanied by her mother, applied for a license, seating that she wished to marry a young man named Carl Gebelhart, who is lying at the point of death in St. Mary's Infirmary.
The Custom House force heard a rumor yesterday that ex-Mayor Alfred C. Chapin of Brooklyn would be appointed Collector of the port and Maurice F. Holahan Appraiser.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The navy cannot have its composite ships. That is the decision of the Attorney General, to the great disappointment of every one connected with the Navy Department. The draughtsmen who have been for months preparing the plans for two gunboats must begin all over again.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 16. -- The body of a man, well dressed and apparently about forty-five years old, was washed ashore at Belmar, N.J., late this afternoon. He wore no shoes, and his shirt at the neck and his coat at the shoulder were cut, as if by a knife.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Contractor Dant, who was doing the work which resulted in the collapse of the Ford's Theatre building, is in a serious condition, and it is feared that his mind will be affected by the disaster.

The exercises of Commencement Week at Pennington Seminary and female Collegiate Institute, at Penulngton. N.J., will begin tomorrow and continue until Friday. The baccalaureate sermon will be preached by President Hanlon at 10:30 o'clock on Sunday morning, and the anniversary exercises of the Young Men's Christian Association will be held on Sunday evening, when Frederick Hammond will make an address.

We are so used to find at exhibitions of works of art the pictures taking the lion's share of notice that yesterday's reception at the Academy of Design was fall of surprises. Not that the pictures can be called poor in a loan collection for which the walls of the old Belmont gallery were dismantled, while Messrs. Marquand, W.L. Andrews, Cornelius Vanderbilt, Collis P. Huntington, and Mrs. Blodgett help the show with various canvases.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., June 16. -- Jacob Jonretti, who was released from prison recently, and celebrated his freedom by smashing the doors and windows in an effort to sot at his wife, is giving the town officials no end of trouble.
