ALBANY, June 16. -- During the session of 1892, it occurred to Mr. Jaines Oliver, the librarian of the Senate, that it would be a nice thing to draw a salary the whole year Instead of only during such time as the Legislature was in session. So he had a resolution passed, which was in these words:

CHICAGO, June 16 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day North Chicago sold at 211 14, West Chicago at 157, New-York Biscuit at 20, Milwaukee Brewing at 2418, Diamozid Match at 10912, Strawboard at 53. Money, 7 cent. Bank clearings, $13,114,285. New-York exchange, $1.50 discount.

When the doors of the Irving Savings Institution were opened at 9 o'olocK yesterday morning there were not a dozen depositors waiting to draw out their money. The run was evidently over. There was received yesterday $3,400 besides $2,500 which was drawn on Wednesday only to be returned.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 16. -- At Wellesley College to-day a fine historical pageant was presented by the young ladies of the Institution. An original drama was given by the members of the senior class to an audience of about 700, composed of members of the Faculty and invited guests.
PARIS, June 16 -- The Under Secretary for the Colonies received a telegram this evening dated Vo-Son, June 15, saying:

The Southern Railway and Steamship Association, which has been in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel for the past three days, adjourned yesterday to meet at Manhattan Beach on July 11. The matter of a new agreement was left in the hands of a sub-committee. The present agreement holds good until July 31, and it is hoped to have a now one framed before that date.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The annual meeting of the National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution was held here to-day. Delegates were present from nearly every one of the thirty States represented in the national organization. Among the first arrivals at the Art Institute were Chauncey M. Depew and Gen. Horace Porter of New-York.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 16. -- Concerning the two bank failures in this State yesterday. Bank Commissioner Breidenthal said to-day: "The cause Is simply the old story of the banks going beyond the legitimate banking business and, making real estate loans, and netting a large amount of real estate on their hands which it is impossible to convert into money at This time.

The stockholders of the Nicaragua Canal held their annual meeting in Denver, Col., on Thursday and elected the following Directors: Warner Miller, Samuel Thomas, Smith M. Weed, Stuyvesant Fish, H.B. Slaven, A.P. Williams, George W. Davis, R.C. Shannon, J.W. Miller, H.R. Hoyt, John W. Mackay, R.A. Lancaster, and N.K. Fairbank.

Thomas C. Brown, Jersey City's wealthiest dry goods merchant. who achieved notoriety about three weeks ago by being immersed in the bay at Greenville. N.J., by faith curists, died at the Faith Curists' Sanitarium, Zion's Sanctuary, near Greenville, of paralysis and Bright's disease, complicated with heart disease, shortly before noon yesterday.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 16. -- The strangest case on record in the history of criminal law in Texas has just come to light. On Dec. 12, 1892, Peter Meggs was convicted at Andersen, Grimes County, on purely circumstantial evidence, of the murder of Michael Ferry, and was sentenced to a life term in the State penitentiary and sent to Huntsville.

For two hours Thursday afternoon the now addition to the Brooklyn Hospital was open for the inspection of visitors, and the grounds at the corner of Da Kalb Avenue and Raymond Street were crowded with people. The old hospital has done good work for a quarter of a centary, and the extension of its facilities was a gala occasion.

The ninth annual exhibition and commencement exercises of the Hebrew Technical Institute were held yesterday afternoon at Arlington Hall, 19 St. Mark's Place. From 1 to 2:30 o'clock the school at 34 and 36 Stuyvesant Street was open for the inspection of visitors.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 16. -- The henequin planters of Yucatan, after receiving the refusal of President Diaz to remove the export tax on henequin, have resolved to appeal the case to the Supreme Court of Mexico and fight the enforcement of the law to the very last. It is claimed that the people of Yucatan are so unanimously opposed to the new measure that they will not obey it.
Briar Cliff Farms, belonging to Walter W. Law, which is about three and a half miles from Scarborough, on the New-York Central Railroad, was visited by the Duke of Veragua yesterday afternoon.

CITY ISLAND, June 16. -- The steam yacht Nada was successfully launched to-day from the yard or A.B. Wood Sons. Mr. Hugh J. Baxter is the owner. The boat and the machinery were designed by Gardner and Mosher. She is 85 feet water line; 85 feet 9 inches over all; 10 feet 6 inches beam, and 3 feet 6 inches draught. She is finished in mahogany. The hull is brightly polished.

The fifteen-year-old boy whom the Brooklyn police arrested for vagrancy on Wednesday, and who gave his name as George Wilson and his home as Philadelphia, escaped the prison when he was brought up before Justice Walsh yesterday, but his father, who called to claim him, promised to keep him under look and key for a while.

TOLEDO, Ohio. June 16. -- Last night a severe hailstorm swept across Williams County, lasting several minutes. The ground near Brynn was white with the frozen crystals, giving the appearance of Winter. The ball was of a uniform size about like hickory nuts.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 16. -- The Superintendent or Insurance is of the opinion that one-fourth of the insurance written in the State is done by irresponsible agents and in what is called in insurance terms "undersround business."

In a single dark and ill-furnished room, several feet below the level of the ground, in a rear tenement at 103 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday found two women of Intelligence -- a mother and a daughter -- and three young children living in abject poverty as the result of no fault of their own.

NEW-YORK. FRIDAY, June 16 -- P.M. In the face of stiff rates for money the stock market to-day was exceptionally strong. This condition was due more to the covering of short contracts than anything else, for there was very little investment buying. The bears recognize that the precantionary measures taken by the banks will prevent any great break in prices.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 16. -- St Dominick's Roman Catholic Church at Oyster Bay had arranged for a picnic and testimonial to its organist, Prof. Veshy, to take place Wednesday and last evening at Shippan Point, Conn. The affair did not come off, and because or it the church is suddenly without a choir.

PARIS, June 16. -- The condition of President Carnot is believed to be serious. He suffered a relapse to-day, and much anxiety is felt as to his recovery. M. Carnot attended the races on June 11, and witnessed the running for the Grand Prlx. Upon his return to his home he was quite exhausted, and Drs. Potaln and Planchon were summoned to attend him.
CHICAGO, June 16. -- Argument was resumed on the Sunday opening question this morning in the United States Court of Appeals by Attorney High for the Government.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., June 16. -- This town is much stirred up over the summary dismissal of five of the teachers in the public school by the Board of Trustees. No welldefined reason is assigned except lack of harmony between the teachers and Principal Gamble.

From the Cleveland, Leader. (Rep.) The promise of Mr. Cleveland's friends that when the extra session of Congress is called early in September to deal "with a financial situation which is the only menace to the country's welfare and prosperity," the Sherman silver-purchase law will be repealed, is strengthened by the partial canvaas of Senators and Congressmen made by the Democratic NEWYORK TIMES and published in Monday's issue of that paper.

The Oneck Stable's candidate for the American Derby, to be run at Chicago one week from to-day, G.W. Johnson, had his trial yesterday, and though the time made was not known, at Morris Park it was known that the trial was a sufficiently good one to warrant the owners of the horse in sending him to Chicago to try conclusions with the other colts that are going from this section, and with the Western three-year-olds.
NEWARK, N.J., June 16. -- The local High School commencement was held to-night at Jacobs's Theatre. The number of graduates was unusually large. The literary programme consisted of the following:

Albert Young, the valet of Jockey Sims, and Emory Hartsfield, the valet of Jockey Overton, bantered each other Thursday evening, and, as a result, Hartsfield is a corpse in Lavin's undertaking establishment in Westchester, the victim of a knife thrust in his heart, and Young, the murderer, is a fugitive.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 16. -- What has been threatened and expected all season happened to-day, and Tonawanda is under guard of the militia. The Twenty-fifth Separate Company of Tonawanda and the Forty-second of Niagara Falls are already in the field, with Col. Welch in command, and two companies of the Sixtyfifth Regiment will be sent there it the situation should become more serious.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- The one hundred and thirty-seventh annual commencement of the University of Pennsylvania was held here to-day In the Academy of Music. Degrees were conferred upon 284 men, in arts, science, law, and veterinary medicine. There were 206 degrees in medicine and dentistry conferred a month ago, so that the total number of graduates this year is 490.

Max L. Clayton, well known as a theatrical agent, came to the city Thursday night from Amityville, L.I., in company with Dr. Orville J. Wilsey, Superintendent of the insane asylum at that place. Mr. Clayton was in Dr. Wilsey's charge, having been an inmate of the asylum for nine months.

Mayor Boody of Brooklyn decided yesterday to accept the invitation of Mayor Carter Harrison of Chicago to be his guest over "Brooklyn Day" at the World's Fair. Mr. Boody told Mirabean L. Towns. Chairman of the Brooklyn Day Committee, that he would leave with the speakers on June 24.

-- There will be three games of the first section of the Metropolitan League played to-day for the cricket championship of New-York. The principal of these will be played at Prospect Park, where the New-Jersey Athletic Club meets the Brooklyns, and the Morris Park plays the Manhattans. The third game will take place at Livingston, S.I., where the Staten Island Cricket Club should have an easy victory over the Newark team.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- Down on Deal Beach. Elijah W. Murphey of Albany, brother of Assemblyman Thomas A. Murphey of the Fifth District of this city, has a Summer residence. The family has already taken possession of it for the season. Miss Virginia Murphey, daughter of the Albany house and niece of the Assemblyman, was taking a stroll upon the beach recently, when she picked up an empty champagne bottle, corked and sealed.

The women's singles In the Manhattan Tennis Association, have been finished in favor of Miss Goodchild of the Hamilton Tennis Club, who, with 11 points handicap, defeated Mrs. Von Klein of the Filth Avenue Club (scratch) for final honors 7 -- 2. 6 -- 3. The event was begun Wednesday afternoon on the Fifth Avenue Club courts. Fifth avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street.

To the Editor of the New York Times: I do favor the repeal of the Sberman law, but do not think its repeal would chancre the balance of trade in our favor, or prevent the exportation of gold to meet the demands upon us. So long as our imports so greatly exceed our exports we must pay foreign countries the balance in the standard money of commerce, which is gold.

More details of the National Cordage reorganization plan were given out in Wall Street yesterday in the shape of a summary of the agreement for underwriting the undertaking, but they failed to add much to what the Street already keew of the project. Among other things the summary pointed out these:

ELIZABETH. N.J., June 16. -- Dr. George H. Perrine of Summit was cot arraigned this morning in the Union County Court, as expected, having refused to plead guilty to the charge prepared by the prosecutor. He says he will get bail in a day or two, and will let tie matter go before the Grand Jury.

This afternoon the scene of the daily racing shifts to the pretty Sheepshead Bay track of the Coney Island Jockey Club. Superintendent Clarko has the handsome grounds in perfect condition and the tracts as good as constant work can make them. They will be safe, at all events, and fast In all prob ability, though that is of much less importance.

It is many a year since a criminal case in this country has excited such universal interest and been the subject of so much discussion as that of the Borden murder. It has all the fascination of a mystery about which there may be a thousand theories and upon which opinions may differ as variously as the idiosyncrasies of those who form them.

BERLIN, June 17. -- 2 A.M. -- Returns have lean received from 220 out of 397 electoral districts. In 98, candidates have been elected; in 122, second ballots will be necessary. The National Liberals, Conservatives, and Clericals are holding their own. The Richter Radicals remain very far behind.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 16 -- The evidence in the Borden trial is all in. The defense rested early this afternoon, and at 4 o'clock the last of the Commonwealth's witnesses in rebuttal stepped from the witness stand. Monday the arguments of the opposing counsel will be made, and the celebrated case is expected to be given to the jury by Tuesday morning.

MAJOR A.S. KIMBALL. Quartermaster, has been relieved from duty at Chicago and has loft for Washington. Gen. Miles, In a general order, expresses his appreciation of the valuable services of this officer and his intelligent administration of the affairs of the Quartermaster's department not only as disbursing officer at Chicago, Ill., but as Chief Quartermaster of the Departments of the Columbia and of Arizona.

LONDON, June 16 -- In the House of commons to-night W.K. Cremer moved that the House, having learned that the United States Congress had authorized the President to conclude treaties or arbitration, expressed the hope that the Government would open negotiations with the view to refer all differences between the two nations to arbitrators.

"Eliphalet Stratton to the bar!" Every lounger in the Myrtle Avenue Police Court in Brooklyn yesterday morning rubbed his oyeg and craned his neck to catch a glimpse of the man of eighty-four, who was arrested on Thursday for having tried to starve his young wife.

Heroism, bravery, and faithful service among the gallant fireflighters of New-York are to have their re-ward to-day, when, in the name of the Fire Commissioners, Mayor Gilroy will present to four members of the Fire Department the Bennett and Stephenson Medals.

The movement or prices through the week has been insignificant in itself, but significant of slow emergence from the state of suppressed alarm which recently characterized the market. It is possible now to sell. There are bids from others than shorts, and stocks which recently one did not dare to offer, can now be bought and sold with comparative freedom.
From the Boston Transcript, (Ind. Rep.) THE TIMES'S statement exhibits a decided change of opinion in the South favorable to sound currency, which leads that paper to say:

NEWPORT. R.I., June 17 -- The visit of the Norwegian ship Viking, bound for the World's Fair at Chicago, has given a decided impetus to the opening of the season in bringing hundreds of outside visitors to the City-by-the-Sea. Capt. Anderson and his crew have certainly been given a warm-hearted reception to these shores that could not possibly be outdone.

Wall Street is bearing no talk of gold exports nowadays. Imports of the yellow metal figure in the gossip of the Street, for nobody doubts the beneficial effects of the promise that the Sherman silver-purchase law shall be repealed.

FASHIONABLE GOSSIP IN BROOKLYN. -- Brooklyn made a record for unique weddings last week, one "electrical" and one "musical." The marriage of Miss Isabel Blakeman to H.G. Issertel was an "electrical" affair. The bride, who is out or Brooklyn's beautios, electrified her guests with her personality, and the house was decorated with garlands of incandescent lamps of railed colors.

By superior batting and fielding the Washingtons won a same from the New-Yorks on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Baldwin was hit safely ten times by the Senators, and the majority of the hits were made at opportune moments, or just when they were needed to score runs. Really baseball is an uncertain game. The Giants won three straight from Louisville, the latter went to Washington and won two straight, and the Senators defeated the New-Yorks.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Despite the repeated statements that the President and Secretary Carlisle would reach a conclusion to-day regarding the, disposition to be made of the case of Appraiser Cooper of New-York, who recently deserted his desk, after sending his resignation to Washington, leaving his subordinates to say that he would not return, the question of what is to be done with Mr. Cooper remains unsettled.
KINGSTON, N.Y., June 17 -- Baron Fava and the members of the Italian Legation arrived at Stamford to-day in a private car, and will remain there two months.

BALTIMORE, June 17 -- Cardinal Gibbons has received the long-expected letter from the Holy Father on the school question with the request to send copies of it to all the episcopate of the United States.
--Mr. Dariua Cobb remarks in Kate Field's Washington, on the question of the good that American students get by their stay abroad:

The cornerstone of the Lewis Avenue Congregational Church, at Lewis Avenue and Madison Street. Brooklyn, was laid yesterday afternoon. Exercises were held in the chapel. The Rev. Robert J. Kent, pastor, presided. On the platform were the Rev. James Montgomery, pastor of the Janes Memorial Church; the Rev. Dr. J. S. Chadwick, pastor of the Sumner Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, and the Rev. R.R. Meredith of the Tompkins Avenue Baptist Church.

LONDON, June 17 -- Arthur A. Zimmerman, the American champion amateur bicycle rider, sailed today from Southampton for New York on the American Line steamer Paris. Zimmerman intended to take part in the championship races of the National Cyclists' Union of England, but as he declined to ride any hut a machine of his own selection, he was refused a license to ride as an amateur.

PALMYRA, N.Y., June 17 -- A party of Mormons from Wood's Cross, Davis County, Utah, has been in Palmyra this week. The place has a lively interest for all Mormons, for it was here that Mormonism had its birth. Brigham Young used to live with Deacon Snow two miles south of the village of Port Byron, and, when he left, was owing the Deacon quite a board bill.

The second century of the year was scored yesterday at Prospect Park in the Cricket League championship came between the Manhattan and Morris Park Clubs. F.J. Prendergast was the hero of the occasion, and his hard-kit innings of 101 had much to do with his club's victory by 142 runs and 6 wickets to spare. W.F. Lewis and A. Wallis also showed fine form at the bat and J. Mart distinguished himself with the ball.

"I should be glad to see a complete investigation of the Pension Office, to determine what basis there is for the charges of mismanagement and the pensioning of those who are not entitled to receive pensions," Gen. Russell A. Alger said to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

"Until Savin's uncle died and all this money came into the family, he was a model husband," said A.H. Hummel yesterday, addressing Judge McAdam of the Superior Court. "He provided a pleasant home for his wife and treated her as any good man shoud treat the woman to whom he is married.

FLUSHING, L.I., June 17 -- The junior members of the Flushing Athletic Club held their annual Spring games on the club's grounds this afternoon. There were sixteen contests, with some interesting lowering of junior records. There were many entries. The games were open to all athletes under seventeen years. Summary of the events is as follows:
BRIDGEPORT. Conn., June 17 -- This city of late has become the headquarters for bunko men and dealers in green goods.

There is no more beautiful region in the conntry than that mountain region of the Catskill range lying in Ulster and Delaware Counties. Other mountains may possess snow-olad peaks. be higher and more inaccessible and further away from the strife and turmoil of everyday life, but none is so rich In landscape, cascade, and lake as the picturesque Catskills.

Yale's men of muscle had an easy job disposing of the Princeton ball players on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. It was so easy that all interest in the contest was lost after the third inning, when the New-Haven collegians bad a lead of halt a dozen runs and the youths from Nassau Hall had tailed to send a man around the bases.

Only one of the three events on the card at Parkway was decided yesterday. The 2:40 class to road cart and 2:32 class to sulky did not fill, hut the 2:50 trot to road wagon, members driving, furnished a close and exciting race. In the last heat the four horses finished heads apart. Lady Harvester was ruled out by the judges for an unpaid fine incurred by her former owner.

It was stated yesterday that the RapidTransit Commissioners have been endeavoring to devise a plan during the past week upon which all the members could agree, but that nothing practical had resulted.

Mr. Enoch Black, swollen with wealth and the pride of accumulation. Invited a well-authenticated English correspondent of his house to spend Sunday with him at his country seat at Ovington. The well-authenticated correspondent hesitated and suggested other engagements, as if he had not adroitly sought the bidding, and then accepted, thus giving to courtesy the zest of the compliment.

June is the month of roses. With the opening Spring they come like the song birds, on the gentle south triad. And do you know that in the long ago, unwritten of in history, the dead world ot tradition, the legends relating to flowers are the oldest of them all ?

A bottle of gilding in the hand of vogue is more dangerous than the proverbial pot of paint in the hand of a woman. The latter daubs every available useful article within reach in the name of freshness.

-- The Attorney General of Kansas proposas to bring suit against the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railroad for the annulment of its charter. This step is taken because that company has removed its offices from the state of Kausas to St, Louis, keeping merely local offices in Parsons, Kan.

In spite of the threatening weather, quite a number of tennis players gathered on the Crescent Athletic Club courts, Bay Ridge, yesterday afternoon to witness the third meeting of the Inter-Club Tennis Association of Kings County. The opening matches were played In the rain, but later in the afternoon if cleared off and the courts wore comparatively dry. The event of the afternoon was the men's singles, which were finished up to the final round.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The Court of Appeals has ananimously decided in favor of open Sundays at the World's Fair. The court holds that the Local Directory is in full control, and that the Government has no standing.

The world's greatest men, from OTHELLO to Gen. GRANT, have mostly been men of few words. Men with little brains have learned to presume upon this fact, and by consistently holding their tongues have striven to build up reputations for unfathomed wisdom; but it is easy to distinguish, the reticence of real greatness from the bogus article.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Contractor George W. Dant was severely condemned, by the evidence given to-day at the Coroner's inquest over the remains of the Ford's Theatre victims, although some of those who gave testimony against his methods spoke highly of his ability as a practical mechanic and bricklayer.

From the Baltimore Sun. The Lafayette Grand Army Post has adopted a series of resolutions expressing the opinion that members of the Grand Army could render useful and active assistance in exposing frauds upon the pension list it each post is furnished with a printed list of pansioners in its State, giving names, residence, and service of pensioners.
These verses of Victor Hugo, written in 1869, are to appear for the first time in a volume entitled "Toute la Lyre," to be published in Paris some time this month:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 17 -- The village of Stockbridge has been greatly excited today over two burglaries which took place there last night. The house known as Laurel Cottage, occupied by David Dudley Field and family, was entered through a kitchen window between 12 and 1 o'clock by a man who stole a watch from under the pillow of Mrs. Laura B. Field.

Mareschal Jose Simeao de OJiveira, President of the Brazilian Commission at the World's Columbian Exposition, is seriously ill at the Hotel Savoy, and his physician says that his illness may have a fatal termination.

Samuel Spencer of the Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners has sent to Mayor Gilroy copies of letters which passed between himself and Secretary Bushe and which explain explioitly his own position. Commissioner Spencer is now in Saratoga, and he is loth to return to New-York to attend a meeting of the Commissioners this week unless he can have some assurance that there is a prospect of an amicable agreement.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 17 -- The Democratic County Committee held a meeting here this morning. There has teen for some time a split in the committee between the adherents of State Senator Charles P. McClelland and those of Sheriff John Daffy on the question of the Chairmanship. At the last mooting the Sheriff's men were routed and McClelland was chosen Chairman by a majority.

From. the London Globe. Mr. Charles Tomlinson, F.R.S. has related some curious instances of low-lying meteors. of phosphorescent meteors, some are caused by decaying animal matter, as in the case of the decayed fish which had been flung into a tree near Thurso about 1860, where it frightened the people with its ghostly appearance at night, until one bold spirit advanced alone to the tree, after his companions had fled, and discovered the secret.

Another attempt is to be made to re-establish the lame and vogue of Niblo's. The big theatre on Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets, has been leased by Carl and Theodor Rosenfeld, the managers of Eleonora Duse and the Lilliputians, who say it is their intention to make it again a first-class theatre in every respect.

City Hall this afternoon attracted the attention of Lawyer Matthew Smith as he was leaving the City Hall. He ran to the spot and found that the three-year-old daughter of Barber FranK Silva had fallen into a pool of water twenty feet deep and was drowning.

BERLIN, June 18 -- 2 A.M. -- The returns have almost ceused coming in, although, reports from thirty districts are still lacking. At 12 o'clock the Army hill parties and groups had eighty-three seats, the opposition parties eighty-five.

It was a proud day for the firemen yesterday, and for their wives and sweethearts, who thronged Riverside Park from the lower end to Eightieth Street, to witness the presentation of medals for bravery and discipline by the Mayor and the Fire Commissioners.

The Viking ship arrived off City Island yesterday at 1 P.M. She met with a royal reception from the United States double-turreted monitor Miantonomoh and a fieet of gaylydecked excursion craft. The snip now lies peacefuily anchored off West Thirty-sixth Street, in the North River.

Following a late reply to a request for suggestions for girls' reading comes a similar question concerning the boys of the family. An article taken some months ago from a Chicago weekly, and kept in a mother's scrapbook, is so pertinent that extracts are freely made from it.
Papers were served on Mme. Celestine Mullins at her home, 706 Madison Avenue, on Friday, in a suit for $50,000 damages, brought by Mrs. Josephine Bell of 300 West Seventy-fifth Street.
NEW-YORK. SATURDAY, June 17 -- P.M. The trading in to-day's stock market amounted to only 46,246 shares and the fluctuations were very narrow. The tone Was fairly steady.

BOSTON, June 17 -- The commencement exercises of the Parkins Institution for the Blind brought out an audience on one of the hottest afternoons of the past week that crowded the Boston Theatre even to the back seats of the top gallery.

Bishop Wiggor of NewarK, N.J., presided yesterday at the fourteenth annual commencement exercises of the Institute of the Holy Angela at Fort Lee. The institute 18 carried on as a college for young ladies and a preparatory school for little girls, and is conducted by the school Sisters of Notre Dame.

A great deal of interest is felt among people who are interested in the theatre, in Mr. A.M. PALMER'S scheme to increase the revenues of the Actors' Fund. The original idea, when this charity was established a dozen years ago, was to support it almost entirely by a series of annual benefit performances in the various cities.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 17 -- In view of the agitation over the financial condition of New-Rochelle, President Walter Large to-day issued a statement showing a deficiency of more than $23,000, and the taxes of the fiscal tax year have already been levied and collected.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 17 -- The New-York state Division of the League of American Wheelmen held its semi-annual business meeting here this morning in the parlors of the Yates House. The meeting was well attended. The matter of charging wheelmen a toll of 6 cents at Sag Harbor, L.I., was taken up and the Executive committee was instructed to engage legal advice and fight it.

What will Speaker CRISP talk about in Tammany Hall on the Fourth -- silver ? We are very sorry to thrust upon the Speaker a topic which is evidently distasteful to him, one which he would gladly dodge at the present time, but we solemnly assure him that there is no subject, save that of the Sherman act, upon which the people of New-York have the least desire to hear him talk.

LONDON, Jane 17 -- The regatta of the Royal Yacht Club was Held to-day over the usual course off the Isle of Wight. There was a good breeze from the east, and the yachts made a pretty picture as they started off with their huge mainsails bellying to the wind. Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie took part in the race, and again showed that the Americana will find in her a dangerous competitor for the America's Cup.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17 -- Ex-Gov. Rodman M. Price of New-Jersey is lodged in tie Bergen County Jail at Hackensack on a writ of attachment for contempt of court. The order of arrest was issued from the Court of Chancery Jan. 17, 1893, and Mr. Price, it is held, eluded arrest until yesterday, when he was arrested by Detective Baker as he alighted from a train at Oakland.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 17 -- The Republican State Central Committee met here to-day and selected the following Executive Committee:

More explanations of the budgets of Kings County and Brooklyn were listened to by the county Board of Estimate yesterday. Health Commissioner Griffin said an increase in the salaries of his department's Inspectors had been asked for because of the increased work to be done. The item of $46,700 for the contagious-disease hospital was $2,110 more than was asked for last year, two new pavilions being greatly needed.
Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate, and his party from the Catholic University left Washington on Friday for the extended tour through the West which has been arranged for him.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 17 -- This afternoon Justice Irving G. Vann handed down his decision of the demurrer raised to the complaint in the action of Jacob Grouse and others against Euia Henrietta Kosterlitz, Edgarita Dorothea Crouse Wilson, Impleaded, and others.

The Sculpture Society appears to have been launched quietly, and with those in charge to whom the future of the art is of greatest moment. It has made no mistakes in the past to give its members pain, for the sufficient reason that it is but just born. It has everything before it and will be judged by the results of its early years of effort.

A Memsahib is the title given to the woman of the species Sahib, and Sara Jeannette Duncan writes as would a woman perfectly familiar with Calcutta and Indian life. Mrs. Helen Frances Browne, nee Peachy of Canbery, (a little English town,) is a nicely-bred young person. She became engaged to Browne, who was in business in Calcutta, the courting having been, done in England.

"Is It a baby farm?" asked Register John T. Nagle yesterday in sending to the Coroner's office a certificate from Dr. T.T. Janeway of the Northern Dispensary that last Thursday May McGrade, less than a year old, died at 8 Varick Place of "acute gastritis due to insufficient feeding." The inquiry concerned Mrs. Celia McDonough of 380 Cherry Street, who had charge of the child from April 6 to June 13.

Many passengers sailed on yesterday's outgoing fleet. Among those in the saloon of the American liner New-York are the Marquis and Marquise de C. Arqudin, Mrs. P.T. Barnum. Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould and Miss Anna Gould, the Baroness de Tuyll, Bancroft Davis, Jr., W.Q. Judge, Mr. and Mrs. Irving B. Richman, Sir Donald Smith and Lady Smith.

Sandow's purely personal but very interesting exhibition of his muscles was the only novelty of last week, and that is surely not dramatic. The drama is taking its vacation. A dozen or more playhouses are open and prosperous, and the roof gardens, in which the programmes of song and dance and jugglery are changed from week to week, are always crowded on not nights.

To the stirring strains of the "Soldier's Farewell," the Seventh Regiment marched from its armory, at Sixty-seventh Street and Park Avenue, yesterday noon to the Grand Central Station. There the regiment boarded two special trains and went to Roa Hook, just beyond Peekskill, where they were received by the Twenty-third Regiment of Brooklyn, which has been doing excellent work at the State Camp during the past week.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The President would not have found out, if he had not soon it in the papers, that he has been in a rather poor state of health during the last week. A casual remark to a visitor or two about pains in his arms or back, attributable to cold or lack of exercise, is easily and conveniently named rheumatism, as everybody finds such, symptoms easily described with that much abused natno.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 17 -- This has been an exceedingly unpleasant day on the Thames. The water was rough and the air so cold that but little practice wag had by the college crews. The first race is that next Tuesday between Cornell and Columbia freshmen, and The attention or college men Is now directed to it.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 17 -- The appointment of Henry B. Graves as Postmaster in Geneva was favorably received, toy the business interests of the town. The appointment was expected and consequently created no surprise, there being but one other applicant in the field.

HUNTINGDON. Penn., June 17 -- At 5:30 this morning J.W. Ellwood, the notorious Post Office burglar, who has been confined in jail here awaiting the pleasure of the Government authorities at Flttsbnrg to remove him, walked out of the open front door of the jail, and his whereabouts are unknown.

"President Cleveland has consented to act as arbitrator between the Governments of Brazil and the Argentine Confederation in a question relating to the boundary line between those countries," Dr. Magallaes of Brazil said yesterday at the Hotel Brunswick.

The sloop yacht Eclipse, owned by L.J. Calanan of this city, and the tug Forward were in collision yesterday afternoon at about 6:30 near the Bay Bidge Ferry. The yacht was on her way down the harbor when the tug, in compliance with the usual methods of tug Captains, assumed that he, instead of the sloop, had the right of way.
The Kings County Board of Estimate met at the Brooklyn City Hall on Friday and made a great show of economy by publicly announcing that they would not increase the salary of a single office holder.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 17 -- The Rev. J.A. Deniston, for three years minister in St. John's, Episcopal Church, Tenth Street and Van Alst Avenue, Long Island City, has been notified by the Vestry of the church that his ministrations will cease on Juna 30.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The statement of the United States Treasurer, shoving the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day, is as follows:

BOSTON, June 17 -- Nine of the Boston theatres have been closed this week, but the very few open have done good business. Barnum Bailey's circus, however, has chiefly occupied the attention of amusement seekers, and the crowds it has drawn have been immense, hundreds having been turned away every night. This being a holiday here three performances were given.

After all, it is the style of the woman more than the style of the gown that makes the costume a success. It was only a plain brown serge, but the woman who wore it was one of those dainty, womanly creatures -- of medium height and well rounded-whom men and women alike admire because they are so wholesome and fresh and sweet looking that they inspire new faith in womankind.

SARANAC LAKE, June 17 -- The prediction made in some quarters that the World's Fair would hurt the Summer trade of this region hag already been proved without foundation, for in no year previous have there been so many arrivals in June as this year. There is not a resort in the mountains that is not open and entertaining a fair number or guests.

The production of Leoncavallo's " I Pagliaool' has given the lovers of music here something to talk about. In spite of the determined effort of a noisy claque to arouse a factitions enthusiasm over every number the work cannot be said to have made a profound impression at its production. Yet the newspapers have expressed a variety of opinions about it, and the end is not yet.

The United States cruiser Chicago sailed at noon yesterday from the Brooklyn Navy Yard for Europe. She was heartily cheered by the crews of the Baltimore, San Francisco, Yorktown, Bennington, and Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The Chicago Derby, which was ran at Hawthorne to-day, drew large crowds to the track. It was won by Morello the three-year-old by Eolns out of Carlse, and owned by the Elkton Stables.

ORANGE, N.J., June 17 -- The Young People's Society of the Unitarian Church, has elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President -- Edward Aborn; Secretary -- Miss Alice Jenkins; Treasurer -- Frank Beunt, It was decided to adopt the title used by all these societies in the older churches of liberal faith, the "Unity Club."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- There has been a great, deal of conjecture regarding the permanent location of the Papal delegation in Washington. It is now authoritatively announced that the Archbishops of the Church in the United States have taken the matter in hand, and a suitable dwelling for the Papal delegation will be erected. At the meeting of the Archbishops in Chicago the details will be decided.

In December, 1872, the United States steamship Lackawanna was lying off the Viceroy's landing at Calcutta, India. We had on board the first American Admiral ever seen there. We were entertained not only viceregally but right royally. Balls, dinners, parties, , of all kinds were the order of the day, and more particularly of the night.

The New-York Letter Carriers' Mutual Benefit Association, Empire Branch No. 36, will have its second annual picnic and games at Sulzer's Harlem River Part, Monday, July 3. Money is needed to build up the sick and funeral fund of the association, which was drawn upon heavily last Winter.

According to the London correspondent of the Bradford Observer, Mr. Labouchere has been mode the victim ot practical joking on the part, probably, of facetious Unionists. The other day a load of furniture was sent to his house from Shoolbred's, which he had never ordered. Another day a quantity of coal was sent to Ills house by a firm of coal merchants, who found that they had been hoaxed.

The superiority of the Seventh Regiment as a "strong" shooting organization -- the strongest in the National Guard -- has not been disputed by any of the regiments of the National Guard which hare shot over Creedmoor in class practice as yet, and unless a phenomenal record is made by the Ninth and the Sixty-ninth, which are to occupy the range this week, it is not likely to be this season.

The pitiful story of the destitution of the two widows living in a wretched tenement at 103 Sackett Street, Brooklyn, published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, touched the hearts of many readers, and $31.05 was sent to THE TIMES office for them. Of the money sent in $16.05 was delivered to the mother yesterday, the rest not reaching the office till late in the afternoon.

LENOX, Mass., June 17 -- The cottagers here have been spending a very quiet week. There have been no large entertainments, and the weather has been so warm that the greatest pleasure was to be found in driving In the cool of the day. George G. Havon had out his fourin -hand on Wednesday of this week. He drove four very fine horses, and had with him several members of his family.
BOSTON, June 17. -- A special dispatch from Fall River, speaking of the reported confession of Jose Correiro, suspected of the murder of Bertha Manchester, says:

Some of the trades unions in this city seem to have an incorrect understanding of the factory laws in regard to sweat shops, and imagine that the Factory Inspectors have the power to suppress them. A committee from the Cigar Makers' Union called on State Factory Inspector Connolly and Assistant Inspector Franey, and demanded that they proceed forthwith to break up the system of tenement-house cigar manufacture.
"Though we go back to old styles in dress furniture, and architecture," said a venerable woman recently, "and enjoy the change, there are some old styles that are never revived and happily so.

It is not unlikely that the Mahan system of flash signaling from lighthouses will be adopted by the Lighthouse Board. The official test is yet to be made, but a private test was made in New-York Harbor on Friday night than was in every way successful.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The International Typographical Union decided this morning to publish the report or the investigation of the Childs-Drexel Home, as so much, of the prooceedings had already become known. The investigation was conducted by President Prescott of the International Union in person.

From the Scottish Leader. In the border counties stories are going the round regarding the habits or a surgeon who died the other day after practicing for the lone period of sixty-one years. Eccentric, closefisted, and with a reputation for odd sayings, the doctor dressed like a tramp and was widely known over the borderland for his peculiar habits.

While Philip Lefkowitz, a telegraph messenger boy, was walking through Greene Street Friday afternoon he was accosted by a young man who asked him to take a letter to the store of Eames Co., 25 West Houston Street, and bring back an answer. The boy took the letter to Mr. H.A. Eames, the senior member of the firm.

LONG BBANCH, June 17 -- Can the Long Branch drive be saved, for the uses of coming generations? For ten years it has been a matter of great concern now the caprices of nature could be subverted and the moat celebrated ocean drive on the coast protected.

Dr. Senner, Superintendent of Immigration, in speaking yesterday about the tramp steamship Red Sea, now on her way here from Hamburg with 800 Russian Jews, whom the regular steamship companies refused to ship, believing that they would be barred as undesirable immigrants, said:

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The work on the Phila delphia is being pushed rapidly and it is expected that she will be able to sail from the New-York Navy Yard next Tuesday, and she will be followed in a very short time by the Charleston.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 17 -- The Twenty-third Regiment was succeeded in camp this afternoon by the Seventh Regiment. All in camp who observed the work of the Twenty-third, the cheerfulness with which it was undertaken, and the excellence with which it was executed, expressed the kindliest sentiments for it and its board of officers for their standfast efforts in improving the organization.

The Infanta Eulallo breakfasted at 11 o'clock yesterday, and Shortly afterward, accompanied, by the Marchioness of Arco-Hermoea, left the house 28 East Sixty-second Street, and went on a shopping tour. She returned a little after 1 o'clock, and at 4 o'clock she received the Duke of Veragua and his family. The Duke and Duchess, the Marquis of Barboles, Donna Maria, the Marquis of Villalobar.

From the Baltimore American. Mr. C. D. Barnitz of this city has suggested a means of preventing cholera and other diseases by a cheap and effective method. The remedy is common soot-such as can be obtained from any chimney. Soot is composed of purs carbon and is formed by the hot vapor of the hydro carbons coming from burning fuel striking the cold walls of the chimney or stovepipe and condensing thereon.

When Postmaster Dayton assumes his duties in the Federal Building July 1, it may be that he will know who his lieutenants will be. But if applications for places continue to rain in on him as they have since his appointment, he is likely to be too weary to know or care much just how things stand.

aThe fifth meeting of the Manhattan Tennis Association of this city took place yesterday afternoon on the Hamilton Club courts. One Hundred and Forty-third Street and Hamilton Place. The men's doubles was the event of the day. The entries were divided into two classes: Class A, players graded from minus odds to seventeen points handicap, inclusive, and Class B, mayors graded from eighteen to thirty-five points handicap, inclusive.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 17 -- This village is now under martial law. At 2 o'clock this afternoon President George W. Stanley issued a proclamation calling upon everybody to abstain from violence and declaring the village under martial law.

A World's Railway Commerce Congress will be held in the Art Institute, Chicago, beginning nest Tuesday. George R. Blanohard, Chairman of the General Committee, will preside and will deliver the opening address. Other addresses will be delivered during the day as follows:

The Corinthian yachtsmen are not fair-weather sailors. A hard blow, tumbling sea, and dirty weather generally will never keep them in port 1 they have a race on hand. This was proved yesterday. The schooner race was sailed outside the Hookand for pleasure seekers a more disagreeable day could not be imagined. The wind came from the northeast by east.

The striped suit of convict's clothes which George W. Carter wore when he escaped from Sing Sing Prison nearly two weeks ago was found yesterday in O.B. Potter's barn about a mile and a halt from the prison. Nothing had been heard of Carter nor of Frank Adams, who escaped Wednesday.
John Y. MoKane says the town of Gravesend must buy two steam fire engines tight away. The town will buy the fire engines, for McKan is King of Coney Island.

To a friend who saw Bishop Wigger during the commencement exercises at Baton Hall College last weeK the Bishop made positive and emphatic denial of the recently-published report that he had been summoned to Rome for any cause whatever. It has been said that he had been ordered, to go to the Eternal City to explain his alleged Insubordinate attitude toward Mgr. Satolli, the Apostolic Delegate.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jane 17 -- Joseph Ayoob, the New-York novelty merchant arrested here yesterday, charged with smuggling, is still in custody under $5,000 bonds.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 17 -- Judson B. Andrews, Superintendent of the State Insane Asylum, made a taller statement to-day concerning Edward M. Field. Dr. Andrews said:

-- Manager H.C. Miner of the Fifth Avenue Theatre has concluded to modify the prices of admission for the Summer opera season, which begins to-morrow night with the second edition or "The Isle of Champagne," by the Thomas Q. Seabrooke Opera Company. The general admission will be 50 cents instead of $1, and the gallery sexts will be reduced to 25 cents.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, June 17 -- The Mexican troops are meeting with many obstacles in their effort to subdue the warring Yaqui Indians, who have their rendezvous in the Sierra Madre Mountains west or here.

It was under decidedly discouraging conditions that the Coney Island Jockey Club began Its Summer race meeting yesterday afternoon. The sky was overcast in the morning, so as to keep many from going to the course, and during the progress of the racing there was a slight fall of rain, not enough to interfere with the sport, but enough to make things uncomfortable for all at the track.

North Carolina huokleberriss are now being received gaits freely in the New-York market. They are brought to New-York principally by the Old Dominion steamships and the Pennsylvania Railroad. The man to whom Southern vegetables and fruits are sent have to be on the piers from midnight until lone after daylight to sell to the jobber.

Although announced on the title page as a new edition, the present life of this famous artist of the close of the eighteenth century is issued here, we believe, for the first time. It is the first formal life in English that has been written. On the Continent, and especially in Germany, ample attention has been bestowed upon this gifted woman.
BABYLON. L.I., June 17 -- The mysterious burglar who has been terrorizing feminine Babylon for a week roves to be a poor quality of burglar, but more mysterious than ever, nevertheless.

"Business, both wholesale end retail, is just now generally dull in California and other far Western States." said George A. Knight, one at the leading attorneys and politicians of San Francisco to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday.

The auction sales of real estate for the present week contain some notable offerings. Among them the largest is that of the estate of the late Charles Loughran. The list of his property includes no less than twenty-three tenement or flat houses, a fine mansion, two little Harlem dwellings, and a vacant lot above the Harlem River.

On Saturday, May 27, the Irish championship matches were finished, first place in the singles going to J. Pim, Lansaowne Tennis Club, who defeated Ernest Renshaw, the previous holder of the title, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4. The all comers' doubles went to J. Pim and F. O. Stakes, who will now meet E. W. Lewis and E. G. Meers for the championship of Ireland.

SARATOGA, June 17 -- Typical June weather has been enjoyed here during tills week -- warm, dry days, cool nights, and cloudless skies. The cottages are all occupied, and the coming week the big hotels swing open their doors. Every day afresh batch of lawyers arrives to help the Court of Appeals make law.

The War Department has made known in a practical way its desire to do the utmost possible for the Summer encampments of the State troops. Wisconsin, New-Jersey, and perhaps other States have asked for the presence of bodies of regulars at their camps, and whatever can judiciously be done in this particular will be-conceded.

In this volume of the University Extension Series of Manuals, which Prof. William Knight edits, the information given is precise and the educational faculty shown is striking. Two periods are presented, the first extending from the seventh to the end of the seventeenth century, and the second from 1600 to the present time.

We have no doubt that the statements of Mr. BOTKINE, Secretary of the Russian Legation at Washington, which we printed the other day, in regard to the real reason for the edicts driving the Jews from Russia, are substantially correct. "The Jews," he said, "are cleverer than the Russians.

A well-dressed good-looking man drove up to the door of a little saloon in Eighth Avenue, near One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street, the other afternoon, and having tied his horse to the post in front of the door, took from under the seat of his stylish road cart a large bundle covered with brown paper, and, after a furtive glance up and down the avenue, entered the saloon.

TRENTON, N.J., June 18. -- The argument on the race-track suits last week brought together several men of notoriety in State affairs. Allan L. McDermott and Robert Adrain were at the bar, and ex-Gov. Leon Abbett was on the bench. This is the first time that Senator Adrain has appeared before Justice Abbett, and there was a delightful exchange of pleasantries.

The young lady who wrote "A Girl in the Carpathians" has compiled this volume and written for it a preface. Such comments as she makes on the leading heroines. Hannah Snell, Mrs. Christian Davies, and Mary Anne Talbot are not precisely flattering. The fact is, that when the records are searched it is found that these soldiers in petticoats were in the habit of drawing the long bow.

Stevens Institute students have now turned their attention from the turf to the water. No odds are given and it is impossible to prophesy a winner in the coming race at the Stevens Yacht Club regatta. The race absorbing all this interest will be sailed between Mr. Gilmore's sloop Merope and Mr. Crabbe's sloop Duster on Tuesday, July 4, off Greenwich, Conn.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. -- The Harvard seniors listened to the baccalaureate sermon this afternoon preached by the Rev. William S. Rainsford, D. D., of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church of New-York City, in the college chapel. The text was a passage from the second chapter or Philippians, beginning: " Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others.

WATERBURY, Conn., June 18. -- A descendant on her mother's side of John Adams, her father's ancestors of old Revolutionary stock, Miss Sara Winthrop Smith of Seymour, Conn., may be said, to have plenty of American, blood in her veins. She is a woman suffragist, and with Isabella Beecher Hooker, Francis Elien Burr, and others, has been at Hartford, the past Winter urging the right of women to the elective franchise.

HONOLULU, June 10, (via San Francisco, June 18.) For the first time in the history of the Hawaiian Islands the Hawaiian national flag was floated over the palace on June 2. The formal occupation of the palace by the provisional Government, and the raising of the national emblem over it, are regarded by the annexationists generally and by many of the natives as a final blow to monarchy.

BERLIN, June 18. -- The election returns were virtually completed this afternoon. The report from but one district is lacking. The revision of the returns may make a few alterations, but they will be trivial. The candidates elected number 215. Of these 101 will vote for the Army bill ; 114 against it.

Replies received up to the time of going to press this morning from members of the Fifty-third Congress, in answer to the telegrams sent out to them by THE NEW-YORK TIMES asking whether they favored the repeal of the Sherman silver law, and also requesting an expression of preference as to a form of currency issue, make the total number of answers received from Representatives 203 and from Senators 40.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., June 18. -- The baccalaureate sermon to the senior class of Lehigh University was preached to-day in Packer Memorial Chapel by the Right Rev. Thomas Underwood Dudley of Louisville, Bishop of Kentucky. Bishop Dudley had the largest congregation that ever attended a baccalaureate sermon at Lehigh.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: Among the many recent suggestions made by the Rapid-Transit Commissioners and others but little attention has been given to the capabilities of the New-York Central as a rapid-transit road. The first proposition of the Commissioners was for an entirely new system of railroads, traversing the city from end to end.

MASPETH, L.I., June 18. -- The Township of Newtown is composed of a number of pretty villages, and many of them contain the residences of New-York business men. These villages are near enough to New-York to invite the rough rabble from the city, and the attraction to this class is increased by the recent establishment of a number of baseball parks, beer gardens, and dives.

Among the visitors at Fleetwood yesterday was W.B. Vasig, who reports that he received a telegram from the Charter Oak Park Directorate, asking him to defer his visit, as they were not ready to close the deal by which New-York was to take all of Hartford's trotting events.

Despite the depressing and poverty-stricken surroundings, there was a happy little family yesterday in the dark cellar room in the rear basement of 103 Sackett Street, Brooklyn. The two widows, mother and daughter, whoso sad story of suffering was told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Saturday, spent the happiest day they had known for a long time, and the three small daughters realized that a change had come in their condition.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. -- The year at Harvard is about ended. Next weet the examinations close and many of the students will start for home. The Annex girls hold their Class Day on Wednesday. The feature of the occasion will be an address by Prof. C. C. Everett. The event of the next day will be the great Yale game at Cambridge, the first of the season's series between the two universities.
NEW-ROCHELLE, June 18. -- New Rochelle is bankrupt.

The Norwegian societies of Brooklyn gave a reception to Capt. Magnus Andersen and the crew of the Viking ship at Prospect Hall, in Prospect Avenue, near Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night. All the Norwegian societies in Brooklyn were represented and many of Capt. Andoreen's old neighbors, when he was Superintendent of the Scandinavian Sailors' Home, in Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, were present to give him greeting.
Samuel Adler, proprietor of the Nineteenth Ward Marble and Granite Works, killed himself with a pistol yesterday at his home, 213 East Forty-ninth Street.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 18. -- The Pequot House formally opened for the season last Wednesday. This year the house is under the management of C.A. Blanchard, formerly of the Hotel Marlborough, New-York, and W.H. Hagar, who has also had New-York hotel experience.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- In the report of yesterday's proceedings of the International Typographical Union in session at Chicago, it was stated that the committee appointed to investigate the condition of the Childe-Drexel Home, situated at Colorado Springs, Col., had "found the Board of Trustees guilty of a violation of trust and censured especially as responsible for this condition of affairs J.D.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Chauncey M. Depew has seen the fair, or at least a part of it. In his judgment there has never been a World's Fair equal in all its appointments to the one now in progress at Jackson Park. In speaking of this to-day, Mr. Depew said:

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, June 19 -- A.M. The stock market last week was very dull. The leaders among the railways were St. Paul, Atchison, Reading, and New-England, and among the industrials Sugar, General Electric, Distilling and Cattle Feeding, and Chicago Gas. Fluctuations were narrow.

PERKSKILL, June 18. -- Though it was the Sabbath, the Seventh has had an industrious day. Two guard mountings, (morning and afternoon,) divine service, instruction in drilling, and evening parade have kept the entire command busy. The morning guard mounting was snappy and full of life. At 11 o'clock the entire camp assembled on Pulpit Bluff, in the left and rear of Gen. Porter's tent, where an improvised pulpit of drums had been erected.

It is not only in France that the fodder crops have failed. Other Continental countries are short of feed for cattle and horses, and in England the price of hay is $40 a ton. Speculators, our London correspond- ent says, are buying up the available stocks of fodder in Australia and South America.

Ralph Preston of Hornellsville, N.Y., who is undergoing treatment at the new Pasteur Institute, Ninety-seventh Street and Central Park West, for a nervous complaint, fell from the window of his room on the second floor yesterday morning to the sidewalk, about 25 feet, and was slightly injured.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18. -- Wade Hampton, the United States Railroad Commissioner, is in California looking over the Central Pacific property and trying to figure out how the Government can best cope with the big corporation in collecting the existing railroad debt.

TRENTON, N. J., June 18. -- Mrs. Sarah Jones charges Superintendent William Bower of the Riverview Cemetery at this place with having shoveled the remains of her sister and brother, coffinless, from one grave into another to make room for the body of Sarah E. Nicholson. another sister of Mrs. Jones, who died recently.

The people who were burned out at Coney Island on Saturday morning were not at all cast down yesterday. When the great crowds appeared, they found many of the former tenants doing a thriving business over the ashes of the burned buildings. Some bad pitched tents, while others had put up board shanties.

TRENTON, June 18. -- The New-Jersey Rifle Association will hold its annual meeting on the New-Jersey camp ground at Sea Girt the week beginning Aug. 14. This association is composed of all the crack marksmen of the National Guard of the State, as well as a large number of State officials. During the period of its meeting the National Rifle Association will also have its matches on the Sea Girt ground.

DULUTH, Minn., June 18. -- For three weeks the towns on the new Iron Range Railroad have been fighting for existence against forest fires. There are on the new range the towns of Biwabik, McKinley, Virginia, and Mountain Iron, aggregating in population some 6,000 people.
A man thirty years of age, presumably John J. Mulrennin of 72 Hampshire Street, Boston, committed suicide last evening by jumping off the Brooklyn Bridge, on the New-York side.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As there is so much controversy at present over missions to the Jews, it is important to understand Just what they are, as they vary very materially from missions to the uncivilized heathen, and those who have only missions of the latter kind in mind may well ask why missions to the Jews should exist at all.

Taps were sounded over a grave in Calvary Cemetery late yesterday afternoon, and gathered around the roughly-made mound a score of men and two women gave tribute to the memory of a man who, in the prime of his life, was the active instrument in causing much trouble and annoyance to the English Government.
In Dr. Talmsge's Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday four converts were baptized by immersion in the presence of a congregation that packed the great ckurch.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 18. -- The murder of Bertie Wagner, the little son of Louis Wagner, a farmer near Howell, N.J., by George Wood, a boy employed by Mr. Wagner, has caused intense excitement in that portion of Monmouth County. Young Wood ran away and has not been arrested.
There has been a water famine in the little suburb of Morris Heights. It began several days ago and ended only yesterday.

The Rev. Thomas J. Ducey, pastor of St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twentyeighth Street, was asked yesterday by a NEWYORK TIMES reporter whether he thought that Dr. McGlynn would, be reinstated as pastor of St. Stephen's Church on his return from Rome.

At London British consols for both money and the account were unchanged, the former at 99 1-16 and the latter at 99 1/8. There was some buying of American securities. Bar silver advanced 1/4, to 38 1/2d P ounce. The Bank of England gained u1,911,000 in bullion, and the percentage of reserve to liabilities, which the previous week was 49.55, became 49.79.

To the Editor of the New-YorK Times: In looking through an old scrapbook of mine I found the following communication to the Chicago Times, date not given, which may prove as valuable to your numerous readers as the receipt for cholera medicine published in your paper some years ago, which I have in my scrapbook. The disinfectant is so cheap and simple that all can use it where there is contagious disease.
The recklessness of boys inexperienced in rowing caused a drowning in the East River yesterday afternoon.

The story of the suit brought by Mrs. Josephine Bell, who for many years was known as Mrs. Henry Maillard, against Mme. Celestine Mullins for $50,000 for defamation of character was fully told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 18. -- But a few days ago the word of Julius J. Du Bose was as potent in the County of Shelby. State of Tennessee, as the dictum of that other Julius was in old Rome. To-day, humiliated, stripped of his power and broken in fortune, there are few so poor to do him reverence. He was lately a Criminal Court Judge.

GENEVA, N. Y., June 18. -- The sixty-eighth commencement at Hobart College began this morning with early communion at St. John's Chapel. A sermon was preached at the regular morning service in Trinity Church by the Rev. Charles F. Hoffman, rector of All Angels' Church, New-York, before St. John's Guild, a college society composed of the students who are candidates for holy orders.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 18. -- Gov. Lewelling said a few days ago to a prominent Democrat, "After this year the Populists will have no use for the Democrats." The Populist, one of the leading papers of that party, in its last issue said:

This guide book, as is generally known, is the result of many years of labor. Americans have written of American scenery, architecture, manners, and life. They have shown the clearest and most impressive manner of presenting all their subjects, not only to foreigners unacquainted with America, but to the Americans themselves.

The America's Cup Committee of the New-York Yacht Club has decided to begin the series of trial races, to choose the yacht to meet the Valkyrie, on Sept. 7. One day will intervene between each race, and the number of races will be not less than three and probably not more than five.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Secretary Lamont will soon take up the question of changes in the civil force of the War Department, it is a matter which has been allowed to rest pending the consideration of matters which are of more general importance. In making changes secretary Lamont will be guided by considerations of benefit to the service.

Early morning travelers on the "L" cars may have noticed at the double curve at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Eighth Avenue, overlooking Morningside Park, a stream of people winding its way up the paths which lead to the ramparts. They were of all kinds and conditions of men, women, and children, and every one of them carried a pitcher or a can.

PARIS, May 19. -- The Salon of the Champ de Mars was brilliantly inaugurated by a paying Varnishing Day. Five francs -- $1 -- not much for a picture show, with notabilities, howling swells, and fine gowns thrown in! I am much afraid, however, that the payers were few, and the invitations and passe droits in majority; however, this was not the question.

OTTAWA, June 18. -- The members of the Liberal or Reform Party of Canada will hold a general national convention in this city Tuesday, with the view of organizing and preparing for the next general election for the federal House of Commons. This will be the first national political convention ever held in the Dominion, as hitherto the election campaigns have been conducted by organizations limited in their scope to the different Provinces.

HARTFORD, June 18. -- The Congregational churches in this State will hold the principal anniversaries of the year at Rookville, beginning Tuesday, June 20. The events will include the 184th annual meeting of the General Association. The address to the clergy will be made by the Rev. Dr. J. W. Backus of Plainville, and the Rev. Dr. T. T. Manger of New-Haven will deliver an address on "Christ in Literature."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 18. -- For ten hours to-day the street-railway systems or Minneapoils and St. Paul were tied up. Some few days ago the company issued an order requiring the employes to sign a contract or else quit its employ.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 18. -- Wilfred Laurier, leader of the Dominion Liberals, arrived here this evening to prepare for the Liberal Conven tion which opens Tuesday. It is expected that about a thousand delegates will be present from all parts of the Dominion. It is the first great party convention ever held in Canada, and is arousing exceptional interest.

The Infanta Eulalie, who now prefers to be known as the Duchess of Montpensier, so that she may be relieved from a good deal of royal red tape, went to mass yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral in a manner that formed a complete contrast to her first visit to that edifice, when she was escorted by the Old Guard, and was received with all the pemp and circumstance attendant on royalty.

BALTIMORE, June 18. -- The Democratic State Central Committee, which will meet here next Thursday, will fix the dates for the State Convention and for the various judicial conventions. Controller Marion De Kalb Smith will be renominated, and that will be the only State officer to be voted for this year. Owing to the unprecedented number of deaths and resignations of Judges, there will be numerous judicial elections.

Count Reventlow of Germany, an officer in the Fourteenth Hussars and a descendant of the royal family of Denmark, has been at West Point for the past ten days, making a critical examination of the Military Academy during the closing exercises there. Accompanied by the Countess, who is an American, he was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 18. -- The present session of the General Assembly, which will not be adjourned prior to June 30, will be the longest one on record in the State. Since the 1st of January not less than 2,000 petitions, resolutions, and bills for public acts have been introduced and referred to committees for consideration.

To-morrow there will be a political convention at Ottawa, Canada, of a kind familiar enough to us, but quite novel for the Dominion. It is to be made up of the Liberal candidates for Parliament at the last elections, of editors and proprietors of Liberal newspapers, and of delegates chosen, by the Liberal electors -- in all some 1,000 men.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Bishop Merrill of the Methodist Church says that his denomination will boycott the fair. He has information to the effect that the General Commission will issue a manifesto next Thursday withdrawing the exhibits, and that the 5,000,000 members of the Church will Keep away week days as well as Sundays.

NASSAU, Neb., June 18. -- An expectant crowd of people was on hand at break of day to greet the riders in the cowboy race, this being their registering place. At 3:25 P.M. a cheer was raised by the crowd, and amid a cloud of dust two riders, each leading a horse, trotted up to the Saxton House, dismounted, and registered in the following order: Gillespie, first: Stevens, second.
The American Theatre Roof Garden will open this evening with an aggregation of vaudeville talent. A rehearsal to which were admitted a number of T. Henry French's friends was given last night.

The trouble which has been brewing for six months between, the Board of Managers and the Medical Board of the New-York Infant Asylum has terminated in the resignation of thirteen physicians, specialists, from the staff of the hospital.

SALTILLO, Mexico, June 18. -- The first case of a claim for damages for personal injury that ever came up before a judicial tribunal in Mexico has Been presented before the court here by an Italian, who is suing a mining company of Ban Felipe for the lose of a leg.

Seven days at the Chicago Exposition, with an expenditure of $75, including passage from New-York and return, is amply sufficient "for the best time one ever had in one's life," as a beneficiary of the World's Fair Scholarship Association for Young Women wrote the other day to Miss S.M. Minturn, the head of the Board of Managers of that philanthropic enterprise.

-- John Morley is still engaged on his sketch of Chatham for the Twelve English Statesmen Series, of which he is editor. Only one other volume is now needed to complete the series. This is the one on Edward I., by Prof. Tout of Owen's College, Manchester, which is already in press.

VIENNA, June 18 -- Five thousand workingmen, in defiance of a police prohibition, held a meeting in favor of universal suffrage at Weigsenberge, outside of Bruenn, to-day. When the police attempted to disperse the meeting they were received with, a volley from revolvers and a shower of stones.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $5,644,100. The banks now hold $8,776,800 in excess of the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $3,699,800, a decrease in specie of $1,310,900, a decrease in legal tenders of $7,430,500, a decrease in deposits of $12,389,200, and an increase in circulation of $37,000.

There is a good deal of solid, workable stupidity in politicians of all parties, despite the progress that has been made in the last dozen years. Gov. McKINLEY, for instance, has learned nothing by his experiences since he was Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means in the House of Representatives.

An organization has been formed for the special purpose of agitating for the abrogation of the extradition treaty with Russia. It is not altogether likely that the Government will give the necessary six months' notice until something occurs to show the undesirability of maintaining the agreement.
Two weeks ago eight men were brought to Hoboken from Stroudsburg, Penn., by a train of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad. They were said to have been the victims of a dynamite explosion.

Many attractive features are in a new suburban enterprise that has been set on foot at Tenafly, N. J. In the village proper and within ten minutes' walk of the railway station is an elevated plateau known as Teaneck Ridge. The land here slopes gently to the East, providing excellent drainage and giving a desirable outlook for residences.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 18. -- The Harvard and Yale University crews have been here for a week, rowing twice each day in their eights and spending the intermediate time in sleeping and eating, and in writing their examinations, unless, indeed, they are called upon by their coaches for a little special instruction in the pair oars, which is by no means unusual.

A red-headed man with a bristling mustache staggered along Henry Street at 9 o'clock last Saturday night, lurched, and fell asprawl of the stoop of Michael Teta, a shoemaker, at 5 Henry Street. Presently street arabs began to annoy him, and when they found that he was helpless they explored his pockets.

Prices for what are known as the horse-show sales if harness horses ruled somewhat lower than usual last week, though, considering the lateness of the season and the fact that the market is if anything oversupplied, Tattersalls average of about $270 and W.D. Grand's of over $200 must be considered fair. Carriage builders and dealers are unusually busy for the month of June.
Representative J.G. Maguire, (Dem.) To the Editor of the New-York Times: I am in favor of the immediate repeal of the Sherman silver purchase act. I am not prepared to answer your second question.
Walter Besant, the English novelist, was a passenger by the Cunarder Etruria, which arrived from Liverpool Saturday night. It is his second visit to America. He spent a few weeks here in 1876.
The Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Baptist Tabernacle, against whom numerous Charges were recently made, celebrated yesterday the twentieth anniversary of his admission to the ministry.

NEW-HAVEN, June 18. -- The Constitutional Convention bill at the State Capitol has received a blow in the house of its friends, and its passage, even in the Senate, where the Democrats have a majority, now seems seriously imperiled.

LONDON, June 18. -- Discount rates were rather firmer during the week at 1 1/4 for three months and 1 for short bills. A renewed demand for gold is expected from Austria, where u10,000,000 is yet required. Meanwhile all arrivals of bar gold in the open market are taken for Germany.

"Delacroix Intime" would not be an inappropriate name for the two volumes which have just made their appearance from the gained presses of the Rue Garanciere. They embrace the artist's almost daily jottings between the years 1823 and 1854. The "study" which precedes them, by way of introduction, has been written de main de maitre by M. Paul Flat, and is in itself a valuable contribution to the biography of the great French painter.

Katie McCormick is but ten years old, and by no means a big girl for her age, but her desire for adventurous exploration is as well developed as that of the great Stanley himself, and in the gratification of that desire her small heart knows no fear.

PEEKSKILL, June 18. -- Under Adjt Gen. Porter's energetic administration the New-York State National Guard will soon be in a position to take the field with every modern appliance for the comfort, welfare, and health of the men.

George P. Rowell, publisher of Printers' Ink, has started out to learn why the ruling of the Post Office Department in 1891 which still excludes his publication from carriage through the mails at the rare for second-class matter should not either be reversed or else be made to apply to all trade and class publications.

The colored porters who look after the comfort of the patrons of the Wagner cars running into the Grand Central Station declare that the color line has been drawn against them. What makes the offense worse in their eyes is that the offender is the Railroad Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.

LONDON, June 19. -- Only an excursion among the leading bankers and financiers of London to get an expression of opinion on a specific subject like the repeal of the Sherman act could reveal how little they really know about American affairs. Reuter's News Agency has already given them the results of the canvass of Congress made by THE NEW-YORK TIMES.
WILMINGTON, N.C., June 19. -- The Bank of New-Hanover was not opened this morning, and the following notice was posted on the door:

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Having set itself a task, and that to make Col. F.C. Ainsworth the person most responsible for the accident and loss of life at the Ford's Theatre Building, on Tenth Street, a week ago last Friday, the Coroner's jury this afternoon brought in its anticipated, verdict, holding Col. Ainsworth, Contractor Dant, Superintendent Covert, and Engineer Sasse to be responsible for the disaaaster to the building and the attendant loss of life.
