The changes officially made in the Richmond Terminal reorganization plan are as follows: The East Tennessee improvement and equipment bonds are to receive 75 per cent, in bonds preserving their present lien, bearing interest at 4 per cent. for five years, from March 1, 1893, and at 5 per cent thereafter, and 50 per cent. in preferred stock; also $25 in cash on completion of the reorganization.

The East River Bridge Commissioners met yesterday morning at 10 o'clock and held a abort session. It was expected that George B. Cornell, the engineer of the new bridge, would testify, but he was unable to attend on account of illness in his family.
JAMAICA, L.I., June 19. -- Instead of harmony all is discord in the choir loft of the Jamaica Reformed Church, and a charming soprano, Miss Burrill of Brooklyn, is the innocent cause of it all.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 19. -- Five o'clock to-morrow afternoon is the hour agreed upon for the Cornell-Columbia freshmen race over the two-mile course. It has not attracted much attention. From all indications it will be a race worth seeing. Columbia has brought fast crews to the Thames before, and holds the record for the fastest two miles ever made there, 9:41, although it was done under exceptionally favorable conditions of wind and tide.

LONDON, June 19. -- Richard M. Hunt of New-York received, at the Royal Institute of British Architects to-day, the Queen's Gold Medal. This distinction was conferred upon him in view of his work at the World's Fair in Chicago.

The record of the British yacht Valkyrie up to the present ought to be peculiarly gratifying to Americans. Every one has heard the old saying that an Englishman never knows when he is whipped, and in no class of contests does it have a more apt application than in those for the America's Cup.
In the Court of General Sessions yesterday Frank Davis, alias Sinclair, the notorious burglar, was sentenced by Recorder Smyth.

"I believe the banks which have recently suspended in New South Wales will pay pound for pound to all creditors and depositors," said Joseph Marks of Sydney to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter at the Holland House Sunday. Mr. Marks is Commissioner from New South Wales to the World's Fair. He has been for more than thirty years a resident of that portion of Australia, and is prominent in business and financial circles.
There were no public sales of real estate yesterday.

The first death resulting from the running of the cable cars on Broadway occurred last evening, when Johnny Wallace, a seven-year-old boy, was so terribly crushed and mangled that he died within a few minutes.
Adolph S. Jaeger, a well-to-do and prosperous cigar manufacturer, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself twice in the left breast at his residence, 250 East Seventy-second Street.
At a meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment held yesterday in the Mayor's office, Controller Myers was authorized to issue bonds amounting to $917,861.66 for various public improvements.

The Populist Governor of Kansas has made a curious record since he took office a few months ago, but it is not probable that in exercising his power to pardon convicts or to commute their sentences he will go beyond the extraordinary action of his Republican predecessor, Gov. HUMPHREYS, in the case of the two murderers WINNER and McNUTT.

The Kings County Tennis Club continued its club tonrnament on its grounds, Kingston Avenue and Dean Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The men's doubles were finished in favor of H. McGowan and E.M. Payne, who from scratch easily defeated C.R. Swaney and Dudley McGrath, also scratch, in the final round. Last year Dr. Frazer and F. Pen. dreigh took first place in the club tourney.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, June 19 -- P.M. Speculation is paralyzed by the abnormal state of the money market. All conditions favor the bear side, but the leaders are afraid to do anything, fearing an early return of easier money. On the other hand, the bulls lack confidence, fearful of they know not what.

Peace reigns in the Rapid-Transit Commission. The Commissioners are agreed. They have concluded to grant to the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company all the facilities for the extension of the company's service covered by their past resolutions, on a basis of compensation to the city and under restrictions that are a compromise between the views of Commissioner Starin and of Commissioners Spencer, Bushe, Steinway, and Inman.

Every morning about 9:50 o'clock mere is a serious jam of passengers bound for New-York on the Brooklyn approach to the East River Bridge. Yesterday morning at 9:52 the usual struggling crowd was on the platform, when a train drew up and there was a rush to board it.

The gun did business on thin earth according to the most approved Summer methods yesterday. The mercury burned its way up into the nineties and staid there with a persistency that caused man and beast to suffer.

Detective Van Leer of the Coney Island police yesterday arrested William Murtha, alias Harry, and alias Willie Montague, who is wanted for daring robberies committed in Newark, Paterson, and other places in New-Jersey.

Henry Guy Carleton, the playwright, is in trouble for failing to pay his debts. Samuel R. Morrison got a judgment against Mr. Carleton some time ago for $345.84. Failing to collect, Mr. Morrison obtained an order on Sept. 22, 892, for Mr. Carleton's examination in supplementary proceedings.

The prediction can be made with safety that the Fifty-third Congress at its first session will put raw wool on the free list and greatly reduce the duties on woolen goods. The duties on clothing wools now average 55 per cent., and the average duty on the woolen goods imported last year was nearly 96 per cent.

Several of the auction sales of real estate announced for to-day are likely to prove of interest. The principal one la that of the Loughran estate, with its large collection of tenement and apartment property. It is all desirable, and many inquiries bare been made of the auctioneers for book maps of description. Many years have elapsed since so large and valuable a list has been offered.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 19. -- Lieut. Gov. Sheehan is somewhere on the Continent now, but the work he had in mind, when he rushed the dark-lantern Police Commissioner bill through the last Legislature, is going on just as smoothly as if he were here personally to superintend it.

The Jersey City Tennis Club began its open tournament yesterday afternoon at the club courts, Hoagland. and Glenwood Avenues, Jersey City. The event of the day was the men's singles. Duncan Candler of Brooklyn is the best oft the entries and will probably take first place. He had an easy time in the two matches played yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, June 19. -- In spite of the torrid heat, the thermometer registering 95 at 10 o'clock this morning, the two battalions of the Seventh Regiment took possession of the drill ground, this morning, and for an hour and a half showed the spectators what they know about extended order. Officers and men were proficient in theory, and only needed practice to bring their theories to a very high state of perfection.

The announcement in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES that owing to ring rule the village of New-Rochelle was in a bankrupt condition did not occasion much surprise in that beautiful suburban place, for the reason that all the taxpayers had long been aware of the empty condition of the village treasury, but, nevertheless, little else than the grave question of how to get out of the tangle was discussed there yesterday.

There was a very lively row at the meeting of the Jersey City Street and Water Commissioners yesterday. The subject in dispute was the vacation of Railroad Avenue for the benefit of the New-Jersey Junction Railroad. The rosolution vacating the street was vetoed last Thursday by Mayor Wanser and before acting finally, the board consented to give the property owners a hearing, contrary to the usual custom in such cases.

DULUTH, Minn., June 19. -- A second train bearing refugees from the burned district arrived here at noon bearing nearly 200 people, the first having arrived at 1:30 A.M. Advices from Virginia are that only ten houses escaped the flames.

Two members of the gang of young burglars that has been robbing Public School No. 44, at Throop and Putnam Avenues, Brooklyn, have been captured, and will be held until their companions are arrested. They are Mortimer Halpin, ten years old, of 503 Madison Street, and Arthur Armstrong, eleven, of 453 Madison Street.

TAMPA, Fla., June 19. -- The body of Ignazio Camparito, an Italian, was found this morning. His throat had been cut from ear to ear and his breast, back, arms, and neck bore about twenty-five Knife wounds. It is supposed that the murder was committed last night about 9 o'clock, as those in the vicinity heard screams at that time.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 19. -- The annual "fence" crations were delivered at Yale this afternoon. As usual, the entire college gathered about the fence and listened to the efforts of the two crators chosen respectively from the freshman and sophomore classes, the sophomores handing the fence over to the freshmen, who now can occupy it for the first time in their college course.

ALBANY, June 19. -- The session laws of 1893 are all in type, and they will be bound and ready for delivery by the middle of July. They make, with the data the Secretary of State has to add, close on to 2,000 pages. This is about 700 pages more than the average, notwithstanding that there are fewer long laws than for some years past.

ALBANY, June 19. -- To-night had been set for the punishment of Charles H. Armatage, the recalcitrant Democrat and President of the Common Council. Some months ago Mr. Armatage deserted the Administration Democrats, and, going over to the Hill State machine, with three other Democratic Alderinen acted with the Republicans on all party matters.
ALBANY, June 19. -- A bold robbery occurred between 12 and 1 o'clock this afternoon at the jewelry establishment of Joseph Neafach, on the second floor of 33 South Pearl Street.
TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 19. -- Everything is progressing quietly here to-day and nine barges, all that are tied up at the docks, are being unloaded. Each boat is guarded by militla.

Johnny Lambley seems to have gone into training as a rival to the two strong-armed men that are now on exhibition at a couple of the roof-garden shows in this city, Sandow and Sampson. He took his exercise while riding Stonenell in the first race at the Sheepahead Bay tract yesterday, and not a man who saw the performance but will now be willing to back him against either of the imported strong men.

In the Building Department during the past week plans and specifications were recorded for the construction of sixty-one new buildings, involving a total estimated expense of $1,300,000, and also for alterations to be made to sixty-seven different structures at an outlay of $80,000.

Nicholas Aleinkoff, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Russian National League, when seen yesterday by a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES and asked to state the objections of his countrymen to the treaty recently entered into between this country and Russia, said:

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Prof. T.C. Mendenhall of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, on the part of the United States, and Commissioner King, on the part of Great Britain, will soon leave Washington to determine the vexed question as to which country is the legal owner of Pope's Folly Island, near the waters of the boundary line between the United States and Canada, off the coast of Maine.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Corn was king to-day. It advanced 1 1/4c and was strongest at the close. There was a suspicion that manipulators were at work and that an aggressive movement is contemplated by some of the heavy local bulls in the market. Shorts were free buyers. The papers were full of harrowing details of the great drought in Europe, while receipts in Chicago are running below expectations.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- The assiguees of Herman Shaffner Co., the insolvent bankers, completed the examination of the firm's affairs yesterday and filed a report. The liabilities, secured and unsecured, are shown to be $2,350,010; the total assets estimated as good, $1,894,905, and the total assets of every kind $2,312,818, leaving an excess of liabilities of $37,102. The substance of the report is as follows:

Another man jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday and lives to brag about it. This time it was a thick-set young plumber, John J. Haggerty. He is twenty-two years old, married, and lives at 21 Cherry Street.

Hell Gate was the scene yesterday morning of a collision between a steamer towing two barges, crowded with excursionists, up the East River and two schooners that were being towed in the same direction by a tug.

The sale of the Belle Meade yearlings at Tattersalls last night brought out the most spirited bidding seen at the thoroughbred yearling sales this year. Michael F. Dwyer and Foxhall Keene had a lively bidding bont for the brown colt, half brother to Watterson, by Iroquois Dutchess, Mr. Dwyer finally securing him for $7,200 -- the highest price of the year for a thoroughbred yearling.

WASHINGTON, Jane 19. -- "There is nothing new in the fin-keel yacht," says Naval Constructor Philip Hichborn, whose long experience as a designer and builder of all sorts of floating craft enables him to take a great interest in the construction of yachts. He said to a correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES to-day:

The trial of Alderman William J. McKee of Brooklyn, who, with several other members of the Common Council, is under indictment for the alleged Columbian celebration frauds, was resumed in the Court of Sessions before Judge Henry A. Moore and Associate Justices J.S. Stryker and James F. Kelly yesterday.

BABYLON, L.I., June 19. -- The midnight prowler who has been terrifying women here for a week appeared again on Saturday night About 9:30 P.M. Mrs. George Larned saw a man on the roof of the kitchen extension of her house. She raised an alarm, but the fellow escaped.

The "cold thirteen" of the Board of Aldermen, Brooklyn, massed its forces once more yesterday afternoon, threw away an offer of $257,000 to the municipality, and voted miles of streets to the P.H. Flynn syndicate and the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, the great transportation monopoly of the town.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19. -- Mrs. Harry Ackerman, who some time ago created a scene on a Haledon electric car by thrashing her husband, who is a conductor, has found evidence in this city which she tried to use to-day at Paterson in having her husband arrested for bigamy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 19. -- A handsome young man, supposed to be Elmer James of Philadelphia, tied lead to his legs while on the pleasure yacht Annie May this evening, and leaped to his death in the ocean. He engaged old Capt. Somers at 6 o'clock to take him as far out to sea as possible.

The Cassell Publishing Company is in the hands of a receiver. Oscar M. Dunham, President of the company, cannot be found. It is alleged that he has absconded after converting about $180,000 of the concern's funds to his own use.
CITY ISLAND, June 19. -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Viking, Mr. H.A. Hutchinson, and Susqnehanna, Mr. Joseph Stickney. Sloop yacht Katrina, Mr. George Work.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 19. -- Peter Thill died this morning from the effects of three bullet wounds received by him from Victor Gareise yesterday morning after a quarrel about some painting and a woman of whom Gareise was jealous.

BERLIN, June 19. -- Herr Liebknecht, the well-known Social Domocatic leader, in an interview to-day upon the Army bill and other matters pertaining to Thursday's elections, admitted that the Government would get a majority of the members of the Reichstag to vote for the Army bill by effecting a compromise with certain of the political factions.

Sorosis held its last meeting of the season at Sherry's, in Fifth Avenue, yesterday. It was so warm that one of the younger members of the club succumbed to the heat and was carried across the hall to an ante-room, where she was stretched on the floor for over an hour, while several of her clubmates slapped her hands and bathed her face and applied a solution of ammonia to her nostrils.

Morris Wagner, aged thirty-two, a clerk living at 317 East Seventy-sixth Street, and Jacob S. Cronise, a broker at 45 Exchange Place, were injured yesterday afternoon in front of 35 Broad street by a cornice which fell on them from the fifth story of the building owned by H.H. Cammann Co.

Capt. Magnus Andersen of the Viking and five of his bold Norse sailormen were prisoners yesterday in the Butler Street Police Court in South Brooklyn. A policeman stood the guests of New-York and the Nation in a row before Justice James G. Tighe and charged them with being drunk and disorderly.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- President Cleveland does not conceal the satisfaction he has derived from the perusal of the letter of Senator Butler of South Carolina, written to a constituent and published yesterday, touching the question of appointment. A part of the letter was reproduced in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of to-day.

The West again asked New-York for money yesterday, and was favored with shipments of currency which aggregated almost $1,500,000. Chicago figured as usual in the demand, and so did most of the principal cities of the West and Southwest. A little money was sent to New-England.

Everybody who takes the least bit of interest in racing is expected to beat the Coney Island Hanracetrack this afternoon. The tenth Suburban dicap is to be run, and this is the race of the year with the crowds. It is to America what the Derby is to England, the Grand Prix to France, or the Melbourne Cup to Australia, so far as the general interest in the contest is concerned.

Detective Shaughnessy went to 247 Kosciusko Street, Brooklyn, yesterday and arrested Mrs. Mary F. Post on the charge of having stolen a pair of diamond earrings valued at $111.36 from R.H. Macy Co. of this city.

The occupants of the five-story apartment house at 136 West Sixty-seventh Street, owned by Jacob Messner, were given a terrible fright yesterday morning, when huge pieces of granite crashed into the rear wall of the building and tore away a great section of it.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Will not vote to repeal Sherman act of 1890 without some provision to issue a like amount of good money in its stead. I favor gold and silver money coined on equal terms, supplemented by a Government issue of paper money made a full legal tender.

ALABAMA, -- Second District -- Counties of Baldfrin. Escambia, Covington. Grenshaw, Conecuh, Butler, Wilcox, Pike, and Montgomery. Represented by J.F. Stallings, (Dem.) Seventh District -- Counties of St. Clair, Etowsh, Cherokee, De Kalb, and Marshall. Represented by W.H. Denson, (Dem.)

Whatever may be the result of the Borden trial, there can hardly be two opinions as to the superiority of the manner in which it has been conducted over that which is apt to characterize "sensational" murder cases in this State. It is, in fact, a credit alike to the bench and the bar of Massachusetts.

BOSTON, June 19. -- There was a fair amount of trading in Atchison and Sugar, but other arbitrage stocks were extremely dull. The tone of the market was somewhat weaker. Among local securities West End Railroad sold down to 55, do. Land to 13 1/4, Westinghouse preferred to 44, Central Massachusetts to 13 1/2, Butte and Boston to 6 1/4, and Calumes and Hecla to 280.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 19. -- In the presence of an audience that so filled the courtroom that it would have been hard to squeeze in another person, ex-Gov. Robinson spoke the last words of the defense to the jury that is trying Lizzie Borden on a charge of murder. He spoke for four hours.

Ex-Gov. James E. Campbell of Ohio, who has been slated by some of the Ohio politicians as the most probable candidate of the Democrats in the Gubernatorial campaign this year, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- Speculation to-day was stagnant and devoid of feature. Reading assented stock was trading in for the first time and ruled 1/8 below the regular stock. The weekly bank statement showed a decrease in reserve of $1,536,000. Loans increased $2O9,000; deposits decreased $1,240,000; circulation increased $31,000; national bank notes increased $22,000; due from other banks increased $607,000, and due to other banks increased $584,000.

This afternoon the annual lawn tennis tournament for the championship of the United states in women's singles, women's doubles, and mixed doubles will be held under the auspices of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association at Wissahicken Heights, Chestnut Hill. The grounds selected are those of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, which are considered to he among the finest in the country.

Every once in a while the Committee on National Affairs of the Republican Club feels called upon to take a hand in running the affairs of the Nation. It's a harmless sort of amusement, and tickles the fancy of the club members very much.

-- At a meeting of the Directors of the Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railroad in Toledo yesterday the following New-York capitalists entered the Directory to fill vacancies: John Jacob Astor, J. Edward Simmons, George W. Quintard, Amos F. Eno, Joseph Walker, Jr., H.B. Livingaton, and E. Dichman. These changes are the result of an agreement reached by the Bondholders' Committee.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 19. -- The Capital National Bank, which suspended one month ago, having been "caught" by the Chemical National Bank of Chicago, resumed business to-day.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- In spite of the fact that it was very warm to-day, visitors at the World's Fair did not suffer to any great extent from the heat. There was a refreshing breeze all day long from Lake Michigan, and it made life pleasant at Jackson Park. The attendance was not large, however, and those who ventured out had plenty of elbow room to take on the sights.

The gigantic tunnel scheme of the New-York and New-Jersey Terminal Railroad Company was under consideration by the Aldermen's Committee on Bridges and Tunnels yesterday. About a year ago this company made its original application to the Aldermen for permission to build its tunnel in this city. THE NEW-YORK TIMES fully described the scope of the project at the time.
BOSTON, June 19. -- Stivetts to-day pitched his best game of the season. To add to this the local men put up a wonderfully strong game in the field, and the result was the Brooklyns failed to win.

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., June 19. -- Fred D. Van Horen, agent of the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association of New-York City, was found dying yesterday in a barn at Stevens's Point, a village five miles from here. It is suspected that he is the victim of foul play. The authorities will make an investigation.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 19. -- The ninety-ninth commencement at Williams College is now well under way. Alumni are arriving rapidly, many of them from New-York, and hardly a room is to be had in town. The events to-day were a play presented by the junior class and a concert by the Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Club.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 19. -- O.B. Jamison, furniture and carpet merchant of Mansfield, has failed with heavy liabilities. Chattel mortgages on all his stock and personal property and mortgages on all his real estate were filed about 8 o'clock Saturday night in the County Recorder's office.

NEW-HAVEN Conn., June 19. -- Much excitement was aroused to-day among Yale men on account of the presentation of the rules which are to govern Yale athletics. They are much the same as those now in force at Harvard, and do away with the obnoxious undergraduate rule. Their terms allow graduate students to compete.

OAXACA, Mexico, June 19. -- A terrible tragedy is reported from Pinar Del Rio, in the State of Chiapas. Vicente Bocalandro, a highly-educated young man who was in bad financial circumstances, fell in love with Miss Mercides Cartaya, whose father is one of the wealthiest and most prominent citizens of that part of Mexico.

Maul's pitching appeared to suit the New-Yorks yesterday, and they won a rather tame game. For four innings the Senators looked dangerous, but after that they were never in the hunt, as the Giants settled all doubts as to the result in the fifth, sending eight men around the bases.

The roof garden of the new American Theatre, Eighth Avenue, Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, was formally opened to the public last night. The garden was crowded, many persons being in evening dress, and there was a long and attractive programme. Maggie Cline sang her five-hundred-dollar no-name song amid a clatter of applause that caused the electric lights to bow to one another in lively fashion.

As early as 6 o'clock yesterday morning a small crowd had gathered at the foot of One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street, on the banks of the North River. They assembled with the object of seeing the shipment of a large number of wild animals, birds, and reptiles to the Summer menagerie at Glen Island.

James H. Biglin, brother of Bernard Biglin, and his son Morgan, were taken before Justice Burke in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, charged with assault. They had been arrested on complaint of Victor Herdling, the elder Biglin's son-in-law, but as the complainant did not appear, the prisoners were discharged.
Many burglaries have been committed in Brooklyn lately, and in most cases the criminals have escaped arrest. Residents of the City of Churches are complaining about the police.

WEST POINT, June 19. -- There were many anxious friends here awaiting the result of the mental examination of candidates for admission to the Military Academy which was made known this afternoon. Of the 121 who presented themselves, 60 were successful. Four of the alternates who passed -- Ericker. Crawford, Smith, and Tanner -- will not be admitted, as their principals were among the successful candidates.

The reversal by the Court of Cassation of the sentences by which an inferior court sought to inflict richly-deserved punishment upon CHARLES DE LESSEPS and those associated with him as defendants in the Panama Canal Company trials appears to be regarded in France as the end of the legal proceedings against the numerous thieves who successfully conspired to rob the people of a vast sum of money through the agency of that company.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 20. -- A pretty lawn Wedding took place at 1 o'clock this afternoon at Waldheim, about two miles southeast of this place, when Miss Mary Armour, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman O. Armour, was married to William "Gilman Nichols of Staten Island. The officiating clergyman was the Rev. Dr. Young of the Moses Taylor Presbyterian Church at Elberon, N.J.

The General Passenger Agents of the Trunk Line Association discussed the question of cheaper passenger fares to and from Chicago yesterday, and unanimously resolved that a low excursion rate was a necessity. They adoptted a resolution recommending that the Executive Committee authorize the trunk lines to run excursion trains from New-York to Chicago and return at one-half the standard rate.

The entanglements of the Cassell Publishing Company, caused, as is alleged, by the illegal conversion of $180,000 by its President, Oscar M. Dunham, have forced the W.L. Mershon Company of Rahway, N.J., to close their extensive works. This action throws 250 people out of employment.
Some person or persons, who are presumed to live along the line of the Coney Island Boulevard, have an antipathy toward bicyclists.

The range was occupied yesterday by a detachment of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, composed of Companies A, B, C, I, and K, under command of Col. Cavanagh and numbering about 215 officers and men, including some of the field, staff, and non-commissioned staff, and a few from other companies. The weather was fair, with a brisk "ten o'clock" wind.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, June 20 -- P.M. Similar conditions to those of yesterday prevailed in to-day's market. The tightness of money checks trading, and outside of the professional operations which are undertaken for fractional profits on either side, little is being done. At the same time there is a steady though not voluminous liquidation of long stock in progress, and it has extended also to the bond list.

The commission which is investigating the Custom House was in secret session part of the time yesterday, but in the afternoon an open session was held. At the secret session more evidence was given regarding the alleged abuse of their power and opportunities by Special Treasury Agents in political campaigns, the testimony having direct reference to the circulars which were sent out from the New-York Special Agent's office in the Fassett campaign.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, June 20. -- L'Echo du Mexique, a French newspaper published in this city, states that an attempt will probably soon be made to annex Nicaragua to the United States, and in this connection it calls the attention of the Mexican people and appeals to them to be ready to resist any invasion of Nicaragua which the Americans may make in the near future.

It is natural that the President, as was reported in our Washington dispatches yesterday morning, should feel very much gratified by the frank statement made by Senator BUTLER of South Carolina as to the constitutional and legal relation of members of the Senate and the House to appointments.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Surgeon General Tryon has an important change in view. He will detail a medical retiring board, which shall be separate from and independent of the Medical Examining Board. This will insure a more equable consideration of cases than is possible under the existing system.
A collision occurred at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon between two trains on the Ninth Avenue elevated road near Thirteenth Street, in which seven people were more or less injured. Their names are:

On June 20, 1843, the Rev. George W. Deems, a Methodist clergyman, came from Baltimore to this city and married Miss Anna Disosway to his son, Charles F. Deems. Yesterday the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles F. Deems celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage. There was no formal reception, an no invitations had been sent out.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Wheat to-day was weak at the lowest prices ever known for it, and compared with last night closed nearly 1c per bushel lower for July and 1 1/2c lower for September. Corn was easier on realizing sales of long corn and good reports of the growing crop. It declined 7/8c since yesterday. Oats were comparatively firm, the decline in July being only 1/4c.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 20. -- The People's Bank of this city suspended payment to-day. Assurances are given that depositors will be paid in full. The suspension is caused by the assignment of James McMillan Co., the hide merchants. Mr. McMillan was President of the bank. The bank is only two years old, and its paid-up capital was but $100,000.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- No warrants were served this morning on the defendants in the verdict in the Coroner's jury over the victims of the Ford's Theatre disaster, but Col. F.C. Ainaworth, William E. Covert, Superintendent of the theatre building, and Francis Sasse, its engineer, appeared voluntarily in the Criminal Court, before Judge McComas, and gave bail for their appearance.

Women with babies in their arms, and boys and girls with cans and pails, begin to collect on the pier at the foot of East Third Street early every morning. They are patrons of the cheap milk depot established by Nathan Straus. They wait about enjoying the water breezes till the depot is opened.

Lowlander yesterday placed the tenth Suburban to his credit. To his credit also goes the fastest Suburban ever run since its inauguration, in 1884. Tarrifier won the second money, $5,000, and the third money went to Lamplighter, who finished in third place, just where he of did one year ago, when both Montana and Major Domo beat him home.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 20. -- Tonight Lizzie Andrew Borden sleeps in her old home at Fall River a free woman, innocent in the eyes of the law of the awful crime with which she was charged nearly a year ago.

The following circular, regarding the proper diagnosing, recording, and sanitary surveillance of diphtheria cases was issued yesterday by the Board of Health, after careful study of the subject by the Commissioners and the official bacteriologists:

LIVERPOOL, June 20 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef and pork in moderate demand. Hams in fair demand. Hacon in moderate demand; shoulders, about 12 to 18, steady at 47s. Cheese in fair demand. Tallow and spirits of turpentine in poor demand. Resin in moderate demand. Lard -- Spot in moderate demand; futures in no demand. Wheat and flour in moderate demand.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 20. -- The bill providing for a Constitutional Convention in this State was carried in the Senate this afternoon by the casting vote of Lieut. Gov. Cady. The Democrats voted unitedly on the measure and the Republicans opposed it as a party policy.

The Rev. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Baptist Tabernacle at Stuy vesant Square, made an attempt yesterday and failed to evict his opponents in the quarrel in his church from the chapel building where they occupy apartments.

The idea of establishing in Paris a daily paper which shall represent the best elements of the great American dailies, which shall be published under Protestant auspices, and whose object shall be to counteract the skepticism and agnosticism of modern France, is meeting with considerable moral and financial support in this country.
Senator Edward Murpny, Jr. is at the Hoffman House. He came to this city yesterday to attend the races and incidentally to discuss plans for the State campaign this Fall.

"These Aldermen are only Trustees for the people of Brooklyn," said William J. Gaynor, counsel for the Union Street Railroad Company of Brooklyn, speaking yesterday of the refusal on Monday of the Brooklyn Common Council to grant franchises to his client.

At a special meeting of the Academy of Medicine last evening a report of the Quarantine Committee appointed some months ago was submitted and received. This committee of twenty-one members, with Dr. T.G. Thomas as Chairman, is unanimous in the demand for a national quarantine, but it would seek to have such a province under a National Board of Health in full control of all local bodies.

PARIS, June 20. -- Upon the resumption of the sitting of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration to-day, Sir Richard Webster, of counsel for Great Britain, maintained that both Great Britain and the United States were under moral obligations to sanction, by legislation, whatever regulations as to the seal fisheries the tribunal might adopt, but, he added, this obligation was not legally binding.

The family element entered largely as a factor in the sale, in partition, of the estate of the late Charles Loughran by James S. McQuillen of D. Phoenix Ingraham Co. at the Real Estate Salesroom in the Trinity Building yesterday.

Mrs. Cleveland, accompanied by Baby Ruth, passed through the city yesterday, on her way to Buzzard's Bay, where she will spend the Summer at Gray Gables. She left Washington, over the Pennsylvania Road, a little after 9 o'clock in the morning, occupying the private car of Vice President Frank Thomson. Besides the baby wore the baby's nurse, Mrs. Cleveland's maid, and the steward of the White House.

Eight brave firemen who left their quarters with their comrades just after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon to answer a call from Ninth Avenue and Thirty-second Street were carried, half an hour later, to the New-York Hospital bruised and maimed. They were:
Mareschal Jose Simeso do Oliveira of Brazil, President of the Brazilian Commission to the World's Columbian Exposition, died at the Hotel Savoy yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock.
One of the worst accidents in the history of the Coney Island railroads occurred yesterday afternoon on the Bay Ridge branch of the Manhattan Beach Road.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Secretary Carlisle has issued a circular, headed "Discipline of Official Force," which directs that the office hours of the several bureaus, offices, and divisions shall be from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., with a recess of half an hour between 12 M. and 1 P.M. each day.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 20. -- The ninetyninth annual alumni and Class Day at Williams College is ended to-night, although lights and music are still oozing out of the doors and windows of Goodrich Hall, where the senior promenade concert is in full blast.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 20. -- Eighteen hundred delegates, nearly double that expected, gathered in the Liberal Convention this afternoon. The enthusiasm and the weather were equally hot. Sir Oliver Mowat was Chairman, and his speech was the feature of the afternoon session.

Thomas Rowland, a bricklayer of Hudson City, N.J., was passing Harris Cohen's clothing store, at Park Row and Baxter Street, Monday afternoon, when, as he alleges, a "puller-in" known as "English Charlie," employed by Cohen, caught him by the arm and tried to induce him to enter the store. Rowland broke away, when another "puller-in" seized him by both arms.

MADRID, June 20. -- A large dynamite bomb was exploded at midnight a few feet from the house of Canovas del Castillo, ex-Premier. The explosion was heard throughout the city. The immediate district around the house was shaken as if by an earthquake.

SING SING, N.Y., June 20. -- A draft of fifty convicts was sent to Clinton Prison this evening from the prison here. Among them was George Albro or Appo, son of the Jap. Quimbo Appo, a murderer now in the Matteawan Asylum for the Insane.
The jury to try Alderman William J. McKee of Brooklyn on the indictment against him for fraud in connection with the Columbian celebrations last Fall was completed yesterday as follows:

NEW-ORLEANS, June 20. -- A few days ago Col. John C. Wickliffe, Louisiana Commissioner to the World's Fair, lert Chicago for New-Orleans, and it was supposed that he came home for the purpose of getting Gov. Foster to settle the disputes among the Louisiana Commissioners.

WEST SUPERIOR, Wis., June 20. -- The forest fires along the South Shore and Northern Pacific Railways are still burning. At Sanborn Lampson's lumber yard and several dwellings have been destroyed. Conductors on the South Shore report Ewen, Mich., entirely devastated. The road between Dogwood and Mason Junction, a distance of forty miles, cannot be used until the bridge, which is 200 feet in length and about 30 feet in height, can be rebuilt.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The builders of the Detroit have made a curious discovery. The cruiser was yesterday placed in the dry dock at the Baltimore Shipyard for cleaning and painting, when it was found that the blades of both screws of the ship were broken, bent, or cracked. On one screw one blade was broken half off, and another blade was badly bent and cracked.

The great out-door spectacle prepared for this season at Manhattan Beach will be based on the bombardment, assault, siege, and capitulation of Vicksburg. For months the scene painters, property men, and costumers have been at work and now their labors are nearly completed. The rehearsals have been going on some time and they are nearly over.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 20. -- This week the fliers of the Eastern Trotting Circuit are at the fair grounds, and the meeting began to-day with three classes, two of which were finished when darkness came. Ben Bolt was fast enough to dispose of a big field in the slow trotting class.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 20. -- The news of Lizzie Borden's acquittal was received with the greatest surprise in this city. Even her warmest friends and most ardent supporters dared not hope anything better than a disagreement after reading the District Attorney's forcible argument in behalf of the Government.

The Rapid-Transit Commission having after much labor and anguish come to a unanimous agreement as to the terms upon which the Manhattan Railway Company can have and enjoy the privileges proposed in the resolutions of April 12, it is now for that corporation to decide whether it will extend and increase its facilities for what it is pleased to call rapid transit, or whether we shall revert to new efforts for an independent system.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 20. -- At 11:30 o'clock to-night a severe and sharp shook of earthquake was felt here. Reports so far indicate that the shook was general throughout the State. At Columbia the shock lasted fully fifteen second, No damage is reported.
Great indignation was expressed in Brooklyn yesterday over the treatment of Capt. Andersen and his Viking crew by Police Justice Tighe.
"We were 'between the devil and the deep sea' when we passed the Sherman Silver act," said ex-Senator George F. Edmunds to a New-YORK TIMES reporter at the Holland House yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Daniel Lord, third of New York died at 7:30 o'clock this morning from injuries received by falling from a fourth-story window in the home of R. Hall McCormick of 124 Bush Street, whose guest he had been for the past week. It is believed that Mr. Lord was walking in his sleep, and had gone to the window to obtain fresh air.

BABYLON, L.I., June 20. -- The rumor that Babylon's mysterious midnight prowler may be the notorious "Tom" Richardson who a year ago had neighboring Islip in a semi-panic still further shakes the already unsettled serves of timid Babylonians.

After threatening suicide for months, Adam Hellmers, a German cooper, fifty years old, carried his threat into execution while in bed early yesterday morning by strangling himself with a piece of rope in his room at 411 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street.

Edward McMullen, a Western Union lineman, was fearfully burned by live wires in Jersey City yesterday. He had ascended a pole at Newark Avenue and Grove Street to stretch a new copper wire, when he slipped and fell across the network of wires.

New-York. -- The swift and stanch sound Steamers of the Norwich Line, City of New-York, City of Boston, and City of Worcester, are in full commission for the Summer season. One of them leaves New-York every night, except Sunday, at 6 P.M., and connects at New-London, Conn., the next morning for all points north and east by rail and other boats.
The money market was very firm. Call loans were made at 15@20 cent. most of the day, but the extreme range was 6@25 cent. The last loan was made at 8 cent.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- There is a possibility that the Government will anticipate the July first payments of interest on its bonds. A rumor to this effect was current in New-York yesterday, but when the correspondent of THE NEWYORK TIMES sought last night to secure some confirmation of it he was assured by prominent officers of the Treasury that it had no foundation.

ROCKAWAY, L.I., June 20. -- Charles Loehlin and Frederick Lewis, residing in Flatbush, L.I., were fishing from a rowboat in Beach Channel this afternoon off the steamboat pier when the oyster sloop Trident ran their boat down, throwing both fishermen into the water.

James Grange, bookbinder at 66 and 68 Duane Street, made an assignment yesterday to Andrew Gilhooly, attorney, of 5 Beekman Street, giving preferences for $20,734, including $14,118 due Lawrence Frazier Co. Mr. Grange started in business in 1885 with less than $500 capital, it is said, and speedily worked up a large business.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Referring to the article published in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES regarding the two widows in Brooklyn whose condition has been so much improved by donations from the readers of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, I note that they are in need of a seeing machine, and have to say that if you will give us their address we will authorize our Brooklyn office to send them one without charge.

There is every indication now that the Directors of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company will not accept the compromise offer which has been made to them by the Rapid-Transit Commissioners, but will continue to dicker, hoping for a lower offer.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Bankers and railroad men, kings of finance and kings of transportation, fraternized together at the Art Palace this morning. The bankers had invited the railroad men to be present at the opening session of their congress. In the front seats were bankers from about half the States in the Union, together with representatives of financial institutions in Paris, Rome, and Nova Scotia.

HOWELL, N.J., June 20. -- Considerable satisfaction is expressed here over the arrest in Brooklyn of Lewis Wood, the fourteen-year-old boy, who, on Saturday last, it is alleged, shot and killed Bertie Wagner, the three-year-old son of Farmer Wagner. Special Detective Charles R. Strong will call on Gov. Werts to obtain a requisition from Gov. Flower for Wood.

Thirteen safe hits and 10 errors explain the defeat of the New-Yorks yesterday. At no stage did they look like winners. They played a listless game, and seemed to regard defeat at the hands of "Jim" O'Rourke's mistits as something inevitable. The Senators also played poorly in the field, but they made up for their errors by some hard hitting.
The Dnke or Verague remained in his rooms yesterday on account of the heat. In the afternoon several members of the Spanish Society Beneficencia called and paid their respects.

A decision announced last week by the Circuit Court of Appeals directs attention to the manner in which the McKinley tariff and the Treasury Department were used during President HAERISON'S term for the pecuniary benefit of those combinations of domestic manufacturers which the Republican Party professed to regard with abhorrence.
Charley Lee and Robert Chay Avoy, Chinamen, who arrived here on the steamer Yumuri of the Ward Line from Havana, and were detained by the customs officers, were released yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- In pursuance of resolutions introduced in the City Council about three weeks ago, Chicago will have a gala day at the World's Fair. The event will be known to future generations as "Liberty Bell Day," and the time fixed for the celebration is July 4.

The will of Edwin Booth was filed for probate yesterday in the office of the Clerk of the Surrogate's Court. By its provisions Mr. Booth disposes of personal property valued by the executors at $605,000. The amount of the realty, if he left any, is not given. The bulk of his estate goes to his daughter, Mrs. Edwina Booth Grossman.
John James Haggerty, the Cherry Street plumber who jumped into the East River from the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge on Monday, was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 20. -- The Cornell-Columbia freshmen race this afternoon was a procession from start to finish. At no time was Columbia in the race. The start was made at 5:45:45, and ten minutes and eight seconds later Cornell crossed the line a winner by thirty-four seconds. The official time was -- Cornell. 10:08: Columbia, 10:42.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Senator and Mrs. Stanford's life in this city was naturally a very prominent one. They came here eight years ago, when the shadow of their great grief over the loss of their only child, Leland Stanford, Jr., whose death occurred two years previously at Florence, Italy, was still over them.

Philip Shyre, fifty years old, of 1,857 Madison Avenue, was charged in the Harlem Police Court yesterday by Mrs. Johannes Shyre, twenty-seven years old, with abandonment. Mr. Shyre, who is a wealthy cloak manufacturer at 428 Broadway, made no defense, and was paroled in the custody of his counsel, John C. Murzinger, pending a further hearing on Tuesday.

George Hanley, who is but sixteen years old, and whose home is in Chicago, created great excitement in the neighborhood of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Third Street, and incidentally shot a man and a boy last evening. Fortunately neither of them was seriously injured.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 21. -- To-day, one of the longest in the year, made its presence known in the most offensive manner, bringing along with it not only a very high degree of temperature, but a disagreeble ally in a large amount of humidity, which is an enemy that the human body cannot meet on even terms. Before leaving for Albany, at 10 o'clock, Gov. Flower had made a thorough inspection of the camp.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- A report that $1,500,000 gold was engaged by New-York banks for shipment by steamers sailing for England to-morrow converted a very weak grain market into a strong one, and wheat and corn both recovered from breaks they made in the first hour. Provisions were weak on heavier receipts of hogs, and closed at a considerable decline since yesterday.

LONDON, June 21. -- Continued dullness and sagging prices marked to-day's business. The probability of gold being taken for New-York by the end of the week was the principal cause of weakness, but there were also rumors of difficulties in Australian trade circles.

The suggestions of the committee of the Academy of Medicine with reference to the functions of the National Bureau of Health, the establishment of which it recommends, are carefully worded and sufficiently recognize the distinction between State and national jurisdiction, but in much of the current discussion of the subject that very important distinction is practically ignored.

After playing like second-rate amateurs during the past week, the Baltimores took a flying trip here yesterday and won from the New-Yorks. They put up a most creditable game of ball, both at the bat and in the field, and gained a victory on merits.

The commencement exercises of the Training Department of the Normal College were held yesterday morning in the chapel of the school. The prettily-decorated chapel was filled to overflowing with the proud parents, relatives, and friends of the graduates. Trustee Randolph Guggenheimer, Chairman of the Normal College Committee, presided. Each participant in the exercises was greeted with rounds of applause.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 21. -- Gov. Lewelling has returned from the Columbian Exposition, and to-day expressed his opinion that the fair would be a financial failure unless the railroads made a one-fare rate for the round trip. He expressed himself very decidedly upon this matter, claiming that the railway companies were making a mistake, especially as they are now, advertising half rates to Cleveland.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, June 21 -- P.M. There was a little more life to to-day's market than on recent occasions, and there was unquestionably a much more hopeful feeling. The opening had been rather tame and the prices lower, but when it was announced that $500,000 in gold had been ordered from abroad the whole list responded promptly. The bears became alarmed over the improving prospects and hastened to cover their outstanding short contracts.

Funeral services over the body of the Rev. Charles B. McKenna, the heroic young priest of the Church of St. Ann, who was drowned, in the North River off One Hundred and First Street on Thursday, June 15, in an endeavor to save his cousin, Mrs. Margaret Burchell, from drowning, were held yesterday morning in the Church of St. Ann in Twelfth Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Tennis at Wissahickon continued without cessation to-day. The better players are beginning to get together, and consequently good tennis is the result. In ladies' singles Miss Schultz of New-York beat Miss Wistar of Philadelphia in a prettily-playet set, 6-3, 6-1.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 21. -- The Dominion Liberal Convention adjourned to-night, after passing resolutions which practically formulate a pew platform for the liberal Party. The main planks are tariff reform, in the direction of free trade, and reciprocity with the United States. The reciprocity resolution was as follows:

PARIS, June 21. -- Sir Richard Webster of counsel for Great Britain submitted to the Bering Sea tribunal yesterday a series of regulations, comprising eight clauses, which Great Britain asks the tribunal to adopt.

PATERSON, N.J., June 21. -- Two drowning accidents happened in this city to-day. Patrick White, seventeen years old was bathing in the river near Morlot's dye works and was seized with cramps. He sank before assistance could reach him. Claude Mauzy, twenty years, undertook to swim across the river above Lincoln's Bridge, and became exhausted before he reached the eastern bank.

To-night, before the Coney Island Athletic Club, "Jim" Daly, Corbett's old sparring partner, and "Joe" Butler, the Philadelphia heavyweight colored fighter, will meet to a finish. The preliminary bonts are between "Billy" Ernst and "Billy" Vernon, and George Reynolds and "Mike" Leonard. The Vernon-Ernst bout ought to be a very good one.
In the death of Leland Stanford, California loses one of its foremost citizens, whose energy, foresight, and wealth contributed largely to the prosperity of the State.

When the greatest crowds were surging along Sixth Avenue, between Fourteenth and Twenty-third Streets, yesterday afternoon the fire engines dashed up to the corner of Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. At the same time, a few minutes before 5 P.M., the crowd in the street saw flames bursting from the windows of all the six stories of the brick building at 108 West Eighteenth Street, occupied by George W. Alexander as a bookbindery.

Whatever investigation may show as to the exact cause of the terrible accident on the Bay Ridge Branch of the Manhattan Beach Railroad on Tuesday night, and wherever the immediate blame may he placed, it is safe to say that the primary cause of the disaster was recklessness in operating a railroad where special care should have been exercised.
New-York will in all probability have a breathing spell of cooler weather for the next few days.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 21. -- Arkansas City and Caldwell banks are still guarded by armed men, in anticipation of a raid by Indian Territory desperadoes. The cause of the alarm was the appearance on the streets of Arkansas City of ight well-armed men, whom no one seemed to know, but who bore the appearance of being night riders from the Territory, about four miles distant.
A surveyor employed by the Richmond County Board of Assessors and his assistants have been at work for two days in that county with a police guard to protect them from a belligerent farmer.

A meeting of the men interested in the International Navigation Company, which recently filed a certificate of incorporation at Trenton, N.J., was held in Jersey City yesterday at the office of President Charles B. Thurston of the Jersey City and Bergen Railway Company.

A most extraordinary scene was witnessed yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas. The jury empaneled to try the case of Pollock against Pollock, completely carried away by the chivalrous sentiments expressed from the bench by Judge Pryor, burst into applause. The spectators quickly took the cue from the jury box and in a second the big room was ringing with shouts of approval, handclapping, and other demonstrations of satisfaction.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June. 21. -- Lightning struck the first centre pole in the menagerie of Ringling Brothers' circus this afternoon while an exhibition was in progress, at River Falls, Wis.

The Manhattan Opera House was reopened last night after a brief season of silence. The entertainment, which was the result of Manager Hammorstein's recent voyage to Europe in search of novelties, was a comic opera in three acts, called "The Talisman." The libretto, which is the work of Dennery and Burani, has no relation whatever to the famous novel of Sir Walter Scott.

Workmen have begun tearing down the buildings which formerly composed the New-York HoteL At the outset their efforts will be directed toward demolishing the northern portion, fronting on Broadway and Waverley Place. New business buildings will be erected on the site.

William Easton was to have sold at Tattersalls Repository last night the second installment of the trotting stock, property of the estate of George Valensin. This programme, however, could not be carried out, owing to the non-arrival of the young Sidneys and the rest of the Valensin stock from California.
MENLO PARK, Cal., June 21. -- United States Senator Leland Stanford died early this morning. He passed away peacefully at his residence, Pala Alto.
TRENTON, N.J., June 21. -- The Court of Errors to-day decided that the Werts ballot-reform law is constitutional.

Local politics always takes on some curious phases when the weather gets real warm. Rumors of various kinds which would be regarded as too weak and puny for general circulation at any other season of the year appear to thrive and grow fat upon these hot days.

The foreign exchange market was weak during the morning, but raillied in the afternoon. The posted rates for aberling were reduced 1/2c on the pound, but were subsequently restored to $4.83 for 60-day bills and $4.85 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.81 3/4@$4.82 1/2 for 60-day bills, $4.84@4.84 1/4 for demand, $4.84 1/2@$4.84 3/4 for cable transfers, and $4.80 for commercial.

Police Justice Tighe of Brooklyn yesterday morning crawled out of the uncomfortable hole into which he got himself by his treatment of Capt. Anderson and the crew of the Viking ship as gracefully as he can do anything, except, perhaps, referee a prize fight. He arraigned the hardy Norsemen before him, and, without so much as looking at them, growled:
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 21. -- The following prize awards were announced from the Williams College commencement stage this morning:

The annual festival of Trinity Church High School was held yesterday in the chapel of the school building, 90 Trinity Place. Many friends of the students were present. The ceremonies were simple, but impressive. The Rev. Dr. J. N. Steele, assistant rector of the parish, presided. The programme, arranged by George B. Towle, the new Head Master of the school, was rendered excellently, and gave new proof of the high educational standing of the institution.

The international bicycle races that are to be held in Chicago are attracting attention in England. The London Field says: The preparations being made in the United States for holding a series of international races in connection with the Chicago Exhibition should, if the expectations of the promoters are fulfilled and the meeting is ably and honestly conducted, result in an unprecedented success.

Francis Spies, a well-known merchant, and the only member of the firm of Marcial Co. of 36 Broadway, committed suicide yesterday morning at his home, 64 East Fifty-fifth Street, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver.
Col. Frank Yokel, who keeps a hotel next door to Police Headquarters, on Eighth Street, West Brighton, Coney Island, was fined $100 yesterday by Judge Newton for violating the excise law.

William R. Morrison of the Inter-State Commerce Commission sat on a sofa at the Holland House yesterday afternoon with ex-Senator George F. Edmunds discussing public affairs. They are close personal friends, although they do not agree on political questions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 21. -- Job E. Hedges, assignee of H.H. Warner, filed his schedule of assets and liabilities to-day. The statement shows a favorable situation. The total indebtedness is shown to be $1,046,369.37, of which $653,027.86 is secured and $393,341.51 unsecured. Of the secured liabilities $375,000 is indebtedness to the H.H. Warner Company, Limited.

In the trial of Alderman William J. McKee of Brooklyn for felony in connection with the Columbian celebration last October, Assistant District Attorney Clarke made the opening address in the Kings County Court of Sessions. Brooklyn, yesterday.

James Purcell, a driver in the Street-Cleaning Department, was remanded in the Jafferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of homicide, in causing the death of John O'Brien, who died at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday morning.

Henry Villard's resignation as a Director of the Northern Pacific Railroad and as Chairman of the board was accepted yesterday and John D. Rockefeller was elected a Director in Mr. Villard's place. The office of Chairman of the board will be discontinued.

New-York. -- Patrolman William Rennett of the Fourteenth Precinct, while stopping a runaway horse and wagon at the Bowery and Second Street yesterday, was knocked down and severely injured. He was taken to his home.

A boy going through Gold Street soon after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon discovered smoke issuing from the top story windows of 4 and 6, and before the flames were extinguished three alarms were seat out, several firemen were almost overcome by the heat and smoke, and the building and contents were damaged to the extent of $30,000.

CAPT. GEORGE G. GREENOUGH and FIRST LIEUT. WILLIAM P. STONE, Fourth Artillery, will proceed to Fort McPherson, Ga., and report to First Lieut. William E. Birkheimer, Adjutant, Third Artillery, Judge Advocate of the general court-martial in session at that post, as witnesses before the court in the case of Sergt. Thomas Ryan, Battery K, Third Artillery.

Funeral services over the body of Margaret Manton Merrill, the writer and elocutionist, who died on Monday, were held yesterday afternoon in St. Agnes's Chapel, Ninety-second Street and Columbus Avenue, Pastor Edward A. Bradley officiated, and there were present many friends of Mrs. Merrill, including representatives of Sorosis and the Professional Women's League.

The fin of the Stewart Binney cup defender Pilgrim is fast approaching completion, but not as fast as her designers would like. It was thought that she would be taken to Boston this week, but yesterday Mr. Binney said he thought that it would be Monday before she could be towed out of the Erie Basin.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 21. -- The river's condition is still unchanged, and from the fact that the crevasse at Reserve Plantation is the only break of importance all eyes are centred upon it. It is one of the most stubborn fights which a crevasse has received in years, and to-night will probably come the crucial test, which will mean salvation or ruin to a large section of sugar lands.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 21. -- Miss Blanche Culbertson has been accused of ingratitude and disobedience in trying to break her father's will. In her answer filed in the Floyd Circuit Court at New-Albany, Ind., she denies the charge.
The first shipment of gold to this country made in months will be sent out from Southampton to-day. It will be brought to this country by the steamer Columbia. Its amount is $500,000.

From the Charleston News and Courier. (Dem.) THE NEW-YORK TIMES recently sent a dispatch to Speaker Crisp at his home in Americus, Ga., asking him to express his views in regard to the repeal of the Sherman silver law. This is a question in which, all the people of the country are deeply interested, and the inquiry of THE TIMES was entirely proper under the circumstances.
TOPEKA, Kan., June 21. -- J.M. Simpson, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, this evening announced his opposition to the equal-suffrage amendment to the Constitution. He said:
The Duchess of Veragua is sitting for her portrait in oil.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 21. -- The one hundred and twenty-seventh annual commencement of Rutgers College was held to-day in the Opera House. The addresses were:
Starlin's Glen Island will be opened to the public to-day.

MADRID, June 21. -- Great excitement prevails throughout the city to-day in consequence of the attempt last night to blow up with dynamite the residence of Senor Canovas del Castillo, lately Prime Minister. Though the occupants of the residence of the ex-Prime Minister escaped unscathed, the explosion was the cause of the death of one person, the fatal injury of, another, and the wounding of several others.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Strangers are pouring into the city by thousands from every direction, and so great is the rush to the World's Fair that while in some cases the baggage department forces have been increased threefold and the baggageroom in proportion, it is as much as the roads can do to handle the enormous traffic. A distinct feature is the tremendous rush of European travel.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your Parts dispatch from the Bering Sea tribunal in your issue of June 17 appears the following:

A petition was circulated, and freely signed, among Reading security holders in this city yesterday, requesting the reorganization syndicate to extend the time for receiving assents. According to the official announcement, yesterday was the final day for receiving deposits of securities under the reorganization plan. Sufficient securities to insure the success of the plan have not yet been deposited.

BALTIMORE, June 21. -- Cardinal Gibbons furnishes for publication official translations of the Pope's encyclical letter upon the school question referred to in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES. The letter came to him through Cardinal Rampolla, who wrote as follows under date of June 1:

"Oh, look at that dog, he is mad," cried a boy to his playmates in Amsterdam Avenue, near Sixty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock, as a black Scotch terrier came running up the avenue with the saliva dripping from his mouth and snapping at everything he met.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- A new railroad labor organization, to embrace every branch of service from the locomotive engineers to the flagman at grade crossings, was started last evening at a meeting held in Ulich's Hall. The main cause of the movement was the failure of the individual railroad organizations to accomplish their aims in the shape of protection of members in their straggles against railroad companies.
The suit of Maida Craigen Buchanan, the actress, for divorce from her husband, Arthur Ernest Buchanan, was tried yesterday before Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas.
WOLCOTT, N.Y., June 21. -- Manley Cole of North Wolcott made a remarkable catch near the shore of Lake Ontario late yesterday afternoon.

WALTON, N.Y., June 21. -- An interesting and complicated case involving a violation of the State fish law, which prohibits the spearing of eels and suckers, will be settled by a jury trial in Cannonsville to-morrow.

Telegrams were received from the officials of the Brazilian Government yesterday saying that the body of Marechal Jose Simeao de Oliveira, who died at the Savoy Hotel Tuesday, would be buried with full military honors. Telegrams of condolence were also received by members of his family from Brazil and Washington.

Herman Goldner, a furrier, of 316 Floyd Street, Brooklyn, applied at the Lea Avenue Police Court yesterday for a warrant for the arrest of Herman Lanzer of 305 Floyd street and Joseph Roesch of 42 Sumner Avenue.

ALBANY, June 21. -- About 2,500 persons went to Ridgefield this afternoon to witness the races at the meet of the Albany County Wheelmen. The day was one of the hottest and most sultry of the season. Consequently the crack riders did not exert themselves, and as fast as they won prizes dropped out. When Windle had won the half-mile dash he fainted, and had to be carried to his dressing room.

George C. Magoun, Ernst Thalmann, and Gustav H. Gossler, the Committee on Reorganization of the National Cordage Company, yesterday made public the plan upon which they have agreed. Its main points had leaked out, but no approach to a detailed statement had previously been obtained.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 21. -- Through the generosity of a friend of Cornell University, the library of Prof. Zarncke of the University of Leipsic has been purchased and presented to the university. This collection embraces more than 18,000 volumes. It is said to be unequaled by any private library in Germany and surpassed by but few of the greater university libraries.

The number of persons killed in Tuesday' railway accident at Parkville, on the Bay Ridge branch of the Manhattan Beach Railroad, remained at seven yesterday. "Judge Quinby of Utica," reported killed, would increase the list to eight, but it is apparently doubtful if such a person was killed. It is almost certain, however, that this number will be swelled by the addition of at least three more victims, who are frightfully injured.

"If the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company does not accept either of the last two propositions made to it by the RapidTransit Commissioners, and so discharge its obligations to the people of the City of New-York, I shall be much disappointed. I certainly am in hopes that one of the propositions will be accepted, and I believe that we will get rapid transit out of it," said Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 21. -- Previous to his incarceration in the Hackensack jail upon the charge of using profane language in the public highway, "Swearing Parson" James Van Blarcom purchased cattle from Farmer C.W. Sayre of Morris County, giving in payment a check on the First National Bank of Paterson. The "Swearing Parson" had no money in the bank to meet the check, and was sued for the amount, $200.

A story was circulated yesterday to the effect that among the victims of the disaster was "Judge Quinby" of Utica, who was said to have had $6,000 in his possession when taking the train at the race track.

The names of the successful applicants for admission to the Normal College nave been announced by President Thomas Hunter. Over 1,100 girls presented themselves for examination, and only 652 passed the required examinations. The examinations were held on June 2, 5, 6, 7, and 8. They were examined in spelling, arithmetic, grammar, history, geometry, composition, drawing, and geography.

BERLIN, June 21. -- Dr. Johannes Miquel, Prussian Minister at Finance, who has more than once been mentioned as the probable successor of Chancellor von Cuprivi when the latter makes up his mind to retire from office, is frank in his utterance regarding the significance of the late elections.

-- The Atlantic Coast Line, in connection with the Pennsylvania Railroad, will begin a fast train service on July 2. Trains will leave New-York daily at 9:30 A.M., arriving in Charleston at 6:50 A.M. on the following day; Columbia, S.C., at 7 A.M., Savannah at 8 A.M., Jacksonville at 1 P.M., St. Augustine at 2:35 P.M., and Tampa at 10 P.M. This will reduce the traveling time twelve hours between New-York and Tampa.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 21. -- The Viking ship will be anchored off this city Saturday afternoon. Capt. Andersen and crew will be entertained at Washington Headquarters, the courtesies being extended by the Trustees of that institution. The Newburg Boat Club will probably meet the vessel near Cornwall and escort it to Newburg.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., June 21. -- The customs officers of this district announce the discovery of extensive smuggling. According to their statement the schooner Sarah E. Babson was purchased by Albion P. Parkhurst and fitted for a trading voyage to New foundland under the command of Thomas Olsen.

A recent census bulletin, prepared under the direction of Dr. Henry K. Carroll, contributes some interesting statistics concerning several bodies of Baptists, including the Regular, (North and South,) the Primitive, and the Old Two-Seed-in-the-Spirit Predestinarian. The Northern and Southern bodies are numerous, the former aggregating 800,025 members and the latter 1,276,491.

Lizzie Freeman, the twelve-year-old daughter of Charles S. Freeman, a traveling salesman from Boston, died yesterday at 321 West One Hundred and Twelfth Street, without having had medical attendance. Deputy Coroner O'Hare made an investigation last evening, and found that the child was the victim of faith curists.

Police Justice TIGHE of Brooklyn got out of his predicament in a characteristic fashion. He exhibited the stupid brutality of a bully in holding the Captain and crew of the Viking on the false charge of a dunderheaded policeman and setting down their examination for a time that would subject them, to the greatest annoyance.

There was not much done in breadstuffs today, while prices were irregular. Wheat was taken up to a fair extent by exporters, but had only moderate speculation; its opening showed a decline of 1/8@1/4c, followed by 3/8c lower prices, and as influenced by lower cables, from which there was an advance of 1/2c on reports of large gold importations and on a decrease in the supplies of grain east of the Rocky Mountains.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., June 21. -- Four banks closed their doors to-day, the First National, the Southern California, the Broadway, and the East Side Bank.

BUFFALO, June 21. -- The lumber shovers are weakening at last, after the most prolonged battle between capital and labor that has ever taken place in Tonawanda. The men have not only deserted the National Longshoremen's Association and thrown President Thomas McGovern overboard, but they say they are ready to give up their union and go to work as individuals, providing the lumbermen agree to allow William Cramer, their President, to manage their affairs.

ALBANY, June 21. -- The Regents of the university held a meeting this afternoon. The provisional charter of the New-York Military Academy of Cornwall was made absolute. The charter of St. Mary's Catholic Institute of Amsterdam was amended so as to provide for seven Trustees. St. Faith's School of Saratoga was chartered.
The money market was very firm. Call loans were made at 6@15 cent. The last loan was made at 8 cent.

Alice, the African lioness at Central Park, passed the day yesterday nursing and licking her three baby lions on a with the same affection that a cat has for her kittens, only she growled whenever Keeper Dowey happened to come in with food, as if she meant to say, "Don't you dare to take away my cubs."

Charges of a serious nature were made against the Aldermanic Railroad Committee of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon by Edward M. Grout, Secretary of the Union Street Railway Company, at a meeting in Mayor Boody's office.

In that "address to the American people" which was recently published by the Manufacturers' Club of Philadelphia, a high-tariff association controlled by Mr. THOMAS DOLAN of the Reading coal combination, Mr. JOHN WANAMAKER, and their associates, one of the assertions by which the association seeks to give force to its arguments in support of McKinleyism and the McKinley tariff iS as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day directed Treasurer Morgan to anticipate the payment of the July interest on the 4 per cent. United States bonds and on the Pacific railroad bonds.

PEORIA, Ill., June 22. -- W.W. Johnson Co. of Cincinnati, one of the largest distributing houses of the Whisky Trust, who two weeks ago announced, their withdrawal from the trust and declared that they would hereafter sell only such goods as were produced by independent distillers, have made application for reinstatement.

MONTREAL, June 22. -- Private advices from London state that Messrs. George Gould and Broker Foxwell of New-York, Duncan McIntyre, and Broker Forget of Montreal, who will all be in London on June 26, will meet in consultation on that date those of the Grand Trunk Rail way shareholders who are dissatisfied with the present management of the Grand Trunk under the Presidency of Sir Henry Tyler.

LONDON, June 22. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gladstone stated the alterations the Government has decided to make in the financial clauses of the Irish Home Rule bill. He proposed a provisional term of six years to effect the financial arrangements.

The Washingtons defeated the Brooklyns in ten innings at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. Stein and Dailey were the battery for the home team, and Duryea and McGuire acted for the visitors. The latter players received their ten days' notice of release a few days ago. but it was recalled after the fine work they did in yesterday's battle.

The Academy of Music, in Brooklyn, was crowded to the doors last night when St. James's Business School held its graduation exercises. Dr. Robert F. Cunnion awarded diplomas to Francis A. Clancy, Dennis J. Devine, Charles F. Doyle, Thomas A. Doherty, Thomas J. Fitzgerald, William P. Harrison. Albert J. Keenon, Thomas J. Kelly, David F. McMahon, Daniel J. Madden, Edward L. O'Brien, Peter S. O'Grady, Cornelius D. Riordan, and William F. Southwell.
SAN FRANCISCO. June 22.- A careful estimate of the late Senator Stanford's property indicates that its value is somewhere n the neighborhood of $35,000,000.

For each child committed to charitable institution by ttte Police Justices, the city pays $2 per week. To make certain that all children so committed are properly a charge upon the city, Controller Myers gets a report from the Gerry society.

PEEKSKILI, N.Y., June 22. -- The sensation of the day in camp was the arrival of the first class of the West Point Cadets. They left the Point at 8:15 A.M., fifty strong, under the command of Capt. Louis A. Craig, Sixth Cavalry, who is not only recognized as the most efficient instructor, but the most popular one the cadets have had in many years.

LONDON, June 22. -- So far as is known to-night, u100,000 of American coin has been, withdrawn from bank and u60,000 in bars has been bought in open market for shipment to New-York. Seventy-seven shillings and ten pence per ounce is bid for gold bars by Continental houses.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Orders from outside were extremely scarce to-day on 'Change. Wheat, corn, and oats, also provisions, were left pretty much in the hands of the local speculators. Fluctuations were not violent, nor was business active. Wheat averaged firmer, but closed, as compared with yesterday's resting price, 1/8c lower for July and 3/8@1/2c lower for September, showing a reduction of rather better than 1/4c in the carrying charge.

The Rev. David James Burrell of the Marble Coilegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentyninth Street, who, during his ministry in Minneapolis, was prominent in the discussion of the Catholic school question, had this to say yesterday of Pope Leo's letter to Cardinal Gibbons:

John Frazer, twenty-four years old, a trackman in the employ of the Third Avenue elevated railroad, met with a terrible death yesterday morning on the railroad track near the Franklin Square Station. He was caught by the step of the angine of a moving train and dragged along the track nearly 300 feet.
The Long Island Railroad officials did not appear to feel very comfortable yesterday morning. They had several things to trouble them.
Another contributien was received yesterday at the office of THE NEW-YORK TIMES for the "Two Widows" of South Brooklyn. " C.O.D." was the contributor

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 22. -- The factso of an extensive land swindle, by which Western people had been victimized through purchasing bogus deeds of land supposed to be in NewHaven, came to light about a year ago. To-day two more such cases were announced.

The Fairchild commission went on yesterday in its work of examining the examiners in the Public Stores, for the purpose of determining their competency and the extent to which the customs laws are administered.
