PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- The Duke of Veragua and party arrived from New-York at 1:30 this afternoon, and were met at the Pennsylvania Railroad station by ex-Minister to Russia Charles Emory Smith and George W. Childs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22. -- Diamonds valued at $3,000, which were mysteriously lost on the beach by Mrs. L.F. Requa of 65 West Fifty-second Street, New-York City, to-day were restored to the owner, eight hours after their disappearance.

MADRID, Jane 22. -- The official Investigation into the bomb explosion at the residence of Senor Canovas del Castillo at midnight Tuesday has led to the discovery of a plot that embraces Anarchists in several European countries. The popular excitement caused by the outrage has died out In a great measure, but the officials are still endeavoring to ascertain the names of all those implicated in the affair.

The Police Commissioners rid the force yesterday of Policeman Thomas S. Harper of the Thirty-third Precinct, against whom was a sheaf of complaints. He was also charged with malingering. It was discovered that another policeman's appeal against dismissal for leaving the city without permission did not avail him, so Harper was turned loose because he went to Greenpoint without leave on the 31st of last March.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22. -- The case of Robert Alden Fales, Newark's boy murderer, will be taken before the United States Supreme Court early in the October Term, according to Prosecutor Elvin A. Crane.

The lone-pending negotiations for the purchase of the Democratic Club property have come to naught and were yesterday declared off. The clubhouse is at 617 Fifth Avenue, on the eass side, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets. Adjoining it on the north is the Buckingham Hotel, the proprietor of which, Mr. Kemp, bought the property on the other aide of the clubhouse with a view to increasing the size of his building.

Martin Engel, successor to John E. Brodsky as President of the John A. Logan Club of the Third Assembly District, was assaulted two years ago in the dive of John McKeon, at Hester and Chrystle Streets, by Maurice Lee and John Ellis. With the aid of a beer Keg, nearly every bone in his face was broken.

"Oh ! my baby ! my darling ! Marjorie !" Every person in the crowded courtroom turned around at the cry. A child of three, with long flaxen hair and deep blue eyes, and dressed in snowy white from head to foot, toddled unsteadily over the floor, and in a moment was caught up in the arms of its mother.

Lawrence Lamb, until recently employed as a gatekeeper at the City Prison, was found dead yesterday morning on the sidewalK at the corner of Canal and Renwick Streets, having either fallen or jumped out or a window of his bedroom on the third floor of 2 Renwick Street. He was a native of Ireland, seventy-one years of age, and came to this country when young.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., June 22. -- Mrs. Cleveland, Baby Ruth, and nurse arrived on Commodore Benedict's steam yacht Oneida at 11:20 this morning. The arrival of the distinguished visitors had been anxiously awaited, and the friends and neighbors extended to them a hearty welcome.

The export interest in wheat to-day was light, with only 15 boatloads taken up, but there was a large business from investors, or to the extent of 300,000 bushels; the speculation in the options of the grain was much less general; the crop reports were better, which tended to local realizing. The corn dealings were at 1/2@1c decline, as the crop reports were of an improved character, with more anxiety over selling.

The twenty-fourth commencement exercises or the Normal College were held in the college chapel yesterday morning, beginning at 10 o'clock. Long before the sates were opened there was a large crowd waiting to he admitted. In five minutes after the gates were opened the galleries of the chapel were filled to overflowing with the proud parents, relatives, and friends of the graduates.
GENEVA, N.Y., June 22. -- The Hobart College commencement exercises were held this morning in the assembly room of the Geneva High School, and were attended by a large audience.

Mrs. Hannah Van Orden. one of the four panic-stricken women who jumped from the fourth-story fire escape at the fire in George W. Alexander's bookbindery at 108 West Eighteenth Street Wednesday afternoon, died yesterday at the New-York Hospital. Mrs. Van Orden was forty-eight years old. She leaves several small children.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Jnne 22 -- P.M. The proposed plan for the reorganization of the Reading Railway was officially declared to be a failure to-day. The announcement created little surprise, for it had been known for some time that certain large holders in this city would not give their assent to the proposition.

The beautiful architectural effect of St. Patrick's Cathedral will soon be enhanced by the addition of a set of elegant Stations of the Cross. These were ordered several years ago from the Stoltzenberg Company's ataliers, in Roermond, Holland. After two years' steady work the artists have finished three of the Stations.

The failure and abandonment of the Reading reorganization plan, which was announced in dispatches from Philadelphia yesterday, was not unexpected here. Nearly all of the security holders who declined, to assent to the plan are New-Yorkers, and they have not hesitated to assert that the plan could not be made operative without their support.

The Kings County Board of Estimate took up the county and Brooklyn budgets again yesterday afternoon. The meeting began with the reading of Corporation Counsel Jenks's opinion on the duties of the board in regard to deficiencies.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Naval Constructor Richborn has had reproduced a sketch of the old-time yacht Problem, and also of the yacht Smuggler built in 1891, or forty-seven years after than the Problem, as referred to in Tuesday's TIMES. Mr. Hichborn thinks the similarity between the two yachts strikingly apparent, and bearing out the recent editorial in THE TIMES that there was nothing new in the fin keel.

The meeting of Good Government Club B at 167 West Eighty-first Street last evening had a fair attendance. This club is the second of a number of clubs that are being organized under the auspices of the City Reform Club in different parts of the city to work for reform in city government.

The needed repairs, improvements, and painting on the Floating Hospital have been completed, the salt-water bathroom has been enlarged, and St. John's Guild is ready to conduct six trips a week of this hospital for sick and suffering children.

California drew on New-York for funds yasterday on a scale not even approached by Chicago at the time of the recent financial scare in that city. Nearly all the city banks with correspondents in San Francisco or Los Angeles were called upon to hurry money to the Pacific coast.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A general plan for the betterment of the departmental service of the Government has been agreed upon by the several heads of the executive departments, and it is thought that when it shall be put into operation as the result of investigations now being made, it will produce results of a radical character.

RIDGWAY, Penn., June 22. -- The Ridgway Bank, a private institution, this morning posted a notice on its doors stating that, owing to the present depressed financial situation rendering it impossible to realize on securities of any kind, and therefore being unable to meet all obligations, it had been decided that it was for the beat interests of all creditors of the bank to close the doors.

In the discussion recently carried on in THE NEW-YORK TIMES as to the proselyting of the Jews by Christian missionaries, A. Benjamin, an agent for the United Hebrew Charities, was conspicuous by his attacks on the Christian Jews who are doing missionary work among their people in this city. Missionary Warzarviack, who has charge of the Home for Persecuted and Inquiring Christian Jews, at 65 Avenue D, seemed to be particularly obnoxious to Mr. Benjamin.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 22. -- A crime committed this morning at Brightwood, a suburb of Indianapolis, suggests the famous Borden murder case just disposed of.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 22. -- The recent press dispatch from Carrizo, Texas, stating that there was a revolution in progress among the people of the State of Guanajuata against the State Government and that all the Mexican troops that have been on the Rio Grande frontier during the late Garza troubles are being sent to the scene of the outbreak is without foundation.
Mr. James R. Keene yesterday served as one of the Stewards of the Coney Island Jockey Club, taking the place made vacant by the retirement of John Hunter.

PARIS, June 22. -- A large number of visitors were present to-day at the session of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration. Among those who listened to the proceedings was the Hon. James B. Eustis, American Ambassador to France.

As a direct result of the intense heat of Wednesday and Thursday, Jonn McCanna of 4O Madison Street is in the Chambers Street Hospital with a fractured skull, and Samuel Lamb, seventy years old, a veteran keeper in the Tombs, lies dead in his home, 2 Renwick Street.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., June 22. -- The feeling that has existed for the past ten days between the citizens of Woodbridge and the Board of Trustees and Principal Gamble of the public school, because of the dismissal of live lady teachers has been partially abated by the reappointment last night of the teachers.

Anybody leas like a desperado could hardly be imagined than the vacant-eyed, thick-lipped youngster who, answering to the name of George Hanley of Chicago, is now in the prison of the Harlem Court House as the result of a shooting exploit in Harlem Wednesday night, the story of which was told in yesterday's NEW-YOHK TIMES.

The Parkway Driving Club of Brooklyn gives its last Spring matinee trot to-morrow. The gates will be opened to the public. To render the occasion more noteworthy, seven members of the club have put up $1OO each which will be competed for as follows:

The Scotch Presbyterian Church in Fourteenth Street was filled last night with friends at the pupils of the Metropelitan College of New-York. The occasion was the seventh commencement the college. In the pulpit were the officers of the school and several of the graduates in evening gowns. The concert given by the pupils and graduates was a particularly entertaining one.

Lydia Bolles, a pretty and interesting nine-year-old child, was attacked by a cat at her home in Manning Avenue, Jersey City, Wednesday and so severely bitten and scratched as to cause her parents much anxiety, it being thought that the animal had hydrophobia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jane 22. -- The politicians have begun to study the State Constitution to see whether it is absolutely impossible for Gov. Markham to get that vacant Senatorehip himself, and they have about reached the conclusion that, as the Constitution says merely that the Governor shall not he "elected" Senator during his term of office, he might legally be appointed.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 22. -- All is quiet here so far to-day. This morning's train from Buffalo brought 300 Poles, and this number was supplemented by laborers from Pittsburg and other places. There appears to be no lack of men and the supply is increasing, but the lumbermen say they mast have protection to keep them at work.

The topmost branch of the sturdy vine of public sentiment that supports the public schools of New-York is entwined around the College of the City of New-York. It is there that the boys of the common schools who prove themselves to be the most receptive and efficient students are granted at public expense the advantages which youths upon whom the goddess of material fortune has more graciously smiled enjoy in the pretentious universities.

A merry party assembled yesterday moraine in the large waiting room of the Pennsylvania Railroad station at Jersey City. It was composed of those ladies and gentlemen and little folk of Brooklyn who attend the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, and they were bound for the World's Fair in charge of Henry Gaze Sons, tourist agents.

The facts disclosed by official inquiries concerning the prevalence of tuberculosis in the dairy herds of Massachusetts, to which we have referred heretofore, have so impressed the Legislature of that State that at the recent session a law was passed which provides for the inspection of such herds.
Charles W. Dayton, who on July 1 will formally enter on the duties of Postmaster of this city, will go to Washington to-day for a conference with Postmaster General Bissoll.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The President made the following appointments to-day:

Russell Sage, upon reading the interview with Mayor Gilroy in yesterday's NEW-YORK TIMES in reference to the final propositions of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners to the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company, said that he was curious to know how the Mayor would go about breaking down the monopoly of the Manhattan Company in case both propositions were rejected.

BURLINGTON. Vt., June 22. -- In the special Episcopal Convention for the election of a Bishop of the Diocese of Vermont to-day the Rev. Samuel Hart, D.D., of Hartford, Conn., was chosen on the fourth ballot.

The Staten Island Athletic Club and Morris Park teams played a very close cricket, game at West Brighton, S.I., yesterday, which resulted in a victory for the Athletic men by the narrow margin of 5 runs. The scoring was low on both sides, owing principally to extremely sharp work in the field.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 22. -- This was Charles S. Green's day at the Kirkwood Park trotting meeting. The veteran trainer, who came into prominence nearly twenty years ago by driving Lucille Golddust to her record of 2:16 1/4, won two of the four races on the card with descendants of the oldtime rival of Goldsmith Maid, and captured a third with the horse Horace Prince.
The following communication was received by THE TIMES yesterday:

Women who meet each other in street car seem to forget straightway that any one else is in existence. There were two of them in a Broadway car yesterday going down town. They had met quite accidentally, and were making the most of the accident. The space they occupied would easily nave accommodated four people, but they did not know that, nor did they seem to care.

The taking of evidence in the trial of Alderman MoKee in Brooklyn was finished yesterday. The lawyers will sum up this morning, and the case will probably go to the jury shortly after the noon recess.
Dramatic incidents abounded yesterday in the trial of Mrs. Ellen Pollock's suit against Alexander Pollock for $50,000 damages for the alienation of her husband's affections.
CITY OF MEXICO, June 22. -- The police authorities here have been informed of a doable tragedy enacted near the town of Tixela, in the State of Gnerro.

Yesterday was a great day for the boys in Male Grammar School No. 1, in Vandewater Street. The commencement exercises were held in the afternoon, and all the morning the boys were in a flutter of excitement. At 1 o'clock, the hour for the exercises, the main hall on the top floor of the school building was crowded with visitors.

Mayor Gilroy received a visit yesterday from he Marquis de stackpoole of London, who has invented a system of water filtration. He desired to interest the Mayor in his system, so that he could obtain permission to try his invention in this city. He wanted an opportunity to demonstrate its practicability in purifying the city's water supply.

The funeral services of the late Mareschal Jose Simeao d'Oliveira, President of the Brazilian Commission to the World's Fair, who died on Tuesday, will be hold at 10 o'clock this morning at the cathedral. A preliminary service, conducted by Father McMahon, will be held at the Hotel Savoy, beginning at 9 o'clock.

ALBANY, June 22. -- Charles F. Peck, ex-Commissioner of Labor Statistics, who caused certain State documents to be burned, and is now sojourning in Europe, should have answered to his name in the Court of Sessions to-day. But neither he nor his stenographer, Elbert Rogers, who assisted in destroying the documents, answered when thair names were called.
Membership in the Hoboken Turtle Club has always carried with it the attributes of destination as a citizen of worth as an individual and, above all, of capacity as an eater and drinker.

PERRY, Kan., June 22. -- The most destructive cyclone that ever visited Eastern Kansas passed through Williamstown and the surrounding country in Jefferson County about 7 o'clock last evening. It traveled southeast and took in a scope of country half a mile wide and about six miles long. Not a house, barn, or tree was left standing in its path.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Dr. Charles F. MacDonald, whose appointment as Consul at Hamilton, Ontario, was announced yesterday, is one of the best-known men in the Federal service in Washington.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

Whether the trotting stakes of Charter Oak Park, Hartford, are to he decided at Fleetwood or not, there is every indication that the old driving track at Morrisania will have the banner meeting of its twenty-two years in August next. Secretary Thomas Greenwood of the Driving Club reports a very promising condition of affairs as far as all the club's'closed events are concerned.

The trouble between the Trustees of the S.R. Smith Infirmary, Staten Island's charity hospital, and five of the leading physicians of the island, who resigned from the medical staff of the hospital over a year, ago, has been revived by what the physicians declare to be a fresh insult on the part of the Trustees.

Henry Sheldon Co., dealers in coffees and teas at 109 Front Street, have placed their affairs in the hands of the law firm of Taylor Parker of 15 Wall Street. There has been no assignment, but there has been a suspension.

The Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen has, after an investigation, remitted in part the suspension placed on the college men who competed on May 27, at Manhattan Field. A petition was sent the board, signed by the men suspended, and further evidence was furnished to the effect that several of the men asked if a sanction had been obtained and were told that it had been.

ALBANY, June 22. -- Of the 3,595 convicts confined in the state prisons at the close of the last fiscal year, 193 were life prisoners. Twentyeight of these were confined in the asylum for the criminal insane at Matteawan. Twentyseven were convicted of murder in the first degree, 162 of murder in the second degree, and 4 of manslaughter in the first degree.

The Jersey City Tennis Club tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club grounds, Highland and Glenwood Avenues, Jersey City. The men's doubles was the only event of the day, though there are some matches to decide second place still unplayed. John F. Hobart and S.L. Smith of the New-York Tennis Club have shown fine form so far, and many think they will carry off first honors.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 22. -- The test vote in the House on the bill providing for a constitutional convention was taken this afternoon after a two hours' debate, and resulted in defeating the measure by a majority of 27. The total vote on yea-and-nay roll-call was 169.

TROY, N.Y., June 22. -- The casting of the Columbian Liberty Bell at the Clinton H. Meneely Bell Foundry occurred at 8:25 o'clock this evening in the presence of at least 1,000 persona, most of whom were residents of this city. The casting was a perfect success. The work of placing the mold upon the core was accomplished late this afternoon.

Policeman McManns at the East Twenty second Street Station House is the latest, officer to get himself into trouble. He is not charged with clubbing his prisoner, but there are some peculiar circumstances connected with an arrest he made Wednesday.

The thirty-seventh annual commencement o Hasbronck's Institute took place at the Congres gational Tabernacle, Jersey City, last night. The salutatory was delivered by Miss Gertrnde May Bushfield and the valedictory by Miss Mamis Finlay, who won second and first Honors respectively.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 22. -- The examinations are over at the Yale and Harvard quarters, and the crews can now give their undivided attention to their rowing till the race. The time of this race is not yet definitely settled, and there is some talk of its being rowed up stream. Judging from past experiences, this would entail much danger to craft on the river following the crews.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 23. -- Alfred H. Gardiner, a distinguished-looking man, fifty years of age, was arrested to-night at 9 o'clock in Garden City, and brought here by Detective Kavanagh, who turned him over to the police of the Second Precinct.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The Duke and Duchess of Veragua and their party were entertained at a reception and garden party given in their honor this afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. George W. Childs at Woollen, the latter's country home. Six hundred invitations had been issued, and more than 500 persons were present.
The West has begun to pay back to NewYork the money it drew from the country's financial centre to meet the urgent calls of two weeks ago.

The foreign exchange market was steady early in the day, but weakened on the higher rates for money. The posted rates for sterling were advanced during the morning, but subsequently were reduced again to $4.84 for 60-day bills and $4.86 for demand. Actual rates were nominal.

The latest number of the Treasury Department's "Statistical Abstract" contains a table which shows the annual revenue and expenditures of the United States for the last twenty years. In one column of this table is shown the "excess of revenue over payments," and in this column the line of annual excesses is unbroken.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The army will purchase twenty Gatling guns for field service. The guns will be of longer barrel than that of the present service weapon. The contract has been awarded to the Gatling Gun Company of Buffalo. It is worth over $25,000.
Eighty-eight members of the Ninth Regiment qualified in the second class at Creedmoor yesterday, and seventy-eight won the State marksman's badge, by making 30 points or over at 200 and 300 yards.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 23. -- There was an exciting time in the House this morning growing out of the debate over the bill providing for the removal of the grade crossings in the City of Bridgeport, which passed the Senate yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The future of the Reading Railroad Company occupied the attention of the financial community to-day, but no information as to what course will be adopted could be obtained from any reliable source. The receivers held a lone session, during which the situation in all its bearings was thoroughly discussed, but the result of their deliberations was not made public.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Corn broke over a cent a bushel to-day, dragging down oats and wheat. The occasion of the break in corn was the enormous movement which has started up within two days. The estimate yesterday of 320 cars for this morning was the first sign of a jump in receipts. When the receipts reached 348 cars there was some surprise and some weakness.

In the Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday, Judge McAdam heard, argument on a motion to continue an injunction which he granted on June 14 restraining the State Trust Company of 50 Wall Street from disposing of stock of the Grand View Hotel, in Chicago, which the company holds as security for a loan. The plaintiff is Andrew J. Cooper, who charges the trust company with usury.

Now that the railroad companies in Brooklyn are practically fastening the trolley system upon the people of that town beyond their power to resist, the managers ought to devote a part of the largely-increased profits to hiring men intelligent enough to run them with ordinary prudence.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Lowering clouds this evening have caused great anxiety among the owners and trainers of American Derby candidates at Washington Park. There is, however a brisk breeze from the south, and that their hopes for a fair day to-morrow may be realized is not improbable. The track is now in flue condition, and, if it remains dry, fast time may be expected.
Father and son shared the honors of the witness stand yesterday in the famous trial of Pollock vs. Pollock.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 23. -- The body of Mrs. Hannsh Giles, thirty-six years old, or 474 Hamilton Street, Astoria, was found floating in the East River near the Astoria shore this afternoon. Mrs. Giles was the wife ot Reuben Giles, Assistant Superintendent or Construction at the East River Gas Company's works in Astoria.

Alderman William McKee of Brooklyn, who was tried in the Kings County Court of Sessions for complicity in the Columbian celebration frauds, was acquitted yesterday afternoon by the jury after four hours' deliberation. Immediately upon the announcement of the verdict Aldermen Heaney and Wafer, who are still under joint indictment with him and awaiting trial, stepped forward and grasped him by the hand.

LONDON, June 23. -- As soon as the news of the disaster became known in London, the Duke of Edinburgh, who was lately promoted to the position of Admiral of the Fleet, visited the Admiralty and conferred with the officials there. A meeting of the Admiralty Board was held, and a telegram of instructions was sent to Rear Admiral Markham.

Joseph Genoa, five years old, and his sister Theresa, seven years, were taken from the tenement, 86 Mulberry Street, to North Brother Island on Thursday evening suffering from smallpox. Their mother and her baby were sent there ten days ago afflicted with the disease. The other occupants of the house were vaccinated yesterday and the house was thoroughly fumigated.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 23. -- When Lieut. Gov. Sheehan was defeated last Fall in his scheme to change enough election returns to make his friend William H. Love Superintendent of Education, he told that young man to be of good cheer, for it would not be long until he would have something for him.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- Harvard's annual festival, the senior class day, was seriously interrupted this year by the rain, yet in spite of the bad weather there was much merry making. The exercises in Sander's Theatre in the morning were fully up to the average in interest. The opening prayer was made by the Rev. Willlam Lawrence, the Bishop-elect of Massachusetts, and then came the oration of Billings Learned Hand of Albany.

The Infanta Eulalie and her husband, Prince Antoine, the Duke of Tamames, the Marquise d'Hermosa, and other members of the royal party of Spain will sail at 1 o'clock this afternoon on the French liner La Touraine for Havre.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- A disastrous fire in the Murray Nickels Drug and Spice Manufacturing Company's plant, at 147 to 155 West Polk Street, occurred this afternoon. One man was probably burned to death and four others were seriously injured.

In accordance with the decision rendered by Corporation Counsel Jenks of Brooklyn, the Kings County Board of Estimate yesterday allowed money to make up the first deficiency for which it has provided since it took the Brooklyn and county budgets for 1894 under consideration. The deficiency was one or $45,000, and was included in the $320,000 which the county wards wanted.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- James H. Platt of Colorado made a silver speech before the Bankers' Congress to-day, pleading for free coinage. In the course of his address he denounced the Sherman act. He called it a "collection of miserable makeshifts and blunders." said he:
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 23. -- Shortly before noon to-day the Cataract Bank of Niagara Falls closed its doors. On the main entrance was placed the following notice:

LONDON, June 23. -- The new financial proposals in connection with the proposed establishment of an Irish Parliament were issued, to-day. The original Clauses 10, relating to a separate consolidated fund and taxes; 11, relating to hereditary revenues and income tax; 12, relating to the financial arrangements as between the United Kingdom and Ireland, and 13, relating to the Treasury account of Ireland, are omitted from the new proposals.

A well-dressed young man presented at the box office of Tony Pastor's Theatre last Thursday evening a card reading "E.R. Johnson, NEW-YORK TIMES." He asked Manager Sanderson for a free seat at the performance. Mr. Sanderson, never before having seen the young man, very properly refused to comply with the request.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 23. -- The rain to-day interfered with the morning exercises of the Seventh Regiment. After a steady downpour, which began at 8:30 last night and lasted to 1 o'olook to-day, the clouds lifted and permitted Col. Appleton to give the battalion drill, which was postponed in the morning. The early morning drill by companies, however, had been performed in spite of the rain, and the command went through the exercises cheerfully.

BERLIN, June 23. -- The Socialists of Lubeck, incensed at the result of the second ballot for member of the Reichstag taken in that city yesterday, which resulted in the defeat of Johann Schwartz, the Social Democratic candidate, by Herr Goertz, Radical Unionist, made a demonstration last night that soon degenerated into a riot.

Towboat men are exercised about the new rules for the guidance of boats being towed in local waters which are now ready to be promulgated by the Treasury Department. The boatmen contend that the proposed rules will, if enforced, lead to many disasters, and a delegation representing corporations and individuals, owning 3,000 vessels, yesterday went to Washington to protest against the adoption of the obnoxious regulations.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Secretary of Agriculture Morton is a Western Democrat who is not afraid of Western demagogues nor of his own convictions. When he talks he habitually says something. This has come of a mental habit of independent thinking, and it does not suit a great many of his fellow-citizens in Nebraska, who mistake talk for thought.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The President to-day made the following appointments:

A finer-looking lot of trotting-bred yearlings were never brought into a sale ring than the young Sidneys sold at Tattersalls last night. They were tired and stiff with ten days in the cars from California, but they looked as clean and fine as any thorough-breds. There was a large attendance, and prices ruled very fair, though not so good as was expected.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 23. -- The Tonawanda strike is over. The looked-out lumber shovers are to go to work next Monday. All day to-day a settlement was expected, but it was 5:30 P. M. before the Lumber Shavers' Protective Union in session at St. Louis Hall, Tonawanda, agreed to accept the proposition of President John Robinson of the Lumbermen's Association.

The deep foliage of Jones's Wood sparkled last night with a thousand bright lights. Under the tall arches formed by the branching trees hundreds of young men and pretty girls wandered, listening to the strains of music which flooded the air from the dancing pavilion and floated out across the East River. The object of the festival was to raise money for the benefit of the Immigrant Girls Home, at 7 State Street.
Messrs. Dunn and Maofarlane carried on the inquiry into Custom House methods at yesterday's session of the investigating committee at the Barge Office, Messrs, Fairchild and Magone being absent.
The funeral services or the late Mareschal Jose Simeao d'Oliveira, who was the President of the Brazilian commission to the World's Fair, were held at the Hotel Savoy yesterday.

Abraham Steers, one of the best known lumber merchants in the city, and formerly President of the Lumber Association, is temporarily embarrassed. His embarrassment is attributed to the financial stringency. He has ample assets, but has been unable to get further accommodations. His assets consist chiefly of real estate, mortgages, machinery, stock, and accounts.
The history of the navies of the world, and particularly those chapters relating to the navy of Great Britain, abounds in records of disasters, attended with great losses of life.

The first graduation exercises of tie male department of Grammar School No. 94 took place yesterday afternoon in the school assembly room before a large audience of friends and relatives of the pupils. This school was first opened last September.

We find in the London Economist of June 10 a very clear and comprehensive article on "The Currency Position in the United States." It traces succinctly the operation of the Silver Purchase act of 1890 in increasing the outstanding demand notes of the Government, payable in gold, and in steadily promoting the outgo of the gold from which they must be paid, if required.
Herrmann, the magical, performed the greatest feat of his life yesterday.
A new movement, and one which promises to attract much attention from real estate men, was yesterday made public. This is the estabishment of an up-town real estate exchange and auction room.

There was not an unoccupied seat in Music Hall, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday when the fortieth commencement of Manhattan College was held, and many pretty girls stood in the aisles and applauded the young graduates when they delivered their orations. The college is conducted by the Christian Brothers, and the commencement was honored by the presence of Archbishop Corrigan, who sat on the platform.

Park Policeman Alfred C. Newall, who does duty in Central Park, has been detected in extorting money from a visitor to the Park. His Captain and a Sergeant saw the money paid by the man the officer thought was his victim.
LONDON, June 23. -- A most terrible calamity has befallen the British, battle ship Victoria, flagship of the Mediterranean squadron, and about 430 lives have been lost.

The old quarrel between Arthur and Edwin Bedell, publishers of the Advance, and Civil Justice William P. McCrea, President of the North Side Publishing Company, broke out again Thursday, and resulted in the ejectment of Justice McCrea from the premises of the Westchester Times and the arrest of the Bedell brothers.

Charles F. Hart, a well-known business man of New-Brighton, S.I., and a member of the Athletic Club's champion four-oared crew, was driving through Franklin Avenue yesterday, when he heard the screams of a boy. He discovered D. Ogden Fowler, a stalwart New-York broker, whipping with a carriage whip a boy whom he had caught stealing cherries. Mr. Hart sprang from his buggy to save the boy, and Fowler beat a hasty retreat into his house.

-- Mr. Dixon Kemp, Secretary of the British Yacht Racing Association, has officially measured the Valkyrie. On the load water line she measures 86.82 feet. According to the agreement between Lord Dunraven and the New-York Yacht Club the challenging or defending yachts were not to exceed 85 feet in length by more than 2 per cent., and any excess of the 2 per cent. was to count double in time allowance.

Special Cablegram to the New-York Times. LONDON, June 23. -- This was another dull day, with Americans particularly weak on account of the failure of the Reading plan. Reading shares fell to 6 5/8, but income bonds and 43 kept steady, as an assessment is expected on the stock under any new plan proposed.

Vice Admiral Sir George Tryon of the Victoria was Commander in Chief of the British forces in the Mediterranean. He was Known almost as well in the American Navy as in the British Navy. Of late he was regarded as the best fighting flag officer possessed by England.

BOSTON, June 23. -- What may be regarded as the first stop in the construction of the Cape Cod Ship Canal was taken yesterday afternoon. when the first business meeting of the Old Colony and Interior Construction Company, which has been chartered to build the canal, was held and an organization effected.

The Pratt Institute of Brooklyn, which is doing a great work in the technical and manual instruction of young people, fitting them for the practical and mechanical walks of life, has closed an unusually prosperous year.

NEW-YORK. FRIDAY, June 23 -- P.M. The stock market to-day was dull and heavy. The trading was at no time active, and the general list showed little rallying power. Brokers' offices were, as a rule, bare of customers, and operations were confined to the scalping of board-room traders.

The Victoria, a picture of which taken from the Scientific American is given elsewhere, was one of the largest iron-clads in the British Navy. She was built at Elswick, on the River Tyne, by Sir William Armstrong, Mitchell Co., and was launched April 9, 1888, in the presence of over 200,000 people who had gathered to see the monster take the water.

The candor that has characterized Secretary Lamont's administration of the War Department, especially with reference to changes in the grade of the clerical force, has led the Civil Service Reform Association to instruct its Secretary to express to Mr. Lamont the association's approval of this method of managing a public department.

A new train will be started on Sunday, July 2, via the Pennsylvania Railroad, to be Known as the "Atlantic Coast Line Express," to run from Eastern cities to the South. At the same time train "No. 27, fast mail," now leaving New-York at 12:15 night and Washington at 10:57 A.M., will be discontinued to points south of Weldon, N.C.
Cries of "Murder!" "Police!" "Thief!" in a woman's voice rang out through the open windows of the three-story tenement house at 39 East Broadway soon afternoon yesterday.
Little Marjorie Savin will never knew a real home unless her parents become reunited.

The feature of a vary same day's racing at the Sheepshead Bay race track yesterday afternoon was the running of a dead heat by Longstreet and Gloaming in the final race of the day. This was a run of a mile and an eighth over the turf track, for which the two named and Adelbert were the fancied ones in the speculation. Adelbert's chances were killed by Watterson fouling him on the back stretch.
-- The New-York Air-Brake Company has declared a quarterly dividend of 1 1/2 cent, payable Aug. 1. The transfer books will be closed July 15 and reopened Aug. 1.

Policeman Thomas J. Crystal of the Prince Street Police Station yesterday morning again gave proof of his bravery. This time it was in saving, at the risk or his own life, the nervous mother of a five-week-old baby, who tried to commit suicide by Jumping into the North River. She fought her rescuer in the water, and at one time it looked as if both must drown.

There was a meeting last night in the Astor House of the National Cycling Association to make preparations for the first meeting of the association, to be hold in this city on July 3 and 4 under the management of the New-York Cycling Association. The meeting will take place on Manhattan Field, and it is thought that it will prove one of the greatest bicycling tournaments over given in this country.

Mayor Wanser of Jersey City has been absent from his office since Tuesday afternoon, though the fact was not generally known. Visitors were told by Clerk Nevin that the Mayor would probably be back "in a day or two." It is now learned that the Mayor is in St. Luke's Hospital, NewYork, where he has undergone an operation for kidney trouble.

The failure of the Reading plan, while of considerable significance, is not likely to have a very marked effect upon the property itself. With its great earning capacity and large assets, it should be able not only to take care of its current expenses and charges, but also to preserve its securities from sacrifice and, perhaps, even to reduce the amount of its floating indebtedness.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Charles W. Dayton, who will become Postmaster of New-York on July 1, arrived in Washington, to-night with Mrs. Dayton and registered at the Shoreham.

BOSTON, June 23. -- Preparations for me launching of the Jubilee, the Palne cup defender, at Lawley's to-morrow morning were practically completed this evening, and the boat will go overboard, rain or Shine. The hour set for the launching. 7:30. is an early one, but time and tide wait for no man, and the tide to-morrow morning is high at 7:55 o'clock by all the almanacs, coast pilots, and nautical guides which can be found.

An aged and very stout colored woman signaled a down-town Broadway cable car to stop at Houston Street yesterday. Before getting aboard she proceeded to question the conductor regardless of his impatience.

LONDON, June 24 -- Few details of the sinking of the British battle ship Victoria are expected before Monday, when the survivors are expected to reach Malta. The list of those saved reached here early this morning and was posted at the Admiralty, where it was viewed by a large crowd which had been waiting all night for news.

During the greater part of next season but two of the New-York stock companies will be playing in this city. Mr. Daly's company will remain abroad during the entire season, and Mr. Palmer's organization will certainly not be seen here before next January. The two companies which will play their full season are Daniel Frohman's Lyceum and Charles Frohman's Empire Theatre organizations.

CLAYTON, N.Y., June 24 -- The Spanish caravels, Santa Maria, Pinta, and Nina, en route to the World's Fair, passed through the intricate channels of the Thousand Islands this afternoon in tow of the tug Thomas Wilson of Ogdensburg.

The transatlantic speed record, made by the steamship Paris, is still to that vessel's credit, but she came perilously near losing it when the Campania reached port Friday night 1 hour and 13 minutes behind the record time.

The Jersey City Yacht Club held its thirty-fifth annual regatta yesterday. All the yachts belonging to the club were entered, but they did not all start on account of the light wind. What breeze there was came from the northeast, varying to northwest and it was mainly in puffs. The start was made a few minutes before noon from off the clubhouse. There were live courses.

CADETS ASSIGNED TO SERVICE -- Secretary Lamont to-day assigned to the service as Second Lieutenants the following cadets, who were graduated at the West Point Military Academy this year: M. Smith, Second Cavalry; Cassatt, Ninth Cavalry; T. Smith, Seventeenth Infantry; Walker, Ninth Cavalry; Edwards, Seventeenth Infantry; Pattison, Third Cavalry; Hartwick.

The loan exhibition of paintings opened last Summer at the Neighborhood Guild, 26 Delancey Street, proved so popular with the multitudes that crowd the east side that another venture of the same sort this Summer was a foregone conclusion. The paintings this year are in greater force, and water colors and pictures in black and white are hung on the walls.

New-York is fast becoming a city of roof gardens. With the opening of that of the Manhattan Opera House last evening, there are four of these institutions now in full swing, and more are threatened for next Summer. At all of them an excellent vaudeville entertainment is offered for a very reasonable price, and all of them are doing a fair business on warm evenings.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 24 -- The large hotels opened this week and the season is fairly started. The Grand Union had nearly fifty guests several days before the time fixed for opening. Most of them had engaged rooms for the Summer and the hot weather had driven them from the city.

The cricket league championship game at Morris Park yesterday was the opening contest of the home club on its own grounds. It made every exertion to win, and after a very close finish placed the victory to its credit by 7 runs. [This was] due principally to the good stand made by T.J. O'Reilly, while H.L. Walker bowled with great effect toward the conclusion of the game.

"There are three ways in which women get money," says a writer in the Canadian Magazine, "through the dead fingers of their dead kin, the living ones of their existing relatives, or by their hands or wits. Latterly women make more money. It is now less of a stigma to earn a livelihood than it was twenty or even ten years ago.

Some of the new water-proof wraps are remarkably pretty and becoming. A few years ago no woman expected to look well in a waterproof. A gossamer in those days was as utilitarian a garment as any dress reformer could desire. It was strictly for use; beauty was not considered.
One of the best-preserved connecting link between the American past and present -- the Rem Lefferta homestead mansion at Fulton Street and Arlington Place, Brooklyn -- will soon be demolished.

A faithless wife, rejected by both husband and lover, and driven almost mad by the taunts of those who Knew her, wounded to the death the man for whom she had destroyed her home Just as the home-bound crowd hurried through Grand Avenue in Brooklyn at dusk last evening.
There was very little tone in money. The nominal rate for call loans was 6 p cent.

The first lawn party of the season was given at the American Yacht Clubhouse at Milton Point yesterday. This is a new feature of this club and it proved to be very successful in every way. The club has been almost dead for the past two or three years, but this year Mr. W.H. Catlin and a few other members decided to try and revive things. They wanted to make the club a success socially.
ELEBRON, N.J., June 24 -- Among the recent arrivals at the Elberon are the following:
LONDON, June 24 -- The following appeal, issued by the leaders of the Paruellite section of the Irish Parliamentary party, explains itself:

NEWARK, N.J., June 24 -- With the good roads and delightful weather the second annual century ran of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs to-day to Princeton and return was a highly-successful event. About 150 wheelmen started off from in front of the Continental Hotel in two relays early this morning. The first or slow division, started at 4 A.M., and the fast division three hours later.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 24 -- The City Hall Commissioners had an exciting meeting to-day, in which Contractor Patrick J. Condon took an active part. He and Richard English, who were the two lowest bidders last Tuesday, were invited to submit supplementary bids. They were both present to-day prepared to submit new bids, but were informed that the Commissioners had concluded that their action was illegal, and had decided to readvertise.

The nightduty of Sergt. O'Toole and Policeman Doherty at Police Headquarters was made less wearisome than usual yesterday by a man who introduced himself as "Prof. Eben J. Owen, the Boy Orator, of Hollywood Villa, 5 North, Stamford, Conn."

Anthony Berkwitz, ten years old, of 103 East Third Street, whose father is a tailor, and Robert Masters, twelve years old, of 303 East One Hundred and Third Street, the son of a barber, were caught in the rain Thursday evening and sheltered themselves under the awning of Herman Levy's meat shop at 1,933 Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Mr. C.W. Dayton called at the Post Office Department early this morning, and Postmaster General Bissell gave him a half hour of his time to talk over the bond that he had brought to submit for approval and to make some suggestions with reference to his assumption of the New-York office, which he is preparing to occupy about July 1.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., June 24 -- For a month past the season at the Water Gap has been well under way. The "month of roses" possesses an especial charm to these who know the Gap and the beautiful valley country of the Delaware, and the hotels are often as well filled as during midsummer.
Here is a list of the principal offices to be filled in the city at the next general election in November:

In the trial of Alderman McKEE of Brooklyn for complicity in the Columbian parade frauds, District Attorney RIDGWAY, in summing up, said: "If the Legislature keeps on building safeguards around the personal liberty of offenders, it will soon be impossible to convict anybody. The legislation for the past twenty years has all been in the interest of the lawbreakers."

MENLO, Cal., Jane 24 -- The funeral services of Senator Leland Stanford were held to-day on the grounds of Stanford University at Palo Alto, and the remains were placed, in the family mausoleum. Special trains from San Francisco brought great numbers of people. Employes of the ranch numbering 150 men acted as an escort.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 24 -- The arrest of seventeen tramps, followed by the capture or two alleged train wreckers at Marlborough last right, has caused much excitement in that place. For a long time Marlboroagh and several other towns on the West Shore Road have been infested with tramps.

BOSTON, June 24 -- Such newness as there has been at the very few open theatres this week was offered by the George A. Baker Opera Company at the Bowdoin Square, it having presented on successive nights "Said Pasha," "The Beggar Student." "The Chimes of Normandy," "The Black Hussar," "Fra Diavolo," and "The Bohemian Girl."

For some weeks pedestrians in Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, during the early morning hours have been accosted by rough characters that asked for from 10 cents to $1. About 1 o'clock yesterday morning George Smith, twenty-three years old, of 111 Withers Street, Williamsburg, was held up by two footpads and, upon refusing to give them a dollar, was shot through the left side, just below the heart.
TACOMA, Washington, June 24 -- Linus E. Post, who was President of George W. Vanderbilt's bank, has been found at Shanghai.

BERLIN, June 24 -- The progress of to-day's by elections appears to support the Government's calculation that the reballoting will give it 69 seats. Taking the adherents of the Army bill elected on the first ballot at 130, the Government will thus hold in the new Reichstag 199 votes out of 397.

The sinking of the splendid battle ship Victoria in the Mediterranean has raised many serious questions. But the hurried expression by some of our esteemed contemporaries of the opinion that the modern armored ship has been shown to be extraordinarily vulnerable will hardly withstand calm contention.

"Our cook left us a few days ago." said a depressed-looking newspaper man the other evening. "She said she couldn't live in a house the head of which lived so irregularly and kept such terribly bad hours, even if his wife was ill. And there has been nothing but trouble for me since. I had to get my own breakfast this morning.

ORANGE, N.J., June 24 -- The disappearance of Edward F. Church has created a sensation in South Orange as well as in the adjacent territory. Mr. Church was well known in this section and enjoyed the respect of his neighbors. In addition to being President of the Board of Trustees of South Orange and a Director of the Saxony Woolen Mills Company of Trenton, he was prominent in politics and society.

"What THE NEW-YORK TIMES had to say on Sunday last in regard to the rifle practice of the National Guard, and particularly in respect of collective firing," said a ranking officer, "was directly to the point. Did you ever stop to think," he continued, "what takes place at Creedmoor during the shooting season of a regiment ?

FLEETING PICTURES -- Times and men change. We live our little day and are gone, but here upon our walls live souls embodied in canvases, monuments of human spirits which from age to age are still instinct with life.

NETHERWOOD HEIGHTS, N.J., June 24 -- The Hotel Netherwood opened for the season of 1893 on Saturday, the 10th. A large number of guests from New-York, Brooklyn, and other cities registered on that day. From the bookings, which are largely in excess of former years, a prosperous and brilliant season is assured.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Something is at last to be done for the medical department of the army. For the first time in many years the army has a Surgeon General who finds it worth while to carry out ideas. The trouble has been in recent Administrations that the head of the Army Medical Corps was usually to be retired before he could hope to realize the plans he might lay out.

The rapid growth of cycling in the last four years brings up the question why cycle racing is not more popular in the metropolis. The boulevards and drives are thronged with wheelmen, but the race meets are simply attended.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 24 -- In a ten-inning baseball game to-day Harvard beat Yale by a score of 3 to 2. This is the first game of the series. Should Yale win the game at New-Haven on Tuesday a third game will be played at New-York July 10.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 24 -- The arrangements for a special lake weather service, which were begun last year, are being carried out by Mr. Cleveland's Administration. One of the notable features is the laying of two cables from the weather station at Alpena to Thunder Bay Island and Middle Island, which is now about completed.

Cries of "Murder!" "Help!" "Police!" startled people living near the foot of East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street at 3 o'clock yesterday morning. Capt. Grace of the tugboat Refuge, which carries passengers from Harlem Bridge to Randall's Island; Engineer Whitney of the House of Refuge, and John Rankin, a teacher in the House of Refuge, each in a separate boat, started in the direction of the voice.
Ex-Minister to Portugal Gilbert A. Pierce, who was appointed by President Harrison a short time before his Administration closed, reached this country yesterday on the Campania.

No one expected that Alderman McKee would be convicted. Convictions of public officials in Brooklyn for malfeasance in office have been so rare that there is no record of one in recent years, and the public viewed the McKee trial in the light of experience and scarcely hoped for a conviction.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jnne 24 -- After the most sucessful and industrious week in the history of the State Camp, the Seventh Regiment gave way this afternoon to the Forty-seventh Regiment or Brooklyn and a battalion composed of four separate companies. The unstinted praise bestowed upon the Seventh by the headquarters officers is more than deserved by the soldiery bearing of the command.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- There are some men hardhearted and cynical enough to say that the Woman's Building and all of its varied exhibits simply serve to demonstrate the superiority of man. The amount or indignation that such a slur would provoke if made in the Woman's Building, where, to be candid, there are almost as many women as exhibits, it is impossible to estimate in advance.

LONDON, June 24 -- Frank Ives, the American billiard champion, in an interview to-day, said that he intended to resume practice on an English table without delay, as otherwise he would be unable to begin the match with Roberts immediately after playing the French game.
Lumber had gone up, and the big mill on the Aspohegan was working overtime.

In his thoughtful introduction to this collection of specimens of William Blake's prose and verse. Mr. Honsman says that comprehension of any art work requires an understanding of the temperament which produced it. Of course, such an assertion leads the way back to an old dispute which will probably last as long as art does.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jane 24 -- The most sensational political news in Ohio for weeks is the break between ex-Gov. Foraker and "Boss" George B. Cox of Cincinnati. For years Cox has been Forakor's chief lieutenant. He has managed the "boys" in Hamilton County in the interest of the Republican Party, and monopolized such private and personal "perquisites" as naturally fall to that position.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 24 -- Two extra freight trains, west bound, collided about one-half mile west of Corfu, on the Central Road, at midnight last night. Twenty-five cars and two engines were derailed, badly damaging the tracks and blocking all traffic. Seven of the trainmen were injured.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- One of the large rooms of the Art Palace was crowded at noon to-day with the delegates in attendance on the International Congress of Banking and Financiering, in response to a call for a special meeting to exchange views regarding the present financial situation in this country. The representatives of the local banks had also been invited to attend, and the response from officers of these institutions was large.

-- General Manager K.H. Wade of the Southern California Road announces that the general freight and passenger departments of this road have been separated, and the following appointments are now effective: S.B. Haynes, General Freight Agent; T.A. Whitmore, Assistant General Freight Agent; H.G. Thompson, General Passenger Agent, and H. K. Gregory, Assistant General Passenger Agent, all with headquarters at Los Angeles, Cal.

LENOX, Mass., June 24 -- The mercury touched 90 on Tuesday of this week, which is the highest it has been in Lenox in June for several years. There was, however, a good breeze from the west, and the mountain air on this hilltop, which is 1,300 feet above the sea, was bracing even at this temperature. The cottagers were able to keep cool on their north plazzas, and enjoyed driving late in the afternoon.

CONEY ISLAND, June 24 -- "Evelyn Granville," the ex-actress and wife of Burton C. Webster, the bookmaker, who is now serving nineteen years in Sine Sing for the murder of Goodwin, visited the Manhattan Beach Hotel this afternoon with her baby boy and nurse, much to the sorrow or Manager Silleck. Mrs. Webster took a seat at a table in the dining hall and ordered luncheon.

ORANGE, N.J., June 24 -- The postponement of the polo games, which were to have been played on the Essex County Club grounds this week, changed a prospective season of activity into one of the dullest weeks known here in a long time. Polo always attracts a large and fashionable crowd.

OTTAWA, June 23 -- So far there has been, no denial by any Ministerial authority of the statement that the Canadian Government endeavored to prevent the appointment of the Earl of Aberdeen to the Governor Generalship, and it is an open secret that his appointment, in spite of the desires of the Conservative leaders, has greatly annoyed the latter.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Mr. Tarsney's baidheaded pensioner has been found, according to a story made public this morning.

NEWARK, N.J., June 24 -- At a blind crossing on the Newark Branch of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, at Washington Avenue, Avondale, about which the residents have made repeated and unavailing complaints, a young mother and three children in a merry carriage party of five were horribly mangled to death by an Erie passenger train at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Definite information of the causes of the collision between the Camperdown and the Victoria is awaited with great impatience at the Navy Department, and in its absence there is a great aversion on the part of prudent officers to indulge in speculation.
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., June 24 -- Lucy Murray, the eight-year-old daughter of Henry Murray, a carpenter, was attacked and seriously injured by a vicious dog this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 24 -- The only event of sufficient interest to cause a flutter in society this week was the flying visit of the Infanta Eulalie, who came here on the steam yacht Susquehanna and did Newport in truly democratic style. Of course, her visit would not have been complete without a look at Newport's society rendezvous, the Casino, on Bellevue Avenue.

The curious behavior of some plants can scarcely be explained under any other supposition than that their actions are due to some connection between sensation and consequent motion that seems to be closely related to the movements of animals. We touch the skin of a person and the person shrinks instantly; a similar touch causes a worm to shrink, and the same affect precisely happens when some plants are touched.

That success depends upon: Using a reliable make of glass jars and testing the air-tight quality of each by pouring a little water into it, adjusting the rubber and cover, and standing it upside down.
GALVESTON, Texas, June 23 -- What will undoubtedly be a long and expensive litigation has begun over the estate left by Samson Heidenheimer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- The banner crowd of the season saw Philadelphia win to-day's game from New-York in the eleventh inning. The game was just such as would delight a big crowd, every species of play and misplay being exhibited. In the ninth inning, with two out, Hamilton got his base on alls, stole second and third, and crossed the plate on Ward's fumble of Thompson's slow hit, tying the score.

To-day there will be religious services in Festival Hall, within the World's Fair grounds at Chicago, and doubtless they will be followed by like services on succeeding Sundays during the fair. It is conclusive evidence that a part, at least, of the religious community is fully reconciled to Sunday opening.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 24 -- Saint John's Day, the day held sacred by the Masonic fraternity all over the world, is also the great yearly period to another class of people very different from the brethren of the mystic tie. It is the one day held moan sacred by the believers in the mysteries of the voodoo, in the United States, in Cuba, Haiti, San Domingo, and wherever the voodoo rites exist.

The Frenchman who covered the dead walls of Paris with calls for subscriptions to a Society of Aviation, to start with a capital of half a million francs, may have been lacking in the highest qualities of public spirit. He is at present in jail for taking money for little private flying machines, costing from $500 to $2,000, which he has failed to deliver.

BOSTON, June 24 -- Jubilee, the Paine cup defender, was launched at Lawley's City Point yard at 7:25 this morning. The launch was in every way a successful one, and was witnessed by several hundred people. There was little enthusiasm, though, and no demonstration. Gen. Paine was not present, but his wife and daughter were, and also his son, John B. designer of the boat.

A NEW-ENGLAND BOYHOOD. By Edward E. Hale. New-York: Cassell Publishing Company. Most of these reminiscences of the Boston of his childhood and youth were contributed by Dr. Hale to the Atlantic Monthly. He has brought them together with some new chapters and an introduction of historical and biographical interest.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Boundless, magnificently hidden by Garrison, won the tenth American Derby to-day in the best time ever made for that event, and before the biggest crowd ever seen on the Washington Park track. St Leonards was second, and Clifford came in third. The time was 2:36, and as the track was a second or two slow it marks an excellent performance.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The outlook for the Summer business in this place is good. There have been many changes and a good many new cottages built this year, and most of these are now occupied for the season.

Ex-Policeman Daniel J. McInerny was held in $500 bonds by Justice McMahon, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday for assaulting his prisoner. Peter Smith of 565 First Avenue. Smith was held in $300 bonds for assaulting John Carolan of 348 East Twenty-third Street.

Fourteen tales written, by Mr. Kipling within the last two or three years are here gathered together for the first time; indeed, a few of them have never appeared in print before. There is a dedication in verse, "To the True Romance," which is quite Kipling like and mystic, and contains at least one stanza that affects the reader like the sound of strange music:

Real estate brokers and auctioneers discussed with much interest yesterday the new up-town exchange and auction room project, the details of which were exclusively printed in THE NEW-YOKK TIMES yesterday. A few approved of it, but were unwilling to be quoted on the subject. Others thought the plan would not prove successful.

RIHFIELD SPRINGS, June 24 -- The opening of the doors of the Spring House and Earlington last Saturday marked the beginning of another season's bathing, riding, driving, coaching, dining, singing, flirting, and all things lazily pleasant that make up the joy of a Summer's outing. The early arrivals found the place looking as fresh and demure as though it were making its maiden bow to the public.

The Entre Nous Tennis Club has just finished its annual Summer tournament on the club grounds, De Kalb Avenue, near Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. The events were men's singles, women's singles, men's doubles, and women's doubles. The events were all handicap. The men's [singles was won by John H. Burtis, from scratch, who defeated Walter Q. Savage for final honors. The match was close requiring four sets to decide it.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The statement of the United States Treasurer, showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day, is as follows:

There was a good holiday crowd at the Sheepshead Bay races yesterday, but the sport was of a very commonplace sort for this track. Small fields once again ruled, and there was considerable grumbling among racegoers as well as among the bookmakers over the fact, which pleases neither. Perhaps, now that the Eastern horses have gotten so thoroughly exterminated at Chicago, they will return and the fields at the tracks hereabouts will improve accordingly.

Alexandra Weill of Lazard Freres sailed yesterday for Europe, where he will spend the Summer. Before he left the city he gave to a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES a summary of his views of the financial situation in this country and abroad.

-- New features of the programme at Koster Bial's this week will be Mile. Juanita Bardoux, the French singer, in an imitation of the methods and mannerisms, with songs, of the famous French vaudeville artist, Yvette Guibert, whose performances have been attracting so much attention in Paris during the past three years, and the first presentation in America of Solomon and Morton's now one-act nautical operetta.

Copyright, 1893, by the New-York Times. LONDON, June 24 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- The tragedies of ocean form a big and solemn part of England's history. It is only in the presence of such a sweeping calamity as that which gripped upon English heartstrings yesterday that one comes to realize how the sea still dominates the imagination of these islanders and forms an integral part of their national life.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Notwithstanding that the richest purse over hang up in Amerca was being run for by fourteen crack racers just eight blocks from the exposition grounds, the attendance at the World's Fair to-day did not suffer. In fact it was much larger than yesterday, and everybody enjoyed a long term of sightseeing, as the crowds remained late at the grounds.

To the Editor of the New YorK Times: Owing to the lateness of the season, our business has been correspondingly light, although not preventing an unusually good opening of our famous clambakes, every day adding to the number of our patrons for dinners, The outlook at present shows every indication for an unusually busy season.

Thomas Coughlin is in the Tombs under $1,000 bonds to await the action of the Grand Jury. He is charged with having attempted Friday morning to steal a diamond stud valued at $150 from Albert S. Warner, law partner of Louis J. Grant, at 93 Nassau Street.

The only new thing in the local world of music in the week just ended was the production of "The Talisman" at the Manhattan Opera House on Wednesday evening. This production claims recognition as a musical incident simply because it is set forth by the manager of the theatre as opera comique. But in truth it is not possible to discuss the "work" from a musical point of view, because its music is absolutely inane.

Two games of ball were played at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon, and Manager Foutz's men won both by hard and timely batting. The Senators were the victims, but Manager O'Rourke's wounded feelings were soothed somewhat by big gate receipts. Nearly 9,000 persona saw the games -- the biggest crowd that gathered in Brooklyn this season.

Capt. Seymour Spencer Smith, ex-Commander of the British scuadron on the China station, who has been in the police courts seven times for intoxication since his arrival in this country less than two weeks ago, was before Justice McMahon in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for the third time in two days. The charge was intoxication.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 24 -- The number of new people who will pass the warm season here surpasses all records. The boarding houses and hotels are filling rapidly and cottages and houses are renting well. The probabilities are that more homeless family men will Summer at the Montclair Club than have been accommodated for several years.

SOCIETY INCIDENTS AND GOSSIP -- The few society people remaining in town are singing the funeral dirge of the town season. Like Micawber, they are waiting for something to "turn up." Gossip now has its headquarters at the Newport Casino and the Tuxedo Clubhouse.

Bed draperies are much in vogue. Of late we have been having many lessons in the art of home decoration and to the bed has been given a prominent place. In France, let the room be ever so simple or the bed ever so small, some drapery is always seen, and by its aid a certain dignity is attained.

Not much real estate is to be offered at auction this week, and nearly all is by order of the courts. The most notable of the sales announced is that by Mr. Richard V. Harnett on Wednesday in the partition of the Pearsall estate. Three parcels on the Bowery and tenements on Second and First Avenues and at Houston and Allen Streets are on the list.

County Clerk Henry D. Purroy was one of the prominent passengers on the Paris, which reached her pier yesterday morning. President John 3. Scannell of the Fire Commission, Coroner John B. Shea, Deputy Street Improvement Commissioner Jacob Seabold, Commissioner Whalen of the Tax Department, Meyer Butzel, and John Halloran met Mr. Purroy at Quarantine, where Dr. Jenkins tendered his tug to the party.

After deliberating for months-on self-destruetion, Isaac Lloyd, a shoemaker, carried out his intention early yesterday morning by shooting himself in the month with a revolver in his bedroom at 27 Frankfort Street.

The West continued yesterday to pay back to New-York part of the money it drew from this centre in its times of financial worry. The repayment was made mostly in drafts and papers for collection, as on the day before.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, June 24 -- Thursday morning was opening day for the big hotels on the island. The confusion attending the final preparations all disappeared like a mist before the sun when the first train arrived from the city. The hotels and cottages are built on the side of a hill that slopes gradually into the water, and some of them are almost hidden among the trees.

COOPERSTOWN, June 24 -- The Cooperstown Railroad Company will run five trains daily for the Summer season. Leaving New-York at 1 P. M., travelers arrive here at 7:25 P.M. Going west the steamer Natty Bumppo leaves here at 9:30 A.M, and 2 and 4:45 P.M., and arrives at 12:20, 4, and 6:45 P.M. The steamer connects at the head of Otsego Lake with tally-ho coaches for Richfield Springs.

ASBURY PARK, June 24 -- The long-looked-for influx of pleasure seekers from the cities made its appearance at the Jersey coast resorts today, and Asbury Park succeeded in capturing a lion's share. The evening trains rolled into the new station crowded with guests, and, as a consequence, the hotels and beach resorts took on their usual Summer life and gayety.

James R. Keene, owner of St. Leonards and Chorister, and M.F. Dwyer, owner of Don Alonzo, heard the story of the running of the American Derby as it was flashed over the wires on the veranda of the Coney Island Jockey Clubhouse. A wire led directly to the track, and several hundred people waited until long after the races at Sheepshead Bay track were ended to hear the story of the running of the Derby.

-- Of J.M. Barrie's sketch from "Vanity Fair," lately presented by Mr. and Mrs. Charrington. Mr. Labouchere says: "Mr. J.M. Barrie's Becky Sharp is a literary crime. Out of the last few chapters of 'Vanity Fair' he has constructed a dull and sordid little comedy which burlesques the social downfall of Mrs. Rawdon Crawley, burlesques the devotion of the faithful Dobbin, and burlesques the sentiment of stout Jos Sedley.

Representatives of the banking house of Speyer Co. of this city went to Philadelphia yesterday to confer with the Reading receivers relative to the extension of the three-million-dollar loan which will be due on the first of next month. It is believed that Speyer Co. will extend the loan.

The Marine and Feld Club of Bath Beach held their fifth annual canoe regatta yesterday on the waters of Gravesend Bay, off the club grounds. It proved to be the most successful canoe event yet seen this season. The competitors in the various races not only comprised the best-known racing men of the dozen or more clubs situated in the vicinity of this city, but included several from a distance.
MANHATTAN BEACH, Juna 24 -- "The Storming of Vicksburg" as presented at Pain's fireworks show at Manhattan Beach had a touch of realism introduced into it to-day.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The outlook for Summer-resort business at Saratoga is very good. The engagements at the various hotels are much larger than they were last year, and a larger number of cottages have been taken by Summer residents.

A poorly-clad and miserable-looking man, whose name is unknown, was found dead and half hidden in the weeds in a vacant lot at the corner of Conduit and Railroad Avenues, East New-York, yesterday morning. About two hours before he had robbed the butcher's shop of Frederick Nicholaus, on Crescent Street, of all the knives and cleavers it contained.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 24 -- The news that the farm laborers were organizing a union to cover the State of Kansas was heard by the Populist State officers with dismay. The State Secretary of the Farmers' Alliance, who is a clerk in the Governor's office, declared the movement a plot by the politicians to ruin the new party.

TRENTON, N.J., June 24 -- Judge William Walter Phelps was enthusiastically greeted Tuesday when he reported for duty in the Court of Errors and Appeals. He was a striking figure on the tall end of the bench. The first day he kept notes. The second day was so hot he gave it up.

-- The semi-annual dividend of 3 p cent. declared by the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company, is payable Aug. 1 at the Grand Central Station. The transfer books will be closed at noon July 1 and reopened Aug. 2.

The Forty-seventh Regiment of the National Guard left for the State Camp at Peekskill on a special train from the Grand Central Station at 1:14 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The regiment mustered 489 men when it assembled at its armory in Williamsburg shortly after 11 o'clock.

TRENTON, N.J., June 24 -- The efforts of the schoolmasters of New-Jersey to excel the other States in their Columbian Exposition educational exhibits were not in vain. Both Gov. Werts and secretary of State Kelsey have extended to the department their official congratulations. Other prominent Jerseymen have made enthusiastic reports on the exhibit.

W. Bourke Cockran, the Tammany Sagamore, owns a handsome country seat in the town of North Hemstead, L.I., on what is known as Sand's Point. Mr. Cockran has several hundred acres of highly-improved land.

-- A statue has just been unveiled in Paris in memory of Theophraste Renaudot, whom it is now the fashion to call "the father of journalism," but to whom a seventeenth century pamphleteer addressed a bit of pleasantry beginning: "Concerning the decayed nose of Theophraste Renaudot, alchemist, empiric, charlatan, usurious as a Jew, perfidious as a Turk, wicked as a renegade, the great rascal, grand gazetteer of France."

Repeal of the Sherman Act. From the Saratoga Sun, (Dem.) We are very glad to know that there seems to be an overwhelming majority in favor of the repeal. With our currency all worth its face, and the tariff fetters removed from commerce, we will have such an era of national prosperity as never has been dreamed of.

DOUGLASTON, L.I., June 24 -- The regatta of the Douglaston Yacht Club was sailed in Little Neck Bay this afternoon under excellent conditions. The wind was a light north by east, which freshened to a strong southwest later in the day and gave plentiful sport. The steamer Blackbird was chartered by the club for the benefit of its guests and friends.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 24 -- The coming week will be one of note in the Catskills, The New Grand Hotel, which is the only hotel in the Catskills on a mountain top with direct connection by rail, will be opened Wednesday. It is in the air 2,500 feet, where the air is clear and pure at all times. The New Grand will open with an unusual number of city guests.

WALTON, N.Y., June 24 -- While Train No. 1 on the Ontario and Western Railway was passing Troutbrook, thirty-four miles south of here, the rails spread and the entire train, consisting of baggage car, mail car, and five coaches packed with people returning home for Sunday, were thrown on the upper side of the track and piled in a heap.

ORANGE, June 24 -- Barring several bad falls, owing to the manner in which the track was banked, the bicycle tournament held at the Orange Ovai, East Orange, this afternoon, under the management of the Orange Athletic Club Cyclers, was a great success. No records were broken, but Champion A.A. Zimmerman was there, and that one fact was enough to guarantee a big meet.

A Central News telegram from Madrid, dated Wednesday, says: "An extraordiaary outrage by brigands was perpetrated this morning on the Royal Road between Bilboa and Santander, which is the principal and most frequented highway between these two important places. A wagon was proceeding along the road laden with $8,000 in specie intended to pay the workmen at the Sectares Mine.

DENISON, Texas, June 24 -- Another train robbery was attempted last night a few miles south of the scene of the Wednesday night's attack. It was the south-bound Missouri, Kansas and Texas No. 3 again. Conductor James Smith, Engineer Danforth, and Express Messenger Narner. When the train reached Stringtown a stop was made.

There was very light buying interest to-day in breadstuffs. Wheat was sold off 18@14c under lower cables and light export clearances, while the receipts were liberal; foreign houses were interested chiefly in the late options and especially in December. Corn brought a slight advance on moderate offerings of supplies. Flour was at easy prices and dull.

The world has not been always kind in its inventive ways, else it would have found a pleasanter word than "old maid" for the unmarried woman. "Spinster" recalls corkscrew curls and a simper. with entire forgetfulness of the pretty origin of the word, while "maiden lady," if not so much mincing in sound, is suggestive of starch and primness.
