HAVANA, June 24 -- The Madrid Government has finally settled upon $25,984,241 as the budget for the fiscal year of 1893-4, and a probable income from all sources of $24,444,759, showing a deficit of some $550,000.

I have always been deemed handsome, so universally so that I have never considered the fact, for conceit hath its source in doubt. Some men are born so ugly that their comeliness, which is the gift of years, remains a matter of surprise. Others start from infancy with an evanescent beauty which becomes a reminiscence to their kindred, and a secret faith to themselves.

A.B. Humphrey, Secretary of the Republican National League, returned Friday night from the meeting of the Executive Committee in Chicago. He said be did not know the precise date when the national headquarters of the league would be transferred from this city to Chicago, but the change would be made as early as convenient.

The Infanta Eulalie sailed yesterday on the French Line steamship La Touraine for Havre. More than a thousand parsons were at the pier to bia her farewell. They made the air ring with cheers as the steamship backed out into the stream.

MONTREAL, Quebec, June 24 -- The Governmental inquiry into the building of the two iron bridges across the Lachine Canal at Montreal is unearthing one of the biggest public-works scandals ever discovered in Canada. The original sum voted for the two bridges was $175,000, but the work has already cost $600,000 and is not completed.

-- In view of possible contingencies arising between France and Slam the French have in and near Siamese waters, and available for immediate service, the armored cruiser Triomphante, first-class cruiser Forfait, dispatch vessel Inconstant, and gunboats Lion and Comete. This force is in command of Rear Admiral Humann. In addition the Cochin China division can furnish the gunboat Lutin and four torpedo boats.

The delegates from New-York City and Brooklyn to the convention of Republican State Leagues, to be held in Saratoga to-morrow and Wednesday, will leave to-day, large delegations starting on the New-York Central train at 10 A.M.

The members of Congress who have not yet declared their intentions as to the repeal of the Sherman law, as well as those who avow themselves in doubt as to what they ought to do, have had occasion to do a good deal of thinking in the week that has passed since the revised results of THE TIMES'S canvass were presented.

The racing this week will bring to a close the summer meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club, the horses moving from there to the broad stretches of the track at Monmouth Park, where they will face until the close of August.

To the Editor of the New-YorK Times: On Sunday, May 21, THE NEW-YORK TIMES printed cuts of the New-York State Monumental Gettysburg, to be unveiled July 3. In the article descriptive it states that it required considerable diplomacy to "smooth out the numerous conflicts between rival organizations, due to jealousy and forgetfulness."

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date last year. The figures are received weekly by cable by the Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Mr. George Kennan, the well-known writer and lecturer on Russian subjects, has returned to Washington after a five weeks' trip to England, whither he went to make arrangements to lecture throughout the United States next Winter on the Russian penal system and other topics with which he has made the world familiar.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 25 -- The arrangements for the great national Saengerfest of the North American Saengerbund are practically completed, and the fine temporary auditorium was dedicated this evening with a concert by the united singing societies of Cleveland and the Philharmonic Orchestra, and addresses by the Rev. F. Yon Schluembach and Judge G.B. Solldus.

CONEY ISLAND, June 25 -- It is a pity that the infanta Eulalie left these shores without adding to her stock of impressions that of a Sunday spent among the sights and sounds of the biggest show on earth, the one and only Coney Island.

-- There will be a special race sailed by yachts of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club on July 3. It is for the Plant Cup, and is for cabin catboats under 30 feet on the load water line. The entries close with the Regatta Committee next Saturday. The course will be six miles to windward or leeward and return from a starting line off Finch's Island. The start will be made at 11 o'clock.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 25 -- The one hundred and ninety-third commencement exercises of Yale were opened this morning with the annual baccalaureate sermon by President Dwight. The class of '93, including both the academic and scientific departments, was present for the first time in many years, in mortarboards and gowns.

CRANSTON'S-ON-THE-HUDSON, June 25 -- The acquaintanceship between Mrs. U.S. Grant and Mrs. Jefferson Davis, which had its inception at Cranston's last Saturday, as told in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES, promises soon to develop into warm friendship. Both ladies met informally to-day upon the veranda at West Point's famous hostelry and chatted with each other for a full half hour.
At Thirty-fourth Street and First Avenue a woman waved her umbrella last evening to stop a Forty-second Street and Boulevard car.

PEEKSKILL, June 25 -- For the first time this season a school of officers was established this afternoon, which was attended by Col. Frederck Phisterer, Instructor in Chief; Col. R.H. Hall, United States Army; Major H.P. Stacpole, Major George P. Hilton, and Lieut E.E. Hardin, United States Army. All the officers, field and line, attended and learned many things from a practical standpoint which they before knew only theoretically.

In an affray on Pier 37 East River, at the foot of Market Street, early yesterday morning, William Brower, a chainmaker, twenty-six years old, of 119 Clinton Street, was struck on the head with an oar. He was taken to Gouverneur Hospital unconscious, and died from concussion of the brain.

Staten Island, which now has fifty miles of recently-completed macadam and Telford roads, is one of the most, attractive of the suburbs of New-York for cyclers, and every Saturday afternoon and Sunday finds a small army of wheelmen from this city and even Brooklyn taking a spin over the beautiful thoroughfares of the island.

The Federal statutes say that on and after July 1 there shall be imposed upon all tin imported into this country a duty of 4 cents a pound. Not a pound of tin is produced in the United States, but we import and consume in various industries about 44,000,000 pounds per annum. The greater part of this large quantity comes from the East Indies.

CONEY ISLAND, June 25 -- James J. Jones, a young man who gave his address as 274 West Thirty-eighth Street, New-York City, was locked up in Chief McKane's headquarters this evening for imitating the tactics of wild Western cowboys.
Barnet Rubin, a German grocer, twenty-three years old, living at 226 East One Hundred and Sixth Street, was set upon Saturday night by three boys of the neighborhood and roughly handled.

Every one whose good fortune it has been to visit and thoroughly "do" the great "White City" on Lake Michigan, wherein the nations of the world are holding their Columbian Exposition, has nothing but praise unstinted for the complete magnificence of the exhibition.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., June 25 -- The Rev. Terence J. Earley, pastor of St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church here, created a sensation by announcing from his pulpit to-day that he had been deceived by a member of his congregation who had married a Protestant during the week.

HALIFAX, N.Y., June 25 -- The Chignecto ship railway was one of the great engineering schemes of this age, and it now seems destined to be one of the most futile attempts of recent years, ranking with the Panama Canal on a small scale, and, so far as is known, without the swindling which characterized De Lesseps's magnificent undertaking.

Paleography is the art of deciphering ancient inscriptions or writings, and in the above volume the principal librarian of the British Museum gives clear outlines of Greek and Latin paleography. As a study paleography is by no means a simple one, requiring as it does not alone scholarship, but such an eye training as few possess.

HANOVER, N.H., June 25 -- President Tucker's first baccalaureate at Dartmouth was preached in the college church this morning. The audience was made up of students, their relatives and friends, and citizens from this and adjoining towns. The large building was completely filled.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Gen. Catchings of Mississippi, who was a member of the last House Committee on Rules, in speaking of legislation which will occupy the attention of Congress at the special session next Autumn, said:

TRENTON, N.J., June 25 -- Owing to the disappearance of Edward F. Church, President of the village of South Orange, the Saxony Woolen Company of this city, whose selling agent he was in New-York, has applied for a receiver. The application was made to Vice Chancellor Bird, and Watson H. Linburg was appointed.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 25 -- The liquor dealers of North Carolina evidently intend to forestall and prepare for the agitation of any prohibition movement in this State or the enactment of each a law as that recently adopted in South Carolina.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The recent issue of the Briggs heresy trial and his condemnation is to me only another evidence of that clerical savagery latent in the breast of every true ecclesiastic and Church council. To condemn, anathematize, persecute, and, where possible, torture and kill any progressive nature and crush his opinions, is the prerogative of such as those who have condemned Dr. Briggs.

-- The Kings County Wheelmen's twelfth annual race meet to be held next Saturday at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, promises to be most interesting. The prize list includes six high-grade pneumatic safeties, besides a sewing machine, Winchester rifle, split bamboo rod and reel, ornamental gold clock, and other second and third prizes of proportionate value.

The arguments before the Arbitration Commission in Paris are drawing to a close, and even from the meagre abstracts transmitted by cable it is easy to discern the issue which they have tended to evolve. That august tribunal will in effect be asked, in behalf of the United States, to establish a new principle of international law.

The agitation for a special meeting of the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen is taking definite shape. Representatives of the divisions that are back of the movement are now signing a call for the meeting. Massachusetts takes the lead in the matter and Connecticut seconds her efforts to force a meeting to be held.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your recent editorial on "The Trolley Slaughter" reflects a popular prejudice which is so far unjust that its appearance in your columns is surprising. I have determined, with your permission, to call your attention to certain general considerations and statistics which will convince you. I believe, of this injustice.

BERLIN, June 25 -- The results of 101 second ballots taken yesterday and Friday were known at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The Social Democrats won 24 constituencies; the National Liberals, 18; the Conservatives, 13; the Richterists, 15; the Democrats, 7; the Clericals, 7; the Radical Unionists, 6; the Free Conservatives, 4; the Simon Pare Anti-Semites, 4 ; the Poles, 3.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 25 -- Atchison County, this State , is proving a rich field for the archaeologist. In addition to the ancient fort excavated from the solid rock, which was fully described in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, there has been discovered another and larger fort, built somewhat in the manner of the work ascribed to the mound builders.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 25 -- This was opening day at the Asbury Park Beach Auditorium. Four services were held, and thousands of cottagers and visitors from the hotels enjoyed the sermons and addresses by men of national reputation. The meetings were in charge of the Rev. S. Edward Young, pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church here.

Most New-Yorkers are familiar with the figure of the little newsboy who sits in a perambulator at the corner of Twenty-third Street and Broadway. He is always there in rain or sunny weather, and rumor says that he has made quite a little fortune during the last fifteen years. The other day a kind-hearted lady stopped to buy a paper of him, and as she did so, deposited in his lap a small toy dog.

WOLCOTT, N.Y., June 25 -- The engagement of Nettle M. Colburn of this village and Fred Arnold, traveling salesman for New-York State for Jacob Meyer Co., laces, New-York City, has been declared off, though the wedding was set for June 28, and the trousseau was nearly ready and plans had been laid for a honeymoon trip to France and Switzerland.

Patrolman Patrick F. Dwyer of the East Sixty-seventh Street Police yesterday afternoon saw a crowd of men insulting passers-by at the corner of Third Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. The policeman ordered them to disperse.

The palmy days of Plymouth Church, when Henry Ward Beecher was in the zenith of his fame, were last evening recalled by the memorial services held in Association Hall, Fulton and Bond Streets, Brooklyn, to commemorate the eightieth anniversary of his birth. The hall was crowded with the old friends and admirers of Mr. Beecher.

PROHIBITION PARK, S.I., June 25 -- At the seventeenth Summer School of the American Institute of Christian Philosophy, which will meet at Prohibition Park, S.I., from July 6 to 12, the general theme to be presented is "The Bible and Society; the Claims of Both, and How the First Meets the Needs of the Second."

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Although a great deal has been done by the State to secure proper care for the insane, instances of serious and even fatal injury to them at the hands of their attendants are still common. How shocking to every humane person is the history of such cases need hardly be said, and they surprise almost as much as they shock us.
CHARLOTTE TEMPLE, -- "H.H.L.": Please give a short sketch of Charlotte Temple.

OMAHA, June 25 -- Michael Corcoran of this city charges that the trial of Bishop Bonacum is a malicious persecution and conspiracy originating in Republican and Clan-na-Gael hatred, whose leader is none other than Patrick Egan, late Minister to Chile. THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S correspondent called on Mr. Corcoran at his residence and asked him what he knew about the origin of the Bishop Bonacum trouble.

NEW-LONDON, June 25 -- This week is race week and the crews are all here, devoting themselves to perfecting their form and to getting rid of as many faults as possible before their respective races. Harvard and Yale are the only colleges to send university crews this year, and their race will be immediately preceded by that between their freshman crews and Columbia freshmen.

The spread of Theosophy among the Faculty of the Wilson Industrial School for Girls, at St. Mark's Place and Avenue A. has culminated in the dismissal of two other teachers and the indefinite closing of the school.

Because John D. Crimmins refused to serve again as President of the Houston, West Street and Pavonia Ferry Railway Company, and of the Metropolitan Crosstown Railway Company, some political gossips gave him a place in the race for the Collectorship of the Port of New-York.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Your issue of May 26 contained a correct synopsis of my plan and estimate of a proposed rapid-transit railroad system on the viaduct plan through the blocks on the west side.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $3,294,825. The banks now hold $5,481,975 in excess or the logal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $4,714,300, a decrease in specie of $2,295,200, a decrease in legal tenders of $3,117,700, a decrease in deposits of $8,472,300, and a decrease in circulation of $97,100.

LONDON, June 25 -- It is understood that Rear Admiral Markham will be court-martialed with the officers of the Camperdown, as that vessel carried his flag as second in command of the squadron when she came in collision with the Victoria.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the discussion of plans far rapid transit I do not remember to have seen the following proposed though, perhaps, it has been:

The indignation which Grand Army men feel because of the desecration of the Gettysburg battlefield by the running across it of a trolley road is so great that it is feared that the road will be torn up by them.

Every fireman in the department, from Chief Hugh Bonner down to the humblest employe, is interested in the plan to furnish light refreshments to the men while on duty at protracted fires by making use of the lunch wagon which the Church Temperance Society maintains during the night in Union Square.

NEW-HAVEN, June 25 -- The week past, while not quite rising to the size of a constitutional epoch in this State, will have its niche in history as making several steps onward in the movement toward a new organic law. A nominal and outward defeat of the convention plan has taken place, but a defeat only in name and semblance.
The money market was very firm. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 4 @ 25 cent., tae average being about 10 cent.
Residents on the Heights in Brooklyn are preparing to make a monster protest to the Police Department against the lack of protection given to them and their property.

The twenty-fourth annual regatta of the Pavonia Yacht Club will be sailed to-day. The start will be made off Oyster Island Buoy at 11 o'clock. The big boats will race to Sandy Hook and the smaller ones will turn at different points on the way down. The Loyal, Commodore B.F. Sutton's schooner, is entered. The Loyal is a good boat and can sail last, too, but she should be in racing trim to win.

RANGOON, June 25 -- For several days the Moslems have been preparing to celebrate a religious festival to-day. This morning they were forbidden by Mr. Fleming, British magistrate, to sacrifice a cow near the Hindoo Temple.

The wave of financial stringency and disaster, which upon superficial observation seems to have invaded every part of the United States within the past few months, is practically a mere spasmodic ripple upon the usually placid stream of American commercial prosperity.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 25 -- Summer guests are beginning to arrive in numbers at the hotels along the shore in this vicinity. The cottages likewise are filling up with many family parties. The prospects for a large number of guests, a prosperous season for the hotel keepers, and a jolly one for visitors and cottagers are good.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service, referring to-day to the outlook for cholera in the United States during the present Summer, said:

Delegate Matthew Barr, who acted as Secretary at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union, said he had a complaint from Progressive Musical Union No. 1, saying that the cigarmakers had hired a band of musicians from a boycotted union for their picnic.

-- The third annual tennis tournament of the Longwood Cricket Club will be held on the grounds of the club at Longwood, Boston, Mass., on Monday, July 17, and following days. It will be given under the management of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association. The Longwood Challengo Cup will be offered by the club and it will become the property of any one winning it for three (not necessarily consecutive) years.

The Rev. Father McGlynn, who has been in Rome making his peace with Pope Leo, has returned to this country. He was a passenger on the North German Lloyd steamship Werra, which reached Quarantine early yesterday morning and was docked at her Hoboken pier before noon.

The Republican Bourbons of Ohio do not receive from the party journals of the country that ardent indorsement which they had expected. There is a general feeling that they have made a very bad mess of it. There were three points in the action of the Ohio Republicans: (1) McKinleyism with no change save in the direction of higher duties; (2) prohibitory duties on wool; (3) opposition to any Democratic reform of pensions.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 25 -- The Duke of Veragua and his party arrived in Albany this evening at 7:15 on the palace car Genoa. They were met at the station by Mayor Manning and Major Harmon Pumpelly Read, Edward A. Durant, Major James Otis Woodward, Barnwell Rhett Hayward, and J. Meredith Read, 3d, of the Citizens' Committee appointed to receive and entertain them while in Albany.

-- Rear Admiral Bancroft Gherardi said recently to a NEW-YORK TIMES representative that the cruiser Baltimore will probably be the next ship to leave the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The Admiral said that it was as yet uncertain how much time would be required to repair the Baltimore, but that as soon as she is ready for sea she will sail.
NEWARK, N.J., June 25 -- Mrs. Clark P. Williams, one of the victims of the Erie crossing disaster at Avondale, died at 11:20 to-night. County Physician Elliott and Dr. Mitchell were in attendance.

Two notable auction sales of real estate to-day are those of Mr. James L. Wells, who offers eleven lots at Tremont, and Mr. John S. Mapes, who will dispose of 200 choice lots in Westchester Village. Besides these will be the sale by Mr. R.V. Harnett of a dwellind in West Eighty-first Street. Details of these sales are as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 25 -- The first international conference of the Epworth League, which will meet here, promises to be one of the greatest religious gatherings of the year. The Committee of Arrangements says that 10,000 delegates will be in attendance. The hotels are inadequate to accommodate such a crowd, and the homes of Cleveland Methodists will be thrown open to receive the visitors.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 25 -- Ever since the close of Commencement Week the examination papers of applicants for admission have been coming in, and they have now been all received with the exception of those from a few places in foreign countries and on the Pacific coast.

Emile Waxweiler, associate editor of La Flandre Liberate, the political organ of the Liberal Party at Ghent, Belguim, is in town, and will soon start on a tour of the country. His principal object is to make a political and economic investigation.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- A tribute to a great statesman was paid this afternoon by the unveiling, in the banqueting hall of Donegal Castle in the Irish Village on the Midway Plaisance, of a colossal statue of William Ewart Gladstone. The event was participated in by an audience that crowded the hall and packed itself on the lawn outside, and in which there were many Irish representatives.

Albert Simmons, an electrician, living at 429 West Forty-fifth Street, threatened to drown himself Saturday afternoon. Instead of drowning himself he was arrested, and, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, fined $10.

LONG ISLAND CITY, June 25 -- A desperate burglar was wounded and captured, after an exciting chase through Astoria's streets, at 3 o'clock this morning, by Private Watchman Michael Kloman. The watchman's big Newfoundland dog, Jack, played an important part in the affair, and to-day Astoria regards Kloman and his dog as the heroes of the hour.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 25 -- Two years ago Mrs. Mary Lawler of Leavenworth was missing from her home. It was at first suspected that she had eloped, leaving her husband and one child, but as the months passed and nothing was heard of her this suspicion was given up, and the belief, prevailed that she had committed suicide by drowning herself in the Missouri River.

A Chicago bank officer presents in the July number of the Forum what he calls "The World's Fair Balance Sheet," which may be regarded as a semi-official statement of the financial condition, and prospects of the exposition. Though it is based largely upon estimate, so far as receipts are concerned, it is the most definite statement thus far made, and is of some interest.
Behind the bars at Police Headquarters is John Corcoran, for several years the credit clerk of C. Godfrey Gunther's Sons, fur dealers at 184 Fifth Avenue.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Pennsylvania Railroad Company is now building a large station here and expects to put on an extra train to and from New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Washington. A large and artistic church is being constructed here by the Episcopal denomination, and the city is to be otherwise improved by a board walk, over a mile in length, on Surf Avenue.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 25 -- It is now finally settled that the Yale-Columbia-Harvard freshman race will take place on Wednesday afternoon at 5 o'clock, and the Yale-Harvard 'Varsity race on Friday morning at 10:50. The latter hour was chosen because it will be flood tide at New-London at 9:12, and in order to avoid, if possible, a postponement until the afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 25 -- The members of the Quaint Club of New-York spent to-day as the guests of Mr. John G. Weaver at the Ocean House. A very pleasant time was enjoyed, carriages being at the disposal of the visitors, who were carried to all the spots of interest. At 7 o'clock to-night all the members discussed an elaborate dinner, the menu being on pretty souvenir cards in design as quaint as the club.

-- The boat clubs along the Harlem River were well patronized by the oarsmen yesterday. It was an excellent day for the crews who have regattas coming on soon in which to compete, and it was cool enough to make rowing a pleasant exercise. Many pleasure parties were out and the scene on the river was a lively one. All the boats of the Union Club were out and the float was vacant of shells.

The Central Park open handicap tennis tournament began Saturday afternoon on the lower grounds. Many players were entered and but two rounds were completed. Among the stronger players in the contest are Fischer, Bostwick, Paret, Haight, Bates, Ripley, and Colwell.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The exhibit made by Columbia College at the World's Fair is designed to present in graphic form the present position of the college and the evidences of its rapid and healthy development into a thoroughly-organized university rather than to illustrate the work of its students. The space allotted to this exhibit is fortunately ample and most favorably situated.

The Rev. Dr. W.W. Atterbury, Chairman of the New-York Sabbath Committee, in speaking the other day on the opening of the Chicago Exposition on Sunday, said his organization had done all that it was possible for it to do to prevent the existence of such a state of affairs, but was powerless to do more in that direction.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 25 -- President E.B. Andrews in his baccalaureate sermon at Brown University to-day, spoke from the text Matthew xxv., 27, "Thou oughtst, therefore, to have put my money to the bankers, and at my coming I should have received back mine own with interest." Dr. Andrews was impressed with this as one of Christ's deepest insights.

To the Editor of the New- York Times: An article in THE TIMES of June 12 regarding the neglected grave of Richard A. Proctor has been called to my attention. Perhaps a brief statement from one of his intimate friends would be of interest to the public, for, having passed much time with him for three years previous to his death, I knew the sorrows, the hopes, and ambitions of this wonderful man.

WORCESTER Mass., June 25 -- The Eastern Circuit meeting in Agricultural Park closed yesterday. The track was slow. Three events were on the card, and though each race went in straight heats, it was horse racing throughout, except in the 2:29 class, trotting. In that event Mambritionian jogged away from the field. The attendance was 1,200.
The students at Columbia College are a gay lot of boys, although they do not have the freedom they would have in a college town.

BOISE, Idaho, June 25 -- That this country is rich in opals from Squaw Creek, a, stream emptying into the Snake River, to a distance about twenty miles above is now an established fact. The location varies in distance from thirty-five to sixty miles of this city. The gems found upon the flats, or bottom lands, of the river are not as good as those beyond the action of its waters and upon higher grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- The steamer Falcon, which will take Lieut. Peary's expedition to Northern Greenland, will leave here to-morrow morning for New-York. The majority of the members of the expedition will go aboard at New-York, and the work of loading the cargo will also be completed there.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 26 -- In the annual regatta of the Eastern Yacht Club, sailed off this port to-day, the Volunteer won in the schoouer class over the Mayflower and Marguerite, while in the forty-six-footers the Wasp beat the Harpoon. These were all the starters except the thirty-footer Handsel, which dropped out after sailing about a quarter of the course.
To-day the action of Mrs. Ellen Pollock for $50,000 damages against her father-in-law, Alexander Pollock, will go to the jury.

HONOLULU, June 19, per Steamer China, via San Francisco, June 26 -- As each successive steamer from San Francisco arrives at Honolulu bringing no news that Hawaii's affaire will soon be settled by the United States, the disappointment of annexationists and royalists alike becomes keener. Both parties are anxious to have the vital question, of stable Government decided as soon as possible.

We gave yesterday morning the substance of a statement by Mr. EDWARD ATKINSON of Boston containing his views of the situation which Congress will have before it as to tariff reform when it gets the financial legislation out of the way, and containing also his views of the general considerations by which Congress should be guided in treating the reform of the tariff.

"I want a plain black suit of clothes," said a young man in a big down-town clothing store. "Black, did you say?" queried the salesman, although the intending purchaser had spoken with painful distinctness.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I, June 26 -- Nearly every man in North Hempstead and many of the women turned out in the pelting rain this morning and wended their way to Liberty Hall here to listen to the arguments in the controversy between W. Bourke Cookran and his neighbors over his closing up of an alleged highway on Sands Point.

Sissieretta Jones, the "Black Patti," got a severe lecture yesterday from Judge McAdam of the Superior Court on the evils of ingratitude. Incidentally, also, she was enjoined from singing under any other management than that of Major James B. Pond.

JOLIET, Ill., June 26 -- Never before in the history of the Northern Illinois State Penitentiary has there been such a sensation at the prison as took place this afternoon when the pardons of the Anarchists were handed to Warden Allen. Mr. Edward S. Dreyer, a Chicago banker, arrived from Springfield with the pardons for Michael Schwab, Samuel Fielden, and Oscar Neebe at 3:25 on the Chicago and Alton Railroad.

Comte do Treveneue. The death is announced in Paris of the Comte Henri Louis Marie Chrestien de Treveneuo, Senator, lineal descendant or the Comte de Treveneue, who fought in the Crusades under King Louis IX. He was born at Lantic Sept. 13, 1815. He was a pupil of the St. Cyr military school, of the Ecole des Beaux Arts, where he studied architecture, and a lawyer.

There is either a flend in the Eastern District of Brooklyn who delights in cutting off the hair of young girls, or else there are a number of young girls with luxurious hair who desire to have it cut short, and, being refused their parents' consent, use the scissors themselves and throw the blame on "Jack the Shearer."
Granville W. Garth has been appointed cashier of the Mechanics' National Bank to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William Sharp, Jr.

RAHWAY, N.J., June 26 -- After an absence of nine years from home David Hoffman, Jr., suddenly returned here last week to find that his wife, who had been led to believe him dead, had married another man. The occurrence is much discussed here, where all three are well known, and no end of speculation is made as to how the affair will end.

Coroner Shea yesterday held an informal investigation in the case of William Brower, the Clinton Street chairmaker, who died in Gouverneur Hospital from concussion of the brain, caused by being struck on the head with an oar during a fracas on the Market Street pier late on Saturday night last.

In spite of the most discouraging weather, adverse winds, and no end of Governmental red tape, the Norse ship Viking sailed away from her anchorage in the North River yesterday bound through the inland passage for Chicago.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund met yesterday in the Mayor's office and approved plans for and authorized the construction of gaileries, stairways, and approaches from the Tombs Prison to the bridge which is to be erected across Franklin Street to connect the Tombs with the new Criminal Courts Building.

Six races were run over the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday in order that Michael P. Dwyer and a host of other men like him, who make a business of backing horses in races, should not have their business interfered with. There was nothing akin to sport in it any more than there is in the constant spinning of the ball at the roulette table or the continuous deal from the faro player's box.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 26 -- This has been a wet Class Day at Yale, but it has been an enjoyable day notwithstanding. At 10:45 the graduating class, numbering 186, marched in a body to Battell Chapel, where the presentation, exercises were held. President Dwight had charge of the exercises, and opened them with prayer.

Francis A. Gau, a German cabinetmaker, sixty-eight years old, committed suicide early yesterday morning by hanging himself in his bedroom on the top floor of the tenement house 349 West Seventeenth Street.

When the big steamship Alaska of the Gulon Line swung into her dock at 9 o'clock yesterday morning she was greeted with cheers by a crowd of two or three hundred young men and women decorated with Christian Endeavor badges.

Thomas Costigan, familiarly known among local politicians as "Tom," is one of the celebrated heavyweights of this city. For years Mr. Costigan has been eligible to membership in the Fat Men's Club without being measured or weighing in.

VALETTA, Malta, June 26 -- Five more of the crew of the steamer Widdrington, which arrived here Thursday night from St. Louis, France, have been attacked with cholera. The disease broke out on the steamer on the voyage, three persons having been stricken with the disease. Two of them died, and the vessel was placed in quarantine for a week.

The efforts of Col. William E. Sinn, the manager of the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, to get a separation from his wife, who is generally known as Cora Tanner, have proved of no avail. Chief Justice Clement of the City Court, Brooklyn, yesterday gave judgment, with costs, for the defendant.

The veterans and members of the Sixty-ninth Regiment assembled in full force last evening at the armory building, in East Seventh Street, on the occasion of the election of a Major for the Second Battalion. The election was held in accordance with the provisions of the amendment to the Military Code, which requires each battalion of the militia regiments to have a Major in conformity with the regulations of the regular army.

George Smith, a fireman on the Broadway branch of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, is, according to the ideas of the police of the Sixth Precinct, Williamsburg, a champion romancer. At 1 o'clock on Saturday morning he was found in Lorimer Street, near Scholes Street, with a bullet wound in his side.

Col. George B. McClellan, President of the Board of Aldermen, was surprised yesterday morning by the receipt of a bill for $2,000 from John Austin Stevens, Jr., who claimed this amount from the city for what he is pleased to term his services in connection with the land parade and ball during the Columbian celebration in April.

James R. Collins, a New-York manufacturer and importer of bags, told the Custom House Investigating Commission yesterday, underoath, that the Government was losing annually $250,000 in uncolleoted duties on foreign-made bags.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- With appropriate and interesting ceremonies the New-Hampshire State Building was opened to-day. Gov. John B. Smith and stall and about seventy-five prominent citizens of New-Hampshire arrived in Chicago a week ago and have been seeing the fair. Since that time the party has been, increased by the arrival of members of the Legislature, State officials, and others.

In a review of the German Iron and Steel Association's report concerning the prices of iron and steel in Germany for the last ten years, the Engineering and Mining Journal says: "The price given is the price at the works to home consumers, the export price of the rails, for instance, being in some cases $7.50 lower than the home price."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 26 -- Gov. Altgeld to-day issued pardons to Samuel Fielden, Oscar Neebe, and Michael Schwab, the Anarchists serving terms of imprisonment at Joliet Penitentiary for alleged complicity in the Haymarket riot in Chicago on the night of May 4, 1886.
Funeral services over the remains of the late Charles P. Palmer are to be held this morning in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, at 10:30 o'clock.
The distinguished German journalist and man of letters, Herr Veltesoor, who is passing through this city on his way to Chicago, sends us the following communication:

The fastest regular train service yet established between New-York and Boston was begun yesterday on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad. A handsomely-equipped train of four cars -- two drawing room, one combination, and one of President Clack's private cars -- left the Grand Central Station at 10 o'clock A.M., and sped swiftly over the well-ballasted shore line to the "Hub" in two minutes less than five hours.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 26 -- Suit for $50,000 damages was brought in the Union County Circuit Court to-day against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. The plaintiff is Lawrence C. Baugert, a well-to-do farmer and milk dealer, who had a remarkable escape from death.

The first detailed account of the collision wherein the big sailing ship Alexander McCallum was sank by the Cunarder Servia was told yesterday, when five men who formed a port of the McCallum's crew reached, this port on board the steamship Alaska of the Guion Line.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 26 -- The three-masted schooner Thomas W. Haven went ashore off the East End at noon today. She had previously dropped her anchor, but the sea was so heavy that the cables parted, and the vessel was driven upon the beach, broadside on.
Corporation Counsel Jenks of Brooklyn has written a letter to THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in which he says:

AN ARMY RETIRING BOARD is appointed to meet at the call of the President thereof at Columbus Barracks, Ohio, for the examination of such officers as may be ordered before it. The board will consist of Col. Melville A. Cochran, Sixth infantry; Col. Simou Snyder, Nineteenth Infantry; Lieut. Col. John B. Parke, Second Infantry; Major William E. Waters, Surgeon; Capt. Louis Brechemin, Assistants Surgeon, and First Lieut. Harry L. Bailey, Twenty-first Infantry, Recordor.

Our comments upon the condition of the water supply of Chicago have been based on the testimony given by the newspapers of Chicago and by the sanitary authorities of the city, and in almost all cases we have published this testimony. The condition of the water is again the subject of discussion in the World's Fair city, and we turn again to the columns of the Chicago press.

The Metropolitan School of Shorthand and Typewriting, 95 Fiftn Avenue, holds its first annual reception this evening in Sommer Hall. 9 East Seventeenth Street. The school has been founded a little over a year, and during that time about seventy pupils nave received instruction, day and evening. Twelve will receive certificates of proficiency.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The following telegram was sent to President Cleveland to-day, signed by thirty-eight of the business houses or Chicago. It is understood, that several others who did not sign this massage have sent private telegrams of similar import.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Gov. Altgeld's pardon of Fielden, Schwab, and Neebe, the three Anarchists convicted of participation in the Haymarket riot of May 4, 1886, has created the most intense feeling in this city and throughout the State.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, June 26 -- P.M. The whole tendency of prices in the stock market was downward to-day. Except in a few cases where small lots changed hands everything on the list showed a loss. Trading was more active than had been the case for several days.

The quotations of silver in the London market are in pence per ounce at the British standard of purity, which is .925 fine. The quotations of the New-York market are for pure silver, that is 1.000 fine, in dollars and cents. The price in New-York is determined by the price in London, which is the world's great market for the metal.
Silver bullion certificates declined to 77 and closed at 78, a decline of 3 1/2 from the last previous sale.
LONDON, June 26 -- From Beyroot comes an account of the sinking of the Victoria by the Camperdown off Tripoli last Thursday.
The Baptist ministers held their regular weekly meeting at the Baptist Tabernacle, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The President has been made aware, through the canvass of the members of the Fifty-third Congress made by THE NEW-YORK TIMES and by personal information from members, that the prospect for the repeal of the Sherman Silver Purchase act has strengthened during the last few days.

The correspondent who entered a defense of the death-dealing trolley in our columns yesterday assumed that what was lost in human life was gained in speed of travel. Allowing that increase of speed on the public streets justifies sacrifice of human life, which we do not believe, he seems to us to be quite mistaken in his claim.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Compared with Saturday night, wheat is up 1 3/8c and corn 3/4c. In wheat, the opening was about 1/8c higher than Saturday's closing, and, with a few fluctuations, prices were advanced 1 3/8 @ 1 5/8 c, then eased off slightly, ruled steadier again, and the cloning was about 1 3/8c higher for July and 1 5/8c higher for September than the closing figures Saturday.

LONDON, June 26 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- The Indian Council has passed an act, to take effect at once, closing the Indian mints to the free coinage of silver. This was predicted in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of June 17.

Detective Sergeant McClusky is hunting for a fellow who on Saturday pretended he was "Sanitary Inspector Martin" when he called on Mrs. G. Meyer at 26 Irving Place and said that houses owned by her in East Seventy-sixth Street were in need of repairs and would cost several hundred dollars.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Another hearing before Master in Chancery George L. Crawferd was held this afternoon in the matter of the application of the Reading receivers for permission to issue certificates.

RONDOUT, N.Y., June 26 -- Dr. Burtsell has not yet received any communication from Dr. McGlynn since the latter's return. When asked by a NEW-YORK TIMES correspondent if Dr. McGlynn would be restored to the pastorate of St. Stephen's Church, he replied:

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The President, Secretary Carlisle, and the financial officers of the Government generally received their first authentic news of the startling action of the Government of India in suspending silver coinage through the press dispatches. There had been rumors on the subject earlier in the day, but they were passed upon as rumors only, though their substantial accuracy was not doubted.
Yesterday was the greatest day of the year for the boys and teachers of Grammar School No. 20, in Chrystie Street. It was the occasion of the closing exercises in the male department.

In May the Grand Jury made a presentment calling attention to the overcrowding in the city institutions, particularly in those used for the care of the insane. Some of the buildings were declared to be uninhabitable. On June 7 Mayor Gilroy sent a letter of inquiry to the Commissioners of Charities and Correction.

While County Clerk Henry D. Purroy was abroad he made a trip through Ireland, going over much of the ground he visited on his two prior trips, and also visiting many interior towns and villages. Speaking of his tour, Mr. Purroy said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday:

The demands of consistency appears to be the real reason why Mrs. E.I. Armstrong, matron, and Miss Louise J. Kirkwood, sewing teacher, were called upon by the Board of Managers of the Wilson Industrial School to resign their positions last Friday. When Miss Chapin, the teacher, was dismissed by the lady managers some three weeks ago, they were not aware, they say, that the matron and Miss Kirkwood believed in the Theosophist creed.
ALBANY, June 26 -- The Eintracht Society to-night begins a celebration of its silver anniversary. The celebration will last until Wednesday. Residences about the city are gay with decorations.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 26 -- The Duke of Veragua and party were astir early this morning. After breakfast the ducal party and the Citizens' Committee were escorted to the City Hall, where Mayor Manning presented the Duke with the freedom of the city, which was incased in a black walnut box.

Plans and specifications have been registered in the Building Department during the past week for the erection of seventy-two new structures, involving a total estimated cost of $1,282,000 and for alterations to be made to fifty-six buildings at an expense of $350,000.

LIVERPOOL, June 26 -- The four crack yachts of the season -- the Prince of Wales's Britannia, Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie, Mr. J. Jameson's Iverna, and Mr. A.D. Clarke's Satanita -- started to-day to sail a race over a sixty-mile course.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 26 -- The Department of Communication and Public Works has granted a concession to Felipe de Mazarraza for the construction of a railroad in the State of Vera Cruz, from Coatepee, by way of Jico and Leocelo, to Cozautlau, with a branch to the station of Pacho Viejo on the Interoceanic Railway.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Hutchison came out of his retirement to-day, and, with the exception of the first inning, pitched finely. He gave Foutz a base on balls to start with. Brouthers scored him with a three-bagger, and the big first baseman came home on a wild pitch. That settled the game then and there. Weather clear and warm. Attendance. 2,400.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The Scoggans' Little Buchanan filly took a decided crimp in the calculations of the talent at Washington Park upon a track that was so fast and dry that it required frequent sprinkling. Content, in the mile race, was supposed to be a "cinch," and tons of money went in at 3 to 1. Content finished tenth. The mile was made in 1:40 1/2.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club, the leading organization of independent Democrats in Brooklyn, refused last night, by a vote of 41 to 22, to commit itself in favor of an independent candidate for Mayor next Fall.
The fight between the opposing factions in the congregation of the Baptist Tabernacle goes merrily on.

Shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Brooklyn Grand Jury left their room and appeared before Judge Moore in the Court of Sessions. Their entrance into the courtroom created a sensation among the few politicians who were there listening to the trial of a case.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 26 -- Wesleyan's class-day exercises were held this afternoon. Arrangements had been made to hold them under the sturdy elms of the campus, but rain drove the assembly of pretty girls and capped and gowned students into the memorial chapel, which was crowded to overflowing.

The case of Frank Ellison of 324 Fifth Avenue, who is charged with feloniously assaulting Broker William H. Henriques of 94 Park Avenue on June 5, at Thirty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, was called for the fourth time yesterday morning in the Jefferson Market Police Court before Justice Voorhis.

The deepest significance of the defeat of the Constitutional Convention bill by the Republicans of the Connecticut Legislature lies in the fact that the question of holding the convention was to be referred to a vote of the people at the same election at which delegates were to he chosen. It was in the highest sense a question of government by the people.

Examiner Pattern of the Appraiser's Stores brought a number of bag importers and manufacturers before the Custom House investigators at the Barge Office yesterday to contradict the statement of Importer James Boss Collins made the previous day that it was easy or practicable to tell American jute or burlap bags from foreign bags of the same materials.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The Colts corralled the runs off Stein in the first inning. Then Manager Foutz put in Lovett, and he was effective until the ninth inning, when the locals hammered him for 4 runs. Had Anson not tried to stretch his single into a double the score would have been tied. The Brooklyns harvested 9 runs in the fourth in nine singles and a triplet.

LONDON, June 27 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Since first nights became the fashion in London no theatre has been the scene of more triumphant enthusiasm than that which marked the opening of Augustin Daly's beautiful theatre in Leicester Square to-night.

The action of Vice Admiral Tryon in refusing to leave the bridge of the Victoria while there was a chance is being compared by military men in this city with the action of Brig. Gen. George A. Custer at the Big Horn massacre. According to now generally accepted facts, an opportunity was offered Custer by a Government Indian scout to cut his way out.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The clerks In the War Department are greatly disturbed over the rumors or changes in the civil force expected to occur on Friday, the last day of the fiscal year. Each chief of division has been invited to make recommendations of clerks whose services may be spared, and of those entitled to promotion. Those lists are in the hands of the appointment clerk and will be examined carefully by Secretary Lamont.

Detectives of Inspector McLaughlin's staff have been for nearly three weeks looking for a young man, W.W. Van Zandt, who had been employed as cashier by George M. Rosenblatt, a jeweler, at 202 Broadway, and against whom charges of forgery and embezzlement have been lodged. The amount of his peculations will reach $3,000.
NEW-ORLEANS, June 27 -- A peculiar accident has taken place in the United States Mint here. In one of the vaults of the building about a million dollars in gold, silver, and greenbacks are stored.

Max Thuns, the young man who defrauded twenty boarding-house landladies, is incarcerated in the Tombs and will probably remain there for weeks unless some one generously becomes his bondsman in the sum of $2,500 pending his trial in the General Sessions. Meanwhile, Thuna is undoubtedly glad to be behind the bars which shield him from the fury of the women whom he swindled.

-- Messrs. Drexel, Morgan Co. give notice that over 96 cent. of Richmond and Danville and Georgia Pacific Railway securities have been deposited under the plan of reorganization and that outstanding holders can get in only by paying 1 cent. penalty on stock and 2 cent. on bonds on or before July 8, 1893.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 27 -- This is Alumni Day at Yale. Squads of graduates, each group representing a class back for reunion, tramped about the campus all the morning, reviving college recollections at the sight of old buildings and familiarizing themselves with those of a later date. At noon the classes of '43, '48, '53, '58, '63, '68, '73, '78, '83, '87, and '90 held reunions.

There is another illustration of the pettiness of many features of our complicated customs revenue system in the tremendous amount of attention given by the investigating commission to burlap bags. It seems that while there is a duty on imported bags, those which are sent out from this country as receptacles for exported articles may be brought back free.

The foreign exchange market was unsettled. It opened weak, but gained strength later in the day, and closed steady. The posted rates for sterling were $4.83 1/2 for 60-day bills and $4.85 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.81 @ $4.81 1/4 tot 60-day bills, $4.83 1/4 @ $4.83 1/2 for demand, $4.83 3/4 @ $4.84 for cable transfers, and $4.79 for commercial.

BERLIN, June 27 -- The Bundesrath has approved the new Army bill, which is said to be substantially the old bill drafted on the lines of the Huene compromise. The bill will be laid before the new Reichstag immediately after the opening on July 4.

RYE, N. Y., June 27 -- Lieut. Peary was the guest of the American Yacht Club at Milton Point to-day. A reception and luncheon were given In his honor. In consequence of the short time given for the Issuing and acceptance of the Invitation, and also perhaps on account of the weather, the attendance was light.

-- It is supposed that the purchaser of the English race horse Meddler, sold at auction by Tattersalls yesterday for nearly L16,000, was W.H. Forbes, who has a stock farm near Boston and who recently leased the services of Victory for two years with the privilege of purchase, from William Lakeland. It is known that Mr. Forbes was anxious to secure the horse and that he is in England, presumably for that purpose.
Charles W. Dayton will take hold of the tiller ropes as Postmaster of New-York on July 1. He returned from Washington yesterday, where he has been conferring with Postmaster General Bissell.

The fourth "ocean party" of the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor sailed from Twenty-second Street and North River on Monday for the "People's Seaside Home" at Coney Island. These outings are highly appreciated by the mothers and children from the tenement districts who enjoy the bounty of the association.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Prices have all been stronger to-day, and the market in general has showed an improved tone. Considerable shorts were covered to-day, but the close was only at a fractional concession. Reading securities were stronger than for some time. There were rumors of some favorable arrangement that will give Reading the financial assistance it needs.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- The annual commencement of the Newark Normal and Training School was held in Association Hall this evening. The hall was crowded, with the friends of the graduates. The latter are now eligible to teach in the public schools of New-Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The Summer campaign for the sulkies began hero to-day and lasts for two weeks. For the first meeting at Point Breeze there were large fields, thirty-two horses, starting in the three classes this afternoon.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 27 -- The feeling in financial circles in Buffalo to-day has been of confidence; nothing of a panicky nature has been caused by the suspension yesterday of the Queen City Bank.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, June 22 -- Edmond Paul, a distinguished Haitian statesman, died here of progressive anaemia Sunday last. He was educated in Paris, and was a pupil of Michel Chevalier, the celebrated French writer on political economy. Following his master, Edmond Paul devoted himself to the study of political economy, and was known as a writer outside the bounds of his native land.
"We find for Mrs. Ellen Pollock, and award her $37,500 damages."

The steamer which passed the schooner Thomas W. Haven while flying signals of distress and refused to render assistance is believed to be the Berks, Capt. Pierson, of Philadelphia, which was bound east, laden with coal. She put into Sandy Hook for a harbor on Monday aiternoon, and must, therefore, have passed the schooner about the time she went ashore.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 27 -- Principal George A. Atwater of School No. 3 was exonerated, shortly before 2 o'clock this morning, by Bayonne's Board, of Education. His public trial Monday night lasted five hours. Serious charges were preferred against him in writing by two dozen residents of the Third Ward, where the school is situated.
CITY ISLAND, June 27 -- The following yachts passed hare to-day:

The Misses Neal Married. June of this year has beaten its double-wedding record of years past. The fourth double wedding this month took place last evening in the West End Presbyterian Church at 8:30 o'clock.

Since the official announcement of the failure of the Reading reorganization plan the question has been frequently asked whether Isaac L. Rice was prepared to offer a plan of reorganization. Mr. Rice's published statements, relating to Reading have shown that he is well informed regarding the company's financial condition and necessities.

A sad-faced woman, with large, dark eyes and pretty brown, fluffy hair, lay dead on the sidewalk when Policeman Owen Sullivan reached 227 Madison Street at daybreak yesterday. It was soon found that she had thrown herself from the window of a hall bedroom on the fourth floor of the house, and that she was Mary Reilly, a book sewer for W.H. English, at 60 Murray Street.

A rapid-transit meeting was held last night on Washington Heights which fairly well filled the Athenaeum in One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street. Congressman John R. Fellows, Orlando B. Potter, and Lawson N. Fuller had been announced to speak, and the handbills circulated before the meeting promised that Alderman Robert B. Saul would preside.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: 1. "When a commercial panic is impending, the only way to avert and, allay it is to give prompt, immediate, and liberal assistance to all houses who can prove themselves solvent."

The earnestness with which the June Grand Jury in Brooklyn in setting about the work of investigating the abuses of municipal administration which surround it on every hand has greatly alarmed the spoilsmen of that city, who are ever alert to discover the first sign of danger, either to their persons or their purses.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 27 -- The university crews have put in a very busy day, and Yale particularly ought to be well satisfied with her showing. In spite of "Bob" Cook's statement yesterday that he should not permit the young men whom he was in charge of to go over the course on time, he sent them the four miles this morning at a clipping pace.

The Board of Health yesterday ordered the following tenement houses vacated: 270, 282, 284, 286, and 288 East Fourth Street, 661 First Avenue. 1,453 Broadway, and 106 Bayard Street, they having been reported by Sanitary Superintendent Roberts as unfit for human habitation by reason of their unsanitary condition and lack of necessary repairs.

The programme for New-York's days at Gettysburg, next Saturday, Sunday, and Monday, was completed yesterday. Gens. Sickels, Butterfield, and Carr have been working on it several days. Gen. Butterfield has had charge of the formation of the organizations that are to participate in the ceremony.

When the Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday afternoon Commissioner of Public Works Michael T. Daly reported that he had $311,900 balance on hand out of the $1,500,000 special appropriation for repaying the streets this year. He also submitted the following list of streets which he desires to repave with this balance:
"Give me back all my letters!" Col. George B. McClellan, President of the Board of Aldermen, was sitting in his office in the City Hall when a young man entered and made this demand upon him.

NEW-HAVEN, June 27 -- Once more Yale is on even terms with the ball players of Harvard. The wearers of the blue won to-day's game in grand style, and another contest will be necessary to decide the college baseball championship of 1893.

Samuel Spencer has ceased to be a Rapid-Transit Commissioner. His resignation was accepted yesterday afternoon by Mayor Gilroy, who at once appointed David F. Porter of 132 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street as Mr. Spencer's successor.

Samuel Rowland, foreman; P.D. Ackerman and George B. Roach, members of the jury before which Alderman McKee of Brooklyn was tried, called npon District Attorney Ridgway yesterday and presented to him a letter of which the following is a copy:

SARATOGA, June 27 -- "The Kindergarten," as some of the old Republicans who have been associated in politics with Thomas C. Platt and the other practical politicians have irreverently spoken of the State League of Republican Clubs, took a step to-day which it thinks will put it more nearly on a par with the State "machine" than it has ever been before.

SARANAC LAKE, June 27 -- The annual tour and convention of the New York Press Association, which is composed largely of country editors, began to-day. The party is one of the largest of its find ever assembled. President Kessenger is delighted. Arrangements were made for a party of 150, but the list was swelled to 260.

There is a serious schism among the Afro-Americans in Brooklyn caused by the opposition of T. McCants Stewart to the appointment of Miss Georgiana F. Putnam of 37 Fort Greene Place as head of department in Public School No. 83. Miss Putnam, who is colored, has been a teacher of colored children for twenty years in the public schools of Brooklyn.

An underpaid, overworked, sleepy switchman and the confusion of his first waking moments seems to have been the cause of the killing of eight persons and the maiming of a score of others in the wreck of the Manhattan Beach Railroad race train at Parkville last week, Tuesday.

New-York. -- Annie Sheehan was acquitted yesterday of the charge or manslaughter in the Court of General Sessions. She was accused of causing the death of Rose McCall, with whom she had been living at 134 Cherry Street. There was a quarrel in the house on Feb. 27, and Rose McCall, who was sixty years old, was found lying at the foot of the stairway. She died a few days later at Gouverneur Hospital.
CITY OF MEXICO, June 27 -- The tremendous drop in the price of silver yesterday and to-day, bringing exchange on New-York to 66 per cent, has created much discussion among Mexican bankers.

BOSTON, June 27 -- The Directors of the New-York and New-England Road held their regular monthly meeting here to-day. There were nine of them present. The business was routine and related largely to traffic matters. The earnings for the quarter have not been made up yet, so that nothing was presented to the board regarding the results in detail.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 27 -- The Wesleyan University Alumni Association elected the following officers to-day:

A lady accompanied by her son, a lad of about twelve years, was riding in a street car up town the other day. The young gentleman had on what was evidently his first suit of "grownup" clothes. His shirt, collar, tie, and scarfpin were immaculate. His derby hat was spick and span. His suit was evidently made by a good tailor, and his faultless kid gloves were of the latest shade.

The five-story brick double apartment house at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and East Ninety-fourth Street, 50 feet on the avenue by 80 on the street, has been sold by Morris Rubens to James L. Reynolds for $85,000.

District Attorney Nicoll was asked yesterday for his opinion of the action of Gov. Altgeld of Illinois in pardoning Samuel Fielden, Oscar Neebe, and Michael Schwab, the Anarchists who were serving terms of imprisonment in the penitentiary at Joliet, Ill., for alleged complicity in the Haymarket murders committed May 4, 1886.

The flurry over silver has somewhat obscured the financial situation, but it is none the less apparent to those who have thought of other things than the white metal that there is substantial reasons for better feeling in nearly every section of the country.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau allows the following results:
An important decision in the affairs of Charles C. Carpenter, formerly a manufacturer of corsets and suspenders at 557 and 559 Broadway, and at Elizabeth, N. J., has been rendered by Judge Ingraham.

A black satin bag, with violets embroidered on the ontside, and soven one-hundred-dollar bills, a Swiss watch, and a three-handred-dollar pair of diamond and sapphire earrings on the inside, is being carefully searched for by the police of Brooklyn.

There was considerable excitement among the Italians of Williamsburg yesterday when it was found that Pietro Ferrara and Michael Angelo, who ran a banking concern at 314 and 316 North Second Street, under the name if P. Ferrara Co., had disappeared.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, June 27 -- P.M. The stock market showed more strength to-day and there was a gain in prices in many of the active shares. At the opening a heavy tone prevailed, bat later in the day there was a sharp rally, and the market at the close was firm.

CINCINNATI, June 27 -- Michael Sullivan was on the pay roll of the New-York Club a year ago. To-day, however, he wag drawing salary from the Cincinnati Beds, and he Ditched against his old clubmates, winning his game in handsome style. He kept the batting of the Giants down to seven hits, and his fielders gave him excellent support.

The sixth shoot of the gun clubs of Kings County for the silver cup offered by the Coney Island Athletic Club took place yesterday at Wcodlawn Park. The match has been considerably simplified by the withdrawal of the North Side, Crescent, and Glenmore Gun Clubs. The next shoot will take place on July 25 on the grounds of the Coney Island Club at Brighton Beach.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Secretary Lamont has noticed that some criticisms have been made of the assignments made by him of the cadets recently graduated from the Military Academy, stress being laid upon the assignment or many cadets as additional officers, when all the vacancies In the cavairy and Infantry were not filled.

The East River Bridge Commission met yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock, and as all the testimony was not in, decided to apply for an extension of time at the General Term of the Supreme Court on June 30.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27 -- The State Military Board, acting as the Armory Commission, to-day awarded to Joseph Jewkes Sons the contract for the erection of a new armory in Jersey City, for the National Guard of Hudson County. The cost is to be $129,966.

Every time a Republican orator makes a speech nowadays he seeks to give some reason why his party was defeated last November. Scores of reasons have been given. Col. Floyd B. Wilson of the Republican Club added a new one to the list while speaking before the Republican organization of the Eleventh District at its meeting at 16 West Twenty-seventh Street last night.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Judge Gary, who presided at the trial of the Anarchists who have been pardoned by Gov. Altgeld, positively refuses to express an opinion concerning the pardons, saying that he decided long ago to enter into no controversy upon the subject of his judicial conduct Said he:

THE PETREL arrived at Unlaska, Alaska, June 2. THE BANCROFT. -- AP order has been issued by the Navy Department postponing until July 6 the final sea trial of the Bancroft. The trial was postponed to allow the contractors to repair her shaft, which she damaged recently while going into dock.

"Within the last few weeks a storm of protests has broken upon the hearts of those who are responsible for the scheme of running an electric railway over the famous battlefield of Gettysburg," writes John Reed Scott in the current number of Harper's Weekly.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 27 -- Dr. Robert M. Gilbert has just returned from Menardville, Menard County, where he visited the silver mine being worked by a company at Texas capitalists. He says that they are working a small force, and are taking out about three tons of ore a day. Specimens of carbonate sent to Denver assayed thirty-five ounces of silver and five ounces of gold to the ton.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The people sold wheat to-day who bought it yesterday. Timely rains where needed for Spring wheat unsettled the bull sentiment. At the close July wheat was 3/4 c and September 5/8 c below yesterday's closing prices. The good growing weather and a slack shipping demand dragged down corn to the extent of 3/8 c for July and 1/4 c for September.

Justus Schwab, one of the apostles of communism and Anarchism, felt jubilant yesterday over the pardon of the Anarchists by Gov. Altgeld. On a blackboard on the wall of his saloon, at 50 First Street, was posted a small picture of Gov. Altgeld, and beneath was the following dispatch from Chicago:

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 27 -- Dull, leaden clouds lent a dreary aspect to the usually bright hues of the lovely New-England landscape which especially characterizes this part of Connecticut. Pears have been expressed that the rain which fell in light showers at intervals to-day will interfere with the progress of the big boat races which begin to-morrow.

-- The Volunteer Football Club of Harlem, which gained an enviable record last year for its many victories, intends being represented with one of the strongest elevens in the country next season. Several ex-collegians will play on the team, and they will also have the services of expert coachers and trainers. Games have already been arranged with several of the leading colleges and athletic clubs, and but few open dates remain.
The remains of Prof. Richard A. Proctor, the eminent English astronomer who died in this city of yellow fever four and a half years ago, are at last to have a fitting resting place in Greenwood.

HALIFAN, N.S., June 27 -- The ship Albert, belonging to the English Mission to Deep-Sea Fishermen, arrived at St. Johns, N.F., yesterday. She will cruise along the Labrador coast in the Summer months, affording religious and medical assistance. She has three doctors, two for hospitals built on the coast, and two trained nurses are coming out by an Alian Line steamer to assist them.

MOUNT KISCO, June 27 -- This village was thrown into a high state of excitement about 9 o'clock this morning by pistol shots in George Knapp's grocery store on Main Street. Sylvester Sherwood, who bad made repeated threats to kill Lawyer A.J. Adams, had tred to knock him on the head with a loaded whip handle, but was frustrated in the attempt, and the lawyer had fired the shots.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- For many years Catherine Schmiedham of this city believed her sailor husband, Carl Schmiedam, a Norwegian, to have been lost at sea. The woman, with her two children, lived in Brooklyn when she was informed of her husband's death. He was reported to have been drowned off the coast of Newfoundland.

Hundreds of grammar school students and graduates were made happy yesterday. Graduation exercises were held in several schools, and the proud parents and friends of the graduates crowded the assembly rooms. Some of the graduates will go to the College of the City of New-York and others to the Normal College.

LONDON, June 27 -- The action of the Indian Government was discussed in all its bearings in the speculative markets to-day, and it was concluded that the result must be favorable to America, first, because it would compel Congress to repeal the Sherman act, and, secondly, because it would stimulate the Lancashire cotton trade and diminish Indian competition in grain, causing larger exports of cotton and wheat from America.

Mr. R.V. Harnett's offerings of Bowery, Houston Street, and First and Second Avenues property to-day promise to be a feature of the auction market. Mr. William Kennelly has on his list houses and lots on East One Hundred and Thirty-third and One Hundred and Thirtyfourth Streets. The details of all sales are appended:

Boundless, winner of the American Derby, was shipped to this city yesterday, and is expected to arrive here this evening to run for the Realization Stakes at the Sheepshead Bay track on Saturday afternoon. The owner of the colt yesterday telegraphed to E.R. Garrison, who rode the colt to victory in the race for the Derby, offering him $5,000 it he would accept the mount and win the race with the horse.

BOSTON, June 27 -- Clarence Hobart is still leading all the experts in the West Newton tennis tournament with an unbroken record of four victories and no defeats. To-morrow morning will see the completion of the first half of the tournament, each man having played every other. This system will be repeated, and on Friday night the player having the greatest number of victories will be declared the winner.

According to the usual practice of the British Admiralty, it is likely that the family of every enlisted man who was lost with the Victoria will receive the unexpired enlistment portion of the man's pay. The pay of a British seaman is about $12 per month. This sum is small when compared with the $25 per month paid to seaman aboard American men-of-war.

SIMLA, June 27 -- In explaining to the India Council the bill providing for the stoppage of the free coinage of silver and other monetary measures, the adoption of which was announced yesterday, the Marquis of Lansdowne, Viceroy of India, said he hoped the Government would not be criticised for disposing of the important question at a single sitting.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The politicians Here are Quite sure that the President has made up his mind to appoint a Collector and an Appraiser for New-York before he leaves Washington for his Summer vacation. The fact that the President talks about the matter doubtfully and that Secretary Lamont occasionally admits that the subject is under consideration gives color to the predictions of the politicians.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The President to-day made the following appointment:
Joseph T. Safford, a hotel clerk, has brought suit against his wife, Virginia, for the annulment of their marriage on the ground that she had another husband living when she wedded him.

It would be interesting to know the inner workings of the mind which conceived the proposed change in the lights carried by tows. The ordinary landsman is incapable of perceiving any reason why the lights carried by vessels should be made any more difficult of comprehension than they are now.

POTSDAM, N.Y., June 27 -- Gov. Flower participated to-day in the commencement exercises of the Normal School. He reached Potsdam yesterday, and was escorted from the station to the school building by citizens. Gen. E.A. Merritt delivered an address of welcome, to which the Governor responded in appropriate terms.

A peculiar complication in the case of Dr. Sarah B. Chase has arisen. She was convicted of manslaughter for causing the death of Margaret Manzoni by a criminal operation. On June 14 she was sentenced by Judge Marline to nine and a half years' imprisonment in the Auburn Penitentiary for women.

AMIHERST, Mass., June 27 -- The weather today was anything but pleasant for the Class Day exercises, but as no rain fell, the outdoor programme was completely carried out. The class or '94 gave Its second dumb-bell drill in the gymnasium in the morning. Immediately after this the planting of the ivy took place. W.C. Breed delivered the oration and G.B. Seng was the poet.

It is not too much to say that the whole country was startled by the sudden announcement that Gov. ALTGELD of Illinois had pardoned the three Anarchists confined in the prison at Joliet, two of whom were originally condemned to death for their share in the frightful Havmarket massacre of 1886.

Funeral services over the body of Charles P. Palmer were attended at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning at the Church of the Incarnation Thirty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, by at score of his most intimate friends. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Brooks officiated.

Thirty-five young men were graduated from the Boys' High School in Brooklyn last evening. The hall where the exercises were held, in the schoolhouse at Putnam and Marey Avenues was crowded. Diplomas were issued as follows:

De Wolf Hopper, the comedian, was married yesterday to Edna Wallace of Charles Frohman's stock company. The ceremony was performed in Newark, N.J., by the Rev. Nelson A. MacNichol of the Halsey Street Methodist Episcopal Church, that city.
The Brooklyn Grand Jury continues to keep the spoilsmen of that city in a state of painful suspense.

DENVER, Col., June 28 -- A very important conference will be held in this city tomorrow afternoon. It will be attended by representatives of the owners of all the more important mines in this State, in Montana, in Nevada, and in Utah, some of whom are now on their way from the East.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 28 -- South Carolina is always doing something unusual and unexpected. There is hardly ever a time that she does not attract public attention by some curious legislation, whether it he the passing of acts of nullification and secession or the direct reverse, legislation within her own borders by which personal liberties are counted as nothing.

While the bearing of the Victoria disaster on the employment of rams in naval warfare is still the theme of discussion, the tendency is, perhaps, rather to overrate its significance in that respect. Its specific lesson might fairly be called, not so much the need of constructing rams as of giving stronger and more effective armored prows to battle ships and practicing them in the manoeuvres for crushing an enemy.

The people of this country are just now intensely interested in certain public questions, chiefly, however, that relating to the condition of the currency, but they do not seem to be regarding them in a spirit of partisanship, which is a good sign. The efforts of party organs to assign party responsibility for the existing condition and to make party capital out of it are notably feeble and ineffective.

BOMBAY, June 28 -- The newspapers here generally approve of the action taken on the silver question, but express the hope that the Government will compensate the banks, the holdings of which are largely in silver.

The sidewalk was filed with hurrying people. Three peddlers stood on the curb, one with shoelaces, another with, candy, another with gold paint. Neither looked as if be expected, to sell anything. Nobody paid the slightest attention to them.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 28 -- The closing commencement exercises took place at Yale to-day. At 9 o'clock the usual procession was formed near the Treasury Building. It was led by the Sheriff or New-Haven County. President Dwight and the other officers of the university followed, and after thorn came the alumni in the order of their classes, beginning with '38 and ending with the graduating class '93.
