Chief Engineer McCanna reports that the four brick buildings erected at St. Johnland by Contractor John A. O'Rourke, and upon which over $1,000,000 has been expended by the Charities Commissioners of Kings County, have been constructed at variance with the specifications and terms of the contract.

The conservative University of Virginia could not permit a woman to attend its lectures, but it did suffer Miss Caroline Preston Davis to stand its examinations in mathematics at the close of the year, and as she passed the whole course successfully, the Faculty bestowed on her the certificate of excellence and made her practically the first female graduate of the university.

"Long Jim" Conway, the shepherd, of the sheepfold in Central Part, beside the broad sweep of meadow land which the militia covot for a parade ground, received a large number of Visitors yesterday morning.

To-day's sales of real estate at auction include the offering by Mr. George R. Read of valuable flat property in this city and of dwelling and flat property in Brooklyn. The sale is by a receiver's orders and should command attention. Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly offers, in foreclosure, an east side tenement. Mr. John S. Mapes also sells on the grounds at Westchester Village very desirable suburban lots.

On the complaint of the City Improvement Society the employes of the Bureau of Incumbrances swept down on that part of Park Row between Ann and Beekman Streets yesterday forenoon. They cleared away the bulletin boards, sign boards, and bootblack stands which have for so long aided in blocking up the always-crowded thoroughfare.

HANOVER, N.H., June 28 -- Last night's trains brought a large number of alumni who came especially to be present at the inauguration of President William Jowett Tucker of Dartmouth College. The procession formed in front of the old chapel at 10:30, and, led by a band, marched across the campus to the college church, which was filled to overflowing, the crowd having been increased by arrivals on a special train from Nashua.
Adrian H. Muller Son sold the following securities yesterday at auction at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway:

The dispute between France and Siam must have developed a new phase if, as the cable reports, a French gunboat is getting ready to bombard Bangkok. The quarrel relates to the eastern boundary of Siam, which the latter country holds to be a chain of mountains parallel to the seaboard, whereas France insists that the frontier of Annam extends as far west as the Mekong, the chief river of Siam.
Silver took another downward plunge in the market yesterday. Early cables from London sent quotations whirling, and for a time no one was able to make out at what price the white metal would sell.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 28 -- One of the numerous things that Lieut. Gov. Sheehan had his Legislature do for the Buffalo Police Department was to pass what was called the "Three-Platoon Police bill." This provided that the entire police force should be divided into three platoons, and that each patrolman should be on duty 8 hours out of the 24.

SARATOGA, June 28 -- It was a good thing for the peace and quiet of this town that no more delegates from Republican came to the sixth annual convention than about 400. These few succeeded in making such a lively fight over the insignificant offices that the place has had entertainment enough for one day. The squabbling was all done outside of the convention hall, and the proceedings there were of the tamest sort.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28 -- The Daughters of the Revolution took possession of Roswell Manor, the beautiful home of Mrs. George Inness, Jr., at Montclair to-day, it being the anniversary of the battle of Monmouth, which they celebrate. Two hundred people, mostly members of the society, assembled in the spacious parlors, where an enjoyable programme of music and addresses was carried out

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Nobody in the country at the present time is in as unenviable a position as Gov. John P. Altgeld of Illinois. His action in pardoning the Anarchists has aroused the most bitter feeling against him. and his whole record is being investigated with a view of making it uncomfortable for him if he continues to cater to the disorderly classes of society.

Members of the Freight Traffic Association of the Middle States held their usual June meeting at Long Branch yesterday. The first session was called at 10 o'clock to settle the question of rates on peaches for this season from the different points in the New-Jersey district to Newark, Paterson, Hoboken, and Elizabeth. It was decided to use the same rates which were in effect last season.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 28 -- The North and South Railway Convention was called to order at 2 o'clock this afternoon in Representative Hall by Gov. Crounse, who briefly narrated its inception, its aims, and its ambitions. He also welcomed the delegates to the State, while Mayor Weir presented the freedom of the city. The hall was fairly Well filled, many well-known Nebraska Populists being present.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -- The steamer Australia arrived this morning from Honolulu, bringing the following advices:

MADISON, Wis., June 28 -- Judgment was taken before Judge Slebecker of the Circuit Court to-day in the case of the State against Richard Guenther, ex-State Treasurer and exMinister to Mexico. The action was brought to recover the moneys received by Guenther as interest on public lands while he was Treasurer, and interest on this amount from the time he went out of office in 1882, after four years' service, to the present time.
Edward W. Tanner of 204 West Fourth Street has been, missing from his home since Monday, June 23, and his relatives have asked the police to assist in the efforts to find him.

Chicago, June 28 -- July 4 is to be the greatest day of the fair. Arrangements for the celebration of the day with befitting dignity have already been arranged. At a meeting this afternoon of the Committee on Ceremonies, the American Exhibitors Committee, Mr. Millett, Director of Decoration, and others, it was decided to designate the day "Liberty Bell Day."
Col. George B. McClellan, President of the Board of Aldermen, walked blithely into his office in the City Hall yesterday forenoon. His mind was free from trouble.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 28 -- The boldest attempt at train robbery that ever occurred in Texas was made this afternoon about 2:30 o'clock near the little village of Brackeuridge, in Wilson County, thirty-five miles south of the city. The train was the San Antonio and Aransas Pass passenger, No. 3, which left here at 1:20 P.M.

CLEVELAND, June 28 -- The situation on the lakes and in the relative industry of ore mining is worse than it has been for years. Mine after mine is shut down, and Mr. W.C. Mather, President of the Cleveland Cliffs Mining Company, all of whose shafts and mines will be closed down Friday night, says that toe snipments of ore down the lakes will be curtailed, nearly 50 per cent. this season.
Silver bullion certificates sold down to 68 1/2, or 9 1/2 below the figures of the lost actual sale. Transactions in certificates on the Stock Exchange represented 195,000 ounces.

A "Cabinet officer" is reported to have said yesterday that "the country had been brought to its present financial condition by the very men who were now clamoring for an extra session of Congress," and that they have reached the end of their rope and could no longer profit and thrive by speculation, and wanted the Government to come to their relief, that they might again enter upon an era of speculation and peculation."

Battle Bontanyi told Judge McAdam of the Superior Court yesterday that she had been entrapped into a divorce by her husband and two lawyers, George Gallinger and Abraham Levy. The husband is Aurel Bontanyi, at one time the President of a Harlem riding academy.

Arthur Zimmerman, the champion bicycle rider of the world, has decided to take part in all the championship races at Trenton on Saturday next, when the tenth Columbian meet of the New Jersey division of the League of American Wheelmen will lie given.

Among the dispatches from Peru last week was one which stated that the Government of that country bad fined the Peruvian Corporation L5,000 a month for falling to finish a railroad on the date agreed upon by contract.

BOSTON, June 28 -- A great surprise took place to-day in the West Newton tennis tournament. This was the entirely unexpected defeat of Clarence Hobart of New-York by R.D. Wrenn, the Harvard expert, in two straight sets, Wrenn has been steadily improving in his play ever since the meeting commenced, and to-day appeared in his best form, while the New-Yorker had an off day.

The Middle States championship tournament was begun yesterday afternoon on the Orange Lawn Tennis club courts, Mountain Station, Orange, N.J. Though the rival tournament at West Newton has secured the crack players, the Orange tournament was of sufficient interest to attract a large crowd of local enthusiasts who gathered at the club ground promptly at 3 for the opening matches.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A paragraph is going out to-night to the effect that Secretary Hoke Smith has been presented with a list of pensioners whose names have been found by Commissioner Lochren to be on the list without sufficient reason for issuing pensions to them.
The Governing Committee of the Stock ExChange to-day authorized the listing of the following securities:

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 28 -- State Inspector Dr. Cooper Curtice has visited Woodville, this county, where the Ayrshire herd of cattle belonging to F.A. Converse has been suspected of being afflicted with tuberculosis. Dr. Curtice made the teat with Koch's tuberculin, and as a result seven of the animals were killed yesterday.

LONDON, June 28 -- The galleries of tae House of Commons were packed with people to-day, their presence being due to the expectation that Mr. Gladstone would make a statement in regard to the course the Government had decided to follow with reference to the Home Rule bill.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 28 -- S.T. Howe, formerly State Treasurer and one of the leading financiers of the West and President of the Kansas National Bank of this city, said, in speaking of the present situation:

The thirty-six young doctors who are taking a post-graduate course at Bellevue Hospital have sent a protest, signed by the whole staff, to the Board of Inspection, asking that the quality of their food be improved and its quantity increased.

LAST WEEK OF SANDOW -- Sandow will make his farewell appearance in the Casino next Saturday evening, which is also the last night of "Adonis." The extraordinary accomplishments of this young Hercules have awakened a great amount of curiosity in all quarters and among all classes. Scarcely ever has a more heterogeneous audience been seen within the walls of one of our city theatres than that which crowds the Casino at 10:30 o'clock nightly.

The second eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club did some great tatting in the match at Livington yesterday with the Morris Park team. W.S. Callender played a splendid inning for 56, and in partnership with M. Graham he put on 92 runs before the fall of the first wicket, a record-breaking performance for a second eleven game in New-York.

Our able contemporary, the Sun, which in times past has looked upon silver with the eye of favor, if not of affection, now bluntly expresses the conviction that silver is done for as a measure of value. We quote from its leading editorial article of yesterday, to which it gives the prominence of double leads:

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The yearlings of Woodford Brothers, Paris, Ky.; Milton Young, McGrathiana Stud; Applegate McMeekin, and other breeders were sold at Garfield Park last night. The best sales follow:

A large audience at the Broadway Theatre last night heard De Wolf Hopper and Delia Fox sing several new songs in "Panjandrum," and saw that the plot of the opera, if it can be said to have a plot, had been changed considerably, especially in the first set. The piece is as laughable as ever. In fact, the change was a great improvement and the piece went with even more vim than before.

It was not a remarkable day's racing that was had at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. In fact, it was decidedly commonplace, for there were no horses of a very high class competing, and the fields were small for the money that was offered for the handicaps. Perhaps the feature of the racing was the performance of Stonenell in the opening race, when he won at a mile.

The official Government test of the Brown segmental wire gun has now been in progress at the Sandy Hook proving grounds for over a week. The teat is being conducted by an official board of ordnance officers of the army. The full details of the trial will not become known until the report of the board is submitted to the Chief of Ordnance at the War Department.

The grammar schools of the city sent forth a great number of graduates yesterday, and School Trustees were in great demand as speakers. Principals and teachers were in high feather, and looked with pride upon the young graduates who had been under their wings for several years.

Superintendent Byrnes will be asked, this morning to concentrate his energies for a short time upon the task of finding Johannes Caspray. Caspray is a tall, dark, handsome German, thirty years of age, who disappeared two weeks ago, leaving a number of creditors behind.

Surveyor Lyon wrote a letter to Secretary Carlisle yesterday which promises to bring the Surveyor into as much, prominence with reference to the work of the committee now investigating the customs service at this port as was held by Appraiser Cooper when the committee began its work.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -- Frederick G. Van Pelt, son of G.S. Van Pelt, a lawyer, of New-York, died yesterday from having taken thirty-eight ounces of chloroform. He had been addicted to the use of chloroform as an intoxicant.

Assistant Factory Inspector Franey yesterday received a visit from J.S. Weinthal, Deputy Factory Inspector at Hoboken, N.J., and W.J. McCloud, Deputy Factory Inspector at Elizabeth, N.J. The New-Jersey officials said a whole colony of clothing sweaters from New-York had settled in Bayonne.

AMHERST, Mass., June 28 -- The seventy-second commencement of Amherst College closed to-day, with the "senior promenade" in the evening. At the annual meeting of the General Association of the Alumni in the morning, George Harris of the Andover Theological Seminary was elected President to serve for a term of one year.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The searing before Master George L. Crawford to-day on the application of the Philadelphia and Reading Rialroad receivers for permission to issue receivers certificates to the amended extent of $3,742,968 was largely consumed in arguments.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The Executive Committee of the Democratic State Central Committee met at State Headquarters on Penn Square Monday afternoon and decided upon Tuesday, Sept 19, as the date and Harrisburg as the place for the holding of the next Democratic State Convention.
It is understood down town that the Manhattan Railway Company will soon come to terms with the Rapid-Transit Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Harvard University has honored a naval officer by selecting him for a professorship at the Lawrence Scientific School. Secretary Herbert Monday accepted the resignation of Chief Engineer I.N. Hollis of the Engineer Corps, to take effect at the end of three months, during which time the officer will go on leave.

A private letter from Kiev, South Russia conveys the information that everything possible is being done in the Czar's dominion to be little the World's Fair and prevent Russians from coming to this country to visit it. The writer says:

New-York. The School of Social Economics, at 34 Unfon. Square, while only in the third year of its existence, promises to be one of the successful educational institutions of the day. This is partly due to the low fee and the completeness of its courses. Particulars can be had by addressing President George Gunton at the above address.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23 -- This is Commencement Day at Harvard University. The exercises at the theatre in the morning were of the usual character. Among the distinguished guests on the platform were Gov. Russell and his staff, Lieut. Gov. Wolcott, and a deputation of officers from the two Russian war ships now in Boston Harbor.

SARANAC LAKE, June 28 -- This place is crowded as it bas never been before. Every hotel and boarding house is filled. Besides the "country editors," a branch of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union is Holding a meeting here, and there is being held a meeting of Episcopal clergymen. The village fathers are well pleased and have adopted resolutions welcoming all.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- In the matter of the proposed interment of the body of the late distinguished astronomer, Richard A. Procter, a misconception of the precise facts of the case appears to prevail. The remains of Prof. Proctor have never received actual burial. They are now, as they have been since the day of the funeral, in the private vault of the undertaker.

LONDON, June 28 -- Stock markets closed flat, with general declines, in sympathy with lower prices for all so-called silver securities, such as Mexican Government and railway stocks and Peruvian issues, as well as Denver shares, which are considered to be dependent on the prosperity of the Colorado silver mines.

Manager Ward yesterday telegraphed that the Cleveland Club had released Davies to the New Yorks. Davies is a promising pitcher, and he could not got enough work to do with the Clevelands. He is a tall slim chay and is said to be a good all-around player.

With the verdict for $37,500 given Tuesday in the Pollock case Mrs. Ellen Pollock's struggles were by no means over. Alexander Pollock, her father-in-law, against whom she got the verdict, gave an exhibition yesterday of his determination to fight the judgment to the last.

PARIS, June 28 -- Tie Hon. E.J. Phelps of counsel for the United States continued his closing address before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration to-day. He reanalyzed the International law bearing upon the case before the tribunal, showing that all marine animals in which there was a property interest were treated as property by the nations best entitled to protect them.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, June 28 -- P.M. Lower prices were the role on the Stock Exchange to-day, and the active stocks as a rule lost what they had gained the day before. Trading was fairly active, with total transactions of close to 275,000 shares.

Mr. SAMUEL SPENCER has insisted upon his resignation from the Rapid-Transit Commission and Mr. DAVID F. PORTER has been appointed to the vacancy. Some time ago Mr. STEINWAY declared that the condition of his health would make it necessary for him to retire, bat he has concluded to remain for the present.

The National Real Estate Association's committee to formulate a uniform system of titles, transfers, and registration will meet this afternoon in the Real Estate Exchange offices at 59 Liberty Street, and will continue in session for several days. George E. Pomeroy of Toledo, R.E. Montgomery of Denver, David K. McCord and J. Cradock Simpson of Montreal, and Frank T. Terry of Milwaukee compose the committee.

WEST POINT, June 28 -- The "beasts" come into camp to-morrow, and the first class men arc looking forward with joyous expectations to the time when they can command as servants the services of the "beasts," as non-officially the class of '97, West Point Military Academy, are now known.

For the first time since shipments of money from this centre began to the interior and Western points, there was an offset in receipts yesterday. It came from Chicago, and amounted to something more than $300,000. Financiers construed this shipment to mean that for the present New-York may expect to be in receipt of money that will balance some of the large shipments that have been recently demanded.

Capt. Alexander Cornell of Company H. Eighth Regiment, was placed on trial by courtmartial last night for unmilitary conduct, and after a four hours' hearing it was developed that his witnesses had consulted with him in anticipation of their examination.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, June 28 -- The terrible drought which has prevailed in this city and surrounding section for the past four years has been ended by a rainstorm. The flood came so unexpectedly that hundreds of people narrowly escaped death by drowning in that part of the city lying along the Mexican National Railroad track.

LONDON, June 28 -- A dispatch from Bangkok, capital of Slam, says that the French gunboat Latin has anchored in the river opposite the centre of Bangkok and has made preparations to fire upon the city. The topmasts of the gunboat have been struck and guns have been mounted in the fighting tops. The French Admiral in his flag ship is expected to arrive in Siamese waters from Saigon.

Probably no branch of the Government service has been publicly "investigated" to the same extent as the New-York Custom House. It has been for years the favorite sporting region of those eager pot hunters, the Special Agents, and within the past thirty years there have been a dozen Congressional committees, composed of members of either house, engaged in investigating upon this or that pretext.
Lieut. Peary, with Mrs. Peary and eleven other explorers, will start off again on Friday night north pole hunting. The Lieutenant and his wife are at the Bartholdi Hotel now.
Money on call opened at 50 cent, and went as high as 73 cent. It closed at 6 cent, the lowest point for the day.

Messrs. L. Contanseau Co. of 69 Broadway, the American agents for Kelly Co. (Limited) of London, who published the "London Post Office Directory," announce the publication of "Kelly's Directory of the Merchants, Manufacturers, Shippers, and Buyers of the World" for 1893.

Lieut R.E. Peary's arctic steam whaler Falcon, on which he is to make his second Greenland exploring expedition, came up the bay yesterday morning. Under command of Capt. Henry Bartlett, she left Philadelphia Wednesday last. Alter entering the harbor, the Falcon was picked up by the tug J. Fred Lohman and towed to the excursion dock at the Empire stores, Brooklyn.
The day-or the night, rather -- of deliverance is at hand for the sleepless, nerve-racked residents of Columbia Heights, Brooklyn.

Surveyor LYON'S defiant attitude toward the Treasury Department under which he is a subordinate official is peculiar in several respects. The department has instituted an inquiry for the purpose of ascertaining whether the administration of the Customs Service at this port cannot be simplified and improved.

DENVER, Col., June 29 -- "The action of the Government of India," sold Senator Teller this morning," ought not to nave depressed silver to the extent that it seems to have done, and I think that the fall in silver has resulted largely from a misapprehension on the part of the people of the East as to what action the Indian Government will take.

The scandal of the attempt to force the taxpayers of Brooklyn to purchase the plant and franchise of the Long Island Water Supply Company at an exhorbitant price has again been brought prominently before the public eye. Judge Calvin E. Pratt of the Supreme Court has furnished the medium for its present appearance with an order setting aside the award made by the Commissioners of Appraisal appointed by the court.

HELENA, Mon., June 29 -- Ex-Gov. Hauser, chief owner of the Helena Smelter, which is turning out about $300,000 in bullion every month, says it will not close, as there is enough gold and lead in the ores of Montana to keep it running in spite of the low price of silver.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- McGinnis pitched a good game to-day against the New-Yorks, but the support he received was saffron-tinted, and the Giants won in a canter. The colts are not playing with any life of spirit, and are not in the baseball swim. The score:

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- The market was weak this morning, but prices rallied during the last hour, closing generally at the highest quotation of the day. Stringent money caused a restriction in speculation and forced some little liquidation in the early trading. New-York exchange was exceedingly hard to get all day, and sold for $5 per thousand.
FIRST RACE. -- For horses that have run and not won during this meeting; a sweepstakes of $15 each, with $1,000 added, of which $250 to second and $100 to third. Futurity course.
Monday morning too salt of Mrs. Ellen Pollock against her father-in-law, Alexander Pollock, will come up in court again in a new form.

NORWALK, Conn., June 29 -- The annual ten-mile handicap road race of the Norwalk Wheel Club was held here this afternoon. The course was from the Green to Gregory's Point twice over. There were thirty-six entries from Connecticut and New-York. Thirty started and twenty-five finished, each contestant receiving a prize.

HANOVER, N.H., June 29 -- Dartmouth's one hundred and twenty-third commencement was ushered in by as fair a day as ever the sun shone on. The exercises took place in the college church, where the following programme was carried out:

The West Side Lawn Tennis Club continued its Summer tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Eighty-ninth Street, near Central Park. Men's singles were the events of interest. The matches were scratch, and were open to members of the club only.

Recent acquirements of the stock of the Missouri Pacific Railroad by persons identified with the Chicago and Alton Railroad are beginning to attract much attention in railroad circles. There is a growing belief that the Chicago and Alton people will have an influential voice in the management of Missouri Pacific ere long.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 29 -- The business programme of the New-York State Press Association Convention was concluded this morning. During the proceedings Charles R. Skinner, as Chairman of the Legislative Committee, was presented with a gold watch in recognition of his services. In his report Mr. Skinner laid the defeat of the Anti-Libel bill to the differences which existed between Assemblyman Hennessy and his colleagues from Kings County.

NORTHPORT, L.I., June 29 -- John Benham, son of Centreport's Postmaster, and James Howard were arrested and held in $2,000 bail each by Justice Strawson this morning, charged with having caused the death of Mrs. Edward E. Sammis's three weeks' old babe last evening.
Wheat touched the lowest price on record yesterday.

New-Jersey can justly boast of having the fastest bicycle rider in the world, the best roads in the country, and the prettiest bicycle clubhouses in the Union. Arthur Zimmerman, the champion of the world, lives in a quiet little town in the southern part of the State, bat his name is a household word wherever the wheel is seen.

Boundless, the winner of the American Derby, arrived at the Sheepshead Bay track early yesterday morning, accompanied by his owner, Mr. Cushing; his trainer, McDaniels, and a couple of attendants. The horse seemed to be in perfect condition and made the trip from Chicago without apparent inconvenience. Boundless lay down in the car for about half the journey, so that he was not leg-weary on arrival.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- "Ed" Corrigan's br. c. Vassal pulled down the Kenwood Stakes to-day at Washington Park, with Fred Taral, his jockey, working as the boy never did before. It was a doubly popular victory, because the Hawthorne contingent had banked tons of coin upon his victory at the odds of 2 to 1, and Jockey Taral was cheered by the thousands in the grand stand.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 29 -- A bright spot in the gloom of financial depression was seen at the Gate City Bank Building in this city to-day. Since the defalcation of Lewis Redwico, which wrecked that bank. President Hill and other officers have been working assiduously to reach a stage whore they could repay depositors dollar for dollar, and this morning the work of paying oat the money began and was continued throughout the day.

The Duke of Veragua was yesterday decorated with the emblem of the Knight of the Grand Cross in the Order of the Knights of Columbus, of which he recently became a member. The ceremony took place at the Waldorf Hotel, where the Duke received a committee appointed to confer on him the badge.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., June 29 -- Perth Amboy fairly outdid itself to-day. The citizens turned out en masse, and enjoyed a holiday similar to those they take on circus days. Even tardy citizens were up early decorating and trimming their homes. All of the principal stores were hidden behind, bunting and flags. It was all in "commemoration of pure and wholesome water, June 29, 1893."
The programme for the annual Fourth of July celebration of the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, has finally been prepared.

NEW-YORK. THURSDAY, June 29 -- P.M. Tight money caused a big drop in stocks this morning, which lasted until half a dozen of the strongest basks in the city came to the rescue and produced the needed amount of funds. Thereupon the money rate dropped to 6 per cent, and stocks ad- vanced sharply.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 29 -- Jersey City experienced a politico-social sensation yesterday in the announcement that Mayor P.F. Wanser was married a year ago. Since the Mayor Treat to St. Lake's Hospital, New-York, vague statements have been made as to the presence of his wife at the institution. It was not known in this city that he was married.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 29 -- All those collegians and watermen whose heads did not ache too much from the over-night celebration of the Yale freshmen's victory or the convivial methods of expressing sympathy with the defeated crews of Harvard and Columbia, arose bright and early this morning. The perfect zephyr of a southern breeze, a blue and almost cloudless sky, and a flood of glorious sunshine greeted their awaking.

The two classes of boys who have enlisted on the training ship St. Mary's with a view to completing the two years' course in seamanship and navigation promised them by the Board of Education of this city are out of spirits and out of pocket, too, by the recent refusal of the Board of Estimate to appropriate the necessary funds wherewith to provide for the Summer cruise.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 29 -- While Gov. McKinley is preparing for a round of speechmaking at farmers' picnics, country fairs, and similar social gatherings prior to the opening of the Democratic campaign, his appointees in the various State institutions are making capital against him by the manner in which their duties are administered.

The Grand Trunk Railway does not propose to run excursion trains to the World's Fair -- at least, not enough to amount to anything, and it is trying to prevent the other roads from running any. An official letter has been issued protecting strongly against the extension at time recently granted on excursion tickets by the roads of the Central Traffic Association.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 29 -- To-morrow morning at 10:50 the great four-mile race on the Thames between Harvard and Tale will be rowed, wind and weather permitting. The prospects to-night are for one of the closest races that has ever been rowed between the representatives of the two universities.

The munificent sum of $21.71 has been sent by the Russian Government to Mr. Frederic Remington as an indemnity for the troubles he underwent in the Czar's dominions last Summer. Mr. Remington bore the special passport of the United States, and his trip to Russia was undertaken simply for the sake of making sketches connected with his private work, and was devoid of all political significance.

The members of the Fairchild Commission were apparently not concerned yesterday at the attack which Surveyor Lyon made on Wednesday on the legal status of the commission. Ex-Secretary Fairchild smiled when asked to define the status of the commission.

Mr. George R. Read, by order of Receiver Charles Siedler of the Lorillard Brick Works Company, yesterday offered for sale at the Real Estate Exchange Salesroom in Liberty Street some flat and residence property in this city and Brooklyn. Enough persons were present at the sale, but they seemed to be attracted more by curiosity than by a desire to bid.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Gov. Altgeld's action in pardoning the Anarchists has roused the residents of the town of Naperville, near this city, to such a pitch that they gave expression to their feelings last night by hanging the Governor in effigy.

LIVERPOOL, June 29 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef, pork, and hams in moderate demand. Bacon in poor demand; Cumberland cut, about 28 to 30 lb, easy at 55s; long clear middles, about 45 lb. dull at 53s. Shoulders -- About 12 to 18 lb, easy at 44s. Cheese in moderate damand; American finest white dull at 45s. Tallow in moderate demand. Spirits of turpentine and resin in poor demand.

The convention of the New-Jersey members of the League of American Wheelmen at Trenton has an importance beyond that of sport. The person who is impelled by inclination or compelled by smallness of means to exercise his lower limbs in the manner invented by ADAM is prone to regard the bicycle rider as a hybrid, compounded of pedestrian and horseback rider.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 29 -- Preliminary steps were taken yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel Kenmore for the organization of a New-York State Civil Service Reform League. The meeting was called by representatives of the local organizations in various parts of the State, and delegates were present from New-York, Brooklyn, Buffalo, Rochester, Geneva, and other places.

LONDON June 29 -- The sale of the art collection of Baron Revolstoke was continued to-day at the auction rooms of Christie. Manson Woods. The sum realized to-day was L10,300, while the total amount taken at the sale reaches L150,000.

Highland Beach, on the Sandy Hook Peninsula, is one of the beautiful places near the city for a day's excursion. Visitors can have an hour's sail down the bay, and can enjoy ocean and river bathing, rowing, fishing, and an excellent table.

The preliminary trial of the machinery of the new armored cruiser Maine was conducted, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday. The test embraced the running of both the main and auxiliary engines. At the works of the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company, the builders of the Maine's engines. It was said yesterday that the official trial of the engines would not take place for fully ten days.
READING, Penn., June 29 -- Pietro Buccieri, the murderer of Sister Hildaberta, was hanged here to-day. The drop fell at 11:00 and at 11:26 he was pronounced dead. Over 750 people wore present.

AMSTERDAM, June 29 -- The market here for silver has been, with the other markets of the world, greatly affected by the action of the Government of India in dealing with the currency question in that country. In the open market the price of fine silver has dropped from 63 guilders to 60 guilders per kilo.

Another army of graduates assembled in the grammar schools yesterday. White-frocked girls and happy-faced boys grasped their diplomas with pride. Some at them will go to the College of the City of New-York, some to the Normal School, but for many of them school days are over.

TRENTON, N.J., June 29 -- Speaker Thomas Flynn and Robert Adrain, President of the Senate, to-day exercised their prerogative as members of the State Board of Education. They attended the annual meeting, in which there was considerable interest because of the contest over several of the County Superintendents' election.
Five of the city banks came to the rescue of the market yesterday and averted a money panic. They were the First and Fourth National, the Chase, the Corn Exchange, and the Gallatin.

NEW-LONDON, June 29 -- One of the principal topics of conversation among not only the patrons of aquatics but also the members of the business community of New-London to-day was the enterprise exhibited by THE NEW-YORK TIMES. The opinion of a prominent merchant alone goes far to show what influence the encouragement of a live newspaper will have upon such an event as the annual university boat race.

AUGUSTA, Me., June 29 -- John L. Stevens, ex-Minister to the Hawaiian Islands, at the invitation of his fellow-citizens of this city, delivered an address this evening, in which he reviewed his course in Honolulu and discussed the question of annexation. He spoke as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 29 -- The first International Epworth League Conference began here to-day, and will continue during the next three days. By to-night it is expected that 5,000 delegates will be present. Before the conference is over it is thought that the number will be doubled. All day a constant stream poured into the city.
"I want to use your telephone," said a stylishly-dressed woman, with a haughty air, entering a Lexington Avenue drug store.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- American exhibitors will join in the celebration of the glorious Fourth, not as an association, but by united effort of the individual members of the newly-organized association. The American booths, pavilions, and sections in every building will be covered as much as possible with the national flag and bunting of red, white, and blue in the form of stars and stripes.

Senator John P. Jones of Nevada said yesterday at the Grand Hotel that if the next Congress repeals the Sherman act and does not pass a substitute which will go as far toward meeting the demands of the silver men as the present law a new political party will at once spring into existence.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 29 -- Just outside the city, on Lexington Avenue, which is one of the prettiest drives in this vicinity, is an old, colonial-looking stone house, behind which a high fence incloses a large field and bears the inscription. "Passaic Athletic Club."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 29 -- A distinguished visitor, in the person of Lieut. Albrecht Heese of the German Legation at Washington, was in camp to-day as the guest of Gen. Porter. Lieut. Heese gained his title by meritorious services in the artillery of the German Army.

DOWNSVILLE, N.Y., June 29 -- Hundreds of trout in a brook near Shinhopple, in Delaware County, have been killed by tar, which was turned into the stream from the chemical works in that place a few days ago. For several miles below the works the fish, have been killed, and trout, some of them very large, have either been washed ashore or floated down stream.

Frank Ellison, who assaulted W.H. Henriques, the broker, a few weeks ago, is still a prisoner in Jefferson Market. When his case was called before Justice Voorhis yesterday morning he was attired faultlessly in a suit of blue serge, new russet shoes, and a shirt immaculate in its whiteness.

LONDON, June 29 -- In the House of commons to-day Mr. Gladstone moved the adoption of the resolution, the terms of which were read in the House yesterday, providing for the quicker passage of the Irish Government act, (the Home Rule bill.)

Fully 2,000 veterans, representing ninety-two New-York regiments, will go at the expense of the State to Gettysburg to participate in the ceremonies which are to take place there on July 1, 2, and 3. Many other veterans will go at their own expense, and it is estimated that between 6,000 and 10,000 men will witness the dedication of New-York's monument on July 2.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Mr. Maurice J. Power has not declined the appointment by Secretary Carlisle to be Shipping Commissioner at New-York, but he may do so. He is here to talk with Secretary Carlisle and the President about the matter, and he will lay before both gentlemen some circumstances that may lead the Administration to conclude that it may be necessary to select another person for that office.

The Racing Board of the Losgue of American Wheelmen has made a ruling in the case John S. Johnson and F.H. Tuttle, who were suspended on Monday last. This case has excited widespread interest among wheelmen, owing to the prominence of the men concerned, and also from the fact that it is the second blow this season at the professionalism supposed to be prevalent in cycle-racing circles.
BOSTON, June 29 -- Elias Mailloux, charged with forgery and formerly accountant or the Public Works Department of the Province of Quebec, has been arrested in Salem.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Postmaster General Bissell has admitted Printers' Ink, the publication of George P. Rowell, to the privilege of the mails as second-class mail matter. This publication had been accepted as second-class matter from 1888 until January, 1892, when Postmaster General Wanamaker, for reasons that have been set forth at great length in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, directed that it be excluded from the mails as matter of the second class.

It would be very easy to fall into serious error as to the future value of silver at the present moment. The collapse in the market caused by the action of the Indian Government is by no means likely to be permanent, and does not destroy the forces which, left to their legitimate operation, must give a genuine and reasonably-stable value to the metal.
Ex-President Benjamin Harrison is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He came to this city yesterday afternoon, accompanied by Mrs. McKee and her two children.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 29 -- A special train on the San Antonio and Aranaas Pass Road arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning from Breckenridge, bringing in the body of Frank Martin, the fireman, who was killed yesterday afternoon by John D. May, the train robber. The funeral of Martin occurred this afternoon, and was largely attended.

Rabbi Morris Plevein of 144 Gwinnett Street, Brooklyn, E.D., who was arrested on Wednesday charged by Herman Iglo with stealing a gold watch and chain belonging to Sigismund Ebenstein of New-York, was discharged from custody by Justice Goetting in the Lee Avenue Police Court yesterday.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 29 -- Silver is the all-absorbing topic in Mexico, and the Government is taking all possible measures to avert the worst effects of the crisis. A tax on all Federal salaries is being decreed. There is still talk of placing an export tax on silver dollars, and plans have beep proposed for keeping all the gold mined in Mexico within the country, so as gradually to acquire a gold fund.

BOSTON, June 29 -- The annual meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa of Massachusetts was held in Sanders Theatre, Harvard College, to-day, and, as usual, a distinguished speaker and a poet gave high character to the literary proceedings. The oration was by Gen. Francis A. Walter, President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who spoke on college athletics.

As trolley car No. 23 of the Union Electric Road was leaving the station at Boston Avenue and One Hundred and Seventy-fifth Street yesterday afternoon the brake on the car broke. The car became unmanageable and overtook car No. 59 before the current was shut-off. The front platform of car No. 23 and the rear platform of the other car were emashed.
ORANGE, N.J., June 29 -- The commencement exercises of the Orange High School passed off without disturbance in Music Hall this evening, to the surprise of many in the audience.

The course of the principal banks whose Presidents are members of the Clearing House Committee in taking out certificates yesterday to the amount of $6,000,000 and loaning it on the Exchange was a prompt and judicious use of extraordinary resources to meet an emergency of considerable severity.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- After ten heats trotted and paced to-day, only one of the three classes was disposed of at Point Breeze, leaving four events for to-morrow, when the meeting ends. The attendance was the best of the week and the sport higher in class than that of the preceding days.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- While the United States is expending $100,000 in a barn-like addition to the Federal Building here, on which $28,000 has been spent in repairs in the last ten years, and on which $50,000 should now be expended to make it habitable, the City Building Inspector is having an examination of the structure made which will probably result in the condemnation of the main building.

Considerable regret is expressed in New-York cricket circles over the news that Cambridge University has given up its proposed visit to the United States this season. The Intercollegiate Cricket Association had intended to invite the Englishmen to a college game, and the skill which has been displayed at Haverford College, the University of Pennsylvania, and Harvard this season guaranteed that they would have been given a good game.

Those Old Settlers of Chicago gave away about a dozen gold medals at their picnic the first of the week to various unique persons whom they thought deserving of them, one going to "the girl working longest in same family." This was bestowed upon Emma Sohillinger, now forty-four years old, who has worked in the same family since September, 1859.

"East Seventy-first Street, between Third and Park Avenues, looks as if fortifications had been thrown up hastily there to bar the advance of an enemy from the north," said Dr. Robert S. Morris of 146 East Seventy-first Street yesterday. "On the south side of the street is a deep and wide ditch, above which frowns a five-foot wall of paving stones and earth covering about four-fifths of the sidewalk.
DENVER, Col., June 29 -- Every smelter and every mine in Colorado will be closed.
Postmaster Van Cott yesterday appointed fifty-five mail carriers from the eligible list of those who had passed civil service examinations.

The Middle States championship tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the Orange Club courts, Mountain Station, N.J. The result of the afternoon's play leaves first place between A.E. Foote, the Yale champion, and W. Gordon Parker, the Inter-Club champion of Kings County. The two will meet in the final round this afternoon and a great match is expected, with Parker as the favorite for first place.
The following notice was issued yesterday to the lawyers of Kings County:
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The President to-day made the following appointments:
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

City Clerk George W. Stage of Painesville, Ohio who left town under suspicious circumstances on Monday, has been arrested in Columbus. After failing to negotiate the certified checks in Cleveland, he went to Columbus, secured money on a check, and was arrested. As far as is known he had in his possession certified checks amounting to about $12,000.

PARIS, June 29 -- Upon the opening of the session to-day of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration Bit Charles Russell of counsel for Great Britain said that he had obtained more evidence in regard to hair seals, concerning which Senator John T. Morgan, one of the American arbitrators, had made inquiries yesterday.

Silver had another hard time in yesterday's market. London, as usual, set the downward pace, which was rapid enough to make the market at the start one of such violent fluctuations that for a while no one could fix the price for the white metal.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 29 -- The exasperating French shore question has cropped up again in an unpleasant form in Newfoundland. French lobster packers have lately been importing supplies per British steamer Harlaw from Canada and the United States both at Bonne Bay and St. George's Bay.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, Kaaterskill, N.Y., June 29 -- The opening of the big Hotel Kaaterskill to-day was most auspicious, and already nearly a hundred guests have registered. Many of them came up by way of the Stony Clove Railroad from Phoenicia, but those who came by the Otis elevator route declare it the most delightful ride they ever took.
The doors or all the public schools in the city were closed yesterday and the scholars put up their books. How the young girls and boys are ready for two months of idling and healthy play.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- It rained just enough to make the Washington Park track suitable for Pessara's going, and Walcott Campbell's bay handicap horas, splendidly ridden by Fred Taral, pulled down the Oakwood Handicap, worth about $6,000, after Ed Corrigan had planned a victory with his entry. Riley, Huron, and Helen N. sot a flying pace, closely followed by Highland, the field well bunched.

The Grand Jury of Kings County has made a vigorous presentment against the Mayor and Board of Aldermen of the City of Brooklyn for the scandalous manner in which valuable railroad franchises have been granted to favored corporations while another offering much more favorable terms to the city was excluded.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A method of increasing the fighting capacity of the navy and of bringing the efficiency of the old ships-of-war nearer the standard of the modern vessels is under consideration by Commodore Sampson, the Naval Chief of Ordnance. It is likely that in his annual report, which will be submitted in October, he will recommend certain important changes.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Cleveland has yielded to the pressure upon him by the business men of the country, and has called an extraordinary session of the Fifty-third Congress, to convene Aug. 7.

The test case of Receiver Freedman of the Manhattan Athletic Club against J. Chester Chamberlain, a broker, for $25 unpaid dues has been decided by the General Term of the Supreme Court against Mr. Chamberlain. The case was brought to determine whether the club members could be held responsible for the dues which the by-laws provided must be paid in advance.

Heinrlch Conried, manager of the Irving Place German Theatre, returned yesterday from Europe. He traveled all over Germany and Austria in search of new talent for the coming season. Mr. Conried said: "I have Waited Frankfort, Cassel, Munich, Vienna, Buda-Peath, Ems, Wiesbaden, Leipsic, Berlin, Nuremberg.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Senator Lodge said to-day: "I confidently believe that the repeal of the purchasing clauses of the Sherman act would now pass both Houses, but the friends of sound money and the people who are now suffering in the business world must bear in mind that the time for any concession or compromise is past, and we must have repeal and nothing but repeal.

Yesterday afternoon the final round in the Middle States championship tournament was played on the Orange Club courts, Mountain Station, N.J. The rival players were W. Gordon Parker, the champion of the Inter-Club Association of Kings County, and A.E. Foote, the champion of Yale University. The knowing ones expected Parker to win, but the Yale man took the match in straight sets, but one of which, the last, was at all close.
For the third time in three years Yale has won the dramatic race which plays itself out for the delight of tens of thousands between the high banks of the Thames above New-London.

The graduating exercises of Brooklyn Grammar School No. 15 were held Thursday evening in Association Hall, on Fulton Street, near Bond. The auditorium was crowded with friends of the graduates. Charles B. Teale of the School Committee presided.

Inspector Peter Seery of the Bureau of Combustibles in the Fire Department has issued 260 licenses for the sale of fireworks, in anticipation of the Fourth of July celebration. Five dollars is paid for each license, the money being turned over to the Pension Fund of the Fire Department.

The breadstuffs dealings were to a fair extent, but at lower prices, especially for near months on the money situation. Wheat closed at 1 1/2 c decline on July, with a desire to realize freely; there were good weather reports for the crop. Corn was slow and rather easy, although but little changed in price. Flour was on offer at easy prices and had a slow sale.

At the last meeting of the Park Board a communication was received from Prof. Alexis A. Julien of Columbia College, asking the board, in the high name of justice to the late King Rameses, to restore the obelisk in Central Park to something like its ancient appearance by gliding the intaglio work of the hieroglyphies, as it was gilded when the Egyptian workmen finished the job.

The ruling of Postmaster General Bissell admitting Printers' Ink to the mails as seoond-class mail matter is accepted with satisfaction by that large portion of the newspaper fraternity which has watched with close interest the struggle which George P. Rowell has made in securing his rights.

A Broadway car was rocking along on its uptown trip late in the afternoon, and the men passengers were going through their ordinary performance of reading newspapers, each disregarding the presence of anybody besides himself in all the world. Near the middle of the car sat a man perhaps thirty-five years old. His newspaper was held loosely in his hand.

BRISTOL, R.I., June 30 -- The Rogers boat Colonia had another trial trip to-day, and this time showed something of her qualities. In a fair southwear-breeze aho stood up well and waltzed away from the famous forty-six-footer Wasp, which, was out to give her a try, as if the latter was standing still. Her mainsail now seta very much better and looks as though it might come out all right.

The first half of 1893 has made history rapidly for financial and commercial interests in this country. On this account the record of business embarrassments for that period, as compiled by Bradstreet's possesses an importance commensurate with the excitement, the uncertainty, and the depression that have prevailed.

Judge Lawrence, writing the decision for the General Term of the Supremo Court, has decided that the powers of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children must be upheld. In the case of Zelda Sanders, a child actrees, and Regaloncita, the little dancer, daughter of Mrs. Charlotte Ewer, both of whom were arrested by the society, an appeal was taken to the General Term.

A small boy once saw Charles Sumner's frank on a public document and, avaricious of autographs, straightway sat down and wrote to him, saying: "By the aid of Webster's unabriged, the Latin and Greet lexicons, and the assistance of my High School teacher, I have made it out to be your name. If that is so, and you can do it again, please do it for me."

FORT LEE, N.J., June 30 -- Peter De Lacy's poolrooms were raided this afternoon while the place was crowded with customers, and jet hardly any of the patrons knew that the book makers had been arrested. The complaint was made by James Smith of Hackensack, who is a correspondent of a New-York newspaper. The warrant was issued by Justice Cumming of Hackensack and was served by Constable Herring, also of Hackensack.
Favoring conditions from various quarters served yesterday to make the financial atmosphere clearer than it has been for some time.

Practice trials indicate that fast time will be made at the twelfth annual meet of the Kings County Wheelmen at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, this afternoon. The four-lap track has been specially prepared for the races. W.F. Murphy rode a practice mile over it yesterday in 225. Malby, the trick rider, will be present, and a band will furnish music between the events.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, June 30 -- P.M. Prices were better on the Stock Exchange to-day. In the morning the market was dull and steady, except in the case of Sugar, but afternoon there was more life in the trading, and a good deal of strength developed.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 30 -- The stroke of 12 o'clock to-night will sound the death knell of the saloon in South Carolina, the birth of the monopolistic sale of liquors by the State, and the throwing out at employment of many hundred citizens, whose business will be confiscated should they attempt to prolong it after the day set by the State for the inauguration of her own business and political scheme.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 30 -- After several days of hard legal sparring in the United States Circuit Court before Justice Howell Jaokson an important decision was rendered to-day in the noted suit brought by the receivers of the Richmond Terminal Company for the control of the Georgia Central Road.

It was in search of game almost as big as herself that the little whaling schooner Charles H. Hodgson sailed out of New-Bedford, Mass., a little more than a year ago. Besides Capt. Smith, her skipper, she had on board a crew of seventeen men. The vessel put into this port for repairs yesterday, having been damaged by a Hatteras storm and the untoward sinking of a captive whale which was moored alongside the craft.

It has been discovered mat the "John Corcoran" who was arrested last Saturday night on a charge of embezzling $5,000 from C. Godfrey Gunther's Sons, fur dealers at 184 Fifth Avenue, is Lieut. J. Watson Cochran of Company D. Seventh Regiment.

Cicero Harrison, seventy-eight years old, a cousin of ex-President Harrison, mysteriously disappeared from the steamship Guyandotte, which arrived at this port last night, and on which vessel he had engaged passage from Norfolk to this city. He was accompanied by his daughter, Mrs. Mary Oliver, of Jackson, Mich., who told the story of his disappearance.

Five weeks from Monday Congress will meet. It will be asked by the President to repeal the act of 1890, or so much of it as compels the purchase of 4,500,000 ounces of silver per month with paper redeemable in gold. Mr. CLEVELAND has adopted this policy at the urgent request of the business men of the country expressed in various ways in all parts of the Union.
CHICAGO, June 30 -- About 2,400,000 adults and children paid their way in the exposition grounds in the month which closed to-day, the average daily attendance being 80,000.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- There is to be an examination at the New-York Navy Yard July 6 of applicants for the position of Master Shipwright in the Construction Department. The pay is $6 per day. Two examinations were held in 1891, and the candidates who stood highest failed to obtain sufficient percentage to secure the place.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- The market has been steady all day. There was a number of orders to buy Metropolitan Traction. This stock has been sold some by New-York, but has developed numerous local orders to buy for cash. About 2 o'clock, on a rumor that Congress would be convened in early extra session, quotations advanced rapidly, closing near the highest prices of the day.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- Anthony J. Drexel died this morning in Carlsbad, whither he had gone to spend the Summer.

John F. Kavanagh, a lawyer, who gives his address as 320 Broadway, was in the Bureau for the Collection or Assessments and Arrears, in the Stewart Building, about noon yesterday. Charles W. Chipp, the Assistant Collector, saw him there and at once became much interested. He hurried to the office of Disbursing Clerk Charles A. Clark, in the Auditing Bureau, as he happened to Know that Mr. Clark wanted to see Mr. Kavanagh very much.

It was after the hour for closing business upon the Street yesterday when the news came that President Cleveland had named Aug. 7 as the date for convening Congress in extra session. The announcement was received with universal approval and complimentary comment.

It would seem as if the politicians who misrule the City of Brooklyn, looking ahead and seeing the just punishment that the unscrupulous operations of the ring to which they belong would surely bring down upon them, had gone so far as to have the laws of the State fixed so as to protect them.

"Gettysburg": Only the railway fares of surviving participants in the battle of Gettysburg will be paid on the occasion of the commemoration, July 2 and 3. To obtain the free transportation to Gettysburg and return, write to Gen. Daniel E. Sickles or Col. Zabriskie, 23 Fifth Avenue.
LONDON, June 30 -- The foreign guests invited to attend the wedding or the Duke of York and Princess May, which will take place next Thursday, are beginning to arrive.

This afternoon the Coney Island Jockey Club will bring its meeting to a close with the running of the Realization stakes as the feature. In this race, which will be worth about $25,000, Boundless, the winner of the American Derby, will have to meet and defeat St. Leonrads, Ramapo, Sir Walter, and the Sunbeam colt, the latter being an unknown quantity in the race.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The effect of the announcement of the President's proclamation upon Senators and Representatives in the city was very marked, Senator Voorheos, (Dem., Ind.,) Chairman of the Finance Committee, first knew of the President's act when informed by a reporter. He was not surprised.

In the Postmaster's room in the Federal Building yesterday afternoon a double reception was held, the incoming Postmaster, Charles W. Dayton, being congratulated by a number of his friends, and the outgoing Postmaster, Cornelius Van Cott, received many handshakes and kind expressions from those who have been under him for four years, and also from a number of his personal friends.

There was hardly a feature to the racing at Sheepshead Bay track yesterday. It there was one, it was the defeat of Lady Violet in the Mermaid States, for three-year-old fillies. That so good a filly as she should have been beaten in the race was a pity, but he was hardly the Lady Violet of a year ago, or Afternoon would never hare caught and beaten her in the stretch as she did yesterday.

VALETTA, Malta, June 30 -- The Britlsn cruisers Edgar and Phaeton, belonging to the British Mediterranean squadron, arrived here to-day, having on board the surviving officers and crew of the battle ship Victoria. The Edgar brought 18 officers and 140 men and the Phaeton 9 officers and 127 men, a total of 27 officers and 267 men.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The regular troops are hampered in their work by the absence of many officers on detached service. Secretary Lamont is daily more and more embarrassed by this condition. The detail last week of twenty-two officers as Indian Agents has drawn officers from posts where their services were greatly needed, while other detached duty, some of it quite unmilitary and unnecessary in its character, has deprived the troops of their commanding officers.

TRENTON, N.J., June 30 -- The Mercer County Clubhouse was the Mecca of bicyclists to-night. A bicycle outfit acted as a card of admission, and the parlors were crowded with a large and enthusiastic gathering. While the meeting was in progress, hundreds of persons lined the sidewalk outside and watched an artist give a stereopticon display.
Byrd Douglas Wise, the little six-year-old son of ex-Congressman John S. Wise, met with a serious accident on Tuesday night, and it is feared that the boy will lose the eight of his left eye.

Veterans of the civil war began their annual pilgrimage yesterday to Gettysburg, Penn., where the New-York State monument to the dead soldiers is to be dedicated to-morrow. A special train left the Pennsylvania Railroad station in Jersey City at 9 A.M., having on board the Gettysburg Monument Committee, Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, Gen. Henry W. Slocum, who will deliver the oration at the unveiling of the monument; Gen. Daniel Butterfield.

Joseph Fox of 443 Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, E.D., appeared before Justice Goetting yesterday morning to complain against Dr. Charles Maguire of Wythe Avenue and South Third Street, whom he accused of attempting to murder him.

At the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway, yesterday two sales were had in foreclosure proceedings. Mr. Bryan L. Kennelly sold 67 Montgomery Street, east side, 47.6 1/2 feet north of Cherry Street, 21.10 1/2 by 58.7 by 20.5 by 57.5 1/2, with two-story frame store and dwelling in front and brick stable in rear, and strip of land 2.2 1/2 by 29.8.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 30 -- New-Haven is about the Happiest city in the United States to-night. There are 100,000 people here, and every one of them wears blue in his heart and not on his face. The best pare of it is that the victorious crew is here and helping the local citizens to celebrate in the traditional orthodox fashion.

NEW-LONDON, June 30 -- Everybody was satisfied that he had seen the best race over rowed on the Thames. The Harvard men, while naturally disappointed at the result, had no complaints to mate. They were satisfied that the race had been rowed on its merits, and that the best crew had won.

DURANGO, Mexico, June 30 -- About fifteen years ago Stephen Zakany, a Polish nobleman, arrived in Mexico and purchased one of the largest and most beautiful haciendas in the State of Sinaloa. He settled down on his new property and became known all along the Pacific coast of Mexico on account of his wealth, and enterprise.
School Commissioner Randolph Guggenheimer, in speaking to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday about the school ship St. Mary's, said:
President Cleveland arrived in this city from Washington last night, and at once started on the Oneida, E.C. Benedict's steam yacht, for Buzzard's Bay.

The palace Sound steamers Maine and New-Hampshire of the Stonington Line are carrying crowds of tourists to the New-England Summer resorts. This favorite line is the only direct Sound route to Narragansett Pier and Watch Hill.
ALBANY, June 30 -- Gov. Flower was asked to-day what he thought of the financial situation. He replied:

HALIFAX, N.S., June 30 -- Admiral Sir John Hopkins, who succeeds Admiral Tryon in command of the Mediterranean fleet, will take with him his flag officers -- Lieut. H.G.G. Sandemon, Secretary-Paymaster W.H. Rowe, and Capt. William Desvoux Hamilton. A new Admiral on appointment always selects his own Flag Captain and staff.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The President's determination to leave the city was only reached this morning, and his departure so suddenly leaves a number of important appointments agreed upon unsigned. It is understood that the President will transact only the most urgent public business, while at Buzzard's Bay, and what official announcements are to be made will be given out at the Executive Mansion in Washington.

COLOMBIA, S.C., June 30 -- Gov. Tillman has received a letter from Dr. Joseph Allard, pastor of the French Congregational Church of Fall River, Mass., asking what inducements would be offered to French-Canadians, including a large number of Roman Catholics, to settle in South Carolina.
Silver bullion certificates advanced to 69, and closed there. Transactions represented 100,000 ounces.

The Custom House Investigating Commission at the Barge Office yesterday brought out some important facts as to the manner in which the Appraiser's Office has been conducted. Messrs. Macfarlane, Magone, and Dunn were present.

TRENTON, N.J., June 30 -- From present indications the bicycle meet and races to be given to-morrow by the New-Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, under the auspices of the Mercer County Club, promise to sclipse anything of the kind ever seen in this section of the country. This city is crowded with wheelmen from all parts of the State.

District Attorney Nicoll received a letter yesterday through Justice Van Brunt from Dr. J. B. Andrews, Superintendent of the State Asylum for Insane at Buffalo, respecting the condition of Edward M. Field. The communication was in answer to a question from the District Attorney regarding the privileges allotted to Mr. Field, his mental faculties, and particularly "what precautions have been taken to expose the charge of malingering."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 30 -- The statement published in the Brooklyn papers to-night that Lieut. and Quartermaster A.R. Baird had resigned his position in the Forty-seventh Regiment because of his dissatisfaction over Major Pettigrew's disgrace was denied by Col. Eddy to-night. He said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES to-night:

The regular monthly business meeting of the Baptist Tabernacle last evening was marked by a number of exciting features. Several of the women present became very angry, and had it not been for the protection of a few brothers of the church the Rev. James W. Pntnam, the assistant pastor, might have regretted a hasty sentence he uttered.

Suit has been begun against the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Company by the Holmes Refining Company of Buffalo to recover $165,000 damages for loss occasioned by the fire which recently destroyed the refining company's plant in that city. The charge is made that the flames were started by live coals dropped with a lot of cinders by the fireman of the railroad's engine.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Building Commissioner Toolen made a personal examination of the Federal Building to-day, and then prepared a statement of his inspection, in which he informed the people of Chicago of the dangerous condition of the building, and advised the tenants to get out of it if they valued their lives as worth saving.

In a press dispatch from Washington, reporting the opinions of prominent officers of the Treasury Department concerning the precautions taken to prevent the introduction of cholera from Europe, it is said: "The system of inspection on both sides of the Atlantic is believed to be as nearly perfect as it can be made."

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- To the surprise of Pay Inspector Stevenson's friends the President to-day disapproved the recommendations of the board for his promotion to the highest grade in his corps, and remanded the case to Secretary Herbert for reconsideration.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Scared speculators had to pay 60 cent. interest to-day for money to carry wheat. Liquidation was on a stupendous scale. It was the last day before the long-anticipated July delivery, and marked a crisis in the wheat trade. Numbers of unlucky traders had held on to their July wheat, hoping for some bulge or spurt on the bull side to let them out.

CORNING, N.Y., June 30 -- The Democratic County Committee of the Second District of Steuben County met at Addison to-day. The Hill faction was represented by Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, and F.G. Babcock of Hornellsville. The Cleveland Democracy was led by Edwin S. Walker of Corning, George N. Orcutt, and De Menville Page of Hornellsville.

The rumors which have been freely circulated in Catholic circles for some time looking toward important changes in the ecclesiastical administration of the Archdiocese of New-York yesterday culminated in a positive statement from one high in the Church that Archbishop Corrican would soon be relieved from part of the onerous duties which now devolved upon him.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 30 -- A novel race will start from the town of Tyler, in Eastern Texas, the home of Gov. Hogg and numerous other Texas statesmen. A purse of $5,000 is offered by Clyde Seabury to the winner and $1,000 for the animal taking second place.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 1. -- The Forty-seventh Regiment and the separate companies have not left an enviable record.

MONTREAL, July 1. -- The preparations for the twelfth International Christian Endeavor Convention, to be held in this city, are now practically completed. The delegates will begin to arrive on Tuesday, July 4, and those from the United States will celebrate Independence Day on British soil.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- The action of the Nurserymen's Association of the United States in adopting resolutions denouncing the exposition management for alleged discrimination against the pomological interests at the World's Fair followed similar action by the Columbian Horticultural Society of North America, and was the culmination of the grievance which the fruit growers had against the management of the World's Columbian Exposition Company.

LONG ISLAND CITY, July 1. -- It cost Mayor Sanford $1,700 to be elected, last Fall. After he was elected, it cost him another $3,000 to oust Mr. Gleason, who tried to hold on to the office. City Treasurer Bleckwenn a few days ago evolved the plan of getting up a public subscription for Mr. Sanford to reimburse him for this outlay.

BARKER. I think I may safely say that Barker has been the bane of my existence. We were at school together, and he made me break the rules so often that I was never free from punishment or ever able to come within measurable distance of the height of my ambition -- the good-conduct prize.

CHAUTAUQUA, July 1 -- The Chautauqua Assembly season of 1893 opened to-day. It is the twentieth year of the assembly, and in the course of the season a reunion will be held of those who attended the first assembly.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 1. -- The week at Oys- ter Bay has been a busy one, and the members of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club have added to their already ample laurels as hosts. The cozy clubhouse on Coutre Island has been the scene of much gayety and enjoyment and a number of distinguished visitors have been guests of the club within a few days.

A millionaire naval architect might almost be regarded as one of the wonders of the age. Millionaires are great patrons of the royal sport of yachting. In fact, to keep up with the times in the yachting world one has to be a millionaire. This can easily be seen by the fact that to own and race one of the cup defenders thin year will leave very little change out Of $100,000.

The acquittal at Alderman McKee, the setting aside by Judge Pratt of the award to the Long Island Water Supply Company, and the discovery that the Penal Code has been so amended asto prevent the Grand Jury from indicting public officials for misdemeanors, have made the Brooklyn spoilsmen feel quite happy.
The President's action in calling the extra session of Congress so much sooner than was anticipated had a marked effect on the leading markets, and a more buoyant feeling prevailed.

G.P. Putnam's Sons have published "Lorenzo de Medici: A Historical Portrait," by Edith Carpenter, one of those unpretentious little volumes, written for the pleasure of writing and agreeable to readers for their reflected contentment, in the composition of which women have always been adepts.

In one respect at least the stanch ship Falcon, which is to take Lieut. Peary, his wife, and an exploring party into the polar regions, is fitted out more completely than any other vessel which ever sailed upon a similar expedition.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- It is understood that in a few days a general reorganization of the Weather Bureau will be made. No action has yet been taken by Secretary Morton in regard to the recommendations made by Assistant Attorney General Colby, who conducted the recent investigation into irregularities in the bureau.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have just returned from a visit to the World's Fair, and am anxious to inform those of your readers who are about contemplating a visit to the Columbian Exposition that the many extortions imputed to Chicago do not exist.

LONG BBANCH, N.J., July 1. -- A goodly number of sporting men, cottagers, and hotel guests gathered at the beautiful Hollywood grounds this morning, to witness the Futurity Prize shoot, one of the annual live-pigeon matches. Of the eleven men entered but eight appeared, as follows: Fred Hoey, L.S. Thompson, L.D. Davenport, R.A. Welch, L. Edwards, J.S. Williams, T.D. Thomas, and Edgar Gibbs Murphy.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 1. -- The great State of New-York is about to pay honorable tribute lo the 7,100 of her sons who were killed and wounded in those fateful days in July, 1863, on the picturesque and now historic field of Gettysburg.

Mrs. Dorothy Sonwell, or "Little Dot, the snake charmer," as she is better known, who was poisoned by a vicious rattlesnake on Friday, was feeling better yesterday. She is at the New-York Hospital, and the physicians there say they hope she will be able to be out in a day or two. She is in no danger of dying from the poison.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Ten thousand people saw the Queen Isabella Stakes won by J.J. McCafferty and his great filly, Helen Nichols. The race was at Washington Park and was worth $16,000. It was won without the application of the whip or spur to the sides of the beautiful daughter of Iroquois. Maid Marian, the Kendall stable filly, was outclassed, and was beaten for the place by Dare Vela.

Probably the high-water mark of the Summer exodus to Europe was reached yesterday, when nine tourist-laden transatlantic steamships sailed down the bay. Many persons of note were among the voyagers, including the following:

-- Arago, the physicist and astronomer, has had a steamship and a boulevard named for him; his portrait was painted long ago by Ary Soheffer, and is now in the Observatory at Paris. He is remembered at Estagel in the eastern Pyrcnees, the village where he was born, by a bronze status modeled by the late Oliva, sculptor; also by a bronze statue at Perpignan, designed by Meroie.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 1 -- one chronic croaker who has been predicting a bad season and kindred calamities for the Jersey coast resorts -- Asbury Park in particular -- retired from business to-night. The sight of the crowds slighting from too trains at the station was too much for him. The visitors have been pouring in all the week, but the rush was the greatest to-day.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- There is a small but very beautiful building which commands a lovely view of one of the picturesque lakes at the World's Fair, in which the merchant tailors of the United States exhibit the choicest and best specimens of their art. New-York City merchant tailors have responded to the call of the craft for representation here with the same promptness and enterprise that characterize her other active business men.

From Lille, the ancient capital of Flanders and the ancient residence of the booklover and man-hater, Philip, Duke of Burgundy, called the Good, comes this work by Auguste Angellier. Professor in the local faculty of letters. He has decided opinions on the art of literary criticism, and has used 1,000 large octavo pages, printed in bourgeois type, not to express, but to apply them.

STONINGTON, Conn., July 1 -- A pair of swallows have got a very dainty home in a curious, hard, conical mansion on a post near the gateway of the railway station in this ancient Puritan borough. For several years the birds have had the same home, coming from the far South in the second week in May, and none of the early birds is greedy enough to try to take the queer house from them.

An old journalist of Toulouse, M. Etienne Vige, has brought over a score of paintings, which are shown at Bonaventure's bookshop in the Hotel Imperial. Their owner has the usual roseate idea of the value of his precious canvases, but they are worth examination, and in some cases are valuable pictures. There are old French, old Dutch, and old Italian pictures in the collection.

Trainloads of veterans left the oity yesterday for Gettysburg, where the New-York State monument, "Victory," is to be unveiled and dedicated to-day. Many soldiers went to the battlefield on Friday, among them being Gens. Stokies, Slocum, Butterfield, and Greene.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 1. -- This quiet town among the bills of Western Connecticut has already welcomed a large number of Summer guests. Ridgefield has always been a favorite Summer resort for numbers of New-York City people. Following is a list of those who are now occupying cottages here for the season:
