WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The President's call for an extra session of Congress in August seems to have given almost universal satisfaction, except to the uncompromising free-coinage men, and the comments made by Senators and Representatives here today have been almost uniformally favorable.

VALETTA, Malta, July 1. -- Notwithstanding the efforts that are being made by the naval authorities here to prevent the survivers of the Victoria disaster from giving any information concerning the loss of the vessel, the following story of the casualty is given by a sub-officer who was attached to the Victoria:

Richard Dillon, a policeman in the Humbold Street Station, Brooklyn, gained distinction Friday night by rescuing the families of John Tucker, William Wiley, and an aged woman, Mrs. Garrison -- eleven people in all -- from the flamas at 318 Driggs Avenue.

Mr. JOHN L. STEVENS, lately our Minister to the Hawaiian Islands, has made an explanation to his fellow-citizens of Augusta, Me., of his official conduct in connection with the annexation movement. He furnishes the real explanation somewhat unconsciously by plainly showing that from first to last he was an intense partisan of the annexation policy, and affords ground for believing the charge that he worked zealously to promote the movement and to give it success.

The manufacture of the new Krag-Jorgensen rifle for the United States Army, it is announced, will be begun to-morrow at the United States Armory at Springfield, Mass. The appropriation of $400,000 made by the last Congress for use in the manufacture of a new rifle for the army became available on July 1.

President ELIOT of Harvard University, in his speech to the alumni on Commencement Day, announced that the Law School had raised its stamdard by requiring, after the year 1896, the degree of A.B., S.B., or Ph. B. as a prerequisite for admission to its courses. There is already such a requirement in the Divinity School, and President ELIOT expressed the hope that hereafter it would be adopted for the Medical School.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- Arthur Zimmerman, the champion bicycle rider of the world, won three championship races at the meeting held here this afternoon, but the Union County Roadsters carried off the honors of the day. They captured both the loving cup and the gold medal offered by THE NEW-YORK TIMES in the team race, and left for home to-night in a very happy mood.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 1 -- The Union Counts Roadsters own this town to-night. A dispatch received from Trenton late this afternoon announced that the Roadsters had won THE NEW-YORK TIMES loving cup given to the winner of the team race. A.C. Watson, the crack rider of the club, came in first. The other riders were C. Willis and N.H. Money.

As the vacation days come on, the activities of the children become almost uncontrollable. They plan long walks, rambles, and rides. They are not "going to look into a book until next September." The tonnis players, the croquet experts, and all the rest are eager to begin a long series of games.

There was quietude in the old Browning mansion, as was to be expected of such staid respectability at so late an hour of the night. Only one light was burning, and that was in David Pierson's room, just underneath the caves. Only one indweller was awake, and that one was David Pierson himself, but he made no sound as he paced the floor in slippered feet.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 1 -- That portion of the Texas border between El Paso and Presidio has lone been known as "the bloody peninsula," owing to the fact that it is the rendezvous of a numerous band of cut-throats, robbers, and smugglers. The killing yesterday of Capt. Frank Jones of Company D, Texas Rangers, is the latest crime committed by these Mexican desperadoes.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 1 -- Every Saturday records a large number of arrivals at the George Hotel, Black Rock. The gayety is at its height at this beautiful Sound resort, and hotel guests, cottagers, and those owning Summer homes in the vicinity join in making the teas, fates and musicales events to which all look forward with pleasure.

In the course of a very courteous interview with a representative of THE NEWYORK TIMES Mr. HARRISON was kind enough to give his recollections, flavored with a few personal reflections, upon the history of the Sherman law. He did not "care to go into a full discussion of the financial, question," remarking humorously that that "would require a large book."
What a blessing those women are who go about "picking up the dropped stitches in life," who remember what others forget and who know just what to do and how to do it in every emergency!

As was foreseen, the Social Democrats surpassed all the other parties as regards their organization. Many factories being closed, hundreds of young workmen placed themselves as volunteers for the whole day at the service of the party leaders. Even last evening they distributed 100,000 pamphlets in Berlin. As a proof of their admirable organization I may mention the following:

"It is impossible to say what will be the practical result of the experiment about to be made in South Carolina with the new liquor law," said Congressman William H. Brawley of that State to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., July 1 -- The marvelous feat of making the trip from the Grand Central Station in New-York City to the top of Kaaterskill Mountain in three hours and thirty-five minutes has been accomplished. The flying journey was performed to-day by the fast Catskill Mountain special over the Hudson River Railroad.

The Fourth! Fireworks! There is an asso- ciation of ideas in these words quite independ- ent of the alliteration, for in every juvenile mind the two ideas grow up together and age is powerless to destroy the vigor of this strong youthful impression, as the enthusiastic crowds which witness the annual firework displays abundantly testify.

The twelfth annual race meet of the Kings County Wheelmen and the opening races upon the new bicycle track at Eastern Park, Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon. In its long series of race meets this club has never had an unfavorable day and yesterday demonstrated the fact that the club was still on the good books of the weather bureau.

In spite of the light and variable breeze which prevailed during the greater part of the day, the eighth annual regatta of the New-Rochelle Yacht Club yesterday was a great success. Thirty-eight boats started in the various classes and almost all finished the course, though the times of all could not be taken on account of the lateness of the finish.

"An' it's Tommy this, an' Tommy that, an' Tommy, set out of the way. But How are you, Mr. Atkins,' when The band begins to play; " sings Mr. Kipling, the poet laureate of the defenders of "The Widder," as the British troops feelingly refer to their Queen.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 1 -- The captured San Antonio and Aransas Pass train robber and murderer, whose alias is John D. May, has been, transferred from the Wilson County Jail to the Karnes County Jail at Helena, where he will be kept until Ms preliminary examination. He will then be brought to Bexar County Jail here for safe keeping until his case comes up for trial.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- After supper the wheelmen congregated in the Secretary's room at the Mercer County Wheelmen's Clubhouse on North Warren Street. The prizes, pronounced to be the best ever given at a Division meet, were arranged on a table for general inspection at 7:30 o'clock. Dr. G. Carleton Brown, Consul of the New-Jersey Division, who was the spokesman, presented the prizes.

In his valedictory remarks on the close of a lone and honorable career as the responsible head of the New-York Journal of Commerce, Editor David M. Stone permits himself to note that he has given forty-four years of his life to the service of his paper without a single vacation. It is a grave admission, yet Editor Stone makes it without a blush, and even seems rather to glory in it than to be ashamed.

BOSTON, July 1. -- Pauline Hall and her opera company began on Monday evening at the Tremont Theatre their Summer season, presenting, for the first time in Boston, Czibulka's "Amorita." It was well sung and played and handsomely mounted. That and the succeeding performance of the week have been liberally patronized, and the opera is announced to be continued "until further notice."

ISLIP, L.I., July 1. -- The season has opened auspielously. The well-known cottagers have all arrived, including the Wilmerdings, Cuttings. Livingstons, Demorests, Hollinses, Hollisters, Knapps, Paterses, and W.K. Van- derbilt. Among the last to arrive have been Lieut. H.C. Du Val, Bradish Johnson, H.L. Hyde, and M.F. Wharton.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Wheat shot upward to-day nearly 3c a bushel. Monthly deliveries accomplished without disaster, and export clearances of 2,000,000 bushels within three days, backed up by the calling together of the Congress, seemed to restore confidence and to give the market a bucyancy of feeling to which it has been a stranger for many a weary week.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- The annual meeting of the New-Jersey Division was called to order a few minutes after 9 o'clock by Chief Consul G. Carleton Brown. About sixty division members were present at the opening, but before the adjournment the clubhouse of the Mercer County Wheelmen, in which the meeting was, held was crowded to overflowing.

The Duke de Veragua departed from New-York on the French liner La Bretagne at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. He went on board the steamer Friday night, and there was no congregation of well-wishers gathered about to call him from his comfortable cabin.

In West Tenth Street, between Waverley Place and Greenwich Avenue, under the roof of a house the tenants of which are all hard-working people, lived a poor seamstress, eighteen years of age. Pretty, graceful, affable, but pale and thin with soft and delicate chestnut hair, she had the style of beauty that is praised in a woman of wealth.

The store of Marcus Co., jewelers, on the northwest corner of Broadway and Seventeenth Street, was robbed at noon yesterday when the place was crowded with customers and there was a throng of people in the street. But the thief was soon captured with his plunder.
The detailed list of sales of real estate at auction announced for the present week is here with given:
" -- There will be music at the Mall, Central Park, to-day at 4 P.M. by Rogers's Seventh Regiment Band.

AMERICUS, Ga., Jaly 1. -- Americus is an interior town, the home of Speaker Crisp and Editor Myrick, erstwhile candidate for Berlin. Mr. Myrick's paper is Crisp's organ. Before the Chicago Convention Myrick was an anti-Cleveland editor, and since his failure to be appointed on the consular force has resumed his antagonism.

-- Dr. J.W. Day of Waterloo, N.Y., who shipped about twenty head of trotters to France in March last, is having lots of trouble with the customs officials on the other side. Early in May he left Paris for Berlin with six horses, a roadcart, sulky, harness, and his private baggage. The doctor writes rom Berlin: "I am converted to free trade. The French have the roadcart.

The mystery surrounding the death of Cicero Harrison, the wealthy carriage manufacturer of Jackson, Mich., who was lost overboard from the steamship Guyandotte of the Old Dominion Line on Thursday night, has been solved as far as it ever is likely to be.

The city yard is at last coming to the front as of yore, and the old-fashioned methods are being adopted. Many years ago, when going out of town was only aspired to by the wealthy class, and with people of slender means was unheard of, the back of the house filled a need that was greatly enjoyed by the inmates.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- It is but fair to begin with Germany in reviewing the contributions of the nations to the Columbian Exposition, because the extent and the completeness of the German exhibits in almost every department and the evident effort to make them extensive and complete are the most obvious and striking facts of the exhibition.
The Board of Aldermen will meet to-morrow to receive the assessment rolls from the Department of Taxes and Assessment and then adjourn until Aug. 22.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Navy Department is preparing a new set of seals to be used in the office of the Secretary as well as in the different branches of the departmental service. The seal now in use is one of Antiquated pattern, being a representation of an eagle that is a good deal of a goose, mounted in an impossible attitude upon a very clumsy anchor.

GRASS VALLEY, Cal., July 1. -- A tramp shot and dangerously wounded a brakeman named Bruce at Gold Run several days ago and then escaped. Late last night he was found in an old foundry on the outskirts of Grass Valley, and was soon surrounded by officers and citizens. A fight followed, and the tramp shot and instantly killed Sheriff Pascos of Nevada County.

The item in the weekly bank statement which attracts least attention is that of circulation. The statement issued yesterday shows an increase of $65,000 in the circulation of the national banks in the City of New-York. The total circulation is now $5,618,400, as against $5,538,400 one year ago and $3,608,200 two years ago.

We may call "Phineas Finn" a political romance, but the dominant note in it has naught or little to do with governing men. Whether it was written for reform or "the pease porridge" business, one of those satirical asides Trollope did so well, it is the history of a gentleman from Killaloe, who to sweet manners and honesty of purpose united the manlier traits.
At 2:35 o'clock this (Sunday) morning four alarms of fire were sounded from the box at the corner of Church and Murray Streets for a fire in the five-story building, 26 Park Place.

The one flower that all humanity loves is the violet. In its lowly, unostentatious fragrance, which tells yon where the blossom is hidden before your eyes rest upon it, it is like a gentle woman whose soul has in it the fragrance of good deeds whereof the right hand knows not what the left hand does, who is sometimes sent into this world to teach us what angels are.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The President, before leaving Washington yesterday, signed an order reorganizing the Military Department of Arizona, under the name of the Department of Colorado, with headquarters at Denver. The Department, of Arizona consisted ot the Territories of New-Mexico and Arizona and that portion of California south of the thirty-fifth parallel.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 1 -- The Legislature last Winter, in accordance with the general demand for better roads, passed an act providing for the publication of a highway manual containing the general laws relating to the powers and duties of highway officers and resident taxpayers, together with practical directions and suggestions for the proper construction and maintenance of roads.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 1. -- The many tributes of respect and esteem which are paid to the memory of a great man whom he dies were tendered with honest sympathy to the bereaved family of Anthony J. Drexel to-day. They came mostly from his personal friends and business associates, but in the long procession of mourners were men and women of every social and financial grade in every part of the world.

M. de Saint-Amand writes of that Marguerite who is the sister of Francis I. and Catharine de Mediois and her contemporaries at the French Court. The ladies of the sixteenth century under certain aspects were attractive women with their half pagan and half Christian characteristics. From confessors they turned to lovers, stopping en route at the astrologers.

PROVO, Utah, July 1. -- The First National Bank here closed its doors yesterday morning. A.D. Senoat is President and W.H. Dusenberry cashier. The assets are $115,000 and the liabilities the same. Inability to make collections or rediscount is the cause of the failure. Officials expect the bank to resume business soon.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- Manasquan is one of the smallest towns in the State, but it has produced the greatest bicycle rider in the world. Arthur Zimmerman is, without doubt, the peer of any man that over sat astride of a wheel. He proved that here to-day when he won three championships of the State -- the half, the mile, and the five-mile.

George Bleistain of Buffalo, editor of the Courier and Chairman of the Anti-Sheehan Home-Rule Democratic Committee, was at the Hoffman House yesterday. He has been in Washington two or three days, and while there called on Secretary Lamont, Postmaster Generall Bissell, and others prominent in the departments.

The Sherman law is not and cannot be the sole cause of our trouble. We must go back twenty years to the demonetization of silver - baok to the protective tariff -- back to the national banking system, to get a clear view of the conditions under which the business interests of our country have suffered such serious in- jury.

TRENTON, July 1 -- The serious business of the meet being over the cyclists prepared to have a good time for the remainder of their stay in Trenton, and they succeeded right well. South Warren Street in the neighborhood of the Mercer County Club House was almost impassable on account of the number of wheels there.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1. -- This has been a dreary week insociety circles, as tie continued cold snap has made wood fires and overcoats a necessity. The coming week, however, prem- ises, with anything like fine weather, to atone for pasts discomforts, and the opening dance at the Casino on Tuesday night will be a welcome relief.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Two changes in the bills promised by the centrally-situated theatres for next week will serve to break the monotony which has prevailed in Chicago theatrical matters the last month. The fact that both pieces have been seen in Chicago frequently is not likely to operate against their popularity, as the theatres, crowded as they are nightly, are patronized chiefly by the floating population brought here by the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Representative McMillin (Dem., Tenn.,) said that the President had taken the surest and promptest way out of the difficulty, and he expected good results to accrue from the session. Early action would restore confidence throughout the country and settle the present turbid elements.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES has rendered an important service to the country in publishing the results of its canvass of the members of the House and Senate on the repeal of the Sherman Silver Purchase act. At the present time the canvass covers about 200 members of both houses and reveals an overwhelming sentiment in favor of repeal.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 1 -- Every hotel and boarding house in the Catskill Mountains is open, all the Summer trains from the cities are now running into the mountains, and the busy season has begun in earnest. And a promising beginning it has been, too. Trains yesterday and to-day on both the New-York Central and West Shore Railroads have run with crowded cars, and hundreds of people have gone up the Ulster and Delaware.

"Billy" McGlory, the notorious divekeeper, who mysteriously disappeared last February, was in town yesterday. He arrived late Friday night, but has become so highly cultivated by his travels abroad that he positively refused to be seen by his former associates, and he also scorned newspaper reporters.
Ex-Gov. Rice of Massachusetts, in his oration at the unveiling of the Farragut Monument in the Marine Park at South Boston on Wednesday, related the following:

That a leading publishing house in New-York has recently issued a book entitled "The Making of a Newspaper," and that occasional magazine articles on the same subject appear to be in some demand, is indicative of a desire on the part at readers generally to know something more of that which appertains to the "fourth estate."

The Staten Island Athletic Club was treated to a great surprise yesterday at Central Park, where the New-York Cricket Club defeated them by 21 runs after a same strupgle. A.C. Dacre distinguished himself for the New-Yorks, and in batting and bowling he obtained the best figures.

It is not very many years ago that the roads of Long Island possessed a very unenviable reputation among the local wheelmen, and those who attempted to enjoy the invigorating air and diversified scenery of the island usually bad their ardor damped and their legs sorely tried by the poor condition of most of the roads, particularly those leading to the loss frequented and, usually, more desirable places.

William E. Leavitt, a wine dealer of 573 Broadway, appeared before Judge Cullen in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, and applied for a divorce from his wife Laura W. Leavitt, on statutory grounds, naming as corespondent Eugene A. Maurice, a stock broker at 340 Broad Street, who is now living with Mrs. Leavitt at monmouth, N.J. Mr. Leavitt resides in Brooklyn.

The Middle States championship tennis tournament was finished yesterday afternoon on the Orange Club courts, Mountain Station, N.J. The chief event of the day was the match between A.E. Foote of Yale University, challenger, and Richard Stevens, St. George Cricket Club, the holder of the Middle States Championship Cup.

Guiseppe Campanari, the baritone who was so successful during the Hinrichs season at the Grand Opera House, used to be a 'cello player in the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He studied the instrument under Mazzucate, the conductor, who died in 1879. In 1880 Campanari, having discovered his voice, made his debut in "Un Ballo in Maschera" at the Del Verme Theatre.

ST. PAUL, July 1 -- The second International Reciprocity Convention, just hold here, has had the effect of crystallizing and cementing public sentiment in the Northwestern States of the Union and in Manitoba and the Northwestern Territories of Canada in favor of some joint action between the two countries which will he favorable to increased trade relations with each other.

From 10 at night till 2 in the moraine the brasseries at the Butte are in session. Ah! the Interminable books and the reek of the cigars, until at last a hesitating exodus begins. An exhausted proprietor at the head of his waiters, crazed with sleepiness, eventually succeeds in driving these noctambulist apostles into the street.

LENOX, Mass., July 1 -- The simple dedicatory exercises of St. Helen's Home, the building for the benefit of the "Fresh Air" children, which Mr. John E. Parsons of New-York has fitted up at Curtisville in memory of his daughter Helen, who died a little over a year ago, will take place to-day. It was formerly a country hotel, and has been renovated and put in perfect order.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 1. -- The Rockaway Hunt Club's elegant clubhouse at Cedarhurst was entirely destroyed by fire early this morning. The contents of the clubhouse were also destroyed, and several of the club members and inmates of the structure had narrow escapes from being burned to death.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, July 1. -- The opening of the Casino to-day formally marks the com- mencement of the season at this pretty shore resori, and both permanent and transient vis- itors will be pleased to note the over-growing popular adjunct to "swell" Newport.

Sir Ambrose Shea, Governor of the Bahamas, accompanied by Lady Shea, arrived in this city yesterday on the Cienfuegos of the Ward Line. He is at the Metropolitan Hotel. He will sail for England Wednesday.

Frederick A. Burnham, Grand Master of Masons in the State of New-York, yesterday announced the list of appointments on his staff, and also the appointment or thirty District Deputy Grand Masters. The new officers are to serve one year. They are as follows:

If the people would only attend to their own private affaire the politicians of the Brooklyn ring would be a very much happier lot of men. It makes them nervous to have the fences behind which they have intrenched themselves exposed and in danger of being knocked down.

The residents on the line of the Greene and Gates Avenue trolley road in Brooklyn have been greatly annoyed during the past week by the constant ringing of trolley gongs and also by the reckless speed at which the cars are sent. Yesterday the following letter was received at the Mayor's Office:

There was no dissent among banking men and merchants yesterday from the opinion that President Cleveland's call for an extra session of Congress in August had been most opportune, and had illustrated the President's fortunate faculty of doing the right thing at the right time.

Major Alfred F. Sears, Vice President and General Manager of the North Peru Company, who has just arrived here from Peru, speaking to a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES on the political situation in that country, said:

This is the season of fruits with the Tammany braves. This reference has nothing to do with political fruits, although the braves are having a fine harvest in that direction. The braves, by the regulation of the Tammany Society, divide their year into four seasons according to the Indian custom in vogue in the days of the great Chief Tammany, the patron saint of the organization.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 1. -- New-London people look upon college boat-race week as the opening week of the Summer season among the resorts in this vicinity. Previously only the regular cottage owners and those who have Summer residences inland comprise the arri- vals. They generally get settled about the middle of June.

The New-York City Congressman are now rearranging their plans for their Summer vacations. Most of them did not figure upon having to go to work in Washington as early as Aug. 7, but they will take their vacations in July and be ready to struggle with the Nation's problems in August.

The "little sweetheart Rosalie" of John Howard Payne's correspondence was a pretty child whom he had always petted and of whom he complained whimsically at her marriage for the purported cruelty with which she had thrown over her old admirer. The saddened man never forgot the bright-eyed girl, who has lived out a long life at the birthplace of both these oddly-assorted friends in the quaint old seaport town of Easthampton.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1. -- Walter Q. Gresham, Secretary of State, was at the Bates House to-day. He has been visiting his mother in Harrison County, and stopped over here to see a few of his friends. In regard to the President's proclamation, he said: "I am very glad, indeed, that he has done so.

The Altiora Tennis Club has Just finished its an- nual Summer tournament on the club grounds, President Street, between Sixth and Seventh Ava- nues, Brooklyn. The events were men's singles and men's doubles. F. Heitkamp, the champion of the club, did not enter, so that first place in the singles went to W.W. Bostwick, Jr., who defeated Jay S. Jones for final honors, 6-1, 7-5, 6-1.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- The flying start was seen here to-day in THE TIMES'S team race, and nearly every expert who witnessed it seemed to be pleased. To see the men all start off on even terms instead of the zigzag fashion peculiar to the standing starts was something of an innovation. Here are some of the expressions at opinions: ...

Vice Admiral Sir George Tryon's reputation for being perhaps the ablest tactician in the British Navy was gained by him as the result of the British naval manceuvres of 1888. Tryon during those manceuvres was a Rear Admiral in rank. He had associated with him then as second in command Rear Admiral Robert O'Brien Fitzroy, C.B. To Tryon was assigned, by order of the British Admiralty, the work of attacking the coasts of Great Britain.

No matter how charming may be one's Phillada, a certain aroma of interest will always cling to the "Ladies of St. James's." In this case especially so, as the ladies in question are not only Americans, but the wife and daughters of our first Ambassador to England.

Many boxes of rate and interesting specimens, which have been stored in out-of-the-way places, their contents unknown except for a bare catalogue of the articles, have recently been opened up at the Museum of Natural History in Manhattan Square. The exhibits have been carefully arranged and catalogued since the new portion of the museum was opened, and attract much attention from the visitors to the institution.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., July 1. -- A visitor to Brentwood looks about involuntarily for an Evangeline to complete the picture of Acadis, but, unhappily, Evangelines are scarce in Brentwood, for its surroundings are peculiar. It is not a farming section nor a dairy district. It is a vast tract of balsamic pine growth for miles about, often and appropriately termed "the Lake-wood of Long Island."

The apparent anomaly of storehouses here being filled with grain awaiting transportation to the markets of Europe and no carriers to convey it thither, while there are whole acres or steamships lying idle at British piers, has its explanation in the fact that cargo rates have hitherto been too low to make the voyage a profitable one to the shipowner.

There was a noticeable decrease in the mortality of the city last week, as compared with the preceding week, and the number of deaths was the lowest that has been reported for the last week in Jnne for many years past. The number of deaths reported during the past week was 702, and there were 1,019 births and 384 marriages.

Few of the thousands or busy people who rush daily along the north side of Fulton Street, between Nassau and William Streets, are aware that behind the iron front of a tall business building at 113 and 115 Fulton Street there is concealed a house of prayer.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- George E. Vickers, General Agent for the Pennsylvania World's Fair Commission, will leave here to-night for Chicago and endeavor to prevent the removal of the Liberty Bell from the Pennsylvania station on the Fourth.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- The season is now fully opened at the "Newport of Long Island." The cottagers arc all here and the drives present an animated appearance. South- ampton will enjoy one of the busiest seasons socially it has yet experienced. The Meadow Club will hold its annual open tournament, in- cluding the play for the tannis championship of Long Island, from Monday, July 31, to Satur- day, Aug. 5.

ORANGE, N.J., July 1. -- For the past few weeks nothing has been heard of the schemo to establish a family club at the brow of the mountain near St. Cloud. It is announced, however, that the club is an assured thing and will be an actuality before the Summer is over.

For sentimental purposes the Sherman act is already repealed. The proclamation of the President calling the extra session has been received by Wall Street and the whole country as a virtual announcement that the time for its repeal has come. The few weeks which intervene between now and the day that Congress acts, and the amount more or less of silver which the Treasury Department must buy in that interval, are of no account.

There is a flood tide of humanity flowing into the Great City every morning. It ripples over from Brooklyn by way of the iron band that spans the East River and links together the sis- ter cities. It floats over or upon the ferryboats that have little reason to be jealous of their overhead competitor in accommodating travel, since the bridge, with its grip cars and its wide walk, does not take all.

The Distaff Series of little books, which is on the eve of publication, is of especial interest to New-York women. It is the outgrowth of the work of the Committee on Literature for the World's Fair, the "Distaffs" being some of the folios which supplement, in the library of the Woman's Building, the book collection.

LONDON, July 1 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- This year the 19th of August falls on a Saturday. It is a date which Irishmen may well paste in their hats, for it is now supposed that in the early morning hours of that day the British House of Commons will finally pass the Home Rule bill.

A runaway last night at Eldorado during the performance of Bolossy Kiralfy's "King Solomon" came near proving serious. During the first scene of the spectacle, while James Mahony was driving a team of spirited horses at tached to a Roman chariot in the arena immediately in front of the stage, the animals became frightened by the hiseing sound from a calcium light and started off at a furious galt.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 1. -- Chauncey B. Ripley of this town, who has been appointed advisory counselor in the Department of Agriculture of the Columbian Exposition, is the owner of a large herd of Jersey cattle. He is about to place on exhibition at the Chicago Exposition a number of his choicest animals.

Apparently Kaspar Hauser, the Man with the Iron Mask, and The Diamond Necklace are topics that will never pass out of discussion. Once any one is summoned, they all seem to stalk on the stage. No one has recently grinned through the iron mask or flashed the diamonds, but the Kaspar Hauser shade having now again been evoked, the others are certain to put in appearances.

If this remarkable season is more remarkable for one thing than for another it is for its variety of coloring. While the general result hardly can be called good, yet there are some very delightful effects secured, and some of the most charming of these come from combinations which always have been reckoned the crudest and most outre.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- There is no finer or more magnificent single exhibit at Chicago than one in the Paris section of manufactures, which attracts universal attention. This is the display of Louchet Brothers of Paris, makers of porcelain, bronze, and enamel art objects. The products of this firm unquestionably represent in design, workmanship, and finish the highest achievement in decorative art.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- The first race was a one-mile novice. First prize was a gold medal, second prize a cold medal. The starters were Arthur Dysord, OBC.; J.H. Overton, city; W. S. Martin, UCR.; Clifton A. Rose, city; William Hall, WW. Dysord took the lead at the start, followed in order by Overton and Martin. Dysord led the field along the back stretch, with the others closely bunched.

All who have visited the World's Fair at Chicago agree that it is the most wonderful and stupendous exhibition that has ever been held in the world and they are never weary of sounding its praises. Among the many people who have visited the exposition, none are more enthusiastic than the merchants. Many of them have exhibits at the fair.

Victory has at last smiled a upon the brawny athletes of Harvard, and the glory which perched on the proudly-waving blue of Yale at New-London has been eclipsed by defeat in the last trial of strength for the year between the two colleges.

President CLEVELAND'S determination to summon Congress on Aug. 7 has been received with extraordinary unanimity and heartiness of approval by the country. The mere issue of the call, together with the strong probability that favorable action will be taken by Congress, has had a beneficial effect.

Contractor Michael Barry's stables, wagon shed and barns, a group of old wooden, buildings in an open lot in One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street, between Fifth, and Lenox Avenues, were destroyed by fire early yesterday morning, and twelves horses perished in the flames. The dwelling occupied by Barry and his family had a narrow escape from destruction, and four men in his employ had to flee from the wagon shed in their night clothes.

The new trend in the rapid-transit problem which the past few days has disclosed did not excite much comment among real estate men, although much satisfaction is expressed that some outcome may be expected from the two years' agitation and discussion of the matter. Several districts, it is believed, will be gainers in values and population if even the elevated railway extensions should be agreed to.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1. -- The torpedo fleet is this season to do practical work for the first time. The two boats comprising the float -- the Cashing and the Stiletto -- are now for the first time attached to the torpedo station. They will be used in instructing the classes of naval officers who are to report here for enlightenment upon practical torpedo work.

The marriage of Princess May of Teck to Prince George, Duke of York, will take place Thursday of this week. This is known in England as Old Midsummer Day, and is the birthday of Princess Victoria of Wales, and the same date as the marriage of the Queen's granddaughter, Princess Louise of Anhalt.

PARIS, June 5. -- A good many people have come back from Chicago; many more have written from there; long newspaper letters, frank in expression and judgment, but courteous in form, have appeared in all the leading papers. Those of M. Uzanne in the fiqaro and of M. Marcel Monnier in the Temps seem to be the most complete at present.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 1. -- Another chapter was added to the Wanser romance yesterday by the discovery that George Rickard, Mrs. Wanser's first husband, still resides in this city. He is the owner of a dry dock at the foot of Washington Street.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The stiffening up of the silver market reported from New-York and London to-day was in accordance with the expectation of officials of the Treasury Department, and is ascribed to the closing down of so many of the mines and smelting establishments in the West.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- The Mecca of all lovers of fine china is the Manufactures Building. Here the treasures of Rudolstadt, Meissen, Dreadon, Limoges, Worcester, and Berlin are literally poured out in a bewildering array of the most delicate, the most tasteful, and the most beautiful of the products of the old country potteries.

-- The subjoined threat emanates from De Grimm himself: "Baron de Grimm and Prof. Adolph Corbett are receiving congratulations upon the completion of an American military spectacular play which may outrival the most thrilling of the military dramas that have preceded it. Its prevading sentiment is American and stirringly patriotic, and the leading part sufficiently strong and sympathetic for the most ambitious talents among the foremost emotional actresses.

In an assemblage of many crickets kept for certain observations in a rearing drawer, or box, (onja de herborizacion,) the numbers diminished from day to day; at last only one -- not a little fattened -- remained by the side of the remains of his former companions.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Considerable surprise has been expressed that Manby of Paris, the celebrated designer and maker of ladies' costumes, has no exhibit at Chicago. The numerous inquiries of patrons hare been answered by the statement, authorized by Mr. Manby, that he was prevented from making a display here because he has been remodeling his establishment at 21 Rue Auber.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The calling or Congress in extra session is already evoking gossip as to the organization of both bodies. Such changes as are to be made in the official force of the Senate, including a new Secretary and Sergeant-at-Arms, have already been determined upon, and the new officers will enter upon their duties and salaries when the Senate meets.

In common with most of the writers of literary criticism, nowadays, Mr. Gosse does not assume, in these essays, at least, to be an infallible judge. He takes pains to say that he does not assume the authoritative attitude. He claims for these interesting papers the credit of representing only a "frank examination of the literary life of to-day."

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The scheme for changing the military departments into which this country is divided is an interesting one. It is still in an imperfect state, and has the form of a project submitted by Gen. Schefield to Secretary Lamont. The latter will carefully consider the proposition and may alter the present plans materially.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 1 -- The inception of operations of the dispensary law was attended last night in Columbia with wild and bacchanalian ravels. This law is, as has been told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, an innovation and an experiment of the most novel sort. Under it the State takes entire charge of the selling of intoxicating beverages.

The arguments advanced in THE TIMES last week in favor of the flying start in bicycle races have carried the day and the flying start will be used in all scratch races at the touna- ment of the National Cycling Association at Manhattan Field, July 3 and 4.

Many householders in Brooklyn would cheerfully contribute to a purse to induce a visit from the "Pied Piper of Hamelin." Portions of the city are infested with a plague of rats, arising from the introduction and extension of the trolley system. Never before was there such a boom in the sale of patent rodent exterminators.

The annual Summer handicap lawn tennis tournament of the Knickerbocker Field Club of Flatbush, L.I., was commenced yesterday afternoon on its grounds at Avenue A and East Nineteenth Street. A large gathering of the society people of the town were seated around on the spacious lawns and much enthusiasm was manifested.

-- The Springfield Bicycle Club has made up its list of events, which in as follows: Wednesday, Sept. 13 -- One mile, 2:35 class: half mile, 1:10 class: half mile, open; two mile. 5:10 class; one mile, springfield International record race; one mile. 2.25 class; half mile, handicap; one mile. 2:15 class; two mile, handicap: one mile, consolation. Thursday. Sept 14 -- One mile,

BRISTOL, R.I., July 1. -- The Iselin-Morgan syndicate boat Vigilant was given her maiden trip to-day, and after the yacht returned those on board were very enthusiastic over her work. The Vigilant left her moorings at 12:15 o'clock and stood over toward Poppasquash. A good breeze from the southwest was blowing, and she made a pretty picture as she went about and stood over toward Hog Island.

Cheerfulness pervaded the Exchanges yesterday. The President's proclamation calling an extra session of Congress for next month, although, it had been to some extent discounted in the stock market Friday afternoon, coming yesterday as an assured fact, met an enthusiastic response at all the Exchanges.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- The French section in the Manufactures Building at the World's Fair is as rich as the German in specimens of beautiful china, and one of the most beautiful made in a wealth of lovely products is the display of Bawo Dotter, importers and manufacturers of china, glass, and pottery. This firm has an enviable reputation for its products, and it makes two exhibits at Chicago.

The West Side Lawn Tennis Club continued its Summer tournament on the club grounds, Eighty-ninth Street, near Central Park, yesterday afternoon. All the events were finished except the men's doubles, A.S. Taylor and A.C. Postley being still left to flight for final honors. Postley has won all his matches thus far by detault, yesterday winning from Arthur Taylor, who failed to appear at all during the afternoon.

The meeting of the American Fisheries Society which closed recently in Chicago was of unusual interest and largely attended. Some very valuable papers were read. One by Prof. J.D. Quackenbos of Columbia College, on the Sunapee trout, attracted especial attention. Dr. Quackenbos says that this trout, about which there has been so much controversy, is a member of the Charr family and aboriginal to New-England.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 1. -- That fa- mous surgeon James R. Wood, known by all Old New-Yorkers, used to say that Cold spring Harbor was as near heaven as one could get on earth, and consistently built him a Summer res- idence here and spent season after season in this ideal place.

BERLIN, July 1. -- Although no two estimates as to the ultimate composition of the Reichstag may exactly agree, all reliable reckonings show a divergence of only five members la the estimates of those who will support the Army bill, the calculators placing the number favoring the measure at between 205 and 210. As there are 397 members of the Reichstag, these calculations show a sufficiently strong majority to pass the bill.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 1. -- That fa- mous surgeon James R. Wood, known by all Old New-Yorkers, used to say that Cold spring Harbor was as near heaven as one could get on earth, and consistently built him a Summer res- idence here and spent season after season in this ideal place.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 1. -- The most promi- nent event here during the past week was the reception and ball given by the alumni of Cooperstown Union School and Academy to the graduating class of '93. About 300 persons attended the reception. The patrenesses are: Mrs. J.A.M. Johnston, Mrs. T.C. Turner, Mrs. S.A. Bowen, Mrs. A. Forbes, Mrs. J.O. Den- niston, and Mrs. G.P. Keeae.

The English language is not the easiest in the world for a foreigner to learn, especially if he be a Frenchman, but the French are making heroic efforts in that direction. Not so long ago, when the politicians were coddling Russia, Frenchmen tried to pronounce certain words in Russian and Parisian papers had the hardihood to print some.

LOCAL GOSSIP AND INCIDENTS LAST WEEK. -- Everybody in society seems to be going hither and thither, and as a consequence there is not much gayety in town or country. Just now a peculiar quiet has settled over Tuxedo, but with this week the rush to the park will begin, and then the fashionable colony will again come to life. As usual, patriotism will make a great day of the Fourth of July.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 1. -- Reports from Europe indicate a great deficiency in the forage crops of Southern England, Belgium, Holland, portions or France, and a part of Northern Germany. The deficit has to be supplied from some source, and the prospect is that there will be large shlpments through Galveston. A prominent exporter said to-day:
Death interrupted the 11 o'clock mass at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in Henry Street yesterday.

The Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen performed a simple act of Justice a few days ago toward a prominent racing man, and it has been variously misconstrued and twisted into all sorts of evil shapes. Last Monday Messrs. J.S. Johnson and F.H. Tuttle, both now residents of Syracuse, were suspended pending investigation. The charge was riding a certain make of wheel for a manufacturer and receiving payment for each services.

This week the scene of racing shifts from the Coney Island track to the long and broad stretches of the Monmouth Park track, where for the first time in its history the association will try the experiment of daily racing for forty-six days straight. There comes with it also practically a new management of this old association, which has heretofore been of the most conservative and old-fashioned sort.

The secret of the Victoria disaster seems to have been disclosed. One of the survivors has said that Admiral TRYON ordered the change of front, which has already been so fully described, when the distance between ships was six cable lengths. The change required a turn of sixteen points, or 180 degrees, which is the same as a countermarch in military tactics.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Gov. Altgeld was rather severely scored at the patriotic Sunday exercises at the World's Fair this afternoon for his recent action in pardoning the Chicago Anarchists from the Joliet penitentiary. The ceremonies wore conducted in Festival Hall under the auspices of the Regular Army and Navy Union.

Frank Lowenthal, alias "Ike" Lowenthal, alias William Irwin, alias Sheeny Irving, alias "The Professor," one of the best-known criminals of the present day, was a prisoner in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning. He was arrested on Saturday in Bloomingdale Brothers' store, Fifty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, for stealing five souvenir spoons, which he was seen to pocket by Private Detective George Oestreicher, who knew Lowenthal well.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 2 -- After the cere- monies at the New-York State Monument were concluded Sickles's Excelsior Brigade marched to their new monument on Sickles Avenue near the peach orchard.

The question as to the probability of the Archdiocese of New-York soon being partitioned and a new diocese created to take in all that part of the present diocese outside of the city limits is exciting the keenest interest among the Catholic clergy of this city and was freely discussed by them yesterday.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 2 -- The thirtieth anniversary of the battle of Gettysburg was fittingly celebrated to-day by New-York State unveiling the beautiful statue of "Victory" in the national cemetery in the presence of at least 12,000 persons, among whom were Gov. Flower and his staff, Gov. Pattison of Pennsylvania, Gen. Henry W. Slocum, Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, Gen. George S. Greene, and all the other surviving Generals of the war from New-York State.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 2 -- Many valuable scholarships are vacant just now at the Naval Academy. Up to July 1 these vacancies may be filled by the Members of or Delegates to Congress in the districts or Territories they represent. Under the law 371 naval cadets are allowed in the academy -- one for every Congressional district, one for each Territory, one for the District of Columbia, and ten appointed at large by the President.

DENVER, Col., July 2 -- A dispatch was received in Denver to-day from New-York suggesting a compromise measure to the silver men. It was in brief "that the Government issue no legal tender below $5, and that the Government buy 25,000,000 ounces of silver every year."

"The action of President Cleveland in calling Congress to meet Aug. 7 will doubtless be a good thing for the country, but it will interfere with my literary work," said Congressman Timothy J. Campbell of the Eighth New-York District yesterday.

A Trinity professor and his young son were dressing together one morning not long ago when the father thought he saw a chance to inculcate into his son a few good ideas. He looked out of the window and saw the small boy who lived next door to them working hard in the garden, and this was his opportunity. "Henry", he said, "look at Walter Jones working out there in the garden.

Lady Burton's biography of her husband, the late Sir Richard Burton, will be published in this country by D. Appleton Co. Besides portraits it will contain several maps and other illustrations. Sir Richard himself wrote the greater part of the material from which the early portions of the book have been prepared.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Ex-Senator John B. Henderson of Missouri, who has devoted long and careful study to matters of finance, has addressed to Secretary Carlisle the following communication:

Referring to the death of the late Vice Admiral Tryon, recently lost on the Victoria, it will be interesting to Torontonians to learn that one of the Tryon family is at present living in Toronto. Mrs. Bailey, wife of John C. Balley, civil engineer, of 211 Carlton Street. Lord William Tryon of Upper Grosvenor Street, London, was appointed Governor of the provinces of New-York and North Carolina.

A party of distinguished Russians arrived in this city yesterday on their way westward from St. Petersburg to Siberia, where they will hold offices under the Czar. They came around the long circuit of the earth in order that they might study America and American business methods in some of the larger cities and at the World's Fair.

The regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club to be sailed to-morrow promises to be a most interesting event. The entry list is large and included the names of some fast yachts. There is only one thing that can prevent enjoyable sport to the yachtsmen and their guests, and that is lack of wind. So far this season the racers have been disappointed at moat of the big regattas.

The fire yesterday morning in the big five-story iron building which occupies the Church Street end of the block between Park Place and Barclay Street gave the firemen a very hard fight. The blaze, discovered by A.B. Ellis, the ticket chopper at the Park Place station of the elevated railroad, started on the third floor.

The heat is fearful all over the country, and the drought continues. Cholera has abated at Alais, but broken out at Montpellier. The inhabitants of the rural districts are realizing the disastrous effects of the prolonged dry season. There is no forage anywhere in the Vosges, in the Cantal, and the Lozere, alone the Loire, along the Rhone, and even in many parts of North Brittany.

KINGSTON DEPOT, N.Y., July 2 -- Summer guests in the Catskill Mountains read THE NEW-YORK TIMES at their breakfast table this morning. THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S special newspaper train, which started on its initial trip from Weehawken this morning at 3:40 o'clock, made a remarkably quick trip, and exactly at 8.08 o'clock a big bundle of TIMES reached the Kaaterskill.
At the opening races of the National Cycling League at Manhattan Field this afternoon the flying start will be given a practical test. In each race the men will begin their journey while in motion.

The Messrs. Morris have issued a very handsomely-gotten-up souvenir of the Morris Park races with something like fifty views of lifelike scenes on this most beautiful of all tracks in America, including several views in and about the clubhouse. Those who have the souvenir issued a couple of years ago will find in this a clevarly-designed companion, with features that will please every racegoer.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 2 -- A sensational story reached hero to-day from Fayetteville, Ark., to the effect that George Watkins, for whose murder in 1886 a man named Hedgepeth was hanged in Boone County, Ark., about a year ago, is and has been living at his Old home in Kansas.

As the steam tug Kerker was towing a small yacht up the East River, at 11:45 o'clock yesterday morning, she ran into the empty lighter Billow, just opposite Pier 45. The lighter immediately capsized and sank.

LONDON, July 2 -- A midshipman from the Victoria arrived at Calais early this morning with Rear Admiral Markham's dispatches concerning the collision off Tripoll. He was brought by special steamer, the Maid of Kent, to Dover, and was conveyed thence by special train to London. He drove directly to the Admiralty Office, where the Admiralty Board, notified in advance of his coming, received and read the dispatches at once.
Mrs. Georgia Drew Barrymore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Drew, wife of Maurice Barrymore, and herself an actress of fame and ability, died yesterday morning at Santa Barbara, Cal.

We have no desire to underrate the dignity or integrity or knowledge of the law or zeal for pure government of the average Police Justice of Brooklyn. They may possess all these in extraordinary degree, but their positions in the body politic under existing conditions do not necessarily imply their possession of them.

In giving to the public the letter of ex-Senator HENDERSON of Missouri, Secretary CARLISLE has acted judiciously. This letter was written in accordance with, a promise to the Secretary, and contains the substance of statements made to the Secretary by Mr. HENDERSON touching the monetary condition of the country.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 2 -- Suddenly and almost without warning the waters pouring through the Rescue Crevasse, now 800 feet wide, swept down the New River basin last Tuesday night carrying destruction and terror in their path, and not only imprisoning the unfortunate people in their houses and cabins, hut driving them into the garrets, and in many instances to the roofs of the buildings.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 2 -- There is great excitement among the farmers living in the vicinity of Easton. Within a day or two seven cows, some of them valuable stock have died from hydrophobia. About a month ago a mad dog appeared in the vicinity. Before it disappeared it had bitten a farmer named John Powell and a boy named Case.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday snowed a decrease in reserve of $4,230,250. The banks now hold $1,251,725 in excess of the legal requirements. The chances in the averages show an increase in loans of $7,664,300, a decrease in specie of $2,934,900, a decrease in legal tenders of $1,316,600, a decrease in deposits of $85,000, and an increase in circulation of $66,000.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 2 -- The sun blazed down upon the camp to-day, and burned up the grass of the parade grounds until they looked like-great brown blankets, with only here and there a little patch of green. At 1:30 the thermometer registered 90 in the shade.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 2 -- The new export tax on coffee and henequin went into effect to-day. On coffee it is $8 per 100 kilograms, equal to about 220 English pounds, and on henequin 62 1/2 cents per 100 kilograms.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 3 -- The veterans went to the places assigned to them at 1 o'clock, to prepare for the parade. The organizations formed on the four Bides of Iowa Square and along Baltimore Street, their lines reaching all the way to the cemetery gates. The Gen- erals and guests of honor entered carriages at 1:30 P.M., and took their positions in the square.

Tin, the metal, which has been on the free list, is now dutiable at 4 cents a pound, thanks to one of the most indefensible provisions of the repudiated McKinley tariff. The new tax was imposed by law last Saturday. About one-third of the world's annual product of this metal is consumed in this country in various industries.

The suspension of Cigarmakors' Union No. 144, because it refused to hire music approved by the Central Labor Union, was the cause of a heated discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 2 -- Fully 10,000 worshippers attended the three principal services at the Beach Auditorium to-day. The morning sermon was preached by the Rev. 8. Edward Young, the pastor in charge. His theme was "Patriotism," and the announcement that Secretary of the Interior Hoke Smith would deliver an address at the national service drew a big crowd at 4 P.M.

The men of prehistoric times, if legends of many countries are to be believed, succeeded not infrequently in making wings that enabled them to navigate the air, and constructed boats in which they explored the depths as well as the surface of the scintillant sea.
LONDON, July 2 -- Despite rumors of trouble elsewhere the Stock Exchange yesterday exhibited vigorous strength.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- There has been considerable discussion to-day among the few Senators and Representatives in Washington about the programme to be adopted when Congress meets, but it is too early yet for any clear idea to be formed as to what will be the course adopted.
The enjoyment of the votaries of lawn tennis in Central Park was rudely disturbed Saturday afternoon.

The prizes for the third annual race meet of the Riverside Wheelmen, which is to be held at Manhattan Field on Saturday, are now on exhibition at the Metropolis Restaurant on Fourteenth Street. The diamonds can be seen at Peck Snyder's on Nassau Street. The diamond which will be given as first prize in the ten-mile event is a one-and-one-eighth-carat stone.

Sir Fitzroy MacLean, K.C.B., Chief of the Clan MacLean of Scotland, is at the Waldorf Hotel. As Chief of the clan he has been entertained by prominent members or the MacLean family in Chicago, where he has been for about a month. He will remain in this city for a few days and will be the guest of the members of the family at a number of receptions and dinners.

BERLIN, July 2 -- The silver crisis has affected several large German houses unfavorably, but in general has not injured business seriously. The Boerse was rather feverish on Tuesday and Wednesday, when rumors were current that important firms in Berlin and Frankfort had become involved through their transactions with London.

JOHN BERRY and other cowboys have finished their ride from Chadron, Neb., to Chicago. They started at 5:42 on Wednesday, June 14, and the shortest estimate of the time they would require was fifteen days. BERRY, the winner, actually reached the World's Fair entrance at 9:30 Tuesday morning, thus requiring less than fourteen days, or, to be exact, twelve minutes less than 328 hours.
The ship Falcon, which is to take Lieut. R.E. Peary and an exploring party to the polar regions, left Her Brooklyn pier at 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon for Boston.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 2 -- The casual observer would hardly be able to realize that South Carolina has passed through the first day of the most revolutionary business law or recent years. Over 600 barrooms nave been closed constructively and in reality by the Evans dispensary law, and their places taken by three State barrooms.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, July 2 -- This was formal opening day at Rookaway Beach, and thousands journeyed hither to assist in the celebration. As early as 10 o'clock the trains were crowded with pleasure seekers, and by noon 10,000 persons were on the beach.

Winding paths leading out of the Mail in the Central Park were crowded Sunday with "young men and maidens, old men and children," all faring peacefully and enjoying the smell of the flowering shrubs and the sight of sunshine and shade upon the green slopes. Past a great, fragrant syringa bush came the twisted figure of a hunchback, whose feet also were deformed.

The boathouse of the Dauntiess Rowing Club at One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street and Harlem River was crowded Saturday afternoon with pretty young women. It was ladies' day with the club, and an enjoyable time was had. The carsmen indulged in eight contests on the river. The water was too choppy for fast time. In the eight-cared barge event each member of the crew had a girl by his side.
Four-year-old Frank Bottner, who, on Saturday last, fell into a bonfire, died yesterday morning at the Brooklyn Hospital.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- James J. Corbett has signed an agreement with the Columbian Athletic Club of this city to fight Charles Mitchell before the club for a purse of $45,000, provided Mitchell will not meet him before the Coney Island Athletic Club. In case of Mitchell's default, the champion agrees to meet Peter Jackson in his place.

NORFOLK, Va., July 2 -- Mrs. Oliver, the daughter of Clcero Harrison, has not arrived in Norfolk. She was expected here at 10:15 this morning. The train and hotel were searched, but no one answering her description was found. It is supposed that she stopped in Washington and will arrive here to-morrow morning.

Nathanael Greene's life has been frequently related, from the time of Charles Caldwell in 1819 until the work of George Washington Greens appeared more than fifty years afterward, a period in which were also published not only the work of Simms, but that of William Johnson. Moreover, papers on which lives of him must be based lie scattered all through the many publications that relate to the War of the Revolution.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- James Flood, ex-cashier of Donohoe, Kelly Co.'s bank, who is under conviction for the embezzlement of $164,000 bank funds, has broken silence for the first time since the discovery of the defalcation and cleared up, apparently, the mystery which has surrounded the disappearance of the money and the manner of its withdrawal from the bank.
In the Hanson Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn, a royal welcome was extended yesterday morning to the Rev. Thomas Spurgeon, son of the late Charles Spurgeon, the famous London preacher.

The chief argument by which the movement for a revision of the Constitution of Connecticut has been supported is supplied by the figures which show remarkable inequalities of representation in the House of Representatives of that State. The bill for a constitutional convention in which the people should have an opportunity to revise the provisions of the Constitution under which these inequalities appear was recently defeated by the Republicans of the House.

The history of this collection of sayings is rather interesting as well as surprising. No previous attempt has been made to present the greater part of them in an English translation. While the original collection complete comprises in German over 1,000 sayings, not more than 150 of them have heretofore appeared in English.

CINCINNATI, July 2 -- One may travel in Germany without leaving America. On Wednesday morning the New-York Liederkranz special train of six vestibuled cars rolled out of the Grand Central Station in New-York. A hundred and fifty members, both singing or "active," and non-singing, but none the less musical, made their farewells for the eighteen-day-trip, and the scene was like one in the great railway stations upon the Rhine.

BERLIN, July 2 -- The triumph of Count von Caprivi is regarded as complete by the friends of the Government. The Emperor himself has set upon his conduct of the elections the seal of imperial approval. Untempered confidence pervades official circles that the Chancellor now has a Reichstag which, within reasonable limits, will do his bidding.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 2 -- It begins to look as if the murderer or murderers of Fannie Wyokoff, whose body was some time ago found in Mud Creek, Columbia County, will soon be discovered. Two witnesses at the inquest in Hudson yesterday, Albert H. Frinkel and Miss Metta Frinkel, swore that the day before the body was found they saw a girl in Woolschlager's yard accompanied by a man.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 30 -- Few people in the United States realize the vast proportions already assumed by the business of a court established only two years ago, and in fact, very few know that there is such a court, one that already has on its dockets a case involving more money interests than has ever been tried by any court in the United States, and probably in the world.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 2 -- Speaker Crisp left at noon to-day for Washington. While in the city he had many callers. Asked about the reason for his trip East at this time the Speaker said: "I am on my way to Washington in answer to a telegram from Mr. Carlisle, who intends to go to Chicago on Thursday, but who desired to have a conference with me before he left the city.

Jefferson's life has been written ably and exhaustively and his voluminous writings have been published in more than one edition, not to name the new and noble one which the Putnams have now in hand. That he deserved a place in any series devoted to men who have made this country will pass without question.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 2 -- Situated on Main Street, between Cherry and Lewis Streets, is the clubhouse of the Union County Roadsters. The "U.C.R. -- At Home" in raised letters over the door insures to all a hearty welcome.

CONEY ISLAND, July 2 -- Seekers after recreation made Coney Island a city of great numbers to-day, although the rush of visitors up to 4 o'clock was unusually small. Then every line of conveyance was taxed to its limit.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 2 -- The reception to Major Gen, George S. Greene opened the observances of the day. His old brigade had gathered on Culp's Hill, and within view of a score of monuments erected to mark the places where comrades fell the survivors and their guests gathered and saluted their commander, who is in his ninety-third year, and is the oldest living participant in the battle of Gettysburg.

Although all the cricket clubs of this vicinity have matches arranged for to-day, few contests will take place in the championship series of the Metropolitan League. In the second section the Victorias are scheduled with the South Brooklyns at Prospect Park, and the Paterson second plays the Morris Park second at Morris Park. The New-Jersey Athletic Club goes to Bridgeport, the New-Yorks to Paterson, and the Kings County St. George to Newark.

The British practice of sending a large and modern-type squadron to cruise in European waters and at long distances from home ports has been taken up of late by the French. Just now the French have a large squadron cruising in Spanish and Portuguese waters, comprising the following warships: Suffran, Victorieuse, Furieux, Epervier, Requin, Fulminant, Tonnerre, Surcouf, and four torpedo boats.
Lovers of outdoor sports will be hard to please if they cannot find events to satisfy them to-day. Some of the more important events are given.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- When the National Commission assembled this afternoon President Palmer announced that J.M. Webster of New-Mexico was present with credentials showing that he had been appointed Commissioner, vice R.M. White, removed by President Cleveland. Commissioner Holliday of Arkansas offered a resolution that a committee of six be appointed to pass upon the credentials and report to the commission.

The civil war left many wounds which were not of the sort that heal readily, for they were wounds of the spirit; and for that reason the Abolitionists, who were accused of bringing on hostilities, have waited long for recognition from the public. But the good people of Newburyport think that, so far as their fellow-townsman, William Lloyd Garrison, is concerned, they have waited long enough.

BOSTON, Mass., July 8 -- The Pilgrim, the fin-keel cap defender of Stewart Binney design, had her mast stopped and her bowsprit put in place to-day. The work of fitting her out is being pushed as fast as possible. Capt. Edward Sherlock, who is to sail the boat, came around on her from New-York and is now more enthusiastic than ever over her general behavior.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 3 -- The three days' celebration of the one hundreth anniversary of the settlement of Auburn opened yesterday. Nearly all the pastors in the city preached historical sermons, and in the afternoon a union centennial service of all the churches was held at St. Peter's.

LONDON, July 3 -- In the House of Commons to-day the Right Hon. Sir U. Kay-Shuttleworth, Secretary to the Admiralty, stated that the Admiralty had decided to convene immediately at Malta a court-martial in the matter of the loss of the Victoria.

The assessed valuation of property in this city is approaching the two-thousand-million mark. As reported to the Board of Aldermen by the Tax Commissioners it is for the current year $1,933,518,528.90, an increase of $105,254,253 over that of last year. An unusual feature of this increase is the amount credited to personal property, which is $47,576,464, including the corporation and bank taxes.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- At to-day's session of the National Convention of the Socialist Labor Party, Delegate Rappaport of Indiana, for the Committee on Resolutions, offered a resolution expressing "admiration for Gov. Altgeld of Illinois because of his frank and courageous statement of the reasons for which he exercised his prerogative" in pardoning Anarchists Fielden, Schwab, and Neebe.

Little Esther Jacobs is probably a very miserable young woman this morning. Her twenty-five-thousand-dollar verdict for breach of promise against Henry B. Sire has been set aside by the General Term of the Superior Court, and a new trial ordered.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, July 3 -- P.M. There was little doing on the Stock Exchange to-day, and there was the dullness which is generally looked for at a session falling between two holidays. Transactions barely exceeded 73,000 shares. The weakness was most pronounced early in the day.

Senator WILLIAM E. CHANDLER of New-Hampshire has been spending some time in the Maine Woods. We do not know exactly how long he has been there. We should not have known that he had been there at all if he had not written to the Tribune that he "emerged" a few days since, from which we infer that he had been substantially plunged in the retirement and shade of that remote region.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 3 -- Three killed, many injured, and the guncotton factory burned down to the very sills is the result of the fire at the torpedo station this afternoon.
Bridge jumping is coming into style again. Yesterday, for the third time in as many weeks, a human being took his life in his hands and plunged from the big structure that spans the East River.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- "There never has been a time since the act of 1890, known as the Sherman act,' was passed that I would not have voted for its repeal," said Senator John Sherman at the Lexington Hotel to-day. "The Sherman act was a compromise measure, and it was passed to save the country from a free-coinage bill that had been passed by the Senate by an overwhelming majority.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 31 -- Mrs. Golkres keeps a boarding house at 412 Clinton Street, Hoboken. She has a daughter Kate, who was engaged to be married to Isaac Liefschoftas, a tinner, who boarded in the house.

The first game of the polo tournament for the Alden Cup, the original of which was burned last week in the clubhouse fire, and which is to be replaced by a new one, was played yesterday on the grounds of the Rockaway Hunt Club at Cedarhurst L.I. The teams were the Meadow Brooks and Rockaways. The players for the former were R.D. Winthrop, G.P. Eustis, W.C. Eustis, and O.W. Burd, Captain.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- One hundred and fifty members of the German Liederkranz of New-York arrived at the Great Northern Hotel to-day. They have been making a tour of the principal cities of the Central States, and are now fresh from a short stay in St. Louis.

An unparalleled increase in the total assessed valuation of property in this city was shown yesterday when the Board of Aldermen met at noon and received the tax assessment books for the year 1893 from the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments. These books will remain open for inspection for the next fifteen days.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Senor Antonio Lazo Arriaga, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the Republic of Guatemala to the United States of America, represented President Jose Ma Reyna Barrios of Guatemala this afternoon at the formal dedication of the handsome Guatemala Building in the White City.

Monmonth Park Association began its long Summer meeting of forty-six days at the big track which begins at Eatontown and ends at the grand stand at Little Silver yesterday. Considering the fact that it, was the day before a holiday the attendance was large, in spite of the fact that the Brighton Beach Association also opened its summer meeting yesterday.

BOSTON, July 3 -- A bill in equity was filed in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon in which the Northern Investment Company of Lexington, Ky., with offices at 246 Washington Street, this city, is named as the defendant. The bill alleges that the company is hopelessly involved, and that its present management has paid dividends, and even an extra dividend, with borrowed money or by the sale of new stock.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 3 -- A terrific thunderstorm raged here for several hours to-day. Several barns were destroyed by lightning. An Italian employed at the Plattsburg Barracks was struck by lightning, but recovered from the shack.
A few mornings ago, shortly after the adadjournment of the Jefferson Market Court, a man came in and wanted a warrant.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3 -- Senator W.A. Peffer of Kansas was at the Capitol to-day looking up statistics relating to farm mortgages and rates of taxation. He had this to say:

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 3 -- Assistant District Attorney Daniel Kenefick, who has had much to do with the trials of the men indicted for election frauds in this city last Fall, was much disgusted when the jury failed to convict Patrick Smith last week. To-day, in speaking of the manner in which the District Attorney's office is handicapped in the work of bringing the men who perpetrated the frauds to justice, he said:
Judge McAdam of the Superior Court was severe in some comments he made yesterday concerning the acts of Max Hallheimer, a lawyer in an assignment case.

The friends of Howell Osborne did not readily recognize him yesterday afternoon at the office of one or the down-town brokers. He wore a pair of black goggles, which extended well down over his cheek bones, and his face was decorated with generous patches of courtplaster. Bracelets of plaster also encircled his wrists, and his hands, especially at the knuckles, were rough with the marks of recent abrasions.

The armored Russian, cruiser, Admiral Nachimoff, which would have divided honors with Britain's fine cruiser Blake had she been able to arrive here in time for the naval review, yesterday showed herself for the first time in these waters. She attracted much attention as she steamed up and came to anchor off Thirty-fourth Street, North River.

A committee representing the Directors of the Georgia Central Railroad Company came to this city yesterday to attempt a readjustment of the affairs of that company which will prevent the sale of the great property under the Sheriff's hammer.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 3 -- Mr. Bradley has frequently requested the reporters to refrain from giving him the title of "Founder" in their correspondence. As his request has been of no avail, he has hit upon a novel plan which he hopes will have the desired effect. In the office of the Asbury Avenue Pavilion, attached to a wire waste banket, are fifty-four gold watches suspended, with a card attached containing the following notice:

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 3 -- Independence Day will be observed, here to-morrow in a style not witnessed, since the Centennial year. There will be a military parade and Charles H. Winfield of Jersey City will deliver an address. The Veteran Zouave Band will give an open-air concert at Jackson Park in the afternoon, and at night a concert and brilliant display of fireworks will be given in the centre of the town.

George F. Faxen, a furrier, of 172 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, was charged in the Gates Avenue (Brooklyn) Police Court yesterday with desertion by his wife, Wilhelmina Faxen, who resides at 102 1/2 Sheffield Avenue, Brooklyn. Mrs. Faxen said she married Faxen eight years ago in Stockholm.

Only those who have personally witnessed the pleasure and delight brought to a patient in a hospital or tenement house by a cluster of roses, pansies, or violets, can appreciate the practical utility of the work done by the New-York Flower Mission. Its distribution of fragrant blossoms among the sick poor is no mere whim of the moment.

Henry Sohl, a lithographer, nineteen years old, was allot in the left temple and almost instantly killed last night by Christina Scheibler, eighteen years old. He was visiting the girl at her home in the basement of the tenement house at 628 East Ninth Street. A brother of Sohl and a young friend and associate of the dead youth were present at the time, and they both agree that the shooting was accidental.
PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 3 -- Elmer Chaddeck, the murderer of William Polen, was taken from jail this morning for a preliminary hearing before Justice Beckwith.

The Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club will hold its annual open tournament for the championship of New-Jersey in men's singles on the club grounds, Seabright, N.J., on Monday, July 10, and following days. First and secons prizes will be given in both singles and doubles. All matches will be the best two in three advantage sets, except the finals, which will be the best three in five advantage sets.
