Great excitement was created yesterday afternoon at 5:30 o'clock along Broadway as half a dozen fire engines and hook-and-ladder companies dashed furiously down to Rector Street.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Mr. George P. Rowell, publisher of Printer's Ink, is having considerable difficulty in ascertaining exactly what are the terms upon which his publication can be sent through the mails as second-class matter.
NEWARK, N.J., July 3 -- Edward Doebner, eight years old, of 354 Bergen Street, was buried beneath a landslide in an excavation being made for a cellar at Hunterdon and Springfield Avenues to-day.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The series of World's Fair congresses at the Art Palace was resumed to-day, the present week being devoted to music. The event has brought to Chicago a brilliant gathering of musicians representing the Women's Musical Congress, the College of American Musicians, the Music Teachers' National Association, and the Illinois Music Teachers' Association.

The new steam yacht Embla was launched early this morning at Seabury Co.'s yard at Nyack-on-Hudson. The launch was to have taken place yesterday afternoon, but the tide did not serve high enough, and Mr. Hanan and his party of friends had to wait until 1 o'clock this morning. The yard then looked like fairyland. Powerful searchlights made it as bright as day, and the yacht was decorated with electric lights and Japanese lanterns.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Controller Eckels is advised that the First National Bank of San Diego, Cal., which failed about month ago, will resume business next Wednesday. It is probable also that the suspended Washington National Bank of Spokane, Washington, will resume business in about ten days.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 3 -- Congressman Robert Neill of the Sixth Arkansas District reached this city to-day, completing the list of the Arkansas contingent which has been in Little Book during the past week. THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S correspondent asked him what position the Arkansas delegation would take on the silver question when Congress assembled.
Nearly 600 waiters employed at Coney Island and Sheepshead Bay hosteiries are determined to strike some time day week unless the proprietors accede to their demands for more pay and better food.

The melancholy fate of the British Admiral, Sir GEORGE TRYON, is not the first instance of misfortune closely associated with the name of TRYON. Somewhat more than a hundred years ago one WILLIAM TRYON, a native of Ireland, went down with a certain ship of which he had command -- a ship of state known as the Province of New-York.

The brightening financial situation was reflected yesterday in the course of the markets for securities, staples, and money. The improvement in securities which followed the President's proclamation last week was well sustained, and steady prices ruled for cotton. High rates for money disappeared entirely, commercial paper found ready sale, and silver advanced.

During the past week Superintendent Brady of the Building Department received applications for the erection of forty-five new buildings, involving a total estimated cost of $1,819,000, and plans for alterations on forty structures at a cost of $140,000.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jnly 3 -- The most remarkable resolution ever adopted by a political convention was that agreed to by the Rice County Democrats Saturday in defining the terms upon which they would enter into a fusion with the Populists. The latter were told that they must divide the offices in line with the following resolution:

NEW-HAVEN, July 3 -- After the close of the baseball and rowing season Yale thoughts turn instinctively to the future football. Any Yale man who might be met to-day and asked about the baseball match or the race at New-London would say "Chestnuts" and begin to talk about the prospects for the eleven next Fall. Yale has been feeling anxious about football for a month.

The Baron Hirsch Fund Schools, the headquarters of which are in the Hebrew Institute, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, held their "English Day" exercises yesterday, and in song and recitation the pupils vowed undying allegiance to the flag of their adopted country.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 3 -- The suit of Thomas O'Brion for divorce from his wife, Margaret, which has been before Vice Chancellor Green since last January, closed to-day. The absence at Father Hickie probably prevented a remarkable scene.

BOSTON, July 3 -- A hearing was granted to-day before the Railroad Commissioners on the petition of the Old Colony Railroad Company for authority to exchange its stock, under the provision of the acts of 1893, for the stock of the Old Colony Steamboat Company not now owned by it in the ratio of four shares of the former for three of the latter.

BOSTON, July 3 -- The market was dull to-day, and arbitrage trading was comparatively light. Prices were weak in sympathy with New-York. Some of the local dividend payers were in better demand by investors. Boston and Albany advanced to 204, Bell Telephone to 187, Fitchburg preferred to 80, West End Railroad to 53 1/2.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 3 -- A strange sequel to Gen. Sickles's work at Gettysburg, in the course of which he has placed $260,000 of New-York State's money into this field, occurred to-day when a Deputy Sheriff served notice upon the General in an action for trespass brought by William H. Tipton, the photographer, made returnable in the courts in this village on the fourth Monday of August.

The Post Office Department has recently adopted a measure which, it is hoped, will not only tend to prevent the mailing of enormous quantities of "green-goods" circulars, but will also furnish a clue to those who send out the alluring offers to supply good greenbacks at ridiculously low prices.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- At 6 o'clock fire started in the kitchen in the cafe on the sixth floor and did $100,000 damage to the stock of Fish, Joseph Co., dry goods merchants, 112 to 116 State Street. The building is owned by Ed Pardridge, and his loss is included in the estimate.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 3 -- The strike of the coal miners in Kansas and Missouri is fast assuming a dangerous condition. The strikers are determined that no outside miners shall be permuted to work, and they are especially determined that negroes shall not be imported for that purpose. They declare that if the operators carry out their expressed intentions and employ negro miners there will be violence.

PARIS, July 3 -- The conflict between the students and the city authorities has now assumed the form of rioting, and there were several conflicts this evening in which the students did not come off second best.

DENVER, Col., July 3 -- Information has been received here from Colorado Springs that Henry Starr and Kid Wilson, two members of the notorious Starr gang of train and bank robbers, who have caused the death of a dozen men and terrorized the Indian Territory and Arkansas for months, were arrested here this morning. The men arrived at the Spaulding House at a late hour last night with Mrs. Starr.

PARIS, July 3 -- The Hon. E.J. Phelps, of counsel for the United States, continued his closing address before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration today. He examined into the rights claimed by Russia in 1799 and 1821, and into the resulting protests from the United States and the treaties between America and Russia.

Charles Knoedler of the firm of Knoedler Co., the art dealers, who has been confined to his bed since April 29, suffering from injuries to his spine, is rapidly growing better and hopes to be able to leave town early in August.

The July Grand Jury for Kings County was sworn in yesterday. In its deliberations the greatest interest will be taken in view of the fact that the two preceding Grand Juries have had to take under consideration the conduct of the Brooklyn ringsters, the last one having censured Mayor Boody and the Aldermen for their action in granting the trolley-road franchises illegally, regretting that they could not indict the officials.

A rumor was circulated yesterday that there was, a run oil the Williamsburg Savings Bank, Broadway and Driggs Avenue. A NEW-YORK Times reporter visited the bank at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and found that business was being conducted in the usual manner.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- There will be another model military camp on the fair grounds in addition to that of the United States Government troops. The British cavalry, infantry, and artillery which have been giving a tournament in Chicago will become permanent residents of the White City. Their camp was laid out to-day on a plot of ground southwest of the stock pavilion, and it will be as free as the United States camp.

"The action of President Cleveland in calling an extra session as early as Aug. 7 was wise," said Capt. Evan P. Howell, editor of the Atlanta Constitution, to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

Police Superintendent Campbell of Brooklyn yesterday complimanted Policeman Richard Dilion of the Nineteenth Precinct, Williams- burg, who rescued the family of John Tucker from a fire at 218 and 220 Driggs Avenue Friday night.

TRENTON, N.J., July 3 -- In relation to Mrs. Rickard, whose marriage to Mayor Wanser of Jersey City was recently made public, through the Mayor's illness, the records of the Court of Chancery throw some light. These records show that she la the divorced wife of George Rickard and that a man bearing the same name as her new husband was one of the causes that led to the divorce.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 3 -- After a morning spent in tuning up the Jubilee at her moorings, Gen. and John Paine went for another trial spin in the bay. The wind was fresh from the southeast, a reefing breeze for other craft, but the Jubilee carried her three lower sails. She took long boards off and on, being nearly close-hauled going out, and about before it coming home.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The report of the Board of Army Officers that selected the new rifle for the United States Army, known as "the United States mogazine gun, model 1892," and erroneously termed "the Krag-Jorgenson," has been printed by the Ordnance Department, after going through the regular channels to the Board of Ordnance and Fortification and to the Secretary of War.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Assistant Secretary Hamlin, in view of the repeated violation of the law as to the sale of goods on exhibition at the World's Fair without the payment of the custom duty attaching, has instructed Collector Clark to hereafter strictly enforce the law, which provides a penalty for its violation of a fine of not more than $5,000 or imprisonment of not more than ten years.

Arthur Zimmerman, the champion amateur bicycle rider of the world, was among the crowd at the opening races of the National Cycling Association at Manhattan Field, yesterday. The spectators cheered him heartily as he made his appearance on the grounds.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 3 -- The Viking ship arrived here at 4:30 o'clock this morning. A hearty welcome was given Capt. Andersen and his crew, and at noon a reception was tendered them at City Hall. The Captain expects to be in Cleveland at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

The glorious Fourth will be celebrated at the Madison Square Roof Garden to-night by an illumination of the entire Garden. The orchestra, under the direction of Gustave D'Aguin, will play patriotic airs. An especially good bill has been prepared, including the Whipplemanns in brand-new warbles, Charles B. Lawler, Elsie Adair, Pearl Andrews, Edwina, Rendall, Brooks, Baggesen, Lawton, and Vanderlip.

It is announced in well-informed naval circles that Secretary Herbert will in a few days assemble a board of naval officers to consider the subject of a modern type of small-arm for the navy. Capt. Montgomery Sicard, the commanding officer of the double-turreted monitor Miantonomoh, is prominently spoken of in connection with the Presidency of the board.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 3 -- Frank Smith and Charles Barber, fourteen and fifteen years old respectively, both employed in the Singer Works here, were out rowing this afternoon and caught a tow on an excursion barge, the Willlam Myers, opposite Elizabethport. The barge swung around with the tide, upsetting the boat and throwing both lads into the water.
This is the glorious Fourth, the day on which Yankee Doodle wraps himself in the starspangled banner and sings "Hail Columbia" in a voice that echoes round the world.

ONEONTA, N.Y., July 3 -- A murder, brought about by a drunken row, occurred in the milk house on the farm of William Archer at East Meredith last evening. Andrew Reynolds, better known as "Doc" Reynolds, shot and killed James Reynolds, son of the late Harvey Reynolds, of this place. The shot took effect in the left lung, and the victim died in a short time.
LONDON, July 4. -- The markets were irregular to-day, but, on the whole, good, considering the lack of business.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- The one hundred and seventeenth anniversary of the national independence was celebrated in this city more extensively than was any previous Fourth of July since 1876.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4. -- Gottfried Nikolay, a yonng Russian, of Cedar Grove, is in a peculiar plight should he fall to report for military duty in Russia next month, or furnish a good excuse for such offense, his parents will have their home confiscated by the Russian authorities, so he says.
Miss Ann Morgan of 508 East Thirteenth Street, who was thought to be nearly 100 years old, died Monday from old age.

RED BANK, N.J., July 4. -- The first annual regatta of the Shrewsbury Yacht Club was sailed today in a spanking breeze from the northwest. The plazzas of the new clubhouse, opposite which the start was made, and the adjoining river bank were filled with spectators. The race was sailed according to the club rules, the time allowance being that of the New-York Yacht Racing Association.

EAST ORANOE, N.J., July 4. -- The East Orange Lawn Tennis Club continued to-day its annual Snmmer tournament on the club courts, East Orange. The events were the men's Singles and the men's doubles, the latter being substituted for mixed doubles, which were at first scheduled to take place.
Thomas Murray, a married man with three children, received a wound from a revolver in Brooklyn yesterday morning that will probably cause his death.

The second of the two league games played in the Metropolitan District yesterday was the match between Paterson and Morris Park, which took place on the grounds of the latter. The bowlers did good work in the game, and low scoring was the order of the day. Paterson's 66 was answered with 40 by Morris Park, who thus lost the game by 26 runs. The score:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 4. -- The bicycle meet of the Asbury Park Athletic Association attracted 4,000 spectators to the association's grounds this afternoon. William F. Murphy of the New-York Athletic Club, Z.M. Wells, the Canadian champian, now a member of the Mercer County Wheelmen, and Joseph J. Diven of the Bank Clerks Athletic Association, Philadelphia, wore among the crack riders who took part.

Two boys narrowly escaped death yesterday in Harlem, and their companion, Mark Goldberg, eleven years old, of 166 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, lies between life and death in the Harlem, Hospital. The reckless individual who put the boys in danger is unknown.

Gloom and mourning yesterday pervaded the third floor of the tenement 231 Stanton Street, where lay the body of Henry Sohl, the young lithographer who was shot and killed by Christina Soheibler on Monday evening in front of her house, 628 East Ninth Street. The body lay in a coffin, while the dead man's sister and mother and several other female relatives and friends stood weeping bitterly.

ORANGE, N.J., July 4. -- The Summer games of the South Orange Field Club wore held to-day. The quarter milo cinder tract of the club was in line condition. There was a large crowd in attendance and the flay was perfect. There was one accident, in the sixth lap of the two-mile handicap L.V. Mocksridge of New-York and Whitefield Smith of the Riverside Athletic Club fell and were badly bruised.

The Lorillard Athletic Club of Jersey City gave its annual games and picnic at Caledonian Park yesterday. The events were runs of 440 and 880 yards and one and two miles. There were also exhibitions ou boxing and a display by the Murphy brothers. The grounds were crowded.

The Tammany Society has at least the distinction of keeipng up from year to year a more fervid celebration of the anniversary of our national independence than any other organization in the country. If in that celebration there is fully as strong a flavor of partisanship as of patriotism, it is to be excused on the ground that Tammany is a partisan organization and makes little pretense to being anything else.

ST. Louis, July 4. -- In the morning game both clubs played well to-day. A high wind favored the batters on field hits. The New-Yorks won by good hitting and infield work. The weather was threatening, turning to rain in the last inning. Attendance, 4,600.

Frank Liago, aged twelve, and Patsey Radigan, aged eleven, are the heroes of the latest Cherry Hill tragedy. They are under arrest, charged with being concerned in the drowning of "Tommy" Moloney, aged twelve.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- It was not until 11:20 o'clock that Director General Davis, arm in arm with Vice President Stevenson, appeared at the head of the steps leading to the platform, and a mighty shoot then went up from 200,000 throats. Behind the Director General and the Vice President came the Mayor and Corporation, the National Commissioners and Board of Directors, the Lady Managers, and several hundred special guests of the occasion.
VINELAND, N.J., July 4. -- The bicycle races held this afternoon on the Vineland Trotting Association track were excellent, and some very good time was male, Summary:

The annual picnic and games of the Sixty-ninth Regiment were held yesterday in the Empire City Colosseum on Avenue A, near Sixty-ninth street. There was a large attendance, and the sports were in most cases closely contested.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 4. -- Gov, Flower and Adjt. Gen, Porter and staff arrived in the State Camp to-day from Gettysburg, and their arrival gave additional interest to the celebration of Independence Day.

CLEVELAND, July 4. -- Cleveland had a big lead in the morning game with Brooklyn and would have won had not Capt. Tebeau been compelled to retire in the sixth inning because of a dislocated knee. As it was, the game was drawn at the end of the ninth inning. Both pitchers were batted hard. Attendance, 6,000. Weather warm and clear.

"I do not think there is any immediate danger of his dying," said Dr. S.C. Minor of Bellevue Hospital, yesterday, referring to the condition of Dennis McCarty, who jumped off the Brooklyn Bridge Monday afternoon, "but it will be impossible to give a decided answer for two or three days.

The Executive Committee of the Manhattan Railway Company will meet to-day, and it is believed that something in regard to rapid-transit plans will then be discussed. The budget of resolutions and other papers for which the counsel of the company called a week ago has been thoroughly reviewed by him, and is ready for presentation to the Directors whenever they may wish to examine it.

PHILADELPIA, July 4. -- The Cup and People's regatta held here to-day was the most successful of any which has yet been held. The races were all extremely interesting, and the finishes in nearly every one were exceptionally close. There were two accidents, but in neither case were the men injured, although in one the boat was materially damaged.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 4 -- Revival of interest in shell and barge rowing among members of the New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne was welcomed at the club regatta held to-day. While the organization was well equipped and fortunately situated for the sport, rowing interests were not aroused until Trustee Edward P. Allen became Chairman of the Boating Committee.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 4. -- Between 15,000 and 20,000 spectators at Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon saw one of the finest amateur regattas ever rowed in this country. It was the annual regatta of the New-England Amateur Rowing Association. J.A. St. John of St. Louis was referee and Walter A. Stimpson of Boston. President of the New-England Association, was starter. Every one of the eleven events was closely contested.

BERLIN, July 4. -- The Reichstag was opened to-day by Emperor William in person. At noon the Castle Guards marched into the White Saloon, which occupies the southeastern corner of the royal palace, and took positions about the dais from which his Majesty was to read his speech opening the session. Following the guards came the members of the Bundearath, the representatives of the individual States composing the German Empire.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 4. -- The "Glorious Fourth" was made doubly so to-day by the sixth race meet of the Union County Roadsters, winners of the famous loving cup presented by THE NEW-YORK TIMES. From early morn when the church bells pealed forth merrily the one hundred and seventeenth anniversary of the Nation's birth to 2 o'clock bicyclers came to town by twos, threes, and scores.
By the burning of a quantity of loose powder on the bar of Mary Schlotterbeck's beer saloon at 436 East Seventeenth last night three persons were injured:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 4. -- General Butterfield was at Cold Spring this evening, and was asked about the photographer Incident at Gettysburg. He replied:

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The setting of the warm afternoon sun did not witness a lessening of the arrivals at the grounds, which at no time since the gates were opened in the morning had ceased. In fact, the attendance between 6:30 and 8:30 o'clock was the largest of the day, the beautiful evening bringing out immense crowds, which severely taxed every mode of transportation.

Over in Brooklyn powder was king yesterday. Even the clatter of trolley-car gongs was drowned out by the roar of the firecracker and its various adjuncts, and every other kind of noise was silenced by the incessant detonations.

PORT RICHMOND, S. I., July 4. -- The Summer services at the auditorium at Prohibition Park, Staten Island, were formally opened for the season to-day with meetings a banquet, a concert, and a fine display of fireworks. The meetings and the concert attracted large crowds, but the fireworks in the evening attracted fully 7,000 people to the park.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- America's first flag and the silent old bell of Liberty met in Pennsylvania's Building under dramatic circumstances this afternoon. The meeting was as distinct a feature of the day's celebration as it was spontaneous, the promptings of patriotic hearts. The Paul Jones flag presented by the United States Congress to Lieut.

The Larchmont yachtsmen are patriotic. They believe that the Fourth of July should be celebrated in a glorious way, and what the Larchmont boys believe in they always put in practice. Consequently their biggest regatts is always sailed on the Fourth. It is a singular fact, too, that during the past few years the Fourth of July regatta off Larchmont has been the best of the year.

The fifth annual regatta of the Audubon Yacht Club. West One Hundred and Fifty-third Street and the Hudson River, was sailed yesterday in a fine northwest wind. The course was from the clubhouse to Rockside Park, on the New-Jersey shore, thence along that shore to Edgewater, and from there to the start. It was sailed, over twice, making a total distance of twelve miles.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 4. -- The usual Fourth of July exercises were observed at H.C. Bowen's residence, Roseland Park, to-day. Charles A. Russell of Connecticut delivered an address of welcome, and prayer was offered up by the Rev. William Hayes Ward of New-York. Seth Low, President of Columbia College, New-York, made an address as President of the Day.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 4. -- The Young Men's Institute grounds at Patchogno were fairly packed to day owing to the mach-talked of bicycle race between Charles Lush of Amityville and Elliott Young of Orient. The race was for two and a halt miles for a special prize. A few honrs before the races the two contestants objected to ride on account of the inferiority of the prize.

LONDON, July 4. -- A gala performance was given in Covent Garden this evening. It was attended by the Duke of York, Princess May of Teck, the Czarowitch, the Prince and Princess Waldemar of Denmark, the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh, and Prince and Princess Christian. The audience was notably representative of England's smart society.

TEXEDO, N.Y., July 4. -- A large and enthusiastic crowd came out to see the tennis matches hero today, and while no very important events took place, some exciting contests were seen. Clarence Hobart defeated A.H. Foote of Yale in a well played match of three sets, and S.C. Millett made F.H. Hovey play carefully to defeat him.

At Morris Park yesterday the borne team had a good match with the St. George Athletic Club which was productive of both fast and slow scoring. Dr. Hurlburt played most patiently for 38. and H.E. Jackson hit vigorously for 30, and their two innings contributed mainly to the Morris Park's rather easy victory.

Mrs. Minnie Gertrude Cochrane, the wife of William H. Cochrane, who mysteriously disappeared from his home, 973 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, last March, returned to her home yesterday from Galveston, Texas. This is the third trip Mrs. Cochrane has made in search of her husband, and each time she has returned to her home without any tidings of him.

"This early morning's fire cost us between $250,000 and $300,000 actual net loss besides the less of business and other expenses or delay in getting ready for the Fall season," said Manager Harris of Henry Siede's large fur store at 14 West Fourteenth Street, to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday afternoon.

FLUSHING, L.I., July 4. -- The attendance at the Flushing Race Track to-day to witness the trotting, and athletic games was very large. The events were spirited and enjoyable and there was plentiful enthusiasm on the part of spectators and participants. The following are the summaries of the day's events:

LONG ISLAND CITY, July 4. -- It became known to-day that an almost successful attempt by prisoners confined in the Queens County Jail to escape had been discovered and frustrated by Warden John McDougall Sunday. Until this afternoon, even, he had not learned the full extent of the plot of the five prisoners who made the attempt.

Three centuries ago, when that sage old warrior, Tammany or Tammanend, was Chief of the Delawares and of the famed confederacy of the Lonni-Lenape, he often gathered his followers about him and gave them pithy advice.

-- The Rev. Edward P. Blodgett will to-day, with his congregation, celebrate with appropriate religious exercises the fiftieth anniversary of his installation as pastor of the little Congregational church in Greenwich, Mass. The church, which was organized in 1744, is known for its long pastorates, two ministers having occupied its pulpit for 94 years and three for 121 years.
WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The following call for a national convention of the American Bimetallic League was Issued to-day:

At 1:45 yesterday morning, as Officer Shieck of the Mercer Street Station was passing through West Fourteenth Street, he discovered smoke issuing from the handsome five-story building No. 14, which is occupied by the extensive furrier establishment of Henry Siede. An alarm was immediately turned in, and in a few minutes the clang of the bells and the clashing of the horses' hoofs could be heard in every direction.

BUFFALO, July 4. -- Clifford Calverly, the young Canadian who last year stretched a wire across the gorge at Niagara Falls and did feats on it that surpassed the best at efforts of Blondin, conceived the idea of establishing a record for the walk on the wire across the gorge.

From an early hour yesterday crowds began to cross the various ferries on the way to Eldorado, where the only matinee of Bolosay Kiralfy's King Solomon" for the season was given. By 4 o'clock the grand stand was packed with people and the beautiful grounds contained AS many more. The ballets and marches as seen by the resplendent rays of the sun made a great hit.
"Where did I sleep last night? I didn't sleep. That's what happened to me. I couldn't get no rest at all, and I was tired, and my leg was a-singin' out."

BRIDGEPORT, July 4. -- The great event of Bridgeport's Fourth of July was the unveiling of the bronze statue of P.T. Barnum. The ceremonies attending the unveiling took place in presence of more than 20,000 persons congregated at Seaside Park.

We heartily commend to the attention of all members of Congress the remarks of Senator SHERMAN on the remedy for financial difficulties in the United States. The following are of particular pertinence and value:

New-Jersey was intensely patriotic yesterday. Visitors to the great stretches at Monmouth Park -- and there were some 20,000 of them -- could not help noticing the fact. Those who went to see the track by rail went through the succession of pretty little towns that line the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, and every one of these towns was resplendent with the national colors.

MEDFORD, N.J., July 4. -- Two hives of bees have taken possession of Dr. L. Reeves's house, and there is a miniature reign or terror. One hive is in the chimney and part of the other under the eaves. They are using the garret as a playhouse, and those in the chimney hare been taking their recreation in the dining room and the parlor.
There was about the usual number of Fourth of July accidents yesterday in this city and Brooklyn. One in Brooklyn was fatal, and several others were sorious.

About 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon Louis Mesick, twenty-six years old, a bricklayer living at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Second Avenue, and Isidor Glasser, forty-seven years old, a house framer living at 73 Lenox Avenue, were amusing themselves by shooting with a rifle at a mark on a vacant lot at the southwest corner of One Hundred and Fourteenth Street and Lenox Avenue.

Fashionable society about the city made the most of Independence Day. There was not a "smart" colony included in the New-York suburbs that did not take advantage of the beautiful weather to exhibit its patriotism.

HARTFORD, July 4. -- Five thousand spectators witnessed the bicycle tournament at Chatter Oak Park this afternoon. president Traoy of the Hartford club has referee end T.W. Fahy of the Columbia Cycle Club starter. The racing was the best ever seen in this city by wheelmen.

The New-York State Society of the Cincinnati held its one hundred and tenth Independence Day commemoration at Delmonico's yesterday afternoon. Forty members were present. Gen. William Greene Ward presided.

"More money," says Mr. NEILL of the Sixth Arkansas District, "seems to be the only thing needful. We are more than supplied with everything else." In one sense this is true. Individuals do very generally need more money, or its equivalent, credit But if credit could be re-established the money would promptly be forthcoming.
CHICAGO, July 4. -- The Rev. John T. James of Aldie, London County, Va., made an attempt this afternoon to smash the rum power.

The strong and steady wind which was so eagerly greeted by the yachtsmen yesterday, and which by its refreshing coolness, contributed so greatly to the pleasure of the day, both afield and afloat, was far from welcome to the oarsmen. To them it meant rough water and difficult steering, slow time, and possible collisions and fouls. And all these conditions obtained at Flushing Bay where the Long Island Rowing Association rowed its eighth annual regatta.
One man was killed and eight other persons were severely injured last evening in a collision of two trolley cars on Third Avenue, near Sixty-fifth Street, Bay Ridge.

KIRKWOOD, Del., July 4. -- This was a great day for the kite track at Kirkwood, Del. Two world's records were smashed. Saladin broke the mile pacing record for stallions in a race, and Ayers P., with running mate Telephone, lowered the world's mile trotting record, with mate, of 2:06 to 2:03 1/2, and Conway and Sadie M. both chipped a quarter of a second off their records.
CHICAGO, July 4. -- Director General Davis next introduced the orator of the day, Hampton L. Carson of Philadelphia. He was warmly welcomed, and spoke in part as follows:

PARIS, July 4. -- The students have put the police at defiance to-day, and to-night practically are in possession of the district around the Boulevard St. Germain. The authorities are reprehensible of more serious trouble. Gen. Saussier, Military Governor of Paris, has prepared his garrison to carry out stern measures.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The World's Fair was ablaze with patriotism to-day. Chicago's two million of permanent population kept holiday to-day, and half a million of strangers from outside points, far and near, helped to celebrate.

The most successful of the series of festivals and games given by the New-York Letter Carriers' Association was enjoyed yesterday at Lion Park, One Hundred and Eighth Street and Columbus Avenue. Thousands of the letter carriers' friends attended the festival, and other thousands bought tickets that the sick fund of the association might be benefited.

The Knickerbocker Field Club continued its tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club's courts, Eighteenth Street and Avenue A. The holiday brought out an unusual crowd to witness the matches, and some very good playing resulted. The men's singles, men's doubles, and women's singles were the events of the day, and all are well advanced through the opening rounds.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The Sheridan Stakes, a sweepstakes for three-year-olds at one and a quarter miles, was the event at Washington Park to-day, and it proved an easy thing for the 25 to 1 shot, Ingomar. The stake was worth $10,780 to the winner. Clifford was a hot favorite at 3 to 5 in the betting, but the best he could do was to run third. The summaries :

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Fairchild commission has informed Secretary Carlisle that it is very much embarrassed by the action of the New-York Custom House officials, especially that of Mr. Lyon. Previous to leaving the city this morning Secretary Carlisle, after receiving this information from New-York, transmitted it to the President, at Buzzard's Bay, for whatever action he thought advisable in the premises.

The new arrival in port, the Russian cruiser Admiral Nachimoff, was gayly decked with bunting from stem to stern (yesterday in honor of Independence Day. She presented a beautiful picture as she lay in the North River off Thirtieth Street. Just below was the Miantonomoh, also bedecked with flags.

GETTYSBURG, July 4. -- Nearly all of the Generals and officers of distinction and most of the rank and file or the Army of the Potomao have returned to their homes. The only men of prominence left are the members of the commission appointed by Congress to mark the lines of Lee's army, under an appropriation of $-25,000.

A regular meeting of the Executive Committee of the Manhattan Railway Company was held yesterday in the office of the Missouri Pacific Railway Company in the Western Union Building, at which only routine business was transacted.

In commenting on this exposure, the Eagle said editorially: "The story is out. The details will Dear carefulest study. Under Ranken were duplicated records unauthorized by law. Under Delmar appear to be oven triplicated records -- so greedy was be -- equally unauthorized by law.

MORICHES, L.I., July 5. -- Eastport, ordinarily a quiet, modest hamlet, a short distance from this popular Summer resort, has a sensation. The only minister of its only church, (Methodist,) the Rev. D.E. Day, young, handsome, and widely esteemed, whose wedding half the little village was prepared fittingly to celebrate, has been refused by his fiancee.

BERLIN, July 5. -- King William, in his speech closing the Prussian Landtag, congratulated the members upon the numerous internal reforms they had achieved in the five years of their sitting, all of which had resulted in benefit to the people of Prussia.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor completed its labors yesterday. A resolution was adopted asking the United States Senate not to accept any treaty with China which might repeal or modify the present Geary Exclusion act. Mr. Gompers was directed to call on President Cleveland and the Cabinet and protest against the non-observance of the eight-hour labor law on Government works.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- The unfinished event of yesterday's regatts, the four-oared shell race, which was declared no race because of the destruction of the Delaware Boat Club's shell by a collision with a passenger barge, was rowed on the Sahuylkill this afternoon. There were five starters, Ariel Boat Club, Baltimore; Delaware Boat Club, Chicago; Pennsylvania Barge Club, Fairmount Bowing Association, and Crescent Boat Club of Philadelphia.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 5. -- A fire at Larksville, three miles from here, this morning destroyed, the grocery store, lumber yard, and several outbuildings of Harry Nesbitt, a dwelling belonging to Charles Lawson, John Keating's barber's shop, Dorie's Hotel, and John Powell's meat market, The entire loss is estimated at $20,000; Nesbitt's loss alone is $10,000, partially insured.

NEWARK, N.J., July 5. -- The Irish-American Military Union's encampment closed to-night. The afternoon was devoted to competitive drills, and the first prize, a large silver urn, was won by the Emmet Guards of Washington, D. C. Company C. Hibernia Rifles of Meriden, Conn., won the second prize, a silver cup. The third prize, also a silver cup, was won by the First Philadelphia Signal Corps.

The committee of Directors of the Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia which has come to New-York to reorganize the finances of the company held a preliminary meeting yesterday at the office of H.B. Hollins Co., Broad and Wall Streets.

LONDON, July 5. -- Business was nil to-day, and quotations were nominal. Silver improved on American buying, rupee paper rose to 70. Hardly any tenders were received for Council drafts, and the amount to be offered next week is reduced to 40 lacs.

ALLOWAY, N.Y., July 5. -- On the 22d of June the four large barns of Delos W. Dillingham, a wealthy farmer of this village, were burned with their contents, including a brand-new thrashing machine and cattle. Some of the neighbors declared it to be the work of tramps; others said burglars had done it. This last theory was given color by an apparent attempt to enter the house, though nothing was missed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 5. -- The tie game of the Fourth of July morning was played off this afternoon, and Cleveland won by better batting at the finish. Kennedy started away at a rapid clip but did not last out Dalley made a beautiful home run drive and McKenn again fielded as though inspired.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- When the seemingly endloss stream of visitors began to pour through the gates of the White City this morning, the last, vestige of yesterday's grand celebration bad been removed. Nothing remained to indicate that over 300,000 people had congregated here in honor of the natal day of American liberty.

The Fourth of July will be remembered as a great bicycling record-breaking day. From a quarter mile up to ten miles the figures were lowered. Another feature of the day's wheeling sport was the unusually large attendance, five meetings in this section attracting considerably over 30,000 spectators.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 5. -- City Controller Woolen has given to the city press for publication to-day a long statement regarding the issue of the $600,000 refunding bonds and the refusal or Coffin Stanton of New-York to take them after having received them by a competitive bid.

NEW-YORK. WEDNESDAY, July 5 -- P.M. There was little strength displayed in the stock market to-day. Business was light, the aggregate transactions representing only 108,000 shares. At the opening the market was very dull, with prices a shade lower than those of Monday.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 5. -- Senator Roger Q. Mills was here this morning en route for Virginia. Speaking of the political situation Senator Mills said:

TONAWANDA, N.Y., July 5. -- Everything is quiet here to-day, notwithstanding that it was thought that after the soldiers were withdrawn trouble would occur. To be prepared for this, twenty-eight deputies were sworn in and are now guarding the docks night and day. This morning about the usual number of Poles came down from Buffalo and went to work.

HONOLULU, June 28, via San Francisco, July 5. -- Developments for the past six days have been three arrests for conspiracy to overthrow the provisional Government, a threat against the life of Clauas Spreckels, and the organization of a society within the ranks of the annexationists for the purpose of shooting down certain royalists in the event of any open attack upon the present Government.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Chicago is beginning to realize in a practical and substantial way upon its investment in the Columbian Exposition. In the period embraced within the last 120 days of the fair it is estimated that a sum ranging from $120,000,000 to $150,000.000 will be brought to Chicago and left here.

The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn, the once excommunicated and now reinstated Roman Catholic priest of this city, was reported in a Brooklyn paper yesterday as saying some severe things about the Right Rev. Charles E. McDonnell, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

Lieut. Cochran of the Seventh Regiment, who was arrested upon the return of the regiment from the State Camp at Peekskill for embezzlement from the firm of C.G. Gunther's Sons, furriers, is still in Essex Market Jail. His case is set for hearing this morning, but a postponement is expected, as an effort is being made to settle the matter out of court.

Congressman Champ Clark of Missouri wants it understood that his name is Champ, not Beauchamp. Mr. Clark is at the Hoffman House. He said to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter Tuesday that the mistake that had been made in his name had caused him a great deal of annoyance.

The newly appointed diplomatic agent and Consul General to Egypt, Frederic C. Fenfield, is a resident of New-York City, although appointed from Connecticut. He has received his final instructions from the State Department, and will sail for England with his family to-day by the Hamburg-American liner Columbia.

The "Tunnel Gang" of Harlem celebrated the Fourth in their usual vicious manner. After insulting and frightening many people they attacked Jacob Michaels, a blind cripple, of 171 East One Hundred and Eighth Street, who was standing in front of his home Tuesday night.

LONDON, July 6. -- At the wool sales to-day 12,004 bales, mostly New-Zealand, were offered. The greater part was bought by home dealers. Extreme prices were obtained for all except the commoner qualities. Continental and especially French buyers bid keenly. Good mediums showed a hardening tendency. A small supply of scoured Capes was actively competed for and sold almost at par with the last series of sales.

"If I can't go with a man in my own bailiwick as a friend and neighbor, then there is not much pleasure in being a Judge," said Justice John Jerolomon of the Eighth District Court yesterday to Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers.

LONDON, July 5. -- The acuatic event next in importance to the Oxford-Cambridge boat race opened to-day. This was the Henley-on-Thames rowing regatta, for which there are more entries this year than over before. Among the competitors are many foreigners, a large number being Frenchmen, who are members of the Union des Societes Fran caises de Sports Athletiques.

It looks as if the Adams might be withdrawn from Honolulu and sent to Apia, so threatening are the disturbances in Samoa. The quarrel is the old one between the adherents of Chief MATAAFA and the King, aggravated somewhat, however, by the reported purpose of the latter to put down, all opposition, and by the general dissatisfaction felt at the working of the existing form of government.
The Woman's Protective League met yesterday afternoon at 29 West Thirtieth Street and listened to a lecture on "Fencing" by Miss Olive Oliver.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., July 5. -- The cancemen in camp at Chimmon's Island spent the Fourth very quietly and with, no formal celebration, though, some of the boys came over to help in the festivities here. A number of visitors were received at the island and viewed the camp with much interest. In the afternoon the Knickerbocker war cance made a trip among the islands with a merry party on board.

NEWARK, N.J., July 5. -- Robert A. Haggerty, Chief of Police at the Monmouth Park Race Track, will hand in his resignation to-morrow, because sixty-one Pinkerton men have been appointed as police and ticket sellers at the track. There is an uprising among the home talent under Chief Haggerty, who has served at Monmouth twenty-two years.
ALBANY, July 5. -- The following correspondence is self-explanatory:

The Cheater Hill Club of Mount Vernon held its usual tennis tournament on the Fourth. The events were men's singles and men's doubles, both of which were handicap. In the singles G. Fish, (scratch,) A. Clark, (10,) Arthur Keane, (10,) P. Simpson, (scratch,) L.H. Rogers, (scratch,) and R. Hamilton, (10,) are still undefeated.

Forty of the fifty physicians recently appointed by the Board of Health as the Summer corps for duty in the tenement houses reported for duty to Dr. Morean Morris yesterday morning. They were assigned to districts in the city where tenement houses most abound, and where the poor are in cramped and uncomfortable quarters.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- George L. Crawfora, Master in the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad receivership, to-day filed a report in the United States Circuit Court favoring the granting of receivers' certificates to the extent of $3,742,968. The matter came up before Judge Dallas, and it was arranged that counsel should be heard to-morrow upon any objection that may be raised to the confirmation of the report.

BALTIMORE, July 5. -- The Baltimore Clearing House Association, in view of the unsettled financial situation, has adopted a regulation that hereafter checks, drafts, notes, acceptances, and discounted bills not payable in this city shall be received and forwarded by the banks at the depositors' risk only until final payment is received.

PEEKSKILI., N. Y., July 5. -- The State Camp had a distinguished visitor to-day in the person of the venerable Gen. George S. Greene, father of Col. Greene of the Seventy-first Regiment. Gen. Greene, who is ninety-three years old and a veteran or the war, had just returned from Gettysburg, where he did distinguished service in the historic fight there in 1863.

There will be a meeting to-day at the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation of committees appointed by that body, by the Chamber of Commerce, by the Produce and Mercantile Exchanges, and by the Wholesale Grocers' Association, to consider what should be done to insure good results to trade from the State convention of the Canal Union, which will be held in this city in September.

-- The women students at Cambridge University, England, have good reason to exult in their successes this year. No fewer than ten passed the Mathematical Tripos, and two are Wranglers -- Miss Johnson and Miss Stoney, both of Newnham. Miss Johnson has taken higher honors than any lady except Miss Fawcett, who was the Senior Wrangler in 1890.

Local Union No. 30 of the United Garment Workers of America has instructed its counsel to apply to the Supreme Court for a mandamus to compel Police Justice Kech, in the Essex Market Police Court, to hold Contractors Solomon Wallach and Jacob Seidman for trial for discharging men who would not leave the union.

While Henry Luhrs, fifty-five years old, of 1,620 Avenue B, was driving a baker's wagon across the railroad track at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street at 6 A.M. yesterday he was run into by Trolley Car No. 32 of the Union Electric Railroad Company. The wagon was badly smashed and the horse had his foreleg broken.

Some days ago we said: "The manufacturers of woolen goods will do well to assume that the duties on raw wool will be removed and to base upon this assumption their action and their suggestions and their arguments with respect to the duties to be imposed upon goods manufactured out of wool.

The dispatch from Washington published yesterday in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, to the effect that no letter had been received by Secretary Carlisle of the Treasury from Surveyor Lyon of the port of New-York, created a good deal of interest at the Custom House and Appraiser's Stores.

KINGSTON, July 5. -- During a very severe thunder storm early this evening a powder house in Second Avenne, on the outskirts or the city, was struck by a bolt of lightning. A terrific explosion immediately followed and the powder house, which contained fifty kegs of blasting powder, was blown to atoms -- fence rails, stones and bricks were scattered for half a mile.

Excitement was at a high pitch for several hours yesterday on Broadway, especially in the vicinity of Trinity Church, because a cable car got beyond the control of its gripman. The car was No. 77, and its levers were operated by John Snider.

Statements have been published that large payments are being exacted as a bonus or rental from the owner of the large private bath at the Battery Park; from the Post Office mail contractor who carries the mails to and from the outgoing and incoming steamers, for the privilege of using a dock at Battery Park, and that tribute is paid by an excursion steamboat company for a similar privilege.

ST. LOUIS, July 5. -- One of the leading features at the fair grounds yesterday was a balloon ascension and parachute drop by Mme. Crawford. After some delay, such as always occurs at balloon ascensions, the great bag was ready for its upward flight. The word was given and the balloon rose, carrying with it the long, white, dangling parachute and Mme. Crawford.

GAGETOWN, Mich., July 5. -- E. M. Babcock, wife, and child, of Fostoria, Mich., came here on the Fourth of July to visit with Mrs. Babcook's father. Allen Roberts. All went down to Cass City to take in the celebration, returning about 1 o'clock this morning.

The long struggle between the torpedo and the devices for evading it still goes on. To meet the dangerous torpedo boat, rapid-fire guns were brought into use, lest the swift little craft might dart in and do its work before the heavier and slowlyhandled ordnance could be brought to bear. To guard against its stealthy approach at night, electric search lights were called into requisition.

There was a full attendance at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education, notwithstanding the oppressive heat, and business of considerable importance was transacted. President Adolph Sanger was in the chair.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The weekly weather and crop report of the Weather Bureau of the Department of Agriculture for the week ending July 3 is of a character which can be generalized without going into details by States. During the week the weather was cooler than usual generally over all agricultural districts except in the vicinity of the upper lake region, Minnesota, and Texas, where the temperature was slightly above the normal.

The trading on the Produce Exchange was much less general and at easier prices. Wheat was down 1/4@3/4c, under lower cables, increased supplies, and realizing here and at the West. Corn was slow and 1/2c lower, with larger offerings and an increased visible supply. Floor was offered at easier prices, and had a light sale.

SILVER CITY, New-Mexico, July 5. -- The Southwest Silver Convention was called to order at 10 o'clock, and the first speaker to address the convention was Gov. Thornton of this Territory. He spoke for an boar on the silver question, and his speech was listened to with marked attention.

THE GUNBOAT MACHIAS. -- Capt. Train, who was ordered some time ago to hold himself in readiness to command the gunboat Machias, received orders yesterday to proceed to Portsmouth, N.H., and assume command of that vessel. As soon as he reaches the Portsmouth yard, the Machias will be placed in commission and her other officers ordered to her. Lieut. W.P. Day will be ordered as the executive officer of the Machias.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 5. -- The rumors current in London of the abdication of King George of Greece were interestingly discussed to-day by Demarchus C. Brown, Professor of Greek in Butler University, who has just returned from Greece, where he spent a year.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 5. -- The Honorable M. H. and Mrs. Herbert, with Miss Mabel Wilson, were out to-day as guests of Lloyd Phoenix on his steam yacht Intrepid.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 5. -- Published opinions of foreign bankers that Mexico will be bankrupted through the recent fall in silver are not taken in earnest here. Nothing approaching a business criais is apprehended.
The sale under foreclosure by William Kennelly of 113 East Seventy-first Street announced for yesterday was not held, the cane having been settled.

The Clinton Lawn Tennis Club of Brooklyn has just finished its open Summer tournament, held on the club courts, Monroe Street, near Ralph A venue. The events were man's singles and men's doubles, all the matches being handicap.
The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met yesterday afternoon and pasted the budgets for the coming fiscal year. Aldermaa Pickering presided.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 5. -- "When the Grand Jury meets to-morrow," said Assistant District Attorney Cornelins to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter, "on their own motion they will probably investigate the charges of cruelty made against Jailer McDougall in connection with his treatment of the prisoners who attempted to escape from the jail."

Congressmen Crisp of Georgia, McMillin of Tennessee, Clark of Missouri, and Fellows of New-York were together for two or three hours at the Hoffman House yesterday morning. Col. Phil Thompson of Kentucky joined the party, and all hands discussed politics informally. They said their talk was wholly informal, and they were not attempting to outline any policy to be followed on silver or other legislation when Congress meets.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 5. -- The arrival of Mrs. Jefferson Davis and her daughter, Miss Winnie Davis, attracted some attention. They were accompanied by Mrs. Samuel Tate, who will spend the Summer with them.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., July 5. -- The particulars of the drowning in St. Regis Lake on the afternoon of July 3 of Miss Mary Byrd of Winchester, Va., who was camping out with some friends, were received here to-day. Miss Byrd, with two other young ladies, went rowing on the lake. The boat was upset and the young ladies were thrown into the water.
A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Miss Edith Drake, daughter of Banker James M. Drake of the firm of Drake, Mastin Co., as a disorderly person.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Taral's wonderful finish and Wildwood's game race were the features of the races at Washington Park to-day. The for a a carried 115 pounds, and in a fierce drive broke the record for one mile and seventy yards; the distance was covered in 1:44 flat, that being a half second better than the record which is held by Maid Marian and Whitney.

The little fire of the students' wrath in the Latin Quarter seems to have kindled a great matter in the City of Paris, insomuch that even the National Government of France is disquieted thereby for the moment. It illustrates in a striking manner the mercurial character of the Paris population and the readiness of the elements of disorder to make a demonstration against public authority on the smallest provocation.

The meeting of the Chamber of Commerce to-day ought to do much good. It certainly will do much, if the right things are said and done. The Chamber itself is a body of unusual importance. Its membership includes active and prominent business men in all classes in the city, men whose judgment would be respected and their influence recognized in their several pursuits all over the country.

HAVANA, July 5. -- Operations among the brigands have suddenly become active, notwithstanding that the "Gabinete Particular." with its staff of officers, was established at great expense for the sole object of suppressing these Robin Hoods, who for a long time have defied all efforts to capture them.
Money on call loaned at 3@15 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

A telegram from Chief of Police Little of Elmira informed Inspector McLaughlin yesterday of the arrest in Elmira of Jacob Guth and his wife Frances. Guth is wanted in this city on a charge of stealing $3,000 from a wardrobe in the house of Mrs. Clara Schreiber, 250 East Third Street. He is her son-in-law.

The recent failure of James Grange, a bookbinder at 66 and 68 Duane Street, seems to have been a graver matter than was at first supposed. It is now charged that Grange committed wholesale forgery, and that he has fled the country.

A United States mail wagon came into collision with a Ninth Avenue street car at the corner of Park Place and Greenwich Street at 7 o'clock last evening, and William Sheehy, the driver of the street car, of 405 West Fifty-third Street, was thrown to the ground and severely injured.

The Thingvalla Line steamship Hekla dropped anchor off the Quarantine Station yesterday morning, and soon after Deputy Health Officer Tallmadge, whose duty it was to inspect the vessel, was apprised by telephone that a large quantity of bedding had been thrown overboard from the vessel while coming up the bay.

MONTREAL, July 5. -- This has been a day of quiet enjoyment for the Christian Endeavorers in this city. They climbed the heights of Mount Royal, took little excursions on the St. Lawrence, shot the foaming rapids at Lachine, besieged the stations to greet new-comers, and in many other ways made themselves at home in Canada's metropolis.

The Russian Czar's fine belted cruiser, the Admiral Nachimeff, was an object of general admiration yesterday, as she rode at anchor in the North River off the foot of Thirtieth Street. She is a magnificent specimen of modern naval architecture, with a low black hull and wickedly graceful lines.

Miss Agnes O'Neil, eighteen years old, a sister of Miss Nellie O'Neil, leading lady in W. H. Crane's company, is bewailing the loss of a long braid of dark-brown hair which an audacious man snipped from her head on Eighth Avenue, between Forty-seventh and FortyEighth Streets, in the full glare of daylight Tuesday afternoon.

Excitement having subsided in the downtown markets since the President's proclamation assured an extra session of Congress to deal with one of the chief causes of business depression, the interest of banking men and merchants is fast centring upon the problem that will confront Congress when it comes together next month.

ORANGE, N.J., July 5. -- A game of ball was played to-day on the Lincoln Avenue grounds between the members of the Orange Common Council and the members of the Board of Education. The game of five innings lasted two hours and twenty minutes, and it was witnessed by a large crowd. Mayor Fell noted as umpire and City Counsel Horton at scorer. The proceeds were divided between the Memorial Hospital and the Orphan Home.

PARIS, July 5. -- Midnight -- Rioting was resumed at 9:30 o'clock to-night. A mob in the Boulevard St. Michel assumed a threatening attitude, and the police charged upon the crowd, driving the rioters down the Rue des Ecoles as far as the Place Maubert.

OMAHA, Neb., July 5. -- The American Loan and Trust Company of this city, O. M. Carter President and C. S. Montgomery Vice President, went into the hands of a receiver this afternoon at the request of the stockholders. The company has a paid-up capital of $400,000, has done a good business, and has been considered a sound institution.
NORFOLK, Va., July 5. -- The mystery concerning the disappearance of Cicero Harrison, Mrs. Harrison, and the black satchel is still unsolved.

Application was made to District Attorney Nicoll yesterday for requisition papers on which to bring to this city from New-Jersey Alonzo J. Whiteman, who was arrested at the Monmouth Park race track on Tuesday, charged with having passed a worthless check on Purdy F. Case of 155 Broadway on June 1.

District Attorney Ridgway said yesterday that THE NEW-YORK TIMES was wrong in stating that the amendment to the Penal Code preventing the Grand Jury of Kings County from indicting Brooklyn city officials for the commission of misdemeanors was made by the Legislature in 1889.

Mayor Gllroy received a visit yesterday from Louis Gordon of 66 Mott Street and Jacob Katz of 201 Henry Street, who complained that a gang of ruffians in the Seventh Ward amused themselves by pulling the beards of Hebrews and otherwise annoying them.

The meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday was a very significant demonstration on the part of the business men of New-York, and its utterances may to taken with entire confidence as expressing the sentiment and opinion of the business men of the whole cotintry. The large attendance in midsummer was an evidence of the extreme interest taken in the subject matter of the discussion.

BUFFALO, July 6. -- When the jury failed to convict Patrick Smith, the second man to be tried for participation in the election frauds in this city last Fall, an investigation into the methods of jury-drawing was set on foot, and the result has been some disclosures which add to the odium attached to the Sheehan wing of the Democratic Party by all good citizens of Buffalo.

HOMESTEAD, Penn., July 6. -- Homestead slept very little last night. The fact that the morning sun would usher in the anniversary of the battle with the Pinkertons, coupled with rumors that an attempt was to be made to burn the mill, drove sleep away from many couohes, and all night the streets wore thronged. But these were idle stories, and whare turmoil and bloodshed reigned a year ago, all was quiet to-day.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, held in this city yesterday, it was resolved to pass the usual dividend of 1 per cent. for the current quarter. This action occasioned, surprise, as the published statements of the Denver and Rio Grande earnings have indicated a prosperous easiness on that road the past year.

MONTREAL, July 6. -- The Christian Endeavor Convention proceeded diligently with business to-day. At 6:30 A.M. prayer meetings were held in half a dozen of the largest city churches, but it was not until 10 o'clock, when the first meeting was held in the Drill Hall, that Montreal had an opportunity of fully appreciating the great multitude that had entered the city's gates within the preceding twenty-four hours.

Capt. Donald McKay of the Queen's Artillery, London, was one of the passengers on the Majestic, which reached this port Monday. He went to the Waldorf Hotel, where he remained over night. Yesterday morning he went to Newport.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Financial ruin stares the Duke of Veragua, late the honored guest of this Government, in the face. He returned to Spain to find that his ancestral palace, his art gallery, and even his bull farm were in danger of being sold at a sacrifice to satisfy importunate creditors.

Henry Laub, a hairdresser and barber at 159 Second Street, and the fortune or misfortune of having the only stoop in the neighborhood. The neighbors and their children have been in the habit of sitting on his stoop, much to the discomfort of Laub and his wife.

The marriage of the Prince of Wales, father of the Duke of York, to Princess Alexandra, daughter of Prince Christian and Princess Louisa of Denmark, took place on Tuesday, March 10, 1863. St. George's Chapel was the scene of the wedding. The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Bishop of London, the Bishop of Winchester, The Bishop of Chester, and the Dean of Windsor were the officiating clergymen.

Lady Mansel and Maggie Cline have fallen out. They are not friends, and they will not be for some time, if ever again. Maggie has said unpleasant things against milady. Maggie has been watching the weather, and claims to have discovered that when it rains at all on the American roof garden the water begins to come down just at the time when Lady Mansel is on the stage doing her skipping-rope dance.
LONDON, July 6. -- Second rounds were rowed at the Henley Regatta to-day. The weather was fine and the water in excellent condition.

-- John C. Yager, Superintendent of the Wagner Palace Car Company, went with his wire up into the Adirondack region on the Fourth and fished for trout in Dr. Webb's fine park. The trout came out in special excursion parties to greet him and he might have taught a barrelful had he been so disposed. His chief prize weighed two and a half pounds.
Money on call loaned at 4@8 p cent. The last loan was made at 4 p. cent.

District Attorney Ridgway of Brooklyn and the Democratic machine politicians of that city are greatly exercised over the disclosures of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, showing how the June Grand Jury of Kings County was prevented from indicting Mayor Boody and the members of the Common Council of Brooklyn.

That the Tammany organization in the Ninth Assembly District is in fine trim was very clearly indicated last night when, at a time of year when most political organizations are indulging in midsummer rest, nearly 300 men attended the meeting of the District General Committee, crowded the big hall that is used for the headquarters in Hudson Street, near Abingdon Square, and cheered the speakers as enthusiastically as if a campaign was in progress.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 6 -- From the best sources obtainable it may be stated that the Democratic State ticket which will be voted for next November has been decided upon with one single exception, that of Secretary of State. Only two of the six State offices that will be voted for will be filled by now men.

At one of the most thoroughly representative gatherings of business men ever held by the Chamber of Commerce, that body yesterday, by a vote practically unanimous, demanded the repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman law, and recommended to Congress the appointment of a commission to study the subject of coinage and currency and report a plan for a comprehensive currency at the regular session of Congress in December.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 6. -- News reached here of a destructive cyclone in Pocahontas and Calhoan Counties. It has been impossible to got details or even positive information.

Harry Wheeler won both the scratch events at Eastern Park yesterday, in the second of the series of meetings under the auspices or the National Cycliag Association. In the handicap events, how ever, he failed to get better than third in the halfmile race, and in the five-mile contest being hopelessly in the rear, he retired at an early state.

PARIS, July 7. -- A mob took possession of the Boulevard du Temple at 10:30 o'clock last night and began breaking windows. The police charged twice before they could force back the rioters. The police used their revolvers and several rioters were shot. The rioters fired back, but wounded only one policeman.

A few clubmen were in the Real Estate Salesroom at noon yesterday when the sale of the Manhattan Athletic Clubhouse was to have taken place, but most of those interested were absent because they had learned that an adjournment was to be had.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, July 6 -- P.M. Transactions on the New-York Stock Exchange to-day just managed to exceed 100,000 shares, and these figures serve to tell yery well the story of the day's market. Dullness ruled from opening to close, and there were hardly any "features" which would be classed as such where there was even ordinary activity in the trading.

The philosophy of quarantine regulation is concisely summed up by Secretary CARLISLE in a letter of advice to Collector BEARD of Boston, wherein he says that, while the rules cannot be relaxed, there should he no unnecessary delay or detention of vessels in enforcing them, "as it is the purpose of the department to facilitate commerce in every proper way consistent with the public safety."

The conditions in the down-town markets yeaterday all seemed to be working toward renewed confidence. Prices everywhere remained steady, and while none of the markets was active, good feeling appeared in every one of them.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 6. -- This was a day ful of excitement in the, State camp. To lead off with, about 1,000 of Company B's friends came up from New-York and took possession not only of the company's street, but of the camp in general. Then late in the afternoon a report reached headquarters that two members of the Seventy-first Regiment had been drowned in the Hudson.

When Rajahs, Rahpoots, Akhoonds, and other East Indian potentates are either on their war to the Columbian Exposition or eager to wend thither from the birthland of fakirs and Mohatmas, one need not be surprised at finding the following order mailed from Africa to a firm in New-York City:

A revival of the old rumors about the Vanderbilts taking a large and active interest in the Reading Road, with a view of bringing it into close connection with the New-York Central and the. "Big Four," attracted some interest in railroad circles yesterday. But those same rumors provoked an emphatic negative from the lips of Chauncey M. Depew.

"Yes, I believe it is Col. Appleton's intention to confer here to-morrow with the Seventh Regiment's Captains in relation to the proposed trip of the command to Chicago," said Capt. Charles E. Lydecker in his office at 120 Broadway yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Washington has been a deserted city for nearly a week, yet announcements that are calculated to give the impression that they are based upon the opinions of members of the Fifty-second Congress as to what that body will do in the extraordinary session are going out daily and are provoking discussion.

Mme. Yucca, the strong woman, who is one of the features of the entertainment offered on the Manhattan Opera House Roof Garden stage, is keenly desirous of bringing about a public meeting with another lady of muscle in order that their several claims to being the strongest woman in the world may be settled once for all. The object of Mme. Yucca's solicitude is Minerva, who is known in private life as Hannah Woolford.

The Englewood Field Club continued its club tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Englewood, N.J. In the men's singles Howard A. Colby and Howard Donghty won the only two matehes of the day. Colby defeating Duryee and Doughty defeating Arthur Coppell. The men's doubles were begun. None of the matches were very close.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The indications are that only one or two, if any, of the members of the Jones faction recently convicted of murder in connection with the Choctaw troubles will ever be executed. Some months ago, when the Jones and the Locke factions were on the point of meeting in battle, a careful investigation was made to determine who wore the duly-constituted authorities of the tribe.

The Fire Commissioners yesterday received a copy of the decision rendered by the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas for the defendant in the case of the Fire Department vs. John Gilmour. This decision upsets the practice of enforcing penalties for infractions of the laws of the department which had obtained for years.

The heirs of the Bixby estate are determined to eject the New-York Concert Company from the Casino, which is built on land held by the concert company under a leasehold from Robert F. Bixby, as executor. The bondholders and creditors will endeavor to reorganize the company and secure an extension of the lease, which expires in 1902.

HELENA, Mon., July 6. -- A convention of 300 prominent mine owners, bankers, and business men was held here to-day to devise ways and meads of raising the price of silver. It was the drat silver convention held in Montana. It was an earnest and enthusiastic affair. Marous Daly of the Anaconda Mines was Chairman, and ex-Gov. S.T. Hauser was Chairman or the Executive Committee.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., July 6. -- Dr. John E.W. Thompson, who was Consul to Haiti during President Cleveland's first term, was arrested early this morning and could have been sent to the Raymond Street Jail for twenty-nine days had he not owned a watch upon which he borrowed enough money to pay a fine.

After an absence of two years Miss Marie Halton, the comic opera singer, has returned to New-York. During her absence she has played and sung in London and in the principal Australian cities. She has also blossomed into a full-blown London manager, with a theatre of her own. Miss Halton is the sole lessee of the Shaftesbury Theatre, which is sublet during her forthcoming season in this country.

The foreign exchange market was stagnant, with rates slightly easier for short and cables. Posted rates were $4.84 for 60-day bills and $4.86 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.82 1/2@$4.82 3/4 for 60-day bills, $4.84 3/4@$4.85 for demand, $4.85@$4.85 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.81@$4.82 for commercial.

The new Postmaster, Charles W. Barton, in his speech at Tammany Hall on the Fourth of July, alluded to the political changes that had come over the country, and said that he came near getting into trouble in New-York thirty years ago bacause he was a Democrat.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 6. -- county Clerk Brodie is preparing a list of the legal voters in Pulaski County, as required under the act to enforce the provisions of the new amendment to the State Constitution. It is made obligatory on the part of all male citizens of the age of twenty-one years and upward to pay a poll tax of $1.

Orders have been issued to Capt. Montgomery Sicard, commanding the double-turreted monitor Miantonomoh directing him to sail from this port to Boston and undertake a cruise with the men of the Massachusetts Naval Brigade for gunnery instructions.

LONDON, July 6. -- The House of Commons was crowded to-night with persons eager to see Clause 5 of the Home Rule bill forced through the committee. The members worked steadily. Only an occasional ebullition of Unionist resentment or bitterness disturbed the proceedings.
NORFOLK, Va., July 6. -- The identity of the old man who suddenly disappeared from the Old Dominion steamer Guyandotte, that left this city Thursday last for New-York, is no longer a mystery.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 6. -- The President is confined to his room at Gray Gables. Col. D.S. Lament says Mr. Cleveland has an attack of rheumatism in his foot and knee, a complaint from which he has suffered for many years, and which is no doubt aggravated at this time by the hard work and severe strain on his strength which he has undergone since March 4.

Frank Ellison, who has been in Jefferson Market prison more than a month awaiting the result of Ms attack upon William H. Henrlquea, the broker, of 94 Park Avenue, was taken into the courtroom yesterday for the sixth time, but his examination was again adjourned fox a week.

NEWPORT, R.I. July 6. -- The principal event in society circles to-day was a reception and luncheon by Mrs. Gray, wife of Judge Gray, her first of the season. The lower rooms were prettily decorated with out garden flowers and potted shrubbery, and a very large number of cottagers responded to the invitations.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Sensational crop damages gave Wheat a good lift to-day. The market turned from rather weak to very strong and closed firm with a gain of lc per bushel over opening prices and 3/4c above its yesterday's closing quotations for September. Corn started firm and increasing in price and firmness as the session progressed, closing with a net gain of 1/2c. Provisions were dull but firm.

The Police Commissioners assessed themselves about $60 each yesterday. At the meating of the Police Board a postal card from a citizen of Morrisania urged the adoption of a military cap in place of the bag caps which have given so much concern to Commissioner McLean. President Martin suggested as a compromise that Mr. McLean's resolution of abolition be adopted, and that the objectionable cap be replaced by a police hat.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 6. -- This usually quiet city is in a state of excitement to-night over the presentation of THE NEW-YORK TIMES loving cup to the Union County Roadsters, which they won in the team race at the New-Jersey Division meet at Trenton last Saturday. When the news of the victory was received, Rahway's citizong turned out in force to welcome the boys, and the Roadsters have since been overwhelmed with congratulations.
Guy do Maupassant, the distinguished French romancist of the naturalistic school, who had been confined in Dr. Meurish's private asylum for the insane in Paris for some time, died yesterday morning.

BOSTON, July 6. -- A dispatch from Leipsic, just received by Col. Henry L. Higginson, announces that Emil Paur, who succeeded Arthur Nikisch in conducting the Opera House at Leipsic, will succeed Mr. Nikisch as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which position Mr. Nikisch resigned several weeks ago.

Mayor BOODY of Brooklyn yesterday stated his intention to secure, if possible, the publication of the testimony taken by the recent Grand Jury. "If there is any power," he said, "by which it can be presented to the public that power will be exercised." When this point is decided the Mayor says that he may have further communication to make to the public.

MOUNT VERNON, July 6. -- The sensational accounts published in several New-York newspapers to-day of the suffering by hydrophobia at young John Brassington at this place aroused the indignation of the family.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 6. -- Eli Marks, the best-known gambler in the South, is reported to be dying. He is now at the house of a friend, twenty miles from the city, on the river road. He is too feeble to walk, and hopes of his racovery have been abandoned.
The country Deans of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese or New-York started this weeks, on their visitation to the various parishes in accordance with a rule recently promulgated by Archbishop Corrigan.

VALETTA, Malta, July 6. -- The British battleship Camperdown. which, while flying the flag of Rear Admiral Markham, ran into and sank the Victoria, the flagship of Vice Admiral Tryon, causing great loss of life, was placed in look here to-day to undergo repairs.

LOUISVILLE, July 6. -- Louisville and New-York played a tie game this afternoon, the game being called at the end of the ninth inning on account of darkness. Umpire Seward was very rank in some of his decisions.

ABOUT NEW-LONDON. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. McViokar and Mr. and Mrs. Larry Perkins will soon figure among the New-London colonists from this city. They will be the guests of Mrs. Lansing, who has neatly enlarged her Summer home there.
