Mr. and Mrs. John Agar will forsake Oyster Bay for short time and go to New-London, Miss Rhine, lander is already at New-London, and also Mrs. Lispenard Stewart.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Victoria disaster has attracted the attention of naval officers again to the lack of practice our naval ships have had in late years in fleet drills and the necessity of constant practice, inch as Admiral Tryon's squadron was undergoing at the time of the collision, to prevent just such calamities in time of war and to familiarize our officers and men with the exact turning radius of each ship.

Our amusing neighbor, the Mail and Express, gave the place of honor on its editorial page yesterday to the following remarks, which it regards, we suppose, as a bristling and unanswerable argument in support of the repudiated McKinley tariff: "For the ten months ending April 30, 1892, the value of the starch exported from the United States to foreign countries was $510,855.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 6. -- The second day's session of the convocation of the Regents or the University was called to order this morning by Bishop Doane, the Vice Chancellor, 185 educators from out of town being present.

All the Chinamen who are accustomed to attend Christian churches and Sunday schools in New-York, Brooklyn, and Jersey City are at present laboring under fits of what may appropriately be termed the "Celestial blues."

When boys with left-over fireworks set rubbish ablaze in the cellar of Leopold Bohm's five-story double tenement house at 152 West Seventeenth Street yesterday afternoon, an air and light shaft adjoining the stairway carried the flames to the roof. The sixteen families in the house, thanks to ample fire 'escapes, managed to get out unharmed

BRIDGEFORT, Conn., July 6. -- Arthur Beckwith, the millionaire who escaped from Dr. Buell's sanitarium in Litchfield, and for whom for several weeks detectives scoured Litchfield, New-Haven, and Fairfield Counties, is now in an insane retreat in New-Jersey. He was captured in Cuba.

The Democrats ought not to allow the silver question to become a party issue. If when Congress meets it promptly repeals the Sherman act, or at least its purchase clause, the Republicans will be left in enforced idleness; they will be destitute of working issues and must content themselves with pecking at the petty faults and mistakes of their opponents.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- The German Liederkranz had an enjoyable time to-day. Most of the members went to the German Building early in the afternoon and were entertained by the German Commissioner. Herr Mermuth. Several part songs were given by the society at this building.

The two Russian cruisers Dimitri Donskoi and Rynda arrived yesterday at this port from Boston. The Dimitri Donskoi and Rynda proceeded from New-York for Boston recently to be present at the unveiling of the Farragut monument.

The patrons of the cafe of the Hotel Metropole, at Broadway and Forty-second Street, who were sipping mint juleps and other Summer drinks, were startled about 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the darting figure of a man who disappeared through the door and up Seventh Avenue. In his hands the man held a bloody knife, and his eyes had a wild expression.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Commander Higginson is apparently not out of the troubles, that have crowded on him, beginning since he delayed taking the Atlanta to sea when ordered to do so by the Secretary of the Navy.

Charles Hellstrom, a Swedish pianomaker of Ledgwick and Lynn Avenues, was arrested Thursday night at Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street for hugging a young woman who was passing. Bystanders said he had hugged at least four other women.
LONDON, July 7. -- The heat is affecting the markets as well as the crops, and business is reduced as much as the hay, which is barely more than 40 per cent, of an average crop.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Bureau of Ordnance War Department has approved the programmes for the test of the Gordon ten-inch disappearing gun carriage and the Brown segmental wire gun. The tests will soon be made at the Sandy Hook Proving Ground, but no date for them is fixed.
Mrs. Emma Porter, a "fortune teller" at 9 Sixth Avenue, shot her landlady, Mrs. Southerland, last evening, inflicting a dangerous wound.

There are serious disadvantages in the financial system, under which the city is compelled to borrow money for current expenses during a considerable part of the year. In the recent disturbed condition of the money market it has had to pay rates on revenue bonds which are not a fair measure of the municipal credit and which involve a loss of considerable amount.

HOLLYWOOD, N.J., July 7. -- The Hollywood Columbian Jubilee shoot took place on the grounds of the Hollywood Gun Club to-day. The spectators were not numerous, but those fortunate enough to be present witnessed an exhibition of wonderful shooting. Among the spectators were Richard Croker, Michael F. Dwyer, Roger A. Pryor, Jr., Congressman John R. Fellows, Corporation Counsel Clar. Dr. Gideon Knapp, and Judge J. Clarence Conover.
Excise Commissioner Leicester Holme started for a ride last evening with Mrs. Robert Fulton in an open landau, with a pair of mettlesome horses from a livery stable in West Thirty-second Street.

John Connors, poorly dressed, and with a general air of poverty and dissipation, was before Justice Meads, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday afternoon, and was remanded until this morning on a charge of having attempted to rob the jewelry store at Broadway and Cortlandt Street.

Forty-one of the attendants employed at Bellevue Hospital are at present confined in the corrugated iron building, formerly used as the erysipelas pavilion, because of one of the clerks of the institution having developed symptoms of typhus.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 7. -- The work of the week for the Seventy-first Regiment in the State Camp was practically ended this morning with the extended order drill. To-morrow the regiment and the separate companies now in camp will be relieved by the Twelfth Regiment of New-York, Col. Dowd commanding, and the Tenth Battalion of Albany, under Lieut. Col. Fitch.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 7. -- The Hudson County Grand Jury has indicted ex-Senator William D. Edwards, now Corporation Counsel of this city, and James Luby, editor of the Jersey City News, for criminal libel. The charge was made by Senator William D. Daly, who alleges that the News holds him up to ridicule. Mr. Edwards is jointly indicted as part owner of the paper.

Augustus A. Low, M.L. Collins, E.J. Rustin, J. Bergen, and H.B. Hubbard called upon Mayor Boody of Brooklyn yesterday and asked him to enforce the ordinance against the destruction of trees. They said Sunday school people are In the habit of nailing picnic notices on trees, thereby injuring them.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., July 7. -- The storm of Wednesday night did considerable damage at the camp of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association on Chimmons Island. The wind blew down fully one-half the tents, thoroughly drenching their occupants and contents. As a result, the most of the men did little but dry out their clothes and bedding yesterday.

CAIRO, Ill., July 7. -- Charles F. Miller, a mulatto, who it was thought murdered the two Ray sisters near Bardwell, Ky., Wednesday, was hanged this afternoon and his body burned. The only evidence against Millor was circumstantial, and a strong plea made by him when it was decided to burn him at the stake convinced many that they might not have the right man, after all.

NEW-ROCHELLE, July 7. -- The marriage of Miss Mary W. Tefft, daughter or Dr. Edwin B. Tefft, to Harmon Lundgreen. tier father's coachman, in New-York June 26. is still the tople of conversation in this pretty little village. The parents of the young lady, however, are annoyed by the talk the wedding has created. They say that although they did not choose their son-in-law, they are contented with him.

-- City Register Whitmore of Boston has notified the Israelite rabbis of that city that by a new State law they are given the same powers in regard to celebrating marriages, if duly licensed to act by a congregation of their faith in that State, that ministers of the Gospel have long had. Rabbis from other States cannot legally perform the marriage ceremony in Massachusetts, and this it true of all ministers and magistrates.

LONDON, July 7. -- This was the last day of the Henley Regatta. The final rounds in the different events were rowed and the prizes awarded to the successful competitors. The weather during the two previous days of the regatta was beautiful, which is strange, considering the fact that "Henley weather" is synonymous with rain, drizzle or cold. To-day the good conditions continued, the weather being sunshiny and hot.

The Art Exhibition prepares by persons interested in the University Settlement Society, at 26 Delancey Street, is being largely attended. This annual exhibition is an important part of the work or the Neighborhood Guild, which is the sub-agency of the University Settlement for getting at and helping the residents of this most crowded and most neglected part of this city.

The call issued for a meeting of the representatives of the hide and leather trade to take option regarding the repeal of the silver-purchase law is plain and to the point. It states that "the continued purchases of silver by our Government have created universal distrust, both at home and abroad, have contracted general business, curtailed credits, and, if allowed to continue, must bring general disaster throughout the entire mercantile community of this country."

Tommy Maloney, the newsboy who was supposed to have been "drownded" -- according to the vernacular of the Cherry Hill district -- at the foot of Beekman Street last week, is very much alive. His appearance in the Maloney tenement, at 56 Oak Street, yesterday morning was the occasion for much rejoicing.
The financial outlook has so much improved that the down-town markets are no longer worried over unfavorable conditions.

HELENA, Mon., July 7. -- The Montana silver conference which adjourned here last night was attended by 300 delegates, representing every business interest of Montana. Sentiment was unanimous for free coinage. Speeches were made by Senator Power, Congressman Hartman, Marcus Daly, Lee Mantle, and others.
QUEENSTOWN, July 7. -- The Cunard Line steamer Campania, Capt. Halnes, from New-York July 1, for Liverpool, arrived at at 8:40 o'clock this morning.
NEWPORT, E.I., July 7. -- Associate Justice Samuel Blatchford died at 7:20 o'clock this evening. He passed away peacefully and quietly.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., July 7. -- The handsome first prize in the doubles of the Tuxedo tennis tournament now belongs to Clarence Hobart and Fred H. Hovey, while O.S. Campbell and V.G. Hall have to content themselves with the winning of souvenirs. The fortune of war deprived W.A. Larned and E L, Hall of the second przes as they certainly showed better form than Campbell and V.G. Hall.

MONTREAL, July 7. -- The presence of the great army of Christian Endeavorers here attracts another class of "endeavorers," who are neither Christian nor desirable. Industrious pickpockets made many attempts last night to rob delegates emerging from the tent meeting. From the pocket of the Rev. Mr. Mills a roll of bills amounting to $60 was abstracted, and the thief remains undetected.

EASTPORT, L.I., July 7. -- The young pastor of the little Eastport Methodist Church, the Rev. D.E. Day, is the subject of much gossip because his bride refuses to live with him. The affair is most mysterious, and investigation makes it only more so.

There was standing room only last night in the Aldermanic Chamber in the Brooklyn City Hall. Fully 500 representative citizens were gathered there to protest before the Railroad Committee against the proposed construction of trolley roads through some of the residential streets of the city by the Broadway Railroad Company.

Etienne Hunter, forty-two years old, a traveling salesman recently in the employ of W.A. Reilly Co. of 19 Mercer Street, was held in $720 bonds by Justice Burke, at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, for wife desertion. He agreed to par his wife $60 a month for the support of herself and two children, but, failing to secure a bondsman, was locked up.

PARIS, July 7. -- Before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration to-day, Mr. Phelps continued his closing address in behalf of the United States. He reviewed the report made to the American Government toy Mr. Elliott, who was appointed to investigate the facts in connection with the seal herds, and while so doing he was asked by Sir Charles Russell of counsel for Great Britain why this report had not been printed.

PARIS, July 7. -- There have been conflicts tonight between police and rioters. At the corner of the Rue d' Angouleme the rioters in the Boulevard Voltaire were met by a body of dragoons and lancers. They were ordered back, but pressed ahead.

The precautions taken by Superintendent Byrnes to keep the Anarchists in order at their mass meeting at the Windsor Theatre last evening to celebrate the event of the pardoning of the Chicago Anarchists by Gov. Altgeld had a very salutary effect upon them, and the meeting turned out to be a very tame affair.

The Englewood Field Club continued its tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Englewood, N.J. The good playing of the women contestants was again the noticeable feature of the day. Most of the events ore finished up to the final rounds, which are scheduled for this afternoon.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 7. -- Circuit Judge Hudson, recognized as one of the ablest Judges in the State, has decided the dispensary law now in operation in the State to be unconstitutional.

PORTLAND, Me., July 7. -- At Oakland yesterday the postponed meeting of the Directors and stockholders of the Madison Woolen Mill, the largest in Maine, was held. This mill is at present in financial straits in consequence of disagreement with the former selling agents, H.J. Libby Co., New-York.
Money on call loaned at 6@20 cent. The last loan was made at 6 cent.

-- The seven-hundred-dollar piano offered in the Atalanta Wheelmen's 100-mile race to the club bringing through the greatest number of riders is causing a, lively competition, The piano is on exhibition in Newark, and it is a matter of conjecture whether it will adorn the clubhouse of the Kings County Wheelmen, the Union County Roadsters, the Newark Wheelmen, the Elizabeth Wheelmen, or the Century Wheelmen. The Century, it is said, will enter over forty men.

The steamship Red Sea, which is now en route to this port from Bremen with 800 immigrants on board, is likely to meet a reception that will deter any other speculators from shipping steerage passengers to this country on board tramp steamships.

BERLIN, July 7. -- When the new Reichstag met to-day for the first time for the consideration of regular parliamentary business nearly all the 397 members were in their places, for it was known that the Government would at once introduce the amended Army bill, and general interest was felt to know what conces sions. If any, the Government had made on the original bill.

The Executive Committee of the Catholic Summer School held at the Catholic Club yesterday the last meeting before the opening or the school at Plattsburg next Saturday. The Rev. Fathers Laughlin, Conaty, and McMillan and Messrs. Riley, Moran, and Claxton were present.

MEADVILLE, Penn., July 7. -- Yesterday's heavy rain left the kite-shaped track loose and soft for the harness horses this afternoon. Mr. C.J. Hamlin's stable once more monopolized the honors, Blue Bell winning a highly-creditable maiden race in the 2:33 class, and Moonstone, another starter from the Bufalo turfman's string, capturing the stake of $1,000 for 2:40 pacers.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- "No, the extra session does not hasten my return," said Secretary of the Navy Herbert before starting back to the national capital to-day. "In fact, I shall be in Washington a month, before Congress meets.

-- William Dean Howells tarried for awhile in Buffalo the other day, and a local reporter ran across him in the street, Thus the reporter tells what he saw: "The man was a little below the average height, thick set, and erect. His head was large and well shaped. His face was stern, rugged, and leonine. Heavy gray brows shaded sharp blue eyes.

Antonio Morrogo, an Italian, twenty-two years old, who was arrested Thursday night on a charge of having murdered Pietro Mona at Mechanicsville, Saratoga County, Jane 13 last, was held yesterday in the Ewen Street Police Court, "Williamsburg, to await the arrival of officers. He acknowledged having killed Mona. Mona and Morrogo came to this country from Naples about a year ago and went to Mechanicsville, where they secured employment as laborers.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Controller of the Currency has declared dividends in favor of the creditors of insolvent national banks as follows: A second dividend, 15 per cent., in favor of the creditors of the First National Bank of Kansas City, making in all 40 per cent, on claims proved, amounting to $101,705.

The consolation matches in the Middle states championship tournament were finished yesterday at the Orange Club courts, Mountain Station, N.J. W. Bostwick of the Altiora Tennis Club was the winner, defeating William Vander Kieft in the final round in straight sets, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4. Bostwick used his peculiar "chop" stroke to good purpose.

LONDON, June 23. -- The effect of the action of the Executive Government of India in regard to liver is the following: To rupee paper is given a fixed gold value of 18. 4d. The Indian mints will no longer coin silver for private Individuals; i.e., free coinage is abolished. It is not determined that there shall be a gold coinage for India.

Reid Wardell, the gambler who blackened Howell Osborne's eyes in Burn's restaurant on Sixth Avenue, and who was arrested Wednesday afternoon, was arraigned before Justice Grady in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, morning. As Osborne failed to appear Wardell was discharged.

The sale was announced yesterday of the northeast corner of Sixth Avenue and West Thirty-fifth Street. The lot is 24.8 by 100, and is covered partly by a frame building and partly by a two-story brick one. In March, 1889, the property was bought for $86,400 by Henry McAleenan. He has now sold it to Adam Engel, who keeps a chophouse in the rear portion of the property, for $139,000.

William O'Brien, a criminal whose movements have been watched by the police the last two years with considerable solicitude, was shot and probably fatally wounded last night in Catherine Street by a fellow-criminal who escaped.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 7. -- Three thousand persons witnessed the first days racing of the Toledo Cycling Club and the opening of the new one-third mile track at the exposition grounds this afternoon. The principal event was the mile open race, in which Johnson, Sanger, McDuffle, and Bliss were the principal riders. Sanger went off with a big lead, and at the end of the first lap was over seventy-five yards clear of the field.

Prof. Charles F. Ward of Rochester is reported to have had a peculiar encounter with, the New-York Custom House officials. According to the Rochester Democrat, he has for some time been expecting the arrival of certain geological specimens from the Giants' Causeway on the Irish, coast. Being Intended for educational uses, they are not dutiable.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Prices marched up the hill today and then marched down again. In wheat a falt business was transacted. The opening was about 12c higher than yesterday's closing, ruled firm, and prices were further advanced 58c, then eased off and declined irregularly 1 18c for the September delivery, then held steadily, and the closing was about 18c higher for July, 14c higher for September, and 34c higher for December than yesterday's closing.

Two two-horse races, neither one of which was worth dignifying by calling it a race, and four other contests between a very poor class of horses was the card set out for racegoers at the Monmouth Park track yesterday. The attendance was meagre in the extreme and the racing worse than commonplace. All of which was wrong. Why it is so only owners of race horses can toll.

NEW-YORK. FRIDAY, July 7 -- P.M. Business was again light on the Stock Exchange to-day, the total transaction a barely exceeding 103,000 shares. There was no excitement at any time to vary the dullness. Prices were generally firm, and the strength displayed was maintained to the close.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- In order to secure the widest possible publicity Dr. Walter Kempster, who went abroad for the State and Treasury Departments to make an investigation of the causes and communicability of cholera, has furnished to the press a synopsis of his more elaborate report, which will be issued later.

PHILADELPHA, July 7. -- A special agent of the Treasury Department yesterday seized nearly 1,600 pounds of tobacco which had fraudulently passed by the Custom House at Ogdensburg, N.Y., as fillers, when it was the finest Sumatra leaf, used only as wrappers. It is said that the losses of revenue to the Government by these Canadian importations covering a number of years amount to over $1,000,000.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- F.W. Dunwell, his wife, and three children were struck by lightning in their sleeping rooms Wednesday night. Mr. Danwell and his year-old baby were severely hurt. Mrs. Dunwell and the two older children were not seriously injured. The family lives in a pretty cottage. The house is partially wrecked.

Not long ago the pastor of a Presbyterian flock in Western New-York was making calls in the rural portion of his parish with his wife. They visited one poor family and listened to complaints of how the boys of a godleas household near by had recently on numerous occasions waylaid the boys of this particular household.

The fourth annual regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club will be sailed to-day. Fifty-one yachts have entered, and some rattling good races may be looked for. The start will be made off the clubhouse at Riverside, Conn., at 11 o'clock. Following are the entries:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 7. -- Close, sultry weather greeted a small number of spectators at the closing races of the Summer circuit meeting at Belmont Driving Club to-day. The track was in excellent condition.
Actual business was done at $4.82 12 @$4.83 for 60-day bills, $4.84 12@$484 34 for demand, $4.85 @$4.85 14 for cable transfers, and $4.81 for commercial.

Mayor Gilroy issued a call yesterday for unceasing vigilance in the protection of the public Health. It was in the form of a memorandum to the Department of Public Works, the Street-Cleaning, Health, Fire, Police, and Dock Departments. It follows:

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The attention of the War Department has been called to the operations of a man who signs himself J.J. Fuller and represents himself as a nephew of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

-- To-day will be a busy one in the championship series of the Metropolitan League. Seven games are scheduled, two in the first section, three in the second, and two in the second eleven. The Manhattan and Paterson teams will play at Prospect Park, and the Newarks will play their return game at Morris Park. At Central Park, the match between Harlem and Victoria promises to be closely contested.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 7. -- Eluding the surveillance of the other State officers, Secretary of State Osborn issued a proclamation this evening. He holds that the time has come to strike a blow at the capitalists of this country and Europe, and thinks the bimetallic convention called to meet in this city on July 20 will be the time to begin the battle.

GLASGOW, July 7. -- The regatta of the Corinthian Yacht Club, which was held on the Firth of Clyde to-day, was entirely uninteresting. There was no wind, and the crack yachts entered for the race lazily drifted around the course once. The second round of the contest was abandoned. The Valkyrie proved a good drifter, winning the race in 5:11:04. The Britannia was second in 5:14:05.

An interesting controversy has arisen over District Attorney RIDGWAY'S interpretation of the law in regard to trials for misdemeanors in Kings County. Men quite as learned in the law as he contend that his interpretation is wrong, and that the amendment of the Code of Criminal Procedure upon which, it is based does not take away or restrict the power of Grand Juries to indict for such offenses.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- There is little to be feared from the report, which has found its way into print, of the purpose of some of the silver men in the Congress to combine upon a silver candidate in opposition to Mr. Crisp.

GLASGOW, July 7. -- The regatta of the Corinthian Yacht Club, which was held on the Firth of Clyde to-day, was entirely uninteresting. There was no wind, and the crack yachts entered for the race lazily drifted around the course once. The second round of the contest was abandoned. The Valkyrie proved a good drifter, winning the race in 5:11:04. The Britannia was second in 5:14:05.

An interesting controversy has arisen over District Attorney RIDGWAY'S interpretation of the law in regard to trials for misdemeanors in Kings County. Men quite as learned in the law as he contend that his interpretation is wrong, and that the amendment of the Code of Criminal Procedure upon which, it is based does not take away or restrict the power of Grand Juries to indict for such offenses.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- There is little to be feared from the report, which has found its way into print, of the purpose of some of the silver men in the Congress to combine upon a silver candidate in opposition to Mr. Crisp.
The season has fairly set in at most of the Summer resorts, and many beautiful toilets are seen. At one of the inland resorts near the city the costumes worn at a recent dance were notable.

TRENTON, July 8. -- The State Camp at Sea Girt has been put in condition for the coming of the First Brigade. Under the supervision of Col. George A. Felton of Quartermaster General Donnelly's staff, 400 tents have been erected.

On account of the big attraction at Manhattan Field, only 3,000 persons saw the races of the National Cycling Association at Eastern Park yesterday. Those who remained away missed some very exciting contests, particularly in the handicap events, which were of the closest character.

The Knickerbocker Tennis Club began its second annual open tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Brook Avenue, between One Hundred and Fortieth, and One Hundred and Forty-first Streets. The entries in the singles proved to be so large that the committee decided to make that the only event of the day. All the matches were handicap which the contests close.

A meeting of the Rapid Transit Commissioners will be held this week to consider what shall be done with the plans for elevated railroad extensions. As has already been published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, the Directors and the Committee on Extensions of the Manhattan Railway Company have failed to take definite action upon the propositions submitted to the company by the Commissioners three weeks ago.

From the Westminsiter Gazette. Yesterday morning Col. Curzon held an official inspection on Woolwich Common of three field batteries, comprising eighteen twelvepounder breech-loading guns. One of the batteries was No. 45, just returned from a course of target practice at Okehampton, and in command of Col. North.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- "The silver men are not demoralized, and we will be ready to meet Mr. Cleveland and his friends on the battle ground in a special session," said United States Senator Henry Teller, and he spoke with the confidence of a man who seemed sure or his ground.

Adam Bacon and Samuel Jones were wont to take lunch, together afternoons in the Selwyn cellar. They were similar in taste, liking quiet, plenty of room and air, and a deliberate discussion of some such trifie as a grilled bone, a Welsh rarebit, or a salmon salad to the limpid flow of Mnenchiner beer. They had their accustomed table and waiter, and the former was always as prepared as the latter was prompt.

from the Sotton Budget. Last Winter there came off a dinner to which was invited a lot of widely different people. Mixed pickles was nothing to this assemblage. There were Mayflowers and parvenus, professors and greengrocers, "literary fellers" and college boys.
The Manhattan Opera House Roof Garden closed last night, leaving but three of these popular institutions open.
A HOUSE HUNTER IN EUROPE. By William Henry Bishop, New-York: Harper Brothers.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 8. -- This has been the gala week in all Sea Cliff's history. Up to the Fourth at July the season was quiet, but upon Independence Day it opened with a bound and with a vigor that insure unlimited life and gayety for the rest of the season.

The Englewood Field Club tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Englewood, N.J. It was expected that all the events would be completed by dark, but play was stopped by rain with some of the matches still unfinished. The men's singles, the women's doubles, the consolation women's double, the mixed doubles, and the men's consolation singles were decided.

LOCAL GOSSIP AND INCIDENTS. -- Local society is in such a lethargic condition that there is little going on worth recording. Catering and florist establishments, which are the pulse of the social heart, are as quiet as closed meeting houses. Occasionally a social light will wander into town for luncheon and shopping, but New-York now has no attraction for society people.

The funeral of Associate Justice Samuel Blatchford of the United States Supreme Court will be held in Newport on Tuesday. Chief Justice Fuller, with all of his associates who are in this country, will be among the pall bearers, and many of the great Judges and lawyers of the United States will be among the mourners.

The great advancement in lowing a few years ago and the demand by rowing men for more regattas induced several enterprising and active coating men to form a new association which would embody all the associations in the immediate vicinity and furnish an opportunity for the amateur crews in this section to try their still and strength.

"Mr DEAR CECILIA: "Your letter followed me here. 'Here' means the most delightful of farmhouses in the loveliest dak in Lakeland. It is farmhousey enough to supply fresh butter and real new-laid eggs -- with worn oak stairs two hundred years old, low ceilings, and uneven floors; but civilized enough to satisfy luxurious longings for plated forks and sponge baths.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 8. -- The Fourth was passed very quietly at the shore resorts in this vicinity. Very little was attempted in the way of fireworks except at Eastern Point, where it is the annual custom or the hotel people and cottagers to unite in observing the Fourth. In the evening at the Pequot cottagers and house guests joined in an informal hop.

-- THREE HAUTE Ind., July 8. -- Eighteen of the pick of Budd Doble's string, including Nancy Hanks, Stamboul, Belle Vara, Manage, Datmarch, Pitley, McDoel, Lee, Russell, Margrave, Ballons, and Eland, who have been in training here since the close of last season, left for Detrott to-day to enter the grand circuit.

BERLIN, July 8. -- At to-day's session of the Reichstag Herr Groeber, Centrist, who in the last Reichstag voted in opposition to the Army bill, spoke against the new measure in the name of the Centre Party. The Centrists, he declared, were firmly opposed to the bill, and all the newly-elected representatives of the party were pledged to vote against it.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 8. -- The New-Jersey Sheep and Wool Company, James N. Pidcock, Jr., President, has given two mortgages to the First National Bank of this city to secure promissory notes and loans. The mortgages, aggregating $67,902,15, cover the company's factory and grounds at Jersey Avenue and Fifteenth Street, and have been filed in the Register's office.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 8. -- Dennis Corcoran is at the Charity Hospital, dying from a bullet wonnd just over the heart.

-- At the Spitzer sale the Louvre Museum bought a rectangular bas-relief in pottery, made by Bernard Paliasy, reprosenting a nymph of the waves with the letters EAV in the sky above a seashore and seaport. The nymph of Water rests one elbow on an urn from which a stream flows and carries another urn on her knees.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8. -- Clarence Dingmar was until yesterday utterly unknown to fame. He has been arrested once or twice for chicken stealing and kindred little peccadillos, but outside of the police and the people who lived on his street, he was unhonored and unsung. He became twenty-three years old a short time ago, and decided that it was about time for him to make a name for himself.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 8. -- The week at the Gap has been one of pleasurable excitement. The hotels celebrated the Fourth, in the main with music and dancing. One of the happiest guests at the Kittatinny is United States Senator McPherson of New-Jersey, whose hobby is fishing, and who has found plenty of it.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 8. -- The popularity of Asbury Park as an ideal Summer resort was once more demonstrated this week, the Fourth of July throng presenting the proof that the town is more than holding its own. The holiday crowd was a record breaker and met, in every particular, the expectations of the hotel keepers.

LONG BRANCH, July 8. -- With the Fourth of July, the festivity of the Bummer season here is supposed to take on full swing, and it generally does, but this year the Nation's birthday has passed and those who are here prepared to gather in the dollars or the Summer visitors are getting only a small harvest.

-- The Columbia College Tennis Club announces a college tournament for Tuesday, Sept. 26, and following days. The object of the meeting is to select representatives for the intercollegiate championship tournament, which takes place at New-Haven during the first week of October. The Colombia tournament is also held to decide who are the college champions in the two events, singles and doubles.
"The trouble with the fair," said the Boy, "Is, it's too big."

NEWPORT, July 8. -- Newport has had its fill of exciting incidents this week, both within and without the charmed circle of society. The accident at the United States torpedo station on Monday, by which throe men lost their lives and half a dozen others wore seriously injured, attracted widespread interest throughout the whole community, and a rapidly-increasing subscription shows the deep sympathy for the families of the killed and wounded.

LONG ISLAND CITY, July 8. -- The storm swept across Long Island City. The crashes of thunder and vivid lightning flashes were accompanied by a howling gale, which swept through a narrow track across the city with cyclonic force. Outside of this track the damage done was not great, but within its limits there was literal devastation.

BOUND LAKE, July 8. -- With the arrival of Chester Loomis, the art instructor, the West Gallery of Paintings has been thrown open here, and the exhibition, as usual, is one of very general interest to the art lovers in this part of the State. This exhibition is, in fact, merely an exhibit of some of the chief pictures shown at the Sprine exhibitions of the American Society and the National Academy.

The call for a meeting of the League ot American Wheelmen for the purpose of investigating the Executive Committee's acts and Road Improvement Bureau of the League of American Wheelmen is not being received with approval by several of the State divisions who have been heard from.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 8. -- Wheat speculators are looking for a bullish Government crop report on Monday afternoon, and they advanced wheat lo bushel today on the faith of what they expect. Corn, on similar grounds of an inverse kind, declined a trifle. The Government crop report is expected to indicate a prospective heavy crop. Provision men did some buslness in lard and ribs at slightly improved prices.

On the return of the Seventy-first Regiment to its armory in One Hundred and Seventh Street yesterday afternoon from Peekskill it was learned that every member from the Colonel down is indignant at the conduct of B. W. Bocker, Traffic Manager of the American Express Company. Mr. Booker discharged three of his employes because they had obeyed the call to camp as National Guardsmen.
From Versailles to Fighting Iroquois. THE REFUGEES. A Tale of Two Continents. By A. Conan Doyle, Illustrated. New-York: Harper Brothers.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 8. -- The lace mill strike, which, has involved the financial interests of Patchogue, is over. The mill owners on the first day of June notified the men that a reduction of 25 per cent. in their wages would be made. The lace weavers struck and the National and Federated Lace Weavers' Union gave the strikers a weekly allowance.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8. -- President Barrios, the Dictator of Guatemala, has declared G. Santalana, a young Guatemalan inventor, a traitor to that republic, and death awaits him should he fall into the clutches of Barrios.

William Henry O'Brien, the well-known thief, who was shot Friday nigh by Samuel Mills, an associate, as has been told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, was in a critical condition last night. The bullet entered his abdomen and lodged in the musolos near the spinal column. It was cut out by Dr. O.J. Ward at the Gouverneur Hospital.

The gentlemen prominent in the Democratic Party in Brooklyn who denounce the movement to expose and, if possible, correct jobbery in the City Government there as "an attempt to attack Democracy" are doing their party a very ill turn, In the first place, there is no doubt that very much the larger number of the voters of Brooklyn ore Democrats on national issues.

The cover of this pleasant little book is ornamented with a distaff and flowers of flax, the decoration being inspired by a not unfeminine liking for symbols. All this is proper, since the volume is the first of a "Distaff Series," the volumes of which are to be distinctly representative of women's work, written, set up, and bound by woman.

"A Trip to Chinatown" still braves the midsummer heat at Hoyt's Madison Square Theatre. It is to be withdrawn soon, however, and the faithful people who hare played continuously for nearly two years are to have a much-needed vacation. On Aug. 14 Joseph R. Grimsar and Phoebe Davis will begin a short season at this house in "The New South," a play which created a favorable impression at the Broadway last Winter.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- There is to be an important armor-plate test on Tuesday at the naval ordnance proving ground, on the Potomac. The test was to have taken, place before, but Secretary Herbert desires to witness the firing, and it has bean postponed until his return.

POMEROY, Iowa; July 8. -- A revision of the roll shows that the dead here now number forty-four. The scene is one of the saddest ever witnessed, and even the strongest are compelled to turn away from some of the sights at the City Hall Hospital, where the worst of the 108 injured are.

A noticeable feature of the Anglomania which prevails in New-York is the employment of cockney attendants by some of the prominent clubs. They have managed to surround the admission of an unintroduced stranger to the club precincts with an amount of ceremony that would suffice for the vestibule of the Grand Llama.

Committees representing to Board of Trade and Transportation, the Chamber of Commerce, the Produce Exchange, the NewYork Mercantile Exchange, and the Canal Union met at the Board of Trade and Transportation rooms Thursday to discuss the question of holding the State convention of the Canal Union in this city.

MONTREAL, July 8. -- Another day of the Christian Endeavor Convention is yet in store for the enthusiastic delegates, and Monday morning will witness a general stampede from the city. Mr. Baer makes the statement that, outside of the big convention in New-York City last year, this has been the greatest convention ever held.

In the good ship Falcon, which has called away to carry a band of intrepid voyagers up into the frozen regions, was noticed as a part of its cargo a sewing machine. Mrs. Peary has told of the prize which a needle proved to the Esquimau woman, and how on her previous voyage, one of them unprovided with such a treasure came and asked for one of them, offering her child in exchange.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 8. -- The decision of Judge Hudson that the dispensary law is unconstitutional has caused, considerable commotion, and matters pertaining to liquor selling will be in an unsettled condition until the Supreme Court Shall sustain or overrule the decision.

NEWPORT, R.L. July 8. -- The funeral of Justice Blatchford will take place at 2:30 o'clock Tuesday afternoon. Services will be held in the Summer Episcopal Chapel of All Saints. They will be conducted by Bishop Potter, who probably, will be assisted by Bishop Clark of Rhode Island and the Episcopal clergy of Newport.

The calamity on the barge Republic at Cold Spring, Aug. 12. 1891, whereby thirteen, persons lost their lives and more than fifty others wore injured, was recalled by a decision handed down yesterday in the United States District Court by Judge Benedict.

Wilfrid Ward's previous volume, giving a history of his father's connection with the Oxford movement, met with general approval at the hands of able critics in England. It was praised specially as being moderate in language, courteous to opponents, and an excellent specimen of the biographical art.

One of the most evenly-contested and stubbornly- fought polo games ever played at Cedarhurst was decided yesterday on the grounds at the Rockaway Hunt Club. It was the third and final game in the Alden Cup tournament, and the victory of the Westchesters was by a narrow margin.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 8. -- The Nantucket Summer season will be a short one this year, say the inhabitants of this little island town. Hardly any visitors arrived during June compared to the number usually here, and it is feared that the World's Fair may prove too strong an attraction for many of the usual visitors during the latter part of August and the first of September.

LENOX, Mass., July 8. -- The attention of the cottagers has been centered the last week on Mankeense Lake, where the young people have been dancing and boating. There are a larger number of boats on the lake than ever before. While nearly every one else has a rowboat, Dr. Greenleaf and Anson Phelps Stokes have sailboats.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- One week from to-day the Judges who are to make awards to exhibitors at the fair will begin their work. A few of the foreign Judges have already arrived in Chicago and are quietly inspecting the exhibits in different sections. Most of them are now aboard ocean steamers bound to New-York, Boston, or San Francisco, and will reach Chicago Thursday or Friday of next week.
NORTH BEACH, L.I., July 8. -- The hurricane which struck this place this evening caused the death by drowning of one man, and probably two others were lost.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 8. -- Mrs. Laura M. Johns, President of the Kansas Equal Suffrago Association, has issued an address in which she announces that the suffrage campaign has began. She is an indefatingable little woman, filled with the one idea of suffrage, to which she directs all her energies. She is shrowd, knowing what so few women seem to know -- when to broach her peculiar ideas.
Col. Fred D. Grant, recently United States Minister to Austria, returned to this country yesterday on the steamship New-York. He is in fine health.

Judge Cullen of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on the application of Judge Henry M. Goldfogle and Charles W. Brooke, has set tomorrow morning for bearing their argument on the motion, for a new trial in the case of Frank Daffy, who was sentenced to sine and a half years' imprisonment for the murder of James Cunningham.

-- Guy L. Gary, who defeated George F. Taylor and Henry O. Tyler in the mile race at Walthun is only twenty years old. His riding weight is 145 pounds. He won his maiden race at Worcester on Memorial Day last year and then the Prees Cycling Club, always on the lookout for good men, signed him. He next won the ten-mile road race at Somerville.

The Federal Judges are appointed by the President of the United States, with the advice and consent of the Senate. A great General had become President. He was under the influence of corrupt friends and advisers. This newspaper made public some of the misdeeds at the rulers at Washington. The men thus exposed sought to silence the Sun by a gross abuse of the forms of law.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The New-York State Building has a number of features which add to its general effectiveness and cause people to speak of its regal beauty and grandeur, but none of them is more admired or more universally commented on than is the beautiful floral display, which characterizes and distinguishes it more than anything else.

WATERFORD, Conn., July 8. -- Quite a colony or New-York and New-Jersey people are spending the Summer in cottages on the banks of the Niantic River, a narrow but picturesque stream that for about seven miles winds along the base of wooded hills through the townships of Waterford and East Lyme, and enters the Sound at the village of Niantic, just below the State encampment reservation of the Conncetient National Guard.

William Howard Conkling, the well-known dry goods merchant, who died at his home, 171 West One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, on Friday, was born in Mendom, N.J., in 1837. He was educated at the Mount science Academy, and, after graduation, began his business life in his father's store in the village.

With all the important theatres of New-York closed for the vacation season except five -- Daly'e, where there is an entertainment of magic; the Broadway Theatre, where tuneful folly holds sway; the American, where "The Prodigal Daughter" survives the beat; the Madison Square, where "A Trip to Chinatown" still amuses, and the Academy -- we must go to other towns for theatrical topics.
CONEY ISLAND, July 8. -- The storm here to-night was the worst in many years.

It any one has any doubt that bicycling is it popular sport, he should have gone to the meet of the Riverside Whselmen at Manhattan Field yesterday. This was the third annual meet of this popular club, and the attendance fully justified the assertion that bicycling has become the favorite recreation.

Before the races began at Monmouth Park yesterday afternoon. Auctioneer S.D. Bruce disposed of thirty-one head of thoroughbred yearlings, the get of The Bard. Stratford, and Wilful, and the property of the Cheaterbrook and Foxhill Studs. The youngseters brought fair average prices, the total realized being $15,275.

No better evidence of improved financial conditions could be furnished than that in the face of a decrease of surplus reserves in the banks for the last week at $6,333,750. The stock market held steady yesterday. There is no possible inference from this fact other than that those who operate in general securities feel reasonably sure that the worst is over and that better times are close ahead.
Much has been said about the different vocations whereby a woman can earn a comfortable living, and, with others, piano tuning is now enumerated.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL., July 8. -- The presence of more than fifty charming young women attired in exquisite gowns made the opening ball of the season, which was held in the Kanterskill ballroom this evening, the most brilliant society event ever held in this fashionable resort.

STONINGTON, Conn., July 8. -- New-York and Brooklyn people seem to nave many friends in this historic and picturesquely-situated town, overlooking Fisher's Island Sound. Quits a number are thus early in the season being entertained here.
BIG RAPIDS, Mich., July 8. -- The Northern National Bonk closed its doors this morning. Withdrawal of funds by depositors caused the suspension.

James W. Beyle, the loader for Tammany Hall in the new Ninth Assembly District, expeots to have a great Tammany club in his district before many months. Already the club has 400 charter members at $25 each, and seventyfive of them have taken books and promised to get ten members on each book at $10 apiece.

When the storm was raging last evening. Edward Casey, a young architect, who roomed on the top floor of the Alpine, 55 West Thirtythird Street, with Henry W. Hodge, a mechanical engineer, who has an office at 29 Broadway, attempted to cross Twenty-third Street at Fifth Avenne. The rain cams in sheets, and Mr. Casey, to shield himself, covered his head with his umbrella and made a blind dash across the street.

Tommy Maloney, the undrowned, who came walking back to his mother at 5 o'clock last Friday morning like one risen from the dead, was something of a hero in Oak Street yesterday, and it must be remembered that nobody is a hero in Oak Street unless he has shown himself to be at least as tough as nails.

BABYLON, L.I., July 8. -- Babylon is gay, eruberant, effervescent Life within its picturesque limits is a round of happy days. The sesson is on in earnest, and driving, bathing, the dance, sailing, and other features which fill out a pleasurable day are attended by superior conditions here.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Considerable secrecy has apparently been thrown around the operations of the Intercontinental Railway survey authorized by Congress in accordance with the plan adopted by the Pan-American Conference in 1890. Though reports of a more or less detailed character have been incorporated in the estimates laid before Congress, there has been a hot fight over the appropriations for continuing the work, which have only slipped through in conference between the two houses.

The dispatch published yesterday from Leadville by J.J. Hegerman, the owner of the Mollie Gibson Mine at Aspen, Col., to Frederick D. Tanpen, President of the Gallatia National Bank, imploring him to use his influence with Secretary Carlisle to hove an order issued for the resumption of silver purchases came a day too late to make any very serious impression here.

The last number of the Gortenlaube tells the story of a religious enterprise which has all the romance of the arrange episode of Mermonism without any of its repulsive features, says the Manchester Guardian. About the middle of the present century a Swabian peasant farmer -- Christoph Hoffmann -- conceived the notion that he was divinely called to build at Jerusalem a temple in readiness for the approaching millennium.

From Elsanor Kirk's Idea. Once upon a time, not so very long ago, I was asked to spend, a few hours in a sick-room, a very sick room indeed. The day nurse was exhausted and temporary assistance was necessary. Of course I consented to serve, though I would gladly nave scrubbed the sidewalk instead, had I been permitted to exer- o cise my preference.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 8. -- Amityville is one of the beauty spots of Long Island where nature and her handmaidens have deposited their best and choicest gifts. Woodland and meadow, field and forest, combine with a silvery beach and the glorious stretches of the Great South Bay to make one of the most delightful of all watering places.
A musical paper says that Dr. Dvorak blackens his face when he retires to compose American music on negro themes.

The librettist having said that the costumes for his opera comique, which is to be produced in the Autumn, were to be made in New-York, but that their designs required a visit to Venice, the bibliomaniac asked: "The Venice of the sixteenth century?"

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 8. -- The Columbian year at the Thousand Islands has opened auspiciously, and the Summer season bids fair to be an unprecedented, one. Already many foreigners and people from the old country have passed up the St. Lawrence River on the line steamers and in private yachts for the World's Fair, and not a few of them loiter here to drink in the beauties of this Venice of America.

Excise Commissioner Leicester Holme was at his desk in the office of the board yesterday, looking and feeling none the worse for the runaway accident in which he figured Friday evening. Speaking of the affair, he said:

In one of the three or four old-fashioned districts of New-York-Gramercy, Stuyvesant Washington, or even Abingdon Square -- on the sidewalk of a deserted street, before a courtyard, the open iron gate of which is surmounted by a signboard bearing this inscription:

The Grand Central Real Estate Exchange in East Forty-first Street has been formally incorporated. Its rooms yesterday were fitted up ready for business and the manager, Mr. Oscar C. Selbbach, was in attendance to explain the workings or the new establishment to visitors.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 8. -- The assertion that President Cleveland is seriously afflicted with any malady is all nonsense. It is purely and simply "an invention of the enemy." The most favorable stories that have been sent from here regarding his condition are the true stories, and this is one of them:

The Bowery Savings Bank, which was chartered by a bill introduced in the Legislature Jan. 8. 1834, By Peter S. Titus, a member of the Assembly from this city, will soon own and occupy one of the mess commodious and costly bank buildings in the country. The erection of the building was projected several years ago, but only recently did the Directors prepare to build.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 8. -- Lightning to-night set fire to seventy-five freight cars in the yard of the Consolidated Road in this city. Twenty-four of the cars were without freight, and thirty-six contained cartridges shipped by the Winchester Arms Company of this city to various sporting goods houses in the South and West.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 8. -- There was a large number of cottagers present at the July competition for members and subscribers of the Golf Club played during the last week. The club itself issued no invitations, but cards were sent members and subscribers to invite their friends. There wore a number of contestants in the competition.

MEDICAL DEPARTMENT CHANGES. -- By direction of the Acting Secretary of War the following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical Department, are ordered; Capt. William H. Corbusler, Assistant Surgeon, is relieved from duty at Fort Wayne, Mich., and is ordered to proceed to Fort Supply, Indian Territory, and report in person to the commanding officer of that post for duty, relieving Major Paul R. Brown, Surgeon.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., July 8 -- The regatta on Flushing Bay this afternoon of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club was somewhat disappointing because of the small number of entries. Bat three were entered in Class A, cabin sloops and cutters 26 feet and over, and but three in the second, Class B, comprising similar boats under 26 feet.

Miss Annesley Kenealy, who has been appointed a judge of awards on hygiene and hospital exhibits at the World's Fair, was a passenger on the steamship New-York, which arrived from Southampton yesterday.

PARIS, July 8. -- E.J. Phelps of counsel for the United States finished his closing address before the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration to-day. He opposed the British proposal to establish a twenty-mile zone, within which sealing should he prohibited, basing his objection on the inefficiency of the proposal and upon the impossibility of setting the limits of the zone effectually.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8. -- During the last few weeks an old landmark, which has been a beacon or light to those seeking the safe harbor of Christ's saving grace and love, has passed away, and on the site occupied by the demolished building, at Pearl and Fair Streets. is rising the wails of a church edifice equal in beauty.

Nina Wright, a young girl of Adrian, Mich., recently tried to ride a bicycle. After going about two miles, her dress caught in the gearing. A young man came to her rescue, but could not free her without tearing the dress. This Nina objected to. The young man picked up Nina and the wheel, pat them in a safe place by the side of the road, and then started to tee town for a wrench.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 8. -- The sons and daughters of this pretty little valley, in company with many other visitors, have arrived for the season to enjoy the boating, bathing, fishing, drives, and beautiful scenery hereabout.

ORANGE, N.J. July 8. -- There has been an unusual exodus from Orange this week. The Oranges are fast deteriorating from a fashionable resort in Summer to a one-day mountain amusement place. The number of pilgrims who stroll to the top of the mountain at Eagle Rock and above South Orange increases weekly, but the Bummer residents have largely decreased this year.

FLATBUSH, L.I., July 8. -- A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Chief Engineer William H. Swartwout of the Fire Department, and he was arrested to-day charged with assaulting Thomas Regin, a prominent builder of Windsor Terrace.

-- On the night of July 4, George Arbanasin, proprietor of a resort three miles from Stockton, Cal., was found murdered at his place. Louis H. Schultze, an ex-sailor, surrendered Friday to the police and confessed having killed Arbanasin to avenge his sister, whose downfall Arbanasin had wrought undor a promise of marriage and who committed sulcide about two years ago.
CONEY ISLAND, July 8. -- By the giving way of the platform at the West Brighton Station of the Brighton Beach Elevated Railroad to-day, a number of persons were seriously injured.

It may not be generally known that Naw-York has in Carlo a G. da Garmendia a citizen who is a descendant of one of the oldest noble families of Spain. For over 500 years the ancestors of Mr. de Garmendia have taken conspieuous positions in making Spanish history, and now the Spanish Government holds in particular esteem every representative of the family of de Garmendia y de Cordova de Basque.

The success of last Sunday's experiment has induced the management of the Dore Gallery to open its doors to-day from 2 to 6 P.M. for the convenience of those who cannot attend at other times during the week.

BOSTON, July 8. -- The coming of Sandow to the Tremont and of Samson to the Part, each appearing in his remarkable feats of strength, is the only notable event at the Boston theatres this week. They perform at the close of the regular bill.

This volume was originally published thirty years ago, and bore the rather "too previous" title, "History of Federal Government from the Foundation of the Achaian League to the Disruption of the United States." The author never went beyond his first volume in a work that must have required at least three for its completion.

There are few regiments in the State as popular as the Twelfth, commanded by Col. Heman Dowd, and this fact was emphasized yesterday at noon, when it was greeted with cheer after cheer as it marched from the armory at Sixtysecond Street and Ninth Avenue to the Grand Central Station.

NORFOLK, Va., July 8. -- The woman variously known as Mrs. Harrison and Mrs. Oliver who was with Cicero Harrison Case when he was lost off the steamer Guyandotte a week ago Thursday, has been within twenty miles of Norfolk and gone away without making her presence known to those who have been looking for her.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 8. -- The Fourth was quietly observed here, many taking advantage of the day to picnic on the shores of Otsego Lake. In the evening a fine display of fireworks was given by those occupying cottages in different parts of the village. The John A. Dix new memorial bell on Christ Church was rung by request of its donor, she Rev. Morgan Dix.

LOUISVILLE,. Ky., July 8. -- The New-Yorks were downed again by the Colonels in a well-played game. Ex-King Kelly was behind the bat for the Giants and played a listless game. Both Baldwin and Hemming pitched good ball. The former was given poor support.

"Murph, the newsboy," shared the honors of the State Camp at Peekskill last week with Gov. Flower, Gen. Greene, and other distinguished visitors. It was not "Murph's" intention to be conspicuous, but circumstances led up to the fact, and he was almost lionized.
Weather Forecaster Dunn demonstrated his ability yesterday when he said that a thunderstorm would break over the city before sundown.

In a paper on "Vocations," a woman suggestively says: "The fashionable sin of to-day among women, whatever it may be, is not idleness. To a student from Norton or South Hadley, Wellesley or Smith, idleness is simply an impossibility. If years of thorough methodical, intellectual training have not formed habits and tastes for work, they have resulted in nothing.

The friends of the Dake de Veragua in this city are much exercised over the story that he has lost his fortune, and that when he returns to Madrid he will be without money. Whether the Duke lost the money in speculation in Paris or not, it is certain that his finances were in a bad way when he left Madrid for this country to become the guest of the United States.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 8. -- Congressman Sperry of this city, whose friends say that he is entitled by rank and seniority to the Chairmanship of the Banking and Currency Committee in the Fifty-third Congress, had a two-column interview in a local paper this afternoon, presenting his ideas as to the work that will be accomplished by the special session of Congress.

Paris Correspondent London Dails Telegraph. M. Turpin, the investor of melinite, is naturally very reticent on the subject of the new engine of destruction which he has planned. He has assured the correspondent that it was not his intention to give any information about the formidable weapon to the public, as his secret is reserved for the Government.

The auction sales of real estate announced for this week include only such as are by order of the courts in legal proceedings and contain few offerings of any general interest. The complete list is subjoined:

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., July 8. -- The season at Fisher's Island is now approaching its height Hotels and cottages are filling up, every trip of the steamer Munnatawket from New-London bringing additions to the already large contingent of recreation seekers. The island is growing in popularity as a Summer resort, judging from the new faces that are seen here.
Carl Emanuel, a tourist's agent, died yesterday at the Chambers Street Hospital from an overdone of opium, taken presumably to produce sleep.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Signal Office has been conducting some interesting experiments with a field telephone line imported from France. Capt. C.E. Kllbourne of the Signal Corps has submitted a report of the three accasions when the line was tested to the Chief Signal Officer.

From, the London Dally News. L'Anti-Alieniste is the title of a remarkable and amusing little sheet-written and produced by the patients -- they would no doubt strongly object to being culled lunatics -- of the great Bioetre Asylum. Its editor-in-chief is one Charles Etlinger, and its price the same as the Times.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Foxhall Keene's good colt El Telegrafo won the World's Fair twenty-thousanddollar stakes to-day at Washington Park. Walcott Campbeil's Dolly Varden was secondhand Rhett Goode third. In the betting for this event, Fltrtation and Ganelon were equal favourites, being quoted at 3 to 1. EI Telegrafe was also well liked and hearlly played by a select lew, His price being cut from 5 to 1 down to 4 to 1.
On a tablet in Trinity Church is the inscription, familiar to hundreds of thousands of NewYorkers:

OYSTER BAY, July 8. -- The season at Oyster Bay is now at its height and joy is unconfined. The harbor is full of yachts, hovering about the pretty Seawanhaka Clubhouse on Centre Island, the drives are gay with life, and lavish entertaining is a daily and nightly occurrence.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 8. -- Having become tally convinced that the Populists either cannot or will not do anything to relieve his financial distress, and being determined not to work, Edmund Morgan, a Rice County farmer, has evolved a scheme which he believes will at least afford him a comfortable living.

The feeling of encouragement in financial circles was not visibly diminished or damped by yesterday's bank statement, which showed a decrease of $6,333,750 in the reserves, reducing the joint reserves of the Associated Banks some $5,000,000 below the legal requirement. A elightly easier tone was reported in the loan market, some time accommodations being given at 8 and 9 per cent., as against 12 per cent. earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A few years ago, when the Summer was assumed to be a season for Washington, when everybody who could get away would seek some place loss favored by the sun, the people who were obliged to remain in the capital and those who left it were willing to Admit that there was a season when Washington might be regarded as " dead."

SHELTER ISLAND, July 8. -- Fourth of July evening Shelter Island and the surrounding bay was a scene from fairyland. The grounds of Manhanset House and the Prospect House were illuminated and decorated, and the handcome cottages were not behind in the elaborate display of decorations, colored lights, lanterns, and fireworks.

Disappointment was unmistakable in Wall Street that the rally in the market on the call for the extra session should have been so brief. Activity had departed by Monday's close, and since then there has been dullness nearly amounting to stagnation. An inquiry of a large operator, who might be expected to be doing something on the bull side, received the laconio reply: "The money market prevents."

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 8. -- All the week the trains of the Ulster and Delaware Railroad have been carrying hundreds of people into the Catskills, and the season is now under fall headway. There are about four thousand city people in the mountains, but the floodtide of travel will not be reached until the end of this month. At Stamford the season has started in to be the gayest ever Known in that delightful village.

LONDON, July 8. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent] -- It is agreed, on all hands that London never before has seen such a tremendous crowd as packed the processional streets to suffocation from the earliest hours of Thursday till the beginning of daylight on Friday morning.

The meeting of the American Historical Association will open in Chicago Tuesday and will last three days. The officers of the association are James B. Angell, LL.D., University of Michigan, President; Henry Adams of Washington and Edward G. Mason of Chicago, Vice Presidents; Herbert B. Adams, Ph.D., LL. D., of Johns Hopkins University, Secretary, and Clarence W. Bowen of New-York, Treasurer.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- While the Secretary of the Treasury has come to Chicago ostensibly for pleasure only, questions relating to the sale of exhibits in bond at the fair by exhibitors and the policy to be pursued toward the offenders will be passed upon before he goes away.

The Committee on Extensions of the Manhattan Railway Company asks for more time to consider the propositions of the Rapid-Transit Commission, bat gives no intimation as to whether it regards them with favor or not. The commission's resolution of June 19 called for an answer by July 10, but the company's committee wants sixty days more.

The death of SAMUEL BLATCHFORD leaves only one Justice on the bench of the Supreme Court Who has passed the age of retirement or nearly reached it. Mr. Justice FIELD is seventy-six years of age, and has served on the bench for thirty years continuously, having been appointed by President LINCOLN, though a Democrat in politics.

There have been rumors of late of serious differences existing between the two associations whose cause for being is the placing of a suitable memorial over the grave of Mary Washington, at Fredericksburg, Va.

From the London Dally Newt. It appears from the report made to the Foreign Office by Acting Consul Fraser, stationed, at Chungking, that the heathen Chinee is about as guileless at home as abroad. The Consul reports that an upward-bound chartered junk was last December reported, to the local authority at Wushan as having gone on a rook and lost overboard several valuable Hitems of cargo.

-- Beerbohm Tree is not an Ibsonite. But he thinks Ibsen has "stage sense" as well an poetry and imagination. In producing "An Enemy of Society" he had rather to tone down points than to exaggerate them. "I really think," he says, "that an English audience do not need to have come things repeated and hammered into them as much as apparently the audience for which Ibsen wrote.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, July 8. -- The Casino opened Wednesday night with the first hop of the season. The attendance was very small, owing probably to the inclement weather. It was a regular downpour, and many of the guests, thinking it only a shower, were caught in it before they could protect themselves, with serious damage to pretty dresses and bonnets.

John Clay, heretofore a guest of the Broadway Central Hotel, and a supposed English gentleman of means, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning charged with swindling the proprietor of the hotel out of a board bill. Clay claims to be a mechanical engineer and a representative of the English house of James Watts Co.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 8. -- In the firemen's tournament at Manlton the Crowells Hose Company at Colorado Springs won the first prize in the wet test, beating the world's record. Time -- 0:28 1-5. Distance -- 600 feet. The previous record was made at Boulder -- 0:80 1-5. The Rough and Heady Hook and Ladder Team of Central City won first prize in a 500 foot test, carrying a twenty-foot ladder.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 8. -- In this stirring, bustling Columbian year tourists turn with relief from the thought of hot, dusty, crowded Chicago to the cool shades of the Adirondack woods. For those with a limited vacation the entire time spent at the great "White City "means a subsequent return to business cares worn out alike in mind and body.

MELBOURNE, Victoria, May 27. -- "Australasia is the workingman's Paradise!" "We are the richest people per: capita under the sun!" "The expanse of transportation to Australia is so great that it gives us a batter class of emigrants than are poured into America from the sewers ot Europe." All this and much more of the same kind.

ST. JOHN, N.B., July 9. -- The relationship of Canada to England involves what may be called unconscious servitude, an obsequious attitude destructive of political vigor and selfreliance. Loyalty is confounded with patriotism, the one absorbs the other, and the sentimental adulation wasted on the Queen destroys the noblest instinct, love of country.

Secretary HERBERT talked briefly at Chicago on the one question of absorbing interest at the present time, the financial situation, and the legislation it requires. He said: "A lack of confidence in American securities, both on the part of European and home investors, has caused the present financial panic, for which the Sherman act is directly responsible.

NEW ORLEANS, July 9. -- The great "June rise" of the Mississippi River is again overflowing the garden of the Southern States. But for the line of levees extending from Cairo. Ill., to within fifteen miles of the Gulf, the great river would be from ten to forty miles wide from the month or the Ohio to its triple mouthed entrance into the sea.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., July 9. -- Saturday was a gala day at the camp of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association at Chimmona Island. A good breeze from the west made very good sailing, though it roughened the water a little too much to suit the paddlera. About twenty-five men from the New-York clubs came up to spend Sunday, besides a large number of visitors who inspected the camp and watched tie races.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 9. -- Stockholders in the "irrigation canals" of Western Kansas and Eastern Colorado may wonder why they receive no dividends when they receive reports regarding the wonderful crops that are raised "under the ditches." These canals have been constructed at great expense and are miles in length.

In s private letter written from London by William Q. Judge, General Secretary of the American section of the Theosophical Society, he announces that Prof. Ganendra Nath Chakravarti of Allahabad, India, will attend the forthcoming Theosophical Convention at the World's Fair Congress of Religions.

TRENTON, N.J., July 9. -- Senators McPherson and Smith have both indorsed ex-Senator James Butcher of Salem County for Collector of Internal Revenue in the lower New-Jersey district. Mr. Butcher voted for the race-track bills against the expressed wishes of his constituents, and it is thought that President Cleveland will not appoint him to office.
TRENTON, N.J., July 9. -- The family of Frederick B. Miles, a Philadelphia merchant who has a cottage at Bayhead, were poisoned to-day by eating Bavarian cream custard.

FALLS CITY, Neb., July 9. -- The State Bank at Shubert, a small town south of here, has failed. The Bank Examiner investigated the books yesterday, and last night G.V. Argabright, the cashier, decamped, leaving a statement that he was $21,000 short, having spent that sum on the Board of Trade, and that he preferred to leave his family rather than go to the penitentiary.
Hiram Camp, ex-President of the New-Haven Clock Company, died at his home in Fair Haven, Conn., late Saturday night. He had been in poor health for a year or more.
A new volume in the series of Twelve English Statesmen is ready in London -- "Edward I.," by T.F. Tout. John Morley's sketch of Chatham is the only one of the twelve volumes yet to appear.

Those Republican journals that are telling their readers every day about the "malicious raid" of the Administration upon the pension roll should find time to express an honest opinion as to the discoveries already made by Commissioner LOCHREN in the course of the inspection which the Pension Bureau is making.

NATURALIZATION. -- "Felix": I came to this conntry when nine years of age, and my father was naturalized while I was a minor. When I became of age I asked several lawyers about my right to vote, and I was assured that I was in all respects a citizen and held the right to vote because of my fathers naturalization. For years I have bean voting and I am now holding a public office.

BOSTON, July 9. -- In a recent comment upon the pre-election conditions existing in West Virginia and upon the use of Federal patronage in shaping political sentiment. THE NEW-YORK TIMES said that the control of patronage "is rather a disadvantage than an advantage to the party in power." This is true in Massachusetts as well as in West Virginia, although its application to the prevalling situation must be made upon different grounds.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9. -- The twenty-sixth Bundes Turnfest of the North American Turnerbund will be hold in Milwankee July 21 to 26. It will be the most-largely attended fest in the history of the organization. The nearness of Chicago and the World's Fair will be the means of largely increasing the numbers in attendance.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9. -- The NewYork Liederkranz arrieved in Milwaukee from Chicago on a special train at noon today. Members of the Milwaukee Musical Society, with Bach's Band, met them at the station and escorted them to the Hotel Pfister. Then, as they filled the corridor, President Joseph C. Emerling of the Musical Society spoke a few words of welcome.

Alonzo J. Whiteman, who is in Freehold, N. J., awaiting requisition papers on which to be brought to this city to answer the charge of having passed a worthless cheek on Purdy F. Case, has written to a friend in this city that he is anxious to come and moot the charges. He was arrested at Monmonth Park last Tuesday.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 9. -- A dispatch from Sour Springs states that Judge Warrick Tunstall, aged seventy-four years, who mysteriously disappeared last Tuesday morning from his home, was found yesterday morning in a pasture about nine miles from the Springe. He was lying asleep when found, and was speechless from hunger, thirst, and general exhaustion, but was soon revived by stimulants.

In a small bedroom at 37 East Fourth Street yesterday Lillian Payne, a young wife not yet out of her teens, lay suffering great agony in spite of all that medical science could do to aileviate her pain. In the jail at the Essex Market Police Court Arthur Payne, her husband, was held without benefit of bail to await the result of the injuries he had inflicted upon her.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 9. -- Word comes from Englewood, Clark County, of the drowning of William Waddell, his wife, and four children while in camp on the border awaiting the opening of the Cherokee Strip.

The big armored cruisor Maine was subjected daily the past week to preliminary trials of her main engines. Members of the official naval board wore in constant attendance upon these preliminary tests. The indieations from the present workings of the angines, engineers say, point to a successful official trial.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 9. -- The Twelfth Regiment, which succeeded the Seventy-first at the State Camp, has settled down to hard work. Thr men came hero yesterday with the intention of outstripping their predecessors, and everything has begun auspiciously.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The recent disaster to her Majesty's ship Victoria seems to have proved to the enthusiastic advocates of the ram the very great value of that weapon in naval warfare. Is that a fair deduction from the circumstances attending, the collision?

A reader of the TIMES, wishing to give credit to the older rowers of Harvard, believes in counting the series of events between Harvard and Yale from 1852 and the earlier six-oared races, and furnishes the following table to show that Harvard still leads Yale by three victories:

CITY OF MEXICO, July 8. -- Mariano Leyva, a wealthy farmer of the Valley of Mexico, when crossing a range of mountains recently when be suddenly lost his footing and was precipitated into a deep chasm. He saved himself from being dashed on the rocks below by grabbing hold of a bush about 100 feet from the top of the canon.

In speaking of the famed Chancellor Pasquier, Taine has remarked that he "is probably the best-informed and most judicial witness of the events of the first half of this century." Taine's opinion is fully confirmed by the memoirs of the Chancellor, the first volume of which has just been given to the public through the Duc d'Audiffret-Pasquier.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 9. -- It was Sanger's day at the races of the Toledo Cycling Club yesterday. The time made by the winner, 2:28 1-5, was five seconds slower than Johnson's best mile Friday, but the pace was a fast one from start to finish. The best time of the two days' racing is 2:20, made by Sanger in the fourth heat of the one-mile handicap.
