The New-Haven steamboat Richard Peck, whoso highest ambition, is to show her heels to some other boat, the Puritan of the Fall River Line preferred, has had her pride lowered by the little yacht Vamoose.

MONTREAL, July 9. -- In a blaze of enthusiasm the Christian. Endeavorers to-night wound up their twelfth annual convention. The sole incident regretted, by the vast majority of the delegates participating in it is that a few rabid, members uttered words which engendered ill-feeling among the Catholic population, and created bitterness where harmony should have reigned.

Twenty-five members of the Kings County Tennis Club journeyed to Ridgowood, N.J., Saturday to try conclusions with the local players of the Hohokus Valley Club. The meeting was the result of an invitation to the Kings County Club to spend the afternoon and evening at Ridgewood as the guests of the Hohokus tennis players, and the tennis matches were made the excuse rather than the object of the trip.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 9. -- It is now definitely known that the Mexican whom Sheriff Ney of Medina County shot and killed last week and who gave the name of Zaragosa Flores was in reality Challos Garcia. Garcia, though a young man, had made a criminal record that placed him in the category of the worst and most desperate men of the Southwest.

BERLIN, July 9. -- The present week will be one of political trades and deals. Government agents are already scurrying hither and thither to rally the Parliamentary forces. Members of all parties, except the Social Democrats and Richter Radicals, are in, daily conference with the representatives of the Chancellor.

BERLIN, July 9. -- About 400 excursionists from the principality of Lippe-Detmold visited Prince Bismarck in Friedrichsruhe to-day. Both the Prince and the Princess responded to the cheers of the excursionists by appearing on the balcony of the castle. Despite the recent reports of the Princess's bad Health, she looked strong and cheerful.
To-day's auction sales or real estate are four in number and are all in foreclosure proceedings. They will be had at 111 Broadway. The list follows:
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 9. -- The excursion of a merry party of picnickers from this city met with a sad ending at Chickamauga to-day.

Vessels that capsize in a seaway do not usually survive that feat, but the cutter Queen Mab, which yesterday reached port in tow of the tug Triton, managed to achieve that triumph during her voyage from Plymouth, England, to Bermuda. An outline of the eventful trip and the cutter's disastrous encounter with an Atlantic cyclone was told when the crippled vessel put into Bermuda for repairs.

The examination of Mrs. Sarah E. Whyte, otherwise known as "Lurline, the Water Queen." who is charged with assaulting Eugene Sandow, the strong man, was adjourned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday until July 17.

"You must write me every day while you are gone, Mary," said Mrs. de Trolley of Brooklyn, and Mary, like a dutiful daughter, said, "Yes, mamma." But Mary had no notion of wasting her time in Chicago writing letters; so she wrote a dozen before starting. She mailed the first letter at Albany, and supposed as she dropped it in the box that she was forwarding merely a report of progress, comfort, and contentment.

POMEROY, Iowa, July 9. -- Sunday has passed very quietly here outside of the large crowds of people that are coming in from all directions. Some of them paid as high as $2 per head to come in a wagon to see the ruins. Every available horse and vehicle within a radius of twenty miles was utilized, while hundreds walked.

-- Barge parties were popular on the Harlem River yesterday. President Shannon of the Wyanckes had charge or a party bound for Bronson's. The Dauntless and the Lone Star barges, crowded with friends, went to College Point, where teams of the clubs crossed bats and played an interesting tie game of baseball. The Empire's barge had a pall up to Seeley's, where the boys passed a pleasant afternoon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 9. -- Dr. Leslie A. Sutton of Gayhead, Dutchess County, a prominent member of the Dutchess County Medical Society, has been sued for $5,000 damages for Blander and assault. The plaintiff is Mrs. Jennie M. Cochran of Hopewell Junction. Mrs. Cochran is the wife of the Rev. Wilbur W. Cochran, now engaged in missionary work in India.

While praise services were being hold yesterday in the Baptist Tabernacle in Second Avenue, a man in the gallery kept careful watch on the big stereopticons which the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter, pastor of the church, has often used in his illustrated lectures on religious subjects.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., July 9. -- William Platt, forty-five years old, of 225 Nassau Avenue, Greenpoint, went in bathing at Rockaway Park to-day, and dived from a high dock at that point. The water was but four feet deep. He struck the bottom with such force that he broke his back.

-- The New-York Jockey Club will begin its tennis tournament at Morris Park on Aug. 7. The contestants will compete for a crap valued at $500, which will become the property of the one winning it three times. Each temporary owner will have his name engraved on it. Besides the cap there is a silver flower dish which will be awarded to the winner of the tournament.

A statement has been issued from Washington giving the number of appointments in the Presidential Post Offices and in the fourth-class offices during the first four months of this Administration and the corresponding period of the preceding Administration. The Presidential appointments are 434, against 578 under Mr. HARRISON; the fourth-class appointments are 8,956, as against 11,109 under Mr. HARRISON.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: It is to be regretted that the in most respects admirable letter of ex-Senator Henderson to Secretary Carlisle should he marred by the acceptance by the former of the balance-of-trade falacy. As a matter of fact, the balance of trade has little, if anything, to do with the movement of gold across international boundary lines.

When the Tammany Aldermen, under the provisions of the reapportionment law, cut the city up into thirty new Assembly districts last year, the good Republicans of this town scanned the new map closely and looked fondly at the new Twenty-third Assambly District. "That will be a Republican district, at any rate," they said with satisfaction.

Owing to the very low price of wheat in our markets and the prospect of small crops in several European countries, the quantity of wheat and wheat flour exported in the last five weeks has been large. We append the report of shipments published in Bradstreet's for the weeks ending on the dates mentioned:

In a pamphlet just issued, called "The Manual of the American Bible Society," the Rev. Albert S. Hnnt, D.D., one of the Secretaries of that organization, has collected a number of curious and interesting facts concerning the publication and circulation of the Holy Scriptures.

JERSEY CITY, July 9. -- "She says we ought to do our baptizing in running water." said the head usher to Deacon Thomas Miller, as they stood talking together today on the side steps of the Bergen Baptist Church, in Madison Avenue.
The first-class British torpedo gunboat Antelope will be launched at Portsmouth on Wednesday. The Antelope is being engined by Yarrow Co.

GOSHEN, N,Y., July 9. -- When eccentric old Thomas White died here in 1807 he left a will which provided for the annual payment of $1O apiece to the pastors of four churches in Orange County, requesting that once a year they preach a sermon called "The White Sermon." The conditions of this peculiar will in relation to the preaching of "The White Sermon" are as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 9. -- For months the management of the Southern Hotel have been, trying to catch a smart sneak thief, who has made life a burden to them. He has stolen all manner of things, from silk handkerchiefs to gold watches, from the rooms of guests, and all efforts to catch him seemed futile.
VANCOUVER, B.C., July 9. -- A correspondent at Honolulu, writing per steamship Warimoo, under date of July 1, says:

From the Boston Herald, (Ind.,) July 7. New-York has spoken on the currency question, and her voice will find an echo in every important commercial city of the country, outside of the silver mining States. Her merchants have given emphatic expression to their condemnation of the Sherman act and their demand for the prompt repeal of its silver purchase clause.

Ex-Gov. Person C. Cheney of New-Hampshire, who was appointed United States Minister to Switzerland in January, returned to this country yesterday on the Champagne accompanied by his family. They will go, to-day or to-morrow, to their Summer home at Rye Beach.
CONEY ISLAND, July 9. -- The storm of last night, which did little damage here, made today an ideal one for pleasure-seekers. The air was fairly cool and delightful breezes were plenty.

The number of seamen allowed in the United States Navy by law is 7,250. In addition there are 1,500 apprentice boys. The apprentice system was established in the early seventies, when it was supposed that it could furnish a sufficient number of trained seamen for the navy, and would make the enlistment of all others unnecessary.

The appointments of this year's graduating class at West Point include no fewer than sixteen additional Second Lieutenants -- that is, after the vacancies in the arm or corps are filled, these officers have been added, as the law allows. Five of the sixteen go to the Engineer Corps, four to the cavalry, and seven to the artillery.

Dr. Horacio Guzman, who has been the representative of the Nicaraguan Government at Washington, came to this city yesterday from the capital. He will sail on the Newport for Nicaragua to-day, having been recalled by his Government.

PARIS, July 9. -- M. Peytral, Minister of Finance, resigned late last night. A Cabinet Council was held this morning. Wide differences of opinion as to the proper policy toward the mobs in Paris became apparent at once, and a general Ministerial crisis is imminent.

Through the advice of Lawyer John D. Townsend, Banker James H. Drake has decided, not to have his daughter Edith, arrested. The lawyer thinks the girl and her lover, Samuel McGibney, have been married.

Surveyor Lyon, who was supposed to have ended his labors in office, has returned to his desk in the Custom House. Auditor Blatchford, who was left in charge of the Surveyor's Department, being called away to attend the funeral of Justice Blatchford, Mr. Lyon decided to go back to his office and hold the fort until his resignation is accepted.

The officers of the three Russian war ships now lying in the North River were the guests yesterday of Gen. Daniel Butterfield, who entertained them at his Summer home, Cragside, near Cold Spring on the Hudson. Afterward the party visited the Military Academy at West Point and reviewed the cadets. They were taken up the Hudson on the steam propeller Aurora.

DENVER, Col., July 10. -- The Chamberlain Investment Company, the largest real estate concern in the West, closed its doors this morning. The liabilities, direct and contingent, are $2,332,190 and assets $2,940,691. The failure was brought about by an attachment obtained by D.H. Furgeson, President of the Denver Savings Bank, for $3,600, on which he held securities greatly in excess of the amount.
The Staten Island Athletic Club is preparing for its first annual carnival of Summer sports. The entertainment will take place at the club grounds every evening during the week of July 17.

That prosaic but invaluable volume, the NewYork City Directory, has just appeared in its one hundred and seventh edition. It is the oldest publication in existence in this country. The new volume maintains in every way the high standard for accuracy and completeness which the Trow Company has established for its publication.

ST. Louis, Mo., July 10. -- A. party of market fishermen at work Saturday morning in a slough setting back from the Ohio River at a smallgroup of houses called O'Bryan's Landing, about fourteen miles south of Cairo, Ill., was attracted to a clump of willows growing close to the waters' edge by a horrible stench.

Senor Alciabiades Sirocco of Bolivia is in mucn trouble. Ever since the band of Indians from Bolivia were stranded at New-Brunswick, N.J., while on their way to the World's Fair, he has had charge of them.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Among the fourthclass Postmasters appointed to-day were the following:

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 10. -- The President made his first fishing trip to-day since he arrived at Gray Gables. He was accompanied by Col. Lamont and Dr. Bryant. The party went down the bay five miles, cast anchor off Wine's Neck and fished for several hours, their eaten being soup, tautog, and bass.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- The local market opened dull and lower in sympathy with London prices. Traction stocks were dull and firm. The selling of Metropolitan Traction has ceased for the moment, and there are quite a number of buying orders in the market in the neighborhood of par. It is believed that Mr. Voorhees will not make any concessions to the Reading employes.

An application is to be made to-day in behalf of Mayor BOODY to Judge MOORE of the Brooklyn Court of Sessions for an order directing the publication of the minutes of the Grand Jury of Kings County for the June Term with reference to the inquiry into the acts of the Mayor and Aldarmen in granting certain street railway franchises.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., July 10. -- The resignation of the Rev. Dr. John S. Penman, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of this place, while it occasioned little surprise here, will probably cause some dismay am one the Presbyterian, leaders throughout the country, inasmuch as Dr. Penman had been considered one of the coming bright lights of the Church.

Civil Justice Moore, sitting yesterday in Judge Alfred Steckler's court, decided that the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter had no right to order His late co-laborer at the Tabernacle Baptist Church, the Rev. James W. Putnam, to quit the flat he occupied at 162 Second Avenue.

A tornado which had happened to come that way the night before had carried off the awning, killed the proprietor, and maimed half a dozen waiters, but business was going on in the usual way, notwithstanding. "That ain't nothin," remarked one of the natives when a stranger commented upon the seemingly quick recovery.

The funeral of Alpheas R. Geer, who died Sunday morning from injuries received at the Murray Hill Turkish Baths, will take place today at 2 P.M. The funeral services will be held at the home of O.J. Geer, the father of the deceased, 282 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn. The son's home was in Garfield, N.J. On account of the serious illness of the daughter of O.J. Geer the services will be private.

A.C. Young, who has large mining interests in the Pachuca district of the State of Hidalgo, Mexico, arrived in this city yesterday. Mr. Young has made a careful study of the financial conditions in Mexico.

ROBY, Ind., July 10. -- John Griffin, the Braintree Iad, was knocked out in the fourth, round by "Solly" Smith, the Pacific coast champion, at the Columbian Athletic Club Arena to-night in a contest for a $6,000 puree and featherweight championship. It was a chance blow that won the fight for Smith.

SUBSISTENCE DEPARTMENT. -- The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the subsistence Department are ordered: Capt. Edward E. Dravo, Commissary of Subsistence, will be relieved from temporary duty in the office of the Commissary General of Subsistence, and will then proceed without delay to Denver, Col., and report in person to the commanding General.

Complaint has teen made of the marshy taste of the Croton water in this city. Some people have been tearful lest it indicated organic matter in the supply which might prove unhealthful. In some cases householders have found the water very muddy.
LONDON, July 10. -- The American yacht Navahoe, Mr. Royal Phelps Carroll, owner, which is to sail in several of the English regattas, arrived at Cowes, Isle of Wight, to-day. She reports "all well."

This is the story of a series of episodes in the Tooderloin district which caused the blase loungers of that wicked pare of the town to marvel greatly: Sunday afternoon, when Broadway about Eighteenth Street was made the parade ground of young women with their escorts, there were four promenaders who caused even the oldest of the loungers to turn about and take a second look at them.

LONDON, July 10. -- There is a well-directed organized combination at work in New-York and London to foster distrust by circulating rumors of financial difficulties. Each day brings rumors of some American capitalist in trouble, coupled with inquiries worded somewhat as follows: "What well-known house is in difficulties ? What bankers are reported shaky ? and so on.

Dr. Frank J. Freel, Coroner's physician of Brooklyn, yesterday examined the body of Charles Rookwell, a home and fresco painter, who died in a cell at the Twelfth Precinct Police Station, at Atlantic and Schenectady Avenues, Brooklyn, last Saturday night, and decided that the man had not died from alcoholism, as alleged by the police, but from a ruptured blood vessel in the brain.
John Over of 148 West Sixty-fourth Street seated himself upon the stoop of 168 West sixty-fourth Street about 9 o'clock last night and shot himself through the heart.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The controversy between Surgeon General Tryon of the navy and Capt. J.W. Philip of the cruiser New-York is not settled, and the matter was before Secretary Herbert to-day.

BUFFALO, July 10. -- Louis L. Trowbridge, who passed a bogus draft for $2,500 on the Third National Bank in this city a year ago, was brought here yesterday from St. Louis. He gave himself up to the police there with the expectation of being sent to California, where he had committed a crime. His surrender to Buffalo officers was not on his programme.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, July 10 -- P.M. The bears were aggressive to-day, and they were successful in bringing about a lower level of prices. Mr. Cammack, their leader, gave out a most pessimistic interview, his first public utterance in a long while, but there were suspicions that his published opinions were not his real sentiments, and that he was manceuvring to cover his outstanding short contracts.

There is no further occasion for the savings banks to retain accumulations of currency in their vaults. They passed their danger point on July 1, and as no run took place and there were no evidences of fright on the part of depositors on that date or during the week subsequent, it is tolerably clear that no unusual withdrawing of savings is to be apprehended.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 10. -- Judge Hudson's decision declaring the Dispensary act unconstitutional has been filed. The Judge quotes many authorities on the limits of legislative authority and on what is the police power of a State. The prohibition and sale of intoxicating liquors, he declares, comes within the police powers of the State.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 10. -- Capt. J. N. Daniels, a prominent citizen of this city, returned to-day from a ten days' hunting trip in the mountains 100 miles northwest of here, in the course of which he made a wonderful discovery and had an experience which nearly cost him his life.

Mayor Boody will to-day ask Judge Moore of the Brooklyn Court of Sessions to order that publicity be given to the minutes of the June Grand Jury, which expressed regret at not being able to indict him and the Aldermen because District Attorney Ridgway had advised them that there was a section of the Code of Criminal Procedure which deprived them of the power to do so.

TRENTON, N.J., July 10. -- The principal argument in the suit to test the Gerrymander act of 1891 was began to-day before a branch of the Supreme Court, which consists of Justices Depue, Lippincott, and Reed. The Republican side was represented by Cortlandt Parker, R. Wayne Parker, Thomas McCarter, and John R. Emerv.
A very light demand for money from the interior and considerable shipments of currency to this city helped to show yesterday that the financial situation was continuing to improve.

The trunk line Presidents will meet in the Jersey Central Building, in Liberty Street, today for the purpose of settling, if possible, the question of cheap excursion rates to and from Chicago. Nearly all of the Presidents have, by letter, signified their approval of the proposition to issue a half-rate ticket for the World's Fair, making the cost for the round trip from this city $18 and $20, according to the route traversed.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- It was a very light card at Washington Park to-day, and the attendance was very much smaller than on previous days. The feature of the day was Little "Soupe" Perkins's work in the saddle, ho landing four winners and finishing second on Forest Ross in the closing event.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The art of France in interior decoration and furnishing has in the opinion of judges in these matters, been equaled, if it has not been surpassed, by a well-known Now-York City firm, which has achieved great distinction as artistic designers and furniture makers. This firm is Herts Brothers, at Broadway and Twentieth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The statement of the United States Treasurer showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day is as follows:

The Building Department during the past week received applications for the erection of thirty new buildings, involving a total estimated cost of $1,184,000, and also for alterations to be made to thirty-six different structures at a cost of $114,000.
The Health Department is rich in hospitals and sanitary camps, both at the East River and Sixteenth Street and on North Brother Island.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Secretary of Agriculture has during the past few weeks received many requests, some of them direct, some through United States Consuls abroad, and some through the foreign legations in Washington, for information as to the extent and character of this year's forage crops in the United States.

Until the financial tangle of the City of Indianapolis can be straightened out the NewYork Life Insurance Company will stand between that city and actual distress by furnishing money enough to tide over the emergency which confronts it. Edward N. Gibba, Treasurer of the New-York Life Insurance Company, sent a telegram yesterday to this effect on behalf of the Directors of his company to the Mayor of Indianapolis.

The cricketers of the steamship Majestic went up to Morris Part yesterday for a game with the home club and administered a defeat to them by 11 runs. T. Fayer, for the sailors, did the best work of the day and obtained top score with a hard-hit contribution of 24, while Henry Martin did the best work for Morris Park.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 10. -- A killing took place Sunday at Chef Menteur a hunting and fishing resort near the city on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 10. -- Pension Attorney John W. Eighney of this place said to-day that there are 350 veterans in Montgomery County who are receiving pensions under the act of June 27, 1890. Under the recent ruling of the Pension Department the names of 250 of them, he declares, will be dropped from the list.

BOSTON, July 10. -- Arbitrage trading was smaller than for several days. Union Pacific was weak, while New-England held its gain of last week and was inclined to advance. Old Colony declined to 180 1/4, West End Railway to 55 1/4, and Quincy Copper to 105. Boston and Albany advanced to 208 and Bay State Gas to 8. The bank statement was as follows:
Henry Zinsler desires a divorce from his wife Marie, because he says she deserted him in Rome for the Ambassador of the Argentine Republic, A. Montero.

The latest Columbus medal restores to Spain, in symbol, legend, and artistic merit, the glory accorded to Italy by the superb medal engraved at Milan. The latest medal is the work of I.C. Lauer, the medallist of Niirenberg. It is issued in three sizes, 2 3/4, I 3/8, and 11-16 inches in diameter, in gold, silver, bronze, and gold-plated metal.

MAY'S LANDING, N.J., July 10. -- Henry Gravers, a well-known, farmer of Winslow, a few miles from this place, died from a rattlesnake's bite yesterday. He had a fierce battle with, the reptile, and the manner of his death has created the greatest excitement in that borough.

Mrs. Kate Lawrence of 261 West Thirty-ninth Street, who advertises herself as Dr. K. Lawrence, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday to await the result of an operation upon Gertle Carney, seventeen years old, of 51 Columbus Avenue. Miss Carney visited Mrs. Lawrence on July 3 with Oscar Berger, to whom she was engaged, and soon after returning home she became very ill.

CASINO ROOF GARDEN. -- The weekly change of programme attracted a very large crowd to the roof garden of the Casino last night. The entertainment was excellent in every particular, and is deserving of all the applause it received. Trewey, who closes his engagement next Sunday and returns to Europe, gave his ever-popular "shadowgraphs," and also introduced several pretty juggling tricks.
Capt. Brady, the skipper of Charles R. Flint's last steam yacht Javelin, waa amused yesterday when he road the accounts of the race between the Javelin and the speedy little Vamoose on Sunday.

The United States cruiser San Francisco, now in Gardiner's Bay, Long Island Sound, will engage in target practice until July 15. On July 15 the San Francisco will sail for Boston, Mass., and in company with the double-turreted monitor Miantonomoh will, on July 18, embark the Massachusetts Naval Reserve Batsalion for a practice cruise at sea.
The money market was comparatively easy. Call loans were made at 4@10 cent. The last loan was made at 4 cent.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The July returns to the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture makes the following averages of condition: corn, 93.2; Winter wheat, 77.7; Spring wheat, 74.1: Cats, 88.8. rye, 85.3; barley, 88.8; potatoes, 94.8; tobacco, 93. The preliminary acreage of coin is reported as 103.3 as compared with the acreage harvested last year, being an increase of something over 2,000,000 acres.

In the Real Estate Salesroom, at 111 Broadway, yesterday Mr. James L. Wells sold under foreclosure, for $3,600, the premises 664 East One Hundred and Forty-sixth Street, south side, 99.8 1/2 feet east of Willis Avenue, 25 by 100; two-story frame dwelling and barn. Adler Herman were the purchasers.

The members of the wholesale drug firm of W.H. Schieffelin Co. were somewhat amused yesterday over a dispatch from Pittsburg which stated that drug houses in that city were complaining because the firm had demanded payment for its goods in gold.

DENVER, Col., July 10. -- The state silver mass meeting to be opened in this city to-morrow promises to be the biggest convention ever held in this city. It will last two days. Every mining camp and town in the State will send a big delegation.

The Indian chiefs who have arrived at the World's Fair, representing the Iroguois or Six Nations, have as one of their number an interesting man named SOLOMON O'BAIL. He is a grandson of that celebrated Seneca half-breed who was known in his time as the Corn Planter. The Indian warfare of the Revolution had not more than one or two distinguished leaders who, in point of services, surpassed the Corn Planter.
A queer case in the double identification of a man of the name of Joseph Sauer, who died in this city in 1880, is puzzling the keepers at the Morgue.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10. -- The parade grounds of the State Camp were never in better condition than they were to-day and a cool wind from the hills made the weather all that could be desired.
Annie Unger, a young woman of Winfleld, L. I., yesterday caused the arrest of Mrs. Dora Perlmann of 205 Wallabout Street, Brooklyn, and Aaron Rusky for grand larceny.

CHICAGO, Ill, July 10. -- Thousands of people, bent on pleasure, saw death in its most appalling and heartrending form at the World's Fair to-day. In a fire which destroyed the great cold-storage warehouse just inside the Sixty-fourth Street entrance to the grounds, a dozen lives were probably lost, and many men received serious, if not fatal, injuries.

-- The principal tennis event of the season in the West will be the tournament given by the United States National Lawn Tennis Association on the grounds of the St. George Cricket Club, beginning July 25. It is expected that the mesting will last two weeks. The events of greatest interest will be the contests for the championship of the United States in doubles and the World's Fair championship in singles.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, July 10. -- Charles F. Miller, a barber, who works at the Sturtevant House, Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway, New-York City, was awakened early this morning at his home by his wife, whom he had told to call him in good season that he might keep a business engagement in Long Island.
An action for a limited divorce has been begun against Samuel Thalmun of the firm of Isaac Somers Co., wholesale liquor dealers at 20 Nassau Street.
WORCESTER, Mass., July 10. -- Congressman Walker made public the following letter from Senator John Sherman, which her received to-day; The Hon. J.H. Walker:
-- L. Victor Baughman of Maryland and Major A.O. Bacon of Georgia are at the St. James Hotel.

-- East-bound freight shipments out of Chicago last week were 46,793 tons, against 47,408 tons for previous week and 51,087 tons for the corresponding week last year. Michigan Central carried 5,464 tons, Wabash 2,923, Lake Shore 9,335, Fort Wayne 6,329, Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis 5,020, Baittimore and Ohio 2,780, Chicago and Grand Trunk 2,351, New-York, Chicago and St. Louis 4,586, Chicago and Erie 5,072, and Big Four 1,943.

PITTSBURG, July 10. -- After winning seven straight games Pittsburg lost to-day to what has been termed the New-York cripples in a hardhitting, but loose fielding, game. It was a close and exciting contest throughout, New-York winning in the ninth on doubles by Connor and Doyle.

LONDON, July 10. -- The discussion of the ninth clause of the Irish Government act, which relates to the representation in the Imperial Parliament of Irish counties and boroughs, began to-day in Committee of the Whole of the House of Commons, the Right Hon. John W. Mellor in the chair. The bill provides for the retention of eighty Irish members in the Imperial Parliament, a reduction of twenty-three in the present representation of Ireland.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Pension Bureau has notified a great many pensioners turonghout the country who are drawing pensions under the act of June 27, 1890, known as the Dependent Pension act, that payment of their pensions will be suspended for sixty days, during which time they are required to show cause why they should continue to draw pensions.

"An enemy has done this," quoth Congressman Timothy J. Campbell yesterday evening to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter when, sitting down to dinner in the cozy front basement room at 14 Columbia Street, he denied the report setting him forth to the contempt of his east side constituents as a full-blown author and the perpetrator of a book to be known by the McAllisterian title of "Washington Society as I Have Found It."

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- It is apparent to those who read the Montana newspapers that the people of that State are being wrought up to a state of high excitement and determination about silver, and are combating, by resolution, the commercial event which has led to the shutting down of many of the silver mines and the loss of employment to many of its citizens.

The art of the magician Kellar, defiant of penetration, yet withal exceedingly pleasing to witness, mystified and amused a large audience at Daly's Theatre last night. He is apparently the most candid of men when doing the most wonderful things, and his audiences still feel that he is taking them into his inner confidence when he is most completely blinding them.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 10. -- Thomas Slugg, a small farmer at Carteret, three miles from here, has a pasture lot in front of the railroad station in which he put two horses belonging to a New-York business man to graze last night. This morning the horses were found lying on the ground with their throats partly cut and their breasts, legs, flanks, and noses slashed.

The art of the magician Kellar, defiant of penetration, yet withal exceedingly pleasing to witness, mystified and amused a large audience at Daly's Theatre last night. He is apparently the most candid of men when doing the most wonderful things, and his audiences still feel that he is taking them into his inner confidence when he is most completely blinding them.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 10. -- Thomas Slugg, a small farmer at Carteret, three miles from here, has a pasture lot in front of the railroad station in which he put two horses belonging to a New-York business man to graze last night. This morning the horses were found lying on the ground with their throats partly cut and their breasts, legs, flanks, and noses slashed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- Henry Baker, aged thirty-three, a furniture commission merchant, and William Golden, aged twenty-one years, a member of the firm of Morris Lewis, cloth dealers of this city, were drowned in a pond in an old quarry on Mr. Baker's country seat, at Hillside, yesterday afternoon.

Gratifying reports of the earnings of railroads are coming in from every section of the country. The statements for May and June show a steady increase in both gross and net earnings over the corresponding periods of last year, and there is abundant reason to believe that the percentage of increase will be maintained for some months to come.

The Knickerbocker Club tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Brook Avenue, between One Hundred and Fortieth and One Hundred and Forty-first Streets. The large number of entries in the men's singles made it impossible to start the other events.

BUFFALO, July 10. -- Erie Ontario Van Brocklin, named in honor of the two great lakes, who has been Secretary of the Board of Fire Commissioners since 1880, was this afternoon arrested on a charge of embezzlement preferred by his superiors, the Commissioners.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., July 10. -- Among the passengers arriving at this port by the Pacific Mail steamer Colon to-day was Gen. Roberto Sacasa of Nicaragua, who, with his wife and two sons, is en route to Chicago, Washington, and NewYork. The party embarked at Coronto, the steamer Colon being the first to visit the port since the revolutionary disturbances began there.

Edith Hastings was found guilty in the Court of General Sessions yesterday of the larcency of a breastpin. She is a pretty young woman, and at one time was cashier in the Scarboro restaurant, in New Street. She was accused of theft by Miss Edith De Vaux of 176 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, who on June 12 passed the night with Miss Hastings in her flat, at 120 West Thirty-fifth Street.

CANDO, N.D., July 10. -- Albert Bamberger, the young murderer who killed Ben Kreider, his wife, and four children, last Friday, narrowly escaped lynching this morning. He had been caught at Deloraine, Manitoba, a few miles from the border, and agreed to come back with the Sheriff of Ramsey County without extradition papers.

The deplorable condition of Mecca at the present time should direct attention to the failure of the European powers to take effective measures for the permanent exclusion of Indian cholera from Europe. As we showed a few days ago, the powers have thus far accomplished scarcely anything by means of their sanitary conferences except the establishment of an International Sanitary Council in Egypt.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 11. -- The Citizens and Taxpayers' Association of Elizabethport is resolved to test the legality of the dog ordinance passed last year by the Elizabeth City Council.

BOSTON, July 11. -- The work of fitting out the Pilgrim proceeds with a slowness which is very aggravating to those in charge, for the delays are not due to any oversight of theirs, and might have been avoided by those who promised to have things on time. The ironwork for the boom, which was ordered in April, has just been finished, and this is a sample of the way many things have gone.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11. -- Funeral rites over the remains of the late Associate Justice Samuel Blatchford of the United States Supreme Court were performed at 2:30 this afternoon. All Saints' Chapel, which has been the scene of so many splendid weddings, was to-day the scene of a more solemn ceremony. The plain little structure in which society worships during the Summer months was crowded, while the streets around were filled with spectators and carriages.

At Seabright yesterday afternoon the local club began its annual tournament for the tennis championship of New-Jersey. There was little interest in the matches, owing to the failure of some of the crack players to appear. Neither of the Hall brothers was present. They were not defaulted and will play this afternoon. But three matches were played yesterday, Billings winning from O.H. Lowe, Larned defeating S.M. Allen, and Maxwell defeating H.M. Alexander.

SHELBYVILLE, Ill., July 11. -- Thornton's Banking House, Thomas M. Thornton, proprietor, has made an assignment for the benefit of creditors. The crash was wholly unexpected, as the house has long been looked upon as one of the strongest private banks in Central Illinois.

The firm of J.S. Conover Co. of 28 and 30 West Twenty-third Street, one of the oldest and most prominent firms in the manufacture of grates, fenders, fireplaces, wood mantels, and tiles, made an assignment yesterday without preference to William H. Harris of 220 Broadway.

In the real estate auction room at 111 Broadway yesterday there was more animation and bustle than had been there for a month before. The curious thing about it was that there was nothing offered which seemed to call for the unwonted appearance of activity. Still, from seventy-five to a hundred well-known speculators and operators were in attendance.
James B, Bouck was yesterday elected President of the Brooklyn Board of Education at the annual meeting. He received 29 votes to 14 cast for his opponent, James Weir, Jr.

The committee of the Baptist Tabernacle which is investigating the charges against the pastor, the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter, made by the former co-pastor of the church, the Rev. James W. Putnam, met last night for the last time. To-night the committee will present the findings to the church at a congregational meeting.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Morello, who last Saturday was beaten by a common selling plater, came out to-day and, with 127 pounds on his back, won the Drexel stakes in a gallop, defeating Charmion and Buck McCann.

It is no secret that the result of the opening of the World's Fair on Sunday has been very disappointing to those who advocated it, both within and without the local Directory and the National Commission. Various causes are attributed for the small Sunday attendance, but none of them nor all of them put together seem to be wholly adequate.

Champion A..A. Zimmermau doea not like to talk about himself. Even when, with his father, mother, brother, and sister in their quiet home at Manasqnan, N.J., the conversation turns upon bicycle racing and some member of the group begins to tell of the champion's deeds, the tall youth gets up and quietly walks away.

In the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning there was a curious little scene. A stout, good-looking woman, weighing almost 200 pounds, stylishly dreased in brown cloth and wearing a handsome bonnet, was arraigned before Justice Grady charged wlih disorderly conduct at the corner of Thirty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue on Monday night and with striking her husband.

-- In addition to the regular bi-monthly meeting of the Central Traffic Association lines, a meeting of the General Managers has been called in Chicago for to-morrow. The most important matter they will consider is the action of the Grand Trunk in placing its tickets on sale in several hotels, a violation of the association, rules.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 11. --The Casino and the battling beach are the principal centres of Interest, the latter during the hot spell attracting an ever increasing crowd. At the former the orchestra is giving general satisfaction under the able leadership of Prof. Johns of New-York, and the morning and afternoon, concerts are very enjoyable to the Casino patrons.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 11. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day issued a long opinion upon the Parkville tunnel disaster of June 20 on the Manhattan Beach Division of the Long Island Railroad, in which eight persons were killed and many injured. The facts and circumstances, as developed by testimony taken before the Coroner's jury in Brooklyn and by an examination of the scene by Commissioner Rickard shortly after the accident, are exhaustively detailed.

The United States dispatch steamer Dolphin, now repairing at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, is under orders to convey Secretary of the Navy Herbert on a tour of inspection of all the naval stations and naval plants on the Atlantic coast. The Dolphin will sail with Secretary Herbert, it is announced, in the course of a few days.
Spirits of turpentine dull and weak at 28@28 1/2c. Regins quiet and easy at $1.17 1/2@$1.20 for common to good strained.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., July 11. -- The French flagship Naiada, Admiral Larmarnaix, left St. John's last night. The French Admiral's purpose in sailing was to snub Gov. Sir Peter O'Brien and the Newfoundland Government.

DETROIT, Mich., July 11. -- To-day, at the second and last day's races of the Detroit Wheelmen, the State record of 2:24 was lowered to 2:17 by J.R. Blias of Chicago. About 1,000 people who were present enjoyed good racing. There were eight events as yesterday, and all were hotly contested and pretty good time was made.

TRENTON, N.J., July 11. -- There is trouble between the sanitary pottery pressers and the manufacturers, and a big fight is threatened. Both manufacturers and pressers are holding meetings to-night, and through committees trying to settle the difficulty. The sanitary pressers are the best paid of all pottery operatives. They have over 300 in attendance in Washington Hall, and the men are talking strongly in favor of a strike.

The Government report as to the condition of the grain crops on July 1 indicates that the estimates of the wheat crop heretofore made must be cut down. A very considerable loss in the Spring wheat district is shown in the reduction of the condition percentage from 86.4 to 74.1 since June 1. Summaries based upon the percentages of the report indicate a total crop of leas than 400,000,000 bushels.

The ground of the South Side Gun Club in Newark were visited by a large number of sportsmen yesterday, the attraction being the sixth monthly team shoot in the series for the championship of the New-Jersey Trap Shooters League, combined with an all-day tournament under the management of the South Side Gun Club. The grounds are well equipped for trapwork, and a large marquee was furnished for the restaurant.

The Crescent Athletic Club began its annual Summer handicap tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Bay Ridge. The men's singles was the only event of the day. All the entries were divided into three classes and each class into subdivisions. A, B, C, and D. A handcap of half fifteen separated each division. The winners of the three classes will play off for the prizes, 15 points being the difference between the classes.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Judge Jenkins, in the United states Circuit Court, to-day handed down a decision in the suit brought by Wanamaker Brown to restrain the World's Columbian Exposition Directors from opening the fair gates on Sundays, the court holding that the complainants have no standing in a court of equity.

The second eleven of the States Island Cricket Club journeyed to Bergen Point yesterday afternoon and defeated the second eleven of the New-Jersey Athletic Club by 13 runs after a very interesting game. L. De Bost, B. St. G. Walker, J. Balmer, W. A. Hamilton, H.F. Fox, T. Clarke, and W.Q. Wilkinson all did well for their respective sides. H. Maxfield did the best work with the ball, taking six wickets.

STAPLETON, S.I., July 11. -- Since the Staten Island authorities have had McIlvaine, the burglar who was shot while robbing the Stapleton Post Office, in their custody there has been constant fear that his friends would make an attempt to rescue him. He lies at the Smith Infirmary very ill and utterly unable to leave his bed.

Miss Carolina Williams was married to George W. Dilks, a printer, in the Thirteenth Street Presbyterian Church on July 11, 1843, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Burchard. Yesterday Mr. Dilks, who has become one of New-York's bestknown citizens, and his wife celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the event.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11. -- The market opened lower in sympathy with London. Metropolitan Traction was fairly steady, with quite liberal purchases at par. Lehigh Valley was weak on the belief that trouble is brewing among the coal companies. The Reading receivers refused to allow Mr. Little, the expert of the bondholders' committee, to examine the books of the company.

A young men escorted his lady love to the race course. It became a perplexing question as to how he could keep up his character a wealthy man on a salary of $10 a week. He found a solution for the vexed problem in one of the races.

CITY ISLAND, July 11. -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Theresa, Mr. Gustavus Sidenberg, and Orienta, Mr E.R. Ladew; schooner Coronet, Mr. John D. Wing; aloop yacht Nellie, Mr. W.H. Hathaway.

LONDON, July 11. -- The House of Commons, sitting in committee, continued this evening the discussion of Clause 9 of the Home Rule bill. This clause concerns the question of Irish representation at Westminster.

There was not much activity to the breadstuffs business. Wheat, while temporarily firmer early on the Government report and stronger cables, became weak and sold Off 1 1/4@1 3/80, on reports of financial trouble in Kansas City and depressed Wall Street, the long interest attempted free realizing; but found the buying interest tame.

At the entrance to the unpretentious apartment house, 69 Woodhull street, Brooklyn, hangs a bit black and white erape. It tells of the closing chapter in the career of a boy who, at an age when he should have been full of hope and courage, had already become daunted in the struggle for existence and so ended all by taking his own life.

GEORGE FORRESTER died in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Monday night. He was born in Ridgebury, Conn., in 1818. He left there when twelve years old to seek his fortune in this city, where an elder brother had already established himself in the dry goods business. Entering as a clerk, in course of a few years he was taken into partnership, and still later on became sole proprietor of the business.

Lorella Kearns, three years old, a daughter of James Kearns, a saloon keeper at 675 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, was run over and instantly killed at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Nineteenth Street at 6:20 last evening by trolley car No. 41 of the Fifth Avenue line.
The escape of another prisoner from the Kings County Penitentiary was reported last night.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 11. -- The President did not go fishing this forenoon, but after breakfast sat on the piazza until noon, when he drove over from Gray Gables to Buzzard's Bay. Col. Lamont occupied the seat with the President, and Dr. Bryant sat with the driver. Mr. Cleveland was dressed in a very becoming dark suit and wore a derby hat.

One or two of our contemporaries in this city have recently published assertions and opinions about the death rate and the alleged effect of the water supply upon the mortality that were intended to be alarming, but which were put into print with a curious disregard for vital statistics and other facts.

Within the last few days the work of supplying all the field batteries of the United States Army with the new 3.2 inch breech-loading rifle has been completed by the War Department. Each battery of light artillery now has four of the guns, and some of them have six.

The sales for to-day of real estate are all in legal proceedings. In the case of the Sheriff's sale of Hawley Chapman's interest in a number of up-town flats, the sale is one adjourned from last Wednesday. Counsel for Mrs. Chapman interposed the objection that a lunatic's property could not be sold under the circumstances. A similar plea was, however, overruled in Brooklyn as to a sale of Chapman's property there.

YONKERS, July 11. -- The Common Council last evening awarded a number of contracts for paving the city streets, The work on Palisade, Avenue was awarded to Dougherty, Berrigan, Pennell O'Hearn, to be paved with granite blocks, for $35,802; South Broadway and New Main Street to the Sicilian Asphalt Pavement Company, for $32,630; Woodworth Avenue to the Barber Asphalt Pavement Company, for $35,104, and Ashburton Avenue to the same, for $27,517.
From the Evening Post. The Brooklyn ring of to-day is not familiar with the history of the Twed ring, for most of its members have become prominent as politicians and statesmen since Tweed's death.

CONEY ISLAND, July 11. -- An explosion to-night in one of the buildings of the Gravesend plant of the Pain Fireworks Company seriously injured two men and blew the building to pieces. The wreck of the factory was burned.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 11. -- Andrew Debney, a wealthy farmer near Columbus, brutally assaulted his wife last week, and leaving her for dead, fled. The woman was taken to the hospital where she died.

A scream in a hall bedroom in a flat on the second floor of 1,976 Park Avenue at 5:30 A.M. yesterday aroused the people in the house, and when a policeman went to the room he found Mrs. Max H. Buhman wailing over and embracing her pretty sister, Susanna Bartach, who had shot herself in the breast with a revolver that lay near her.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Whitelaw Reid, ex-Minister to France, who with his family had been seeing the World's Fair, putting in ten or twelve hours a day in that way for several days, was asked last night, just as he was starting back for New-YorK, if he had read ex-Senator Ingalis's criticism of his candidacy for the Vice Presidency.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- In no portion of the White City was there so dense a throng today as in the vicinity of yesterday's fatal fire, where stout arms toiled among the blackened debris to recover the charred and unrecognizable trunks or bones of former comrades.

Mayor David A. Boody of Brooklyn yesterday made his application to Judge Moore in the Court of Sessions for permission to inspect and copy the minutes of the June Grand Jury of Kings County. Although decision was reserved, Judge Moore made an announcement from the bench which leaves no doubt that he will grant the application.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 11. -- R.H. McCracken, a prominent mining man and capitalist of this city, returned to-day from Mexico, where he has been arranging the details of a scheme to consolidate all the iron industries of that country into one syndicate, which will take the form of a joint stock company.

Men of thought and conscience at the beginning of their careers commonly adopt a governing rule by which their steps are directed. Anthony J. Drexel adopted one, and until death removed him from the busy, helpful path that he had trod so long in the world of business it was his sole guiding principle in all the important and multitudinous affairs with which he had to do.

It appears from an examination of the affairs of the Republican State League that there has been a large fatality among the clubs composing it since the 8th day of November last. Of the 1,000 which were then claimed as the living working forces of the league, 300 or thereabout have since died.

SARATOGA, N.T., July 11. -- The tournament for the tennis championships of New York State was begun to-day at the Woodlawn Oval. The weather was perfect and the attendance large. The poor condition of the courts, which have only been sodded, three weeks, was the only drawback, causing many inaccurate bounds.

Rudolph Lausen, a saddler, of 61 South Second Street, Williamsburg, yesterday applied to Police Justice Goettlng in the Lee Avenue Police Court for a warrant for the arrest of Ladislaus Berlinsky and his wife for grand larceny. The circumstances, however, were such that the warrant could not be issued.
WINNHMUCCA, Nov., July 11. -- The Chairman of the State Central Committee of the Silver Patty of Nevada, has issued the following:

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Treasury officers talked to-day more cheerfully about the financial outlook than they have talked for weeks. The tone of the newspapers, except in the far West, strikes them as indicating a returning confidence that has been hoped for earnestly by those who have been watching the tendencies for a month with some misgivings.

A large representation of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association convened at the Manhattan Beach Hotel yesterday to resume consideration of the new agreement regarding rates and other matters for next year. The present agreement goes out of effect on the 1st of August. At the recent annnal meeting of this association at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, in this city, this matter of a new agreement was left in the hands of a special committee.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, July 11-- P.M. The stock market was more active today, but the increased trading was at the expense of values. The bull leaders have apparently lost heart, and offered no resistance to the attacks of the bear combination, which is especially aggressive at this time. There being no buying orders in the market, stop orders were reached, and their execution assisted the decline materially.
Mayor Boody has not made application to Judge Moore for permission to examine the minutes of the Kings County Grand Jury of last December.
John R. Dos Passos said:
"There is no use in buying what we don't want and building warehouses to store it in," said ex-Speaker Galusha A. Grow of Pennsylvania to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter yesterday at the Victoria Hotel.
The money market was somewhat firmer. Call loans were made at 6@12 P cent. The last loan was made at 6 P cent.
More gold is coming back to this country. The steamship Trave, sailing from Southampton to-day, will bring here $335,000, consigned to L. Von Hoffman Co.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- The literary congresses ore well under way. The first to be called to order thin morning was the congress of authors. It devoted the morning session to a general consideration of literary copyright. A.L. Spofford, the Librarian of Congress, was the presiding officer. He introduced the topic of the day with an interesting paper concerning the practical workings of the copyright law.

Frederick A. Ward yesterday asked Judge Culien, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to appoint a commission to take the testimony of Mrs. Henry Smail, at Aleppy, India, in the suit of Margaret Holt against the executors of the late James Darragh of that place.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 11. -- The will of Hiram Camp, the great clockmaker who was buried this afternoon, was made public to-day. His estate is valued at about $300,000. The public bequests include the following:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 11. -- An expedition was made yesterday afternoon to test the Merriam pack. Eight soldiers ware led from the Stale Camp by Major Lewis Balch, Surgeon of the Tenth Battalion. They carried on their backs their blankets and other equipments. Each pack weighed over twenty pounds. Four of these soldiers have made many long marches before with packs.

LONDON, July 11. -- The suspension of the New-Zealand Loan and Mercantile Agency Company created no disturbance on 'Change to-day, as it was one of the after effects of the Australian crisis and created no surprise. The assets of the company are mostly locked up in Australian land, mainly sheep runs, and the immediate cause of the failure was inability to raise money in Australia on wool shipments.

DENVER, Col., July 11. -- The Colorado Silver Convention to-day was both big and sensational. Coliseum Hall, the largest in the city, contained fully 2,000 people when the convention was called to order byPresident Merrick. Most of the day was spent in speechmaking. The Committee on Resolutions did not complete its work and an adjournment was taken until to-morrow morning.

Louis Sohlicter, alias J.W. Gaylor, brought to this city from Philadelphia on requisition papers, was taken to the District Attorney's office yesterday and held in $1,500 bail to answer an indictment charging him with forgery in the second degree.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 11. -- Prof. Brooks, director of the Smith Observatory, observed the new comet last night low down in the northwest. The position at 10:45 was right ascension 8 hours 33 minutes, declination north 46 degrees 59 minutes. The motion is very rapid in the right ascension and toward the body of the Great Bear. The comet was easily visible with the naked eye, and has a tail five degrees in length.

BUFFALO, July 11. -- Mrs. J.L. Wheelock lives at 405 Fifth Street, in this city; her house is exactly opposite the Erie County Penitentiary. A burglar, who was not intimidated by the knowledge that across the street a good many scores of his kind were wearing striped suits and learning such useful trades as chair bottoming and overall making, entered Mrs. Wheelock's house early yesterday morning.

About 100 women with their races painted with a creamy white color that completely concealed the rose and tan which the sun and ocean breezes had imparted to their cheeks, landed at the Iron Steamboat Company's pier not far from midnight, Tuesday. Their dresses also were liberally, if not artistically frescoed with the paint.

The Orangemen of New-York, Brooklyn, and Jersey City yesterday commemorated the victory of Prince William or Orange over James II., at the Battle of the Boyne, by a parade in this city and Brooklyn and a picnic at Bennor's Ridgewood Grove, where the Rev. Dr. Peters counseled moderation and brotherly love for Catholics.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 12. -- Capt. Abram Baker committed an unprovoked assault last night on John G. Young, a hotel clerk. Young was sitting close to Baker when the latter arose and, without any warning, struct the young man in the face.

Under the pilotage of Assemblyman Otto Kempner the New-York Citizens' Democracy was last evening laun ched upon the political seas or the city as a regularly organized body. The meeting of organization was held at 99 First Avonue, and about 100 persons attended.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The navy will have a new Chief Constructor. Commodore T.D. Wilson, who has held that position since 1886, has resigned, and will go on two years' leave, on account of ill health. To-day Naval Constructor Philip Hichborn, who has held the place of Assistant Chief during the past nine years, wan sworn in as Chief Constructor.

HARTSHORN, Indian Territory, July 12. -- James Townsend, a butcher from McAlester, Indian Territory, arrived here yesterday noon and started for the country to purchase cattle. When a mile and a half from town he was stopped by three masked men and robbed of $1,000. An opened express envelope containing $500 woe dropped to the ground by the robbers and left as worthless.

NEW-YORK. WEDNESDAY, July 12 -- P.M. Weakness was the feature of the stock market at the opening. There was liquidation in the Grangers, the Vanderbilts. General Electric, Chicago Gas, Sugar, and the Gould stocks, and for fifteen minutes there was considerable excitement.

The loan exhibition at the Academy of Design is open during the hot term by daylight only, but when the cool weather comes in Autumn the galleries will be open at night. Meantime, there is a small but steady attendance.

An opulent gentleman who recently purchased seven houses on the west side with the intention of living in the central one and renting the six others is said to have received from his wife an assurance that she had no wish to go into the country this year, her house being in itself ample change from the heated air and crowded streets of the older parts of the city.

There was a lively time at the Tabernacle Baptist Church, in Second Avenue, near Tenth Street, last night, when the Rev. Daniel C. Potter was exonerated from the charges brought against him by the Rev. James W. Putnam, assistant pastor of the church, and John V. Huiell.
From the World. This Brooklyn case presents several aspects, all interesting to the verge of the scandalous.
CHICAGO, July 12. -- All the literary congresses were largely attended at to-day's sessions, with the exception of the Folk-Lore Congress and the Congress or Librarians.

Manager Ward of the New-Yorks intends to strengthen his team if there is any available talent in the market. He has been corresponding with some friends in the South, and on the strength of their recommendation has secured German and Wilson, the battery of the Augusta (Ga.) Club, Letty of Savannah, Colcolough of Charleston, and McGinnity of Montgomery.

Julius Richter and his wife, Louise, went to Greenwood Lake Sunday with the Columbus Zither Club, of which he was an influential member. He drank considerable whisky, and when Jersey City was reached Richher disappeared. His wife went to their home, 117 First Street. Yesterday she found her husband in a saloon on First Avenue and persuaded him to go home with her.

It was charged yesterday by a member of the March Grand Jury of Kings County, and the charge was published, that County Judge Henry A. Moore of Brooklyn had visited the Grand Jury room during the deliberations of the jurors, and had advised them that enough evidence to convict certain officials of the city, whose indictment for wrongdoing was being considered, could never be obtained.

A party of Japanese mechanical and civil engineers called at the City Hall yesterday to see Mayor Gilroy. They are in this country on an official mission from their Government to inspect and report upon our breweries, our system of sewerage and water works, and boilermaking.
WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The gold reserve today increased $599,898, the total amount being $97,886,575. The currency balance remains at about the same figure -- $27,353,881.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 12. -- The German Liederkranz of New-York scored the great triumph of the Saengerfest this afternoon in its special chorus at the matinee and this evening in the magnificent reception given Die Neue Welt," the prize composition of Conductor Heinrich Zoellner, which was the leading number on the evening programme and was sung by the great chorus of the North American Saengerbund, over 3,000 strong, under the splendid direction or the composer.

PEKKSKILL., N.Y., July 12. -- Gov. Roswell P. Flower arrived at the State Camp at 4 o'clock this afternoon from New-York, and at 8:15 P.M. he started for Albany. He was accompanied by his niece, Mrs. Halsey.
"They do some queer things over in Brooklyn, don't they?" said ex-Judge and ex-District Attorney William Fullerton yesterday in response to queries from a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter.

In pursuance of a resolution passed at a large meeting of bondholders of the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Railroad Company held at the offices of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company a few days ago, Mr. R.G. Rolston, President of the trust company, has appointed a commutes for the protection of the rights and interests of the bondholders of the railroad company.

The investigation into the alleged frauds in connection with the burial at veterans by Kings County Supervisors was continued yesterday in the Court House, Brooklyn. One of the veterans, for whose burial $35 had been charged to the county, was John Humphries. The check was made payable to Daniel J. Lane, and was indorsed by Fred Otten, a saloon keeper.

It was reported yesterday that Commissioners inman and Steinway of the Rapid -- Transit Commission were in favor of giving the Manhattan Company the desired extension of time to consider the latest proposition submitted by the commission.

MILWAUKEE, July 12. -- The Grand Jury, after investigating the failures of F. A. Lappen Co. and the Plankinton Bank, has reported indictments for all the officers and Directors of the Plankinton Bank. They are F. T. Day, President; William Plankinton, Vice President; William H. Momsen, cashier, and Eugene S. Elliott, F. W. Noyes, C. L. Clason, and Judge James G. Jenkins, Directors.

With his second wife as a complainant and with his alleged first spouse as a witness against him, Fletcher Allison Haines, son of Lawyer Benjamin Howell Haines of 52 Broadway, seems to have a slim chance of escaping the consequences of his marital entanglements.

FIRST LIEUT. FRANK GREENE, Signal Corps, is relieved from further duty in the Department of the Colorado, and will report by letter to the Commanding General, Department of California, for duty at Chief signal Officer of that department. Lieut. Greene will retain charge of the military telegraph lines in Arizona and New-Mexico until relieved therefrom.
MANCHESTER, N.H., July 12. -- Statesman Blair has come out as an advocate of the repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman act and will vote repeal when the matter shall some up in Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- One important result of armor-plate tests yesterday will be to extend the use of the Harvey process. Secretary Herbert was satisfied with the tests as far as they went, but he has reached the conclusion that while the plates were as good as could be expected from plain nickel steel they did not show the resisting power of the Harveyized nickelsteel plate.

CITY ISLAND, July 12. -- The following yachts passed hers to-day: Bound East-Steam yachts Vision, Mr. Clarence McKim; Lagonda, the Rev. William L. Moore; Allegra, Col. S.V.R. Cruger, and Helvetia, Mr. C. O'D. Iselln. Schooner yacht Atlantic, Mr. C. Barnum Seeley.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12. -- The Mereer County Board of Freeholders had an all-day session, and it was the stormiest ever held in the county. There were open charges of bribery and corruption, growing out of the award of contracts for the building of thirteen miles of roads. It was claimed that the Road Committee did not award the contracts to the lowest bidder, but gave them to two contractors who had formed a combine.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 12. -- A little child of Joseph Holland of 93 Clinton Street died Sunday and was buried yesterday. The funeral was interrupted by Annie McKoever, Holland's housekeeper, who said she was Holland's wife. She declared that the child about to be buried was killed by him.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Chief of the Department of Publicity and Promotion Handy yesterday sailed for the resignation of fifteen of the men who have worked with him to advertise the fair. Those dropped were member of the editorial staff, the press clipping department, and the catalogue department.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 12. -- Miss Emma Vaders, the actress who for several years was Booth's leading lady and afterward served in the same capacity for Joseph Jefferson, while a guest at the Florida House in this city, was attacked with insanity in a mild form induced by overstudy.

A small steam yacht has been built in South Brooklyn which, her owners say, will be a world beater. She has been constructed for the express purpose of lowering the colors of the Vamoose, the Norwood, the Fisecn, and other fliers of note, and if she does anything like what her owners claim for her she will come very near beating the Empire State Express.

The body of the late Samuel Blatchford. Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, was laid to rest yesterday noon in the family plot in Greenwood Cemetery. The funeral party reached this city Tuesday night on a special train from Newport.

But for her good fortune in possessing, unlike Brooklyn, officials who keep jealous watch and ward over her public money and constantly make rigid investigation into public accounts. New-York, as was found out yesterday, might have "paid the piper" nearly $2,500 in excess of the sum justly owed in return for the music provided during the Columbian celebration.

LONDON, July 12. -- A dispatch to Lloyds from Rio Grande do Sul states that Admiral Waldenkolk, who is at the head of the revolution in the State of Rio Grande do Sul, arrived in that city on July 8 from Montevideo. He was acoompanied by a number of armed Brazilians, who had seized the steamer Jupiter, on which they were traveling, when the vessel was a short distance from Montevideo, her sailing port.

The sale of the Manhattan Athletic Club House under foreclosure of the first mortgage is announced to take place on Thursday next in the Trinity Building salesroom. The adjournment from the 6th inst. was for the purpose of enabling the second mortgage bondholders to take measures to protect their interests.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The atmosphere about the Weather Burcan has cleared off very perseptibly since the recent investigation, and affairs are running along smoothly with but little probability of any further changes being made in the near future. Monday Chief Harrington had a personal conference with Secretary Morton, and the relations between the Secretary and his chief weather officer, which, as an outgrowth of the investigation, had become somewhat strained, are improving.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 12. -- The Bankers' Association of Buffalo, desiring to put itself on record on the important matters coining before Congress at the extra session called, by President Cleveland for Aug. 7 next, presents the following proposistious:

"The action of Secretary Hoke Smith in reprieving the nine Choctaw Indians condemned to death is on the side of justice," said Miss Emma C. Sickels, Chairman of the Indian Congress at the World's Fair, yesterday. Miss Sickels is now in the city.

The first trip of the season was made yesterday by the floating hospital of St. John's Guild, At 8 o'clock the hospital float, towed by a tug, left the foot of West Fifty-ninth Street. It had a fairly-large crowd on board, which was augmented by the women and children who got on at the foot of West Thirty-fourth Street and West Tenth Street. About 10 o'clock the trip down the bay was began.

When completed, the new synagogue of the Hebrew congregation Shaaray Tefilla, on West Eighty-second Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, will be one of the handsomest Jewish temples of worship in this city. It is to be of the Moresque style of architecture, from designs by Brunnor Tryon, and its rich Oriental ornamentation will be in effective contrast with the other buildings on the street.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Roosevelt gave the Grand Duke Alexander of Russia and the officers of the Russian fleet a reception at their country place here, Lotos Lake, to-day. President Cleveland had written Mr. Roosevelt that he would gladly give a personal answer to the invitation sent him were he not kept at Buzzard's Bay with an attack of rheumatism.
Roundsman John J. McKenna of the Park Police was fined $10 in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for creating a disturbance in the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station early yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- The Great Western Handicap, a sweepstakes for all ages, with $2,000 added, was the attraction at Washington Park to-day, and it proved an easy victory for Rudolph. In the betting Yo Tambien had the call, and wag heavily played at 6 to 5. Rudolph being second choice at 4 to 1. Falero at once went to the front and cut out the running for a half mile.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12. -- Much interest is being taken by wheelmen here in the big century road race of the Atalanta Wheelmen, which will be run Saturday to Princeton and return. These runs always bring out many fast road racers, and the course is a favorite one. The prizes are numerous and especially valuable, and there is sure to be a large number of the starters to finish.
NEWPORT, R.I, July 12. -- Among to-day's arrivals are Mrs. Bayard and Mr. Louis P. Bayard of New-York as guests of Paymaster Willlams at the torpedo station.

Another of the innumerable instances pointing to the almost unanimous desire of representative business men for the repeal of the silver-purchase law was given yesterday morning in the rooms of the New-York Hide and Leather Club in Gold Street, which served as a meeting place for the members of the leather and boot and shoe trades, who came together to adopt an address and resolutions urging upon Congress the speedy repeal of the Sherman law.
A meeting of the regular Democratte Association of Flatbush was held in Orglock's Hull last night, at which resolutions calling for the removal of President James F. Kelly were passed.

-- A lady, passing the Summer on the lake shore being told that salt water was more buoyant than fresh water, took a salt cellar with her when she went in bathing Thursday forenoon, and sprinkled the waves before venturing in. -- Buffalo Courier.

The leading men of the leather trade met yesterday and took practical steps to awaken the attention of their correspondents and customers in the South and West to the necessity of the repeal of the silver purchase clause of the law of 1890, as a condition to the restoration of confidence and renewed prosperity.

Another of the innumerable instances pointing to the almost unanimous desire of representative business men for the repeal of the silver-purchase law was given yesterday morning in the rooms of the New-York Hide and Leather Club in Gold Street, which served as a meeting place for the members of the leather and boot and shoe trades, who came together to adopt an address and resolutions urging upon Congress the speedy repeal of the Sherman law.
A meeting of the regular Democratte Association of Flatbush was held in Orglock's Hull last night, at which resolutions calling for the removal of President James F. Kelly were passed.

-- A lady, passing the Summer on the lake shore being told that salt water was more buoyant than fresh water, took a salt cellar with her when she went in bathing Thursday forenoon, and sprinkled the waves before venturing in. -- Buffalo Courier.

-- A ten-year-old hero is Llewellyn Hopkins, son of Andrew Hopkins of South Brewer, Me. Though almost helpless from a recent severe Illness of typhoid fever, he mustered temporary strength enough to rescue a playmate who was drowning. This he did by crseping out as far as he could on a log and then reaching out to the boy a long strip of bark which he tore from the log.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 12. -- Henry W. Squires, alias H.W. Cromwell, a member of the Manhattan Bicycle Club of New-York, was held this evening by Justice Williams in the sum of $1,000 for embezzlement.

-- The work of elevating the tracks of the New-York Central Central One Hundred and Eighth Street and the construction of a steel viaduct across the Harlem River is being pushed rapidly to completion. It has been necessary to erect a temporary station Stoat 200 feet south of the One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street crossing to be need while this work is in progress.
Wall Street bears did their best yesterday to repeat their raid of the day before and to preach the doctrines of general calamity, but they found it not altogether easy work.

People who were looking for peace and repose could have found it yesterday afternoon at the Monmouth Park track. There was racing there, but it did not interfere with the dreams of a day-dreamer more than the car traffic does with the repose of a man who is ruminating on Chestnut Street, Philadelphia. That is, it was dull to the last degree.

The great iron bridge at Washintrton Heights and all that portion of the eliffs overlooking the Manhattan Field known as "Deadhead Hill" were thronged with some 5,000 persons early yesterday afternoon. They were attracted, as were 400 paying spectators who occupied seats in the grand stands in the inclosure, to witness a balloon ascension announced to be made by Capt. Emil Carten, the French military aeronaut.

-- The inventive genius of Wall Street rumormongers must have been pretty thoroughly exhausted this week. The story starters have broken their records for industry. No report was too ridiculous for them to start and circulate.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July. -- Congressman Richard P. Bland, the great apostle of bimetallism, has issued a long letter upon the silver question, in which he says:

There is one interpretation of the marked decline in the selling prices of stocks on the Exchange occurring in the last two days that is not without a basis for rational encouragement. The decline was certainly unlooked for, and as certainly was not to be explained by the general and obvious conditions.

We are sincerely sorry to see that inharmony has broken out between Mr. WHITELAW REID and Mr. J.J. INGALLS, The quarrel is bitter and bad enough as it stands, but we apprehend that it will be worse before it is better. These angry recriminations between members of a defeated party are always to be deprecated, because of the danger that things may be told which should be sedulously concealed.

THE UNMANAGEABLE MISSISSIPPI. The people of the Lower Mississippi Valley seem to be at their wits' end for some means of controlling the unruly "Father of Waters." The real trouble with the prodigious stream is not so much its water as its mud, and if they could find some way of disposing of the solid part of its contents they might be able to manage the liquid part.

A conference was held yesterday afternoon in the office of Commissioner of Public Works Daly, on the condition of the water supply. There vere present, besides Mr. Daly, Health Commissioner Edson and Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Croton Aqueduct.

DENVER, Col., July 12. -- The interest in the silver convention had not in the least abated from yesterday when it was called to order this morning. Standing room was not to be had by late comers. After the appointment of delegates to the St. Louis and Chicago silver conventions and to the sound-money meeting at St. Paul, the Committee on Resolutions presented the following report, which was unanimously adopted:...
LONDON, July 13. -- The Times, discussing the silver crisis, says:

Two leases made to the United Domestic Sewing Machine Company for twenty years from Nov. 1. 1892, one being of 853 Broadway at $25,000 per year and the other of the adjoining property. 50 East Fourteenth Street, at $10,000 per year, were put up at auction by order of the company's receiver at the Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broad-way, yesterday. Mr. William Kennelly was the auctioneer.
