Many sanitary officials, whose statistics have hitherto gone unchallenged and whose ability has not been questioned, sustain THE NEW-YORK TIMES in the assertion that the announcement of the "early arrival" of typhoid fever was premature, if the usual post-Summer crop of the disease was spoken of, and absurd if it meant that the disease was one that did not exist except at certain seasons.

LONDON, July 13 -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Thomas Sexton, (Anti-Parnellite,) member for North Kerry, asked Mr. Gladstone to grant a day for the discussion of the motion notice of which was given by Mr. Sexton yesterday, declaring that Chairman Mellor in suspending Mr. Sexton Tuesday night at the sitting of the Committee of the Whole had exceeded, his authority.

MILWAUKEE, July 13 -- A simple arrest by the police on a dispatch from the Fon du Lac authorities has brought out quite a romantic story. Yesterday Chief Janssen arrested one Frank Blunt, who was wanted at Fon du Lac on a charge of grand larceny. The search resulted in showing that Frank Blunt was a woman.

LIVERPOOL, July 13 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef and pork in moderate demand. Hams in poor demand, short cut, about 14 to 16 lb. easy at 56s. Bacon in moderate demand. Cheese in moderate demand; American finest colored steady at 46s 6d. Tailow -- The demand is improving. Spirits of turpentine in moderate demand. Cottonseed Oil -- Liverpool refined steady at 22s 3d.
The Knickerbocker Club tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Brook Avenue, between One Hundred and Fortieth and One Hundred and Forty-first streets.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 13 -- A crowd of 15,000 people feathered at Home-wood Park to-day to witness the first meeting that has ever taken place between the two famous pacers Mascot, 2:04, and Hal Pointer, 2:04 1/2, in the free-for-all race.

BUFFALO, July 13 -- "Wie gehts?" shouted J. Adam Lautz, Chairman of the committee of the Orpheus which has charge of the entertainment of the New-York Liederkranz, as that body's special train rolled into the Union Station at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

There was a good deal of improvement yesterday in the financial situation as New-York sees it. The money market was easier, the currency movement to this city increased, and in the stock market there was a development of strength in nearly all the active shares.

The Secretary of the American Society of Authors is H.H. Van Dyck, and he and many of his brother members are being kept at fever heat by Mrs. Katherine Hodges, her now authors' society, the American Protective Society of Authors, and her bitter denunciations of the pioneer association, its supporters and adherents.
Richard Morgan Olcott, doing business as Olcott Co., exporter of grain and general merchandise at 56 Hew Street, made an assignment yesterday to Lawyer John S. Durand of 146 Broadway.
LONDON, July 13. -- There was considerable excitement in the American market this morning, and prices advanced sharply on large purchasas by commission houses and investment firms.

Nominations to the Charter Oak Stakes closed on Monday. The class for this trotting event has been shifted a notch this year, being now for hones eligible to the 2:18 class, instead of the 2:20. This change seems to be agreeable to owners, for there are eighteen subscribers, the largest number in any year. In 1892 fifteen paid entrance fees and fourteen started.

The handsomest of all the yachting centres on the Sound is the home of the Larchmont Yacht Club. The house is beautifully situated on a small bay in which the yachts find safe anchorage while their owners enjoy themselves in the commodious house. The outlook from any part of the home is a grand one and a view of the sound can be had for miles.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 13 -- The famous Veteran Zouaves of this city, or Gatling Gun Company, as they were known in the State National Guard, have been disbanded by order of the State Military Board. Gen. Drake, commander of the Zouaves, received the order from Gen. Plume to-day.

The tramp steamship Red Sea, which has lately become a shining mark for popular attention, arrived at Quarantine yesterday none the worse for the many wild rumors which have been circulated, concerning her and the 801 passengers which she has on board. The passenger list, by the way, was augmented instead of being depleted during her peaceful but extended voyage from Bremen.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- A couple of thousand merry, bright-looking, prettily-dressed boys and girls, hailing from everywhere from Maine to California and Texas, swarmed all day about the New-York and Pennsylvania Bulldogs particularly, but they seemed to think that all of Jackson Park had been transformed into the White City for their especial enjoyment and education.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 13 -- A correspondent of the Kansas City Times went to the home of Gov. Jones of the Choctaw Nation, twenty miles from Caddo, and interviewed the Governor as to his purpose regarding the execution of the sentence upon the nine Choctaws convicted of several political murders and sentenced to be shot.

Papers were served yesterday upon Cornelius Furgueaon, John, Cowenhoven, W. Bannett Wardell, William Keegan, and the members of the New-Utrecht Board of Improvements restraining them from lighting the useless gas lamps which adorn the cornfields and the vacant lots of that town. The taxpayers of New-Utrecht are the plaintiffs in the matter, and they object to paying any more money for a useless waste of gas.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Secretary Herbert has taken action in two cases of importance concerning navy yard commands. He has decided to make permanent the suspension of the order of Commodore Kirkland to take command of the South Atlantic station, and will allow him to remain as commandant of the League Island (Penn.) Navy Yard.
Frank Ellison, who brutally attacked Broker William H. Henriques on June 5, was indicted for assault in the first degree by the Grand Jury yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A New York man stands a good chance of building the first submarine boat for the navy. The Navy Department, however, desires some additional information from the two inventors who have submitted suitable designs before a decision is rendered. The report of the board, composed of Commander Sperry, Prof. Alger, and Constructor Capps, on the designs submitted recently is an interesting one.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 13 -- Exceptionally good playing marked the third day's games in the annual tennis tournament for the Seabright Tennis Cup. The singles to-day were decided in favor of William A. Larned by a victory over E.L. Hall. This makes Larned the champion of this tournament, and his match with Stevens, the holder of the challenge cup of last year, will be played Saturday.

The Seaside Sanitarium, composed of three cottages at Port Richmond, S.I., and one at Hamil's Station, Rockway Beach, is now open for the reception of destitute and sick children of New-York City. Free tickets can be obtained at the office, 309 West Twenty-ninth Street.

Joseph Vence, an Italian boy eighteen years old of 422 East One Handled and Thirteenth Street, was seriously stabbed in the abdomen early last evening by Prank Crudeli of 424 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, and was taken to the Harlem Hospital in a critical condition. He will probably die.

-- The Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Railway was reorganized in Indianapolis yesterday, preparatory to turning it over to the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railway, which has paid $2,4000,000 for it, $50,000 in cash, the balance to be paid Aug. 1. The new controllers will take possession at the date named. R.B.F. Pierce retires from the management, and these officers were elected: T.B. Atkins, President; Jonn Telford, Secretary, and W. P. Hatch, Treasurer.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 13. -- Evan W. Scott, timekeeper in the machine shops of the New-York and New-England Railroad at East Hartford, was arrested last evening by Deputy Sheriff Foley for appropriating money of the company to his own use. This morning twelve other employes of the road were also arrested for complicity in the swindle.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 13 -- One hundred and five guests attended the dinner tendered to Judge William Walter Phelps by his friends and neighbors at the new Englewood Hotel this evening. The affair was a thoroughly enjoyable one, Mr. Phelps being in his happiest mood.
The three-masted schooner A.R. Keene, commanded by Capt. Rogers, which was run down in the upper bay Wednesday night by a mud scow, is now in water up to her rails off Bay Ridge.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- Another body was found in the ruins of the cold storage warehouse this morning and identified as that of Charles W. Purvis, truckman, Hook and Ladder No. 5, acting as Lieutenant of Engine Company No. 4, World's Fair Brigade. An arm was found intact, and on one of the fingers was a ring with the word "Purvis" engraved upon it.

BUFFALO, July 13 -- The little village of Westfield, which is on the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad, out in Chautauqua County and within a few miles of the Ohio line, has been wildly excited all day over the tragic death of two burglars who tried to enter some of the village stores early this morning.

The Rev. James W. Putnam, who insists that he is still the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter's assistant pastor at the Tabernacle Baptist Church, has again refused to have anything whatever to do with the committee appointed to investigate his charges against Mr. Potter.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 13 -- Judge James G. Jenkins of the United States Circuit Court, under indictment by a Grand Jury, charged with bank wrecking in connection with the Directory of the Plaukinton Bank, feels the disgrace attendant upon his position keenly. He appeared at his office in the Federal Building this morning at an earlier hour than usual looking jaded and restless.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 13 -- The rumor that Gen. Bernardo Reyes. Governor of the State of Nuevo Loon, was to become the official candidate for the Presidency of Mexico, to succeed Gen. Diaz, had become so general in the press and among the people of this country that it had come to be accepted as a fact.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 13 -- Capt. Peter L. Lapeyre of Live Oak County is in the city. He is an "old-timer" on the Texas coast. In connection with a number of cronies the other night the subject of snakes was Drought up. "We do not have a great many of 'em out our way now," remarked Capt. Pete, "for we have a bird that keeps 'em down considerably.

The dealings in breadstuffs to-day were slow, with prices irregular. Flour was hard to sell at easier prices, with absence of export demand. Wheat sold at 1 8c advance early, on stronger cables, but soon declined 7 8c on unfavorable financial reports from London, while there were larger supplies of the grain and local realizing, only to close stronger on local covering.

Gen. Lew Wallace is in this city conferring with his publishers about his forthcoming book. It is to be called "The Prince of India; or, Why Constantinople Fell," and will be in two volumes of a little more than 500 pages each. Gen. Wallace said he expected it would be out in August.
Antonio Villano, eleven years old, had an accounting yesterday with his father, Raffael Villano, a fruit dealer at 50 James Street, that made him sore of heart and body.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., July 13 -- A cloud burst over Finderne, one mile east of here, about 7 o'clock this evening. A great amount of water fell in a few minutes. The roads were washed out and fields of grain leveled to the earth. A passing train was caught in the deluge, and the water forced itself into the cars while all the windows and doors were closed.

--The Race Committee of the Hartford Wheel Club has arranged the following programme for the two days' meet to be given at Charter Oak Park on Sept. 4 and 6: First Day -- One-mile novice; one-half-mile open; one-mile. 2:46 class; one-mile handicap; one-mile, 2:35 class; one-half-mile international; one-mile League of American Wheelmen State Championship; one-half-mile handicap.

CONCORD, N.H. July 13 -- They say up here in New-Hampshire that Senator Chandler has a Presidential bee in his bonnet again. One of that kind of bees got into his bonnet a year and a half ago and died.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 13 -- The largest dispensary in the State, the one at Greenville, was to-day closed up under a temporary injunction granted by Judge Norton.

During the six months ending July 1 there were 3,838,915 pounds of meat, fish, fruit, and vegetables destroyed by the Health Department of the City of New-York. The destruction of this enormous mass of matter and the work which it involves was referred to by Assistant Chemist Ernest J. Lederle yesterday, as he told a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter something of the work which is being done under his supervision by the department officers.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 13. -- A number of young men, Summer residents of Far Rockaway, formed a baseball club and yesterday journeyed to East Rockaway, by stage, to play a match game with a native nine at the latter place. They took a mascot along in the person of sixteen-year-old Joseph Leach, the son of Thomas Leach, a prominent Far Rockaway resident.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 13 -- The Rev. Dr. L.C. Mayham was arrested this afternoon for assault and battery, on a warrant issued by Police Justice Frazee. The complaint was made by Thomas Fagan, the sixteen-year-old boy whom Mr. Mayham is alleged to have kicked and abused Saturday, while the boy was at work in the new Second Methodist Episcopal Church.

The City of New-York took the visiting Russian naval officers under its wing yesterday and showered its hospitality upon them, and the representatives of the friendliest power in Europe to the United States, at a time when friendship was of great value, were much impressed with what the greatest city on this continent can do when she puts her best foot forward.

The Rapid-Transit Commissioners met at Mr. Steinway's house yesterday afternoon and decided, as had been foreshadowed in the expressions of individual members, to require the Manhattan Railway Company to make some definite statement of its intentions by Aug. 17.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 13 -- In May, 1889, James Burns was sentenced for a term of thirteen years for robbery in the first degree, committed in Herkimer County. On Jan. 10 last Gov. Flower pardoned Burns on condition that he abstain from the use of intoxicating liquors for five years from that time.
CONEY ISLAND, L.I., July 30. -- The funeral services of the dead minstrel and comedian, William Lester, were held at Washington Cemetery in Parkvllle at noon to-day.
FARGO, N.D., July 13 -- Albert Baumberger, the Cando (N.D.) murderer, was placed in the jail here at 7 o'clock this morning. Sheriff Fadden of Grand Forks brought him here, fearing lynching.

-- The United French Societies of this city will celebrate the national holiday of the French Republic to-day at Sulzer's Harlem River Park. At the request of the committee having charge of the celebration. Mayor Gilroy has directed that the tricolor ot France be displayed over the City Hall.

BERLIN, July 13 -- At to-day's session of the Reichstag Dr. Osann, a National Liberal, moved the adoption of a resolution declaring that in consequence of the fodder famine the proposed army manoeuvres ought not to be proceeded with.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 13 -- The United States schooner Brenda, Capt. Ellis, arrived here yesterday in tow of the tug Gen. Humphreys and anchored off the old wagon pier. She has on board the surveying party engaged in the waters of the harbor, the lower bay,

We dislike extremely to present even the semblance of discourtesy to a distinguished stranger "in our midst," who is also a delightful novelist, but we are bound to point out that if Mr. WALTER BESANT had foreseen the awful cisatlantic consequences of founding a Society of Authors, respect for his intelligence forbids the thought that he would have founded it.

By the arrest of Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer, alias Hugo Wehler, alias William Reuter, alias Schaffer, alias Oswald, alias Stoffen, and his wife, Mary, in Detroit Wednesday night an end has been put to a gigantic scheme of swindling life insurance companies by poisoning persons on whose lives policies had been issued.

A letter from Secretary of State Gresham, bearing on a complicated case, was yesterday received by Harcourt Bull, a lawyer of 19 Broadway. Mr. Bull, as the attorney of Salvatore Guadagno, had endeavored, to attach money in the hands of Count Naselli, Acting Consul General for Italy in this city.

"A good many people think the anti-treating movement which I started is a dead letter, and has gone completely out of existence," said Oliver Sumner Teall while seated in his comfortable office at 60 Wall Street yesterday. "They are mistaken, however. It took me some three weeks to get the circulars, pledges, and other matters in shape.

The authoritative denial of the report that there had been forty deaths from cholera in Alexandria, and the assertion that cholera has appeared in no part of Egypt, afford fresh testimony as to the efficacy of the labors of the Egyptian International Sanitary Council, the only really useful agency of this kind for the exclusion of Indian cholera from Europe that has been established by the sanitary conferences of the powers.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Economy in the maintenance of the public buildings of the country was enforced by the last Congress, which appropriated only $580,000 for the pay of custodians' forces in eighty-six buildings. But $69,979 is allowed for seven more buildings than were appropriated for last year, to the extent of $655,000.

State Assessors William H. Wood, Henry D. Brewster, and John A. Mason made their annual visit yesterday to the Department of Taxes and held a conference with President Barker on the subject of the equalization of the State Taxes.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 13 -- The foreclosure decree in the Los Angeles Cable Railroad case will be signed to-day by Judge Van Dyke. The sale will take place some time in August, and, in all probability, the property will be bought in by the Consolidated Electric Railway, which holds a first mortgage. The title of the case is The Illinois Trust and Savings Bank vs. The Pacific Railway Company and others.

Our Democratic neighbor, the Sun, publishes in a very conspicuous place some remarks about the President's health and opinions, which appeared a few days ago in the Philadelphia Ledger, and says that the Ledger "attributes to him sentiments [concerning the tariff] marked by uncompromising hostility to the Chicago [Democratic National] platform."

HARTFORD, Conn., July 13 -- Gov. Morris this afternoon appointed Representative James Roche, Democrat, Judge of the City Court of New-Britain to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of Judge Valentine B. Chamberlain, Republican. It had been expected that the Governor would appoint a Republican in accordance with the understanding when the Republican House elected Judge Barbour, a Democrat, Judge of the Police Court of Hartford to succeed Judge McConville, a Republican.

The Commercial Cable Company notified its patrons yesterday that communication with Rio Janeiro and other points on the Brazil coast bad been seriously interfered with owing to the political troubles in Rio Grande do Sul. Business houses and Exchanges were also notified that cables in cipher would not be received in Brazil.

Miss Louise L. Potter is ten rears old and was born on the Windy Coast of Africa of negro parents. She is a Princess of the Bassa tribe, but just now she lives in New-York and is not anxious to leave the city.

LONDON, July 13 -- The Times's correspondent at Bangkok telegraphs that the Siamese Government has refused to permit two more French gunboats to enter the Meinam River, twenty miles from the month of which Bangkok is situated, and has threatened that if the gunboats attempt to cross the bar at the mouth of the river they will be sunk, and France will be held officially responsible for beginning war in Slam.
Lloyd Aspinwall's alleged gambling operations now promise to make work for the criminal authorities.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 13 -- The Department of Kansas Grand Army of the Republic has determined to come to the assistance of such of its members as have been or may be stricken from the pension rolls by order of Secretary Smith. The department will employ attorneys here and in New-York and will bring their cases before the Court of Claims, which they will ask to reinstate those dropped off.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- "Mr. Berry, the United States Consul at Santos," said Capt. Holland of the brig Odorilla, which arrived from Santos, "is living at the English Home at Sao Paulo, a town about twenty miles from Santos.

NORFOLK, Va., July 13 -- Mrs. Wallace returned to-day from Metompin Beach, where she had gone to see whether the body of the old man washed ashore on the beach Saturday was that of Cicero Harrison Case. The body was disinterred and examined by Mrs. Wallace, and from marks on the body was recognized as that of her father.

DETROIT, July 13 -- Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer, who was arrested here last night, is charged with having committed no less than five murders -- all by poison -- and with having attempted several others. He is also charged with being a swindler.

Gen. John M. Schofield, Gen. Henry L. Abbott, Col. H.W. Carson, Major Clifton Camly, and Capt. C.C. Morrison of the army and ex-Congressman B.M. Cutcheon of Michigan, constituting the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications, witnessed some tests of the big guns at Sandy Hook yesterday. The experiments were conducted to ascertain how the machinery of the gun carriages worked rather than to test the firing qualities of the guns themselves.

Mr. Qgden Goelot has Just chartered tlie steam yacht The White Ladye of Mrs. Langtry for five months, with the option of purchasing the yacht at the end of that time if he likes the boat and she comes up to all requirements. The White Ladye was built by Ramage Fergusson of Leith for Lord Ashburton. When launched she was Christened Lady Mabel.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Secretary of Agriculture has ordered the suspension or the inspection of sheep, beef, and lambs at the abattoir of the Jacob Dold Packing Company, Buffalo, N.Y. This action was taken upon the report of Inspector Devoe, to the effect that none of the beef, mutton, or lamb inspected at this abattoir is sold to the inter-State or foreign trade.

NEW-WESTMINSTER, B.C., July 13. -- The Rev. H.W. Peck. who has been a resident of Honolulu for five years, having been connected with, the educational department of the kingdom, is in this city. Regarding affairs in Hawaii, Mr. Peck said:
New Street enjoyed the novelty of an explosion about 2 P.M. yesterday. No one was injured, but a good many curbstone brokers were frightened and bespattered with mud.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- Dr. Gustave E. Guzman, Special Commissioner of Guatemala to the World's Fair, is here on his way to Chicago, Dr. Guzman is in charge of the Guatemala exhibit.
Mayor Boody of Brooklyn was in conference with Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy, ex-Secretary of the Navy, his private counsel, for more than three hours yesterday.

The outcome of the deliberations of the Directors of the World's Fair is a decision to close the fair on Sunday until the end of the season. This is a very curious result of the agitation that has gone on, but it may none the less be the most sensible thing that the Directors could do.

MOUNT VERNON, July 14 -- Two laborers engaged on the Mount Vernon Public Improvement Works were Killed while fighting upon the tracks or the New-York and New-Haven Railroad, near Palhumville, at 8:25 this morning. The express train which leaves New-York at 8 o'clock dashed upon them from around a curve.

A tall and a short man were standing outside the rail in the Stock Exchange at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, engaged in an apparently angry altercation. Suddenly the big man called the smaller a liar, and lunged out with a wild left for his face. The blow fell short, and a crowd of excited members rushed in and separated the men.

The fact that Chauncey M. Depew has decided to postpone his trip to Europe an to about the 1st of August has given rise to some comment and conjecture in Wall Street. He has made two or three visits down town within the past week, and his conferences with financiers have not escaped notice.

The Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter, pastor of the Baptist Tabernacie, was examined in supplementary proceedings before Judge Van Wyok, in the City Court, yesterday. He rather astonished Read, Hatting Winter, counsel for his creditors, Haeneke Co., coal dealers, who say that the doctor owes them $333.64, by stating that John A. Taylor of Jeans Taylor had been appointed receiver for him.

PARIS, July 14 -- To-day is the one hundred and fourth anniversary of the fail of the Bastile, but the fetes have been marked with tameness, and the usual celebrations have been conspicuous through their absence. This is due entirely to the feeling engendered by the recent riots.

STILLWATER, Minn., July 14 -- Stillwater was visited by a death-dealing tornado a few minutes after 3 o'clock this afternoon. It lasted less than two minutes, but two men. William Anez and Samuel Simonson, were crushed to death, and about a dozen other persons were injured.

There was nothing in the financial situation yesterday to show any lessening of the favorable conditions which had prevailed the day before. Receipts of currency from the interior continued on Just as heavy a scale, the Clearing House settlements included a very fair proportion of cash, the money market was easier, and on the Stock Exchange the general tone was decidedly better.

"The story in THE NEW-YORK TIMES regarding the trouble in the American Society of Authors was not improved by Mr. H.H. Van Dyck's correction of it," said Mrs. Emma Beckwith of Brooklyn yesterday. "THE TIMES was right and Mr. Van Dyck was wrong."

Alfred C. Cheney. Alfred C. Cheney, President of the Garfield National Bank of this city, died at Lake George on Thursday night. He had been ill for some time, but none of his friends here expected his death.
"I remember," said an old soldier last Sun day morning, "when church-going bells much more distant than those saved the City of Atlanta. It is a story I never saw in print.

LONDON, July 14 -- A city firm has received a telegram stating that the insurrection in the Brazilian State of Bio Grande do Sul has been quelled, and that the blockade of the City of Rio Grande established by the insurgents under Admiral Wanderkolk has been raised. No confirmation of the news contained in this dispatch has been received.
BERLIN, July 14 -- The Army bill passed its second reading in the Reichstag to-day. All the articles or tie bill will pass their third reading to-morrow.

J. Watson Cochran, until recently a Lieutenant in the Seventh Regiment, was arraigned in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of appropriating to his own use money belonging to C.G. Gunther's a Sons, furriers, of 184 Fifth Avenue. He was held for trial, and late in the day he was admitted to bail in the sum of $300.

QUEENSTOWN, July 14 -- The United States warship Chicago sailad hence to-day for Kingstown, the port of Dublin. Prior to her departure Admiral Erben, her commander, sent a letter to the authorities thanking them for the courtesies received by him and his officers while the Chicago was in Cork Harbor.

LIVERPOOL, July 14 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef and pork in moderate demand. Hams in moderate demand; short cut, about 14 to 16 to, steady at 56s. Bacon in fair demand. Cheese in fair demand. Tallow in fair demand. Spirits of turpentine in poor demand; steady at 21s 6d. Resin in moderate demand. Lard -- Spot in fair demand: futures in no demand; prime Western, spot, dull at 50s.

"Colorado has aided with her vote," says the Denver Silver Convention in its address to the people, "to build the tariff wall between this country and Mexico and the silver-producing and silver-using republics of the Southern continent. It was not in Colorado's interest to vote for such isolation, but Colorado, thinking more of her sister States than herself, has patriotically sacrificed her own in their interests."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Capt. J.A. Hutton of the Eighth Infantry is not held criminally responsible for the condition of the financial accounts of the army canteen at Fort McKinney, Wyoming. He was in charge of the canteen at that place for some time, and was detached from the duty several months ago.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Inventors and manufacturers having business with the Patent Office ate much interested just now in the delay in the issuance of the Patent Office Gazette, the official weekly record of patents granted, and also in the difficulty of obtaining copies of their patents.

The story of a peculiar marriage came out yesterday before Judge Bischoff, in the Court of Common Pleas. Mrs. Elinor S. Gibson, through her father. Frederick F. Proctor, the owner of Proctor's Theatre, in West Twenty-third Street, sought to have her marriage to Joseph R. Gibson annulled.

The Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday sent out a circular to 1,100 commercial organizations. It contained the resolutions of the board in favor of the repeal of the compulsory silver purchase sections of the Sherman act, and requested each of the organizations addressed to inform the board of any action on the subject, the object being to present to Congress a summary of such resolutions.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 14 -- The creditors of the Hanmor and Forbes Paper Mill Company, in Burnside, held a meeting in that place this afternoon, A.N. Mayo of Springfield, Mass., presiding. The receiver, Lawrence S. Forbes, reported the liabilities at $40,000, not including a mortgage of $15,000 on the mill. He declined to report appraisal of the property, leaving that to be determined by the creditors.

PITTSBURG, July 14 -- Havelock Jamet, who drove Fides Stanton all his winning races in the Central New-York Circuit, sat behind the fast Canadian trorter to-day, and la a single heat he finished the postponed 2:19 race, worth $2,500 to the winner. Stanton trotted steadily in Ma old trainer's bands, while with Commings on the sulky he had been very unreliable the day before.

In May, 1884, a panic took place in Wall Street, precipitated by the failure of GRANT WARD and the Marine Bank. It did not come suddenly, although these two failures did. Preceding them there had been a constant decline in prices, a nervous feeling had prevailed for weeks, and important failures had been looked for; but it so happened that the failures expected did not come, while the unexpected ones did.
Peter Chrlstman, an insane patient in the Bush wick and East Brooklyn Dispensary, 1,099 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, nearly Killed one of the attendants wlth a scythe yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, July 14 -- The entire interes of the markets was centred in Americans to-day and, opening strong at parities, prices rose until about noon, when two small failures were announced from Liverpool. On this news there was a reaction of about half a point, but prices soon steadied and were again moving up when a desperate attempt was made to create a panic by spreading rumors of difficulties in the Stock Exchange.

It was learned from high Russian sources yesterday that the Russian Government has decided to maintain a permanent fleet of war ships in United States waters, and that the port of New-York will he made Russia's Western naval centre.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Concerning the arrival of the British brig Darma, from Havana, in Hampton Roads, with her Captain dead and three of her crew down with yellow fever, Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has this to say:

New-York. -- Rogors'a Seventh Regiment Band will give a concert at the Mall, Central Park, at 4 P.M. to-day. Lieboldt's Twelfth Regiment Band will play at St. Mary's Park at 4 P.M., and Crowley's Eighth Regiment Band will play at Van Cortlandt Park from 4 to 6 P.M.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 157; North Chicago sold at 213, Canal and Book at 48, and Lake Street "L" at 20. Moner, 7 P cent. Bank clearings, $13,698,588. New-York exchange, $1.50 discount.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 14 -- The St. Louis Lumber Company made an assignment this morning to F.W. Beinidiek for the benefit of creditors. The assets, consisting of a stock of hardwood lumber and outstanding aooonnts, are placed at $40,000.

Frank Ellison was arraigned yesterday morning before Judge Cowing, in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, to pad to the indictment brought against him on Thursday by the Grand Jury, charging him with assaulting W.H. Henriques on June 5 with intent to kill.

Although the six races carded at Brighton Beach yesterday promised some good sport, the crowd was not as large as usual. The racing was good and in all of the events the finishes were close. For the past few days the battle between the public and the bookmakers had been a fierce one, and the latter had much the best of it. Yesterday, however, the tune was changed, for a majority of the favorites won.

-- Wall Street suddenly-waked up to me fact yesterday that bear speculators cannot go on forever monopolizing the stock market. Quotations were buoyant. Advances wore not of the fractional sort merely. The market broadened and big buying orders were executed.

President Lewis of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company appeared before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen in the Brooklyn City Hall last evening and stated his objections to the proposed ordinances regulating the trolley cars in Brooklyn.

All the power of the police of this city has been exercised to bring before the bar of New-York justice Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer and his wife, who were arrested in Detroit Wednesday night on a charge of having caused the death by poison of Gustave A. J. Baum.

The Eden Musee has engaged for one week only a company of Russian female dancers, who will introduce for the first time in this country Russian native dances. The engagement was made in honor of the visiting Russian men-of-War, the officers of which will be invited to visit the Musee and witness the performance, with the Committee of One Hundred and Mayor Gilroy.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 14 -- Two of those wounded in the West Shore wreck here died in St. Luke's Hospital last night. They were Julia Michel or 80 Lee Avenue, Brooklyn, whose skull and thigh were fractured, and Charles F. Sistare of New-London, Conn., who suffered from fractured ribs and internal injuries. The relatives of both were present and took charge of the bodies.
The 800 immigrants brought by the tramp steamship Red Sea were not landed on Bills Island yesterday, and it now looks as if at least half or them would nave to return.

KANSAS CITY, July 14 -- The National Bank of Kansas City suspended payment this afternoon, and is now in the hands of the Controller of the Currency. The assets, President Chick said this afternoon, will be between $2,000,000 and $3,000,000, and the liabilities between $800,000 and $1,000,000.

Robert H. Ingorsoll Brother, manufacturers of novelties and specialties in this city, have been ordered to remove their exhibit from the World's Columbian Exposition on penalty of confiscation. The offence with which they are charged is selling articles from their stand for immediate delivery, the article in question being a souvenir Columbns watch sold for $1.50.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 14 -- New-York could do nothing Young to day, and in addition to that Cleveland fielded perfectly. McKean's work at short was magnificent. Jones was very wild, and in the first two or three innings gave so many bases on tails that with a timely hit or two Cleveland should lave had three times as many runs, bat the hit did did not come.

The Knickerbocker Club Tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Brook Avenue, between one Hundred and Fortieth and One Hundred and forty-first Streets. The final rounds were reached in the men's singles and women's singles, and most of the second round of the men's doubles was completed. Play for the consolatlon prizes in the men's doubles and men's singles was begun.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Carnegie Steel Works have notified the Navy Department that they are ready to begin the shipment of the 200 tons of nine-inch armor for the sides of the monitor Monadnock. The test of the acceptance plate was made at the Naval Proving Grounds, Indian Head, last Tuesday, and, as reported in the NEW-YORK TIMES, proved satisfactory.
In the Building Department yesterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations were filed:

PITTSBURG, July 14 -- Within the next few days it is expected that the Homestead poisoning cases will be reopened and an effort made to prove that Hugh F. Dempsey, ex-Master Work man of the Knights of Labor, who is now serving a seven years' sentence in the Western Penitentiary, is innocent of the charge upon Which he was found guilty.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Mississippi River Commission has recommended to the Secretary at War that no more money be expended in the improvement of the harbor of Vicksburg for the present. This is in consequence of the fact that nearly two-thirds of the excavations have been filled up again by the action of the current, and it seems almost impossible to keep the channel clear.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 14 -- The seemingly interminable hearings continue into the merits of the fence war between Congressman W. Bourke Cockran and his next-door neighbor, J.H. Bunnell, who have Summer homes at Port Washington. The seventh session occurred here to-day before the Commissioners, Fitch, Quinlan, and O'Donnell.

LONDON, July 14 -- A dispatch from Bangkok, capital of Slam, states that twenty Siamese were killed and fourteen wounded yesterday daring the exchange of fires between the forts at the mouth of the Meinam River and the French gunboats Comete and Inconstante, which forced the passage of the bar in the face of orders from the Siamese Government prohibiting their entry into the river.
The money market was distinctly easier. The extreme rate for call loans was 6 P cent, and many were made as low as 4 P cent. The closing rate was 5 P cent.

NEW-YORK. FRIDAY, July 14-P.M. Evidences of returning confidence were not wanting on to-day's market The improvement in the money situation was the chief factor which influenced speculation. Call loans were readily obtained at rates not exceeding 6 per cent., and many were made at a much lower rate.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14 -- Everything is in readiness for the 100-mile road race of the Atalanta Wheelmen to Princeton sad return tomorrow. At Ashworth's Hotel on Central Avenue, East Orange, where the start and finish will he made, THE NEW-YORK TIMES has put in a special wire, and bulletins will he posted daring the race as to the positions of the roadsters.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 14 -- The reorganization of the State militia by Gov. Lewellyn and the replacing of all militiamen of Democratic or Republican proclivities by Populists continue and meet with the approval of the leading Populists. In an interview to-day, State Printer "Ed" Snow, one of that party, said:

The smoldering fires of war in the New-York Branch of the Universal Peace Union broke out yesterday over a very sharp letter that a prominent Peace woman had sent to Belva Loekwood refusing to serve on a committee with Mrs. Mary Frost Ormsby of Influence Club fame. Mrs. Ormsby was a delegate to the Peace Congress in Rome in 1891.

COYTESVILLE, N.J., July 14 -- The funeral of the late Octavia Allen took place at the Allen villa here to-day, the Rev. Dr. Dean officiating. There were quite a number of members of the theatrical profession in attendance, and many beautiful floral offerings were received. The remains were interred in the Brookside Cemetery, Englewood.

ELIZABETH,N. J., July 14 -- Charles Cadott, fifty-four years old, was arrested at his Home, 239 East Jersey Street, to-day, on a charge of assault. The prisoner made a vigorous resistance, and pitched the constable who served the warrant on him out of his house.

The business men's prayer meeting in the Old John Street Church was rudely interrupted yesterday. Mr. MoLaughlin of Jersey City Heights insisted on indulging in a form of worship decidedly at variance with generally accepted rules.

The race meeting of the Monmouth Park Association, which began July 3, has not been the "howling success" that its managers had expected. The managers have concluded that some of the newspapers that have dared to tall the truth about the racing in progress there are responsible for this, in a measure at least.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 14 -- Sneak thieves to-night carried off a tray containing $10,000 worth of diamonds, stones from/the jewelry store of Thomas V. Dickinson on Palls Street, near the comer of Second Street, Niagara Falls.

President H.W. Slocum, Jr., of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad yesterday appeared before the Kings County Board of Assessor and protested against the assessment of $448,000 levied, on personal property. He said the property of the road was worth $1,000,000, and he thought a tax on 70 percent excessive. The Assessors reserved decision.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Despite the torrid heat, there was a large attendance to-day at the sessions of the literary congresses.

Commissioner of Public Works Daly denies the report that the present condition of the Croton water is in any way due to the fact that the nuisances which he ordered abated during his recent raid on the watershed are still in existence.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: With deep regret I found this passage in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES: " *** An incompetent performer is stigmatized as a 'hamfatter.' or more compendiously as a ham.' The origin of the phrase is to us unknown and stands in need of elucidation."
CHICAGO, July 14 -- The World's Fair is to be closed on Sundays after July 16.

PEEKSKILL, July 14 -- The Twelfth Regiment and the Tenth Battalion have nearly completed their week's work in the State Camp, and tomorrow both will leave for home and give place to the Eighth Regiment of New-York, commanded by Col. George Scott, and the Seventy-fourth Regiment of Buffalo, commanded by Col. George C. Fox.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The torrid weather here kept traders out of the pits to-day. In grain there was a strong feeling for a short time at the beginning of the session, which gave place to a long spell of weakness, followed by a partial recovery. Corn continued weak to the close, which was at 1 4c decline from yesterday's resting figures. Wheat is 1 4c higher for September and 1 2c higher for December.

It was during the "crush" hour at the City Hall station of the elevated railroad, when 60 per cent. of the passengers secure seats and the remainder hang on to the straps kindly furnished by the company, incidentally trampling on the feet of the sitters at every curve or whenever the train jerks in or out of a station.

From the San Francisco Examiner. Now that the foremost figure in the Central Pacific Railroad's directorate lies dead at Menlo Park it is pertinent to call to mind the originator of the idea of building an overland railroad. Theodore D. Judah was the man entitled to that honor. Judah lived and died for that idea.

The London Boot and Shoe Trades Journal, commenting upon the drought in England, says it must result in enforced slaughter of cattle and lower prices for hides. It then proceeds with the usual English sagacity in dealing with American affairs, and says:

A piece of recess work arranged for at the last session of the Fifty-second Congress was that of opening negotiations with the five principal tribes of the Indian Territory, with a view to seeing whether they are willing to enter the Union as a State, or to accept the ordinary forma of Territorial government, or, at all events, to make severalty allotments of their lands.

The annual regatta of the Hempstead Harbor Yacht Club of Glen Cove was sailed in the Sound yesterday. The start was made off the club's headquarters fronting on the harbor. A stiff westerly breeze made the race exciting.

For a long time fun-loving members or the Produce Exchange have amused themselves by throwing balls of dough at their fellows without much regard for the rules prohibiting such, sport. Those rules have been, in fact, nearly a dead letter. The Exchange authorities have decided to put a stop to the practice.

WORLD'S FAIR GROUNDS, CHICAGO, July 15. -- The beautiful hall and banquet room of the New-York State Building was Illumined and decorated to-night, and proved the centre of attraction at the Fair Grounds. The halls were filled with flowers and potted plants, and the banquet room was brilliant with decorations of all kinds.

If you are not tall and Slender, dear girls, do not include a collaretted and winged, and bigsleeved Eton suit in your wardrobe. Certainly the temptation is strong, because every girl wants the thing that she sees looting pretty on some other girl, and on the tall, willowy girls, and the petite and dainty maidens these suits undoubtedly are a success.

LONDON, July 15. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- There is something curiously characteristic about the patient, laboriously-temperate way in which the English, are taking this Franco-Siamese embroglic. Their papers reflect with quite remarkable fidelity the popular British feeling on the subject, and I take it this feeling is the most interesting and significant feature in the whole strange situation.

John and Bernardus Cowenhoven of Gravesend began an action in the Supreme Court in Kings County yesterday to recover two strips of Manhattan Beach and $10,000 damages. One strip of the disputed land is 77 feet wide, and the other 66 feet, and both reach from the ocean front to Sheepshead Bay. One of the strips runs under the Manhattan Beach Hotel, and the other between that building and the Oriental Hotel.

Huge McLaughlin, more than any other one man in Brooklyn to-day, controls the political destinies of a great city. Called the "BOSS," there is no one who dare dispute the title with him. He is boss and master of the third largest city on the American Continent. He can make and unmake the fortunes of men at will.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15. -- According to reports brought from Hongkong by the steamer Peru, there seam to be prospects of more trouble between Japan and Corea. The Governor of a Corean province has issued a notification prohibiting trade in rice and other cereals, A number of Japanese families are suffering in consequence of the prohibition.

The restless woman, who has no home duties and craves the joys and honors of publicity, is having a little more than her fair share of public attention nowadays. Her capacity for getting into hot water and staying there seems to have been largely developed in the Columbian year. In her discomfiture she is not an edifying spectacle.

The "Corn Kitchen" at the Columbian Erposition is attracting the attention which it deserves. It is a systematic and persistent attempt, which is to be continued throughout the six months of the fair's duration, to demonenate the value of maize or Indian corn as a breadstuff.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The stale Department has received advices from Minister Baker at Managua confirming the news that a revolt has broken out again in Nicaragua, and that the President of the republic and his Minister of Foreign Affairs are held prisoners at Leon. There was no battle, but the Minister regards the situation as critical.
While trying to remove a horse from an excavation, at Grand and Elizabeth Streets yesterday morning, two men were injured by the fall of a derrick.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 15 -- Nantucket is just getting well over the excitement which the first rush of Summer visitors always brings, and is settling down as if the number of people here was nothing unusual. There has been little or nothing of importance going on, other than the usual amusements to which visitors at a Summer resort devote themselves.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15. -- Jacob W. Linneman of the Press Cycling Club of Buffalo trundied over 100 miles of miscellaneous Jersey roads to-day on a frail wheel, beating over a hundred roadsters who started ahead of him, and winning the first prize in the century run of the Atalanta Wheelmen to Princeton and return.

" Been two whole years in England and never saw that! Why, if I'd been two years there I should have known every back fence in that little island! " The remark was made by a returning tourist who had asked for information concerning which the one questioned was ignorant.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 15 -- Many new faces are noticed this week among the Summer visitors. The social event of the week was a sailing party tendered to members of Brown College Quartet, Mandolin, and Guitar Clubs by the ladies. In the party were Misses Berthaand Marguerite Foote, Emetine Langworthy, Louise Bush, Bess and Laura Greenman, and Miss Henrietta Miner of Mystic, and Miss Beth Knowles of Providence.

BERLIN, July 15. -- The Government hoped that the third reading of the Army bill to-day would be merely formal, and that the session of the Reichstag would close in time to enable the Emperor and Ministers to congratulate each other on the passage of the bill over a luncheon, but events were ordered otherwise.

Nearly 2,000 mothers and children have had a day's outing at the Sanitarium for Hebrew Children at Rockaway Part since July 3. Each one enjoyed a hot dinner in the pavilion. The sanitarium has a resident physician and a corps of trained nurses, and provision is made for the treatment of seventy sick children for one or two weeks.

In one of the larger American cities there is an Italian restaurant, with real Italian service, that bos among its chief patrons many who have lived half a dozen years in Italy, more or less, and are judges of purely Italian viands. In this particular restaurant they find their favorite dishes cooked and served in the genuine Italian manner.
Prominent owners of steamboats and other craft plying in the Hudson River are making strenuous efforts to have revoked the anchorage ground set apart for vessels of war and pleasure craft.
Manager Ward of the New-Yorks last night telegraphed from Cleveland:

-- The sleigh which the Canadians are to present to the Duchess of York as a wedding present is a large, old-fashioned, three-seated affair, which was more fashionable twenty years ago than now. But it is the pattern that she expressed a wish for. It Is made of second-growth ash, overlaid with curved panels of mahogany. It has high single steel runners, painted scarlet, and has a dark-blue body, striped with red.

Mrs. Harriet Webb, who keeps a ticket broker's office at 227 Broadway, and Lewis Lovison, her manager, were charged in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with having in their possession and issuing forged tickets for trips to the World's Fair over the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad. They were held for trial on Aug. 8.

QUEENSTOWN, July 15. -- The Cunard Line steamship Umbria, Capt. McKay, from New-York July 8 for Liverpool, arrived here at 6 o'clock this morning. She reports that one of her passengers, Ascher Weinstein of 808 Lexington Avenue, New-York, fell overboard from the saloon deck at 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 15. -- The last week has been devoid of unusual happenings. The visitors from New-York and Philadelphia have been as numerous as usual, and the weather has been of that ideal sort, neither too hot nor too cool. The pleasure and the health seekers have put in their time enjoying the fishing, sailing, and bathing, with occasional trips to the Monmouth Park race track.
The wagoner Plerre is tall and straight. His eyes are brave and clear: And they shine with a softer, deeper light When sweet Lisette is near.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 15. -- An Englishman giving his name as W.S. Woods arrived nine months ago in Halifax. He said he had held a position as teacher at Eton, England, and presented credentials that promptly obtained for him a position as teacher in the Halifax schools. He also connected himself with St. George's Church, took a prominent part in the services, and became a lay reader.
Mayor Boody of Brooklyn and other members of his "Cabinet" are in fresh trouble.
CALDWELL, N.J., July 15. -- This village was filled to-day with visitors from towns in New-Jersey and New-York.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15. -- Under the charming weather conditions prevailing in Southampton's neighborhood during the week athletics have been lively and the entertaining extensive. At the informal dance at the Inn last evening seventy ladies and gentlemen participated in the most enjoyable affair. Among them were Gen. and Mrs. J.G. Farnsworth of Albany, Mr. and Mrs. W.L. Moore.

For a little miss only eleven years old Lillie Wenglein of 218 East Eighty-fourth Street has a wonderful development of the feminine mania for shopping. That is why she was arrested last Friday night. It also explains why many of the neighbors were more cheerful yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15. -- The story of the rood race, as taken from the special dispatches sent by the riders to THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S operator at Ashworth's Hotel, is one-unusually devoid of unpleasant features such as have characterized other runs of the distance.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The Board of Revision, appointed by Commissioner of Pensions Lochren to examine the pension cases which have come before the bureau since the Disability Pension act went into effect with a view to ascertaining whether fraud has been practiced, has already examined nearly 12,000 claims. About 10,000 of these cases have been sent to the Medical Division for further examination.

LENON, Mass., July 15 -- Dr. Walter Seward Webb has been visiting Mr. and Mrs. W.D. Sloane. He came up from New-York in his private car with a party last Saturday evening, and staid over Sunday, and on Monday went on to Shelburne, Vt. where he will spend the greater part of the Summer. Mr. and Mrs. Sloane will visit him there some time the latter part of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The Secretary of the Interior to-day received from Chief Jones of the Choctaw Nation the following letter, in which he pointedly expresses his views as to the interference of the Government in the execution of the nine Indians sentenced to be shot on Aug. 4:

NEWARK, N.J., July 15. -- At the capacious Atalanta Wheelmen Clubhouse on Clinton Street to-night there was a scene of much enthusiasm. The Racing Committee, composed of J.S. Holmes, H.A. Wadaworth, and Oarl von Lengerke, was complimented on all sides for its efficient management. William V. Belknap, who had been on the go all day at the scene of the start and finish, came in for a good share of praise.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 15 -- Dullness has largely prevailed among New-London's Summer people so far this season, the desire seemingly being for quietness rattier than gayety. Outside of informal dancing in the hotel parlors, an occasional yachting party and a little quiet entertaining by a few of the cottagers nothing has occurred to disturb the serenity of seaside life since the hotels opened.

There is a merry jest current in Italy to which the appearance of Count HERBERT VON BISMARCK in the Reichstag on Friday gives point and plausibility. The anecdote relates to the first visit to Italy of the present Emperor of Germany in his imperial capacity and sets forth that a small Italian officer who was detailed to greet the imperial party at the station was rudely hustled by a large descending German and expressed resentment.

A circular from Vice Chairman Donald of the Central Traffic Association relating to irregular proceedings in the matter of World's Fair excursion tickets has caused considerable commotion among the General Passenger Agents of the Eastern trunk lines.

The first gun of modern ordnance for the protection of New-York is now in position, at Sandy Hook. It is a twelve-inch gun, weighing fifty-one and a half tons, and is mounted on a Snyder disappearing carriage. It is the first twelve-inch gun built in this country. It was constructed at the Watervliet Arsenal, and has fully borne out all the expectations of its designers.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 15. -- The Water Gap has weathered the hot spell admirably and not a day of the past week has been really uncomfortable. The number of July guests at the larger houses is in excess of the record of several seasons cast, and there have been many notable social events.

BUFFALO, July 15. -- Police Justice Thomas S. King is one of the most ardent Cleveland Democrats in Buffalo. He has fought the Sheehan faction tooth and nail over since the Lieutenant Governor had any following. He has pronounced opinions and had no hesitancy in expressing them in vigorous language.

The kangaroo, "Big Frank." who has bean giving exhibitions of the pugilistic skill at Eldorado by boxing with Bial's negro, was brought to Kostor Bial's on Friday afternoon with another kangaroo to be exhibited, there on Monday night. It was placed in a stall in Sutherland's stable, in Twenty-fourth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, in charge of a man named Turner.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 15 -- The George Hotel and grounds were gayly decorated with Chinese lanterns to-night, and the parlors and verandas thronged with guests and cottagers. The usual number of Saturday visitors arrived, to-day, and the fleet of the Atlantic Yacht Club is in the harbor. On the water the lights of the trim craft shone, but the yachts men had deserted their vessels and joined the merry party at the hotel.

Last Summer a series of lectures was delivered before the School of Applied Ethics in the University of Michigan, and the present volume gives in full the teachings of those who have devoted their time and attention to the great problem of bringing man into a happier relationship with his fellows.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 15. -- The Atlantic Yacht Squadron sailed out of Cold Spring Harbor at 10 o'clook sharp this morning. The pretty girls who had helped entertain the yachtsmen last night ware all out to see the start and waived fond adieus from the piazzas of the Casino. Some of the most venturesome went out in rowboats and inspected the Yachts and saw the preparations for the start.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 15. -- Long Island has a Long Branch of its own in this delightful resort. It has all of the advantages of the famous New-Jersey resort and many more peculiarly its own. It is nearer to New-York, a trip of three-quarters of an hour taking the broiled citizen of the metropolis from his Sahara of hot and dusty streets down to this favored region where Neptune holds his merry away.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 15. -- An attempt to tap the Western Union wire carrying the information from Brighton Beach and Monmouth Park was discovered and frustrated this afternoon. The leader of the party of three which came to this city was William Diefenbacher, the electrical expert who was recently released from Sing Sing, where he had served a term for wire tapping at Saratoga.
Two women who spent a week in New-York the last of June kept quiet about one of their experiences until a day for two ago, when they confessed the joke too good to keep.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, July 15 -- P.M. After a strong opening, the stock market hesitated and then became heavy. The announcement of the failure of the Schlesinger iron syndicate cast a damper on speculation, and the bear traders took advantage of the opportunity to hammer prices.
WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The statement of the United States Treasurer showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities today is as follows:

The Sheriff of Kings County yesterday afternoon served an attachment on the Bolivian Indian Troupe at Coney Island, where it is giving an exhibition. The attachment was served at the instance of Herbert J. Hindes, attorney for Emma C. Sickels, the lady so well known in connection with Indian work.

ORANGE, N.J., July 15. -- The grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club at Montrose are about as cool and attractive at this season as any spot in the Oranges. The half mile or more of completely shaded drives which surround the courts are taken advantage of by scores of persona fond of riding and driving.
NEWBURG, N.Y., July 15. -- Several witnesses were examined to-day in the inquest on the bodies of those killed in the railroad collision.

The armory of the Eighth Regiment, at Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, was the scene of great activity early yesterday morning. The regiment was preparing to start for Peekskill to relieve the Twelfth Regiment, and the younger members, who have never been at the State Camp, were anticipating with pleasure their week of camp work.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., July 15. -- Brentwood is deservedly famed as a health resort, and many persons have an idea that it is exclusively an Autumn or Winter retreat. They are agreeably surprised to find it a Summer paradise, fanned daily by refreshingly cool breezes as regularly as the rising of the sun.

Dr. Philip Ten EycK. Dr. Philip Ten Eyck, the associate of the famous Joseph Henry, died yesterday at Albany, N.Y. He was ninety-one years old. None of Albany's citizens nave been better known. His brother, John Ten Eyck, and three sisters, the Misses Caroline and Mary Ten Eyck and Mrs. Lydia Vau Valkenburg, survive him.

BOSTON, Mass., July 15. -- The Pilgrim, the syndicate cup defender of Stewart Binney design, made her trial trip to-day. The trip was a most successful one, and the yacht showed that she is a remarkably fast boat and that she is well balanced. stears easily, and is abundantly able to carry her sail. The wind was strong and puffy from the southwest, and there was considerable of a sea on.

-- Mrs. Charles W. Wetmoro, formerly Miss Elizabeth Blsland, the singularly successful journalist, is spending a quiet Summer at her new country place, at Oyster Bay. For the past few weeks sue has been entertaining the late Governor General of Trinidad and his wife -- Lord and Lady Broome.

MADRID, July 15. -- A dispatch from Bilbao, capital of the Province of Biscay, in Northern spain, states that a terrible railroad accident occurred in that province last night. A train consisting of a locomotive and six carriages, while rounding a sharp curve in the mountains, ran off the track and went over a high precipice.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: As a Vice President of the National Branch of the Universal Peace Union for a quarter of a century. I formed, twenty-one years since, the local branch of that body. My work as National Vice President being in other directions, I have taken scarcely any part in conducting the local, but left its management entirely to others, declining any office therein.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 15. -- The Rev. R.V. Hunter of this city. National President of the Christian Endeavor Sunday-Closing Committee, said to-day:

The roof gardens of the city seem to be growing in popularity steadily. The only drawback to their complete and permanent success is the uncertainly of the weather. On fine, warm evenings they are invariably crowded, but one rainy night makes a great deficiency in the receipts, while the high salaries of the vaudeville artists go on Just the same, and the managerial pocket has to suffer.

The bank statement yesterday was looked for with some anxiety, and was repaired as a small inataliment of comfort in the increase shown in the surplus reserve. It was small, leas than one million; but after the bank statement of the previous week, Which was the worst in ten years, yesterday's gave a ray of hope. Next week's statement is expected to be better yet.

The recent publication in a volume of collected papers by Mr. HENRY JAMES of one of that sensitive writer's essays derogatory to reviewers of books seems to have given fresh interest to the subject of literary criticism. Whatever Mr. JAMES may say on any subject he chooses to write about compels attention.

GOSSIP OF LAST WEEK. -- The beautiful Summer days of last week were much enjoyed by the fashionable people at the country resorts. Golf at New-port, archery at Lenox, add painting at Southampton have been the principal orders for the past seven days. Ward McAllistor's prophecies are gradually coming true. When under proper arrangement English sports will be popular.

The real estate market during the past week differed in no essential from that of the preceding week. Transactions were few in number, and of no especial significance. Plenty of brokers and speculators are in town, or come here every other day or so. Bargains are looked for, but few come. There is no disposition to put property on the market, because this is hardly the season for it, and good property is strongly held.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 15. -- Notwithstanding the intense heat, no diminution of interest or enthusiasm was visible in to-day's sessions of the Baptist Convention.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 15 -- The cool bracing weather of the weak has been utilized by those who own horses and those who can rent them for a continuous round of drives. The Crugermansion, the Observatory, Pray Hill, and all the other points of interest have had many visitors, while the favorite spin around the lake always serves as the parade for those who want to see and to be seen.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- The AEtna Stable's colt Rudolph captured the Columbus Handicap to-day at Washington Park, leaving behind him the pride of the West, Morello, and the well-touted Eastern star Lamplighter. Lamplighter and Diable seemed to be outclassed, or not up to a braising race, for neither got within hailing distance the entire route.

BANGKOK, July 15. -- The French gunboat Forfait arrived at the bar at the mouth of the Meinam River to-day. This is the fourth French war ship to arrive, the Lutin, Comete, and Inconstante being already here. When the Forfait arrived she saluted the British cruiser Pallas, which is lying off the bar, and her salute was returned by the British war ship.

The exclusive announcement in THE NEWYORK TIMES yesterday of the proposed action of the Russian Government to maintain permanently a fleet of war ships in United States waters was read in naval circles here with great interest.

The imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $8,234,580, of which amount $2,372,945 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $1,006,538 and the exports of specie were $943,091.

The Knickerbocker Field Club tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Avenue A and Eighteenth Street, Fiatbush The men's singles and mixed doubles were the events of the day. First place in the men's singles went to C. Bollinger, who defeated L.B. Drowne in a well played four-set match. The score was 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 9 -- 6. 6 -- 3.

Gonverneur Kortright has been appointed Fleet Captain of the New-York Yacht Club for the crulse which begins Aug. 7, when the squadron will rendezvous at Glen Cove, L.I. If weather permits, the programme for the cruise will be as follows:

RO CKVILLE, Conn., July 15. -- The second annual race meeting of the Rockville Wheel Club was held at Hyde Park this afternoon, with an attendance of 3,000, also the second meeting this season of the Eastern Connecticut Cycling Club, which includes clubs in New-London. Norwich, Willimantio, and Rockville.
BRAZIL, Ind., July 15. -- It has only just been learned that an attempt was made Thursday night by seventeen prisoners to escape from the county jail here.

-- Prof. Mace of Syracuse University, who has been lecturing on American history to the students of the university extension Summer meeting in Philadelphia, sailed for England yesterday, and upon invitation will lecture before the Summer meeting at Cambridge University. He is the first American ever asked to lecture before the Cambridge society.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 15 -- The Rev. J.W. Richardson, pastor of the Park Avenue Baptist Church, is at Middlebury, Conn., for July and August.

The ranks of the Peace Society are rapidly lining up in serried array. The war cry seems to have been sounded by the letter published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, in which a well-known peace lady refused to serve on a committee with Mrs. Mary Frost Ormsby, and insinuated that there was a scheme on foot to disrupt the regular New-York Peace Society.

One of the New-England Senators has intimated in a recent interview that the Senate at the extra session will have a good deal of business to attend to before it can get at the question of stopping the purchases of silver. Another Senator, also a Republican, has declared that the men of his party would necessarily be only "spectators" of the actions of the majority.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 15 -- There is an attraction about Stockbridge that brings a certain class of wealthy and literary people here every season. There are an unusually large number of well-known people here this Summer. About the only person of marked distinction that is missed about the piazzas of the Stockbridge House is the late Edwin Booth, who spent several weeks here last season.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 15. -- The Northrup Banking Company has voluntarily placed itself in charge of State Bank Commissioner Breidenthal. The fact that J.S. Chick, President of the National Bank of Kansas City, which suspended yesterday, is also President of the Northrup, caused a run on the latter bank this morning.

For a European health, resort you may go to Aigle-les-Bains, Bagneres de Bigorre, Cusset, Davos, Eaux Bonnes. Friedrichs-hall, Geisslubler, Schinzach, Toplitz, or Wiesbaden; bat you mast first decide what is the matter, and next the place best adapted to bring about a cure. Both these things should be done under the advice of a doctor.

A large fleet of passenger steamships sailed for Europe yesterday, but the number of tourists carried by them was not so large as on previous sailing days. Among the passengers on the various vessels were the following:

There is no better or more appropriate time for the contemplation of Dore's marvelous creations than the Sabbath day. Upon entering the gallery the spectator is struck with the imposing appearance of the vast hall and the magnificent effect obtained by the skillful arrangement of the paintings.

The preliminary trials of the engines of the new United States armored cruiser Maine were practically completed yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. At the offices of the N.F. Palmer, Jr., Company, the builders of the engines, it was said that so far as the contractors were concerned the Maine would be ready for her official dock trial next Wednesday.

NETHERWOOD HEIGHTS, N.J., July 15. -- A large number of guests are registered at the Hotel Netherwood, from New-York and other cities, and the outlook for one of the most brilliant seasons ever noted in the annals of Netherwood is bright. A german is bulletined for the evening or Tuesday, the 18th inst., and the subscription list already shows a large number of subscribers for the event.

The Board of Assessors or Brooklyn listened to an argument yesterday in favor of reducing the elevated railway assessment of $200,000 a mile. Lawyer William J. Cohen, who appeared for the Brooklyn and Kings County Elevated Railroads, stated, that la 1891 the court said the roads should pay $170,000 a mile, which was, in the opinion of the court, 70 per cent, of the valuation of the roads, namely, $245,000 per mile.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Amherst's mighty ball players were shut out by the invincible Vales at the Southside League Grounds this afternoon. The pitching of Carter was superfine, he striking out fifteen men and holding his opponents down to three scrawny hits.
SANERSVIILE, Ga., July 15. -- The most sensational affray this city has ever known occurred this afternoon. It was a duel to death between two of the most prominent citizens.
BOSTON, July 15 -- The week now closing has been the dullest of the year, so far as novelties at the theatres go.

Every sale of real estate at auction announced for the present week is in foreclosure proceedings, except one, which is an executor's sale. A few dwellings are in the list, but the greater number consist of flats and tonements. The complete list is appended, all sales being at 111 Broadway unless otherwise stated:

The Knickerbocker Tennis Club continuants open handicap tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Brook Avenue, between One Hundred and Fortieth and One Hundred and forty-first Streets. The men's singles and women's singles were finished and the men's doubles concluded an to the final round. One of the consolation matchts was also played.

Since Mr. Lee became sole editor of this dictionary the enterprise has gone forward with the same steady pace that marked the progress of the work under Leslie Stephen. Mr. Stephen's ill health forced his retirement from the arduous duties of sole editor and finally from his place as joint editor with Mr. Lee.

Gen. Adam E. King, until recently United States Consul General at Paris, returned to this country yesterday on La Toursine, accompanied by Mrs. King and his son. He went to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where he will remain two or three days. His three daughters are still in Paris, and Gen. King expects to return there to pass a part of next Winter.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 15. -- The first arrests under the new dispensary law took place to-day. Ever since the law went into operation it has been expected that Gov. Tillman's constables would begin making arrests, for liquor has been sold on te quiet in almost every larger city without cessation. Every day the report has gone about that the drag net would be pulled to-morrow or the next day.

Compared with the activity of the day before Wall Street was dull yesterday. News from Kansas City and the Lake Superior iron district was not encouraging, business on the loan market was nominal, as is usually the case on a Saturday, and on the stock market, while some advances were scored, the trend of prices was generally downward.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 15 -- The visitor to Bay Shore finds his lines cast in pleasant places inded. Situated at one of the most picturesque points of the Great South Bay, with charming people all about him and every combination of sports on land and water extending an invitation and health in every breeze, one has simply to enjoy himself and thank his good fortune that he is alive and in Bay Shore.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15 -- Probably in no previous year for many seasons past have there been so many cottages occupied in the middle of July as this year. There is hardly a single cottage vacant, and from now on there will be on ever-increasing whirl of gayety till the season's close.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, CLINTON COUNTY, N.Y., July 15 -- Possibly this well-equipped and popular hotel is more attractive this year than ever before. A large annex, which is connected with the hotel proper by a giass-inclosed passageway, has been built, which adds not a little to the comfort of the house. Guests are arriving every day.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Among so many attractions to be found in Midway Plaisance any one which draws everybody and is a continual centre of interest is specially distinguished. The Libbey Glass Works enjoys this distinction. It is constantly crowded with visitors who are rewarded by an exposition of the highest art in American glassmaking.

From an Occasional Correspondent. WHITEHALL, July 15. -- One of the most amusing and novel Summer lawn parties ever given occurred last evening on the grounds of Banker Brown's beautiful residence on William Street. The tables were profusely decorated with roses and spread for about forty guests. The elite of the village was there.

HOBOKEN, July 15. -- Poundkeeper Wood of this city this morning swore out a warrant for the arrest of Miss Annie Francis, daughter of Rees P. Francis, a wealthy retired lumber merchant who lives in Fifth Street. Wood alleged that last night he found a dog on the sidewalk in Fifth Street. The dog was unmuzzled and did not have a tag showing that its owner had paid the license fee required by law.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- The Shoe and Leather Building at the World's Fair was slow in completion, but it is proving one of the most popular and interesting at the exposition. The building is not large, and every exhibit is a select one, so that the visitor's interest is sustained from the moment he enters the compact structure until he leaves it.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 15. -- The Rev. Henry A. Adams, formerly rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, this city, and later of the Church of the Redeemer, New-York City, has joined the Roman Catholic Church. In a letter which will be published here to-morrow he gives his reasons for his change of heart.

BABYLON, L.I., July 15. -- Babylon is setting a strong pace in the matter of gayety, which her sister resorts on Long Island will find puts shem all on their mettle. Tennis holds its morry away, fishing parties daily, returning triumphant and jubllant; coaching, dancing, and bathing are all daily and nightly in progress. Dullness is unheard of and there is a snap and vigor to the season here that is invigorating.

ASBURY PARK, July 15. -- The Asbury Park Wheelmen are making big preparations for their two days' meet on Friday and Saturday, July 21 and 22. All the speedy wheelmen, Including the only Zimmermar, will compete for the valuable prizes offered. The events for the first day are as follows:

"At this season it will be in place," writes a physician in a paper on household chemistry, "to say something as to the wholesomeness of the extremely cold water, tea, lemonade, , which are so extensively used in this country. It must be acknowledged that medical men are not in possession of facts sufficient to form a positive conclusion, and many adopt the opinions which agree with their desires.
The new City Directory is even more interesting than its predecessors. People in search, of light reading rarely tarn to this volume, yet there is a great deal in it that challenges attention.

Some wise writer said that when artists fall to talking about their art, critics ought to listen and learn. Out in Chicago all sorts and conditions of artists ore gabbling about their art among them musicians. For about, Mme. Lillian Kordlea, otherwise Mrs. Lillian. Norton Gower, read a paper entitled "Women in Song,' and here is a fair specimen or It:

The Manhattan cricket Club sent a team to Newark for a game with the local club and administered a defeat to them by 28 runs yesterday. The Stratford brothers did some great bowling for the local team, and at one time they looked like winning J. Mart and A. Wallis, however, saved the day for Manhattan.

The coming of the watermelon always brings joy to the heart of lovers of that refreshing product of the field, but the prices at the opening of the season prevent many people from enjoying the melons. When the height of the season arrives, however, as it has now, and watermelons pour into the market by the hundreds of thousands, the price falls like a plummet.
