MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 15 -- Great preparations are making here for the wheelmen's lantern parade and fete to be held about the 1st of August. The lawn of the Chelsea Cottage is to be the scene of the fete, and it is expected that nearly a thousand wheelmen, including a number of ladies, will parade. Montclair is nothing if not a cycling town, and the splendid "sandpapered" roads are conducive to fast riding.

From the Boston Transcript, July 7. Plans have been filed with the Worester County Commissioners for what will undoubtedly be the largest dam in New-England. It will be known as Dam No. 5 of the Boston Water Worke Association, and will be situated in Southborough in the Sudbury River Valley. It will be 2,000 feet long and in the centre will be 75 feet high.
The old saying that "new brooms sweep clean" is likely to be verified in the person of Postmaster Charles W. Dayton.

PATERSON, N.J., July 15. -- The Grand Jury of Passaic County came into court this morning and handed in a large number of indictments. There are said to be about twenty indictments against members of the Board of Freeholders and some of their clerks. One of the indictments contained 25,000 words.

The last phrase of this book, which closes a-celebrated series, is prettily symbolical of its author's philosophy, "In the lukewarm silence, in the solitary peace of the workroom, Clotilde smiled to the child, which was nursing still, its little arm in the air straight, raised as a flag, a signal call to life." For the author likes life with lyric enthusiasm. Again Dr. Pascal, his hero, says:

The one thing that attracts most attention at the Monmouth Park races is the number of disreputable persons who are permitted to enter the gates. Men and women of no character are freely admitted to the grounds. They pre-empt the best seats in the grand stand. No respectable man or woman can go to this home of the gamblers without coming in contact with these persons.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 15 -- The Summer season has opened here, after some delay in consequence of the prolonged easterly weather, and there are now several hundred visitors on this isolated heap of gravel and clay. No one comes here for fashion. There is nothing in the air that savors of "style." There is scarcely a fashionable turnout on the island.

The stories told by the immigrants who were brought to this port on the tramp freight steamer Red Sea show that the shipment of immigrants to this country on such boats should be discouraged by the rigid enforcement of all statutes that can be used in the good work of making such traffic unprofitable.

The Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter of the Baptist Tabernacle Had his usual matines yesterday in the shape of an examination in supplementary proceedings, while his hated enemy, the Rev. Mr. Putnam, was called upon, in other proceedings, to testify as to Dr. Potter's financial standing in the community.

HONOLULU, July 7. -- The force of forty-two soldiers and police sent to Kaual to reduce to submission the-twenty-eight lepers in their fastness in Kalalau, one of whom shot Sheriff Stolz last month, was landed and secured, fifteen of the lepers. The captives were brought to Honolulu on July 3. They were mostly in a weak and destitute condition.

In times like the present when so much attention is given to the sanitary arrangement of the house and every possible lurking place of the bacillus or other disease germ is hunted out, purified, and cleaused, a work bearing upon modern appliances in sanitary plumbing is of general interest.

Gustave Lehman, an "extra" gateman in the employ of the Second Avenue elevated railroad, had a narrow escape from death in front of the station at Allen and Grand Streets yesterday afternoon. He is now in Gouverneur Hospital with his right foot cnt and mangled.
CHICAGO, July 15. -- The Bouton Foundry Company, at Thirty-ninth Street and Evans Avenue, has assigned to the Equitable Trust Company. The assets are $175,000; liabilities, $200,000.

The tramp steamship Red Sea, which came into port to find herself famous, spent all of yesterday anchored in the stream off Ellis Island. In the afternoon her crew went to work on her decks with holystones and sand.
ALBANY, July 15. -- It may be set down as an established fact that the Seventh Regiment will visit Chicago during the first week of September as an escort to Gov. Flower.

MORRIS COVE, Conn., July 16. -- The yachts of the Atlantic club squadron bebbed at their anchors at Black Rock all last night. The breeze that many of the yachtsmen whistled for late Saturday afternoon came during the night when it was not wanted, and kicked up quite a swell. Before breakfast the yachtsmen took a plunge in the salt water and were then ready for the day's ceremony.
Michael Moria, seventeen years old, of Prospect Street and Hudson Avenue, and Joseph Marona, twenty-three years old, of 30 Main Street, Brooklyn, quarreled Saturday night over a game of cards.

The Harlem Wheelmen and the Washington Wheelmen of Tremont raced Saturday over the Harrison-Rye course to decide the dead heat for first place which was run at the road race of the Suburban Cycling League June 24. The race resulted in a victory for the Harlem men, as they scored 29 points to the Washington's 26, but it was a close race and hotly contested.

The latest number of the London Economist contains two articles of some length and very carefully written on the recent notion of the Government of India with reference to silver coinage. The first is a very full abstract of the report of the Herschell committee, the second considers some points in the scheme.

FRANK LAWTON, now stage manager at the Madison Square Roof Garden, has signed with Charles H. Hoyt for the coming season. It will be his sixth conaecutive season with Hoyt's companies. He will be cast in "The Milk-White Flag," which will open Chrismas week at the Boston Theatre for a four months' ran. The play, which has not yet been completed.
The large shipments of wheat and, corn to Europe last week deserve some attention. We show in the following table the exports, in bushels, of wheat (including flour) for the last six weeks:

NEWPORT, R.I. July 16. -- Mrs. Maria Louisa Travers, widow of William R. Travers, died at her Summer residence in the Pinard cottage early this morning from Brights disease, with which she had been troubled for the past two years. She was the daughter of the late Reverdy Johnson, who was United States Minister to England under President Grant's Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Gen. Schofield is at loggerheads with the heads of the staff corps in the War Department. The warfare is a quiet one, carried on with that respectful dignity which should distinguish a controversy with the Major General commanding the United States Army. It grows out of the desire among staff officers to have on their uniforms a little device known as the aigulette.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 16. -- After three days and two nights of continuous watching, Detectives Reagan and Mandel of the New-York Central Railroad have caught a man who is believed to be one of the robbers who made the big haul of liquor and cigars from the NewYork Liederkranz commission car last Thursday night.
The biography of A. Bronson Alcott will be republiahed in London soon by Fisher Unwin.
Gen. Edward Jardine, the veteran soldier who for sixteen weeks had been battling against death, died in his apartments at the Hotel Pomeroy at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Thomas J. Wadson. Chancellor of the Bermuda House of Assembly, and Samuel A. Masters, a member of that body, reacted here yesterday as delegates from their Government to ask concessions at the hands of Congress in regard to the tariff. They want reciprocity in trade. Without it, they say, the growth of the Islands will be retarded.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 16. -- The disbandment of Gatling Gun Company A the famous Veteran Zouaves of this city, by the State military authorities has taken most of the people here and elsewhere by surprise. It is, however, really the culmination of a warfare that was begun last Fall on the Veteran Zouaves by the Elizabeth City Council.

The friends of Ascher Weinstein, the real estate speculator of this city, who jumped or fell overboard from the Cunard steamship Umbria, during the passage just completed from this city to Liverpool, feel satisfied that he committed suicide as the result of a sudden insanity. The story of his death, as it comes by the cable, will support no other theory.

In the Issue of July 1 or the Economiste Francais, its editor, M. Paul Leroy Beaulieu, discusses the silver situation as the decision to close the mints of India to the white metal has left it. He also considers the silver policy of the United States and gives a clear statement of his views on the proper course of legislation for this country to pursue. He says:

The attaching of the Bolivian troupe at Coney Island Saturday on a claim of $5,265 by Miss Emma C. Sickeis is being followed by interesting developments. The managers of the troupe are themselves now in a wrangle. There are three. Surocco. Pena, and del Valle, all from Bolivia. Pena and del Valle are respectively uncle and nephew.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 16. -- The Rev. Dr. McGlynn made his first public appearance since his return from Rome in the auditorium at Prohibition Park this afternoon. He received a hearty greeting from 5,000 persons.

NEWARK, N. J., July 16. -- Whealmen here today did little else than discuss Saturday's big century run, which proved such a success, no less than eleven riders breaking the American record for a hundred-mile road run. It was too warm for much wheeling, and at the clubhouses of the cyclists members spent the day quietly telling of their experiences in the trip to Princeton and return.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In view of the discussion which must soon ensue in Congress on the silver question, it becomes important to deal with silver as a product in order to measure its relation to other occupations by a comparison of the number of persons employed, the wages paid, the proportion of capital to product, and the other elements which are necessary to the consideration of any economic problem.

Three men bleeding from cuts presented themselves within a few minutes of each other to Sergt. Finunery of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night. Each man said he had been hit by a lamp, and each said he did not know who threw it.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Although the Directors have voted that the gates of the World's Fair will not be opened, on Sunday hereafter, the matter is not decisively settled yet. A temporary injunction obtained several weeks ago by Charles W. Clingman, one of the stockholders in the Exposition Company, and a taxpayer of Chicago, compelling the gates to be open, still stands in the way.

TRENTON, N. J., July 16. -- Notwithstanding the alleged stringency in the money market, the miscellaneous corporations are paying their far better this year than for several years past. The indications are that the returns will be larger than in any previous year since the board came into existence. About 3,600 corporations will be taxed.

Although, yesterday was one of the most uncomfortable days of the Summer, the thermometer was many points lower than on several days in June. Saturday night was comparatively cool, but with the dawn there came the first rush of the warm wave, and from that moment until midnight last night New-Yorkers fumed, fretted and sweltered.

The Crescent Athletic Club handicap tennis tournament was continued Saturday afternoon on the club courts. Bay Ridge. The second-class singles, third-class singles, firsc-class doubles, and second-class doubles were the events of the day. The handicapping was as follows: In the second-class men's singles those in Division A owed to those in Division B half fifteen and owed those in Division C half fifteen and gave half fifteen.

So many of the Fleetwood members are out of town that the clubhouse is somewhat quiet these warm days. This quietude is not reflected out on the track, where the work goes steadily on of converting green horses into finished trotters or pacers. So many of these " green " steppers are quartered here that, while the speed shown is encouraging, the figures are too slow to merit mention.

PARIS, July 16. -- Rear Admiral Humann, who was in command when the gunboats Inconstante and Comete crossed the bar of the Menam River and proceeded to Bangkok, has made a brief report of the incident to the Government.

BERLIN, July 16. -- The Leipziger Strasse in front of the Reichstag Building was thronged with Berliners yesterday eager to get the first news of the vote on the third reading of the Army bill. Most of those waiting received, in silence the announcement of the vote, for the great majority of the crowd had lingering hopes that at the last moment the scales would turn against the Government.

JACKSON, Miss., July 16. -- Henry Singleton, a negro serving a life term at the penitentiary, yesterday killed Lulu Payne, a female convict, by stabbing her repeatedly with a file. He made the attack while the female convicts were getting water at the cistern.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The International Railway Commission, which was one of the outgrowths of the late Pan-American Congress, is now engaged in winding up the work it has been pursuing for the past two years, and the engineers and surveyors who have been in the field are preparing their reports and reducing their field notes to the shape of maps and charts.
"Dot" Sonwell, the young woman whose specialty is handling venomous snakes, was bitten yesterday afternoon in the back of the neck by a huge rattlesnake in a Fourteenth Street Museum.

The announcement made yesterday that the Rev. Henry A. Adams, formerly pastor of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Buffalo, who has been recently in charge of the Church of the Redeemer, Park Avenue and Eighty-second Street, had become a convert to the Catholic Church was the general topie of conversation among Episcopal clergymen in this city.

Pastor Ch. Piepenbring's work has been translated by H. G. Mitchell from the French, by permission. The translator lauds the book as remarkable for clearness and simplicity, and especially for " frankness and fearlessness, the evident, outgrowth of the faith of a sincere Christian."

The singers of the German Liederkranz who made a three weeks' triumphant concert tour in the West are home again, delighted with their own work and with the hospitable and enthusiastic receptions that were given to them everywhere.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 16. -- Henry C. Bellows of New-York was drowned in the bay, off Wings Neck, last evening. He was eighteen years of age, and a son of the late Rev. Dr. Bellows, the eminent Unitarian minister.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N. H., July 16. -- A fire broke out in the upper part of the Glen House, owned by Charles R. Milliken of Portland, Me. about 6:30 this evening. The fire started over the office and spread with great rapidity. Within an hour the large structure was in complete ruins. The origin of the fire is unknown.

-- Capt. John W. Davison of the Washington Wheelmen, Tremont, in a rider of more than local fame, and has performed some notable feats in longdistance riding. Last Fall he rode from New-York to Hartford and return, a distance of 225 miles, in one day, and the next day rode from New-York to Albany. He is in favor of the flying start for bicycle races, both track and road.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 16. -- The war in the New-York branch of the Peace Union has not been officially brought to the attention of President Alfred H. Love, but that gentleman evidently Knows all about it. This afternoon no declared that he felt convinced that the whole matter would adjust itself peaceably in the end.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Controller Eckels has received the following letter from Henry Clews, the well-known banker:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The silver fanatics will not relish the contents of a letter written to Secretary of Agriculture Morton, by J. Lawrence Laughlin, Professor of Political Economy at the University of Chicago, which is contained in this dispatch. Mr. Laughlin was, previous to his call to Chicago. Assistant Professor of Political Science at Harvard.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 16. -- Intense excitement prevailed in this city to-day over the arrest of John J. Bush, cashier of the defunct Elmira National Bank.

The most celebrated of modern, rulers is not one of the earliest to he embraced in this series of biographies. Nelson and Gustavus Adolphus have received attention before him, while among the ancients Pericles and Caesar long since had been included. Napoleon, in fact, has not appeared on the list of arranged-for biographies. so that, in a measure, this volume was unexpected.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Secretary Morton today expressed both surprise and indignation at an interview with Forecaster E. B. Dunn of New-YorK, publiehed on Friday last.

When J. H. and William Dick, the wealthy Williamsburg sugar refiners, went to their Summer house at Islip, they left their residences, 160 and 166 South Ninth Street, in charge of Rudelph Woebberking of 40 Reid Avenue.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 16. -- But few people are aware that preparations are being made for a revolution in Kansas -- one that will attempt to override all law in the effort to give the "starving class" that which they have not earned. There are men who have lived lone enough in Kansas to realize what is now being done.

George W. Plympton and F. R. Lee, Commissioners of Electrical Sub-ways in Brooklyn, Saturday issued a circular to the Presidents of the various railway corporations using the eleotric trolley system in Brooklyn, which will Interest those who travel on electric lines.

-- Very pathetic is the letter of ex-Gov. James L. Kemper of Virginia, who, in reply to a request from a friend, says: "Propped up on pillows, paralyzed, a helpless and dying cripple and sufferer, I try to write you a line. I know of no painted portrait of my poor face except the one which hangs in the Capitol at Richmond.

Our London dispatches yesterday referred to the curiously forbearing temper in which, the English public take the recent action of France in Stain and the sentiment of pity for the misfortunes of the French people by which this temper is inspired. There are other reasons for moderation on the part of the British Government, which Lord ROSEBERY sufficiently appreciates.

The vile and fiery liquor which is sold in the dens and dives of the east side on Sunday, as well as during legal hours, was responsible at 6 o'clock last evening for the shooting of James Galiagher, twenty-one years old, a plumber living at 301 East Forty-first Street, by Francis Kiernan of 249 West Sixty-first Street.

The horror of Boston maidens of slang is not a new theme, though it constantly finds new illustrations. Last week a Boston woman, wish her nine-year-old daughter, visited a former schoolmate in old city. The hostess is possessed or a nine-year-old boy, and the two at once become fast friends. When Saturday sight came the boy was hustled off to the bathroom to be scoured up for Sunday.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- With banks toppling over in the West, all other news to-day went for naught on 'Change. The amount of wheat on ocean passage decreased 1,432,000 bushels, and the visible supply decreased 2,491,000 bushels, or together nearly 4,000,000 bushels. A falling off in Russian shipments was said to be causing a firmness in English markets, and reports from the Northwestern Spring wheat region hero wore no more reassuring than before.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- A very small crowd witnessed some good races to-day at Washington Park, the most prominent being the pony race at one mile, for which Crawford, with George Miller up, was first choice in the betting, but he had the hardest kind of a time in boating Pocahontas, on whom Fred Taral rode a magnificent finish, only being beaten a nose on the post

Several little girls and an elderly man who were a suit of snow-white duck, all skipping rope, attracted the loungers of Madison Square yesterday afternoon. A half dozen of the little girls and the man had ropes, and in spite of the heat they kept vigorously on with the exercise.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 17. -- Residents and visitors were surprised yesterday when they went to take their Sunday afternoon bath to learn that, by order of Mayor Leonard, bathing was prehabited after 12 o'clock Sunday. A special officer was detailed to give notice to the owners of the several hundred bathing houses, and the result was a greatly-disappointed crowd of both sexes.

The Duplex Street Railway Track Company, a West Virginia corporation, with, an office at 51 Wall Street, made an assignment yesterday to John D. Elwell without preference. An attachment was issued against the company a few days ago for $437 in favor of the Jonson Engineering and Foundry Company.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 17 -- Eleazer Z. P. Dayton, an eccentric farmer of Baiting Hollow, who was accused last week of attempting to drown, six little children by driving them into a deep brook under threats of shooting them, was arrested this afternoon. He was taken before Justice Millard, and his hearing was adjourned until Saturday.

BELFAST, July 17. -- The outter Iverna, which took part in the recent race at Baugor, has met with an accident, which will prevent her from taking part in several fixtures for which she was entered. She was towed here today for repairs, having badly strained her rudder head. It will be a fortnight before her repairs can be finished.

The Rev. HENRY A. ADAMS'S escapade is accounted for by some of his late brethren in the Episcopal Church by the statement that he is weak-minded -- possibly insane, if we rightly interpret some of the intimations put forth. It was not necessary to go quite so far as that. Mr. ADAMS'S motives for forsaking the Episcopal Church for Roman Catholicism concern no one so much as himself.

"Panjandrum" had a now Paquita last evening, and she received the warmest kind of a welcome. Of coarse, no welcome not kept in a refrigerator could have been cool when the thermometer stood where it did lost night, bat another kind of warmth than that characterized the applause given to Mrs. Edna Wallace Hopper by the people who filled the Broadway Theatre.
LONDON, July 17. -- The Prince of Wales met with an accident this evening which, while it had no serious result, gave him a bad shafting up.

NEWARK, N.J., July 17. -- William O. McDowell, who was spoken of by Judge Day in THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S article on the Universal Peace Society yesterday, was found tonight at his residence, 20 Spruce Street, this city. He said he had read Mr. Day's remarks, and thought they were scarcely worth noticing.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 17. -- Despite assertions of strength and the publishing of a favorable statement Saturday, the Missouri National Bank was taken possession of by the Controller of the Currency shortly before noon to-day.
-- A small boy as he watched the game on the Polo Grounds from a seat in the "bleacherts" sang at "Tom" Tucker as he was coaching:

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Forty-ninth Street, at the crossing of the Grand Trunk Railroad, was the scene to-day of another accident whereby three lives were lost and many people injured. A Halsted Street horse car, with forty-six passengers, was run into and hurled thirty feet to one side. The dead are:

LONG BRANCH, July 17. -- Regieter Levy was called on hero to-night by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, and he expressed surprise that Police Justice Ryan should have given utterance to the language attributed to him in the newspapers in reference to the Hebrew population of the east side. He said:

BALTIMORE, July 17. -- Umpire McLaughlin helped to win to-day's game for the home team. It was a howling crowd which greeted the Orioles' return after a month's absence. Kicking and arguing with the umpire was largely a feature.

The absence of the official stenographer of the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday caused a further postponement of the much-talked-of case in which Eugene Sandow. the strong man, charges Sarah E. Whyt, better known as "Lurline, the Water Queen," with attempted blackmail. Justice Koch, who was on the bench, will give a hearing at 10 o'clock Monday morning in the Yorkville Police Court.
BANGKOK, July 17. -- The Government of Siam has consented to withdraw the troops in the Mekong Valley, provided that France agrees also to suspend hostilities.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 17. -- W.E. Buck of Portage Creek, McKean County, Penn., was round lying in the lumber yard of Holland, Graves Montgomery in the lumber district of this city early Sunday morning. He was unconscious and blooding profusely from a bullet wound in the chest.

BOSTON, July 17. -- Gen Alejandro Ybarra, who is suggested for the coalition candidate for President of venesuela, is closely identified with Boston in a business way. He is now living with his family in this city. He married the daughter of ex-Collection Thomas Russell, who was United States Minister to Venezuela under President Grant.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 17. -- "Dub" Meetze was shot and killed, to-day by a posse of citizens who were his neighbors. Meetze was tried and convicted for forgery and horse stealing several years ago. On the completion of his sentence he was ordered out or the State. He said that before leaving the State he would kill some of those who had testified against him and burn the houses of other witnesses.

The testimony on which the June Grand Jury of Kings County censured Mayor Boody and the Aldermen concerned in the electric street railroad franchise scandal will be given to the public to-day unless Mayor Boody changes his mind. County Judge Moore yesterday granted the Mayor's application for a copy of the minutes.

The report of the firing work of the two French gunboats, Comete and inconstante, before the Pamkin forts in Siam was yesterday read hero by prominent ordnance officers of the navy with great interest. The opinion was rather freely expressed by certain American naval officers that the showing made by the French gunboats was exceptionally poor.

The "Cold Thirteen" of the Brooklyn Common Council yesterday gave the people of that city another exhibition of their utter contempt for the wishes of property owners where the interests of rich and greedy railroad corporations are concerned.
-- Mrs. Samuel Corwin of Marlborough, N.Y., aged sixty, while throwing ashes down a two-hundred foot embankment yesterday was precipitated to the bottom and instantly killed.

-- Mr. C.K. Tucterman records an instance in which Charles Sumner neatly evaded a tacit criticism from Macanlay. It was at a London dinner party, when one of the guests asked the American where Washington's body was buried. "His ashes," replied Sumner, somewhat sententiously, "repose on the banks of the Potoraac." "His ashes" said Macanlay, who was present.
In the passenger list of the American liner New-York, which sailed from this port Saturday morning, were the names of a bridal couple -- Mr. and Mrs. Leicester Holme.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 17. -- Walter N. Thayer, Warden of Clinton Prison at Dannemora, came to Albany late this afternoon and related to Gov. Flower the desperate scheme of a number of long-term convicts in his prison to gain their freedom, which involved the cold-blooded murder of several of the prison guards.

BALTIMORE, July 17. -- Two more cable lines and three more electric lines will be put in operation in Baltimore within the next few weeks. There are trolleys in every direction through, all the suburbs, and Baltimore is rapidly becoming a second Boston as far as the use of the overhead system is concerned. There are three things in connection with its street-car system that are of general interest.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 17. -- Commissioner of Agriculture Schraub has just returned from Chicago, where he has been in consultation with the New-York State World's Fair Commissioners with reference to the dairy exhibit. He reports that in the exhibit for this month New-York exceeds all other States, not only in the character of its products, but in the number of exhibits.

The Union Ferry Company of New-York and Brooklyn has notified Controller Myers that it will no longer operate its ferries under the arrangement which has been in force for two years and under which the company pays the city 12 3/4 per cent of its grogs receipts. The company claims that it cannot afford to pay this percentage and carry passengers at the present rate.

The younger society element of Harlem is rejoicing as much as the humid weather will permit just now over the triumph of two of its members who are yet in their teens in getting married despite the opposition of their parents.

The first game of the series arranged by the Boston Cricket Club with the teams of the metropolitan district was played at Morris Park yesterday, where the home team was easily defeated by an inning and 52 runs.

Mr. A.B. MONTGOMERY of Lyon County, in Kansas, is sued by a neighbor, Mr. JAMES BUTLER, for damages thought to be proper compensation for the destruction of the plaintiff's crops by means of a cloud-burst constructed by the defendant. Mr. MONTGOMERY is a rainmaker of repute, but is not always so careful as he might be in the distribution of his products.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 17. -- Lizzie Byram, an intelligent, pretty girl of nineteen, living with her parents on Fourth Avenue, died this morning a victim of hydrophobia.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Educators will have meetings at the Art Institute for the next two weeks. Every possible phase of educational work will be represented and discussed. College professors and college students, the deaf, the dumb, and the blind, typewriters and stenographers, physical culturists, business educators, Chautauquans, exponents of manual training, will all have their innings.
The British tramp steamship Red Sea, of malodorous repute, is discharging her cargo of cement at Woodruff's Stores, Brooklyn. On her return voyage she will load with freight for Bremen.

Two brawny west side young ruffians had an impromptu ring battle, wearing regulation boxing gloves, in the presence of several hundred persons, in a vacant lot at Eleventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, last evening, and, after two rounds had been fought, one of the men was so badly injured that he died a little later in Roosevelt Hospital.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 17. -- For the first time in six years the City of Jacksonville will hold a municipal election to-morrow under a special act of the last Legislature. This abolished the form of Government by which the Governor of the State appointed the city officers and provided for elections by the Australian ballot system.

The slizling hot weather in the city probably accounted for the big crowd that filled the betting ring and grand stand at the race track by the sea yesterday. But if the patrons of the track were looking for comfort at the Brighton Beach race track they were disappointed, for the few puffs of wind that were wafted into the grand stand and betting room did not cool the racegoers.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- The National Commission, which had confirmed nearly every appointment made by its committees and other subordinate organizations without comment, refused this afternoon to approve the nominating of woman judges of the Department of Manufactures. The list was named through Miss Meredith, Secretary of the Woman's Board, to John Boyd Thacher and by him submitted to the commission.

THE DEATH OF MRS. TRAVERS. -- The long-expected but sincerely mourned death of Mrs. William R. Travers will take from the Winter gayeties several of the most charming members of New York society. Owing to the long illness of Mrs. Travers, her home at 17 West Twenty-first Street has not been the centre of many entertainments, bat the large family connection was very much in evidence in fashionable circles.

Monmouth Park's managers are growing desperate. Their attempts to muzzle the press by ruling off their track people who have dared to tell the truth about the prostituted "sport of Kings" does not increase the attendance at the track nor make the game better for the book-makers who pay $100 a day for the privilege of laying the odds.
BOSTON, July 17. -- E.E. Rice is to have the Park Theatre here next season. The matter was settled to-day, and Manager Rice will give Bostoniaus a full dramatic year of his entertaining performances.
United States navalconstructors are watching with interest the progress of the Dubaque (Iowa) shipbuilding establishment in its initial attempt at war-ship construction.

There are many interesting things about that bit of New-York City territory described upon the political map as the Tenth Assembly District. In some respects there are no other districts like it in the city. The Democrats, of course, are so plentiful that the element of uncertainty adds no part to its interest. "Why," said a Tammany man, "the Democrats are so well intrenched in the Tenth that not even the Republicans are against them."

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Navy Department people are disappointed that the City of Brooklyn does not discharge its indebtedness to the United States Government. Some time ago it was arranged to transfer a strip of land from the Brooklyn Navy Yard to the municipality. The ground was assessed at $1,250,000, and Congress authorized the Navy Department, when this sum was turned over to the Treasury, to take $300,000 for general repairs about the yard.

SAN JOSE, Cal., July 17. -- An important discovery regarding the comet has been made at Lick Observatory. Photographic plates reveal the fact that the celestial visitant is not alone in its glory, but has a companion. The second comet is enveloped in the tail of the first, and shows distinctly as a nebulous-like condensation. Its tail also merges into that of the other.

Neither the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Tabernacle Baptist Church, nor any representative of his was present yesterday morning at the third hearing in supplementary proceedings held at the law office of Read. Hatting Wintner, Temple Court. The Rev. James W. Putnam, loader in the fight against Dr. Potter, was there, though, ready to tell more about Dr. Potter.
BUFFALO, July 17. -- Mayor Bishop has been true to his word, and if there are any more Erie Ontario Van Brocklius connected with the municipal service of Buffalo they are likely to be Found out.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The man-of-war ancherage at New-York Harbor was under discussion to-day at the Navy Department. The objections of the owners of steamboats and other eraft plying on the Hudson River have reached Secretary Herbert, and it is likely that the contentions of the steamboat men will result in a change.
The Fairchild Commission, has completed its investigation of the Appraiser's department of the New-York Custom House, and 18 now inquiring into the administration or the Surveyor's department.

-- E. Pim, the champion of Ireland, has Just defeated Mahoay for the championship of Northern England. The latter was the challenger and forced the champion to play his best to retain his title The score of the match was 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6-2. In the doubles Pim was also successful, playing with F. O. Stoker. Their opponents were W. Baddeley and H. Baddeley.

The clergymen of the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal Churches in New-York yesterday discussed with a great deal of interest the announcement that the Rev. Henry A. Adams had resigned as associate rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, at Park Avenue and Eighty-second Street, and had become converted to the Roman Catholic faith.

-- It is announced in Louisville, on the authority of Dr. Prescott B. Scott, brother of the prospective bride, that Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge will marry Mrs. Louise Scott Wing of that city shortly before the meeting of Congress in special session. Mrs. Wing is distantly related to Col. Breckinridge, and is the widow of the Hon. Rumsey Wing, who died about ten years ago while United States Minister to Ecuador.
CHICAGO, July 17. -- Russia has an agent in this city gathering information for her War Department relative to the American system of firing dynamite long distances by means of compressed air guns.

The White Star freight steamship Bovic, which yesterday arrived from Liverpool, had on board a number or valuable horses, among others the stallion Meddler. The animal was one of the large stud of thoroughbreds belonging to the late Abiugdon Baird, who died in New-Orlenus a few months ago while on a visit to this country with "Charley" Mitchell.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, July 17 -- P.M. The stock market was weak all day and closed at the lowest prices. There is undoubtedly a bettor feeling concerning the monetary situation, but, nevertheless, the bear traders sell stocks with great confidence and seem to be once more in full control of speculation.

A suit brought by M.S. Kauffman, jeweler, of 40 John Street, against Capt. William G. Winans, Secretary of the Peerless Rubber Company, at 15 Warren Street, and a member of the Old Guard, Seventh Regiment Veteran Club, Loyal Legion, and New-York Athletic Club, has brought to light an alleged attempt at blackmail.
CATSKILL, N.Y., July 17. -- Farmers living about Freehold and Cairo, Greene County, are just awaking to the fact that they nave been clearly bunkoed out of about $5,000.

The alleged poisoner, Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, as he is beat known to the police of this city, but whose true name is said to be Carl Schaeffer, stepped from the smoking car of the Saratoga and Utica Express over the New-York Central Road at 2:17 P.M. yesterday.

During last week Superintendent Brady of the Building Department received applications calling for the construction of sixty-two new buildings, involving a total estimated cost of $116,000, and also for alterations to be made to forty-one various structures at a cost of $145,000.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- The dance at the Casino to-night was not largely attended, but it was nevertheless an enjoyable affair.

Judge MOORE of the County Court of Kings County yesterday announced that be should make an order "to the effect that the Mayor or his representative shall have a copy of the [June] Grand Jury minutes, that is, simply the bald testimony and nothing else." He added: "Application has been made for nothing else."

VALETTA, Malta, July 17. --The court-martial appointed to try Captain the Hon. Maurice A. Bourke, Staff Commander Hawkins-Smith, and the surviving officers of the British battle ship Victoria, which was sunk in collision with the British battle ship Camperdown off Tripoll, Syria, on June 23, opened to-day upon the Hibernia, the flagship of Rear Admiral Richard E. Tracey, Admiral Superintendent of the Malta Dockyard.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Trunk Line Association and the Central Traffic Association has been called for next Thursday to consider Vice Chairman Donald's allegation that "return portions of World's Fair tickets issued by differntial lines at New-York, returning by various lines lines from Chicago, are purchasable to any number desired, frequently in consecutive numbers and bearing the appearance of never having been used, westwardly."
TOPEKA, Kan., July 17. -- The letter file of Chief Justice A.H. Horton has been robbed of five or six important political letters and one of a suggestive nature written by a Pennsylvania woman.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- A war of recrimination has begun between the authorities, firemen, and Cola Storage representatives as to who was responsible for the great logs or life and to whom is to be credited the glory of saving the body of Capt. Fitzpatrick from the flames.

Police Justice Ryan was not so emphatic in his comments about the Hebrews of the east side yesterday as he was Quoted to have been the day before. He modified his statements considerably, and denied several remarks that were accredited to him in the papers of Monday morning.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 17. -- Speaking of the trip he made to the jettles at South Pass in company with Congressmen Boatner and Robertson and Majors Quinn and Richardson, Major B.M. Harrod, the New-Orleans member or the Mississippi River Commission, says:

The promptness with which Secretary HERBERT began the work of repairing and fitting out for foreign service the various vessels that had been assembled in New-York waters for the international review is amply justified by existing facts.
DETROIT, Mich., July 17. -- More than 15,000 persons filled the grand stand and swarmed about the stretches and turns of the Hamtramck track to-day when the Grand Circuit trotting meeting opened.

Tsano L. Rice Issued another criticism, yesterday on the affairs of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company in connection with, the Lehigh. Valley lease and the coal purchases, to both of which. President Harris has announced his determination to adhere.

A few matches were played in the Knickerbocker Tennis Club tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Brook Avenue, between One Hundred and Fortieth and One Hundred and Forty-first Streets. All the matches for the day were for the consolation prizes, the regular events, with the exception of the men's doubles, having been completed last week.

BUFFALO, July 17. -- All the thieves who broke into the baggage oar of the New-York Liederkranz in this city last Thursday night have been caught. There were seven men concerned, all employes of the New-York Control Railroad.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, July 18 -- P.M. The stock market was demoralized today by a fear that some unknown calamity in the financial world was about to happen either in this city or London, but just where it was to be looked for was not a matter of agreement.

Leonard Boyne, the English actor and leading man in "The Prodigal Daughter," now being played at the new American Theatre, was taken seriously ill last night while dressing for the evening's performance.

-- Cleveland's offer of $2,000 to the trotter that can beat 2:08 5 4 to an old-style sulky over the Cleveland tract flaring Grand Circuit week ought to attract several entries. There are several trotters that on public form stand a chance, if prepared for a mile at their highest flight of speed. Sunol (2:08 1 4) is out of the question, as her owner never trots his horses for money.

A motion was argued before Judge Bookstavar in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday In which lawyer Henry Yonge, appearing for the plaintiff, Mrs. Sarah E. Knight, submitted affidavits tending to show that the Citizens' Mutual Life Insurance Association wrongfully witheld $5,000 due Mrs. Knight.

LONDON, July 18 -- It has been another day of depressed markets and grumbling. Prices at one time looked, as if a credit panic would result. Rumors of impending failures were current all day, but as often as a prominent house was mentioned as being in difficulties, investigation proved the report to be untrue.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Ed Corrigan's Tyro, handsomely ridden by Fred Tarsi, captured the Maiden Stakes to-day at Washington Park. The stake was worth $3,000 to the winner. In the batting Tyro was always first choice, and the Master of Hawthorne must have thought he had a cinch, for he backed him from even money to 1 to 2. Decapod and Linda were next in demand at 5 to 1 each.

Clair Harcourt, an English actress from Australia, who was arrested on a of disorderly conduct made by Manauer Paut of the Hotel Vendome Mondny night, was released by Justice Rogan of the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 18 -- To every merchant and manufacturer in the South and West the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association or Baltimore is sending a circular, headed, in big red letters, "Repeal the Sherman Silver Bill!" It says:

VALETTA, Malta, July 18 -- The court-martial which is trying Capt. the Hon. Maurlee A. Bourke and the other officers of the battle ship Victoria, which was run into and sunk by the battle ship Camperdown while manoeuvring off Tripoli, Syria, on June 23 last, resumed its sitting this morning on the Hibernia, the flagship of Rear Admiral Richard E. Tracey.
Russell Sage has been sued for $100,000 damages for seduction under promise of marriage.

Funeral services over the body of Gen. Edward Jardine were held last night at Scottish Rite Hall, at Twenty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue. The services were of a very solemn character and lasted fully two hours. Several addresses were made, and the impreesive ritual of the Scottish Rite Masons was read by the Master of the lodge, assisted by the chaplain.

There was marked pressure to cell breadstuff's and provisions generally to-day, and sharp declines in prices occurred, especially for the hog product, on account of the financial situation; and cotton and coffee were also lower, with the traders generally watching Wall Street. The decline on wheat was 7 8@1 1 8, with, on the desire to realize, a fair business coming about.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 18 -- The second day's session of the Catholic Summer School of America was marked by a decided increase in attendance as well as by an increasing enthusiasm among the students. It was a large and interested audience that assembled in the morning to hear Dr. Zahn's second lecture on "Science and Religion."

At Prospect Park yesterday the Boston cricket Club received their first reverse, the Brooklyns gaining a victory over them toy 33 runs alter an interesting game. The visitors held their opponents too cheaply and allowed them to get many runs in the first inning, thinking they could easily surpass their total.

The sales of real estate at auction announced for to-day include some north New-York property by Mr. James L. Wells, a West Fifty-ninth Street tenement by Mr. De Walltearss, a White Street building by Bleecker Son, and some desirable property at Elberon by Mr. Charles S. Brown. The details of these offerings are subjoined:

BUFFALO, July 18 -- The recently "Sheehanized" Board of Excise Commissioners came off its high horse to-day and decided to grant a license to John Mason, a Republican saloon keeper in the First Ward. A representative of the board called Mr. Mason over the telephone and politely told him that his license was waiting for him.

The action of the Brooklyn Aldermen, in rushing through the new trolley franchises in direct opposition to the wishes of residents along some of the proposed routes, has aroused indignation in many quarters, and to-morrow morning the Aldermen will have an opportunity to hear what citizens think of their prodigality.
Many commercial bodies throughout the country have informed the Chamber of Commerce that they have taken action in favor of repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman silver act.

BOSTON, July 18 -- After her very successful trials of Saturday and Sunday the syndicate cup defender Pilgrim is taking a few days' rest in Marblehead Harbor. She may go out again to-morrow, but it is doubtful if another trip is made until Saturday. Then, however, almost daily trips may be expected until she starts for New-York the last of next week to be docked in preparation for the big cruise of the year.

A boxing entertainment was given last night at the Windsor Theatre under the-direction of "Billy" Madden. There was a bigger crowd outside the doors than inside. When the first boat was called about 800 persons wore scattered around in the big theatre.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 18 -- "Chlia" Schamber, residing in East Buffalo, left borne on March 1, "never to return," he said. He and his wife had a disagreement about attentions Mrs, Schamber said he was paying to a girl named Carrie Imm.
The announcement that a new play, to be entitled "Darkest Russia," is to be produced in this country has aroused a great deal of adverse comment among a number of Russian subjects in this city.
PARIS, July 18 -- In accordance with his announced intention, M. Dreyfus to-day questioned the Government in the Chamber of Deputies as to the French operations in Siam.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 18 -- The thermometer in the hospital tent at the State Camp registered 92 at noon to-day. On the parade grounds the heat was much more intense, and the men had their powers of endurance thoroughly taxed before the forenoon drill was over. Private Doyle of Company H, Seventy-fourth Regiment, was overcome during the drill and was carried to the hospital.

ROME, July 18 -- A tornado swept down suddenly to-day on Voghera and Casteggio in Piedmont Hundreds of buildings were wrecked. In one section or Voghera hardly a house was left standing. Hot a structure in either town was left intact.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 18 -- Charlie, the twelve-year-old son of William Langford, the railroad contractor, disappeared about a year ago. Last evening his body was discovered under most remarkable circumstances. Near his father's house is a deep cut made in a street opening, and in the wall thus made the children had been digging caves in the sand.
"The death of the chief is likely to have interacting consequences," said Miss Emma'C. Sickels when a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter showed her the above dispatch.

Those public officers of Brooklyn whose harmonious action was necessary to the handing over to Mayor Boody of the minutes of the June Grand Jury, which Judge Moore of the Court of Sessions has told him he can have, and which he says he will give to the public, yesterday played a little game of "now-you-see-me-and-now-you don't" that resulted in delay.

The two factions in the New-York Peace Society are throwing out pickets. The prospects of an early bivouac have been dispelled by the interviews published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES with President Love of the Universal Peace Union at Philadelphia, and, with William O. McDowell of Newark.

-- A party of wheelmen from Eastern, Penn., passed through this city Sunday on their return from an interesting bicycle trip. They were J. Wallace Ingham, Quintus F. Ehler, and Samuel Ackroyd, all members of the Easton Wheelmen. Leaving Easton on June 30, they wheeled leisurely to High Bridge, thence to bound Brook and along the famous Union County roads, through Plainfield, to New-York.

A circular was issued to Georgia Central security holders yesterday announcing that the committee which, at the request of the Directors of the Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia, as well as many of its security holders and creditors, undertook to prepare a plan of reorganization of the Georgia Central system, has reluctantly come to the conclusion that a reorganization upon the lines submitted had become impracticable.

Jacob Wertheim, a cigar manufacturer of this city, appeared before the Fairchild commission yesterday at the Barge Office and said the Government was annually losing from $3,000,000 to $1,000,000 through undervaluations in imports of tobacco to be used as wrappers for cigars.

The troubles of the Rev. Dr. D.C. Potter of the Baptist Tabernacle grow as time goes on. Yesterday he was examined in supplementary proceedings by a clerk in the employ of Henry D. Hotchkiss on a judgment obtained by Austin, Nichols Co., wholesale grocers, in Hudson Street. The sum at issue was $862.58. The examination disclosed nothing of importance that has not already been published.

ALBANY, July 18 -- Civil service laws and roles as they are enacted and obeyed and practiced were discussed in a spirited manner at a conference this afternoon between the State Civil Service Commission and certain gentlemen representing the state Civil Service Reform League investigating Committee and the Committee on Examinations of the Civil Service Reform Association.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 18 -- The situation in the Crawford County coal region is becoming critical. The mine owners hare called upon the Sheriff tot protection, and he has placed armed men on guard at some of the mines and stockades.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 18 -- The Rev. William E. Bartlott, one of the ablest men in this diocese, has gone to Rome, where he was educated. It is said that he bears important documents from Cardinal Gibbons to Popo Leo, most of them concerning the case of the Rev. Dr. Bartsell of New-York.

Since the death of Mrs. LAMB the Magazine of American History, of which for many years she was the devoted editor, has for a second time passed into new hands. In the belated double number for May and June the present owners, announce their intention to extend its usefulness into new and imperfectly-studied historical fields.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The dispatch reporting the arrival of a ship at Valparaiso with a cargo of 60,000 sealskins taken at an unknown point in the Antarctic Ocean was shown Prof. G. Brawn Goode, the well-known author and expert at the Smithsonian Institution, witn an inquiry for his views on the subject. He replied:

DETROIT, Mich., July 18 -- The race for the eight-thousand-dollar Merchants and Manufacturers Purse, which was the feature of to-day's programme at the Grand Circuit trotting meeting, did not prove the great contest that horsemen generally expected to witness when Siva, Fides, Stanton, and Silver Star came together. Although twelve horses went to the post, public form indicated that not more than three or four of the lot had a chance to win.

Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer, alias Carl Schaeffer, was arraigned before Judge Cowing, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning to answer to an indictment charging him with having caused the death of Gustave A.J. Baum by poison in March, 1892. His counsel, Joseph H. Moss of the firm of Howe Hummel, obtained an adjournment in the preliminary proceedings until to-morrow morning.

Things went the bears' way in Wall Street yesterday. Reports of trouble in London, where great weakness prevailed, the news of the suspension of more Western banks, and a fresh crop of rumors designed to help a decline, all figured in bringing about a greater and more general "slump" than the Street had seen in some time.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 18 -- Indignation, is intense in Fresh Pond, a little hamlet eight miles from here, over the apparently brutal treatment accorded little children by Farmer Eleazer Z.P. Dayton Sunday and which caused his arrest yesterday, as told in to-day's NEW-YORK TIMES.

MRS. O.L. JONES AT COLD SPRING HARBOR. -- Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., is more of a gay spot this season than last. Fine turnouts go flying over the adjacent roads during the day. and something is always going on in the evening at one or more of the beautiful places there. A dance was given a few evenings ago by Mrs. Oliver Livingston Jones at Jones Manor.

Lloyd Aspinwall, well known as a clubman and man-about-town, slept last night in Cell No. 9, second tier, Yorkville prison. The charge against him was forgery, and the complainant was Lawyer John Delahunty.

Frank J. Egan, twenty-three years old, the longshoreman who, as told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, killed John J. McDonald, twenty-four years old, of 843 Tenth Avenue, in a prize fight Monday evening at Kilpatrickl Roylance's lumber yard, at Eleventh Avenue and Fifty-eight Street, was arraigned yesterday morning in the Yorkville Police Court on a charge of homicide.

J. Sterling Morton, Secretary of Agriculture, was at the Holland House yesterday. He left Washington Monday night for a vacation of two or three weeks, moat of which time he will spend in Michigan. He will return to Washington shortly before the beginning of the extra session of Congress.

The Crescent Athletic Club continued its handicap tennis tournament on the club grounds at Bay Ridge yesterday. The second-class doubles was the only event of the day. The teams were divided into three classes, A, B, and C, and handicapped as follows: Those in A gave those in B half fifteen and owed half fifteen, and to those in C fifteen and owed fifteen.

In the controversy over the action of the Kings County Grand Jury in its relation to the proceedings of the Mayor and Aldermen of Brooklyn in granting certain street railway franchises there has been a tendency to overlook the merits of the original question as to the terms upon which the franchises were granted and the method of boatowing them.
Hot Weather and other Irritating circumstances made some of the city officials very entertaining at meetings held in the Mayor's office yesterday.

The front of the German Liederkranz Club-house in East Fifty-eight Street was ablaze with light last evening. The word "Willkom-men" was traced out in letters of electric lights over the door, and above this there was a large lyre in rod, white, and blue eleectric lights. The occasion was a reception by the club to those of its members who returned last Sunday from a concert tour in the West.

BOSTON, July 18 -- At a special meeting of the stockholders of the Old Colony Railroad Company to-day it was unanimously voted to raise the grade and location of the Providence Division in Boston, increase terminals, acquire the stock of the Old Colony Steamboat Company, and to accept other minor provisions of the recent acts of the Legislature.
As over, the Monmouth monster opened its jaws yesterday in a yawn of hunger, but without impatience, for it'knew that it would be fed.

DENVER, Cal., July 18 -- Three national banks -- the Union National, the Commercial National, and the National Bank of Comme -- closed their doors this morning, owing to heavy demands of excited depositors. The Mercantile Bank, a small private institution doing business in the Mining Exchange Building, also suspended, owing to the close of the Union Bank, through which its clearances were made.

Ellphalet Stratton, the octogonarian wife starver or 124 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, was tried yesterday before Justice Haggerty, in the Myrtle Avenue Police Court. Mrs. Stratton, the complainant, was scarcely able to be present at the bearing, as aha is still extremely weak from her enforced fast.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 18 -- The City Court room was filled to night with citizens anxious to listen to the evidence in the case of the city against William Bennet, charged with violating an ordinance passed June 1 imposing a fine of $5 and costs upon every bicycler riding a wheel at night without a lantern properly lighted. Bennet's case was a peculiar one, which admitted of much discretion.

If the bookmakers who sweltered and attempted to look brave in the betting ring at the Brighton Beach race track expected to be amply repaid by gathering in the public's money yesterday, they were mistaken. In the opening race the heavily-backed favorite, Dickerson, at the prohibitive price of 1 to 3, was bowled over, and the "bookies" thought that they had started in on a good day for outsiders.

YONKERS, July 18 -- There is considerable dissatisfaction because the trailer line which connects this city and Mount Vernon only stops at such points as suit the convenience of the company, thus forcing passengers to walk lone distances. The company has no right under its franchise to charge more than 5 cents within the city limits.

ALBANY, July 18 -- Another machine man was advanced to-day. Thomas A. Stuart, for the past ten years a clerk in the Adjutant General's office at a salary of $1,500, was appointed Assistant Secretary of the State Board or Health, at a salary of $2,500.

An uneventful meeting of the General Passenger Agents of the Eastern trunk lines was held in this city yesterday. The alleged wholesale marketing, in Chicago, of return portions of World's Fair excursion tickets was incidentally discussed. No action was taken, however, as that subject will be specially considered by the joint committee of the Trunk Line and Central Traffic Associations to-morrow.

All arrangements have been made for the Middle States regatta to be field on the Passaic River on Saturday next, and from the present outlook it will eclipse anything of the kind ever seen in this vicinity. The entry list is a large one and includes all the prominent scullers, members of clubs in the association.

MOBILE, Ala., July 18 -- The Register Company, publishers of the dally and weekly Register, one of the oldest papers in the South, made an assignment to-night to James McPhillips. The company has been for years heavily loaded with, an indebtedness growing out or a lawsuit for possession of the paper a number of years ago.

-- Col. James P. Simmons of Lawrenceville Ga., died on Friday last. He was the only member of the Georgia secession convention of 1861 who refused to sign the ordinance of secession. He was a Union Democrat before the war, a great admirer of Stephen A. Donglas, and did active work on the stump as an Elector on that ticket in 1860.

ROSE COGHLAN IN A NEW ROLE -- Charles Froh. man, who owns the American rights of Oscar Wilde's new satirical play of A Woman of No importance," yesterday contracted with Rose Coghlan that she shall control and play too piece with herself and her brother, Charles Coghlan. Since Mr. Frohman returned to America from London he has been anxious to arrange for both Mr. and Miss Coghlan to appear in his production of the play.

The banquet room of the Union League Club, the scene of gatherings made famous in politics, held last night a company great in finance and what had been intended as an informal social meeting to introduce to New-York bankers James H. Eckels, the Controller of the Currency, and Charles M. Preston, the State Bank Examiner, assumed a dignity and importance befitting the financial situation.
NEW-PALTZ, N.Y., July 18 -- A movement has been started by Edmund Elting of this place to have a monument erected to the twelve Hugue-not refugees who settled in New-Paltz in 1667.

LENOX, Mass., July 18 -- Col. Richard Tylden Auchmuty of New-York and Lenox died at his Summer home in Lenox a little before 5 o'clock this morning at the age of sixty-two. The immediate cause of his death was codema, or dropsy of the lungs. He had some trouble with his heart, which had not been in a healthy condition for some time.

The Western and Southern roads seem to have followed the example of the Eastern trunk lines in reducing the rates to and from Chicago. On some lines they have gone beyond the example, although the redaction to excursionists from New-Orleans is just about equal to that made from New-York.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- Meagre details of the alleged disabling of the United States man-of-war Mohican by the seal-poaching steamer Alexandria have been received.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- President Higinbotham has issued an order to Director of Works Burnham to close James J. Corbett's athletic exhibition on the Midway Plaisance. The order was served on the people who are running the show, but so far they have ignored it. Mr. Burnham says steps will be taken to stop the performance as soon as President Higinbotham returns.

A negro named ISAAC JENKINS, at present residing near Boamton Station, Va., has just added another to the various arguments against the practice of lynching. It appears that a white farmer named CARTWRIGHT has incurred the enmity of some one of his neighbors. Twelve of his horses have been poisoned and his barn has been burned to the ground.

BOSTON, July 18. -- The second day's play in the Longwood tennis tournament developed nothing of special interest. Clarence Hobart decided not to play and defaulted his match, greatly to the disapappointment of the Longwood people. A. E. Foote and J. T. Talmage, Jr., both of Yale, had along match which the former won, Talmage being handicapped by an injured hand.

A more or less merry war is threatened at the foot of West Seventy-ninth Street between property owners. It is at this place where is situated the only wharf on the river for the neighborhood. To find another loading or unloading place one must travel a mile to the north or south. As a result, the foot of West Seventy-ninth Street is a great place for trucks, carts,

Frank S. Beedleson, the one legged bicycle rider of Syracuse, who started from the City Hall, San Francisco, Cal., on May 15, to ride to New-York, is expected to reach the City Hall in this city this evening. He reached Ponghkeepsie last night.

More delay has occurred in the publication of the testimony on which the June Grand Jury of Kings County censured Mayor Boody and the Aldermen concerned in the awarding of the electric street railroad franchises. With its censure the jury regretted its inability to indict Mr. Boody and the Aldermen, because of the interpretation of the law given it by District Attorney Ridgway.
-- The sterling exchange market gave Wall Street a surprise yesterday by suddenly developing a weakness which makes gold-import talk fashionable again.

Patrick T. Breslin, who says that he is merely an employe of his wife at $15 a week in carting and selling ice for her, and that he pays her back $13 a week for board and lodging, was again on the stand yesterday to tell why he could not satisfy a judgment of $100.

James Deever, twenty years old, is in danger of being returned to the Elmira Reformatory, from which institution he was released on parole on Feb. 27. His offense this time is the accidental breaking of a window with, a baseball bat.

The Knickerbocker Club open tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Brook Avenue, between One Hundred and Fortieth and One Hundred and Forty-first Streets. The matches were confined entirely to the consolation events, the men's singles, and men's doubles.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Wheat went to smash worse than ever to-day. There was a break of over 2c a bushel in the December option. During the last hour a general panic seemed to take possession of the owners of grain, especially of wheat, and there was a mad rush to sell which sent September to 65 1/8c and December to 72c, breaking the low price record anew for September.

Rear Admiral Melancton Smith, United States Navy, died yesterday at Green Bay, Wis. He was the son of a veteran of the war of 1812 of the same name and a grandson of Melancton Smith, a Continental Congressman. He was born in this city May 24, 1810.

-- General Superintendent Peck of the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railroad has issued a circular to all conductors, directing them to allow all passengers traveling on World's Fair excursion tickets the privileges of the chair cars and Pullman cars if they so desire, notwithstanding the reading of the face of the tickets, which strictly prohibits the granting of these privileges.
Mrs. Mabel O. Clark bad the unusual experience yesterday of being served with a NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford time table as a summons in divorce proceedings.

More than seventy citizens of SpoKane, Washington, have signed resolutions in favor of a repeal of the Shermau law. Among them are the Mayor of the city, the President of the Chamber of Commerce, the Presidents of several banks and fruit companies, wholesale merchants, mine owners, and manufacturers.

Capt. Thomas Miller of 346 Broadway Was in business in Siam for many years with the late C.G. Allen of Andover, Mass. Together they owned the steamer Jack Waters, which, with a large fleet of barges, plied between. Bangkok and the outer bar at the mouth of the Menam River. The Jack Waters was named after a famous American trotting horse, and she was the pride of the whole river fleet.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The forty fine arts jurors perfected their organization to-day by electing as President W.H.B. Davis of Great Britain First Vice President Signer del Nero of Italy. Second Vice President Signor del Campio of Spain. Secretary Mr. Dlelman of the United States.

BOSTON, Mass., July 19. -- Four players still remain unbeaten in the Longwood tennis tournament to contest the semi-final round. These men are Arthur E. Foots, the Yale champion; Malcolm Chace, the Providence expert and winner of many trophies;

The annual moot of the western Canoe Association began last Saturday at Ballast Island, Lake Erie, and will last two weeks. The Island, which is n Put-in-Bay, near Sandusky, Ohio, is the real home of the association, and all its meetings have been held there since its organization, seven years ago, with but one exception.

Ex-Senator John B. Henderson of Missouri sailed last week for Europe, where he will meet his family and enjoy with them a short vacation. A good many things have happened in the silver agitation since ex-Senator Henderson wrote his now famous letter to Secretary Carlisle at the beginning of the present month.

Two games were played on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-Yorks and the Bostons, and the honors were evenly divided. They were not what could be termed games of the Garrison finish. On the contrary, they were one-sided and rather devoid of interest.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 19. -- C.V. Boughton last night made the first public test of his telephotos. an instrument for communicating over long distances both on land and at sea. The machine is made up of fifty-six thirty-two-candle power electric lights placed horizontally in an iron box, with the bulb facing toward the point designated to be signaled.

WOODS HOLL, Mass., July 19. -- The Eastern Yacht Club, with headquarters at Marblehead. Mass., is in negotiation with parties in Woods Holl, Vineyard Sound, looking to the purchase of beach property on Long Neck, in Great Harbor, for rendezvous purposes.
At that hour of the afternoon when Broadway was at its busiest and when the sun shone hottest Gen. Lew Wallace walked from Grace Church to the St. Denis Hotel yesterday and approached the newsstand.

Controller Eckels availed himself yesterday of the acquaintance he bad made among banking men at the dinner at the Union League Club Tuesday night, and made calls on his entertainers at their place of business. President A.B Hepburn of the Third Notional Bank acted as his escort.

DENVER, Col., July 19. -- The timorous feeling among depositors in the Denver banks, which has resulted in the closing of a number of these institutions this week, seems at last to have reached its limit. This afternoon more money was deposited than was withdrawn.

The Belmont Cricket Club tennis tournament has teen finished through the final rounds. The women's singles and women's doubles were the last events played. The singles went to Mrs. Toulmin after a close match with Miss Kimball, the latter taking the opening set, 7-5. The doubles went to Miss Haunts and Miss Colahan, who won from Mrs. Toulmin and Miss Kimball in a well-played three-set match, 2-6, 6-3, 7-6.

NEW-LONDON, July 19. -- Last Saturday a fleet of more than thirty yachts of the Atlantic Yacht Club started out of Cold Spring Harbor to cruise to the eastward. It was expected that the cruise would last until to-morrow and then the fleet would disband. Through the inefficiency of some of the chief officers of the club the cruise practically came to an end last night at Shelter Island.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 19. -- E.L. Gunn, the missing loan agent from Lima, Ohio, is Ohio's representative of the Connecticut School Fund, and the office here has been notified of the man's intended visit. Carnot O. Spencer, chief clerk of the office, has been sent post haste to Ohio. His sudden and unexpected departure indicates trouble of a serious character.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 19. -- E.C. Benedict's a steam yacht Oneids, having on board President Cleveland. Dr. Bryant, and the owner, dropped anchor off Monument Neck late this afternoon. A few moments later the little launch was lowered, and the party was soon landed at the Gray Gables wharf.
The Boston Cricket Club tackled the Staten Island Cricket Club at Livingston yesterday for the third game of their New-York tour and again Buffered defeat, the islanders winning by 57 runs.

PATERSON, N.J., July 19. -- The Passaic County courtroom at Paterson, Judges Hopper and Van Hovenberg presiding, was crowded this morning when the officials charged with fraud in connection with the purchase of the new County Court House site were arraigned.

Prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday bobbed up and down with so much independence of any causes known to either buyers or sellers that at certain moments the rise and fall occurred together, and men within a few feet of each other were giving and taking different prices for the same stocks.

VALETTA, Malts, July 19. -- The court-martial which is trying certain of the officers of the war ship Victoria for losing their vessel oil Tripoli, Syria, resumed its sitting this morning, this being the third day of the trial. The first witness called to-day was Rear Admiral Markham, whose flag was flying on the Camperd own at the time she ran into and sank the Victoria.

TRENTON, N. J., July 19. -- Attorney General Stockton has made a special report to Gov. Werts in reference to the litigation against those railroads that entered into a combination to control the price of coal. The Attorney General elves a recital of the formation of the coal combine and the steps taken by the State to compel the companies to cancel their contracts.

Wall Street was treated to another exciting time yesterday, with conditions considerably changed from those of the day before, when the bears succeeded in generally smashing prices. They were busy again, but they failed to equal their record of Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Ga., July 19. -- There is great excitement here over a threatened outbreak and possible riot which is expected to take place to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Half a million dollars' worth of contracts for steel forgings a were given out at the Navy Department to-day. These contracts will furnish the material for the gnus for the latest battle ship, the cruiser Brooklyn, the three gunboats, and the Essex. The Midvale Steal Company and the Bathlehem Iron Company get the contracts, each firm receiving nearly an equal share in the amount to be expended for this material.
The work of completing the three dynamite guns intended for the defense of New-York Harbor is being rapidly pushed. The guns are being made at the West Point Foundry, Cold Spring, N.Y.

Although a young organization, the Middle States Regatta Association has from the outset secured the hearty co-operation of all the prominent rowing clubs. Its regatta in 1890 was an unqualified success, which attracted entries of such quantity and quality that the Middle States regatta took its place at once as far and away the most important and popular rowing fixture of the season.

Mrs. Marie L. Moore, wife of Dr. Gideon E. Moore, a consulting physician and chemist of 221 Pearl Street, was confined to her home at 132 Madison Avenue yesterday, and was unable to appear in the Yorkville Police Court to answer the charge of disorderly conduct made by John Hodgkins, conductor on a Madison Avenue car.

The cornerstone of the new Fourth Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, at the corner of Fourth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, was laid at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Bishop E.G. Andrews of New-York.
DENVER, July 19. -- Senator Teller, discussing the financial situation in this city to-day, said:

LONDON, July 19. -- Closely following upon the shafting up received by the Prince of Wales in St. James's Street a couple or days ago by the collision, of his hansom with, another, comes a somewhat similar accident to Prime Minister Gladstone. The latter was proceeding to the House of Commons this afternoon when his brougham came in collision with a van in Parliament Square.

Reports regarding the suspension, or assignment of savings banks in some of the Western States indicate that they are accustomed to methods of employing their deposits which are not regarded as legitimate or safe in this part of the country. Some of them seem to be closely associated with banks of discount and to have their funds largely involved in the business of those institutions.

A strong presumption is raised in favor of a newly-discovered process for purifying water by the approval accorded to it by Dr. EDSON of the Health Board after careful examination. The process is a simple one of mingling with the impure water a small proportion of salt water, treated with, electricity.

The following letter from Elia Rodde, an east side resident, to President Cleveland explains itself. It was referred by the President to Secretary Carlisle, who sent it to Dr. Senner, the Commissioner of Immigration. The letter is a typewritten communication and reads as follows:

Five days have elapsed since the babe of Mrs. Lizzie Noonan of 236 East Thirty-sixth Street disappeared at its birth, but the mystery about the case has not yet been solved. Mrs. Noonan is in a serious condition, no trace of her child has been found, and detectives are still looking for the women who were with her when the child was born.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- The remains of Anthony J. Drexel were consigned to the tomb this morning with services as unostentatious as was the life of the great banker and philanthropist. Only the simple burial ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church was read in the presence of several hundred relatives and friends of the deceased.
BUFFALO, July 19. -- Hosts of irate subscribers would like to lay hands on Sidney G. Sherwood and Russell Osgoodby, who until recently published a Sunday journal here.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Mayor Boody has surprised the Navy Department people by implying an indifference on the part of the City of Brooklyn to acquiring the strip of territory now belonging to the navy yard which has long been the subject of negotiation between the Government and the city authorities.

Miss E. McGarrah is a friend of cats. She owns many cats and she loves them as she would love her children, if she had any. She thinks cats have a right to roam at night. She even believes cats have a perfect right to sing at night.

Charles M. Preston, State Bank Examiner, was in this city yesterday. He spent most of the day in Wall Street, calling on a number of the bankers, with whom he dismissed informally the condition of the banks in this city and State.

Sergt. McCarty of the Second Precinct, Brooklyn, reported yesterday to Superintendent Campbell that he had investigated the record of John Du Bois, who was arrested two weeks ago for attempting to blackmail Mrs. Mary Voss of 74 Fulton Street, and that he had discovered that Du Bois was a very clever rascal.

PITTSBURG, Kan., July 19. -- W. J. Lanyen's strip pits were visited last evening by about 100 miners, who called the workmen out and talked with them in regard to stopping work. The men would not promise to quit, and another meeting was decided upon.

A new game has been introduced at Monmouth Park for improving the breed of horses. Among the bookmakers there are distributed daily a number of free admissions to the track. Some of the small fry among these gentry distribute these tickets among a lot of falrly-well-dressed and prosperous-appearing "touts," who, in return for the free admission, act as "pullers-in " for the bookmakers.
Postmaster Dayton is much annoyed over the way his efforts to provide an efficient service in this city are hampered by the authorities at Washington.

Twenty-one push-cart men were arraignea before Justice Voorhis in Essex Market Police Court yesterday. He fined thirteen of them $2 each and eight $1 each. The fine of $2 was imposed upon the prisoners who did not have licenses.
