BAYONNE, N.J., July 19. -- An investigation of the furnishing of the new City Hall at Bayonne last year has been made by a special committee of the new Council, consisting of Messrs. Allan Benny, George Russell, and George F. Schmidt. When an interesting report was made last evening a stormy scene followed.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 19. -- The Hon. J.C. Patterson, Minister of Militia, informs THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S correspondent that he has received a cablegram from the Hon. Mr. Herbert, Major General commanding the militia in Canada, who is now in London, England, stating that his business there with the Admiralty and Treasury Departments had been successfully completed.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The next important test at Indian Head will be an attack upon a thirteen-inch armor plate, representing the side armor of the Maine. This is the heaviest armor which has been Harveyized, and there is considerable curiosity to see whether this thirteen-inch plate, treated by the Harvey process, will surpass the seventeen-inch plate not so treated which was recently attacked.

WHITESTONE, L.I., July 19. -- The recent meetings of the Whitestone Village Trustees have been uproarious events. A committee of New-York business men residing in the village, representing $150,000,000 in wealth, have asked Judge Winfield S. Overton to do something toward putting a stop to what they regard as unseemly conduct on the part of some of the Trustees.

Russell Sage yesterday refused to say a word touching the suit for $100,000 brought against him by Delia Keegan, through her counsel, John Baptist Marshall of 6 Wall Street. Henry B. Bennett of 45 Broadway, Mr. Sage's lawyer, said he would not dignify the case by talking about it, since the charges would seem incredible to any fair-minded person.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- An important change has been made by the Treasury Department in the classification of wool that will lower the duty on some grades of the article nearly 100 per cent. The change follows conclusive evidence offered by wool importers that certain grades of high-class wool were practically analogous to grades classified lower in the wool schedule of the McKinley bill.

PARIS, July 19. -- The statement published in the Seir yesterday relative to the sending of an ultimatum to the Siamese Government is confirmed by a semi-official announcement made this afternoon. The ultimatum has been sent, but, instead of only twenty-four hours being allowed for an answer, as stated by the coir, Siam will be given forty-eight hours in which to accept or reject the demands made upon her by France.

DETROIT, Mich., July 19. -- Harness racing by piecemeal was the order of the day at the Detroit Grand Circuit trotting meeting this afternoon. A postponed race, held over from yesterday, was finished, together with one event on the regular programme, but when darkness came to-night the trotting free-for-all and the 2:15 class pace remained undecided.

LONDOS, July 19. -- There was much hesitancy at the opening of the Stock Exchange, and in the American market prices began below parities, Louisville being down as low as 50 and St. Paul to 54 1/2. But shortly afterward Raphael began buying, and the Rothschilds' brokers followed with large buying orders, while it was found that Morgan had been absorbing stocks yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 19. -- The Orioles made it three straight by defeating the Brooklyns to-day. Brilliant fielding by both teams made the game more interesting than the score would indicate. But six Brooklynites reached the half-way house during the contest. Hawke was very effective, only Fontz, Corcoran, and Crane securing hits. Crane was an easy mart for the Oriole batsmen.

BUFFALO, July 19. -- It was impossible last night to obtain any save the moat meagre details of the wreck of the excursion train carrying the Sunday schools of the Bethany and Bethlehem Churches of this city. To-day the list of seriously injured is found to be as follows:

ALBANY, N.Y., July 19. -- Jacob A. Kapps, a young lawyer, who paid more attention to Republican politics than to his business, was arrested to-day for fraud in making out checks on the South End Bank, in which he has had a balance of but 79 cents for a long time. His arrest brought about a strange state of affairs.

NEW-YORK. WEDNESDAY, July 19 -- P.M.} The failure of the direful predictions of yesterday to materialize induced a much better feeling on all the financial Exchanges of the world. London was the first to recover from the alarm, and higher prices from that centre were reflected in a strong opening on this market.
Thomas Dunniworth, aged forty years, of 124 Tillary Street. Brooklyn, was Killed yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock by a runaway horse which he tried to stop.

The mall vote of the League of American Wheelmen's Racing Board on the Johnson and Tuttle cases has been completed and received by Chairman Raymond. Mr. F.H. Tuttle received the tall vote for reinstatement, which was more or less expected, as the case against him was not very strong.

Dr. Henry C.N. Meyer, alias Cart Schaeffer, who is in the Tombs under indictment charging him with having caused the death of Gustave A. J. Baum, worries much about his wife and children, especially about his fifteen-month-old son. The boy, he says, has stomach trouble and has to be carefully nursed.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 19. -- The police to-night raided a big faro outfit at 1,005 Arctic Avenue, but though things were carefully planned they captured nothing but the playing layout.

DUNKIRK, July 19. -- An attempt was made here last night to lynch C.T. Chase, the man who was arrested charged with assaulting Annie Lawrence, a twelve-year-old girl. Chase was arrested yesterday and taken to the lock-up. In default of $500 bail he was held for the Grand Jury.

The Knickerbocker sield Club tennis tournament was finished yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Eighteenth Street and Avenue A, Flatbush. The mixed doubles was the last event of the tournament. On Saturday afternoon the final round was left undecided, H.Wall and Miss G. Ahlers (scratch) and C. Bollinger and Miss A. Wostfoll (scratch) both having two sets to their credit when darkness stopped the play.

We wish the needs and the magnitude of the postal business in the City of New-York could be a little better understood and appreciated at Washington. Year after year the press and people of New-York have lifted up this prayer, sometimes in a spirit of irritation, sometimes in weariness and almost in despair.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. July 19. -- People here were treated to a rather surprising announcement to-day in the statement that the Cleveland City Hallway Company would abandon cable power on its Payne Avenne line, about three and onefourth miles in length, and equip it with the trolley this Fall. This company is a consolidation of the Cleveland Cable Railway Company and the Woodland Avenne and West Side Street Railroad Company.

ELIZABETH, July 19. -- To Capt. George B. Forbes, commander of the Atlanta Artillery, who is visiting relatives and friends in New-York and this city, was tendered a reception at the Veteran Zouaves' Armory last night by Gen. Drake and his men.
WHITESTONE, L.I., July 19. -- The latest elopement in Whitestone is that of Miss Lillie June, an attractive girl of seventeen, and Master Walter E. Rose, who is not yet nineteen.

To the Editor of the New-York Times : A sub-editorial in to-day's issue does me an injustice, which I trust you will correct in accordance with your customary fairness. In effect the article says that the views which, as a member of the Municipal Commission. I now favor are entirely right; but that I have been rather late in acquiring them.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 19. -- The annual rifle competition for the Department of the East will commence on Tuesday, Aug. 22, over the range at Fort Niagara, and will continue-about two weeks. The competitors will be the best shots belonging to the regular army east of the Mississippi River, under the direction of Capt. H.P. Kingsbury. Sixth Cavalry, Inspector of Small-Arms Practice, and his assistants.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 20. -- The owner of the building occupied by the Crescent City Athletic Club as a clubhouse yesterday sued the organization for $1,000, the balance due for rent under the lease, which became due when the club missed the payment of its last month's rent. The suit also asks for a provisional seizure of the furniture, which all seems to indicate that the club is in a bad way financially.

The Ladies' Health Protective Association, of which Helen S. Bell is President, Ionia Bird Secretary, and Cecelia E. Fendler Chairman, has just issued a statement urging the necessity of baling stable refuse to check the mortality in the vicinity of stables and to preserve the health of the public.

The folly that was immortalized in the fable concerning the short-sighted person who killed the goose that laid the golden egg is by no means extinct, and a fresh and malignant outbreak of it is threatened just now on the sometime storm-swept and constantly mosquitoguarded shore of Barnegat Bay. As everybody of angling proclivities knows.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 20. -- A great deal of interest is being taken here in the acuiling race between Hanlan and Gaudaur, to be rowed at Lake Cauchiching Orillia Saturday. Gaudaur is regarded as the most likely of the two scullers, and the betting is 30 to 50 in his favor. Gaudaur weighs 176, and is down to his training weight. He is in perfect condition. Hanlan weighs 156.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Sweden had her day at the World's Columbian Exposition to-day. Among the well-known Swedish organizations in the procession were the Executive Committee of Swedish Singers, the American Union of Swedish Singers, the John Eflesson Legion Select Knights of America, the editorial staffs of prominent Swedish journals, the Swedish gymnastic and fencing club, and various Swedish organizations of the Knights of Pythias.
In the Building Department yeaterday plans for the following new buildings and alterations ware filed:

The cartmen employed in the Street-Cleaning Department, who struck last week and went back to work when Commissioner Brennan conceded most of their demands, had a now grievance yesterday. When many or the drivers got their pay envelopes on Wednesday they found them all the way from $2 to $4 short. They were told that they had been dismissed as regular men drawing regular salaries, and had been put on as extra men.
LONDON, July 20. -- A dispatch from Rome to the Central News says:

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Frank Van Ness's colt Morello, notwithstanding the hard fall he got in the Columbus Handicap Saturday last, started in the Dearborn Handicap to-day at Washington Park, and he made his field look like a lot of cheap selling platers, winning in a gallop by four lengths from Plutus.

from the Literary Digest, July 16. Last week we gave a tabulated statement of a part of the replies received to the following three questions sent out on return postal cards to the editors of different journals (mostly dallies in places of 10,000 and upward) throughout the country:
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 @6 p cent, but the bulk of business was done at 5@6 p cent. The last loan was made at 2 p cent.

From the Trenton True American. It has been a matter of general remark that the attendance at Monmouth Park this season has been unusually small, so much so as to make it unprofitable for the railroads running there as well as for the race course. Another fact that has been remarked is the absence of the better classes of the community who have in the earlier years of its history patronized it.

From the Brooklyn Eagle. Postmaster Dayton of New-York City is making a commendable effort to increase the efficiency of the office over which he presides. Mr. Dayton has shown in his brief career as Postmaster an amount of adaptability and enterprise highly creditable to himself and to the Administration responsible for his appointment.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20. -- The last will and testament of Anthony J. Droxel was admitted to probate to-day. The executors, who are also the trustees, are George W. Childs, John Lowber Welsh, Richard C. Dale; his sons, John B. Drexel, Anthony J. Drexel, and George W. Childs Drexel, and his sons-in-law, James W. Paul, Jr., and John R. Fell.

GRAND JUNCTION, Col., July 20. -- The First National Bank failed to open its doors this morning, a notice posted on the doors stating the liabilities to be $50,000; assets, $108,000. The depositors were informed that no one would lose a penny and that the bank would reopen as soon as it could realize upon its securities.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The Congress on Social Settlements listened to-day to papers by Everett P. Wheeler of New-York on "The Settlement in Its Relation to Organized Social Work," by President Tucker of Dartmonth College on "The Settlement in Its Relation to Organized Religious Work," and by Mrs. S. A. Thompson on Continuity in Settlement Work."

MONTREAL, July 20. -- Viceroyalty travels in style in Canada. The apartments aboard the Sardinian in which the Earl of Derby, his Countess, and their daughter. Lady Isabella, will make the voyage from Montreal to what Canadians still call "the old country" were magnificently decorated. Ordinary passengers have the luxury of being seasick in a small cabin but their Excellencies have each a cabin twice the ordinary size.

At last the testimony on which the June Grand Jury of Kings County censured and wanted to indict Mayor Boody and the Aldermen concerned in the granting of the electric street railroad franchises is out. Now that it is open to everybody's inspection, the ring politicians and their friends realize that a mistake has been made.

BOSTON, July 20. -- After whipping our champions, three out of four in New-York, the Giants came here to-day to put a few finishing touches to their work and to add to the discomfort of the local enthusiasts. One inning, however, settled all doubts as to the result. Big Amos Rusie started to pitch, and his carves were batted in all directions, the champions tallying 7 runs.

NANNET, N.Y., July 20. -- Nannet is a village in Rookland County where the land, rolls gently away toward the circling hills in green meadows, where clumps of elm and birch, trees throw long shadows in the afternoon across the lush grass and winding brooks for the benefit of the kine and any stray humans who may come alone, where every prospect pleases and man is now engaged in emerging from his estate of vileness.

Money is needed the more successfully to prosecute the excellent fresh-air work of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor. It manages two branches of this kind of philanthropic labor, and manages it well. The one is the "ocean party" excursions, combining wholesome food, fresh air, and surf bathing, and the other the care of crippled and convalescent children at a well-appointed home.

The action of the American Cable Company against the Mayors, Aldermen, and Commonalties of New-York and Brooklyn was decided in favor of the plaintiff yesterday by Judge Alfred C. Coxe of the United States Circuit Court.

Dr. Henry C.W. Meyer was arraigned yesterday before Judge Cowing, in Park I. of the Court of General Sessions, to the charge of murder in the first degree for killing Gustave A.J. Baum in order to get the insurance on his life.

LIVERPOOL, July 20 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef, pork, and hams in moderate demand. Bacon in moderate demand; Cumberland cut, about, 28 to 30 to, dull at 53s 6d; shoulders, about 12 to 18 IB, easy at 40s 6d Cheese in fair demand. Tallow in poor demand, Spirits of turpentine in poor demand. Resin in moderate demand. Laid -- Spot in poor demand; futures in no demand.

PARIS, July 20. -- The statement is published that Baron Mohrenheim, the Russian Ambassador to France, officially informed the French Government prior to the session of the Chamber of Deputies on Tuesday last, when M. Develle, the Foreign Minister, defined France's position in the Franco-Siamese dispute, that Russia would support France on all the points involved in the Siamese difficulty.

The meeting of the Lumber Trade Association to consider the financial situation was held yesterday afternoon. About fifty firms doing business in the metropolitan district had representatives at the meeting. As soon as James H. Pettinger, President of the association, called the meeting to order, committee was appointed to prepare resolutions expressing the views of the lumbermen on the cause of the present financial situation and the remedy for it.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 20. -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Unquowa, O.B. Jennings estate; Viking, Mr. H.A. Hutchings; Fra Diavalo, Mr. E.S. Stokes; Alicia, Mr. H.M. Flagler, and Theresa, Mr. Gustavus Sidenberg; schooner yacht Clytie, Mr. Henry C. Ward.

The conference held on Tuesday between a committee of the Civil Service Reform League and the commission at Albany, and afterward with Gov. FLOWER, is a good sign in several ways. It shows that the Reform League is not relaxing its vigilance or activity, and is determined to do what it can to secure the enforcement of the law, and, if necessary or possible, its improvement.

A rich man coming to New-York from Europe can get a dozen suite of clothes through the Custom House free, but the Italian immigrant must pay duties on even the pound of cheese and box of figs he carries in his bag.

While Mayor Boody of Brooklyn sat up in the high chair of the President of the Common Council yesterday morning more than 300 men and a few women were facing him, all anxious to be heard against the extension of the trolley railroads in their city. They were property owners in Madison Street, Gates and Greene Avenues, and business men along Fulton Street, who use Livingston Street for the receipt and delivery of goods.

DETROIT, Mich., July 20. -- This was a red-letter day at the Grand Circuit Trotting meeting, the feature of which was not the trotting free-for-all, but the form disclosed by Hulda and Muta Wilkes in the 2:15 class race. Both are five-year-old mares and daughters of Guy Wilkes, 2:15 1/4. Last week, at Pittsburg, Muta won a great victory over the much-touted Wardwell, trotting in 2:13 3/4, with something to spare.

ALBANY, July 20. -- State Senator Edward B. Osborne was found dead in his bed this morning at his lodgings in Clinton Avenue in this city. His death is a reminder of the so-called Senate steal of 1891, when, at the dictation of Gov. Hill, and by the assistance of Isaac H. Maynard, who was then Deputy Attorney General, Mr. Osborne obtained the seat in the Senate belonging to the Fifteenth Senatorial District.

The minutes of the Grand Jury which "presented" Mayor BOODY because it was advised that it could not indict him have been published. There is nothing now in them, except details which confirm what was already known. There will be no prosecution of anybody for "perjury" based on these minutes.

Pension frauds continue to be discovered in various parts of the country, their most common form being that of forged or perjured evidence used by agents in support of claims. These are the natural result of the lax methods that prevailed in the management of the Pension Bureau under the last Administration.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 20 -- The survivors of the Thirty-fifth New-Jersey Volunteer Regiment held their annual reunion here to-day. Nearly 100 hundred of the 180 survivors were present. The noted guests present were: Gen. Wager Swayne of New-York, the veterans' brigade commander; Col. Bernard of the Second New-Jersey, Ambrose Matthews, ex-Department Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic of New-Jersey, and Department Commander Wilbur F. Rogers of Connecticut.
LONDON, July 20. -- The reason for the advance in prices to-day was tersely put by a sporting broker. "The public," he said, "are on the feed."

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 20. -- James M. Dowling, cashier of the United States Mint, was arrested to-day charged with the embezzlement of $25,000 of the money intrusted to his care by the United States Government.

When the Rev. W.H. Ingersoll, who is practicing law at 170 Broadway, this city, arrived at his home, 34 Ashland Place, Brooklyn, last evening he was astounded to find a telegram addressed to his wife which read as follows:
Judge Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning granted an application to remove the case of the People versus R.M. Ricord from Justice Tighe's police court to the Grand Jury.

The latest sensation of interest to social circles in this city has just cropped up at Tuxedo as a second edition of the divorce suit brought against Mrs. Sallie Tuomey Moore by her husband, Louis Bragonier Moore, in which J. Ridgeway Moore, clubman, appeared as a co-respondent.

MILTON MILLS, N.H., July 20. -- The agent of the Waumbeck Company has issued orders for closing the mills here for three months, as soon as the goods now in process of manufacture are finished. The reason assigned for this action is a lack of orders, except at ruinous prices.

HEARN 22, 24, 26, and 30 West Fourteenth St. Friday, as Usual, Bargain Day. Ordinary means fail to accomplish extraordinary results.... Friday's success was attained by great efforts and many sacrifices.... To maintain its popularity these efforts are continued, the losses cheerfully taken....
Gradually, but surely, the consequences of "killing the goose that lays the golden eggs" Is recolling upon the heads of the Directors of the Monmouth Park Racing Association.

LONDON, July 20. -- The first reports received from Zanzibar regarding the trouble in Mashonaland were evidently incorrect in stating that there was a rising against the whites. A dispatch received this evening from Sir Henry Brougham Loch, Governor of Cape Colony, says that the trouble is entirely between the natives and that Europeans are in no danger.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Mr. James H. Eckels, the Controller of the Currency, immediately on his return from New-York this morning, addressed to Frank Adams, National Bonk Examiner at Denver, a dispatch defining the policy of the Administration with reference to insolvent national banking institutions generally, as follows:

A meeting of the members of the New-York Yacht Club was held yesterday afternoon. It was well attended, and business relating to the annual cruise was transacted. Chairman Kane of the Regatta Committee announced that the circular with all details of the races and club steamers that will be chartered for the use of the members and their friends will be issued to-day.

The inhabitants of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, in the neighborhood of De Kalb Avenue and Walworth Street, were startled yesterday afternoon by an explosion of a naphtha tank at 211 Walworth Street, which shook the buildings in the vicinity and resulted in the death of four persons.

LONDON, July 20. -- The Miners' Federation continued its conference at Birmingham to-day. Much interest is manifested in the proceedings, as upon the action of the conference depends the question whether there shall be begun the greatest strike England has ever seen. The conference yesterday decided that the proposed reduction would not be acceptable to the miners.
"Do it, and be quick about it." was the answer John McCaul, a Fourth Avenue car driver, made to a threat of his wife Catherine to poison herself at 362 East Thirty-third Street Wednesday night.

The second eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club again defeated the Athletic Club yesterday at Livingston, where they gained a victory over the latter by 66 runs. Owing to the fact that the Athletic men had only eight men at the bat, the contest was rather one-sided. B. Webber and W. Wiherspoon put up good scores for the winners, and they had passed their opponents' total before they were separated.

VALETTA, Malta, July 20. -- The court-martial appointed to examine into the loss of the battle ship Victoria met again to-day. Capt. Johnstone of the Camperdown, which ran into and sank the Victoria, was re-examined.

Miss Helen Carpenter Gaskin was married to Judge Addison Brown of the United States District Court at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The wedding took place in All Souls' Church, at Fourth Avenue and Twentieth Street. The Rev. Theodore C. Williams, the pastor, officiated.

George R. Malby of St. Lawrence County, the leader of the Republican minority in the Assembly, said yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel that a pretty contest is likely to be seen between Senators Erwin and Mullin for the renomination this Fall. Under the redistricting of the State, since the last election for Senators, Erwin and Mullin are now in the same district.

For some time a number of young Russian Hebrews have made a practice of enticing others of their race into a room on the third floor of 81 Chrrstie Street, where they robbed and tortured their victims.

Both passenger and freight questions were amicably discussed at a joint meeting of Presidents of Eastern and Western trunk lines in this city yesterday. With George B. Roberts, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in the chair, and Chauncey M. Depow as chief peacemaker, there was little chance for friction, and when the meeting dissolved everybody appeared to be in a complacent and satisfied mood.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 20. -- Half-yearly reports of two more of New-York City's trust companies made to the Bank Superintendent show their resources to aggregate $27,557,173. The profits are $593,445 this year; last year, $463,660. The amount of dividends is $125,000, The abstracts of the reports are here given:

The Rev. Dr. William B. Derrick, the Vice President of the Universal Peace Union, which has its headquarters in Philadelphia, speaking of the alleged disturbances in the society, said yesterday to a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

DENVER, July 20. -- Probably there will be no more bank failures in Denver. The panic wore itself out yesterday with the failure of the Peoples', German, and State National Banks. This morning when the First, Colorado, Denver, City, and American National Banks opened their doors there were hardly a dozen depositors in all of them at the paying tellers' windows.
J. Angus Hamilton of 106 East Nineteenth Street reported at Police Headquarters yesterday that a fellow-boarder and friend of his, John Charles Perry, the son of an English millionaire, was missing.

The Boston cricketers received their third successive defeat yesterday, the New-Jersey Athletic Club, by eight wickets, winning at Bergen Point. In the first innings, owing to the good bowling of Ellis and Cobb, the visitors were quickly disposed of for 35 runs, J. Howard being the only double-figure scorer, while in the second innings he batted very well for 27, and R. Mudie played well for 20. G. Simmons contributed 17, not out.

A good man struggling with adversity is always an object of the sympathy of the just. It is, however, a doubtful pleasure to find an offense charged against Mr. RUSSELL SAGE of which nobody who knows him, or knows of him, will believe that he could be guilty. That is the case with the latest of the schemes for extoriug money from the venerable capitalist.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 20. -- The Connecticut School Fund will be a heavy loser through the defalcation of E.I. Gunn of Lima. Ohio. The agent's shortage is reported at $30,000 this afternoon, and the amount it is thought will be increased.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, July 20 -- P.M. London is apparently over its scare and is once more in the market as a purchaser of American securities. Many of these purchases may be to cover short contracts put out early in the week, but there has been unquestionably a fair amount taken for investment.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 20. -- The President passed a very quiet day. Part of the time was spent, at Gray Gables with his guests. Col. Lamont and Dr. Bryant, and later in the day they took a short sail in the Ruth in Buzzard's Bay.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 20. -- An exciting scene occurred in the reception room of the Long Island Home, an institution for the treatment of mildly insane patients, at noon to-day. During an interview between Prof. A.G. Wilsey, manager, and a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, a large man burst into the room.

Job M. Nash, formerly a merchant of Cincinnati, died Wednesday at the St. Marc Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, where he lived. Mr. Nash was seventy-flve years old. He was born at Zanesville. Ohio, his parents having gone there from New-York. He was graduated from Oberlin College. He became acquainted with Col. Thomas Wood in Lafayette, Ind., and was sent by him to New-Orleans with a cargo of provisions.
Fire history repeated itself last night in the wrecking of the exchange of the Metropolitan Telegraph and Telephone Company on the fifth floor of 867 to 871 Broadway.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 20. -- The State Bimetallic Convention, which assembled in this city today, was attended by 300 delegates from all parts of the State, most of them Populists. ExGov. Thomas A. Osborne, a Republican and a Director in the Central National Bank, was elected Chairman. In assuming the chair, he said:

London's heavy purchases yesterday morning gave the cue to New-York, and prices accordingly went op on what was good buying for both accounts. Afterward, as a result of a sharp and well-directed raid upon General Electric, prices receded somewhat. But the concessions in the general list were encouragingly small.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Wheat was convalescent today. The up-turn was due to comparatively steady cables, confirmation of good export translations, higher quotations for stocks, less selling pressure, unfavorable crop reports, covering of shorts, and a brisk investment demand. Corn and oats sold down sharply on great crop prospects. Comparative with yesterday's close, wheat is up 3/4c, while corn is otr 3/4c and oats 1c.
Organizer Jewell of the Republican State League thinks he has found an enemy sowing tares in his wheatfield.

LONDON, July 20. -- The last eleven, clauses of the Home Rule Bill were brought through the committee stage this evening. On Thursday evening or last week the work of the Honso in committee had been pushed forward to Clause 27. This clause, concerning Judges and other persons having salaries charged on the Consolidated Fund, was carried on Monday.

RICHMOND, Va., July 20. -- The marriage a few days ago of Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge and Mrs. Louise Scott Wing of Louisville has caused considerable surprise here. It was understood among the Congressman's friends that he was engaged to Miss Madeline Breckinridge Pollard of Lexington, Ky. The engagement was publicly announced there and here.

LONDON, July 20. -- At the Limerick Assizes recently the Eight Hon. Sir Peter O'Brien. Lord Chief Justice of Ireland, complained at the manner in which the criminal statistics of Ireland were compiled, objecting especially to the fact that doubtful cases were not included in the statistics.

GALVRSTON, Texas, July 20. -- The passenger earnings of Texas railways for the quarter ending June 30 show a slight increase over the same period last year, and as reported to the Controller are as follows:
LONG ISLAND CITY, July 21. -- Two entire blocks of buildings in this city were destroyed by fire early this morning.

On July 3, before the details of the Victoria disaster were fully known, THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in commenting on the deplorable accident, declared that it was due to an error of judgment on the part of Vice Admiral TRYON, and further said that such a mistake by such an officer ought to open our eyes to the need for the constant study of the tactical capacity of every ship in our navy.

The prevalent form of gambling has come to be what is known as "playing the races." The more other forms have been suppressed by the enforcement of laws against them, the more flagrant has this form become, and it is even more demoralizing than buying lottery tickets, playing policy, or taking the chances of games carried on in the privacy of gambling dens, inasmuch as it is more open and accessible.

JERSEY CITY, July 20. -- A large crowd assembled at Bergen Junction this evening to witness the departure of Lincoln Guard, Company A, Fourth Regiment, for Sea Girt Sixtyfive men answered the roll call. They were under command of Capt. J.H. Bumsted, Jr.

Charles F. Washburn. Charles F. Washburn, Vice President of the great wire firm of the Washburn Moon Manufacturing Company, died yesterday morning in Boston. He was a son of the late Charles Washburn, a twin brother of the late Hon. Ichabod Washburn. He was born in Harrison, Cumberland County, Me., Aug. 23, 1827.

While it is hoped that cholera will not make its appearance in the United States this year, the Marine Hospital Service has taken steps to keep the malady under control if it does reach this country. Dr. P.H. Bailhache, the senior medical officer of the Immigration Bureau, has received instructions from Surgeon General Wyman to organize a staff of physicians for this purpose.
Dr. Charles A. Brlggs has published the third volume of his history of his trial for heresy before the Presbyterian General Assembly.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Russia's exhibitors and official representatives here are deeply indignant over the raid made by United States customs officers yesterday on the exhibitor P. Lukutin of St. Petersburg on suspicion that he was selling bonded goods.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21. -- Col. Charles L. Burdett of this city, President of the League of American Wheelmen, has called a special meeting of the National Assembly, to be held in Buffalo, N.Y., on Monday, Sept. 25. The delegates to this meeting will be those who, were elected last Fall, vacancies being filled by appointment by the Chief Consuls of the State or division in which a vacancy may have occurred.

ALBANY, July 21. -- The resources of the United States Trust company were $5,478,021 smaller on June 30 of this year than they were on the corresponding date in 1892. For the first six months of the present year the profits fell off $25,929, when compared with a like period last year; but the dividends increased from $250,000 a year ago to $320,000 this year.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 3@6 P cent. but the bulk of business was done at 5@6 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 21. -- Acting District Attorney Kenefick appeared before Judge Hatch in the Superior Court this morning and moved that the cases of the men charged with falsifying election returns be transferred to the Supreme Court, Criminal Term, for trial. The defendants were represented by Moses Shire, and he offering no objection, the court directed that the order be entered.

The President of the Stock Exchange is booked to make a speech to his fellowmembers this morning, dealing with some recent occurrences in Wall Street, and the rights of vested interests to protection from irresponsible attacks.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., July 21. -- For nearly two hours to-day the greater part of West Brighton was threatened with destruction from a fire in the amphitheatre of Pain's fireworks. Persons passing along the street at 12:50 o'clock discovered the blaze, which started in the pine boarding of the outer wall of the amphitheatre.

It is high time that the civilized world began to take some indignant notice of the proceedings of the French in Siam. The "powers" of the civilized world will, of course, take notice of these proceedings in so far as their several interests are concerned; but indeed Great Britain is the only power of which the interest is both clear and important.

BUFFALO, July 21. -- Things are looking very black for the Solleok Brothers, who failed last Saturday owing the Hon. Warner Miller $35,000 and many others in proportion. There are still other creditors, and quite a large number of them, who will lose various amounts ranging from $1 to $500.

The "healing spring" at the base of the rooks to Morningside Park, whose waters have been quaffed by thousands of people, is simply a leak from an old well, sunk 100 years ago, and lately fed by a leak in an ancient and ruined sewer.

BOSTON, Mass., July 21. -- The experts at Longwood to-day were favored by the Weather Bureau, as a cool breeze made life more endurable to the perspiring players. The weeding, out process brought Stevens of Hoboken and Chace of Providence face to face in the finals and a clever exhibition of backcourt tennis resulted.

LENOX, Mass., July 21. -- The funeral of Richard Tylden Auchmuty wan held at Trinity Church at 4 o'clock this afternoon. The services were conducted by the Rev. W.M. Grosvenor, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington of Grace Church. New-York, and the Rev. Dr. William Wilberforce Newton of St. Stephen's Church, Pittsfield.

Mrs. Mary Mulhearn is just now the most important witness in the famous suit of Delia Keegan against Russell Sage. She is the only sister of Delia Keegan, who is suing the aged financier for $100,000.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, July 21 -- P.M. The advance in prices, which has been the feature of the market for a couple of days, was not continued to-day. The bears again became aggressive, and, although they were not permitted to have everything their way, they were successful in bringing about a lower level of prices for practically all the active stocks.

LONDON, July 21. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gladstone moved the consideration of the new financial clause of the Home Rule bill, the only clause to be discussed prior to the passage of the bill by the House. The motion was adopted, and the House went into Committee of the Whole.

The Bureau of the American Republics is in receipt of the official text of the treaties of commerce entered, respectively, on the 4th of July and the 19th of August, 1892, between the Republic of Uruguay and the Argentine Republic with the French Republic, both of them proclaimed at Paris on the 10th of June ult.

LONDON, July 21. -- Important communications have passed to-day between the Foreign Office and Capt. H.M., Jones, British Minister Resident in Bangkok. Vice Admiral Fremantle Commander in Chief of the Chinese division of the fleet, is hastening to Singapore, where dispatches from the Admiralty await him.

-- A party from the Manhattan Bicycle Club, consisting of James Thompson, George Goldstone, Joseph Stearns, J. Post, Jr., and Charles Cohen, together with Charles Jeanette, President of the Castle Point Wheelmen of Hoboken, have just returned from a bicycle trip to the Delaware Water Gap. Leaving New-York one pleasant morning about a week ago, they rode through Passaic, Pompton, and Suffern to Monroe, where they spent the night.

BOSTON, July 21. -- William Watts, Captain of the British schooner Ocenn Lily, appeared before the United States District Court to-day at the instigation of the United States District Attorney, for not complying with Section 2 of the Marine Quarantine acts of Feb. 15, 1893, and for not having a bill of health issued or the Consul at the port of sailing. He was held in the sum of $5,000.

LONDON, July 21. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gladstone, replying to a question asked by Mr. Robert L. Everott, said that he did not agree with Mr. Ererott's assumption that the new monetary policy adopted by the Indian Governinent would create a larger demand for gold, which would possibly result in a further else in the price of that metal.

If the story which John Gilmore of 439 First Avenue told in the Tombs Police Court yesterday is true, it would seem that the officials of the Elmira Reformatory are not unwilling to "railroad" him to the institution. He has been out on parole for six months.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 21. -- The are which destroyed one block and partly destroyed two more last night, caused over $500,000 damage and left over 100 families homeless. Fortunately no lives were lost, though, there were many narrow escapes. One fireman had his leg badly crusted, and a man Had his hand crushed while aiding a family to escape from the flames.
Spirits of turpentine dull and essay at 27 1/4@28c. Resins weak and dull at $1@$1.05 for common to good strained.

WHITE PLAINS, July 21. -- Justice Dykman to-day handed down a decision in the suit of James L. Heynolds against Gonverneur Rogers and the Bank of Mount Vernon. Reynolds was a stockholder and Rogers President of the bank.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- With two or three exceptions all of the appointments of naval cadets for the next class have boon made. The list is as follows:
TOPEKA, Kan., July 21. -- One of the shrewdest political moves ever known in this State has just been inaugurated by the State Alliance.

Postmaster Dayton, in an interview yesterday, said: "Before assuming the duties of my office I went to Washington for a conference with Postmaster General Bissell. I was most cordially received, and assured by the Postmaster General that in my administration of this office he would give me all the support in his power.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21. -- Secretary F.R. Fortmeyer of the Middle States Regatta Association, who is stopping at the Passaic Boathouse, said to a NEWYORK TIMES reporter to-night that the regatta would be started to-morrow morning promptly at 10 o'clock, instead of at 11 o'clock, as had been previously announced. Provision was made for an extra hour, as the time is found necessary for the trial heats in the junior and intermediate singles.

LONDON, July 21. -- The market opened strong on the continuance of outside purchases and prices advanced steadily, Atchison incomes rising to 38 1/4, Denver preferred to 30 1/4, Erie seconds to 78 1/2, Louisville to 56 3/8, and St. Paul to 59 1/8.

Wheat was 1/4@3/8c higher at the opening as following Chicago, reports of hot winds in the Northwest, and considerable local covering; declined 5/8@3/4c on reports of financial trouble at the West, closing 1/8@1/2c under yesterday after a moderate business.

Commissioner BRENNAN has got out at last. He did not retire "under fire" but, having got well into the season when street cleaning is at its easiest, resigned on account of sickness in his family and enforced absence from the city. As the charges made against him some time ago did, not cause his removal or induce his resignation, he probably considers himself "vindicated."

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 21. -- One of the prettiess clubhouse buildings in New-Jersey was formally opened this evening to the members and friends of the Englewood Field Club. The new building is a two-story Queen Anne structure, picturesque in appearance, with generous piazzas and capacious rooms. The ground, floor is 85 feet long by 45 feet in the centre and 32 feet wide at each end.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 21. -- William Henry Laforge, who lived in the town of Shawangunk, Ulster County, is in the jail here charged with murdering his wife with a Jackknife. Mrs. Laforge was twenty-three years old, while the alleged murderer is over fifty. Since their marriage two years ago they had quarreled many times.

A letter has been received by the New-York Yacht Club from the Royal Victoria Yacht Club, which announces that the yawl ViKing, formerly the Wendur, has forfeited the Cape May Cup to Lord Dunraven's yacht Valkyrie. Mr. Royal Phelpg Carroll intended to challenge for a race for the cup with his cutter Navahoe. Now he will have to race against the Valkyrie.

"Clear the track!" Homebody shouts. A pair of white horses on the fall gallop pass like a flash. There is something which sounds like an alarm gong. Men and women take a skip and a Jump and hold their breaths.

There were no crowds around the stations of the various railroads which take down intending visitors to the Monmouth Park race track yesterday which would be noticeable as denoting that the regular amount of passenger traffic was larger than usual.

BOSTON, July 21. -- The local market was generally quiet. Boston Maine declined 11 points, to 145, but reacted to 152. The selling was supposed to be for the account of an operator who was compelled to liquidate. The market closed firm.

Hotel proprietors at Loon Lake and in Plattsburg, N.Y., have recently been victimized by a man claiming to have been employed twenty-two years by H. O'Neill Co., Sixth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. They have no knowledge or the swindler, and are willing to pay the expenses of his arrest and conviction. He is described as about 6 feet in height and slender, and, when in Plattsburg, he wore a black beard.

The American steamship Paris, which holds the record between this port and Queenstown, is making brave efforts to maintain her reputation as the fleetest of the transatlantic liners. On the voyage which ended yesterday she managed to establish a new record for the Southampton route.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 21. -- Cashier Dowling, charged with embezzling $25,000 of the Government money from the United States Mint, was before the United States Commission this morning. He waived a preliminary examination. W.B. Ringrose, a prominent furniture dealer, signed his bond, and he was released.

A maddened, turbulent crowd of men surged through, the lower end of West Forty-first Street last evening on the trail of a prisoner in the hands of a policeman, uttering cries of wrath and threats of mob violence.
Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy made these appointments at 2 P.M. yesterday. There is to be a new order of things in the StreetCleaning Department. That a change was to be made has been evident for some time.

The publication by Mayor Boody of the minates of the June Grand Jury having opened the way by sanction of the court for the disclosure of proceedings of various Grand Juries which dealt with charges of official missonduct in Brooklyn, some of the jurors who did service within the last few months feel that they have been relieved of the obligation or secrecy imposed upon them and are entitled to talk.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 21. -- Sprinting at a prize-winner's speed and distancing the field of panting creditors who had attachments and executions to file against the Commercial Bank of this city, an attorney dashed into the Clerk of Court's office this morning and filed the voluntary assignment of the bank.
The Boston Cricket Club wound up its NewYork trip yesterday at West New-Brighton, S.I., where it succeeded in placing a victory to its credit by defeating the Harlem Club by 66 runs.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 21. -- Harry Hill, against whom there are many charges of having forged the name of Mrs. J.H. Porter, a prominent leader in society, came into prominence again to-day. The story of the charges against Hill, of his flight, his arrest in Chicago, the sensational statements he made, and his subsequent release on bond after being brought back here has already been told.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21. -- The flag which was carried by the Eighth Regiment at the first battle of Bull Run was unfurled this morning, the anniversary of that engagement, in front of Col. Scott's tent. On a table in the tent was a picture of Brig. Gen. J.M. Varian. who succeeded Col. Lyons as war commander of the regiment.

- There are not yet any woman lawyers in Georgia, and Chief Justice Logan B. Bleckley of the Supreme Court of the State, in a recent lecture aft Atlanta on "The Future of Women at the Georgia Bar," expressed the opinion that the roaring of lawyers is a more important thing than the practice of law, and that it is the mission of woman to do this.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- The Gilmore Band will assist in the entertainment of visitors at the World's Fair after the first week in August Mrs. Gilmore authorising the use of her husband's name. Prof. D.W. Reeves is the conductor, and he is highly spoken of by the musicians of the bands at the fair grounds.

From the Bider and Driver. THE NEW-YORK TIMES has a noble record for fearless independence and honesty of purpose. It began by overthrowing the Tweed regime, which tried in vain to buy off its attacks with $1,000,000. Then it laid bare corrupt doings in the Legislature which a combined effort to expel its able correspondent, George F. Spinney, did not thwart for a moment.

DETROIT, Mich., July 21. -- The Detroit Grand Circuit Trotting Meeting closed with sensational harness racing to-day. The free-for-all pacing race, which horsemen generally expected would prove little more than a walk-away for Flying Jib, developed into a great contest, Mascot winning at the end of the fastest five heats on record.

News of the most reassuring nature, so far as the personal safety of the American missionaries in Siam is concerned, was received yesterday by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, at 53 Fifth Avenue, this city. This news came in the form of a cablegram from the Rev. J.B. Dunlap of the Presbyterian Mission in Bangkok, the seat of the present troubles.
SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., July 21. -- Company A Fourth Regiment, N.G.S.N.J., which is marching from Jersey City to the State camp at Sea Girt, is encamped to-night at this place.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of the Union Pacific against Goodridge, just reported, holds that all shippers must be treated by carriers with absolute equality, and distinctly recognizes the right of lawmaking bodies to regulate railways through railway commissions, especially that feature of State and Federal regulation which requires carriers to obtain permission of the commission before granting lower rates to persons and places.
BOSTON, July 21. -- Again the New-Yorks lost. They outbatted the Bostons and fielded equally well, but for some reason or another they failed to make the necessary number of runs to win.

METROPOLIS, Ill, July 21. -- Richard Shoemaker killed Richard Lukens, Jr., and George Lukens, and seriously wounded their father, Richard, and then committed suicide this evening by sending a bullet into his own body. All the parties were men of high social standing in this city and were well-known throughout Southern Illinois and in Kentucky.
DENVER, Col., July 21. -- Confidence in the Denver banks and commercial houses is being restored nearly as rapidly as the people here attempted its destruction this week.
A horse, 83 reporters, and about 2,000 citizens in ordinary almost blocked business last night in Park Row.

The official trial of the engines of the new United States armored cruiser Maine was begun yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The starboard engine or the big war ship was subjected to a four hours' full horsepower trial. The results warrant the assertion that the starboard engine has more than exceeded the official Government requirement.

A match race for $1,000 a side has been arranged between Japonica and Hartland, to take place on the Brighton Beach race track on Monday, previous to the running of the first regular race. The distance is to be five furlongs, and the weights 130 pounds each.

At an early hour yesterday morning sixty pupils of Baron Hirsch's Trade School in East Ninth Street, who live at Nathan Solomon's boarding house, 109 Clinton Place, were awakened by an alarm of fire. The boys endeavored to make that escape from too building, but they found that the scuttle door in the root and the front and basement doors were looked.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21. -- Carnot O. Spencer, chief clerk of the Connecticut School fund, who is in Lima, Ohio, investigating the affairs of E.L. Gunn, the missing loan agent, has found a shortage of $50,000 thus far. Many oases of fraud upon poor mortgagors who have paid interest, and, some of them, loans, have been discovered.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 21. -- The first homeopathic hospital ever established in Mexico has been formally opened in a building used under the Spanish Viceroys as a powder magazine. President Diaz and Minister of the Interior Romero Rubio assisted at the inauguration. It is believed that this is a precursor of the establishment here of a national homeopathic medical school.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 21. -- The midsummer most of the Asbury Park Wheelmen attracted over 3,000 spectators to the model grounds of the Asbury Park Athletic Association to-day. Six races were run, Hess, Grosch, and other speedy "bikers" competing for the valuable prizes offered by the management. Windle was entered for the handicap, but was unable to arrive in time.

Those of Brooklyn people who live in the Twenty-sixth Ward and the surrounding districts breathe more easily now that the gang of Burglars who have for a long time preyed upon their personal property are at last in the custody of the police.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The Hartford may after all take her place again among the ships of the navy. The Board of Burean Chiefs is discussing the possibility of refitting her for active service, and estimates are being prepared by Chief Naval Constructor Hichborn of the cost of repairing the veteran ship.

After a succession of defeats the Brooklyns finally won a game from the Baltimores yesterday. At the outset the Brooklyns looked like sure winners. They were batting in good form and were fielding grandly. Mullane, who was in the box for Baltimore, had no terrors for them. Manager Hanlon, however, quickly discovered this, and he put McNabb in the box.

Patrick Boss of Brooklyn was indicted in December last by a Kings County Grand Jury for his connection with the Columbian celebration scandal. Ross charged the county $11,705 for the erection of a grand stand from which Brooklyn officials reviewed a parade. J.H. Pigot designed the stand and Ross built it.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 21. -- The arrangement which Major Herbert, commanding the Canadian militia, has just closed with the Imperial Government on behalf of the Canadian Government in regard to the fortifications at Esquimalt, British Columbia, is understood to be as follows:

The Fairchild commission took up the question of tobacco undervaluations again yesterday. Several New-York importers and manufacturers of Havana cigars testified that nearly every bale of fillers contained wrappers.
FAR ROCKAWAY, July 21. -- Two young girls from New-York were drowned in Shell Bank Pond, East Rockaway, this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- An abstract of the reports made to the Controller of the Currency by the national banks of New-York City in response to his call for statements showing their condition at the close of business on Wednesday, July 12, was furnished by Mr. Eckels this afternoon. It is as follows:
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 21. -- Ten thousand turners from all over the United States arrived in Milwaukee to-day to participate in the exercises of the National Bund and Turn Fest.

It is not creditable to the male portion of this community that the Ladies' Health Protective Association is compelled to take up the unsavory question of disposing of the refuse of stables and to intercede with the Board of Health for the abatement of an injurious nuisance, Neither is it creditable to the Board of Health that repeated intercession has been necessary and has thus far been unavailing.

VALETTA, Malta, July 21. -- Capt. Arthur W. Moore of the Dreadnaught was the first witness at to-day's session on the war ship Hibernia of the court-martial appointed to inquire into the loss of the battle ship Victoria.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 22. -- Two races were sailed to-day over the coarse of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay. The first race was for naphtha launches for a seventy-five-dollar silver cup. It was won by Mr. Colgate Hoyt on June 17, but was offered again by Hr. Hoyt. The second race was for email sloops for the Alfred Roosevelt Memorial Cup also valued at $75.

The sales of real estate at auction announced for the present week are not numerous. With one exception they are all in legal proceedings. There are no offerings of special moment. All sales are at the New-York Real Estate Sales-room, 111 Broadway, unless otherwise stated. The list for the week is subjoined:

Mr. GAYNOR has done much for the people of Brooklyn, and in a clear-headed, sensible fashion which deserves their gratitude. Not the least of his contributions in their interest is a phrase in his interview in THE TIMES yesterday morning. He was discussing the course of Mayor BOODY in having his Corporation Counsel.

"We are building a little Summer cottage," said a woman the other day, "or, rather." she corrected herself, "we are building a Summer piazza with, I believe, a bit of a cottage some-where in the background." Which is about how the modern suburban home expresses itself, to the increased advantage of its inmates.

It was stated yesterday that the papers in the long-threatened suit against Mayor Boody and the Brooklyn Aldermen, to test the legality of the franchises to construct trolley roads, granted to the Nassau and Kings County Electric Railroad Companies, had been prepared by William J. Gaynor, and that the service would be made to-morrow on the Mayor and Aldermen and also on Patrick H. Flynn, President of the Nassau and Kings County Roads.

The second of the series of contests for the championship of the Interclub Lawn Tennis League recently organized by representatives of the Hillside Tennis Club of Plainfield, the Bergen Point Tennis Club of Bayonne, and the Jersey City Tennis Club of Jersey City Heights, took place yesterday afternoon on the Bergen Point Club courts, Avenae A. Bayonne.

The new triple-screw cruiser Columbia and the new battle ship Indiana will both probably be officially tested for speed during the coming Fall. This statement is made by a gentleman whose official connection with the above ships enables him to state the degree or their readiness with considerable accuracy.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 22. -- George Shars of Glen Gardner, N.J., to day told Chief of Police Murphy he had been swindled out of $200 by "green-goods" men whom he met at Taylor's Hotel. He said the men sent a letter to Levi Apgar of his town saying they were in a position to make him rich if he would meet them at the hotel.

The Health Department's chemical analysis of the water flowing from the so-called "healing spring" at the base of the rocks in Morningside Park affords ample proof of very dangerous pollution. It appears that this water leaks out of an old and abandoned well, into which is discharged a part of the contents of an ancient sewer no longer in use.

PARIS, July 23 -- 1 A.M. -- A dispatch to the Temps from Saigon says: "A telegram from Stungtrong announces that Capt. Villers, commanding the French forces at Khong. reopened fire upon the Siamese on the morning of the 19th inst. In the course of the day the French captured Forts Dondus, Dongo and Donhan thus confining the enemy to Fort Donsom.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 22. -- The magnet which draws many people hero is the excellent fishing, made so by the fact that over 200 square miles of the St. Lawrence River is legally protected from natters and the slaughter of game fish. This year the fishing is better than it ever has been before. The lovers or the facinating sport have had splendid luck, and unusually large catches have been made.

John Glimore, the east side "dude." was again before Justice Martin yesterday in the Tombs Police Court. He had been remanded on Friday in order to give Agent Erockaway of the Elmira Reformatory time to secure evidence to prove that he had violated his parole.

I remember very well the first day I saw him. A number of us boys were on our way home from school, careless, happy, insolent with excess of life. He came around a corner and tried to slink by us unnoticed, a little, nervous man with clean-shaven, dried-up face, large eyes which were pitiable in expression when he furtively raised them from the ground, and a sad, drawn month.

ST. LOUIS, July 22. -- Advices received here by the family of his wife tell of the death by drowning of Lieut. Powhatan Clarke, United States Army, at Fort Custer, Mon., where he was stationed with his command. The circumstances are not known. Lieut. Clarke was thirty years of age, a son of Dr. Clarke of Baltimore, Md., and was married here to Miss Elsie Clemens about a year ago.
The Staten Island Cricket Club visited Morris Park for their return game with the home club yesterday and would have come away defeated had the Morris Park's fielding been only what it should.

Pony racing at Elkwood Park, Lone Branch, looks as if it would become a very popular weekly event. It is proposed to have three races every Saturday morning daring the season. Yesterday was the second day, and in every way compared favorably with the opening on July 15. Cottagers Game in every kind of conveyance from Long Branch, Hollywood. Elberon, Seabright, Monmouth Beach, and Bed Bank.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 22. -- The sad drowning accident of yesterday, which resulted in the death of Miss Mabel W. Hallett, aged nineteen, and Miss Elizabeth Walters, aged seventeen, both of New-York City. In plain view of friends, rescuers, and many people on the beach, as told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday, has caused general sorrow here, where the young ladies were great favorites.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 22. -- This has been a listless sort of week at Bar Harbor. There has been but little life and positively no gayety. Although there are as many cottagers and hotel guests here as usual, nobody seems to exert himself beyond driving, fishing, canoeing, tennis playing, and taking part in the exhilarating piazza tea.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 22. -- In view of the export tax on coffee, imposed July 1, planters in the States of Vera Cruz. Oajaca, and other districts of Mexico made great efforts to ship all their surplus in June. During the latter half of that month prices ruled at $25 to $26 per quintal of second quality. One steamer, El Gran Antilla, sailed during the last week in June with 10,470 sacks for New-Orleans.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 22. -- Society at this favorite resort is now at its best, and with teas, driving, dances, and receptions the days pass pleasantly. The annual open tennis tournament for the championship of Long Island, to be played at the Meadow Club during the week beginning July 31, will be unusally interesting this season, as nearly all the crack players expect to be present.

-- The announcements at Koster Bial's are "Big Frank," the boxing kangaroo; Charles Haydn, humorist and mimic, in new character impersonations the little English soubretts. Lottle Collard, in New songs and dances; the Parisian dance duetists, M. Dufour and Mile. Hartley, in new features, including "La Musique de is Garde"; the wonderful Borani Brothers, "disappearing demons"; "Wood and Shepard, comedians, and the performance of the two operettas, "La Belle Helene" and "The Admiral."

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22. -- This has been the moat eventful week of the season thus far. Society has been chiefly interested in the entertainment given to introduce a charming debutante, Miss Virginia Fair, a sister of Mrs. Oelrichs; a visit from President Cleveland on Mr. Benedict's yacht Oneida, and an official Visit to the naval and torpedo stations by Secretary Herbert, who cams on the dispatch boat Dolphin.

The exigencies of electioneering are as well understood in Great Britain, doubtless, as they are anywhere else in the world. It is true Lord SALISBURY pretended to be very much shocked by them when the British Minister at Washington had to be withdrawn; but that was only a manifestation of the political hypocrisy with which it is the British fashion to cover political "dodges."

Brooklyn's new hotel, the Regant, situated in one of the most beautiful parts of fashionable Clinton Avenue, which was opened informally July 15, has already become the home of a number of business men, but its formal opening in all its completeness will not occur until September.

Indictments were found by the Grand Jury last week against Policemen William Dwyer and C.W.H., Finken of the Old Slip Station. Both the District Attorney and the police authorities have kept the matter secret, and yesterday they refused to speak of it.
A report by W. A. Harding, accountant, on the condition of the Archer Pancoast manufacturing Company, dealers in and makers of gas mixtures, was made public yesterday.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., July 22. -- Centre Moriches has scintillated with gayoty and life during the week, and each day has been a chain of merry moments. The centrs of all the fun has been the Hotel Brooklyn, which is now full of companionable people. Young people predominate and pretty girls abound. The Summer girl, as round in Moriches, is at once a confection and an enchanting vision.

Judge Thomas J. Maekey of 368 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street is a veteran of the war with Mexico, and is the proud possessor of two medals given for bravery in the field. These medals have a history, and Judge Mackey told it to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES recently.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 22. -- Gov. Lewelling has been forced to prefer charges against Col. Hughes, and the latter will be tried by court-martial Aug. 2 for refusing to obey the Governor's orders to remove the lawmakers from their hall during the legislative war last Winter.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 22. -- A Canadian cruiser recently seized the American fishing sehooner Giles for an alleged infraction of the fishing regulations, and a fine of $2,500 and costs was paid to the Dominion Government.

The recent taking down of the last remains of some ancient houses in Fleet Street, London, suggested to Mr. Archer the writing of this finely manufactured book. The title is somewhat fanciful, since it is rather difficult to see that Fleet Street has been the highway of English letters very much more than its continuation, the Strand, or possibly other London highways.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., July 22. -- The beat of the last week caused an increased demand for hotel and cottage accommodations. The New Portland and the Alpine hotels and some of the cottages have room for more, and will undoubtedly soon be well filled. The hops, daily concerts, and the Sunday evening sacred concerts make their parlors and verandas attractive.

The annual pennant race of the Riverside Yacht Club was sailed yesterday. Ten yachts crossed the line, racing in eight classes. The winners now hold the pennants, but are subject to challenge any time during the season. It was a rattling good day for a yacht race, a strong breeze coming from the south-west all the afternoon. It was too strong for some of the little boats, and one or two went out double reefed.

BERLIN, July 22. -- More than 1,100 excursionists from Brunswick arrived in Friedricharuh yesterday afternoon and marched to Prince Bismarck's house. In response to an address from their spokesman Bismarck made a long speech. His most notable remarks were these:

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Wheat and corn markets today struggled against breaking banks, and emerged smlling, with a gain of 12c sticking to wheat and 1c to corn. Very bad reports of the outturn of the oat thrashings gave that market a lively hoist also. The weak sister among the speculative markets was provisions, which declined, although hog receipts were light.
There is possibly no pleasanter trip for wheelmen than what is known as the Berkshire Hills tour. It has become the favorite vacation tour and comprises all there is good in cycling.

This is an admirable example of good work modestly and intelligently done. Its purpose is manifest in the title. It is to show "how comparatively easy and simple botany is, and what a pleasure it is to know something -- a great deal -- about plants." And it is as a Summer amusement that the writer earnestly recommends it.

The first race was a trial heart of the Junior singles and was started at 10:06. In it were Stephen Smith of the Metropolitans, William F. Kiley of the Atalanta Boat Club, and F.A. Barklie of the Passaic Boat Club. The tide was ebbing with two hours yet to ran and a light breeze was blowing down the river, so that the race was rowed against both wind and tide.

Mascagni's "I Rantzan" has been produced in London and has failed to take the town by storm. The general impression is that the young composer is writing too fast. The London Sunday Times devotes a column to a careful consideration of the new work. The most important part of the criticism is as follows:

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 22. -- The weather during the last week has continued to be perfection for driving and outdoor sports. The farmers are crying for rain, but the visitors are inclined to think everything is lovely. Private turnouts continue to arrive, and as the season reaches the high tide of fashionable life, the early comers bring out their reserve stock of equipages and equines to keep pace with the daily horse show.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 22. -- Many new faces have been noticed this week among the Summer contingent who discover in this picturesque village on the border of the Sound a delightful place in which to spend part of the season. The greater number come from New-York and Brooklyn.
Yearlings of the Silver Brook and Brookdale studs were cold at auction at Monmouth Park yesterday. The yearlings were a nice-looking lot, and the prices brought were quite up to the average.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22. -- Local stocks were steady in spite of the weakness in London. Philadelphia Traction was 81 bid and Metropolitan Traction sold in small lots at 90. It looks aa If liquidation In these securities was over. All our banks are in a strong condition. Lehlgh Valley was again offered down by the bears to 32 1/2, but a few orders to buyrallied the price to 34, and it closed with that bid.

COLLE E POINT, L.I., July 22. -- John Zelmmer, twenty-three years old, remarked to Coroner Corry a few days ago that he "would soon give him a job." Zeimmer, while intoxicated to-day, took a dose of chloroform, and died in a few minutes.

SARATOGA, July 22. -- The two days of exceptionally-heavy showers of the midweek have been succeeded by typical Saratoga weather -- cool mornings and evenings, with days whose brilliant sunshine is tempered by gentle breezes. The week has been comparatively quiet after the tennis excitement of last week and with the races to begin on Monday.

By worsting the team of the Staten Island AC on the diamond of the New-Jersey Oval at Bergon Point yesterday afternoon the ball tossers of the New-Jersey AC clinched their grip upon the amateur league pennant. The victory was easily won by the Jerseymen, their half-dozen runs being earned from "Danny" Clare's delivery. The islanders tallied two unearned runs.

LENOX, Mass., July 22. -- The death of Col. Richard T. Auchmuty ia a great blow to Lenox. The cottagers were much shocked when they heard on Tuesday morning that he was dead. What he has done for Lenox cannot be told in a single paragraph. He was one of the pioneers, coming here in 1866, when he bought a large tract of territory on the Pittsfield road.

TAYLOR'S-ON-SCHROON, Warren County, N.Y., July 22. -- Schroon Lake, at the southern entrance of the Adirondack Park, is a beautiful sheet of water surrounded by hills and mountains. It abounds with fish of all kinds found in the Adirondack lakes. It is easy of access, being only ten hours' ride from New-York and about four hours from Saratoga Springe, on the Adirondack Railroad, stage, and steamer.

ORANGE, N.J., July 22. -- One of the prettiest spots in the Oranges is at St. Cloud, West Orange, and this locality is becoming very popular as an objective point for moonlight strolls and drives. It is just on the brow of the Orange Mountains, at one of the highest points along the cliff, and a breeze is always to be found there.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 22.-- There were nearly 1,000 spectators present this afternoon at the most of the Asbury Park Wheelmen. The leading wheelmen of the country participated in the races. The first prize in each event was a diamond. A strong wind blew down the backstretch, preventing the contestants from making fast time. The fields were very large and there of the races were run off in heats.

GOSSIP AND INCIDENTS LAST WEEK. -- There were several incidents in and about town last week that startled society people. Death carried away three leading representatives of New-York society, and many fashionable people went into mourning. The breaking of the engagement of Miss Grace Morgan to Frederick F. Ayer was the subject for talk over the tea tables at all of the fashionable colonies.

From the House Furnishing Review. Away from the sights and Bounds of a great city, with no fear of the smirch from its dusty streets and the weariness from contact with its perspiring crowds, beyond reach of the hum of the too familiar and overfond mosquito, the Summer girl has found a convenient bough from which to swing her hammock.

BERLIN, July 22. -- The Emperor's departure on a yachting cruise, daring which he will visit several points in Sweden, and the adjournment of the Reichstag marked the beginning of the dead season in Berlin, which is in great contrast to the lively period or ferment caused by the Army bill. The respite, however, will be brief, since the Government will soon be busy considering the Army bill budget.

NORMANDIE-THE-SEA, N.J., July 22. -- The most popular diversion down here is to sit in a big easy chair on the hotel veranda with a book in one hand and a long cooling drink in the other, and, while the breezes make you deliehtfully drowsy, you can look out over the rippled surface of the Shrewsbury and dream the hours away.
MILWAUKEE, July 22. -- The Milwaukee National Bank failed to open this morning, and the South Side Savings Bank closed its doors at 10:30 o'clock.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 22. -- This was woman's day for the political equality clubs of Chautauqa County. A large number of equalityites, with their husbands, arrived early on the grounds. The exercises were held in the amphitheatre in the afternoon. Over the chancel were the mottoes, "Governments derive their just power from the consent of the governed," ana "Woman's ballot means enlarged opportunity for doing good."

The Eighth Regiment, Col. George D. Scott. was successful the last week in getting second place in the matter of highest percentage of attendance at the State Camp of Instruction the current season away from the Seventh Regiment. This is a decided feather in the cap of Col. Scott's command, and should prove a substantial encouragement to the officers and enlisted men of the Washington Grays to future welldoing.

The Brooklyns were unable to follow up their winning streak yesterday at Eastern Park. Eight thousand persons rooted for them in vain. They lost Doth games to Baltimore, who outbustted and outplayed them from the start.

The official Government trial of the engines of the big armored cruiser Maine ended at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday afternoon at 2:45 o'clock. The trial, which occupied two days, was a complete success. Not an accident marred the test, and the ponderous machinery, weighing several hundred tons, worked with all the smoothness and nicety of movement which one might expect of a delicately-adjusted time-piece.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 22. -- The season at Nantucket is moving faster now that the weather has come to stay on the mainland. If one wants evidence of this let him pay a visit to the beach in the morning, where the crowd, has more than doubled within the week.
Prosperity continues to attend the career of the roof gardens. Their full capacity is tasted on warm, pleasant eveninge.

Martin Cavanogh, twenty-three years of age, Irving at 217 East Sixty-first Street, and John Mahon. aged twenty-three, of 134 West Sixty-seventh street, were in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning and were promptly discharged.

"Ever so many years ago," related Mrs. Kate Douglas Wiggin to an interested audience at a luncheon last Winter. "I heard a little child say: 'They don't seem to need any bables here.' I put the pitiful little sentence down in my notebook, and when one day long afterward it happened to catch my eye, 'Timothy's Quest' was the result. The first thing I ever wrote came out years ago in St. Nicholas.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 22. -- The attention or persons aboard the steamer Aquilla on Lake Washington yesterday was attracted by the cries of a young woman in a rowboat. whose male companion seemed to be beating her. When the steamer bore down upon them the woman stood erect in the boat and said:

-- A young man standing with a friend in front of a print-shop window gazed intently at an old and popular engraving for some time and then inquired of his companion what it was. "Wny, it's 'The Prodigal bun,'" said he. "Yes, so it says," replied the other, "but what does it mean?" "What!" exclaimed his friend excitedly; "don't you know about the Prodigal Son I Why, it's one of Shakespeare's best plays."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 22. -- Paradoxical as it may seem, this straight-laced prohibition resort is the Mecca, this Summer, for the Jersey politicians. A stroll on the board walK to-night revealed this fact. The slate makers and slate breakers were out in fall force, enjoying the cool breezes and between inhalations, repairing their political fences and concocting schemes to be sprung on their constituents this Fall.

SHELTER ISLAND, July 22. -- Above all other of her sister resorts is beautiful Shelter Island a yachting centre. For weeks Derring Harbor has been covered with trim flyers, resting upon the water like great white seabirds after a long flight. At night the scene is, if possible, more enchanting than by day. As evening closes in the harbor becomes aglow with twinkling lights, like myriads of fireflies in flight or mermaids waving star-tipped wands.

This is the first part of the third volume issued by the University Faculty of Political Science at Columbia in its praise-worthy series. It is the result of a good deal of personal research among colonial records, published and unpublished. By those who study the political structure of the old colonies it will be found interesting, as well as useful.

During the past four or five years there hare been almost continual complaints from different parts of the city aboat the lack or school accommodations. In some of the more densely populated sections the schools have become so congested that hundreds of children who should be in school have instead been turned loose to become idlers in the streets.
Shakespeare's "As you Like It" will be played at the Hotel Avenel Grounds, Pleasure Bay, next Saturday afternoon for charity.

The Rev. HENRY A. ADAMS is a young man who has considerably exercised the minds of his Bishops in more than one diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and eke of laymen, before he made up his mind to depart from its communion, for reasons that have already been, published.

A careless rock blast yesterday wrecked the house 61 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street. Two persons were instantly killed. Six others were injured, and of these two will probably die. The entire neighborhood where the accident occurred was driven wild with panic.

Since the White House basement was remodeled under the direction of Mrs. Harrison. probably no house in the United States contains more complete and convenient arrangements for housekeeping than can be found in the kitchen and laundry of the Executive Mansion.
