BOSTON, July 22. -- The Dolphin, with Secretary of the Navy Herbert on board, arrived from Newport this morning and anchored off the Charlestown Navy Yard at 8:15, being received with the usual honors.

W.H. Byington will be out of a job on Aug. 1. Mr. Byington has teen in charge of the Bureau of Information in the General Post Office. He was appointed to the place when the bureau was created by Postmaster Van Cott.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 22. -- Gen. McGrath, Col. Judson, and Capt. Shepard of Gen. Porter's staff have discovered a scheme by which a number of men not enlisted in the regiments which have thus far enjoyed the pleasures of life in the state camp have managed to rob the State of many hundreds of dollars.

BOSTON, July 23. -- A large and enthusiastic crowd saw the tennis match for the Longwood Cup between the holder, Hovey, and the challenger, Stevens. Only three sots were required to decide the match, but they were long deuce sets, and nearly as many points were played as in yesterday's five-set contest.

The usual large holiday crowd sweltered and perspired in the oppressively humid heat at the Brighton Besch race track yesterday. The fields were up to the ordinary average, and at the first glance looked as if the winners would take a lot of picking. The talent." however, seamed to have no trouble at all in doing so, as five favorites and a well-backed second choice captured the all events on the card.

-- "I often recall with interest," writes Mrs. Luey H. Hooper from Paris to a Philadelphia paper, "the only time that Constant Coquelin and Edwin Booth ever met. They breakfasted with me on the occasion of Booth's first visit to Paris after his London engagement. I longed for an artist to sketch the pair, one as perfect an embodiment of comedy as the other was of tragedy.
BOSTON, July 22. -- There has been a general hanging-en at the few open theatres this week, With no novelties.

Hot weather is a boon to the management of Eldorado. Every afternoon and evening, when the atmosphere of the city is stifling, the Boats of the various lines leading to Eldorado are crowded. "King Solomon," Boloasy Kiralty's great spectacle, is as potent as ever as a drawing card, while the afternoon vaudeville show and band concerts attract large audiences on week days and crowds on Sundays.

SPECULATIONS IN SUN HEAT. -- So far as our present knowledge goes, it would seem that the brightness of any sun-like body is to be attributed solely to the transformation in some fashion of mechanical power into heat. To take our own sun as an example, it is now an assured doctrine that the heat so necessary for our welfare is sustained by the gradual contraction of the solar volume.
Spirits of turpentine dull and easy at 2714@28c. Resins weak and quiet at $1@$1.05 for common to good strained.

Several thousand people gathered about the parade ground in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday to see the drill or the Second Battalon of the Thirteenth Regiment, under the command of Major Charles B. Luscomb. Because of the warm weather only about 250 members of the regiment reported for duty.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., July 22. -- The Republicans of the new Thirty-second District are beginning to ask themselves whether they shall let the Directors of a paint company run their affairs with the ultimate purpose of controlling the State Senate. The establishment of a paint company as a political power is one of the funniest incidents ever known in the politics of New-York State.

SARATOGA, July 22. -- The informal conference last night between Gov. Flower, United States Senators A.P. German and Edward Murphy, and Congressmen Joan R. Fellows and Amos J. Cummings was in reference to legislation at the rapidly-approaching extra session of Congress, and the policy to be pursued in order that prompt results might be attained.

The evidences of activity in the real estate market have been few during the past week, although there has been by no means a cessation of work by brokers and agents. A characteristic feature, indeed, of the present dull season seems to be the shortness of the vacation trips taken by brokers and dealers. The men appear to keep themselves in readiness to do business, and are watching for opportunities.

From, Hall's Journal of Health. The human body is constantly undergoing tissue change. Worn-out particles are cast aside and eliminated from the system, while the new are ever being formed, from the inception of life to its close.

LAKE GEORGE, July 22. -- The Rev. George R. Van De Water, pastor of St. Andrew's Church, New-York, his wife, and his son Arthur are spending the Summer with Commodore John B. Simpson at Villa Nirvana on the Sagamore grounds. The doctor is busily occupied in the morning preparing his Columbia College addresses for the coming academical year.

SOMERSWORTH, N.H., July 22. -- Fire broke out this evening in the cotton storehouse of No. 3 Mill of the Great Fails Manufacturing Company. A large amount of baled cotton was stored there, and the damage by fire and water will probably be heavy.

For several years the ladies of Montclair, N. J., have supported an institution known as the Children's Home. About a year ago the question of a new building for the home was agitated. The people of Montclair responded handsomely to the call for aid, one wealthy lady coming forward and presenting the organization with a plot of ground in a most desirable locality on which to erect the new building of the home.

Commissioner William S. Andrews or the Street-Cleaning Department walked into the offices of the department on the Chambers Street Bide of the Stewart Building at 9:30 o'clock yesterday forenoon and took charge.

LONDON, July 22. -- In ordinary trials the fear of punishment for contempt of court in discussing cases under judicial advisement keeps the editors discreetly silent. No such punishment threatens, however, in connection with court-martial proceedings, and therefore the leader writers are sighing over the folly of Admiral Tryon and the mistakes which they attribute to his subordinates.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 22. -- The midsummer days are passing in delightful fashion at the Water Gap. The guests at the large hotels outnumber those of any previous year within memory, and the ways of enjoying themselves have never been more diversified. The driving, the riding, fishing, and the rest of the pleasant things in the Water Gap's outing list could hardly fall to please the most exacting.

Several hundred persons went out to Fresh Pond, L.I., yesterday to celebrate the completion of the new columbarium or urn hall built by the United Slates Cremation Company, whose crematory adjoins the new building.

The average man of business is not the man who can afford to leave his office when the heat of Summer makes labor a weary burden. The great majority of those in whose hands are the commercial interests ou the city are men who work the year round, who may, perhaps, take a rest for a week or two, but who often find even that vary inconvenient.
LIMA, Ohio, July 22. -- The recent failure of the Citizens' Bank of Ada for a large amount will probably result in the prosecution of the bank people.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 22. -- Hurley S. Taylor, a music dealer on Broad Street and a member of the Excelsior Quartet, bad a disagreeable experience Thursday sight in Boselle, while riding on a bicycle through that town.

Jacob Werner, butcher, of 426 West Fortyfirst Street, who was threatened with, violence by an angry mob after his arrest Friday night for throwing little Angelo Careno into a bonfire, must answer for his alleged brutality before Justice Hogan, in Jefferson Market Police Court, to-morrow morning.

Mosset is not now preferred as a poet by the young men of France. "Other times, other birds; other birds, other songs," said Heine. But the mind of the poet of the "Nuits" was so intimately allied with the mind of those who were twenty years of age from 1850 to 1870 that an accurate knowledge of one entails a fair estimate of the others.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 22. -- If Chicago will not aid Saranac in having a big crowd this season, the Catholic Summer School at Plattsburg will, for this place is already feeling the effects of that institution by way of the hundreds who are taking in a lecture or two at the school and then joining the great army of pleasure seekers who annually visit the Adirondacks to find rest and pleasure, health and happiness.

Speaking for the Governing Committee, President Frank K. Sturgis addressed the members of the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday morning, serving notice that a stop must be pat to the tactics pursued so recklessly by the bears.

An "omelet party" was the unique entertainment which finished, the season in one of last Winter's cooking clubs. Some scoffing men had hinted that flummeries and fol-de-rols were all that the young priestesses of the range and rolling pin could evolve, and they tossed back a jaunty deflance. "Come and judge for yourselves," they cried, and the "omelet party" was the result.

TRENTON, July 22.-- The scheme inaugurated last year by the Mercer County Wheelmen to give mileage medals to all members covering a thousand miles or over has brought out a large number of contestants for these medals this year. Last year fourteen members received medals, while this year there are twenty-seven who are anxious to have one of the silver testimonials dangling from their sweaters.

In the seventy-seventh annual report of the American Bible Society that body tells of the successful work it has accomplished during the past year. Within that period the receipts were $578,930.76 and the expenditures $56,537.01. The sum of $155,238.32 was appropriated for the foreign department during the present year.
PARIS, June 24. -- There is no necessity of introducing our eminent painter, Mr. H. Humphrey Moore.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22. -- Mrs. Minnie Staachni, wife of Charles Staachni of Hilton, was trampled upon by a horse yesterday afternoon. She was frightfully out and bruised, and when dragged from beneath the animal's hoofs she was unconscious and in a short time died. Mrs. Staachni's husband is a gardener in the employ of Hugo Menzel of Boyden Street, Hilton.

The Servia, sailing yesterday, had among her passengers for Liverpool Wulter Besant, the English novelist; Sir Spencer St. John, the British Minister to Mexico; the Rev. John Bartley. Dr. S. Brookfield, G.L. Collins, the Rev. T. Harrington, Mr. and Mrs. J.W. McConnel, Dr. James O'Connor, Capt. Richard Rose, the Rev. L.R. Streeter, and Prof. James Seth.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 22. -- Guns and loud talking were victorious at last night's meeting of the German Military Society at its hall on Twelfth and North Market Streets. The trouble grew out of a beer boycott.

LONDON, July 22. -- James Gordon Bennett, editor of the New-York Herald, who was injured several weeks ago by falling from a coach, is convalescent. He has suffered two relapses, mainly in consequence of weakness caused by loss of blood at the time of the fall and by close continement to the house ever since. He hopes to go soon on a yaching tour with a view to restoring his health.

Copyrighted, 1893, by the New-York Times. LONDON, July 22. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- The Siamese lamb has forty-eight hours in which to decide with what kind of sauce it prefers to be eaten by the French wolf. It will take about the same space of time for Europe to make up its mind whether the incident is going to stop there or not.

The suit in which the Government asks that the original telephone patent of the Bell Company shall be annulled is still in the court before which it was brought, and has not emerged from the testimony stage, although it is seven years old, and the very patent whose validity is involved has expired after living for its allotted time of seventeen years.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 22. -- Bay Shore is eclipsing its well-earned record as one of the most enjoyable and attractive spots for a Summar's stay. This season is an exceptionally brilliant one and the hotel and cottages are now full of agreeable people for whom the place has a charm easy to understand after one has once been a visitor.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 22. -- When Goodyear discovered the process of hardening rubber he little suspected the important part, this material would play in the life at to-day.
LONG BRANCH, N.J. July 22. -- A little life has been instilled into the Branch this week, and if the hot weather continues the long faces of the hotel men may relax into smiles once more.

Lieut. Gov. Sheehan was at the Hoffman Honse yesterday morning and spent moat of the forenoon in consultation with the Buffalo men who came to this city to welcome him home from Europe. Among them were August F. Soheu, Police Commissioner of Buffalo; George J. Zillig, Frank F. Reynolds, Matthew Scanlan, and John H. O'Brien.

It appears that the nocturnal cat has risen in Brooklyn to the proportions of a public nuisance which it has become necessary to abate. The abatement has been undertaken, as readers of THE TIMES are aware, by members of the Midnight Band of Mercy, and they propose to show mercy at midnight to themselves and their neighbors, and incidentally to the cats, by tenderly chloroforming notorious performers into silence.

It has long been a problem with the wheelmen that frequent Lone Island for a riding ground as to the best way to cross from one side of the island to the other without encountering bad stretches or sandy roadways.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 22. -- Miss Katharine Runyon is at West New-Brighton, S.I.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Lillian Russell is ill. On Tuesday night the Columbia Theatre was closed, and it has not been reopened. Miss Russell's illness was not considered serious at first, and announcements were made that the house would be reopened next Monday night, when "La Cigale" would again be seen. But there can be no doubt that she is severely ill with diphtheritic sore throat.
The Mohammedan and the Brahmin of high caste met, made salaams, and presented the compliments of the season, the one to the other, is the corridors or toe Hotel Waldorf yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- The gates of the World's Columbian Exposition will be closed to-morrow, but Director General Davis will probably be called to the bar of Judge Stein's court on the following day and arraigned for contempt of court in not observing the injunction prohibiting the closing or the gates on Sunday.

NEWARK, July 22. -- Lovers of boating saw some grand racing on the Passaic here to-day. It was the fourth annual ragatta of the Middle States Regatta Association, an organization composed of wide-awake amateur oarsmen and promoters of rowing.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, CLINTON COUNTY, N.Y., July 22. -- Time cannot be said to hang heavily at this charming resort. The pleasures afforded are of such a varied character that the most captious find criticism impossible. The beach, which is firm and gently sloping, is especially attractive in the early morning and late afternoon, and the gay laughter of the bathing parties awakens pleasant echoes.

LAKE LUZERNE, N.Y., July 22. -- The Luzerne season has begun most auspiciouly. Although the season will not be at its height until August, well-known visitors from New-York, Brooklyn, Troy, and Albany are flocking to this pleasant resort among the foothills of the Adirondacks even now. Many of the families at the Wayside Inn and the cottages have been regular Summer visitors at Luzerne for a score of years.

-- Many pleasing stories are being told of the late Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia since his death, among them this: Some years ago he lent money to a business man in Philadelphia, who was unfortunate and finally failed. The man took to the banker an insurance policy on his life, saying it was all he had. Mr. Drexel afterward paid the premium until the man died, leaving an only daughter.

Though GEORGE C. PERKINS of California has served in the Senate of the State and been its Governor, the main reason for his appointment by Gov. MARKHAM to succeed the late LELAND STANFORD in the United States Senate is said to be his ability to contribute $100,000 to the Republican campaign fund in the next State canvass.

-- The Scranton Press Club will hold a rowing regatta at Lake Ariel, in Wayne County, Penn., which is about twenty-three miles from soranton, on Saturday, Aug. 26. There will be nino events, as follows: Junior single sculls, intermediate single sculls, senior single sculls, junior double souils, senior double aculle, junior four-oared shell, senior four-cared shell, intermediate four-cared shell, and senior four-cared gig.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 23. -- Though the change in the Nation's social and political system since 1860 has been startling beyond anything in the country's history, yet in all this bouleversement there has been a certain degree of advantage, until the South, which some of its old-time statesmen and publicists would have had us believe could not exist without slavery, has really become richer in material wealth than it was before the disruption.

The Long Branch steamer Mary Patten on her return trip to this city last night from Long Branch became disabled off Sandy Hook by the breaking of the walking beam, and did not reach the Battery wharf until after midnight.

The police have been able to get no clue to the robber or robbers who entered the ticket office of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, at the Grand Central Station, Saturday evening, and stole about $800 from the cash drawer.

The men who have their fortunes invested in silver smelting are not discouraged by the present situation or by the outlook. Nathaniel Witherell, Vice President of the Consolidated Kansas City Smelting and Refining Company, said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES Saturday:

PROVIDENCE, July 23. -- There has been virtually no change in the situation of the local money market during the past week. Regular customers are easily accommodated by the banks at from 6 12 to 7 cent, on good twoname paper or collateral loans, but, on the other hand, few outside offerings find any market even at extreme rates.

-- The five-mile members' handicap race of the St. George's Athletic Club was decided Friday evening on the new grounds of the club at Monitor Park, Weehawken. The track is live laps to the mile. Twenty men started, the result being as follows: T. Nixon first, C. Duval second, J.Renzland third, J.W. Kumff fourth. Time -- 33:05.
Edward Bloom, eighteen years old, of 78 Varet Street, Williamsburg, died yesterday morning from bleeding at the nose.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, July 23. -- Heretofore it has been the practice for many of the regiments which have been in camp to have a quiet time Sunday and to begin the real work of the week Monday morning, but the Twenty-second of New-York City deviated from this custom by having a practical school of instruction this afternoon.

The thirty days' racing season at Saratoga will begin to-day. There will be fifteen regular days and a like number of extra days. The first race will be started each day at 11 o'clock A.M., and there will be five events on the card. Quite a number of Western horses are booked for the handicap and stake races, and the prospect of an excellent season is good.

If a movement in which ex-Congressman John J. Quinn, George W. Gibbons, John Healy, D. A. Spellisey, and other Irish Americana of this city are interested proves successful, petitions will be presented to both houses of the next Congress asking that the State Department institute an investigation into the treatment of Irish-Americans confined in English jails for political offenses.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 23. -- Heart Village is fighting a forest fire to-night. Several business buildings are threatened.

-- The Harlem Wheelmen made a club run yesterday to Babylon, L.L., and return. Among the members who participated were Capt. E.H. Frost, H.P. Boese, Charles A. Fulle, Morris Friedenreich, and W.D. Wehrenberg. They made an early start leaving the clubhouse, at Lenox Avenue and West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, at 6 o'clock and riding to the East Ninety-ninth Street Ferry.

A boyish-looking young man wandered about the corridors of the Imperial Hotel Saturday night. He was smooth shaven and had a ruddy complexion. The ordinary observer would have set him down as one of the social leaders of Pinxville, Vt.
FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., July 23. -- The strong gale blowing to-day from the northwest played havoc with small boats, many of which were blown from their moorings and tossed upon the beach.

There was published on Saturday a long interview with. Mr. DEPEW concerning the causes of the prevailing financial stringency and the remedy that should be applied. The opinions of Mr. DEPEW are clearly indicated by the following brief extract:

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- There is some talk in the War Department of leaning a new volume of the Army Regulations. The latest edition was in 1889, since which date there have been many amendments, until a corrected copy of these rules bears very little resemblance to the original work.

Among the arrivals on the steamer Paris Friday night was Marcus R. Mayer, the well-known theatrical manager. As he stepped ashore he was met by a number of friends and taken up town to the Gilsey House. Mr. Mayer was looking the picture of health. He was seen by a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter Saturday in reference to his trip abroad.

The trolley secured another victim in Brooklyn yesterday. Charles Dowd, ten years old, who lived at 98 Luquer Street, South Brooklyn, was run over and instantly killed at Court and Nelson Streets about 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

HERMOSILLO, Mexico, July 23. -- An American miner named Charles Hoogland went to the chief officer of the Custom House guards in the border town of Jasade, this State, in the Winter of 1890 and reported that in the night a band of smugglers would cross the line into the United States with a large cargo of dutiable goods.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 23. -- Lee Walker, the negro who assaulted Miss Mollie McCadden near Bond station, and on the same day assaulted a colored girl, and who was captured Friday, was lynched early this morning in spite of the fact that twenty-five well-armed Deputy Sheriffs guarded the jail and that Sheriff McLendon had given it out that the mob should not triumph.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Those who watch ordnance matters with any closeness are awaiting with interest the test of the new nickel-steel gun which is building by way of experiment at the Washington gun shops. The nickel-steel forcings have bean on hand some time, and everything about the gun is ready for assembling so soon as William Sellers, the Philadelphia machinery man, gets his new furnace erected here.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 23. -- The action of the State Board of Railroad Assessors in increasing the assessed valuation of railways is likely to result in bankrupting some sixty or seventy counties and in closing as many as 400 public schools in the western and central portions of Kansas. It has already been officially given out that the railway companies will refuse to pay their taxes which will become due in December.

The French Line steamship La Bretague, which arrived from Havre yesterday, had a number of prominent people on board. Among them was Mgr. Denis Latas, Archbishop of Zante. He obtained special permission from the King of Greece to attend the religious congress which is to be held in Chicago.
The number of victims -- forgers, embezzlers, defaulters, murderers, and suicides -- demanded by and provided for the gambling element about the nice tracks is enormous and startling.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 23. -- Frank H. Farrington, Jr., of Syracuse has been appointed receiver of the affairs of Selleck Brothers, the embarrassed real estate dealers at this city and Syracuse.
PARIS, July 24. -- At midnight it was stated that Siam's reply to France's ultimatum is considered unsatisfactory.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Belva A. Lockwood, the noted peacemaker, does not purpose taking a hand in the fight which is now raging in the New-York branch of the Universal Peace Union. She declares that she has nothing to do with the controversy, and advises the belligerent members of the society to practice what they preach and arbitrate their differences if they cannot settle them in any other peaceful way.

LONDON, July 23. -- The passengers on board the Guion Line steamer Arizona, Capt. Brooks, from New-York, which arrived at Queenstown at 4:35 P.M. to-day, report that that veese had a very narrow escape from collision with an unknown Red Star Line steamer during a thick fog on the 17th inst. The latter steamer crossed the Arizona's bows not fifty yards distant.

A quick conception, the journalist's art, father than that of the essayist's, made Grace Greenwood distinguished. She had the power of discriminating, and knew exactly what the public wanted. It is a cleverness few possess to say anything so it can be at once understood, and clearness was one of Grace Green wood's attributes.

Our correspondent at Topeka draws a gloomy picture of the condition of the western part of Kansas. His story is based upon the results of personal inquiry and observation in eleven counties. In two of these there has been no rain for ten months. Many settlements have been abandoned by all of their inhabitants, and in other places only a very few persons remain.

CITY ISLAND. N.Y., July 23. -- The following yachts passed hero to-day, bound east: Steam yachts Vinita, Mr. Charles E. Hill; Vamoose, Mr. W.B. Hearst: Javelin, Mr. C.R. Flint: Cora, Mr. John A. Morris, and Isoleno, Mr. John H. Flagler; schooner yacht Atlantic, Mr. C. Barnum Seeley.

TRENTON, N.J., July 23. -- Eight Senators are to be elected in New-Jersey next November. This will give zest to the Fall campaign, because these Senators will be in office when the successor to United States Senator McPherson is chosen. It is safe to predict that the senior Senator will succeed himself.

We have already deplored the dearth of principalities and powers at the World's Fair. The drawing power of royal personages upon the sons and equally upon the daughters of the prairie have not yet been fairly tried. It is true that the fair is already, as world's fairs go, assured of a very comfortable success, and that the "record " in point of attendance is second only to that of Paris in 1889.

Mayor Boody of Brooklyn has called a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen for this afternoon at 1 o'clock, to reconsider their recent grant of the trolley franchise to the Broadway Railroad Company. It is has intention to return the franchise without his signature and to request the Aldermen to amend the grant so as to omit Livingston and Madison Streets and Greens and Gates Avenues from the proposed trolley routes.
The work of the trotters yesterday at Fleetwood was carried on under decidedly disadvantageous conditions. The drought and a strong, hot wind made the track as dry as powder.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed in increase in reserve of $3,012,550. The banks now hold $1,256,550 less than the legal requirement. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $4,308,300, an increase in specie at $1,584,400, an increase in legal tenders of $503,700, a decrease in deposits of $3,697,800, and an increase in circulation of $129,000.
There was a story published in one of the morning newspapers yesterday to the effect that Joseph Jefferson, the great actor, was dying at his Summer home in Buzzard's Bay, of a cancerous affection.

His Highness the King of Kings, Jajat Jit Singh, Prince of Kapurthala, the East Indian potentate who is temporarily in this city, ate clams at Manhattan Beach yesterday while many thousand people watched him.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The test of the biggest gun of the navy will soon take place at the naval ordnance proving ground on the Potomac. Two of these guns are completed, and practically ready for testing, the interest, of course, centring on the trial of the first gun. The testing of the twelve-inch gun met with, so much success that the experts are led to expect something correspondingly greater of the next larger calibre.

NEW-YORK. MONDAY, July 24 -- A.M. The lowest level of prices which has prevailed on the Stock Exchange in twenty years was made during the week which closed on Saturday. The depression was brought about by liquidation for both foreign and domestic account and by sales by the bear clique.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23. -- Lincoln Guard, Company A, Fourth Regiment, N.G.S. N.J., arrived here at 12:15 this afternoon, after an uneventful march of fourteen miles, having broken camp and started from Red Bank at 7 o'clock this morning. The guardsmen were met out on the road at Deal Beach by Company A of the Third Regiment, located here.

William Q. Judge, General Secretary of the American Section of the Theosophical Society, has taken another step toward Oriental distinction. He has become a Juggernaut. He has learned to ride a bicycle.

DISTINGUISHED MARKSMEN TO REPORT AT BELLEVUE RIFLE RANGE. -- The following-named officers, distinguished marksmen, will report in person Aug. 6 to the commanding officer at the Bellevue Ride Range, near Bellevue, Neb., to participate in the coming animal cavalry competition: Capts. Joseph Garrard, Henry H. Wright, and Matthias W. Day, Ninth Cavalry, Fort Robinson, Neb.

From the New-York Tribune. With the aid of the Saturday half holiday there was crowd enough at Monmouth yesterday to make a showing. The words "a respectable showing" had almost escaped, but that is according to the point of view from which the showing is looked at. In proportion it was a fair crowd, but in character it could have been improved upon.

TOLEDO, Ohio. July 23. -- The town of Paulding, a place of some 3,500 inhabitants, forty miles west of this city, was almost wholly destroyed by fire this forenoon, and, but for prompt assistance by the Fire Departments of Van Wert and other neighboring towns, scarcely a building would be left.

"Jack" Lewis, a bookmaker, was held in $1,000 bail for trial on a charge of grand larceny in the West Brighton Police Court yesterday. Lewis has been making a book at the Brighton Beach race track since the beginning of the meeting. Saturday the favorites were too much for him. He discovered that he did not have enough money to pay off his customers, and was about to "welch" when arrested by Policeman Whalen.

There is a very well defined feeling among some of the old-line Tammany men -- those who have been with the organization in stormy political weather as well as in the fair days of success -- that men who have come over from the County Democracy within the past few years, and have been given good offices by Tammany, are discriminating against the old Tammany men.

BERLIN, July 23. -- The departure of the Prussian and Imperial Deputies from this city and the absence of Emperor William and several Ministers on their vacations have caused the temporary suspension of strife in domestic politics, and left the minds of Berlin editors and politicians free to consider international questions.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., July 23. -- Rockaway Beach had a twenty-five-thousand-dollar fire this afternoon which at one time threatened to repeat the disastrous one of last Fall when nearly half of the popular resort was wiped out.
HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y., July 23. -- The arrival of the officers of the Russian fleet yestrday afternoon was an event long to be remembered by the 700 guests at this mammoth hotel.
Little Lucian Martinez has been so zealously guarded from physical and moral harm by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children that he is now dying at Roosevelt Hospital.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23. -- The success of the Middle States regatta was the one topic of talk among the carsmen and their friends here today. At the various boathouses along the Passaic members of clubs told over the story of the races and discussed the merits of craws and single soullers.

Gen. John W. Noble of St. Louis, ex-Secretary of the Interior, sat in the corridor or the Windsor Hotel Saturday. With a white straw hat he encouraged the midday breeze, occasionally wiping his forehead and stroking his whitish beard. His knees were crossed. In one hand he held an umbrella, which from, time to time he jabbed vigorously at the marble floor while he talked with a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Great crowds yesterday visited the scene of Saturday's blasting disaster on Grattan Lyman's land in East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, between Fourth and Madison Avenues. A platoon of police from the station in East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street kept the crowd from swarming into the partly-wrecked tenement and from climbing over the disrupted bed of rock.

The falsity of the story about the attack of the poacher Alexandria upon the war vessel Mohican seems now to be established by proof sufficient to convince even the stoutest believers in that wonderful yarn. It has been conclusively proved that no such extraordinary encounter could have occurred at the time or the place spoken of.

Thomas Paine's writings, as edited by Moncure D. Conway for publication by the Putnams, will till four volumes. The edition will include his social, religious, and literary writings, as well as those which pertain to politics.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 23. -- A concession has been granted by the Department of Fomento to the Pearl Fishing Company of San Jose for the fishing of pearl oysters around San Jose Island, which is situated in the Gulf of California in front of Ensenada de Dolores and Punta del Mechudo, to the north of the Island of Espiritu Santo.

CRANSTONS, N.Y., July 23. -- Twenty West Point soldiers of Company E. Engineers, and a similar number from the cavalry detachment, engaged in a hand-to-hand fight at Nissen's notorious dancing pavilion in this village last night, just before midnight, and the result is that several bruised and lacerated heads are being nursed to-day at the Soldiers' Hospital.
The money market showed some improvement The supply on call was good and loans were made at 3 @11 cent., the average being between 5 and 6 cent.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- If there is a controversy in the New-York branch of the Peace Society. Mrs. Mary Frost Ormsby does not propose to be drawn into it unless she shall be called upon by misstatements or libelous statements to defend herself.

The number of people who make a study of economic questions and acquire an understanding of the principles that underlie the issues of tariff and currency is small. In ordinary times, when industrial and commercial affairs are running along under normal conditions, the bulk of the people gives little attention to such questions.

The most formidable vessel of war which ever visited American waters made her appearance in New-York harbor yesterday. She is the Russian armor-clad Nicolai I., one of the latest additions to Russia's powful fleet.

CAMP WIRTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 23. -- The first night of the encampment was marked by a series of incidents and episodes that, in some cases, were extremely amusing, and indicated on the part of the sentinels a desire to fulfill all of the instructions imposed upon them for vigilance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 23. -- The appointment of George O. Perkins as United States Senator to succeed the late Leland Stanford is a complete surprise to the politicians. The name of Mr. Perkins had been "mentioned," as had that of every prominent Republican in the State, but he was supposed to be entirely overshadowed by others.

"I want you to arrest that man over there on the corner, he robbed me of 25,000f. in Marseilles," said an excited Italian, rushing up to Policeman McConnell of the Mercer Street Station, at the corner of Bleecker and Wooster streets, Saturday night.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 23. -- When the Legislature of this State passed the anti-poolroom law, it was supposed it had dealt a death blow to pool-rooms in the cities of this State, but the bookmakers will not let go their hold on the business and already have in view several ways or getting around the law.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Naval officers are finding something to discuss in the way in which Admiral Harmony was placed on the retired list. One officer who knows something of naval methods and customs characterizes the action as one of "unseemly haste" not justified by the situation.

BED BANK, N. J., July 23. -- The Shrewsbury Yacht Club held its second race of the season yesterday afternoon. During the early part of the present week Police Superintendent Byrnes, who is a Summer cottager here and also a member of the Shrews bury Yacht Club, presented to the club a pretty pennant with the understanding that it was to be sailed for Dy Class E yachts only.

HAVANA, Cuba, July 22. -- The recent death of Capt.-Gen. Arias has cast gloom over the island and throughout Spain, as he had gained the confidence of the Cabinet and the majority of the people by his wise administration. Without being a partisan politician, he held a high place in the esteem of the Foreign Minister at Madrid.

The Regatta Committee of the New-York Yacht Club has issued a circular containing the list of events to be decided daring the cruise and details of the boats for the use of club members. The racing events are:

Two young men with bandaged heads' and a third young man whose legs and back were black and blue, he said, stood in a row yesterday morning before Justice Hogan in Jefferson Market Police Court. They were Daniel Lee and Thomas Lee of 501 Canal Street, and Lawrence Collins of 10 Battery Place.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 23. -- A decision of great importance to the lumber interests of Minnesota has been made by Judge Mitchell of the Supreme Court. It reverses the decision of the lower court and allows association lumbermen to join together and injure the business of individual competitors, raising or lowering prices at will.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 23. -- A trip through the farming district of Northwestern Connecticut discloses the fact that farm help is very scarce. The farmers, who mourn the absence of laborers to help them till the farms, do not attempt to account for the scarcity, but that is the condition of things all through the farming districts of Northwestern Connecticut, and principally in Litchfield County.

Major John A. Tibbitts, soldier, lawyer, and journailst, died Saturday at New-London, Conn., of Bright's disease. He was born in New-London forty-nine years ago. Graduating from Williston Seminary, Easthampton, Mass., at the age of eighteen he enlisted in the Fourteenth Regiment and went to the front. He was twice wounded at Antietam, and was promoted to Second Lieutenant of Company F of New-Britain.

The remarks of German financiers on the question of silver contained in our dispatches from Berlin indicate anything but a disposition in Germany to return to bimetallism. Dr. GEBHARD, Governor of the Deutsche Bank, declares that bimetallism is dead and "anybody attempting to revive it will be merely flogging a dead horse."

TRENTON. N.J., July 22. -- Just as the caviare sandwich becomes popular, the sturgeon becomes scarce. The Jersey fishermen who grow rich making kegs of caviare for the Hamburg canners to repack for the American trade have grown despondent. It is not generally known that there is at the lower end of New-Jersey a great industry that represents the investment of $500,000, and gives employment to several thousand men.

BUFFALO, N.Y July 23. -- The financial affairs of Meech Brothers, theatrical managers, are becoming as complicated an a crystal maze. A summons and complaint was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office in an action begun by John T. McLaughlin, as assignee of John H. and Henry L. Meech, against George W. Wheeler and Mary Wheeler, his wife, and several others, tenants of the Academy of Music Building.

From the Baltimore Sun. For the six months ended with the 1st of July there were 132 corporations formed in Baltimore, with an aggregate capital stock of $3,476,000, as shown by the charter records of the Superior Court. The capital stock of the incorporations is divided among sixty-one of the number.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The White City was deserted to-day and the warm sun shone upon desolate thoroughfares, lonely Columbian Guards, and a few inhabitants of Midway Plaisance who had left that cosmopolitan quarter early in the day to view the big buildings. The Sunday-closing order was rigorously enforced, and any person who entered the exposition grounds had to prove that his presence there was absolutely necessary.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 23. -- There having been so many conflicting reports regarding the alleged failure of crops in Western Kansas, and the destitution that naturally would follow such failure, a visit was made to that section for the purpose of making a personal inspection and ascertaining the truth. The results of that visit have been the continuation of the tales told of distress, as well as of the abandonment of the country.

GENEVA, July 23. -- The sole political issue of any interest in the Twenty-sixth Senatorial District at the present time concerns the nomination of a Republican candidate for State Senator to succeed the Hon. Charles T. Saxton of ballot-reform fame. The contest has been carried on thus far in a quiet and earnest manner, and is now rapidly approaching white heat.
The fact that the Navy Department Intends to do something toward changing the obstructing anchorage of the Russian war vessels in the North River has caused a great deal of talk in maritime circles.

Terence V. Powderly has at last decided to give up the office of General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor. He will not be a candidate again at the next election of the order, which is to be held soon, nor will he accept if re-elected.
GRAVESEND, L.I., July 24. -- The annual picnic of the Brooklyn Riflemen, which was held at Woodlawn Park to-day, was interrupted by a distressing incident.

There was plenty of excitement at Brighton Beach yesterday. The racing in itself was particularly interesting, but the number of accidents, one of which cost Jockey Thomas Flynn his life, furnished what the races failed to.

The forthcoming armor test at the naval proving grounds will be in some respects of peculiar interest and importance, as being that of a Harveyized plate, one of a lot furnished for actual use on our war vessels. Hitherto the trials of armor treated by the Harvey process have been, if we rightly remember, confined to plates constructed simply for experimental purposes.

The theatrical colony availed itself last night of the hospitality of the management of Eldorado and witnessed the King Solomon spectacle from the vast amphitheatre at Weehawken. Among the guests were Roland Reed, George Salisbury, Mrs. Sol Smith, Kate Mayhew, Louise Valentine, Olive Gates, George Ranger, Arthur Wellsley, Sydney Price, Ada Gilman, John C. Rice, John Devoe, Nellie Whiting, Fred Wilson, Gertrude Perry, and Emma Calef.

MISS JOHNSTONE BENNETT arrived in the city from Paris Sunday, and will begin rehearsals of her new play, "Fanny," written by Sims and Raleigh at the Standard Theatre next Monday. Only the first act of the piece has yet been received by Manager Charles Frohman, but he expects the rest by Thursday's mail from London. W.J. Fergnson and Robert Cotton will play the opposite parts to Miss Bennett, who has a character role.

Since the exodus of householders began in the district east of Central Park early in the Summer, the policemen who patrol that part of the city have had frequent occasions to notice the disappearance from the outer doors of vacant houses of door knobs, bell-pulls, hinges, door plates, and bronze and brass ornaments of every kind which could be removed with screwdrivers.

To the Editor of the New-Yark Times. The present partisan controversy as to the cause of our present financial derangement recalls to my mind a lecture that was delivered before the Reform Club in New-York otter the election and inauguration of Mr. Harrison in 1888-9, and afterward published in one of our daily papers, in which was predicted, substantially, everything that has since taken place, including oar present silver orisis.
SING SING, N.Y., July 24. -- Maurice Tretten, a convict in Sing Sing Prison, escaped this afternoon.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 25 cent. The average rate was about 4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.
Congressman Timothy J. Campbell's brother, Thomas Campbell, will not be disturbed probably in his possession of his restaurant stalls in the new West Washington Market.

-- A Natchez shoemaker advertises to sell shoes at 50 cents a foot. An Ohio shoemaker who was asked what became of the one-legged man's odd shoe, replied that economical customers, suffering from that affliction buy a pair of shoes, and, if they have only the right foot, use the right shoe for a dress shoe. Then wetting thoroughly the left shoe, they drive in a right last, letting the shoe dry on the last.

ORILLIA, Ontario, July 24. -- Gaudaur defeated Hanlan to-day with the greatest case. He covered the three-mile coarse in 19:53. Hanlan rowed the distance in 20:05, the same time he made on Saturday, allowing for the delay caused by the collision then. The water was perfectly smooth when the men started at 6 o'clock. There was very little betting.

The general agents of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia, to the number of about 100, will hold their annual meeting at the Plaza Hotel to-day. They will begin the day with a drive through Central Park, and, after visiting the museums, will take dinner at Gabe Case's restaurant in the park.
CHICAGO, July 24. -- John Boyd Thacher, speaking of the methods of the Bureau of Awards, said this evening:

Priscilla J. Joachimsen, President of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, died at 61 East Seventy-fifth Street yesterday morning after a long illness. She was the widow of ex-Judge Joachimsen, and, with him, founded the charitable institution of which she was President.

RED BANK, N.J., July 24. -- Superintendent Thomas Byrnes of New-York told a correspondent for THE NEW-YORK TIMES to-day that he had not the slightest intention of resigning from the police force. He made this remark with emphasis and characterized the story in a New-York morning paper to the effect that he intended to resign from his position as an atrocious fabrication.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, July 24 -- P.M. The bears raided the market at the opening to-day, and with considerable success, as there were apparently no buying orders. But the moment pressure relaxed the recovery was quite as pronounced as had been the previous weakness. After the first hour the market became steady and very dull. Toward the close, however, the bear leaders became aggressive once more, and the final dealings were marked by weakness and irregularity.

BROOKLYN PERSONALS. -- Much interest has been felt in Brooklyn society over the engagement of Miss Polly Pratt to Livingston Emery. Miss Pratt is the daughter of Justice Pratt. Mr. Emery comes of an old New-England family. He was graduated from Columbia College in the class of '86.

The yachts of the New-York Yacht-Racing Association are now cruising on the Sound. The fleet sailed from Echo Bay, New-Rochelle, yesterday morning at 8 o'clock for Black Pock. Admiral B.F. Sutton was on the schooner Loyal and Fleet Captain A.J. Prime sailed on the schooner Florida. Quite a large fleet of little boats started out. They represented twenty-six clubs.

Hamilton Willcox, of whom Mrs. Emma Beckwith has spoken with indignant scorn as a man who has been trying "to boom himself as President of the New-York Peace Society," was shown the interview with Mrs. Beckwith printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday and asked if he would comment upon it.

Justice CHARLES DEAN LONG of the Michigan Supreme Court should have prevented his friends from protesting against the action taken by the Pension Bureau with respect to his pension. Their protests have had the effect of bringing before the public the history of that pension, which includes certain facts that no true friend of Justice LONG endowed with ordinary common sense can regard without a feeling of shame.

The suit of Delia Keegan against Russell Sage for $100,000 damages had its first public airing yesterday. It came up for argument before Judge Bookstaver of the Court of Common Pleas on the motion of the plaintiff to vacate the extension of twenty days granted to Mr. Sage on July 14 to enable him to put in an amended answer to the complaint.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 24. -- That little Minnie Burch of Jamestown came to her death by arsenical poisoning will in all probability be the verdict of the Coroner's Jury which has been nvestigating her mysterious death. It cannot be very well anything else. If the evidence of the medical experts is to be believed, and the reason the verdict has not already been rendered is a desire to ascertain just where the blame lies.

In the New-York Real Estate Salesroom at 111 Broadway yesterday Mr. William Kennelly sold under foreclosure the three five-story brick tenements 305, 307, and 309 East One Hundred and First Street, each 25 by 100.11, at $8,000 each, to James A. Roosevelt, the plaintiff in the action. The other announced sales were postponed.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Prof. Harrington of the Weather Bureau, in reply to the report that he felt aggrieved by the recent action of Secretary Morton in regard to himself and the Weather Bureau, makes this explicit statement:

BANGKOK, July 24. -- M. Pavie, French Minister Resident, has lowered the flags over his offices, and has notified the Siamese Government that he will leave the city to go aboard the French war ship Inconstante on Wednesday. He has requested the Government to provide pilots to conduct the Lutin and Comete down the river.

Charles Hugo of 229 West Sixty-ninth Street, who was arrested Sunday in Central Park for stealing his own dog, was released from custody yesterday by Judge Koch of the Yorkville Police Court, and his dog was restored to him by the Park Police.

-- Helen Keller, the wonderful deaf, dumb, and blind girl, who has been taught so much despite her triple affliction, has been visiting Prof. Graham Bell in Washington, She has lately taken up the study of French, and already has a good knowledge of the language. In a letter to a friend she once wrote: "I am always delighted when any one writes me a beautiful thought which I can treasure in my memory forever.
The Brooklyn ring is having a sorry time of it trying to get the street-railroad franchise muddle into such shape that it will appear less disgraceful than it now does.

SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., July 24. -- The Thirteenth Regiment, N.G.S.P., is holding its annual encampment at Montrose to-day. The camp was visited by Gov. Pattison and staff. Gen. Snowden of Philadelphia and staff, Gen. Gobin, commanding the Third Brigade, and staff, ana Capt. Rogers of the regular army, who has been detailed by the War Department to inspect and report upon the efficiency of the National Guard of Pennsylvania.

The first of the half-fare excursion trains from New-York to Chicago started yesterday morning -- one on the Erle Railway and one on the Baltimore and Ohio Road. The passengers who went by the Erie paid $18 for a round-trip ticket, which will be good for a return passage within a period of ten days. The Baltimore and Ohio tourists paid $17 for the same privilege.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 24. -- The Hotel Champlain has a distinguished guest in the person of a young man with an income of $400,000 a year. He is the Nawab of Rampur, and arrived at the hotel this morning from Montreal with a long retinue of companions and retainers.
WEST NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., July 24. -- The staten Island Athletic Club last night began what it has designated a "Roman Holiday."

Freight traffic into and out of Chicago continues to be exceedingly unsatisfactory to the roads. East-bound shipments of dead freight last weeK Buffered a considerable decrease as compared with those of the previous week. They amounted in the aggregate to 47,359 tons, against 50,257 tons tot the previous week, and 62,240 for the corresponding week last year.

The Staten Island Cricket Club continued its handicap tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Livingston, S.I. The events were men's singles and men's doubles, both of which have been finished through the second round.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The Treasury Department is informed that fifteen persons, eight of thorn ex-Federal officials, have been indicted at Portland, Oregon, for smuggling Chinese and opium into the United States.

The Government has begun an investigation into the immigration of Chinese at this port. Extensive frauds are charged in the administration of the Chinese Exclusion act, and hundreds of Chinamen are alleged to have been smuggled in on fraudulent certificates or on fraudulent certification of genuine certificates, by perjury and false impersonation.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 24. -- in 1892 the Legislature of South Carolina passed a Naval Militia bill authorizing the formation of a battalion of Naval Reserves, and three companies of militia from coast counties -- the Chicora Rifles of Berkeley, the Lafayette Artillery of Charleston, and the Beaufort Volunteer Artillery of Beaufort -- immediately thereafter were mustered in and inspected just prior to July, 1892, the tank and file numbering 208.

Ex-Alderman Richard B. Leech, a member of the May Grand Jury in Brooklyn, said yesterday that that Grand Jury wanted to investigate a public scandal, hut was prevented from doing so by the refusal of the District Attorney and his assistants to leave the Grand Jury room while witnesses were being examined in relation to the subject.

Policeman Pollock saw a man on the roof of 314 Bowery at 4 o'clock Sunday morning noting in a suspicious manner. Pollock made his way to the top of the lodging house at 302 and then discovered that the man had broken the souttle of 314 and had entered the cigar factory of Louis Jacoby.

Daniel F. Beatty, the organ manufacturer of Washington, N.J., was arrested yesterday afternoon at the Christopher Street Ferry in this city, on his way home. An indictment found in Vermont charges him with misusing the United States mails in sending circulars through the country misrepresenting his wares.

The Rev. Dr. I.K. Funk, Treasurer of Prohibition Park, Staten Island, and editor of a temperance paper in this city, denounced the Board of Health at a meeting of the Prohibitionists at the park Sunday afternoon. He said the Board of Health had for a number of years issued a circular in Summer advising mothers during the heated months to give their infants whisky if necessary.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 24. -- This has been a more than ordinarily interesting day in the State Camp, and in many respects it was one of the most important in the history of the camp. The chief feature of the day was the work done by the Signal Corps in flashing messages to New-York by means of the heliograph.

There is a peculiar lack of consistency and fairness in the policy adopted in Kansas and apparently widely favored among the farmers of the West in the treatment of railroads. In past years it was a common charge that too much money was made in the construction of Western railroads, and that capital was inflated and rates for transportation, made inordinately high.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- It is said at the Navy Department that Admiral Harmony's recent retirement was in strict accordance with his written request. He cabled the department from Hongkong March 13, asking to the ordered home and retired upon arrival in the United States. He suggested June 7 as the most convenient date for his departure.

OANTON, Minn., July 24. -- Excitement over the Catholic church "window miracle," or "miracle window," has been growing at a rapid rate during the past ten days, and hundreds of infirm people are again coming here with the hope of being cured of their ailments by prayer under the "miracle window." This, too in spite of the fact that the window was removed during the Winter by order or Bishop Cotter.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 24. -- There is an interesting fight in progress between the town authorities of Bloomfield and the Phoenix Hose Association, which, after having tried to sell the fire apparatus, has announced an intention to lease the hose house to the Montclair Bicycle Club. The town authorities propose to ask the Court at Chancery to decide whether the town or the firemen own the property.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Acting Mint Director Preston this afternoon, in response to his counter offer, purchased 50,000 ounces of silver at $0.6960 per ounce. There is no expectation of purchasing the full quota of 4,500,000 ounces of silver per month.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- The commercial travelers are gathering in Chicago from every nook and corner of the country to attend the Columbian demonstration. Last night 890 came from Cincinnati and an hour later 250 more reached the city from Cleveland. This morning every train that arrived was filled with the pilgrims. Two trainloads are en route from Duluth by way of St. Paul.

From the New-York Tribune. A Western bookmaker, who was discussing the situation with one of the best-known of the Eastern layers of odds, said: "This is the beginning of the end of racing in the East. It is all right for men who have grown rich by racing to fall into the methods of another species of gambling that is sure to degrade it and destroy a sport that attracts all classes.

Eugene Sandow, the strong man, came to town from Boston yesterday to press his charges of assault and blackmail against Sarah E. White, known as "Lurline, the Water Queen." in the Yorkville Police Court Since she out him across the face with a whip in front of the Casino on the night of July 1 the two have met several times before Police Justice Koch.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 24. -- Israel Lewis and his employers, Baden Martin, were arrested this afternoon on complaint of William Tilley, between whom and the members of the Sea Cliff Yacht Club a bitter feud is in progress.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The following additional statement has been issued from the Pension Office with reference to the suspension of Judge Long's pension:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 24. -- There is a storm of indignation against Sheriff McLendon for his exhibition of weakness Saturday night in surrendering Lee Walker to a drunken mob. Half a dozen men could bare defended the jail and driven the lynchers into the Mississippi River.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange held another special meeting yesterday afternoon at the request of the Law Committee. Its object was to give further consideration to recent rumor manufacturing. Its result was a set of instructions to Lewis Cass Ledyard, counsel to the Exchange, to formulate charges against H.G. Weil.

Jajat Jit Singh, King of Kings, Prince of Kapurthala, yesterday devoted much of his time to examining the business institutions of this city. He went to the Stock Exchange in the forenoon, to the Equitable Building, and to the City Hall.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 24. -- Tae Essex Troop of Cavalry, which is the crack cavalry organization of the State, and whose headquarters are at Newark, is commanded by an old campaigner, Col. James E. Fleming, who is however, to his command only Capt. Fleming, as he gets his title from a former command in the late war.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 24. -- Isaac Townsend Smith, Consul General of Siam to the United States, is the guest of William H. Lee of New-York at his Summer residence in this city. This morning he visited the Colt Firearms Works, bat disclaimed that the visit had the least reference to Slam's complications with France.

Daniel Lee of 501 Canal Street and Lawrence Collins of 10 Battery Place, who say they were assaulted by Policeman James J. Dougherty of the Prince Street Station, called on Inspectory Williams yesterday. They told their story, which was published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, and made a formal complaint against Dougherty.

Our neighbor the Tribune makes some very sensible observations on the lack of mail facilities for distributing the NewYork Sunday newspapers. The Government, the express companies, and the railroads, it says, provide an adequate service on week days. But on Sundays "the service is limited, and the New-York newpapers are compelled to employ hundreds of miles of special trains on that one day of the week."

Letters received yesterday by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions in this city contain news of an unprovoked attack upon Miss Anna Melton, an American missionary, who was stationed at the time of the outrage in a little village among the Nestorian mountains, in Turkey. Miss Melton escaped with her life, but was mercilessly beaten and bruised by her assailant.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- "Iceman" Turner came to Washington to-day to see how the contest for the Doorkeepership of the House of Representatives looked from this end of the line. Mr. Turner found but few members in the city, and these appeared to have no knowledge on the subject. He said to newspaper correspondents who questioned him regarding his candidacy that he believed he had sufficient support to secure the position.

The residents of the tenement district in the vicinity of One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue became very much alarmed yesterday when it was discovered that a mad dog was looked up in the house of Augustus Nathan, at 90 Lawrence Street. Mr. Nathan's family is out of town, and when he left home in the morning he locked up his two dogs, a setter and a black-and-tan, in the house.

The case of Alfred T. White and Gen. Christian J. Christensen against Mayor Boody and other Brooklyn officials, to restrain them from paying excise moneys to the Inebriates' Home was argued before Judge Cullen in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.
HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., July 24. -- There is an epidemic of diphtheria here. The first case noticed was last Friday. Sunday and Monday six deaths of children were reported to the Board of Health.

There was more animation to-day in Produce Exchange dealings than on Saturday. Wheat was dealt in quite freely on a rising market through, as influences, decreased risks, a falling off in the amount on passage to Europe and in the visible supply. The advance in prices was 1 1/4@1 1/2 Corn was sold up folly 2 1/8@2 5/8 on poor crop weather and as following wheat.

LONG ISLAND CITY, July 24. -- The Rev. John McGuire, pastor of St. Mary's Catholic Church, which was destroyed in the fire of Thursday night, arrived from Europe on the steamer Alaska this morning. He was early on the scene of the fire, and was almost heartbroken. Groups or moist-eyed parishioners gathered about him and tendered their sympathy.

Samuel Bernstein, eighteen years old, of 133 Madison Street, and Harry Spairo, nineteen years old, of 29 Allen Street, were held in the Tombs Police Court yesterday on charges of robbing the United States Express Company.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- There was a stirring up of the whole grain trade to-day. For the first time in three months great bull movements were started in all the pits. Bullish sentiment has been so much suppressed for weeks and the trade was so largely oversold in all markets that the turn in the tide was of a sensational character.

The rule of corrupt rings of politicians reaches its most pernicious clim ax when it succeeds in swaying the action of the juries of the people in the administration of justice. The prevention of indictments for official misdemeanor in the County of Kings through the influence of a Judge and a prosecuting officer subservient to such a ring is not the only recent instance of political interference with the independence of juries.

The cable announcement in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday that the Campania had sailed from Queenstown and was expected to establish a new westward record lends additional interest to the big Cunarder's performance on this trip.

Dr. M.L. Rhein and his wife had a little experience with a Park policeman on Thursday night which they are not likely soon to forget. Both are enthusiastic bicyclists, and it was due to their use of the wheel that they were subjected to insolent language, dragged across Central Park under arrest, and put to considerable inconvenience.

From the Kingston Leader. The expulsion of the representatives of THE NEW-YORK TIMES and the New-York Tribune from the Monmouth Park race track is bearing good Iruita. If a few more reporters and city editors were expelled from the privileges of the paddock and the clubhouse the public would cot much more reliable information concerning the races.

CONST ISLAND, July 24. -- "Suspicions character" was the entry made at the police station against George Fisher, thirty-two years old, who was arrested to-day. He said he lived at 70 East Seventy-second Street, New-York City. A few of the things found in his pockets were:

HUNTINGTON, Ind., July 24. -- At Schaeffer Schaeffer's powder house at 3 o'clock this afternoon Homer Householder and Hugh Harvey were shooting with a rifle, and when a bullet entered a window an explosion followed, both being blown clear across a small stream, and their bodies torn to pieces.

Many Republican clerks in the Federal offices are seeking admission to Tammany in the hope of better securing their places. No less than ten former Republicans have joined the Tammany organization in the Tenth Assembly District within thirty days, and the same is true of another Assembly District.

Recent reports as to the presence of cholera in Italy simply confirm the announcement made some days ago by Dr. YOUNG, the representative of the Marine Hospital Bureau stationed at Naples. Dispatches from Some now say that the disease has appeared in Piedmont as well as in Naples.

Like the dally lottery drawings at New-Orleans the improvement of toe broad of Horses goes daily on at the Monmouth Park race track, with occasional prizes for the players and a regular income for the men who are licensed under the laws of the State of New-Jersey to carry on the gambling that was illegal up to February last.

Several days ago, Troop L, First Cavalry, an Indian troop, was mustered out of the service by order of the War Department at Fort Wingate. Now similar orders have required the mustering out of Troop L, Fourth Cavalary, at Fort Walla Walla, and Company I, Fourth Infantry, at Fort Spokane, while farther instructions from Washington are that the enlistment of Indians at Fort Reno shall cease.

RICHMOND, Va., July 25 -- The announcement that Gen. Weaver, the Populist candidate for President last year: Jerry Simpson of Kansas, Congressman Watson of Georgia, and other prominent leaders of that side are to take the stump in this State and the Carolinas early next month is exciting attention. Gen. Weaver and Watson are announced to speak in North, Carolina on Aug. 5.

-- A gentleman connected with the Norwich (Conn.) Bulletin says he has become the possessor of an East Indian bamboo cane which belonged to Israel Putnam and otherwise has a history. As told, Putnam, while walking in Havana, saw a Spanish planter strike a negroslave with the cane. He seized the cane, and, though pursued, escaped to his companions in safety.

VALETTA, Malta, July 25 -- At to-day's session of the court-martial which, is investigating the loss of the battle ship Victoria, Cant. Gerard H.U. Noel of the battle ship Nile, belonging to the Mediterranean squadron, was the first witness called. He testified that he understood the signal displayed by the Vieteria to mean solely that the two columns were to turn inward.
LONDON, July 25 -- The House of Commons, sitting as Committee of the Whole, continued this evening the discussion of the financial proposals in the Home Rule bill.

EX-Gov. Samuel T. Hanser of Montana was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, and with numerous acquaintances discussed the possible action of the silver convention which will meet in Chicago Aug. 1, and of Congress, which will meet a week later.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- In consequence of gross carelessness on the part of the local authorities, which nearly caused an epidemic of yellow fever, the Marine Hospital Service has assumed control of the quarantine service at Brunswick, Ga. Surgeon General Wyman's official report to Secretary Carlisle is as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Postmaster Dayton of New-York came to Washington this evening and went to the Shoreham. To-morrow he will go to the Post Office Department and have a long talk with First Assistant Postmaster General Jones on the subject of the-needs of the New-York Post Office.

It was learned yesterday through authoritative Russian sources that the Russian fleet now at the port of New-York is under orders to join the French Mediterranean squadron at Toulon. It was also stated yesterday that three of the Russian war ships now here have received preparatory orders which may cause them to continue, after reaching Toulon, to East India waters.

The Chinese in this country would have a stronger case and more sympathy in their protests against the harsh features of our exclusion law. such as the provisions for imprisonment and deportation, if they were less addicted to "ways that-are dark and tricks that are vain" in their efforts to smuggle their countrymen in, or if their countrymen were less addicted to such ways and tricks in their efforts to get in.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 25 -- Gov. Lewelling's action in notifying eleven companies of militia to be in readiness to move to the mining district, coupled with the arrest of M.L. Walters, leader of the strikers, has had a quieting effect, in spite of the importation of negroes from Alabama.

The "blood-to-the-bridles" doctrine of Gov. Waite of Colorado was given what threatened to be a practical indorsement by friends of free silver coinage in this city at a meeting in the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

Counselor Maurice B. Blumenthal of 150 Nassau Street has been retained, by Mrs. Sarah Goldstein, a widow living on the top floor of the tenement house at 181 Orchard Street, to bring salt for $25,000 damages against her landlord, Theodore Fischer of Brooklyn, and Marshal George Hatzel of this city.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Miss Lillian Russell has become so popular among the club men of Chicago as to arouse a very ludicrons opposition by the wives of the club men to her appearance at public places, where it was possible for the fair singer to receive the attentions of the men.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 4@10 P cent. The average rate was about 10 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau states that the rainfall has been deficient throughout the Northern States. There was almost a total absence of rain from Nebraska eastward over the States of the Ohio Valley to Pennsylvania, and while the corn crop is as yet uninjured, it is in a threatened condition in Nebraska and Illinois.

The Morris Park Cricket Club sent in a Tory poor team, to meet the St. George's Athletic Club on their own grounds yesterday, and sustained a defeat by eight wickets as a consequence. T.J. Chadwict did the beat batting for the winners in the first inning, and F.J.E. Welch in the second, while for Morris Park T.J. O'Reilly did the best work.

The Columbian Liberty Bell Committee, which planted a flagpole at the Highlands of Navesink and brought about the casting of the Liberty Bell and ringing it in Chicago on July 4, has these-farther plans in prospect:

When the focus of investigation in Brooklyn shall turn upon the District Attorney's office as seems likely soon to happen, there may be some interesting Questions for Mr. RidgWay to answer, as to whether the bucket shops have escaped the penalties of the law by means of influences within his office.

AKRON, Ohio, July 25 -- The second section of the Baltimore and Ohio express, west bound, and running on the Pittsburg and Western Road, was wrecked one mile cast of Mource Falls about 4:30 this morning. A special train brought the following injured passengers to the City Hospital here:

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Mr. Harrison Loring, Jr., was at the Navy Department to-day on business connected with the completion of the cruiser Marblehead. The chip is now at the Quintard Iron Works, where the machinery is being placed in position. It is expected that the cruiser will be ready for her trial trip in a few weeks.

The Rev. James W. Putnam, ex-assistant pastor of the Baptist Tabernacle, was formally expelled from the church at a meeting of the members last night Elder A.G. Vanderpoel read the report of the commitee, which rooommended that "the hand of fellowship be withdrawn from Dr. Putnam." The recommendation was carried with but one dissenting voice, that of Daniel Harding, and his vote did not count, because he is under suspension.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 25 -- At Dodgeville, on the Old Colony Division of the Consolidated Railroad, just before 1 o'clock this morning, the first section of the midnight train from Boston to New-York, going at a rate of forty miles an hour, struck a freight car and Knocked it into kindling wood, while the engine and every car of the train were shattered badly.
The New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad has gone into the hands of receivers. They are John King. President of the company, and J.G. McCullough, one of the Directors.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A rumor reached Washington to-night that the arbitrators in the Bering Sea controversy between the United States and Great Britain, who have been, in session at Paris since March listening to arguments in the case, had decided in favor of the United States.

SOCIETY PEOPLE OUT OF TOWN -- Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Lord, parents of Daniel Lord. Jr., whose distressing death occurred at Chicago s few weeks ago, are now at their place at Lawrence, L.I., with their daughter. Mr. and Mrs. John Fox and John Fox, Jr., are at Foxhurst., Baidwin's, L.I. Mr. and Mrs. Eben Sumner Draper of Philadelphia have gone to The Ledges, at Hopedale, Mass.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 25 -- The Merchants' National Bank, the Louisville Deposit Bank, and the Fourth National Bank suspended to-day.
LONDON, July 25 -- Americans opened dull at parities, and after some hesitation advanced slowly until noon, when good buying of Erie seconds gave the market a lift.

BOSTON, July 25 -- The syndicate cup defender Pilgrim was out for trial spins Sunday, yesterday, and to-day. On Sunday she had a five or six mile run with the Paine cap defender Jubilee, and impartial judges say she gained folly a quarter of a mile in that distance. Certain it is that Pilgrim stock is going higher the longer she tails.

NORWALK, Conn., July 25 -- Papers were served to-day in a suit for $20,000 brought by John W. Haddeck, a wealthy New-Yorker residing in Darien, against Hiram H. Draper, a neighbor. Haddock charges that Draper has alienated Mrs. Haddock's affections.

Senator William M. Stewart of Nevada, at the Holland House yesterday, gave out an interview on the silver question in which he admitted that the Sherman Act would be repealed at the coming session of Congress.

The feast of St. Ann will be celebrated to-day by Roman Catholics. The little French Church of St. John the Baptist, in East Seventy-sixth Street, near Third Avenue, is visited daily by hundreds of devout persons, who go there to view the sacred bone of St. Ann. It has been credited with many wonderful cures, and its fame has spread all over the country.

Now that the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen and Mayor Boody have given the right to the street railroads to extend their lines through scores of miles of the city's streets, the companies have set to work to get the further right to use the trolley system over the new lines. It was to consider their application in this direction that the Railroad Commissioners met in the Council Chamber of the City Hall yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- The annual meeting of the National Educational Association opened at 3 o'clock to-day in the Art Palace in connection with the World's Congress Auxiliary of the World's Columbian Exposition.

BUFFALO, July 25 -- The Lieutenant Governor of the State of New-York is wise in his day and generation. Notwithstanding his order that his followers should make no demonstration on the occasion of his home coming, it had been the intention of his Democratic General Committee to turn out and welcome him, and to have red fire burned and rockets aunt up as soon as he stepped off the train.
BOSTON, July 25 -- Mason Hamlin's organ and piano factory, at Cambridge, Has shut down for three weeks, owing to the dull business.

Collector Hendricks is expected to return to his office to-day. One of the most pressing matters demanding his attention is the investigation of the charges made against some of his principal lieutenants by Col. J. Thomas Scharf, Special Inspector of Chinese Immigration at this port, and explained in detail in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday.

Harvey T. Lewis, Supervisor of the Seventeenth Ward, Brooklyn, was indicted yesterday by the Kings County Grand Jury for presenting false claims against the county for the burial of indigent war veterans.
STATE CAMP,PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 25 -- The good work of the Signal Corps in signaling heliograph messages to New-York yesterday has been the subject of much favorable comment in camp to-day.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 25 -- The prompt action or Police Captain George W. Grant and his courageous, officers perhaps saved Charles M. Parmele of this city from being lynched by a mob last night. The crowd, comprising men, women, and children, gathered around Parmele's house, 134 Plainfield Avenue.

QUEENSTOWN, July 25 -- The long-distance ocean race from San Francisco for this port has practically been finished. The five vessels that took part in the race were all British. They were the bark Pinmore, Caps. Maxwell, and the ships City of Athens, Capt. Morrison; Bowdon, Capt. Law; Lochee, Capt. Barrett, and Lord Templemore, Capt. Walker.

WASHINGTON, July 35 -- The World's Columbian regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at Detroit Aug. 9 and 10 promises to tie very successful. Entries for the various events close July 26, bat the Executive Committee baa decided to receive all entries which may bear the postmark of that date, even though they may reach Secretary Schmidt at Washington some flays later.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- It seems that, after all, army officers who have any right to attend the World's Fair may do so, and have their mileage as well.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 25 -- T.C. Purdy, econd Vice President of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company, which has contracted with the Galveston, Houston and Henderson Railway to transport its trains between Galveston and Houston, said in an interview to-day:

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The young man who distinguished himself in New-York some months ago as a borrower of money from hard-fisted, bankers, and who lived a riotous life at exclusive metropolitan clubs, has been in Washington.
