He spent two weeks here and met some of Washington's most solid citizens, from whom he succeeded in obtaining considerable money.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 25 -- A Western Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train, consisting of an engine and three coaches, crashed into the rear of a freight train this morning near Pine Creek, three miles outside the city, injuring the following persons:

Stock Exchange prices fared badly again yesterday. With the news of the Western bank failures and reports or called loans to help them, the bears raided the list with as much energy as they had displayed at any time in their attacks in the last month. They did some of their most telling work against the Vanderbilt shares.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 25 -- Julius Catlin, Jr., deceased, of New-York, was left one-halt of the income from the estate of his father, Lieut. Gov. Catlin of this city. The principal at the time of the Lieutenant Governor's death in 1888 was $726,000. Charles Catlin of Chicago, brother of Julius, was left a life interest in $60,000.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 25 -- Vice President Stevenson and party arrived here at 7:30 this morning and were driven to a hotel for breakfast At Salem the Vice President was welcomed by Gov. Pennoyer. Notwithstanding that the hour was early, a great crowd had assembled at the station. Gov. Pennoyer, who recently resented any advice or suggestion from Washington, said:
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 25 -- The Bank of Commerce, capital $200,000, and the Indianapolis National Bank, capital $300,000, have suspended.

PHILADELPHIA, penn., July 25 -- The local team basily defeated the Brooklyns this afternoon and by hard hitting earned 10 of the 16 runs scored. Stein pitched for the Bridegrooms for six innings, but he was very wild, giving nine men their base on balls, four of whom scored.

Gratifying as it would be for New-York yachtsmen to believe that the Morgan syndicate yacht Colonia had shown herself to be an amazingly fast vessel, it will not be wise to let enthusiasm run away with judgment. It is an old saying among yachtsmen that racing craft always sail fastest when alone.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 -- This afternoon Treacy Wilson shipped to "Dave" Pulsifier his stallion Tonny, who has boon mating a season in Kentucky. Tenny in in good condition and will be pnt into training. Fifteen bead of other thoroughbreds wore also shipped with him to New-York.

The decision of Judge CULLEN in the suit brought by a taxpayer of Brooklyn to prevent the construction of a street railroad under the franchise granted to the Union Street Railroad Company last year seems to afford a pretty solid basis for the proceeding which Mr. GAYNOR proposes to take for the annulment-of the franchises more recently granted to the "Flynn syndicate."

Dr. John Rae died Monday at his residence, 4 Addison Gardens, London, after a prolonged illness. Dr. Rae, who was a distinguished arctic explorer, was born in the Orkney Islands. He studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh, and after graduation there he took his degree as Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons before he was twenty-three years old. He was soon appointed surgeon to a ship of the Hudson Bay Company.

Baltimore's diamond-field representatives were badly beaton by the Giants yesterday, Who handled the Orioles like a team of amateurs. Hawke started in to pitch for the visitors, and, in the language of the small boy, his curves were pic for the New-York batsmen. They sent the ball in all directions for singles, triples, and home runs.

The notion of President ANDREWS of Brown University that the Brussels Conference gave rise to a very general approval of bimetallism in Europe is hardly sustained by the recent expressions of German financiers and economists, one of whom, as our Berlin dispatches stated the other day, irreverently calls the discussion of bimetallism "flogging a dead horse."

ATHENS, July 25 -- The Greet Consul at Smyrna, Asia Minor, reports that five cases of cholera and two deaths from the disease have occurred there. The Greek Government has ordered that all vessels arriving from Smyrna be subjected to eleven days' quarantine.

Matthew Green, a foreman in the Street-Cleaning Department, murdered James W. Halstead, a dyer at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Twelfth Avenue, yesterday afternoon on the sidewalk at Thirty-fourth Street and First Avenue. The murdered man was fifty-five years old and lived at 216 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street.

By a fire in the tenement house 121 Attorney Street yesterday morning a little girl lost her life. Had it not been for the daring of three men who happened to be passing, five others of a family would have perished.
The Fairchild commission yesterday stuck its probe into the Naval Office of the port.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N. J., July 25 -- First Lieut. Albert Van Walraven is in command of Company C of the Second Regiment. His company comes from Paterson, and is the flower of the regiment. Lieut. Van Walraven is a young man of genial disposition and is thoroughly beloved by his men. He lives in Paterson, where for many years he has been a toller in the National Guard.

Lieut. F.M. Buady of the United States frigate St. Louis, now at Philadelphia, went to Police Headquarters yesterday and identified Thomas Wallace, a bricklayer eighteen years old,who was arrested on Monday night as the burglar who broke into his rooms at 134 West Thirty-ninth Street in this city on the morning of July 11.
BANGKOK, July 25 -- M. Pavie. French Minister Resident, started down the river this afternoon on the war ship Inconstante, accompanied by the war ships Lutin and Comete.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 25 -- The threatened mutiny of an entire company of the First Regiment was only averted by the decision and firmness displayed, by Lieut. Col. Breitnall, commanding the regiment.

Special Inspector SCHARF, who has been placed in charge of the immigration of Chinese at this port, in a report to a Special Agent of the Treasury Department has made some pretty sweeping charges with reference to fraudulent evasions of the exclusion law with the alleged connivance of customs officers.
Yesterday was st. Anne's Day and the last day of the annual nine days' feast set apart by the Roman Catholic Church in honor of this particular saint.

To the Duryea Presbyterian Church in Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, belongs the credit of first introducing women ushers into the church, and it must be confessed that the novelty was a very pleasing one to the young men and also to the majority of the church members. The plan was tried, last night at the anniversary of the organization of the Society of Christian Endeavor.

BANGKOK, July 26. -- M. Pavie, the French Minister Resident, prior to his departure, had a final interview with Devawongse, the Siamese Foreign Minister, who said that his Government was astonished that France considered the Siamese reply to the French ultimatum as a refusal to comply with its terms.

Mrs. Anna M. Melville does not want her Husband. George D. Melville the juggling clown, to take part in the action for divorce she has begun against him. She says he intends to marry Minnie Conway, the actress, as soon as she gets her decree. She intends to prevent this, at least until he has paid her the arrears of alimony due at the rate of $25 a week.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- " It has been a very profitable visit to me," said Poatmaster Dayton of New-York to the correspondent of THE NEWYORK TIMES this afternoon, just before taking the train for home.
"I was yust in bed in a few minutes when I heard an awful racket. I woke my brudder Yon, and the two of us caught one of the burglars."

LONDON, Jnly 26. -- The Committee of the Whole of the House of Commons resumed its discussion of Mr. Joseph Chamberlain's amend- ment to the financial clause of the Home Rule bill, provding that the provisional arrangement that Irish taxes should be collected for six years by the Imperial Government should be so changed that the collection of such taxes should rest permanently with the Imperial Government.

To make room for their increasing business the dry goods firm of A. D. Matthews Sons, Fulton Street and Gallatin Place, Brooklyn, is about to add an extension to its large store. The firm has bought the four rear buildings, which, run through to Livingston Street, and in their place an addition to the present store will be built.

LONDON, July 26. -- The American department attracted the whole attention of the Stock Exchange to-day. After opening dull, it was found that no stock was being pressed for sale, and prices advanced above parity, and further improved when it was found that only one small jobber in the mining market, named Holmes, was declared a defaulter.

GLOUCESTER, N. J., July 26. -- Three favorites and three outsiders were the winners here to-day. A heavy windstorm just before the third race caused a postponement of the race for fifteen minutes. Many persons feared the grandstand would collapse and sought safety in the open field.

BUFFALO, July 26. -- Spot Spring wheat quiet, cost, insurance, and freight, in fair demand. Sales, 3,500 bushels No. 1 Northern, spot, 67 1/4c; 8,000 bushels No. 1, hard, cost, insurance, and freight. 69c; 25,000 bushels No 1 Northern do, 66 7/8@66c; closing No. 1 hard spot. 71c, do, cost, insurance, and freight, 69c; No 1 Northern, spot, 67c, do, cost, insurance, and freight, 65 3/4c.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 26. -- The Philadelphias and Brooklyns played two games this afternoon, the first of which was a "tie" and the second the home team won. The first game was stopped by a hard, shower at the end of the filth inning with the score standing 4 to 4 and the rain did not cease within the time set by the rules for allowing a game to be continued.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 26. -- One most extraordinary feature of the present deranged condition of the silver market is that American sliver bullion is beginning to be imported for coinage into Mexican dollars. Bullion dealers say that this business can be done at an excellent profit while the present low quotations continue, and so long as there is a substantial premium on dollars over their melting value.

The blood-red sunset of Tuesday foreboded the suffering which the people of this city would have to undergo yesterday. It warranted a prophecy of intense heat and dense humidity, and the prophecy was realized in one of the most uncomfortable days of the Summer.

VALETTA, Malta, July 26. -- The court-martial appointed to investigate the loss of the British battle ship Victoria sat again to-day on board the Hibernia, the flagship of the Admiral Super intendent of the Malta Dock Yard. Sir Michael Cnlme-Seymour, Commander in Chief of the Mediterranean squadren, presided.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 26. -- Clarence M. Overman, late President and Director of the Citizens' National Bank of Hillsborough, Ohio, was arrested by the United States Marshal to-day at Hillsborough on a warrant sworn out by United States Attorney John W. Herron, and brought before United States Commissioner John E. Bruce.

A cablegram received yesterday by the Rev. Father Clancey of St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church, Jersey City, announced the death of the Rev. P. M. Corr, rector of the church, at Dublin on Tuesday. Father Corr went to Ireland July 1 to be treated by a specialist in Bright's disease.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., July 26. -- This has been another disagreeable, rainy day. There was too much wind this morning for the President to take his regular fishing trip down the bay. Just before dinner it commenced to rain, and between the showers the President, Col. Lamont, and Dr. Bryant drove over to the village, this making the third visit here since the President arrived.

FORT WAYNE, ind., July 26. -- There was a large crowd at the League of American Wheelmen races this afternoon, which was greatly disappointed at the non-appearance of Johnson, Sanger, and Windle, champion riders. George F. Taylor and George Smith did some last riding, while in the State events W. C. Marmon and E.V. Minor of Indianapolis won everything in eight.

UTICA, N. Y., July 26. -- It became known today that a registered letter pouch from Portland, Oregon, to New-York City was rified of a portion of its contents en route, and that when the pouch reached the Post Office in New-York it was discovered that nearly sixty registered letters were missing. The pouch had been out, and the opening had been carefully laced with a leather string.

There was scarcely a feature to the day's racing at Brighton yesterday, five uat of six favorites winning with ease from their respective fields. Just as the horses got away from the post in the first race. It begin to rain, and soon after clap after clap of thunder pealed ont and made the horses nervous.

Col. Henry Mapleson and Manager Whitney have completed arrangements for their Fall production, of Reginald De Koven's opera. "The Fencing Master." Laura Schirmer Mapleson will be the star prime donna of the organization, and the company will include the following well-known artists: Grace Golden, Dorre Theo, contralto from the Milan Opera House; Marion Langdon of the Carloton Opera Company.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- B. H. Nemitz; reprasentative of thirty-five Swiss watchmakers exhibiting at the World's Fair, wai arrested this evening at Toronto, Canada, ana will be brought here to answer to a charge of grand larceny and embezzlement if the application for his extradition shall be allowed.

The resignation of John Whalen as a Tax Commissioner is a thing that will not surprise any of the leading Tammany Hall politicians when it comes. That it will be handed in long before his term expires is certain. He has so large a business as a real estate lawyer that he finds it very difficult to attend to that and to his official duties.

The Staten Island Cricket Club continued its handicap tennis tournament yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Livingston, S. I. The mem's singles was the only event of the day. The system of handicapping was the same as that employed since the beginning of the meeting.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., July 26. -- A severe electric storm struck this section about 1:30 this morning, the rain falling in torrents for fully three hours. Several outbuildings were struck by lightning, one barn in the city being destroyed by fire.

More frauds in the registry of Chinese coming to New-York from their native country were discovered yesterday by CoL J. Thomas Scharf, the examiner appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to investigate the entrance of Chinese at this port.

There is a faint preliminary note of the coming State canvass in the " official call " for the State Convention of the People's Party. The State Committee whose Secretary and Treasurer issues this call is about the only evidence of the existence of the People's Party in this State at present, and it would be difficult to state what it is made of and what its objects are.

Messrs. Mandelbaum Lewine have sold, through George J. Kenny Brother, to William H. Gallery, 299 and 301 Elizabeth Street, lot 40 by 100 feet, with two four-story tenements in front and one four-story tenement in rear. The price stated is $33,000.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 26. -- The twenty-sixth Turnfest came to a close to-night. Among the prize Tinners were, in the first group, the Newark Turn Verein and the New-York Turn Vorein; in the second group, the Bloomingdale Seniors, New-York, and the Turn Verein Vorwartz of Newark; in the third group, the Camden Turn Verein, the Hartford Turn Verein.

Charles Kleinmeier, whose father, George Kleinmeler, is a baker at 22 stanton Street, took a our dog from the street a week ago. He chained it in the cellar, where the temperature is much of the time over 100 from the big bake ovens. The heat, it is supposed, caused the dog to go mad.

With the morning papers bringing the news of the Erie receivership, Wall Street could not but look for a decline in prices yesterday. The result of the day's trading, though, was a slump which for the wide range it covered and the extent of the fall in quotations has been matched by nothing in this season of tight money and successful bear campaigns.
Who is going to get the United States Marshalship for this district, to succeed John W. Jacobus?

DUNKIRK, N. Y., July 26. -- During the past ten days a number of employes of the Brooks Locomotive Works have been laid off because or a lack of work, and matters are now assuming serious proportions. During the present week, it is said, between thirty and forty more will be laid off in the blacksmith shops, and a proportionate number in other departments.

The Inadequate facilities for distributing to out-of-town points the New-York Sunday newspapers are becoming year by year a more universal cause of complaint, not only among those who live permanently within half a day's journey of the metropolis, but especially among New-Yorkers who summer at the seashore, by the lakes, or in the mountains.
BOSTON, July 26. -- The Scotch yachting correspondent of the Boston Globe, writing from Glasgow of the latest racing in British waters, says:

The guests of the Hotel Waldorf were aroused from their sleep at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning by the clattering of fire engines in Fifth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, and when they looked oat upon Fifth Avenue they saw that the carriage warehouse of A. T. Demarest was in fiames. For two hours or more they watched the flames with interest.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- At last the Navy Department has received an account of the operations of the Bering Sea squadron up to the latter part of June. The mail has brought a report from Capt. Ludlow, who is in command of the entire squadron, and the news contained in the report touching the disposition of the sealers to observe the modus vlvendi is gratifying to the officials.

Henry W. Roseborn yesterday secured the lease of the Casino for eight weeks, beginning Sept. 25, with the privilege of extending it for twelve additional weeks if he desires. The contract was signed at the Casino at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The rental is to be $750 a week.
CONEY ISLAND, July 26. -- Coney Island was visited by two terrific thunderstorms this afternoon and loss of life and property resulted.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Attendance at the first round of the gentlemen's doubles in the National Lawn Tennis Association's tournament was much better to-day, the St. George grounds being bright with nattily-dressed men and women and studded with tally-hoes and fashionable vehicles. Col. and Mrs Fred Grant were in the crowd of onlookers.

Col. Marshall McDonald, United States Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, in command of the United States Fish Commission's schooner Grampus, came into this port last Sunday with the news that he had taken about twenty "tilefish" in a place where there had previously been no sign of them.

Supervisor Harvey T. Lewis of the Seventeenth Ward, Brooklyn, who was indicted on Tuesday by the Grand Jury for presenting false claims to the county for the burial of indigent veterans, called at the District Attorney's office yesterday morning and surrendered himself. He was accompanied by Thomas F. BurKe, a plumber, of 163 Columbia Street, who gave anrety in $5,000 for the Supervisor's appearance in the Court of Sessions this morning.

WOLCOTT, N. Y., July 26. -- Jacob Livingstone, an eighty-year-old miser, living seven miles northeast of this village in a backwoods section of the township of Wolcott, known as Caycat, was on June 11 robbed of about $7,000 in gold and bank notes. This money be has been hoarding ever since the war. He lives alone in an old-fashioned farmhouse, fast tumbling to pieces.

NEW-YORK. WEDNESDAY, July 26 -- P.M. } It is fair to say that the Erie receivership had been anticipated for some days, but when it came overnight its influence was as if the possibility had never been dreamed of. The first prices were considerably below yesterday's closing, and by the end of the first hour all the active stocks were down a couple of points or more.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- In anticipation of the visit of Postmaster Dayton of New-York and as an offset to the assertions which have been made relative to the attitude of the Post Office Department toward the New-York Post Office, First Assistant Postmaster General Jones caused to be prepared the statement which follows:

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N. J., July 26. -- The hottest day of the year at Camp Werts opened at 7 o'clock this morning with the thermometer at 91. A gentle southwest breeze came whistling in over the Jersey spruce from the left flank of the camp, but specimens of the torrid zone were carried along and dropped with it, and threw the temperature three or four degrees higher.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Several very clever forgeries have just been discovered by the banks here. The amount involved is somewhere between $50,000 and $75,000, and the police are looking for C. B. Lookstaed, a German inventor, whom they charge uttered the forgeries. Lockstaed lived at 3,016 South Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jnly 26. -- It was the stock market that undermined the Board of Trade prices to-day. Business was somewhat scant in all the pits. Wheat closed about 3/4C lower, corn 1/2c, cats 3/8c, and short ribs 30c lower. Pork is nominally 75c off, and lard 12 1/2c.

LONDON, July 26. -- The recent article in the Pall Mall Gazette, in which the paper professed to have discovered the thief who, about fifteen years ago, cut from its frame and stole from the art store of Thomas Agnew Sons, in Old Bond Street, Gainsborough's celebrated painting of the Duchess of Devonshire, has created much comment in art and other circles.
John Good when asked yesterday regarding the report that cordage interests were about to be harmonized and organized said:

FAR ROCKAWAY, L. I., July 26. -- During a severe storm of wind and rain this afternoon, trees were uprooted and broken off, and telephone and telegraph wires damaged so that some difficulty was had in communicating with New-York.

VANCOUVER, B. C. July 26. -- The steamship Empress of India has arrived with news of the murder of two Swedish missionaries by Chinese fanatics at Sing Pu. The Revs. Wikholm and Johanson, the missionaries, arrived in Sing Pu last April. They were the only missionaries there. Sine Pu is an important market place northeast of Han-Keoo, and contains about 30,000 inhabitants.
WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The First National Bank of Grundy Centre, Iowa, has informed Controller Eckels that it expects to resume business Aug. 1, under a new management.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 26. -- John Smaus killed his wife and two of his children at their home in Oak Alley this morning and then set fire to the house.

The placing of the Erie Railway in the hands of a receiver in consequence of a friendly suit brought by one of the company's principal creditors was the chief topic of talk among railroad men and Wall Street financiers yesterday.

The scene at the Fifth Avenue Hotel on Tuesday evening, when, the free-silver men of New-York met to choose delegates to the convention of their kind in Chicago on Aug. 1, was an instructive one. If the "leaders" of the "movement" in the West shall but interpret it intelligently, it will do them a great deal of good.

District Attorney James W. Ridgway of Brooklyn exhibited himself yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES as a foul-mouthed official. The reputation that he holds as a peddler of filthy stories paled before a torrent of profanity and disgusting bluster calculated to surpass even his own unenviable record in that line.

Again this year we have a fiction number of Scribner in the issue for August, the occasion being duly commenorated by a variation in the cover. The number has several other excellent features that readers will enjoy. A paper on " Types and People at the Fair" by J. A. Mitchell has a timely value, and is agreeably written.

Doubtless English opinion, in the matter of the French claims upon Siam, has been very much understated by the British Government and by the accredited organs of English opinion. There is no fault to be found with this. On the contrary, the extraordinary moderation of tone is a matter for congratulation.

The Stock Exchange was yesterday the scene of greater excitement than at any time since the current period of depression set in. The appointment of receivers for the Erie Railroad and the failure of a Stock Exchange firm, following on Tuesday's bank failures in the West and accompanied by a pretty heavy demand for money from tne interior, were the immediate causes of the excitement.

SAN FRANCISCO, CaL, July 26. -- Honolulu dispatches say that it has been learned positively that the Hawalian provisional Government's policy and position regarding future treaty relations with the United States are and will continue to be, in brief, as follows:

The unraveling of some fifteen feet of the strands of that section of cable between the Thirty-sixth Street and Houston Street power houses caused a serious stoppage of traffic on the Broadway cable-car road yesterday afternoon.
Spirits or turpentine quiet and steady at 27@ 27 12c. Resins dull and easy at $1@$1.05 for common to good strained.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Sandy Hook appears to be moving nearer the metropolis, according to Col. G.L. Gillespie, the engineer officer at New-York, who has written a report on the river and harbor work carried on during the fiscal year ending June 30 in the vicinity of New-York. That annual report and the annual reports of the other engineer officers are treasured with great care this year by Gen. Casey, chief of the army engineers.

It is to be hoped that the statement published in yesterday's TIMES about the New-York Post Office may be extensively circulated throughout the country. In particular, it is to be hoped that it may find its way into the Sunday schools, which are the strongholds and fastnesses of the ex-Hon. JOHN WANAMAKER.

-- The ten-mile road race for the championship of Union County, N.J., will be run over the Elizabeth-Cranford course on Aug. 6. There will be two teams of six men each from the Elizabeth Athletic Cyclers and the Elizabeth Wheelmen. The championship is represented by a silver trophy, which the Wheelmen won last year, bat which the Cyclers say they are going to get this time.

In the United States Circuit Court two suits were began yesterday by the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of New-York, based on the rights to the Edison incandescent lamp, one being directed against the Mount Morris Electric Light Company, Edward May, and Julius May, and the second against toe United Electric Light and Power Company, Caleb H. Jackson. Herman H. Westinghouse, and George Westinghouse, Jr.
The foot and train passengers on the Brooklyn Bridge were startled juat before 6 o'clock yesterday afternoon by cries of "Runaway! Runaway!"

To wing on the ocean is not the sort of job that conservative seamen, especially those who have had experiences with straining bitts and whipping hawsers, are likely to grow enthusiastic about. If either vessel is anyway handicapped, and a gale besets the tow, the chances are that one or both will add their names to the roll of missing ships.

RAILWAY, N.J., July 27. -- Chris. Paulsen, a contractor and builder of Rahway, has determined to outdo the indomitable Capt. Andrews, if possible, and cross the Atlantic Ocean in a Norwegian skill which he has just completed.

Inspired by the idea, perhaps, that the not Summer weather will help to blunt the reason or those he hopes to make his victims, the wily and ever-assiduous "green-goods" man is on the warpath again. The following circular, sent out as a bait to catch a merchant in Durango, Mexico, was received yesterday in the office of THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

Rainbow's last race at the Monmouth Park track, when he ran a good second to that very good race horse, Sir Walter, did not appear to fool anybody very considerably. Yesterday afternoon ha was in the race for the Raritan Stakes as a sort of capital prize for the daily lottery. But the bookmakers are up to the games of the Louisiana Lottery, as well as to their own.

The New-Jersey Athletic Club easily defeated a weak team of the Staten Island Cricket Club at Bergen Point yesterday afternoon by 48 runs. J.H. Lambkin and J. Balmer batted very well for the Station Islanders and made a majority of the rang between them. T.G. Clarke, M.R. Cobb. H. Tyers, F.G. Payne, and A. Gunn did good work for the victors at the bat and made most of the runs between them.

Senor Salvador Mendonca, Brazilian Minister to the United States, accompanied by Mme. Mendonca, is at the Hotel Brunswick. He came to this city to pay his respects to Thomas L. Thompson of California, recently appointed United States Minister to Brazil, who is at the Marlborough Hotel.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 27 -- The camp grounds to-day presented the appearance of a county fair. Outside the grounds, fakirs of all kinds were gathered from early morning selling chattels destructive of digestion. Inside the grounds, the liveliest scenes of the week were enacted. The friends of the soldiers swarmed over the parade ground into the companies' streets.

VALETTA, Malta, July 27. -- The court-martial that was appointed to inquire into the loss of the battle ship Victoria to-day rendered its decision in the case of the Hon. Maurice A. Bourke, Captain of the Victoria. The court found that no responsibility attached to Capt. Bourke for the disaster, and he was therefore acquitted of all blame.

Gov. Flower came to this city yesterday morning and passed the entire day at the office of Flower Co., in Exchange Court. The Governor met there a number of bankers with whom he discussed the financial situation.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Civil Service Commissioner Roosevelt, discussing to-day the current changes in departments and the general comments which those changes had elicited from both political parties, said:

-- A regatta for the challenge pennant of 1885 of the North Shrewsbury River will be sailed at Red Bank to-morrow over the ten-mile triangular course. The streamer is now held by The Kid, a remarkably fast yacht owned by Bayard Thayer of Boston. The yacht has teen in charge of Herman Duryea, but Mr. Duryes being in Europe on the yacht Navahoe, The Kid has been in the keeping of Edward Willis of Navesink.

-- Henry C. Jewett, the wealthy trotting-horse breeder of Jewettville, near Buffalo, has made some unexpected changes in his plans for the Summer campaign in the Grand Circuit. For several years he has tried to breed and develop trotters able to cope successfully with those raised by his neighbor, C.J. Hamlin, at East Aurora, but hitherto all his efforts have resulted in failure.

-- Roanoke College, Va., has just celebrated the close of its fourth decade, and rejoices greatly in its prosperity. Its friends say it never received a single dollar of income from invested endowment funds during its first three decades. Bequests had been left, but none of them became available until 1883, and the professors were supported almost exclusively from the income from tuition fees.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 27. -- Neither the Pilgrim nor the Jubilee took a trial spin to day, though both were booked to do so. The reason for remaining at anchor was that there was too much breeze to have allowed the carrying of even lower sails, and neither Gen. Paine nor Capt. Sherlock cared to stretch the big mainsails out of proper shape by putting a reef in them when it was not absolutely necessary.

ASBURY PARK, July 27. -- The bicycle races to be held Saturday afternoon under the auspicoa of the Asbury Park Athletic Association are attracting much attention among the fast wheelmen of the country, many of whom will compete for the valuable prizes offered by the management.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 27 -- Three years ago the custom of politicians coming together on the day of the Governor's review began, and each summer the crowd has been getting larger and the character of the mass has been getting more complex. Politics, on Governor's Day, is overlooked, and all who gather to see and be seen are simply patriotic citizens.
HAMBURG, July 27. -- A workingman named Prinz was stricken with cholera in the street this afternoon. He was taken to a hospital.

The French naval force available in East Indian waters for the blockade of the Siamese coast is under the command of Rear Admiral Edgar Humann. This officer flies his flag generally on board the French war ship Triumphante. The French naval designation of his command is Division. Navale de l'Extreme Orient.

The American Tube and Iron Company of 93 John Street has been placed in the hands of receivers. It is a large corporation, having branch offices in Chicago, Boston, Pittsburg, St. Louis, and Cleveland, and mills at Middletown, Penn., and Youngstown, Ohio.

A sals, under foreclosure of a second mortgage, of the three-story brick building 336 East Seventy-fourth Street was act down for yesterday at lli Broadway. Owing to the illness of Mr. Bryan L. Konnelly, the auotioneer, the Dale was conducted by Mr. Peter F. Meyer. The property measures 16.8 by 102.2. There was due on the second mortgage $3.122, and on first mortgage the sum of $5,196,66.

Postmaster Dayton yesterday asked for the resignation of William Plimley, Superintendent of the Money Order Division, to take effect on Sept. 1. Mr. Plimley will leave on a vacation Aug. 1, to be gone for a month. His successor will be Joseph Elliott, Jr., now with the New-York Life Insurance Company.

Harry Wright watched his boys lose a game and tne lead in the League race at Eastern Park in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. From the outset it was evident that the Brooklyns would win. They batted in good form and took advantage of erratic pitching on the part of Taylor.
CHICAGO, July 27. -- The following petition was received to-day by the National Commission:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 27 -- The proprietor's ball is the attraction at the West End this evening, the Casino being the point toward which the stream of humanity seems tending. The place is beautifully decorated, the same general plan being carried out as last year, but on a scale of greater magnificence. The eight massive pillars supporting the roof are entirely concealed by masses of laurel and flowering shrubs.

The money market was active. In the morning call loans were made at 10@75 cent., low transactions being reported at less than 25 cent. In the afternoon rates relaxed, and in the last hour money was in ample supply at 6 cent.

BALTIMORE, July 27 -- Baltimore's Board of Trade met this afternoon and took decisive action against the Sherman act, calling on Maryland's Representatives and Senators in Congress to vote for the repeal of the purchase clause without delay. These resolutions were adopted:

From present indications there will be a grand shake-up in the Brooklyn Baseball Club. President Byrne is off on the road in quest of new players to take the placed of some of the men who have not given satisfaction. From a place in the front rank the Brooklyns have fallen back to fifth place, and their chances of carrying off the pennant are about as rosy as those of the Giants.
The Penn Mutual Agency Association, composed of officers and agents of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Association of Philadelphia, held its tenth annual business session at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

BANGKOK, July 27. -- Notice was given today of the blockade by the French fleet. Outgoing vessels have been warned that they must clear from Bangkok and Koh-si-Chang before Saturday or submit to detention. The blockade will extend along the entire north coast of the Gulf of Siam. The French fleet with M. Pavie. French Minister Resident, have gone to Kon-si-Chang.

The outdoor production of "As you Like It" for the benefit of the newspaper Summer charities, which takes place at the Hotel Avenel grounds to-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock, promises to be the moat noteworthy performance of this character that has ever taken place in this country. The actors who have volunteered their services include names that warrant the expectation of a fine performance of the charming pastoral comedy.
Postmaster Dayton returned to his desk yesterday, very well satisfied with his visit to Washington.

The Staten Island Cricket Club tennis tonrnament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts, Livingston, S.I. The name English system of handicapping was employed, with the usual close matches. Men's doubles and men's singles were the events of the day.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, July 27 -- It is reported that A.C. Beckwith, who was appointed United States Senator by Gov. Osborne after the failure of the Legislature to elect a successor to Francis E. Warren, either has resigned the appointment or is about to resign it.

LIVERPOOL, July 27 -- 3:45 P.M. -- Beef in moderate demand. Port in poor demand: prime mess Western, medium, easy at 91s 6d. Hams and bacons in poor demand. Choose in fair demand. Tallow in fair demand. Spirits of turpentine and resin in moderate demand. Lard -- Spot in poor demand; futures in no demand: prime Western, spot, dull at 48s 6d.

LONDON, July 27. -- On the Government programme 10 o'clock this evening was the hour set for the closure of the debate in committee on the Home Rule bill. The parts of the bill-left over for the discussions of the last week and for the divisions this evening were the new financial clauses, the schedules, and the preamble.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 27 -- First Lieut. J.H. Keim is in command of Company F. Fourth Regiment. He has been in the National Guard for fourteen years, having joined the Fourth New-Jersey Regiment as a private and mounted through the various grades. He has been a Lieutenant six years. He is thirty-five years of age, a photographer by profession, and lives in Jersey City.

WOODSIDE, L.I., July 27. -- An old and moss-grown well, the source of the water supply of the people of Woodside Heights, was guarded to-night by armed and angry citizens, determined to solve a mystery. For days a white-robed figure has haunted the well, causing terror among the women and children, and even putting young men to ignominious flight.

The explosion of an oil stove at 123 Clinton Street about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon caused a lire that endangered the lives of many people. Had the fire occurred at night many lives might have been lost.
Washington E. Connor, banker, operator, and a figure in Wall Street, has resigned from the Republican Club. Its latest bit of political philosophy was more than he could stand.

NEW-CASTLE, N.H., July 27. -- The match between Malcolm Chaco of Brown University and C.B. Budlong in the Wentworth tournament was played today. For the first four games Budlong had it all his own way, and Chace was very unsteady. Then the latter took a good brace, and by accurate lobbing and good not work outplayed his antagonist and won, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27. -- The market opened fairly steady and, following the strength of the New-York market, advanced. Pennsylvania was in active demand in the loan crowd at one-fourth of 1 cent. and, with little offering, advanced to 49 18, which price was bid at the close. Metropolitan Traction sold up to 87, and there were orders to buy Philadelphia and Baltimore.

LONDON, July 27. -- Seven races were run at the Goodwood meeting to-day. The first race was for the Bous Memorial Stakes. It was van by T. Cannon's b.c. Reminder, by Melanion, out of Postscript. Mr. Henry Milner's b.f. Jocasta was second, and the Duke of Westminster's b.f. Sanderling third.

Three of the Russian war vessels which have been anchored in the North River took departure for Newport yesterday. They were the Admiral Nachimoff, Dimitri Donskoi, and Rynda. The vessels got under way at 4 P.M. and stood down the river, with the big armorclad Nachimoff in the lead. Following her came the Donskoi, with the Rynda bringing up the rear.

LONDON, July 27. -- Large investment purchases quickly moved American prices above parities to-day, Erie seconds going to 60, Louisville to 52, St. Paul to 51 34, Union Pacifies to 17 12, Atchison incomes to 32, and Canadian Pacifies to 72.

CLEVELAND, July 27. -- The suburban residence of Mr. Daniel P. Eells at River Bank was destroyed by fire last night. All the valuable works of art, relics, and possessions gathered in a lifetime were in the house, and all were lost. The loss will probably foot up to 8200,000; insurance not known.

LONDON, July 27. -- Lord Dunraven, owner of the cutter Valkyrie, which is to attempt to win the America's Cup, expects to sail for New-York on Aug. 12. The object of his early visit to the United States is to witness the preliminary races between the American yachts to decide which of them will defend the cap against the Valkyrie.

The "Republic" of Nicaragua seems to be relapsing into the condition which some years ago appeared to be chronic with what are known as the Spanish-American republics -- that of government by revolution. It is characteristic of the people of those countries that they have little reverence for law and established authority and an exaggerated notion of the divine right of revolution, whenever the existing Government is unsatisfactory to them.

William S. Mellen, General Manager of the Northern Pacific Railroad, died in Victoria, B. C., yesterday from an attack of neuralgia of the heart. He was an able and widely-respected railroad man. Born in Will County, Ill., Feb. 26, 1846, he began his railroad career in 1865 as a station telegraph, operator at Milton Junction, in Wisconsin.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27. -- Just before the steamship Oceanic left the wharf at Hongkong particulars were received of the wreck of the Russian cruiser Vitiaz off the coast of Corea, the announcement of which was received by cable at the time. Two officers and fifteen of the crew were drowned or are missing.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27. -- Vice President Voorhees of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad did not confer with the Lehigh Valley employes Grievance Committee this afternoon. The committee, which numbered about forty, called at the Reading offices shortly after 3 o'clock in pursuance to an appointment made with Mr. Voorhees, but were told that the Vice President was out of the city and would not return until to-morrow.

The Citizens' Union of the Twenty-eighth Ward, Brooklyn, protested vigorously at its meeting last evening against what it termed, the ring rale of Brooklyn, and called on every citizen to vote for good government.

The situation on the Stock Exchange yesterday was very much relaxed from the strain of the two days previous. There was no event of any significance of which use could be made by the "bears," though they tried to make the most of the increase in the Clearing House certificates and the failure to redeem any.

Next to picking up big healthy "fat takes" and drawing their salaries. THE TIMES and World compositors delight in a same of ball. Last week the nines of the two chapels played a "tie" game, and in order to settle the question of superiority they met at Prospect Park yesterday afternoon.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 27 -- A more perfect day never dawned upon the State Camp of Instruction, and no regiment this year has acquitted itself in so creditable a manner as did the Twenty-Second to-day in the battalion drill in extended order.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27. Dr. George Fiacher, who has resided in this city since 1881, committed suicide last night by drinking an ounce of Hydrate of chloral. That the doctor premeditated suicide there is no doubt, because he left on his desk a certificate of his own death, filled out in his own handwriting, and in the space "Reported by" he had inserted "him-self."

An East Indian boy, smooth-cheeked, black-eyed, of chocolate complexion, clear-out features, slight of form, and of less than medium height -- a Prince who is to rule over nearly 1,000,000 men -- came to this city last night from Chicago accompanied by a large retinue.

SPOKANE, Washington, July 27. -- The First National Bank has suspended, and the Spokane Savings Bank, which is connected with it, is also closed. President Glover of the First National says that the bank has only temporarily suspended, and that all depositors will be paid in full.

In the introduction to "Poor's Manual of Railways" for 1893 a variety of important statistics is given. They show that in the last fiscal year the net increase in railroad mileage in the United States was 4,429 miles. The total length of track laid up to Dec. 31 last was 175,223 miles.

BOSTON, July 27. -- The market opened quiet, became strong early in the day, and closed at the top prices. At the Clearing House this morning money was slightly easier -- that is there was leas pressure for Clearing House money, owing to the fact of the increase yesterday in loan certificates. Loans were made at 7 3 10 and 8 cent., with the larger amounts at 7 3-10 cent.

The Chairman of the Finance Committee of one of the biggest and most representative manufacturing concerns in the country, which does a large foreign business, recently sent the following letter to the leading officials of the organization:

The World publishes an interview with Mr. WILLIAM C. WHITNEY, ex-Secretary of the Navy, in which his opinions as to the course that should be pursued with respect to the currency laws and the tariff are clearly and forcibly expressed.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The provisional arrangement entered into between Commissioner of Patents Seymour and the National Lithographing Company of this city for the printing of the Patent Office Gazette and the reproduction of patent plates has culminated in the signing of a regular contract by which the company binds itself to perform the work for a year in a satisfactory manner.

VERSAILLES, Ky., July 27. -- A dance was given at Rose Hill Seminary, near here, Tuesday night. All the society leaders of Woodford County attended. One of the belles was escorted by R.W. Davis. A rival for the young lady's favors is Swift Hunter, equally prominent socially. Each young man is about eighteen years old.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 27 -- As the details of the killing of Henry Osteen at Tarpon Springs yesterday come out they suggest that he was killed by mistake. He was a watcher at the bedside of "Bud" Stephenson, who killed Town Marshal Whitehurst on July 4, and who is still confined to his a bed with the wounds received at that time.
Flint Co. of this city sent the following circular latter, which explains itself, to representative manufacturers throughout the country, under date of July 20:

PORT RICHMOND, S.L. July 27 -- The Salvation Army of America has entrenched itself in Prohibition Park, and under its flags of yellow, blue, and red, the soldiers of salvation are making determined rallies against Satan.

The relations between the Collector's department of the New-York Custom House and Col. J. Thomas Scharf, the special agent recently appointed to investigate the cases of Chinese who make applications for landing at this port, have become more strained than ever.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Gen. A.J. Warner, President at the Bimetallic League, who issued the call for the Chicago silver Convention Aug. 1. gave out this afternoon this statement as to the object of the convention:

Manufacturers who have closed their mills because of canceled orders, bankers whose doors are temporarily shut, and merchants who have suspended operations will have considerable time on their hands during the coming weeks. We advise them to employ it in diligent missionary effort to promote the repeal of the purchase clause of the Sherman act.
Wall Street felt better yesterday. Wednesday's scare seemed to have worn itself out, and generally more favorable conditions prevailed.

CONEY lSLAND, L.I., July 27 -- The mystery that hung over the identity of the man who was Killed by the bolt of lightning last evening and of his three companions, who were injured, was due to the overzealousness of one of the sleuths of the Coney Island police. This Vidooq naturally asked the injured men and woman their names and the name of their companion who had been killed.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 27. -- Cashier E.S. Francis of the Pittsfield National Bank shot and killed himself in his room at the Maplewood Hotel this morning at 10:30 o'clock.

John B. Butler, a Harlem business man, had a novel experience when he went to his home, 238 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, about 3:40 o'clock yesterday morning. When he reached his front door he discovered that he had left his latchkey at his club. He was annoyed, because he did not wish to awaken his family at that hour, but he soon found a way out of his dilemma.

CHARLESTON, West Va., July 27. -- The speed of the Maacotte, the Government steam yacht built by Charles Ward, the inventor of the Ward coil boiler, was tested to-day under the observation or A.M. Scott, the Government Engineer, for whose use it was made, and Charles Ward and others.

Ten of the self-elected delegates to the silver conference which will be held in Chicago Aug. I met yesterday afternoon at the office of Richard Lacey, 7 Old Slip. At the meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Tuesday night fifteen delegates were chosen to go to Chicago. The delegates were all appointed by the Chairman of the meeting, and consisted of those who had called the silverite's together.

NEW-YORK. THURSDAY, July 27 -- P.M. The tide turned in Wall Street to-day, and the change came when least expected. In the morning the Governing Committee of the Exchange met and discussed the propriety of closing the board, the Clearing House Committee issued $1,300,000 loan certificates to the banks, and in the loan crowd call money commanded 75 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- The military era of the world's Fair win open with the month of August Militia from all parts of the United States will be in attendance. The West Point cadets will also pitch their tents along the lake shore, in front of the Government Building.

We see nothing remarkable in Commissioner ANDREWS'S request that the Commissioners of Accounts should make an examination of the books and accounts and financial methods of the Street-Cleaning Department under his predecessor. He naturally desires to know just where he stands.
LONDON, Jnly 27. -- John Rogers, husband of Minnie Palmer, the well-known American actress, has instituted proceedings for a divorce from Miss Palmer.

Dr. A.W. Wheeler, the United States Marine Hospital Surgeon, who was recently sent abroad by the Treasury Department to examine into the sanitary condition of the ports where emigrants are embarked for this country, yesterday sent the following communication to Dr. Senuer, Commissioner of Emigration:

Reiner, the miser, is dead. The Public Administrator yesterday took more than $10,000 in cash oat of an old iron-bound trunk which the miser kept in his squalid room. In addition there wore in the trunk fifteen diamond rings, eight loose diamonds, five pairs of diamond earrings, six diamond studs, ten sold watches, three silver watches, and a lot of miscellaneous coins and trinkets.

Chairman J.F. Goddard of the Trunk Line Commission proposes to investigate the alleged manipulation of the half-fare excursion tickets to Chicago by scalpers. Reports are current that certain of the roads interested are slyly paying commissions to scalpers, thereby practically converting the scalpers into drummers for the said roads.

We suppose that there are not many lawyers within the city limits of Brooklyn and outside the law office of the District Attorney of Kings Connty who regard "bucket shops" as just as legitimate and just as legal as the Stock Exchange. Nor do we think there are many who, if they were also officers of the law, would care to advertise that they-are ready to take the proprietors of bucket shops as their clients.
Mrs. Fannie Korn of 101 West Sixty-eighth Street was placed on trial in the Court of General Sessions yesterday charged with murder in the first degree.
Surrogate Ransom handed down an opinion in the Fayerweather will case yesterday.

The state of affairs at the Monmouth Park track was anything but pleasing yesterday. There were few people there to take even a languid interest in what was going on. The racing was decidedly of the off-color sort. Originally there were forty-two entries for the six races. When owners and trainers got through declaring their horses out of the several races there were but twenty-nine horses left to start.

WOODSIDE. L.I., July 28 -- The little village of Woodside Heights has never had a sensation before, and the present tumult over the appearance of a ghost, practical joker, or escaped lunatic, at the village well, as told in to-day's New-York TIMES, has agitated the entire community.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The Federal Council held a meeting to-day to consider what customs reprisals should be made against Russia for the increased duties levied by that country on German products. The Council finally resolved to place an additional tax of 50 per cent. on all Russian products imported into Germany. The new duties will be collected on and after Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Because of the conflicting statements regarding the number of failures of national banks Controller Eckels prepared the following statement to-day, which will undoubtedly strengthen public confidence: "Recent dispatches having appeared in the newspapers to the effect that since Jan. 1, 1893, '200 banks' have failed, the following statement has been prepared that the public may be property informed:

LONDON, July 28 -- The annual manoeuvres between the red and blue squadrons began with the declaration of war at 10 o'clock last night. The red fleets, under Vice Admiral H. Fairfax, consist or thirty-one men-of-war and about a dozen torpedo boats. The blue fleets, under the command of Rear Admiral Fitzroy, are of proximately similar strength.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- It was 4 o'clock to-day whan the final game of the championship in the doubles in the lawn tennis tournament was started on the St. George Club's grounds, and the fair-sized crowd that had gathered to witness the match manifested much impatience and openly showed their disgust, which the management fully merited. When the day's sport ended it was after 7 o'clock and growing dark.

LONDON, July 28 -- The tone was buoyant to-day and a strong opening was quickly followed by advancing prices. Americans opened about 1 per cent, above parities and the speculative favorites advanced another one in spite of four small failures.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Navy Department is now engaged in a set of experiments that will be of great interest to coal producers. The purpose is to find an American bituminous coal for naval use that shall be free-burning, non-coking, and smokeless.

The disclosure in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday morning that there was a "green-goods" place being operated in a saloon at 69 Dey Street, kept by Charles Walchow, caused some activity among the police of the Second Precinct.
Helen Dauvray, the actress, may be arrested for contempt of court.

BOSTON, July 28 -- The market opened a shade better and continued dull until about 1 o'clock. Money at the Clearing House this morning Between the banks loaned at 7 3-10 and 8 P cent. One prominent bank which has so far maintained the 7 3-10 P cent, rate, marked up to 8 P cent. with the result that some of the loans were paid off with Clearing House cortificates.

COURTS-MARTIAL have been ordered to convene at Fort Clark, Texas. Detail: Capts. C.R. Paul. C.H. Potter, Eighteenth Infantry; H.S. Kilbourne. Assistant Surgeon; H.H. Adams, John Anderson, First Lieut. F.M. Beall, Second Lieut. W.F. Grote; Second Lieut. G.D. Moore, Eighteenth Infantry, Judge Advocate.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 28 -- The Camp of Instruction will be almost deserted tomorrow, when the Twenty-second Regiment leaves the plateau on its return to New-York. That the regiment has more than fulfilled the anticipations of its most sanguine friends is borne oat by the brilliant record it made during the week.

The Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen has suspended C.M. Murphy pending an investigation into his amateur standing. His friends were greatly surprised, and they are trying every means to find a way to save him.

The Monmouth race course in years past has bad a reputation of respectability, but the parties who now control have resolved to banish the gentlemen who represent the Tribune and THE TIMES because of the unvarnished tales they told of rascality practiced there to enrich the men who control the "bookmaking."

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., July 28 -- The village of Round Lake was handsomely decorated this afternoon as the little car drove in from Saratoga with Gov. Flower, Mrs. Flower, and Mrs. Schley on board. The station was packed with people who cheered the Governor as he was driven away.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 28 -- The tax budget for this city was completed by the Finance Commissioners yesterday and signed by Mayor Wanser before his departure, notwithstanding the official statement given out that the budget would not be completed until Monday.
PARIS, July 28 -- The wine docks at Bercy, a suburb of Paris, were on fire this morning. Ten thousand caska and 500 hogsheads of wine were destroyed. The loss is placed at 4,000,0001.

-- The Logansport Manufacturing Company has commenced suit in the Circuit Court in Indiana for $75,000 damages against the Wabash Railroad Company. On the afternoon of July 14 last the buildings at the manufacturing company in Logansport were destroyed by fire, entailing a loss of nearly $100,000. The manufacturing company claims that their buildings were set on fire by sparks from a Wabash locomotive, which passed just before the fire broke out.
There was much excitement for a short time at and near the ferry slip at East Tenth Street about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon because the lives of a babe and its mother were in peril.

The poor starting of "Jimmie" McLaughlin was the feature at Brighton Beach yesterday. In three of the races one of the starters was lelt standing still, while in the other events the fields were strung out when the flag was dropped. For the miserable starts McLaughlin was not wholly to blame, however, for the boys at Brighton Beach are an unruly set.

WASHINGTON, July 28 --- The official announ cement of these appointments, made from the White House this evening, threw the few politicians remaining in the city into a fever of excitement. Recent declarations by people who are now shown to have been drawing upon their imaginations purely had created the impression in some quarters that some one of the frequently-mentioned candidates for these important positions would be named.

CAMP WERTS, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 28 -- The guards will be called in, drawn up before post headquarters, and the colors lowered at noon to-morrow. Col. Campbell will retire from the command of the brigade, and the camp will be formally closed. The troops will not begin to leave camp, however, for two hours thereafter. Much work will have to be done.

The fifth annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club will be sailed to-day on the Sound off Greenwich. The club steamer Crystal Stream will leave the foot of East Thirty-first Street at 7:30 o'clock this morning, the steamboat dock at Greenwich at 10:30, and the Indian Harbor hotel dock at 10:45.

-- Considerable interest has been aroused in the cricket matches which have been arranged for to-day, the meeting of the Manhattan and the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Prospect Park providing one of the most promising contests. The Staten Island Cricket Club will also play at Prospect Park, where it meets the Brooklyns in a championship match, and the Paterson team plays its return game at Morris Park.

--The Jersey City Tennis Club, the Bergen Point Tennis Club of Bayonne, and the Hillside Tennis Club of Plainfield are having a hot fight for the interclub championship. The Jersey City Tennis Club is at present in the lead, with three victories and but one defeat. The Bergan Point Tennis Club comes next, with two victories and two defeats, and the Hillside Tennis Club it last, with one victory and three defeats.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 28 -- Both Low, President of Columbia College, opened the third session of the congress on higher education in the Art Palace this morning by briefly outlining the educational work of Columbia College.

Controller MYERS is quite right in scrutinizing very closely the claims of the Commissioners who appraised the value of the property to be taken for a public park at Corlears Hook, and in having an investigation of their work made. The value of the property to be taken is but something over $1,300,000, and the Commissioners have been five years in finding it out, and have made up charges for their services amounting to $57,000.
Col. Scharf yesterday completed his investigation into the cases of the three alleged Chinese merchants who were permitted to land from the steamer Yumuri, which arrived here from Havana July 20.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Capt. O'Rourke introduced his new Wilkesbarro pitcher, Stockdale, to a Washington crowd this afternoon, and the honors of the occasion were distinctly his. He not only pitched a good game, but fielded his position admirably and batted like a veteran. The New-Yorkers could do nothing with him except in the third inning, where Rusie's three-bagger and Ward's single earned the only run the visitors scored.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 28 -- The reception tendered Mgr. Satolli this evening by Catholics of Minnesota was one of the moat brilliant affairs of its kind ever given in Sr. Paul. At least 2,000 people from thirty different towns were present.
Benny Bernstein exhibited his soulling propeller, which he has constructed for the steam launch Terror, in Parlor K. Astor House, yesterday afternoon.
The news of ex-Justice Kilbreth's appointment reached New-York about 7 o'clock last evening. It soon spread about the city.

PATERSON, N.Y., July 28 -- While Patrick McVilla, sexton of St. John's parochial school, was trimming shrubbery in the Catholic cemetery, a spark from his pipe ignited the withered grass, and soon flames spread in all directions, enveloping him and the monuments around. McVilla pulled his cap over his ears and made a break through the fire, half blinded and half suffocated by the smoke.
The result of the Campania's effort to wrest the championship from the fleet American liner Paris was made known at 10:19 o'clock last night, when the Cunarder made her appearance off Fire Island.

There was a large trading in wheat to-day under realizing orders with a good deal of nervousness over the Wall Street situation, while there was reported a bank failure at Chicago. Prices broke fully 1 3/4 @2c, reacting a little toward the close. Corn was fairly well supported at moderate supplies. Flour was offered at weak prices and ruled dull.
JERSEY City, July 28 -- Prosecutor Winfield on Tuesday laid before Judge Lippincott the following letter:

Mr. William Kennelly sold under foreclosure for $5,700 to Emeline Shaw, the plaintiff in the action, premises on Alexander Avenue, west side, 85 feet north of One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, 15 by 75. Other sales announced for yesterday were adjourned without date.

BANGKOK, July 28 -- The representatives Here of the several powers, the leading merchants of the city, and the commanders of the British and German gunboats met to-day at the British legation to discuss what action should be taken in the event of rioting on the part of the Chinese, who form a large percentage of the city's population.

LONDON, July 28 -- The hand-to-hand conflict in the House of Commons last night has made a deep impression throughout the country, and on every side much regret is expressed that the affair should have occurred.

Katharine Kreutzer, the wife of Kaspar Kreutzer, a German tailor, who lives at 528 East One Hundred and Fifty-third Street, committed suicide yesterday morning at 1 o'clock by hanging herself to a rafter in the cellar. Mrs. Kreutzer's mind was unbalanced and she had often said that the Lord had demanded that she should sacrifice her seven-year-old daughter.

Nearly every savings bank in New-York, Brooklyn, and Williamsburg was represented at a meeting held yesterday afternoon at the offices of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Institution in Chambers Street.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 28 -- At 10 o'clock this morning, one hour before the time set for the execution of Walter E. Shaw, the matricide, a telegram was received from Gov. Hogg granting a respite of one week to examine into Shaw's mental condition.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The indications now favor the belief that the purchases of silver by the Government this month will not much exceed 2,500,000 ounces. Today 250,000 ounces of the white metal was offered at prices ranging from 70.50 to 70.60.

George Lotz, a medical student, who has been attending the lectures at the Medical Department of Columbia College during the past four years, committed suicide yesterdar afternoon in his room at 428 East Seventy-second Street, by taking hydrochloric acid.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Oscar P. Schmidt, Secretary, has up to this afternoon received the following entries for the national regatta to be held on the Detroit River at Detriolt, Mich., by the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on Aug. 9 and 10,1893:

WSHINGTON, July 28 -- It is a source of surprise to many people that with the opening of the extraordinary session of Congress, only ten days away, there is but a Corporal's guard of Senators and Representatives in the city at present.

Whoever will take the trouble to imagine it will have no difficulty in imagining the tone in winch the London press would have discussed the occurrence of a free and general fight in a legislative chamber, if only that chamber had been of the House of Representatives at Washington, and not of the House of Commons at Westminster.

Willie Gromlich, a seven-year-old boy, strayed away on Monday last. The police found him and sent for his mother, but before she put in an appearance to claim her wandering child be strayed away again. He is still lost and his mother is grief stricken. Sergt. David Porter of the Church Street Police Station is now under charges from his superior officers for allowing him to get away a second time.

The America's Cup Committee has decided that the series of races for the America's Cup will begin on Oct. 5. This date was selected some time ago, but Lord Dunraven wrote and asked that if possible the races take place in September, as the end of October was a bad time for the Valkyrie to make the return trip across the ocean to England.

The Marsh Family Association of this country is composed of descendants of seven of that name who emigrated to America between 1633 and 1675, all coming from England, and settling in Massachusetts and Connecticut. It is believed that their descendants to-day number 200,000. The relationship between three or four of the seven has been established, out the connection of the others cannot be determined, though it is thought that all were related.

Good Government Club A at the corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, held one of its informal meetings Thursday night at the clubhouse. There was a talk by Mr. W. Harris Roome, followed by music by the quartet from the Lamba' Beneficial and Social Circle. Mr. Roome spoke on "Home Rule." He said:

OCALA, Fla., July 28 -- Railroad men arriving here from Sanford, the headquarters of the South Florida Railroad, report the sale of the entire system of the Florida Central and Peninsular Railroad Company to the Plant Investment Company, controlled by H.H. Plant of New-York. The price paid was $13,000,000. The new management will take charge Oct. 1.
Bradstreet's in its issue of to-morrow summarizes its telegraphic advices as follows:

EX-GOV. Alonto B. Cornell owes the Mnnhattan Trust Company $10,000 for money loaned. The company obtained judgment, and when it could not be collected, the ex-Governor, was summoned in supplementary proceedings.
The money market was active. Call loans were made at 3@25 P cent., the average being about 15 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.
Lawyer J. Baptist Marshall, attorney for Delia Keegan, who has sued Russell Sage for $100,000, as told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, yesterday served this notice on Mr. Sage:
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 28 -- The following mills in Burrillville have closed: A.L. Sayles Sons, Arnold Perkins, Job F. Flake, Jr., W.A. Inman, William Tintham Co., J.D. Nichols Sons.

COOPERSTOWN, July 28 -- Walter H. Bunn, who has just been appointed Appraiser of the Port of New-York, was born at Morris, Otsego County, July 21, 1840. He has been a resident of this village for twenty years. He studied law with Judge Samuel Bowne of Morris, who served for a time as member of Congress.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 28 -- City Treasuror Brightman is trying to negotiate loans to carry on municipal business. The financial pinch in other parts of the country is just beginning to be felt here to a considerable extent. The water-works-extension department, which this rear was to have been provided for by loans, baa partially closed, most of the laborers having been discharged temporarily.

Committeemen Hughes, Judge, and Extance, of the Kings County Board of Supervisors, who were delegated to probe the Veteran-Burial-Fund frauds, held another session yesterday and succeeded in finding more corruption.

Wall Street had a variety of experiences yesterday. In the morning there was a fall display of strength, and in the afternoon there were declines, due largely to rumors affecting two or three properties. The result of it all was a list which was pretty evenly divided between gains and losses for the day.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The President to-day leaned a proclamation in regard to reciprocity of wrecking between the United States and Canada.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Utler demoralization characterized the wheat market throughout the session to-day and all previous records for low prices were again broken. There was a veritable panic on the part of holders of long wheat to get rid of their enormous load. One firm is reported as paying as high as 3 1/2 c a bushel to carry over a large line of wheat into September.

The veterans of the Morris Part Cricket club played their first game yesterday at Morris Park, and succeeded in obtaining a victory over the team or the steamer Teutonic by 114 runs. The fine batting of A. Golfer, A.H. Fowler, and J. Garland contributed materially to this result, while the bowling of W.H. Rutty and Henry Martin was excellent J. Davis hit out for the saliors for 43.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Judge Stein's citation to appear, a response to contempt proceedings was answered by Director General Davis and, with few exceptions, the members of the Council of Administration and Directory of the World's Columbian Exposition. The respondents appeared in court under a rule to show cause why they were not acting in violation of the Clingman injunction by closing the World's Fair gates on Sunday.

NEW-YORK. FRIDAY, July 28 -- P.M. The impetus under which the market closed yesterday, together with still higher quotations from London, carried prices up sharply at the opening to-day. The bear leaders fought desperately, but the advancing tendency was not checked for an hour or more.

-- E. Headley of the Paasalo Boat Club, Newark, N.J., and Aman of the Fairmounts, Philadelphia, are among the entries in the senior angles at the regatta in Patapsco Bay to-day. In the entries for four and eight oared events are several crews from the Schuylkill Navy. Fairmount, and older Philadelphia boat clubs. Two clubs from Washington are represented, the Potomacs and Anoiostans.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Controller Eckels has placed the national banks that failed yesterday in the hands of Bank Examiners, as follows: Examiner Weightman, in charge of the Oregon National, at Portland, Oregon; Flynn, Ellensburg National, of Ellensburg, Washington; Wilson, First National of Helena, Mon.; Lyman, Montana National of Helena; Jennings, First National of Spokane, Washington, and Bostwick, of the First National of Middlesborough, Tenn.

HOTEL WENTWORTH, NEW-CASTLE, N.H., July 28 -- Malcolm G. Chase of Brown and Robert D. Wrenn of Harvard appeared on the exhibition court this morning in finals to decide the ownership of the handsome solid silver loving cup, the first prize in singles in the tennis tournament this year. Both men throughout the set struggled for the net. Then it was a question of who could pass the other.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 -- Quite an excitement was created on 'Change to-day by the news that cash wheat had taken a drop of 3 cents. This action was the result of the announced intention of Chicago bankers to call in all call loans made to the elevator men on wheat.

-- The annual athletic carnival of the Scottish societies in Chicago next week will be of unusual importance. It will likely take four days to work through the long programme. Two days will be given up to professionals, amateurs will take the third, and the fourth will be taken up by the lacrosse match between the champion Shamrocks of Montreal and the Toronto Club.

Postmaster Charles W. Dayton and Chief Engineer Birdsall of the Department of Public Works are members of the Commission for the Improvement of Park Avenue by the raising of the tracks of the New-York and Harlem Railroad from One Hundred and Sixth Street to Harlem River. Yesterday Controller Myers sent a request to Corporation Counsel Clark for an opinion as to his right to pay these Commissioners.
The proposition to have the Government run early Sunday morning newspaper trains out of New-York is one which meets with great favor wherever it is suggested.

Washington E. Connor's resignation from the Republican Club because of the address prepared by the club's Committee on National Affairs, with the apparent indorsement of the club, attributing the present financial troubles to the Democratic Administration, provoked varied comment yesterday among Republican bankers, business man and politicians.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 28 -- There is now little doubt that Commissioner General Garneau of the Nebraska World's Fair Commission will be requested to resign, failing in which he will be summarily removed from office. Gov. Crounse is out of the State at present, and Lieut. Gov. Majors, with the virtual sanction of the Chief Executive, will do the decapitation act.

Anton Rump, who keeps a saloon at 225 East Forty-fourth Street, bad a wife who mysteriously disappeared about a month ago. Several hundred dollars of the profits of his saloon are deposited in a savings bank in her name, and to prevent her from disposing of the money he secured an attachment in the City Court yesterday from Judge Newburger against the deposits.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The following call has been issued:

George W. Meeks was appointed yesterday to be Superintendent of Delivery at the General Post Office in place of Samuel B. Bowne, who was placed in charge of the newspaper mail division. Mr. Meeks has been in the employ of the Post Office for about twenty years, holding various places of responsibility and acquitting himself well in all of them.

-- A bicycle club has been organized at Long Branch with twenty charter members. The officers are as follows: President -- Charles H. Throckmorton; Secretary and Treasurer -- Leon Cubberly; Captain -- Charles L. Edwards; Bugler-E.S. Tilton. The club will hold a road race and carnival on Wednesday, Aug. 16, and the following committee has been appointed to make the necessary arrangements: Alfred Seaman, Lean Cubberly, Charles L. Edwards, John Gifferd, and E.V. Walton.

The man who said that "all Americans abroad are social adventurers" made his escape. The writer of this volume insists that the American abroad is just as good as anybody else, and if he keeps to his nationality he is a little better. There are snobs at home and abroad, but the most insufferable of them is the Anglo-American, or the Franco-American snob, and, wonderful to relate, a Russian-American is sometimes discoverable.

LONDON, July 29 -- Emperor William, on board the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, arrived at Dover this morning from Kiel. Count von Hatzfeldt, German Ambassador to Great Britain, was awaiting the arrival of toe yacht. He at once embarked, and the Hohenzollern proceeded westward for the Solent.
William Archer in the London World says of the performance of Jules Lacroix's French version of the "Edipus Tyrannus" of Sophocles by the Comedie Francaise at Drury Lane:

GALVESTON, Texas, July 29 -- The harbor improvement work at this port has now reached such a stage that the ultimate success of the jetty system in giving all the water needed on the bar at the entrance to Galveston Bay is admitted, even by those who at first were inclined to doubt the feasibility of the plan.
PASIS, July 24 -- Gradually, but with fatal repetition, all the old and celebrated Parisian landmarks disappear, tossed by the treadmill of progress and change into the long oblivion of yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., July 29 -- A clever swindling scheme has been worked in Trenton, Camden, New-Brunswick, Princeton, and other towns. It was insuring credulous, persons, principally colored, in an inustrial insurance company which only existed in the minds of the fraudulent agents. It is supposed that the amount realized was upward of $5,000.

So rapidly have the managers of the Monmouth Park Association been losing money this season, owing to the perfectly absurd manner in which they have been running affairs, that they are not able or willing to pay for the license under which they are carrying on their business or "Improving the breed of horses."

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 29 -- A reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES found Judge Kilbreth in his charming home here to-day. The Judge is as brown as an Indian from the outdoor life which he so thoroughly enjoys.

LONDON, July 29 -- Skies are clearing over slam and the ominous clouds which threatened to precipitate a European war are fading away toward the horizon. How long the patchwork truce will last is a matter on which conjecture is free to exercise itself.

We hardly know whether ex-Judge KILBRETH and Mr. BUNN are to be congratulated or not upon their appointment as Collector and Appraiser at the Port of New-York. Both are men of excellent reputation, and Judge KILBRETH, in particular, is well known and highly respected in this community.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 29. -- The Twenty-second Regiment has in made the record for which it has been working. It left camp to-day with a percentage of 88.10, the highest made this year. Some of the regiments have approached this record, but they have not equaled it.
The National Industrial Alliance is hurling out abuse at the men who got up the silver meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last week, which was presided over by ex-Senator Boyd.

Honors were evenly divided at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. Two games wore played and Philadelphia and Brooklyn each won one. The Brooklyns stood a capital chance to win both, but lost the first game in the last inning when the Quakers made a fine spurt.
