It should be understood that the action of the Executive Committee of the Associated Savings Banks of this State, recommending that Trustees exercise their power to require notice of the withdrawal of funds, was taken wholly for the protection of depositors, and is entirely in their interest.

The appointment of ex-Police Justice James T. Kilbreth as Collector of the Port of New-York and of Walter H. Bunn as Appraiser has been received favorably by the Democratic Party of New-York, and all the leaders have kind and encouraging things to say of the new appointees.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The decleration contained in a recent letter from New-York to the Louisville Courier-Journal that the tariff would have no place in Mr. Cleveland's message to Congress, is taken by a local paper to be authoritative for the reason that the writer of the letter in question enjoys the confidence of a prominent member of the Administration.

The lowest price on record was reached yesterday in the wheat market, when sales were made in Chicago at 56 1/4 cents a bushel. The sharp decline of prices on Friday and Saturday in the Chicago market, which rules all other wheat markets this side of the Rocky Mountains, was due directly to the calling of loans which had been made by the banks to owners of wheat stored in that city.

ORANGE, N.J., July 29 -- Mrs. Sohmidt and Mrs. Saubenheimer, who live on Fulton street, Orange Valley, were yesterday afternoon picking blackberries in the woods above Montrose, on the side of the Orange Mountains. They were horrified at ending the body of a man lying on the ground with blood streaming from a gash in his throat and his head lying in a small market basket.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 29 -- This week has been the most brilliant in the most successful Summer in the history of this charming place. As a fitting close to such a week, was the superb annual hop at the Glenada tonight. In honor of the event, Proprietor Gerard made the place a picture of fairyland by illuminating the hotel, the casino, and the grounds beautifully.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- Major Pangborn, President of the Associated American Exhibitors, made a speech to-day before the National Commission which caused a decided sensation.
MILWAUKEE, July 29 -- The Commercial Bank of Eau Claire, Wis., is in the hands of a receiver. Runs were started on other banks, but were counteracted by heavy deposits by many leading business men.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 29 -- Col. Nathan Toomer, one of the wealthiest colored men living in the South, instituted suit to-day for $100,000 against the Pullman Palace Car Company. Nathan Toomer is nearly white and is one of the largest landowners in Augusta, Ga. He has represented his district in the Legislature and is a prominent leader of the negroes of the South.

KINGSTON, July 18 -- The Island of Jamaica, British West Indies, claims to be a sufferer under the workings of the McKinley act. The Government of Jamaica arranged with the Government or the United States for reciprocal trade under that act. To comply with the requirements of the act, Jamaica had to make very largo additions to her free list.

The provisional detachment of the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, the First and Second Batteries of the National Guard, and Light Battery K of the First Artillery of the United States Army departed for the State Camp at Peekskill yesterday morning.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 29 -- The first dancing assemblage of note this season was given this evening at the Pequot House, on invitation of the management issued early in the week. It brought together all the dancing element of the Summer contingent at the hotel and cottages and from the country residences of society people in the vicinity.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 29 -- The week has been a gay one in Oyster Bay, well-known society people being guests and visitors, and pretty teas and other attractive features have been the order of the day. The Seawanhaka Yacht Club's house on Centre Island has been a potent attraction, as usual, to cruising yachtsmen as well as to visitors from the mainland.

STRANGE AMUSEMENTS -- In 1654 the public punishment of criminals became a prominent feature of carnival. It was felt to be a serious-check upon the gayety of the festival, but excused as an awful example for such as were inclined to profit by the general license for criminal behavior -- rendered necessary now that precept had been found inadequate to cope with the disorders.

The members of the Hartford Club are feeling particularly Jubliant this week, as they have just acquired title to their eight-thousand-Acre tract in Sullivan County, N.Y. The knights of the rod are in ecstacy over the news that the tract embraces four lakes well stocked with bass, pickerel, and perch, besides two trout streams well known to lovers of angling.

LONDON, July 29 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- If negotiations over the Siamese question during the last week had resulted in open rupture and the prospect of a great foreign war had loomed imminent upon these islands, I fancy Englishmen would still he giving first place in their minds to that astonishing scene on the floor of their Parliament Thursday night.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- The local market has been irregular and feverish, but recovered somewhat in the last few minutes and closed steady. There was a moderate demand for Pennsylvania, which recovered to 49, there being very little stock offered. Lehigh Valley was sold down by bear traders to 33 1/2, subsequently railying to 33 5/8.

The West Side Gang made another raid Friday afternoon on the "Dolly Vardon" train of the New-York Central Railroad, running between the Thirtieth Street station and Spuyten Dayvil. As a result half a dozen members were caught by the police and are now on Blackwell's Island.

"We take everything in sight," said a Russian fish vendor to a reporter for THE NEW-York TIMES yesterday, at Essex and Hester Streets. "What difference does it make if we take up the street with our carts? There is nobody in this neighborhood but Russians, and I am sure none of them complain."

ARVERNE, L.I., July 29 -- Those fortunate New-Yorkers who decided upon Arverne for their Summer's stay are congratulating themselves upon their choice and find, their lines cast in pleasant places indeed. It is not wonderful that this charming place has bounded into favor. It is only remarkable that its incomparable advantages were not discovered before.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 29 -- Summer visitors to this village seem to delight in picnics, and every few days there is a party formed for a day in the woods. The favorite spot is some seven miles up country, under the shadow of Lantern Hill, so called from the fact that it is the first land seen when coming in from the ocean.

-- The Lycenm Theatre will reopen a week from to-morrow night, when E.H. Sothern will begin his annual engagement. He will revive "Lettarblair" for three weeks, alter which he will present his new play. "Sheridan," by Paul M. Potter. The scene of the first two acts of "Sheridan" is the old historical city of Bath. In 1774, when the action of the play begins.

The Imports for the week, exclusive of specie, were $9,549,731, of which amount $2,689,594 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports at specie were $1,752,885 and the exports of specie were $901,840.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 29. -- The long-expected debate on the silver question came off to-day, with variations from the original announcement. Representative Michael D. Harter of Ohio arrived in due season, but Senator William M. Stewart of Nevada did not come. A man known as "Farmer" Dean of Honeoye Falls, N.Y., came as a substitute for Senator Stewart.
BOSTON, July 20 -- The Globe's Scotch yachting correspondent, in giving further details of the racing on the Clyde and in Belfast Lough, and in comparing the tour new British racing cutters, says:

The annual regatta of t e Indian Harbor Yacht Club was sailed yesterday on Long Island Sound. Sixty entries had been made, but owing to the heavy rainstorm in the morning the number of starters was reduced to thlrty-one.

"Do you know," said a prominent electrician to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES the other day, "that there are a number of reputable physicians in New-York and Brooklyn who while pretending to cure their patients by electricity, are actually endangering their lives by misuse of the electrical current?" On being asked for an explanation he said:

HARTFORD, Conn., July 29. -- Work has been stopped at the copper mine at Bristol. The managers say that they abandon working the mine for the present owing to the difficulty in raising money. Pumps will be kept at work to prevent the mine flooding.

QUEENSTOWN, July 29 -- The arrival of the Chicago in this place created a great deal of excitement, particularly among the lower classes, who at once connected her presence with the measures now under consideration in relation to home rule. The papers declared that Admiral Erben and Capt. Mahan, whose names they twisted into Erbyne and Mahon, had been particularly selected on account of their Irish descent to come over here.
REMINISCENCES OF THACKERAY -- In the Spring of 1859, shortly after I was engaged to be married, I was staying at Oxford, and received from him the following letters:

At the end of the eighth inning the score of the game on the Polo Grounds yesterday was even, and the followers of the Giants began to grow fearful. Little German had pitched another excellent game of ball, but the support given him was not of the best character. After retiring the Senators the New-Yorks delighted the onlookers by sending in the 1 run necessary to win through good batting by Tiernan and O'Connor.

SARATOGA, July 29 -- The last week in July in Saratoga has been accompanied in its passing by some sharp thunderstorms, with one cold day and evening that brought out fur capes. The storm of the early part of the week was very severe on Mount McGregor, the wind approaching a cyclone in its fury, twisting trees and blowing the rain in blinding swirls over the summit.

The fondness in this country for a water life is a growing one. Every season sees a creator number of persons practically living afloat, and as there are unlimited waterways in every direction, there is every chance that the practice will continue to be more and more widely observed.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 29. -- The Fourth Regiment returned to this city from Sea Girt at 5:15 this afternoon. The men were bronzed and hearty-looking, and said they had enjoyed their excursion greatly, but were not sorry it was over.
Richard C. Gordon, who is twenty-six years old, and who is in the cotton business at Savannah, Ga., with his brother, W.W. Gordon, had an experience yesterday that he will not forget for some time.

Some of the most effective cotton gowns owe much to the use of white braid. This is employed in various widths and put on in a wonderful variety of wars. A blue-and-white-striped cotton had a wide band of the stripes around the skirt some distance from the foot. The stripes, which were narrow and alternat- ing, ran up and down in the skirt and horizontally in the band.

-- One of those unpleasant amateur weather prophets is at it again, predicting that we shall have a wave of great warmth resulting in severe storms between Aug. 2 and the night of Aug. 4. Excessive heat is to be followed by thunder, lightning, hall, and wind, and perhaps seismic disturbances, with phenomenally low barometric pressure and direful cloudbursts.

-- The Sculpture Society appears to find favor with the public since the Secretary, Mr. Ruckstuhl, reports that a hundred members, elected by the special Nomination Committee, had qualified by the end of June, and that the second hundred are now rapidly coming in. The Fall will see many more accepting their nominations or submitting their names for membership.

BOOKS DO NOT MAKE MEN -- Masses of accurate knowledge existed in the world before books began -- witness the older triumphs of architecture and hydraulics -- and much of it was handed on from generation to generation, as the secrets of farming and cattle breeding are now, without any writing at all.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., July 29. -- The plant of the United Indurated Fibre Company was entirely destroyed by fire this morning, only the pulp mill used in connecnection with the works being saved. The whole plant was valued at $200,000, and the loss is $100,000; insurance, $172,000. The fire was caused by the explosion of gas from an overheated oven, and resulted from carelessness of Night Watchman Frederick O'Donnell, who was burned to death.

RELIEVED FROM DUTY -- The following-named offi- cers are relieved from duty at the institutions of learning designated opposite their respective names, to take effect Sept. 1, and will then proceed to join their respective companies: Capt. Herbert S. Foster, Twentieth Infantry, University of Vermont, Burlington. Vt.; Capt. John C. Dent, Twentieth Infantry, state Agricultural College of Colorado, Fort Collins, Colorado.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- The World's Fair will be open to-morrow, Sunday. This was settled last night at a meeting of the Council of Administration, at which resolutions were adopted reciting the proceedings in the Clingman injunction suit, and finally ordering:

Alonzo Robinson, thirteen years of age, of 40 West Sixty-seventh Street, and Percy Nicolls, aged eleven, of 36 West Sixty-seventh Street, both colored, tried in genuine highwayman style yesterday afternoon to snatch a purse from Mrs. Emma Bancker of 100 West Sixty-ninth Street.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 29 -- Though the last week has been marked by the same quiet which usually characterizes this quaint old Summer resort, yet the visitors have found ways to amuse themselves without making any special display.

LENOX, Mass., July 29 -- The cottagers have been greatly interested this weak in Wall Street. They have kept the telegraph operators pretty busy for the last few days. This anxiety has detracted somewhat from social entertainments, although there has been a good deal going on daring the week.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 29 -- Vice President Stevenson and party arrived from Victoria at 12 o'clock yesterday, and were at once driven to the Rainier Hotel. A trip on the lake had been planned, but in view of the warm weather and the fact that Mrs. Stevenson was much fatigued, it was decided to enjoy the cool breezes from the Hotel Rainier.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- It is reported to-night that Mr. Crisp will reach the city to-morrow night. This is a change of programme on his part, tint it will be welcomed by many who are anxious that the present apathy in Washington shall speedily end. With the prospective: Speaker of the next House in the city, and the candidates for the next important positions opening headquarters, next week promises to be very lively.
From Table Talk, At Stoke-upon-Trent was established in 1791 the pottery now so famous for its beautiful products, and which bears the name of its founder, Thomas Minton.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., July 29 -- The Summer is slipping pleasantly by at this popular little resort. Gen. Earie has no reason to feel depressed, for his big hotel is filled to its utmost capacity, and on Saturday night cots have to be called into requisition.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 29 -- The sweet domesticity -- yes, that is the proper indication of "our house" by the sea, and the tranquil landscape lying on the land side-a plain studded with verdure and umbrageous trees, runs to the well-wooded hills -- have been much changed the past week by the presence of the military, the annual encampment of the State Militia.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 29 -- Henry A. White, Chairman of the Butler County Populist Committee, when asked "What's the matter with the price of wheat?" proceeded to give the "plutocrats" and Republicans a scoring. His most striking remark was that the Socialists of Germany and the Nihilists of Russia had their counterpart in the People's Party of America.

"We made over our house lately," says a woman who has lived for some time in a large town in the interier of the Stats, "and I was surprised one day while the work was still in progress by a visit from one of the expressmen of the place. He was driving by, when he suddenly reined in, and, stopping, came up on the piazza, where I was standing.

"A large number of the diamonds found in the trade," said a member of one of the leading diamond firms of this city, "come from the Cape mines at the southern end of Africa. There are seven or eight of these mines, the largest being the Kimberly, which covers some twenty acres of land. In the last sixteen years these mines have yielded largely, many fine stoues having been found.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29 -- The arrival of three Russian men-of-war in the harbor yesterday caused a ripple of excitement, as it bad been reported that they would not come to Newport but would proceed into Eastern waters. The vessels are the Dimitri Donskoi, the Admiral Nachimoff, and the Khynda, with Admiral Kaznakoff in command.

BOSTON, July 29 -- To-night the last performance of "Amorita," by the Pauline Hall Opera Company, was given at the Tremont Theatre, and Sunflow, the strong man, ended his engagement there. Next week Miss Ball will appear in a revival of "Puritanla," and Aug. 14 in "Mme Favart." It has been found to be impracticable to bring oat here this season, as promised, that new opera by McClellan and De Koven.

LONDON, July 29 -- Markets opened firm to-day, but became dull and closed weak on feats caused by cables from America stating that over 300 banks had failed since May 1 and that New-York and Brooklyn savings banks had passed a resolution to insist on a sixty-day notice for withdrawal of deposits.

Milk was made purposely a loosely-united fluid so that it should be more easily assimllated by young life. At a temperature not much above normal milk goes to pieces. When agitated it splits up. No manor how a single element in milk is taken from it, its nutritive qualities as a whole are notably diminished. It might be called the most "susceptible" of fluids, and on that account the most liable to fermentation.

NETHERTVOOD HEIGHTS, N.J., July 29 -- The season thus far at the Netherwood has been one of the most brilliant and prosperous in the history of the hotel. The register shows a large number of prominent families from the principal cities. The season at this point has really been phenomenal.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- A report was telegraphed from New-York last night that the Gas Trust would pass the next dividend, would issue $10,000,000 of bonds for construction purposes, and that arrangements had been made to place the bonds. C.K.G. Billings was at Geneva Lake last night. Lyman J. Gage and Charles Henrotin had heard no such report.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 29 -- The Summer days are passing pleasantly in Sea Cliff, and the proverbial marriage bells are not merrier. Happy days merge into jolly evenings, and the man who comes to scoff remains to celebrate his existence.

The Morris Park Cricket Club, for the second time this season, encountered the Paterson eleven in a league game and again Buffered defeat, this time by 46 runs. The game took place at Morris Park, where the heavy rain of the morning only helped to make the hard ground in better condition for batting than usual.

PARIS, July 29 -- At the Herald office in this city it is said that nothing has been heard to confirm the rumor of James Gordon Beunett's relapse. Members of the staff regard the rumor as having no foundation in fact.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 29 -- It has been an uneventful week save for the ball at the West End on Thursday. Bathing, driving, dancing, and flirting by the guests; growling, complain ing, and figuring by the proprietors summarizes it. The ball was a big affair, conspicuous for its display or diamonds. The Casino, it goes without saying, was tastefully fixed up for the occasion.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29 -- The Ohio Asylum for the Epileptic Insane at Gallipolis will be ready for the reception of male patients by October, when five cottages will have been completed. It is the first institution for the separate care and treatment of this class of unfortunates that has been established in the United States, and has cost thus far about $300,000, the site having been given to the State.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, July 29 -- The fact that Mrs. Grant is to spend a part of August on the St. Lawrence River calls to mind the visit of her husband, which brought the Thousand Islands into prominence as a Summer resort. The Islands were said to have been discovered by Gen. Grant. This is not true, but thousands discovered the attractiveness and charms of the Thousand Islands through Gen. Grant's influence.

There is something rather kaleidoscopic in the Sunday aspect of Jackson Park in the City of Chicago. On one Sunday the "White City" within its walls is silent add deserted, and the exotic settlements of the Midway Plaisance are lonesome and forlorn for lack of paying patrons, while the excluded crowd that flees from the Chicago streets gazes disconsolately upon the barred gates.

Mr. Issac Townsend Smith, the present Consul General for Siam, in New-York, has been connected for over forty Years with the Siamese Government as financial agent, Consul, and Consul General, and is therefore well qualified to speak of the little kingdom whose quarrel with France may have such far-reaching resuits.
RAHWAY, N.J., July 29 -- Mr. Bayard Woodruff and his daughter, Miss Carrie, are at Saratoga Springs.
The Philadelphia Cricket Club sent its second team to Staten Island yesterday, where they played a very exciting game with the home team, defeating them by the narrow margin of 2 runs.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- It was said at the Treasury Department to-day that the dispatch in THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning regarding the July silver purchases represented the situation accurately.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29 -- The cigarette tax law of this State, which goes into effect Aug. 1, and from which so much was expected by Republican lawmakers, turns out to be a very easily-evaded enactment. The American Tobacco Company has had agents actively at work in the State, and will, probably secure through the law a practical monopoly of the cigarette business in Ohio.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 29 -- The prettiest contest that has taken place in the Amateur Baseball League this year was played this afternoon between the New-Jersey Athletic Club and the Englewood Field Club. The New-Jerseys scored the only ran made, clinching the Amateur League championship. Both pitchers were admirably supported, but that given Westervelt could not have been excelled.

SOUTH ACTON, Mass., July 29 -- No. 2 Corning Mill of the American Powder Company blow up at 8:20 o'clock this morning. One man, named William Clone of Oxbridge, Mass., aged about twenty-seven, unmarried, was instantly killed. He had been working for the company two years. His body was not badly mutilated. The explosion was very severe, and broke most of the glass in buildings near the mills.

The nautical experts who follow the fortunes of the world afloat from the little Ship News office at the Battery were gratified yesterday to learn that they were only one minute out in their calculations of the Campania's time.

A half hour before the time for the performance to begin at Eldorado last night flames were discovered under the stage and an alarm was given. Before assistance arrived $500 worth of costumes were consumed and King Solomon's temple, which was once before struck by lightning, was destroyed.

Concerning that much-talked-of enterprise of the fair, the Woman's Dormitory, of which much was hoped by women of slender purses, one who has personally experienced its advantages and disadvantages speaks as follows:

In a cell in the Jefferson Market Prison there is languishing a young man just turned twenty-one years of age. His name is John Dore, by profession he is a banjo teacher, and he may well serve as the proverbial "dreadful warning" to young men who, when dealing with womankind, add to the handicap of a small income an equally small supply of common sense.

Matters are shaping themselves for a most brilliant meet in Chicago next week, under the management of the League of American Wheelmen. For the past ten weeks, committees have been busily employed perfecting the arrangements, and as the time for holding this meet approaches, everything is shaping toward a successful termination of their efforts.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 29. -- The annual bicycle meet of the Asbury Park Athletic Association took place this afternoon on the grounds of the association on the bunks of Deal Lack. There were over 2,000 spectators present, a large number of whom were guests from the fashionable hotels. Just before noon a heavy rain fell, which deterred many from going to the grounds.

There was comparatively little excitement on The Stock Exchange yesterday, but for a half holiday a fair amount of business was transacted. As a rule prices were lower. The bears were an active as ever and in some shares they succeeded in forcing a substantial decline.

KINGSTON, N.Y., July 29 -- The faces of all the hotel proprietors in the Catskills are now wreathed in smiles as pleasant to see as a refreshing mountain landscape bathed in the morning sun, for August, the best month in the whole Summer, promises to be much more profitable to them than they had expected.
The weekly bank statement issued to-day showed a decrease in reserve of $3,045,125. The banks now hold $4,301,675 less than the legal requirements.
There was no scare among the depositors in the New-York savings banks yesterday.

CHAPTER I. Count Jozsi and Count Felix, Kaplinski were strikingly unlike as they stood side by side in the doorway of Count-Balinski's large reception hall, in which the guests were at this moment dancing, a lively mazurka. This evening the brothers were, for a wonder, enjoying the same scene, and both were admiring the two belles of Warsaw, Doris and Marya Balinski.

The auction offerings announced for the present week are all in legal proceedings, as is customary at this season of the year. The sales given in the list appended are to be held at 111 Broadway, unless otherwise stated.

The Treasury officials are determined to stop the illegal landing of Chinese at this port if they can do it Under advices from Washington an Inspector was sent to Canada yesterday to look into the matter of bringing Chinese across the border. The suspicion is that the majority of the Chinamen now coming to this city are coming from Canada.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 29 -- Major James S. Yard, a member of the Law and Order League of Monmouth County and an opponent of the Monmouth Park race track, prints the following editorial in his paper, the Democrat, published Thursday:
PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 29 -- Mrs. Amelia Sandford and daughters of Sandford Avenue have left Tarrytown, N.Y., and are now at Watch Hill, R.I., for the rest of the Summer.

ORANGE, N.J., July 29. -- The Once a Month Club was entertained this afternoon by William B. Williams, general manager of the Union News Company, at his beautiful home on Essex Avenue. The nineteen business men who compose the club dine together once a month as the guest of a member, and each host strives to outdo in novelty and sumptuousness the efforts of his predecessor.

ASBURY PARK, July 29 -- The social event of the week was the kirmess held in the Opera House for the benefit of the beach band fund. The hotel guests and cottagers took an active interest in the affair, which was both a social and financial success. Capt. Charles W. Eddy and Mrs. Helen Miles drilled and coached the children for the dances and marches, and the youngsters acted their parts creditably.

His Highness the Nawab of Rampur, the East Indian Prince who in at the Windsor Hotel, is troubled because he thinks a breach of courtesy has been made by one of his suits. Statements were made by Merza Farrokhy, the learned man who came to this city in advance of the Nawab and was interviewed as to the relative rank of the Nawab and the Rajah who was here a week ago.

The results of an inquiry as to the origin of an epidemic of diphtheria in Hightstown, N.J., show once more how the germs of contagious or infectious diseases are carried and disseminated by the milk supply. It was discovered at the beginning of the investigation that eighteen out of twenty cases then under observation were in families which procured milk from the same dairy farmer.

The first electric locomotive of any considerable size in the United States and the first high-speed electric locomotive of any importance in the world was completed recently at the Lynn Works of the General Electric Company, and was sent to the Chicago Exposition on July 14. It is now on exhibition in the Transportation Annex.

The unusually severe weather which prevailed in Pike County, Penn., last Winter -- the thermometer often dropped so low that it was compelled to retire to a snowbank to keep warm -- did great harm to the small game with which the preserves of the Blooming Grove Park Association are so well stocked. Even the deer suffered greatly, but the crop of bears seems to have thrived and waxed numerous.

The monetary conditions which have prevailed for several weeks, and which culminated in such surprising results in the stock market daring the past few days, have commanded much attention from real estate speculators and brokers. It is now right in the midst of the dull season, when transactions are few, and when customers as well as brokers like to take their vacations from business.

Schedules of the assets and liabilities of Lawyer Francis H. Weeks, who disappeared After failure and assignment on April 26, were filed yesterday by Assignee Richard W.G. Welling with Clerk Kieley of the Court of Common Pleas.

MANHANSET HOUSE, SHELTER ISLAND, July 29 -- Yachts are birds of passage, and of the great fleet of nearly 100 large pleasure craft which filled the harbor a week ago many have flown. But their flight is irregular and varied by many wheelings and returnings to this favorite harbor; and if "Collie" Colt takes his Dauntless away to-day, Mr. Flakier is likely to bring his Alicia in to-morrow.

"There are many strange ways of getting a living in this world," said a farmer from Ulster County to a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. "What do you suppose I am going to New-York for at this time of the year when farmers should be harvesting their crops?"
BALTIMORE, July 29 -- "Will start at once. Hold lady. Will pay all expenses," was the telegram, dated Chicago, received to-day from Dr. George Kriehn or the Johns Hopkins University.

The savings banks in Brooklyn are not worried over the situation, and while several of them have taken advantage of the rule requiring depositors to give thirty or sixty days' notice before withdrawing money, others have refused to put the rule in operation, believing it to be unwise.

The floral decorations within St. James's Palace were most exquisite. The staircases were bordered with blossoms, while overhead hung baskets from which fell sprays of orchids. There were plenty of roses on the alter of the chapel, and the entrance without was arranged with yellow carnations, white hydrangeas, fuchsias, marguerites, and forns.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., July 29 -- Never before in the history of Hightstown has there been such a generous use or whitewash as during the past week. The epidemic of diphtheria has led everybody to cleaning, and, as a consequence, the town has run short of lime. Everything is whitewashed, oven to the curbstones, throughout the borough.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., July 29 -- There are few bits of river scenery as perfect as that of the Delaware, here at the Gap, in the moonlight of the present week. The little steamer Kittatinny has been in constant commission each beautiful evening, and, together with a small flotilla of cedar craft, has kept afloat a merry lot of people.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29 -- The cultivation of his rich friends is breeding trouble for Gov. McKinley. Many of the humbler party workers are greatly disgusted at his exclusive ways. The Governor's behavior has been such as to suggest that he cares little for the mass of his party, except for its votes.

DENVER, July 29. -- The committee of the Chamber of Commerce and Board of Trade appointed to prepare a memorial to Congress in favor of the increase of the circulating medium of the country by the free coinage of the silver produced from the mines of the United States and to demand a paying out of the money hoarded in the vaults of the Treasury, has made its report.
LAKE GEORGE, July 29 -- For a week a stiff gale has been sweeping the lake and thunderstorms have been numerous, but the weather does not seem to have affected the spirits of the Summer visitors.

Jacob Worth, the leader of the regular machine Republicans in Brooklyn, has let his cat out of the bag. He has come out in favor of a straight Republican candidate for Mayor tills Fall. The Republican boss, regarding the time as propitious, had himself interviewed the middle of the week on the political outlook by one of the Democratic newspapers of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Theodora M. Erck of 752 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, is suing her mother-in-law, Mrs. Mary Erck of 36 Thomas Street. Brooklyn, for $25,500 for deceit and fraud in inducing her to marry Joseph Erck, the son of the defendant.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, July 29 -- P.M. The stock market opened fairly steady, with the exception of Chicago Gas and General Electric. In the former the first sale was anywhere between 41 and 44, against 47 at the close yesterday, and it fluctuated hetween 40 and 43 3/4 for the remainder of the session, closing at 42 5/8, a net loss-of 4 3/8 points.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- A peculiar accident, which resulted in the death of one woman and serious injury to three others, occurred at the east end of the Harrison Street bridge this afternoon. An open car approached the bridge at a good rate of speed. As the car struck the east end of the bridge the latter shook and swayed up and down for a moment.

Events moved rapidly in the Siamese complication yesterday. Great Britain having notified France that she would decline to recognize the French blockade of Siam and that such a blockade would be construed as an act of hostility against the British flag, France hastened to except ships of Great Britain from the blockade.

BERLIN, July 29 -- It is generally held here that the tariff war that has been started between Russia and Germany is more likely to cause damage to the former country than to the latter. It seems that Russia, in applying her maximum tariff on German products, was mainly influenced by the unfavorable early reports regarding the harvest prospects in Germany.

Many prominent Canadian residents of this city met on Thursday night at 352 West Fifty-first Street and formed themselves into a society for the furtherance of endeavors to bring about the annexation of Canada with the United States.

Ex-Gov. Thomas A. Osborne of Kansas, a Republican and a Director in the Central National Bank of Topeka, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. He presided over the Kansas State Bimetallic Convention, held at Topeka on July 20, which protested against the demonetization of silver by Congress. He said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:
The last month of Summer brings forth rich gifts from its treasure house to make the moonlit and starlit nights sources of untiring enjoyment. The August stars are beautiful.

BLADENSBURG, Md., July 28 -- Not far from the City of Washington lies the sleepy little town of Bladensburgh, made famous by the battle fought there on the 24th of August. 1814. The British troops, following up the vanquished Americans, reached Washington, but, though occupying it only one day, they in that short time burned the Capitol, the Executive Mansion, and other Government property.

Nathan Straus's charitable milk depot on the pier at the foot of East Third Street has justified its existence and shown the humane wisdom of its idea from the day of its opening, on the 1st of last June.

The French naval manoeuvres for 1893 ended on July 28. The period of manoeuvre extended over nine days. The manoeuvre work was confined mostly to the Mediterranean. The entire reserve fleet was called out to operate with the active fleet. Vice Admiral Vigues was Commander in Chief in the Mediterranean this year. His chief of staff was Capt. Roustan.

The weakly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $3,045,125. The banks new hold $4,301,675 less than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $2,705,300, a decrease in specle of $1,221,400, a decrease in legal tenders of $3,898,500, a decrease in deposits of $8,299,100, and an increase in circulation of $110,900.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 30 -- Unless the Rev. Edward Bell, editor of the Astoria Republican, resigns from the committee appointed by Ringgold Post of the Grand Army to collect subscriptions for a soldiers' monument in front of the Queens County Court House in Long Island City, it is probable the memorial may never be built.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An article upon the social and political traits of Canadians appeared in your issue or the 10th inst. As the author refers to me therein under a slight misnomer, might I ask you to allow me a few words in reply?

OMAHA, Neb., July 30 -- Judge Dundy of the United States District Court yesterday afternoon suspended the Nebraska maximum-rate law. passed by the last Legislature, which would have become operative on Aug. 1. The theory on which the court granted the order is that the law reduces rates to such a low figure that it practically confiscates all Nebraska railroad property without compensation.

Robert Dunlap, sixteen years old, of 104 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, visited the stables of the Borden Condensed Milk Company, 98 Sterling Place, yesterday morning to tee his father, who is foreman there. While passing one of the stalls he accidentally brushed against, the tail of a mule. The mule kicked young Dunlap in the head, knocking him across the stable.

Underwriters continue to be exercised over the unprofitable character of the business of fire insurance, and at a loss for the means of putting it on a more satisfactory basis. Their troubles hare been generally attributed to two causes -- unrestrained competition, which has resulted in taking risks at too low a rate, and an increasing scale of losses by fire, which cannot be safely calculated.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 30 -- A thousand-dollar bond of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Indianapolis Road was stolen twenty years ago while the series was being printed by a Cincinnati firm. Thirty-eight of the coupons have been paid, aggregating $1,330.

Maurice Grau, of the theatrical firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, was feeling very happy yesterday when he stepped ashore from the French steamer La Bourgogne. His work in Europe had been a success, and he was bringing to his partners in the management of the Metropolitan Opera House a bundle of contracts with some of the best singers on the Continent.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Admiral Gherardi, commandant of the New-York Navy Yard, has sent to the Navy Department his estimates for repairs and improvements of the yard, during the next fiscal year. The work which is contemplated will cost in the neighborhood of $2,500,000, the estimate under the Bureau of Yards and Docks alone aggregating $2,186,414.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 30 -- Donald McNaughton, executive officer of the New-York State World's Fair Commission, died in the New-York State Building at the fair grounds to-night.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 30 -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel Halleron, pastor of Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church. Jersey City Heights, in the preludo to his sermon this morning attacked ex-Sheriff Davis and County Clerk McLaughlin.

The manufacturers whose business has beau disturbed by the new duty on tin, the metal, which was imposed on July 1, and the importers who are said to have lost $2,000,000 in their attempts to procure a very large supply of tin before that date. will be interested in Tin and Terne's explanation of the failure to produce the metal in this country.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 30 -- Senator John Martin is now a pronounced Administration man, not because of any special influences brought to bear upon him, but, because he sees in this decision the foundation of a strong Democratic Party in Kansas.

BERLIN, July 30 -- As was expected, Germany's response to Russia's tariff discriminations against her has been swift and drastic. In France hopes are nursed that the general diplomatic relations between the two countries and Courts will be disturbed by this commercial warfare. The belief here is that the friendly feeling consequent on the Czarowitch's two recent visits in Berlin will not be altered by the dispute as to customs taxes.

The following article by Louis Windmuller, entitled "A Brief History of the Present Crisis," is to appear in the Outlook in its issue of Aug. 5. It is now published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES by permission:
The latest development in the matter of providing an American pension for the Duke of VERAGUA is full of suggestion to the people of this great Republic.

BERLIN, July 30 -- Public interest has been divided during the last week between the Franco-Siamese quarrel and the Russo-German tariff war. Important as is the Federal Council's summary action against Russia, it has hardly reached in public opinion the plane of high international politics occupied by the Siamese question.
CITY OF MEXICO, July 30 -- It is expected that President Diaz will soon issue a decree outlining a plan for a considerable reduction of the army by the disbandment of 4,000 or 5,000 men.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 30 -- George T. Weed, who was appointed Collector or the Port of Plattsburg yesterday, is a son of Smith M. Weed, and for a number of years he has been prominent in Northern New-York politics.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 30 -- The body of Miss Genevieve Schultz was found in Tonawanda Creek, just outside the village of Batavia, this morning. She had been missing from home all night. Her death is very mysterious.
DENVER, Col., July 30 -- The situation in Colorado has been grossly exaggerated by correspondents of the Eastern press.
LONDON, July 31 -- The Daily Graphic says editorially to-day:

The work of preparing for the Grand Circuit meeting at Fleetwood is progressing steadily. The grand stand is being cleaned and fixed up better than in its palmiest days. Everything about the ground is receiving attention, fences are painted, bushes trimmed, and the band stand enlarged. The local trainers orders to vacato all stalls at the track a week before the visiting stables are due to arrive.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 30 -- Sandford Sons' carpet mills shut down last night for at least two weeks. They employ 2,000 hands. The following mills and factories have also closed: The Van Antwerp Knitting Mills, indefinitely; Johnstown Knitting Company's mills, two weeks; Shuler Spring Works, one week, and Starin Silk Mill at Fultonville, two weeks.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 30 -- Bishop Wigger presided this afternoon at the dedication of the nev school building erected by St. Nicholas's Roman Catholic Church in Washington Place at a cost of $25,000. The Bishop drove over from South Orange. He was met at the city limits by a number of invited guests in carriages.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- The exposition was open to-day under the order of the court, but the attendance was extremely light. The grounds were almost deserted, and the visitors in the buildings might easily have been counted. During the morning hours almost the only persons entering the gates were exhibitors, their helpers, and others employed in the grounds, but between noon and 3 o'clock the cars landed a few visitors at the gates.

OTTAWA, July 30 -- One of the first official acts of the new United States Consul here, J.B. Riley of Plattsburg, was to furnish the State Department at Washington with information in regard to the action of the Canadian customs authorities in stamping boxes of American cheese, which are passing through Canada in bond for shipment to Europe, with the words, "United States produce."

The fine weather yesterday brought the oarsmen out in full force, and the Harlem was dotted with all manner of craft from the single shell to the eight or ten oared barge. The balconies of the clubhouses were filled with members who preferred to watch and pass Judgment upon their more energetic followmember, while hundreds paused on the bridges or loitered on the banks to watch the animated scene.

The programme of the eighth annual convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, to be held in Detroit on Sept. 14 to 17, inclusive, was announced on Saturday at the executive offices of the organization, at 13 Astor Place, this city.

BANGKOK, July 30 -- While the Government of Siam accepted without reservations France's ultimatum, it received previously the assurance that the kingdom would not be dismembered until after the consideration by all powers concerned of France's demand for the territory between the eighteenth and twenty-third parallels.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 -- The first german of the season was given by T.R. Proctor at the Spring House last evening. The wide veranda in front of the main drawing room was hung with mammoth Chinese lanterns and baskets of blooming plants. The whole house had a holiday air. Men in evening dress were rushing about the corridors looking for lost benquets, lost fans, and, possibly, lost hearts.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- With the Speaker of the next House domiciled in his old quarters at the Metropolitan Hotel, and a dozen or more Representatives and correspondents paying their respects to him, the lethargy which has marked matters political in Washington for weeks may be said to have disappeared to-day.

BUFFALO, July 30 -- A family living in this city may soon become the possessors of more than $25,000,000. They claim to be the nearest heirs to the estate of Philip Reinhardt, who died intestate in India about forty years ago.
In this season of ocean records the performance of the British steamship Dorset, which yesterday arrived from Brazilian ports, should have a conspicuous place.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 30 -- The good people of the East who still imagine that the Indians of the West are mere helpless children, victims of the vices and the greed of the white men, will hare their eyes opened by reading the report of Sub-Agent J.J. Walsh of the Coeur d'Alene Reservation, in Idaho, just across the line from Washington.

Because a young married woman, of New-Hampshire became tired of her husband, an honest house carpenter, and loathed pork and beans and pumpkin pie and longed for pate de foie gras, orange souffle, terrapins, and canvasback duck, there came misfortune to her. Josephine's fine epidermis was scratched with such a coarse material as homespun, and required nothing short of lace, and duchess, honiton, and point d'Alencon at that.

The Sandy Hook boats carried enormous crowds of Sunday excursionists to the upper New-Jersey shore resorts yesterday. From the first trip in the morning until the last in the evening the boats were loaded from end to end, and on the return voyages in the evening hundreds of pleasure seekers bad to get along without seats, notwithstanding that these boats have better seating accommodations than most of the vessels in the harbor.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- About 100 delegates to the National Silver Convention had registered at the headquarters in the Montauk Block up to this evening. According to the advices received by the Committee on Arrangements, fully ten times this number will be on hand within the next twenty-four hours.

PROVIDENCE, July 29 -- The existing stringency which now dominates the larger financial centres of the country has been conspicuously reflected in our local money market during the past week. Loans and discounts are now made simply as accommodations to regular customers, and 7 cent, may fairly be quoted as the minimum rate in Rood two-name paper on notes, with high-class collateral security.

BERLIN, July 30 -- Prince Bismarck went to Kissingen yesterday by way of Goettingen. He received all the cheers and homage to which he had been accustomed on his previous Summer journeys since his retirement from office. At every station a crowd of admirers awaited his train and manifested the usual enthusiasm when he showed himself at the window of his railway carriage.

PARIS, July 30 -- The meeting of Ministers to consider Siam's unreserved acceptance of France's ultimatum was held at the Elysee between 5 and 7 o'clock this evening. President Carnot came from Marly-le-Roi to preside.
BALTIMORE, July 30 -- The second annual regatta of the Patapsco Navy was held yesterday over the regular course and was in every respect a success. The winners of the several events were as follows:

BUENOS AYRES, July 30 -- The Radicals have begun a revolutionary movement in the Provinces of Buenos Ayres and Santa Fe, and fighting has teen going on in twenty towns in the first-named Province since daybreak to-day.

The steamer Grand Republic made a landing at the Battery last night on her last trip from Rockaway Beach, with all her lights out. This caused a rumor that the vessel had met with a serious accident, but the lights had simply been put out because of a silent accident to the engine which works the dynamo.

A compact and snug little political territory is the Fifth Assembly District, a rectangular section of the most thickly-populated part of the east side of the city, where there is plenty of interest taken in politics and where Democracy is dominant, of course.

The sentimental side of the subject of drunkenness has been so often presented that we welcome this volume, which has no maudlin nonsense about it. The book is not in any sense a textbook of teetotalism; it is not even written expressly for the physician. What Dr. Wilson wishes to explain, never losing the hope of remedying what is among the most terrible of evils, is that drunkenness is a nervous discase.
COLLECTION OF CERTAIN DEBTS. -- "Inquirer": May a debt accumulated for drinking strong liquors at a public inn be collected, according to the laws of the State of New-York?

LONDON, July 30 -- The measurements of Royal Phelps Carroll's Navahoe have not yet been received at Cowes from the Yacht Racing Association. Tomorrow, therefore, she may race unmeasured. Many yachtsmen at Cowes find the Navahoe quite similar to the Satanita. Of all the large tonners she has the heaviest rating.

The British naval manoeuvres for the rear 1893 began Friday last. The period of duration is ten days, and the field of operations is the waters in and about Great Britain and Ireland. There are eighty-five war ships and torpedo boats engaged. This is a larger number than the British Admiralty has over before been able to assemble for manoeuvre work.
A story was told in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday which caused even the old court loungers, accustomed as they are to the recital of queer and unusual tales, to marvel.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- One of the most daring robberies ever attempted in this city was committed at the residence of Mrs. R. Ammon, Saturday afternoon, in broad daylight. After binding and Ragging her the thieves carried away nor diamonds and gold watch, valued at $2,000, and made good their escape.

Thomas F. Waldron, bill clerk of the Brooklyn Board of Supervisors, who was brought into the investigation of the Grand Army burial frauds by the testimony of Henry Von Glahn at the hearing Friday, has made a statement denying that the thirty-five-dollar check with which he paid his rent came into his possession in an improper way.

The foreign exchange market was without special feature until Wednesday, when it felt the influence of the higher rates for call money, and a pressure of security bills. On Thursday the market was weak, but after that it was firmer and quiet. On Saturday posted rates were $4.82 for 60-day bills and $4.84 for demand.

Trans-Harlomites found recreation last sight in a fire that ravaged seven frame buildings and a brick house on the block whose boundaries are Lincoln and Third Avenues, the Southern Boulevard, and One Hundred and Thlrty-fourth Street. The loss was less than $35,000.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, July 31 -- A.M. Last week was one of considerable interest in Stock Exchange circles. For the first time in many weeks the bears met with opposition, but it did not come until they had pretty much everything their own way. Early in the week the Wisconsin Marina and Fire Inurance Bank of Milwaukee closed its doors, and banks in Indianapolis and Louisville as well as at several leas important points suspended.

On July 12 the British Admiralty authorities launched at Devonport dockyards the new first-class twin-screw torpedo gunboat Antelope. The Antelope is a vessel of 810 tons displacement. She was designed by W.H. White, Chief Constructor of the British Navy. Her principal dimensions are: Length, 230 feet; beam, 27 feet; main load draught, 8 feet 9 1/2 inches.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 30 -- A wedding ceremony, which was being celebrated with all the brilliant display attending Hebrew marriages, was brought to an abrupt close at this place to-night by the arrest of the bridegroom on a charge of at- tempting bigamy.

A dilspatch from Oakland, Cal., last night Stated that Ellsworth Westervelt, a New-York merchant, who recently visited friends in California, had mysteriously disappeared, and that alarm was felt for him.

This is to be decidedly an off year in State politics. Out of the forty-four States in the Union, only thirteen will hold State elections -- Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, Nebraska, New-Jersey, New-York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Dakota, Virginia, and Wisconsin. Iowa, Massachusetts, Ohio, Wisconsin, and Virginia alone will elect full tickets.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., July 30 -- With Col. William Evans in energetic -- in fact, almost gymnastic -- command, the Salvationists to-day fairly wrapped Prohibition Part in their favored "blood and fire." The three meetings duriug the day were given to the singing of hymne with a vigor that swamped the powerful band in attendance and to the giving of what is known in the "army" as "testimony."

TRENTON, N.J., July 30 -- Gov. Werts has been much amused, during the leisure time he had at camp to give to politics, to read about the bad humor of some of the Democrats up In Morris County. This is the Governor's voting place, and for many rears he took an active part in the counsels of his party. Since he had been Governor tab has been the subject of considerable comment.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., July 30 -- Three denominations worshipped in the East Avenue Baptist Church, in Long Island City, to-day -- the Roman Catholic, the Methodist, and the Baptist. The last was the only one of the three that was in its regular church.

The report of the Central News Agency at London concerning the prevalence of cholera at Naples not only confirms the early reports of the representative of our Government at that city, Dr. Young, but also convicts the Italian authorities and the diplomatic representatives of Italy in other European countries of an attempt to conceal important facts which should have been disclosed for the protection of the people of other nations.

The failure of Sunday opening of the World's Fair was made more complete and emphatic than ever last Sunday, when there were but 18,637 visitors. If all these were paying visitors, the receipts can scarcely have covered the running expenses of the fair for the day. If the smallness of the attendance had been brought about by the Sabbatarians, they would have a right-to point to it with pride.

Dr. August I. Burton, thirty-four years old and unmarried, was found dead in bed by his father, Dr. Reuben B. Burton, with whom he was in practice at 223 East Forty-eighth Street, yesterday morning. Death was due to chloral hydrate, but there is no proof that he committed suicide. There is evidence, however, that he drugged himself and was intemperate.

The half-Fare excursions to Chicago over the roads in the trunk line and the Central Traffic Association have thus far been more successful than some of the General Passenger Agents expected they would be. They have been so well patronized, in fact, that the ticket scalpers, both here and in Chicago, hover about them, like files around a barrel of sugar.

From Yesterday's Tribune. The Tribune's remarks of a week ago, relative to the great need of better mail facilities on Sunday mornings for distribution of the Sunday newspapers to points in various directions from New-York City nave been cordially commended by THE NEW-YORK TIMES. THE TIMES has united in the demand for better railroad mall arrangements from New-York City Sunday mornings in a manner which snows the energy and intelligence of its new business management.

The one subject of interest just now to every one in the horse and carriage trails in the refusal of Mayor Gilroy to renew the license of William East ton of Tattorsalis, Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, permitting him to act as auctioneer in this city, Mayor Gilroy has given out that he based his refusal on the fact of Director Easton being an alien and that no other cause influenced his decision.

There was a scene at the Monmonth Park track yesterday afternoon such as very few racegoers have ever seen. It was one that few of them would ever wish to see again. If Fred Taral has his way, they will never ace it with him as the principal actor.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- World's Fair exhibitors and employes betray no eagerness or disposition to conform to the order of the administration regarding the scrutiny and stamping of passes "good after August 1." Many of these full-term passholders say they are not going to run after the chief of their department or the subordinates of Superintendent Tucker to be inspected and investigated.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 31 -- The Italian war ship Etna, which arrived in port last evening, tired a salute of twenty-one guns, and expected to have an acknowledgement. This, however, was not forthcoming, and Admiral Magnaghi this morning was looking for some one to give him an explanation as to why the salute had not been returned.

MOUNT VERNON, July 31 -- Walter Reynolds, a stepson of Postmaster Charles L. Perry of New-Rochelle, and said to be a relative of ex-Vice President Levi P. Morton, was employed by Malloy Brothers, contractors for paving the streets of New-Rochelle, as general bookkeeper.

One of the principal troubles with which W.J. Gayner has had to contend in his unselfish efforts to purify the municipal administration of Brooklyn has been the small-minded people who have persistently accused him of trying to get the anti-machine Mayoralty nomination.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 31 -- Official returns that have just been issued, show a marked increase in the ravages at cholera in the parts of the empire where the disease is epidemic.

President Byrne of the Brooklyn Club has made a statement in reference to the alleged injustice done Richardson in laying him off without pay. He cites cases in which the player, while at home, reported for duty unfit to do himself justice, and avers that his condition was caused by drinking.

PLEASURE BAY, July 31 -- After all the preparations made for the open-air performance of "As You Like it" in the grove to the rear of the Hotel Avenel, the entertainment was spoiled by a storm of rain this evening.

DULUTH, Minn., July 31 -- C.H. Graves, exPresident of the Lake Superior Elevator Company, in speaking of the story relative to the use of forged paper, denies that any forgad paper had been used by the Northern Pacific Elevator Company. George Spencer, now President of the Lake Superior Elevator Company, also denied that any money had been obtained by the use of forged warehouse receipts.

To meet the needs of poor children and their mothers, who cannot leave their homes to go to any of the more distant fresh-air resorts, the Department of Charities and Correction have allotted to the Bartholdi Creche a very desirable spot on the western shore of Randall's Island, opposite East One Hundred and Twentieth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The estimate of 2,500,000 ounces as the limit of the silver purchases by the Treasury Department for July proves to have been too liberal. Acting Director of the Mint Preston accepted 216,000 ounces-to-day at .7030, which, swelled the total for the month to 2,384,000 ounces. This represents a shortage of 2,116,000 ounces in the amount which the department is authorized to purchase by the Sherman law.

We have steadily urged upon the American people the fact that the operation of the law of 1890 stood squarely in the way of the investment here of foreign, capital. As the time draws near when this obstacle is likely to be removed, the foreign capitalists are beginning though not in an extended way as yet, to take advantage of the conditions which the continuance of that absurd law has produced.

Unless some extraordinary power intervenes, Stephen Martin, who was paroled from the Elmira Refcrmatory, will be compelled to return to that institution solely because he cannot obtain employment. Young Martin is at present under the care or the Prison Association, and, from his story. It would seem that he is a victim of circumstances.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Berlin dispatch to THE NEW-YORK TIMES of July 24, in which the early dissolution of the Latin Union was suggested as more than probable, has found an echo here, and a diplomatic officer, who cannot allow the use of his name, talks freely about the subject. He regards the dissolution as extremely probable.

The National Quarantine Committee of the New-York Academy or Medicine is out with a bill which it proposes to have introduced in Congress for the purpose of establishing at Washington a National Health Bureau.

The biggest pleasure party that ever left this city, by way of the water at least, was the twentieth annual invitation excursion of the John F. Ahearn Association yesterday, when six barges and two steamboats, all crowded with holiday-makers, were picked up by two tugs at the foot of Clinton Street, East River, and taken to Washington Park, on the Hudson.

Collector Hendricks and ex-Justice James T. Kilbreth met for the first time at the Custom House yesterday afternoon. Collector Hendricks had been at his home in Syracuse for several days and did not intend to return to the Custom House until to-day. Upon reading that Judge Kilbreth would come up from Southampton yesterday, the Collector changed his plans and decided to be on hand to meet his successor.

At all of the savings banks in this city yesterday an unusual number of nervous depositors wanted their money. More than three-quarters of these wore women. With exceptions so few as to be conspicuous, those who went to the banks to draw out their savings were evidently illiterate. At the east side banks, where the depositors are mostly foreigners, the "run" was heaviest.
NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 31 -- John Stephenson, the veteran car builder, died at his home here this afternoon.

-- Louis Irig died in Whitney, Neb., last Friday morning, after a prolonged sleep of three months. He had been almost blind, but was a tireless worker and in good health until the beginning of his prolonged nap. The medical fraternity could not discover its cause. He had only two waking intervals -- once he was awake and talked lucidly for an hour and at the other time he staid awake only ten minutes.

The entries closed for the Chicago International bicycle races on Saturday last, and present a field unparalleled in the history of cycling. Every man of note in this country is entered, and all of them will come together in the international events. Some forty men are entered whose names do not appear on the list below, owing to the fact that no entrance fees accompanied the entry blanks.
BOSTON, July 31 -- The market opened irregular, but became firmer as the day advanced.

Judge Bartlett in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, decided that the will of the late Countess Catherine E. De Vandricourt. bequeathing to the "Home for the Blind in the City of Brooklyn" about $9,000, should be set aside.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Secretary Hoke Smith was shown the story telling how the residents of Rome, Ohio, had been aroused to anger when J. L. Reed, a soldier eighty-two years old, was dropped from the pension roll, and bad vented their wrath by making a straw dummy, christening it after the Secretary of the Interior, and then tossing it into a big fire.

There was a hand-to-hand conflict in a room just outside Controller's Myers's office yesterday afternoon between Howland B. Hall, a stenographer, and Benjamin F. Camp, once Superintendent of the New-York Post Office. Mr. Camp is well advanced in years, and Mr. Hall is young and strong.

Some attributed it to hard-luck, others to poor judgment, while a majority of the spectator a were charitable enough to believe that Stain bad one of those pushing days when he is almost invincible, but any fair-minded, unprejudiced person who knows anything about baseball and saw the game as Eastern Park yesterday. In which the Brooklyns presented the Giants with a string of "goose eggs," will admit that New-York played a poor game.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31 -- The officers of the savings banks of St. Paul held a meeting to-day and resolved to begin at once enforcing the State law allowing them thirty and sixty days' notice from depositors for the withdrawal of deposits. The action was taken as a precautionary measure.

A party of about sixty wheelmen from this city and vicinity will leave Saturday night for Chicago in a special car on the West Shore Railroad. At Rotterdam Junction, near Albany, they will be joined by about twenty men from Hartford and forty from Boston. They expect to arrive in Chicago early Monday morning and to spend two weeks there.

Joseph Herzog, twenty-nine years old, a light-complexioned and near-sighted German painter who is in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, awaiting a bearing on a charge of having assaulted a young girl, was identified yesterday as the man who cut a braid from the head of Caroline Clundt of 390 Linden Avenue.

LONDON, July 31 -- The regatta of the Royal London Yacht Club took place to-day off Cowes, Isle of Wight. A week never opened with greater elclat and a regatta never excited more lively interest. The Solent probably never before was so crowded with yachts and launches of every size and description and craft of every rig.
The death at Paris of Henri Francois Duchinski, the Polish scientist and patriot, is announced.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31 -- No trace of missing Anna Gray Orr has been found. Since early Saturday evening, when she disappeared, her father and scores of neighbors and several members of the Police Department of this city have searched the woods and swamps in the vicinity of Castle View, which was her home.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 31 -- Information has been received at Caldwell and other points that the Cherokee Strip will be opened about Sept. 1. In consequence of this news the towns and villages along the eastern border have begun to assume the appearance of camps, filled with anxious people.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- There will be a declaration of war to-morrow, and the signal of hostilities will be given by the combined convention of Populists, free silverites, and Greenbackers.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The visit to Washington of Thomas H. Shirley of Louisville on behalf of the Western banks who are carrying loans upon whisky in bond was not succesful. Mr. Shirley is a lawyer, and he represents in this matter banks in Louisville, Cincinnati, Chicago, and Pittsburg.
LIVINGSTON, Mon., July 31 -- The Park National Bank suspended payment this morning. No statement of its condition has yet been made.

For an hour yesterday morning the bears had things their own way on the Stock Exchange. Nearly everything on the list was down below the closing figures of Saturday, and it was hard to find a security with much support. Lake Shore broke 5 points, and Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, St. Paul, Rock Island, Chicago Gas, Sugar, Northwestern, and Manhattan all showed breaks of a couple of points or more.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 31 -- The Everett Woolen Mills, employing 250 hands, will shut down Saturday for a month to await a more settled financial situation.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 31 -- The new steel United States revenue cutter Hudson, built by John Dialogue Son, Camden, which is to be used in New-York Harbor as a boarding boat, was given her official trial trip on the Delaware River to-day.

The silver fanatics of Colorado are casting about for some means of establishing a "bimetallic currency" of their own in that State, independent of the rest of the country and the rest of the world. The Attorney General has been asked his opinion about the practicability of establishing depositories of silver bullion, upon which certificates might be issued and made assignable by delivery and receivable for dues to the State.

The disposition of a considerable number of depositors in savings banks to withdraw their money seems to continue and to be rather stimulated than checked by the announcement that notice would hereafter be required. That was inevitable on the familiar principle that the desire to withdraw money increases with any objection to its withdrawal, but it does not detract from the wisdom of the announcement.

The horses entered in the events at Brighton Beach yesterday were a poor lot, but the racing was fairly good and the finishes exciting. What was lacking in quality was made up in quantity, for in most of the races the Holds were large ones.
Money on call loaned at 3 @ 45 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.
About 5,000 people saw W.C. Williamson make his hot-air balloon ascension yesterday at Eldorado.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- It would be manifestly unfair, with only twenty or thirty members of Congress in town, to jump to an opinion as to what is to be the temper and the energy of the other 420 members of the two branches at the assembling of the extra session.

-- The Chicago track on which the international races will be run has been inspected and approved by the Track Committee, Messrs. Gerould, Van Sicklan, and Irwin. After some slight resurfacing to repair damages toy recent rains, it is said the track will be almost as smooth as glass.

PORT RICHMOND, S.L., July 31 -- The Summer campaign at the Salvation Army ended to-night. The forces of Satan have been put to ignominious flight, and fifty-one persons who had been doing battle in the ranks of evil have deserted to the legions of salvation.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 31 -- The detail from the Thirteenth Regiment of Brooklyn reached the State Camp at 1 o'clock this afternoon, and an hour later the First and Second Batteries of the State Guard and Battery K of the First Artillery, United States Army, arrived. The baggage was not all in camp until late in the day.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, July 31 -- P.M. The market opened weak on lower prices from London, a rush of soiling orders, and no support. Dispatches from London attributed the weakness there to the unfavorable showing made by our bank statement on Saturday, to liquidation for the local account, and to a certain amount of manipulation from this side.

A runaway car on the cable line made a sensation in Broadway between Twenty-third and Thirty-first Streets yesterday afternoon. A tangled thread in the cable became fastened in the grip of Car No. 117, ana John Carville, the gripman, could not drop the cable. Vehicles ahead of the car which could not get off the track were pushed along.

When the Senate Committee on Immigration, of which David B. Hill is Chairman, was in session in this city some months ago evidence was given before it tending to show that a number of Italian bankers here were engaged in the importation of contract labor, and that each of these bankers conducted an Italian banking business mainly as a cover for the illegal importation business.

Under foreclosure of mortgage, Mr. John N. Golding sold yesterday at 111 Broadway the four-story stonefront dwelling 109 West seventy-seventh Street, 18.6 by 104 by 15.4 by jog 3.2 by 3.2 by 100.8. Morris Mayor was the purchaser at $24,500.

Mr. Fred Gallatin's steam yacht Almy has been getting ready for a trip north at Tebo's Yard. She steamed to Bay Ridge yesterday afternoon and anchored there until Mr. Gallatin and his guests went aboard. She got her papers from the Custom House in the afternoon and was booked to steam from this port early this morning. Her first stopping place will be Buzzard's Hay Head.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Bertrand Nomitz, ex-manager of the Swiss exhibit of watches and jewelry, who came from Canada to answer the charges brought against him by Consul Holinger and Commissioner Perrenoud, accompanied Capt. Bonfield, the Swiss Consul, the Swiss Commissioner General, and Lawyer Richburg to Justice Porter's court to-day, where the case was continued by consent for one week.

BANGKOK, July 31 -- The uneasiness among the people here, far from lessening, is increasing. Seven more French gunboats have arrived at Koh-si-Chang, making a total of thirteen now there. Negotiations are still going on, but the progress made is not reported. The intentions of the French are awaited with fear and apprehension.

Collector HENDRICKS did a very imprudent thing in writing his letter of July 26 to Secretary CARLISLE questioning the propriety of the instructions of the Treasury Department in regard to authenticating the certificates of the Chinese Consul respecting the right of Chinamen leaving the country to return.

A distinguished party of ladies and gentlemen arrived in this city yesterday by the steamship Berlin from England on the way to Chicago. There were twenty-nine gentlemen and eight ladies in the party. The gentlemen comprised the royal commission detailed to visit the British section of the World's Fair in Chicago in behalf of the Society of Arts of Great Britain.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., July 31 -- County Detectives Oliver and Housell arrested City Recorder Henry Dillon, Marcus Stricker, and his son Joseph Stricker, all of Perth Amboy, yesterday, on the charge of extortion and collecting illegal fees. The complaint against the Recorder was made by Isaac B. Esbery, who charges him with demanding and receiving $1 Dec. 15, 1892, and $3.20 May 5, 1893, for receiving complaints, which fees are illegal.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Secretary Carlisle has taken a hand in the Chinese complication at New-York, which has been the occasion of so much friction recently between Treasury Agents and Collector Hendricks. Several letters have passed on the subject and Secretary Carlisle brings the matter to a close in the following letter, which on Saturday he sent to Collector Hendricks:

George Dole Wadley, General Superintendent of the Central Railroad of Georgia, has resigned, and his resignation has been accepted. T.D. Kline, formerly Superintendent of the Southwestern Railroad and lately General Manager of the Mexican National, was appointed to succeed him.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 31 -- The weather to day was warm and the track in excellent condition for racing. The attendance was large, and included the Rajai Rajagan of Kapurthala and suite, who occupied, five boxes on the east front of the grand stand. Gov. Flower was also present, this being his first visit to the truck this season.
Dionysius Latas, Archbishop of Zante, is in town with his secretary, the Rev. Homer Peratis, and is a guest at the St. Dents Hotel.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., July 31 -- Justus Sohl, fifty-five years old, proofreader on a market publication in New-York, received a ghastly welcome on his return from work to his home, 142 Twelfth Street, this city, this evening. It has been customary for his young wife to greet him as he stepped off the ferry, but she was not there this evening.

RONDOUT, N.Y., July 31 -- The cornorstone of the new Roman Catholic Church at Westshokan was laid with imposing ceremonies yesterday afternoon by Archbishop Corrigan. Among those who assisted were Bishop McDonnell, the Very Rev. Edward McKenna of Westchester County, the Very E.M. Sweeney of this city, the Rev. Eugene McKenna of West Hurley, and the Rev. James N. Connelly.

Mrs. Agnes Debus, the young woman who, on Friday last, either threw or dropped her baby into the East River front the ferryboat Southside when off the foot of East Tenth Street and then sprang after the child, was taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning from her home, 170 Avenue C. violently insane.

Peter Hughes, a laborer, living on the top floor of the three-story frame building 228 Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, beat his wife Bridget to death Sunday evening. He is looked up in the Adams Street Police Station and will be arraigned before Justice Walsh Thursday.
BUFFALO, Aug. 1 -- A hot fight is on between the upper and lower houses of Buffalo's municipal Legislature.

'For the first time this season the New-Yorks won a game from the Brooklyns yesterday afternoon. The latter bad won three straight games from the Giants, and the followers of the ex-champions were beginning to lose all hopes of checking the defeats when the Giants rose in their might and won with runs to spare. All of the victories achieved by Brooklyn were close, but not so, however, with the New-York game.

Burchard von Oettingen, Stud Master and Director of the Government Stud as Beberbeck, Germany, is at the Hoffman House on his way to the World's Fair to examine thoroughly the horses to be exhibited there. Herr von Oettingen is sent to this conn, try by the Emperor William to examine into our methods of breeding, training, feeding, and improving horses.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The mimic warfare between the red and blue fleets of the British Navy is being carried on in the Irish Sea. Combats between sections of the fleets are of daily occurrance, but nothing specially noteworthy has occurred.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- The National Convention of the American Bimetallic League met at 10 o'clock in this city this morning. The delegates overcrowded the First Methodist Church auditorium an hour before the meeting was called to order, and it was early apparent that a larger hall would have to be sought for future sessions.

Charles Trainor of 345 West Forty-third Street wanted to go up the Shrewsbury River yesterday, but instead he took an unexpected bath near Pier A. Just as the steamer Pleasure Bay was leaving her landing. Trainor started on a run and made a mighty jump, but he fell short of the boat and dropped into the water.
The duplex cable system was put into operation on the Broadway line at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. Smash-ups, defective grips, and delays need nave no terrors now for passengers.

-- Major Gen. Pierce M.B. Young having resigned his position as commander of the Georgia Division of the United Confederate Veterans because of his appointment as United States Minister to Guatemala, Gen. John B. Gordon.
