Commander in Chief of the association, announces that Gen. Clement A. Evans has been appointed to serve in his stead.

CITY ISLAND, Aug. 1 -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Allegra, Col. S. V.R. Cruger; Corsair, Mr. J. Plerpont Morgan, and Papoose, Mr. H.C. Baxter. Schooner yacht Fenella, Mr. William A. Hazard.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 1 -- Authentic advices received here state that Minister Blount has determined to turn over mutters in Hawaii, so far as the United States interests are concerned, to Commodore Skerret of the Boston, and will sail for the United States on Aug. 6 without waiting for the appointment of his successor.

There was a surprising shake-up in the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday. Three clerks in the construction department, one in the Storekeeper's department, one in the steam engineering department, and a copyist were decapitated, and six men from this side of the river took their places. The following are the changes made:

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 1 -- The attorneys of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Com- pany and the International and Great Northern Railroad were before District Judge Stewart this morning for the purpose of receiving from him a temporary injunction restraining the International and Great Northern Road from interfering with the contract entered into by the "Katy" with the Galveston, Houston and Henderson Railroad to transport its trains to and from Houston.
The Real Estate Salesroom in the Trinity Building made a show of animation yesterday. Four auction stands were occupied and others besides the usual visitors to the room were present.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Money at the Clearing House loaned at 7 3-10 and 8 cent. NewYork funds sold at $1 and $1.25 premium for cast, payable in Clearing House certificates. At the same time an offer was made to sell at 50c discount for greenbacks or gold. Several of the savings banks have enforced the sixty-day notice for amounts from $50 to $200.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The regatta of the Royal Southampton Yacht Club was held to-day. The contestants were A.D. Clarke's Satanita, P. Donaldson's Calluna, J. Jameson's Iverna, and the American yacht Navahoe, owned by Royal Phelps Carroll. The course was from Netley to and around the Brambles, then to the East Lepe buoy, then again around the Brambles -- a distance of forty miles.

Edward M. Morgan has been retained by Postmaster Dayton as Superintendent of the City Delivery. Mr. Morgan is a Republican. He has been in Post Office work since 1873, having first served as a carrier and then in important positions in various stations. In 1889 he was promoted to the Superintendence of City Delivery.

COWES, Aug. 1 -- The race for the Queen's Cup, open to boats owned by members of the Royal Yacht Squadron, took place to-day. The starters were the Valkyrie, Britannia, Meteor, (owned by the German Emperor.) Viking, and Mohawk.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The weekly crop statement of the Weather Bureau says: The weather during the past week has probably resulted in a general improvement of crops in the East Gulf and South Atlantic States. Texas and Arkaunas report more unfavorable conditions, owing to continued drought in many sections. On the Pacific coast the weather was especially favorable for all crops in Oregon and Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The inventors of small calibre rifles, some of whom expressed dissatisfaction at the conclusions of the board of army experts at Springfield, Mass., will have a chance to submit their devices to a Government board which will seek a suitable arm for the navy. The naval ordnance experts waited until the army selected a small magazine arm before deciding upon a rifle.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 1 -- After the landing of the William Clancy Association at Point View Island to-day, Joseph Daly, one of the excurtionists, went in bathing. Getting beyond his depth, he sank. As he was sinking for the third time, Thomas Connors of 12 Broome Street, New-York, jumped after him. The men struggled in the water, and two other men went to the rescue and they were brought ashore.

Walter E. Bunn, the new United States Appraiser at this port, was sworn into office late yesterday afternoon by Collector Hendricks. He did not visit his office at the Appraiser's Warehouse, but word reached there in the afternoon that he would probably put in an appearance to-day.

Real estate, and especially that within the city limits, has been giving a pretty good account of itself in these troublous financial times that have played ducks and drakes with so many other forms of investment. No property has been sacrificed, values have been quite well maintained, end forced sales have been few in number.

Timothy D. Sullivan, better known as "DryDollar " Sullivan, the leader of the Third Assembly District, was a proud man yesterday on the occasion of the "eighteenth annual mammoth invitation picnic and games" given by the association that bears his name at Sulzer'a Harlem River Park.

More gold coming this way, easier money rates, and strength in the stock market were features of the day in Wall Street yesterday. Even the failures in Chicago did not produce such demoralization as might have been expected, and the close showed prices generally at an advance over Monday's last quotation.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 1 -- The political changes in Long Island City have arrayed former friends against each other in the various city departments. In none has the bitterness become so intense probably as in the Fire Department. Of the twelve firemen of the lower end of the city it is alleged that charges have been preferred against all but four.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- With her big club topasit set over her lower sails the Boston syndicate cup defender Pilgrim came tearing up the harbor Monday afternoon under the influence of a brisk southerly breeze. She had come from Marblehead and was on her way to the navy yard at Charlestown, where she was docked to-day for cleaning and painting in preparation for the New York cruise.

WOLCOTT, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The Sheriff of Wayne County to-day closed the hardware store of Frank A. Bunce in Wolcott and also seized his house and lot on a Judgment for $40,000. Two years ago Henry E. Nichols of Westbury, Cayuga County, brought suit through Lyon Pierce of Auburn charging Bunce, his former guardian, with misconverting the estate of his father, Henry Nichols, Sr.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 1 -- The most important political contest in Maryland this year is in the First Judicial District When Judge Irving died, Associate Judge Holland and his friends expected that he would be elevated to the vacancy, but Gov. Frank Brown thought otherwise, and asked Henry Page to resign from the House of Representatives and accept the Chief Judgeship.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad and the Chicago and Eastern Illinois gave notice to-day that the salaries of all their officers and employes of general and local offices would be reduced 10 per cent. This action, it is claimed, is necessitated by the continued decrease in the earnings of the roads.
An alarm of fire and clouds of smoke carrying burning sparks aroused the guests at the Gedney House, Broadway and Fortieth Street, at a little before 3 o'clock yesterday morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1 -- In the United States Circuit Court Judge Green dismissed the case of the Accumulator Company of Newark against the Consolidated Electric Storage Company of Camden for want of Jurisdiction. The dismissal practically ends one of the most remarkable patent cases on record, and implies, at least, that the patent on the Faure electric storage battery has run out.

SARATOGA, Aug. 1 -- The chief month of the Saratoga season opened auspiciously to-day with fine weather, the town well filled, and increasing arrivals by every train. Into August's thirty-one days is now to be crowded the real "season" here at the Spa, all the foregoing weeks from the middle of June leading up to this brilliant climax.

Secretary of the Treasury Carlisle came to New-York last night. He is on his way to Buzzard's Bay to meet President Cleveland and confer with him on matters which are conceded to be of more than usual importance.

BUENOS AYRES, Aug. 1 -- The Radicals who are at the head of the revolutionary movement now in progress in this and other prov inces declare that their object is to effect as complete a revolution as that which occurred in 1890, and to destroy the surviving elements of the regime of ex-President Celman in the local administration here and in Santa Fe.
Money on call loaned at 4@10 cent., the average being about 6 cent. The last loan was made at 6 cent.

-- Sanger's race at Milwaukee last Saturday, in which he lowered the mile bicycle record to 2:09 4-5, will rank as one of the greatest performances of the year. He lowers the record by five seconds in competition with a field of riders. The race was the one-mile handicap. Danger was at the scratch. Charles Murphy at fifty yards. Bliss and Banker at sixty yards, and the limit men at eighty yards.
The Kings County Board of Supervisors held its annual meeting yesterday and accepted County Treasurer H.B. Adams's annual report of the county's finances.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- The number of paid admissions to the fair last month was 2,759,971. The paid attendance for May was 1,050,037, while that of June was 2,675,113.

Capt. Crowley of the British ship Verajean, which reached this port yesterday, told of meeting the Flying Dutchman 800 miles east of New-York. The Flying Dutchman is a dory, 2O feet over all, commanded by Capt. Gardiner, who sailed from Shelbourne, N.S., June 12.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 1 -- It is announced that Miss Ollie Wilkinson of this city will be married next week to Mr. Charles Macalister of Philadelphia. With this announcement is a cablegram received yesterday saying that Mr. Walter J. Wilkinson, the brother of Miss Ollie Wilkinson, will also shortly be married to Mrs. Charles Macalister, a divorce having recently been granted to Mr. and Mrs. Macalister.

BUFFALO, Aug. 1 -- Though the Grand Circuit cracks drew a large crowd here this afternoon the ten days' meeting began very tamely. All three of the classes went off in straight heats without anything like a race in one of them.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Successful above all precedent and expectation was the fourth annual baby parade, which took place this afternoon on the board walk. The day was superb for the purpose. Mature drew a veil across old Sol's burning face, and sea-ruling Neptune sent up a gentle breeze to cool the heated promenade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A New-York physician has undertaken to study the aurora, and he will have the co-operation of the Navy Department. Dr. M.A. Veeder of Lyons, N.Y., has prepared the blanks for recording observations, Lieut Peary of the navy, who proposes during the next two years to occupy a station in Greenland, 77 north latitude, will make close observations of the aurora from that station.

Lloyd H. Curtiss, twenty-one years old, committed suicide on Monday by inhaling Illuminating gas at his home, 200 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street. His father is Dwight H. Curtiss, who is a member of the Produce Exchange and has an office at 2 Stone Street.

The magnates of the Monmonth Park Association had a meeting yesterday. It was a long one and it was probably an important one. J. A. Morris had his own counsel at the track, and when that counsel came was accompanied by Mr. Morris's family physician, Dr. Hasbrouck. The presence of Mr. Coddington and Dr. Hasbrouck would seem to indicate that the case was a serious one.

There is evidently need of the diffusion of elementary knowledge among many depositors in savings banks. Many of these depositors are, of course, illiterate, and while they are among the last to be reached by a financial "scare," it abides with them, when it has once been reached, with a corresponding tenacity.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Under-the influence of further investment purchases and the cessation of liquidation, the markets generally improved to-day and closed at about the best.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Cleveland will probably reach Washington before many of the members of the Senate and the House, for it is learned here to-day that it is his intention to leave Gray Gables on Thursday in time to catch the Fall River steamer that night and to be in Washington early enough Friday to have a meeting of the Cabinet, if he regards a meeting on that day necessary.

John Cutts, a retired real estate dealer of 117 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, is a prisoner in the Adams Street Police Station accused of getting money from the city under false pretenses. He will be examined by Judge Walsh to-day. Controller Corwin is the complainant.

While August is usually the dullest month in the year among horsemen and those interested in the carriage trade, the soles just now are especially brisk and promise to make a record for this hottest of all months. There is a Rood demand for unmatched pairs and good road horses, and the dealers are feeling correspondingly happy.

Postmaster Andrew T. Sullivan's new delivery system was put in operation yesterday, and the officers of the Brooklyn Post Office were delighted with the result of the first day's trial. This system had not been need anywhere before, and was the invention of the Postmaster. Its aim is to avoid carrying letters about ten miles around when half a mile across will serve as well.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- The United States cruiser New-York, now receiving her finishing touches at Cramps' shipyard, went into commission at noon to-day.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 1 -- Secretary Gresham left Glen Suminit to-day for Washington. The mountain air has greatly improved his health. In an interview he said he did not think Congress would waste any time on the financial question.

Josiah Quincy, Assistant Secretary of State, who has charge of the business of the Consular Service, has told a Boston Herald reporter something of the system that has been followed by the present Administration in making appointments to the service and of the efforts made to secure thoroughly capable men. In dealing with the number of changes made since March 4, Mr. Qnincy says:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Chief Naval Constructor Hichborn has no easy taste before him in his new office. He finds at least two of the ships which have been accepted, and one of which has been placed in commission, the Monterey and New-York, incomplete. It will take another three months to finish the Monterey, and two months' work a till remains to be done on the cruiser New-York, although that ship went into commission to-day.

The eldest eon of the late Jacob Wilson, a wealthy and well-known real estate dealer of this city. Is expected to arrive in the city today from the Pacific coast, his coming being for the purpose of bringing a salt to recover his share in his father's estate. The trial of his salt promises to be fall of romance and sensation.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Work began in earnest for the batteries this morning. At 8 o'clock each battery mounted guard, and at 9 o'clock the First and Second Batteries went to the field for the regular battery drill. The First Battery, commanded by Capt. Wendel, occupied the east plain, while the Second Battery, under Capt. Wilson, was drilled on the North Plain.

STAPLETON, S.I., Aug. 1 -- The second attempt to prove that the late Joseph Rubsam, the millionaire brewer of this place, had executed a will other than the one admitted to probate was abandoned yesterday. The hearing in the matter has been in progress before Surrogate Stephens of Richmond County for some months.

It is unfortunate that there should have been so much friction at the fair between the management and the exhibitors, especially the foreign exhibitors. It is impossible to resist the conclusion that this friction has been produced by a lack of tact on the part of the management or of the agents through whom the management operates.

At the Jersey City Tennis Club tournament. Jersey city Heights, play was continued yesterday with men's singles. The tournament is a handicap one conducted on the point system. This is quite an innovation for the Jersey City Club, as their first tournament of the year was given under the old method of games and sets.

His Highness the Nawab of Rampur, who has been at the Windsor Hotel for several days, will sail on the Tentonic this evening accompanied by his entire retinue. His baggage, consisting of the modest pile of forty-one trunks and various miscellaneous package, was taken to the steamer yesterday.

PHIIADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- The statements of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies for the month of June show that gross receipts of the railroad company were $1,974,748.78; expenses, $1,172,992.94; profit in operating, $801,755.84. Net receipts from other sources were $76,310.32, making the net profit for the month $878,066.16.

The precipitate rush of frightened depositors to the savings banks of this city which characterized Monday was yesterday very largely checked. All the banks had the time notice rule in effect, yet the rush of depositors and the general feeling of anxiety among them was conspicuously diminished.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 1 -- It is asserted here that fifty-six men, or about one-third, of her crew, deserted from the Montorey in twentyfour hours during her northern trip. This is said to break the record or the navy.

A committee of the New-York Academy of Medicine has put forth for public consideration the outline of a plan for the establishment of a National Bureau of Public Health within the Treasury Department, and several sections of a draft of the law proposed for the purpose have been published.

Officers of various savings banks when asked yesterday about the prospect of their disposing of Government bonds to national banks freely admitted that such sales might be made. No proposition has yet been formally considered by the savings banks' Presidents or by their Executive Committee.

Mark Baldwin yesterday proved that he is as proficient with the sun as he is with the baseball. He was the "dark horse" in the pigeon shooting sweepstake in which the New-York ball players took part on the grounds of the Pelhamville Gun Club.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 1 -- Rear Admiral Maguaghi has cabled to Rome the facts connected with his discourteous reception by Mayor Desjardins and the omission of a return salute by the military authorities. He was very indignant this morning.

Georce W. Vanderbilt recently learned that he had been robbed of about $10,000 by one of his employes, and through one of his lawyers he has caused an attachment to be issued against a deposit which the alleged dishonest employe had in the Park National Bank of this city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Up to the hour of 4 o'clock this afternoon just fifty-three members of the House of Representatives had reported at the House Post Office. About the first thing a member does when he reaches town is to call at the Post Office and give directions concerning his mail, so that it seems safe to estimate that not more than sixty Representatives are in the city this evening.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 2 -- T. Thomas Fortune, editor of the Colored Age, and Col. William Murrell, editor of the New-Jersey Trumpet, may fight a duel because of the board-walk war at Asbury Park.

"Russell B. Harrison comes into this court and presumes to speak for a company with which his connection is somewhat questionable," said Lawyer Clarence Birdseye during an argument before Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court yesterday. "I think it is somewhat peculiar," added the lawyer.

It is denied that ex-Gov. CAMPBELL of Dhio is ready to make the fight for the Governorship this Fall with Gov. McKINLEY. That is to be regretted. The party could hardly get a better candidate. The two men are very fairly representative of their respective parties on national issues, and, for that matter, on local issues.

-- The Wyanoke's baseball team will play the Seawanhaka's team at Point View next Sunday. The Wyanoke's team claims the baseball championship of the Harlem River boat clubs and is very anxious to arrange a match with a team from may club that may dispute it.

William Sulzbacher and Benry Gitterman, comprising the firm of Bulzbacher, Gitterman Wedeles, importers of woolens at 70 and 72 Worth Street, made an assignment yesterday to Martin H. Lehmaler, without preference.

Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department, who is now in this city, has discovered in the figures of which he is master conclusive proof that exports of gold, have been due to the Sherman Silver law.

Herr Henkenius, in the Deutsche Rundschau, has an interesting paper on the origin of cannibalism, which appears to have sprung up among mankind after they had made a certain social advance. The lower animals rarely devour their own species, and no traces of the vice have as yet been found among the relics of the paleolithic men.

Maria Bardwell, about twenty-eight years of age, who wrote herself a resident of Boston, committed suicide some time Tuesday night at the United States Hotel, at the corner of Pearl and Fulton Streets, by shooting herself in the right temple with a thirty-two-calibre revolver.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- There was a little delay in the opening of the second day's session of the Silver Convention because the agent of the hall refused to unlook the doors until he should be paid his rent. When finally the convention was called to order it was announced that the Committee on Resolutions would not report until afternoon.
Guido Arthur Schurfig will be placed on trial to-morrow in the Court of Special Sessions for circulating pamphlets calling on working people to arise, sword in hand, and begin a social revolution.

The sale, or, rather, exchange, of the Glenham Hotel property by Robert L. Cutting, announced in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, was the subject of comment among real estate men. The price is kept secret, but $250,000 will prove to be rather over than under the amount. At this price the purchaser, Mr. T.A. Havemeyer, obtained what may prove to be a bargain.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 2 -- Insurance rates in the Northwest yesterday underwent an advance of 20 per cent. It applies to all mercantile property and other "specials," the rate on paper and pulp mills being increased 50 per cent. The advance is the result of heavy losses and the falling off of business.

Old New-Yorkers, particularly the Judges, lawyers, bankers, and brokers who like quiet corners, away from the noise and bustle of commercial life, will read with interest that John Sutherland, who for more than a generation had a restaurant in Liberty Street, has retired from business, but they will be comforted by the information that he has a worthy successor in James Harcombe.
Street Commissioner Andrews yesterday issued the following order to Superintendent William Robbins ol his department:

It has become widely known throughout the east side that Congressman Timothy Justinian Campbell has a weakness -- he cannot bear to take his pleasures in selfish solitude. Be yielded to this weakness twenty-three years ago, when he was in his first callow chickenhood, and every year since those golden days he has indulged the same amiable habit.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Two suits have been begun in the Supreme Court by residents of Morris County against the Board of Chosen Freeholders of Morris County, and mandamuses have been issued compelling them to show cause on Nov. 7 why they do not repair and improve certain roads in Morris County under the Road act or 1891.
Two men were mobbed in the streets Tuesday night, and narrowly escaped serious harm at the bands of angry men and women.

ROME, Aug. 2 -- The Pope has directed the Catholic inhabitants of Naples not to fast on Fridays as long as the cholera prevails. His Holiness feared that the physical weakness engendered by fasting might cause the people to be mere Susceptible to the disease.

-- The Greenwich Wheelmen have largely increased their membership since they moved from Charles Street to their present commodious quarters in the large, old-fashioned house at 509 Hudson Street. They have taken in twenty new members in the three weeks they have been in their new house, giving them a total membership of seventy, and they expect to take in five more at their next meeting.

SOUTH CHANGE, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Ex-Tax Collector Moses P. Smith of South Orange was arrested this afternoon by Police Sergeant Charles H. Burke, on a warrant issued by Police Justice O'Reilly, charging him with embezzling $13,000 of the funds intrusted to his care as Township Collector.

Police Justice Joseph Koch, in his effort as counsel to compel the Board of Excise to grant a license to Burt C. Wadman, who kept a hotel and saloon at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street and Third Avenue, has made an attack on Police Captain Brooks of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station.
"Well," remarked Judge Dugro in the Superior Court yesterday, "you would not separate a husband and wife for a counsel fee, would you I"
A friend of Rear Admiral Humann, in this city, shows a letter written a month ago on board the Triomphante by the Commander-in-Chief of the French naval division in the Extreme-Orient. Humann says:

Since the Board of Aldermen passed an ordinance recently regulating the speed of bicycles within the city limits there have been many complaints by wheelmen of the treatment they have received from park policemen.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- The soldiers were astir early this morning. At 5 o'clock Capt. Cochran of the Thirteenth Regiment drilled his men in extended order, and soon after guard mount Capt. Dillenback led Battery K to the north plain to show the First and Second Batteries what United States Artilerymen can do.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Clarence Hobart and W.A. Larned are left to contest the finals in the tennis tournament here, and the winner will challenge Edward L. Hall for the championship cup. The games to-day resulted as follows:

The slaughter of the innocents by the Brooklyn trolley was continued yesterday when Madeline Walsh, only eleven months old, the youngest child of Charles Walsh, cigar dealer at 296 Smith Street, was run over and horribly mangled in her presence of her mother. This makes the sixth child killed by the electric cars within six weeks.

The officials of the savings banks in this city declare positively that there has been no agreement among them to dispose of Government bonds in order to replenish their cash reserves. At most of the banks it is stated that there is an abundance of cash on hand to meet all prospective demands.

Lieut. CoL Selden C. Clobridge of the Fourteenth Regiment, who has been for more than fifteen years assistant bookkeeper in the Tax Office. Brooklyn, was arrested just before noon yesterday by Detective Bagnarello of District Attorney Ridgway's office on a charge of grand larceny.

Lester German's gilt-edged pitching was responsible for the defeat administered to the Brooklyns on the Polo Grounds yesterday. Only five singles were charged against him, and three of these were of the scratch order. Aside from German's pitching the features were Connor's batting. Doyle's work in centre field, and Wilson's catching.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Advices from Porto Novo show that, although Behauzin, the deposed King of Dahomey, promised to submit himself to Col. Dumas, the commander of the French forces, on July 25, he did not appear. His followers, it is said, are persuading him to renew his resistance to the French.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 2 -- A.B. Wheeler, Jr., the defaulting manager of the brick and tile works on the Vanderbilt estate in Transylvania County, has made restitution of $17,500 of the money taken during the last three years. He is still under arrest at Biltmore Station.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 2 -- John H. Quinn, the well-known turfman, was arrested to-night charged with assaulting a colored waiter in the dining room of the Plaza Hotel.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 2 -- For many years there have been traditions that Lafitte, the buccaneer, had left vast sums of gold coin and silver bare buried about Galveston Island previously to his having been ordered away by the United States Government. From time to time persons have dug on the island and mainland in search of this treasure, and their utter failure appears to have in no way prevented others from making the attempt.
YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Fire to-day destroyed a score of small buildings on the east side of Warburton Avenue and back on Mill Street and caused a loss of about $100,000.

The TIMES and World baseball teams played a very exciting and close game at Prospect Park yesterday afternoon. The features were the heavy hitting of Perkins and Cole of the World and Scott and Boyle of the TIMES. The Score:

A bleached negroes, her face strangely mottled with patches of yellow and spots of ebon black, revealed to Justice Grady yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court that dusky maidens who prefer the skin of Japhet to one of the darker hue of Ham are just now using a preparation which is guaranteed to soften the shade of midnight into the less sombre light of early dawn.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- There were two topics of interest to the Treasury people to-day. One was the restoration of the one-hundred-million gold reserve, which reached, at the close of business, more than $100,700,000. The other was the increased demand for national bank circulation, principally by New-York banks.

Stocks advanced sharply yesterday. From the opening the market was strong, and although the activity lagged a little in the middle of the day there was a rush to buy just before the close, which sent prices in many instances to the highest point of the session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Receiver Huidekoper of the Richmond and Danville Railroad to-day ridiculed the report that the Pennsylvania Company had secured, or was about to secure, the Richmond and Danville, and that in consequence thereof the Baltimore and Ohio would abandon its track over which it mattes connection with the Southern system.

Gen. Neal Dow spoke on "The Liquor Traf fle and the General Welfare." which is not a new topic to him, in Portland on Sunday evening, and with the antagonistic spirit characistic of him, took occasion to "pitch into" Chief Justice John A. Peters of the Supreme Court of Maine, because he had decided that one extreme anti-liquor law was unconstitutional.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 -- Boston yachtsmen had this afternoon a flue chance to see the Jubilee, the yacht which John B. Paine has designed and Gen. C.J. Paine, his father, has built to defend the America's Cup. She was hauled out about 2 o'clock on the marine railway at the Atlantic Works, East Boston, in preparation for the New-York cruise by cleaning and painting.

Amasa Lyon Co., manufacturers of umbrellas at 684 Broadway, have become unable to meet maturing obligations, and on the application of the trustees of the company. Sylvester J. O'Sullivan, the Treasurer, has been appointed receiver.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2 -- The first garden party of the season was given to-day by Mr. and Mrs. E.S. Willing, at their cottage on Narragansett Avenue, in honor of Grand Date Alexander of Russia. It was a brilliant affair. The grounds were magnificently decorated, while the circular piazzas were inclosed and set with tables tete-a-tete. Under a canopy tent on the south side of the grounds the Hungarian Band played.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- A dispatch from Paris to the Pall Mall Gazette says that the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration has made good progress and that it is expected that a decision will be rendered in a fortnight. The dispatch adds that every point at issue has now been adjudicated and that the decision will give entire satisfaction to Great Britain and Canada.
Money on call loaned at 3 @ 6 cent., the average being about 5 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

Mabal Glenn, Adair, Geraldine, and Grey Eagle made a pretsy race at Brighton Beach yesterday in the owners' handicap at five furlongs. Half a furlong from the finish they raced heads apart, Mabel Glenn winning by a head.
Judge Patterson of the Supreme Court rendered judgments in property owners' damage suits against the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company yesterday as follows.

Hundreds of colored children who too seldom get an outing were made happy yesterday through the efforts of the New-York Association for improving the Condition of the Poor. As many as the iron steamboat Cetus could conveniently carry were taken to Coney Island on the association's first fresh-air party of the season exclusively for colored persons.

It was as jolly as a funeral at Monmouth Park yesterday. There were hardly as many mourners a one sometimes sees at a funeral at Calvary Cemetery. But the mourning was emphatic to the last degree down in the betting ring. The forty-one bookmakers who had been induced to pay $100 each for the privilege of making a book on the races were the vociferous mourners.

-- It has been decided by the managers of the Stanford estate to dispose of over 1,000 blooded horses from the celebrated Palo Alto Ranch, and retain only a nucleus with which to conduct the work of breeding fine horses begun by Senator Stanford. All of the get of the famous Electioneer and his family, of Neptune, General Benton, George Wilkes, Nutwood, and other strains are to be placed under the hammer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 -- Notwithstanding a show of confidence, the trade was expecting further failures to-day, and the expectation was soon fulfilled. One very prominent carrier was widely known to be behind in his margins, virtually broken last night. This was the firm of D. E. Eggleston Co. It was carrying lard and pork for the bankrupt Cudahy- Wright clique.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- One Hundred and forty-nine thousand ounces of silver were offered for sale to the Treasury Department to-day at prices ranging from $0.71 to $0.7150 per ounce, all of which was declined, and $0.7090 tendered.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Sir Edward Grey, Parliamentary Secretary of the Foreign Office, announced in the House of Commons this afternoon that the French blockade of Bangkok had been raised to-day.

-- F.H. Hovey failed to appear at Toronto last week in defense of the Canadian championship, owing to the national double championship tourney at Chicago. In his absence the title went by default. Last year Hovey won the title by default from Manafield. With Bixby, he also won the double championship, which was also defaulted last Week to Paddock and Cole of Detroits.
Jacob L. Dodge, a wealthy young man about own, was divorced yesterday under peculiar circumstances.

Tariff reform can wait. The new currency system, whatever it is to be, can wait. The naked repeal of the silver-purchase provisions of the Sherman act without complications or the discussion of substitute measures is the first and the sole imperative duty of the extra session of Congress.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Fire at 4 o'clock this morning destroyed the large barn on exVice President Morton's place at Ellerslie, near Rhinebeck, a chicken house, carpenter's shop, and other buildings. There were nine horses, eighty head of Guernsey cattle, several hundred tons of hay, a number of reapers and mowing machines, and other valuable property destroyed.

Dr. Senner, the Commissioner of Immigration, and his associates at Ellis Island have not been at all encouraged in their efforts to enforce the contract-labor law by the work of the Special Inspectors who are stationed at Quarantine for the purpose of detecting undesirable immigrants.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, Aug. 2 -- P.M. The anxiety of the bears to cover their outstanding short contracts, in view of the distinct improvement in the general situation, resulted to-day in pronounced advances all along the line. In the afternoon quotations advanced a point between sales, and for a while a veritable bear panic prevailed.

It was a great surprise for Postmaster Dayton yesterday to receive word from Washington that $50,700 had been appropriated for the new station in the Industrial Building, and that he alone was to have charge of the expenditure of the money. Such a thing had not been heard of before in the Post Office.

There was one safe in the office of Woerishoffer Co., 52 Exchange Place, which was not to be opened yesterday morning. The trouble was that John H. Morgan and Harry Ware Pelletier, clerks in the firm's drain department, had not reported for duty. The firm sent to their homes in Brooklyn to find out what was the trouble.

With a wide-brimmed, black slouch hat, tipped well back on his head, a frock coat with the lapels turned jauntily back, and trousers that were large, light, and airy, Col. Pat Donan leaned against the desk in the corridor of the Astor House yesterday afternoon. His fine silky beard, through which the streaks of gray have been growing a little thicker since he was last here, was groomed to perfection.
Mrs. Sophronia Twichell. Mrs. Sophronia Twichell died suddenly of peritonitis Wednesday evening at her residence, 318 State Street, Brooklyn.

The Italian yacht Corsaro owned by Capt. Enrico Alberto d'Albertis, arrived here very early yesterday morning and dropped anchor opposite the Atlantic Yacht Clubhouse at Bay Ridge. The flag of Italy was hosted over the Corsaro and even if it were not, the build and rigging of the yacht would have easily distinguished her from the yachts of American build that lay there.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- A disagreeable set-back was given the wheat market to-day. The first rebuff came from the suspension of Lazarus Silverman, a leading private banker. The effects of this blow were more than overcome, but in the last hour the market slumped again on ugly rumors about mercantile concerns, the failure to work round lots of cash wheat for shipment, and the light export businets reported from the seaboard.

There were found in the offices of the Pension Bureau a few days ago sixteen decisions, relating to as many individual pension cases, which were written by Assistant Secretary BUSSEY while TANNER was Commissioner of Pensions, and which had not been enforced either by TANNER or by his successor, Commissioner RAUM.

After repeated endeavors on the part of the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn, and after his friends had almost given up hope. Vicar General McNamara, acting for Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn, has granted to Dr. McGlynn the privilege of saying mass in public.

The scarcity of currency was the most important feature of the situation in Wall Street yesterday. Cash was not easy to be obtained in large amounts, and those who wanted big sums sometimes had to pay a premium for them. In return for the money they gave certified checks.

NEWPORT, R.I. Aug. 3 -- In honor of the Czarina's birthday, this has been observed as a general holiday aboard the Russian ships at anchor in this harbor. Special services were held in the morning aboard each vessel, and all were gayly decorated with bunting. At noon national salutes were fired and the Russian flag was hoisted aboard the United States training ship Richmond, which also dressed ship and saluted.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 3 -- A distressing accident occurred at the boathouse of the Chelsea Yacht Club, on Broadway, Chelsea, near the bridge over the Mystic River, this evening.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Aug. 3 -- The Populists of Virginia met here in State Convention to-day. Nearly 500 delegates, chiefly from the rural districts, were in attendance. There was not a negro in the lot. Among the visiting statesmen were Congressman Simpson from Kansas and Congressman Pence from Colorado. Simpson spoke to a mass meeting last night and Pence to-day addressed the convention.

Special Chinese Inspector Scharf and Deputy Collector Gunner made a second investigation yesterday of the case of nine Chinese passengers from Havana on the steamer City of Alexandria. Chu Yi, actor, was released, Chn Fung testifying that he had engaged the traveler for his Chinese theatre.

Postmaster Dayton received yesterday a report from the Board of Health on the sanitary condition or the Post Office, which was inspected early in the week by Dr. S. McCallum and John T. Turner. The Inspectors say:

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Secretary M.P. Ryan of the New-York State Firemen's Association says the annual convention, to be held here Aug. 15 to 18, will be a grand success. He has been notified by 400 companies of the State that they will attend. Other companies will come from all over the United States and Canada.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- According to the Lancet, the well-known English medical weekly, cholera has been epidemic in Marseilles for the last three months. The local officials, it is asserted, hare carried their policy of deception to such lengths that even the Government has been led astray in regard to the real state of affairs.

At 111 Broadway, yesterday, Mr. Henry W. Donald of R.V. Harnett Co. sold, under foreclosure, 144 Lexington Avenue, west side, 36.11 1/2 feet north of East Twenty-ninth Street, four-story stone-front dwelling. Henry Allen was the purchaser at $11,200.
Wheat Dull and Lower, Corn Dull and Unchanged, Cotton Lower and Quiet, Coffee Steadier, but Dull.

One of the most interesting features of the present financial situation is the sudden disposition shown by the national banks to issue new circulating notes. For some years now the tendency has been the other way, the banks complaining that with the large premium on the bonds it was impossible to find a profit in circulation.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The yacht race for the Town Prize of L100, open to yachts of over thirty tons, took place to-day. The course covered a distance of fifty miles. The start was made from Cowes, Isle of Wight, and the yachts sailed twice to and around the Warner Lightship and back.

The Charity Organization Society calls attention, through THE NEW-YORK TIMES, to an especially deserving case of destitution under its charge. The case is that of a man thirty-six years old, who was formerly a driver. His name is withheld for good reasons. He was paralyzed in October, 1892, and has not been able to use his legs since.

Raymond Whitcomb of 31 East Fourteenth Street are making extensive arrangements for accommodating visitors to the World's Fair who travel under their charge. They have just erected a new hotel on the Midway Plaisance, to be used exclusively for their patrons. The house, besides being finely appointed, is within a few minutes' walk of all parts of the exposition, and combines all the best features or the modern hotel.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 3 -- There is a political stir here because of the announcement of a sugar combination embracing the maritime provinces. Nova Scotia, New-Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island. Under cover of an English incorporation, directly contrary to the Dominion Anti-Combine act, J.F. Stairs, member of the Dominion Parliament for Halifax, is the chief promoter.
Citizens of Kings County are now asking each other whether District Attorney Eidgway is going to protect prize fighters from indictment, as he has protected Mayor Boody and other public officials.

The framers of the Constitution cannot be supposed to have foreseen the tremendous task to be assumed by the Chief Executive of the Nation whose government they were shaping. It is, indeed, probable that had they been able to conceive a small part of the responsibility and power that would centre in the office within a century of the first inauguration, they would not have done their own work so well.

The somewhat meagre details of the race at Cowes, in which the American yacht Navahoe finished third, do not present grounds for the discouragement of those yachtsmen who hope to see Mr. ROYAL PHELPS CARROLL'S pluck and sportsmanlike spirit rewarded by final victory. The cable has informed us that the Navahoe was tried on all points of sailing, and the account shows plainly that there were windward work, reaching, and running.
J. Edward Simmons, Chairman of the Committee of General Mortgage Bondholders, and William Mertens, Chairman of the Committee of Income Bondholders, issued the following circular yesterday:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- The uncertainty of tennis was shown to-day in the defeat of Clarence Hobart by W.A. Larned in the finals of the Long Island Championship. Hobart hit the top band of the net instead of getting the ball over. Larned's play was unexpectedly strong, especially in his service. Hobart showed good nerve in each of the last two sets.

RYE, Aug. 3 -- Richard F. Downing, a broker having his New-York office at 20 Exchange Place, annually entertains his friends at his charming country residence here with a Rhode Island clambake. He gave his a eighth annnal clambake this afternoon. There were assembled 200 of the prominent men of Westchester County, New-York, and Brooklyn.

James H. Hurst, a lawyer at 2 Wall Street, and Major John B. Powell, a railroad contractor living at the Hoffman House, quarreled in the cafe of the St. James Hotel about 5:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and in Jefferson Market Police Court this morning Major Powell will be asked to tell just why he raised huge lumps on Mr. Hurst's head with a heavy walking stick.
Henry Clay Ditmas, a wealthy sporting man and official turf correspondent, died suddenly at his home. King's Highway, L.I., early yesterday morning. The cause of death, was Bright's disease.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- In response to many requests from the editor of the national Tribune, who asked that a test be made to show the number of fraudulent pensions by having 1,000 cases drawn from the admitted files and examined, Commissioner Lochren replies that he has not compiled with the requests of the editor for several reasons.

The beginning of the end has come at Monmouth. Philip J. Dwyer, Treasurer of the Monmonth Park Association, stepped out or the active management of affairs at the track yesterday and Alfred Hennen Morris, son of the lottery king, assumed control of affairs. Hereafter he will be the head and front of the offending. The passing of affairs into the hands of the Louisiana Lottery crowd is now complete.
The Anchor Line steamer Karamania arrived yesterday afternoon from Naples with a general cargo and 471 steerage passengers consigned to Henderson Brothers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Evidence of a startling nature concerning the Cold Storage Warehouse fire was taken by the Grand Jury today. The witness who gave this startling testimony was John Joseph Duggan, formerly a Stony Island Avenue saloon keeper. He is the man who first told of the looting of the Cold Storage Warehouse and its firing by a gang of thieves.

For some time complaints of robberies have been made at the East sixty-seventh Street Police Station by occupants of flats in the precinct Detectives were on the lookout for the thieves for some time, and were surprised when they discovered the robberies had been committed by two young girls, and not by men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- While there has been no canvass made of the members of the Fifty-third Congress who have arrived here, everybody who is interested in knowing what that body will do when it has met is getting the opinion that it will surely repeal the purchase clause of the Sherman silver act.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 3 -- An important discovery and a capture were made to-day by Detectives James Sarvis and Owen Kavanagh of Long Island City. Five thousand dollars' worth of stolen property was recovered, and two daring burglars were arrested for the theft. The prisoners are Charles Stark, a Boston thief, and James Reilly of Washington, D.C.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Aug. 3 -- The Woodstock Yarn Mills of J. Morton Brown Co. suspended operations at noon to-day, and nearly 200 men, boys, and women were thrown out of employment. Soon afterward a levy was made on the property under execution on a judgment for $151,000 which the firm had confessed to William Johnson, trustee for thirty-two creditors, whose claims range from $200 to $46,000.

NEW-YORK. THURSDAY, Aug. 3 -- P.M. Prices reacted to-day somewhat, as it was natural they should after the energetic advance of yesterday, but there was no evidence of weakness. The decline came early in the day on selling by those who expected the reaction and who were anxious to turn their paper profits into money.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 3 -- Baltimore won to-day's game by bunching their hits. Nine of their eleven hits were made in three innings. These, with three sacrifices, a base on balls, and a wild pitch, tallied 7 runs.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- If T. Thomas Fortune, editor of the Colored Age of New-York to-day reads the New-Jersey Trumpet he will find therein the editorial which he has dared Col. William Murrell to publish under the threat of being challenged to a duel. Col. Murrell has printed the following in the Trumpet:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The work of arranging the reports showing the condition of the national banks of the country at the close of business July 12 last is proceeding rapidly in the office of the Controller of the Currency. This afternoon the Controller furnished the following abstract indicative of the condition of the 273 national banks in New-York State, outside of New-York, Albany, and Brooklyn, on the date mentioned:

ROME, Aug. 3 -- The efforts of the Government to stamp out phylloxera in Northern Italy have led to serious conflicts with the peasants. The Minister of Agriculture, with the view of stopping the ravages of the pest, recently ordered the destruction of vineyards covering a large area in the Province of Novara. The peasants, losing employment through these steps, began to riot.

PUEBLO, Col., Aug. 3 -- During the last two weeks the departures of Anstrians and Italians from Pueblo for their native land has almost reached the extent of a stampede. The movement began soon alter the banks closed their doors, in one of which a considerable number of these people had their savings. Those who took out their money desired to redeposit it later, but the banks refused to open accounts with them.

The action of the Illinois court in fining the Directors of the World's Fair for contempt of it seems unduly harsh. The Directors were assailed on the one hand by a popular clamor to open the fair on Sunday, and they had high judicial authority for that course. It turned out that the popular clamor did not represent a popular demand, and they closed the gates.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 -- Senator Lodge, speaking of the probability of a repeal of the purchasing clauses of the Sherman law, said:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. E.D. Salter, who professes to act for a company in New-York, took orders from many women of this city for corsets several weeks ago. She received from each customer 50 cents or $1 cash, and in some cases even more.

Henry Allen Co., brokers at 31 New Street, who failed recently, will bring criminal suits against members of the National Cordage pool, and they charge officers of the National Cordage Company with obtaining from them a large sum of money by misrepresentation both as to books and statements of the financial condition of the cordage company.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The advance established in New-York yesterday was well maintained here to-day, and after a firm opening, in which, realization and investment purchases were well balanced, the latter feature predominated and prices rose, few stocks being on offer.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Ten thousand persons saw the big pacing race for the first division of the ten-thonsand-dollar parse here to-day. Before the cracks came out for the important evens the 2:15 trot furnished no mean part of the day's excitement. Hulda was the favorite, but she had to trot in 2:12 1/4, 2:10 1/2, and 2:08 1/2 in order to win, the average for the three heats being the lowest ever trotted.

Eight more Republicans were discharged yesterday from the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The decapitated are ex-Supervisor F. Ballon of the Thirteenth Ward, copyist; William B. Conklin, Twenty-second Ward, copyist; Francis Barbour. Ninth Ward, skilled laborer; John Tobin, Seventh Ward, skilled laborer, and Richard Moore, skilled laborer, and George Laidlaw, Alexander McDonald, and J. McCracken, copyists in the commandant's offices.

It looks now as if the really important business of the extra session of Congress would not be much delayed by the "campaigns" of the various aspirants for the places in the service of the respective houses. The Senate, having gone through the wrangle over "patronage" in the Spring, will not have to waste very much time upon it now.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- A disastrous explosion occurred to-day on board the German armor clad steamer Baden at Kiel. Lieute. Oelsnor and Zembsch and seven seamen were killed and seventeen persons were wounded.

The fourth annual clambake of the Stuyveeant Democratic Club was held at College Point yesterday. Police Justice William H. Burke, the Tammany leader of the Twenty-sixth Assembly District, is the President of the club. When all the fan was over last night, he remarked: "Well, this beats the record."

We published yesterday an interview with Mr. WORTHINGTON C. FORD, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics in the Treasury Department, concerning a very important discovery made by him with respect to great errors in the official record of imports. In this record, as prepared by his predecessor, it appears that the balance of trade for the year ending on June 30 was against the United States in the sum of more than $93,000,000.

The report of the receiver of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railroad for the fiscal year ending June 30 will be issued soon. It will show: Gross earnings for the year, $1,961,850; operating expenses, including taxes, $1,255,250; net from operating road, $706,600; terminal and other income, $126,000; total income, $832,600; deducting fixed charges, including interest on second incomes, $591,000; surplus, $241,600.

Pilot John Brown McMath, for twenty-nine years pilot of the United States revenue steamer Washington of this port, died Wednesday night at his home, 319 Seventh Street. South Brooklyn, aged fifty-six.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 3 -- The National German-American Bank of St. Paul, with a capital of $2,000,000, will not open its doors to-morrow morning. Joseph R. Lockey, President of the Institution, has issued an address to the public this evening, in which he says:
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Theodore Thomas, musical director, sent his resignation to the Committee on Liberal Arts of the Board of Directors of the fair to-day.

Lieut. Col. Selden C. Clobridge of the Fourteenth Regiment, who was arrested Wednesday for complicity with John Cults in the tax-rebate frauds in Brooklyn, was released yesterday by Police Justice Walsh on a bond of $3,000. The bondsman was Alderman Arthur J. Heaney, who qualified in $6,000. Lieut. Col. Clobridge was present in court with his friend Col. Harry W. Michel of the Fourteenth Regiment, and his attorney, William G. Cooke.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 4 -- Before leaving for New-York in charge of officers this afternoon. Mrs. Meyer, wife of Dr. Meyer, who is in the Tombs charged with wholesale poisoning, denied the story printed to-day which said she had been abused while a patient at Harper Hospital.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- It was an uneasy, feverish day in the wheat pit. Prices ran up and down several times within a range of 1 3/8 c, and left off about 3/8 c lower than on the day before. Corn averaged strong and closed 1/2 c higher. Provisions were in the main firm, but dull.

With reference to his removal from office and the appointment of Mr. SHERMAN HOAR to succeed him, ex-District Attorney ALLEN of the Boston district recently said: "I do not care to comment on the action of the Administration further than to say that I have been aware for some time that my zeal in certain matters was likely to shorten my official life.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Canada's two strongest lacrosse teams, the Shamrocks of Montreal and the Torontos of Toronto, met at the South Side Ball Park yesterday afternoon in a contest for a five-hundred-dollar silver trophy. The match resulted in an easy victory for the Shamrocks, who captured five out of six games.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The body found floating off Stratford Light last night by Capt. Lewis of the New-York tug Richard Schaubel was to-day identified as that of C.D. Fuller, a Princeton College student. He was the son of C.D. Fuller of Fuller Brothers Co., manufacturers of nails at 139 Greenwich Street. New-York City.
The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday took up the case of H.G. Weil of A.J. Weil Co., and sentenced him to suspension for a year.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The weather here to-day was hazy and warm, but this did not deter a fairsized crowd from attending the races. The fields were large, the racing good, and the track fast.

The United States cruiser Bennington, Commander Charles M. Thomas commanding, left the Brooklyn Navy Yard at 1:30 yesterday afternoon. Just before sailing Commander Thomas said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES: "I shall anchor for the night inside of Sandy Hook, and early to-morrow will adjust the ship's compasses at the compass buoys.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 4 -- Frank Van Loon, the Columbus Grove bank robber and murderer, was hanged in the annex at the Ohio Penitentiary this morning. Van Loon protested his innocence to the last. The drop fell at 12:17, his neck being broken. He was pronounced dead in fourteen minutes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- James H. Walker Co., dealers in general dry goods, and one of the largest and best-known firms in the city, confessed judgment in Judge Winde's court to-day on a note for $5,495 in favor of Edward Noa. Shortly afterward the rumors of the past few days to the effect that the company was embarrassed were confirmed in the formal petition for the appointment of a receiver.

TOPEKA, Aug. 4 -- "Lewelling is King of Kansas by the grace of the people" is the watchword now. God being but a subsidiary character. Acting under orders, Adjt. Gen. Artz went over to Leaven worth recently for the purpose of disbanding the colored militia company in that city which "disgraced" the State last Winter by offering to assist in maintaining the laws.

MAHWAH, N.J., Aug. 4 -- In the Northeast corner of New-Jersey, adjoining the Hudson River and Rockland County, N.Y., the small hamlet of Mahwah is situated, and in this picturesque part of the country is the noted Mountainside Farm of Theodore Havemeyer. The country is hilly and close to the Ramapo Hills, which rise toward the west as the outposts of the Highlands of New-York.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 4 -- Rusie was quite a pitcher to-day. Three singles was the sum total of Baltimore's batting. Ten hits, with a total of thirteen bases, and a few Oriole errors gave the Giants an easy victory. Ward's error gave Baltimore 2 of its 3 runs. Robinson's throwing to bases was like the weather -- very bad. The score:

The performance of the yacht Salanita in the Town Prize Race is especially worthy of note in view of the remarkable stories of speed which are afloat at this time of the year. We have already referred to the rumors of yachts having made great runs at the rate of from 15 to 17 knots an hour, and we have noted that such runs are never made in the big races near Sandy Hook.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 1 -- The entrance examinations for Yale, Harvard, Princeton, and the other colleges have shown that the freshman class in these respectable institutions of learning will be a very large one, and they have also brought to the attention of the thoughtful the fact that all over the country there are young men who expect to get acquainted with the peculiarities of university life in a month or two.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 4 -- At the annual Synod of the Diocese of Denver to-day, Bishop Matz presiding, a resolution was passed approving the Bishop's school policy.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4 -- At the last meeting of Bowood Lodge, the principal association of the Sons of England in Canada, a resolution was adopted deploring the loss of the British war ship Victoria, and calling upon the Dominion Government to make the maintenance of two vessels of the imperial fleet a permanent charge upon the revenues of Canada.

The messenger boys threaten to strike to-day if they are not paid their week's wages. Heretofore they have been paid off every Saturday, but about two weeks ago they were told that thereafter they would be paid every fortnight. They did not like the arrangement, but they only grumbled.

Daniel J. Rooney has been a clerk in the Post Office for thirty-seven years, and in all that time he has been absent but six days, a record which stands at the head of the list. He called upon Postmaster Dayton yesterday and asked for a promotion so that he might show before he died, he said, that his services were not wholly unappreciated.

Advices which have been received from the United States warship Chicago announced that she would sail on July 23 from Kingston, Ireland, for Southampton, England. At Southampton the Chicago, it was stated, would be given an overhauling of her machinery. The boilers of the vessel need immediate attention.

No sickness of any kind appeared yesterday on the steamship Karamania, from Naples, which was held at Quarantine Thursday night for observation because of the death of three passengers from causes not fully determined. Health Officer Jenkins decided not to release the ship for the reason that he was unwilling to take chances on a vessel from a port now infected.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- It has just leaked out from the archives of the Pension Bureau that Deputy Commissioner fell, who has made numerous public statements severely condemning the disability pension of Judge Long and others, was himself in the same boat with these pensioners.

Joseph Safran, the six-year-old son of Jacob Safran, a tailor of 131 East Broadway, was run over and killed about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Car No. 94 of the Avenue B Line, driven by Thomas Mulry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 -- Advices from Ban Jose de Costa Rica, Central America, report that there prevails throughout the republic a financial panic caused by the condition of the silver market. Failures have been numerous and more are expected.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4 -- "We object, because no power in the land can inquire into the facts," was the remarkable objection of Judge Advocate Doster to the question, "Who were in the hall at the time?" during the trial of Col. Hughes to-day for disobedience of orders and "giving information to the enemy."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Indian Inspector Falson arrived in the city this morning from the Choctaw country, whither he was sent some time ago under instructions from the President and Secretary Smith to prevent, if possible, further hostile demonstrations among the Choctaw factions. Mr. Falson was also instructed to recognize Chief Jones as the head of the legally-constituted Government of the nation, and to require obedience to the laws as administered by him.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The Long Island championship changed hands this morning, and W. A. Larned is now the proud possessor of the title, vice Edward L. Hall, defeated. Larned's match of to-day took four sets to decide the victory, the same number he played with Hobart yesterday. A great crowd witnessed the contest, and saw what proved to be exceptionally clever tennis.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Before the Congress of the Decorative Arts to-day Mrs. Ellen H. Richardson read a paper on clay as a material for decorating. She said that when the time comes when houses will be tiled all through and can be washan out daily with a hose, dust and microbes will be abolished. She contrasted the abodes of the ancients with modern houses, to the disadvantage of the latter.

N.L. Cort Co., importers of tin, tin plate, and other metals, of 245 Water Street, one of the oldest and best-known houses in the metal trade, failed yesterday. The partners, Nicholas L. Cort and his son, Mortimer H., made an assignment to Frederic G. Dow, lawyer, of 192 Broadway, giving seven preferences for money loaned, aggregating $34,425.

BUFFALO, Aug. 4 -- The trotters did not attract as much of a crowd to the Grand Circuit meeting today as the pacers brought out on Thursday, this, too, in spite of the fact that the purse of $13,000 is the largest one ever competed for by the open class. Still, there were some 8,000 people present, and they saw a long-drawn, hard fight for the big prize.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Theodore Thomas is in the mood to resign his position of Musical Director at the exposition, and there are potent influances at work to bring about the resignation.

The motormen and conductors of the Smith Street trolley road, Brooklyn, are on the verge of a strike. They are dissatisfied with the treatment they receive at the hands of the company, and unless concessions are made to them they say they will tie up the road.
STATE CAMP, PERKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The forenoon drills to-day closed the Summer's work at the State Camp. The camp has been occupied for eight weeks.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 4 -- The payment of pensions began in this city at 6 o'clock this morning by checks issued on the Sub-Treasury at New-York. In order to expedite matters four of the leading local banks agreed to furnish currency to the amount represented by checks presented in person.

ALBANY, Aug. 4 -- One hundred and one million two hundred and thirteen thousand dollars This enormous amount passed over the paying and receiving tellers' desks of New-York City's twenty-five savings banks during the first six months of this year. The amount received was greater than that paid out by $882,217.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 4 -- The Executive Council of the Provisional Government of Hawaii has decided to institute prosecution for criminal libel against Charles Creighton for having put Minister Blount's name on the cane presented to Clans Spreckels, which Blount claims was unauthorized, unless a satisfactory apology is made to the American Minister by Creighton.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 4 -- Bankers and whisky men are greatly agitated over Secretary Carlisle's order requiring Government depositories to turn over the surplus to the Sub-Treasury instead of sending it to New-York as heretofore. The whisky men declare that they cannot get the necessary currency and will have to close business.

The announcement that the messenger boys meditate a strike is startling. Everybody who has had occasion habitually to use a district messenger boy undoubtedly meditates a strike against the boy. The boy is a vagrom, irresponsible person, who, when he is intrusted with a message of great urgency, may or may not deliver it.

SAN FRANCIS, Aug. 4 -- San Francisco is the storm centre of California politics. A knowledge of the conditions here is essential to a comprehension of party prospects in the State. As a promising campaign in New-York has often been wrecked on a Mayoralty deal on Manhattan Islandl, so the verdict of California on great national issues has more than once been reversed by the rivalries of bosses for the local patronage in San Francisco.

The second annual Free Loan Exhibition of paintings hold by the University Settlement So ciety at the Neighborhood Guild, 26 Delaney Street, ended last Saturday evening. During the two weeks of the exhibition there were 56,659 visitors, an increase of more than 21,000 over the attendance last year. Of this number 27,187 were children.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Henry Henze, a produce dealer in this city, has disappeared under circumstances which indicate that he has committed suicide owing to domestic trouble.
Henry Allen, the banker, is evidently determined in his intention to pursue the Cordage Trust manipulators in the criminal courts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The old Essex is to be a receiving ship, and will be stationed at Philadelphia in place of the St. Louis. The Essex was began at Kittery, Me., in 1874 by the Government and completed in 1876 at Boston by Donald McKay.
May B. Thorne committed suicide with morphine Thursday night in her room at 48 West Twelfth Street.

A lady who was a member of one of the officers' families living in the navy yard one day gave permission to a new servant to go to Boston. The girl was lately over from the home-rule country and had a pleasant brogue. She was told to return by way of the private gate and to say to the guard "Resident."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- "Iceman'' Turner is by long odds the most anxious man in Washington to-night. He wants to succeed himself as Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives, and for the last week or more he has cheered his friends with the announcement that the members of the New-York delegation were bound to support him.
Commissioner Daly of the Department of Public Works yesterday submitted to Mayor Gilroy his report for the quarter ending June 30.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Aug. 4 -- P.M. There was some uneasiness at the opening of the stock market this morning, based on the possibility of the appearance of cholera at Quarantine and on the failure of the German-American National Bank of St. Paul, which was announced in THE TIMES this morning.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The question of the application of church funds has involved the Methodist Church of Inwood in a row in which the women of the church and the Trustees are in hostile array against each other.

John H. Morgan and Henry Ware Pelletier, the clerks in the employ of Woerishoffer Co., bankers and brokers in Exchange Place, who failed to appear at the office Thursday morning, are still missing. The firm has expert accountants at work on the books which were in charge of Morgan and Pelletier, but thus far they have failed to find any shortage in their accounts.

There is trouble in the synagogue Chebrs Anshel Radzilower, 44 Orchard Street. The former rabbi, Louis Cohen, did not please the members of the congregation, who considered him too unorthodox and irreligious, and he was discharged.

The annual picnic of the Hudson Boat Club of Manhattanville was held last night at Guterding's Cosmopolitan Park, One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street and Tenth Avenue, and was attended by fully 1,000 persons. The large hall of the Casino was handsomely decorated with plants and flowers, and hung with the many banners and trophies won by the club in past years.
Money on call loaned at 3 @ 5 cent., the average being about 4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

BUFFALO, Aug. 4 -- There is running in Buffalo to-night at 391 Washington Street, right in the heart of the business portion of the city, one of the largest gambling rooms in this State. It occupies the ground floor of a large block. It extends from Washington Street half way through to Ellicott Street, and has many hundred square feet of floor space.

It is Collector Kilbreth now. With rather more than usual ceremony, the new head of the Custom House relieved Collector Hendricks yesterday afternoon. There were brief speeches, and a handsome set of silver was presented to fair, Hendricks as a token of the esteem in which he is held by those who were associated with him in the service.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- The steam yacht Rachel sank last night, and of the twenty-nine guests on board, nine were drowned.
Mayor Boody of Brooklyn started in the business of Press Censor yesterday.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 4 -- The President put in a full day's rest to-day at Gray Gables in order that he would be better able to stand the long and continuous trip to Washington. Secretaries Carlisle and Lament were with him.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4 -- There were sensational developments to-day regarding the Mitchell Bank. Washington Becker, as receiver of the Wisconsin Marine and Fire Insurance Company Bank, has begun unit in the Superior Court against John L. Mitchell, David Ferguson, and John Johnston to collect promissory notes made May 22, 1893, which aggregate $600,000.
Henry Schlechte, Sr., of 40 West Street, Williamsburg, alleges that he was recently made the victim of a plot whereby his wife and his son, Henry Schlechte, Jr., hoped to get possession of his money.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Speaker Crisp will go into the Speaker's chair on Monday with a much better opportunity to gain credit for his Administration than he started with two years ago.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 -- At the Clearing House this morning money loaned between the banks at 7 3-10 @ 8 cent. There is, however, very little loaning of money and there are few inquiries. When banks are debtors they generally apply for Clearing House certificates. There was no letup in demand for New-York exchange, and the supply seems to be crowing scarcer.
The body or Miss Maria Bardwell, who killed herself at the United States Hotel Tuesday, was taken to Boston last night by her twin brother, Benjamin Bates Bardwell.

Peach baskets in a few weeks will become a nuisance to be got rid of as quickly as possible. Just now they are in great demand, and huge trees are being gnawed up by the insatiable machines that are being run to their fall capacity in the making of them. The wood used is poplar, gum, and sycamore, and occasionally birch, and costs $1 a cord standing in the forest.

During the absence of Superintendent McCaffery of the Blackwell's Island bakehouse Thursday morning John Buckley, nineteen years old, who was employed there with other short-term prisoners, escaped from the island. The authorities think Buckley swam the river to Brooklyn.

A conference was held Thursday night at the Ashland House between the brassworkers who belong to the Knights of Labor and those who belong to the International Brotherhood of Brassworkers and are affiliated with the American Federation of Labor. The object of the conference was to try and amalgamate the two organizations into one national union.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 4 -- David Harvey, Jr., sitting as a Supreme Court Commissioner, began this afternoon to take testimony in the case of the Township Committee of Eatontown against the Monmouth Park Association to set aside the certiorari granted by Chief Justice Beasley to the Racing Association, to prevent the repeal of the resolution of the committee fixing the license fee at $5,000.

Chicago furnished Wall Street with one of its principal topics of interest yesterday. Various dispatches from the Western city announced that one of its bankers, failing to get money from New-York in other ways, had put a draft for $25,000 in the hands of an express company for collection from the Western National Bank of this city.

ELIZABETH, Aug. 4 -- A suit for $10,000 damages was brought yesterday against the Central Railroad Company by Benjamin E. Hinde, a New-York broker, for injuries which his wife, Mary Frances Hinds, sustained in the disastrous rear-end collision at Greenville on Dec. 8, 1892.
BUFFALO, Aug. 4 -- A new factor is to be introduced into Chautauqua County politics this Fall by the candidacy of Mrs. Martha R. Almy for the office of School Commissioner in the Third District.
A meeting of the Executive Committee, or the Committee of Thirty, of Tammany Hall was scheduled for last night. It did not take place Opinions differ as to why it was not held.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Americans opened steady and advanced daring the first hour, Louisville reaching 56, St. Paul 54 3/8, Atchison 15 1/8, Erie 11 7/8, Union Pacific 20 1/2, and Canadian Pacific 73 1/4. Buying then seemed completed, and prices sagged on rumors that Union Pacific needed money and Atchison would have difficulty in renewing collateral notes falling due this year.

On the face of it the extreme scarcity of available currency, i.e., of the notes that ordinarily pass from hand to hand in the exchanges of daily life, may seem to lend a certain support to the claim of the advocates of silver and other supposed "cheap" money, that there is not money enough in the country, and to their argument that, instead of stopping the issues of Treasury notes, the Government should increase them.

J.A. Derse, who said he was City Marshal of Crete. Neb., was arraigned before Justice Meade in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning on the charge of carrying concealed weapons. Policemen Baton and Wilson of the Old Slip Station preduced a large pistol which had been in Mr. Derse's hip pocket.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 4 -- Ambassador Bayard, writing from London to a friend in this city, says:

-- The monument erected in London between 1671 and 1677 to recall the great fire was original with Sir Christopher Wren, but was not carried out according to his intention. He proposed that bronze flames should issue from the loopholes of the shaft and that the top should carry a phoenix to represent London risen from its own ashes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 4 -- As was foretold in a dispatch to THE NEW-YORK TIMES last evening, the National German-American Bank failed to open its doors this morning and announced a temporary suspension consequent upon a steady drain of withdrawals. The bank officials announce that every liability will be made good, but they require time to realize on their securities.

During the Brighton Beach meeting "Jimmie" McLaughlin has made each a miserable failure in starting that many patrons of the track have come to the conclusion that he is better fitted to start trolley cars than race horses. The climax was capped in the second race yesterday. A field of eight, two of which fell before the others were in motion, were sent away from the post.
The Hotchkiss rapid-fire gun has been known to the navies or the world for the past ten years, although its province bus until now been limited to ship work.

APIA, Samoa, July 19, via San Francisco, Aug. 4 -- War broke out between Malietoa's and Mataafa's forces, but war ships of the powers intervened and stopped the fighting. Mataafa and his chiefs have surrendered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Brazilian Government has determined that no cipher messages shall be received by telegraph at the port of Santos on account of the revolutionary troubles in that vicinity. This information came to the State Department to-day from Mr. Conger, the United States Minister to Brazil, who is now at Petropolis.

WILLIAM HURRY, one of the oldest builders and real estate dealers in this city, died Wednesday at his Summer residence, Toms River, N.J. He was born in Philadelphia in 1804 and came to New-York when a young man. He studied architecture and became a builder. He built the New-York Hotel and many up-town residences, and was agent for several large estates.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Frederick Oakes's Jintzy won to-day the first of the three races with Hermon Duryea's Twilight. The race was over a ten-mile course to windward and back, and the stakes in each are $150 a side. The wind to-day was fresh from the east, and the yachts carried all sail and big crews. The course lay from Sandy Hook dock to Point Comfort.

H.W. Martin, ex-Postmaster at Bennington, Vt., called upon Postmaster Dayton yesterday and told an interesting story concerning the methods of Albert H. Scott. Chief of the Salary and Allowance Division. In relation to the Post Office at Bennington in 1889.
