A reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES went to the District Attorney's office in Brooklyn yesterday to ask District Attorney Ridgway whether he was going to prevent the violation of law which "Pompadour Jim" Corbett, the champion slugger and talking fighter of America, has so boldly announced that he intends to commit at Coney Island.

Since the presence of cholera in Naples was reported to the authorities in Washington by Dr. YOUNG, the resident representative of the Marine Hospital Bureau, we have repeatedly urged that all possible legal measures to prevent immigration from Naples should be taken. There is now in the lower harbor a steamship that left Naples on July 15 with 471 steerage passengers on board.

Dun's Review in its issue to-morrow will say: "Demoralization in speculative markets has been followed by a more healthy tone, and heavy imports of gold inspire hope that monetary troubles may abate. The week has been one of surprises. Enormous liquidation in wheat brought the lowest price ever known on Tuesday.
It is not probable that a duel will take place between Col. William Murrell, editor of the New-Jersey Trumpet, and T. Thomas Fortune of the New-York Age.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 4 -- The City of Scranton was startled to-night by a report to the effect that President E.S. Moffat of the Lackawanna Iron and Steel Company, who went abroad about six weeks ago for the benefit of his health, committed suicide in London to-day by shooting himself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Dolphin, with Secretary Herbert on board, reached Washington about 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. The Secretary has been absent nearly a month inspecting the navy yards on the Atlantic coast.

MANHANSET HOUSE, SHELTER ISLAND, Aug. 5 -- The Shelter Island Yacht Club races were sailed today under some disadvantages. The races in the three classes of catboats were for double prizes. The day's events decided which boat should have its name engraved on the Colambas Cup given by Prof. Honsford last Summer, and also decided the winners of the silver cups given by the club.

The past week among real estate men was, like the week before, seasonably dull. Perhaps the only notable transaction was the sale of the Glenham Hotel property, already noticed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES. The general feeling among brokers is one of confidence.

COOPERSTOWN, Aug. 5 -- This has been a delightful week, and the Summer guests have made the most of superb weather and numerous sources of amusement. The Glimmerglass, as Cooper named Otsego Lake, has been a delight to a very great extent. Picnics at most of the beautiful points on the lake have been numerous this week, and no day has gone by without three or four large parties.
RAHWAY, Aug. 5. -- The Rev. R.P. Cobb, rector at St. Paul's Church, and Mrs. Cobb are at Ocean Grove.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- President Cleveland, accompanied by Secretaries Carlisle and Lamont and Attorney General Olney, arrived in Washington at 1:44 this afternoon over the Pennsylvania Railroad. They were all met by their respective private secretaries. The President was driven directly to the White House.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- It was as quiet as a Sunday school on Change to-day. Wheat advanced 1c, nevertheless. The opening was from 1 8 to 1 4c higher than yesterday's closing, and, with, some fluctuations, advanced 3 4@ 8c, then held steady, and the closing was at top figures. The New-York bank statement caused some little reaction, the market selling off early to the inside figures, but there was not much wheat for sale.

A good-sized delegation of Senators and Representatives was in this city for a time yesterday on its way to Washington. Senators Hoar of Massachusetts, Hale of Maine, Hansbrough of North Dakota, and Pettigrew of South Dakota were at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Senator J.D. Cameron of Pennsylvania, who arrived in the morning from Europe, hurried at once to Philadelphia.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 5. -- August generally brings the gayest period of the Water Gap's season and it is already evident that the present is to be no exception. The days are passing delightfully here and few of the people crowding in with the advent of the new month may be classed as " transient." Those coming for short visits remain for long ones and few leave at all willingly.

This French novel bears a remarkable likeness to the typical English novel of the present day. It is not a bit "Frenchy," although an unfaithful wife and a gay deceiver are among its principal personages. Doubtless people who enjoy the stories of Mr. Besant and his British contemporaries will find the slow, placid course of this simple romance just to their taste.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- The Bowdoin Square Theatre was reopened to-night with "The Still Alarm." "Lost in New-York" will follow Joseph Arthur's fire-engine play.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 5. -- The sixteen members of the engineer division of the first class and the fifty members of the second class stationed at the Academy daring the Summer were paid off last Thursday and vent on leave until Oct. 1. They are:

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- The Coroner's jury which has been inquiring into the death of Miss Genevieve Shultz, who was found in Tonawanda Creek a week ago, rendered a verdict last night that she "came to her death by drowning under circumstances unknown to the jury."

Mlle. Reichemberg has tendered her resignation from the Comedic Francaise. She is unrivaled as an "ingenue" in plays of Mollere and Pailieron, as Suzel in "L'Ami Fritz," and as Germaine in "La Joie Fait Peur." She is the eldest and most popular Societaire of the company. She is forty, a pupil of Augustine and Madeleine Brohan and a graduate of the Conservatoire.

It is a pity that the main purpose of the musical department of the World's Fair of exhibiting musical art in all its phases could not be carried out, but it has been made impossible by the cancellation of engagements with various American and foreign organizations and artists under the necessity of reducing expenses.

Miss M. Carey Thomas was only twenty-seven years old when she accepted the responsible post of Dean of Bryn Mawr College several years ago. In appearance she is a striking-looting woman -- of only medium height, however -- who parts her reddish brown hair over a full, white forehead, and whose large, fair face possesses that imperative charm, a cordial and ready smile.
SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The State camp at Peekskill was closed to-day, and as the batteries departed the First Battery fired a national salute.

BOSTON, Aug. 5 -- Beyond the strength and scarcity of New-York funds, there was little news of interest at the Clearing House this morning. Money between, the banks loaned at 73-10 and 8 cent., but there was little demand and little offering. New-York funds are practically unobtainable. There were sales of $150,000 at $3 premium for cash, and $25,000 at $5 premium, and the latter price would probably be paid for considerable amounts if offered.

At the request of the L.M. Green Association, a sketch of the life and work of the late Miss Lucy Merriam Green, long notable as the Principal of the girls' school established at No. 1 Fifth Avenne, by Mrs. Esther Smith, has been prepared her friend, William Allen Butler, and printed for private circulation among the nearest friends of this amiable and accomplished lady.

Last Monday morning, when the daily Dorrowing of stocks began. It developed that the situation had greatly changed in the market. In the general business situation there bad been no over-night change, but in the speculative situation based upon it there had been a very significant one. Speculative selling. It was found, had outstripped actual liquidation.

The most recent anecdote might perhaps be found again in ancient Egypt and Chaldea, and the Phoenician merchants may have carried it to Greece by the transverse roads of history. All the merit has lain in the manner of the writing. One may not persuade Loredan Larchey of this. The venerable Conservateur of the Bibliotheqne de I'Arsenal does not like the rewriters of anecdotes, and almost calls them plagiarists.

Arrangements have been made fully to supply the vessels of the fleet with THE NEW-YORK TIMES every morning during the cruise. News-dealers at the various points touched will put out for the boats immediately after the arrival of the early trains. It is intended that no reader of THE TIMES shall be disappointed in receiving his favorite paper.

Edward Keating, thirty-four years old, of 152 George Street. Brooklyn, had a sweetheart named Ida Doherty at 12 Ditmars Street. Edward went to Ida's home yesterday and asked her to marry him. She told him to wait ten years, which he took as a virtual dismissal.
August Belmont was asked yesterday by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES to make an expression of his views, for publication, upon the present financial conditions.

Mary Heyer said to be the wife and accomplice of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer, and jointly charged with him with wholesale poisoning for the purpose of defrauding insurance companies, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon in charge of Detectives Von Gerichten and Trainer, who were sent to Detroit to bring her on from the hospital where three weeks ago she gave birth to a child.

The Horseshoe Harbor Club had a gala day yesterday. The annual aquatic sports of the club were held and attracted a big crowd to the pretty little clubhouse at Larchmont. It is situated on the Horseshoe Harbor just above the Larchmont Yacht Clubhouse. The harbor is very appropriately named, rocks forming a cove shaped like a horseshoe. These rocks were yesterday crowded with pretty girls who wore bewitching costumes.

The Brooklyn and Morris Park Cricket Clubs played their return league match yesterday at Prospect Park, and the Brooklyn boys, after a close game, succeeded in reversing the result of the first match by winning by a margin of 16 runs.
The New English Dictionary still leaves something to be desired as a complete treasury of words in English of all ages, but it is a splendid dictionary for the future.

There is a certain analogy between our national legislation that excludes Chinese laborers from the country altogether and that which is intended to prevent the bringing here of any class of laborers under contract, and there is a similarity in the methods adopted for evading the restrictions of the law in the two cases.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Although not a rider, I am a great admirer of bicycling, and am much pleased to know that THE NEW-YORK TIMES proposes giving close attention to "wheeling interests." While treating the "daily happening" and "events" to come," there is much else that could be discussed with profit to the bicycle world.

For sixteen years the Pastime Athletic Club have given its annual games in conjunction with a picnic, but this season it decided to hold the two events separately. Yesterday the seventeenth annual games were held on the club's grounds, at Sixty-sixth Street and Eastern Boulevard, and in every way more than realized the most sanguine expectation of the committee.

The big steamship New-York looted very fine and like the well-groomed racer she is as she came slowly up the North River yesterday morning and tied up alongside her pier. Capt. Jamison reported a good passage with little fog or delay.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The display of military, sporting, and target arms, cartridges, and gun implements made at the Chicago Exposition is quite naturally pronounced superior not alone in extent, but in improvements and quality, to that made at any previous international show.

The Bank Clerks' Whist Coterie was holding its weekly meeting at the rooms of its President, Mr. Thaddeus Butts. This title, by the way, was more respectable than accurate; for whist was never played nor enacted. But the hour was late, and the game, whatever its nature, had been abandoned. Easy-chairs were easily occupied, and through clouds of tobacco smoke disjointed remarks were gradually consolidating into a conversation.

GREAT BRITAIN AS A SEA POWER -- The whole maritime energies of the French Republic after the battle of the 1st of June in 1794, and of the French Empire after the battle of Trafalgar, were directed to the subjugation of England through the destruction of her commerce. The command of the sea was not disputed.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 5. -- An attempt was made, with the aid of dynamite, at 11 o'clock to-night, to blow down the high brick walls of St. Mary's Parochial School, in Fifth Street, which was destroyed in the big fire of two weeks ago.

Front London Woman. Pink roses make an especially protty Summer table decoratien, particularly if combined with green and sliver. For instance, the table centre may be of Harris linen in a pale shade of green, embroidered with a conventional design in faint tones of pink touched here and there with silver thread.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., Aug. 5. -- With concerts and dancing almost every evening, attractive parlor entertainments and progressive euchre parties and other enjoyable features, visitors to Brentwood, "the Lukewood of Long Island," find their lines cast in pleasant places. All these things mean entertaining, happy hours indoors.
Brooklyn and Boston played two games at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon, and the Bostons carried off both games. In both contests they led at the bat and in the field and deserved the honors gained.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 5. -- The baseball game between the New-York and Detroit athletic representatives this afternoon came very near ending in a riot which could not but have resulted disastrously to the visitors because of their inferior numbers and the intense feeling created against them. The New-Yorkers began the "dirty ball," but the Detroiters are without sufficient excuse for continuing it.

The New-York Tourist Wheelmen differ from moet cycling organizations in that they possess no clubhouse, but they desire none and do not expect ever to have one. They do not even have a meeting room, but hold their meetings at the home of their President. Dr. Henry E. Westbay, at 55 West Forty-second Street. In spite of these apparent disadvantages, they maintain a strong club organization and keep up a membership of over fifty.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- A person might travel all over this country without finding a more beautiful and attractive spot than the site of Winnisook Lodge, the headquarters of the famous Winnisook Club. This lodge is on the divide between the Big Indian Valley and the valley of the west branch of the Neversink River.

None toe soon for the comfort and reassurance of his friends and followers has the veteran Hugh McLaughlln sought in the comparative retirement of Greenport the rest and repose which are nowadays strangers to him in Brooklyn. Before very long there will be a strenuous call for him from the thick of a desperate battle -- a battle whose ferocity and whose impendency nobody realizes more intensely and more uneasily than Mr. McLaughlin himself.

From the Brooklyn Jlagle. There is a touch of pathos in the idea of this old man being able to get little relaxation by the exercise of that will power which has made him what he is. He is doing bat little outside fishing. He prefers to wile the wily eel from the dock end rather than lure the sea bass from its rocky lair.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- A.W. Lawshe of the Trent Tile Company of this city has sent a letter to Jeremiah O'Rourke, the Supervising Architect of the Treasury, answering Mr. O'Rourke's criticisms on New-Jersey tile.

Chapter I. "Interesting people have tempers." It was my sister Kate who made that remark in a calm and even tone of voice which nettled me. I had been nettled all that morning, and I knew it. So did she, which made her utterances more pointed. She was leaning back in a very comfortable easy chair, the most comfortable one in my possession, and she was darning at the time.

SOUTH POLAND, Ma., Aug. 5. -- The Poland Spring season is at height, and it is the most successful one in its history. Over 600 guests are at the Poland Springs Hotel to-night, and every room is taken and cots are put up on the lower floors.

THE FUTURE OF THE WEST INDIES -- As a field for colonization by Europeans, and more particularly by British settlers, the West Indies cannot be recommended. On the loftiest slopes of the Blue Mountains of Jamaica a limited area may, perhaps, be found where a northern race might enjoy a suitable climate.

The experience of the Navahoe in the regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron recalls very strikingly the experience of the Genesia and the Puritan in the outside race. Most American yachtsmen are now prepared to admit that, in that weather, the Genesia was the better boat, and that the very small difference at the finish would have been much more than reversed if the Puritan had not greatly "out-tacked" the British cutter.

There were more people at the Monmouth Park race track yesterday than there has been in many weeks, and the racing was of a class that seemed to please them. To be sure, the regulars wondered a little about the chance of form shown by Integrity, who ran better with 6 to 1 against him than he did at his last appearance, when he was the favorite in the speculation.

More than half the passengers of the Anchor Line ship Karamania were transfered to the lower bar yesterday afternoon. The transfer of the others was prevented by rough water. Those who remained will probably be removed this morning. Then the vessel will be fumigated. The hospital ship Carlton as well as the transfer barge are now in quarantine service.

People, perhaps, take their laughter as they do their religions. It is an emotional question, depending, possibly, on climatic influences. The American is essentially a story-teller in its broadest sense, for he has the inventive power, and above all, as Mr. Alden expresses it, "that air of addressing a vast popular assemblage which is so characteristic of dignified American conversationalists."

Commander F.W. Dickins, who recently served as the official escort to the Duke of Veragua, has been ordered to hold himself in readiness to command the Mononnahela. The Monongahela is a training ship for naval apprentices. Her recent commander was Commander T.A. Lyons. Commander Lyons was detached from the Honongahela July 19 and granted sick leave.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, Aug. 5 -- P.M. Strength was the feature of to-day's stock market until the bank statement was published. That showed an extraordinary loss of $9,716,125 in reserve, a decrease of $9,231,900 in deposits, and a loss of over $12,000,000 in actual money holdings.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5. -- Vice President and General Manager Lucius Tuttle of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad this morning confirmed the report that the shops of the road in this city, Harlem, and Hartford would soon run on eight-hours-a-day time. He said:

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 5. -- One of the principal events in Stockbridge in the near future will be the floral boat parade on the Housatonic. The time has not been fixed, bnt it will be about the middle of the month. A large number of boats handsomely decorated with flowers will be sent along the river. The young ladies are especially interested in the plan.
ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The Summer days are slipping happily by and the end is not yet in sight.

Senator R.F. Pettigrew of South Dakota was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday on his way to Washington. He said he did not expect to see the Sherman act repealed until after a vast deal of talking and hard fighting on the part of the silver men.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- The trial opened here to-day of M. Ducret, editor of the Cocarde, and M. Norton. The latter la charged with having forged the documents that were alleged to hove been stolen from the British Embassy which purported to show that certain Frenchmen were guilty of treason. M. Ducret is charged with complicity in the forgeries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- An excursion to the great wheat fields at the Northwest, for the entertainment of representatives of agriculture and Foreign Commissioners, has been arranged by the Milwaukee and St. Paul and Northwestern Railroads. The party will probably leave Chicago Aug. 21. It will be entertained at St. Paul and Minneapolis and stay over one Sunday at Lake Minnetonka.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Naval Register is in a very tangled-up condition as a consequence of the refusal of the President to promote, on recent findings of the examining board, Commander M.L. Johnson, the equipment officer at the Portsmouth Navy Yard. Johnson still stands at the head of the list of Commanders, with another report of his fitness for promotion somewhere between the Navy Department and the White House.

If Jockey Harry Jones is allowed to ride in the same fashion at Clifton that he did at Brighton Beach yesterday it will be necessary to have a corps of physicians on hand in order to treat the backers of his mounts for severe attacks of heart disease. This exhibition of what some of the spectators declared to be careless riding and what many others called intentional negligence was given in the fourth race.

WESTERLY, R.I., Aug. 5. -- Down the river, off Watch Hill, is the fisherman's paradise. Mr. Ichabod Sisson anchored his little boat outside the reef one day recently and made the record for flounders, his catch aggregating 521 pounds in weight. The largest one tipped the beam at twenty-six pounds, and the rest were all big fellows.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5. -- Annie Smith of Willlamsburg, N.Y., the mysterious recluse whose attempt at suicide by starvation was published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning, has near relatives in this city. The name and address of Patrick Smith of Ivy Street were found in her possession after she had been taken to the hospital yesterday.

The camp at Sea Girt, which closed a week ago, is naturally the pride of every New-Jersey-man who is at all interested in military affairs. So far as general arrangements go the camp is well conducted. The general staff is competent, and the officers detailed for this particular duty are thoroughly proficient and are educated soldiers.

There was not much change in the financial situation yesterday. The scarcity of currency continued to be felt, and there were reports of further shipments of gold from Europe. The bank statement did not make a good showing, but conditions had given little reason to hope for a better one than was presented.
"I expect the House of Representatives will pass a bill repealing the purchasing clause in the Sherman act without delay," said William C. Whitney to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES last night.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The season is at its height, and that means that there are lots of pleasant ways to kill time and plenty of jolly people to assist in the assassination. What with dances, tennis parties, bathing, driving, and flirting, the time is taken up from early morn until the dawn of the next day.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 5 -- After a short session to-day the court-martial convened for the trial of Col. Hughes adjourned until Monday afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Five days ago we had the double-leaded authority of the Daily News, which is not only the historic mouthpiece of Gladstonian Ministries but has for principal owner the present Postmaster General, for a belief that the crisis between England and France had reached a point of great and solemn gravity.

The members of the Old Guard will have their annual outing on Thursday at Pleasure Bay, N.J. The battalion will leave by the steamboat route from Pier 8 North River, foot of Rector Street, at 9 o'clock in the morning, and will reach Long Branch at 10:45, where stages will convey the members to Pleasure Bay.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 5 -- This is the month for gayety on Lake George. It is here that the Summer girl appears in her most brilliant glory, clad in costumes that for splendor outshine the sun, and going from one extreme to another in dancing, recreation, and music. Rowing, fishing, tennis, swimming, riding, driving, dancing, walking, and flirting are some of the pastimes that come handy to her.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- In the Delaware River here there is a boat built alter the pattern of a catamaran, the propelling power being arranged in the same manner as a bicycle. There are two boats made of zic, connected by a slight platform, upon which are two saddles and two sets of gears, similar to a bicycle of tandem pattern.

The Washington dispatch in yesterday's TIMES concerning the opportunity of Mr. CRISP ought to commend itself to the attention of that gentleman. He was elected before, in spite of a very general belief that he did not represent the real and the declared purposes and principles of the Democratic Party.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 5. -- "About 700,000 spindles stopped here to-day for an indefinite period" is the sentence attached by brokers to their weekly statement of the condition of the cloth market, and the Mule Spinners' Association leads off its monthly circular with the words, "Husband your resources." The two expressions picture the mill situation here today about as clearly as it can be painted in words.

SARAH T. BOLTON, one of the oldest and most famous women in Indiana, died at her residence in Indianapolis Friday night. Mrs. Bolton was kown as the poetess of Indiana and wrote poems, among them being "Paddle Your Own Canoe" and "Indiana." She was the wife of Nathaniel Bolton, deceased, the founder of the Indianapolis Sentinel, the oldest daily paper in Indiana, and at one time Consul to Geneva, Switzerland.

Street Cleaning Commissioner Andrews yesterday dismissed 268 employes of his department on the grounds of inefficiency and incapacity. That he would make dismissals had been expected for several days.

A really thrilling aerial feat is being nightly performed in Bolossy Kiralfy's reconstructed spectacle, "King Solomon," at Eldorado. Miss Lizzie Vaidis, one of the celebrated Vaidis sisters, trapeze performers, stands on the apex of a wooden tower 80 feet in height, and, after posing a few seconds, dives head first into a net spread below the stage.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 5. -- Father William H. Tole, pastor of St. John's Roman Catholic Charch, has made a statement regarding the funeral of Mrs. Evelina Moran Budway. The fact that Mrs. Budway, who was a Catholic and a prominent member of St. John's Charoh, was buried Friday in the Rural Cemetery, which is non-sectarian, has caused a sensation in the town.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Charles F. Crisp of Georgia has been chosen to be the Democratic candidate for Speaker of the Fifty-third Congress, as was expected, and he will be elected on Monday. His nomination was made to-night by acclamation while the Republicans were deciding to vote for Thomas B. Reed.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 5 -- The last week has been a busy one for the local bonifaces. As usual, the 1st of August was moving day, and many of the July guests went in search of new pleasures at other resorts, while the trains brought extra loads of new-comers to bathe in the white sulphur waters or to Join the throng who drive, ride, bowl, dance, and strive to make life merry.

A yellow dog, frightened so badly that it lost its wits, ran down Broadway from Twenty-sixth street yesterday morning. A crowd of boys followed, some of them shouting "Mad dog! " Many persons became as excited as the dog. Women and men dodged into convenient doorways.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- The tennis tournament at the Meadow Club has been the event of the week here. The contests have been exciting throughout and eagerly witnessed by a large assemblage each day. The tournament ball on Friday evening was a brilliant affair.

Screens are always welcome, always find a place. Other objects may be unnacessary, may to regarded even as usurping space needed for other things, but screens serve well so many ends that they are certain to find a corner, let the room be completely furnished as it may.

Quite recently THE NEW-YORK TIMES called attention to what has been stigmatized as "boiler-plate news agencies." These concerns, for a consideration, supply out-of-town newspapers with electrotyped "copy" on all sorts of subjects, thus practically providing an article of ready-made journalism for newspapers that cannot afford the luxuries of type and presses of their own.

WHITE SULFHUR SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 5. -- The rumor that Proprietor Bishop of the old Sweet Springs was killed proves incorrect. Powell Beckner, the overseer of the old Sweet Farm, was killed by a man named John Wylie.

SEA GIRT, Aug. 5. -- This is the month that the crowds flash to the seashore before topping off the season by a sojourn in the mountains or the Adirondacks in early September, and there are now more guests at the Beach House than have been at any time yet, and more will arrive next week.
KINGSTON, Aug. 5 -- Preparations are being made for the annual camp or the American Canoe Assiciation which will be opened Aug. 12.
IRVINGTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Mrs. Mary Monaghan is not a "common scold." Some of her neighbors say she is, but she isn't. She says so herself.

"It would be amusing." remarked a physicians lately, "if it were not so often disastrous, to watch, the pell-mell fashion in which persons go at remedies and supposedly beneticial health suggestions. They go to the springs, and because some mineral spring water is advised in some case, they jump at the conclusion that all spring waters are good for any case.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Sea Cliff is enjoying itself and pitying those whose fancy took them to other places for the Summer. There are plenty of rational, sensible people who will affirm that Sea Cliff is the one incomparable resort on all Long Island. The ranks of Sea Cliffs admirers and advocates are constautly increasing.

SORRENTO, Me., Aug. 5. -- A visitor to the rugged and romantic coast of Maine finds among its almost endless succession of attractive and picturesque resorts few spots surpassing Sorrento in varied beauty and scenic effect. The pioneer land owners and cottagers who converted the shores of Frenchman's Bay into a Summer paradise mast have had Italian characteristics in mind when they named their little settlement.

Here is a book which ought to be in the hands of every brigade and regimental commander and commissariat officer in the National Guard. Were its lessons thoroughly learned and its suggestions adopted, the State troops could never again find themselves in such difficulties for want of proper sustenance as those of lane Summer at Buffalo.
ORANGE, Aug. 5. -- There is a romantic story going the social rounds this week, and there is a great deal of guessing as to who the principals in the episode are. The story runs thus:

Commissioner ANDREWS seems to appreciate the fact that, in order to clean the streets of this city and keep them clean, there mast be not only an efficient head of the department, but a well-organized and efficient working force. He has begun the process of weeding out the incapable men, and he is credited with a determination to infuse more energy and industry into the working of the department.

Farmer Jacob Remsen's old homestead stands on Clarkson Street near the Flatlands Neck Road, just across the Brooklyn city line, in the town of Flatlands. It is a favorite resort for marketmon, who generally stop there to real their horses and to have a sociable chat with "Uncle Jake," as he is called.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- There is likely to be trouble in the United States Marshal's and Post Office Inspector's offices here over the escape of the Rev. Dr. Frederick Howard of Jackson, Tenn.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Mr. Frank, a miller from Kansas City, Mo., says "green-goods" men have robbed him of $7,500, and he and Detective Patterson are now looking for the men who walked off with his good money. The miller entered Justice Charles Cothren's office this afternoon and related a strange story.
Proceedings have been begun to have Louis Schermerhorn adjudged a habitual drunkard.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5 -- Mr. J.B. Horreshoff, Jr., in an interview last night concerning the adverse criticism of the yachtsmen and the press of London upon the Navahoe, said that the critics in their eagerness to show the alleged inferiority of an American built boat forget several factors that enter into the problem of sailing a yacht successfully.

At their meeting next Tuesday, the General Passenger Agents of the trunk lines will probably take up the matter of continuing the halfrate excursion trains to Chicago through September. There is a general disposition among the railroad men to extend the time for the running of these trains. The cheap rates have been effective in bringing out people who otherwise might not have gone to the World's Fair.

A branch of the Moslem Brotherhood of the World has been established in Brooklyn. The new society has been named Khadijah No. 6. Its objects are to promote the study of Islam doctrines, laws, and customs. Khadijah was the name of Mohammed's first wife.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- The Board of Lady Managers indulged in another decidedly unpleasant wrangle to-day. It lasted about two hours, and in that time many unpleasant and disagreeable things were said, tears were shed, and many of the ladies gave vent to their feelings by hissing and uttering strange noises.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 5. -- The increased number of visitors who have come to the island within the past week has rejoiced the hotel proprietors, who have been looking to the month of August for their profits. The island, however, is not as lively as it generally is at this season.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 5. -- Down the river in a catboat is where many of Mystic's Summer visitors go at every opportunity. No pleasant day passes but some half dozen or more boats earry out large parties. It is a beautiful sail through two or three miles of wooded hills and islands to the broad bosom of the Sound, where there are many points of interest to attract attention.

Mayor Boody said yesterday he would probably notify the General Government next weck of the city's acceptance of the offer to sell the Wallabout lands, at the navy yard, for $1,200,000. He says the price is high, but it is important that the city should acquire the property. As the option given by the Government expires Aug. 15, the matter will have to be attended to at once.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Burgeon General Sternberg of the army has issued a circular of information for candidates seeking appointment in the Medical Corps. There are at present five vacancies in the list of Assistant Surgeons to be filled. The places pay $1,600 per year for the first fire years, when the Assistant Surgeon is promoted to a Captain and receives $2,000, with increases after five, ten, fifteen, and twenty years service.

The appointment of receivers for the wholesale and retail dry goods house of James H. Walker Co. in Chicago, announced in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, has not occasioned any alarm in the dry goods trade of this city. It is believed that the firm can show assets far above its liabilities, and that when a settlement is made every creditor will be paid dollar for dollar.

SARANAC LAKE, Aug. 5 -- Another week has gone and the height of the season is fast approaching. Delightfully cool weather has prevailed for several days, and the highways and byways, the forests and the waters, have been fairly alive with joyous humanity.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 5. -- News was received here this afternoon of the killing of an old citizen and the wounding of Sheriff Patterson of Woodruff County at McCrory, Ark., at 10 o'clock last night. The murderer, who is a negro, escaped to the woods and is being hotly pursued by a crowd of indignant citizens.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 5 -- The annual regatta of the East Bay Yacht Club, which took place off Moriches to-day, was successful, although but five of the yachts entered for the event crossed the line at the start, which was made from off the Hotel Brooklyn dock at 3 o'clock. The weather was all that could be desired, and a spanking soutwester favored the racers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- In its big establishment near the east entrance of Midway Plaisance the Libber Glass Company exhibits, in addition to every well-known variety of glass products, an assortment of spun-glass articles, in which glass has usurped the place of linen, silk, and other textile fabrics. The display is an interesting study.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- In the course of the silver discussion in the last session of Congress, Josiah Quincy, now Assistant Secretary of State, was a deeply-interested observer of the course of the anti-silver Democrats, and from time to time as the contest went on ventured to advise his friends in Congress from Massachusetts what he thought it would be best for them to do in certain circumstances.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, L.I., Aug. 5. -- All is yachting. To turn one's eyes upon the superb stretches of water that surround this little Eden is to meet a bewildering vista of white clouds of sails and trim, saucy hulls. Alert, flashing back the sun's rays, the glistening yachts make an inspiring picture. On shore, yachting suits clothe stalwart masculine forms and yachting caps surmount the shapely heads of half of Shelter Island's fair visitors.

The fourth Saturday pony racing matinee at Elkwood Park showed a marked improvement in the matter of attendance. Elkwood Park Athletic Association is now a member of the American Hunt and Pony Racing Association, and yesterday was the first time the races were ran under the management of the latter organization.

If the late Commodore John G. Stevens of the New-York Yacht Club could be present at Glen Cove to-morrow he would witness a sight that would astonish him and one which in his most extravagant dreams he never anticipated.

ROMAN TOMBS -- In 1870 the tomb of a certain Q. Sulpicius Maximus was discovered. It dates from the end of the first century. In A.D. 95 Domitian, who, for all his atrocities, had some taste for literature, instituted a contest for young poets. The subject was Jupiter rebuking Apollo for trusting his chariot to Phaeton.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 5. -- The week has been comparatively, quiet among the shore resorts in this vicinity. Since the invitation hop given Saturday evening by the management of the Pequot House, the Summer people have had to depend upon select dinner parties and an occasional coaching outing or yachting party for amusement.

Judge Benedict, in the United States District Court, Brooklyn, delivered a decision yesterday in the libel salts of the Ward Steamship Company against the steam tug Talisman and the bark Talisman, and also in the counter suit brought by Theodore J.C. Range, owner of the bark, against the tag and the Ward steamship Niagara.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The hook-and-line fishermen, who sought last February to have a bill passed to abolish pound not fishing, have made up their minds that they will not be defeated next Winter for the want of organization. They have secured a permanent association, which is to extend over the entire State. At present those principally interested are the fishermen in the vicinity of Long Branch.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- There need be no doubt of the position of the Democratic members of the New-York delegation in Congress regarding the Sherman act.

TAYLOR'S - ON - SCHROON, Aug. 5 -- Great Schreon Lake is fast filling up with Summer boarders. The Taylor House has 120 guests, and expects 40 more this week. Among those expected are Joseph Blumenthal and family of New-York. Ex-Sheriff Peter Bowe and family of New-York have engaged a cottage for the season at the Taylor House.

PARIS, July 17. -- The fete was not a gay one, certainly, but it was no fault of the date, neither of the people, nor of the past and passing events. By the way, the only reasonable explanation of the recent street quarrels that has come within my reading limits was the NEW-YORK TIMES'S editorial. It was just that and nothing more.

The Crescent Athletic Club handicap tennis tournament was continued yesterday afternoon on the club courts. Bay Bidge. The interclass championship in the singles was decided, which leaves the play-off between the class winners in the doubles as the only match still to be contested.

The three Russian war ships, Dimitri Donskoi, Admiral Nachimoff, and Rynda, reached this port yesterday from Newport. The three ships anchored in the North River, between West Twenty-third and West Thirty-fourth Streets. They lie in the above order, with the Rynda occupying the position the lowest down stream. The ironclad Nicolai I. lies just above the Dimitri Donskoi.

The plans of the leaders of both political parties now are laid for late meetings of the State Committees, which will call the State Conventions to nominate the officers to be voted for on the State tickets this Fall. Through Thomas C. Platt, the Republicans are committed to a very late convention and to a short and aharp campaign.
PLATTEVILLE, Wis., Aug. 5. -- The First National Bank has suspended, but will resume in a short time. The assets are $50,000 in excess of the amount due depositors.

SOCIAL DOINGS ON STATEN ISLAND -- One of the pleasantest incidents of the week on Staten Island was Willard Brown's moonlight party on Jacob Cram's steam launch, when a number of young people, including Mr. Brown's fiancee, Miss Gertrude Williams, enjoyed a sail around the Lower Bay, returning to the island about midnight for supper. Mr. Brown and Miss Williams will not be married before next Spring.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The residence of the Rev. Gottlieb Andreas, pastor of St John's German Evangelical Lutheran Church on Fairview Avenue, was the scene of a hasty marriage this morning. The groom was forty-five years, apparently, and the bride gave her age as twenty-five.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Cassidy and McBurney, in left field and third base respectively, made miserable exhibitions in this afternoon's game between the Staten Island Athletic Club and the Englewood field Club, in which the former was victorious by a score of 5 to 2. The above-named players made nine errors between them, which were responsible for all the runs secured by the Athletics.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 5. -- In proportion to its population, Normandie has more really pretty girls than any other resort on toe coast. There are half a dozen types of American beauty at the hotel. It would be unkind to the others to single them out by name, and it would be no easy matter to select a mere half dozen.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 5. -- This bit of Paradise is on the topmost wave of the most successful and enjoyable season in its history. In high favor with pleasant, companionable people, all of whom are here this season, attractive events follow upon each other's heels, and a dull moment is unknown. Daily tussles with old Neptune are the delight of the pretty girls, who are here in shoals.

When the Cunarder Umbria reached Quarantine last night it was reported that Thomas Thompson, one of her 214 second cabin passengers, was missing. Thompson was booked at Liverpool for New-York. The officers or the vessel do not know whether the man slipped ashore at Queenstown or whether he disappeared during the voyage.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- An exhibit which attracts a great deal of attention in the centre of the West Gallery of the Manufactures Building is that which the Canfield Rubber Company makes of its Canfield Dress Seamless Shield, the inventor of which, Jared H. Canfield, is a distinguished instance of the opportunities presented in this country to men whose ingenuity and inventive genius lead them to devise articles of popular use.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5. -- A parallel of to-day's game would be hard to produce. New-York won it in the ninth inning. German gave nine bases on balls and his a batsman. Four of these scored. Three Baltimoreans reached home in the second inning without a hit being made. The sixth inning was a circus. A double and eight balls filled the bases, and then Baldwin relieved German.

Dr. John T. Nagle, Register of Records, made report yesterday that is in everyway reassuring on the health of the city for the week which ended at noon. There were but 829 deaths against 1,084 the week before, and 909 the average for the corresponding period since 1887. There were 312 marriages and 1,254 births.

American exhibitors at the World's Fair in Chicago will do well to look closely into the source of foreign orders for their goods before making shipments abroad. Otherwise, their experience may not be so fortunate as has been that of H.H. Heinrich, a maker of marine chronometers at 14 and 16 John Street.

Paula inherited a kind of crankiness. Her father was a philosopher and entertained many strange ideas, among others that the marriage bond was "a meaningless tie, binding only when agreeable to both parties." Brought up with such notions, why did Paula marry Mr. Ferris, who was a quiet, sober-minded lawyer, some ten years older than she?

Obscure and remote as are the roots from which sprung France's quarrel with Slam, they confessedly furnished a colorable pretext rather than a legitimate provocation for the arbitrary attitude and belligerent acts of the European power.

THE FOX, THE BADGER, AND RABBITS. -- The fox noses the rabbits out at times, and scratches them out. As to the badger, what could be more delicate for his very acoommodating appetite than tender young rabbits? They put flesh on to his ribs after his fast -- often a long and compulsory one -- in Winter.

The series of interesting books to which this belongs contains scarcely another volume that appeals to so wide a number of readers. Swimming, as the author says, is the most universal of all physical exercises. It has had votaries among all classes, all nations, and all races, extending backward in history to the earliest times of which we have authentic records.

THE MERCHANT NAVY IN QUEEN BESS'S TIME. -- When Elizabeth came to the throne the whole merchant navy of England engaged in lawful commerce amonuted to na more than 50,000 tona. You may see more now passing every day through the Gulf Stream. In the service of the Crown there were but seven revenue cruisers in commission, the largest 120 tons, with eight merchant brigs altered for fighting.

On the beach the children oaper about like monkeys, but when decked out in their fairy frooks and turned loose on piazza and lawn they hover about like butterflies and are always poised for flight Probably the airy materials of their costumes assist in this pretty effect, but yet more is due to the present fancy for bretelles, berthas, and all sorts of fly-away drapery.

The launch of the United States torpedo boat Ericsson at Dubuque, Iowa, some day this month, promises to be a marked event in the history of the development of the new navy of the United States. The exact date of the launching is as yet unknown, but the new crafts is so far advanced that it can be launched as soon as the water in the Mississippi is in good condition.

The trial races between the four eighty-five-footers built to defend the America's Cup will be the most interesting yachting events of the year outside the race for the cup itself. It will be a hot contest between four good and fast boats sailed four of the best yachting skippers in the country.

RED BANK, N.J., Ang. 5 -- The Shrewsbury Yacht Club had a very light wind for its race this afternoon. The contest was the second in the series of three races for prizes offered by the club. The first race was won by the Undine in Class D. and Gortrude A. in Class E. The latter won the silver jewel case offered to the yacht in that class winning the most races in the series.

The residents of the pretty suburban town of Montclair, N.J., think that they have the handsomest and best-equipped country school in the United States. It has recently been completed at a total cost of $125,196. It is called the Montclair High School, and is situated between the Orange Road and St. Luke's Place, at the foothills of the Orange Mountain.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- In the yachting world great in terest is manifested in the performances of the American yacht Navahoe. The week's racing in the vicinity of the Ile of Wight has attracted large crowds of spectators, and the racing has been highly successful, from the popular British point of view.

The old patrons of the Imperial Music Hall will scarcely recognize the place in its new dress. During the past three weeks many changes have taken place, calculated to improve the attractiveness of the theatre. The balcony has been lowered seventeen inches, and the stage five inches, while its area has been materially enlarged.

The speech of Mr. REED on accepting the nomination of his party for Speaker on Saturday evening was not a wise one. It was sharp, adroit, sarcastic, but animated by a spirit of partisanship. Mr. CRISP'S remarks were more dignified. But neither of these Congressional leaders seems to have any clear vision of the infinite pettiness of all partisanship in the presence of the duty now before Congress.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 6 -- A disastrous and fatal wreck occurred about midnight on the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad at Lindsey, a small town twenty-two miles east of Toledo. Chicago Express No. 9, which left New-York Friday night, was all but annihilated, while local freight No. 47 had two cars smashed and the engine demolished.

The Twentieth Assembly District is one of the new spots upon the political map of this town. It is one of the results of the reapportionment of 1892, and although it is among the smaller districts of the city in point of territory, it is one of the best Democratic districts in the whole thirty.

ALBANY, Aug. 5 -- By the reports of the district Fish and Game Inspectors for the month of July, just made to the State Inspectors, it is shown that violators of the fish and game laws are being followed closely.

"Counterparts; or, the Cross in Love." owed its fame to "Charles Auchester.' Forty years ago curiosity was aroused as to the identity of "E. Berger," a pseudonym which stood for the author. Miss Elizabeth Sheppard. The dedication of the first book to Mr. Disraeli, of the second to Mrs. Disraeli, "with the deepest gratitude," at once save the clue.

RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Henry Jaberg, who survived the rare "Diffenbach operation," having a leg amputated at the hip joint, returned to her home in Linden to-day. She is the daughter of C. Ramsin, a rich farmer and stock raiser, and has been an inmate of the Elizabeth Hospital six months.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks issued on Saturday showed a decrease in reserve of $9,716,125. The banks now hold $14,021,800 less than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $2,231,300 a decrease in specie of $6,702,100, a decrease in legal tenders of $3,322,000 a decrease in deposits of 89,231,600, and an increase in circulation of $166,700.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 6 -- A nest of river pirates has been discovered on an island in the Kansas River, about four miles west of this city.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 6 -- The second session of the Catholic Summer School of American was formally closed this morning with high mass in St. John's Church. The celebrant was the Rev. Mr. Walsh of Albany. The deaco was the Rev. J.H. O'Rourke of Port Henry and the sub-deacon Father Cotter or Plattsburg. The Master of Ceremonies was Father McMillian.

James H. Hart, jeweler, of 539 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, has lately missed silver spoons, forks, and other articles from his stock, but has been unable to trace the thief. John Chewleleuski, sixteen years old of 242 Navy Street, who was employed by the jeweler, tried to pawn six silver forks with Moses Selig, 504 Atlantic Avenue, Saturday evening. He wanted $15.

In changing its name from the American Home Missionary Society to the Congregational Home Missionary Society, that old organization in the Congregational Church has east aside the title by which it had been known for more than sixty-seven years. The change in the corporate designation or the society was due to a condition in the will of Joseph Henry Stickney of Baltimore, who bequeathed $150,000 to it provided the change in name should be made.
ROCKAWAY BEACH, Aug. 6 -- Rockaway Beach was visited by the fiercest squall of wind and rain in the history of the place this evening.

The Summary Statement of the Bureau of Statistics for June was published on Saturday, and the reports for the month and for the entire fiscal year, now for the first time accessible, show clearly the astounding blunder of the predecessor of the present Chief of the Bureau, to which we have already referred.

THE LYCEUM STOCK -- No such scene of enthusiasm has ever been witnessed in a San Francisco theatre as that which signalized the farewell performance of the Lyceum Company at the Baldwin. "The Charity Ball" was the play, and when the curtain fell on the last act, the entire audience stood up and called the curtain up four times on the assembled company.

If there had been another dog in the basement of Patrick M. Mallon's saloon at the foot of West Seventy-seventh Street at 12:20 o'clock Sunday morning, fifty-seven men who are now at liberty in this city would be in prison cells, or at most out on bail. One dog was in the basement -- a lusty bulldog hungry and ready to fight.

ARVERNE, L.I., Aug. 6 -- Mayor Gilroy and Mrs. Gilroy were entertained at a small dinner party at the Hotel Arverne Saturday evening. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Brown and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Mulqueen.

Harry Richardson, an accountant for the Fidelity and Security Company of this city, dislocated his neck while bathing at Bath Beach, L.I., Saturday afternoon, and is now lying at the point of death in the Homeopathic Hospital in Cumberland Street, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Aug. 6 -- The German arrangements for the active enforcement of the lately-increased tariff on Russian products are now complete and the new customs regulations will be rigidly observed. All along the Russian frontier an army of officials with patrols have been attached to the customs service. On the German side customs officials have been drafted from all points and have been sent to reinforce the posts in Eastern Prussia, Posen, and Silesia.

QUEENSTOWN, Aug. 6 -- The Guion Line steamer Alaska, Capt. Murray, from New-York July 29, arrived here at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon, after a most eventful voyage. The Alaska encountered log the entire passage.

James Brady of 1,323 Amsterdam Avenue, an engineer on the tugboat Rescue, lying at One Hundred and Thirty-second Street and North River, went down to attend to his duties at 10 o'clock last night. With him was his tiny daughter Katie, but two and a hair years old.
"Are polygamists to begin their teachings among us?" is a question East New-Yorkers have been asking with some concern recently.

John Woodford, eighteen years old, of 917 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested as be was preparing to go to church yesterday morning for accepting a bribe to drop a complaint against a "shell-game" swindler.
BANGKOK, Aug. 6 -- Ratifications of the Franco-Siamese agreement were exchanged on Friday. M. Pavie, the French Minister, will resume his post here on Monday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -- The United States coast-defense vessel Monterey has arrived from Puget Sound. Officers and crew are delighted with her. The men call her a "soft ship," meaning that she is more easily worked and gives more pay and privileges than the average man-of-war.

CORYDON, Ind., Aug. 6 -- Samuel and William Conrad shot and Killed four men and fatally wounded another man at 1 o'clock tills morning. The shooting occurred at the home of the Conrads, which was surrounded by a mob bent on lynching them for the alleged murder of their father.
RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 6 -- Another chapter was added to-day in the long-existing feud which has existed in Upper Rahway for several years between Claude Gorisse and some of his neighbors.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 6 -- The campaign in New-Jersey can be said to be fairly opened, judging by the activity shown by the candidates in the counties. Apart from a smart fight on the Legislature, there will be a lively contest in eighteen counties over Sheriff, County Clerk, and Surrogate. The election for Sheriff occurs every three years and for Surrogate and County Clerk every six years.

ZURICH, Aug. 6 -- The International Socialist Congress opened in this city to-day. Delegates were present from sixteen countries. The visitors were welcomed by M. Burkly of Zurich in a speech which was delivered alternately in German, English, and French, and which dwelt chiefly upon the progress of the labor movement in the last thirty years.

Fifteen-year-old Thomas Scanlan is a hero in the eyes of his boon companions in Downing Street and its neighborhood. He is also under arrest, and, unless Eugene Reilly's strong constitution enables him to recover from several severe stab wounds, he will be charged with murder.

Frances Crimmins, aged five, and her brother Bartley, aged two, were yesterday put to play on the fire escape at 204 West Sixty-first Street. Some boards which covered the well of the escape tipped, and both the children slipped through and fell to the paved courtyard, five stories below.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 6 -- The Portland Water Company's large reservoir on Munjoy Hill burst this morning at 5:30 o'clock with serious results. Four persons, who were in a house in the path of the rushing water, were killed. They were:

Max Eiseman of Coney Island, seventeen rears old, was arrested Saturday on the order of Inspector McLaughlin and brought to New-York. He was arraigned yesterday morning in the Tombs Police Court on the charge of luring Wallace Sweeney, a boy of twelve years, from his home in New-York and getting him down to Coney Island, there to teach him the tricks of the sneak thief's and pickpocket's trade.

The police of the West Twentieth Street Station are endeavoring to clear up the mystery surrounding the death of Eugene Walsh, a young laborer, which occurred yesterday morning at the New York Hospital, from a fractured skull and other injuries, the result of a brutal beating.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- There is a possibility that the subject of the repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman law will be brought before the House to-morrow before the organization of that body is complete. A movement was set on foot this evening looking to the immediate discussion of a joint resolution representing the views of the opponents of the Sherman law.

Gen. Roberto Sacasa, the constitutional President of Nicaragua, is at the Clarendon Hotel. His wife and two sons are with him, and as soon as advices from Nicaragua as to the condition of the Government have been received, and some matters of private business have been attended to, they will accompany him to Europe.
A flash of lightning descended at the corner of Hageman Avenue and Berryman Street. East New-York, at 6:15 last evening, and instantly killed a man and a little girl whom the man had in his arms.

The Scribners have been prompt to make arrangements to publish the authorized English version of the memoirs of the late Chancellor Pasquier, the first volume of which was reviewed at length in THE TIMES from the French edition several weeks ago. The work will be issued here with the title "A History of My Time," and comprises three volumes.

The handsome Auchincloss memorial pulpit of Grace Church has lately undergone an alteration. Formerly, to get into the pulpit it was necessary to ascend a spiral stairway. This stairway, bulging out to one side, was an awkward looking affair from the body of the church, and the rector, going up or down, was apt to stumble.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 6 -- The Order Germania of different cities of New-York, Connecticut, and New-Jersey, comprising 110 lodges and 30,000 members, had an outing at Point View Island to-day. Point View Island has never before seen such a crowd. They came on the steamers John Lennox, Bay Queen, and Blackbird and the barges Sumner, Warren, Nelson, Vanderbilt, Curry and Arthur.

Mrs. Caroline Milbauer, a German widow forty-three years old, died yesterday at the Lebanon Hospital from lockjaw. The woman kept a small store at 3,541 Third Avenue. Ten days ago, while walking across the store, she stepped upon a rusty tack, which ran into her foot, inflicting a slight wound.

The call-money market was firm early in the week, but became easy after Wednesday. The extreme sale on Monday was 51 cent., but later in the day it fell to 3 cent. On Tuesday 10 cent, was the highest and 3 the lowest, and after that the range was from 2 @ 6 cent.

Edward Keating, an iron molder of 152 George Street, Williamsburg, who tried to shoot Mrs. Ida Dougherty of 12 Ditmars Street, Saturday, and who took rat poison because he thought the dying howls of a dog which he had shot by mistake were the moans of his sweetheart, died in St. Catharine's Hospital at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 6 -- Dr. I.K. Funk, William T. Wardwell, W. Jennings Demorest, and the other Directors of National Prohibition Park are continuing their effort to secure the rescinding of the "few drops of whisky" clause in the "directions" issued by the New-York Board of Health.
The financial depression was discussed yesterday by the Central Labor Union.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 -- The causes that led to the downfall of the Indianapolis National Bank are gradually coming to light, and it is alleged that when the final report of Special Bank Examiner Young is completed it will show that the methods by which the bank was wrecked were little better than those of the old-fashioned pirate.

Arrangements have been made fully to supply the vessels of the fleet with THE NEW-YORK TIMES every morning during the cruise. News-dealers at the various points touched will put out for the boats immediately after the arrival of the early trains. It is intended that no reader of THE TIMES shall be disappointed in receiving his favorite paper.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 5 -- Our local money market has exhibited during the week simply an aggravation of the various disturbing conditions which have prevailed for some time past, the most conspicuous being the continued scarcity of currency, which is now acutely felt on all sides. Several of our banks require checks drawn on them to be stamped: "Payable only through the Clearing House."

-- The Countess von Roque of Rouen, Francs the mother of Mrs. Florence May brick, has instituted suit in Richmond for the recovery of 2,000,000 acres of land in Virginia and West Virginia which she claims were obtained from her family through deception and fraud. Other claimants say they are prior owners. There are many legal complications, and among the large number of persons interested are many families in this city and in Paris.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 6 -- The report of the condition of the Louisville City and Merchants' National Banks, which recently suspended payment, have been forwarded to Washington by Bank Examiner Betts. There is considerable rivalry between them as to which will first resume payment. Both have been reported to Controller Eckels as perfectly solvent, and there seems to be no reason why they should not soon begin business again.

The most recent volume from Kate Sanborn before the appearance of this was the well-remembered "Adopting an Abandoned Farm." It came at a time when there was much striking discussion of the decay of agricultural pursuits in New-England, resulting in an apparently appalling record of deserted lands and firesides.

Although metropolitan trotting horse men can scarcely expect to see such rapid work over the Morrissnia track as the grand circuit racers have been putting up at Cleveland and Buffalo, they can count on witnessing faster harness miles than ever before seen at Fleetwood. At all times a fairly good track, Fleetwood's mile will be in tiptop condition for the last week of this month.

A party of Brooklyn wheelmen recently completed a very interesting long-distance wheeling tour of 600 miles over Canadian roads, and they are very enthusiastic over the beauty of the country and the interesting experiences which they had on the trip. The party was composed of John L. Shepherd and B. Ashforth of the Long Island Wheelmen, Dr. F. W. Topham of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club, and C.M. Fogg of the Century Wheelmen of Philadelphia.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 6 -- The announcement that Walter B. Richie is no longer a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor has injected elements of uncertainty into the contest that will much increase the interest in the great convention which meets at Cincinnati Wednesday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 6 -- A gang of thieves which for some time past has been salling up and down Long Island Sound and committing all sorts of dupredations is now being pursued by Deputy Sheriff Knowlton of Long Island and a posae of men in a fast sailing vessel.

-- Bishop John P. Newman of the Methodist Episcopal Church lately wrote from Buenos Ayres that he expected soon to sail for home and to reach New-York about the 10th of August. He has been visiting the missions in South America, has been absent about four months, and his tour will have covered about 14,000 miles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- At noon to-morrow the Congress will meet, and with a full attendance of Democrats in both houses. The country will watch its proceedings with great interest and with a confidence that the outcome of the extra session will be beneficial to the people.

Mr. Kinney devotes the major portions of his volume to education, the ground he covers being that of physique, manual labor, observation, and the instruction of boys and girls. Education is generally considered in its narrowest and most incomplete interpretation as a literary preparation.
RACINE, Wis., Aug. 6 -- Business among the factories here is beginning to brighten. During the last month not more than one-third of them were in operation, even on short time.

The feast of St. Ignatius, founder of the Society of Jesus, was celebrated yesterday morning at the Jesuit Church of St. Francis Xavier, in West Sixteenth Street, by a solemn high mass, the Rev. Father Denny, S.J., being the celebrant. As is the custom with the order, in its observance of the feast day of its patron saint, a priest outside or the society was invited to preach the sermon.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 6 -- The British steamer Danube arrived from Vancouver yesterday morning with fifty-seven Chinese passengers, including one Chinese woman and her maid. The woman is said to belong to an aristocratic Hongkong family. She is very pretty. Permission was given by the Customs Collector for herself and maid to land this afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Discount during the week was firm at 3 cent. Money was plentiful at 1 cent. A return allows that L1,585,000 in gold was withdrawn for the United States during the week. It is understood that all orders sent here have been filled, and that the demand will now cease for the present. Silver continues firm, with a moderate Eastern demand.

Few subjects come amiss to the man or woman who thinks, and Haryot Holt Cahoon, without that higher and more deliberate style which Agnes Repplier possesses, has certain excellencies as an essayist. She speculates little. She rather draws conclusions from what she sees. She seems to have as a salient trait a capability, peculiar to her sex, of landing on the flight above without mounting the steps.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 6 -- The trial of Mrs. Mattle Shann of Princeton for the murder of her son, John Shann, by using mercurial poisoning, to obtain $2,000 insurance money, begins Tuesday in the Mercer County Court before Supreme Court Justice Abbett.

Mgr. Marquis of Quebec arrived in this city on La Champagne yesterday morning, and brought to the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, in East Seventy-sixth Street, a relic of St. Anne, grandmother of Jesus Christ. This is the third relic which has come to this favored sanctuary, but it is not the one which Father Tetreau, pastor of the church, expected.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 6 -- In September, 1892, there was organized under the laws of Pennsylvania the United States Pipe Line Company, whose business was to be the transportation of both crude and refined petroleum from the oil regions to the seaboard, to the great lakes, and to other points for distribution.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- All entrances to the exposition grounds were open to-day during the usual hours, but the crowd that passed through the gates was extremely small. The fair was open but in name only.

Arthur Eggeling, the German comedian, who appeared at the Amberg Theatre on Irving Place a few years ago, will sail from Bremen on Aug. 21 to appear at the new Germania Theatre on Eighth Street, under the management of Adolph Philipp.

The plan of action which THE TIMES has set forth as the best one for Congress and for the country finds favor among men of both parties at Washington. Senator WASHBURN of Minnesota, a Republican, and Senator PALMER of Illinois, a Democrat, agree in favoring an immediate and unconditional repeal of the silver-purchase feature of the Sherman act, putting off for a time any consideration of a substitute measure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Controller Eckels today anthorized the First National Bank of Hutchinson, Kan., lately suspended, to reopen for business.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 7. -- Statistics of the Custom Houses showing importatiens for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1890, are just published. The Treasury is always two or three years behind in obtaining importation statistics. The total importation was $52,018,658, and included goods valued at $212,385,98 brought in free of duty.
A lawsuit possessing special interest for touchers in the public schools is being pushed by George Steinson, formerly First Assistant in Grammar School No. 29.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- For four hours this afternoon the Board of Lady Managers wrangled, and when the meeting adjourned the report of Mrs. Meredith, which was the cause of all the trouble, was still before the body. There were tears, hisses, stamping, and other noises.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- A strike of the carpenters, painters, plumbers, steamfitters, steam titters, helpers, marble cutters, and polishers employed on B. F. Keith's new theatre, on Mason Street, was started as 2 o'clock this afternoon by Business Agent Burke of the Building Trades' Council.
The money market was quiet. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 3@6 p cent. The last loon was made at 3 p cent.

PORT HURON, Mich., Ang. 7. -- A presumably incendiary fire Sunday morning destroyed the block near the Butler street wharf Known as Flat-iron Point. Too buildings destroyed number fifteen and ware tenanted by poor people, who lost their household effects. Loss $10,000, partially insured.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- A great menace to the navigator is in a fair way or receiving attention. An international system of removing floating wrecks from the path of the sailing vessel and transatlantic steamer is under consideration at the State Department.

In spite of the fact that Edwin Hedley of the Passaic Boat Club was defeated on Saturday last in the senior singles at the Canadian championships, he is a big favorite for the event at the National regatta, to be held at Belle Isle, near Detroit, to-morrow and Thursday. Many of the oarsmen here believe that Byan, the 1892 champion, seeing that he could not defeat the fast rower from the Passaic.

Mary Meyer, the reputed wife and alleged Accomplice of Dr. Henry C.F. Meyer in the wholesale poisonings said to have been committed for the purpose of defrauding insurance companies, was taken to the bar of the Court of General Sessions yesterday and pleaded not guilty to the charge of murder on which she has been indicted.

Juliana Dannenbaum and her nephews, Joseph and Hermann Finkelbaum. sixteen and nineteen years old respectively, landed on Eilis Island last week. Joseph was found by the examining surgeon to be atilicted with favus, a contagious disease of the scalp. He was placed in the hospital, and was to have been returned it the surgeons found his case incurable. The other two were released.

The Board of Health, through the Sanitary Committee, of which Dr. Edson is Chairman, has not abrogated the "few-drops-of-whisky clause" in the board's "Directions." The board has, however, informed, the Summer corps of physicians that the advice to mothers to give a few drops of whisky in water, food, or milk to the children should only be followed in rare instances.

ZURICH, Aug. 7. -- At to-day a session of the International Socialist Congress there was a beated debate on the question whether Anarchistic and independent Socialists duly certified as delegates should be permitted to attend the congress. Finally a resolution was carried to admit delegates only from societies recognizing the necessity of the organization of labor concurrently with political action.

Russia's war ships in the Hudson River will not depart to-day. To a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES Post Captain R. Ducker, command- ing the ironclad Nicolal I., said yesterday that the fleet would probably sail to-morrow, having been detained by orders from St. Petersburg.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The House was not prepared to-day to ask the President to send in his message, but to-morrow the Committee of Notification, appointed by the Speaker this afternoon, will go to the White House, to announce the readiness of the House to hear from him, and it is probable that early in the day the message will be read in the Senate and the House of Representatives.

Currency in Wall Street yesterday was as scarce as ever, and the demand was perhaps heavier than on Saturday. One result of this condition of affairs was an increase in the premium paid for ready money, the rate going as high as 3 per cent. Last week the bulk of the business was done at from 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 per cent.

Frederick Wegner, the Brooklyn rat catcher, began his work in Central Park yesterday. He was engaged by the Park Commissioners for a period of three months to kill off the rate and moles that infest the Park, for which service he is to be paid $250.
This county ticket of the cold-water men for the coming election was constructed, after much difficulty, at the Prohibition Party Convention held in Cooper Union last evening.
Gen. Fitz John Porter was appointed cashier of the Post Office yesterday by Postmaster Dayton, to succeed Richard Van Cott. The salary is $2,600 and the bond $50,000.

Harry Richardson, who broke big neck while diving at Bath Beach Saturday afternoon, is still alive, but his death is only a question of a few days. He lies on a cot in the Homeopathic Hospital, Brooklyn. His wife and his nineteenyear-old son have been at his aide almost continuously since he was taken to the hospital Sunday morning.

The American liner New-York Drought more business for the customs officers than any other steamer had furnished in months. Col J.H. Storey, who used to be chief of the Surveyor's staff, was restored to his old duties a few days ago, and yesterday had the privilege of directing one of the biggest seizures of laces and embroideries ever made here.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- At noon to-day the Bowdoln Square Theatre property was disposed of by peremptory auction sale, by order of the mortgagees, at the Bowdoin Square entrance to the theatre. The property was first advertised for sale by the mortgagees. Woodbury Leighton, on Nov. 7 of last year, and snoe then the sale has been postponed thirteen times.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- The stock market was quiet all day, but closed lower. At the Clearing House this morning the situation was generally quiet. Money between the banks continues at same rate -- 7 3.10 to 8 p cent. -- but, as we are on a loan-certlfloate; basis, there is very little of the usual borrowing. The feature continues to be the demand for New-York funds.

The Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions in this city received yesterday a personal letter from Secretary of State Gresham, in which he pledged the Government to do all that is possible to compel the Porte to punish the perpetrators of the latest outrage upon an American missionary in Turkey.
Benjamin Spangberg, who had been an employe of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad since it was built, was killed yesterday morning at the curve at Fifty-third Street on the Sixth Avenue line.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 7. -- Lake Erie fishermen are hurling anathemas an the Federal powers and the tariff law, but persons familiar with the Facts of the case and the practices of the craft rejeice at the turn of affairs which has sent the United States revenue cutter Commodore Ferry to patrol the boundary and deal severely with lawless fishermen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- To meet the continually increasing demand, for national bank notes from banks which are taking advantage of the low rate of Government bonds and buying them and increasing their circulation, Secretary Carlisle has ordered the force of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing to work from 8 A.M. until 6 P.M. This is two hours over the usual time.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 7. -- The Essex County Club invitation tournament was started this afternoon on the club courts. All the cracks are here but Hovey and Larned. W.H. Taylor, the Pacific coast player, was invited to compete, but was unable to do so. This leaves the trophy open to Hobart, Wrenn, Malcolm Chace. C.F. Budlong, J.F. Talmage, Jr., and A.E. Foote.

The Amateur Athletic Union World's Fair Championship Games Committee held an important meeting at Treasurer Curtis's office yesterday. The following gentlemen were present: A.G. Spauiding, Chicago Athletic Association: H.S. Cornish, Chicago Athletic Association: W.B. Curtis. Treasurer Amateur Athletic Union; Julius Harder, and James E. Sullivan.

The bone of St. Anne, which Mgr. Marquis of Quebee brought from Rome, and which is the largest relic of the saint on this continent, will be placed to-day in the shrine with the two others in the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, East Seventy-sixth Street.
Mrs. Josephine Bell was examined in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on charges of assaulting Henry Maillard, the chocolate manufacturer, two weeks ago, and threatening to kill him.

Although William Brookfield, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and several other Republicans have come out very strongly against trying to make the present stringency in the money market a party issue, some other Republicans who are prominent in the local affairs of the party do not appear to take the same view of it.

District Attorney Ridgway made no attempt to stop the prize fight at Coney Island last night. George Dixon saved him the trouble. By a series of stiff right-handers he stopped the contest in the third round and, in the language of the prize ring, put his opponent, "Eddie" Pierce of the Fourth Ward, to "sleep" in the most approved style.
The only bids for bank stocks were 172 for Manhattan and 109 for Western National.
