George W. Gale, an old-time actor, died suddenly yesterday morning at his residence, 338 East Ninetieth Street, from a complication of diseases. Mr. Gale was born in London fiftyeight years ago. His father was George Burcher Gale, an aeronaut, who lost his life by a fall from his balloon. He first appeared in pantomimes at the Drury Lane Theatre in London, and came to this country while quite young.

Edward H. Sothern began his annual engagement at the Lyceum Theatre last evening, not at all too early, judging from the size and quality of his audience, though the dog days have just set in, and we might, with reason, suppose every body to be out of town. The assemblage was made up largely of New-Yorkers whose aces are familiar in the theatres.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 7. -- A large poster in a store window here causes much comment. It is a notice signed by Recruiting Officer Lieut Archer W. Yates, Second Lieutenant of the Ninth Infantry, having his office at Ogdensburg, N. Y., holding out strong inducements for recruits to join the United States Infantry and cavalry. A Conservative paper referring to the matter says:

The body at Baby Katle Grady, (not Brady,) who was drowned on Sunday night in the North River at the foot of One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, was found early yesterday in the water at the foot of West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street by Patroliean Stanton of the Thirtieth Precinot, who had been looking for it since daylight.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 7. -- Insurance Commissioner Linehan to-day presented his report covering the investigation into the affairs of the People's Fire Insurance Company. He finds that the par value of the assets Aug. 3, 1893, was $604,983, a deficit since Dec. 31, 1892, of $390,899. The liabilities. Including capital paid in, amount to $955,882.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- "ln Mizzoura," a new four-act play by Augustus Thomas, was produced by Nat C. Goodwill at Hooley's Theatre to-night. The play is founded on an express robbery which ocourred several years ago.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, Aug. 7-P. M. The stock market disappointed those who had expected it to break heavily in consequence of the bad showing made in the bank statement on Saturday. The opening was quiet and at the beginning traders were far apart in their ideas of what prices should be. Stock was not offered in large volume and transactions were few.

LIMA, Peru, July 12 -- This country is feeling most severely the depression of the mercantile interests of the United States. This is a silver country in the ultimate sense of the fact. All its banking is with England. A bill can be paid in New-York only by a draft on London; thus Peruvian merchants are at the mercy of the English house in all transactions where the national currency is concerned.

Lorenzo Moracio, twenty-nine years old, single, and a native of Angelo Regio, Italy, and a passenger on the steamship Karamania, was attacked mildly with diarrhea Saturday afternoon. He had previously passed the medical examination with the other passengers on the vessel, but Health Officer Jenkins ordered his immediate isolation.
The Democratic General Committee of Kings County met last evening in Jefferson Hall, Brooklyn, and adopted the following addition to Article XL of the Constitution of the Democratic organization:

A meeting of the Logan Club was held last night at its headquarters, Ludlow and Grand Streets. The Logan Club la interesting just now because it is the only "independent" political club in the Third Assembly District.
James Thornton, author of "My Sweetheart's the Man in the Moon," "Daddy Wouldn't Buy Me a Bow-Wow." and other songs current on the variety stage, was again arrested last night for intoxication.

There was enough of a chill in the air last night, when encountered on top of the tall theatres, to make a few of the more timid roof-gardeners wonder if it wasn't almost cold. So a coat collar or two was turned up, and the horticulturists gave orders for substances that were calculated to produce heat rather than its contrary.

The only auction sale of real estate announced for yesterday at the salesroom in the Trinity Building was adjourned to Thursday. It is in foreclosure proceedings, and affects thirteen tenement houses on Tenth Avenue, Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets. Two sales are on the list for to day at the salesroom and one by the Sheriff at the City Hall as follows:
The twelve spots which on Sunday were discovered on the face of the sun were very much plainer yesterday.

A circular sent to Police Headquarters offers $100 reward for information which will restore George M. Brinkerhoff of Springfield, Ill., to his family, He was last seen on an Illinois Central Railroad train which left Chicago at 9 P. M. on July 28.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 7. -- The Herald's London correspondent states in a cable dispatch that it may be said with safety that, should the Vakyrie not win the America's Cup this year, there will likely be a challenge for it in 1894. The correspondent continues: "On most reliable authority the statement is made that an order has been placed with Designer Watson for a ninety-footer, and the Scotch.
The following extract from a letter written by a well-known London banker, under date of July 29, to a New-York banking house is interesting :

Weakfish are plentiful both in the lower and upper bays. It not unfrequently Happens that anglers return not only with their baskets full but burdened with strings of fish besides. Parties daily set out from Lindquist's, at Bayonne, and at Prince's Bay and report ample returns. Great South Bar also affords excellent sports Two gentlemen fishing off Point Lookout on Sunday returned with their beat well ballasted.

George Sharrott a left-handed youth from Staten Island, now a member of the Brooklyn Club, asked as a special favor to be allowed the privilege of pitching against the New-Yorks at Eastern Park yesterday. "Just give me a chance," he said, "and I'll mow those big Giants down like grass before a soythe." President Byrne was favorably impressed with the confidence of the youth and put his name on the score card.

A private meeting of the heads of most of the city departments was held yesterday in the Mayor's office to discuss the sanitary condition of the city and the need for protection against cholera. There were present Mayor Gilroy, Dr. Jenkins, Health Officer of the Port; President Wilson of the Board of Health, Health Commissioner Edson Commissioner of Public Works Daly, Corporation Counsel Clark, Street Cleaning Commissioner Andrews.

The Tribune publishes an interview with F. A. YEAGER of Pittsburg, "manufacturer and consulting engineer," who would like to have people believe that the prevailing stringency has been, caused in some way by the promise of the Democratic Party to revise the tariff. " There is no question about it," he says.

The verdict in Paris against the editor of a blackguard newspaper and an obscure mulatto is of interest, inasmuch as it sheds some additional lustre on the character of the Parisian press in general, fully as that character has been illustrated by the revelations of the Panama inquiry. It also and indirectly illuminates the character of the Parisian populace.

CINCINATI, Ohio, Aug. 7. -- The advance guard of the State Democracy was arriving on all trains to-night, and by to-morrow evening most of the delegations will be on the ground. This is the first State Convention held in Cincinnati since 1876, and elaborate preparations have been made for the event. It will be held in Music Hall, the scene of the National Democratic Convention of 1880.

James Carton, a laborer living at 432 West Seventeenth street, was charged in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with causing the death of Eugene Walsh, a young laborer of 91 Tenth Avenue, Sunday morning, and was remanded until to-day.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Rev. Albert Von Schilgen, pastor of St. Michael's Catholic Church, is at war with the Young Men's Society of his parish. He has threatened from the altar to excommunicate the members if they do not abandon a picnic which they intend having against his wishes.

Major John B. Powell and Lawyer James A. Hurst, who had a set-to in the corridor of the St. James Hotel last Thursday, have, through the Kindly offices of their respective lawyers. John Easton and Stephen C. Baldwin, declared a truce and will adjust their difficulties in a civil court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The topic of chief interest in Washington to-night is the proposition of W. Bourke Cockran of New-York regarding the silver question, which was referred to in the dispatches to THE NEW-YORK TIMES last night.

ROME, Aug. 7. -- The Pope gave audience today to Mgr. Earliest of Baltimore, with whom he conversed for a long time on the extension of the Catholic Church in the United States. Mgr. Bartlett presented to the Pope a list of American converts.

While workmen were excavating for the repair of a leaky gas pipe in the grass plot between the Register's Office and the Court of General Sessions in the City Hall Park last Friday they exhumed three human skeletons which had evidently been in the ground more than a hundred years. Two of them were remains of adults and the other that of a youth.

WOODSBURG, L. I., Aug. 7. -- Police Sergeant Lancer of New-York and his family are spending the Bummer in a cottage at Woodsburg. On the grounds there is an old well, from which the children delight to draw water.
The members of the Central Council of the Irish Independent Party gave a dinner last night to Edward G'Flaherty, the Chairman of the council, at Jaeger's, Madison Avenae and Fifty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Long before the time for calling the House to order the floor of the Hall of Representatives was crowded, as usual, with members and their friends, who repeated, with few variations from the scenes of former Congresses, the handshakings, the renewal of acquaintances, the cordial greetings, and the exchanges of information upon subjects interesting to the individuals from different sections of the country.

The City of Churches abounds in tennis clubs and tennis players, and among the most prominent of the strictly tennis organizations is the Brooklyn Tennis Club, whoso courts are on Pulaski Street, near Throop Avenue. Its players have won numerous honors on local courts, and its representatives have always been considered formidable at the annual interclub tournaments for the championship of Kings County.

Two fishermen, who formed part of a crew of a little French smack, yesterday reached this port on board the Allan-State Line steamship State of California. They became separated from the smack in a fog, drifted for seventy hours in a dory, and were almost mad from exhaustion and thirst when rescued by the Glasgow liner.

A meeting of the Directors of the Union Pacine R Railroad will be held in this city to-day, and important questions of finance are expected to come up for consideration. There hag been considerable talk recently and some uneasiness in financial circles about the future of the Union pracitic. Men prominently interested in the management declared yesterday that there was no danger of any break in the financial stability of the company.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 7. -- Connecticut people are awaiting with unusual interest the announcement of the composition of at least one committee in the House of Representatives the coming week.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 7. -- A funeral train was thrown into the wildest kind of disorder yesterday afternoon by a nest of hornets.

The flag on the Kings Couaty Court Honse was at half mast yesterday through respect to Capt James A. Duffy, head of the court officers of the Court of Sessions, who died on Sunday of preumonia at his home, Front and Main Streets, Brooklyn.
Special Chinese Inspector J. Thomas Scharf has issued a reply to the criticism of his course by ex-Collector Hendricks. Mr. Scharf's discourse is vigorously worded. He begins it by saying:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Before and after the meeting of the Senate to-day there was a general discussion by the members of the subject of the repeal of the purchase clause of the Sherman law. It was soon discovered that Senators who had been reckoned as advocates of free coinage were now either wavering or outspoken for the repeal.

While the patients on the fifth floor of the Skin and Cancer Hospital, at 243 East Thirty-fourth Street, were wondering how soon dinner would be along at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a big balloon came crashing through the skylight.

The 250 passengers on the club steamer Taurus had a delightful sail up the East River and a very pleasant day's outing on the Sound, but they did not see much of the race. There was plenty of room on the boat and everybody on board was able to get a good and unobstructed view of the fleet, but when the yachts were flytug in the strong wind the Taurus oould not keep up.

Commissioner ANDREWS of the StreetCleaning Department has been credited with the expression of some doubt as to the practicability or the desirability of carrying out the "block system" of street sweeping. This doubt, if it exists, must be due to a lack of sufficient funds for doing the work of the department fully under that system during the rest of the year.

Adam Wollanter, a German peddler of watches and jewelry, was drugged in April, 1890. in a saloon kept in Bond Street by "Fatty" Flynn, and when he recovered consciousness he found himself at Broadway and Bleecker Street. His satchel, containing watches and jewelry, and his money were gone.

Ormonde, the "horse of the centnry," stepped on to American soil at sundown last evening. The unbeaten son of Bend Or and Lily Agnes made his third ocean voyage on the freight steamer Massa-chusetts. The Massachusetts left the Royal Albert Docks, London, England, on Friday, July 28. Fog during two days delayed the crack freighter fully twenty-four hours beyond her usual time. Beyond that, Capt. John F. Gates says the voyage was devoid of incident.
LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The markets displayed holiday dullness to day and such fluctuations as took place were the result of small transactions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- An enormous number of bills was damped into the Senate mill to-day, where the majority of them will lie, as it is understood that there will be precious little grinding done until the silver repeal question is disposed of.

If there was one thing more than another which Henry Ward Beecher enjoyed in the services of old Plymouth Church it was the congregational singing. So great was the delight which he took In the musical feature of the divine services that he spent many years in collecting and compiling the hymns which for more than forty years have been printed in "The Plymouth Hymn Book."

Mr. and Mrs. Horace B. Dunbar will go East about the middle of the month. They contemplate a yachting trip to Newfoundland as soon as Mrs. Dunbar feels equal to the fatigue of the journey. They are in receipt of the following letter of condolence:

CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 -- Large numbers of delegates to the State Democratic Convention have been arriving to-day and to-night. Mr. Neal will be here early in the morning to take personal charge of his canvass. He will also be the leading speaker at to-morrow night's mass meeting.

John C. Leahey, a wealthy real estate owner and builder, was found dead on the doorstep of his boarding house, 771 North Second Street, Williamsburg, yesterday morning, and it is believed he was murdered by sandbaggers.

In the course of a conversation had with a representative of THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday a solid citizen of Brooklyn, who is intensely disgusted over the fact that Kings County has come to be known as a "Paradise of Prize Fighters," said in reference to the recent prize fight at Coney Island:

In the salesroom at 111 Broadway yesterday Mr. William Kennelly sold under foreclosure, for $5,000, to Charles Brook, the plaintiff in the proceedings, the three-story brick dwelling on the East side of Hamilton Place, 22.10 1/2 feet fonth of West One Hundred, and Forty-second Street, 15.9 by 55.78 by 14.6 by 48.8 3/4.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 8 -- The trial of Mrs. Mattie C. Shann, indicted for murdering her twenty-year-old son, John F. Shann, by administering poison at their home in Princeton, April 18, in order to secure $2,000 insurance, was begun this forenoon.

NEW-YORK. TUESDAY, Aug. 8 -- P.M. The market was dull during the morning, operators professing au indisposition to do anything pending the publication of President Cleveland's message to Congress. But when the message reached the Street the increased activity was not sufficiently marked to justify the assertion that it had made any decided change in the situation.

From the London Daily News. This is how the Pandit Indravarma Saraswati describes "The Oriental Weather in England in the Year of Centuries, 1893," (the title of his contribution to the Asiatic Quarterly Review:)
RICE LAKE, Wis., Aug. 8. -- The Barren County Bank has assigned. The liabilities are $20,000, the assets five times that amount.

The Produce Exchange markets were only moderately active and prices show a decline of 1 1/8@1 3/8c on wheat and 3/4@1 1/8c on corn. The principal influences to the decline were lower cables, realizing here and at the West, large shipments from India, and an unfavorable view taken of the President's message. Shippers bought rather freely of spot wheat at the decline.

Just before the close of business on the Stock Exchange yesterday came news of the failure of Horace L. Hotchkiss Co., bankers and brokers of 36 Wall Street, who suspended and made an assignment to Waldron Williams, a dealer in lumber. They gave preferences aggregating $22,306 for money on deposit in favor of the following:

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 8 -- The inquest on the body of John Chew, who was killed at Monmouth Park Saturday night, was held by Coroner Van Dyke to-day. Prosecuting Attorney Ivans appeared for the State, and Howe Hummel of New-York represented "Snip" Donovan.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8. -- The conduct of Mackenzie Boweli, acting leader of the Canadian Government, in moving a resolution condemning Gladstone's Home Rule bill at the recent meeting of the Grand Orange Lodge or Canada may cause a split in the Dominion Ministry and a political crisis.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 8 -- The Women's Republican Clubs and the Populist Progressive Leagues, the latter being the women's organization formed within that party, have defined their positions and issued their challenge to the men of the State, or to such of them as dare oppose either Prohibition or Woman Suffrage.

HOTCHINSON, Kan., Aug. 8. -- The National Bank of Hutchinson reopened its doors yesterday after two weeks' suspension. The bank is said to be on a solid basis. It succumbed temporarily on account of its inability to meet large unexpected demands.
If the Democrats of Ohio nominate LAWRENCE T. NEAL, for Governor they should make him stand on his own platform.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau says: Drought has been relieved in the Carolinas, where crops have been greatly improved, although the rains came too late for early corn. Drought conditions are now central in the central valleys. Northwestern States, and in portions of the Middle Atlantic States and lake region, and its effects are reported as more or less damaging in Illinois.

Dade -- Sprague. Miss Josephine Worth Sprague was married at the Episcopal Church of St. John, Clifton, S.I., at 5 o'clock yesterday, to Lieut. Alexander Lucien Dade of the Tenth United States Cavalry.

Vice President Stevenson passed East last Thursday en route from the Pacific coast. He said to a St. Paul reporter: "Our trip was most enjoyable, through a new country on a new road -- the Great Northern -- which I consider one of the most remarkable lines in America -- new in construction, but perfect in accommodations, equipment, and management.

Mrs. John Dorick of 147 Columbia Street, Brooklyn, died in St. Peters's Hospital Friday morning of abscesses. She had been ill a long time, but her physicians were unable to determine the nature of her disease. Her husband secured her admission to the hospital a week ago.

MANCHESTER. Mass., Aug. 8. -- Hobart and Chace are in the lead for the Essex County Club trophy, each having finished to-day's matches without a defeat. Of the two Hobart is at present ahead, with three victories and no defeats to two victories and no defeats for Chace. This morning wrenu and Chace appeared to decide their unfinished match of yesterday.

The money market was quiet. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 2@6 P cent. The last loan was made at 2 P cent. Time money was unchanged. The demand continued urgent, but few transactions were made. The nominal rate was 6 P cent, to which was added a commission of from 2@5 P cent.

It would require more ingenuity than the District Attorney of Kings County can fairly be credited with to explain in what way the brutal prize fight at Coney Island on Monday evening differs from the prize fight which is forbidden by law. Certainly it presented every characteristic that impelled the representatives of a decently-civilized community to enact the law against prize fighting.

Lawyer Clarence Birdseye said, during an argument on Wednesday, Aug. 2, before Justice O'Brien of the Supreme Court: "Russell B. Harrison comes into this court and presumes to speak for a company with which his connection is questionable. I think it is somewhat peculiar."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Promptly at 12 to-day the House was called to order and listened to prayer by the new Chaplain, who at once established a reputation for brevity that he will find it agreeable to cultivate. The floor was well occupied, the attendance of members being almost as large as it was yesterday, but the galleries were so sparsely filled as to indicate a moderation of interest in the new House.

In spite of the fact that she arrived from the suspected ports of Naples and Marseilles, the steamship Massllia, which reached New-York yesterday morning with 316 steerage passengers aboard, brought no more serious sickness with her than a silent case of measles, the sufferer being a little child. Dr. Jenkins, who had the Massllia detained in Quarantine and who made a most careful examination of her, was delighted with the healthful condition of her passengers.
MORRIS COVE, Conn., Aug. 8. -- It has been a day of doldrums for the yaohts. The wind all the morning was up and down the mast and the yachts just drifted with the tide on the Sound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- If any one supposed that partisanship was to be eliminated from the discussion of the silver question in the Senate to-day's proceedings show the fallacy of any such belief. The cheapest kind of "peanut politics" was injected into the discussion to-day by Republican Senators, and, although the inwardness of their attempt was not thoroughly expressed.
The racing at Clifton yesterday was good and the betting on each event brisk. Two favorite and three well-backed second choices won.

The officers and managers of railroads are showing a commendable consideration for the workmen in the service of the companies, as well as for their own interests, in their manner of effecting a necessary reduction of expenses. So far as practicable they bring the labor force down to the requirements of their business by shortening hours instead of discharging men.

The Russian squadron selected for service in the Mediterranean is announced as ready to leave Cronstadt at once. The vessels select ed are to remain in the Mediterranean the next twelve months, during which period all arrangements, it is stated, are to be made for the permanent presence of a Russian squadron in Mediterranean waters.

Next to winning the championship, the New-York patrons or baseball want to see the Giants finish ahead of Brooklyn in the League race. Early in the season, when the New-Yorks wore losing name after game, and Brooklyn was up near the leaders, the joy of the cranks across the bridge was unbounded, while the enthusiasts in this city were almost suffering from aberration of mind.

NEWARK, N.J., Ang. 8 -- Ex-Alderman Coyle of Harrison was to-day committed for trial on a charge of attempted highway robbery. Last night he met Alderman Wade in a saloon and the latter displayed a roll of greenbacks. The two men started for their homes together.

BREWSTER, Aug. 8. -- Mayor Gilroy, Health Commmissioner Edson, Commissioner of Public Works Daly, and Engineer Birdsall came up from New-York to-day to look Into the merits of Col. Albert E. Woolf's system of purifying water, an account of which was recently printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES. The party was accompanied by Dr. Benjamin Lee of the Board of Health of Pennsylvania and Peter Hogan,. the Civil Engineer.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 8. -- President Ferdinand Schleisinger of the Chapin Mining Company and the head of the Schleisinger mining syndicate, will tender his resignation within three days, to take effect at once.

Herbert E. Dickson, receiver of rents and referee for the Bale of realty belonging to the estate of Abner Mellen, Sr., was removed from both positions because it wan alleged there was a deficiency of $28,800 in his accounts. The facts came out in the partition suit brought by Sarah E. Mellen against Abner Mellen, Maria L. Kendall, and William C. Bannix, heirs to the estate of Abner Mellen, Sr., now pending before Judge O'Brlen.

Wall Street paid more attention yesterday to the President's message than it did to the currency premium, the gold imports, or the failure of one of the houses best known on the Stock Exchange. All of these things were, however, of a character to cause a good deal of a stir in ordinary times.
The Rev. Herman P. Faust of the Hebrew Christian Mission at 128 Forsyth Street says that the United Hebrew Charities often refuses to give aid where it is plainly needed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Following is the message of President Cleveland on the financial situation, read in both houses of Congress to-day. The document was received throughout the country as a harbinger of better times, and sound money men everywhere regard it as an able exposition of the causes which have led to the present financial depression.

QUEBEC, Aug. 8 -- The Italian bark Columbus from River Saguenay, laden with lumber, was struck by the steamsnip Orenholme off Cape Rosier on the 6th inst. She went to the bottom in a few minutes after the collision. The crew was brought to this city by the Oxenholmo.

Edward Meredith, who shot at Philip Daly, the gambler, in the parlor of a flat at the corner of Twenty-eighth Street and Fourth Avenue on the afternoon of Dec. 3, 1888, and who was sentenced on Dec. 20 of the same year by Judge Martine to eight years and ten months in Sing Sing, will appear before Judge Barnard in the Supreme Court, Poughkeepsie, this morning, on a writ of habeas corpus.

Within the last week the great Summer snowstorm has burst upon the South, and fields that before were green are now white as an arotic valley in January. Over an area three times as large as Massachusetts, half as large as the State of New-York, covering more than 15,000,000 acres, the cotton bolls have opened, and the creamy-white fibre has come forth to make a spotless mantle for the plants and the fields.

Don Estanislao S. Zeballos, the new Minister from, the Argentine Republic to the United States, who is due to-morrow on the Spree, takes the place of a much older man, Don Calvo, who died after his appointment as Envoy Plenipotentiary to Washington, especially intrusted with the conduct of the case of Argentina against Brazil before President Cleveland.

CONEY ISLAND, L. I, Aug. 8. -- Jennie Mathers, sixteen years old, who lives at 10 Richard Street, South Brooklyn, and works at 120 Fulton Street, was arrested last night on suspicion, as she was considered too young to be alone on the Island. She came down Sunday with a bundle of clothing and hired a room for a week at a cheap hotel.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 8 -- New-Orleans had a mild touch of the panic to-day. The Police Board and a large mercantile institution paid off employes yesterday in checks on the Germania National Bank. Many of the men happened to fro to the bank to-day in a bunch and several letter carriers seeing them emerge with rolls of bills, came to the conclusion that the hank was shaky.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- Wheat slumped 2c a bushel to-day, but recovered 3/8c of the loss. Corn closed 7/8c lower than last night. Disquieting, but apparently baseless, rumors of more financial troubles locally were chiefly responsible. In addition the trade was hoping the massage would contain some suggestion of moans to immediately relieve the present congestion pending the deliberate discussion of a permanent remedy.

Bishop John P. Newman of Omaha is in this city having just returned from an official visit to South America, where he made the annual examination into the condition of the missions carried on there by the Methodist Episcopal Church.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 8 -- While the Board of Lady Managers of the World's Fair was in the midst of a spirited wrangle this afternoon, a delegation of women from the Midway Plaisance walked in. To these women had been extended a special invitation to visit the Women's Building and the meeting of the board that they might be benefited by the society of civilized women and see what wonders their civilized sisters had performed.

The President's message to Congress was received with much favor in Wall Street and among business men. Men prominent in the financial world spoke in commendation of it, and expressed the hope that it would result in action by Congress that should have a beneficial effect on the financial situation. Following are some of the commendatory things said about the message:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Jeremiah Ford of 513 Park Avenue, Hoboken, reported at Police Headquarters in that city to-day that his brother. Martin Ford, a longshoreman, thirtynine years old, had died suddenly from cramps at his home yesterday afternoon. He said his brother had been living at 119 Charlton Street, New-York, where he became ill yesterday morning.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 8. -- The court-martial now in session for the trial of Col. Hughes of the Kansas National Guard for disobedience of orders and giving information to the enemy is still taking testimony.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- The stock market opened dull and heavy, Boston and Maine being especially weak. It was quiet at the close, but generally lower. At the Clearing House money between banks loaned at 7 3-10 and 8 P cent., with possibly a larger amount at 8 P cent., as compared with yesterday; nevertheless, transactions, except on a loan certificate basis, are apparently growing smaller.

Daniel Magone of Ogdensburg member of the Customs Investigating Committee, appeared at 8 o'clock yesterday morning at the Barge Office ready to go ahead with the investigation of the Surveyor's office. In course of time Poindexter Dunn and Wallace Macfarlano also appeared, and after another wait S.M. Blatchford arrived.

Harry Phillips, twenty-seven years old, of 422 Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was arrsigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday for threatening to shoot His mother, but, as she declined to make a complaint in court, he was released.

RED BANK. N.J., Aug. 8. -- A race was nailed here to-day for the challenge pennant of the North Shrewsbury River. The ten-mile coarse was sailed and Frank James's Pauline won, beating Warren Silcock's Dolphin about 4 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The caucus or conference that is to be held to-morrow is one of "the friends of silver," and all who think that free coinage of the white metal is the cure for the present doubt and distrust are to be made welcome to it. It is impossible to tell now just how many members will attend it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Comment on the message is as various as it might be expected to be. To the large proportion of members who have made up their minds that repeal of the Sherman silver-purchase authority is imperative, it is satisfactory, although to some of them who are naturally inclined to adhere to old predilections in favor of tree coinage it is considered regrettable that there is no suggestion about bimetallism.

LONDON. Aug. 8. -- Mr. Gladstone announced in the House of Commons to-day that the Government Intended to hold an Autumn session of Parliament. The announcement was received with loud cheering by the supporters of the Government.

Play on the tennis courts of the Nyack Country Club was continued yesterday afternoon, and the matches were more interesting than on Monday, as the poorer players bad fallen by the wayside. In the singles Ludlow did the best work of the day. beating E.Thayer and Davis with apparent ease. This leaves Ludlow, who has reached the finals, to play the winner of the Holt-Palmer match, and the critics expect Palmer to be the man.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- For $1,000 Robert Hicks, connected with the Siamese exhibit at the World's Fair, was willing to maim his left hand; for $7,500 he was willing to lose it, and for $20,000 he stood ready to take his life. Accident insurance companies were to pay this money to Mr. Hicks -- or to his mother -- in case he succeeded in carrying one or another of his plans into effect.

The St. Nicholas Bank yesterday sent out a circular throwing out paper drawn on the Madison Square Bank of 202 Fifth Avenue. After investigation the Clearing House Committee refused to make any formal statement for publication, but a member of the committee stated unofficially tnat the capital of the Madison Square Bank had been impaired to the extent of nearly $90,000, and that in all probability the bank would not be open for business to-day.

SARATOGA, Aug. 8. -- A day of almost ceaseless rain was ushered in yesterday morning with a single clap of thunder at 6 o'clock that roused every sleeper in the village and startled those who were already awake. All the artillery of the storm, however, was expended in this single blast, and tne rain fell till sunset to the unbroken rhythm of its own music.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Matters took a livelier turn at the Grand Circuit meeting this afternoon and favorites were defeated in the first two events, both of which were well contested. Eltrida, the speedy filly from the South that had given Fantasy such a good race at Pittsburg last month, was a pronounced favorite among the three-year-olds, but was not up to her old form and sot distanced in the third heat.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 8 -- Excessive cigarette smoking caused what is known as "tobacco heart" in Charles S. Seholt, the Astoria representative of the Long Island Star. He was found dead in bed at his home in Jamaica Avenue, Astoria, this morning.

The value of our exports of lard, bacon, and other hog products in the year ending on June 30 was more than $84,000,000. On Aug. 1 there was a great and sudden fall of prices in the homo markets, caused by the failure of certain speculators in Chicago who had been maintaining a "corner" in pork and lard.

The President's message was delivered to the evening papers shortly before noon yesterday with the statement from P.V. De Graw, general Southern manager, that it was furnished in advance under pledge that no part of it would be published until the release was given by Mr. De Graw, the moment the message should reach Congress.
The following official announcement was made yesterday:

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 -- Harry Mackey, son of Willlam Mackey, one of the wealthiest lumbermen of the Ottawa Valley, gave notice to-day that he would make application, at the next sesaion of the Dominion Senate for a divorce from his wire, who was Laura Estelle Stall of New-York. They were married about a year ago but lived together only a few months.
The friends of the Rev. Dr. McGlynn held a picnic and festival yesterday in Washington Park, Sixty-ninth Street and Avenue A, and fully 2,000 people gathered to-Iisten to an address by him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8. -- The Catholics of this dio-ese to-day celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of the priestly labors of Bishop John A. Watterson. Among the letters of sincere regret was one from Henry Watterson, who explained privately to the Bishop why he could not be present.

ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 9. -- Nathaniel Poyntz, the President of the First National Bank, recently suspended. Cashier James L. Glles, and Director J.B. Parramore have been arrested on a charge of fraud. President Poyntz, in the custody of a United States Marshal, was taken to Jacksonville to-day, and on examination was held to appear at the next term of the United States court.

When Leader James W. Boyle of the Tammany organization of the Ninth Assembly District looked out of the windows of the club-house on West Ablagdon Square last night at 9 o'clock he was happy. A while ago the new loader induced the Park Board to have a band of music play in Ablngdon Square for the benefit of the west siders every Wednesday evening.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The agents of the Pemberton Cotton Mills sent out notice this morning stating that owing to the extreme difficulty in obtaining currency with which to pay their employes weekly, according to law, the mill will close Saturday noon, Aug. 12, for three weeks. The corporation employs 710 operatives, its annual pay roll amounts to $275,000, and its annual cloth production is 10,000,000 yards.

A jolly mariner stood on the deck of the steamship El Rio yesterday and told guileless reporters a story about whales. The narrator of the yarn is mate or the vessel. He is too modest to have his name mentioned, at least he said he was, and so requested.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 9 -- Gov. Osborne has decided not to appoint any one to the Senatorship made vacant by the resignation of A. C. Beckwith until the Senate shall have decided the question whether or not a Senator appointed after the failure of the State Legislature to elect is entitled to a seat.

More gola imports received, more engagements of the yellow metal reported from London, a demand for currency which Kept up the premium ready money has commanded for several days, a stock market which first declined and then rallied sharply, and news that the city banks were advancing the rate on loans to their country correspondents were features of yesterday in Wall Street.

A meeting of cordage manufacturers, designed to produce harmony in the trade, was held in the office of the John Good Company, Broad and Beaver Streets, yesterday. The National Cordage Company, generally known as the trust, was not represented. It has not, however, taken an attitude of hostility to the movement.

The drivers and sweepers of the Street-Cleaning Department of tills city were not paid their wages yesterday, and they felt disappointed, as it was the first pay day under the administration of Commissioner Andrews.

The latest official report estimates that there are about fifty abandoned hulks floating on the Atlantic and perilous to navigation. Most of them are on the sailing route to and from the equator, but sometimes such wrecks are found drifting across or along the passenger steamer lanes to Europe.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- There were large crowds at the fair to-day, attracted by the many events of interest planned for the pleasure of visitors. The Virginia Day exercises attracted the sons and daughters of the State which has given the country so many Presidents. Knights of Pythias flocked Into the grounds from an early hour, and the disciples of Izaak Walton threw their lines into every pond of water in the grounds.
Depositors who Burried yesterday morning to the Madison Square Bank to ascertain how safe their deposits were found the doors closed and the following notice posted on each entrance:

Even in these times of shrinking capital and suppressed enterprise we continue to get reports of the starting of new cotton mills in North Carolina and other Southern States. A factory in which $200,000 has been invested is just completed at Lexington, N.C., and we are told that the operatives will be drawn mostly from the native population of the surrounding country, and the output will consist entirely of ginghams.
The troubles of the former President and Directors of the National Cordage Company, the failure of which created a small panic last May, are by no means at an end.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The Faculty of Arts and Sciences of Harvard University -- the Faculty which has charge of the college, the Scientific School, and the Graduate School -- has issued its announcement of courses of instruction for next year. The chances in the courses as a whole show the constantly strengthening tendency toward greater specialization and toward a study which covers more and more minutely the whole Held of Knowledge.

A brindled pup of the bull variety occupied Cell 7 in the Church Street Police Station last night. Why he was there was all a deep, dark, impenetrable mystery to the canine prisoner. The more he puzzled over it the more inscrutable it became.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- Earl Spencer, First Lard of the Admiralty, gave a dinner this evening in honor of Admiral Erben and Capt. Mahan of the United States cruiser Chicago, which is now at Southampton. The dinner was given at Spencer House, St. James's Place, the Earl's London residence.
LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 9 -- The session of the Queens County Board of Supervisors here this afternoon closed with a heated debate.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 9 -- A smile of grim satisfaction played over Police Justice Hotfield's features here to-day as he sentenced Laundryman Sam Wing to pay a fine of $20 and costs or go to jail for sixty days for attempting to kiss Miss Ella Cronk in the public street. The Asiatic protested his innocence, but the Justice shouted:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 9. -- An informal meeting of representatives of Republican League clubs of Hudson County was held at the Union League Clubhouse in this city last night to discuss the Shrievalty nomination. There was a division of opinion, some being in favor of a straight-out nomination, with Col. John J. Totfey as the candidate, while others advised an independent nomination at a citizens' convention.

BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- The annual report of the Boston and Albany Railroad shows the balance carried to the credit of profit and loss, after paying all charges, to be $28,885, mating a total credit of $151,114,97.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 9 -- The feature of the day in the Gubernatorial fight was the conference of the Campbell faction, which decided to centre on Charles W. Baker of Cincinnati for the time being. The meeting was very bitter against Neal. The action was taken only as a plan to rally so as to throw the combined strength to Campbell.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- While the announcement that the committees of the House will be completed Monday next is not verified by the immediate friends of the Speaker, it is believed that the list, or a part of it, will be made out speedily, and that the discussion of the silver question will scarcely be under way by common Agreement before the usual machinery for the consideration and report of bills Trill be ready.

By a series of misplays and a combination of errors at the wrong time the New-Yorks dropped a game in Brooklyn yesterday to Manager Foutz's men. It was a close contest and this is the only thing that can be said in its favor.

BAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 9. -- The through traffic on the Southern Pacific Boad between this city and Ban Francisco has been resamed. after several days' interruption caused by washouts in Arizona and Western Texas.

Rear Admiral T.A. Jenkins. Rear Admiral Thornton A. Jenkins, one of Farragut's most efficient officers in the naval campaign in the Gulf of Mexico in the war of the rebellion, died yesterday in Washington, of heart failure. He was eighty-one years old.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. William Macartney (Conservative) moved the adoption of an amendment to the Home Rule bill providing, in effect, that the Irish members who shall be retained in the imperial Parliament shall vote on no bill, motion, or amendment except motions that may be made amendatory of the Home Rule bill.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The lantern parade and lawn party of the Montclair Wheelmen this evening in celebration of their first anniversary will rank as the most successful entertainment of its kind that has yet been given in New-Jersey.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 9. -- As was announced after yesterday's session of the Grand Jury, indictments against policy gamblers will shortly be reported. Whenever that may happen, the character of the evidence will, of course, be disclosed. There is good reason for saying that this evidence will illumine for campaign purposes the subject of official protection of crime in Hudson County.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug 9. -- Two homely-looking white sloops were at anchor in New-London Harbor, right off the Pequot House, when the squadron of the New-York Yacht Club sailed in. Both attracted considerable attention from every yachtsman in the fleet.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- In trying to save her little sister from drowning, Miss Anna Thurston, seventeen years old, lost her life this morning in Huntington Harbor.

PANAMA, Aug. 9. -- The report that a number of arrests had been made at Barranquilla and Carthagena of men alleged to have been implicated in a conspiracy to blow up the cuartels in those places with dynamite is generally doubted here. According to the report, the plan of the conspirators was to release the prisoners, who, it was supposed, would aid them in a revolutionary movement.

The investigation of the New-York Juvenile Guardian Society by the State Board of Charities was begun at the office of William R. Stewart, 54 William Street, yesterday morning. The committee which conducted the examination on behalf of the board was made up of Oscar Craig, President; Dr. Stephen Smith, member from New-York, and Edward H. Litchfield, member from Brooklyn.

While three painters were working on a swinging scaffold at the sixth floor of 55 South Street, shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday meming, a rotten guy rope parted and they were plunged to the ground. All the men received serious injuries, which may prove fatal.

A woman was killed and another woman and a baby were injured in a fire yesterday afternoon that partially destroyed the three-story brick dwelling at 62 Bank Street. The circumstances that led to the fire and the manner of the woman's death are probably without parallel.
BIG STONE GAP, Va., Aug. 9. -- The Big Stone Gap Bank has suspended. It is believed depositors will be paid in full.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The second day of the tennis tournament has been favored by good weather. The playing was excellent throughout, and some fine tennis was seen. Andorson gave Wright a hard fight in the finals of the singles, but was finally defeated. 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4. To-morrow he will contest for second honors against Dean Miller.

Three black boys and one white boy, all four of whom are about as bad as boys are made, were arraigned before Justice Welde, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, and charged with arson. The complainant was Superintendens Lowry of the House of Refuge on Randall's Island. The boys were held for trial in default of $1,000 bail each, and probably will pass the rest of the years of their minority at Elmira.

Monmonth Park will carry out its announced intention of racing until the 24th at August The township of Eatontown, which granted it a license, for which the Monmouth Park Association refuses to pay the five-thonsand-dollar fee demanded, will have nothing more to say about the matter. Chief Jastlce Beasley of the Supreme Court of New-Jersey decided that matter yesterday.

LEBANON, Penn., Aug. 9. -- Robert H. Coleman, iron ore millionaire, has executed a deed of assignment to his brother-in-law, Archibald Rogers, of Hyde Park, N.Y., and Henry T. Kendall of Reading, Penn., Vice President of the Pennsylvania Trust Company, both of whom have for over a year been managing his estate.

The Customs Investigating Committee continued its work through many hot, tedious hours yesterday, and thrashed out a little wheat from a big pile of chaff. As usual, the three Commissioners sat in a row behind the table, appearing to some of the witnesses as terrible as the three Judges of the classic internal regions.

TORONTO, Aug. 9 -- Jacob Lewis of the United States Secret Service is making Toronto his headquarters at present. His mission to Canada is to locate a well-organized gang of smugglers, who for atleast a year have been evading the United States customs officials, sending in large quantities of opium and jewelry.

BUFFALO, Aug. 9. -- With another perfect day for The Grand Circuit cracks, there was some capital sport at the driving park. The meeting of the four fast three-year-olds in the first event helped the attendance, but it was the least exciting contest of the afternoon. Silicon, the best two-year-old out last season, was a complete disappointment, and the Buffalo filly.

BUFFALO, Aug. 9. -- The Congress of the Disciples of gentle old Izaak Walton began at Niagara-on-the-Lake to-day. No better spot could have been selected for the meeting In the eddies of the Niagara River just where it flows into Lake Ontario, there are bigger black bass and better fishing than anywhere in this part of the State.

MELBOURNE, Victoria, July 29. -- If an American over here complains of the heavy duties that exclude most of our goods from this market -- though we are treated quite as well as is England -- the Australian replies:

Theodore Moss, Secretary of the Board or Electrical Control and theatre proprietor, was ordered yesterday by Judge Freedmap, in the Superior Court, to produce in court on Monday his two grandsons. Randall and Beverly Keator, aged five and two years respectively. Habeas corpus proceedings were brought by their father, Thomas R. Keator, a banker and broker, whose place of business was until lately at 80 Broadway.

John H. Meister, proprietor of the New-England Bakery, at Henry and Sackett Streets, Brooklyn, murdered his wife Meta by shooting her in her bed shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, and then committed suicide.

The firm of Fuller Brothers Co. of 137 and 139 Greenwich Streat, which is said to be the oldest and largest concern in this city dealing in naile, has made an assignment to Cadwallader R. Mulligan of Dover, N.J. The members of the firm, George, Horace W., and Charles D. Fuller, have always been regarded as conservatives business men and of the highest character, and much sympathy is expressed for them.

Lucille H., who won in the 2:20 class for pacers at Grand Rapids Tuesday, has the record for a four-year-old pacer, going the second heat of the race in 2:12. She is by Socrates out of the fast mare Motto by St. Mark. The reports of the race say that she was never extended during the race, and if this is true there will soon be another contestant for the pacing championship.

Col. Charles J. Murphy, recently appointed special representative of the United States Department of Agriculture, sailed for Europe on the New-York yesterday. Col. Murphy's a mission requires him to visit many countries for the purpose of collecting information for the use of the department, the special object of his work being to learn where new markets for products of American industry can be found.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The attendance at the races to-day was very large. The weather was warm and bright, but the tract heavy. The association will give its first annual garden party on the grounds on Saturday. All of the horses at Horsehaven will be paraded on the track prior to the first race.

MR. KENT AND His HOUSEBOAT. -- Mr. and Mrs. William Kent, who were among the interested spectators of the performances of the yachts of the New-York Yacht Club squadron from the dect of the Taurus on Monday, have passed most of the Summer on board of their houseboat, the Half Moon, which is one of the most complete boats of its kind afloat.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The third day's play in the Easex; County Club tournament was productive of two surprises. Foote, the Yale champion, defeated Malcolm Chace in straight sets, and C.F. Budlong iron from Hobart. Chace was way off in his match with Foote and lost point after point by drives into the net. The Yale man put up a very strong game.
The police have captured two thieves and a receiver of stolen goods who since last May have been industrious in ill-doing, to the detriment or E. R. Mead, Co., grocers at 195 Franklin Street.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 9. -- The annual regatts of the National Association or Amateur Oarsmen could not have been held under more favorable circumstances. The day was perfect and the course, stretching along the American side of Bella Isle, was pronounced by all contestants as fine as the world affords. There was a gentle wind with the current, but it scarcely rippled the water.
The health authorities of this city are now thoroughly prepared to meet the cholera should it get to this port, bat they have not the least expectation that it can pass the guards on the other side.

The young girl who was found suffering from carbolic acid poisoning in front of the Methodist Church in East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street Monday night, and who died at the Harlem Hospital, was identified at the Morgue yesterday as Lizzie Metzke, a native of Prussia, fourteen years old, who had been in this country about a year and a half.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 9 -- The United States Circuit Court yesterday appointed George Spencer of Duluth receiver for the Union Improvement and Elevator Company and for the Lake Superior Elevator Company, after giving bonds in the sum of $100,000 in each case.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 -- The local market opened steady except for Lehigh Valley, which was very strong, advancing from 29 12, thi closing price last night, to 32, with a subsequent reaction at the close to 31. The stock is quite scarce in the loan crowd and commands a premium. Pennsylvania closed at 50 bid and was strong all day, commanding 13 per cent for the use of the stock.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 9 -- The congregation of the Hickory Street Presbyterian Church, is shocked by the announcement that the pastor, the Rev. C.L. Weiswasser, has eloped with Mrs. George Scheur, a prominent member of his church and President of the Ladies' Aid Society.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 9. -- The associated banks of New-Orleans decided to-day to suspend payments in currency until further notice. They took this action on account of the scarcity of money. Efforts will be made to prevent as much injury to business Interests as passible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The representatives of the Carpenter Steel Company of Reading, Penn.. were here yesterday and entered into contract with the Army Ordnance Office for supplying the coast-defense system with 100 armor-piercing projectiles. This contract will require the employment of several hundred additional men in the shops of the company.

Delightful weather and a promising card drew a big attendance to the Clifton race track yesterday. The grand stand was as cool a spot as could be found in New Jersey, and this, coupled with the fact that four favorites and a well-backed second choice won, made the patrons happy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- The corn pit was the centre of interest moat of the time to-day. "Wheat-was largely a side issue. The Government weekly weather bullerin showed serious damage to corn in many States by drought, and reports from the country were more emphatic than before regarding the imminence of a great disaster to the crop. There was some weakness near the close on a report that rain was falling in Nebraska.

The two rival athletic clubs of Staion Island -- the Athletic of West Brighton and the Cricket of Livingston -- played an interesting game of cricket yesterday at Livingston, but the athletic men were no match for the cricketers, and were defeated by a margin of 129 runs. To this result the fine batting of K. Bokeby, for the cricketers, contributed not a little, while Wright, their professional, was also very successful in both departments.
A prisoner who gave the name or James Butler was remanded in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday until the police can procure evidence to sustain a charge of robbery.

Perhaps the most admirable part of Mr. CLEVELAND'S message was the singularly clear fashion in which he set forth the only principle on which the United States can use silver as money. There is no subject as to which there is so much confusion of thought, and yet very few of great importance as to which the history of great commercial nations points so plainly to a single, simple, comprehensive principle.

Another East Indian Prince arrived in this city yesterday on his way to the World's Fair. His card gives his name and title as Maharaja Sir Waghjl Thokore, Sahib of Morvi. With him is his son, his Highness, the Prince Lukdhieji.

NEW-YORK WEDNESDAY, Aug. 9 -- P.M. Wall Street labored under considerable depression when business began to-day and a sharp decline ensued in prices. The closing of the Manhattan Square Bank was regarded as only a minor incident in the situation, but it had more or less of a disquieting influence.

the day, but toward the close was fairly active, closing strong at about top prices. Clearing House exchanges to-day were $11,217,107, as against $14,655,523 for the corresponding day last year. Balances to-day were $1,156,619, as against $1,512,718. At the Clearing House this morning money between banks loaned at 7 3-10 and 8 P cent.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 10. -- As this was the great day of the national regatta, when the final heats were to berowed, and the strong interest which the Northwest once felt in aquatic sports had been fully revived, the attendance was immense, and, had the park commission allowed the erection of a grand stand covering the whole American side of the island.

There were signs yesterday that the currency scarcity was a trifle less acute. Premium rates for cash were lower. Heavy receipts of gold and some shipments of funds to this city from the interior helped to bring such relief as was given to the situation.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 10 -- A great gold strike is reported in the Fortunatus Mines of Sheridan, Wyoming. It is said that after eighty hours' work the result was 128 ounces of gold, worth over $2,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- One record was broken by the cyclists in the big League of American Wheelmen meet to-day. This was the mile tandem competition record, and A.T. Crooks and M. Dernberger of Buffalo did the breaking. In addition to lowering The time from 2:26 to 2:20 25 they hold the national championship at that style of riding at that distance.

Dr. Joseph N. Henry complained to Mayor Gilroy yesterday that dog catchers had made two attempts to seize his pet terrier, Marquis, when the dog was held by a leash. He said one of the men was Louis Rotto, Official Dog Catcher No. 9. Mayor Gilroy sent for Rotto, and Dr. Henry positively identified him. Rotto said he had lent his badge to another man that day and he was not responsible.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- What is believed to be a very extensive conspiracy to defraud the Government is now being unearthed by the Inspectors of the Post Office Department. C. P. Barrett of Spartansbnrg, S. C., who is believed to be the head conspirator, has been arrested on what is thought to be positive proof of his guilt.

Harry Wright's Philadelphia players until a few days ago were strong candidates for first honors in the League race, but yesterday they played at the Polo Grounds, and were like so many amateurs in the hands of the Giants. The latter won as they pleased. They hit hard, ran bases with rare speed and good Judgment, and at times played brilliantly in the field.

A curious phase of the distrust and timidity that have prevailed for weeks past regarding the financial future appears in the unusual extent to which money is quietly taken out of circulation and looked up. What has been going on is a "run," not on banks and financial institutions, but on the currency of the country.

The members of the Roman Catholic Parish of the Epiphany, who, since the removal of the Rev. Dr. Burtsell by Archbishop Corrigan, have paid visits to him on the anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood, will not go to Rondout this year, because the doctor has asked them not to do so.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 10 -- The suspension of the First National Bank last evening was followed to-day by the suspension of payment by the American National Bank, one of the largest and strongest in the city. The bank has a capital stock of $1,000,000 and a surplus fund of $116,000.

SAN ANTONIO. Texas, Aug. 10 -- It is now definitely known to the Federal authorities here that scores and probably several hundreds of Chinamen have entered the United States from Mexico at different points along the Rio Grande during the last ten days.

Robert Watson, thirty-six years old, who had been employed for nearly a month at the Manhattan Beach Hotel, was removed from Bellevue Hospital yesterday to North Brother Island, having the symptoms of typhus rever.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The markets were dominated by the American position and news in regard to the probable termination of the currency crisis. Little interest is taken in what Congress may do, as it is thought that the position is more likely to be alleviated through gold movements than through legislation.

At last the rat has found a friend. This little animal, which mankind has regarded as fit only to be tilled and the cat tribe as legitimate prey, has won a place in the heart of Superintendent Hankinson of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Be does not go so far as to say that rats shall not be killed, but he does declare that they must be killed humanely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- With the Committee on Rules appointed, and the rules reported, as they probably will be at once, the House will be able to proceed with the discussion of any measure that may be brought before it, and referred at once to the Committee of the Whole.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The second day's hearing as to the sanity of Edward Meredith, who shot "Phil" Daly in December, 1888, was replete with interesting material.

In the Supreme Court yesterday, Judge O'Brien appointed Miles M. O'Brien of the H. B. Claflin Company and Peter F. Meyer, a wealthy real estate man and auctioneer, receivers for the Madison Square Bank. Their bonds were fixed at $200,000. Judge O'Brien, in making the appointment, said:

The passengers of the Stonington boat New-Hampshire on Tuesday evening were treated to a little excitement which was not down on the bill. She entered Hell Gate about one minute ahead of the Javelin, the speedy steam yacht belonging to Messrs. Charles R. and Wallace B. Flint, which had Just shown her stern to the Puritan. Off North Brother Island the Javelin was ahead of the New-Hampshire.

SUFFERN, Aug. 10 -- The body of a man said to be Richard Mussen, a wealthy silk manufacturer doing business in New-York, was found beside one of the quiet roads here about 7 o'clock to-night. There was a bullet wound in the head. No weapon was found. The body had evidently been lying there but a short time.

That product of the soil of California which promises to become one of the most profitable to the horticulturist is the olive. As yet the business of growing the olive and mating olive oil is in its infancy on this side of the Atlantic, but there are a dozen or two even in California who are paying especial attention to this Industry.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 10 -- The schooner Acacia, Golding, from Port Johnson, of and for St. John with a cargo of 167 tons of coal, when about six miles east-southeast from Chatham about 12:30 last night, was run into by a large unknown steamer and sank in about forty minutes.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 10 -- This morning Clarence Hobart defaulted in the Essex County invitation tournament owing to a sprained finger of his right hand. The injury was caused Tuesday during his match with Wrenn. Hobart slipping on the court. He fell on his hand, and though the injury was not serious then, it has since developed into quite a bad hurt.

EASTON, Penn., Aug. 10. -- The result of the conference between Vice President Voorhees of the Reading, the Superintendent of the Lehigh Valley, and the Grievance Committee or the latter road last week at Bethlehem, was made known to-day.

From Printers' Ink. Printers' Ink notes with pleasore the efforts that are being put forth by New-York's new Postmaster, Charles W. Dayton, for the purpose of securing better postal service in this city. The numerous errors made by the New-York office in distributing second-olass matter have on several occasions been made the subject of comment in these columns.

The free-coinage men are wiser in their day and generation than the children of light. They have got together and formulated a bill for the repeal of the act of 1890, coupled with a provision for unlimited coinage at a ratio left to be determined hereafter, and apparently this is to be the nearest the top of the House calendar of all financial propositions.

A sorry-looking man, lame and hungry, yesterday told George I. Graham, agent for the Polish Emigrant Society, at 16 Moore Street, a story which led to a revival of the charges that paupers were shipped from Boston to this city and left to shift for themselves.

Preparations have been made at the yards of the Cramps of Philadelphia to launch, to-morrow, the new triple-screw cruiser Minneapolis. The Minneapolis is a sister ship of the cruiser Columbia, launched by the Cramps last year.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 -- During the past Summer an army of workmen have been employed producing a wonderful transformation within the walls of the historic Museum, and when the establishment is thrown open on Monday evening. Aug. 21, the habitues of this refined old playhouse will witness many and welcome alterations.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Aug. 10 -- P.M. The first prices to-day were considerably below yesterday's closing, but the weakness was short-lived. Prices advanced almost from the start, and although the trading was not heavy a fair day's business was done. General Electric, Sugar, Rock Island, and Burlington had the advance, and the general list kept up with the pace.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Is Gen. Alexander Hamilton insane?

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 -- Lawrence T. Neal is realizing to-night the truth of the old saying that "all things come to him that waits." For eight years a candidate for the highest office in the gift of the Ohio Democracy, he suddenly finds his ambition gratified, and that without even a semblance of a struggle.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 10 -- In the retrial of Alexander S. Letts, charged with defrauding the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the State to-day introduced a new witness, Scott Jackson, who has been indicted for complicity in the frauds since Letts was first tried.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 10 -- The litigation between the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company and the International and Great Northern Railway for control of the Galveston, Houston and Henderson Road between Houston and Galveston took a new turn to-day, which promises to lead to protracted and interesting legal proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The President's stay yesterday at Woodley, his country house, was spent in considering applicationo for pardons. He considered sixteen cases, involving an immense amount or work, and this morning examined two more applications. Full pardons were granted in nearly all the cases.

Brooklyn church circles are interested in the wedding of the Rev. H. Price Collier and Mrs. Katherine Delano Robbins, which occurred Tuesday, in Chicago. Mr. Collier was formerly pastor of the Unitarian Church of Our Saviour, Monroe Place and Pierrepont Street, and the bride is the widow of Charles Robbins of the wholesale drug firm of McKeason Robbins.

BUFFALO, Aug. 10 -- Popular indignation became too pronounced for even the Sheehan police officials yesterday, and they determined to close the big gambling room that had been running for nearly two weeks.

The annual clambake and outing of the Old Guard is an event to which that famous organization and its friends look forward eagerly during the Spring and Summer, and when yesterday came around, the day set for the bake this year, the members were up bright and early. One enthusiastic member said he had slept on the pier all night getting ready for it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The August report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture shows that the condition of corn has declined a little over six points during the past month, the average for the entire breadth being 87, as against 93.2 for the month of July. This decline is due in the main to the drought, which has proved both extensive and persistent.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- At the regular weekly meeting of the Directors of the Bank of England, to-day the bank's rate of discount was advanced 1 P cent., making the rate now asked 4 P cent.

Walter Rutan, Captain of the Montclair Wheelmen, was very complimentary to THE TIMES in giving so much attention to the wheelmen. He said, "I am sure the wheelmen at New-Jersey fully appreciate what THE TIMES is doing for them and good roads."

Secretary Burns of the Department of Parks informed the Board of Health yesterday that there are only two springs in Central Park used for drinking. One is near Concourse Hill, at Eighty-first Street and Eighth Avenue, and one near the house on the hill at One Hundred and Sixth Street and Eighth Avenue. In Riverside Park there is a spring near Ninetieth Street.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 10 -- Startling has been the sequel to the murder of Private William Laugherty of Fort Anderson at Briceville last Monday night. Soldiers sent by the State to Coal Creek to uphold the law have committed a most glaring breach of it by lynching Richard Drummond early this morning.

His Highness the Thakore Saneb of Morvce, the East Indian potentate who is staying at the Brunswick Hotel, took a stroll in Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon while Lieut. Humfrey, who has charge of the potentate, was smoking his after-dinner cigarette. With the Thakore was his son. Prince Lukdhirji about fifteen years old.
Michael Finn, a well-known east side character, known as "Miok the Fiddler," fell out of the third-story window of the house at 352 East Thirty-third Street yesterday morning and was killed.

Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan came to this city yesterday afternoon, to remain until tomorrow on what he said was a purely business errand. He went to the Hoffman House. State Controller Frank Campbell of Both and A.N. Brady of Albany came with him and accompanied him to his hotel. Senator Jacob A. Cantor joined them soon after their arrival.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 10 -- The health authorities all over the South remained awake last night in consequence of the reports of yellow fever at Pensacola.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- The Saratoga Victory Manufacturing Company has closed its two mills at Victory Mills, and the operatives, 800 in number, were notified that work would not be resumed under a month. Boston capitalists compose the company.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 10. -- When Mrs. Mattie Shann came into the hotcourtroom this morning for the third day in the trial for her life, she was paler than usual and extremely nervous. The court had hardly got under way when her counsel asked for a recess that she might be allowed to withdraw. She was led into one of the rooms and placed near a window.

The employes in the Street-Cleaning Department were all paid off yesterday, after a delay or one day, in part due to the difficulty in getting money from the banks. There will probably be no strike now. The drivers, having been paid, have no grievance, but the sweepers still complain that they are overworked since the force was reduced by the dismissal of 233 men.

BUFFALO, Aug. 10 -- The fishermen have had another great day at Niagara-on-the Lake. Not withstanding it was almost daylight when the last fish story in the competition for the steel rod was told, the fishermen were after the base soon after breakfast.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 10 -- The Paymaster of the Long Island Railroad had small bills enough to pay off but half of the employes to-day, and was compelled to stop paying off early in the day. As in all cases where a great number of hands are employed, there were all sorts of rumors current among the unpaid employes.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 10 -- Owing to the scarcity of currency in the city, the Danbury and Pahquioque National Banks are preparing to issue local currency in the shape of certified checks. They will be accepted at the banks for deposit only, and will be payable at New-York national banks through the New-York Clearing House.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 10 -- The missing securities of the People's Fire Insurance Company are turning up daily. In the vaults at the National Bank of the Commonwealth, where they had been mislaid, eighty-eight shares of the First National Bank of Marion. Ind., were found yesterday. Securities to the amount or $4.400, which are in the hands of Nashua parties for collection., were also reported.

CHESTER, Penn., Aug. 10. -- The largest sidewheel steamboat in the world slid off the ways and into the Delaware River to-day as gracefully and easily as if she were a cockleshell instead of a four-thousand-tonner. The yards of the Delaware River Iron Ship Building and Engine Company, formerly the John Roach ship yard, were crowded with people.

Discouragement follows discouragement at the Monmouth Park truck. Yesterday afternoon, with two stakes on for decision, there were so few people at the track, and these few had so little money, that the bookmakers said that the business transacted was the smallest that had probably ever been done on a race course since racing became so great a game as It has been daring the last six or eight years.

Louis Windmuller has written a letter to J. Haraen Bhoades, President of the Greenwich Savings Bank, suggesting a method of procedure by savings banks, which he thinks will help restore confidence and alleviate suffering on the part or depositors.

Recorder Smyth handed down a decision yesterday denying Dr. Robert W. Buchanan a new trial. Buchanan was convicted on April 26 of killing his wife by poison. The trial lasted about four weeks, and much expert testimony was introduced on both sides.

The President of the Madison Square Bank is quoted as stating that the State had deposits in the bank long before the unsecured loan was made to Treasurer DANFORTH, as if that mitigated the case. It does not matter whether the bank accommodated DANFORTH because he deposited the State's money with it, or whether DANFORTH deposited the State's money with the bank because it accommodated him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- There were rumors at the Capitol this morning that the President was seriously ill, followed in the evening papers by the statement that he was about to leave Washington to "go fishing.''

Oliver Stunner Teall has resigned from the old Vaudeville Club. He has a new idea for providing entertainment for the silk-stocking element that likes to be out a bit late and patronize places a little bit oat of their line, provided they can do so in a manner that will enable them to maintain their identity and not become a part of the common herd.

The criminal proceedings instituted by Ernest B. Balch against ex-President J. M. Waterbury and ex-Directors G. Weaver Loper, Frank T. Wall, and E. M. Fulton of the National Cordage Company do not appear to have created apprehension in the minds of the accused. On the contrary, they laugh at Balch and his proceedings.

Arthur Kuntz, a stylishly-dressed German, was arrested at the corner of Forty-second Street and Ninth Avenue on Wednesday night helplessly intoxicated, and was looked up in the Forty-seventh Street Police Station. His face was badly bruised and both eyes were discolored. In his pocket were found $70.62, a bank book on the German Savings Bank at Fourth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, and a few other articles.
The money market was quiet. Call loans on stock and bond collateral were made at 3@5 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

The foreign exchange market was firm all morning, but fell sharply in the afternoon. The posted rates for sterling were $4.84 for 60-day bills and $4.89 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.82 1/2@$4.83 1/2 for 60-day bills., $4.87 3/4@$4.88 1/4 for demand, $4.90@$4.91 for cable transfers, and $4.81 for commercial.

The final games in the tennis tournament of the Nyack Country Club exelted the greatest interest. An hour before the first game was called spectators began to secure good seats, and when Ludlow and Holt stepped on the northwest court to begin the finals of the singles, there were several hundred spectators assembled ready to applaud good play.
John W. Mackay, the California millionaire, who is ill at the Belgravia, Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, was improving yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The parts of the new furnace for assembling heavy ordnance have reached the Washington gun shops from Philadelphia, and will soon be placed in position. The furnace is the invention of William Sellers, the machinery builder, and is intended to prevent the sticking of tube and jacket of great guns while in process of assembling.

The racing at Clifton was good, the weather a trifle warm, and the betting brisk. Four favorites and a well-backed second choice were victorious, and at the end of the day the public had much the best of the battle with the bookmakers.

The Customs Investigating Committee continued its examination yesterday in the affairs of the Surveyor's Office by examining some United States weighers. The usual board conducted the examination -- Messrs. Dunn, Magone, and Macfarlane. Mr. Macfarlane said the main purpose in questioning the Surveyor's officers was to see the men and get a general idea of their intelligence.

For seven years Miss Clara Perry Thomas of 237 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street has been waiting for the time to come when she could become the happy bride of David J. Solomon. At last, Wednesday of this week was named for the wedding day, but before the day she looked forward to with so much pleasure she received a blow which caused her much pain.

AUCKLAND, New-Zealand, Aug. 10 -- According to the latest advices from Apia, order has been completely restored in Samoa. As the result of a conference between toe foreign Consuls and the Captains of the war ships, Mataafa was deported to the Union Islands aboard the German man-of-war Sperber.

Mayor Gilroy was shown a newspaper statement yesterday intimating that Congressman W. Bourke Cookran had sought favor with President Cleveland by treachery to Tammany. The Mayor looked wearied at the reiteration of the old yarn about Mr. Cookran being "out" with Tammany.

After an interesting game at Bergen Point yesterday afternoon the second eleven of the New-Jersey Athletic Club defeated the second eleven of the Staten Island Cricket Club by 37 runs.
