In the first innings of the latter K. S. Walker and R.St.G. Walker were the only double-figure scorers, while in the second innings J. Douglas played well.

Katie Reynolds, fifteen years old, and Philomena Cooney, thirteen years old, who were arrested several days ago on charges of robbing flats in Yorkville, were rearraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday and remanded until to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The fight for the repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act may begin in the House to-morrow. If a bill is not brought forward to-morrow by Congress, the contest may be delayed, by negotiation until the patience of the people who sent the Congress here may be exhausted.

VANCOUVER, B.O., Aug. 10 -- Special advices from Honolulu per steamer Miowera state that everything has been quiet on the islands since the last mail. The Postal Savings Bank has been able in one week to pay $17,000 into the Treasury from excess of deposits over withdrawals. Indicating strongly increased public confidence in the stability and strength of the Provisional Government.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- General Managers of the Eastern roads virtually ordered an advance in World's Fair rates to-day. Wherever those originally agreed to April 10 have been reduced they are to be restored. This decision was not arrived at without a great deal of dissension. It was past 8 o'clock before the meeting adjourned, and it was only at the last moment that this decision was finally reached.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 -- The market has been steady all day and arbitrage stocks were almost neglected on account or the high rates for New-York exchange. Lehigh Valley was heavily sold around 30, but remained steady on the covering of aborts. Metropolitan advanced to 70 on small purchases and Philadelphia to 68.

William S. Renehan, proprietor of the Central Bridge Hotel, at One Hundred and Fifty-fourth Street and Macomb's Dam Bridge, was the defendant before Judge O'Brien in the Supreme Court yesterday in a suit brought by James Fitzpatrick, a butcher at 2,733 Eighth Avenue, who asks for $5,000 damages for an assault which he says Renehan committed on him.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The race for the Ryde Town Cup under the auspices of the Royal Victoria Yacht Club, of which the Marquis of Exeter is Commodore, took place to-day. The course sailed over was forty miles long, extending from Ryde, where the clubhouse is situated, to and around the Waruer Lightship, off the eastern end of the Isle of Wight; then westward to a mark boat off Cowes, and back to Ryde.

NEWPORT, K.I., Aug. 10 -- The Vigilant and the Jubilee to-day furnished one of the most exciting and prettiest races ever witnessed. At no time over the course were they more than three and a half minutes apart, and, considering that the wind was very light all day lone, this is a very small margin.

FLUSHING, L.L, Aug. 10 -- The Minqua Club, the Tammany social organization of the Twenty-eighth Assembly District, started this morning from their clubhouse. West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, at 8:30. They marched to the foot of One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, executed a flank movement, and, boarding the steamer Blackbird, started at 9 o'clock for Donnelly's Grove, College Point, on their sixth annual excursion.

W.H. Dix of Brooklyn went to England a few weeks ago, taking with him a number of Bank of England notes, which he purchased from H.C. Lehrenkraus, 379 Fulton Street. He passed a twenty-pound note on a London merchant, and next day was informed that it was a forgery. He found it difficult to convince the authorities of the Bank of England that he was not engaged in the business of circulating forced notes.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 10 -- R. Dudley Winthrop, a young society man and crack polo player of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club, is lying critically ill at the clubhouse at Westbury, the result of an accident in the polo field Saturday afternoon. Mr. Winthrop is thirty years old and is the son of Banker Robert Winthrop of 3 Broad Street, New-York.
Miss Mary E. Towle, a young woman in the employ of J.G. Johnson Co., dealers in millinery goods at 600 Broadway, had a most unpleasant experience on Wednesday and yesterday.
CAIRO, Aug. 11 -- The return of the Khedive from his visit to the Sultan at Constantinople has been marked by a farther tension in the political situation, and a Cabinet crisis is now on.

James Willis tried to steal a watch in Williamsburgh a few days ago and was committed to Raymond Street Jail lo await trial. He pleaded that he had a starving wife and family and was forced to steal in order to get food for them. His story excited sympathy, and a number of persons sent money to Justice Goetting to be given to the starving ones.

Samuel Tasarki of Cook Street and Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, is in Raymond Street Jail, where he was sent a week ago for refusing to marry Esther Lampel of 176 Suffolk Street, this city. He must remain there until a rabbi can be found who will marry him in Jail.

JURSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Mary Bligh of New-York to-day obtained a divorce from Matthew Bligh, a Jersey City fireman. Jan. 25 the house in which Bligh lived and which he owned caught fire. His rooms were on the top floor, where he lived with his wife and three children. Mrs. Bligh and two of the children escaped to the roof and were saved, after being slightly injured.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Aug. 11 -- The two big woolen mills in Raritan, one mile above here have gone on three-quarters time, and the people in the town who depend on the mills for their living feel discouraged.

The new role In regard to standard classes will be rigidly enforced at the Madison Square Garden Horse Snow In November. All horses competing in these classes must be registered as well as to be standard, and a certificate of registry must be presented in order to prove that the horse is standard.

TARRYTOWN, Aug. 11-- The publication this morning of the domestic infelicities of Gen. Alexander Hamilton, a lifelong resident of this village, was a surprise to the majority of the citizens, but there were a number who had been looking for something of this sort.

NEW-ROCHELLE, Aug. 11 -- With the view of effecting an early payment for the lands and other property taken or destroyed by Commissioner of Public Works Daly in Weatchester County for the water sheds, in the endeavor to Increase and keep pure New-York City's water supply. Corporation Counsel Clark of New York City will apply to Justice Dykman, sitting at White Plains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- The best wheat market in months developed to-day. The cash price is up 3c a bushel. For the September option there was an advance of 2 1/2c, and the closing was steady within 1/8c from the top figures. The low crop estimates, light receipts, and better financial outlook were the main reasons. Corn broke on the rains over the West, and only scored a net gain of 1/8c.

BAYONNE, N. J., Aug. 11 -- The bodies of three young girls, who were drowned while bathing in Newark Bay yesterday, were to-day recovered by dredgers. They were taken to the homes of their families in West Forty-third Street.

It was an off day at Monmonth Park Yesterday in every way. The attendance was of the alimmest and two-thirds of those present came there on complimentary tickets of admission, The card was a padded one, fourteen of the horses named to start in the six races falling to put in an appearance when the animals wore called to the post.

It has often been remarked that the motives of the Rev. Dr. PARKHURST are doubtless good. In fact it is necessary for anybody who dislikes to see a minister of the Gospel making a fool of himself to recur to the goodness of Dr. PARKHURST'S motives whenever a public announcement is made of one of Dr. PARKHURST'S performances.
SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- There is little doubt that Richard Muser, the lace importer of New-York, who was found dying near his lodge gate here early yesterday, committed suicide.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 -- At the Spring election the Democrats of North Plainfield succeeded in electing a Mayor and a majority of the borough Council, for the first time in the history of the borough. The Republicans have been scheming to regain control. Councilman Connolly, Democrat, resigned, owing to his inability properly to attend to the duties of his office.

TRENTON, N. J., Aug. 11 -- A bottle of smelling salts held continuously to Mrs. Shann's nose assisted her to almost perfect composure in the hot courtroom to-day. The crowd was greater than on any previous day of the trial Four-fifths of the spectators were women, who sat throughout the day listening to the dry expert evidence for a chance to look on the pale face of the woman accused of poisoning her son.

The fall of the Samoan leader. Mataafa, in the recent battle against the forces or the King, Malletoa, brings to a close an Interesting and picturesque career. It is probably the close, also, of a long series of internal commotions in that island, of which the awful calamity which overtook the American and European war ships in March.

The new triple-sorew cruiser Minneapolis, which will be launched to-day from the yards of the Cramps of Philadelphia, is the second triple-screw war ship built for the new navy of the United States. The first was the Columbia The Columbia is still at the yards of her builders, the Cramps. She will probalily be ready for her initial trial tests in four weeks.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Aug. 11. -- A clever robbery was perpetrated at Charles H. Costa's saloon, 15 Montgomery Street, to-day. A man entered and called for a drink, laying down a five-dollar note. Costa changed the bill, taking out his cash box, which he placed behind the bar. The customer pocketed his change and sat down to read a paper.

Navigation hereabout was made very exciting and a little bit perilous yesterday morning by the presence of one of the densest fogs that have, ever obscured objects in this locality. Earlymorning traffic was considerably delayed, and from out the impenetrable veil which screened the river and bay came a din of whistles and fog bells, and frequently the noise of splintering timbers as luckless ferryboats and other river craft bumped into each other.

Active preparations are being made aboard the United States cruiser Baltimore for her departure for foreign service. The Baltimore is at present, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. She is under orders to proceed to the China station. It is estimated at the navy yard that the Baltimore will be ready to sail not later than Aug. 28.

From the Westminster Gazette. The report that the Marquis of Bate has purchased the priory, St. Andrew's, with the view of the establishment of a Roman Catholic College under the shadow of the university there la no doubt correct. Blairs, whioh the new college is to take the place of is charmingly situated on the hanks of the Dee a few miles from Aberdeen.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Aug. 11 -- P. M. The improvement in sentiment in Stock Exchange circles was most marked to-day. The change became most perceptible when it was found that time money was to be had at 6 per cent. without commission and in reasonably large amounts.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 -- The market opened quiet and generally steady. It closed firm. At the Clearing House this morning there was a distinctly better feeling prevailing. The improvement was possibly more apparent than real, and still there was a less disposition to pay high premiums, which indicates that people generally believe that the tendency is now toward more normal conditions.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 11 -- The Directors of the United States Whip Company have voted to stint down all the factories In the whip syndicate until Aug. 28. The shut-down is occasioned by the inability of the companies to dispose of their goods.

At the end of the eighth Inning on the Polo Grounds yesterday the chances of the New-Yorks winning from the Philadelphias were exceedingly Slim, and expressions of regret and disapproval could be heard in all quarters. The score was 10 to 7 in favor of the visitors and as the Giants of late are not noted for their finishing qualities a lead of 3 runs looted like a certainty for the Quakers.
DANVILIB, Va., Aug. 11 -- A meeting was held here to-day, attended by most of the prominent business men of the city, to consider the financial condition and to suggest some means of relief.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 -- P.B. Baird, Vice President of the Buffalo Furnace Company, on Aug 9 telegraphed to the Controller of the Currency the following latter concerning the use of certified checks as currency:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 11 -- Speculation is still active regarding me Lehigh Valley Railroad. A good deal la hoard bearing upon the possibility of a close affiliation with the Pennsylvania Railroad. This is positively denied by Lehigh Valley officials who are In position to speak with authority.

MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA, Mass., Ang. 11 -- The fifth day's play in the Essex County Club invitation tournament was rather uninteresting, owing to the luck of the drawings, which brought none of the cracks together. The defaulting of Hobart yesterday robbed the meeting of the stellar attraction, and to-day Budlong, who has put up good tennis from the start, was compelled to withdraw because of sore feet.
QUARANTINE, S. I., Aug. 11 -- The following bulletins were issued by Health Officer Jenkins to-day:

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- G. A. Perkins, who described himself as editor of the American Magazine and counsel for the American Embaaey, appeared in the Bow Street Police Court to-day to answer to a charge of intoxication and disorderly conduct. The officer who made the arrest stated that the prisoner had stood on the steps of a police station early this morning and denounced the police as scoundrels.

SUMMIT. N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Gov. Flower was the guest of the Teachers' Association of the Second School District of Schoharie County to-day. This was the first visit of a Governor to this section or the State in forty-five years.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The examination of Edward Meredith as to his sanity was continued to-day and resulted in demonstrating that the methods followed, for years in sending convicts from the prisons of the State to the insane asylum at Matteawan are wrong.

The one-thousand-dollar Goelet schooner yacht prize for this year is a large and truly artistic piece of sliver work in style somewhat after that of the Louis of France, though in itself entirely original. Its main feature is that of a mermaid of most graceful form entwined with dolphins and various suggestions of the sea upholding a large and beautiful shell which forms a bowl of usefulness and grace.

Miss Mary E. Towle, who was charged in Jefferson Market Police Court Thursday by Henry E. Sanford, a jeweler at 823 Broadway, with stealing a ring from his store and who was released by Justice Hogan after signing a paper agreeing not to sue Mr. Sanford for false arrest, is at St. Joseph's Home, 110 Congress Street, Brooklyn.

James Drysdale, aged, thirty-six, who had been a reporter on newspapers of this city, was found dead at 7 o'clock last night in a chair in his home. 301 East Eighty-fourth Street, with his throat cut from ear to ear. On the floor lay a small penknife.

TOPEKA. Aug. 11 -- Affairs in the American colony in Sinaloa, Mexico, have assumed such shape that bloodshed and Imprisonment are likely to ensue, if, indeed, there hare not already been these results.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- It is difficult to say whether the successful opening of the silver fight in the House or the departure of the President excites the most interest and conversation in Washington to-night. The fact that the discussion on the silver question has been opened, and with a most amicable arrangement by the repeal men and the advocates of free coinage, is gratifying to both sides to the arrangement.

George Fowler, alias Wardell, twenty-three years old, an ex-convict, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday without bail to await the result of injuries inflicted upon Mrs. Mary Brown, twenty-three years old.

YONKERS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Jeremiah Devlin of Devlin Co., clothiers, New-York City, died suddenly here this morning. He was nearly eighty years old. He was occupying the Blanchard place at 288 Palisade Avenue.

ST. PAUL. Minn., Aug. 11 -- Information was received to-day from Butte and Helena that the merchants of Montana had declared a boycott upon the wares of the wholesale merchants of St. Paul and Minneapolis. A circular from the Butte Board of Trade reads as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- The market has been dull but firm all day. Philadelphia and Metropolitan were taken in small lots at advancing prices. After the close of the Exchange to-night 69 was bid for Philadelphia and 80 for Metropolitan on the Street. It is said that Metropolitan is likely to pay dividends in October.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 -- When the gun was fired for the schooners, the wind was very light. Some of them were manoeuvring at the lightship end of the line and others were bunched to leeward of the flagship. Lasca calculated her time well, and, rounding up under the stern of the May, crossed on the port tack. Ariel was next, just to windward of the Lasca.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 11 -- The races for the Goelet cups to-day proved anything but a success. Every one had looked forward to these races, and expected that the contest in the sloop class would show which was the best of the eighty-five footers. The race turned to a big drifting match. The wind died out soon after the start, and was very fiuky all the rest of the day.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 11 -- The women of Kansas have become potent factors in politics, and have made snob a determined stand that they will stay. Some of the old-timers look upon this innovation with distrust, believing that there will follow an overturning of conventional methods. Others appear to welcome the change, professing to believe that the political paddles will hereafter contain clearer water.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11.-A. A. Zimmerman won the first of the international championship races ran during the League of American Wheelmen meeting In addition to capturing that event a ten kilometre dash, he reduced in the same race the six-mile American competition record of 18:40 2-5 made by Seeley in New-York last year to 15:33 3-5.

Fleurette was the surprise at Clifton yesterday, with from 40 to 60 to 1 against her. She was cut loose In the fourth race, in which Geraldine, the Californian sprinter, was made the odds-on favorite, but Lendrum took Fleureue to the front at the start and kept her going throughout the four-and-a-half-furlong journey. She won by two lengths from Adair while the favorite finished last.
From the Engineering Record. Prof. James L. Greenleaf of the School of Mines, Columbia College, New-York City, writes:

The two parties in the House of Representatives, one favoring the unconditional repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act and the other favoring free coinage, came to an agreement yesterday in a manner that was creditable to both, sides.

The ex-President and Directors of the National Cordage Company waited in vain yesterday for the service upon them of the summonses issued against them by Police Justice Grady of the Jefferson Market Police Court on application of Ernest B. Balch. One and all of the four men for whom summonses were issued expressed anxiety to be served, but reiterated their belief that no service would be attempted.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- "It has just struck me how this town got its name." said an observant conductor of a trolley car as it reached its terminus at the camp meeting grounds. "When I took the first car out from here this morning at 6 o'clock those people were singing all over the woods.

Arnold Hohenstein, ten years old, was instantly killed early yesterday morning by falling through the airshaft from the third floor to the cellar at the tenement house at 333 East Eighty-fourth Street, where he lived with his parents.

The premium on currency was lower yesterday, and Wall Street began to be hopeful that the worst of the money famine, from which it bad suffered for a week, was over. Trading in cash was still carried on on a heavy scale. However, in spite of the generally easier feeling in the Street.

CHICAGO. Aug. 11 -- Entries for the cattle and horse exhibits have closed, and shipments will begin to arrive the first of the week. Two cars loaded with horses and cattle were shipped from Vermont to-day, and will reach here Monday and be placed in one of the thirty great barns erected at the south end of the grounds. Canadian entries will be shipped from fort Huron and Detroit next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Not until this afternoon did the members of Congress learn that the President had left the city early this morning, instead of deferring his departure until this afternoon, as had been announced in the papers of yesterday and to-day.

The acceptance by the Directors of the World's Fair of the resignation of Mr. THEODORE THOMAS as Musical Director was almost a necessary consequence of the reaction upon the fair of the general dull and discouraging condition of business throughout the country. This was plainly put by Mr. THOMAS in his letter of resignation.

Georjro C. Taylor, doing business as a diamond importer at 860 Broadway, corner of Seventeenth Street, under the firm name of Taylor Brother, is said to have removed all his valuable assets from his safes on the night of Aug. 7 and eluded his creditors. Mr. Taylor could not be found at his place of business yesterday, and it was said that he had not been there in several days.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 -- The experts who were employed by Mayor Bishop, after the exposure of the long-continued stealings of City Clerk Van Brocklin, to investigate all the city departments, began with the Fire Department yesterday. They made a partial report of what they had discovered and late last night supplemented the report with personal statements which, reflect severely on the Controller's office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Although, the silver and anti-silver leaders were engaged about two hours this morning in matters relating to the proposed programme, the agreement for a general debate, to be followed by a vote, was reached in less than ten minutes after the two aides came together.

Dodging the newspaper reporters seemed to be Bank Examiner Judson's amusement yesterday. It was inferred that he Had received, orders to say nothing more in regard to that unsecured fifty-thousand-dollar loan to Treasurer Danforth from the Madison Square Bank or how it was that the $200,000 of the State's money was kept in the bank after the special examination of last July showed that the capital of the bank had been impaired some $80,000.

DETROIT. Mich, Aug. 11 -- The favoring weather which marked the National regatta gave way this afternoon to rain and wind that roughened the course, but did not hurt the attendance or delay the races of the amateurs of the Northwestern Association. It was after 3 o'clock when Russell, Berry, and Rumohr, the winner at Hamilton, got away in the first heat of the Junior singles.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Dullness reigned on the Exchange and a weak opening in Americans was followed by lower prices, the downward movement being helped by a poor Government report of American crops and sales by small speculators in view of the settlement beginning Monday.

The bodies of Mrs. Meta Meister, who was murdered by her husband at Henry and Sackett Streets, Brooklyn, Wednesday morning, and of John Meister, the murderer and suicide, were buried yesterday in adjoining graves in Greenwood Cemetery.

In a fit of melancholy, the result of long brooding over the death of her husband and four of her five children, Mrs. Lena Kriete, a German woman, thirty-two years old committed suicide early yesterday morning by jumping into the East River at the foot of One Hundred and Twenty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The House having agreed upon a plan of procedure regarding the silver question, interest has been transferred in a largo measure to the Senate, where it is known that there are widely divergent views on the subject of the repeal of the purchasing provision of the Sherman law.

RONDOUT, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- The Baptist Ministerial Association, comprising ministers and laymen of that denomination in New-York and Brooklyn, is in session at the Summer residence of the Rev. Leighton Williams, in Marlborough. The conference will end this week.

A little group of material men and other interested parties gatnered about one of the auction stands in the Real Estate Salesroom at 111 Broadway yesterday to witness the sale under foreclosure of the big apartment building at the northeast corner of Madison Avenne and One Hundred and Sixteenth Street. The embarrassments occasioned by the building of this structure led to the suicide of William H. Mollroy in Chicago a few months ago.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have been a subscriber to your great Journal for close on to a quarter of a century. In all that long space of time I have never been more amused than with the comments of the Russian naval officers now in this port, as reported in your columns, upon the magnificent reception given to the gallant British tars during the late naval land parade.

The American Wool and Cotton Reporter, an acknowledged authority in the industries with which it is concerned, undertakes in its latest issue to correct what it has found to be a prevailing misunderstanding as to the cause of the closing movement in the cotton and woolen factories, and in the course of its explanation sets forth some interesting and encouraging facts.
HENRY M. TELLER. Senator from the State of Colorado, is reported to have made the following statement since the assembling of Congress at Washington:

The new steamer of the Fall River Line reached here yesterday in tow of two tugs. She was taken to the dock of the W. A. Fletcher Iron Works, Hoboken, where her engines will be put in. The boat was built by the Delaware River Iron Shipbuilding and Engine Company, formerly the John Roach Ship Yard, at Chester, Penn., and was launched Thursday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- On the Stock Exchange today West Chicago sold at 110@107. North Chicago at 160@158, City Railway at 260, Diamond Match at 98, Lake Street L at 20. Money, 7$ cent. Bank clearings. $8,947,018. NewYork exchange sold at 5 discount to par.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 12. -- There was much dissatisfaction manifested over last Saturday's races of the Shelter Island Yacht Club. The racing rules have been changed this year, and the Regatta Committee for some reason or other was very loose in its interpretation of them. The clause that stipulated how the entries should be made was disregarded by all but two boats, the Curlew and the Myrtle.

There were three good pony races at Elkwood yesterday, but the attendance was the smallest of any of these Saturday pony matinees. Secretary James Sykes was starter. J.W. Albough, H. Paddock, and G.W. Curtis judges, and Ellery Green, T. Vinton Murphy, and B. Hoey timers.

So active a part have the railroad ticket scalpers here taken in the handling of the halfrate World's Fair excursion tickets issued by the trunk lines that they have aroused the vigorous opposition of certain of the lines.

La Champagne, sailing yesterday, had among ner saloon passengers for Havre Mr. and Mrs. George Eustis and W.E. Eustis, the Earon and Baroness P. de Fontenilliat, A.E. Olarovsky, the Russian Consul General, and Mrs. Olarovsky; Gen. Maignon, Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Rusch and Miss Rusch, Mr. and Mrs. H. Rhein, Mr. and Mrs. Hopkinson Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Mark Aronson, Gustav Bising, the Rev. Vicente Astori, and the Rev, James Annovazzi.
A young Mexican, carrying a perforated tin box which resembled an old-fashioned lantern, strolled along West Fifty-ninth Street one opening recently and stopped in front of the Hotel Pomeroy.

For some reason that does not appear to racel goers, Monmouth Park Association had a gala day yesterday. To be sure, there was not a great crowd at the track, but it was so much of an improvement over the attendance in the past that there was a deal of comment about it.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Islip was never more charming in appearance, never held a more companionable colony of pleasant people, and never presented a more animated, enjoyable, and generally agreeable season than it has this Summer. This is especially true of the last week or two. The forms of enjoyment nave been as varied as could be well imagined.
It is widely reported in Brooklyn that "Boss" McLaughlin has decided it would not be good politics to renominate Mr. Boody for Major -- that he is unavailable as a candidate.

It is astonishing how greatly a play Is Improved by success. To be sure, "Lettarblair" has always seemed to be a bright and witty little piece, but when it was first acted, at a trial matinee, two seasons ago though it was liked, nobody predicted a prosperous future for it.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Two attempts have been made by unknown parties to destroy or damage Ryan's Hotel, near the Pennsylvania station. Hall the building is owned by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, and the other part, which is valued at $18,000, by Brewer Gottfried Krueger of Newark.

Tarducci, in this important work on the two Cabots, is painstaking and sincere, writes clearly and amiably, and knows how to be sentimental without being commonplace. He proves his facts by original documents and supports his theories by good reasoning. He had powerful predecessors in the same field in Harrisse and Biddle.

One of the carious phases of the perturbed condition of politics in Kansas if the prominent part taken therein by the women of the State, or, perhaps we ought to say, certain classes of women, who, it is to be hoped, constitute a small, though active and aggressive, part of the gentler sex.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12. -- There is a stir here over the announcement that Major Gen. Herbert has prepared a memorandum to Council which has been approved by J.C. Patterson, Minister of Militia, making some radical changes in the militia staff which will not only startle the militia officials, but the Canadian people as well.

E.J. Phelps of Vermont, formerly United States Minister to England, and a member of the Bering Sea Arbitration Commission, was one of the passengers on the Paris from Liverpool yesterday. On reaching this city Mr. Phelps went to the Clarendon Hotel, where he said be would remain for two or three days.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Oyster Bay is thronged with city people at present. The majority of the visitors are ladies, and they take dally excursions to the many secluded and cool places which abound in and around the village. Boating, bathing, and fishing occupy much of their time.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- Mr. H. Maitland Kersey says he has heard from Lord Dunraven that the Valkyrie will sail from England next Wednesday. With fair luck she ought to reach here by the last of the month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Pardridge's short line of wheat is looming up as a factor in the market. He has had perhaps 700,000 bushels called from him on each of the past three days. He has been a seller in the pit on bulges besides, and is said to be short 4,000,000 bushels.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, Aug. 12. -- The past week at this famous hotel on the mountain top has been one of unusual pleasure to the 700 or more guests who are enjoying the cool and bracing atmosphere up here among the clouda.

SARATOGA, Aug. 12. -- The intense heat of the week has not passed Saratoga by, though the line shade and clear, dry air of this region has made it endurable. Up North, Broadway and on the other beautiful residence avenues of the village everybody has simply lived out of doors, a condition that the upper verandas of the cottage palaces makes possible.

WHY GROW OLD. -- I find that if old people are put on a good meat diet in the way of strong soup, beef tea, and animal food, and only just sufficient farinaceous food and fats and sugar to maintain the heat of the body, they increase wonderfully in energy and, as they often express it feel twenty years younger.

EYES OF DEEP-SEA FISH. -- The eyes of deep-sea fish are very varied; some have neither eyes nor eight; others have greatly enlarged eyeballs, so as to catch the least glimpse of light. Their eyes tend either to disappear or to be unusually efficient; but since no trace of sunlight can penetrate to any great depth, and it is probably quite dark beyond a depth of some 200 fathoms, of what use can eyes be.

THE STORY TELLER AND PUNCH IN EGYPT. -- We stood for some time on the edge of a silent, many-circled, squatting cluster of dotted white turbans round a small space in the centre, where sat a story teller. It was dark there but for the moonlight, and silent but for the loud, not unmusical cry of the entertainer and the echoes of the fair.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 12. -- Jobbers in coal oil and gasolene are anticipating a rapid rise in those commodities in the near future. Already there has been a considerable advance in price made gradually, and the upward tendency may be expected to hold until the oil companies have made material progress in restoring petroleum products to the figures which prevailed six years ago.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Bluetishing is the order of the day. There are vast shoals of them off shore, and the Hotel guests have been gathering them in by the basketful. A number have been caught off the pier at high tide. This kind of sport appeals most to men, but a number of the young women are handy with the hook and line.

The fifth animal competition and games of the St. George's Athletic Club were held yesterday on the new grounds at Monitor Park, Weehawken. The new track, which was used yesterday for the first time by members of other clubs, gave great satisfaction to the visiting athletes. Owing to the nature of the ground at Monitor Park it was found impossible to lay out a perfectly level track without a great deal of blasting.

PEEKSKILL, Aug. 12. -- Half the Medical Board of the Helping Hand Hospital has resigned or refused to serve longer because of the scandal which results from trouble among those who have the management of the institution.

As William Hawkins of 48 Underhill Avenue, Brooklyn, was riding in his carriage on Bergen Street Friday afternoon Joseph Pearce, fourteen years old, of 607 Bergen Street, threw a stone and hit him in the face. Hawkins leaped from the vehicle and gave chase, and the boy took refuge in the wagon shop of C.J.J. Barry, 623 Borgen Street.
RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Miss Minnie Squier is passing her vacation in Hunterdon County.

The most significant piece of musical news this morning is the announcement from Chicago of the postponement of the engagement there of the Abbey Italian opera troupe, which is to include Calve, Melba. Plancon, and the de Reszkes, from October until next March. What effect this trill have upon the New-York engagement we do not yet know; indeed, the plans of the opera season are still a little foggy.

-- They will have a real live Italian Count in the Casino Roof Garden this week. For family reasons he calls himself Signer Bovelli. Mr. Barton says it will be his first appearance in this country, but not his first appearance on the stage. For several seasons he has appeared in the cities of Continental Europe, presenting his entertainment, which consists of singing in several languages and playing the piano with both hands and feet.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, Aug. 12. -- The Mexican Financier of this city says that there is a marked improvement in the monetary situation here and a noticeably greater movement of money, as snown in the liquidation of obligations of the banks and in the large transactions in European exchange which have taken place during the week.
ROME, Aug. 12. -- The Pope has received the following letter from Cardinal Gibbons:

To the great surprise of its depositors and of many other persons in Brooklyn and New-York, the Commercial Bank, at 363 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, did not open for business yesterday morning. Shortly before 9 o'clock the cashier posted the following notice, written on a letterhead of the bank, upon the front door:
No attempt was made yesterday to serve the summonses charging certain officials of the National Cordage Company with perjury and miademeanor.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A very large attendance assembled on the Saratoga race-track grounds to-day to greet the Saratoga Racing Association's first annual garden party. All the horses at the track were paraded before the clubhouse before the races were started. The weather was good, though a trifle cloudy, and the racing excellent. In the steeplechase Jockey Callahan was thrown from Ballarat and badly injured.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- In the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, suit was filed to-day for $50,000 for breach of promise against Representative William C.P. Breckinridge of Kentucky by Madeline V. Pollard.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 12. -- The departure of the Now-York yacht fleet, for Newport Thursday morning seems to Have taken with it all the life and gayety of the week at the New-London resorts. A large amount of entertaining was done, afloat and ashore, incidental to the presence of the fleet, and it was not until this evening that the Pequot colony awoke to life again with the usual Saturday night hop.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, Aug. 12. -- Shelter Island has been a delightful place to spend a vacation this Summer. The charming weather has been no small factor in adding to the attractiveness of the place. Yachting, as usual, occupies the time of the pleasure seekers. New-London was the Mecca for lovers of this sport during the earlier part of the week.

Max Ernst and Leopold M. Whitehead have been appointed receivers of the firm of Whitehead Toklas, manufacturers of clothing, 628 Broadway, on the application at D. Solis Ritterband, attorney for Mr. Whitehead, in a suit brought to dissolve the firm on account of disagreement between the partners.

From the Utica Herald. It is well known that sea water has a most beneficial effect upon the appearance of horses, imparting a satin gloss to their coats, a brightness to the eye. and a generally refreshed appearance. It is no unusual thing at Cape May and various other seaside resorts to see ostlers giving the animals in their charge their sea plunge as regularly as the most systematic bather on the beach.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Greenwood Lake resorts are all enjoying a prosperous season, notwithstanding the general business depression. The cottages along the beautiful shores are all occupied by family parties.
The three Italian war ships Vittorio Emanuele. Amerigo Vespucci, and Flavio Gioja reached this port yesterday afternoon from Annapolis, Md.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The Libbey Glass Company's spun-glass display is little short of marvelous, including as it does upholstery for furniture, curtains, lampshade ornaments, mats, table covers, and neckties. The spun-glass fabric is durable and ductile, and possesses a brilliancy greater than any textile ever made.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 12 -- The afternoon's bicycle races were witnessed by fully 8,000 persons who enjoyed the hotly-contested events. J.P. Bliss, the little Chicagoan, distinguished himself by winning the mile handicap from the fifty-yard mark in 2:13 1-5 through a brilliant spurt at the finish. He also won the mile invitation, pushing Tyler down the stretch at an extraordinarily last pace.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Bohemians and the Independent Order of Foresters swelled the attendance at the fair to-day to mammoth proportions. The day was cool and bright, and the visitors evinced the Keenest pleasure in viewing the many things of interest.

Capt. William Meakim of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station yesterday charged Policeman Thomas Coatello with the commission of an unprovoked assault upon Patrolman Bernard J. Smith.

The annual regatta of the Friendship Boat Club was rowed yesterday on the Harlem River, with the finish in front of the boathouse. The distance was a little less than half a mile. All the Events were well contested, particularly the eight-cared shell and barge races, which excited much enthusiasm. Each was won by less than half a length. Bachelors formed the crew in one boat and married men in the other.

The value of the sanitary inspection service established at European ports by the Marine Hospital Bureau, and especially the value of the work done by the representative of the bureau at Naples, Dr. YOUNG, are shown more clearly every day. But for the vigilance and fidelity of Dr. YOUNG, the presence of cholera in Naples might have been concealed from the out- side world until after the arrival of the Karamania at this port.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 12. -- The lacrosse match on the Rosedale grounds here this afternoon between teams of Toronto and the New-York Athletic Clubs afforded good sport for the small crowd that witnessed it. All the games were well contested, and the New-York players made a much better show with Canada's crack team than many first-class Canadian teams have done this season.

BOSTON, Aug. 12. -- Market opened quiet and irregular and closed generally weak. At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in good demand at 7 3-10 and 8 cent., mostly 8. New-York funds sold at $1, $1.25, and $1.50 premium for cash, with $1.50 asked at the close.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 12. -- To those unfortunate citizens who are broiling at certain other Summer resorts and who are the prey of the alert and vigorous mosquito. Cold Spring Harbor extends its distinguished consideration, and Incidentally hugs Itself. Visitors here are at considerable trouble to keep warm, and the oldest inhabitant would not know a mosquito if he met one.

The Australian cricketers, now in England, have accepted the invitation of the Germantown Cricket Club to play here before their return home. A cablegram received in Philadelphia gives this welcome news, and these famous exponents of the game will play two three-day matches in the Quaker City on Sept. 29, 30, and Oct. 2, 6, 7, and 9.

THE ORCHIDOPHILE. -- To the naturalist in the tropics a collection of orchids is a never-ending source of interest. He cannot help Feeling that they are not only living things, but that they have faculties not generally credited to members of the vegetable kingdom. He sees them rejoicing in congenial positions, and shrinking before a strong wind or the burning rays of a tropical sun.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- The yachtsmen when asked for their opinions of the merits of the four cup defenders admitted that from the races so far they could form no definite opinion as to superiority.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The event of the week in theatrical circles was the production of Augustus Thomas's play "In Mizzoura" at Heoley's Theatre by Nat C. Goodwin. It has proved to be a great success. Since the first night, notwithstanding bad weather, the audience has been large.

The simple folk that inhabited the mountainous regions which the Vancouver estate comprised possessed many of the attributes of peasantry. Chief among these was loyalty to the proprietary family. And so when the news spread of the birth of an heir, the hilltops were bright with bonfires, and on the day of the christening there was a general pilgrimage to the mansion.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Many New-Jersey farmers and their families have for years observed the second Saturday in August as "salt water day." The favorite meeting place is Wreck Pond, on the coast between Spring Lake and Sea Girt. Here the grangers and their families had a jolly time to-day.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- To say that crowds of people have come into the mountains during the past week no more than expresses the fact. The weather has been delightful for several days, and lawn tennis, ball playing, and horse racing have come to the tront.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 12. -- The political fight in this State, which has continued since last March, was ended to-day when the Supreme Court gave its opinion that Gov. Brown had the constitutional right to prorogue the Legislature, as he did at Newport last May. This establishes the right of the entire Republican State Government to hold over for the year.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 12. -- The twenty-first annual convention of the New-York State Firemen's Association, which begins here on Tuesday and concludes Friday, will be the most remarkable gathering of the fire laddies ever held in this country. It is confidently expected by the Executive Committee that when the grand parade occurs on Friday afternoon at least 25,000 firemen will be in line.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 12. -- The battle ship Triumph, the port guardship at Queenstown. By ing the flag of Rear Admiral St. John, arrived here to-day from Malta, having on board most of the survivors of the Victoria. the tiagship of the British Mediterranean squadron, which was recently sunk in collision with the war snip Camperdown on Tripoil, Syria.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 12. -- A week or two ago the Rev. James A. Smith, pastor of the Methodist Protestant Church at Silver Mine, stood in his pulpit and announcad that he would have to preach on an empty stomach and that both he and his family were nearly starved, having subsisted on blackberries only for the week previous.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Aug. 12. -- A NEW-YORK TIMES correspondent had a talk to-day on the condition of things in Canada with Mr. Henry Folger of the well-known firm of Folger Brothers, bankers, railroad men, vessel and mine owners. Mr. Folger bas always taken a deep interest in every phase of the tariff. He is a keen and careful observer, and his firm is regarded as one of the most progressive in Canada.

BOSTOS, Aug. 12. -- The Grand Opera House was opened this evening. The house has been renovated both before and behind the curtain, and is much improved in appearence. The attraction was "The White Squadron," presented by Mr. Pearson's company. Next week "The Power of Gold" will be given, and in the week beginning Aug. 28 the stock company will make its first appearance in repertory.

HUNNIWELL, Kan., Aug. 12. -- In a draw not more than two miles southeast of town is encamped a family awaiting the opening of the Cherokee Strip. The family consists of husband, wife, and seven children. The children have had six fathers.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 12. -- An attempt was made here to-day by Mrs. Barbara Van Wert of Newark, N.J., to regain possession of her thirteen-year-old daughter Phoebe. When the child was four years old her father placed her in the Foster Home in Newark, because, as he alleged, "her mother was not a fit person to take care of the little one."

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 12. -- The decisive match of the Essex County Club tournament was played here this afternoon. Malcolm Chace of Brown and R.D. Wrenn of Harvard were the rival cracks who met for final honors, and Chace came out ahead in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1. The work of the Brown man was brilliant throughout. He outplayed Wrenn at all points and won the match on its merits.

In order to facilitate the prompt sending out of alarms in case of fire, the Fire Commissioners will soon place upon the lamp poets at street corners signs indicating the location of the nearest fire-alarm box.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 12. -- Bar Harbor has undergone a transformation scene within the last fortnight, and it is one which the residents are devoutly praying may not be of as transitory a nature as such scenes usually are. Every cottager is entertaining guests, and there is an air of bustling activity in the streets and shops.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Chairman Caldwell of the Western Passenger Association had a hearing at his office to-day on the claims of the Rock Island for relief against the action of the Burlington and Missouri in advertising half-fare rates to the World's Fair. The Rook Island claims that as its competitors have advertised half-fare rates, it has a right to make them.

The sea was at war with the land, long ago. The land had stretched an arm to bar its way. The sea, chafed by the mate resistance, swept on across the beach, clove through the crest, where rooted reeds bound fast the shifting sands and spread upon the meadows a salt rime, and foamed and swirled, until the tree crowned knolls were islands, and the soil turned to an ebon ooze.
A story is told of a well-known literary man and his wife which would, seem to indicate that not all of the artifice and scheming should be put down to women.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Vincent Rockwell of East Front Street is at Asbury Park.
SIMILIA SIMILIBUS. -- This doctrine of like helping like was of universal application, and in medical works of the Middle Ages we meet constantly with such prescriptions as these:

THE FRENCH COMEDY IN LONDON, 1871. -- The terrible crisis through which France passed during the Franco-German war could not but influence the stage directly and adversely. Pan em et circenses was the cry of the Romans during the decadence of the empire. But when bread is scarce, and sometimes not even to be found, theatrical entertainments are hardly thought of.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, Aug. 12. -- The first week in August brought more Summer guests here than the entire month preceding. June was a good month, but July was dull. The opening of the second week in August, when the season should be at its height, finds thousands of pleasure seekers along the river, but not so many as were here a year ago.

Although the Navahoe has not been doing well of late, Mr. Royal Phelps Carroll's friends are still hopeful that he will bring to America the Royal Victoria Challenge Cup. While Mr. Carroll has crossed the ocean to race for the Royal Victoria Cup, he also has his eye on two American cups that were taken to England by the cutter Genesta in 1885.
SAN FRANSCISCO, Aug. 12. -- Minister Blount was not among the passengers from Honolulu on the steamer City of New-York, which arrived this morning.

Mr. Warner, in this pleasant monograph on Washington Irving, remarks that this year occurs the one hundred and tenth anniversary of his birthday, and he speculates on the question why New-York City has no statue of Irving. He consoles himself in reflecting that it is certainly better "that multitudes should ask in New-York why a man has not a statue than that multitudes should ask why he has one."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- There appears to be a discrepancy between the remarks of Mr. Bland (Dem. Mo.,) and Mr. Lafe Pence (Pop., Col.,) on the subject of silver, and the actual situation in the States which they in part represent. Both gentlemen would have the people understand that there is a great clamor for silver in their States and a corresponding hatred of gold and the gold standard.

Richard Muser, lace importer at 467 Broome Street, who was found Thursday morning at the lodge gate of his Summer home at Suffern, N.Y., with two bullet holes in his head, will be buried to-day in Palisades Cemetery, Weehawken, N.J., beside two of his children. Funeral services will be held at 11:30 o'clock this morning at the home of his father-in-law, Louis Becker of Bergenwood, Weehawken.

The Giants were in luck yesterday, and to that met alone can the failure of the Philadelphias to win a game be attributed. The visitors were playing a grand game of ball, and at three stages were in the lead. Home runs by Connor and Burke twice tied the score, and then, when defeat stared the Giants in the face, the rainstorm came up and robbed the poor Quakers of a victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- That stalwart old Democrat who does not hold office, but who likes to live near the other Democrats who do, and who finds his life lengthened by the mere gratification of going about from office to office to see that the public business can be done by Democrats, has had a holiday since the Senate and the House met at the beginning of this session.

We are always apace with the times, and recognize that a dollar should purchase considerably more to-day than heretofore. There is no better investment than supplying present and prospective wants at values now prevailing in our establishment.

In a long article on household glassware the London Queen starts off with the unassailable proposition that "nothing, save flowers, lends so much charm to a well-appointed table as tastefully chosen decanters and glasses."
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 12. -- The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company is still unable to get currency for the payment of the Mining Department employes for July, being behind over $300,000.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Yachts are already gathering at Moriches in advance of what promises to be a pretty and novel event next Saturday. The East Bay Yacht Club will hold a "ladies' regatta." But one man is to be allowed to each boat. The commanders and crews will be women exclusively.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 12. -- Ex-United States Senator Palmer, President of the Columbian Exposition, arrived at the Coleman House this week for a fortnight's rest. The Mayor and the members of the Common Council called upon him yesterday and extended the freedom of the resort. This evening a reception was tendered to the ex-Senator.

Mr. Ober's interesting book on Columbus was inspired by the felicitous thought of making a personal visit to all those lands. European and American, with which Columbus, in making his voyage of discovery, came into contact. Beginning in Spain at the historic bridge, the author went to the equally historic convent and to Palos.

"Liberty Hall," written by R.C. Carton, has been selected by Charles Frohman for the opening of the preliminary season of the Empire Theatre. It will have its production on Monday evening. Aug. 21, and this will be the first representation of the comedy in this country. Although the regular stock season at the Empire will not begin until November.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Aug. 12. -- The French brigantine Francis, Capt. Mordrel, from St. Malo, St. Pierre, and bound for the Grand Banks to engage in fishing, was run into Aug. 9 by the steamer collingham, Capt. Watson, bound for London. The Francis was almost cut in twain.

Among real estate men just now one week is very much like every other week. Midsummer dullness is the feature, and there is much of it. Neither in public nor private sales has the past week been especially notable.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- Americans opened steady, on the decline of the currency premium in New-York, and closed firm, despite the probability of high contangoes Monday, when rates are expected to rule about 6 per cent.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 12. -- There are many children at the Fort William Henry, at the Fernwood, and at other hotels on the lake, and it seems no more than fair that the bright little ones, future American men and women, should receive attention. The way these youngsters manage to extract the greatest possible amount of enjoyment out of every day is astonishing.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- With ceremonies that were practically a repetition of those at the launching of the commerce destroyer Columbia, the Minneapolis, a sister ship, was successfully sent from the ways at the William Cramp Sons' Company's shipyard here a Little after 2:30 o'clock this afternoon.

In the course of his strong and sensible speech in the House on Friday Mr. RAYNER paused to express his contempt for the twaddle that is still occasionally heard about living up to platform pledges. Mr. RAYNER had referred to the demand of the Chicago Democratic platform that the Sherman act be repealed.
Among the experiments at Sandy Hook this Summer, those in which high explosives have been successfully used as the bursting charges of shells have possessed no small share of interest.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 12. -- A peaceful resort, where the business man ceases from troubling and the weary is at rest, is this old sea-girt isle, probably the most quaint and interesting ocean resort on the American coast.

SALTILLO, Mexico, Aug. 12. -- The Guber natorial campaign in the State of Coahuila is likely to result in a war between the two parties who are striving for supremacy in the State. The election does not occur until September, and the opposing forces are already well armed and equipped, and ready for real war.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 12. -- George R. Barnes, the burglar and desperado who murdered Detective James Harvey in this city last week, has been identified by Chief of Police Harrigan of St. Louis as Lucius R. Wilson, alias "Dink" Wilson, a member of a notorious gang of train robbers of the Southwest.

SUMNER AND MACAULAY. -- The Senator was very happy at repartee, and I recall a clever response of his at a dinner table in London. One of the guests asked him where Washington's body was buried. "His ashes," replied Sumner, somewhat sententiously, "repose on the banks of the Potomac."

THE INTER-RELATION OF FORCES. -- Water freezes and becomes ice at 32 of Fahrenheit, whereas mercury only freezes at 39 below zero of Fahrenheit; olive oil, on the contrary, shows signs of congelation at from 40 to 45 of Fahrenheit. The three substances quoted being all liquids, the difference in the loss of heat requisite to bring them to solidification is very great indeed.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- The week has been pleasantly eventful at Southampton. Entertaining has been general, and a more enjoyable August has never been recorded. The Kirby House shelters a large number of visitors, some who are new to the joys of the place and others who are veterans in their knowledge and appreciation of Southampton's charms.

AVON-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The feature of Thursday at this place was the fancy fair managed by cottagers and guests at some of the hotels for the benefit of the Home of the Merciful Saviour for Crippled Children. The home is situated at 4,400 Baltimore Avenue, West Philadelphia. At present it gives shelter and medical attendance to sixty otherwise helpless children.

The cruiser Marblehead, now nearing completion at the wharf of the Quintard Iron Works, foot of East Twelfth Street, this city, is of 2.000 tons displacement. She will carry 2 six-inch thirty-five-calibre guns, 8 five-inch rapid-fire guns, 6 six-pounders, 2 one-pounders, and 3 torpedoes, besides some Gatlings. She will carry a complement of 242 men and 18 officers.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Another week has gone by. The only sorrow it has brought to the visitors here is that it brings them one week nearer to the close of a delightful season. The hotel is full, all the cottages are occupied, and every one appears to be having a good time.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 12. -- The coal miners' strike, which was begun in this city, although the mines are located in Southeastern Kansas, is practically at an end. The strike was a political one, though the miners themselves believed that they were making a struggle for personal benefits.

Excavations for the new building of the Manhattan Life Insurance Company, in Broadway, next to the Consolidated Exchange, have been going on for several months, and have been watched with interest by the brokers. In New Street there has generally been a crowd of spectators looking down into the deep hole. Yesterday the contractors had a huge sign stretched across the space which the new building will eceupy.

BOMBAY, Aug. 12. -- The riots growing out of the religious differences between the Mohammedans and Hindus resident in this city have had more serious results than were at first apprehended. Six persons who were injured in the rioting have died in the hospitals, and many other are still under the doctors care.

From, London Nature. There is perhaps no micro-organism which has been so exhaustively studied as regards its behavior in water as the Bacillus anthracis. The list of memoirs on this subject has, moreover, been lately increased by the elaborate report just issued to the Water Research Committee of the Royal Society, intitled "The Vitality and Virulence of Bacillus Anthraois in Potable Waters," by Percy Frankland and M. Ward.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- The Finance Committee, composed of delegates from the Federated States, will meet in Berlin immediately upon the completion of the holiday leave in September of Dr. Miquel, Prussian Finance Minister. The semi-official announcement from Frankfort that the conference which was recently in session there had agreed to the general principles of the new taxation plan is not credited here.

With the regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen last Wednesday and Thursday, followed by that of the North western Amateur Rowing Association on Friday and Saturday, the past week at Detroit was a lively one for the oarsmen. This week the interest will shift to Lake Geneva, Wis., where the Chicago Navy will hold a big amateur rowing regatta, beginning to-morrow and lasting the entire week.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sunday, Aug. 6, I read with much pleasure your editorial review of Prof. Goldwin Smith's contribution in the August number of the North American upon the question of continental union, or the political reunion of the two great English-speaking communities who now occupy and control this continent.

Messrs. Miles O'Brien and Peter F. Meyer, receivers for the Madison Square Bank, qualified yesterday before Judge O'Brien of the Supreme Court. The bondsmen were Edward Farrell and Jeremiah Fitzpatrick, each pledging $200,000 as a surety.

The fame of Saratoga potatoes is almost world-wide, and is usually associated with the waferlike slices of that vegetable which, crisp-light brown, and delectable, are known to the world of the ouisine and table as Saratoga chips.

A DOUCHE FOR THE LITERARY CONGRESS. -- The congress. I gather, is to "assist literature by promoting the independence of those who write." But are we who write "dependent" at this hour? In what sense are we "dependent," except as painters, sculptors, hatters, actors, are dependent?

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 12. -- The weather during the week has been decidedly warm, and that of Wednesday and Thursday could be called hot without any danger of exaggeration; but Richfield delights in a few hot days every Summer, so that it can prove its boast of always having cool nights, no matter how high the thermometer may be at noon.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 12. -- "What is the real degree of progress made by the race that was freed a generation ago?" is a question which interests the Northern as well as the Southern citizen who has his country's good at heart. It is very difficult to obtain sufficient information touching this matter to justify conclusions reaching the entire negro population of any State.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 12. -- The Summer season is now in full blast here, and all the hotels and cottages are well filled. Many rich New-Yorkers, followins the example set by Mr. Edgar Ketchum of High Bridge, N.Y., a few years ago, have purchased cottages in and around Bethlehem, where they make their Summer home.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Mercer County has about as badly-arranged a courtroom as can be found in the State. The ceiling is low, the windows small and few, and the roof made of tin. It was a huge oven this morning, baking 900 people, who crowded into it to near the fifth day's proceedings of the Shann trial. The spectators were nearly all women and young girls.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 12. -- As a means of promoting a feeling of comfort, some of the guests here have been publishing a record of the thermometer, taken daily at 7 A. M., and the whole locality is proud of the fact that its range for the past week has been from 59 to 65.

Bank Examiner Judson was asked yesterday who had paid Mr. Danferth's note for $50,000 with the interest, to the Madison Square Bank, but he declined to tell. He could not tell when he would complete the examination of the books of the Madison Square Bank, but said he probably would by to-morrow, when the receivers would take hold.

CITY OF MEXICO, Mexico, Aug. 12. -- A sensation has been created here over a duel that did not occur. The particulars have just been made public. Francisco Migoni and Rafael Macedo, two prominent citizens of this city, were engaged to fight a duel a few days ago, the seconds of the former being Gen. Sostener Rocha and Joaquin Larralde, and of the latter Gen. Mendez Rivas and Arturo Arce.

Hospitality is the most jovial word in the English lexicon and the most inclusive. It Implies the genial latchstring forever fluttering from our door and the incessant banging of trunks upon our front steps. It stretches its syllabic proportions over a loan and varied line of gayety from the barbaric roast ox to the orthodox pink tea.

The King is dead. Long live the King! The Infanta Enlalie has departed, but there comes another greater than the gracious Princess -- the Archduke Franz Ferdinand d'Este, who will one day wear the crown of Austro-Hungary and whose destiny is to rule over 40,000,000 people. The Austrian man-of-war Kaiserin Elizabeth is steaming across the Pacific toward San Francisco, where this imperial Prince of the House of Hapsburg-Lothringen will first set foot upon American soil.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 12. -- Intimate friends of Gov. Waite say he has determined to call an extra session next month after his return from an Eastern stumping tour.

William Smyth, a bad-looking negro, twentyeight years old, of 205 West Sixty-first Street, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for trying to shoot Policeman Quinn of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station, and for assaulting a coal dealer. John Mitchell, fifty years old, of 320 West Forty-first street.

While the Autumn work is not yet placed before the public, it is sufficiently advanced in several lines to make it worth discussing. The wholesale millinery houses will most of them give their formal opening to the trade in the course of this month.

SOME AUTUMN WEDDINGS. -- There will probably be an unusual number of fashionable weddings in the coming Autumn. Miss Marie Wood and James E. Stratton will be married early in the Autumn in the Church of the Heavenly Rest. Miss Evelyn Wood will attend her sister as maid of honor, and two cousins of Mr. Stratton will be among the four bridesmaids.

BABYLON, L.I. Aug. 12. -- Babylon has hed a week memorable for jolly features and filled with varied pleasures. Not the least of these, in the minds of many, is the success that has attended the parties who have gone out bluefishing. Throughout the week this sport has been excellent. Among the enthusiastic anglers who have large catches to their credit are Messrs.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Admiring friends at Cape May Point have presented to ex-President Harrison a box of Cape May pebbles, which are acceptable gifts because of their clearness and brilliancy. Some were in the rough, as gathered on the beach of the Delaware Bay, and others were out by the lapidary and had the fire of diamonds.

The annexed letter, written by an unknown friend of Frank Ellison, the athlete, who assaulted Broker Henriques, has been received by THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Mr. Ellison's admirer mournfully states that the prisoner is an orphan and "has no family except a brother-in-law,'' and offers, inferentially, in mitigation of Mr. Ellison's outrageous assault, the alleged fact that the prisoner was a Union soldier at the tender age of fourteen years:

About 300 members of the Western Pennsylvania Division of the Grand Army of the Republic assembled in Pittsburg Friday night and passed resolutions "condemning Secretary HOKE SMITH'S attitude in respect to the pension question and asking for a more liberal interpretation of the pension laws."

CINCINNATI, Ghio, Aug. 13 -- Miss Madeline V. Pollard, who figures in the Breckinridge-Pollard suit in Washington, attended the Wesleyan Female College of this city in 1885. She was one of its most brilliant pupils. She was frequently visited by an old, gray-bearded man, who gave his name as Rhodes. He paid all her expenses, and she declared that he was her guardian.

As the final preparation for its second season, which begins this evening, the Imperial Music Hall opened one of its doors last night, just wide enough to admit a score or two of newspaper men, and as many more people of other kinds, unclassified, but no doubt wise and critical, and in their attentive presence a full dress rehearsal of the week's programme was held.

Notwithstanding that yesterday was Sunday, the closing of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn on Saturday continued to engross the thoughts of a large portion of the inhabitants of the City of Churches. Among the usual crowd of strollers on Fulton Street in the neighborhood of the Brooklyn City Hall were many inquisitive persons.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 13 -- The trouble in Meachambeat is at an end for the time being. The pease has disbanded and quiet reigns. Three of the worst men in the gang and the acknowledged leaders escaped by taking refuge in Satilla Swamp.

The sanitary interests of this port and of the whole country are now represented at Naples not only by Dr. YOUNG of the Marine Hospital Bureau, but also by a physician who is the agent of the Quarantine authorities of this harbor, and we direct attention to an inference that may fairly be drawn from this physician's telegram of Saturday night to Health Officer JENKINS.

There was joy yesterday, for the first time in two years, in the home of Gen. Peter J. Claassen, 262 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. It was occasioned by the return of Gen. Claassen from the Erie County Penitentiary, where he was sent in March, 1891, to serve a term of six years, for wrecking the Sixth National Bank, this city, of which he was President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The temper of a few members of the Senate toward the proposition to repeal the silver-purchase clause of the law of 1890, as has been stated in these dispatches before and may profitably be asserted again, is now the obstacle to repeal, and not the lack of a Democratic majority for repeal.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 12 -- The New-Jersey State Rifle Association will hold its third annual competition at the rifle range here, beginning Monday and continuing until Saturday.

Austin Roe. Austin Roe, 86 years old, died suddenly of heart failure at his borne in Patchogue, L.I., Friday night. Mr. Roe, who was widely known as "Uncle Austin," was the oldest hotel Keeper in that region. He was born in Setauket, L.I., in 1808. He leaves four children.

Exposed to every breeze that blows, and with an array of light that at nighttime converts it into a veritable fairyland, with a first-class band playing all through the day, with balloon ascensions, vaudeville entertainments, and last and greatest the huge spectacular show. "King Solomon," Eldorado becomes more popular as the season advances.

-- The Dauntless Rowing Club had three brooms hoisted to the top of the flagpole on their boathouse yesterday, and twice as many more decorated the corners of the balcony, in celebration of the triumph of their intermediate eight-oared crew over that of the Atalantas at Detroit last Wednesday. All day long the house was crowded with the friends of the club, who came to hear how the race was rowed.
It is not probable that Francis Henry Weeks, the absconded trust funds manipulator, will ever face a "jury of his peers," as he is to be expelled from membership in the University Club.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 13 -- Josiah Morris Co., the leading private banking house of the State, made an assignment yesterday. It was due to the continued withdrawal of deposits during the last sixty days, and especially to large drafts made yesterday. At a meeting of the other bank officers last night it was resolved, commencing Monday morning, to enforce the Clearing House system.

There is a general expectation that the business of buying and selling currency, which has been so curiously active for the past ten days, is pretty well exhausted, though it is not impossible that it may be revived later on. It has had one effect on which those engaged in it as sellers to the brokers had not counted -- it has brought many of them into strained relations with other business men.

We have waited patiently for some expression of opinion by our Republican contemporaries concerning the great and very remarkable blunders of Mr. BROCK, late chief of the Bureau of Statistics, and his superior officer. Mr. CHARLES FOSTER, Secretary of the Treasury, in the matter of the valuation of imports.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- Morgan luck still clings to the New-York yachtsmen. As it was decided to remain at anchor a good fresh breeze blew all day long from the northwest. It was annoying to every one. Ever since Monday there has been nothing but calms and fogs. It was more than they could stand, so to-day many of the yachts went out sailing.

There is reason to believe that the anchorage grounds of this port will soon be changed in that portion known as the North River anchorage. One of the officers of the port was making investigations Saturday along the New-Jersey side of the Hudson, between Twenty-fourth and Seventy-second Streets, with the view of reporting upon the best position for a new anchorage place on the New-Jersey side of the river.

O'NEILL, Neb., Aug. 13 -- Friday, Aug. 4, Barrett Scott, county Treasurer of Holt County, left O'Neill for Sioux City. His continued absence and the fact that lead than $20,000 of the $90,000 which should be on hand in the banks of the county, and $15,000 of that in the defunct Holt County Bank, forces the belief that he has absconded.

The outing of the Hickory Club of the Fifth Ward at College Point, L.I., yesterday, will pass into history as one of the most remarkable ever held in the vicinity of New-York. It typified the intense love, loyalty, and admiration which the members bear toward their President, ex-Senator Michael C. Murphy.

Israel Taylor, a machinist, forty-five years old, living with his wife and family on the top floor of 223 Forty-eighth Street, South Brooklyn, out his throat and then jumped out of a window about 3 o'clock yesterday morning. He rose from his bed and stabbed himself three or four times in the neck and throat with a pocket knife.

Nineteen heavy-eyed young men were arraigned before Police Justice Burke, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday morning. They were members of the Ivy Social Club, an organization said to be mainly devoted to putting down strong drink, which has headquarters at 550 West Forty-fourth Street.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The Venerable Rev. Dr. Thomas McClure Peters, rector of St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Ninety-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New-York, and Archdeacon of the Diocese of New-York, was found dead in bed this morning at the residence of Frederick R. Manser, Jr., 144 Hudson Avenue, this city.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- Notwithstanding the fact that the customs war between Germany and Russia is being fought with much vigor on both sides, the official newspapers of Germany are taking particular pains to nurse the idea that the most friendly relations continue to exist between Emperor William and the Czar, and that even the Berlin and St. Petersburg Governments are on good terms.

William Hurry, whose death occurred last week at an advanced age, was the son of Mrs. Samuel Hurry, who as Eliza Ann Whiteside, then but a very young girl, was a favorite o Washington's. The Whiteside mansion in Philadelphia was near that of Washington, and Mrs. Hurry was the daily playmate of the Custis children.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- M. Lockroy, a former Cabinet Minister, was fired at yesterday by a man named Moore, a notorious Socialist. Lockroy, at the time of the shooting, was ascending a staircase in a house in the Rue Charonne, where his Electoral Committee was sitting.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 13 -- An atrocious case of dog poisoning occurred in Long Island City a few days ago. Seven valuable St. Bernard dogs, owned by Dr. Arthur Ritter, a dog fancier, were Killed by the use of arsenic. Two of the dogs were puppies four and a half months old, and eight weeks ago Dr. Ritter was offered $500 apiece for them, but declined to sell them at any price.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 13 -- About $2,000,000 worth of property was destroyed by fire this afternoon. Over 200 houses are burned and at least 1,500 persons are rendered homeless.

Many Catholics of this city expect to attend the Catholic Congress to be held on the World's Fair grounds, Chicago, the week of Sept. 4. The congress has special interest for members of the Catholic Church here because of the prominent part which will be taken by New-Yorkers in its proceedings.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 13 -- The Department of Marine to-day issued its annual shipping list, giving all statistics up to Dec. 31, 1892. The total shipping on the register books of the Dominion on that date was 7,007 vessels of 964,129 tons, valued at $28,923,870.

Two alarms were struck at 7:20 A.M. yesterday for a fire in A.H. Sonn's manufacturing building and stable, 322 and 324 East Forty-fourth Street. About $2,500 damage was done. A window casing fell on Fireman James Monaghan of Hook and Ladder Company No. 7 and out his scalp severely. He was cared for at a drug store and went home.

A young man, born to wealth, and educated at Princeton, is suddenly impoverished. He is studious and ambitious, and he takes to science. He has already made an honorable name for himself in the field of electrical engineering, when his Boston uncle dies and leaves him a million.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 13 -- Seven thousand pottery workers are out of work in this city. Many of them are actually suffering for the necessaries of life. The potteries have been doing little for over a month, keeping barely enough hands employed to fill the orders on file. Within the last week many of them have been forced to shut down.

New-York possesses the largest fleet of fast ocean-going tugs that can be found on the Atlantic seaboard, and now that yacht races are in season, some of the tugboat owners are asking why a race between tugboats would not be an exciting contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- There were no developments to-day in the Breckinridge-Pollard case, but it was discussed wherever the publication of the filing of the suit against the Congressman had been read. A call at the hotel this evening elicited the information that Mr. Breckinridge had no further statement to make.

It rests with the Senate of the United States to stop the purchase of silver and the issue of Treasury notes therefor, to restore confidence in the value of the currency of the United States, and to remove the chief cause of the disastrous condition into which the business of the country has been plunged.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The following notice to mariners has been issued:

When a Grand Jury of Kings County some time ago revealed the fact that it was prevented from finding indictments, where it believed they would be justified by the evidence, through the interposition of the District Attorney, public attention was directed very sharply to the important relation of the prosecuting officer to the "grand inquest" by which the judicial pursuit of crime is initiated.
