This is a book which it is difficult even to describe and almost impossible to review critically within the limits necessary for a newspaper writer to observe. Its author, the Duke of Argyll, is one of the finest figures in the public life of England during the latter half of the present century.

Michael Kennedy presided yesterday at the meeting of the Executive Board of the drivers employed by the Street-Cleaning Department at 550 East Sixteenth Street. Eight stables were represented, and Kennedy reminded the delegates that in the future all drivers' grievances must be brought before the board.

WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The body of Richard Muser, the lace importer, who shot himself in the head at his country place near, suffern, was buried to-day in the family tomb in Weehawken Cemetery. The services were conducted by the Rev. Mr. Mansfield of the Protestant Episcopal Church of Suffern, which Mr. Muser attended.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Aug. 13 -- There was a rear-end collision on the electric railroad that runs to Prohibition Park this afternoon. The train was crowded with passengers. The cars were wrecked and travel was blocked. No one was seriously injured.

There is a passivity about the ordinary Hindu which makes him rather a tame character in romance. Mrs. Steel's volume contains ten short stories of East Indian life, the most striking of which is entitled "Gunesh Chund." The author brings out particularly the superstitions of the Hindus and how they are bound up in the traditions of the past.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., Aug. 13 -- As the eastbound mail train started from Crawfordsville Junction last night, an attempt was made by half a dozen men to rob the car of the Adams Express Company. When on the edge of the woods, near the junction, C.W. Julier, the messenger, noticed several men hanging on the outside of the car and attempting to enter.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 13 -- To-day's visitors here who found the breeze a trifle too searching for a dip in the sea were consoled for that deprivation by the sights on shore. Magical changes have been worked in the appearance of the island since yesterday, and when the State Firemen's Association comes here Tuesday for its twenty-first annual meeting, the transformation into a forest and canopy of bunting will be complete.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 13 -- The police raided the rooms of the Recreation Club, 17 Avery Street, a gambling establishment, before midnight Friday and seized thousands of dollars' worth of gaming implements and furniture of the most expensive kind.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed a decrease in reserve of $2,527,575. The banks cow hold $16,545,375 less than the legal requirements. The chances in the averages show an increase in loans of $3,078,200, a decrease in specie of $2,305,000, a decrease in legal tenders or $408,000, a decrease in deposits of $741,700, and an increase in circulation of $733,100.
The good full-sail breeze which blew out of the north yesterday afternoon went a long way toward making the annual midsummer regatta of the Oriole Yacht Club Held in Jamaica Bay a decided success.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 13 -- Many yacht owners left Newport this morning for Vineyard Haven, taking advantage of the strong northerly wind that kicked up a rough sea in the Sound. It was exhilarating sailing, and some friendly brushes were indulged in.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 13 -- An important letters relative to the long-existing St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church troubles in Bayonne has been given out by ex-Postmaster Thomas Brady, who led the organized movement recently against the church management. The letter was prepared after weeks of deliberation. It reflects the views of the anti-Killeen party.

Many of the lively political incidents in the old Nineteenth Assembly District when it swept up the west side of the city from West Fifty-Second Street to Spuyten Duyvil Creek took place in the lower end of it. The district fights that ultimately resulted in the Hugh J. Grant group of young men coming so conspicuously to the front in the politics of Tammany Hall and of the city were fought and won there.
Mgr. Satolli is expected to reach this city from Washington at 1:55 o'clock this afternoon. He will be the guest of Archbishop Corrigan.
GOVERNMENT OF CANADA -- "B.M.": Please give me some information about the Government of Canada. Is it rounded on a copy of the British Constitution or of the American?

The Venetian fete, which the Harlem Regatta Association will hold on that river on the evening of Saturday, Sept. 9, promises to be the greatest event of the season on the river, and will probably surpass in interest and beauty the very successful similar fete of last year. The fete last year was under the direction of the Wyanoke Boat Club, which carried it through with most satisfactory results.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The Democratic newspapers of the State are making a demand on the political managers to be careful about the nomination of candidates for Assemblyman and Senator, and not jeopardize the interest of the party by placing in nomination any men who will be the means of stirring up an independent movement.

SING SING, Aug. 13 -- A great throng of people gathered at the Sing Sing Methodist Episcopal camp meeting to-day. The meeting opened Thursday, but to-day was the first crowded attendance. Between 6,000 and 7,000 persons were in attendance. They came in all sorts of conveyances.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Because of the unprecedented amount of garbage and offensive matter that has been washed upon the beaches along the ocean front for several days, the wealthy residents of Far Rockaway, the hotel keepers, and the owners of bathing pavilions have combined to invoke the aid of the State Board of Health in suppressing the nuisance.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 13 -- One of the members of the Board of Lady Managers of the fair has given an account of the recent unpleasantness in the board. The trouble is largely a continuation of the Phoebe Couzins quarrel, which arose shortly after the formation of the board. Mrs. Meredith of Indiana was an active agent in the removal of Miss Couzins from the Secretaryship.

ST. GEORGE, S.I., Aug. 13 -- Philip Johnson, a young man well known in fashionable society in New-Brighton, was arrested yesterday afternoon by Policeman Mitchell at South Beach, on the charge of disorderly conduct. Johnson is a son of Archdescon Johnson, rector of Christ Church, New-Brighton.

The Pennsylvania Battalion of Naval Reserves will leave Philadelphia to-day for this city to embark for a five days' cruise on the United States cruiser San Francisco. The Pennsylvania battalion will be mobilized with the first division of the New-York Naval Brigade from Rochester. The Rochester Battalion is also due to reach this city to-day.

A careful reading of this work leads to results which in one respect may be called unsatisfactory; yet this arises from man's own insignificance. The importance of the subject no one can question. We do grope, and must continue to grope, among the lower forms of life, before we can approach that grander and greater topic which overshadows all, and this is man and his origin.

Mr. Fuller shows some of the sinister aides of Socialism, but has no sympathy with those who take false steps in their endeavors to regenerate the world. There is only one of his characters, Ditton, who once was a clergyman, that it readily has any pity for. Ditton would rather preach the necessity for war than for peace.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- It was largely the stock market that disturbed grain to-day. The action of prices in Wall Street and a break in quotations for Chicago cable securities operated to unsettle the trade. Compared with Saturday night, wheat to-night is 1 1/4 @ 1 1/2 c lower. Corn is down 3/8 @ 5/8 c. Provisions were very quiet to-day, but quotations were pushed up 12 1/2 @ 20 c.

The officers of the Republican State League will hold a meeting to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock at the headquarters of the league in the Madison Square Bank Building, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, to discuss how they may raise funds to conduct a campaign after the style of the practical politicians.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Aug. 14 -- The feature of the day at the American Canoe Association camp was an impromptu race between Howard Gray's racing canoe V. of the Vesper Club, Lowell, Mass., and a twenty-five-foot St. Lawrence River skiff, carrying forty-five feet of sail and a trained crew of seven men. The skiff, the Levolta, came down from Kingston at 3 P.M. and sailed past the camp before a strong westerly wind.

Police Justice Grady expected the parties in the criminal proceedings for perjury in the ease of E.B. Balch against James M. Waterbury, Elisha M. Fulton, Jr., Frank E. Wall, and G. Weaver Leper of the National Cordage Company to appear before him in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday. There were sufficient reasons why they did not do so.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The programme of the Senate outlined by THE NEW-YORK TIMES Saturday morning will be followed by that body. When the Democratic "steering" committee adjourned on Friday, it was with the understanding that so far as the repeal of the obnoxious clause in the Sherman law was concerned there would not be hurried action pending the result of the vote in the House.
When Mrs. A.M. Palmer, fresh from her ocean voyage, waited into the rooms of the Professional Women's League, of which she is President, yesterday afternoon she received an enthusiastic greeting.

William Sinclair pleaded guilty on July 5 to attempted larceny, having broken the window of Leon Sacha's jewelry store at 8 Maiden Lane and endeavored to make off with some rings. When be came up for sentence Inspector McLaughlin happened on the bench with the Judge, and he thought he recognized in Sinclair an old offender.

LIEUT. GEN. SIR EDWARD BRUCE HAMLEY died suddenly in London on Saturday from heart disease. He entered the Royal Artillery in 1943, became a Captain in 1850, a Major and Lieutenant Colonel in 1854, a Colonel in 1863, and a Major General in 1869. He was elected member of Parliament from Birkenhead in 1885, and re-elected in 1886.

The Rev. Dr. Frank L. Wilson married at the Forty-third Street Methodist Episcopal Church on July 10 of this year Bennis T. Smith, twenty-two years old, and Nannie M. Macgavock, a stylish-looking blonde, who gave her age as twenty-three. The witnesses were Mrs. Eva Cochran Wilson and William Vollhart.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The Senate Hotel, a three-story structure in Madison Street, near Fifth Avenue, was burned this morning. Seven persons were killed and many injured. The loss on the building and contents is practically total, but the amount will not exceed a few thousand dollars.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 14 -- The trotting stable of the well-known horseman, John D. Creighton, was burned to the ground at Donerail to-day. Two wellbred fillies perished in the flames, and a third burned nigh unto death. Junemont. 2:14, and John Turner, together with a score of others, were in the building, but were saved.

PAUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The hearing on habeas corpus proceedings obtained in behalf of Edward Meredith, an alleged insane convict, who shot Phil Daly, the gambler, on the afternoon of Dec. 3, 1888, was continued to-day before Judge Barnard in the Supreme Court.

The life of Mrs. Blanche Bradley of 917 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, was saved yesterday by a case of relics which she wore suspended at her throat, but the Siberian bloodhound that attacked her is now dead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Cool weather and bright skies brought to the Capitol a large number of members this morning than was present Saturday, and the speeches on the silver question were listened to with better attention.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Matron Elizabeth Doyle of the Foster Home, on Belleville Avenue, last Friday afternoon, with her assistants, took the children of the home on an excursion to the Shelter House, Coney Island. Among the children was Phoebe Van Weart, who had been placed in the home nine years ago, when she was only four years old.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Albert Zeillon, thirty-four years old, an advertising agent and inventor, committed sucide this morning by shooting himself in the head at his home, 348 Fay Avenue. The top of his head was nearly blown off.

MONCLOVA, Mexico, Aug. 14 -- The trouble over politics in the State of Coahuila is serious, but both native and foreign enterprises will be thoroughly protected by the Federal authorities even should a general conflict between the two political factions occur.

"We are now tabulating the propositions made from all parts of the country as to the solution of the financial difficulty," said Senator R.F. Pettigrew of South Dakota at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

TARRYTOWN, Aug. 14 -- The action of the Second Reformed Church in suspending Gen. Alexander Hamilton from membership shows that the church fully investigated the matter and found him unworthy to remain on the roll of membership. The Rev. E.E. Thomas is pastor of the church.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 -- The speculation to-day has been irregular and dull. Local securities were all strong at higher quotations, and arbitrage and specialties lower in sympathy with the weakness in the New-York market. Northern Pacific securities were the weak features, both the preferred and the common stock declining to the lowest quotations yet reached.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 14 -- The indications point to murder, and not accident, as the cause of the death of Louis L. Norton, the young man who was drowned near the breakwater Friday night.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Aug. 14 -- The State Health Officer of Florida to-day announced that an investigation into the cause of death of the Rev. F.C. Waite and Ellen Wood, who were reported to have died of yellow fever in the City of Pensacola on the 9th of August, has been thoroughly and impartially made. He has been ably assisted by Surgeons W.H. Carter and G. M. Magruder of the United States Marine Hospital Service.

Dr. Robert W. Buchanan, the wife poisoner, was sentenced to die the week beginning Oct. 2 by Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday. He will be removed from the Tombs to Sing Sing on an early train to-day.
GALVESTON, Aug. 14 -- A New-York commercial newspaper recently printed the following:

CONEY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- There was considerable excitement about the Sea Beach Palace Hotel at noon to-day, when flames were discovered coming from the northeast corner of Pain's fireworks inclosure, which adjoins the hotel.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- Inquiries have reached this city as to the state of the Queen's health, it having been reported in certain quarters that she had been stricken with paralysis. The report is entirely without foundation.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 -- The market opened quiet and generally lower, and closed dull and heavy. At the Clearing House this morning there was very little change to note. Money between the banks was in good demand at 7 3-10 and 8 P cent. New-York funds were in request, as is generally the case Mondays. Sales were made from $1 to $2 premium for cash.

Though the National Wall-Paper Trust has been in existence only a little over a year it has already secured a great part of the wall-paper trade, and within the last few weeks it has made a more that will practically wipe out of existence fifty of the largest and best known wall-paper jobbers in this country.

Julian Magnus, Marie Mainwright's manager, has organized a team of Thespian cricketers to play today at Livingston against the Staten Island Cricket Club. Mr. Magnus has canvassed the Rialto and secured a very fair eleven from the professionals now in the city. He has gathered around him Bob Hilliard. H.B. Hollis, N.F. Blande, J. Garland, J. Castle, Harriaon Wolf, A. Bagge, Cecil Magnus, and Ernest Tarleton.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 14 -- The Counties of Ulster and Dutchess and the surrounding country, the most fertile land along the Hudson River, are suffering from a drought so severe that much damage has been done to crops, and farmers are having great difficulty in getting water for their cattle. No rain of any consequence has fallen in a month.

LONDON, Aug. 14 -- American securities opened dull on Saturday's bank statement, but soon steadied and advanced to above parities, when it was found that carrying-over rates were easy. The banks charged 4 1/2 per cent. for loans and contangoes were done at 6 per cent. in the morning, falling to 4 1/2 later, when it was found how small the account was.

The Board of Health, the Street-Cleaning Department, the police, and the Fire Department made a combined attack yesterday on Hester Street and Mulberry Bend. When they got through, those two thoroughfares were no longer redolent with the various odors of stale fruit, flesh, and fish; they were no longer filled with a miscellaneous assortment of push carts and peddlers' wagons.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 -- The annual meeting of the National Croquet Association opens to-morrow on the grounds in this city, and bright and early the members will begin to roll the balls in the opening games of the Twelfth tournament. Eight courts are in complete readiness. They are constructed in The most scientific way, with beds as hard as marble and elastic cushions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Supervising Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service is highly gratified, with the effect of the application of the regulations abroad for the exclusion of cholera.

WOODHAVEN, L.I., Aug. 14 -- William J. Rose, Assistant Foreman of the Brooklyn Hills Fire Department, was struck by a Rockaway Beach train at 11 o'clock last night and instantly killed. He was walking in the out between Myrtle Avenue and the Jamaica Plank Road toward his home at the time of the accident.

As the racing at Clifton goes on from day to day, the poor starting of "Billy" French becomes more than ever apparent. When Mr. French dropped the flag in the first race of the meeting, it was evident that his success in the starter's stand would not be brilliant; but the patrons of the track are, as a rule, liberal, and as it was on the opening day they did not criticise him vary harshly.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 -- The National Convention of the Sons of Veterans began a five days' session here to-day. The National Council spent the day arranging the order of committee reports. The convention proper will open for business at Pike's Opera House to-morrow morning and will close on Friday with an excursion to the Soldiers' Home at Dayton, where the newly-elected officers will be installed.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 14 -- Mrs. Mattie C. Shann faced the most disagreeable part of her long trial to-day, when the defense opened and called witnesses to snow the dark side or her dead boy's character. She had just dried her eyes from continuous weeping because of the touching deathbed scene that Capt. Woodbury Holt had described to the jury as part of his opening address for the defense.

The tariff war between Russia and Germany will tend to increase largely the quantity of rye exported to Germany from this country. Sufficient attention has not been paid in the United States to the European market for this cerea. Very large quantities of rye are consumed in Germany and the other countries of Western Europe.

The Most Rev. Francis Satolli, D.D., Archbishop of Lepanto and Delegate Apostolic to the United States, arrived in this city at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon and is now a guest of Archbishop Corrigan at the episcopal residence, 452 Madison Avenue.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 3 @ 5 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.

Two battalions of Naval Reserves embarked yesterday for a six days' training period at sea on board the United States cruiser San Francisco. The battalions comprise in all about 150 men. One battalion comes from Philadelphia, and the other from Rochester.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 14 -- The score of cotton mills owned and operated by B.B. R. knight of this city, and situated in Rhode Island and Massachusetts, started up this morning after having been stopped a week. The firm is one of the largest, if not the largest, in the country engaged in the manufacture of cotton goods.

ROBY, Ind., Aug. 14 -- "Dan" Creedon of Australia, the middleweight champion of the Colonies and the possessor of the Australian belt, and Alexander Greggains of San Francisco, the champion middleweight of the Pacific coast, came together to-night in the arena of the Columbian Athletic Club for a purse of $5,000 and a side bet of $2,000.

Monmonth Park's managers ware running about the track yesterday trying to find that "era of prosperity" that one of the Executive Committee had announced as having set in, through the columns of his paper. They were not able to find any trace of it. But they did find evidences of financial stringency in the treasury that makes the stringenoy in the city look like a perfect deluge of wealth, comparatively.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Aug. 14 -- The smoke from a clambake caused a false alarm of fire here yesterday. When the Empire Hose Company reached the spot Chief Engineer McCormick, it is said, accused Charles Doscher, one or the oldest members of the company, of sending in the alarm. Doscher claims that Mc Cormick at the same time began striking and pushing him. He retaliated.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 14 -- The outlook in the iron and steel trade is brighter to-day than it has been before since the financial troubles began.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Aug. 14 -- The run of the New-York Yacht Club's fleet to this port to-day was a fairly successful one, although there was no windward work and nothing but running and reaching. The Vigilant, Jubilee, and Colonia of the cup defenders made a lively race, which was finally won by the Vigilant, with the Jubilee second.

The result of the run of the yachts from Newport to Cottage City gives new point to the suggestion made in THE TIMES that important yacht races in general and the race for the Goetet Cup in particular should he sailed subject to a time limit, and should not be deemed to be won or lost in case that limit were exceeded.

Bryan L. Kennelly had the only sale of the day yesterday at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway. It was a sale under foreclosure of mortgage, Charles J. Breck, referee, of the property 237 East Forty-fifth Street north side, 200 feet west of Second Avenue. The lot is 25 by 100.5, and there is a five-story brick tenement with store upon it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Another big crowd saw the fair to-day. Everything indicates that this week will see a greater number of persons at Jackson Park than have paid to see the fair any previous week. The record from last Monday until Saturday night showed an average of more than 100,000 admissions daily. These are the best figures Horace Tucker's department has been able to give out thus far in the World's Fair season.

The investigation made by the Florida State Board of Health tends to prove that there really have been no cases of yellow fever in Pensacola, and this conclusion is supported by the fact that no additional cases have appeared there in the ten days which have passed since the two persons who were supposed to have died of this disease were taken ill.

Little Griffin, the Brooklyn centre fielder, opened the game at the Polo Grounds yesterday in a very lively manner, hitting the first ball that Rusie pitched for a clean home run. While the fleet-footed base runner was clearing the circuit, the big pitcher looked on in astonishment. He smiled a ghastly smile, rolled up his sleeves, and retired the three following batsmen with ease.

The exclusive announcement in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday that Francis H. Weeks, the absconding lawyer, was to be expelled from the University Club on charges preferred by Mrs. Nicholas Fish, through Sherman Evarts, revived interest in Weeks's career and brought about much gossip in legal, banking, and club circles.

It is a considerable tribute to British rule in India that riots between different factions and sects of the natives should be so infrequent. The collision in Bombay between the Mohammedans and the Hindus affords a striking suggestion of what would be likely to happen in the peninsula if British rule were withdrawn.

When business began in Wall Street yesterday morning, the demand for currency was lighter than it had been on Saturday, and the premium upon it was lower. There was less of a crowd in the offices of the money brokers, and, for the first time in a week, their trade in cash seemed to languish.
LIVERPOOL, Aug. 14 -- American live cattle, sinking the offal, 5 7/8d lb. Bleaching powder. $8.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 14 -- The Council of this city has received a communication from the Board of Trade of Cincinnati regarding the proposal to connect the two cities by a ship canal. The communication is in the form of a series of resolutions.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 14 -- An enterprising burglar broke into the house of Capt. Henry Bunce late Saturday night and probably figured himself out as a modern Monte Cristo as be staggered off under a load of greenbacks he had found in one of the old sea Captain's chests which he had rifled.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 14 -- The third annual rifle competition under the direction of the New-Jersey State Rifle Association was opened this morning. Gov. Werts's flag was ran up in front or his headquarters and the Governor himself was on the range for two hours under the escort of Gen. Bird Spencer, Chief Inspector of Rifle Practice, and Post Adjt Delancey G. Walker.
Collector Kilbreth had many callers yesterday. Among them .. ere Timothy J. Campbell, J. Rhinelander Dillon, Congressman Ryan, and Capt. John White of Boston.

We have not thought it the wisest policy to undertake at the special session any measure of currency reform beyond the simple repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act. That much the country urgently needs; for the further amendment and perfection of its currency system it can safely wait a few months.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 -- Sufficient time has elapsed since the recent Democratic Convention to obtain a good idea of now its work has been received throughout the State. Everywhere among Democrats there is enthusiasm for the ticket. The candidates are all well-known and popular men, standing high in their communities and most of them with more than local reputation.

A suit for damages resulting from an assault growing, curiously enough, out of a horse's love for apples was begun yesterday in the City Court by Samuel Ziswalt of 17 Norfolk Street against Charles Gottlieb of 15 Norfolk Street.

The "first-nighters." so long exiled from the Madison Square Theatre, had another chance last evening to see again the severely-decorated interior of that place of amusement. The "Trip to Chinatown." champion lingerer in New-York's appreciative lap, had at last departed, and "The New South." a play with an infinite amount of energy in its action and an infinitesimal number of R's in its dialogue, took the vacant place.

Justice O'Brien, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, appointed Sarah M. Warner or 313 West Thirty-second Street, guardian ad litem of Mrs. Cora Warner Yamasaki, the eighteen-year-old wife of Norges Yamasaki, who claims to be a Japanese artist.

It is seldom that a new member so impresses himself upon the House as did Mr. Hendrix of Brooklyn on Saturday. His speech was his maiden effort in that body, and as a clear exposition of sound financial views, it held the earnest attention of his colleagues to the close.

Although it is reported that the cities and the neighboring farming districts in the Northwest are overrun with unemployed men, the farmers cannot obtain the workmen who are needed for harvesting the crops. The unemployed, it is said, refuse to work upon the plea that wages are too low.

The patrons of the Clifton race track nave been unkind enough to say of Starter French that he is a poor starter, and uses the worst judgment. His start in the sixth race yesterday proved that his poor starting has been due to poor eyesight, and not to poor Judgment.

The Directors of the Manhattan Railway Company declined yesterday to build the elevated railroad extensions proposal by the Rapid-Transit Commission. Announcement to this effect was conveyed to the commission in the afternoon in a note from George J. Gould, President of the Manhattan Company, inclosing a resolution of the Directors that in the present condition of business they did not wish to undertake new contracts.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 -- The tournament games of the National Croquet Association began at 8 o'clock this morning. A cool breeze swept across the grounds and the forest background shaded three of the courts during the earlier hours of the day The mombers of the association who were present and had entered for the championship in the three divisions were:

Only twice this season have the New-Yorks failed to score a run in a game. A few weeks ago Stein of the Brooklyns kept the Giants down to a few scattering hits, and did not allow one of the local players to reach the home plate.

In spite of recent official declarations from the managers of the Northern Pacific Railroad that the finances of that company were all right, the road was placed in the hands of receivers yesterday. The application for a receivership was made by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company "to protect the interests of the property."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The fifth meeting of the Grand Circuit series began here this afternoon with the same perfect weather that has favored the horses since they started at Pittsburg six weeks ago. There was nothing of special attraction for the opening, so that the attendance was below 3,000.

The death at Toulouse is announced in Paris of Gen. de Lartigue, former Commandant of the Twelfth Army Corps, leader at Reischoffen of the charge of the Cuirassiers, which music, poems, and all iconography, from a painting by Detaille to colored prints of Epinal, exalt in France as one of the rare brilliant deeds in the Franco-Prussian war.
John H. Rowland, a Director, and one of the heaviest stockholders of the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, said yesterday that the bank was not in a condition to resume business.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15 -- Mackenzie Bowell, Acting Premier, received the following cable from the Premier, Sir John Thompson, at noon to-day:

Messrs, Magone, Dunn, and Macfarlane praceeded yesterday with their work of investigating the Surveyor's office. A number of United States weighers and assistant weighers were questioned as to the dally routine of their duties, among them John P. Rogers, an Assistant Weigher in the Second District, whose work is upon the Hamburg and Thingvalla Dooks in Hoboken.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- The market has been stagnant and, with the exception of light offerings of Northern Pacific securities, there has been no particular feature. Small lots of Metropolitan and Philadelphia Traction changed hands at a slight decline from yesterday's closing. Lehigh Valley was arm around 32 on buying for investment.

Readers of THE TIMES are familiar with the fact that, from the time Mr. BLAINE consented to submit to arbitration the questions which he had so laboriously argued in behalf of our Government, it has maintained that the decision of those questions in a manner opposed to his contentions was inevitable.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The premium on currency increasing the discount on New-York drafts here today was chiefly what knocked 5/8 c off the price of wheat. Corn suffered also to the extent of 3/8 c. There was a decided scarcity of offerings of provisions. Compared with last night pork is up 27 1/2 c, lard 17 1/2 c, and ribs 20c.

The Rev. Sylvester Malone of the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul, Williamsburg, yesterday celebrated the forty-ninth anniversary of his ordination. The celebration was simple, although the parishioners were desirous of making the occasion a public jubilee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The proceedings in the House to-day, notwithstanding the interest in the silver question, wore uninteresting. Expectation was aroused by the announcement that Mr. Bourke Cookran would speak for unconditional repeal and Mr. Bryan of Nebraska would be heard in advocacy of free coinage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- James H. Blount, who was appointed Commissioner to investigate Hawaiian affairs, and who subsequently received the appointment of United States Minister to Hawaii, returned from Honolulu this morning on the steamer Gaelic, after a sojourn there of over four months. The announcement of his departure was made public only the day before he sailed, although the Government had been previously notified.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- A good idea of the activity and thoroughness of Dr. Young, who is at Naples fur the Marine Hospital Service, may be obtained from his correspondence with the Supervising Surgeon General. A week ago Dr. Wyman received the letter in which Dr. Young detailed his discovery of the cholera in Naples, very soon after it had appeared.

A woman, apparently a German, about thirty-two years of age and dressed in very ordinary attire, shot herself twice in the head with a revolver in Central Park yesterday morning, and died from the effects of the wounds at the Presbyterian Hospital about two hours and a half later. There was nothing found on her person to disclose her identity.

Probably not many readers will read the account of the impressive service at the cathedral, in which the Papal Delegate and the Archbishop of New-York took part, without some sense of the incongruity of the ceremony with the relations of the dignitaries who took the principal parts in it. This is a feeling which not even the eloquent and touching professions of loyalty by the Archbishop, in his address, will altogether suffice to dispel.
The United States Open Air Horse and Cattle Show Society will soon be a thing of the past. From the very outset fortune has refused to smile on the association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Surgeon General Tryon of the Navy Medical Corps has made a carious discovery regarding that branch of the navy, and proposes to correct the inconsistency which carelessness and custom have wrought.

From The New-York Times of Jan. 6, 1891. Mr. Blaine's letter of Dec. 17. 1890, to the British Minister puts a new face upon the Alaska seal question, opens the way to a just and sensible settlement of our dispute with Great Britain, and sends grim-visaged war somewhat more than twenty marine leagues to the rear.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Dr. S.H. Frazer. President of the Newark Wheelman, has received from the Atalanta Wheelmen the decision of Referee Merseles on the protest of the Kings County Wheelmen against the award of the piano to the Newark Wheelmen for finishing the greatest number of men in the recent road race to Princeton and return. The decision reads:

Thirty-nine crippled but very happy children left New-York yesterday for a three weeks outing at Asbury Park. They came from the Orthopedic Hospital at 126 and 128 East Fifty ninth Street, and they ranged in sizes from little ones in arms to children of fourteen years of age.

What is the basis of their hope we do not know, or even if the hope professed by them is sincere, but the opponents of the unconditional repeal of the silver purchase law express a good deal of confidence that they will be able to secure from Congress some sort of an unlimited coinage act on a new ratio.

In spite of the writ of habeas corpus served on the Superintendent of Bloomingdale Asylum for the Insane. David J. Solomon, who was sent to the asylum on Aug. 7, the day before he was to marry Miss Clara Perry Thomas, was not produced in the Supreme Court yesterday. He was confined on the certificates of two physicians, who said he was suffering from paresis.

RIFLE, Col., Aug. 15 -- It is reported to-night that war has broken out between the cattlemen and sheepmen on the Mesa, north of Parachute, and that three cattlemen are killed and the sheepmen penned up in a canon and fighting stubbornly.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, Aug. 15 -- P.M. Dullness approaching stagnation prevailed in to-day's stock market. London bought a few stocks in the morning, principally St. Paul and Louisville and Nashville, but the demand was not heavy, and was readily supplied.

Maurice J. Power, who was recently appointed Shipping Commissioner at this port, vice James C. Reed, did not assume the duties of his office yesterday, although he was duly sworn in by United States Commissioner Shields. The reason for his not taking possession of the office as explained by him last night, was that his bond had not been filed in time for him to assume the duties yesterday.

The financial disturbance has postponed an extension of rapid transit in this city indefinitely. The reply of the Manhattan Railway Company to the last proposition of the Rapid Transit Commission is simply that in the present situation of financial affairs it cannot undertake any new contracts requiring large outlays of capital.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 15 -- The Iowa League at Republican Clubs met in annual session at Calvary Tabernacle to-day, with about 700 members in attendance, besides hundreds of delegates to the State Convention, which meets to-morrow.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Aug. 15 -- Recently the Manitoba and Northwestern Railroad passed into the hands of a receiver. At the time he took hold the wages of all employes for the months of April and May and part of June had not been paid. The receiver applied to the courts for power to pay these wages, but the application was strongly opposed by the English bondholders.

The fourth World's Fair excursion train of the New-York Central, which left the Grand Central Station yesterday morning, carried 1,032 passengers. This is almost twice as many as have patronized any previous excursion train, and furnishes conclusive evidence both of the popularity of these excursions and of the New-York Central route.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The news or the decision reached by the Paris arbitrators in the Bering Sea case has excited intense interest in Washington, and opinions differ as to the meaning of the decision.
Rutgers Place was very much excited yesterday morning by a fire that occurred in a five-story tenement house. One woman was badly turned and will probably die, and many people had narrow escapes.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The Times says: "On the broad questions of international law the decision is wholly in our favor. In framing the regulation we have been somewhat less successful. The rules are conceived in a spirit according closely enough with that embodied in the British proposals, but it is probable that some of them will cause dissatisfaction in Canada.

Police Justice Grady, feeling that Ernest B. Balch or his attorney, Ambrose H. Purdy, trifled with the court in neglecting to press to a hearing on Monday the charges of perjury against James M. Waterbury and his Cordage Trust associates, has written a sharp letter to Mr. Purdy on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- One of the moat important events in the ordnance world will take place in a week or two at the naval ordnance proving ground at Indian Head. It is the testing of the first thirteen-inch gun built for the navy.
Commissioner Andrews of the Street-Cleaning Department sent the following letter to the Police Commissioners yesterday:

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The six or seven thousand spectators of the Creedon-Greggains fight at Roby last night had an experience that should make the more respectable among them think twice about appearing again at any similar gathering. They were cooped up for three boars in a monster wooden barn called by courtesy an arena, with but two narrow exits.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- The application for a receiver for Warren F. Leland's popular Chicago Beach Hotel has caused a misapprehension that Mr. Leland asks to be corrected. The hotel is running as if no such application had been made.

The question of superiority between the two catrigged yachts Hebe and Cassie, which has agitated the baymen of Jamaica Bay for two seasons, was decided yesterday afternoon. The Hebe won. Besides deciding the question of superiority, there was a purse of $100 at stake. Capt. Daniel Comelins of Rockaway Beach was chosen judge and Messrs. Albert Foraker and John Timson of New-York were timers.

FLATBUSH, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Dennis McCue, a private coachman for James Kane, a broker of 99 Wall Street, New-York, had a fierce encounter this morning with his master's big St. Bernard, Rover, which went mad at Mr. Kane's home, on Irving Place.
Inspector McLaughlin's quarters at Police Headquarters looked like a room in a wholesale cloth house yesterday, for all around the walls large packages of cloth were piled up.

The team of Thespians which Julian Magnus took down to Livingston yesterday to play a cricket game with the Staten Island Cricket Club returned to the city a very tired body of men. The islanders, having disposed of them for 71 runs, kept them busy hunting the leather for nearly three hours while they compiled the enormous total of 371.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. Mattie Shann was the principal witness in her own behalf today in her trial for poisoning her son. and she testified with calmness and preoision. When the all-important question was put to her by ex-Senator George Vanderbilt whether she ever dissolved the antiseptic tablets and gave thom to her son John, she quickly brushed the heavy veil from her face, rose from her chair, and said:

Twenty-one Chinamen, large and small, were on board the steamer Yucatan from Havana, when she reached her pier yesterday. Special Chinese Inspector Scharf and Deputy Collector Gunner spent the afternoon investigating their stories.

POUGHKREPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- This morning Dr. Allison resumed his answer to Dr. O'Sullivan'a cross-questions in the Meredith hearing. Dr. Allison said he had received a number of reports of Meredith's violence and of his Attempts to influence other inmates, but on close questioning, he admitted that he could not give the names of the persons who made the reports.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 15 -- On the padded stage of the Coney Island Athletic Club, an arena dedicated to fistic war, King John Y. McKane, Lord Absolute of the island, stood to day and made a peace offering. The offering was a huge golden key, and with it all of the 700 men who sat in the boxes and seats about the ring were, in theory, supposed to receive the freedom of Coney Island.

The United States cruiser San Francisco, with the Naval Reserve contingent of Philadelphia and Rochester on board, yesterday steamed out to sea, whore during the next few days the young gentlemen who have temporarily donned the unfamiliar garb of Uncle Sam's blue jackets will have an opportunity to show how much or how little they know about seamanship and other matters which concern naval men.

An awning in front of Henry Eisler's Red Star furniture store, at 75 Bowery, caught fire at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, and although the fire did little damage the Bowery for a time was the scene of great excitement.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Gen. Alexander Hamilton, when seen to-night at the home of his son, the Rev. Alexander Hamilton, rector of Emmanuel Episcopal Church, Lyons Plains, town of Weston, six miles from here, was willing to express himself freely and fully in regard to the stories told in the press about him.

Ex-Minister Edward J. Phelps of Vermont, who was one of the counsel representing this Government in the Bering Sea arbitration, read with much apparent interest yesterday the cabled report of the decision of the arbitrators. When he had finished he looked up smilingly and said:

NYACK, Aug. 15 -- At Tomkins Cove, Rockland County, this morning Henry Smith went into his yard, put a dynamite cartridge into his mouth, and lighted a fuse which was attached. When the explosion occurred Smith's head was blown off and his left hand and arm were gone. The dead man leaves a wife.

"Poste Restante, Panama, Central America," was the address of Francis Henry Weeks, the trust funds embezzler, late in July. At least this statement was made yesterday morning at a meeting of lawyers representing trust clients of Weeks.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 15 -- There was a short session of the Grand Jury at the Court House to-day. No witnesses appeared, and the jurors merely discussed informally some of the testimony before them about policy shop keepers. As Judge Lippincott is on his vacation it was not thought worth while to vote upon any case. A long session will be held a week from Thursday, when Judge Lippincott will have returned.
PARIS, Aug. 15. -- The decision of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration was handed down at 11:07 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- There is a slight improvement to-night in the condition of Representative Oates of Alabama. Last night he was restless and feverish, but passed a comfortable day, and there is a slight relaxation in the pains in his head. Mrs. Oates is expected here tomorrow.

The effect of requiring the strict enforcement of reasonable sanitary regulations at ports of departure in Italy has been to stop the shipment of emigrants from that country. It will be recalled that the Karamania sailed from Naples two or three days before the presence of cholera in that city was discovered by Dr. YOUNG, the competent and faithful representative of the Marine Hospital Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Another big armor plate will be attacked at the naval ordnance proving ground at Indian Read. The plate comes from the Bethlehem Works and is 17 inches in thickness. It represents 775 tons of armor, intended for the barbettes of the battle ship Oregon.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 15 -- The townspeople here are very busy just at present congratulating themselves over the completion of their new Town Hall, the agitation for which began three years ago. Summit has many fine buildings, the majority of them private residences, but up to date the public offices have been in most unpretentious and somewhat ramshackle buildings.

RICHMOND, Va. Aug. 15 -- The Democratic State Convention meets here Thursday to nominate Governor, Lieutenant Governor, and Attorney General, and to adopt a platform of principles. So far as the selection or the head of the ticket is concerned, that is practically settled. Congressman C.T. O'Ferrall of Rockingham will, unless something unusual occurs, secure this place.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 15 -- Senator Chandler of the United States Senate Committee on Elections makes an exhaustive report, in which he declares that Senator John Martin was not elected. In his argument he says:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Although no plan of action has been decided upon by the majority in the Senate regarding the proposition to repeal the purchasing provision of the Sherman law, the silver question is now well to the front in that body. It came up to-day on the resolution offered by Mr. Lodge of Massachusetts last week, calling for immediate debate and a vote on the proposition not later than Aug. 22.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 1/2 @ 5 cent. The last loan was made at 4 cent.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 15 -- Zimmerman pushed his wheel six times around the half-mile trick as National Park this afternoon and was rewarded with jewelry, each piece representing a first prize, vained in the aggregate at $525. His choicest winning was in the one-mile international, for which he got a big diamond valued at $250, a mate to one of the same value which he captured yesterday.

At Bergen Point yesterday the Albion Club were very badly defeated by a team of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, which gained a victory by 147 runs in a hollow fashion. A. Gunn and C.H. Eilis did some great batting for the winners, with excellent contributions of 63 and 58, while J. Mitchel's 17 was the best effort of the Alblons. The score:

The Temple Ahawath, corner of Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue, was at 6 o'clock last evening the scene of a pretty wedding. The bride was Miss Pauline Theodora Guinsburg, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Theodore Guinsburg, and the bridegroom Moses J. Conn. The officiating clergymen were the Rev. Dr. Alexander Kobut and the Rev. David Cohn of the Temple Rodoph Scholom, Lexington Avenue and Sixty-third Street.

Aubrey Crocker will sail for Liverpool to-day to take charge of the Navahoe. All hope, however, has not been given up in Mr. Carroll's yacht winning some races. It is expected that her new Captain will get the best sailing qualities out of the craft. Capt. Crocker will race her for the Cape May and Breton's Reef Cups.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Mr. Gladstone announced in the House of Commons to-day that he had received a private telegram from Paris to the effect that, with a few exceptions, the award of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration was satisfactory to British interests.

An important meeting of the Directors of the New-York, New-Haven, and Hartford Railroad was held in the offices of the company at the Grand Central Station in this city yesterday. President Charles P. Clark, who returned from Europe last week, presided. Action on the financial crisis was taken.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 15 -- Nearly everyone connected with the fleet of the New-York Yacht Club was disappointed to-day. The run was from Vineyard Haven to New-Bedford, and a fresh breeze blew from the southwest all day long. This made it a beat to windward to Quick's Hole and then a reach to the finish -- Clark's Point.

Postmaster Dayton made the employes of the Post Office happy yesterday by paying them a fortnight's wages instead of compelling them to wait until the end of the calendar month. In all $95,000 was paid out in the main building and the various branches, and the men were given currency instead of checks.

William McGlory, the former divekeeper who has been in jail since June 30 for contempt of court in refusing to pay a bill for liquors bought of Lanahan Son of Baltimore, was released yesterday afternoon. McGlory owed $1,200, but had paid $200 on account.

The Recorder's sudden conversion to the cause of free-silver coinage has a queer look. That newspaper announced in its issue of Monday that even if it were alone among Eastern newspapers it was going to fight "for the people against the plutocracy," and continued in this singular strain:

BOSTON, Aug. 16 -- The market opened quiet and generally weak. The closing was irregular, but generally above the lowest. It is reported here that the General Electric will close down its works at Lynn to-morrow and resume next Monday on half time, or three days in the week. This has not yet been confirmed. At the Clearing House this morning the situation was quiet, and little actual change in conditions was noted.

Very likely the Viceroy of India had reason when he rebuked the authorities of Bombay for allowing two religious processions of "natives" of "opposite religions faith" to take place on the streets of Bombay on the same day. But the Indian calendar, whether Hindu or Mohammedan, presents its festivals and saints' days according to the full of the moon, or other natural phenomenon, and takes no account of other calendars.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 16 -- The Republican State Convention assembled this morning with every county in the state represented. ExSenator Harlan, who was a member of President Lincoln's Cabinet, was made temporary Chairman, and made an hour's speech, favoring harmony in the Republican ranks. Prohibition, he said, was not one of the principles of Republicanism.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- After the race for the Albert Cup in the regatta of the Royal Albert Yacht Club on Monday the owner of the Satanita lodged a protest againat the cup being awarded to the Britannia, which was first to cross the line. The protest was based on the ground that the Britannia had forced the Satanita to put about on a wrong tack, thus causing her to fall behind.
Mgr. Satolli performed in Archbishop Corrigan's house last evening his first official act as Papal Delegate to the United States since his arrival in this city Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Col. Charles T. O'Ferrall, the steadfast friend of Mr. Cleveland in Virginia when it was not so easy to be a Cleveland man as it is to-day, will be nominated tomorrow for Governor or Virginia, and possibly without opposition enough to make it worth while to count the votes against him.
A poor, lean, old, white horse, harnessed to a truck driven by Charles Powers of 217 Navy Street, Brooklyn, started to wend its weary way over the bridge about 6 o'clock last evening to Brooklyn.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In your issue of July 19, under the heading of "Louisian's Interest Fund," there is an item of New-Orleans news, under date 18th same month, stating that there was a surplus of fully $400,000 to the credit of the interest fund, and that the state Board of Liquidation had decided to invest it in Louisiana consolidated bonds.
"This is no way to do business," remarked Mayor Gilroy at yesterday's meeting of the Quarantine Commission in his office.

The Jubilee of Music, an annual event, will begin at Manhattan Beach to-night, and in Pain's Outdoor Theatre it will be celebrated in befitting style after the "Storming of Vicksburg." The memory of P.S. Gilmore will be recalled in a mammoth fire picture, and after it will be shown the portrait of Sousa. Gold versus Silver will also have a prominent place.

In spite of the magnificent tennis weather yesterday afternoon, but one match was played in the tennis tournament of the Staten Island Cricket Club. Trafford and Pierson, the latter allowing fifteen and one-quarter, faced each other in the semi-final round of the singles. Trafford is better known on the football field than on the tennis court, but plays a good game for so heavy a man.

Damodar Gordhundas, a wealthy merchant of Bombay, is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, and the news of the trouble in Bombay surprised him very much. His family and business interests are in that city, and late last night he cabled to get the exact condition of a flairs. He expects an answer to-day.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 16 -- The Township Committee of Linden last night, by a vote of 7 to 1 granted a license for five years to the Linden race track and fixed on $5,000 a year as the fee which the Blood Horse Association should pay anaually for the big privilege. Very few persons in the township knew that at last night's meeting a license would be applied for.

"How do you feel charley" asked the "Well! well! well!" crank of President Byrne after his team had been detested by the Giants on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. All through the contest this peer of all enthusiasts kept a shouting for the New-Yorks. At each good play by his favorites he dove, down in his pocket, took therefrom an amber-colored flask and smiled with himself.

Frank Stockvis, the salesman for William Cutajar of 80 1/2 Pearl Street, who disappeared from Ridgefield, Conu., July 11. is in South Dakota. F.W. Frischen of 138 Maiden Lane has received a telegram from a South Dakota mercantile house asking for references as to Stockvis's character.

The racing at Clifton yesterday was fully who was promised by the good card. The number of starters in some of the races was depleted by numerous scratches, but just enough were left to make the contests exciting.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- This was a great night at the World's Fair. The nations of the world intermingled at a ball. Every class of all peoples was there. The Natatorium Building, where the grand fete was held, contained thousands of people, who gladly paid $3 to participate.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 16 -- At the county line trestle on the Atlantic and Danville Road, just east of Milton, this morning, at 2:50 o'clock, two passenger coaches and a sleeper were precipitated into the creek below, a distance of sixty feet, killing seven persons outright and wounding a number of others.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 32@4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

One of the victims of the iron rule of the Czar of Russia, of whom George Kennan wrote in his articles on the exiles of Siberia, is at the Astor House. He is a man of high, intelligence, educated in the universities, and a novelist who has written a dozen or more books.

Has been used for over fifty years by millions of mothers for their children whle teething, with perfect success. It soothes the child, softens the gums, aliays al pain, cures wind co c and is the best remedy for harrhea. Sold by al druggists in every part of the world. Twenty-five cents a bottle.

The rapid transit situation looked by no means desperate yesterday, even with the Manhattan Company out of the field. At to-day's meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission, with the way now clear for new plans and with no excuse for farther reliance upon Mr. Gould and his associates. Commissioner John H. Starin will urge that the commission proceed to lay out an independent line.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 16 -- Three reckless and daring men made a desperate attempt last night to break into the Queens County Jail in this city to liberate friends. They got into the jail, but not in the way they expected to get in.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug 16 -- The last squadron run of the fleet of the New-York Yacht Club was sailed to day. It was from New-Bedford back to Newport. Now the races for the Astor Cup have to be sailed, and then the fleet will disband.

Collis P. Huntington, President of the Southern Pacific system, was asked yesterday for an expression of opinion on the situation, so far as it relates to the transcontinental lines. He said that he was not in possession of the necessary information to talk about the transcontinental lines generally. He did know about the Southern Pacific, however, and he considered that property in very good shape.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 16 -- Trade in wheat was moderately active to-day. In corn and oats it was light, while in provisions the brokers ensconced themselves in their arm chairs and went to sleep. The tendency of prices was downward. Compared with yesterday's closing prices, wheat was 1/2c lower, corn was off 1/4c, and oats were from 1/8c to 3/8c lower.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- The cup presented to Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry, a picture of which was given in Wednesday's NEW-YORK TIMES, is much admired by the yachtsmen on the cruise. Many have not seen the piece of silver, but from the picture in THE TIMES they have been enabled to get a most excellent idea of it.

Currency was in considerable demand again yesterday and the premium was as high as on Tuesday. That is, the bulk of the business in the money brokers' offices was done at 2 to 2 1/2 per cent., with a number of transactions at 3 per cent. The price paid by the brokers to sellers of currency ranged from 1 to 1 1/2 per cent.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Bridget McKiernan of 85 Kearny Avenue was this morning committed to the county jail without bail for a murderous assault upon her husband, John McKiernan. The woman keeps a fruit stand in Washington Market and if wealthy, owning several houses. She had $1,5000 in her pocket when arrested.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 18 -- No little disappointment was manifested this morning when it was learned that the team from the Seventy first New-York National Guard had failed to arrive to participate in the regimental team and the Inter-State matches which were shot for today on the range of the New-Jersey State Rifle Association.

The Directors of the Manhattan Railway Company exhibited a spirit quite characteristic of that corporation in their curt reply to the Rapid-Transit Commission that, owing to the present disturbed financial condition of the country, they deem it unwise at this time to "assume or make any new large contracts or extensions of their line."

The trouble in Bombay began Aug. 11 A number of Mohammedans and Hindus became involved in a dispute which soon led to a general riot. The Mohammedans were observing one of the festivals commanded by the Koran, while the Hindus were also taking part in celebrating a day set apart for religious observance.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 16 -- Twenty-five years ago to-day Cardinal Gibbons was elevated to a Bishopric in the Roman Catholic Church. Although his silver jubilee occurred to-day, yet there was no celebration of the event. The ceremonies that naturally attend upon such an occasion have been postponed until some time in October.
BOMBAY, Aug. 16 -- The religions race rioting was resumed in this city to-day, and for several hours the streets were the scenes of desperate conflicts.
The Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank in Brooklyn were in secret session for three hours yesterday at the office of William N. Dykman, counsel for the bank, at 191 Montague Street.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 16 -- On the Texas and Pacific Railroad Sunday night about 11 o'clock, at Mansfield, La., two men mounted the blind baggage platform and two others mounted the platform at the end of the express car. These were ordered off by the porter. Instead of complying they sent him running terrified through the train by pointing pistols at his head.

LUNG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 16 -- A daring masked burglary was perpetrated at 3 o'clock this morning in the Ravens wood section of this city. It was entirely successful the burglars getting away with $450, the savings of years of Patrick Leahn and his aged wife, who were the victims of the robbery.

The announcement in THE NEW-YORK TIMES that the address of Francis Henry Weeks at the end of last month was Panama, Central America, and the presentation of the facts of his social and criminal career, were read with interest and much commented on yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The arrival of Minister Blount at San Francisco was not a surprise to the State Department. Some time in July Mr. Blount informed the President of his intention to leave Honolulu for San Francisco. He stated that be would sail on Aug. 6, and on his arrival at San Francisco would leave almost immediately for Washington.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, Aug. 16 -- P.M. The market opened at fractional declines, but there was no marked pressure to sell, as many suspected there would be, on the announcement of the Northern Pacific receivership. That that event had been pretty thoroughly discounted was evident from the fact that the preferred stock carried a premium for loaning.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 16 -- A Denver music house has secured a judgment against ex-United States Senator Stephen W. Dorsey for $450 for a piano. The piano has a history.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- The Hearing as to the sanity of Edward Meredith was concluded this afternoon, and Judge Barnard will give a decision within a few days.

Thomas E. Oakes and Henry C. Rouse, two of the new receivers appointed for the Northern Pacific Railroad, were in consultation in the offices of the company yesterday. They did not, however, take formal possession of the property, some necessary details yet remaining to be arranged. When they do get down to work they are likely to encounter some perplexing financial problems in the adjustment of the company's widely-distributed and urgent debts.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 16 -- Traffic over the Shore Line Branch of the Consolidated Road was stopped for five hours this evening owing to a discovery at the old Quinnipeac Bridge at Fair Haven.

ST. PAUL. Minn., Aug. 16 -- The question of moving the 100,000,000 bushels of wheat now being harvested by the farmers of Minnesota and the Dakotas is one of paramount importance, and the leading bankers of St. Paul and Minneapolis have held a conference to discuss ways and means of meeting the emergency.

A special meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Actors' Fund of America has been called by the President. Mr. A.M. Palmer, to consider the new plan to secure an income to the Fund proposed by Mr. Louis Aldrich. The meeting will be held in Mr. Palmer's office, at Palmer's Theatre, next Monday afternoon.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 16 -- The apparatus brought to Coney Island by the firemen from up the State is marveloua for its beauty of construction. It is hard to imagine a handsomer hose carriage than the parade carriage of Washington Hose Company No. 2 of Peekskill. This machine stands on a framework of steel, with ball-bearing wheels 7 feet in diameter, and is a mass of silver plating.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 16 -- His Imperial Highness, Prince Komotou Youbito, the heir of the royal Japanese house of Komotou No May a and a cousin of the Mikado, was a passenger by the steamer Empress of Japan, which arrived here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Those persons who were yesterday disposed to believe that the United States fared badly in the decision at Paris of the Bering Sea arbitration are feeling better to-day since reading the news from Canada. And a little reflection has made it apparent to those who had taken the view of Mr. Blaine that they should have been prepared for just the disappointment they have met.

Prof. Charles A. Reason, said to be the oldest teacher and Principal of the public schools of this city, died yesterday at his residence, 242 East Fifty-third Street, from Bright's disease. Prof. Reason was a colored man and was born in 1818 in this city of parents who were refugees from Haiti. His parents were well to do and sent him to school early in life.

CANARSIE, L.I., Aug. 16 -- William Van Ahnen's Hotel, one of the largest on Canarsie, was burned to-night. It was a threestory building with pavilions, at the grove, about three-quarters of a mile from the shore.
Herter Brothers, builders of 191 Broadway, made a satisfactory arrangement with their creditors yesterday.

With reference to the reported failure of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad Company to carry out its agreement for the purchase of the Indianapolis, Decatur and Springfield Road, an officer of the first-named company said yesterday
CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 16 -- President Cleveland's message not having been telegraphed here. It has just been received by mail. Speaking of the message, a prominent banker said:

H.H. Warner, the manufacturer of proprietary medicines at Rochester, N.Y., who has an office at 41 Broadway, this city, and who was forced to make an assignment some time ago, sailed for Europe early this month. Some of his creditors did not know of his intended departure and started sensational stories about its alleged suddenness and secrecy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Voorhees bill to increase the circulation of national banks was laid over in the Senate to-day. Before this was done, an important amendment was proposed to it by Mr. Cockrell, to authorize the redemption (at par and accrued interest) of such 2 per cent. bonds (over $25,000,000 in all) as may be offered, and to authorize the issue of new Treasury legaltender notes in payment therefor.

The Great Northern Leger. LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The race for the Great Northern Leger Stakes of 800 sovereigns was run to-day at Stockton, and was won by Mr. B. Swanwick's b. f. Queen of Navarre, by Galliard, out of Pampeluna. Sir H. Jardine's b.c. Canning, by Wisdom, out of Briony, was second, and Mr. W. Winn's unnamed chestnut colt, by Tertius, out of Lady Salisbury, third.

MONTREAL, Aug. 16 -- William Weir, President or the Ville Marie Bank of this city, has addressed an open letter to the President and members of the Senate and the House of Representatives of the United States in which he discusses the financial situation existing in the United States and suggests the adoption of certain remedial measures.

WEST POINT, Aug. 16 -- The United States Corps or cadets will leave here to-morrow morning for the World's Fair at Chicago, where they will be encamped in Jackson Park for ten days. Capt. Spurgin, Commissary of Cadets, is at present there having the encampment laid out, the tents and equipage of camp having already been sent on.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The placing of Northern Pacific in the hands of receivers caused a weak opening in Americans and started rumors of impending receiverships for other roads. In fact, every American railroad whose shares are selling under 25 was talked about in turn, and these attacks, assisted by decreased gross earnings, were successful in causing a serious decline in Atchison bonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Some of the Republican critics of Representative Bryan, (Dem., Neb.,) were pleased to suggest, when that gentleman made his well-remembered speech in the Fifty-second Congress on the tariff, and won a great deal of applause and fame for it, that "that was always considered a very good speech in Nebraska," thus delicately intimating that he was a man of one speech.
Joseph V. Keeley, for two years cashier of the New-York Club, is a prisoner in Jefferson Market Prison charged with appropriating to his own use money belonging to the club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Although wheat is going out of the country at a rate which, it kept up, will leave it a scarce article at home, the price is 1/3 c lower than last night. Reports of failures East and West, and more Clearing House certificates issued at NewYork, combined, to press the market.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 17 -- The Narra gansett Pier tournament was continued here to-day. The singles was the only event of the day. Learned winning from Willis and Chace defeating E.L. Hall. The latter match attracted the most attention.

Herman M. Biggs, Chief Inspector of Pathelogy. Bacteriology, and Disinfection in the Health Department, has submitted to President Charles G. Wilson his report of the cases of diphtheria that nave come under his observation since May 6. His Investigations show that a considerable proportion of the pseudo-membrancous and exudative inflammations of the throat and upper air passages, commonly considered diphtheria, are not true diphtneria, but are of a far less serious nature.

Acting Mayor Simpson of Jersey City gave a hearing yesterday afternoon to all persons opposed to the ordinance giving to the Consolidated Traction Company the right to establish trolley routes through that city. Several individual property owners objected that the trolleys would injure their property, but the most vigorous protest came from the Jersey City Rapid Transit Company and the Central Railroad Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 -- A stockholder of the Northern Pacific Railway, whose name is withheld, has employed Attorneys Read Pettit to bring suit against Henry Villard, Edwin H. Abbott, Charles L. Colby, and Colgate Hoyt on the general charge of malfeasance in office and mismanagement of the affairs of the company in their capacity of Directors thereof.

Robert A. Ammon of the law firm of Friend House is counsel for Richard Goodwin Platt. defendant in a breach of promise suit brought by Marie E.J.S.L. Willard, who claims the title of "Countess von Valiache." Mr. Platt is a young bachelor of good family, fine presence, and a member of many clubs, and the disconsolate "Countess" protests that he has deceived and maltreated her, and should pay her $50,000.
Just an illustration of man's inhumanity to woman:

John Koster and Albert Bial have decided to sell at public auction their concert hall, fixings, properties, and lease of land, in short, everything which goes to make up the working outfit of Koster Bial's, in Twenty-third Street, next Sixth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- In the House this morning the silver debate was resumed.

To-morrow afternoon the second of the series of races to be given in this city by the National Cycling Association, or Cash Prize League, will take place at Manhattan Field. The racing will begin at 2:30 P.M., so as to give the spectators a chance to see the ball game on the Polo Grounds.

PANAMA, Aug. 17 -- Francis Henry Weeks, the New-York absconder, was here with his wife in the latter part of July. Discovering that the United States of Colombia had a treaty of extradition with the United States, the fugitive and his faithful companion suddenly left this city.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Aug. 17 -- The feature of the Columbian Rowing Regatta to-day was the senior single quarter-mile dash. It was won by Edwin Hedley of the Passaics in 1:17 -- two seconds lower than John F. Corbett's famous time in the Duluth regatta of 1890. Fine time was also made in the junior four quarter-mile dash.

The London Economist in its latest issue discusses in considerable detail the course and prospect of American railroad bonds. It prints a table of twenty railroads showing the present price of their various securities, the highest price reached in 1802, the amount of the fall, and the yield in income at the present prices.
The woman who committed suicide Tuesday in Central Park was Josephine Stelzberg, an Austrian Baroness, who lived in poverty at 170 Meserole Street, Williamsburg.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- John W. Casilear, the well-known artist, dropped dead here about 6 o'clock this evening. He was eighty-two years old. One son survives him, J.W. Casilear of Brooklyn.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Gen. Paine was found on board the Jubilee to-night and said that four or five minutes was rather a bad beating.

The present silver policy in the United States had its immediate origin in protectionism, but it soon began to attract all the elements of the population affected by Socialistic ideas, and these now probably control the greater number of those engaged in the movement, apart from a portion of the silver mine owners.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- A dispatch from Bombay says that, although there has been no renewal of the rioting in that city to-day, confidence has not yet been fully restored. The shops are closed and every train leaving the city is filled with families carrying their personal effects, who are returning to their native districts with a view to securing safety in the event of general trouble.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The presence of Barnum's Circus in town reduced the crowd of women in attendance at the Shann murder trial to-day. The court room was consequently more comfortable than at any time since the trial began.

Surprises were the order of the day at Clifton yesterday. The surprises were all furnished by M.T. Donovan. who has been rusticating at Saratoga for the past few weeks, but who joined Counselor "Bill" Brien and a few other owners at Clifton yesterday. Mr. Donovan had been unable to do much with his string at Saratoga, so in order to fill his purse he entered three horses in as many races at Clifton.

Rudolph Aronson, manager of the Casino, appiled to Judge Freedman in the Superior Court yesterday and obtained permission to sue Fablus M. Claus and Henry T. Cutter, as receivere for the New-York Concert Company, for $1,000 which he claims they owe him as his salary for managing the place of entertainment.

The Rapid-Transit Commission and the Manhattan Railway Company parted company yesterday when the commission, having formally received the letter and resolution of the Manhattan Directors, declining to undertake new contracts, adopted the following:

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 17 -- The State officials have made a move beneath the apparent innocence of which lurks a scheme of ominous import, if the words of the Secretary of State can be relied upon. A petition signed by all the State officers has been sent to Gov. Stone of Missouri which calls for a commercial division between the West and the East.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2@4 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The business portion of Atlantic City narrowly escaped destruction by fire at an early hour to-day. The fire destroyed $75,000 worth of property. One life is supposed to have been lost. The fire started before daylight in the wooden Grand Opera House. All the fire engines in the city worked in vain to keep the flames from spreading from the playhouse.

About 5,000 of the unemployed Hebrews of the east side, restless and uneasy at their failure to obtain employment, attempted yesterday to hold a mass meeting in Walhalla Hall, 50 Orchard Street. From an orderly gathering it became transformed into a mob of angry, excited men which demolished property and made it necessary to have called out the police reserve of several of the nearest stations.

Bartley French, who was awarded the contract for the collection of garbage in Brooklyn Jan. 23, 1892, transferred it to Daniel O'Connell, the Ninth Ward Democratic leader. The date of the transfer is February, 1892, but O'Connell did not accept it until June, 1893, and there is speculation as to why the affair should have been kept a secret until now.

RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Capt. Chris Paulsen, who intends to cross the Atlantic in a sixteen-foot Norwegian skiff, started on his perilous trip to-day. He had intended sailing sooner, but was delayed by the non-arrival of his instruments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The main interest, officially, in the Bering Sea decision now centres in the question of damages that this country will be obliged to pay Great Britain for the use of seal-hunting subjects who were kept out of Bering Sea through the operation of the modus vivendi or were seized as poachers prior to an agreement.

TRANSFERS -- Passed Assistant Surgeon A.R. Wentworth has been ordered to the Naval Hospital at Portsmouth, N.H. Boatswain J.H. Brown has been detached from the Norfolk Navy Yard and ordered to the Franklin, and in charge of the tug Wahnets. Recount orders detailing Capt. Augustus G. Tassin, Twelfth Infantry, Indian Agent at Forest City Agency, South Dakota, are revoked, and be is detailed agent at Colorado River Agency, Arizona.

The Sculpture Society, recently organized at 37 West Twenty-second Street, has issued a circular to sculptors and artist artisans setting forth that the first exhibition of the society will be held in New-York in December and January. The announcement is made at this time in order to give artists a chance to prepare original work.

The fight of the taxpayers of New-Utrecht against the 4,000 gaslamps which an enterprising Board of Improvement has distributed indiscriminately through the daisy fields and cow pastures of that town was resumed yesterday before Judge Bartlett, in the Supreme Court. Brooklyn.

Heavy receipts of gold from Europe furnished one of the features of the day in Wall Street yesterday. Among them were the lots brought to this port by the Steamer Lahn, which arrived on Wednesday night, but did not deliver its cargo until yesterday.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 17 -- This moraine at 3 o'clock the croquet players in the National Asaociation began the tournament contests with vim, and in twenty-five minutes E.O. Butler won from Ohaitant without, letting his antagonist make an arch. Strong won from Maurer without giving the latter a shot. Knecht won from Dickey, Dickey won from Bishop. Germond won from Greenslit.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 17 -- The mysterious black sloop yacht, trim, fleet, and silent, the entry of which into the various harbors along Long Island Sound this Summer has been followed by singularly clever robberies, slipped into Peconic Bay late last night.

Six hundred Schnorers and their friends spent a very lively day yesterday. The occasion was the annual clambake of the Schnorer Club of Morrisanis, which was held at Pleasure Island, near Bridgeport, Conn.
