BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Secretary Charles H. Keep of the Lake Carriers' Association said to-day, in speaking of the traffic on the lake:
Wheat was very dull and closed at a decline of 1/4 c on local realizing, easier cables, and weaker Western markets, with only a local switching and scalping trade.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 17 -- Rafael Diaz, a Cuban engaged in the wholesale cigar business in this city, is one of the leaders in the revolutionary movement which has for its object the freeing of Cuba from Spanish rule.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 -- The appeal of the McDonald will case to the Supreme Court was filed in the office of the Clerk this morning. It bears the title of Josephine F. McDonald (widow of Senator McDonald) and others against Malcolm A. McDonald and others, and is appealed from the Hamilton Circuit Court. The transcript fills 1,958 typewritten pages, and is one of the largest documents ever filed in the Supreme Court of Indiana.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- A sung of men has been arrested in Biskupitz, Croatia, because they have mutilated young children. The men have for years made a trade of crippling children and then sending them one to beg, or selling them to others for the same purpose. Children were stolen or were misled with promises to visit the house kept by the gang on the outskirts of the town.

MONMOUTH, Ill., Aug. 17 -- John Clark, living northwest of this city, while going to a neighbor's house across a swamp, tripped and fell. On starting to rise be was horrified to find a blue racer twined about his feet.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 17 -- The Democratic State Executive Committee met here to-day and elected the following officers: Chairman -- James P. Seward, Mansfield; Vice Chairman -- T.J. McDermott, Zanesville; Secretary -- William T. Wear, Urbans; Treasurer -- Gilbert H. Barger, Columbus.

When John A. Morris injected himself into facing, with Ma Louisiana Lottery methods, there came with him a taint that it is going to be hard for the managers of other race courses than Monmouth Park to rid themselves of try as they may. People in the North do not like to see the coils of the lottery serpent about a sport that they had learned to enjoy.

SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Like an old hen brooding over her chickens, the People's Party expects to settle down with unfolding wings over the farmers of Central New-York. It proposes to accomplish this motherly deed by a unique scheme called the "farmers' encampments."

Dr. von Helmholtz of the University of Berlin, who has bean sent as a delegate by the German Government to the Electrical Congress in Chicago, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyds steamship Labn. He is the guest of Dr. Herman Knapp. Both gentlemen left for Chicago in the afternoon.

The will of Justice Samuel Blatchford of the United States Supreme Court, who died at his Newport home July 7, was filed for probate yesterday by his son, Samuel A. Blatchford. The will was drawn June 15, 1876, the executors being the Judge's son and Judge Sedgwick. The witnesses were Francis M. Bangs, Charies W. Bangs, and William Nassau.

A meeting of the Rapid Transit Commissioners of unusual significance was held yesterday at the house of Mr. STEINWAY, who has evidently deferred or abandoned his intention of resigning. Mr. INMAN was absent, but the new Commissioner, Mr. PORTER, appointed in the place of Mr. SPENCER, the special friend of the Manhattan Company, was present.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Aug. 17 -- P.M. Dullness, amounting almost to stagnation, was the feature of to-day's stock market. The total transactions amounted to only 117,102 shares, and in only three stocks did the trading exceed 10,000 shares. These were Distilling and Cattle Feeding, (19,365.) St. Paul, (13,012.) and General Electric (12,632.) Next to these came Burlington, with 6,345.

Mr. Nathan Strauss of New-York is now in Germany, where he is creating considerable envy by driving a pair of Maine-bred mates to a light Brewater wagon. One of the mares is by Somerset Knox and the other is by Judge Advocate. They can go fast and are superb specimens of the American trotter.

STATE CAMP, SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The inter-State and the New-Jersey State matches were decided at the butts here to-day. The first was captured by the Engineer Corps of Washington, D.C., and the latter will in all probability be won by the Second New-Jersey Regiment. The scores in the latter had not been fully computed to-night.

John Murphy, twenty-seven years old, of 246 East Eighty-seventh Street, an elevated railroad guard, was a prisoner in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, charged, with assault. After hearing the evidence of a number of witnesses. Justice Martin held him for further examination in $500 ball.

A father's stern word that he would teach his bad boy a lesson, a mother's tears and wild pleadings that her boy and family be not disgraced, and a boy so stricken with fear and remorse that he almost fell in a fit, made a pathetic and sensational scene in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night.

LEADVILLE, Col., Aug. 17 -- The American National Bank, which closed its doors on July 1, resumed business this morning. The depositors will be paid 25 per cent. cash, 15 per cent. on Dec. 1, 20 per cent. on March 1, 1891, 20 per cent. on June 1, 1894, and 20 per cent. on Sept. 1, 1894.
The failure of the Commercial Bank in Brooklyn is beginning to assume a serious appearance.

The creditors of J.N. Walker Co., wholesale and retail dry Roods dealers of Chicago, met at the Merchants' Club, 108 Leonard Street, yesterday afternoon to near the report of the receiver, the Chicago Title and Trust Company. About 250 merchants were present.

In the interests of peace and harmony the Rev. Edward McGlynn called at the residence of Archbishop Corrigan late yesterday afternoon. Unfortunately, Mgr. Satolli was enjoying himself on a trip up the river, and the leader of the Anti-Poverty movement found only the gracious butler of the Archbishop to receive him.

NEWPORT, Aug. 17 -- The Vigilant won the first of the Astor Cup races, and she won handsomely, too. She defeated her opponents in a good stiff breeze over a coarse laid fifteen miles to windward and return, and in a lumpy sea. It was no fluke race, and those on the beaten yachts have no excuse to make for their defeat except that they were not fast enough.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- United Ireland of Dublin to-day says that the reported representations made to the Right Hon. Herbert H. Asquith. Secretary of the Home Office, regarding the mental condition of Dr. Thomas Gallagher, convinced him that the prisoner was insane, and orders were given for Dr. Gallagher's release from prison.

MONCLOVA, Mexico, Aug. 17 -- The political troubles in this State of Coahulla are growing more serious, and a general outbreak is threatened. The Federal Government is massing its troops at every available point in the State to preserve order. The Cardenas party has a force of several thousand armed men in the field. They are stationed at all of the more important towns in the State.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 17 -- The second day of the annual meet of the New-Jersey Association of Trotting Horse Breeders drew a large crowd at the Trenton Driving Park to-day. Summaries:

In the contribution which Assistant Secrotary McADOO makes to the current number of the North American Review upon the lessons of the Victoria disaster, undoubtedly the points of chief interest are those which may be considered to forecast features in the policy of our own Navy Department.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 17 -- The Oliver Iron and Steel Company, one of the largest concerns in the country, went into the hands of a receiver to-day. Application was made before Judge Acheson of the United States Circuit Court, by the National Tube Works Company of New-Jersey and E.C. Converse of New-York and Pittsburg.

Jean Martin Charcot, whose death at Morvan, France, was announced in these columns yesterday, was graduated as a physician in 1853, attached to hospital service in 1856, and appointed Director of the Government Asylum for the Insane, La Salpetriere, in 1861.

The Brooklyn Citizen will hold a ten-mile handicap load race on the Ocean Parkway, near Prospect Park, Brooklyn, to-morrow morning at 1O o'clock. A solid silver cup will be given to the winner, and a special time prize to the rider making the best time over the course. The first three men to finish will receive prizes given by the makers of the machines they ride.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 17 -- The St. Paul and Minneapolis Publishers' Association, the Typotnetae, the employing printers, and the Executive Committees of Typographical Union Nos. 30 and 42 met to-day to discuss a proposition looking to the reduction of the cost of composition.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Judge Barnard filed his decision in the Meredith have late this afternoon. He finds Meredith insane and orders that he remain at Matteawan Asylum, in the course of his decision he says:

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 17 -- For the past month the police here have been annoyed by small incendiary fires happening in the heart of the city. In each case they were discovered before much harm was done. The incendiary, who turns out to be a very small chap, Raymond McGill, twelve years old, seems to have a mania for this kind of work and also for petty thieving.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 17 -- A youthful bicycle rider probably fatally injured an old lady and, near the same spot almost simultaneously, two irate Summer girls disturbed the serenity of this village by horsewhipping another youngman late last night and collected the largest crowd that the village has ever seen.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The United Presbyterian Synod voted to-night to exonerate the Rev. J.B. Lee and to sustain his appeal from the action of the Philadelphia Presbytery. An appeal was also heard from two members who were suspended from the Second United Presbyterian Church of Buffalo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The decline in wheat since last night amounts to 10 bushel, and corn and osta are each 1/20 lower. Provisions lost from 3Oc to 40c in pork, 10c to 12 1/2c in lard, and from 15c to 27 1/2c in ribs.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 18 -- There have been many complaints made by the visiting fireman at Coney Island. One of the most grievous is that concerning their quarters. Members of West Pittston Hose Company of West Pittston, Penn., complain that they were quartered in a hotel where eight men were compelled to sleep in rooms meant for two men.
Henry Weeks, the filcher of trust funds, had fled from Panama on discovering that he could be extradited from the United States of Colombia, caused a great deal of discussion.

So far, in the Senate, the remarks of Messrs. COCKRELL and WOLCOTT have been the most spirited defense offered for the silver party -- if it can be so called -- in its opposition to the repeal of the purchase clause of the Sherman act. Both Senators are ardent advocates of the unlimited coinage of silver.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Though there were twelve heats finished at the Driving Park to-day, only one event was decided, and the wind-up of the Grand Circuit meeting here was delayed in consequence.

Papers were served yesterday on Amelia Hansen, a young Danish hairdresser of 1,272 Third Avenue, in a writ of habeas corpus to compel her to produce before Justice Van Brunt in the Supreme Court to-day her two-year-old boy, Bernhardt, who a Mrs. Paulina Lang claims was given over to her in payment for his board.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis, Aug. 18 -- The attendance upon the Columbian regatta to-day was better than on any of the preceding days. The weather was lovely and the lake in fine condition. The senior single international was Hedley's race from the beginning, but it was, nevertheless, a spirited contest. His work of yesterday had not affected his fine form, and his strong, sweeping stroke told effectively.
QUARANTINE, S.I., Aug. 18 -- The following bulletin was issued by Health Officer Jenkins at 12:30 P.M.:

PANAMA, Aug. 18 -- Francis Henry Weeks, the New-York embezzler, fled from this city to San Jose, the capital of Costa Rica. He made no effort to conceal his identity while here, but used his own name when he registered at the Grand Hotel.

The junior members of the Paterson Cricket Club paid a visit to the juniors of the Staten Island Cricket Club yesterday at Livingston, and after an interesting exchange of hostilities they wound up a full two-innings game by claiming a victory by 22 runs.

Mayor GILROY has given utterance to some pretty severe but well-deserved strictures upon the conduct of the Manhattan Railway Company with reference to the franchise for an extension of its system, and has declared that there should be "no more dilly-dallying with this greedy corporation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The House Committee on Rules took a convenient opportunity to-day to offer a resolution in the House authorizing the Speaker to appoint committees, as provided for in the rules at the last Congress, with the increased membership as proposed in the committee yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The Illinois Trust and Savings Bank yesterday engaged $400,000 gold for import, making altogether $350,000 which is coming on the steamers Columbia and La Bourgogne. The gold engaged for shipment to this country by Chicago banks since the movement set in is about $8,000,000.

Mayor Gilroy added his voice yesterday to the feeling already expressed by Controller Myers and Commissioner William Steinway in favor of leaving the Manhattan Railway Company out of account in all future plane for rapid transit. The Mayor had followed with close interest the efforts of the Rapid-Transit Commissioners to come to terms with the Manhattan Company.

There was but one sale of real estate at auction yesterday -- a sale under foreclosure, at the New-York Real Estate Salesroom, by Richard V. Harnett Co. The properly was 364 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 25 by 100.11, with a five-story brick flat upon it. Due on the judgment, $22,343. Samuel G. and Julia A. Lockwood, the plaintiffs in the foreclosure suit, became the purchasers at $22,000.

-- A Toledo (Ohio) wheelman, who was arrested and fined for riding on the sidewalk, watched the policeman who had arrested him until he saw him enter a saloon. As the rules of the Police Board in Toledo forbid that, and are strictly enforced, the wheelman turned in an alarm for the patrol wagon, and when it arrived directed the Sergeant to the saloon.

-- The Maine Central Railroad Company causes its brakemen to warn the passengers not to forget their coats, umbrellas, or packages, and yet all sorts of things are left in the cars. One man gent back, the other day, for his false teeth that he had forgotten. The agent had three sets left on his hands. He sent them all, and the absent-minded man found one pair fitted him.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Aug. 18 -- A strange story of wronged wives and kidnapped children was developed at this place to-day by the arrest of Andrew Britton, or Britto, on a charge of non-support and the arrest of the woman who has been known here as his wife on a charge of cruelty to children.

Police Justice Hogan read young Milton M. Berrick, the seventeen-year-old son of Lawyer A.M. Berrick, a severe lecture yesterday afternoon, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, before discharging him on a charge of disorderly conduct.

Since Mgr. Satolli's arrival from Rome the bickerings of the Catholic clergy, which called him to this country, have all been amicably adjusted, save in the Archdiocese of New-York. Here there have been persistent and covert attacks on Mgr. Satolli, and when he became the guest of Archbishop Corrigan there was much surprise in Catholic circles, for it was generally believed that Archbishop Corrigan and his friends had inspired the attacks on the Delegate.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- The following was given out at the Department of the State Board of Charities to-day:

Justice Van Brunt in the Supreme Court yesterday named Charles II. Daniels and Dr. Paul Alien as a commission to into the sanity of David J. Solomon, who is now in Bloomingdale Asylum suffering, so his two brothers an Superintendent Lyon assert, from paresis.

In nearly all the morning newspapers of this city yesterday. THE NEW-YORK TIMES being one of the exceptions, there appeared a story so heartrending in its details that the nervous and sympathetic must have been sadly disturbed by its reading.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Numerous complaints have been made to-day to the World's Fair officials on account of the savage brutality displayed at the sun dance held by the Quackahl Indians last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Secretary Herbert has set his foot down solidly on promiscuous changes in ships in course of construction. There has been a good deal of this sort of thing under other administrations, and doubtless much of the present delay in the completion of ships is the result of the alterations which were recommended by various officers stationed at the shipyards where ships were under contract.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The entire day in Justice Abbett's court was spent in the arguments of the counsel who are engaged in the defense and prosecution of Mrs. Shann, charged with having poisoned her son. Justice Abbett will charge the jury to-morrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Clevelaud to-day found a warm and loyal but not unexpected supporter on the floor of the House in Dr. William Everett of Massachusetts.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 18 -- The nominations and the platform of the Democratic State Convention, which adjourned this morning at 3 o'clock, give general satisfaction to the party. The selection of Col. C.T. O'Ferrall for Governor was settled weeks, if not months, ago. The Colonel is one of President Cleveland's friends in Virginia.
BOMBAY, Aug. 18 -- This was a Mohammadan prayer day, and there was a general espectation that further troubles would occur between the members of that sect and the Hindus.

It was reported in Brooklyn yesterday that the Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank had decided to request the State Superintendent of Banking to call for the appointment of a receiver for that institution.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Aug. 18 -- P.M. Fluctuations in the stock market no longer mean anything. The trading at times is so light that it is difficult to determine the drift of the market. Every one is wishing for something to turn up to improve the situation without knowing exactly where to look for it, and in the meantime the dilatoriness of Congress in dealing with the financial situation adds to the gloom and depression.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The Brown segmental gun to-day, with a charge of twenty-one pounds of Leonard smokeless powder and a sixty-two-pound shot, gave the enormous muzzle velocity of 2,665 feet per second, with a maximum pressure of 46,800 pounds per square inch. This is the highest velocity ever obtained in this country.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 18 -- The Street and Wator Board had a somewhat exhilarating meeting this morning. The subject of debate was asphalt pavement, the objects division of work in favor of the highest rather than the lowest bidder, and some unpleasant personalities resulted.
County Physician A.W. Shepard of Brooklyn will perform an autopsy to-day upon the body of Frederick Suckau of 624 Third Avenue, who died at his home on Thursday night under suspicious circumstances.

The General Headquarters of the National Guard, through the Adjutant General's office at Albany, has promulgated its decisions in the cases of Capt. I.J. Cobin of the Seventy-first Regiment and Capt. William A. Cornell of the Eighth Regiment, both of whom were cried by courts-martial upon specified charges. The decisions and sentences are in accordance with the announcement previously published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

There is not much use in trying to discount the future in lawn tennis, as Carroll and Jenks of the Staten Island Cricket club discovered last Thursday. They were in the semi-finals, and, if victorious, would have played Cater and Maxwell for first prize. Cater being anxious to finish up the tournament before going on his vacation, Carroll and Jenks proposed to play off the finals provisionally, as they were sure of beating their opponents.

At the meeting of the Board of Street Opening and Improvement yesterday morning Assistant Engineer J.O.B. Webster of the Public Works Department presented the plan and grade maps for the opening and widening of Elm Street from Chambers Street north to Great Jones Street.

AMERICAN CANOE ASSOCIATION, CAMP KINGSTON, Canada, Aug. 18 -- Canada's hopes have fallen. Her one-armed dark horse went down like chaff before the American racing fleet to-day. Unofficial races were sailed forenoon and afternoon, and the interest in each was the showing that Kenneth Cameron, the one-armed man from Kingston. Ontario, would make against the American fliers. The Canadian was beaten on all points of sailing by all the Yankee canoes.

A fire early yesterday morning in the five-story brown-stone apartment house at 226 West Sixteenth Street, which is occupied by seventeen families, caused a loss of $5,000. The fire started in the dumb-waiter abaft and soon extended to the fifth story. The tenants were immediately awakened and swarmed down the stairs and fire-escapes.

SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Populist farmers' encampment scheme has fallen flat. When the State Committee decided to bag all the farmers of Central New-York with rhetorical nets, they undertook more than they could accomplish.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 18 -- The action of the State Republican Convention Wednesday in repudiating prohibition has caused a great deal of excitement. The Des Moines News (Independent Republican) prints a double-leaded editorial article under the heading, "Prohibition Must Be Saved," and calls for a citizens' State Convention. In the course of the article appears the following:

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 18 -- The last day of the great convention of the Volunteer Firemen's Association of the State of New-York could not have been fairer. Coney Island was early astir; in fact, much of it had been stirring all night. By daybreak the streets were filled with redshirted firemen, and as the early trains began to roll into the stations they brought in still more fireman.
In all probability an appeal will be taken from the decision of Judge Barnard of the Supreme Court, declaring Edward Meredith insane, to the Court of Appeals.

The twenty-fifth ocean party of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor was cared for yesterday in the usual happy manner at the Seaside Home, Coney Island. It was the second party of negroes taken to the seashore this season, and about 1,000 enjoyed an outing. These health-giving excursions are entirely non-sectarian and are paid for entirely by voluntary contributions.

The charges brought by Henry Allen of the brokerage firm of Henry Allen Co. against James M. Waterbury, President of the National Cordage Company, J. Weaver Loper, Frank T. Wall, C.L. Atterbury, J.C. Farmul, and Chauncey Marshal, Directors in that company, are in a fair way to get before the Grand Jury within two weeks.

More gold came to Wall Street yesterday, and again there was a great demand for cash from various parts of the country. The premium on currency was maintained, and the offices of the money brokers were filled with buyers and sellers of coin and bills.

An event of more than ordinary interest will be the reopening, under the management of Edmund C. Stanton, of the Grand Opera House at Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street Monday night. Since the close of the last season wonders have been worked in the way of improvements and decoration in the theatre.

Health Commissioner Griffin of Brooklyn created a lively row in Mayor Boody's office yesterday morning by giving the lie direct to Eugene G. Blackford and a number of other residents of the Twenty-fourth Ward, who were protesting against the city piggery nuisances in Flatbush. But for the restraining influence of the Mayor, blows might have been struck.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- An attempt was made to-day to sail the second race for the Astor Cups. It proved a failure. The wind died out right after the start, and then only at times came from all points of the compass. The race eventually became a drift, and when it was seen that the racers could not possibly finish within the time limit -- six hours -- it was declared off.

Kate Heger, seventy-two years old, attempted to commie suicide yesterday afternoon by throwing herself into the East River at the foot of East One Hundred and Twentieth Street. She was rescued by Ambulance Driver McGovern of the Harlem Hospital, who happened to be on the pier at the time.

The Maryland Steel Company of Baltimore is building a steel steam yacht for Mrs. Lucy C. Carnegie of Pittsburg. Penn., which she will use for cruising in Southern waters. Mrs. Carnegie is the widow of Thomas Carnegie, a brother of Andrew Carnegie. She owns an island off the coast of South Carolina, where she is in the habit of wintering.

An entire block of two-story wooden buildings on Cooper Street, near Hamburg Avenue, Ridgewood, (Brooklyn,) was destroyed by fire yesterday morning, and seventeen families were made homeless. Seven people were injured. Their names are as follows:
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 3 @ 5 cent. The last loan was made at 3 cent.

Our pranksome and mischievous old friend, JOHN BOYD THACHER, is considered at some length in a letter which has been written to the French exhibitors at Chicago by M. KRANTZ, the French Commissioner General. This letter is printed in the Paris newspapers, and is well calculated to disturb the equanimity of the Chairman of the Committee on Awards.
In order to get whatever dollars the firemen had left after the tournament down in McKanesville, the promoters of the Coney Island Club arranged a "rare fistic treat." It took place last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- After a long delay a bill calling for the repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman law is at last on the Senate calendar. It was placed there to-day on the favorable report of the Senate Committee on Finance.

"I do not believe that Emin Pasha is dead!" The speaker was Dr. Carl Peters, the African explorer and one of the leaders of the Emin Pasha relief expedition. He is now at the Waldorf Hotel, and is on his way to Chicago to attend the Ethnological Congress. He arrived in New-York yesterday on the Furst Bismarck.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 18 -- A four hours' rain last evening cooled and cleared the air, so that the shooting at the closing of the three days' tournament of the Inter-State Manufacturers and Dealers' Association here was more comfortable than on the two previous days. The attendance was about the same throughout the tournament and the shooting up to the average.

-- The New-Jersey Athletic Club has no fear of the result of the game with the Morris Park Club at Bergen Point to-day, but their rivals for the championship, the Staten Island Cricket Club, dread the journey to Paterson, where they have ere this been treated to a surprise. The Manhattan play the Newarks at Prospect Park, where the taflenders should have plenty of leather hunting.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- The entries and drawings for the annual tournament of the National Tennis Association, to be held on the Casino grounds next week, were announced this afternoon. There are sixty-seven entries, falling only three below the unprecedented record of last year, when an even seventy were on the list. The drawings are as follows:

DENVER, Col., Aug. 18 -- A most sensational action in connection with the recent failure of the People's Savings Bank came up in the District Court yesterday afternoon when a petition was presented asking for the removal of Frederick Schrader, assignee of the bank, upon the grounds that he is not conducting affairs legally, and making specific charges of fraud and collusion in the conduct of the bank.

NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 18 -- "Willie" Knecht, the boy player, won the championship to-night in the national croquet tournament. At the close of the day's games he and the Rev. Philip Germond of New-York were tied for first place, each having won six and lost two games. Three games to play off the tie were arranged, the winner of two to be champion and hold the beautiful gold prize of the association.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 -- The story of the suit to be brought in Philadelphia against four Directors of the Northern Pacific for malfeasance in office was shown to-day to one of them, Mr. Edwin H. Abbott.

Further testimony as to the vigilance of Dr. YOUNG, the Sanitary Inspector stationed at Naples by the Marine Hospital Bureau, is furnished in Health Officer JENKINS'S report concerning the condition of the Weser, which arrived at Quarantine yesterday morning with all of her 999 steerage passengers well.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Thomas G. Bowles (Conservative) asked toe Government whether the award of the Bering Sea Tribunal of Arbitration imposed upon Great Britain the obligation to forbid pelagic sealing by British subjects at any time whatever within a sixty-mile zone around the Pribilof Islands.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 18 -- J.S. Johnson knocked fifteen and a quarter seconds off the three-mile bicycle record on the Minnehaha track to-day, making the distance in 7:15 1/4, against 7:31 made by Waller at Indianapolis July 5, 1892. Zimmerman, Taylor, Eliss, and Lumsden will be present at to-morrow's races.
Marie Tempest, the clever prima donna of the comic-opera stage, arrived in this city yesterday on the Fuerst Bismarck, after a visit of two months in Europe.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Scalley of Farmingdale have been childless for many years, and felt a longing to hear the patter of baby footsteps in the lonely old house and listen to the childish prattle of baby lips, even if they had to adopt a baby to bring about these results.

SEA GIRT, Aug. 18 -- The District of Columbia marksmen not only carried off all the honors at Sea Girt to-day, but smashed the record. The marksmen of New-York, Pennsylvania, and Massachusetts, whose States treat them with an open-handed liberality to which the Washingtonians are strangers, have reason to congratulate themselves that they failed to send teams to compete for the Inter-State and Hilton trophies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The official list of awards in the Department of Fine Arts was given out to-day by the National Committee on Awards. The awards for sculpture will not be ready for a few days. To each of the artists a medal and a diploma setting forth the points of excellence in his works were awarded. The exhibition of paintings made by French artists was disappointing to the jurors.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 18 -- One of the sensational things developed by the failure of the Indianapolis National Bank was that, although the bank could not legally loan more than $30,000, 10 per cent, of its capital stock, to any single borrower, the Indianapolis Cabinet Company, controlled by Frank Coffin and Percy Coffin, had succeeded in borrowing in excess of the legal limit, through the establishment of branch concerns.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- It was known this morning that large amounts of gold would be withdrawn to-day, and all departments suffered in consequence. Consols fell to 97 7/8 on sales of about a million, said to be for account of one of the houses shipping gold, and this is probable, as the proceeds might well be needed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 18 -- The conditions in the Lake Superior iron-mining district are not improving. To-day the number of miners out of employment is not less than 12,000, while the scattered forces still employed are working for wages 20 to 33 per cent. less than a year ago. The mines are shipping from their stock piles principally, and these shipments are remarkably small.

-- Thomas A. Edison is visiting the Chicago fair, but is not letting the crowd there or the officials know It. He has made no general display of his inventions, and baa not visited the Electricity Buiding. He told a friend than he had no time to spare for that when there were so many other things of greater interest to him.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- This has been Great Britain's day at the World's Fair. The crowds began to arrive early. Before 8 o'clock there was a crush at the gates and it continued at intervals during the day. Englishmen were out in large numbers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Among the visitors to the House of Representatives to-day was the Rajai Rajagan of Kapurthala State, India, on his tour through the United States. There were in the party, besides the Maharaja, Miam Aziz Bakhsh, Revenue Minister of Kepurthala, and Capt. Sundar Singh. They were in charge of Col. C.F. Massey of the English Army.

The arrival yesterday of the steamship Cachemire from Naples with all of her 208 immigrants in a healthy condition was something of a relief to Health Officer Jenkins and Immigration Commissioner Senner. The reported appearance of cholera in Naples has caused all vessels arriving from that port to be regarded with suspicion by those whose duty it is to exclude the Asiatic plague from these shores.

The third and decisive race among open cat-boats under 24 feet for the championship of New-York and Newark Bays and the Kill Von Kull was sailed yesterday afternoon over a triangular course of fifteen miles on Now-York Bay, the Alida winning from the Lizzie B. by 37 seconds on corrected time. The former having won the second race, her owner now becomes possessor of the silver trophy emblemgtic of the championship.

Superintendent of Immigration Stump and Dr. Senner, the Commissioner of Immigration at this port, yesterday held a conference on Ellis Island. It concerned immigration matters, particularly the question as to how undesirable foreigners can be prevented from reaching this country by way at Canada.

There-were eight Nubians seated with legs crossed in Ottoman fashion on the steerage deck at the Normandle yesterday. They came from Chicago. They were homesick, and they carried varnished walking sticks as memorials of their American experience. They were wrapped in gray linen, in yellow linen, in multi-colored shawls, and their hair was crimped -- tressed like the hair of the statues which date from Amenhotpou III.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The following facts, which have come directly to my knowledge, will be interesting and encouraging to American manufacturers: A year ago an American Inventor wanted a small upright engine to drive a special machine which he was introducing here. The power required was about eight to twelve break horse power.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19 -- From time to time new structures have arisen on the Yale campus, and each in turn has received its due share of attention and comment, but one whose walls are now appearing just above ground level bids fair to establish a record in excellence of design, thoroughness of structure, and elegance of material that will stand unrivaled for years.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Driving is decidedly the thing this season. Everybody who is anybody owns a turnout. The result is that the hotel stable is overcrowded, and it has been hard work to find room for the horses and vehicles, not to mention coachmen, footmen, and grooms. The fashionable drive is to Long Branch.

PHILADELPHIA, Ponn., Aug. 19 -- Thomas Graham, who in 1879 was sentenced in Camden, N.J., to twenty years imprisonment for implication in the murder of John M. Armstrong, for which crime Benjamin Humor was hanged at Camden, was released from the State prison at Trenton to-day, six years and three months of his sentence having been deducted for good behavior.

I remember very well the day when I first saw Katie. There were six of us, juniors at Pierson, who had formed an eating club and had consigned ourselves to the mercies of Mrs. Ames. I trust these were tender for the sake of an exception.

UNDECIDED: 1. In a case of illness it is quite proper to acknowledge the interest of friends in your prostration. A visiting card "with thanks for kind inquiries" is sufficient, and this in turn should be taken by your friends as an indication that you are restored to health and ready to see them n writing to a servant use the simplest form Carmody.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The President has approved the following:

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The Newark Bay Boat Club of Bayonne held its annual recatta on Newark Bay this afternoon under favorable conditions. Only members could take part. In the sailing, the start was made at 3:12 P.M. It was high water, and a strong southeasterly by south wind was blowing. The yachts were in three classes and sailed three times around a triangular course on Newark Bay, covering ten miles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Headquarters were opened to-day at the Grand Pacific Hotel by the Committee on Organization of the coming Catholic Congress of the United States. The Hon. William H. Onahan, Secretary of the committee, said to-night that the occasion will bring together perhaps the most notable gathering of ecclesiastics and laymen ever before seen in America.

The United States naval authorities at Washington have received notice of a series of regulations which have been officially published by the Austrian Government regarding the admission of foreign war ships to the waters along the Austrian coast. The regulations further prescribe the management of foreign war vessels while in Austrian waters.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 19 -- The Country Club was favored with a glorious afternoon for the annual carriage parade and horse show. The principal hotels were decorated with flags and the whole town had a holiday air. Jack Townsend was master of ceremonies and had the parade started as soon as the dinner hour was passed.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 19 -- Enormous export clearances of wheat and an improved New-York bank statement caused an advance of 1 1/4 c in September wheat to-day, 3/4 c which gain was still adhering to the market at the close. Corn, oats, and provisions were dull, the latter extremely so, and price changes were insignificant.

This story is designed, so the author says, to give the principal incidents in the formative history of the great American Republic from the year 1700 to 1760. The Stevens family, whose adventures are interwoven with the larger events of the period, are descended from the Hernando Estevan who was the cabin boy of Christopher Columbus on his first vovage of discovery.

RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Mrs. Julia Taff of this place has applied for back pension for the services of her husband, James Taff, who enlisted in the Sixty-ninth New-York Volunteers, and subsequently in the Connecticut Cavalry, and served in the last war.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 19 -- Senator John Sherman has sent the following letter to Samuel J. Ritchieo of this city:

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 19 -- Large tracts of land, adapted to the cultivation of coffee, tobacco, and cocoa, have been taken up by English and Americans on the Coatzacoalcos River, Isthmus of Tehuantopee. There is excellent natural pasturage for cattle, and settlers expect to make good business fattening cattle for market.

TOKIO, July 19 -- The presence in Tokio of diplomatic representative from Portugal has been made the occasion for reviving rumors which were freely circulated some time ago, to the effect that a serious dispute between that kingdom and Japan was about to become public.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 18 -- The most delightful of the outdoor sports of the season was the boat parade on the Housatonic River Friday afternoon. The day was perfect and the air was cool. There were about 2,000 spectators to see the boats go down the river. It was the first time this boat parade has taken place in the daytime.

Apropos of Marion Crawford's remark about oar mustached butlers, that they amused him after the shorn ones of England, why won't somebody say that our butlers, our American butlers, wear mustaches, and we, when abroad, find it amusing to see the English butlers smooth shaven, and wonder why their masters do not insist that their mouths be covered.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 19 -- A sensational story was told to Chief of Police McKane this afternoon by "Olive, the Gipay Queen," who applied for police protection against Mrs. Ida Palmer, who has lately been managing the Queen's branch establishment at the Sea Beach Palace.

FAR ROCKAWAY, Aug. 19 -- Suit for separation and alimony has been commenced by Mrs. Julia Korn against her husband, Dr. Abram Korn, of 220 East Seventy-eighth Street, New-York City. Mrs. Korn left her husband last June, taking with her two infant children, under habeas corpus proceedings.

Alexander Guilmant, who is to make his first appearance in America at the World's Fair in Chicago on Aug. 31, is a thorough representative of the French style of organ playing. Americans will have their first opportunity to judge of the character and musical value of his work when he performs on the great organ in the festival hall at 3 P.M. on the date mentioned.

The storm which swept over this city and Long Island last evening was a severe one. Much property was damaged and in Brooklyn one life was lost. On Long Island several places were struck by lightning.
Wheat advanced. 5/8@7/8 c, on the better bank statement, large clearances, better Chicago markets, and local covering, but trading was very slow.

The new shapes show some genuine scoop fronts flaring sky ward from queer crowns that look like inverted cake pans, or cake pans with a peaked cover. No prediction can be made about the popularity of these extreme styles, but they are offered.

It is to be regretted that Senator Cockrell saw fit to obstruct the bill introduced by Senator Voorhees to permit national banks to increase their circulation to the full value of bonds deposited. This is a perfectly safe measure and is being commended and called for by the press of all parties. It would at once relieve the existing stringency, as the banks could issue $19,000,000 on bonds already deposited in excess of their circulation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Owing to circumstances sometimes altogether beyond their control, there is usually very little demand for valets in practical politics. In an ideal civilization, when statesmanship shall be enriched by the cultivation and possession of Capuan luxuries, the valet will most likely be as conspicuous a figure as he is upon the stage or in the romances of the aristocracy.

A large crowd witnessed the game at Central Park yesterday between the St. George's Athletic Club and the South Brooklyns, and it was treated to a very good display of cricket. The St. George's men won by 17 runs, but the finish was sufficiently close to prove exciting, and but for the effective bowling of E. Ling and T.W. Harris at the end the result might have been different.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- A man representing himself to be an eye doctor drove up to Mrs. Jane Osterhoudt's house near Pine Bush yesterday and told her he had been sent to her by her son to perform an operation on her eyes. Mrs. Osterhoudt's eyes having been diseased for some time, she readily acquiesced, and allowed him to try what he could do.

Doubtless there is time enough before further legislation can be obtained, if it should prove to be necessary, for the Rapid Transit Commission to make another effort to induce private capital to engage in the enterprise of constructing and operating a new and independent system of rapid transit for the city.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The week at Bay Shore has been the gayest of any this season or of any former season, and the coming week bids fair to rival it in crowding pleasures. The annual full-dress hop at the Prospect House was, of course, the gala event of the week and was the most brilliant affair of the sort that Bay Shore has yet enjoyed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- As the Grand Circuit programme was nor cleared up here yesterday, the two classes carried over were resumed this morning. The 2:14 pacers had gone six heats, chiefly owing to the vagaries of Paul and Hal Dillard. Before the seventh heat to-day Hal Dillard was a hot favorite at $25 to $10 over the four left to oppose the Cleveland pacer.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 19 -- There is in the furthest South an agricultural pursuit that is far and away the most profitable known in the United States. It is the very romance of tilling the soil. It is called sugar planting, and exists chiefly in Louisiana. The profit in sugar raising in this State in the past few years has caused a wonderful increase in the area devoted to sugar.

The annual regatta of the Nonpareil Rowing Club, which was held on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, will rank as one of the most successful ever held on that river, and in the perfection of arrangements was far ahead of any similar event which has been seen there this season. The number of entries was very large for a club regatta and in no event was there a single failure to start.

"A hamper for M. le Cure." "Bien! Be good enough to open it, Suzanne." Suzanne did as she was told. M. le Cure, in soutane, sat at his desk, awaiting this new revelation. He had great faith in the unseen -- as regarded parcels. "O. Monsicur, v'la le beau dindon!"

Mrs. U.S. Grant has declined an extremely courteous invitation to attend the reunion of the Confederate Veterans, to be held in Birmingham, Ala., in September, pleading that she is not able to endure the fatigue of such occasions, the reason she gives for having systematically declined all such invitations that have been received from their brothers of the Northern armies.
Money on call loaned at 3@6 per cent. throughout the day. There was nothing done in time contracts or commercial paper.

Registrar Nagle'e report on the health of the city during the last week shows that there were 805 deaths, against 886 the week before. The death rate was, estimating the population at 1,900,189, 22.10. The average rate for the corresponding period since 1887 was 22.71.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The annual regatta of the Royal Dorset Yacht Club, of which Lord Stalbridge is Commodore, took place to-day. The course covered a distance of forty miles, extending from Weymouth, where the clubhouse is situated, to the Shambles Lightship, the distance being covered three times to make the forty miles.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The ball of the East Bay Yacht Club last night at the Hotel Brooklyn was a charming affair. It seams to be a settled fact that where yachts congregate there beautiful women abound. Last night's ball again emphasized the fact. The Summer girl, as found at Moriches, is too lovely and too lovable for a pen picture.
Two handsome and perfectly-matched speeders will sell for many times the separate value of either, and this is a branch of the trotting market out of all ratio to the supply.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Last week the investment demand for American securities, which was a prominent feature during the previous fortnight, almost entirely disappeared, and does not seem likely to reappear until a different range of values, either higher or lower, is established.

There was a good attendance yesterday at the trotting matinee on the half-mile tract on M.R. Brush's farm at Cold Spring Valley, L.I. C.A. Willis of this city started the horses, and with him in the stand were David Jones, Cold Spring; Townsend Wright, Amityville, and T.H. Bacon, Huntington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The House has had the silver question all to itself to-day. The Senate adjourned last night until Monday, and a number of Senators took advantage of the short recess by going to the seashore and near-by resorts.

While the accusation holds true that there is undue delay in furnishing the children of this city with school accommodations as far as some neighborhoods are concerned, there are other localities where every effort is being put forward to rush the new buildings in course of erection to completion.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- Fully two months ago Englishmen believed themselves to have accumulated grievances against the weather clerk too great for polite language. When these arrears of wrath went on increasing throughout July we tried to cultivate a stoical mood and even joked feebly, while waiting from day to day for that break in the sickening record of sunshine which seemed inevitable.

The Brooklyn Citizen's ten-mile road race yesterday was won by Fred Hawley of the Kings County Wheelmen, who covered the distance m 28:45 3-5. His handicap was 30 seconds. D. Simmons was second, W. Hardifer third, Ray Dawson fourth, and G.T. Wlison fifth. There were fifty-six starters, of whom forty-four finished. The races were witnessed by 2,500 people, but a squad of mounted police allowed the riders to finish without interference from the crowd.

Lord Calthorpe, one of the oldest members of the English peerage, died in England recently. His brother Augustus has succeeded to the title and one of the finest old estates in England, with a rent roll of over half a million dollars a year.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, Aug. 19 -- The meridian of the Summer season of life and gayety at the Thousand Island resorts has been reached. August started in very unauspiciously, and it was feared that the season of 1893 at the Thousand Islands would be a failure, as the hotels only had one-half the number of guests that they cared for during the corresponding period of last year.

A Boston man living out in the suburbs has discovered a fact that may interest a good many persons daring the present sun spot period. What he found was that it is quite possible to see the larger spots that appear on the sun's surface without glass or lens of any kind.

The Nantucket "Sorosis" is a veritable daughter of New-York's famous "Mother of Clubs." Organized under the leadership of a prominent New-York Sorosis member, Mrs. Robecca Morse, it has adopted not only the name but the ideas and aims of the elder organization which, in kindly acknowledgment, has conferred honorary membership upon the first two Presidents of its much-valued namesake.

The State Bank Examiners are still at work on the books of the Madison Square Bank. They are expected to make a report this week. Nothing in it will be studied with more interest than the part dealing with the loans of the bank to persons interested in its management.

The bank statement issued yesterday was the first one that could be called "favorable" that has been put forth for many weeks. It was evident that the process of depleting the banks of their currency had been arrested a week earlier, as the statement of Aug. 12 was plainly upon rising averages.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 19 -- The arrest of Henry Starr and his detention without ball on the charge of murder breaks up one of the most successful gangs of murderers and train robbers that has ever operated in the Indian Territory. There may be others who will endeavor to emulate the exploits of this young man, for he grew into greatness out of the death of the Daltons.
All is not now so peaceful in the home of the Catholic Archbishop of New-York as it was before Dr. Papi expressed for Mgr. Satolli the delegate's views of the situation of affairsin this archdiocese.

The New-Jersey Athletic Clab, as expected, gained an easy victory over the Morris Park team yesterday at Bergen Point, winning by 132 runs after declaring their innings closed with seven wickets down.

Last week it was noted that the only fresh liquidation observable in the market was in the Northern Pacific securities. Professional selling of the general list had failed to brine out long stock and had been followed by advances as the shorts put out were brought in again. The past week has confirmed the views then expressed that liquidation in stocks had reached the point of exhaustion.

The School of Applied Design for Women, organized a year ago for the purpose of affording to women instruction which will enable them to earn a living in the application of ornamental design to manufacture and art, in its prospectus for this year shows how broad a field of work it opens up for its students.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The favored mortals who are spending the Summer at Cold Spring Harbor have had an enjoyable week of it and express a great deal of sympathy for those untutored beings who think they are having a good time at other resorts this Summer.

Judge Carter of Bradford, Col. Whitney of Royalston, and Lawyer E.B. Savage of Haverhill, Commissioners for Massachusetts, together with Judge Bell, N.H. Clark, and C.H. Roberts for New-Hampshire, and Col. Kittredge Haskins, Lawyer J.R. Batchelder, and Judge Levant Read for Vermont, left Brattleborough this morning for South Vernon, where they will proceed to locate the corner of the States of Vermont and New-Hampshire on the north line of Massachusetts.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The recent cool evenings have not caused any of the Summer visitors to think of home, and although many go to other resorts, their places are immediately filled by new-comers, and the hotels and cottages are all filled almost to overflowing.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The Rev. George Hodges of Pittsburg, Penn., and the well-known amateur artist Harold Hayward of Larchmont Manor have been recent guests of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kirke Porter at the Swayne cottage, ShinnecocK Hills. Dr. Hodges gave a most interesting lecture to the students at the art studio on "The Passion Play."

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 19 -- In his lifetime James W. Hyatt, Treasurer of the United States in Mr. Cleveland's first Administration, was thought to be a wealthy man. When he died it was generally supposed that his administrator would find a goodly sum to be turned over to the widow and children. But it is now said that when all debts are paid there will be little, if anything, left of Mr. Hyatt's estate.

The disorderly element of the unemployed brought together last week by the professional Anarchists and Socialists for the purpose of making so-called "hunger demonstrations," one of which, at Walhalla Hall, developed into a riot which the police had to quell, had arranged to make yesterday a red-letter day.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 19 -- Bar Harbor weather has been as fickle for the last week as the proverbial woman is supposed to be, and every vanity known to the Summer calendar has been brought out. This uncertainty has been especially trying to the women, for how to dress has become a problem difficult to solve.

"How to Build the Cathedral" is the title of a tastefully-prepared pamphlet by Bishop Potter which has been distributed among the clergy and laity of the diocese. In the pamphlet the Bishop gives his views as to the best way to secure money to build the new Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on the heights above Morningside Park.

Who will win the all comers'? is just now the one absorbing question of interest among tennis players. The great meeting which is to decide the championship of the United States begins nest Tuesday on the courts of the Newport (R.I.) Casino, and it is a rash prophet who dares to predict with any degree of assurance just which of the host of candidates will bear off the trophy.

The charlatans who sold orvietan, that so-called antidote to poison, on the Pont-Neuf, may have bad some faith in their drug, but they sold it by means which nothing may excuse save a good purpose. They were triumphantly successful in their sales, and the means of effecting them seemed not perhaps very iniquitous.

Daub, the new Brooklyn pitcher, had one bad inning yesterday, and in that short period he managed to present the Cincinnatis with a game. He was not hit hard, but his bases on balls proved disastrous. "Silver" King was in the box for the Reds, and at times he was hit rather lively, but when the bases were occupied he appeared to brace up wonderfully.

Major Morris B. Farr, for many years on the staff of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, and recognized as an authority on military matters, died at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Homeopathic Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. His wife, his eldest son, and his daughter were present at his bedside. An operation for appendicitis had been performed on Thursday, and Major Farr did not recover from its effects.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 19 -- The nomination of Lawrence T. Neal for Governor at Cincinnati forecasts one of the most brilliantly-fought and exciting campaigns in the history of Ohio politics.

The members of Company H, Twenty-second Regiment, are anxiously watching for the expected announcement of an election in their company for Captain to succeed Capt. Hussey, resigned. The company is divided as to the selection, a number wanting the honor conferred upon First Lieut. C.C. Cassidy, while others say they will be satisfied with any competent man who is selected at headquarters.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 19 -- Speaking of his mission to Hawaii, Mr. Blount said to-day:

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19 -- At 9 o'clock this morning Judge Abbett charged the jury in the Shann murder trial. He began his remarks by stating that the only question was whether Mrs. Shann was guilty of administering to her son mercurial poison, which caused his death.

PROSPECT HEIGHTS, Shelter Island, Aug. 19 -- This was an ideal day for racing. There is generally some kind of a breeze blowing in Deering Harbor in the afternoon, but to-day when it began to blow it kept up a good breeze all afternoon. The Shelter Island Yacht Club boasts of some fine sailing craft this Summer, and to-day was the first opportunity given to try conclusions with outside yachtsmen.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Sayville, because of its being one of the most delightful resorts on all Long Island, contains a large and happy colony of Summer visitors. They appreciate a good thing when they find it; hence their fondness for Sayville. The view of the Great South Bay is nowhere finer than it is here. Everything that any favored resort within 100 miles has to offer Sayville has.

The "Remains" of Arthur Henry Hallam have twice been printed, once in 1834, when they were intended for private circulation and had a memoir by the poet's father, and again in 1862. The present edition of his verse follows the first edition of the "Remains," now a rare book. The preface by the editor fills some twenty pages.
Four floors of the warehouse, 290 South Street, fell through to the cellar at 3:15 P.M. yesterday, and nearly a dozen men employed in the building narrowly escaped death.

One of the mast attractive features of Mrs. Sarah T. Rorer's "Talks upon Cooking" is that celebrated cook herself. She is a tall, fair-faced woman, of good presence, who upon the platform invariably wears a plain black gown surpliced with soft white. A big practical-looking apron is tied about her comfortably plump waist, and a dainty three-cornered bit of lace rests upon her dun-colored hair.

It is not often a full-grown fox is caught with the hands in an open pasture, but that is what an East Waterford boy did. He saw the fox sitting on a knoll, and in his bare feet was able to creep up behind and grab Reynard by the tail. He swung the fox around by the tail trying to conquer him, but had to let him go after his shirt was nearly torn off.

President Eliot of Harvard recently suggested a practical scheme by which parents might insure a college education for their sons and daughters. It was proposed that the parent should pay to some reliable insurance company a certain sum annually, beginning with the third year of the child's age, the company guaranteeing to par the child, beginning with his eighteenth year, the sum of $400 per annum for the next four years.

Cabin passenger traffic to the eastward is at a low ebb these midsummer days. Several vessels sailed for Europe yesterday, but one big liner could have accommodated nearly all the saloon voyagres they carried out. Among those who sailed were:

It was established yesterday that John Cashman, the young member of Fire Insurance Patrol No. 1 who Friday night nearly lost his life trying to rescue a boy, Bernard Cravitz of 7 Norfolk Street, at Pier 47 East River, acted with extraordinary bravery.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 -- There must be a hoodoo somewhere in the New-York Yacht Club. The ill-luck that has been following the yachts on the cruise still sticks, and it seems impossible to get a breeze in which to sail any kind of a race, or if there is a breeze, for it to hold a true.

ELIZABETH, N.J. Aug. 19 -- The Worthington Pump Works, which looked out their striking employes three weeks ago, will resume operations on Monday next with one-third of their usual force. The men struck against a reduction of 10 per cent. in their wages. They return to work at the old figure.

The Berwick man who took several thousand dollars from the bank, put it in his vest pooket, and then lost the garment, was convinced that the banks are yet the best places to keep money. He thought some tramp had stolen the vest, but when later he found vest and money in a grain box where he had foolishly laid it, he became more than ever convinced of the security which the Maine banks afford.

The quantity of wheat exported last week has been exceeded only twice in the weekly record of our export trade. Of the two weeks in which the exports were greater, one was in August, 1891, and the other in September of the same year. The following table shows the exports of wheat, and corn for the last five weeks:

There was a lively game of ball at Prospect Park yesterday afternoon between the players of the Andrews Demorest Seating Company and the Andrews Manufacturing Company. The former won by a rally in the fourth inning. Score by innings:
"I think It has been the most corrupt racing that I ever saw."

Edward S. Stokes, the manager of the Hoffman House, and President of the Hoffman House Corporation, which has an extensive control of various hotels and cafes, laughs at the idea that a receiver will be appointed for the corporation property.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Enjoyment has been plentiful all the week and has taker on every form. Bluefishing has led, perhaps, because these gamey fish are plentiful off Islip and the sport is spirited. Large parties make daily pilgrimages out upon the water and return laden with six and eight-pound trophies.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Progressive euchre parties, evening concerts, and informal dances at the Sea Cliff Hotel; bathing, boating, and fishing parties, drives, and tennis have made the week at pretty Sea Cliff a merry one. Realizing that there are not many weeks of the season left, everybody is bent upon extracting all the joy possible out of life while it lasts, and Sea Cliff is an ideal place for the task.

BERLIN, Aug. 19 -- Count Posadovsky Wesner, be successor of Baron von Maltzahn as Secretary of the Imperial Treasury, will assume the duties of the office Sept. 1. On the same day Baron von Maltzahn will give a farewell banquet to the officials of the Treasury and other Government departments.

BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 19 -- New-York and Brooklyn people are swarming into Bethlehem, many of them to remain through the dreaded, "hay fever" season, others simply to see the coaching parade which will take place next Tuesday. The hundreds of Hummer guests and cottagers are looking forward to Aug. 22 as the day of days for 1893 in Bethlehem.

SARATOGA, Aug. 19 -- Two days of almost incessant downpour have net seemed to damp the ardor of summer loiterers here, who in default of some of the sports promised them have had all the gayer house parties and impromptu hops and musicales. Between the showers the avenues blossom out with traps, whose occupants seek hasty shelter when the next cloud breaks, and only the grooms and hostlers growl at the weather.

The editors, reporters, and members of the publication department of the New-York Herald did their last work yesterday at the old headquarters, Broadway and Ann Street, and the paper was issued for the last time from that office this morning. The orders to the members of the staff are to report for duty at the new, handsome, and commodious headquarters up town, at Thirty-fifth Street and Broadway.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 19 -- Thieves have been robbing cottages here this week. This is very distressing to keepers of the gambling houses. They regard it as unprofessional to intrude upon their territory.

Why do not our ladies rebel en masse and persist in promenading during the acts and taking their coffee or tea, claret or champagne cup, in the foyers and refreshment buffets with their gentlemen friends, brothers, and husbands? The only alteration I would have in our theatres is that a handsome foyer as well as refreshment rooms should be added to every house.

The affairs of the Commercial Bank continued to receive the attention of the business portion of Brooklyn yesterday. The announcement in THE NEW-YORK TIMES that criminal proceedings might be begun against the officers of the bank and the rumor that the Directors had decided to request the State Superintendent of Banking to call for the appointment of a receiver were widely discussed.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- The dramatic event of the coming week will be the opening of the reconstructed Museum Monday evening, when Roland Reed will present for the first time in this city "Innocent as a Lamb." The engagement is for three weeks, and will be followed by Barnet and Thompson's new opera, "Prince Pro Tem."
The United States cruiser San Francisco reached this port yesterday after a five days' cruise at sea with the Philadelphia and Rochester Naval Reserve battalions on a cruise of instruction.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In calling on Congress to make an appropriation for the relief of workingmen, the New-York Herald has made a most serious mistake. In this case, as in all others, the giving of money for relief, to be intelligently helpful, should be done with reference to the removal of the cause of the distress as well as for the satisfying of present wants.

Paris Correspondent London Standard. On Sunday evening an amusing incident occurred in the Champs Elysees quarter. A man named Haja, employed by M. Marseille, a wild-beast tamer, thought he had a right to add to his wages by exhibiting his master's bear in the streets. With this object in view, he installed the bear in an open cab, and, taking his seat beside the animal, told the coachman to drive to the Champs Elysees.

BROPHY'S POINT, WOLFE ISLAND, Canada, Aug. 19 -- There never was and probably there never will be a more beautiful camp of the American Canoe Association than this. It is the culmination of all that is desirable in canoe camps, and old members of the association who have followed the meets from the beginning in Lake George, in 1881, are unanimous in their acknowledgment of the superior advantages of Brophy's Point.

The biggest crowd that attended the races at Clifton since the meeting opened, two weeks ago, was at the track yesterday. The betting line and grand stand were crowded. The heat was oppressive, and, although dark clouds hovered over the track, the cooling shower did not come until the horses were at the post for the last race.

Since the season of Italian opera at Covent Garden ended, the London papers have been devoting their musical columns to a review of it. Of course the malcontents find plenty to abuse, but the general opinion appears to be that Sir Augustus Harris has given the metropolis of the world about as good a season of opera as it ever had.

The performance of the Navahoe in the regatta of the Royal Dorset Yacht Club is calculated to confirm the discouraging belief that she will not bring back the cups that she went to the other side for the purpose of winning. She went, it is always fair to bear in mind, a practically untried boat.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 -- A number of fires have occurred in this city recently which have given rise to a suspicion that certain persons were scheming to collect insurance money. The first cause of this suspicion was the removal of the railroad car and machine shops from Huntingburg to Princeton, Ind. Hundreds of men were thrown out of work.

The midsummer holiday has come upon that unfortunate victim of circumstances. Mayor Boody, and found him ill prepared to enjoy a surcease from his troubles. Last year he fied from the madding crowd of politicians to Roslyn, on Long Island, where in the shadow of Bryant's oak he used to muse when he returned of an afternoon from his Broadway banking office and ponder the woes that came to him with office holding.
"I want you to advise me about my money," said a rich widow not long ago to a newspaper woman. "You are a woman of business and can tell me what to do."

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 19 -- Lieut. Gov. Percy Daniels has sent to Washington to be introduced in Congress his graduated income tax bill, which, with the addition of one section referring to the property of aliens, was introduced in the Fifty-second Congress by Senator Peffer and Representative Clover. The bill covers forty-one sections, and, briefly stated, it provides that a graduated annual tax be levied and collected as follows:

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 19 -- The annual regatta has been the chief event of the last week. The races were unusually well contested, and of course attracted a large number of spectators from all the resorts on the lake. H.W. Watrous acted as starter. The judges were G.E. Rogers and Dr. H. Power. The Rev. Charles P. Fagnani was referee.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 19 -- The hope of a revival in lake business by the latter ball of the season, like all the hopes of the vessel men this year, seems fated to end in utter disappointment. The wheat movement, which was looked to to cause an improvement in rates, is checked by the financial situation, and the shipments of coal and ore are curtailed for the same reason.

Readers of the recent memoir of Smetham, with accompanying letters, will be glad to possess this volume. Having learned what manner of man he was and with what charm he could write in private correspondence, they here have examples of the work he intended for the public eye. The slight volume makes an admirable supplement to the former publication.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 19 -- Nothing of especial moment has happened during the last week to disturb the calm serenity of Summer life at Elberon. The weather, in the main, has been delightful. Tennis playing is decidedly the fad just now. Every one who is strong enough to wield a racket plays the game. It must be admitted that they do not all play it well.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 19 -- Bell Island continues to be an attractive spot for Western Connecticut visitors, and the cottages are filled. A number of pleasant entertainments have been given and more are being arranged.

The death is announced in Paris of Auguste Barthelemy Glaize, the French painter whose long rivalry with Ingres is a source of interminable ancedotes. He was born at Montpellier, Dec. 15, 1807. He was a pupil of Achille and Eugene Deveria and a veteran exhibitor at the Salon where his first work appeared in 1836.

With the publication of this volume only one other book in the Twelve English Statesmen Series remains to appear -- the one on Chatham -- and John Morley, who has it in hand, is understood to have made much progress in the writing of it. The appearance of that book will be awaited with interest by all who remember the charm exercised over them by the same writer's account of Walpole in this series.

In the classification of life, from the lowest, the protozoa, to the highest, the vertebrata, the foraminifera, and the infusoria being at the beginning and ourselves at the end, there is one division known as the arthropoda, or animals with jointed limbs, and to this division Mr. Stebbing's volume is devoted.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The cotillion given at the Manhanset House, and which was arranged by Miss Jane Headley, assisted by Miss Alice Lowell and Miss Ada Blackford, was one of the most brilliant events of the season. About seventy-five ladies and gentlemen participated, and Howard Walton of Newark led.

THEODORE A. HAVEMEYER, JR., GONE TO EUROPE. -- Theodore A. Havemeyer, Jr., whose engagement to Miss Katherine Sands, a daughter of the late Samuel S. Sands, was announced early in the Spring, sailed for Europe last Wednesday in the steamship Majestic. He expects to be absent until about the last week of September. The marriage of Miss Sands and Mr. Havemeyer will probably be celebrated in this city before the Christmas holidays.

As was expected, a very close game resulted from the meeting of the Staten Island Athletic Club and Victorias at Central Park, and, after a very exciting contest, the Staten Islanders gained the victory by 2 runs. The bowling of A. Richardson and J.L. Douglas for Victoria and E. Snelgrove for Staten Island gave the batsmen few opportunities to score, for 11 by A.F. Head was the best score of the match.

M. Berillon, the noted French physician, finds that the habit of nail biting among children is extremely common. In a public school in Paris, out of 265 pupils examined during the month of April last, 63 that is to say nearly one-fourth were addicted to the practice. Curiously enough, results very greatly in diferent districts and in different schools in the same district.

IBSEN'S TABLE -- The papers on the table were all most neatly tied up into little bundles, the manuscripts fastened with elastic bands -- everything was in its place; for Ibsen has a most remarkable love of order and neatness. He is faddy, almost to the point of old-maidism, and cannot bear disorder.

An interesting and wordy warfare took place yesterday morning in the Jefferson Market Police Court between Justice Hogau and Lawyer George M. Barnett. The magistrate practically gave the attorney the lie direct. There is a dispute as to the exact words used by the Justice, but many people who were in court say he used the words, "You lie."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The Summer season at this resort is now at its height. Every hotel and boarding house is packed full of health and pleasure seekers. This condition of affairs will continue for about two weeks longer, when the crowds will begin to leave for their city homes, and by the middle of next month the hotel keepers will think of closing for the season.

After the weekly bank statement had been issued yesterday Wall Street felt a little more comfortable. While its showing did not come up to the hopes of some of the optimists, it generally satisfied the Street. It was certainly a great improvement over the statement of the week before.

THE TIMES has had a good deal to say about the degeneracy and the highly unsatisfactory operation of the "special-delivery" service in the Post Office. One feature of it, which is called to our attention by a mercantile firm, ought to receive the attention of Mr. DAYTON. This firm received a letter with a special-delivery stamp long after the usual mail had been delivered, so that the ten-cent stamp actually operated to retard the delivery.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- The threatening weather deterred many from attending the midsummer bicycle meet of the Asbury Park Athletic Association this afternoon. There were nearly 2,000 spectators present, many of whom were hotel guests and cottagers. The racing was quite spirited, although a strong wind prevented the riders from making fast time.

Eppenger Russell, lumber dealers at 66 Bond Street, failed Friday. Shortly before the failure was announced Deputy United States Marshal Biggart of Brooklyn seized a quantity of lumber belonging 10 the firm at the yard on Gowanus Bay and at its works on Newtown Creek. The first was to satisfy a claim made by George C. Southard for $2,377,56, for bringing a cargo of lumber from Mobile, Ala.

The rigid inquiries now instituted at the ports of the United States to keep undesirable immigrants out of the country are likely to divert immigration into Canada, where it is welcomed, and the Minister of the Interior is already rejoicing in the prospect of increased population. What is chiefly interesting to an outside observer is that countries which do not generally export their citizens are now beginning to do so.
The box office of the headquarters of the Coney Island Athletic Club was a cave of gloom yesterday as well as on Friday night.

The last weeks of the season of "King Solomon" and of all the attractions at Eldorado are announced. It is usual at this period to determine the date for the end, and the Board of Directors think about three weeks more will suffice. Sunday afternoon a daring young woman aerohaut, Miss Maude De Haven, will make an ascension in the new mammoth balloon "Eldorado," and will descend in a parachute.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Aug. 19 -- The body of a young suicide was found in a clump or woods near the old Jackson tide mill at Bowery Bay this afternoon. It is that of a young man about thirty years old, of light complexion.

The auction sales of real estate announced for the present week are not especially notable. They are all in legal proceedings and are not numerous, which is considered a good sign. Details are subjoined, all sales being at 111 Broadway unless otherwise stated:

On the 14tn inst. Senator VOORHEES of Indiana introdnced a bill, strongly indorsed by the Secretary of the Treasury, providing that national banks should be authorized to issue circulating notes to the pavalue of the bonds now or hereafter deposited, with the condition -- which is that of the law as it stands -- that the circulating notes of no bank shall exceed the paid-up capital of that bank.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- The week has been a delightful one here. Activity has succeeded the repose which came so naturally with the great heat, and there have been many dances and excursions.

Some time ago Mr. Isaac L. Rice said to a representative of THE TIMES that the lease of the Lehigh Valley Railroad to the Reading was unjust to each road. The recent abrogation of the lease by the Reading receivers seems to justify Mr. Rice's opinion. The following correspondence between Mr. Rice's counsel and the President of the Pennsylvania Company for the granting of annuities is therefore interesting:

PATAUKUNK, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- At a meeting of citizens of Pataukunk and vicinity, held yesterday to consider propositions touching the drought which was then prevailing, but has been broken by the rain this morning, the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The Connecticut National Guard will go into camp at Niantic Monday for six days' instruction under Gen. Haven of New-London, who has acquired considerable reputation during the past four months as Military Commandant of the Connecticut State Prison in Wetherfield. Gen. Haven was advanced to the command of the National Guard last year, and has been through one encampment.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 20 -- While bathing in the ocean, between the two iron piers at West Brighton this evening. Percy Marcias, son of Detective Joseph Marcias of Chief McKane's command, picked up a tightly-corked soda-water bottle. In it was a ragged piece of common manila wrapping paper, on which was written the following:
