SYLVAN BEACH, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The People's Forty has indeed had a watery time of it. Between the elements and the Prohibitionists they have struggled to keep their heads above water. To-day promised to see the encampment grounds crowded, but the morning dawned with a thunderstorm and torrents came down until nearly noon, completely soaking everything.

The handsome brownstone residence at 501 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, was the scene yesterday evening of a ceremony and merrymaking combined that was almost unique in the records of society circles of that city. It was the public engagement of Miss Frances Byk, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Byk, to Henry Stein, a popular young man of Brooklyn.

It required two practical illustrations, in the form of severe stabs in the body, to convince James Foley, a truckman who lives in the Cleveland House, 128 Park Row, that it is unwise to allow curiosity to prevail over common sense.

PARIS, Aug. 20 -- The general Parliamentary election in France to-day was unexpectedly free from disorders and even excitement. In Paris the poll, although much larger than usual, was quite featureless.

The Education Department of the American Social Science Association offers an unusually attractive programme for its day at Saratoga, Sept. 5. Hamilton W. Mabie, the well-known litterateur and editor of the Outlook, will make the opening address. This will be followed by a paper on "The Seamy Bide of the Kindergarten," by Edward Fisher of Berkshire, Mass.
LEROY, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- An accident occurred here at 10 o'clock this morning on the Lehigh Valley Railroad crossing of Lake Street in which five people were instantly killed. Their names are:

The following indicates the amount of bullion in the principal European banks last week and the corresponding date last year. The figures are received weekly by cable by the Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

Samuel Tache is a young German who believes with a countryman of his that it was merely to give space for wandering that the world was made so wide. He puts this theory of his into practice at every available opportunity. He is only sixteen years old, but he has seen more of the world than most people of three times his age.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A serious state of affairs is disclosed on board the United States steamship Atlanta by the naval court of inquiry recently in session at Norfolk, and of which Capt. T.O. Selfridge was the President. The report of the court may result in the courtmartial of three or four prominent officers of the navy.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In October, 1890, it was decided by the Department of the Interior that claims under the Disability Pension act of June 27, 1890, should be adjudicated and rated as those of service origin. Accordingly, Gen. Raum placed 350000 invalid pensioners upon the roll under this act, or78 2-10 per cent of that class of claims acted upon.

If you wish to talk about absent-mindedness you may instance the man in Lewiston, Me., who, the other day, entered an office, transacted some business, and went out, leaving a package done up in a piece of newspaper on a desk. The tenant of the office saw it, thought the man would return for it, and let it lie.

Among the veteran editors of the country Albert G. Tenney, for thirty-five years past editor and publisher of the Brunswick (Me.) Telegraph, holds an honored position. He is now closely approaching his eightieth birthday. In fair health, and with undiminished enthusiasm in his chosen life work. In early life he was connected with newspapers in Baltimore and Boston.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: An attempt to establish the true facts which make prices, necessarily must commence with an inquiry into the relation of the laborer's share in the cost of the product. But we should get entirely wrong results if we followed the old methods of estimating the cost of production by the daily wage rate known to exist.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- The massacre of Italians by Frenchmen at Aigues-Mortes on Thursday came as sadden thunder from the clear international sky. Already it has become the subject of voluminous correspondence among the Foreign Offices of the Triple Alliance, and during the next few days probably will be made the most important incident in this dull season among the Continental powers.

Thoroughly drenched and dripping, from the Battery to Harlem, New-York emerged from the flood early yesterday afternoon. It was the greatest rainstorm of the year, and one of the greatest that has occurred in this vicinity in many years.

Numerically the largest, though not the most influential, class of the advocates of free silver coinage are those who desire the unlimited admission of silver to the mints to produce an inflation of the currency. "Cheap money'' is their cry, cheap dollars and more of them, their desire. These friends of silver ought to study attentively the abstract of the last reports of the national banks to the Controller of the Currency.

No Assembly district in the city has undergone more complete political changes than the Ninth. Once a Republican stronghold, it is now Democratic, and the drift of sentiment is steadily in the direction of Democratic principles. The reapportionment is not responsible for the change. The Republicans say that it is, but the Democrats aver that the change in the lines did not make it easier to carry for the Democracy.

The remarkable results recently achieved with smokeless powder in a service field gun at Sandy Hook have now been supplemented with still higher velocities in the segmental wire gun. The powder thus tried is the Leonard, an American invention, and the result is certainly promising for the development of either this or some other American powder which can be used in field pieces, naval guns, and the new magazine small arm.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Mgr. Satolli has restored to the full powers of Roman Catholic priesthood the Revs. P.A. and W. P. Treacey. The Papal Delegate had on March 13 excommunicated them for insubordination to Bishop O'Farrell.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Aug. 20 -- A terrific cyclone swept this portion of Somerset County early yesterday evening. Trees and shrubbery were leveled to the ground, gardens and crops completely ruined, buildings unroofed, and a vast amount of damage was done.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 @ 6 cent, the average being about 4 cent.

George R. Purvis, a well-dressed and respectable appearing young man, who said he was twenty years old and was a clerk, but who refused to tell where he lived or by whom he was employed, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of forgery. He is in jail now, under $2,000 bonds for trial.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The Bedouin village in Midway Plaisance furnished a lively sensation to-day, and as a result four Arabs are in jail for scourging Hashad Abdalla with their camel and donkey whips.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The week opens with the advocates of the repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman law more confident than over that repeal is a matter of the near future.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 19 -- The condition of our local money market continues to show some slight improvement; that is, there is a leas urgent demand for accommodation on the part of the borrowers. This may be in part accounted for by the inevitable contraction in nearly all kinds of business resulting from the general depression which everywhere prevails.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 20 -- Francis Henry Weeks, the New-York embezzler, is living here. The correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES found him at the Gran Hotel to-day.

What is claimed to be the largest torpedo boat in existence will shortly be launched at the Oriolle Yard at Nantes. France. Work on the vessel, which is to be named Lansquenet, was begun a year ago. She will be provided with twin screws, and is expected to develop a speed of 26 knots an hour. In addition to her torpedo armament she will carry three quick firing guns.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- At a call of the Chicago Tailors' Union for a mass meeting of the unemployed. Metropolitan Hall was completely filled this afternoon with a crowd of between 1,500 and 1,800. The majority of the gathering was composed of Jews, the balance of Germans, Poles, and Italians, with a few Americans.

The Orange Athletic Club cyclers will hold a race meet on the Orange Oval on Wednesday afternoon, Sept. 13. The events will be: Half-mile and mile club championships, and one, two, and five mile handicaps. Prizes will be awarded winners and second and third men. Entries close at the clubhouse, Halstead Street, East Orange, on Monday, Sept. 11.

The Treasury Department intends to enforce more rigorously the law concerning aliens as soon as the World's Fair closes. The department considers that all aliens who come to this country for the purpose of making a living are immigrants whether they arrive as steerage passengers or in the saloon. None but steerage passengers, however, will be required to pass through the Landing Bureau on Ellis Island.

The Italian fleet now in port consists of four war ships. The vessels are the Etna, Vittorio Emmanuele, Amerigo Vespucci, and Flavor Gioja. The Etna, which arrived in New-York on Wednesday from Halifax, is flying the flag of Rear Admiral Magnani.

It is significant that the intellectual renaissance of the sixteenth century was marked and in great measure stimulated also by the strong interest which, in connection with the Reformation movement, began to be displayed in a methodical study of the Old Testament. The activity that followed was profound in its influence on religious thought and maintained its vitality till the middle of the last century.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 -- Henry C. Payne received word to-day from Winnipeg that the court there had appointed himself and Messrs. Oakes and Crouse receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad interests in Manitoba, thus giving them control of the interests of the company, including the 6,000 miles of railroad, the leased lines, the Puget Sound and Alaska Steamship Line, and the terminals.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 -- The ninth animal convention of the Bundes Kriegerfest of North America opened to-day. At 11:30 o'clock the visiting delegates and local societies assembled south of Washington Avenue on Twelfth Street. None of the veterans had forgotten their military training. With erect carriage and unison of step, they marched east to Broadway fully 2,000 strong.

The attention of the country has been so absorbed in the one object for which Congress is now in session that little interest has been shown in LEE MANTLE'S claim to a seat in the Senate, though it involves a question of some importance, and upon its decision depends the right of three States to a full representation in that body.

Bookmakers doing business at the Monmouth Park and Clifton tracks are having a lot of trouble in getting currency with which to carry on their business. Theirs is essentially a cash business, and even certified checks do not go at the race tracks. Bookmakers will only accept cash, and they have a lot of patrons who want cash in payment of bets they may have won.
BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- Mayor Matthews has given a long interview on politics at his Summer home at Jefferson, N.H., in which, in discussing the situation in the Nation and State, he says:

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $4,499,575. The banks now hold $12,045,800 less than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $5,255,500, an increase in specie of $4,728,000, a decrease in legal tenders of $703,700, a decrease in deposits of $1,901,100 and an increase in circulation of $702,200.

Mgr. Satolli will start for Washington at 8 o'clock this morning, after having passed in New-York a week noteworthy for developments of peculiar interest to Catholics throughout the country, as of peculiar significance in their bearing upon the longstanding controversies in this archdiocese and the much-discussed attitude of Archbishop Corrigan toward the Apostolic Delegate.

Two conclusions are warranted in regard to Francis H. Weeks when the dispatch from San Jose is considered. One is, that he continues to live in luxury with the money he stole from his trust clients, and the other that he is not fully alive to the enormity of his crimes, and either believes that "it will blow over" or that a compromise with his victims may yet be brought about.

Macmillan Co. expect to occupy their new building, in Fifth Avenue, near Twelfth Street, on Sept. 1. For many years established in Bond Street, this English house went into Fourth Avenue eight or ten years ago, and here its business has been greatly extended. The career of the firm in this country extends over more than twenty-five years.

"Willie" Knecht, croquet champion for 1893, is the son of Dr. C. Knecht, a practicing physician of Matawan, N.J. He is a student in the Matawan Military Institute, holding the rank of Second Lieutenant. Next year when he enters school again it will be as either Captain or Major. Three years ago, when he was fourteen, young Knecht made his first appearance at the Norwich croquet meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Everything is ready for the President to issue his proclamation opening the Cherokee Strip to settlement. The last formalities were complied with Wednesday, when Chief Bushyhead of the Cherokee Nation noticed the General Land Office that he had selected his allotment, and inclosed $100 in payment of the lands under the contract with the Government.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Edward Brennan, whose home is at 1,780 Washington Avenue, New-York, went out on the river in a sailboat at noon to-day. While off Grass Island be attempted to fasten his craft to a passing steam yacht. In so doing his boat was over turned and he was thrown into the water.

The recent disclosures as to the enormity of the crimes that are daily committed at Monmouth Park under the sanction of law has aroused the people of Monmouth County, and they have begun a campaign for the prevention of the gambling operations at the Monmouth Park race track. That they are thoroughly in earnest is evinced by the active campaign that is in progress, not only in the churches, but among citizens generally.

ROME, Aug. 20 -- The anti-French agitation spreads hourly. Demonstrative crowds paraded the streets to-night shooting for the King and calling for revenge for the Aigues-Mortes massacre. The police were out in double force all the evening and prevented the crowds from becoming riotous.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- There are scarcely a score of yachts left in the harbor hero. Several of them sailed away as soon as the squadron disbanded. Some went east, some westward, and others are cruising around in these waters and over at Shelter Island.

It is very natural to feel discontent, and even disgust, with the amount of time consumed in the debate in the House of Representatives over the repeal of the Sherman law and the counter-propositions of the silver men. The cost is very great and almost incalculable. Those who know what are the consequences of delay know that they will fall heavily in every direction and most heavily on those who are least responsible.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The four-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell of Park Place, Lockport, was out on the street this afternoon in company with a number of older boys. The little fellow was playing about the road when one of the older boys noticed a yellow jacket sleeve hanging from an apple tree in Fred Barger's yard.

MERRICK, L.I., Aug. 20 -- For several hours last night, while the great storm which swept over Long Island was at its height, a searching party of 300 worshippers in attendance upon the big Methodist camp meeting here, were scouring the woods and fields for Mrs. Andrew Foot of Brooklyn, who had disappeared earlier in the day.
Ah Bow gave Chinatown a sensation yesterday by hanging himself.

Delegates from about thirty labor organizations met yesterday afternoon at 257 East Tenth Street to confer upon the best means to relieve the distress among unemployed workingmen of this city. The meeting was called to order by Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor. Robert M. Campbell of Typographical Union No. 6 was elcted permanent Chairman.

It is not generally known that the Italian system of naval education is patterned largely after that of the United States, though the percentage required is not as high as that demanded at the United States Naval Academy.

The virtuous young men of the west side who filled the gallery of the Grand Opera House last night with their shirt sleeves and their enthusiasm must have rubbed their eyes a bit when they first sat down, and must have fancied for a moment that they had lost their bearings and strayed into one or those new Broadway theatres.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Mr. Gladstone, in the House of Commons to-day, moved the adoption of the resolution, notice of which was given on Friday last, to apply the closure to the report stage of the Home Rule bill on Friday next.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 21 -- Discouraged by the steady downpour of rain and disheartened by the email attendance, Manager Dean of the People's Party missionary board decided to pull down his tents at Sylvan Beach this morning. The farmers of Central New-York have not been gathered into the fold as easily as the Populists expected.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 4@5 cent. The last loan was made at 4 cent.

-- They do not have a long Summer vacation at the University of the South, in Sewance, Tenn., for the reason that it is cool and pleasant no there on the mountains at this season. But in midwinter it is cold and dreary on the heights and professors and students gladly hie them away for the long vacation into lower and warmer places.

The tension of international relations throughout Europe is in general no greater now, perhaps, than it has been for five or six years past. But there are new sources of irritation between some of the powers, as between France and England on account of the Siamese business, and between France and Italy on account of the proposal of the Crown Prince of Italy to attend the German manoeuvres in Alsace.

When one receives notice that one is going to be blown up by dynamite, clearly the best thing one can do is to go down into the basement and search the cellar. This is what a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES did yesterday when he was sent to ascertain what, after all, might be at the bottom of the present Anarchist scare.

-- The Buffalo Athletic Club is in very serious financial difficulties. There are three judgments registered against it. The indebtedness of the club is between $4,000 and $5,000. The books show that about $4,000 is due the club, but only half of that can be realized. The furnishings in the clubhouse are very handsome, and represent a large outlay.

Mrs. Nannie Smith, who is charged by Lawyer J.B. Graham with having snatched from him $350 with which he wanted to bar for Bennie T. Smith a path to divorce, was in a changed mood when she woke up in Yorkville Prison yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Civil Service Commission will hold examinations Sept. 7 to fill three vacancies in the Department of Agriculture as follows: Botanical editor, salary $1,500; agricultural editor, salary $1,100; proof reader and bibliographer, salary $1,000. The examination is open to men only. Application blanks will be furnished upon request.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The American Strawboard Company will to-morrow send to stockholders a circular announcing that the quarterly dividend will be passed. The circular will say:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Considerable surprise was shown this morning when it was announced that a new set of drawings had been made for the All-Comers tennis tournament, which, begins here tomorrow. The first drawings were made on Friday night of last week and the list published the next morning. Later Dr. Dwight discovered that two names had been omitted from the list, which compelled him to make an entirely new set of drawings.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 110 @ 108 1 2, North Chicago at 161 @ 166. Diamond Match at 100 1 2 @ 102 1 2, Lake Street L at 19 1 2, Street's at 163 4. Money, 7 cent. Bank clearings, $10,506,988. New-York exchange, $10 @ $15 discount.

Bernard Dolan of 165 Butler Street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a charge of assaulting his wife, Ellen. Sunday noon Dolan locked the doors of his apartments on the second floor and told his wife he would give her five minutes to live.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 21 -- There is plenty of smoke issuing from countless chimneys of many iron mills this morning in the vicinity of Pittsburg. The sligo works of Phillips, Nimick Co. went into full operation this morning. Three thousand men are at work at Jones Laughlin's to-day, and every department is at work except four mills and the sheet-iron rolls.

Pierrot -- the Pierrot was invented by Banville and Gautier, with Gaspard Deburau as a hint and the Theatre des Funambules for a laboratory. That Pierrot's shadow was on the stage his flesh and blood was in the books of 1830. Gilles and Pedrolino pretend to be his elder brothers, and history says without a tremor that Deburau's son and Paul Legrand and Alexander Guyon and Derudder and Rouffe incarnated him.

"Liberty Hall," a pleasing four-sot comedy by R.C. Carton, that had a long run last Winter at the St. James's Theatre. In London, was well received at the Empire Theatre last evening, where it was put forward to begin the "preliminary season," for Mr. Charles Frohman proposes not to call it the "regular season" at his beautiful little playhouse until Mr. Belasoo's new play, called "The Younger Son," is produced in November.

"Jimmie" McLaughlin's latest purchase, the Crossfire colt, that lost so much money for David Gideon and John Daly, ran yesterday at Clifton and was beaten by a poor lot of two-year-olds at five furlongs. He opened favorite in the betting, was made the medium of a big plunge, but the best he could do was to finish sixth in a field of nine.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The awards made by the Fine Arts Committee of Jurors for Sculpture in the Art Palace were announced to-day by Chairman Thacher of the Executive Committee on Awards. The number or medals and diplomas awarded is eighty-seven. Over 1,000 pieces of sculpture were examined, besides those from France.
It was Memorial Day in Chinatown yesterday, and Mott and Pell Streets and the adjacent small thoroughfares were crowded all day long with Chinamen full of excitement.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 21 -- The Ocean Grove Camp Meeting will begin to-morrow morning and continue ten days. Preliminary services were held on the camp ground to-day. This morning 1,000 believers assembled at thef Auditorium and prayed earnestly for the success of the religious festival. The sacramento the Lord's Supper was observed this evening.

The protracted divorce case of Gibert vs. Gibert, which wan begun Jan. 5, 1892, was brought up again yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas, when John D. Townsend, counsel for the plaintiff, Mrs. Annie Gibert, applied to Judge Giegerich for an order compelling the defendant. Audinet Gibert, to return by Sept. 15 the testimony taken in his behalf in France under letters rogatory from the Court of Common Pleas.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 21 -- The difficulty in moving the cotton crop of Texas has been greatly magnified. There will be no trouble, but there may be a little delay. Galveston banks hold in their vaults more money than ever before at this time of year. This is largely gold, though there will be considerable silver need in moving cotton.

For the last fortnight weakfish have abandoned the upper bay and have been somewhat scarce in the lower bay, but are yet found in the open sea in apparently undiminished numbers. Fish are mysterious in their movements, but their absence in this instance is not unaccountable.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 21 -- The decision of Judge Simonton in the United States Circuit Court in the habeas corpus case of Langford was filed to-day. Langford is the agent of the Richmond and Danville Railroad at Prosperity in this State. He was arrested and held under the twenty-fifth section of the State Dispensary liquor law for delivering to the consignee a keg of whisky shipped from an outside State.

Fish, the poor man's meat, will very probably before the end of the week undergo a material advance in price. Yesterday bluefish went up 1 1 2 cents and weakfish 1 cent a pound. This untoward circumstance is due to Sunday's storm.

The composition of the committees of the House gives evidence of Mr. CRISP'S freedom from the pressure of pledges made to help his own election to the Speakership, or to accomplish any other specific purpose not consistent with the promotion of sound legislation. The Ways and Means Committee is a strong one, and has been wisely placed under the direction of Mr. WILSON of West Virginia as Chairman.

Although the Monmouth Park Association is about bringing its unsuccessful and disgraceful race meeting to a close, Monmonth Park's troubles have but just begun. Pending in the Supreme Court of the State of New-Jersey is an action which is likely to affect it, in common with all other race courses in the State, touching the constitutionality of the law under which they have been racing.
Maurice Klinkowstein, liquor dealer of 162 East Broadway, yesterday again fed those who declared themselves to be unemployed and hungry in that district of the city.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- Returns from the election of members of the Chamber of Deputies received up to 6:30 P.M. show the choice of 330 Republicans, 24 Conservateurs Rallies (Conservatives who have accepted the Republic,) 46 Conservatives, and 37 Royalists.

The Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows or the State of New York will meet at 9 o'clock this morning in Scottish Rite Hall, Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, and the meeting will be one of the most important in many years.

The leading Republican organ in this city yesterday published a large cartoon, over which was in large letters this legend: "How Do Workingmen Like the Prospect of Tariff Smashing?" On the left, with the date 1892, was represented a political meeting, with a sentence attributed to HENRY WATTERSON, and on the right, with the date of 1893, a file of workmen leaving a closed factory.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 21 -- There is no truth in the report that Mascot is foundered. In the third neat Saturday he was attacked with cramps and was a very sick horse until this morning, when Andrews, his driver, started home with him to Buffalo. He is now much better, but will not go in any more races until late, if at all, this season.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: My attention has been attracted by an article in your issue of Aug. 3 on the selection of a small magazize rifle for use in the navy. The article states that Capt. Sampson, the present Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, has selected a board of officers to test the various inventions in small arms and to decide upon their merits.

A receivership for the suspended Commercial Bank in Brooklyn has been agreed upon by a majority of the Directors of that institution. In their judgment, it is said, the bank's affairs are so deeply involved that it will not be feasible to resume. It is now practically only a question as to how much or how little the depositors will receive.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The Western Passenger Association has reconsidered its decision to make no lower rates for Illinois Day at the fair, and the result is to be one faro from all points in Illinois and all points in Western Passenger Association territory within 300 miles of Chicago.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- There was a marked absence of business on the Stock Exchange to-day, due to the midsummer depression and to fear of dearer money.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 21. -- The fifteenth annual congress of the New-Jersey Federation of Trades and Labor Unions was held in Holstein's Hall, Hoboken, to-day. Thomas McGovern of Typographical Union No. 1O3, Newark, presided. Mayor Fagan made an address of welcome.

BATH BEACH, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. Barrett, an actress, who is known on the New-York stage as Lizzie Sloane; her fox terrier, three dog catchers, and an excited populace were actors in a performance here to-night, which resulted in a fainting fit on the part of Mrs. Barrett and an expulsion of dog catchers from this place.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 21 -- The Union and the People's National Banks, which suspended on July 18 and 19, respectively, opened their doors for business at the regular hour this morning, having compiled with the requirements of the Controller of the Currency. Each has on hand a considerably larger per cent. of money to meet immediate liabilities than the Controlled requires.

Brooklyn lawyers and politicians are interested in the approaching judiciary conventions which will select candidates to succeed Justice Barnard of the Supreme Court, whose term will expire Dec 31. A number of prominent Democratic lawyers are mentioned in connection with the place.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The cable line here claimed its third victim from among the members of Congress to-night.

Another horse had a narrow escape from death yesterday morning on the New-York side of the Brooklyn bridge. The horse belonged to Michael Gunther, a peddler of 452 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, who was returning home with a load of goods. He was closely followed by several wagons.

CANOE CAMP, KINGSTON, Ontario, Aug. 21 -- The American canoe fleet had most villainous luck today. Most of the cracks capsized four or five times each and those who did not capsize broke down. Some did both.

Dr. Carl Peters, the African explorer, said to a reporter for THE YORK TIMES yesterday that he wished to correct a statement that had been attributed to him in an interview published on his arrival in this city last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- One indication of the change of sentiment regarding the attempt to repeal the purchasing provision of the Sherman law is the increasing talk in Washington about an early adjournment of the extraordinary session. A fortnight ago it was difficult to find a man who believed that the session would come to an end before the day for the beginning of the regular meeting of Congress.

The hearing in the habeas corpus proceedings brought by Thomas R. Keator, a Broad Street broker, to recover possession or his two young children, Randall and Beverley, from his father-in-law. Theodore Moss, Secretary of the Board of Electrical Control, came before Judge Freedman in the Superior Court yesterday afternoon, and after some discussion the case was postponed till next week.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Ang. 21 -- From the most reliable sources gathered through the State it is safe to estimate the cotton crop of Georgia now being gathered at 1,000,000 bales. In some parts of Georgia cotton has been more heavily planted than last year, while others have reduced acreage. Receipts at the cotton centres seem to be about two weeks ahead of last year.

Indignant residents of the Twenty-third Ward. Brooklyn, filled Joseph G. Braun's barber's shop, 303 Halsey Street, last evening. They were there to express their disgust with the treatment they had received from the Brooklyn City authorities and to counsel together as to what could be done to prevent a repetition of the damage done by the flood of Saturday night.

The much-talked-of bout between Featherweight Champion George Dixon and "Billy," Plimmer of England, who leads the class in pugilism next below, will take place at the Madison Square Garden tonight. Not since the old-time days when John L. Sullivan used to box his rivals in this city has such general interest centred in a limited-round competition.

-- There is one way the pursuance of which with insure publicity for any man. Let him write a book. It is commonly supposed that to write a books requires brains, whereas the real requirement is perseverance. Brains are not so necessary as the physical endurance required mechanically to make a certain number or marks upon paper. -- Boston Homes Journal.

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- The market opened dull and fairly steady, but shortly afterward became very strong, and continued so throughout the day. Atchison gained 1 2 and Chicago, Burlington and Quiney 2 3 8. Much satisfaction is expressed at the way the Atchison floating debt has been renewed. At the Clearing House this morning business was very quiet.

Bank Examiners Judson and Prescott have about finished their examination into the affairs of the Madison Square Back, but that they have not entirely done so is proved by the fact that when Receivers James G. Cannon and Miles O'Brien went there yesterday to take possession they did not do so.

Dwyer of the Cincinnati team pitched with telling effect against the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday and nearly succeeded in giving Fontz's men a coat of "whitewash." Burns, however, saved the stigma of a "shut out" by making a home run in the seventh inning. The Brooklyns appear to be in a demoralized condition, and they played yesterday as though defeat was inevitable.

-- The Staten Island Cricket Club has been particularly unfortunate in regard to their drawn matches this season, and twice has victory been snatched from their hands by either the intervention of the elements or the acy the bearer. While these drawn games are ignored in reckoning the league percentages, they have an important bearing on the final result for the championship.
The press dispatches of yesterday from Berlin contain a summary of a report recently published by the sanitary authorities of that city. The following extract should not be overlooked:
In the parlors of the Hoffman House the New-York Committee of the Bimetallic League met yesterday to arrange for a mass meeting in this city. Nine members were present.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Anthony Miller, proprietor of Miller's Hotel, this city, and formerly an Alderman in New-York, made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors to-day. No figures as to liabilities and assets are given.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 21 -- The cotton crop of this State la larger in acreage by 10 per cent. and more in quantity by 15 per cent, than that of last year. It is spotted in places, but the yield of the State will be about 50,000 bales more than last year, the usual crop being 350,000 bales. The number of bales usually shipped from this city is 30,000.

The appointment of the Coinage Committee of the House has been awaited with deep interest by business men because of the important influence the committee will have in shaping future financial legislation. Of the eighteen members of the committee announced yesterday, thirteen recorded their views in the canvass made by THE NEW-YORK TIMES last June, in which this question was asked:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 21 -- From the beat information obtainable the cotton crop in the Memphis district is at least 25 per cent, better than at this time last year. It is also ten days to two weeks earlier. The first bale of the crop of 1892-3 arrived at this market Sept. 1. There are now four bales of the crop of 1893-4 en route which will arrive to-morrow.

EDINBURGH, Aug. 21 -- The statue of Abraham Lincoln, the "martyr President" of the United States, erected as a memorial to the Scottish-American soldiers of the American civil war, was unveiled here today in the presence of the municipal authorities, many distinguished guests a number of Americans, and a large crowd of residents of Edinburgh, including most of the elite of the town, and people from the surrounding country.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 21 -- Mobile's cotton district lies in the valleys drained by the Alabama and Tombigbee Rivers, and is, therefore, in Western Alabama for the most part, but extends also quite a distance into Eastern Mississippi. Statistics are not collected here or anywhere in Alabama showing the cotton output of the State.

Most American readers will be surprised by the result of the French elections, for certainly not many expected that not only the Republicans in general but the Republicans of the special variety represented by President CARNOT and President CARNOT'S representatives in the last two or three Ministries would hold their own.
"If energetic measures ore immediately adopted the delivery of Weeks to the United States Government can be arranged."
LIVERPOOL, Aug. 21 -- American live cattle, sinking the offal, 5 3 4 d.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 21 -- Great anxiety is felt here because the Dominion Line steamer Sarnia is still unheard from. She is now twenty-three days out from Montreal, having left here at daybreak on July 30, bound for Liverpool. When spoken by the Ripon City, about 500 miles east of Newfoundland twelve days ago, she reported that her machinery had broken down, but she refused assistance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Pension Commissioner Lochren has issued a statement concerning the case of Van Leuven, the pension agent. In it he says:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 21 -- This afternoon Theodore P. Hanghey, President, of the wrecked Indianapolis National Bank, was arrested at his home near this city on a warrant sworn out by Receiver Hawkins charging him with embezzlement and misapplication of funds and credits of the bank from Jan. 1, 1892. until Joly 24, 1893.
"I'll have that child in spite of her clubs and her big son, see if I don't!"

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 21 -- The office of the Pullman Palace Car Company on the fourth floor of 19 Montgomery Street was entered by burglars some time between Saturday night and this morning and $700 and several checks which had been left in the safe were taken.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 21 -- Dr. George M. Dawson, who was employed by the Dominion Government to visit the Bering Sea seal fisheries as one of the British Commissioners, and who has been in attendance in this capacity before the Board of Arbitrators at Paris, has returned to Canada. Asked what he thought of the regulations adopted by the board for the protection of the seals, he said:

SATILLO, Mexico, Aug. 21 -- The committee of citizens, members of the Cardenas party, who went to the City of Mexico to request of President Diaz the appointment of a Military Governor of the State of Coahuila, pending the settlement of the present Gubernatorial contest, have returned. They were unsuccessful in their mission, and Col. Garza Galan will probably continue as Governor until his successor is elected.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- The Corinthian Sweepstakes race for the cup defenders, set for to-day, has been postponed on account of bad weather, and yachtsmen have another disappointment to add to the many experienced during the cruise. The Sailing Committee of the clubmen was anxious to start the race, but the boats decided not to go, and so postponement was the only thing possible.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. Mattle C. Shann was acquitted this morning of the charge of murdering her son, John Shann, Jr. She dined with her family in her home on Wither spoon Street. Princeton, at noon.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The article on "Pure Amateur Racing" in your last Friday's issue by one who is evidently an amateur was much to the point, and I cannot let the same pass without commending the writer and THE TIMES for publishing it. The writer utters sound common sense as regards the amateurism of to-day and the semi-professionalism fostered by the organization the League of American Wheelmen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- When asked for a statement as to the reasons which impelled the Speaker to depose him from the Chairmanship at the Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Springer said:

NEW-YORK. MONDAY, Aug. 21 -- P.M. There was a little more activity in today's stock market than on recent days and the movement of prices was upward. There was no new buying power developed, but the improvement in the general outlook made the bears nervous and induced them to cover some of their abort contracts.
Mgr. Satolli has returned to Washington, and Archbishop Corrigan has entered upon a two weeks' penitential season in St. John's Seminary at Troy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- A reception and tea were tendered Col. and Mrs. Mills and the West Point Cadets by Mrs. Ralph Trautman in the New-York State Building this afternoon. The event was a brilliant social function. The West Pointers and military officers all appeared in their uniforms.

Some of the Cleveland players thought that they had lost all their luck, others attributed it to the poor work of the umpire; but Mr. "Buck" Ewing probably struck the nail on the head when he said that the Giants were playing ball hard to beat. The Clevelands lost three straight games on this trip here, and as they left the Polo Grounds last night they were on bad terms with themselves.

The Right Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Ferguson, Bishop of Cape Palmas and adjacent parts, Liberia, South Africa, who is the only colored member of the American Hauge of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church, is at present in this city as the guest of the Board of Managers of the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of that Church at the diocesan residence in Lafayette Place.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Trouble has been brewing for some time in the internal economy of Mr. Pennington's Chicago and Central Indiana Electric Railroad, which has just collapsed coincidentally with the departure for parts unknown of its projector. It culminated this morning in the peremptory demand of its creditors with a showing of assets, with results which are quite startling.

With the prospect that unless conditions can be promptly improved the entire South will soon be forced to pass through a financial ordeal, the banks and other sources of supply for the South are advising those who are in need of money with which to move the cotton crop to appeal to Congress as the only power which can furnish this relief.

The Treasury report yesterday showed that the gold reserve was below the hundred-million mark, but the fact caused very little comment. Since the big impairment of the reserve and its subsequent recovery, its variations bare not been watched very closely by Wall Street. The report yesterday made the reserve about $99,889,000.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Aug. 22. -- J. Malcom Forbea's schooner yacht Volunteer was practically used up in the heavy northeast gale of Monday while riding at a mooring in Hadley Harbor, an inlet in the Island of Nashon, off Wood's Holl. The yacht parted her mooring chain early in the morning, and was thrown by the seas upon a ledge.

The canny Scotchman who called on the meeting at Union Square on Saturday evening not to listen to the crazy EMMA GOLDMAN or to any one else who had no "stake" in the country was a good representative of the class that for long years to come, at any rate, can be depended on to make the Anarchist propaganda in this country of no avail.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- The market has been quiet, sympathizing very little with New York in its active and stronger tone. Traction stocks Keep strong, with sales of Philadelphia at 70 and Metropolitan at 80. Reading stock holds very firm, while the tendency of Lehigh Valley is to decline. Pennsylvania sold down to 49 1/4 on light sales, the lack of any support being the chief reason for the decline.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 22. -- The town was excited to-night over a chase by the police after a negro who had assaulted Miss Mamie McPhillips of New-York, who is living with her parents in a cottage here. A crowd gathered, which packed the street before the police reached the station house with their prisoner. He was safely locked up, though the crowd around the station house had to be driven back by the police.

NEW-YORK. TUESDAY, Aug. 22 -- P.M. The character of the stock market continues thoroughly professional. There are no outsiders interested, and brokers' offices are without customers. To-day prices were strong at the opening on buying for the foreign speculative account, but when it was over the market receded.
ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- The call for the meeting of the Democratic State Committee was issued to-day by its Secretary, Charles R. Defreest.

The programme for the Grand Circuit trotting meeting at Fleetwood is now complete. Last payments on all the stakes have been made. The entries insure racing of a very high order, superior, indeed, to anything that Fleatwood has had for many years past.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- Charles Sumner Hamlin, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was in town to-day and made Gov. Russell's room in the State House his headquarters. He left on the 2 o'clock train for Washington.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Wanda, Mr. James Stillman; Oneida, Mr. E. C. Benedict; Theresa, Mr. Gustavns Seldenberg, and Linta, Mr. Walter Luttgan. Sloop yacht Imperia, Mr. Henry C. Eno.

Another step was taken yesterday by the Board of Aldermen in the long process of determining the income and expenses of the City Government for the current year. This process begins at the opening of the year with the estimate of expenses made by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment and confirmed by the Aldermen, which becomes in effect the appropriation of money for the various purposes designated.

The annual convention of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows of the State of New-York was opened yesterday morning in the Scottish Rite Hall, Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. Grand Master Charles H. Morgan of this city presided. About 700 delegates were present. The morning session was occupied with the reading of reports and the appoint ment of committees.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 22. -- The yacht Silvie, owned by E.F. Pratt, a prominent real estate dealer of Malden, is nearly two days overdue from Newport, and great anxiety is being felt for her safety by the owner's friends.

GILBERTON, Penn., Aug. 22. -- The tearing up of a portion of the Schuylkill Traction Company's tracks here last night by the borough officials resulted disastrously. When the company's officials heard of the action of the Gilberton people, they sent a force of men to effect an amicable settlement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- President Cleveland has issued a proclamation opening to settlement and homestead entry, on Saturday, Sept. 16, at 12 o'clock noon, central standard time, all the lands, except those specifically reserved, recently acquired from the Cherokee Indian Nation and the Tonkawa and Pawnee tribes in the Indian Territory, known as the Cherokee Outlet.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 22. -- A trainload of passengers from Waverly and Newark, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, had an exciting time and a hunt for a would-be train wrecker at Harrison this morning. The train left Newark at 9:18.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Now that the time is approaching when there will be a call for a vote on repeal in the Senate, the silver-coinage men, in and out of that body, are less positive than they have been about what the advocates of free silver will do to prevent the passage of the bill for unconditional repeal.
The money market was somewhat firmer. Call loans ranged at 4@7 cent. The last loan was made at 4 cent.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 22. -- The Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad pay car reached this city to-day a week late. The men were greatly surprised at not receiving their money. In place of the cash their envelopes contained bank check, dated Sept. 11, and this notice:

The Karamania's detained passengers, who had been isolated on Hoftman Island since their vessel's arrival, were yesterday released by Health Officer Jenkins and turned over by him to the immigration officers. The transfer was to have taken place on Monday, but owing to the inclement weather and high seas prevailing in the lower bay, the moving of the immigrants from Hoffman to Ellis Island was postponed until yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 22. -- This week brings the Grand Circuit stables to this city, and the patronage at Hampden Park to-day was surprisingly good for the first of the meeting, which generally has a light attendance here. The track is much slower than those where the fliers have been earlier in the Circuit, and the heavy footing proved too much for most of them.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Weeks is here with her husband. She appears to have recovered from the effects of the discomforts of the trip from Puntas Arenas.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The great all-comers tennis tournament began here this morning. Owing to the severe rain yesterday the grounds were in poor condition, but early this morning the courts were rolled and re-marked and otherwise prepared for the matches of the day. These necessary preparations delayed the opening somewhat so that it was after 11 before the players were set to work.

CANOE CAMP, KINGSTON, Ontario, Ang. 22. -- The American canoeists got their skates on to-day. Paul Butler of Lowell led the way around the course in the club sailing race; George P. Douglass of Newark, N.J., came in nearly a mile ahead in the combined sailing and paddling race, and Donglass and Sparrow, representing the Ianthe Canoe Club of Newark, N.J., took first place, after a very hot fight, in the tandem paddling.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- The wheat market just tipped over to-day. There were free realizing sales on weak cables, stoppage of shipments, and increased contract stocks. Corn weakened on big receipts, rains over the West, and in sympathy with wheat.

George Dixon, the colored youth from Boston who has conquered all the flatic talent of America, England, and Australia, and who has been regarded as the Napoleon of the prize ring for the past half dozen years, met his Waterloo last night in Madison Square Garden. He was beaten in a four-round contest by a youth smaller, shorter in reach, younger, and lighter by half a dozen pounds than the champion.

Your Uncle Anson and his team of colts were on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon as the opponents of the Giants. Their exhibition reminded one of Frank MoNish's "Silence and Fun." They didn't say a word, afforded the spectators plenty of amusement by their inability to handle hot balls, and proved easy victims for Ward and his men.

A very food instance of the practical difficulties in the way of keeping silver in circulation was afforded yesterday, when the Sub-Treasury received just about as many standard dollars as it was called upon to pay out. The amount on each side of the account was close to $60,000.

That portion of the crowd that backs nothing but favorites had a hard time picking winners at Clifton yesterday. In the opening race, they would have nothing but Foxford, who finished second. In this race Cheddar crossed his legs while rounding the first turn, and fell, throwing Nacey, his jockey. Naccy was injured internally.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 22. -- Representative Democrats of Iowa have been coming in to-day in large numbers to attend the Democratic State Convention, which will meet bare to-morrow.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 22. -- The celebrated case involving the Northern Pacific Elevator Company, a large number of New-England banks, and several hundred farmers of North Dakota and Northern Minnesota came up before Judge Williams of Arkansas in the United States Circuit Court to-day.
BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The Imperial Board of Health announces that there hare been thus far this Summer only four cases of cholera in Germany. Three of the parsons attacked died.

S. Sykes Co., wholesale dealers in boys' clothing at 1, 3, and 5 Lafayette Place, have failed with total liabilities of $350.000 and nominal assets of $400,000. William, Edward S., Charles, and Helen Sykes, who compose the firm, made an assignment yesterday to Lawyer M. Warley Platzek, giving preferences for $86,756.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- A gentleman in this city has just received from a friend in Tien-Tsin, China, a letter stating that United Statet Consul William Bowman, who left that city a short time ago for the United States, carried with him a message from Viceroy Li Hung Chang to President Cleveland.

Senator VOORHEES, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Senate, yesterday made a carefully-prepared speech, nominally on the bill reported by his committee repealing the provision of the Sherman act for the purchase of silver bullion, but he embraced the entire situation, and gave his views as to the legislation required by it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Hon. James H. Blount of Georgia, Minister and Special Commissioner to Hawaii, arrived in Washington at noon to-day and took up his quarters at the Shoreham. After a brief rest he went to the State Department and had a long conference with Secretary Gresham.

An attempt was made by the Anarchists yesterday, after Capt. Devery had issued an order to owners of halls advising them not to let the same to organized unions or lodges, to capture a meeting of the United Hebrew Trades in Pythagoras Hall. They flocked into the hall in great numbers.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- The Findlay Rolling Mill Company, employing 400 men, resumed operations yesterday. The men have signed a contract to accept as much cash as can be paid by the company and time checks and notes payable in sixty days for the remainder.

The Finance Committee of the Board of Aldermen, comprised of Chairman Brown and Aldermen Donovan, Flynn, Morgan, and Murphy, recommended yesterday at the meeting of the board that the tax rate for the ensuing year be $1.82 on each $100 of valuation, the lowest rate in thirty years. According to the report the assessed valuation of New-York City property is $1,933,518,529, which is a net increase of $105,234,254.

WESTCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- A.H. Morris, the athletic son of J.H. Morris, who, together with his father, runs the race track at Morris Park, has just now a disfigured countenance. He has, too, suffered a humiliating political defeat. Last night he was worsted in a row and tonight in an election.

Nothing came of yesterday's meeting of the Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank in Brooklyn. The report of the examiners was not ready, and the board adjourned, until today. After the meeting it was officially given out that the report would be ready this morning, and President Keeney said that the Directors would take definite action as soon as the report was received.

Mayor GILROY, in reply to an application from Mr. GOMPERS, President of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday made some remarks that are perhaps capable of being misconstrued or distorted. Mr. GOMPERS had applied to the municipality to help the unemployed and relieve their distress by "making work" for them.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The ownership of the Astor Cups is settled. They go to the Vigilant, the syndicate cup defender in which Commodore Morgan and C. Oliver Iselin are so deeply interested.

William H. Vredenburgh, the active member of the associated counsel of the Monmouth Park Racing Association, went down to Monmouth Park in a hurry yesterday afternoon on the train leaving this city at 1:30 P.M. On his arrival at the tract he went to the office of Manager Croft and first saw that gentleman. Than messengers were at once dispatched for John A. Morris, for Alfred F. Walcott.

Permission was granted yesterday by Judge Van Brunt in the Supreme Court to the New-York Security and Trust Company, as the general guardian of Dorothea Edgarita Crouse, six years old, the alleged child of Daniel Edgar Crouse, the Syracuse millionaire, to compromise the action brought by Crouse's cousins for an accounting under his will and an adjudication that they alone are entitled to the $3.500,000 forming the residue of the dead man's estate.

South Street, along the East River front, was crowded with idle longshoremen yesterday. The striking men of the Mallory and Ward Lines were joined by those of the Clyde Line, increasing the total number of strikers to about 400 men. The cause of the strike is a reduction of wages from 35 to 30 cents an hour for the night men, and from 30 to 25 cents an hour for the day men.

The Government's printing press in the basement of the Post Office Building was not running yesterday, and several of the workmen had a holiday. On Monday one of the cogwheels of the press broke, and to repair it would cost $4.50. There was no money to meet such a heavy demand, and the press was stopped.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- The Hon. William C. Whitney. Dr. W. Seward Webb, and George G. Haven of New-York were among the absentees at the meeting of Boston and Maine Railroad. Directors in this city to-day. The resignation of Mr. Whitney as a Director was read and accepted.

NEWPORT, Aug. 22. -- The Harvards were put out of the polo tournament to-day, but they played a very creditable game, considering that all cave Mr. Baldwin were practically now on the polo field. Their opponents were the Myopias of Boston, who played a strong team game.

A well-dressed young man, carrying several valises, stepped up to the desk of the Grand Union Hotel Friday afternoon and wrote across the register, "Harry L. Spring, Chicago." He had a brisk business manner, and when he said he wanted a good room the day clerk concluded that he meant the best and gave it to him.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Controller Frank Campbell arrived in Washington from Albany this morning. He was at the Capital this afternoon and spent some tmie with both the New-York Senators. To-night he dined with Senator Murphy at the Arlington, and later sat with him in the lobby and discussed matters political in New-York State.

Those who lost their breath yesterday pursuing the headquarters of the social revolution from one of its rallying points to another commenced naturally at the spot where the now famous "Battle of Kegs" between Landlord Batt and Landlord Fliegman and the outbreak of Anarchy simultaneously began.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The first gun of the battle in the Senate for the repeal of the purchasing clause of the Sherman law was fired to-day by Senator Voorhees of Indiana. There has been desultory firing along the Senate skirmish line since the Congress was convened, but not until today did the artillery open.

The New-York Board of Trade and Transportation has selected Tuesday, Sept. 12, as the date for its convention of representatives of the commercial organisations of the country to take action upon the financial and business situation. Willard's Hall, Washington, has been chosen as the place for the meeting. Circulars announcing this decision were sent out yesterday.

The counsel to the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company have prepared a petition to the United States court asking for authority to issue receivers' certificates. This petition will tie presented to the United States District Judge in Milwaukee to-day or to-morrow.

Police Captain Devery of the Eleventh Precinct, Inspectors McAvoy and Williams, and Acting Superintendent Conlin furnished the Board of Police yesterday with replies to the arraignment of Devery's administration of his bailiwick by Dr. C.H. Parkhurst, T.D. Kenneson, and Frank Moss of the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

No one who has watched the proceedings of the Senate for the last fortnight can have failed to be struck by the number of Senators who have displayed a feeling of dislike, often of hostility, toward the national banks. With some of them we regret to say that this is mere demagogism, a desire to get on their side the ignorant and prejudiced people in their own States who know no better.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Aug. 23. -- A contest has been begun in the Surrogate's Court of this county, before Surrogate S.D. Stephens, for the possession of the children of Carson Lake, formerly editor of the New-York Press.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 23. -- Antonio Garza Ramoa, Secretary of the Cardenas political party in the State of Coahuila, Mexico, has arrived here on a private mission. He is a brother of Jose Ramos, who was recently arrested at Piedras Negras for organizing a Cardenas club, and is now confined in the State penitentiary at Saltillo.

There were expostulations, tears, a tearing of hair, and an attempted suicide on Kllis Island yesterday. This riotous grief was caused by an ediot issued by the Contract Labor Bureau that the small army of immigrants held for examination had been adjudged ineligible to land.

-- The Crescent Cycle Club of Birmingham, Conn., will hold an international circuit meet at the Derby driving Park on Saturday, Sept. 2. The events will be as follows: One mile. 3:10 class, open; one mile handicap, Connecticut riders only; one-mile international diamond race: half-mile, handicap, open: one mile, 2:35 class; one mile, open; one-mile handicap, open; one-half mile, open.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Senator Hill of New-York and Senator Peffer of Kansas have formed an alliance. On the proposition whether the financial interests of the country shall be further imperiled by Congressional action aimed at the banks of the great financial centres they stand together in the affirmative.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- On July 1, 1892, there were 123 savings banks in New-York State, having total resources of $701,112,873, and 1,556,133 depositors. On July 1, 1893, there were 126 savings banks, with $728,124,650 of resources, and 1,621,842 depositors.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 23. -- The Long Island Railroad Company and the College Point Board of Health, had a lively passage at arms this morning, and the Board of Health got very much the better of the battle.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The soldiers meeting here to-day was a very large and enthusiastic one although the expected great men like Sickles, Curtis, Webb, and Woodford were absent Corporal Tanner made the main oration, and retailed in his usually vivid style the dreadful evils pensioners are suffering from the rancor of the Pension Bureau.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 23. -- The following comes from Brunswick at 11:30 P.M. "Dr. Hutton reports Harris, the fever patient rapidly sinking. He can live only a few hours. Outlook gloomy. Mayor Lamb issuing posses to all who wish to leave city."

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Persons who read the Now-York dispatches this morning containing the text of some decidedly combative correspondence between Col. William F. Cody of Nebraska, better known as Buffalo Bill," and John W. Hamilton of New-York were rubbing their hands in gleeful contemplation either of a genuine "affair of honor" between these two men with bowie knives behind barred doors or horse pistols at ten paces.
CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 23. -- Another warfare is on among the piano manufacturers exhibiting at the fair, and sensational charges are being made.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The Massachusetts Naval Militia impressed favorably the regular officers who inspected and instructed them, although the comments on the recent practice cruise at Boston is not without qualifying phrases. Boards were selected by Rear Admiral Benham on both the San Francisco and the Miantonomoh and reports on the work of the militia on each ship have been submitted.

Our news columns contain the account of a most delightful, characteristic, and suggestive performance by the Municipal Council of Dublin. It appears that Admiral ERBEN, United States Navy, has lately visited that city with the Chicago, and was duly and, we trust, agreeably entertained bythe Mayor.

-- Ryan, the Chicago centre fielder, who was recently injured in a railroad accident, is out of bed and hobbling around the hospital on crutches. He will be marked for life. Ryan had a close call. The physicians say that had the wound in his throat been a sixteenth of an inch deeper he would have bled to death before any assistance could have been rendered him.
RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 23. -- More than $1,000000 has been bequeathed to John S. Hough of this town by a Culifornian whom he once befriended.

TOPEKA, Ang. 23 -- There are some few men in this Western country who have been studying the present financial situation to some pur pose. While Senator Peffer has been busy formulating his bill for the issue of $600,000,000 another Kansas man has been ascertaining just what $1 is worth, viewed from his neighbor's position. The editor of the Neodosha Register, whose home is in one of the hotbeds of Populism, says:

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- The report that I am about to abandon the Board of Trade to re-enter the mercantile field is wrong." said "Ed" Pardridge, the plunger, to-day. The speculator was a trifle put out over the gossip, and said that while under certain contingencies he might take back his old store on State Street, now leased by Fist, Joseph Co., he had no intention whatever of quitting speculation.

A cyclonic storm struct tnia city last n ignt just before midnight. Tbe wind blew a gale and. the rain lell in torrents. The storm -was by far the most severe that has been experienced In this city this Bummer, and it has boon a season notable bore for the wars which the elements havo waged.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 23. -- Gov. Horace Boies, the idol of the Iowa Democracy, is again its standard nearer, having been nominated to-day for the Governorship by the State Convention of his party. His nomination by acclamation was accomplished not only with harmony, but with greater enthusiasm and determination than attended his nomination two years ago.

Senator HILL'S State has not expected of him any affirmative utterance or action in the great struggle now making at Washington to relieve the country's distress. It has expected that at least he would refrain from malicious mischief. To the performances of such a solemn idiot as PEFFER of Kansas nobody need pay serious attention, although it is conceivable that in times of great tension a jackass might precipitate a catastrophe with his uplifted bray.

George Gretsinger, Jr., the son of Supervisor Gretsinger of the Twentieth Ward, Brooklyn, is again causing his family trouble. He has threatened to shoot his father on sight, and carries a brace of revolvers and a keen-edged razor as evidence of good faith. Supervisor Grotsinger yesterday applied to the police of the Twentyfirst Precinct for protection from his son.

WEIR CITY, Kan., Aug. 23. -- A negro miner came into town yesterday morning from the coal and coke country after supplies. He was recognized as one of the negroes who took the strikers' places and a crowd gathered, jeered at him, and when they discovered he had a revolver in his hip pocket they made a rush for him.

Our esteemed contemporary the Sun copies from a foreign paper an-explanation of why Lord DUNRAVEN refused to allow the Valkyrie to sail anymore races in-English waters. There is an obvious explanation. The Valkyrie had remained in commission long enough to satisfy her owner that she could beat the only American yacht now in British waters.
CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 23. -- An unusually sensational and romantic story comes to light here to-day, in which grand larceny and bigamy are prominent figures.

The annual Fall yachting season of the Larchmont. Yacht Club will begin Saturday with a race for cabin cats for caps presented by Capt. F.W. Flint. The value of the first prize is $100 and that of the second is $50. The start will be made at 11:30 off the clubhouse, and Captains of yachts must apply at the clubhouse before 10 o'clock to receive members, sailing rules, and instructions.

CooK County, Ill., has had some good ball teams in its day, but the team now representing the aforesaid county is not calculated to add to its renown. Where Capt. Adrian Constantine Anson got his nine of misfits is a mystery. They can't play, bat, run bases, or throw a ball; in fact, they are not capable of doing anything but to ride in parlor cars, put up at good hotels, and draw their salaries.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23. -- A special from Youngstown, Ohio, says: "It was authoritatively stated this morning that an effort would be made by the Brown-Bonnell Iron Company to have its large plant resume operations next week. It was stated that the paddle mills would start on Monday next and the finishing mills on Wednesday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- There was a good race to-day at the New-York State Breeders' Troting Meeting here between Mathew Riley's blk g. Reference and J.H. Shults's bik. f. Lou Wilkes. The latter, starting in a race for the first time, won the first heat in 2:19 1/4., another 2:20 performer for Sable Wilkes. Then the Fleetwood gelding got two heats by a narrow margin.

Frederick M. Sherman, assignee for the firm of Thomas M. Burr Co., has fixed Saturday, Aug. 26, as the final day for the filing of claims against the firm, which failed in April. Mr. Barr, who succeeded to the coffee brokerage business established by his father, now President of the Nassan Bank, Brooklyn, and greatly enlarged it, carried the largest line of coffee options known to the Coffee Exchange.

The young woman who was found drowned in the North River at the foot of One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street on Tuesday morning proves to have been Miss Lena Smith. Her body was identified at the Morgue by her brother, Walter H. Smith, and her relatives have taken charge of it.

The replies to the circular of the New-York Board of Trade and Transportation, asking for views of commercial bodies on the need of the repeal of the Sherman silver law, and proposing a convention of business organizations in Washington to consider financial legislation, have been such, as THE NEW-YORK TIMES has told, to cause the board to call the convention for Sept. 12.

The recent visit paid by Rear Admiral Henry Erbon. United States Navy, with his flagship Chicago, to Dublin, has resulted disastrously to the political ambition of the Right Hon. James Shanks, the Lord Mayor of Ireland's capital.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, Aug. 23. -- P.M. Rumor mongers were busy to-day, but their stories were so indefinite that it was impossible to trace any of them down. The strain has been so intense and so lone continued that intimations that a house is in difficulties, no matter how high its standing may be, are received with a certain amount of credence because the probability of such trouble, in view of existing conditions, is recognized.

-- The members of the South western Traffic Association were in session in Chicago all of yesterday, deliberating over the alleged deal between the Rock Island and Texas Pacific, but were unable to get down to the business in hand because of a mass of preliminary work. The meeting will continue today.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 23. -- Interviews with all the Erie banks to-day show general cheerfulness and confidence. National bank deposits in Erie are more than half from the wage-earning class, and within ten days the deposits have exceeded the withdrawals by from $5,000 to $10,000 per day. There is ample currency for all local business, and while Cleveland and Buffalo have been paying with Clearing House checks the Erie banks have been paying currency.

The reports of Rear Admiral A.E.K. Benham and Capt. J.C. Watson, both of the cruiser San Francisco, on the work performed by the Philadelphia and Rochester battalions of Naval Reserves during the cruise just ended aboard the flagship San Francisco, are reported to have been read by officials of the Navy Department with marked satisfaction.

It is promised by State Superintendent of Banks Preston that the long-delayed statement of the affairs of the Madison Square Bank will be made public this evening. Mr. Preston came down from Kingston yesterday and made this promise after a consultation with Bank Examiner Judson, who has been going over the books of the bank.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Secretary Gresham and Minister Blount had another long conference over Hawaiian affairs this morning at the State Department. It has been decided that there is no necessity for the Minister to go to Gray Gables for consultation with the President. The situation will be considered by Mr. Gresham and Mr. Blount until the return of Mr. Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 23. -- At 10:45 o'clock this morning the steel steam yacht Columbia was launched at the shipyard of the Charles Hillman Company. The Colombia is the property of J. Harvey Ladew of New-York. The Messrs. Cramp are the original contractors for her construction and the builders of her machinery, the Charles Hillman Company having built the hull by sub-contract.
ROTTERDAM, Aug. 23. -- Two cases of cholera and one death from the disease have occurred in this city.

So far as its stock market was concerned, Wall Street was not particularly active yesterday. Prices were generally lower, the bears improving their opportunity to set afloat a choice collection of disquieting rumors. They talked of called loans and took a generally doleful view of conditions, as is their wont.

The sale in the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday of $1.150,000 Northern Pacific consolidated 5 per cent. bonds and $392,000 Chicago and Northern Pacific firsts gave Wall Street quite a stir. The questions, "Who is selling?" and "What dees it mean?" were asked with more or less eagerness, and the answers, as is usual in Wall Street, took the form of rumors.

HILL and PEFFER are probably about equally ignorant of the banking conditions into which they propose an inquiry. The resolution really calls upon the banks of New-York, Boston, and Philadelphia, through the Secretary of the Treasury, to say why their vaults are not bursting with currency, and why they refuse to give to all comers what they have not got.

AMERICAN CANOE ASSOCIATION CAMP, KINGSTON, Ontario, Aug. 23. -- Paul Butler of Lowell Mass., is for the second time the winner of the American Canoe Association's sailing trophy. If there were any championships in American cancing this would be the championship of America. Butler won the trophy on Lake Champlain last year in a light breeze. T.S. Oxholm of Yonkers being second.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- The remarkable report of the Atlanta court of inquiry, recently published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, was generally discussed among those interested in the navy. It had been felt for a long time that the condition or the Atlanta justified an inquiry, but no one was prepared for the fastening of culpability on so many prominent officers of the service.

The third game of the contest between chess players Albin and Hodges was opened with the Zukertort move, Kt -- K Bs by Albin at the Manhattan Chess Club on Tuesday evening. Hodges relied on his defense with a Fianchetto da Re and ill Donna. The game was very stubbornly contested, but black got eventually a decided advantage in position, which he subsequently increased by very fine play.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Titus Sheard of Little Falls, ex-State Senator, is at Congress Hall, as are the Rev. D.T. Yerkes of Plainfield and Mr. and Mrs. H. O'Reilly of New-York.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- Ex-Congressman John E. Russell of Leicester will probably be the Democratic candidate for Governor of Massachusetts this Fall. He said yesterday that he would not decline a nomination if the convention should tender it, and no one at this end or the State doubts that the convention will jump at the chance of scouring him as the party standard bearer.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Politics recently crept into the deliberations of the St. James Board of Education and created some feeling among the members. Lawyer Livingston Smith and Melville Smith are Republicans, and Benjamin Bailey is saturated with sound Democracy.

William H. Schooley, a lawyer having an office at 319 Greenwich Street, and living at 454 West Thirty-sixth Street, was charged in the Tombs Police Court yesterday with the larceny of four one-thousand-dollar bonds and with forgery. He was held in $5,000 bail on the charge of larceny and in $1,500 bail on the charge of forgery.

The Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank, in Brooklyn, held another meeting yesterday at the office of President Keeney's personal counsel in Montague Street, and went through their usual form of adjourning to await the report of the Examiners who are going over the affairs of the institution.
The railway mortgage market was generally dull, the transactions in Northern Pacific issues overshadowing all other business. The principal changes were:

BUFFALO, Aug. 23. -- Johnstone Bennett presented her new play "Fanny" here to-night before a very large and very kind audience. The play was well received and Miss Bennett was enthusiastically applauded. "Fanny" is a piece in three acts. It is not particularly tunny. The story is trite.

Zimmermann Forshay, money brokers in Wall Street, received warning a few days ago to look out for certain Spanish gold notes which, they were told, might be offered for sale by persons having no title to them. The notice came from Cardenas Co. of 58 William Street.

Upon the application of Howard A. Taylor of the law firm of Hornblower, Byrne Taylor Justice Van Brunt in the Supreme Court yesterday granted an order for the substituted service of papers on Horace K. Thurber in a suit brought by the Continental National Bank of Boston against the United States Book Company, the Seaside Publishing Company, Edward Lange, and John W. Lovell.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23. -- There is a better and easier feeling among bankers the present week than at any time since the financial stringency set in. Along Third Street and at the Stock Exchange it was generally remarked that the Clearing-House Exchange report of the business of the last week was the most encouraging feature noted in the local market for some time.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- A violent northeaster is sweeping along the coast, and old mariners predict that the storm will do more damage to the shore front than the disastrous gale of 1890.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Postmaster Dayton of New-York reached Washington at midnight and went to the Shoreham. He said to a correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES that he came here for the purpose of having a talk with Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Curtis and Supervising Architect O'Rourke, regarding the improvements in the New-York Post Office Building he desires to have made.
Just about 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon three incredibly dirty gentlemen were standing in Capt. Devery's precinct within a bowshot of his police station.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- The fact that Malcolm Chace of Brown University and W.A Learned, the intercollegiate champion, were to meet was enough to insure a good attendance this morning for the second day of the great all-comers' tournament. Last week Chace had beaten Learned at Narragansett in a hard-fought five-set match, which made the Providence man a slight favorite for the match this morning.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 23. -- Buffalo and Western Now-York Day was a success at the fair. There were fully 3,000 persons present from the western end of the Empire State, and they overran New-York's handsome building all day long. They came from the cities and from the rural districts in big excursion trains. They were joined by a great many Chicagoans who were formerly residents of Western New-York.

William P. Wentworth, for two years bookkeeper at the Victoria Hotel, who absconded about Aug. 1, was arrested in Jersey City yesterday and was locked up at Police Headquarters there to await extradition papers. His stealings amounted, it is said, to $28,750.
