JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 23. -- Fire in the paperbox department of the American Lithographic Company's works at Franklin street and Central Avenue, on the Heights, this morning, destroyed a wing of the building and a large amount of stock. The main building and several presses were badly damaged by water. The loss is $10,000 on building and $24,000 on stock and machinery, which is fully covered by insurance.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- Local securities have been weak all day, and in many cases were pressed for sale. The closing prices were the lowest. Metropolitan was dull and sold down to 79, Philadelphia, on lighs transactions, was offered down to 66, and closed offered at that price. There is a disposition among traders to hammer this stock on all opportunities.

Of course, the decrease in the city tax rate is due to an increase in the assessed valuation of property, greater, relatively, than the increase in municipal expenditures, but it does not follow that the increased valuations are a trick to cover up an actual increase of taxation. If it is a trick it is a very shallow one, for it is impossible to conceal the facts with which it deals.

Jacob Weissbaum made love to Matilda Walter shortly after their first acquaintance in the November of 1891. A public betrothal was not long in following, the wedding day being set down for the last day in August, 1892. But when the time came Jacob pleaded poverty, and took advantage of his plea to borrow and never return, so she charges, $100 from his fiancee.
COBURG, Aug. 23. -- Duke Ernst of SaxeCoburg and Gotha died at midnight last night at his castle at Roinhardshunn.

The foreign exchange market was dull and weak. There was no pressure of bills, but the diminishing premium on cold to arrive induced selling by bankers. The posted rates for sterling were reduced to $4.82 1/2 for 60-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.81 1/2@$4.81 3/4 for 60-day bills, $4.86 @$4.86 3/4 for demand, $4.87@$4.87 3/4 for cable transfers, and $4.80@$4.80 1/2 for commercial.

BERLIN, Aug. 23. -- Prince Bismarck is still taking the waters at Kissingen. On Sunday last a party of 700 of his admirers from the Thuringia district in Central Germany arrived at Kissingen for the purpose of paying their respects to the aged ex-Chancellor. This party upon its arrival was joined by 800 of the people visiting Kissingen, and all together proceeded to the villa occupied by Prince Bismarck and presented an address to him.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 23. -- The investigation into the condition of affairs in the First Recorder's Court culminated yesterday in the indictment by the Grand Jury of Recorder Edward S. Whittaker, Chief Clerk James Barry, and his son, William Barry, formerly affidavit clerk and now minute clerk.
BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- At a special meeting of the Executive Connoll of the Massachusetts Board of Trade to-day the following was adopted:
To the Editor of the New-York Times: By the death of Major Morris B. Farr the National Guard of this State and of the country at large lost a stanch friend.

The strikes of the longshoremen on the docks of the Clyde. Ward, and Mallory Lines along the East River were continued yesterday. Nearly all the disturbances of the day were near the pier of the Clyde Line, where a number of Italians went to work. The other two companies had taken the precaution to bring their Italian workmen in tugs to their steamers or docks, where the strikers could not get at them.

The Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank in Brooklyn met again yesterday at the office of President Keeney's personal counsel in Montague Street. They were in session two hours, finally adjourning when they learned that the report of the examiners, who are going over the bank's affairs, was not ready.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 24. -- But for the wind that came from the west to-day, the conditions for the international tournament given under the direction of the Zigzag Cycling Club of Indianapolis would have been perfect. The tract at the State Fair Grounds was hard and smooth as a billiard table. The prizes were valuable, and the attendance, which was from 7,000 to 10,000, was sufficient to inspire the contestants to their best efforts.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- A ship wreck attended by the loss of seventeen lives occurred in the big storm this morning off this point.

Until the last hour of business yesterday Wall Street was dull. Trading in stocks was light, and there were few signs of strength. Before the close, however, there was an increase in the activity in the stock market and quotations advanced, prices being at their best with the end of the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The official copy of the decision made by the Bering Sea Board of Arbitration was received at the State Department this morning from John W. Foster, agent of the United States at Paris. Secretary Gresham said to-day that he had not examined the text or the decision and could not tell until he had done so what would be the order of procedure.

There is no sign in the vote on the question of seating Mr. LEE MANTLE as a Senator from Montana that it was in the least affected by the attitude of the "appointed Senators" on the silver question, as it certainly ought not to be. The real Question to be settled was too important to have it made a makeweight in any matter of legislation.

The inhabitants of East One Hundred and Fourth street near. Second Avenue were startled at 2:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon by the sound of an explosion. Steam was seen pouring from the lower part of the building 248. The crash of broken glass, the cries of the injured, and the shrieks of the terrified women employed there as they rushed out of the place added to the general alarm.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- A fire which in extent of territory almost rivals Chicago's historic conflagration began in South Chicago about 5 o'clock this afternoon and rafted furiously for several hours. When it had worked its destruction and the firemen felt that they had it in control, the havoc it had done was found to comprise 250 houses, nearly all residences, and extensive dock property.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The storm of last night was the severest for years, but fortunately there were no accidents of any sort, and the material damage, except among the yachts along the shore of NewYork Bay, was very slight. Trees were uprooted and blown down in all sections of the county, and in the parks dead sparrows were scooped up by the pailful.

The criticisms of the First Naval Battalion of this city which have emanated from the Navy Department are, perhaps, a little too severe. It has been insinuated that the young gentlemen of our naval militia are too satin-skinned to endure the hardships of an actual cruise aboard a man-of-war and that they are fonder of social functions than of actual duty.

CANOE CAMP. KINGSTON, Ontario, Aug. 34. -- What promised to be the most interesting event at the canoe meet to-day was the championship skiff race, twelve miles. Seven skiffs and two canoes entered. The skiffs were the Leprechaun, Lavolta, St. Lawrence, Bertha, Bonita, Sunrise, and Akahe. The canoes were Paul Butler's Wasp and David S. Goddard's Bee, both of Lowell, Mass.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The fierce northeast storm of last night and this morning caused considerable damage at this place, and it will be some time before the Branch entirely recovers from the effects of the storm, which, without doubt, was the severest experienced at this place in years.

George Gretsinger, Jr., son of Supervisor Gretsinger of 107 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, who threatened to kills his father and so terrorized his mother and sister that they fled from the house, was arrested Wednesday night. He was arraigned before Justice Watson in the Myrtle Avenue Police Court yesterday. Supervisor Gretsinger told how his son had threatened his life.

Weak flash generally arrive in our waters in June, when the "tide runners" or adult spawning fish appear. Their jnuiors, or "school fish." arrive the beginning of July. The name is a misnomer, for the fish is strong and active, is gamey, furnishing good sport, is toothsome, with an unobtrusive bone structure, and in general make-up and disposition seems to do his best to please.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Mr. Hill, the newally of the Populists of the Senate, kept away from the Chamber to-day, and those who inquired for him were told that he was at his rooms engaged upon a speech which he was scheduled to deliver to-morrow in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- For two and a quarter hours this morning the House Committee on Banking and Currency discussed Representative Johnson's bill providing for the exchange of Treasury notes for Government bonds. The committee then adjourned until next Tuesday, when the author of the bill hopes that decisive action may be takenup on it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Lower prices for wheat, corn, and oats were the result of the trading in to-day's short session. Compared with yesterday's resting prices wheat is 1c lower, corn is off 1/2c, and oats 3/8c. Provisions were in the main firm, closing slightly higher for ribs but rather lower for pork and lard.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The Vienna correspondent of the Times says it has been announced officially that cholera is disappearing slowly from most infected districts of both Austria and Hungary. The valley of the Theiss is the only region where the cholera still spreads. There the ignorant peasants try to conceal cases of the disease from the doctors and sanitary officials and refuse to take any precautions against the epidemic.

The long-delayed statement of state Superintendent of Banks Preston as to the result of the investigation into the affairs of the defunct Madison Square Bank was last night made public. The full schedules will be placed in the hands of the receivers to-day, and they will take charge of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The developments in the Atlanta case may lead to the meet searching investigation to which the navy has ever been subjected. The general failure to observe important and imperative departmental orders on board the Atlanta encourages the suspicion that similar carelessness may have existed on board other ships.

Thomas J. Montgomery, a broker and promoter of patents, who for many years has been a guest at the Victoria Hotel and the bosom friend of William P. Wentworth, the defaulting bookkeeper of the hotel, was taken into custody at the hotel yesterday by order of Inspector McLaughlin.

If a charge of forgery can be maintained George H. Wilson may win a suit in which he claims property at Ralph and Gates Avenues, Brooklyn, worth $100,000 Mr. Wilson claims he is the heir of Elijah Wilson, who died in 1858, and who owned the property in dispute. At that time, Wilson says, he was at sea on board the ship Here.

Isaac L. Rice is dissatisfied with the inactivity of the committees of Reading bondholders in this city. He represents between twelve and fourteen million dollars' worth of bonds and is therefore deeply interested in the policy pursued by the present management of the company. He has sent the following letter to the Chairmen of the committees:
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 24. -- At Black Rock thrilling scenes were enacted during the storm yesterday.

WORLD'S FAIR GROUNDS, Aug. 24. -- Mars, the bloody god of war, was in the ascendant at the White City in Jackson Park to-day. It was Illinois Day, and warriors from almost every nation on the earth, equipped with instruments of death and destruction, were there, and they paraded through the beautiful thoroughfares to the time of patriotic tunes played by scores of martial bands.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- In the terrible fury of last night's storm the fishing schooner Mary F. Kelly was cast ashore at the foot of Sixth Avenue. The Captain and two men were drowned and the steward was killed. Seven seamen were rescued by guests from the hotels.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Senate in executive session to-day confirmed the following nominations:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- There was no adherence to-day in the House to the five-minute role, although the debate was supposed to be regulated by that rule. Nearly every speaker who had something to say which took more than five minutes was able to obtain extension of his time, and so the list of speakers was not as long as might have been expected.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The Bank of Sherman, at Sherman, Chautauqua County, consisting of Archibald Calhoun, James Vincent, and the estate of the late Hiram Parker, made an assignment yesterday. Liabilities about $40,000, and assets, mostly in farms, about the same.

The cyclone did not pass Brooklyn by. Sweeping with fall force over the wooded and gently undulating expanses of the City of Churches, the storm neglected no opportunity of doing harm to the property of its frightened inhabitants. It woke them from their peaceful slumbers with the roar of the wind and the crash of stately shade trees.

ROME, Aug. 4. -- The manoeuvres of the Italian Navy were concluded yesterday. Upon the conclusion of the evolutions or the fleet King Humbert gave a dinner at the port of Gaeta on board the royal yacht Savola. Eighty guests were present, including Admiral Prince Henry of Prussia, who represented his brother, the German Emperor, at the manoeuvres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- By refusing to let Lee Mantle have a seat as the appointee of the Governor of Montana, the Senate has acquired more reputation for respect for the character of the body than it has by anything it has done in a long time. As the outcome seems to be virtuous by intention, at least, it is in the nature of a surprise.

The Maharajah of Kapurthala and suite left New-York yesterday on the Hamburg-American Line steamship Furst Bismarck. He will stop a Southampton, where the vessel touches, and from there will go to London, where he will visit Queen Victoria.

Baron von Saurma Jeltsh, the first Gertman Ambassador to this country, accompanied by his daughter, the Baroness Saurma, and her companion, Miss vou Erokart, and by Baron Kotteler, Counselor and first Secretary to the German Embassy, paid a visit down town yesterday morning.

John Kehoe, a burglar, twenty-three years old, while in the custody of three Brooklyn detectives, to one of whom he was handcuffed, committed suicide in his room at 205 Lee Avenue, Willlamsburg, last evening, by cutting his throat with a penknife. His jugular vein was completely severed, and death was almost instantaneous.

The lower bay, over which the cyclone swished its tail, is now studded with sunken yachts and other smaller craft, and the beach is strewn with boats of various types. At least a score of vessels were wrecked in that locality on Wednesday night.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 24. -- Father Moltner, Chaplain of the Convent of the Good Shepherd, who supported the recent public criticisms of that institution, has left his post, and his absence is the subject of considerable comment. It is supposed that he left because he was not in sympathy with the administration.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Compared with the visionary projects of a young man named Pennington, whose disappearance the other day from Noblesville, Ind., simultaneously with the collapse of a colossal electric-railway swindle was duly chronicled in these dispatches, the imagination of Jules Verne, the theoretical demonstrations of Mr. Keely and of the Rev. Dr. Jasper, and oven the practical application of science by Edison, pale into insignificance.
CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 24. -- "For fifty years I have lived at Coney Island," said John Y. McKane to-day, "and never have I seen a storm like this one."

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 24 -- The New-Orleans Clearing House met to-day and decided to issue Clearing House certificates for small sums to help soothe the congested money market. The recent action of the banks substituting certified checks for cash payment left the planters without money to gather the crops, and the new move is chiefly to relieve them.
Luke Harrigan, a well-dressed man of about twenty-eight years, was remanded yesterday in the Tombs Police Court at the request of detectives from Police Headquarters.
Theatrical Manager Robert A. Grau was taken to a private sanitarium last night by his physician, Dr. Eddy. He has been drinking heavily of late, and his friends decided on this course.

The downfall of favorites at Clifton continued yesterday, for not one of the first choices passed the wire a winner. The day at the track was delightful, and although the going was heavy on account of the rain of the preceding night, a brisk wind dried the track on top, and by the time the third race was over it was in fairly good condition.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- William H. Seward, Jr., son of Brig. Gen. William H. Seward, and grandson of the late Secretary Seward, and Miss Anna Dennis Myers, daughter of Gorton W. Allen, were married in St Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church this evening. Over 1,5OO invitations had been issued, and the church was filled. It was a green and white wedding and the interior decorations were elaborate.

Superintendent Byrnes's return to his post yesterday, two days before his leave ended, was known to the leaders of the Polack peddlers early in the day, and had a magic effect upon them. They knew that they had to deal with a man who had a clear sense of duty and would strictly enforce the law.
NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Aug. 24. -- The damage to the pleasure craft which were last night anchored along the shores of the upper bay will reach over $50,000.

The report published yesterday in THE NEWYORK TIMES to the effect that many Navy De- partment officials were surprised at an apparent unwillingness on the part of the First Battalion of the New-York Naval Reserves to go to sea, and as a result of this seeming apathy were inclined to view with ill favor New-York's naval organization, was read here yesterday with interest by naval men.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 24. -- The court-martial for the trial of Col. Hughes, Third Regiment, Kansas National Guard, is likely to come to a sudden and rather sensational close. Col. Hughes has been charged, with disobedience of orders in refusing to cast out the House of Representatives and with conveying information to the enemy when he carried the tidings that the Governor had declared a truce.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 24. -- It is not generally known that the Second Regiment, Connecticut National Guard, which is at present at Niantic in its annual encampment, is the oldest military body in America. It dates Its origin from the military company organized by the New-Haven colony in 1638, and has a notable history.

The oldest frequenter of Central Park would hardly have recognized it early yesterday morning. The wooded portions looked as if they had been swept by a tornado. Trees of all sizes were lying around, and the ground was littered with a great mass of leaves, twigs, and boughs, which had been torn from the trees by the wind.

Yachts at anchor in the waters about NewYork were great sufferers from the storm of yesterday morning. The greatest damage was wrought among the yachts that lined the shores of New-York Bay from Jersey Avenue, Jersey City, to Greenville.

The steam yacht Marietta, which was designed for H.C. Moore of the New-York Yacht Club by Henry J. Gielow of this city, was given her trial trip yesterday afternoon and developed excellent speed and seagoing qualities that will make her a notable addition to the club fleet. A more severe test could hardly have been given, as the wind blew a gale and a very heavy sea was running.

The fishing schooner Chocura staggered into port yesterday with her flag at half mast, her main boom, gaff, and sail gone, her hold half full of water, and her crew, under the command of Seaman John Resate, worn out, exhausted, and stil trembling from the fright and terror occasioned by the storm.

The cyclone had a riotous time in Flatbush. Houses were blown down, a windmill at the stable of the Brooklyn City Railroad was demolished, trees were uprooted, fences, awnings, and telegraph poles were carried away by the wind, and it has been many years since the elements did so much damage in this beautiful suburb of Brooklyn.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Rain began falling at about 11 o'clock last night and still continued this morning, with the prospect of lasting all day. Not-withstanding the storm, and although the track was flooded, the races were run. The reporters and the race tract officials were about the only persons on the grand stands. The steeplechase was declared off.

The Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows of this State assembled yesterday morning for its third day's session in the Scottish Rite Hall, Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, and closed its annual convention by the installation of the newly-elected officers in the evening. Grand Master Charles H. Morgan presided.

The foreign exchange market was dull and firm. The posted rates for sterling were reduced to $4.83 1/2 for 60-day bills and $4.88 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.82 @$4.82 1/2 for 60-day bills, $4.87@$4.87 1/2 for demand, $4.88 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.80 1/2 for commercial.
The bimetallists of New-York held a mass meeting in Cooper Institute last evening. Every seat in the Assembly Hall was taken, and many unable to obtain seats stood through the proceedings.
The Produce Exchange markets were lower with the West, with cables depressed, and considerable local realizing, wheat closed at a loss of 3/4@1/8c and corn at 3/8@1/2c decline for the day.

The Senators who are wasting the time of the Senate in miscellaneous talk about a lot of amendments to Mr. VOORHEES'S bill for the increase of bank circulation get no comfort from the Chairman of the Finance Committee. On Tuesday, when there was a rambling but pretty sharp debate on the order of business, Mr. VOORHEES announced:

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Aug. 24 -- P.M. The wind and rain storm of last night played havoc with the telegraph wires, and, as a result, this city was practically cut off from communication with other centres. Consequently there were few outside orders in the market during the morning and business was very dull.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 24 -- A telegram was received on' Change from New-York to-day asking what the financial condition in this city was. The following reply was sent by Vice President Annan: " The financial situation in St. Louis is improving. Our banks continue to pay currency to depositors and to supply too legitimate needs of their customers.

With a mighty war of winds and a great tumbling of chimneys, the West Indian cyclone that struck New-York at full tilt Wednesday night swirled off up the coast of New-England yesterday morning. A mass of leaden clouds tagged in its wake, but the sun soon drove them away.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- "You may tell the people of Houston," said Representative Culberson yesterday to a correspondent of a Houston paper, "that free silver is beaten all along the line, in the House and the Senate."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- There was an interchange of populist courtesies in the Senate today which was thoroughly appreciated by the Senators and the occupants of the galleries. Mr. Stewart (Pop., Nev.,) gave notice last Monday that he would address the Senate on the silver question yesterday. On Tuesday Mr. Peffer (Pop., Kan.) announced that he would make a speech on silver Thursday.

Edith K. Hastings of Sandusky, Ohio, obtained from Justice Van Brunt yesterday, in the Supreme Court, an injunction restraining Leoda De Vaux of 167 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street from disposing of a fifth interest in the estate left among his five children by Wait well K. Hastings. Miss Hastings, the plaintiff, conveyed her share to Miss De Vanx in exchange for $50 in cash and a diamond ring worth $150.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- A Unionist meeting was held at Otley, in the West Riding of Yorkshire, to-day, at which the Duke of Devonshire was the principal speaker. He arraigned the Government for attempting to pass the Home Rule bill, and said that he would shortly be obliged to ask the House of Lords to reject that measure.

The Floating Hospital work under the direction or St. John's Guild is going on with excellent results, affording relief to thousands of deserving poor in the tenement districts who could not otherwise receive needed attention. Three trips in the last week were provided by William H. Langley Co., James Speyer, and "A Thank Offering, W.M.J."

It is rather amusing, among the various discomfitures of our absurd friend, Mr. JOHN BOYD THACHER, to remark that he has come back to find fresh trouble in a controversy that he thought he had settled early last Winter, and that, in fact, first brought him before the public as an absurd person. That was his controversy with the pianomakers.

Senator LODGE of Massachusetts has introduced a bill to regulate the appointment of fourth-class Postmasters, which, we assume, is substantially the one introduced in the House in the last Congress. It is significant that this question is to be brought to the attention of Congress and to be put in a way of some sensible settlement.

William Dlercks, fourteen years old, of 300 East Seventy-sixth Street, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for trial on a charge of stabbing in the back Louis Lowenstein, fifteen years old, of 347 East Seventy-sixth Street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Serious trouble developed this morning at the Broadway Market, East Buffalo, due to the bold robbery of provision stands by the unemployed Poles. A large number of people in the Polish district are out of work, and having exhausted the resources of the Poormaster, have resorted to robbery to supply their wants.

Base hits and errors were plentiful at Eastern Park yesterday. The Brooklyn boys led in both and won a rather uninteresting game from the Pittsburgs. The work on both sides was only commonplace. Both Stein and Gumbert were hit hard, but the Brooklyns managed to bunch their hits, while the majority of those made by the Pittsburg men were scattering.

GREENPORT, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Last night a hurricane from the east struck this portion of Long Island. The wind was accompanied by a heavy fall of rain, and one terrific clap of thunder awoke the residents of Greenport. Only one report of thunder was heard during the entire storm.
BETHLEHEM, N.H., Aug. 24. -- The sixth annual White Mountain coaching parade yesterday was the most successful of the series enjoyed by the visitors at this popular resort.
ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The fourteenth annual "Sanderson Academy dinner" of this town was held to-day and took the form of a memorial gathering in honor of George William Curtis.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The Hudson County Grand Jury for the April term was discharged by Judge Lippincott this afternoon after banding in eight indictments. This raises the total number of indictments to 175. It is understood that several of to-day's indictments are against policy dealers. Judge Lippincott lectured the Grand Jury briefly.

Only the sharpost kind of held work on the part of the New-Yorks saved them from a defeat yesterday. Thn Pittsburgs outbatted them 17 to 9 in single bases and 25 to 12 in totals, bat by a series of remarkably clever and pretty plays the Giants saved themselves from defeat. As it was, they failed to win the same ending in a tie after a ten-inning contest.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Four deaths have occurred in the West Bergen section of the city from eating crabs. The direct cause of death in each case was cholera merbus, but it was brought on by the crabs. The crabs were eaten in a tumbledown boathouse kept by Mrs. Mary Ann Lewis at the foot of Culver Avenue, on the bank of the Morris Canal.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The racing under the auspices of the State Breeders' Association at the Hudson River Driving Park to-day bad one very interesting feature -- the contest in the 2:30 class. The black stallion Billy Wilton had no consideration before the start, yet he won the first two heats in 2:20 and 2:21 3/4, to the surprise of everybody.

LEAVES OF ABSENCE -- Capt H.G. Sharpe, twenty-one days from Sept. 10. First Lieut, T.C. Pasterson. First Artillery, one month's extension. Seoond Lieut. E.B. Cassatt, Fourth Cavalry, one month. Major C.B. Sears, extension to Sept. 28. First Lieut. T.B. Dugan, Adjutant Third Cavalry, four months from Oct. 10. Capt. W.P. Carter, Medical Department, one month's leave.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 25 -- The pilot boat E.C. Knight this morning brought here Engineer Albert Stillwell and Seaman Charles Olsen of the foundered Relief Ship No. 37. They were picked up by the pilot boat last evening about twenty miles from Cape May.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 25 -- A prominent Georgian who is close to Speaker Crisp, and who baa just returned from Washington, says that tree coinage will not carry in the House, and that all ratios will be voted down, by from 30 to 40.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- A special dispatch to the Times from Bangkok says that M. le Myre de Vilers, the French Special Envoy, has demanded that the Siamese Government dismiss all Danish officers from the Siamese service.

GILBERTON, Penn., Aug. 25 -- The Coroner's jury this afternoon rendered a verdict in the cases of Parfitt and Holland, who lost their lives in the light here Monday night between the Sohuylkill Traction Company's employes and the town authorities. Parfitt, it said, came to his death from a gunshot wound received at the hands of John J. Briggs.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 25 -- The President's catboat carried a jolly party down Buzzard's Bay this afternoon. Besides the President there were Gov. Russell, Joe Jefferson, Secretary Lamont. Dr. Bryant, and A.H. Wood. When the party left Gray Gables the wind blew very strong and a heavy sea was running. SKipper Wright put in plenty of reefs, thereby avoiding a wetting for his passengers.
The affairs of the Madison Square Bank were put into the hands of the receivers yesterday. and after looking over the statements they took possession.

The Valiant, the largest and handsomest steam yacht in the world, anchored off Stapleton, S.I., yestorday afternoon. The Valiant is owned by Mr. W.K. Vanderbilt, and her owner and his secretary, W.S. Hoyt, made the trip across the Atlantic, and expressed themselves as well satisfied with the way the boat behaved.
The money market was quiet, Call loans ranged at 3 1 2@6 P cent. The last loan was made at 4 P cent.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- There was a grand swing to all the markets on the Chicago Board of Trade today. The bears pressed the selling early and forced the prices down in all grain lits. When everything on the floor was oversold, the trade got some good bull news in wheat, which alarmed the shorts and started speculative buying. Wheat got each a rally that all other markets followed.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 -- Hobart, Hovey, Larned, Wrenn, and V.G. Hall are still in the race for the All-Comers' prize, each having won another round to-day. All the matches but one were played in the morning and were witnessed by the usual large crowd.

YONKKRS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Wlllle Davia, fifteen years old, applied at the ticket office of the New York Central Railroad yesterday for a ticket to Chicago. He offered in payment 81. When told that that sum would only carry him to Poughkeepsle, he was surprised. He purchased a ticket to that place, however, and said he would cot further on later.

Inspector McLaughlin, Capts. Devery, Brooks, Stephenson, and Seibert, and fourteen detective Sergeants among whom were Heidelberg, Jacobs, Titus, Sheridan, Schnacker, You Gerichten, Kransch, and Trainer, called yesterday morning at the District Attorney's office and had a long secret consultation with Acting District Attorney Vernon H. Davis.

It looks as if Mr. HILL were not very well pleased with the result of his escapade of Tuesday, when he made so unpleasant a spectacle of himself in company with Senator PEFFER of Kansas. At any rate the tone of most of his remarks yesterday was much more moderate. It was, of course, petty and personal.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- Friends of the Paine cup defender Jabiles have by no means given up the hope that she will be the boat selected to meet the Valkyrie, in spite of her repeated defeats by the Vigilant, and to-day they started a good-sized "boom" for her, Doth to encourage themselves and to keep up the hopes of other Bostonians that a cup defender may yet be selected from here.

The dullness in the commercial and financial world has extended even among politicians, judging from the lack of interest manifested in the Democratic State Committee meeting, which is to be held to-day at the Hoffman House to name the time and place for holding the State Convention which will nominate State officers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Trains arriving in Chicago last night and, this morning brought hundreds of colored persons. They came from all parts adjacent to tale city, and some from the far-off Southern States, to celebrate the Colored Man's Day at the fair. Distinguished men of the black race were among those at the grounds. The colored men and women of Chicago turned out in force and in their beat attire.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The regatta of the Royal Dart Yacht Club, of which Mr. H. Studdy is Commodore. took place to-day. The station of this club is at Dartmouth, and its clubhense is at Kingswear. The course was in the English Channel, starting from a mark boat off Dartmouth and sailing to and around a mark boat in the channel. The course was sailed over four times making the total distance forty miles.
In the Essex Market Police Court yesterday. Policeman Scott arraigned Henry Eicheahausen, a painter, of 427 East Fourteenth Street, with disorderly conduct and assault.

A section of the storm-battered fleet which which was exposed to the cyclone of Wednesday night limped into harbor yesterday, some of the vessels with depleted crews, and nearly all crippled by the desperate straggle against a storm which might have swamped an old-time frigate had she been exposed to its fury.

The bill introduced into the Senate to promote the interests of the merchant marine by the establishment of a Marine Board has much to recommend it. It is a simpler mode of accomplishing its purpose than has sometimes been proposed. One plan, for example, which has been supported by high authority, is that of creating a new executive department to be known as the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- If Senator Hill had refrained a day or two ago from making an inexplicable and unnecessary demonstration against the Administration with Senator Peffer, it is probable that his speech in the Senate to-day would have been heard with less of wonder as to what he would say next and with more of interest in his opinions -- or in the opinions which he spoke.
It was very warm at Clifton yesterday. Only one favorite won, and the bookmakers had the best of the big crowd present.

In its inquiry into the doings or weighers and gaugers the Customs Investigating Commission has secured a great deal of evidence showing laxity and irregularity and has brought out facts indicating that what was brought to light a year or two ago about the handling of imports from Italy was only part of the story.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- There were nine deaths from cholera in Naples yesterday. Five cases and one death are reported from Casino, about fifty miles northwest of Naples, and four new cases and two deaths from Palermo.
Mrs. Margaret Fowler, a pretty widow, was arraigned in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, on a charge of burglary.

At Eastern Park in Brooklyn to-day, before and after the ball game, there will be bicycle races, under the auspices or the National Cycling Association, for cash prizes. A single admission will be charged to the races and ball game. The first race will start at 2:30 P.M.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 25 -- Yucatan advices represent the inhabitants of the Island of Cozumal as emigrating to the mainland on account of the failure of the crops, and there la a popular movement on loot to give them employment on henequin plantations, which are prosperous. Yucatan is having a regular boom, and no apprehension is felt on account of the efforts of the Government of the Bahama Islands to Introduce henequin culture.

The State Board of Health had along meeting at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. There were present President Florenoe O'Donohue, Dr. William E. Milbank of Albany, State Engineer SoheneK, Health Officer Jenkins, Dr. Cyrus Edson, and Secretary Lewis Balch.

A well-dressed woman, accompanied by a man, was observed standing at the corner of Broadway and Thirty-eighth Street at 7 o'clock last evening. After a few minutes' conversation the woman struck her companion in the face with her clenched list.

The creditors of the Hotel de Logerot, against which property, at Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, a mechanic's lion for $8,692 has been filed by the Pierce Miller Engineering Company for piping for electric wires, boilers, and steam fittings, met at the hotel yesterday afternoon to consider what action should be taken in regard to the debts of the hotel.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25 -- Baltimore has stood the season of depression better perhaps than any other city in the country. There has net been a failure of any importance, the banks have the highest average reserve of those of all the cities in the country, and the much-mentioned record, which is a part of the advertising equipment of the town, that there has not been a bank failure for sixty years, has been pleasantly emphasized.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- The enormous breakers rolled in on the beach today amid the brilliant sunshine with relentless and irresistible force, but only one more victim of Wednesday night's terrible storm was cast ashore. It proved to be the body of Andrew Johnson, one of the seamen of the ill-fated ocean tug Panther.

Shirt-sleeved Peace once more broods over the quarter of the town in which the over-heated imaginations of Capt. Devery and his whiskered adviser, the Sergeant, thought they saw Anarchists swarming in preparation to blow up the city.
TOPEKA, Kan., Ang. 25 -- John W. Breidenthal, Bank Commissioner, to-day sent oat a circular letter to each State bank in Kansas and to many of the national banks, in which he said:

Dun's Review will say to-morrow: The "Improvement observed last week has become much more distinct and general. While actual transactions have increased bat little, the change in public feeling la noteworthy. There are fewer failures, eltber of banks or of Important commercial or manufacturing concerns, than for some weeks past.

There was as exciting tilt between two lawyers in Judge Giegerich's Court of Common Pleas yesterday morning. Adolph L. Sanger, the President of the Board of Education, appeared for G.M. Miller to ask for a vacation of an attachment which had been granted at the instance of Morris Moses, his former partner, to recover $3,700 alleged to be due him after the dissolution of the firm in January.

The white-frocked tars of the Naval Reserve begin their annual cruise to-day. Last night the gallant old wooden war ship New-Hampshire, ablaze with electric lights, lay in the East River at the foot of Twenty-eighth. Street, taking the citizen sailors on board. Borne some on foot, others rode down to the wharf in cabs.

Erastus Wiman's financial misfortunes played a part in the business of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday. F.S. Angell, on behalf of the receiver, applied to Justice Bartlett for the dissolution of the Staten Island Electric Light and Power Company. The collapse of this company was the first step in the fall of Mr. Wiman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- News of the United States fleet in Bering Sea has been received at the Navy Department from Commander Ludlow. commanding the Mohican. Concerning the seal rookeries, he says:

Theodore Yaka and Athanafis Eddidimos, Greeks, both of 471 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and Louis Catrinno of 314 First Avenue, New-York, were arrested at about 6 o'clock last evening and looked up in the Adams Street Police Station, Brooklyn, for fracturing the skull or Mart Mousthai, a Greek interpreter, of 133 Concord Street, Brooklyn.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 25 -- There was a royal reception awaiting the crack harness racers at Hampton Park to-day. The attendance was close to 10,000. The track was considerably improved after the rain, which caused a delay of twenty-four hours.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Although it is reported that Chief of Police John Y. McKane of Coney Island is to be the Democratic candidate for Sheriff this Fall, the Chief says he has not demanded nor has he had any consultation with Boss McLaughlin about the office. When shown the report in an evening paper, the Chief said:

When the Legislature at its late session created the office of Counsel to the Department of Street Improvements in the Annexod District. Matthew P. Breen received the appointment, presumably on a salary of $5,000 a year, but by an oversight no provision was made for paying the salary. Mr. Breen's first month's salary was provided for by the transfer of money from an appropriation made for other purposes.

-- The Rev. John Sheridan Zelle of Plymouth Conn., speaks an unaccustomed word in the Christian Union in behalf of too sexton as among the men who have helped him. The first "under whom he was employed," he says, was a, storekeeper who luxuriated in boned expressions or opinions, and always made a statement "as if somebody had just intimated it wasn't so."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The officers who have charge of the Third Lighthouse District, embracing New-York and vicinity, have submitted a report to the Lighthouse Board. Several important recommendations are made, some of which trill doubtless be incorporated in the annual report of the board.

The result of the Bering Sea decision, it is contended in navai circles, will make more onerous than ever the patrol work of the United States seal-protecting fleet. This fleet consists at present of vessels of the Navy and the Revenue Marine. Just now the waters patrolled by the mixed fleet are bounded by the confines of Bering Sea.

The depositors of the suspended Commercial Bank, in Brooklyn, were interested yesterday in a story to the effect that the statement of the examiners was practically completed, but was being held back by the State Banking Department to give President Seth L. Keeney and his fellow-Directors a chance to get together enough cash to resume.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 25 -- Ten million dollars in gold packed in canvas sacks came into Kansas City this morning on the Santa F6 train from San Francisco. The money was guarded by ten United States Deputy Marshals armed with Winchester rifles. The gold is for the Sub-Treasury in New-York City.

First Lieut. G.N. Whistler, Fifth Artillery, United States Army, who has charge of the firings of the Brown segmental wire-wound gun, draws some interesting conclusions as the result of the trial shot last Friday of the gun at Sandy Hook.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 25 -- The Long Island coast for its entire length is piled high with wreckage which the incoming tide has swept ashore. Evidences are plentiful that the ocean must have been the scene of countless wrecks and partial wrecks during the great storm of Wednesday night.

Baroness Caroline E. von Roques -- mother of Mrs. Florence Maybrick, who is now in prison in England, having been convicted of poisoning her husband -- has filed a bill before Judge J.C. Lamb of the Chancery Court at Richmond. Va. charging David W. Armstrong, her former attorney, with defrauding her out of her rightful interest in over 2,500,000 acres of land in Virginia, West Virginia, and Kentucky.

-- Another good list of games has been provided the cricketers of New-York for to-day, but the New-Jersey Athletic Club, which is tied with the Statsn Island Cricket Club for the lead, will not take part in a championship game. The islanders will meet the Mannattana at Prospect Park, where a good match should take place. The Newarks will endeavor to defeat the Patersone at Newark.

The Columbian Liberty and Peace Bell will arrive in this city from Troy this morning on the Citizens' Steamboat Line. It will be hauled down Broadway Monday morning and taken to Jersey City at 11 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Five-minute talks were supposed to be the order fop to-day, but the House was indulgent to many speakers to the extent of adding a few moments to the time accorded to each speaker under the arrangement, and with one exception too proceedings were marked by the best of good temper.

Samuel Saphiro, twenty-two years old, or 111 Orchard Street, and Lawrence Bonney, twenty-flve years old. of 418 West Forty-sixth, Street, conductor and driver, respectively, of Cor No. 263 of the Second Avenue line, were held in the Yorkvillle Police Court yesterday on a on a charge of homicide.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The War Department has called on Second Lieut. Archer W. Yates, Ninth Infantry, recruiting officer at Ogdens burg, N.Y., for an explanation how a poster inviting recruits to join the United States infantry and cavalry came to be displayed is a store window at Ottawa, Canada.

NEW-YORK. FRIDAY, Aug. 25 -- P.M. There was no pressure to sell stocks to-day, neither was the buying movement pronounced. London sold a small amount early in the day. especially of Louisville and Nashville, but the operations from that centre were very restricted. The upward movement set in about 11 o'clock, St. Paul, Burlington, and Sugar being the leaders. The loss in Louisville was almost fully recovered in the late trading.
HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 25 -- Fishing vessels are just beginning to return from the Banks and tell their story of the great storm.

A private collection of photographs seen recently had for its subject the life of Christ. It included some of the world's most famous pictures, which, although in very modest reproduction, took on an added value and meaning when grouped together in this significant way.

The United States cruiser Baltimore will probably sail for the China station to-morrow. The Baltimore is at present lying at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. During the last week the cruiser succeeded in getting on board the last of the lot of sea stores which go to make up a three years' allowance. The bread stores of the Baltimore weigh not much under twenty tons.

Little Harry Wheeler, the star rider of the National Cycling Association, continues to break the record. Last Saturday he established new time for a mile, and yesterday at Eastern Park he rode five miles faster than they have ever been covered before. Wheeler is in great shape, and many believe that he is the equal now of the great Zimmerman.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The succession of the Duke of Edinburgh to the rulership of the Duchies of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha dominates public interest in Germany, and widely divergent rumors in regard to the matter are everywhere circulated. Putting all those aside, there la no doubs that the succession of an English Duke has surprised and dissatisfied the nation, though the fact is quietly accepted by the duchies concerned.

Jules Claretie's resignation as administrator of the Comedie Francaise has been unofficially announced. Although artists say that the fact would be too agreeable for the rumor to be true, it is undoubted that Claretie's place has been offered to Ludovio Halevy, and that Halevy has declined.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 26. -- Another week of August has slipped by and the "season" shows no signs of ending. It may be that the Ocean Grove camp meeting has been the magnet that attracted the thousands of new-comers this week. Whatever the cause, the pleasure seekers and health seekers continue to come in rapidly enough to keep all the rooms at the hotels occupied.

Sousa's second festival at Manhattan Beach will close to-night. Miss Marie Tempest, Caroline Hamilton, and Basso W.H. Clarke, operatic favorites, will be the soloists, and the band, a drum corps, grand opera chorus, bagpipers, , will make up the closing ensemble of the "Salute of the Nations." Among other numbers Miss Tempest is expected to sing the "Nightingale Song" from the "Tyroleans."

Every Home maker knows that it adds greatly to the holiday festivities to have the table and house handsomely decorated with flowers, green things, and the like, and the most of us know, too, that when we are filled with Christmas enthusiasm oar generosity is sure to be larger than our purse, and if we have only the latter resource, decorations are pretty sure to give way to the more important needs.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 26. -- The return of Prince Cantacuzene this week brings about the last of the cottagers back to Lenox. Anson Phelps Stokes also came on Wednesday, and the Sloanes are here. The Havens, Bishops, Gen. Barlow, David Lydig, and in fact nearly everybody who has been to the seashore has returned, and is busy planning for the September season.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 26. -- At a meeting of the bank Presidents last night it was decided to issue $60,000 worth of Clearing House certificates to meet the money stringency. All the banks of the city in the association found it necessary to take this step in order to meet the deficiency of currency. The certificates, when issued, will pass as gold or any other money.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The children's grand carnival ball was held to-night at the West End Amusement Hall. It was under the personal supervidion of Carl Marwig. A large audience was present and fully appreciated the efforts of the talented little ones to amuse the fashionable audience.

Extraordinary preparations are now in progress for a fitting celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Independent Order of Basai Berlin, the well-known Hebrew benevolent organization, which will occur in October.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 26. -- Gov. W.M. Fishback has returned from Winslow, Ark. His health is entirely restored, although at one time the doctors abandoned all hope of saving his life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The Carnegie representative in the Navy Department, a naval officer, must find independent quarters. He will be no longer aided in his labors by a favored position in a department bureau.

A servant, who was only known as Edith, is supposed to have been frightened to death at 248 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, by the storm of Wednesday night. The house is occupied by Thomas Dempsey, a real estate dealer, who went with his family to Asbury Park Aug. 9, leaving Edith in charge of the house. She was a Swede about thirty years old and apparently in robust health.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The railroad stations at Long Branch have been piled high with outgoing luggage during the week. This is an infallible sign that the season is nearing an end. The consensus of opinion among hotel men is that the first week in September will see the last of a none too brilliant Summer. A few hotels will remain open until the 15th of the month, at the outside.

Not quite fifty years ago -- to be exact, in 1848 -- the elder Alexandra Dumas, who had then become the great man he will always remain, was seized with the ambition to crown his literary glory with that of the statesman. As the first step toward the attainment of this object, he became a candidate for a seat in the Chamber of Deputies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 26. -- The general Summer exodus to watering places and resorts has taken a large number of the naval officers away from Annapolis this season. Some of the officers, however, who have been away on long cruises, or who anticipate being ordered away in a short time, have come to Annapolis to rest and spend the time quietly with their families.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- It seems a pity that Duke Ernst of Saxe-Coburg Gotha could not have lived to read Ma obituaries in the German and English press. They make his death by far the most striking event of the season and unite in hoisting him up to a dizzy rank among the titanic Teutons of modern times.
Murder may be the result of an attack last night on a longshoreman who had gone back to work, by a number of strikers.
A group of despondent Syracuse boomers left the Hoffman House at noon yesterday looking the worse for wear.

The polios have begun to gather in the malicious persons who tried to incite the East Side peddlers to riot and robbery. At an early hour yesterday morning Detectives Jacobs and Krausch of the Central Office arrested Charles Timmerman, who had made incendiary speeches at Union Square and other places.

This is the time of the year when local sportsmen can test the truth of the statements of that "wonderful speed" of everybody's colt that has furnished talk for all of the past Winter. During the Winter, by the fireside, in the clubs and assembling places, especially around the Post offices in country towns, there are many side bets made by enthusiastic owners as to the speed of their respective colts.

Our old friend Ahasuerus, at least in fiction, defies the undertaker. No ending is there for that poor lorn soul. His last conspicuous long-distance-go-as-youplease walk was described by Eugene Sue, and now Gen. Wallace resuscitates Ahasuerus, or Cartaphilus, the Wandering Jew, and he stalks through the pages of "The Prince of India." The author of "Ben Hur" has little sympathy for the most depressing personage ever created in fable.

LAKE MOHEGAN, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The guests at this picturesque resort, embowered among the noble old hills of Westchester County, enjoy all the luxuries that come from a restful and quiet retreat. The fishing in the lake has been up to the average.

The statement of bank averages by the Associated Banks for the week ending yesterday was encouraging. There was an increase in the reserve of $5,308,125, in specie of $4,578,100, in legal tenders of $774,400, in deposits of $177,500, and in circulation of $1,042,000. There was a decrease in loans of $2,932,800.

The Crescent Rowing Club held its annual regatta on the Harlem yesterday afternoon. The course was from the foot of East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street to a finish opposite the clubhouse at the foot of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, and was a mile in length. The races were watched with much internal by the inhabitants of "Scullers' Row" and a large number of visitors, and excited a great deal of enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Bishop Keane of the Washington University has issued the following programme for the representation of the Catholic Church in the World's Parliament of Religions, which will be held in Chicago beginning Sept. 11.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- A man about fifty Years old, dressed in a rather seedy suit of clothes, and whose general appearance was that of a hard-working man, staggered up to an employe of the Times, seated in a chair in the doorway of the office, about 7 o'clock last night and said:

The old publishing house of Macmillan Co., which has been situated at 112 Fourth Avenue for so many years, is about to move to a new home at 65 Fifth Avenue. There has been erected a handsome building which will be devoted entirely to the uses of the firm.
"Tom and I are going to have a chafing-dish supper to-morrow evening," said one man to another." Drop in about 8:30 and we will show you how things are done on this island."

The judges of paintings and sculptures at the World's Fair have finished their labors. with a result that eighty-three men and eight women receive each, a modal for paintings or water colors, pastels or drawings in black and white, and fourteen men receive each a medal for sculptures.
ROME, Aug. 26. -- Seven persona died of Asiatic cholera here to-day.
The weekly bank statement issued to-day showed an increase in reserve of $5,308,123. The banks now hold $6,737,675 less than the legal requirements.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, Aug. 26. -- The situation at the islands now is about as it usually is in September. The financial depression has operated to some extent on this as well as on other Summer resorts of the country to keep away a number who are usually seen here. From the 1st of July there has been a good business done.
Two Englishmen came to blows the other day on the beach at Trouville, and hammered each other for a while with cordial energy. The event moves a writer in Gil Bius to remark:

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Big storms affect Bay Shore not at all. To the Summer visitor extracting all possible pleasure from life the gales of Wednesday night were simply regrettable. When the sun shone the next day the little thrills of alarm that may have disturbed the pretty girls the night before were promptly forgotten, the dancer was on, and joy was again unconfined.

The Italian fleet will probably sail to-day for Algiers. The fleet consists of the Etna, Vitorio Emmanuele, Amerigo Vespucoi, and Flavio Gioja. From Algiers the Italian ships will proceed, the Etna to Naples and the three remaining vessels to Leghorn. At Leghorn the Royal Italian Naval School is situated. The Amerigo Vespucoi, Flavio Gioja, and Vitorio Emmannele are due at Leghorn on Nov. 1.

Didericksen's great statue, "The Struggle for Liberty," is sure to attract the attention and admiration of art lovers when Messrs. Wechsler McNulty open their large drygoods establishment at the corner of Bedford and Fulton Avenues and Brevoort Place, Brooklyn.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26. -- Harold McCormick, son of the reaper manufacturer, had an unpleasant experience in this city Thursday night. He had been in the city visiting a college chum, a son of Frank Rockefeller of the Standard Oil Company.

CHARMS FOR DISEASES. -- Lists of potions, decoctions, and remedies resorted to not only by Dyaks, Finns, and Badagas, but by Greek philosophers such as Serapion and Alexander of Trailles are by no means attractive. It is sufficient to say that they are the quintessence of everything noxious, repulsive, and nasty.

The evidence taken by the Custom House Investigating Commission on Friday. In reference to the lax methods of doing business in the Surveyor's Department resulted yesterday in the arrest of Ainnson B. Ostrander of 239 West Twenty-third Street, head weigher for the Hoboken District, on the charge of defrauding the Government by systematically undervaluing goods.

SYRACUSE, Ang. 26. -- There is organized oppetition in this city to State Committeeman W. B. Kirk's candidacy for the office of State Treasurer. Several secret meetings have been held, and the result is that the Byan Democrats are out for Hugh Duffy of Cortland, and will contend in the caucuses might and main to elect Duffy delegates.

Captains Patrick Sarafield Donovan and John Montgomery Ward with their teams at star ball tossers gave two exhibitions on the Polo Grounds before an assemblage of 15,000, the second largest crowd of the year. Every seat in all stands was occupied and standing room was at a premium. It was one of those crowds that make a baseball stockholder feel that life is worth living.

If there are any ghosts at Palmer's Theatre, left over from the old days, they must have been startled, and perhaps not altogether pleased, last evening when the audience, an audience that was very impressive as to numbers and very well dressed and quite up to date, joined in the chorus of "Little Annie Rooney," and sang it through with much enthusiasm and some vigor.

LICHFIELD AND DR. JOHNSON. -- Lichfield is, of course, the official pilgrimage for all admirers of the good old doctor. Fewplaces are more thoroughly permeated with the flavor of the Johnsonian legend; and though the ordinary sightseer is satisfied with what is shown in the marketplace, there are many more memorials almost more suggestive, and that appeal more forcibly and romantically to the wellskilled visitor.

From the Somerville (N.J.) Democrat. The Republican press has heretofore been one of the foremost agents in spreading alarm. It was disheartening enough to read or failures on all sides without having scarecrows set up in every community. The financial crisis was sure to come from our overtrading, profitless trading, and lavish living.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- The State Auditor, State Treasurer, and Attorney General, as a Board of Appraisers and Assessors under the Nichols law, have fixed the valuation of the property of the Western Union Telegraph Company in this state at $2,011,076.45.
BRENTWOOD, L.I., Aug. 26. -- The week has been eventful here, and pleasant features followed each other in close succession.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 26. -- The police and the socalled unemployed came into collision this afternoon opposite the south entrance to the City Hall. The police, under Inspector Ross, chanced on the men as they marched past and scattered them in every direction.

Memories of last Spring's international naval rendezvous wore revived at the foot of East Twenty-eighth street early yesterday morning. when a crowd strong in numbers, but weak in nautical information, gathered to speed the NewHampshire, with its crew of New-York Naval Reserves, on its voyage to Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island.

In framing their regulations for the future of Bering Sea seal hunting, it is fortunate that the arbitrators at Paris have not overlooked the needs of the North Pacific. Some of the news from that region indicates a large catch of the animals this year outside the limits of Bering Sea. More than seven weeks ago Commander LUDLOW of the Mohican was informed that already nearly 80,000 skins had been taken by the sealing fleet.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Entertainments, dances, card parties, sailing, and innumerable other pleasures have crowded each other in cool Sea Cliff this week, and next week promises to be even more eventful. The net proceeds of the fair for St. Luke's Episcopal Church reached $625.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- In a bill for divorce filed in the Superior Court to-day by Mrs. Bella C. Hassett against William E. Hassett of this city some most astonishing charges are made.

During the storm last Thursday morning Vice Commodore Harold Sanderson's yawl Nonpareil dragged her anchor in Larchmont Harbor and was driven on the rocks at Umbrella Point. She is almost a wreck. Mr. Sanderson is one of the most popular members of the Larchmont Club, and the members were all sorry when they heard of the plight the famous boat was in.

The awards of medals for paintings and sculptures to Americans exhibiting work at the World's Fair have not pleased anybody very much, but not for the reason given by certain correspondents of New-York papers. It is a general objection, based on the fact that no grading of medals was permitted; so that painters and sculptors whose work barely reach the mark have won exactly the same distinction as artists who show masterpieces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- "How long before it wiil be completed?" was asked of Mr. A.R. Spofford, the Librarian of Congress, as he stood on the Capitol plaza a few days ago gazing at the new Library Building, whose shining dome is now a conspieuous object.

RAHWAY, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Imagine an heir to $4,000,000 performing the menial service of janitor of a public library! Such is the work now being done by John S. Huff of Rahway, alleged heir to landed estates in California, New-York, and New-Jersey.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- A world's amateur record was broken at the games of the Boston Athletic Association held on Holmes Field, Harvard, this afternoon. The record put in the shade was that made by W. G. George in England in the mile run. George's record was 4:18 3-5. To-day Tommy Connsff ran a mile in 4:17 4-5.

The case of Henry Eichenhauer of 427 East Fourteenth Street, who was arrested on Aug. 17 by Policeman Scott on a charge of creating a disturbance, came up again in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday.

MCKEESPORT, Penn., Aug. 26. -- The National Tube Works Company, which employs from 7,000 to 9,000 men when operating in full, has posted a notice to the effect that on Aug. 30 five welding furnaces will be started in the lap mill until such time as additional furnaces in that mill, as well as furnaces in the butt mill, can be put in operation.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Schooner Charles M. Trickey from Baltimore, for Dover, N.H., with coal, and schoner Governor, Sargentville, Me., for New-York with paying stones, collided last evening ten miles northeast of Nausett. Cape Cod. The Governor was cue down and sank almost immediately. The Trickey was badly damaged.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 26. -- The scarcity of men at Centre Moriches has become really alarming. Throughout the week some of the fairest flowers of New-York and Brooklyn's society, blossoming here for the Summer, are compelled to waste their sweetness on the desert air. Saturday always brings an influx of brothers, husbands, and finances, it's true, but they only come to stay over Sunday, and Monday morning they take flight again.

In order to intensify the rivalry at the World's Fair sports to be held in Chicago next month THE NEW-YORK TIMES has offered a handsome medal, to be given to the athlete making the best individual performance. It is one of the prettiest medals ever manufactured by Robert Stoll, and the competitor who is lucky enough to win it will have a token that he can point to with pride.

Three men, said to be Western "crocks," were arrested in this city yesterday and looked up at Police Headquarters on suspicion of having been concerned in the recent theft of a bag containing $5,000 in twenty-dollar gold pieces from the counter of the First National Bank of St. Paul, Minn. They are Benjamin Miller, who calls himself Henry Conn; Henry Morris, who gives his name as Edward Gillespie, and John Tomlins.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Aug. 26 -- It is inevitable that the remarkable weather of the past ten days should be mentioned. Normandie has experienced everything in this line from a West Indian cyclone to the ideal day such as poets are wont to rave over. The big storm on Wednesday night gave the guests -- particularly the women -- a scare that they will remember for some time.

The Hon. William Jones was a man who having reached a determination, acted promptly. Therefore, when he decided that he would see the World's fair, he at once set about securing information as to the means of getting to Chicago. The honorable gentleman made a tour of the railroad offices, and gathered together a large bundle of the gaudy descriptive "folders" that are supposed to contain all the information the traveler needs.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.L., Aug. 26. -- The complimentary nop at the Prospect House was a fit ending to one of the gayest weeks in Shelter Island's merry history. It was largely attended, despite the counter attractions of the day and evening, and the press of social events all through the week. It was an exceptionally brilliant affair.
The Andrews-Demarest Seating Company team won a cleverly played game at Prospect Park yesterday over the Andrews Manufacturing Company nine. The score:

FREEPORT, L.I., Aug. 26. -- The Rev. Charles Edwards was up to Tuesday last, a Baptist minister of Freeport. He is now, however, divorced from his congregation, and, to all in tents and purposes, a seceder from his church.

NRWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26. -- Clarence Hobart of New-York is advanced another round toward the championship. This moraine be defeated W. A. Larned, one of the strong men of the tourney, 3 sets to 2. The match was me best of the tournament thug far. Play began shortly after 11, with Hobarts serving. The first game went quickly to Hobart, Lamed only getting a point.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 26. -- This old Revolutionary town is still receiving a large quota of late Summer guests who intend to stay until the season is over.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 26. -- The Fourth National Bank, one of the five Louisville banks which suspended payment a short time ago, resumed business to-day. The City National and the Merchants' National will also resume within a few days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Elijah A. Morse, member of Congress from the Twelfth Massachusetts District, recently informed Pension Commissioner Lochren that he expected him immediately to order a review and re-examination of a particular pension case.

The imports for the week exclusive of specie, were $8,541,635, of which amount $2,260,457 was in dry goods and the remainder in general merchandise. The imports of specie were $8,034,750, of which $161,292 was in silver and the balance in gold. The exports of specie were $759,124.

R.H, MACY CO. EIXTH AV., 13TH TO 14TH ST. Imported Fall and Winter Model Sample Garments. Our regular annual sale of high-class imported model sample garments will occur on Monday, Aug. 28, when we will offer the latest creations of the most prominent artists from Paris, Berlin, and London, and at our usual cut figures.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The last week as been a gay one and many have been the sources of amusement. Tennis, baseball, boating, dancing, riding, and driving have all called for their share of the hours of the day -- and night.

The total imports of gold for the fix weeks ending Friday were over $34,600,000. The Campanies brought several millions more yesterday, and there are some additional millions in transit now. Our total imports for the year so far recorded aggregate over $46,000,000; while the exports for the same period were $68,000,000. The interesting feature of the movement is the suddenness with which the outward stream was arrested and then turned back.
There is nobody in Paris at present to take the place as a writer of novels formerly occupied by Leopold Stapleaux, who had replaced Henri Conscience.

ELBERON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- A peculiar and delightful feature of Elberon life is its deviation from the conventional. People at other resorts begin to pack up and make ready to go home when the 1st of September draws near, but the season never closes here until October.

SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- Thursday's storm was a gale and downpour such as Saratoga has rarely seen, lasting throughout the daylight hours. The rain ceased at 7 o'clock, in time to pack the Town Hall for the play which Rose Coghlan and her company gave. After the performance a dinner was given at the clubhouse by Edgar Murphy to a company of about twenty-five "first-nighters."

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26. -- When the goldenrod blossoms on Mount Desert the tide of Summer life along this picturesque coast has reached its height. It has been a busy week for Bar Harborites, but they stand the strain with remarkable fortitude.

The fast steam yacht Feiseen, owned by W.B. Cogswell of Syracuse, started out from Zebo's Pier at South Brooklyn, Friday afternoon, and met the steamer Monmouth of the Sandy Hook line, which is considered the fastest passenger steamer in New-York Harbor, off Liberty Island on her 3:45 trip to the Highlands, and it was seen by every one on board that a race was at hand.

Easily slips this little book into the fluent literature of the hour. Convenient in size, delightful in form, ready on a moment's notice to give a half day or a half hour of pleasure, appealing to the most fastidious and difficult of refined tastes, yet with food for the multitude of average readers, it will fill its place gracefully and meet with its welcome from the West and East, from the North and South.

Wall Street interest yesterday morning centred in the bank statement. All sorts of estimates of its figures were made, some of them being wildly optimistic and others most despondent. The statement itself proved to be fully up to the prophecies of conservative bankers.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Fred Ferris, an Elmira transfer, has either escaped from Auburn Prison or is in hiding within its walls. The prison authorities are inclined to the belief that he is stowed away.

The Staten Island Cricket Club played its return game with the Manhattans yesterday at Prospect Park. A close game was expected. The Islanders, however, had everything their own way, for after scoring 151 for 6 wickets, they disposed of their opponents for 55, thus winning by 96 runs.

WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 26. -- The most beautiful home in this quiet village is Runnymede, a grand old estate of 1,200 acres. There william Maxwell Evarts and Mrs. Evarts have lived during the Summer months ever since they were married. There the eleven children that have been born to them, all of whom grew to manhood and womanhood and ten of whom are yet living, have spent the happiest days of their lives.

To many readers the most interesting article in the current number of the Forum, will be that of Dr. MCGLYNN on "The Vatican and the United States." It is not every day that we have an authentic account of the reconciliation with the Church of a priest who has been subjected to discipline, even to the extent of excommunication.

Anton Seidl is at his house at Fleischmann's in the Catskllls. He divides his waking hours -- aside from those needed, for eating -- into three parts. In the first part he rests; in the second he orchestrates wild, weird piano compositions by the Abbe Liszt; in the third he plays penuchle. And the greatest of these is penuchle.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- The dominant factor in all Stock Exchange transactions during the last week has been the movement of gold in and out of the Bank of England and the probability of an advance in the bank rate on Monday.

The Morris Park and Kings County St. George Clubs played their return game yesterday at the grounds of the New-York Jockey Club, where the home team would have gained an easy victory but for the intervention of the scythebearer, stumps being drawn when the Morris Parks had only 32 runs to get to win and seven men yet to be put out.

The Democratic State Committee has decided to call the convention that is to make nominations for the next election to meet at Saratoga on the 5th of October. It is assumed that this decision was made on the advice of two or three prominent leaders, but there is no fault to be found with that. Saratoga is doubtless the best available place for a State Convention and the date is early enough.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- Mgr. Satolli, the Papal Delegate, accompanied by his private secretary, the Rev. Dr. Hector Papi, arrived in this city at 8:15 A.M. He was met at the station by a large delegation of prominent Catholics headed by Archbishop Eider.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 26. -- The National Government made a slight bend of the diplomatic knee to-day. In compliance with a demand from the British Ambassador. The act consisted in suspending for thirty days, without pay, Paul Morgan, Captain of the Night Inspectors of Customs at this port.
BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- Josiah Quincy mailed a letter to President Cleveland last night in which he tendered his resignation of the office of Assistant Secretary of State.

The simple French play without words, called "L'Enfant Prodigue," was beautifully presented at Daly's Theatre two seasons ago, and was then hastily withdrawn by Mr. Daly, not because it had failed to draw, but because the manager felt he had made a mistake in venturing into a field so far from that in which he and his actors had found success.

THE LETHARGY OF SOCIETY. -- A member of the Tuxedo Club who has been spending a few weeks as Newport came to town last week and said that he "never knew of such a lethargic season." The same word comes from all the fashionable colonies. Just now fashionable society is on its midsummer move. A large number of Southampton residents hare gone to Newport.

From the Lewiston (Me.) Journal. Some of the uninitiated Canadians bring with them into Maine a lively apprehension of personal peril. Being strangers in a new land makes them nervous, perhaps. A Somerset County farmer, who lives well up on a hillside, tells a story of his hiring through an interpreter a Canadian who could speak no English to work for him.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 26. -- The rain has had the best of it most of the time during the last week, and Thursday the dampness condensed its energy into a regular old-fashioned steady pour from morning to night, so that card tables were more in demand than carriages. The trains still continue to bring as many as they take, and the landlords continue to smile.

DUNVILLE, Ill., Aug. 26. -- While Henry Helmick and his wife were returning home from church last night two highwaymen grasped his horses' heads while two other robbers leaped into the carriage. Mr. Helmick struck his horses with the whip and they reared, breaking loose from the highwaymen.

Anson's men dropped another game to the Brooklyns yesterday through poor field work. They hit the pitching of Daub hard and often, but ran the bases carelessly, and lost opportunities through blunders in handling batted balls. The left-handed youth, Clausen, again pitched a good game. Hatfield being the only man able to gauge his curves with any degree of success.

For the benefit of some Senators who during the past week have shown a variegated ignorance of the national banking law and the operation of the banks, the following brief catalogue of some of the fictions by which they have been deluded is submitted:

The annual regatta of the Corinthian Mosquito Fleet was sailed yesterday off the clubhouse at New-Rochelle. Nine boats started for the cups offered by Commodore F.S. Grant, F.B. Jones, and C.M. Connolly, Others would have started, but Thursday's storm disabled them. The Scarecrow, owned by "Tramp'' Stevens, had her boom broken. The yawl Leith ran on the rocks.

The steamer New-York of the American Line arrived in port yesterday afternoon about 3:45 o'clock. She had a boisterous passage, which proved trying to the various distinguished passengers aboard, but she met with no mishaps and was only a few hours behind time.

Among the midsummer costumes are some lovely creations in black and white, as a sheer, transparent organdy with large black dots raised in bourette work, and a white Swiss with tiny black dots. The latter was trimmed will rows of black velvet ribbon a third of an inch wide. White silk dotted in black makes extremely ohio gowns trimmed in black lace.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore has returned from the World's Fair, where he spent nine weeks gathering material for the coarse or lectures to teachers provided for by the State Superintendent of Public Instruction. He devoted himself to seeing all he could while there, and when the school teachers assemble for the Saturday morning lectures at the American Museum of Natural History in October he will try to tell of his visit for their benefit.

CLAY TABLETS. -- The clay of which the Tell Amarna tablets are composed differed greatly in different regions. Dr. Bezold says: "In color the tablets vary from a light to a dark dust tint, and from a flesh color to dark brick red. The nature of the clay of which they are made sometimes indicates the countries from which they come.
The auction sales of realty announced for this week are neither numerous nor significant. Being all in foreclosure proceedings, they will be held at 111 Broadway. Details of all sales are subjoined:
