New-Yorkers who tolled yesterday in 80 of heat intensified by humidity at 92, have the consolation or knowing that a cool wave is traveling from the West toward the metropolis. This pleasine bit of news was given out by Local Forecaster Dunn.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The people who have not yet thought of returning home from the Catskills are having no reason to regret it, for the weather up there has been exceptionally delightful all this month. Hundreds of people are returning home, but, for all that, the Catskills will keep more Summer guests through September than ever before.

J.W. Roberts, the author of "Looking Within," (A.S. Barnes Co.,) is a man with a sensible mind, and no literary style, good or bad, who, having suffered acutely, it seems, from the effects of the fuss in the East about Bellamyism, set himself to work to write a book refuting the false theories of Bellamy.

BREWSTERS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- A terrible accident occurred this noon on the Harlem Railroad, near Dykeman's Station, just north of here, which cost six lives and in which many persons were badly injured. The killed are:

A charming young girl from the South came, alone and moneyless, to a big Northern city to study art. She was not wholly friendless, however, and she had wit enough to follow the practical advice of one of her friends who bade her borrow of herself rather than of others, further suggesting that she earn the needed money by enlisting in the best paying profession known -- house service.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 27, 2:30 A.M. -- The most terrible accident that has happened on Long Island in many years took place late last night on the Long Island Railroad just beyond Laurel Hill Station, two miles from this city.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 26. -- Dullness has prevailed at the Summer resorts hereabout this week. Weatherwise it has been the most disagreeable of the season. For three days all outdoor pleasures had to be abandoned, with a corresponding drooping of spirits among the Summer colonists, and many seriously thought of cutting shore their vacations and returning to their city homes.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 26. -- There was a quiet ending to the Grand Circuit meeting at Hampden Part to-day, and the patronage fell off considerably. The track itself was better than it has been since the horses came here, but the only fast mile was the first one trotted this afternoon. This was in the 2:15 class, for which Azote sold favorite at 5 to 1 in a field of six.

Under the hot sun of Algeria -- which, by the way, cannot be much more scorching than the orb which is just now meltinc the asphalt in Paris -- electioneering becomes a somewhat exciting exercise. A dispatch from Algiers relates that M. Samary, candidate for the first division of that constituency, was recently engaged in whipping up his supporters in the suburbs, accompanied by M. Vivarez, a local official.

INDIA FOR THE INDIANS. -- The question is, which Indians? People forget that "in many respects the Punjabi Mohammedan and the Bengali, the Sikh and the Madrasi, the Pathan and the Mahratta, are more widely separated in feelings and ideas than are the English and Russians, the French and Germans, or the Italians and Norwegians."

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The Bayonne (N.J.) Rowing and Athletic Association's sixteenth annual club regatta proved a great success on New-York Bay this afternoon. The large and wealthy organization recovered from the disastrous hurricane of Wednesday night just in time. All the boat races except the invitation race were a mile with a turn.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- The Boston Theatre, which had been renovated and beautified, was opened Monday night. George Thatcher and his company appeared in "Africa," the new comic opera by Clay Greene, Cheever Goodwin, and Randolph Cruger. Large audiences have enjoyed this production, and it will be retained here for another week.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- The progressive hearts party given by Mr. C.N. Schermerhorn proved a very enjoyable event. The features of the evening, as the announcements sent out denoted, were card playing and a generally jolly time. As a creator of amusement a booby prize was offered in the shape of an immense bottle of tomato catsup as a reward for the one coming nearest in similarity to the name of the bottle's contents.

When the President's message to Congress was published, the good Dr. Jekyll was dominant in the management of oar neighbor the Tribune, but he was soon supplanted by toe wicked Mr. Hyde. We do not recall a transformation so swiftly made since the days when our neighbor's Mr. Hyde was asserting that the failure of the BARINGS had been caused by the Congressional elections in this country.

J.W. Schofield, the champion amateur bicycle rider of England, accompanied by his trainer, W.O. Bryan, arrived here yesterday on the New-York. He has been refused a license by the National Cycling Union of England on the ground that he is working in the interests of a bicyle firm, a crime that every prominent rider in England and America is guilty of.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In an article copied from THE NEW-YORK TIMES in a Kansas City paper in reference to the extinction of an Oregon tribe of Indians the name is splled Roque. This may be a mistake of the paper that reproduced THE TIMES'S article. On the wall of this bank hangs a map dated the year the bank started in business -- 1845.

Yesterday was one of the few red-letter days that occur in the so consistently luckless calendar of that potty species of gambler the policy player. Men who have for many months past been living at free lunch counters and nave found the public parks not the worat place in the world to spend the night are to-day eating their three meals or settling for a month's board in advance.

The result of nearly eight years of litigation was reached yesterday, when Henry W. Turner, referee in the suit of John Craig against Maria Craig, alias Maria Linden, filed a decision in the Supreme Court.

ISLES OF SHOALS, N.H., Aug. 26. -- For the first time in the history of the Isles of Shoals they have telegraphic communication with the mainland. Last Saturday the submarine cable was laid connecting these islands with the NewHampshire shore. It was not difficult to make the soundings for the cable, as the water at its greatest depth between Appledore and Rye -- the cable termini -- does not exceed seven feet.

I had returned to the city after fire years' absence, and was again settled in my bachelor quarters, so comfortably settled that l might well imagine I had not been away, but for one thing. When I had been appointed, on account of linguistic proficiency, Secretary of our Legation to a South American republic, I was unknown. Events during my service were unusually stirring.

WAVERLY, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The big race meet of the Riverside Athletic Club Cyclers of Newark, N. J., was held on the State fair grounds here this afternoon. The weather was a trifle warm for the cyclers. Not even a leaf was stirring and the little breeze the riders enjoyed was felt only when going at top speed. Late in the afternoon a cool breeze sprung up.

ISLES OF SHOALS, N.H., Aug. 26. -- For the first time in the history of the Isles of Shoals they have telegraphic communication with the mainland. Last Saturday the submarine cable was laid connecting these islands with the NewHampshire shore. It was not difficult to make the soundings for the cable, as the water at its greatest depth between Appledore and Rye -- the cable termini -- does not exceed seven feet.

I had returned to the city after fire years' absence, and was again settled in my bachelor quarters, so comfortably settled that l might well imagine I had not been away, but for one thing. When I had been appointed, on account of linguistic proficiency, Secretary of our Legation to a South American republic, I was unknown. Events during my service were unusually stirring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26. -- At the inquest in the case of "R.W. Parker," who committed suicide at the Grand Hotel Wednesday, the widow of the dead man said that she was married about two years ago in Baltimore to Parker, who then went by the name of W.K. Prescott.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The yachts Satanits, Navahoe, Britannia, and Calluna sailed to-day in the regatta of the Start Bay Yacht Club. The course was a triangular one, starting from a markboat off the entrance of Dartmouth Harbor, and was sailed over three times, making the entire distance forty-two miles, not including the tacking.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27 -- The campaign in New-Jersey this year will be given zest by the Citizens' League, the anti-race-traok organization, which is preparing to make a vigorous fight. The recent licensing of Linden and Clifton has stirred up the reformers. While there will be no meeting of the Executive Committee till the middle of September, there have been conferences of the league leaders recently, and they realize that the fight must be desperate.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 27 -- St. John's Hospital had many anxious callers to-day. There are in the hospital sixteen victims of the wreck at Berlin, who are more or less dangerously injured, and many friends and relatives called to learn of their condition.

The Rev. Dr. Edward Beecher, brother of the late Henry Ward Beecher, yesterday celebrated his ninetieth birthday. Dr. Beecher has lived with his wife and adopted daughter. Voice Adams Beecher, at 182 Macon Street, Brooklyn, since he moved to Brooklyn, twenty-one years ago.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 27 -- County Attorney W.H. Averitt was shot by Robert Hardwick at Stanton yesterday. Hardwick was defendant in a case which Averitt prosecuted. The two men exchanged words across the street. Averitt ran his hand in his pocket as if to pull his pistol, when Hardwick fired. The shot struck Averitt a little to the right of the breastplate and entered his chest, tearing his heart and jungs to pieces.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Hunting's Railroad Circus landed here to-day, and, after landing the menagerie and tents on the ground, the employes refused to raise the tents or do other work until they received the money which they claim was due them, and they went on a strike late to-night. There are only three small tents erected.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 27 -- The First Battalion, Naval Reserves, continues to interest the residents and Summer visitors here. The amateur seamen spent the day as befits the Sabbath. There were, however, a number of visitors on board the old war ship New-Hampshire.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- This city was visited by a violent electric storm this afternoon a little after 3 o'clock. Two black clouds, hanging low and moving swiftly east and west, met here. Rain fell in torrents, accompanied by hailstones of enormous size. The most of them were tomato-shaped and many of them weighed a quarter of a pound each.

The four property men of the Irving theatrical company who were sent to Ellis Island as contract laborers were examined yesterday by the Board of Inspectors. Decision as to their right to land was reserved, but Chief Inspector Quinlan of the Contract Labor Bureau said the quartet would doubtless be returned, as they could not properly be considered either as artists or domestic servants, the only two classes of aliens that are allowed to land.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 27 -- Several St. Louis banks have received a letter from the First National Bank of Chicago which explains why Chicago cannot accept checks on New-York and other Eastern points and credit them at par. The substance of the letter is as follows:

SILVER MONEY AND BULLION -- "Juveen": (1) Why should there be, on one hand a high premium upon silver money and on the other hand, vast piles of silvar bullion bulked away in Government vauits (2) Cannot the Government pay out silver dollars in exchange for bills of high denominations?

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Three thousand devout Catholics gathered here to-day to witness the laying of the cornerstone of the new Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mercy by Archbishop Corrigan. The fete-day appearance of the town contrasted strongly with its funereal aspect last Sunday, when the rain caused the postponement of the ceremonies.

The officials at the annual regatta of the Union Boat Club, on Sept. 9, will be: Referee -- Horace Walters, Dauntless Rowing Club; Timekeepers -- Jacob Abeel, Nassau Boat Club; H.J. Behrens, Nonparell Rowing Club, and Leon Mayer, Lone Star Boat Club; Judges at Finish -- William T. Wilcox, Nereus Rowing Club, and William C. Doscher, Ata- lanta Boat Club.

Quinnemore, formerly Chief of the Court d' Aleae Indians, has a fine farm of 167 acres on the south side of the Spokane River, about a dozen miles above Spokane. Washington, and the other Any the tax gatherer thought it would be a very proper and desirable thing to tax it a good round sum. So he came smilingly with his bill.

It is now certain that the Home Rule bill will pass the House of Commons by a majority varying very little, if at all, from that by which the Government amendments were carried on Friday. That majority was in every case 38. This is but one short of the normal majority in an entirely full House.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 -- The interest in the all-comers tournament increases now that the candidates have been reduced to four players. R.D. Wrenn, Samuel Chase, Clarence Hobart, and F.H. Hovey are still in the race. Hobart seems to be the favorite since his clever showing yesterday against W.A. Larned.

The new Eighth Assembly District in one of the big down-town citadels of Democracy. More voters registered there In the last Presidential campaign than in any other Assembly district in the city, and with the exception of the Seventh Assembly District, it has more election districts in it than any of the others. The Eighth has fifty-five and the Seventh fifty-seven election districts.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 27 -- When John N. Wilson, a mine owner and politician of Carthage, this State, retired to his room at the Moser Hotel at 11 o'clock Friday night, he was in good spirits and bade his friends good-night cheerfully. Last night at 5 o'clock he died in the city dispensary from an overdose of morphine. On examining his clothing, a box containing fifteen morphine pills was found.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 -- At the beginning of the tariff war between Russia and Germany, Berlin politicians made airy prophecies that German industries would hardly feel the change. Their idea of the situation has proved to be a miserable delusion. Without doubt Russia suffers more than Germany, but the losses on this side of the Vistula are far from trivial.

We infer from statements recently made in the newspapers of Philadelphia that certain influential members of the high-tariff association called the Manufacturers' Club are beginning to be ashamed of the resolutions which they supported at a meeting of the club's Board of Directors, and which were said to have been adopted at that meeting by a vote of 14 to 3, in spite of the protest of President DOLAN and Vice President WILLIAM WOOD.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 27 -- By the frightful crash of heavily-laden passenger trains on the Long Island Railroad at Berlin last night fifteen persons lost their lives, seventeen were cut and braised and mangled, and dozens of others were injured more or less severely.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Benjamin Peters Hutchinson, the greatest operator ever known on the Chicago Board of Trade, has probably ended his career as a speculator forever. Over two years ago he failed, and since then has not figured "on 'Change" to any great extent. He has now sold his certificate of membership on the board, and this may be called the last act of his speculative career.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 27 -- At the national service in the Beach Auditorium this after noon the principal speaker was ex-Congressman Roswell G. Horr of Michigan. His subject was "The Nation's Bread and Butter."

ELISHA A. BUCK, proprietor of the Spirit of the Times, was a, native of Putnam County, and was fifty-three years of age. Mr. Buck was originally a railroad, contractor, and always took a deep interest in sporting events. At one time he owned the fasted double trotting team in the country. He first became interested in horses when he was at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1866.

Not for three-quarters of an hour after the collision was a physician taken to the scene to minister to the sufferings of the scores of unfortunates who needed relief. It was a full hour and a half after the disaster before the relief train with a corps of physicians on board capable of giving all needed service reached the spot.

A cricket contest somewhat out of the usual run will take place at Livingston, S.I., on Wednesday, when a team of West Indians will play the Staten Island Cricket Club. The West Indian eleven has been organized by A.S. Durrant of the Brooklyn Club, and he will be assisted by T.G. Clarke, C.H. Ellis, C.P. Hurditoh, G.C. Yeo, H.S.M. Crawford, J. Gill, J. Moran, H.S. Durrant, A.A. Adams, and E.G. Keogh.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 27 -- Andrew Gibson out Charles H. Connors's throat this morning, and afterward ran naked through the fields for thirty minutes, slashing and tearing his own throat until he inflicted wounds from which he died. Gibson was forty-five years old, Connors thirty.

Many bets were made yesterday on the fight between "Mysterious Billy" Smith and "Tommy" Ryan of Chicago, who meet at Coney Island to-morrow night. "Billy" Madden bet Flank Dunn. Smith's manager, $500 even that Ryan would win. Among the hotels Smith seems to be the favorite, Smith himself, in speaking of the fight, said yesterday that he would bet that he would knock Ryan out within four rounds.

Hugh McLaughlin's repose at his Summer retreat in Greenport was rudely disturbed Saturday by a report that he sent ex-Mayor Chapin to "read the riot act" to Mayor Boody shortly after the latter gentleman's accession to office in January, 1892. and that in consequence Mayor Boody discarded his reform ideas and surrendered to the ring.

We are near the end of August and have a cause of unexpected gratification in the unusually healthy condition of the city. All through the Summer months, although, the weather has at times been very "trying," the death rate has been lower than for several Summers past. This is the more gratifying because it was not expected.

As a sequel of the failure of the Right Hon. James Shanks. Lord Mayor of the City of Dublin, to invite the members of the Municipal Council of that city to the luncheon recently given at Mansion House in honor of the officers of the United States flagship Chicago, Dublin's Municipal Council has sat down to a dinner of its own.

DENNIS O'DONIGHUE, Deputy Tax Commissioner, died last evening at his residence in the Amsterdam apartment house, at 195 West Eighty-first Street. Mr. O'Donoghue was a native of this city and in his fifty-eighth year. He engaged for many years in the raw silk business. In the Fall of last year he was appointed Deputy Tax Commissioner, the first political office that he had ever held.

It is fortunate that this is to an unusual extent an "off year" in politics, for the attention of members of Congress now on duty at Washington, with an important task on their hands, is not distracted by any special interest in what is going on at home, and their action will be influenced less than usual by the uncertainties of local contests.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 2 7 cent., the average being about 4 cent.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 26 -- The local financial situation is improved, at least to the extent that the people are more hopeful, and funds are accessible where they could not be reached a week ago.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 -- The new managers of the Republican Party in Massachusetts have come to the conclusion that their chances of success this year will be materially promoted by conducting a short, sharp, and spirited campaign. They have selected Oct. 7 as the date of their annual convention. The election takes place just thirty days later, on Nov. 7.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Chairman Springer of the House Committee on Currency and Banking is quoted as saying:

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 27 -- Around the scene of ruin morbidly curious throngs were gathered all day, and no efforts of the few policemen on hand could make a clear passage for or give freedom of movement to the hundreds of workmen who began to clear away the wreck even before daylight.

BUDA-PESTH, Aug. 27 -- The annual report of the Hungarian Minister of Agriculture has appeared. Its estimate of the world's production of wheat this year is 2,279,000,000 bushels against the official average of 2,280,000,000 annually for the last ten years. According to the report the deficits to be filled by the importing countries will require 379,000,000 bushels.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27 -- The loss of life along the New-Jersey coast during the storm of Thursday has brought into discussion a pertinent query as to why life-saving corps are not kept at work during the entire year. The August storms for the past five years have been causing serious lots of life along the entire coast.

NEWTOWN, L.I. Aug. 27 -- The bodies of thirteen of the victims of the collision at Berlin rested to-day in the stable of Henry Skelton's undertaking establishment in Grand Street. The room which serves as a morgue was not large enough to contain, the dead, so a temporary morgue was fitted up in the stable in the rear.
Many women lose their husbands, but few make the extraordinary efforts to recover them which are being put forth by Mrs. Gertrude Cochrane of 973 Bergen Street, Brooklyn.

The writer off this handsome volume manifests both zeal and courage in the work he has undertaken. His aim is to tell the story of the Church of Scotland briefly, including "that great act of conscientiousness and sacrifice in 1843 that made eminent Scotchmen proud of their country, and added fresh nobility to the Christian world."

Alexander Guilmant, the famous French organist, who is well-known in Europe but a stranger here, was a passenger on the French Line steamship La Bourgogne, which arrived yesterday from Havre. M. Guilmant is a guest of the Waldorf. He will leave Tuesday for Chicago, where Americans will have their first opportunity of judging the musical valno of his works Friday.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 27 -- Just before the dismantled and battered engine of the Rockaway Beach train was taken to the repair shops this morning, one of the crew of the wrecking train discovered what appeared to be a piece of a woman's dress hanging from the dense mass of splintered and twisted timbers crowded into the broken front of the boiler.

Recently a clerk from the Treasury Department detailed to do work for the Civil Service Commission was dismissed. As he has been with the commission for six months and has done his work satisfactorily, it is not easy to see what good reason the Treasury Department could have for his removal, and so far the commission has been unable to get from the department any statement of what the reasons were for the removal.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 -- The Monmouth County and Harvard polo teams met yesterday in the Westcheater Polo Club's tournament for teams of four. The former appeared to be entirely uneducated in the art of the game, though they rode well and had the best strings of ponies seen here in some time. They failed to make a single goal in the afternoon's play, and sustained a crushing defeat.
Sir Henry Bessemer, the renowned inventor, now in his eightieth year, is said to be writing his autobiography.

William Theis, aged thirty-nine years, of 251 West Thirty-eighth Street, was on the roof of 207 West Forty-first Street last evening helping some boys fly a kite, when he stepped backward off the coping and fell to the area. His legs were broken and he was badly hurt about the head. He was taken to the New-York Hospital in a critical condition.
The "old timers" who gathered at Fleetwood yesterday to see the famous trotters of the day recalled many stories of the old track.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 -- The annual regatta of the Hoboken Evening News Rowing Association toot place at Weehawken yesterday. There were six contests, and the entries included all the boat clubs of Hoboken.

When it was determined in the House of Representatives that Mr. WILSON'S bill for repeal of the Sherman act, with the amendments and substitute proposed by Mr. BLAND, should be debated for two weeks, and that then a vote should be taken, we expressed the opinion that the arrangement was a wise one, and creditable to both sides.

The labor conference for the relief of the unemployed met again yesterday at the International Labor Exchange, 257 East Tenth Street, and the sub-committee reported that it had issued a special appeal to organized labor, to employed workingmen, and to citizens in general, calling attention to the urgent importance of immediate relief to the unemployed.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- An attempt is now being made to secure the release of the aged William H. King from an asylum for the insane, where he has long been confined. An application for a writ of habeas corpus was Blade to the Supreme Court to-day, and a hearing in the case will be had on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Senate has reaffirmed its decision that Lee Mantle shall not be recognized as a Senator from Montana. It has also refused a seat to John B. Allen, who was appointed by the Governor of Washington to succeed himself as a Senator from that State. This decisive action was taken this afternoon.

-- In a cellar at 317 Milwaukee Avenue, Chicago, the police Sunday found Peter Carellas, a Greek, nineteen years of age, dead from a bullet wound in his heart. Standing beside the body were Theodore Dinos, Peter Deuetrolus, and John Dinos, all of the same age. They were arrested. The police believe Carellas was murdered by his companions.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 28 -- In the village of Linden to-night a desperate fight occurred between two women, Martha Colvert, forty-two years old, and Mary Murphy, forty-eight years old. The former attacked her opponent with a potato knife, and also struck her on the head with an old cannon ball.
The news of the death on Sunday in a Philadelphia hospital of Cap. James H. Spencer, commander of the Red Star steamship Illinois, was received with much regret in shipping circles here.

All the owners of the four eighty-five-footers are now doing a lot of thinking, and Gen. Paine is not alone in this respect. The yachts are being prepared for the trial races, which will be sailed next week, and the owners are thinking of every possible way to make the yachts sail faster than they already have.

At the very time that a large number of men have been thrown out of employment, some of whom complain loudly that they have no opportunity to earn their daily bread, we hear from various parts of the country that the farmers find difficulty in getting enough hands for the work of harvesting their crops.

COBURG, Aug. 28 -- The body of Duke Ernst of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha. who died at the castle of Reinhardsbrunn at about midnight Wednesday last, was brought to this city to-day and interred in the Horitzkirohe. The coffin, which was covered with a purple velvet pall, was conveyed from the castle to the hearse by twelve foresters.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Aug. 28 -- From an early hour this morning until late in the afternoon Skelton's Morgue, in which the bodies of the victims of the wreck Saturday night on the Long Island Railroad were laid out, was visited by crowds of men and women. Some of the visitors were evidently impelled by morbid curiosity.

-- The Indian has usually an unconquerable antipathy to ascending volcanic mountains, hut a party from the Academy of Sciences of Tacoma ana the Tacoma Alpine Club, have lately succeeded in coaxing Leahi, son of Chief Quiclmuth, to make the ascent of Mount St. Helens with them in spite of his superstitious dread.

Though but twenty-one years old, Harry Jarvis of 236 East Fifty-seventh Street, has managed to make such effectual use of his time as to get himself arrested on a charge of bigamy, which, judging even by his own statements, seems to be well founded.

That a Frenchman who has taught the art of painting to hundreds of Americans and painted the portraits of a host of American ladies and gentlemen should manage to wrench himself loose from the fascinations of Paris in this four hundred and first year of Columbus is not matter for great surprise. M. Carolus-Duran is already so well known in America that a visit to New-York is a visit to many old friends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Free coinage went down to-day in the first half hour of the voting on the Wilson repeal bill, and the defeat of the proposition at issue was but the beginning of a series of defeats, including all the proposed new ratios for silver and the return to the Bland-Allison act.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Aug. 28 -- Eaglesmere, the Summer resort on the crest of the Alleghenies in Sullivan County, had an experience with a windstorm Sunday evening which wrecked one cottage and several barns, and badly damaged other buildings.

NEW-YORK. MONDAY, Aug. 28 -- P.M. The great majority against silver shown by the votes in the House of Representatives had the result of strengthening the stock market, and the good effects continued to the close, the last prices being generally the best for the day.

MADRID, Aug. 28 -- The old City of Saragossa, capital of the province of that name, was the scene yesterday of a serious riot growing out of the dissatisfaction of the spectators at a bull fight with the character of the performance.

SOMERVILLE, N.J. Aug. 28 -- Wit bin the past month two attempts have bean made two miles west of White House, N.J., to wreck last express trains on the Central Railroad of New Jersey. The place is in the deep woods, on top of Pickels Mountain. In each case it was the same train; only going in the opposite direction.

This afternoon at Sheepshead Bay the question of supremacy among the two-year-olds will be settled by the running of the Futurity, the most valuable race of the year. The outlook at midnight was for a rainy day and a heavy track. It will be unfortunate if these conditions exist, for there will hardly be a postponement in these times, when there is racing every day of the week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Representative McCreary of Kentucky has prepared a joint resolution which he will introduce providing for an investigation of the monetary question.

Stupid serenity sat perspiring and undisturbed yesterday in the alleged vortex of Anarchy and civil schism. Orchard Street was a peaceful perspective, bobbing with push carts and slippery with fruit rinds. Alien Street was a dark volley of dull trade, shadowed by nothing more dangerous than the elevated railway. Walhalla Hall and Covenant Ball stood empty and yawning for the revolutionists who came not.

The Spiritualists, mesmerists, and mind readers who are attending the sessions of the Psychical Science Congress at Chicago have tailed to take advantage of a great opportunity. There has been in Chicago for some time an elderly gentleman who is pretty well known in the medical world -- Dr. ERNEST HART, the editor of the British Medical Journal.

The Senate yesterday rejected Mr. COCKRELL'S amendment to the Voorhees Bank bill. This amendment called for the redemption of the 2 per cent, bonds in a new issue of legal-tender notes. It received 23 votes against 29. It is amazing that so many votes could have been secured for this proposition, which is utterly unsound in principle and spiteful and petty in, notive.

Chairman Brookfield of the Republican State Committee came to town yesterday morning from his retreat in the Adirondacks and signed the call for the meeting of the Republican State Committee in this city on Thursday noon of this week at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The call was promptly mailed to the members by the clerk of the committee, Major Reuben L. Fox.

The Columbian Liberty and Peace Bell left Jersey City yesterday afternoon at 1:15 o'clock for Chicago. It is in charge of William O. McDowell, Chairman of the Bell Committee, who is accompanied by the wife, son, and daughter of Clinton E.I. Meneely, who cast the bell. Miss Meneely was the young lady who touched the button, in place of Mrs. Cleveland, when the bell was cast June 20.

A libel case somewhat similar to that which Messrs, W.H. Smith successfully defended the other day has Just come before one of the Correctional Courts in Parts. M. de Sesmaisone, a former Minister Plenipotentiary of the Franch Republic at Haiti, at present residing in Paris, was annoyed at some comments upon his conduct while in America that appeared in the New-York Tribune.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The seventh annual picnic of the John Y. McKane Association is being held this evening at Feltman's Pavilion. It is, as usual, one of the great events of the season, and thousands are in attendance.

One of the victims of the cyclone of last week was William E. Chapman, the well-known President of the Chapman Wrecking Company. Early on Thursday, the morning after the storm, Mr. Chapman left his Summer home at Preston, Conn., with his son, Isaac E. Chapman, for the railway station.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28 -- A prominent stockholder in the Consolidated Railroad has been instrumental in circulating an article, which reads:

The majorities by which the various propositions of the silver party were rejected in the House of Representatives were very much, larger than the most sanguine friends of the repeal bill had dared to expect, while the majority for the repeal bill itself was so great that it may without exaggeration be termed overwhelming.

Haywood H. Harvey, inventor of the Harveyized system of surface-hardening armor plates, died yesterday morning at his home in Orange, N.J. He bad been ill five months. The immediate cause at his death was kidney trouble. Mr. Harvey was born in New-York State in 1823. He was a son of Gen. Thomas W. Harvey.
LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 28 -- By the death of August Jakobson the number of victims of Saturday night's frightful catastrophe at Berlin, on the Long Island Railroad, was to-day increased to sixteen.
Gen. Alexander Hamilton and his wife have been reunited, and, by the terms of a verbal agreement made between them last Thursday afternoon, will live together in either this city or Washington.

WOODSIDE, L.I., Aug. 28 -- After keeping a large portion of the community in a state of terror all day, Alexander Pirie, a stalwart young Scotchman, eighteen years old, was finally subdued and arrested. For a week he had terrorized his brother-in-law, D'Israel Bregtigniere. The latter is a news agent on the Long Island Railroad, and has a small news stand here, in addition.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- The market to-day was strong, with few stocks offering. For Metropolitan Traction 80 1/4 was bid, and for Philadelphia Traction 70. The recant advance in Reading has been on the belief that the interest due on the general mortgage would be paid by the receivers by or before Oct. 1. This report the company refuses to confirm or deny.

By the great storm which swept over the Southern section of the country yesterday and worked such terrible destruction of life and property in Savannah, the entire telegraphic service to the South was destroyed.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Aug. 28 -- Further discouraging news concerning the Peary expedition comes from Labrador by the mail steamer arriving here last night. According to the last report Peary was at Davis Inlet, Aug. 2, and on Aug. 5 he had reached Nain.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Constable William Smith of Farmingdale made two arrests this evening, which will break up a dangerous gang of thieves that have been operating in Newark, N.J., for some time past. The prisoners are Joseph Seltzer and Louis P. Rupp. They were caught with a horse and buggey which had been stolen from Clayton Hoff, liverymen, at Newark.

TOPEKA, Aug. 28 -- Mrs. Laura M. Johns officially announces the opening of the equal suffrage campaign at the mass meeting in Kansas City, Sept. 1 and 2. Mrs. Johns says that the women of Kansas are tally organized, and that a systematic canvass will be carried on. The women believe that by persistent effort they will secure the personal pledges of more than enough voters to give them what they ask.

A telegram from Milan to the Popolo Romane brings news of the first move on the part of any private citizen to coin money in competition with the Government. The house of Gavazzi, well known in Milan, has issued its personal obligations in the form of email coins stamped with the firm's name, and the value represented by the base metal.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 28 -- A crew of eleven sailors from the Italian bark Vincenzo Galatola, which was abandoned at sea off Hatteras, Aug. 24, while on a voyage from Charleston, F.C., for Hamburg, was brought to this port this afternoon by the little whaling schooner Hattle E. Smith of Edgartown, Capt. Zenas Bourne, which herself had suffered damage in two gales which she encountered within the last ten days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The bill allowing national banks to increase their circulation up to the par value of the bonds deposited by them was taken up in the Senate to-day, the question being on the amendment offered by Mr. Cookrell (Dem., Mo.,) for the redemption of such 2 per cent, bonds as may be presented, and the payment therefor in a new issue of Treasury notes.
"There is a man in New-York who has made himself rich in the incendiary business," said a member of a well-known firm of insurance adjusters to a NEW-YORK TIMES reporter.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Aug. 28 -- This was a holiday here, and at least 25,000 people took part in the outlines of various Brooklyn organizations. At the several parks and groves there was plenty of music and amusement. Factory whistles blew, bells rang, and the citizens cheered as the various clubs appeared in town.

It is a self-evident proposition that the short lines of railroad connecting this city with the near-by resorts at Coney Island and Rockaway, over which crowded trains run at frequent intervals daring the Summer, should be under the most careful and systematic management, with every possible safeguard against accidents.

They were the same old Giants yesterday. They couldn't bat, run bases, or field a little bit, and gave every evidence of suffering from an aggravated attack of that tired feeling. Rusle pitched good ball, and held down the hits, but his colleagues, with the exception of Stafford and Davis, were indisposed, and tell easy victims to the skill of Mr. Killen.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28 -- F.H. Hovey is now a big favorite for the all-comers, having defeated Clarence Hobart in straight sets this morning. The victory was unexpected, though Hovey was known to be a strong player. He put up a great game this morning. Hobart was clearly outclassed from the start. The New-Yorker failed to play his usual driving game, and the Hobart stroke was at fault.

The action or the House in the sliver votes gave a decided impulse for the better at all of the Exchanges yesterday. It had been assumed that the resolution of Sepresentative Wilson would be adopted, but the estimates of the majority in its favor had not exceeded 50, and when the preliminary votes in the House showed that the majority would probably be much larger, all the markets took a boom.

As a result of a second examination, which was held on Ellis Island yesterday, to determine whether the four property men of the Irving theatrical company, who had been detained as contract laborers, were entitled to land, the Board of Inspectors concluded that there was no reason for debarring the men. They were released.

Mr. Harrigan is back in town with all his bloom, and Mrs. Yeamans is with him. The little house on West Thirty-fifth Street, which is now the home of the only kind of drama peculiar to New-York, was-reopened last night with a vim and a will that defied alike the humid weather and the approach of the new hurricane from the tropics.

The Directors of the Commercial Bank, Brooklyn, yesterday discussed President Keoney's plans for resumption. They met in the law office of Beyer Dykman, and were in session from 2:30 until 4:30 P.M. At the conclusion of the conference they refused to speak of their plans, referring inquirers to Mr. Dykman.

There is no occasion for prolonged, debate in the Senate. Senator SHERMAN and Senator WOLCOTT, both Republicans, the one for and the other against repeal, have given notice of intention to talk. They are to be heard respectively on Wednesday and Thursday. Their speeches will be instructive from the who points of view.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The Street and Water Commissioners this afternoon made short work of Acting Mayor Simpson's vetoes of the Consolidated Traction ordinance and the ordinance vacating Railroad Avenue, at Point of Rocks, in order to enable the Junction Railroad to pass under the Pennsylvania Railroad.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28 -- For the first time since the civil war New-Haven Harbor is to be protected by a double fortification, one part of which, at the eastern entrance, is intended effectually to guard it from possible invasion at that point, and the other, at neat Savin Rock, will be mounted so as to defend the west shore and entrance.

Frank Howlok, a Polish barber of 112 Heater Street, this city, shot Mary Lakowski at 59 South Second Street. Williamsburg, yesterday morning, and then blew out his own brains. Howlok's death was instantaneous, but the woman was taken to St. Catharine's Hospital, where she is said to have a good chance lor recovery.
NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 28 -- The New-Orleans Bureau of Freight and Transportation has finally been organized permanently and effectively by the election of W.H. Masters as Commissioner.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- The market opened quiet and continued dull throughout the day, closing at about the highest. The monetary situation is showing a radical improvement. Money is accumulating, and with it a much greater degree of confidence is noticeable. At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was nominally 8 cent.

The Citizen's League of Monmouth County are in dead earnest against the rule of the gamblers over New-Jersey, and having issued an appeal to the Christian people to arouse to action, they now send forth an urgent invitation to respectable citizens to join the league. The Monmouth races have become nothing but gambling concerns, where there is not even any pretense of honor; and they have become so under the express sanction of the law.

The editor of the Times appears to have just discoverd that the French detest the English as bitterly, if not more so, than they do any other neighboring nation, and in a leading article on Saturday that paper astonished the world with a labored attempt to account for the cause of this dislike to us. But the reason is a very simple one.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Ex-Assemblyman Charles J. Kurth, who had the monopoly of the law business on this island and in the town of Gravesend, was a prisoner this morning before his antagonist, Judge Newton. Kurth and John Thompson were arrested Saturday evening on a charge of pulling down a tent. They denied the charge, and Chief McKane paroled them until this morning.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 28 -- The second day of the cruise of the Naval Reserves was ushered in with the usual form. At 9:30 A.M. the work of the day began. The battalion was mustered away in boats to practice the usual drill on shore.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28 -- The largest railroad tunnel in Connecticut is well along toward completion. It is situated about two miles from this city at Fair Haven Heights.

Mrs. Celia Stein and her sixteen-year-old daughter, Rebecca, were badly burned last evening by the explosion of a kerosene lamp in their rooms on the third floor of the tenement house at 213 Broome Street. Mrs. Stein was examining the bed in her room, and her daughter held a kerosene lamp.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- It looks as if the Directors of the Bank of England had taken useless and unnecessary steps in raising the rate to 5 per cent., for at present quotations of exchange shipments of gold to New-York would be unprofitable, since no premium is offered on gold to arrive, while bills are sufficiently scarce to be competed for.

"The 'New' Boston Howard Athenaeum Star Specialty Company," playing under "the Old Management which marked the success of its palmy days," was successful in entertaining a good audience at the Star Theatre last night in an atmosphere which would have been found oppressive in the stokehole of a Chinese junk, if a junk have a stokehole.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- George P. Witherbee of Port Henry and six young companions who were sailing in Witherbee's yacht, the Alpha, were capsized in Lake Champlain at 11 o'clock to-day. Witherbee and five of the boys were drowned. Their names are:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The House was called promptly to order at 12 o'clock and the Chaplain invoked the "special divine guidance on members at this critical moment."

A pot of boiling grease in the Globe Lubricating Company's Works, Commerce and Richards Streets, Brooklyn, overflowed yesterday afternoon and the grease fell into an open fire. A sheet of flame that startled everybody in the place sprang up, and in another moment the establishment was ablaze. There were a number of large grease boilers in the room, which furnished food for the flames.

At the regular business meeting of the Professional Woman's League. Held yesterday in the rooms over A.M. Palmer's office at 17 West Thirtieth Street, a letter of resignation was read from Victory Bateman, the actress who last week was made the co-respondent in a divorce suit brought by Amy Busby against her husband.

Inspector Williams and Capt. Westervelt of the Twenty-eighth Precinct are examining into a charge made by Dr. Lazarus Schoney, an aged physician, who lives at 68 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, against one of the Sergeants on duty at the police station in East One Hundred and Fourth Street.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Aug. 28 -- When the National Croquet Tournament at Norwich closed a few days since, the Butler brothers of this city were tied for the championship of the second division. The tie was played this afternoon in this City by mutual consent. Dale won the first game in 1:17:00, beating Earle 9 points. Earlh won the second game in 48:00 beating Dale 24 points.

The handsome residence of William H. Ebling, Jr., the brewer, at the corner of Cauldwell Avenue and Cedar Place, was partially destroyed by fire yesterday morning. The residence was a frame structure, three stories and basement, and was surmounted by a mansard roof.

NEW ARK, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The members of Phil Kearny Post No. 1 of this city, which is the oldest Grand Army of the Republic post in continuous existence in the country, were amused at the misstatements published yesterday regarding the objections made in some quarters to the invitation of the Confederates to the Kearny-Chantilly celebration.

CONEY ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 28 -- What with the ardent disputes which have followed upon the disastrous firemen's convention at Coney Island, and what with the havoc and distress wrought by the recent cyclone, the nerves of this agreeable suburb have been gravely disturbed.

A great crowd at Eldorado last night heartily applauded the new entertainment, which was given by the Morris Circus, an excellent organization of its kind. The horses and ponies are wonderfully well trained. Prince Leo, wire walker: "Little Freddie, the Boy Wonder"; Mile. Naide, who leaps from the eighty-foot tower, are among the other performers.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 28 -- The new Ambassador from China to the United States passed through Omaha yesterday evening on his way to Washington. He was accompanied by his suite, consisting of twenty-six officials, their families and servants.

The Real Estate Salesroom, where all the auction sales of real estate under foreclosure proceedings are held, was yesterday the scene of as activity that has not been equaled since the middle of July. Sales were advertised from four auotioneers stands, and three of them were in progress at one time. The crowd was not large, but it was interested in the properties, and as a consequence the bidding was spirited.

Presiding Justice Van Brunt of the Supreme Court has set aside the judgment of the Court of Common Pleas, admitting to probate the will of Dr. Antoino Ruppaner, for many years physician at the fifth Avenue Hotel and the Hoffman House.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- All the members of the Administration took the greatest interest in the votes on the Wilson bill, Secretary Carlisle especially so. He received in his office in the Treasury Department the official announcement of the several votes as soon as they were flashed across the wire.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 28 -- A terrible cyclone swept over the coast late this afternoon, leaving death and destruction in its wake.

Samuel Van Raoyen, a clerk in the Greene Avenue Post Office. Brooklyn; Charles Van Rooyen, his brother, who is a letter carrier in the same office, and Ralph R. Jacobs, a news-dealer, all living in Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday on warrants issued by Police Justice Martin at the Tombs Police Court, charged with having swindled a two-cent New-York daily newspaper.

The annual twenty-five mile road race for the team championship of Buffalo and the Rose Trophy was decided Saturday, and resulted in a victory for the Prese Cycling Club, and the breaking of the American road record for that distance. There were three teams of six men each entered from the Press Cycling Club, the Ramblers' Bicycle Club, and the Columbia Bicycle Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The official count of the Treasury cash, begun May 31 last, made necessary by the transfer of the office of Treasurer of the United States from E.H. Nebeker to D.N. Morgan, has been completed. The committee having this work in hand, consisting of E.B. Daskam, A.T. Huntington, and Charles H. Noble, was assisted by sixty expert counters and laborers, and has worked constantly since it first began.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Americans opened about half a point above parities on the vote for the repeal of the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act, and prices advanced until New-York opening stopped the rise.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- The America's Cup came near losing one of its most promising defenders this morning, when the sloop Vigilant, owned by the Morgan-Iselin syndicate, was saved just in the nick of time from being dashed against the rocks off Premium Point, New-Rochelle.

BERLIN, Aug. 29 -- In his speech at Kissingen on Sunday to a number of citizens from Frankfort-on-the-Main, Prince Bismarck reminded his hearers of the days when he lived in Frankfort and became so domesticated that he selected a spot in a churchyard there for his own grave.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Mr. Voorhees, (Dem., Ind.,) Chairman of the Finance Committee, reported back the House bill repealing part of the Sherman act, with an amendment in the nature of a substitute. He asked that the bill be placed on the calendar, and be gave notice that he should ask the Senate to take it up and consider it immediately after the morning business, from this time on, until final action be taken.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- The market has been strong in sympathy with the higher prices from London. Metropolitan advanced to 82 and Philadelphia to 72. There seems to be some disposition to buy the former stock. Reading sold at 8 1 2, and the preference bonds were buoyant. The belief is becoming more prevalent that the interest is likely to be paid shortly on the general mortgage 4s.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 29 -- The labor that the "fakirs" of the island put into rehabilitating the flimsy resorts which last week's storm made sport of has all been for naught. The fierce windstorm which raged early this morning destroyed all their work.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The following crop bulletin was to-day issued from the Weather Bureau for the week ending Aug. 28:
ROME, Aug. 29 -- Naples was declared free from cholera today.

The storm turned things topsy-turvy in Central Park, especially about the lower end. The wind came careering along Fifty-ninth Street and made excursions over the fence, to the manifest disarrangement of the plans of landscape gardeners.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Last night's storm, while not equal in severity to last week's cyclone, did a great deal of damage along the North Jersey coast. The wind blew a gale from the east. but on warning from Washington preparations had been made to meet it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 29 -- This city is again isolated and storm beaten for the second time within a week. About 5 o'clock this morning a southeaster came up the Sound, accompanied by a torrent of rain. For as hour the fall was terrific, flooding the streets and gutters. Meanwhile the wind was blowing a tempest before which trees, roofs, and everything movable went down.

A CLINCH -- This facile and agreeable paragraph was inspired by the management of the Empire Theatre: "Love isn't made up altogether of kisses and embraces and sweet nothings, as the author of 'Liberty Hall,' now playing at the Empire Theatre shows. His lovers are natural, every-day people, and they make love just the same as young men and young women in real life do -- quietly, slowly, and without method.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The great hurricane or 1893 has been of a character so terrible that it may pass into history as a date of reckoning, just as some of the old people in Ireland still reckon from "the great wind of 1839."

MADRID, Aug. 29 -- The riots started at a concert in San Sebastian. Province of Guipuzcos, on Sunday evening, because the orchestra refused to play the Basque Hymn, were repeated yesterday afternoon and last night.

FREEPORT, L.I. Aug. 29 -- A shipwreck and the rescue of the Captain and crew by a party of life savers composed principally of women, the drowing of one of the crew, and several other thrilling incidents attended the loss of the bark Martha P. Tucker at Point Lookout today.

C.S. Hamlin, Acting Secretary of the Treasury Department at Washington, has instructed Postmaster Dayton to notify John I. Davenport, Supervisor or Elections, to vacate the Federal building, as it is desired to use the rooms now occupied by him for Post Office purposes. The following letter was sent to Mr. Davenport yesterday:
Yachts suffered much damage by the storm. Many of them dragged their anchors and fouled other boats or docks near them. Some sank, others were driven ashore, and some went to pieces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- During the general prostration of telegraphic wires to-day, chronic short sellers seized the opportunity to raid the wheat market, Pardridge leading. Wheat recovered one-half of the loss occasioned by the early bear attack, but was still 1 8 @ 1 4 c lower for September and 1 2c lower for December than on the day before, as the market closed. Corn was very firm and gained about 3 8 c.

NEW-YORK. TUESDAY, Aug. 29 -- P.M. Not a single stock dealt in to-day showed net decline of three-quarters of a point, while on the other hand forty or more scored advances ranging from 3 4 to 5 1 4 points. It must not be understood from this, however, that the market responded promptly to the improvement in the situation resulting from the overwhelming majority in the House for sound money which was recorded yesrerday.
The West Indian cyclone, which came here leisurely on Monday night, left in a great hurry yesterday.

The Driving Club of New-York have seldom given a trotting meeting at Fleetwood, when had weather has not marred some part of the programme. Their ill luck in this direction has become proverbial, and yesterday, the opening date of the Grand Circuit trotting meeting at the old track across the Harlem, proved no exception to the general rule.

Two-thirds of the people of the Union, speaking through their Representatives in Congress, demand the immediate, unconditional repeal of the silver-purchase provision of the Sherman act. As their will was recorded in the vote taken on Monday in the House of Representatives, 41,000,000 of the population of the United States desire the repeal of the act, against 19,000,000 who oppose repeal.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 29 -- Fateful Charleston was subjected to the full fury of the tornado Sunday night, but not until to-day was it possible for the outside world to gain tidings of the damage wrought by the wind and water.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Anp. 29 -- Barnard L. Lynch, sixty-three, of this city, stopping with his family in a cottage at Pleasure Beach, on the Sound, about five miles from here, and Benjamin Meader Carroll, twenty-one, son of Benjamin F. Carroll, also of this city, were drowned at the beach at noon to-day.

Play in the chess match between A.B. Hodges and Adolph Albin was resumed at the Manhattan Chess Club on Monday evening, the former opening with P -- Q4. Albin defended the game with a Fianchetio dl Re. The New-York crack put in some excellent work and fairly beat his rival in the middle game. At the proper time Hodges gave up a piece for three pawns, and after forty-two moves the game was adjourned.
The cyclone of Monday night and yesterday morning caught many ships unawares, and those of them able to make port told harrowing tales of battle with wind and wave.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The cyclonic storm that set in here at nightfall on Monday to prostrate the telegraph wires and interrupt the service to the newspapers abbreviated some of the accounts that were sent from this city, but it did not come along soon enough to materially spoil the tabular statement to THE NEW-YORK TIMES showing the votes by States and parties.

Although inducements for outside bidders were not lacking in the sales scheduled to take place yesterday at the Real Estate Salesroom, all the properties that were sold were suffered to go to the plaintiffs in the several foreclosure proceedings. One sole was adjonrned -- that of 49 West Seventy-fifth Street, by William Kennelly, to Sept. 5.

CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 29 -- A terrific storm passed over the Cumberland Valley last night, doing considerable damage to property and growing crops. Telegraph wires were blown down and communication was cut off for several hours.

Marie Prescott McLean, the actress, wife of Robert D. McLean, died at 10 o'clock Monday night from the effects of an operation performed in the private hospital of Drs. R.H. and W.G. Wylie, at 215 West Forty-third Street.
At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. Alderman Brown introduced the following resolutions, which were adopted unanimously:

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 29 -- The storm injured many buildings in Savannah, and did great damage to the trees. Only four buildings sustained serious damage. Fifteen people are known to have been drowned, and more are missing. It is impossible to estimate the amount of property destroyed. The dead are as follows:

HAVERHILL, Mass., Aug. 29 -- The storm reached here this morning and did serious damage in all sections. The gale was accompanied by a heavy fall of rain, and was a regular southeaster. The wind through this county and Southern New-Hampshire attained through the latter hours of the day a velocity of fifty miles an hour.

Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD of Brooklyn contributes to the Forum for September a very strong and timely article on "The Brooklyn Idea in City Government." It is none the less strong for being rigidly impartial and in tone even surprisingly moderate. Mr. SHEPARD starts from the unquestioned fact that within the past ten years public opinion of the City Government of Brooklyn has undergone a very great chance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The friends of the purchasing provision of the Sherman law have every reason to be satisfied with the present outlook. This morning the Senate Committee on finance substituted the Voorhees bill, which calls for repeal and declares for bimetallism and an international agreement, for the Wilson bill, which came from the House.

CONEY ISLAND, Aug. 29 -- Only about half the seats in the Coney Island Athletic Club were occupied tonight when "Billy" Madden's boxing tournament began. It was evident that popular prices, stipulated number of round contests, and second-rate fighters do not draw big crowds. The opening bout was between "Billy" Hill, a colored lad known as the "Pickaninny," and Henry Fennick, the "Arkansas Kid."

The members of the Newsdealers and Stationers' Protective and Benevolent Association congratulated themselves last evening on the delightful weather they had for their third annual Summer night's festival at Lion Park. Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Eighth Street. The storm of Monday night had cleared the air, and the rain had laid the dust.
When the great storm began its ravages along the Southern Atlantic seaboard it found few natural obstacles in its way. All along the coast it swept over a low country.

The Giants played a fairly good fielding game yesterday, but luck was against them. Up to the fifth inning they held the Browns in check, but after that, by well-placed hits and taking advantage of the home team's slowness, the visitors stole bases in a lively manner and piled up the runs. Both Breltenstein and Baldwin were hit rather freely. Stafford made a home run.

NEWPORT, R.I, Aug. 29 -- The final round in the all-comers' tennis tournament has been postponed until to-morrow. Early this morning the clouds threatened rain, and Referee Dwight determined to defer the match a day. It has been clear all day, though the wind is blowing too strongly for such an important match to take place. Hovey and Wrenn are the rival players, and Hovey seems to lead in popular favor.
Late China newspapers announce that Dr. Daniel Jerome MacGowan, formerly a resident of Fall River, Mass., died at his home on Boone Road, Shanghai, China, July 19. He was seventy-nine years old.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Prohibitionists from all over the State met here this morning in convention for the nomination of a State ticket. Four Hundred delegates were present.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Aug. 29 -- It was-expected that General Superintendent Blood would furnish information to-day as to the result of the investigation held by the Long Island Railroad Company to fix the responsibility for the terrible disaster at Berlin Saturday night.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 29 -- While the storm of last night was at its height fire was discovered in the Long Island Railroad Station at Seaside Avenue. The flames came through the roof of the east end of the building. In less than five minutes the entire building (a two-story frame) was ablaze.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Two more strange deaths have occurred in this city. The physicians and health authorities have given burial permits stating the cause of death to be cholera morbus. Both cases occurred at 3 State Street. The first was that of William Morton, who died Tuesday and was buried Friday. He was employed in Washington Market and took home large quantities of fruit, principally muskmelons.

The Battery presented a remarkable spectacle all forenoon yesterday. The tide was the highest seen in years, and the strong sou wester swept huge waves and clouds of spray fully 200 feet over the Battery wall.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 29 -- News was received from Port Royal, S.C., to-day that 100 lives were lost in the cyclone that burst upon that town at the rate of 100 miles an hour Monday, followed by a tidal wave that almost swept the town away.

Leon Cottentin, the well-known caterer, restaurant keeper, and hotel manager, yesterday confessed judgment for $1,808 in favor of L. Straus Sons for merchandise, and execution was issued to the Sheriff.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Controller Eckels has prepared the following statement of banks which temporarily suspended during the late stringency and have since resumed business:

This is to be "Gilmore Memorial Day" at Manhattan Beach. The programmes will be of creat interest. Gilmore's favorite pieces will be given by Sousa's Band, and two of his most frequently-employed singers -- Mme. Luckstone Klein and Emeile Schneelock -- will be heard at the afternoon and evening concerts. A welcome addition to these artists will be Marshall P. Wilder.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 -- Two deaths from electricity occurred this morning as a result of the storm. Anthony Vandersslice, for forty years a Delaware River pilot, pushed aside an overhanging wire, which was crossed with a live electric light wire, in Camden. N.J., and was instantly killed. An unknown Italian laborer did the same thing at Eighteenth and Harlan Streets, in this city, and also dropped dead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The feature of the House proceedings to-day was the debut of Mr. Crisp as a speaker on the floor. He was led to leave his chair by some caustic criticisms made by Mr. Reed upon the proposed code of rules, and his appearance in the arena of debate was warmly applauded. The discussion between the two leaders was very animated, but led to no conclusion.

The ravages of the hurricane in Savannah, of which THE TIMES yesterday contained by far the most coherent and complete account that was given, seem to have constituted the greatest disaster in the annals of that city, and later reports tell of even a greater loss of life and property at other points on the coast.
Because of a broken and on a Brooklyn Bridge car yesterday morning thousands of persons were obliged to walk over from Brooklyn to New York.

Our system, of electrical communication, will be very defective and uncertain so long as telegraph wires connecting the chief cities of the country are liable to be blown down by any violent storm that happens to come along. There are times when the interruption of communication from this cause may be a very serious matter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Some apprehension is felt among naval officers here that the United States corvette Kearsarge, having in tow the single-turreted monitor Nantucket, may have been caught in yesterday's blow. The Navy Department shares this anxiety, but has no knowledge of the two vessels except that they were supposed this morning to be off Cape Hatteras somewhere.
HARIFORD, Aug. 29 -- The Connecticut Grand Army representatives who are to attend the National Encampment at Indianapolis will rendezvous in Jersey City on Saturday of this week.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Although this year is regarded as an off year politically, the Republican Party, moribund as it is in this State, proposes to make one desperate effort for victory to stimulate ardor and arouse greater enthusiasm for next year, when a Governor is to be elected.
Money on call loaned at from 2 to 4 cent. The last loan was made at 2 cent.

The Commercial Bank of Brooklyn will be put in the hands of a receiver. This decision was arrived at yesterday by Bank Superintendent Preston, who served notice upon Barnett and Dykman, counsel for the Directors, that no would delay no longer in the matter. Mr. Preston will make his application for a receiver this morning at 9 o'clock, through the Attorney General, before Judge Barnard at Poughkeepsie.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Mrs. Annie Morton of 153 Rose Street was found dead in her kitchen this morning with an ugly wound in her abdomen. The circumstances indicate that she was murdered. George Morton, her husband, has been placed under arrest. He is an employe in one of the potteries. He says he returned from his work yesterday and found his wife under the influence of liquor.

The following table shows the vote on the repeal of the Sherman law by States, grouped in sections, and the number or people in those States either for or against the measure. Only about 2 per cent. of Northeastern States opposed the repeal of the Sherman law, and in Southern States, the stronghold of the free-coinage men, almost half voted in favor of the Wilson bill:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- In this city the force of the wind last night laid prostrate telegraph and telephone wires, trees, awnings, and signs, but so far no serious injury to life or property is reported. Word from Alexandria and Georgetown showed that they had suffered great damage to electric-light and telephone wires.

The Kings County Board of Supervisors yesterday authorized the County Treasurer to borrow $300,000, and then raised the salaries of its employes. The loan is to defray current expenses until Jan. 1, when the taxes necessary to pay the bills will have been collected. Certificates of indebtedness will be issued.

It is some years since New-York has had an opportunity to witness such an exhibition of first-class trotting as may now be seen on the old course at Fleetwood. In fact, it is a good many years since New-York ceased to be one of the trotting centres of the country. There are a good many reasons for this.

A correspondent who heartily indorses THE TIMES'S suggestion that it is the duty of the Western Union Telegraph Company to put its lines between New-York and Washington and New-York and Chicago beyond the danger of breakage and interruption of service from storms makes the point that any plan for the burial of the wires would be open to serious objections besides those based on expense.

-- The Rev. Oliver Hopson, who has been for eighteen years the last survivor of the first class graduated from Trinity Coliege, Hartford, Conn., died on Saturday last at his borne in Tivoli-on-the-Hudson in the eighty-ninth year of his age. When he was graduated, in 1827, the institution was known as Washington College.
No public sale of real estate was had yesterday and only one is announced for to-day. As public sales at this season mean foreclosure sales this condition is regarded as a good one.

The stock market was decidedly stronger yesterday, the good effects of the vote in the House on the repeal of the Sherman silver-purchase law being by no means exhausted. Until the last hour the strength continued, when reports of riots in Chicago and a disposition to take profits on the rise helped to bring about a reaction.

The resignation of one of the members of the Professional Woman's League has resalted in calling general and emphatic attention to that body and its aims. It seems to be agreed on all hands that this resignation, was not a spontaneous expression of fatigue with the society in question, but was extorted under some vague species of menace and duress.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- Miss Bridget Conolly, who died Monday, was buried in Hillside Cemetery despite the tearful appeals and indignant protests of her only sister, Mrs. Michael Buckley of Nyack, and an order of the court directing the undertaker to deliver the body of the girl to her sister.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The voices of two public men of national reputation were heard in the Senate to-day in the discussion of the financial question. The first of these was John Sherman, the author of the bill whose unconditional repeal should be a question of but a few weeks at the most, and the second was Mr. Teller, one of the champions of free silver in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service to-day received a telegram from James Y. Porter, State Health Officer at Port Tampa, Fla., stating that there was one case of yellow fever there in the person of a clerk employed on the docks.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30 -- The great all-comers' tournament is over and R.D. Wrenn is the national champion for 1893. This morning he defeated F. H. Hovey three sets to one, thereby winning the new trophy cup. This becomes his permanent property after he has won it three times, though not necessarily in succession. The former champion, O. S. Campbell, retired on his laurels this year, letting his title go to Wrenn by default.

Two notable changes have taken place in the Equitable Life Assurance Society; one a promotion, the other a new appointment. Both are indicative of a determination to maintain the vigorous policy of management which has characterized the Equitable for many years.

-- The Metropolis Wheelmen had a picnic run to Bayside, L.I., last Sunday, which was a very pleasant affair. The wheel men and women at the club rude the entire distance, and were met there by a large number of their friends, who had gone down by train. All had a pleasant day.
"If the average Summer tourist only realized the delights of the Autumn season in the mountains," said an old traveler recently, "he would never take his annual vacation before Sept. 1."

"Now, it's just like this,"said Oliver Sumner Teall yesterday, with a large smile beaming behind an equally large cigar. "I belong to the Union League Club. A number of very rich men are members of that club, and when one of 'em wants a cab, for instance; he sends out to the stable which has a contract with the club and gets his cab for $1 an hour.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Wheat developed a good deal of weakness to-day, cables came easier, and the offerings were liberal, with but little demand. The probability of dolsy in the Senate in passing the repeal bill may have had something to do with the weakness, but why it should have that effect in the wheat market and not in stocks is not easily explained.

Nathan Hursh, sixty-nine years old, a wellknown builder and house owner of 158 West Sixty-fifth Street, was charged in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday with assaulting William Griffith, forty years old, a negro porter at the down-town station of the Third Avenue elevated road at Sixty-seventh Street. He was held in $100 bail, and paroled in the custody of his counsel.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 3O -- Charles O'Brien, who claims to be a nephew of William R. Grace, ex-Mayer of New-York, and Miss Annie M. Raik were married to-day by Justice Lookwood.

OYSTER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The Naval Reserve yesterday paid well for the semi-idle hours of Tuesday by redoubled labor, and the perspiring faces of the duck-clad men plainly revealed the fact that Commander Miller is determined to come as near making veterans of the four divisions of the First Battalion as possible during the week's cruise.

The death of one man and the severe wounding of another followed the breaking of a derrick yesterday afternoon at the new hotel building which is in the course of erection at 121 to 133 West Forty-fourth Street.

If the rating of rumor mongers had not bean destroyed by favorable conditions now ruling in the money market and by the brightening outlook for general business, the mischief makers who have tried in the last day or two to make financial and political havoc oat of grossly tortured tales of President Cleveland's ill health would be handled in a way calculated to teach some instructive lessons.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, Aug. 30 -- P.M. The restoring of the telegraph service brought into to-day's stock market many buying orders from out of town, while London Was even a heavier purchaser than yesterday. Added to these conditions were the operations of a local combination on rather a liberal scale, and the result was a more active and a wider market than has prevailed for some time.

The professional Woman's League listened yesterday to an interesting paper by the only physician among its members. Dr. Cordelia Williams of the New-York Medical College and Hospital for Women. Dr. Williams spoke on the uses and abuses of popular drugs, the evils of the cigarette habit, and much to the distress of many of her listeners strongly condemned the use of tea and coffee.

August H. Myers and Henry Sheperd, each about twenty-one years old, were arrested early yesterday morning for quarreling in Broadway. At the Thirtieth Street Police Station Sheperd, who has been employed as a "sheet writer" at race tracks, said that Myers assaulted him with a cane without provocation. His head was cut slightly.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 -- Charles E. Balmer, Secretary of the Crescent Building and Loan Association, has been arrested. He is charged by the President of the association with embezzling $1,967.

The Western Union people are slowly picking up the towns and cities which were out off from communication with New-York by Monday's great cyclone. Many hundreds of wires were broken and it will be some days before they are all repaired. Meanwhile the company is attaching quadruplex instruments to its available wires and is working them to their full capacity.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Chicago was spared a riot to-day by the prompt action or the police. This morning crowds of unemployed and idle spectators crowded at the lake front and around the Columbus monument. Indications of rioting appeared, and in addition to the number of officers in plain clothes circulating among the throng, Chief of Police Brennan summoned first 500 uniformed men, and later 1,000.

The foreign exchange market was dull and steady. Posted rates for sterling were $4.82 1/3 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 1/2 for demand. Actual business was done at $4.82@$4.82 1/2 for sixty-day bills, $4.86@$4.86 1/4 for demand, $4.87@$4.87 1/4 for cable, and $4.81 for commercial.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 30 -- Reports of Sunday's storm still continue to pour in, with news of additional loss of life and property, not alone in this section, but along the entire coast as far down as Titusville, Fla., extending north as far as Wilmington. N.C., and in the interior for at least 150 miles.

The hopes of the Democrats of Massachusetts have been greatly raised by the assurance that Mr. JOHN E. RUSSELL will not refuse to be their candidate for Governor and by the report that Mr. JOSIAH QUINCY will again take the direction of their canvass as Chairman of their State Committee.

Word was received down town yesterday that the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company had won its case in the Texas courts against the International and Great Northern Company with reference to the possession of the Galveston, Houston and Henderson Railway Company.

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Aug. 30 -- The Gagui Indians are still on the war path, and hardly a day passes that, they do not commit some crime or depredation upon the waits settlers living adjacent to their territory.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 30 -- A double tragedy is reported from the little town of Sonora, is Sutton County. Pedro Martinez, a fine-looking young Mexican, crossed the Rio Grande about nine months ago in the hope of bettering his condition in the United States. He made his way to the little town of Sonora, where he had relatives, and soon secured a position as laborer and made many warm friends.

The Palisade Boat Club of Yonkers has the honor of opening the Fall tennis season of the local clubs. The club grounds of a admirably situated for those who wish to combine love of tennis with love of nature, as they command a fine view of the Hudson.

The Rev. Edward J. Connell, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima at Rackaway, has brought suit for $10,000 against the Long Island Railroad Company for injuries, physical and mental, alleged to have been inflicted Tuesday, Aug. 18, 1891, by William Dayton, an employe of the railroad.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 30 -- The Republican Convention which met in this city to-day was a harmonious gathering.
