The hour set for the meeting was 10 o'clock but the sight of a street parade made by a visiting circus delayed the delegates for forty-five minutes. After the gayly-decked vans and band wagons had disappeared beyond Capitol Hill, Chairman J. Howard Reeder of the State Committee called the convention to order. There were 253 delegates present.

POUGHKEEPSlE, N.Y., Aug. 3O -- In the quiet seclusion of this beautiful rural neighborhood, freed from whatever embarrassments the presence or the depositors might have entailed, the Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, through Deputy Attorney General John W. Hogan, to-day placed their defunct institution in the hands of a receiver.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Aug. 30 -- There was startling testimony to-night before Coroner Brandon at the inquest to determine the blame for the collision on the Long Island Railroad Saturday night at Berlin by which sixteen persons lost their lives and many others were injured.

The Republican Party, through its State Committee, will meet at the Fifth Avenue Hotel at noon to-day to choose time and place in which to hold the convention which will nominate candidates for State offices to be filled this Fall.
The following resolution was introduced by Commissioner MacLean at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board:
NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 30 -- There were two exciting incidents last evening in Long Island Sound off Northport.

Postmaster Doyton had no word yesterday from John I. Davenport, Chief supervisor of Federal Elections, upon whom he had served notice to vacate the rooms he occupies in the Post Office Building on Sept. 1.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 -- Many of the most eminent lawyers of the United States sat in the pews of the Plymouth Church this morning when the sixteenth annual meeting of the American Bar Association was called to order. About 100 members were present at the opening session, which did not begin until nearly noon. On the platform with President Tucker were Edward Otis Hinkley of Baltimore.

There is now in progress at the old Fleetwood race track a race meeting that is actually for the improvement of the breed of horses. The horses that are being improved through the efforts of the gentlemen comprising the Driving Club of New-York are not the racing machines that are bred for gambling purposes only, the thoroughbreds, but the light-harness horses, which are as truly typical of America as is the rattlesnake or the Yankee.
WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 30 -- Mr. and Mrs. William M. Evarts of New-York to-day celebrated their golden wedding at Runnymede, their country home here, among the Green Mountains.

Mrs. Elizabeth Tighe of Ralph and St. Mark's Avenues. Brooklyn, yesterday complained to Police Commissioner Hayden that Policeman William McCahill of the Twelfth Precinct had assaulted her without provocation. She also made a similar charge against the policeman before Justice Connelly in the Gates Avenue Police Court, and McCahill will be arraigned soon before both tribunals.

PERSONAL NOTES. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Murray Forbes of 105 Madison Avenue have been spending the Summer at Morristown, N.J. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lenox Banks are a still at Kedron cottage, Garrison's, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Sands, Miss A.A. Sands, and Miss Elizabeth B. Sands are among the Lenox residents. Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Roe have been enjoying the Summer about Highland Falls.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 30 -- From disconnected news at hand it is apparent that the great storm will go down, into history as the most destructive of the century, as far as the Georgia and South Carolina coasts are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Having better weather to-day than has prevailed at the capital for a week, the House entered into the discussion of the rules with some spirit, but not with the development of any such controversy as that of yesterday between the ex-Speaker and the Speaker.

When the American bark Tillid arrived in port yesterday there was added another thrilling chapter to the storm's doings at sea. The bark had on board Capt. McDonnell and six men, who comprised the crew of the little coasting schooner Annie S. Conants.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 3O -- By a concurrent vote to-day of the clerical and lay delegates to the Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Vermont Diocese, convened here, the Rev. Arthur Cranshay Alliston Hall, D.D., of Oxford, England, was elected to succeed the late Right Rev. William Henry Augustus Bissell as Bishop of the diocese.

Hubert Von Wahl, a clerk, forty-two years old, of 453 East Fifty-seventh Street, this city, attempted suicide yesterday afternoon in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, by shooting himself twice in the forehead with a revolver.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 30 -- The big fourmaster Charles N. Patterson, Capt. Tunnell of Philadelphia, had a rough experience out in the Sound last night. She was bound from Philadelphia to this port with, coal and tried, to make harbor, but was unsuccessful. Anchor was dropped about two miles outside of the breakwater, and the boat was exposed to the fury of the southerly storm.

Another fine ocean-going steamer baa been added to the United States coastwise fleet. The new vessel is called El Cid. With the exception of El Rio, a sister ship, El Cid is the largest coastwise American steamer afloat. El Cid and El Rio have been built by the Newport News Books Establishment for the Southern Pacific Transportation Company.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- A dispatch from Para, Brazil, says that the British steamship Justin, Capt. Bisson, which sailed from New-York on Aug. 13, arrived at Barbados yesterday. She had passed through a series of terrific storms. Her decks were swept day after day, her small boats, wheelhouse, and engine room skylight were smashed or carried overboard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The new Chinese Minister, Mr. Yang In, accompanied by his wife and three children, the members of his official suite, and servants, numbering fifty-seven in all, arrived in Washington last night. There was a large gathering of curious people at the station to witness the arrival of the distinguished diplomat.
E. Townaend Goldberg, a lawyer of 280 Broadway, was reprimanded by Judge Giegerich of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

The German Looking Glass Company. Limited, a foreign corporation, was assessed on $100,000 of personal property. The company's officers made oath that the personal property amounted to $484,345.67, against which were debts amounting to $464,212.97, leaving but $20,132.70, as they claimed, to be assessed. The Tax Commissioners refused to reduce the assessment on the ground that most of the indebtedness was money due on $575,000 worth of imported goods.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Preparations for the annual fair of the State Agricultural Society at Waverly Park are being pushed forward. Everything points to success. The entries in the live stock departments have closed. In the fine arts and perishable goods departments they may be made at any time previous to the opening of the fair.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 30 -- The indictment in a Tacoma (Washington) court against the President and about a score of other officials of the Canadian Pacific Railroad has culminated n the surrender of W.C. Van Home and D. McNicholl, General Passenger Agent, to a Vermont Federal court to stand trial for alleged violation of the Inter-State Commerce act.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The Prohibitionists had a lively time at their State Convention to-day. Chairman Joseph A. Bogardus called the convention to order at 9 o'clock. After routine business had been disposed of and some prohibition oratory listened to, the delegates got to work on the platform.

Home runs by Burke, Connor, Tiernan, and Stafford, eleven stolen bases, and a dozen bases on balls by generous Mr. "Kid" Gleason, explain the victory achieved by the Giants yesterday. As regards field work, the New Yorks were outclassed, but when it came to getting bases on balls, making long hits, and stealing bases, the poor Browns were like a lot of selling platers against stake horses.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The last stage of the Home Rule bill debate in the House of Commons began to-day. As usual on Wednesday, the House met at noon. The exceptionally large attendance showed that the majority of the members who recently went to the country for their holidays had returned to hear the final speeches of the party leaders and to take part in the final division on next Friday night.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 30 -- The Nantucket, Lieut. Hosley commanding, arrived at the navy yard last night about 7 o'clock, and the United States ship Kearsarge arrived at the naval anchorage from off Hatteras, where they had a rough experience in the last storm on the coast.

BOSTON, Aug. 30 -- About fifty members of the Billings family, which traces its ancestry back to the fourteenth century, assembled to-day for a family reunion at the American House. A dinner 17 as held at 1 o'clock, after which there was a business meeting and informal speaking. Members of the family were present from all the New England States, and one of the family came specially from Baltimore.

To-day's card is a strong one, the principal feature being the effort which the trotting queen, Nancy Hanks, will make to lower the record or 2:04. The speedy little mare is in perfect health, and as Fleetwood track is a shade faster than Mystic Park, Boston, where she trotted three weeks ago in 2:08, Nancy in bound to trot a great mile even if she does not break the record.

Edward D. O'Brien was appointed by Judge Williams, in Watertown. N.Y., yesterday as receiver for the Moffet, Hodgkins Clarke Company, contractors. The company formerly did business at Watertown, but it now has offices at 16 William Street, this city, and in Chicago. A receiver has also been applied for in New-Jersey.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 30 -- The City of Savannah is ashore on Hunting Island, thirty miles off Beaufort. She is a total wreck, and is rapidly going to pieces.

, S.C., Aug. 30 -- For three days Charleston has been a city isolated. Every telegraphic instrument in the city caused its clamor soon after 3 o'clock Sunday afternoon, and not until this evening has it been possible to reach outside points by wire.

While the effects of the financial stringency and the partial suspension of industries throughout the country have caused severe losses to the railroad corporations, there is much that is consoling and encouraging in a careful scrutiny of the latest reports of railway earnings and expenses.

ROUND LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The camp meeting has proved to be one of the largest and most fervent ever held at this place. Mr. Keen, the evangelist, has extraordinary command over the large audiences that assemble in the auditorium and in Alumni Hall almost every hour of the day from daylight service at six in the morning to the evening session.

Among the results of a fire early yesterday morning at 699 Second Avenue was the arrest of two men charged with incendiariem and a hand-to-hand fight between Fireman Goes of the Fortieth Street engine house and Policeman John J. Conley of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station. The men who were arrested were Andrew and Abraham Smith, the owners of the oyster saloon on the ground floor of the building.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- The body of Rafaello Lasso, the Italian who was murdered at Bryn Mawr last night by Angelo Carlatali, was brought to this city this morning and is now at Riley's morgue, where Coroner Mitchell will hold an inquest to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Commissioner of Patents rendered a decision to-day in the matter of the appeal to him of the State of South Carolina from the refusal of tie examiner to register a trade mark applied for in the name of the State, consisting of the word "Palmetto," to be printed on its liquor labels, together with the arms of the State and the name or the liquor.

WEST END, LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 30 -- All kinds of rumors have been current throughout the day and until late this evening as to the reasons for the mysterious disappearance of Eden Howland. He is seventy-three years old, and was one of the most respected citizens of the Branch, having been associated with his brother Henry as a hotel proprietor here for upward of half a century.

The steward, purser, and other officers of the Cunard steamer Campania, which arrived here Saturday afternoon, were considerably surprised when Mrs. C.R. Fiske, a wealthy Boston widow and a first-class passenger on the steamer, made complaint that she had been robbed.
AUGUSTA, Ga, Aug. 31 -- Further and more distressing news of the disastrons work of the hurricane at Port Royal was received to-night.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Two men, giving their names as Louis Schloss of 653 Broadway and Charles Lawrence of 109 East Thirty-first Street, New-York, hired from Capt. Wilkins, the Cooper's Point yacht owner, his sixteen-foot catboat Rufus G. Wilkins Aug. 22 for a four days' cruise down the Delaware.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- The syndicate cup defender Pilgrim is again in the navy yard dry dock at Charlestown. The yacht was successfully docked at high tide at about 1 o'clock this morning. The work of pumpig out the dock was continued early this morning, and as the water was lowered the crew of the yacht were kept busy with brooms and scrubbing brushes cleaning the bottom or the slime and grass that had collected.

CHICAGO, Aug. 81 -- Wheat bulged 2c a bushel in just one hour to-day. The market closed firm at the top prices. Ordinarily on the eve of delivery day, with 16,000,000 bushels of wheat in store, some belated longs might be expected to to pressing September wheat for sale to avoid having it delivered to them on the following morning. The reverse happened to be the case.

T. A. S. Kaliske, shoe manufacturers at 9 to 13 Debrosses Street, failed yesterday, and the Sheriff took charge of their factory on three confessed judgments for $12,663, of which $7,170 is to the estate of Alexander S. Kaliske, $4,576 to William Vogei, both for borrowed money, and $917 to Benno Lewinson for professional services. The house is one of the oldest in the trade, having been established in 1842.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Aug. 31 -- College Point was invaded by Tammany hosts to-day, in connection with the second annual outing of the John A. Lee Society, which hails from the Nineteenth Assembly Distriot, New-York. There were 500 of the braves in attendance, and they were arrayed in red shirts, fatigu caps, and black trousers.

BROOKLYN PERSONALS -- Brooklyn fashionable society is well represented at all the leading colonies by the sea and in the mountains. Miss Whitcomb of Columbia Heights is at Saratoga. Miss Mae Prentice, daughter of Mrs. John Prentice, and a near city neighbor of Miss Whitcomb, is at that favorite centre, Onteora Park, near Tannersville, N.Y.

The Daily Stockholder to-morrow win say: "While generally the disbursements for September call forth very little comment, yet those of this month in the present year are very likely to be read with much attention because of the generally unsettled state of the financial situation. Interest becomes due and is payable on bonds of railroad and similar corporations having a par value of $455,967,217, the amount of such interest being $11,994,785.

A syndicate, with the banking house of Vermilye Co. at its head, has been formed to underwrite the extension of the Union Pacific sinking fund 8 per cent. bonds which mature to-day. The offer of the Union Pacific Company to extend bonds is limited to $3,800,000, of which amount more than $2,000,000 have already assented to the extension.

An authoritative statement was issued from the headquarters of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad yesterday that there was no strike on that road as yet. The employes, it was explained, were in negotiation with officers of the company regarding a proposed reduction of wages. It will be several days before anything definite will be decided upon.

The cap defenders are now receiving the final touches for the trial races which begin next Thursday. The Vigilant, the Morgan-Iselin boat, is at City Island, being thoroughly overhauled and cleaned under the eye of Capt. Hansen. The speed which the Vigilant exhibited during the cruise of the NewYork Yacht Club won her many friends, and most yachtsmen think that she will be selected to defend the cup.

BAYPORT, L.I., Aug. 31 -- Arthur J. Ridley of the New-York dry goods firm of Edlward Ridley Sons is on a visit here at the Summer residence of Theodore Allen. What is thought to have been an attempt to assassinate Mr. Ridley was made by three unknown men at 2 o'clock this morning.

UNION SQARE THEATRE -- Messrs. Keith Albee announce a second postponement of the Union Square opening -- this time to Sept. 18. The delay is largely occasioned by the work of reconstructing the exterior, a new iron and glass front having been built. The Galey Opera Company, which is to sing "Ship Ahoy!" as a part of the continuous performance, have arrived from Atlantic City, and are rehearsing daily.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- A strange scene was enacted in court to-day when Judges Goggin, Dunne, and Brentano attempted to decide whether the injunction restraining the World's Fair Directors from closing the exposition gates on Sunday should stand. It was understood that the court was divided as to the coarse to be pursued. Judges Dunne and Brentano holding that the injunction should be dissolved, while Judge Goggin held the contrary.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 31 -- The Fourth Division of the Naval Reserve, which returned from Bay Shore by rail Wednesday night, makes a good Report of the march. The division beat the National Guard record for similar marches. The distance is twenty-one miles, and the reserves marched it, including the encampment for dinner, in ten hours, the last five miles being made in an hour and a quarter.

Ex-Commodore James S. Smith, Chairman of the America's Cup Committee, yesterday sent out a circular containing the rules for the trial races for the cup defenders, the first of which is to be sailed next Thursday. The circular is as follows:

The Third Avenue Railroad Company has experienced fresh trouble. Last evening Chief Engineer E.H. Lightball, Assistant Chief Engineer J.B. Haviland, and Assistant Engineers F.J. Boas, James Craig, D.C. Harvey, and W. W. Kendall marched one of the company's office in a body. The Chief Engineer and his five assistants sent in their resignations on Monday, to take effect yesterday.

All the circumstances surrounding the appointment of WILLIAM N. DYKMAN, Esq., as receiver of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn are, to say the least, unfortunate and not calculated to create confidence in the settlement of its affairs, or to strengthen the belief of depositors in the honorable purpose and conduct of its past management.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 31 -- A shipwrecked crew arrived in port this morning on the passenger steamer D. H. Miller of Baltimore.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 31 -- By the settlement made yesterday -- and it is believed to be a final one -- of the dispute between Lawrence Hanley, the actor, and Mr. Stainach of this town, an end has been put to a brief, temporary eclipse of the innocent gayety of the local Keeley cure.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- The market to-day has been dull and inclined to be offish. Traction stocks were steady, Philadelphia at 72 and Metropolitan at 82, with larger transactions than usual. The Lehigh Valley Coal Company has agreed to continue the existing arrangements with the coal operators for the present. Lehigh Valley stock has been weak in this market, and closed offered at the lowest price of the day.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir Richard Temple, Conservative for the Kingston Division of Surrey, asked the Government whether or not France was keeping her pledge to respect the independence of Slam.

Mr. Frederich H. Fowler, clerk of the Massachuaetts State Board of Agriculture, has discovered, in indexing, its reports, one made by Dr. Oliver wendell Holmes in 1849, as Chairman of the committee on a ploughing match at the Berkshire Society's annual fair. It begins: "The plough is a very ancient instrument. It is written in the English language, p-l-o-u-g-h, and by the association of free and independent spellers, p-l-o-w.

As THE NEW-YORK TIMES announced yesterday would be done, the Republican State Committee, acting under orders from Thomas C. Platt, yesterday decided to hold the Republican State Convention at Syracuse on Friday, Oct. 6, the day following that fixed by the Democrats, who are to meet at Saratoga.

Reports which reached Wall Street from the savings banks yesterday all went to show that the worry among depositors had very nearly worn itself out in the month since the banks decided to check witharawals by patting into effect their thirty-day notices. Many of the notices expired yesterday, but few of the depositors asked for their money.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug 31 -- The body of Eden Howland, who was to have, been married Sunday to Miss Georginia Smith, was discovered to-day by Michael Deveraux in a marl pit at Poplar, a small village three miles west of Long Branch.

From its neglected, wead-covered grave in the Cedar Dell section of Greenwood Cemetery, the body of Prof. Richard A. Procter, the astronomer, who died in this city of yellow fever Sept. 12, 1888, will be removed on Tuesday, Oct. 3, and placed beneath a beautiful monument which George W. Childs of Philadelphia has caused to be erected to show his great appreciation of the work of the famous English scientist.

COLOMBIA, S. C., Aug. 31-- Several gentlemen from this city, who were in Port Royal or Beaufort daring the hurricane, returned to Charleston yesterday on the first train which came into the city over the Charleston and Savannah Railway. They report that the lose of life and the destruction of property at those places and the neighboring sea islands have been fearful.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Commissioner Lochren of the Pension Bureau to-day issued an order modifying the practice of the office as to suspensions of pensions. The most important change is that which directs that hereafter there shall be no suspensions except in cases where the record shows on its face that the soldier is not entitled to any pension whatever.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31 -- The Chicago limited express train for Boston broke through a frail iron bridge on the Boston and Albany Railroad one mile and a half east of Chester about 12:30 o'clock to-day, and four Wagner cars were crushed, killing fifteen persons, fatally injuring several others, while at least twenty were badly hart.

It was expected that the Rapid-Transit Commissioners would be prepared yesterday to discuss plans for an independent system of overhead transit. That was their intention at last week's adjournment. They counted then without reference to Engineer John Bogart's vacation, which happened to come due between meetings.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 31 -- John W. Meyers, burglar, who escaped from the Tombs Prison in New-York on the night of July 8, was caught at 10 o'clock this morning at Secaucus by Detective Owen Quinn and Policeman Kennedy of the Hohoken police.

Arthur A. Thompson, a young man of Brooklyn, who has been in the employ of the Perry Stove Company of Albany at their New-York agency, 105 Beekman Street, is a prisoner in the Tombs charged with embezzling $19,000 of the company's funds.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 31 -- The question of repeal of the silver-purchase clause is before the Senate as the regular order of business. The bill to increase the circulation of national banks, which was the unfinished business before the Senate, was sidetracked to-day and was superseded in that position by the bill to repeal the silver-purchase clause of the Sherman act.

Central Office detectives are looking for George Hall, who robbed his English bride and her sister of their money, Jewelry, and baggage, and ran away. He is about forty years old, short, stout, with dark eyes and complexion, thin, black hair, and a somewhat flattened and large nose. The party arrival Saturday on the steamer New-York, and Hall took his wife and sister-in-law to 316 East Forty-second Street, where he abandoned them.

The Directors and officers of the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn may have to face the Grand Jury to answer charges of criminal mismanagement emanating from the depositors of the wrecked institution.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The Veteran Zousves of this city will not be again taken into the New-Jersey National Guard. The members are indignant at the manner in which they have been treated by the State military authorities, and especially by Major Gen. Plume, toward whom their anger seems to be principally directed.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 31 -- Already the work of repairing the widespread damage caused by the hurricane is well under way in this city. Only one wire, connects Charleston with the outside world, although four days have elapsed since the storm. It leads to Augusta, Ga. Direct communication to the North is yet to be attained.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Kearsarge witH hEr tow, the Nantucket, had a very rough time of it as sea during the gale on Monday and Tuesday. It was feared that, encumbered by the unwieldy monitor, the Kearsarge had met with disaster. Each ship was prepared for just the emergency which arose.

Preparations for this year's Westchester County Fair are "booming beautifully." At least, Oliver Sumner Teall, the Chairman of the Executive Committee, says so. It will be held at White Plains Sept. 25 to 30. Among the attractions will be pony races, horse-show exhibits, including tandems, four-in-hands, jumping, and fast trotting, bicycle racing, a dog show, and a baby show.

The chief of the criminal administration of Egypt, Zulfikar Ibrahim Bey, is in the city. He is about thirty years old, of slight figure, with sharp, intelligent, clear-cut features and pleasant address. He is the oldest son of Ibrahim Pasha, for many years the Khedive's Grand Master of Court Ceremonies.

The Republican Convention of Pennsylvania seems to have labored under the feeling that no one cared very much what it did or said. According to the party organs, the "convention was not a large one, but composed of earnest workers, who got down to business early." They also got through with business early, and went away with an air of having discharged a perfunctory and thankless task.
There was a small riot in the rear yard of 131 Cannon Street yesterday, in which a policeman and a number of the tenants of the house took active parts.

The result of the fencing in the Senate yesterday is that Mr. VOORHEES, as Chairman of the Finance Committee, now controls the situation. PEFFKR'S resolution of inquiry concerning the national banks was referred to the Finance Committee by a vote of 35 to 31 against the wish and purpose of its mover and his new partner, Senator HILL of New-York.

The trial races for the selection of a defender of the America's Cup, which are to begin next week, will undoubtedly be very pretty aqnatic spectacles. They will not excite so much interest in advance as the race in which the Puritan won the right of representing American yachts, which were the most interesting races of that kind that have been sailed.

NEW-YORK, THURSDAY, Aug. 31 -- P.M. The stock market sagged to-day owing to the taking of profits by certain of the cliques who have been operating in the industrials. Distilling and Cattle Feeding was by far the most active stock on the list, the transactions in it amounting to very nearly 30 per cent. of the day's business.

President Cleveland, Mrs. Cleveland, and Baby Ruth passed through this city last evening on their way to Washington. The Oneida, E.C. Benedict's steam yacht, with the President and family on board, anchored off Greenwich, Conn., early yesterday.

The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessment yesterday appointed Eugene J. McEnroe and Edward J. Hare to be Deputy Tax Commissioners. They take the places loft vacant by the deaths of Deputy Commissioners Germain Hanschell and Denis O'Donoghue. Mr. McEnroe is a resident of the Twenty-eighth Assembly District and Mr. Hare lives in the Tenth Assembly District. Each will receive a salary of $2,700 a year.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 -- The market opened steady. Atchison was the feature, being withheld, and only losing 1/8 Pcent. on the day. Bay State Gas sold down to 9. Bell Telephone advanced 1 1/2. Lamson was strong, gaining 1 P cent., and closing at 16 bid. The monetary situation seems to improve day by day, and if slowly, none the less surely.

The attitude of the large life insurance companies, banks, and other lending institutions toward real estate mortgages has been securing attention from operators for a month past. On Aug. 13 THE NEW-YORK TIMES called attention to the fact that institutions of this kind had determined to increase the interest rate on renewals to 6 per cent.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Warden Durston of Sing Sing Prison is having the electrical machinery and dynamo in the death chamber examined preparatory to the execution of Edward Geoghan, the wife murderer, who is to be executed next week. Heretofore condemned men have been executed on Monday, but as Monday be Labor Day and a legal holiday, Geoghan will be executed on Tuesday.
The ten scholarships recently offered by Joseph Pulitzer to boys desirous of preparing for and taking a college course have been awarded, after competitive examination, to the following applicants:

It was reported two or three days ago that the Consuls representing this country in Germany were soon to hold a meeting for the consideration of various questions relating to the emigration from German ports of persons who had come to those ports from German cities believed to be infected with cholera.

Chris Von Der Ahe's Browns were the Giants' victims yesterday afternoon. The latter played like a lot of pennant winners, and the team from the West, in the language of the diamond field, was never in the game. Two victories were secured over the visitors and they were both won by hard and timely batting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Those members of the House who went away from Washington on Monday, immediately after the close of the voting on the repeal bill, under the impression that all necessity for vigilance was ended, will road the papers to-morrow with some mortification.

Nancy Hanks, the holder of the world's trotting record, and her trainer and driver, Budd Doble, had a reception at the Fleetwood trotting track yesterday such as so grand a piece of horseflesh and so capable a reinsman richly deserved. No such crowd has been at the track since the memorable day on which Jay Eye See and St. Julien tried conclusions over the course, with disastrous results to the latter.
The oyster season opens to-day with a supply smaller than ever before known on an opening day.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: To return once more, and briefly, to the subject of "Protecting the Wires." and to your comments in to-day's issue, I do not wish to be considered as suggesting that the obstacles, other than expense, are insurmountable; on the contrary, the position you take, that large cities should be provided with uninterrupted communication by underground wires, is entirely feasible, especially for emergency purposes.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, Aug. 31 -- Thousands of poor people are suffering on account of the lack of water and food supplies. The protracted drought has caused the city to be deprived of all its pure water supply, and for several months the only water used has come from polluted wells. The city has been swept by epidemics, and the condition of the lower class of people is pitiable.
Money on call loaned at 2 1/2@4 P cent. The last loan was made at 3 P cent.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- At the St. Lawrence County Republican Convention this afternoon at Canton the following ticket was nominated:

NEWTON, L.I., Aug. 31 -- The inquest to fix the responsibility for the collision on the Long Island Railroad on Saturday night at Berlin was continued here to-day. The interest awakened by yesterday's revelations caused the room in the Town Hall, where the inquest was held, to be crowded.

R.M. Stivers, 144 to 152 East Thirty-first Street, is offering one of the largest and most complete lines of carriages and fancy traps in the city. What every one wants on wheels, either new or secondhand, Mr. Stivers can always show. Victories, cabriolets, wagonettes, luxurious omnibuses, spider and mail phaetons, light wagons, and fancy traps can always be found on the spacious sales floor of this establishment.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 31 -- The effects of the hurricane in this vicinity are unprecedented. Men who have been through tropical cyclones, white squalls of the south seas, and Winter gales off Cape Horn say they never before witnessed such storm fury, such destruction, as visited this old town Sunday night.

Domino is still unbeaten. Dobbins, Richard Crcker's game colt, ran a dead heat with him for the twenty-two-thousand-five-hundred-dollar stake yesterday at Sheepshead Bay, but it was due more to Taral's brilliant horsemanship than to Domino's superiority that Mr. Keene's pet is still an unbeaten two-year-old.

To-day's card is the fullest of the week, and assuming that the track will bare a chance to dry out during the morning, the four events should furnish good sport. Last night's rain will improve the track, and by noon the footing should be excellent.

Milard Johnson, who says he is a wealthy citizen of Texas and a guest at the St. Denis Hotel, had an unpleasant experience Thursday night. He is not known by that name at the St. Denis, but the story told of his visit to the Tenderloin district is true.

NEWTOWN, L.I., Sept 1 -- Robert J. Knott, who was in charge of Block Tower No 5, at Berlin, on the Long Island Railroad, when the Rockaway Beach express ran down the Manhattan Beach special Saturday night, broke down to-day. He virtually admitted to Coroner Brandon that the blame for the collision was his.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 1 -- The charter was filed to-day for the Dakota and Gulf Railroad Company, with a capital stock or $18,000,000. This is the organization of the Great North and South Railroad, the outgrowth of the recent Populist Convention held at Lincoin, Neb., at which North and South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas were represented.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., Sept. 1 -- The schoolhouse at Pleasant Plains was nearly destroyed by fire last night. Residents of Pleasant Plains and Prince's Bay were much excited to-day, and some of them declared that some citizen of one village or the other was responsible for the fire, if not the actual incendiary.

At 3 o'clock yesteraay afternoon Mr. Rosen, Mr. Rosenquest, Mr. Rosenberg, Mr. Rosenheim, Mr. Rosenstein, and Mr. Roseborn were in front of the Casino discusing the lamentable damage caused to a glass door by a human projectile violently discharged through its centre by Mr. Max Freeman.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 1 -- The Tenth District Congressional Convention at Ironton, which nominated H.S. Bundy for the vacancy caused by the death of Gen. W.H. Enochs, was a record breaker in the matter of dead-locks. Every one of the six counting had a candidate, and 1,793 ballots were taken before Bundy won.

The Austrian bark Vila, which brought her cargo of bones and rags safely across the western ocean and was abandoned when almost within eight of land yesterday reached this port in tow of the Norwegian steamship Breidublik. The bark was nearly half full of water and had only the stumps of her masts standing when sighted by the steamship on Wednesday.

The Old Guard Battalion held a largely-attended meeting last night at the clubhouse of the Veteran Firemen's Association to consider what was best to do in reference to providing a new home to replace the one which was burned out Wednesday night. Major Thomas S. Sloan presided. Many different projects were discussed.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept 1 -- In a drizzling rain and damp easterly wind Assistant Secretary of the Navy McAdoo reviewed the First Naval Battalion this afternoon. The men left the New-Hampshire at 4:30 in their outters and wholeboats, which were towed by the tug Pulver to a point opposite the polo field on the east side of Oyster Bay.

-- The Nyaek and Piermont out Rowing Associations, and the Averpeck Boat Club of Leonia, N.J., will have a joint regatta on the Hudson, at Nyack, next Monday. The events will be single gigs, doable gigs, and four-oared gigs. The three clubs have subscribed for a challange banner to be held for year by the club winning the largest number of points.

The annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Racing Association will be sailed next Monday. Labor Day. This regatta is the largest of the yachting season. Last year 101 yachts started, and Mr. George E. Gartland, the Chairman of the Regatta Committee, expects that 125 yachts will cross the line in this year's race. The New-York Yacht Racing Association is formed of nearly all the small yacht clubs in this vicinity.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- President Craig of the State Board of Charities to-day designated Tuesday, Sept. 12, as the data for the commencement of the investigation of the State Reformatory at Elmira. The committee will hold its first meetings at Elmira. Deputy Attorney General Gilbert will act ay counsel for the committee.
Money on call loaned at 2@4 cent; The last loan was made at 2 cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 1 -- The market has been very dull, but strong. The rumors of the failure of a large mortgage trust company was confirmed bore at 2 o'clock by the announcement that the Equitable Mortgage Company had been placed in the Hands of a receiver. This form or investment has been a great favorite for a number of years in this city, and the bonds are held largely throughout the city and State.

The Catholic News of this city has received from its Rome correspondent a translation of a letter sent by Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul, Minn., to the Univers of Paris and reprinted in the Moniteur de Rome.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept 1 -- The forty-and-odd life-saving stations on the New-Jersey coast, from Sandy Hook to Cape May, which have been closed since June 1, were reopened this morning. Each station is manned by a keeper or Captain and seven men.

TOPEKA, Ran., Sept. 1 -- Bank Commissioner Breidenthal has received reports from 200 banks in response to his circular notifying them that they cannot carry over 2 per cent. reserve with their New-York correspondents. Mr. Breidenthal says that these reports show that the New-York banks owe the Kansas banks $159,000, while eight Kansas banks owe NewYork $46,000, of which sum one Wichita bank owes $25,000.

Oscar Hiller, the young Swede who was confined in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, because he could not decide whether to marry "Goody" Petersen or Salma Johnson, settled the matter yesterday by marrying "Goody." "Goody" and Selma visited the jail together yesterday morning, and Pastor Everson was also there. Hiller was called into the jail parlor.

The Rev. Dr. Christian Adolf Stoeoker, ex-Chaplain of the Court of Berlin, Germany, noted as one of the founders of Christian Socialism and as a vigorous anti-Semite, arrived in this city yesterday by the steamer Augusta Victoria. During the voyage he made inquiries as to the best way to elude newspaper reporters on the vessel's arrival in port, and he was told to get into a cab and drive away.

John J. Vail, the cashier of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, has left the city. His present whereabouts is known to only a few of his intimate friends. There was a rumor in circulation yesterday in Brooklyn to the effect that he did not intend to return. Its truth was denied by Mr. Vail's friends.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Ex-Speaker Reed entertained the House to-day with an imitation of the man who tries to act as it he could hold his own when his cards are all poor.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- An interesting exhibit is made here by the Putnam Nail Company of Neponset, Boston, Mass., whose display is in the northwest part of the Manufactures Building, Section G, Block 4. At the company's pavilion the famous "Putnam" nail is shown in thirty shapes and sizes. A large card illustrates how these nails are hot forged by hammer blows, and hammer pointed without shearing.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept 1 -- The Minnesota Committee of Fifty is making a tremendous effort to crush out the coal combine. Through its Sub-Committee of Five it to-day lssued, an address to the citizens of the State urging that, pending the outlining of a plan that shall, if possible, afford relief from the present exorbitant prices charged consumers of coal in the Northwest, all who possibly can withhold orders and refrain from purchasing coal.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 1 -- After a long period of quiet the Long Island City Goverment comes to the front with a disturbance on its hands. Singularly enough, ex-Mayor Gleason does not figure in this quarrel.

TOTEKA, Kan., Sept. 1 -- William Kinne of Toledo, Ohio, and Mrs. E.F. Rice of Dunn Falis, N.Y., were married in Atchison on Thursday. Immediately after the ceremony the bride proceeded on her way to Nebraska City Neb., while the groom left for Denver.

CONEY ISLAND, Sept. 1 -- There is indignation among the dwellers here, at the allegation that the Coney Island mosquito has a rival in business and that the far-famed Jersey mosquito, having had a dull season in his country, has immigrated hither, in order to get square meals regularly.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- At Cazenovia was witnessed a novel sight yesterday afternoon. It was called a flower parade and was the first of the kind in this region.

The differences between Mrs. Paran Stevens and Miss Anna Leery have been settled out of court. Miss Leary, as the executrix of her brother, Arthur Leary, who died about three months ago, brought suit recently in the Supremo Court for a settlement of accounts against Mrs. Stevens.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Vice Chancellor Van Fleet was indignant this morning when he learned that Lawyer John Whitehead, who was appointed receiver for the Morristown Printing Company Aug. 26 had been insulted, his authority ignored, and the court's order disregarded by officials of the company.

For what is practically a new trotting association the During Club or New-York, now holding meeting at the Fleetwood track, is making a reputation. Under its management a lot of records have been broken at the track, and many new records have teen made. Yesterday it made quite novel record as a trotting association. Rain is always a bugbear to the managers of meetings where contests between horses in harness are a feature.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during August, of $10,442,898.93.
YEMASSEE, S.C., Sept. 1 -- Beaufort, Port Royal, and all the towns along the coast and rivers bear evidence of the great destruction wrought by the storm on Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Lieut. H.H. Hosley, commanding the old monitor Nantucket, has reported to Secretary Herbert that the injuries to that vessel from its terrible experience off Hatteras during the the at hurricane consist mainly in the imperfect joints around hatches, hawse pipe, and air parts, leaky condition of ventilating engines, and want of free communication between bilge compartments.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 1 -- President Charles P. Clark of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad has made the following important announcement:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- President and Mrs. Cleveland returned to Washington this morning at 4:10 o'clock to find themselves welcomed as they emerged at 7 o'clock from their special car by a very fair imitation or inauguration weather. The welcome they received from Private Secretary Thurber, however, was warm and genuine enough to atone for any discourtesy on the part of the elements.

The arrest of Emma Goldman in Philadelphia and the certainty that she will be indicted for inciting to riot and brought here have had the effect of sending into still greater seclusion the Anarchists of this city who went into hiding when Superintendent Byrnes returned from his vacation.

Judge Shipman of the United States Court has signed an order appointing receivers for the Equitable Mortgage Company, which was incorporated in Missouri and which has its chief office at 40 Wall Street, this city. The receivers are Charles N. Fowler, President of the company, and James M. Gifford, a lawyer of 58 William Street.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: It gave me great pleasure to find to-day in your valuable journal a complete description of the new steamship El Cid.

George R. Kemp, owner of the Buckingham Hotel, and Contractor Gilligan, who is working on the foundations for an addition to the hotel at 615 Fifth Avenue, have been enjoined from continuing the blasting which has been going on there since last February.

The path of last Sunday's hurricane along the southern coast of the United Stated covered all the country between the Savannah River and the mouth of Charleston Harbor. Pert Royal and the United States naval station on Paris Island wore in the very centre of the storm's fury.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1 -- The Government has recovered nearly $200,000 from ship contractors in the way of penalties. Most of the penalties are for delays, although in several instances they are on account of failure to attain the required indicated horse power. In nearly every case the contractor disputes the justice of the penalty, and his only remedy is an appeal to Congress.

A strapping young Italian named Joseph Murri gave an exhibition of strength on the stage of the Fourteenth Street Theatre yesterday afternoon in the presence of Business Manager Maguire and a few others.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The Home Rule bill passed the House of Commons to-night, the vote on the third reading being 301 to 267. Five minutes later the bill had its first reading in the House of Lords. There is great joy among those who have supported the measure in the long, hard fight that began with its introduction months ago and has been kept up without cessation.

The annual Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club will be sailed to-day. The start will be made at 11 o'clock, off the clubhouse, and the yachts will saol over the usual club course, the schooners going to Stamford, the sloops to Captain's Island, and the catboats to Matinnicock. Thirty-five yachts have entered and the contest in nearly every class should be very hot.

The current number of the North American Review contains two articles on "England and France in Siam." One is by Mr. GEORGE N. CURZON, M.P., who has already, in the English reviews, written voluminously upon the subject, and who sets forth, with emphasis, the British point of view.

POMBROY, Ohio, Sept. 1 -- Mrs. Virginia Beverly McLean, widow of Major Wilmer McLean, in whose house Gens. Grant and Lee signed articles of surrender at Appomattox, died Friday at the residence of her son-in-law, H.E. Spillman, at Spillman, West Va. She was seventy-five years old and was a remarkably well-preserved woman, cultured and refined.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Gen J. Madison Drake, Commander of the Veteran Zouaves, who were recently disbanded as a Gatling gun company by order or Gen. Plume, severely criticises the latter. Gen. Drake saya he cannot understand why Gen. Plums has refused to remuster the Zouaves, after having specifically promised to do so, if they would reorganize in accordance with the National Guard laws.

The position of the Wilson, repeal bill in the Senate is now excellent. It has practically the right of way over all other measures or propositions. Senator VOORHEES who, as Chairman of the Finance Committee, has charge of it, has given notice that after reasonable time for debate he shall press a vote upon it.

Pim, Forwood Co. of 22 State Street, agents for the Atlas line steamship Alvo, which sailed from this city on Aug. 16 and has not been heard from since, do not think the vessel has met with any disaster. She should have arrived at the West Indies Aug. 21.

The New Municipal Building Commission met in the Mayor's office at noon yesterday. Acting Mayor McClellan presiding, received the plans for the new building that had been submitted by 130 architects, and closed the competition.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- The election of the Rev. A. C.A. Hall, formerly of Boston, but now of Oxford, England, to the Protestant Episcopal Bishopric of Vermont, is an event of more than ordinary interest to Episcopalians everywhere, but it has a special interest for the Massachusetts Diocese.

NEW-YORK, FRIDAY, Sept. 1 -- P. M. There was Quite a heavy falling off in the volume of transactions to-day, but not results show general advances. The heaviest trading was in Sugar, St. Paul, General Electric, Chicago Gas, and Western Union, and they all scored gains extending from 1 1/8 in Western Union to 2 7/8 in Sugar.

-- A wedding was appointed to be held in Williamstown, Mass., on Wednesday evening last at 6 o'clock. The guests assembled, the bride was ready, and the clergyman and the time came, but the expected, groom did not. There was first wonder, then despair. The minister became nervous, the bride hysterical, her father angry, and the wedding dinner cold.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept 1 -- The State fair which opens at Waverly Park to-morrow will probably be more successful than any of its predecassors. Books will be opened at the fair grounds to-morrow for the entry of manufactured goods, fine arts, women's work, fruits, and farm products. All the departments are already filled, and the buildings and grounds have been put in excellent condition and are ready for the reception of exhibits.
Bedford Cycle Club to Patohogue, L.I. Two days' run. Start from clubhouse, 980 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, at 9 A.M. to-morrow.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 1 -- A NEW-YORK TIMES correspondent ascended the tower of the City Exchange, 150 feet high, this afternoon, and with a powerful glass was the first person in Savannah to sight the tug Jacob Pauisen as she came into the entrance of the river, just off from Tybee Island, with the remainder of the crew and wrecked passengers of the steamer City of Savannah.

"Tommy" Conneff, the great middle-distance runner, who broke all amateur records for a mile in Boston last Saturday, says that he will surely win THE NEW-YORK TIMES medal at the World's Fair sports this month. Last Saturday he ran the fastest mile ever made by a professional or an amateur in a big field of starters, covering the distance in 4:17 4-5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Free coinage found an active supporter in the Senate to-day in the person of Mr. Cockrell of Missouri, who managed to get in the way of every proposition made by Mr. Voorhees to advance the Repeal bill or to reach an understanding by which an early vote upon repeal could be had.

YEMASSEE, S.G., Sept 1 -- The journey through this country from Charleston to Yemassee brought to light even a more pitiful state of affairs among the poor woodchoppers, mine workers, and employes in the phosphate works along the line than did the trip down to Charleston on the Coast Line.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept 1 -- Health Commissioner Edson of New-York has made an examination of cultures of bacteria from one of the men who died in Jersey City with choleraic symptoms. He reported to the Health authorities here, and the following bulletin was issued to-day:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The President sent to the Senate to-day the following nominations in addition to a lot of new appointments of customs officers:

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 1 -- Broker Hathaway, whose failure was announced this morning, had been doing business with the Metacomet and Second National Banks, but they became suspicious some time ago and suspended dealings with him. Now that the story of his transactions is out, it surprises business men that they could have been carried on so long undetected.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Secretary Carlisle stated to-day that the silver purchased by the Treasury Department during the month of August, 1893, was 3,898,022 fine ounces, costing $2,880,532.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 1 -- How many unfortunate mortals met their death in the great hurricane from the West Indies which swept over the coast of South Carolina and Georgia will probably never be known. Advices received here and at other large cities in the belt over which the storm raged already show that between 500 and 600 have perished.

Morris Reno says that reports recently published of the weakening of the Symphony Orchestra are false. He says, further: "Nearly all of the former members have been re-engaged and no material reduction has been made in salaries. Some changes have been made, (principally among the wood wind players,) not for purposes of economy, but to strengthen the organization.

-- Expert Accountant Stephen Little of New-York yesterday began an examination of the Reading Railroad books in Philadelphia in order to confirm the statement of the receivers, which has been completed and placed in his hands. As soon as his examination is finished, the statement will be made public in the form of a circular to the stockholders, and will not be filed in court.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- "Wheat -- The market attracted only a fair attention from the speculative element, and principally for the local account to-day. The orders from, outside operators to-day were generally for small quantities. The abort session of the board to-morrow and its adjournment over Monday (Labor Day) had some influence in cheeking business. Deliveries of wheat are very light, estimates of the amount going around varying from 400,000 bushels to 750,000.

The steamship City of Augusta, which arrived yesterday from Savannah, reports having sighted, on Aug. 30, eighteen miles south of Charleston, the schooner Harold G. Beecher of Now-Haven, Conn., dismasted, waterlogged, and abandoned. The Beocher sailed from Brunswick, Ga., on Aug. 28, bound for New-Haven. She had on board a cargo of lumber, which was valued at $15,000.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The port of Grimsby, in Lincoinshire, has been declared to be infected with cholera, and traffic between it and other British ports has been prohibited. In August there were eighty deaths in Grimsby from what was called at first diarrhea and, later, a choleraic disease. The general ballet now is that many of these deaths were due to cholera.

Dun's Review will nay to-morrow: "The House has passed the Silver bill by a majority astonishing to its friends, and a favorable reault in the Senate is now believed to be not far distant. Instant improvement in the stock market followed, the average of prices rising over $2 share, and there was also a rise in wheat, cotton, and pork.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 1 -- Despite all efforts of the Ashieys and Receiver Burt to Keep the famous Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railroad above water, it seems that the final blow is now about to fall. Ever since its trouble with the Brotherhood the career of this road has been fraught with many vicissitudes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- There are at present between twenty-five and thirty vacancies in the position of Internal Revenue Collector. These vacancies have been occasioned by the Collecters' resignations being asked for.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Hadley B. Cadmus, a feed and grain merchant in this town, is apparently recovering from a severe attack of peritonitis by reason of novel and heroic treatment devised and directed by himself.

The United States District Attorney in Brooklyn yesterday filed with the United States District Court papers in libel against the steamer Mississippi, owned by the American Transport Company. While the dispatch boat Dolphin of the United States Navy was lying off West Twenty-third Street after the naval parade May 6 the Mississippi backed out of Pier 57, ran into the Dolphin, and crushed in her bow.

The bank statement issued yesterday realized the moat sanguine expectations. During the week the resources of the banks were increased by over $5,000,000 in the two items of specie and legal tenders. The deposits increased $3,500,000; the circulation, $1,131,400; the reserve, $5,170,150, reducing the deficiency below the legal requirement to $1,567,525; while the loans decreased $3,438,100.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The worst seaeon in the history of Long Branch has come to an end. In the long and checkered history of this resort the big hotels have never closed so early nor with such a small balance to their credit. In many cases the "balance" is the other way.

WEST POINT, Sept. 2 -- The cadets have returned from Chicago and West Point smiles again. The trip it regarded by the officers as a great success, which will help to give the boys broad, practical, and instructive views of the industries of the world. Major Spurgin will remain another week in Chicago settling bills and attending to other matters connected with the trip.

Would Napoleon have died any happier if he had known the glory that awaited him at the century's closet Crowning men King at his pleasure was a small matter beside this crowning of all the pretty women with his hat.

An exceptionally good day's sport was marred by the delay in the Omnium Handicap at Sheepshead Bay yesterday. There were twelve starters, and they went to the post, directly in front of the grand stand, and were at the post from 3:45 to 5:05. For their pranks at the post Starter Rowe fined nine of the boys $600 each. Goodale, who rode Dally America, was suspended for the rest of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 2. -- Three thousand persons were present at the professional bicycle races at the Tioga track this afternoon. It was the first meet of the Fail series and the events were well contested.

BIRMINGHAM, Conn., Sept 2 -- Whether the crack riders had fooled the Crescent Cycle Club or the club Had fooled the public a crowd of 7,000 people could not figure out to-day. Of all the cracks that had been advertised the only ones to appear were Windle and Tyler, with Warren a good second-class man. Windle and Tyler working together took every event in which they were entered, and Warren attended to the rest.

If we read aright the signs of the times, this country is about ready to resume business in the customary volume and with its usual energy. Trade conditions are mending. We have seen the worst of the financial stringency. Money is getting to be easier and cheaper. In industries where there has been stagnation, life stirs again.

For the first time this season the Brooklyns failed to score a run yesterday in their contest with the Clevelands. Cyrus Young, the big farmer pitcher, was in grand form, and he proved a complete enigma to the heavy hitters of the local club. "Dan" Brouthers being the only man able to make a fair showing against his curves.

No month of all the year is more lavish in the bestowal of gilte for the enjoyment of humanity than September. She sits like a Queen enthroned, while heaped up before her are the abundant harvests, the fruits, and the flowers, elaborated by the sovereign power of the great central star that rules the solar scheme.

Taylor Brothers, pawnbrokers at 94 Hester Street, have become financially embarrassed and have given a bill of sale of their business to M. Simons, the father-in-law of one of the partners, for $94,886. It is said that Mr. Simons took the business to protect himself for loans he had made to the firm at various times and for paper he had discounted.

Alarmed by the exposures by THE NEW-YORK TIMES of reckless mismanagement and aroused to a realization of the necessity for immediate action by the threats of criminal prosecution emanating from depositors, the Directors of the suspended Commercial Bank in Brooklyn yesterday put forth a hastily-formulated plan for resumption.

NEW-YORK, SATURDAY, Sept. 2 -- P.M. The stock market was very strong to-day. From the opening the tendency of prices was upward and gains were made rapidly. At the beginning there was a rush of shorts to cover, and its effects were supplemented half an hour before the close by the very favorable showing made by the weekly statement of the Associated Banks.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 2 -- Word has just been received here that the great storm of last Sunday, which it was supposed had about spent its strength when it reached a point as far south as this city on the coast line, caused great disaster further south on the Georgia coast, between Sapello Island, the quarantine station, and Brunswick.

PARIS, Aug. 21 -- The capricious necessities of theatrical venture brought the premiere of "Una Nuit de Noel" of Messrs. Camille de Rodar and Maurice Lefevre to the present month, the very warmest and most uncomfortable of our long Summer. Its date of presentation was the eve of election day also. Certainly circumstances were discouraging, and more reputed names might easily have avoided the battle.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Cooperstown has not escaped the bad weather which has prevailed during the last week, and the abundance of rainy days has made indoor amusements a necessity. Card parties and impromtu musicales have been popular at the hotels, with the usual amount of dancing.

It is natural and inevitable that the sinking of the finest ship in the British Navy should give rise to a very animated discussion among shipbuilders, naval architects, and naval officers concerning the condition of the navy. Two retired Admirals make contributions to this discussion in the current number of one of the English reviews, and althongh a retired Admiral is almost proverbially a grumbler, these contributions are not without value.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 2 -- It is fast developing that the loss of life and destruction of all binds of property on the sea islands that skirt the southeastern coast of South Carolina, by the recent hurricane has never been paralleled in this country. The loss of life is put by some estimates at 1,500.

New answers are continually arising to the old question, "What is the height of meanness?" The latest is supplied by Augustus Bakrak, Swinton Street, King's Cross, whose bump of selfishness reaches the height of abstracting a newspaper from a free library.

Signs of returning confidence and cheerfulness in business circles are beginning to manifest themselves. A general belief that the silver-purchasing act will soon be wiped off the statute books has inspired nope and courage in the breasts of the manufacturers, the merchants, and the great army of producers as well.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 2 -- These are glorious days at Sea Cliff, far and away the best of the year. Already the sumachs are turning scarlet and coloring the landscape with their fiery tints, as becomes their mission as the early harbingers of Autumn.

The application of the receivers of the Northern Pacific Railroad for authority to issue receivers' certificates has been granted, by Judge Jenkins of the United States Circuit Court in Milwaukee. An order has been signed giving Receivers Oakes, Rouse, and Payne the power to issue certificates not to exceed $5,000,000 for the purpose of redeeming certain securities and meeting certain urgent expenses.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- There is fear and trepidation in banking circles over the coming vote on the Wilson bill, as the passage of the repeal bill by the Senate is expected to be the signal for large investment demands for American securities.
The prettiest girl on the hotel piazza rushed up to the new-comer, holding out both hands.

Some of the earnest friends of the Wilson repeal bill are inclined to criticise the course of Mr. VOORHEES as the leader of the Senate in this matter. They say that he is allowing too great license to the silver Senators in the way of debate and is in danger of being entangled by them in some parliamentary complications which will delay repeal.

The Chinese question occupied a good portion of Collector Kilbreth's time in the Custom House yesterday. The cases of the eight Celestials who arrived here, from Havana on the Ward Line steamer Orizaba last Monday were looked into. The men had been detained on board the vessel in consequence of the protest of United States Chinese Inspector Scharf against their landing.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The season in the Catskills is rapidly drawing to a close, and every day hundreds of people are returning to their city homes. The season at the Kaaterskill, which closed Thursday, has been considerably lighter than last year, but Mr. Harding, the proprietor, has nevertheless enjoyed a very profitable Summer.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 2. -- As a result of to-day's championship games of the New-England Association of the Amateur Atnletic Union, three men will to sent by the association to compete in the World's Games at Chicago. These-three, who equaled or excelled the standards fixed, are O.W. Shead, Boston Athletic Association, in the 120-yard hurdles; E.B. Bloss, Boston Athletic Association.

Probably Mr. Harrigan's comic dramas of New-York low life have a value as "documents" -- which is one of the overworked words of the current vocabulary. They depict so vividly the humorous side of existence in this city's slums and tenement districts a few years ago that it is a pity they cannot be preserved for the use of the historian and the novelist of the future.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Sept. 2 -- The end of August and the first two weeks of September form always the gayest and the most beautiful period of the Water Gap's season. The crisp bright days and cool evenings, with the thousond-and-one diversions that each bring, have made this a favorite time with those familiar with the Gap.

It is an accepted fact among women, founded upon good reason, that when one's belongings are valuable and costly, the services of a maid are not a luxury, but a necessity and really an economy. Delicate fabrics need great care in handling and preserving, and fine boots, shoes, gloves, and handkerchiefs are not to be tossed about carelessly and stlll preserve their freshness.

Monday will be a red-letter day in athletics in this section of the country. The New-Jersey Athletic Club, the leading organization in the State of New-Jersey, will hold its annual carnival of sports at the club grounds, Bayonne City, N.J. A very fine entry list has been received. In the 100-yard run W.M. Richards, intercollegiate champion and now of the New-York Athletic Club, is on scratch.

Lord Ffrench, in a letter to the editor of the Irish Catholic, says there should appear articles setting forth again how clear it is that Ireland has not prospered under the system of government established by the act which deprived her of her Legislature, and how necessary is a considerable change.

Workmen about to build a brick pier for a new building in Lewiston, Me., dug down four feet into the ground and came upon a large flat stone. It pleased them to discover what they believed would be a fine foundation for their pier, and they went to work building upon it. They built the pier to a height of twelve feet, and then were astonished to see it sink into the earth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Capt. Massam of the British steamer Leconfield reports to the United States Hydrographio Office that on Aug. 29, at 6 P.M., in latitude 30 20 north, longitude 79 4' west, he passed the derelict British ship Nettle Murphy burning to the water's edge as far as the mainmast and still on fire aft. The smoke was visible for four miles.

Domenico Cuccio, importer of foreign fruits at 24 State Street, is reported to have trans- ferred all his property to his wife and nephew, and to have gone to Europe with his wife and children. J. Aparicio Co. have brought suit against him for $27,860, said to be due on bills of exchange and drafts made by Fratelli Cuccio at Palermo and accepted by Domenico Cuccio, and also on his notes.
An unusually large number of well-known persons were passengers on the American Line steamship Paris, which reached this port yesterday from Southampton.

The armories of the National Guard in this city and Brooklyn are beginning to take on an air of business again after the Summer idleness. Men are returning from their vacations, officers from their leaves of absence, and a season of activity is promised, both in the line of work and social events.

The Orange Canoe Club of West Arlington. N.J., held its fourth annual regatta yesterday afternoon on the Passaic River in front of its clubhouse. The course for the paddling races was one hall mile straightaway; for the sailing races it was triangular, and about three miles in length. A large number of visitors watched the races from the balconies of the clubhouse or from the adjacent house of the Arlington Canoe Club.

The attitude assumed by THE TIMES during the last few months in relation to the affairs of the Reading Railroad has received frequent commendation, but the expressed determination in yesterday's issue to fathom the schemes which have brought the company to its present embarrassment and to assist in its rehabilitation have drawn forth expressions of approval, not only on "the Street," but in mercantile circles generally.

The day of the pillow sham and of the round bolster is past. The very latest decree of fashion calls for frilled and embroidered slips of linen lawn, and ordains that in them and their lining all the color of the bed drapery snail concentrate. White spreads are promised for the near future, and the pillows are to become the important features of the bed.

John I. Davenport is officially homeless. Postmaster Dayton, acting as Custodian of the Post Office Building, yesterday dispossessed the doughty champion of the "purity of elections." Shortly before noon Frederick J. Swift, the Postmaster's secretary, appeared in the rooms occupied by Mr. Davenport as Chief Supervisor of Elections.

It is perhaps not generally known that there are quite a number of enterprising organizations of women without the fold of the much talked of federation. Prominent among these is the Woman's Club of Milwaukee, which, after joining the larger body, resigned just before the famous first biennial meeting, giving as reason for such action that it objected to fraternizing with the other clubs of its State, as recommended by the federation.

"Fritz" Pfeffer and his Louisville Colonels have been playing a strong game on this trip, and 5,000 spectators journeyed to the Polo Grounds to see them play yesterday. They were sorely disappointed. The exhibition was by long odds the worst of the season. Errors on both sides were plentiful; the men played without any life or spirit; the contest was slow, tiresome, and uninteresting, and the only redeeming feature was that the Giants won.

Those who were at the bicyclers rest on the Playstead during a pare of last evening witnessed a most peculiar and beautiful sight. A huge decayed Tree bad succumbed to the gale, and suddenly at its uprooting and fracture the ground all around it blazed up in luminous phosphorescent light; the trees and shrubhery all about were filled with gemlike shining particles of the flying phosphorus-charged decayed wood.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- Owing the to threatening aspect of the weather the fourth annual reunion of the survivors of the Sixth New-York Artillery, which was held at the fair grounds here to-day, was not so largely attended as had been expected. Fifteen hundred persons were on the grounds when the exercises began at 11 A.M.

Slowly but surely the effects of the mismanagement of affairs on the running tracks of the East since John A. Morris accomplished the destruction of the American Jockey Club, forced it into dissolution, and himself and his Louisiana Lottery methods to the fore, are making themselves felt. Already, since the notorious and disgraceful meeting at the Monmouth Park began.

Mr. C.B. Cline, the press agent, says he thinks "the new Koster Bial's, formerly the Manhattan Opera House, will undoubtedly become one of the most popular places of amusement in town." Here are his reasons : "Every possible detail has been carefully looked after, with a view of affording the public perfect comfort while witnessing the performances.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Yang Yu, Noble of the Order of the Eight Banners, and Minister Plenipotentiary of China to the United States, Spain, and Peru, paid his respects to the Secretary of State in the diplomatic room of the State Department this morning, while Secretary Gresham returned the salutation by bowing and making a few remarks of welcome.
BERLIN, Sept. 2 -- Emperor William left Coblenz for Trier at 6:30 o'clock this morning accompanied by his suits and the Prince of Naples. The Empress followed in a later train.

LITTLE ROCK, Art., Sept. 1 -- It was only a few days ago that news came from Denver that a Judgment -- one of many -- bad been secured against Stephen W. Dorsey, one of Senatorial and star route fame, for $150 for a piano. It was only another step in the fall of a man whose life in recent years has been only a series of reverses.

-- The Race Committee of the Manhattan Bicycle Club has prepared the following scedule of club runs for this month: Sept. 2, 3, 4, and 5, four days' run to the Delaware Water Gap: Sunday, Sept. 10, to Saten Island to join picnic ran of Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs.

The Erie was obliged to run two special trains of ten cars each from Jersey City yesterday morning to accommodate its World's Fair excursionists, which numbered 575. The first train will be run through to Chicago without stops, except for meals. The second section will make no stops, except for meals, west of Susquehanna, at which point a third section will start to accommodate excursionists from points east of Salamanca.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The Red Bank Cyclers is a flourishing bicycle club, which has been in existence only a little over a year. This year-old youngster is healthy and growing, and bids fair to be a giant long before it enters its teens.

A report on the Island of Formosa by Mr. Hosle has been published as a Parliamentary paper, remarks a London journal. It is the first which has been issued in this country since 1886, and in the interval the Island has become an independent province of the Chinese Empire, and railways have been introduced, but the hopes founded on them have not been realized, partly owing to official blundering.

The slipshod fashion in which trotting meetings are managed, in contradistinction to the pratically theatrical management of the running race tracks, was never better exemplifled than at the fleetwood Park track yesterday. There was no announcement That Directum was to appear in the race for the 2:12 class, and the association lost fully $5,000 in gate receipts for the failure to have the fact properly advertised.

Capt. Joseph Markham, United States Army, had for three years enjoyed the privileges of Aberdeen. Society had opened her puffy bosom; St. Simon's had accorded him a seat among the godly, i.e., the opulent; and the club had flung apart its jealously-guarded portals, for the recruiting officer is ex-officio a member of the club at Aberdeen.
"I think the English are the widest people when abroad and the most polite in their own homes of any nation in the world."

SARATOGA, Sept. 2 -- A considerable exodus of what is called the August crowd has taken place yesterday and to-day, but its place is filled by the incoming September folk. The arrivals to-night from the North are heavy, being the vanguard of the loiterers at the upper New-York and New-England resorts who visit Saratoga on the homeward itinerary.

Patrick Head, forty years old, driver of Fire Engine No. 29, located on Frost Street, near Kingsland Avenue, Brooklyn, drank a goblet of diluted carbolic acid by mistake for liquor yesterday afternoon, and died in fifteen minutes.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 2 -- "They seek for happier shores in vain who leave the Summer isles of Maine," but they are leaving. The curtain has been rung down and the drama of Summer life has been transferred to Lenox, the White Mountains, the Hudson, and the many other resorts which fashion has decreed to be the proper places in which to spend the Autumn.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 2 -- On Slab 1 in the morgue lies the body of Frank C. Story, traveling agent for the Mutual Publishing Company of 120 Broadway, New-York. Two weeks ago Story arrived here and put up at the St. James's Hotel, being assigned to Room 138. He drank a little, but not to excess.

BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- All but two of the fifteen theatres to Boston are now open for the season. Monday the Globe, which had been closed all Summer, opened in a renovated condition, with Lawrence Hanley in "The Player." The succeeding attraction will be Eugene O'Rourke in "The Wicklow Postman."

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- On the Stook Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 141@140, North Chicago at 204@205, Diamond Match at 117@ 118, Lake Street "L" at 22. Money. 7 cent. Bank clearings, $12,678,678. New York exchange, 25c. discount.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Sept 2 -- The guests of the Hotel Brooklyn, winch has bad the banner season in its history, under the able guldance of Proprietor F.M. Rogers, are making the most of the few weeks remaining of the season and are having jolly times Dances, progressive euchre, and yachting have lost nothing of their novelty yet, it seems, and have been the medium of some or the moat pleasant hours of the week.

The canoe clubs of New-Jersey are a power in themselves, and just at present they believe they have demonstrated their ability in a most worthy manner before the members of the great American Canoe Association and the canoeists of the entire world. There are many lovers of the tiny craft in England who take an interest in everything their American cousins accomplish.

We shall never, probably, arrive at an agreement as to the real meaning of the word cookney. Camden states that the Thames was once called the "Cockney," and, therefore, a cockney means one who lives on the banks of the Thames. The learned Prof. Skeat prefers to connect cockney with the old English word cokes, a simpleton.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The cornerstone of the Gould Memorial Church at Roxbury was laid at noon to-day. The entire Gould family, except Edwin Gould, was present. George J. Gould laid the cornerstone. The services were conducted by the Rev. W.H. Demarest, assisted by the Rev. L.S. Brown of the Roxbury Methodist Church and several other local clergymen.
Don M. Dickinson, who was Postmaster General under President Cleveland's first Administration, arrived in the city from Washington yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The Wednesday evening dinner at the Seawanuaka Clubhouse was a charming event. It was the most notable dinner of the season in the matter of attendance and general brilliancy. While the season at other points is practically at an end, Oyster Bay continues gay, and these pretty dinners will be attractive features for some time.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 2 -- The reason for the tying up of over 15 per cent. of the vessel tonnage of the great lakes is not hard to understand, when it is known that the 4,000,000 tons shortage in ore alone means the idleness of 100 boats of 2,000 tons each for the whole season. The somewhat larger coal shipments which hare occurred up to this time, could not begin to offset that.
