It is readily conceivable that a hundred years hence the little books of this Distaff Series will have a quaint interest as the first written, edited, set up, and bound by women. It may be, also, that the future historian will regard them favorably as showing in a compact and accessible form the spirit in which women made their pioneer efforts.

The Bijou Theatre was opened for the season last night with a new version of "The City Directory," which bears no relation at all to any previous version of that successful entertainment, except that a casual allusion is made in the first part of it to a canvasser for the city directory, who has nothing whatever to do with the proceedings.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The statement of the United States Treasurer, showing the classified assets of the Treasury and demand liabilities to-day, is as follows:

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The monotony of the World's Fair season among the centrally-situated playhouses is broken at last. Next week two important theatres will enter upon their regular seasons, and a third, which has been closed during the Summer, will show signs of animation. At a majority of other houses the end of the Summer term is in sight.

JAMAICA, L.I., Sept 2 -- District Attorney Fleming was not at home this evening when a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES called. He had gone out of town to spend Sunday. His rumored intention to proceed criminally against the higher officials of the Long Island Railroad, in connection with the accident at Berlin, could not be confirmed.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 2 -- The Lenox cottagers have been having a gay time this week. Everybody is here, the cottages are all occupied, and many of the cottagers have large house parties. Dances, dinners, and outdoor sports of all kinds are keeping the town lively.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1 -- In their report on the mineral resources of Ontario, the Commissioners say that their investigations "lead to the conclusion that more than one-half of the capital invested in mining operations in Ontario is American," and, further, they report that "the American investments are managed as a rule by experienced and trained men, who are capable of giving intelligent direction to the operations under their charge."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Dennis of 42 West Fifty-first Street, New-York, who are occupying the James G.K. Duer cottage, near the Danes, have sold their pretty place at Elberon. The Dennises are pleased with Southampton, and intend buying land and building a house here before another season.

LAKE KUSHAQUA, Franklin County, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Many years ago, long before "the hand of man ever set foot" in this region, wild deer made a pathway through the thick pine forest down to a beautiful lake.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 2 -- The record of Republican misgovernment in Ohio grows longer and more startling the more it is investigated. Rarely in the last twenty years has there been presented to the people a more offensive and sweeping arraignment of an administration than in possible at the present time.

A United States Senator with free-silver proclivities who was in this city last week was taught a costly lesson by a thief, who relieved him of his gold watch, gold chain, gold ring, gold sleeve buttons, two diamonds with a sapphire in the centre, a sliver pencil, and $400 in money.

The tie between the New-Jersey Athletic and Staten Island Cricket Clubs for the lead in the race for the cricket championship of New-York was broken yesterday at Bergen Point. The two clubs had previously maintained an unbeaten record, and in the expectation of seeing a close and exciting struggle a large crowd gathered to witness the contest.

The more light is thrown on the operations of the gentlemen who have undertaken to manage the affairs of the City of Brooklyn for their own profit, and with as little respect as possible for the wishes or rights of the taxpayers, the clearer it becomes that they have no easy task before them for the Fall that is now opened.

The annual cruise of the New-York State Naval Battalion is ended. The New-Hampshire, with the reserves on board, returned to this port yesterday. She arrived at her dock at the root of East Twenty-eighth Street at 3:30 P.M. She left Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. She was towed by two tugs and should have reached here at 2 P.M. Head winds delayed her.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- [By Commercial Cable from Our Own Correspondent.] -- In the Parliamentary game as it is played in England self-deception is always trumps. Nothing can be stranger to an onlooker than the splendid, unwearying persistency with which all the players keep their illusions, or, at least, an excellent semblance of them, straight up to the time when hands must be shown down.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 2 -- The special train bearing the New-York State officials who are to represent the State at the celebration of New-York Day left here this afternoon. The party on board was much smaller than was anticipated. The train came through from New-York City and was made up of a baggage, a dining, and the three Wanner sleeping cars Dryden, Lyra, and Elolse.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- A hurricane passed over the Azores Islands on Aug. 28. Two vessels were wreaked in the Harbor of Fayal and fourteen houses were destroyed in the town. At Terceira three vessels were wracked and twenty-eight houses were destroyed. Five persons were killed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Upon the motion at Mr. Voorhees, the Senate to-day agreed to meet hereafter at 11 o'clock, and it will begin to carry out that order on Monday. The Indiana Senator did not push the Repeal bill to-day, and in a speech he referred to the fact that it had been before the Senate but a short time, and that he was desirous of giving proper opportunity for its discussion.

Morris Tekulsky, President of the State Liquor Dealers' Association, was asked yesterday what he thought of the recommendation said to have been made by some liquor dealers to abolish free lunches in saloons because they are costly and unprofitable.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- A fair speculative business was transacted in wheat to-day and the undertone was stronger. Local operators were bullish and were credited with buying fair quantities of December. Some of the American Exchanges were closed. This curtailed business to some extent. The improved tone of the market was attributed to the decidedly strong bank statement from New-York and to the better feeling in the New-York stock market.

To the lover thereof one of the compensations of living is the succulent and savory lobster, and loud will be the lamentation if the growing scarcity should ultimate in a famine. Twenty-five or thirty years ago, when canned lobster was a boon hoped for, but not known, the public reveled in a cheap and abundant supply of this toothsome edible.
The Catholic Congress at the World's Fair will begin its sessions to-morrow, and from all over the country large delegations of prominent Catholics will be present.
Five new plays will be presented in New-York this week. Three of them have already been acted in other cities, and two are known to have been successful.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 2 -- The goal which marks the highest ambition of a Summer resort landlord has been reached, and this year the Richfield bonifaces rode through the 1st of September with so much surplus business that no one seems to realize that the time for the game is over. Mr. Proctor of the Spring House has been trying for the last ten years to establish a September trade with constantly-growing success.

The Central Labor union has for over a month past been making preparations for its great labor parade to-morrow, Labor Day. This will be the eleventh labor parade that has been held under the auspices of the Central Labor Union.

A gossiping old Bostonian has been reviving recollections of Mrs. Haven's famous coffee room in School Street, which was the favorite resort of all the literary fellows in that city and Cambridge, and merchants with literacy sympathies, for many years, and where one was quite likely to meet any soon Longfellow, Lowell, Proscott, Agassiz, Sprague, and Fields.

A rather singular mistake was made at the Morgue recently, with the result that a man who was unknown and had neither friends nor home was given decent burial by a woman who had identified the body as that of her husband, while the husband, mourned as dead, is a patient in the Charity Hospital on Blackwell's Island.

Few sales of real estate at auction are scheduled for the present week. There are ten in foreclosure proceedings and one of suburban lots. Details of the sales are subjoined, all taking place at 111 Broadway, except to-morrow's:

While cyclones and hurricanes have been devastating the rest at the country during the past week, Brooklyn has suffered, one after the other, a series of political earthquakes. No hapless Charleston negro, praying in the blusterous dark for a chance to live overnight, has had a worse time of it or been so buffeted by the elements as "Boss" McLaughlin, trying to accomplish his task of recovery at Greenport.

SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Sept, 2 -- But a short time remains of the season of 1893, and, on the whole, it has been a prosperous one for the hotels here. Shelter Island has never known a gayer or more delightful Summer. More than ever it has become the popular yachting centre and the Mocca of fine people.

Edmond Pezon, the Paris Wombwell, has lost his collection of wild beasts by a fire which destroyed his menagerie at Royan, in the Department of the Charente-Inferioure yesterday. Full particulars of the affair ate to hand to-day. The fire broke out in the afternoon, and not only the menagerie, but all the booths and shows in the fair, which was being held at Royan, were destroyed.
Speaking of this abuse in the London "Queen," Mrs. Bedford Fenwick, whose career from probationer to Superintendent of a nurses' home permits her to do so with authority, says:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Much of the time of the House to-day was occupied in a discussion of the clause of the proposed rules fixing a quorum for business in Committee of the Whole at 100 members. This was the rule in the Fifty-first Congress, when Mr. Reed handled the gavel.

The trouble which led to an order being issued by Judge McGown of the City Court for James Oliver, the politician, to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt of court in refusing to appear at an examination in supplementary proceedings before Referee Waldorf H. Phillips, was explained yesterday by the ex-Senator's brother, Francis V.S. Oliver.

Beginning this morning and continuing all day to-morrow, westward-bound trains from tills city to Indianapolis will carry thrones of gray and grizzled men dressed in plain blue suits and wearing the simple bronze badge which denotes membership in the Grand Army of the Republic. With many of them will go wives and daughters to attend with, their husbands and fathers the annual encampment which opens to-morrow.

One of the moat active and earnest promoters of the university-extension movement, either in the New World or the Old is Miss Jessie D. Montgomery, a young woman whose name is often seen among the con tributors to some of the best-known English periodicals, and who is at present Honorary Secretary of the Exeter Centre, England.

WASHINGTON, Sept 2 -- A very important conference, in which it is understood that the President was greatly interested, was held to-day at the Treasury Department. It was quite out of the usual conference order and it was held with the view of shaping a policy on the much-discussed proposition to repeal the 10 per cent bank tax.

GOSSIP AND INCIDENT LAST WEEK -- "To the mountains!" is now the ory of fashionable society, and the tide of travel is now running from the seashore to the Berkshire Hills. When Mr. and Mrs. Anson Pheips Stokes start for the hills it is the proper time for all to do the same, and as a consequence the express companies doing business among the Berkshire Hills have their hands full.

NORMANDIE-BY-THE-SEA, N.J., Sept. 2 -- It is September and the end is not yet. It is near at hand, however, for Gen. Earle will probably close the hotel on the 15th. The departures have been numerous this week. The season has been a fair one, but not the equal of other years.

A pair of the black swans in Central Park have made a nest and in it two large pure white eggs were lying yesterday. The locality of the nest cannot be told, for there are many cologists and small boys who would risk a good deal to possess the egg of a black swan.

Dr. Mays will be surprised at the inference which some paragraphed has drawn from his paper in the August "Century" on "Breathing Movements as a Cure," which inference is to the effect that the wearing of corsets prevents consumption in women and is, therefore, a strong point on the side of those who wish to and do wear these articles of clothing.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 2 -- The Pequot House will close about the 20th, and at the same time the other resorts will haul down their flags and the hotel men hie themselves to their city homes after a fairly profitable season. None of them hereabout seems to have made much money, but all appear to be satisfied.

A rattling good northwester favored the Larchmont yachtsmen yesterday, and as a result the Fall regatta was a big success. Larchmont luck has been proverbial this year, and bids fair to stick to the club to the end of the season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Hearings on the tariff will begin before the Ways and Means Committee of the House on Monday. Representative Harter of Ohio will open the hearing, speaking on agricultural implements and flour. On the same day a Bermuda delegation will talk on early vegetables, J.C.S. Davis of Philadelphia on oil cloth, and E.T. Gradsell of New-York on grapes.
BOSTON, Sept. 2 -- Negotiations are now pending which will mean a most important advance on the part of the Boston Art Students' Association.

M. Coppee adorns Ma present tales by pointing morals. Under the title "The Repayment" he holds up to view several cases in which the restoration of money that had been lost was hardly a source of pleasure to the receivers, and in another story called "The Cure for Unhappiness" shows the folly of seeking to acquire happiness from wealth in the midst of associations and dissipations to which one has previously been a stranger.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 2 -- The week has been the most enjoyable of the season. The presence of the Naval Reserves in the harbor has had much to do with the week's pleasures, and the reception to the officers of the New-Hampshire at the Glenada Hotel was an exceptionally brilliant affair.

Fifteen ambitions tennis players entered the tour nament of the Staten Island Athletic Club, which is a part of the Labor Day carnival, the finals being scheduled for Monday morning. Simpaon and Fish, the Chester Hill cand dates, failed to show up, but the other thirteen had a great time chasing the elusive ball yesterday afternoon.

Mrs. Ellen McGee of 371 Knickerbocker Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday morning in St. Catharine's Hospital from the effects of a beating inflicted a week ago by her husband Patrick. Patrick was arrested by order of Coroner Creamer, and locked up in the Twentieth Precinct Station on a charge of homicide to await the inquest.

The Hoboken Cricket Club gained a very easy victory over the team of the steamship Germanic yesterday, when the sailors suffered a defeat by 118 runs after a very one-aided game. H. Smithson hit hard for his inning of 49 for Hoboken, and was well backed up by good contributions from D.C. Harvey, W. Bissett, and W.H. Denzell, all of whom showed good form at the bat.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued on Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $5,170,150. The banks now hold $1,567,525 less than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $3,438,100, an increase in specie of $3,929,600, an increase in legal tenders of $2,123,100, an increase in deposits of $3,530,200, and an increase in circulation of $131,- 400.

Puffer, Goff, and Conneff, the well-known athletes, had quite a controversy yesterday over THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S medal offered for the beat individual performance at the World's Fair sports to be held in Chicago next week. Puffer says that he will break all records over the hurdles and surely carry off the prize. Goff has been training very faithfully, and he, too, feels like a winner.

Secretary CARLISLE has found that some of his new appointees quite misunderstand the nature of the duties they were selected to perform. They have devoted an undue amount of time and energy to what may be generally described as "patronage," sending to the Secretary elaborate lists of promotions, removals, and appointments, some of which having been inadvertently allowed to pass, have had to be revoked.

Mrs. Rose Baum, who lies critically ill in the New-York Hospital, says she was sent to New-York by the officers of the Massachusetts Asylum for the Insane and set adrift. Mrs. Baum is a married woman, forty years old, and her home is in Boston.
WASHINGTON, Sept 3 -- Secretary Lamont has decided not to recommend the appointment of any of the present applicants for the office of Assistant Secretary of War, now filled by Gen. Lewis A. Grant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- It is expected that before the week shall he over the President will appoint Mr. William B. Hornblower of the firm of Hornblower. Byrne Taylor of New-York to he Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States to succeed the late Justice Blatchford.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 2 -- There has been a noticeable improvement in the condition of the local money market during the past week. The minimum rate of discount to regular customers still remains 7 cent, but some of the banks are now so situated as to be able to take advantage of the excellent offerings of outside paper, which are freely made at 10 to 12 cent.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept 3 -- The Republicans of this county are trying a new canons plan this Fall, and from present indications are likely to have exceptionally good results from it. For the last two years the common convention and primary system has obtained, except that all wards of the city and townships or the county have had equal voice in convention without regard to the support given the ticket.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Columbus Hall in the Memorial Art Palace was crowded to-night at the final meeting of the Labor Congress.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 3 -- At James A. Bradley's beach meeting this evening the preachers used the deck of the wrecked schooner Mary F. Kelly as a pulpit. The audience gathered around the schooner, she being high and dry, as the tide was low. An original song by Founder Bradley was sung.

CONEY ISLAND, Sept. 3 -- There was ample evidence here to-day that the highest tide of prosperity this season had been reached. From now on the crowds of visitors to Coney Island will continue to grow less and less, until the first blast of cold weather drives every one away except the Chief and his faithful followers.

The foreign exchange market has been quiet. Posted rates for sterling were $4.82 1/2 for sixty-day bills and $4.87 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.82 @ $4.82 1/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.86 @ $4.86 1/4 for demand, $4.87 @ $4.87 1/4 for cable transfers, and $4.81 1/4 @ $4.81 1/2 for commercial.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Sept. 3 -- When the west-bound San Francisco train arrived at 11 o'clock this morning, several hours late, it was learned that it had been stopped by robbers at Mound Valley, Kan., a small town near Oswego, Kan., and that the express messenger had been killed and the passengers compelled to part with what valuables they had.

Some of the people who closed their houses early in the Summer to spend the hot months in the country are returning to find their homes have been robbed in their absence. Several cases have been reported to the police. In the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday two culprits were held for trial upon charges of breaking into houses.

PITTSBURG, Sept 2 -- The local situation, both as to money and stocks, was vastly improved this week. In keeping with this bankers are disposed to extend accommodations, and all usually active shares have appreciated more or less.

The lease of the Casino to George Lederer and Thomas Canary, which is awaiting the consent of the Supreme Court as well as the signatures of the interested parties, is the very latest outcome of the long-standing and, at times, amusing warfare between the Aronson brothers on the one hand and most of the discontented stockholders in that concern on the other.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept 3 -- Insurance Superintendent S.B. Snider has just returned from the Atlantic States, where, ostensibly, he has been engaged in business connected with his department. Mr. Snider is one of the inner circle controlling the Populists and has a voice in the management of that party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- One sequel to the great hurricane will be an effort to have the Government furnish weather predictions for mariners, as it does now for farmers and business men. To this end the attention of Congress will probably be called to the work of the Hydrographic Bureau of the Navy Department in furnishing information to seafaring men concerning coming storms.

To-day is the twenty-third anniversary of the downfall of the Second Empire in France and the proclamation of a provisional Government which preceded the formal establishment of the republic. Twenty-three years is not a long time in the life of a nation, but it is quite long enough to embrace radical changes in political systems and even in political habits, which are much more slowly changed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Much interest will be taken in the vote to be urged tomorrow by Mr. Voorhees in the Senate on his motion to begin the daily sessions at 11 o'clock from Tuesday.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Outside of the annual town elections, which will take place Oct. 2, political issues in Connecticut are at a practical standstill. The town meetings, however, will be of considerable interest this year, because the boards for the admission of new voters will be chosen in the cities, with the exception of New-Haven and Bridgeport.

TRIESTE, Sept. 3 -- Trieste newspapers of Saturday assert that a Miss Leal, a young Scotch-woman who has recently been playing at the Monte Carlo gaming tables, had remarkable luck for several days, which culminated in the breaking of the bank. She is said to have won L60,000 in one hour.
Auguste Bartholdf, the famous French sculptor to whom the American people are indebted for the Statue of Liberty, arrived in this city yesterday on La Champagne. He was accompanied by his wife.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept 3 -- Bishop O'Farrell dedicated the new Greek Catholic church in that part of Trenton known as Chambersburg this morning. This is the first church of the kind in Trenton and cost $10,000. There was a street parade of foreign societies before the service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- "I cannot say," said Mr. Doekery, (Dem., Mo.,) "whether or not the paralysin which has overtaken the business interests of the country will result in an actual Treasury deficiency. It will depend upon the length of its continuance. It is already operated to reduce receipts of the Government to a very marked degree, and, it continued, will exhaust the entire available surplus.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 3 -- Many New-Jersey people are either mixed in their birthday dates or the State has a climate particularly conductive to longevity. The newspapers of New Jersey are seeking to settle the controversy at to the oldest twins in the State. There have been six contestants and the matter is still open.

At a meeting of the Drivers' Benevolent and Protective Association held yesterday afternoon in Washington Hall, Avenue A and Fourteenth Street, which was attended by delegates from nine stables connected with the Street Cleaning Department, resolutions were adopted thanking Commissioner Andrews for the consideration shown to the committee that waited on him a few days ago in reference to the drivers recently suspended.

Gyanendra Nath Chakravarti, the Brahmin who is on his way to attend the Congress of Religions at the World's Fair, delivered a lecture last evening before the Aryan Theosophical Society at 148 Madison Avenue. W.Q. Judge presided. Mrs. Annie Besant, who was expected to address the meeting, was not present.
CINCINNATI, Sept 3 -- What will prove, perhaps the most disastrous streetcar accident ever recorded took place in this city this evening at 7 o'clock.

The death of Dr. Graves ends one of the most remarkable murder cases on record. For over two years it has been before the public, and at times whole columns have been printed about it every day throughout the United States.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 3 -- S.S. Snider, Superintendent of Insurance, has become sponsor for a novel scheme, whether original or not he does not say. It is a vast pension plan, by which the Government is to insure every man, woman, and child in the Nation on the endowment feature of some of the the insurance companies.

J.J. Vail, the cashier of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn, is expected to return to his home, 245 Jefferson Avenue, to-day. Since leaving Brooklyn last Tuesday, Mr. Vail has been in Saratoga. Ho fled to escape the excitement of the failure.

-- A Canadian teacher of Indians in the fst. Northwest, in the Dominion Government service, realizing that it is not food for man to be alone, journeyed down to anon civilization as he could find in Winnipeg, not long ago, in anxious quest for a wife, and with but six days available for the search. First he communicated with the police, but they protested they could not aid him.

Mr. George J. Kraus, sole proprietor and manager of the Imperial Music Hall, thinks that there are many tangled notions concerning the relative merits of some people who flit about the stage, and he proposes to sever the Gordian knot at one fell swoop. Should this idea of Mr. Kraus's meet with popular approval, the stage will be littered with fallen idols.

ORANGE, Sept 3 -- The career of the ill-fated Orange Wheelmen, which two years ago was one of the most prosperous and enthusiastic cycling clubs in New-Jersey, will be ended on Tuesday, Sept. 12, when their clubhouse will be sold by the Sheriff under foreclosure of a mortgage held by the Orange Building and Loan Association.

NEW-YORK, MONDAY, Sept. 4 -- A.M. The hopefulness displayed in Stock Exchange circles was borne out by substantial gains in prices last week, and the strength which began to display itself as soon as the vote in the House on the Silver bill became known was reinforced later on by other favorable developments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Further inquiry as to the details of the conference yesterday at the Treasury supports the account given in THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning as to the numbers and persons present at the conference and as to its general purpose.

-- President Richard G. Betts of the Manhattan Bicycle Club arrived yesterday morning from a European wheeling tour alter an absence of six weeks. He spent a month on the Continent, accompanied by Isaac B. Potter, and during that time the wheeled through the greater part of France, Switzerland, and Germany, and a portion of Belgium.

The Staten Island Athletic Club has been active in the field of aquatic sport for fifteen years, and the walls of the clubhouse at West New-Brighton are hung with nearly twoscore trophies won by the oarsmen of the club. The boathouse, which is here shown, is a pretty two-story frame structure, on the banks of the Kill Von Kull, directly in front of the clubhouse.

The passage of the Home Rule bill in the British House of Commons was the general topic of conversation yesterday among the Irish-American residents of this city and visitors who were interested in the subject. The passage of the bill was regarded by Irish-Americans as the greatest victory the Irish people had ever achieved in their straggle for independence.
The designs of the two British battle ships Majestic and Magnificent readied this city by Saturday's foreign mail.

At Central Park Saturday the Harlem Cricket Club played a rather peculiar game with the South Brooklyns, whom they easily defeated by an inning and 47 runs, in the South Brooklyns' second attempt at the bat the eleven men were disposed of for a total of 7 runs, the smallest score ever made in a league match in New-York, while F.J. Laughlin had the extraordinary bowling analysis of 8 wickets for 2 runs.

A fire was discovered shortly before 11 o'clock last night on the third floor of the five-story brick building 835 Broadway, on the southwest corner of Thirteenth Street, in the studio occupied jointly by A.T. Millar and Malcolm and Walter Douglass. The fire was discovered by Mrs. Brennan, wife of J. Brennan, fashion publisher, who has an office and studio on the fourth floor of the building.

With the present imperfect knowledge of what may have been the plan for new currency discussed in Washington on Saturday, as reported in our dispatches yesterday morning, it would be useless to comment on the proposition outlined. But it is always timely to refer to general principles that experience has amply proved must be strictly followed if we are to have a sound banking currency.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 3 -- The story of the West Indian hurricane which one week ago swept over the South Carolina and Georgia coasts probably has been as fully told as it ever will be to the outside world. Here, however, it cannot for a long time be passed by as a matter of history, for echoes of the sorrow it brought and suggestions of the destruction that marked its path will come daily.

The Lenox Tennis Club began its Fall tennis tournament on Saturday afternoon at the courts on St. Nicholas Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-second and One Hundred and Twenty-third Streets. There was a good entry list, and the courts and weather were favorable for sharp play.

The Atlas Line steamship Alvo, which sailed from this port for Gonaives, Haiti, Aug. 16, is still on the list of missing ships. The Athos of the same line, which sailed for Gonaives Aug. 28, was expected to bring news of the overdue Alvo. The Athos arrived yesterday, but her officers had heard nothing of the Alvo and could throw no light on her disappearance.
Loie Fuller changed her mind yesterday and will appear at the Standard Theatre to-night, notwithstanding her previous declarations to the contrary.

At Manhattan Field this afternoon J.W. Schofield, the champion cyclist of England, will make his first appearance in this city in a race against Harry Wheeler and the other riders of the National Cycling Association. The races will begin promptly at 2:30, so that the spectators can witness the afternoon ball game on the Polo Grounds. The entries are as follows:

The protest entered by Mr. PURROY against the adoption of any plan for the new City Hall that provides for the retention of the Court House may seem to be belated. But it is only fair to remember that Mr. PURROY took the same ground at the earliest opportunity and before the other Commissioners had committed themselves and the city.

In a report submitted to Secretary CARLISLE, Mr. WORTHINGTON C. FORD, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, sets forth the history of the disgraceful blunders that caused the actual value of our imports in the year ending on June 30 last to be increased by at least $75,000,000 in the official publications of the Government.

Several points in this second volume of Prof. Graetz's history will intarest most those whose belief is at variance with, that of the Jews, and one of these is the author's study of the origin of Christianity. Without discussing the arguments which have been advanced on either side for the last 1,800 years, we wish only to present as clearly as possible the one espoused by the author.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 3 -- Charity Commissioner Francis Nolan of Brooklyn was accidentally killed on the Lake Shore Railroad last night.

BERLIN, Sept. 3 -- M. Herbette, French Ambassador to Germany, is still absent from his post, and Count Muenster has left the German Embassy in Paris to pass some time at his country seat. Derneburg, in Hanover, his excuse being that he needs rest. Signor Ressmann, Italian Ambassador to France, started for Monza on Thursday.

MORICHES, L.I., Sept. 3 -- There is a misunderstanding between John W. Masury, the millionaire paint manufacturer of Brooklyn, and the Regatta Committee of the Great South Bay Yacht Club, Messrs. Frederick O. Bliss, Arthur Doming, Edward Blunt, and Alden S. Swan.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 3 -- The peace and quiet that characterizes the usual Indianapolis Sabbath were somewhat ruthlessly disturbed to-day as the result of the incoming of veterans in advance of the National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, which opens tomorrow.

At this national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, which will open in Indianapolis to-day, Lafayette Post No. 140 of this city will introduce resolutions recommending the introduction in public and private schools and colleges of a system of military training and instruction.

If any vague idea existed that in some way the decision of the Paris tribunal would, when announced, very greatly lighten the task of policing the seal regions, it must already have been dispelled. The patrol, as far as can he judged, will be extended rather than contracted, since both the area in which pelagic sealing is at times prohibited becomes greater and the prohibitory season begins earlier.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 3 -- Dr. T. Thacher Graves, alleged to be the poisoner of Mrs. Josephine Barnaby of Providence, committed suicide in his cell in the county jail last night, presumably by taking poison. He was found stiff and cold at 9 o'clock this morning. On his person was the following letter:

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union, it was announced that the Labor Day parade would start at 10 o'clock this morning from Cooper Institute and march to Broadway, to Waverley Place, to Fifth Avenue, through Washington Square to Fourth Street, to Broadway, down Broadway to City Hall Park, and across the park, where the paraders will be reviewed.

WASHINGTON, Sept 4. -- Yang Yu, the new Chinese Minister, whose rank in his own country is so high that it is only four degrees below that of the Emperor of the Celestial Kingdom himself, presented his credentials to the President to-day.

There have been published recently two interviews concerning glass and the tariff, both of the persons interviewed being manufacturers of glass or glassware. One of them is Col. A.L. CONGER, formerly Chairman of the Ohio Republican Committee and now President of one of the companies included in the powerful combination of plate-glass manufacturers.
"It is an admixture of fact with, a lot or gross nonsense and vituperation." said Manager Daniel Frohman of the Lyceum Theatre to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday afternoon.

Labor's annual holiday was observed yesterday in this city and its vicinity, the principal feature of the observance being the parades. In this city the parade was not as large as that of last year, not more than 4,000 men being in line. It was, however, an orderly, decent-appearing procession, and there was considerable enthusiasm along the line of march.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 4 -- The Tybee Islands and the entrance to the Savannah River were badly wrecked by the big storm. There is little left of the famous Summer resort for Georgia people except two hotels. These are the Hotel Tybee and the Naylor House.

Mr. Hammerstein's popular and well-appointed theatre on West One Hundred and Twentyfifth Street, the Harlem Opera House, was opened for the season last night. The play was "Mavourneen," a now familiar Irish romantic drama, skillfully put together by George Jessup and Horace Townsend, and presented with elaborate pictorial accessories by Mr. Piton's company, Mr. Chauneey Olcott, the singing comedian, being the star.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The Red Bank cyclers demonstrated to about 3,500 people to-day that they know how to conduct a road meet. Upper Broad Street was the scene of the contests, and the road was lined with spectators all along the course. The crowd, on the whole, was orderly, and only one race was interfered with. There were one or two minor accidents, but no one was seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The Pan-American Medical Congress, the greatest gathering of medical men ever held in this country, will begin its sessions in this city to-morrow and continue them until Friday. The congress is an outgrowth of a movement which had its inception at the meeting of the American Medical Association in Washington in May, 1891, and took shape in a series of resolutions introduced by Dr. Charles A.L. Reed of Cincinnati.

The Belmont Cricket Club of Philadelphia sent over a team yesterday to this city to show the metropolitan players a thing or two about handling the willow, and they succeeded in rolling up a big total and gaining a victory by 104 runs.

There has been quite a spurt in the old Scotch game of golf this season. At Newport a series of games has been played. An attempt to get fashion's sanction at the Summer resort was not successful. Society people went out to look at the game, but it was too dull for them. On Long Island a few enthusiasts have started out in the morning and played over a few miles frequently.

METZ, Sept. 4. -- The review of the Sixteenth Army Corps, in the presence of the Bavarian and Hohenzollern Princes, the King of Saxony, the Prince of Naples, the Grand Dukes of Baden and Saxe-Weimar, many Generals, and the imperial suite, was held this morning on the great plain near this city.

MADRID, Sept. 4. -- The Cabinet held a meeting to-day to discuss Cuban affairs. It is stated that further assistance will be extended to the Banco Espanol of Havana, and that the bank will be authorized to negotiate drafts on account of the home Treasury. It is hoped that this measure will tide the bank over its difficulties.

The American steamer Pantogoet, formerly the United States revenue cutter Bibb, arrived in this port Saturday. The Pantogoet encountered the blow of Sunday, night off the Nantucket Shoals. In the blow of Wednesday week the Pantogoet was caught off the New-England coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- There is no longer any secret made of the fact that the President was present at the conference described in THE NEW-YORK TIMES on Sunday, and that it was participated in by the Speaker and the Secretary of the Treasury.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 4. -- This is a year of unusual political honors in Iowa. Horace Boies has been nominated by acclamation for a third term as Governor by the Democrats, and the Republican candidate, Frank D. Jackson, was selected, without solicitation, when he was a thousand miles away.
Labor Day in Brooklyn was celebrated by the labor organizations with their usual enthusiasm, although there were not so many paraders as upon former occasions.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 4. -- William H. Smyth, a man said to be a son of Recorder Smyth of New-York City, committed suicide by shooting himself in Lincoln Park, this city, at 9 o'clock Saturday evening.

The Ianthe Canoe Club of Newark, N.J.,held its ninth annual regatta yesterday afternoon on the Passaic River, in front of its clubhouse at Woodside. It was by far the most successful canoe regatta of the season in these waters. The river resemble the Thames at a Henley regatta, for it was crowded the entire length of the course with, pleasure craft.

WASHINGTON, Sept 4. -- A bill Has been prepared, and will be introduced into the Senate and House simultaneously, granting a disability pension to Government employes, and providing compensation for injuries received in the line of duty. The latter item of the measure grew out of the late Ford's Theatre disaster, which directed attention to the whole subject.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 4. -- Every department of the Carnegie steel plant at Homestead was started this morning, giving employment to about 2,000 men. About 500 are yet idle. They also will be provided with work within a few days.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4. -- Of the many Labor Day celebrations in this vicinity to-day none possessed half as much attraction for a holiday crowd as did the State Fair at Waverly. Fifteen thousand people crowded the grounds, The opening day was, by long odds, the most successful in the history of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society, under whose auspices the affair is yearly held.
On Conservatory Lake, in Central Park, men and boys ate allowed to sail their small model boats. A collision took place there yesterday, and two of the finest boats sank.

The Arlington Canoe Club held its sixth annual regatta yesterday morning. The coarse for the paddling races was a hall mile with a turn, finishing in front of the clubhouse. There were no sailing races. The Ianthe Canoe Club of Newark carried off the greatest number of prizes, winning five of the eight events, while the Rutherford Canoe Club captured the remaining three.
The Lenox Tennis Club performed a miracle yesterday afternoon. Its tennis tournament for men's singles was completed on schedule time, something hitherto unknown in tennis annals.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 4. -- One boy was shot and killed and another was dangerously wounded by William Barrett, an infuriated dairy farmer, who had been goaded into a frenzy by a crowd of boys who threw stones at him and his cattle at his farm in Blissville this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Sept 4. -- The tariff hearing projected by the Ways and Means Committee of the House, which promises to develop into a most interesting and sweeping inquiry was began to-day.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept 4. -- The annual communication of the Grand Castle of the Knights of the Golden Eagle of New-Jersey was held here to-day. There were 200 members of the Grand Castle present. They were welcomed by Mayor Ten Broock and the Rev. S. Edward Young.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4. -- A bold attempt to flaunt the red flag as an adjunct to today's Labor Day demonstration in this city was frustrated by the action of Capt. Glori and the Fourth Precinct police.

No news has been received of the steamship Alvo. Capt. Low of the Athos believes she is lost. The agents of the Atlas Steamship Line, who have until now remained sanguine as to her eventually turning up, are beginning to lose hope. They still maintain the probability that she has broken her machinery and drifted to a port with which there is no telegraphic communication, but this is the only hope they have.

BROOKLYN GOSSIP. -- The Ridge Club, which was organized as a rival of the Crescent Athletic Club, and to dig in the ribs some of the woman haters in the Bay Ridge Clubhouse, will doubtless be a great success. During the Summer months the interest in the new club has not lessened, and the progressive and younger sets in Brooklyn society are willing to assume the expense of a fine clubhouse.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 4.-- The New-Jersey Athletic Club's Labor Day carnival at Bayonne drew an attendance of nearly 7,000 people, and was a success for the prosperous organization. James E. Sullivan, Vice President of the club and Chairman of the Athletic Committee, received the lion's share of the credit from athletes and the public. There were plenty of competitors and close finishes, with one or two exceptions.

The first and most obvious objection to the proposition to coin the seigniorage arising from the Treasury purchases of silver bullion is that it would be an attempt to realize a profit on an uncompleted transaction that at present does not show a profit, but on the contrary a large loss, which in all human probability will never be retrieved.

England's champion bicycle rider made his first appearance before New-York spectators at the contests of the National Cycling Association at Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon. He only started in two races, the one mile open and the consolation.

LONDON, Sept 4. -- In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Gladstone moved a resolution to give the Government the whole time of the House for the remainder of the session, to suspend the 12 o'clock rule, and to appoint Saturday sittings. He announced that the Government only hoped to be able to deal with the Employers' Liability and Parish Councils' bills at the Autumn session.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 4. -- The most charming spectacle seen in Stookbridge this season was the annual torchlight parade through the Ice Glen. The Committee of Ar. rangements consisted of Edward B. Owen and Courtland Van Rensselaer. The company of seventy-five assembled in front of the old Stockbridge House at 7:30, dressed in fancy costumes.

The remarks of THE TIMES yesterday morning, taking occasion of the twenty-third anniversary of the downfall of the French Empire, upon the prospects of the French Republic receive a very emphatic confirmation in the dispatches announcing the results of the supplementary elections. In these supplementary elections the point of view of the intelligent voter is somewhat altered.

Over 12,000 persons saw two games of ball on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The first was lost by the most stupid kind of errors after the Giants had outbatted their opponents 2 to 1. The second was won by the smallest margin, although the local players mode 16 hits to their opponents' 11.
LONDON, Sept. 4. -- The markets to-day were strong but dull, despite unfavorable news about cholera and the continuance of the coal strike.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Six hundred Democrats, composing the David Barry Association from the Twentieth Assembly District, New-York, took possession of Donnelly's Boulevard Park to-day, ate up everything in sight, and then ran races, talked politics, played baseball and football, talked more politics, wound up with a prodigious clambake, and went back to New-York.
The Circulo Italiano Colombo of the Sixth Ward, Brooklyn, is rent by dissensions, and two prominent members are said to be breathing deadly vengeance one against the other.

The three offices of Bernhard Weinborger, banker, broker, and steamship passage agent, 39 Henry Street, 382 Grand Street, and 342 East Houston Street, were closed all day yesterday, and when this fact became known to the Hebrew depositors, there was a rush to the offices.
A well-attended meeting of depositors of the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn was held last night at Haviland Hall, Classon Avenue, near Greene Avenue, that city.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 4. -- Two exciting and close races, decided only by a few feet, were the distinguishing features of the Fall regatta of the New England Amateur Rowing Association on the Charles River this afternoon. The races were witnessed by an enormous crowd, which kept increasing as the afternoon wore off. The water was rather rough, and bothered several of the crews and scullers.

The friends about town of Charles F. Bates were startled when they read in the papers yesterday morning the notice of Mr. Bates's marriage to Miss Annette F. McGrath on July 17, 1890, at Newport. All day Mr. Bates's office was constantly visited by inquisitive friends. To every inquiry he answered firmly that he still remains a happy bachelor.

In connection With the efforts to-perfect the ammunition for the new Krag-Jorgenson gun, shortly to be issued to the tropps of the United States, the recent results obtained by Prof. Hebler of Zurich, Switzerland, with tubular bullets have not passed unnoticed.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 4. -- The annual picnic of the Central Labor Union was held here to-day and was attended by nearly 10,000 persons. The chief interest centered in the bicycle races, for which prizes amounting in value to over $500 were offered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- While Mr. Voorhees did not to-day offer his resolution, of which he gave notice on Saturday, for the beginning of daily sessions at 11 o'olook instead of 12 o'clock, as has been the practice heretofore, he succeeded in getting a vote that was interesting.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The ladles' day regatta of the Shelter Island Yacht Club was sailed under favorable circumstances. The breeze was good, the weather was charming, and the time made in the different classes beats all previous records made this Summer.
New Order as to Pension Rates. WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- Commissioner Lockren of the Pension Office has issued the following order:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept 4. -- A discovery of what has all the appearance of a double murder and may prove to be a triple assassination has just been made at Burlingham, at the foot of the Shawangunk Mountains.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 4. -- Over 4,000 people assembled at Charter Oak Park this afternoon to witness the first day's bicycle races under the management of the Hartford Wheel Club. The world's record for the quarter-mile flying start was broken twice, once by W.W. Windle, who lowered it from 0:27 to 0:26 3/4, and again an hour later by H. Tyler who made it in 0:26 4.5.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 4. -- The eighth annual convention of the National Association of Naval Veterans was opened at Indianapolis today. Rear Admiral Osborne of New-York called the convention to order. All of the officers answered to the roll-call save Fleet Paymaster Alex. G. Fortier of Buffalo, against whose administration of the finances of the organization charges have been preferred.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 4. -- Charleston wishes to announce to the world that she is ready for business again. A sufficient numof wharves have been repaired to accommodate all ships in port, and railroads are running trains on regular schedules. Telegraph communication has been restored to all parts of the country.
Honors were evenly divided at Eastern Park yesterday. In the morning game the Clevelands lost by a single run, but in the afternoon they won with plenty to spare.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- New-York celebrated her day at the fair to-day. As was to be expected from the greatest State in the Union, the occasion was marked by brilliancy.

The steamship City of Birmingham, which arrived from Charleston yesterday, had on board twenty-two of the crew of the wrecked City of Savannah. Immediately after landing the men went to the pier of the Fall River Line, where they took passage on the Puritan for Boston.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- The retirement of Paymaster Barton gives the President a vacancy in the Pay Corps to fill from civil life, and should the findings of the Sullivan Court be approved by the Secretary, he will have another. Another vacancy will also be created upon the final disposition of Pay Inspector Stevenson's case.

Under the teaching of tragic experience railroad managers have learned that at a danger point the best man is not so trustworthy a safeguard as a good automatic machine. This was very clearly demonstrated in the accident on the Harlem Road the other day. An operator was telegraphed to tell the conductor of a train to go to a certain station and there await another train.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound east -- Steam yachts Viking, Mr. H.A. Hutchins; Isolene, Mr. John H. Flagler; Ortenta, Mr. E.B. Ladew; Allegro, Col. S. V.R. Cruger, Schooner yachts Enigma, Mr. George E. Chisholm, and Kittle, Mr. J.M. Ward, Sloop yacht Harriet, Mr. E.J. Graecon.

Patrick McMahon, thirty-six years old, who was employed as a packer in the shoe-blacking factory of Frank Miller, in West Twenty-sixth Street, died late Sunday night at Bellevue Hospital from a fractured skull and interoranial hemorrhage, the result of an assault committed upon him by three men at Ninth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street late Saturday night.

The Staten Island Athletic Club celebrated Labor Day yesterday with a carnival of amateur sports that was continued throughout the day and was continued in the evening by the club members and their friends. There was a good attendance.

The feature of the afternoon's racing was, of course, the exhibition given by Directum, the handsome black stallion from California, who won two races last week and made a record of 2:09 1/2 for himself in the third heat of his last race on Saturday.

Downing C. Lawrence's yard at the foot of Court Street, South Brooklyn, presented a busy scene all day yesterday. A big army of workmen was at work from early in the morning until late at night on the two cup defenders, the Jubilee and Colonia.

-- The efforts made by a committee in San Francisco to arrange a midwinter fair in that city having produced little effect, the work of raising subscriptions and getting promises of loans was made over some time ago to Herman Shainwald. After a month's trial the latter has resigned his post, stating that the Financial Committee originally in charge will be more likely to carry the business on to a success.

The final championship game of the season between the Morris Park and Manhattan Cricket Clubs took place yesterday at Morris Park, where from an early hour the two teams battled tor supremacy. Good form was diplayed on both sides, but at the conclusion of hostilities the Manhattans were proclaimed victors by a margin of 32 rune on the first inning.

FLUSHING, L.I., Sept. 5 -- The Great Neck Athletic Club, composed of wealthy citizens of Great Neck, L.I., held its first annual Fall games yesterday at Harley's race track. There was a large crowd present, who freely applauded the contestants.

NEW-YORK, TUESDAY, Sept. 5 -- P.M. The tendency of prices on the Stock Exchange was again upward to-day. At the opening the market was strong, and although a slight reaction soon developed ill some of the active shares, it was in turn succeeded by another advance. In the afternoon the strength of the market notably increased.

The country may well be grateful to Senator VOORHEES for his common sense in opposing the motion to adjourn early on Monday, "as a mark of respect for the labor organizations and the industrial interests of the Nation." He declared that the Senate, in the present situation of affairs, could contribute to the interests of labor in no other way so well as by attending to its own business.

Mr. COCKRELL was elected to the Senate as a Democrat from the Democratic State of Missouri. He is at present behaving like a Populist guerrilla. His attitude and intentions concerning the repeal bill are calculated to injure the Democratic Party and diminish its strength and credit with the people.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The President of the United States gave graceful welcome to the Pan-American Medical Congress, whose four days' sessions commenced in the national capital to-day. He was warmly greeted when introduced by Dr. Pepper, the Chairman of the congress. He looked well, moved with a firm step, and spoke in a clear, resonant voice.

At this season of the year the thoughts of women turn toward Fall and Winter clothing. B. Altman Co., the extensive dry goods dealers on Sixth Avenue, near Eighteenth Street, have received many of their importations of foreign Fall and Winter novelties. The display is rich and artistic, the assortments varied, and the quality of everything of the best.

The first of the series of races which is to decide which yacht will be selected to defend the America's Cup against Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie will be sailed to-morrow. The four yachts, the Vigilant, Jubilee, Colonia and Pilgrim, will receive their finishing touches to-day, and to-night will be riding at anchor, some off Bay Ridge and some off Stapleton, waiting for the great contest.

Patrolman Thomas Gleason of the Broadway Squad was killed at his post, Broadway and Tenth Street, last evening. He was run down by a cab driven by Patrick White. The hoofs of the horse crushed the policeman's skull and the wheels of the vehicle passed over his neck. White was arrested.
The English military tournament beginning Sept. 11 at Madison Square Garden will be a unique entertainment for New-York. It will continue for two weeks.

CHICAGO, Sept 5 -- On the Stock Exchange to-day West Chicago sold at 141 1 2 @ 146, North Chicago At 211 1 2, Lake Street "L" at 23, Calumet Canal at 47, Strawboard at 37, Street's at 22. Money. 7 cent. Bank clearings, $17,147,873. New-York exchange, 50c. discount.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 5 -- At the State Fair at Waverly the work of making the awards was commenced at 11 o'clock this morning.

-- The Hamilton Wheelmen of West Hoboken held their fourth annual New-Haven run last Monday. The start was made Saturday evening, and the club paraded through West Hoboken, union Hill, and Hoboken to the ferry. Passage was taken on the New-Haven boat, and they arrived in New-Haven early Sunday morning. Here they spent Sunday and were entertained by the local wheelmen.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- There was fair investment demand to-day for American bonds by the Continental and English buyers, and purchases made the market bare of securities, and with unwilling sellers caused sharp advances.

The Board of Electrical Control has been making its appointments and removals for some time without reference to the State Civil Service Commission, and now the latter commission, declaring that the board has been disregarding the law, has called upon the members of the board to explain their conduct.

The announcement yesterday that all the banks in Memphis, Tenn., had been notified by their New-York connections that they were prepared to ship all the money necessary to move the cotton crop caused comparatively little comment in the trade in this city.

The sympathetic reader of the account of the train robbery in Kansas must have been touched by one incident of the raid. "A terrified Kentuckian was compelled to turn over a gallon of old Robertson County whisky." It does not appear that he was compelled to turn over anything else, but was not this enough to touch a feeling heart?

We have referred heretofore to the failure of the leading Republican papers to publish the explanations given to the press by Commissioner LOCHREN of the Pension Bureau and Judge REYNOLDS, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, concerning the recent decisions relating to pensions granted under the law of 1890.
Through the recklessness of the NewYork pilot who took out the White Star Line's big freight steamer Runic yesterday, the United States steamer Ordnance came near being sent to the bottom.

William Emlen Roosevelt has been appointed receiver for the Metropolitan Improvement Company on the application of the Trustees to dissolve the corporation. It was organized June 15, 1883, with a capital stock of $350,000, which was afterward reduced to $17,500. The company was organized to build the hotels and restaurants on the corners of Broadway and Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets, forming a part of the Metropolitan Opera House.
Scores of interested listeners packed the rooms of the Theosophical Society in Madison Avenue last night to hear Mrs. Annie Besant and her associates.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- The great round-up of the Grind Circuit meetings of 1893 began at the Philadelphia Driving Park today. The track was in perfect condition, but a stiff southerly wind retarded test time somewhat. Joseph A. Wendroth, President of the association, officiated as starter, with Thomas B. Loyatt, John Malsinger, and William Henderaon as associates in the stand.

William A Pembrook of the wholesale dry goods firm of Sweetzer, Pembrook Co. of this city, died suddenly in his library at his home, 303 West Jersey Street, Elizabeth, N.J., yeaterday, while reading a morning newspaper.

Mrs. Cyrus W. Field, Jr. is to go into trade. In order to help to clear off the load of debt and dishonor heaped upon the honorable family name by Edwin Field, the brave young daughter-in-law has concluded to join her husband in the work he has undertaken of paying off all the obligations incurred by his wretched brother.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Secretary Lamont's return has been the signal for the renewal of reports that he is about to choose an Assistant Secretary of War in place of Gen. Grant, who has remained in the office since Mr. Elkins went out.

In the Trinity Building salesroom at 111 Broadway, yesterday, Mr. Peter F. Meyer sold, under, foreclesure, for $5,000, to Margie B. Lacy, executrix, the plaintiff in the action, 427 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, north side, 304.7 feet east of First Avenue, three-story stone-front dwelling, 16.8 by 100.11.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The following yachts passed here to-day: Bound East -- Steam yachts Acquilo. Mr. George A. Thayer; Helvetia, Mr. C. C D. Iselin; Orlenta. Mr. E.R. Ladew; Javelin. Mr. Charles R. Flint; schooner yacht Agnes, Mr. J. Norton Winslow.
A hearse containing the body of an infant was struck by a trolley car in Flatbush yesterday afternoon and the coffin was thrown into the street, the Iid broken off, and the infant's body exposed.

Paul Potter's task to make a serious play, with Richard B. Sheridan as the central figure, was one that might well have caused a more experienced playwright to tremble and pause. Presumably, everybody knows something about Sheridan. But the things that people know about him, all put together, would not make a good play.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The Doncaster September meeting opened to-day. The great Yorkshire Handicap plate of 1,300 sovereigns was won toy M.R. Lebandy's five-year-old Chesterfield, carrying 8 stone 10 pounds; Lord Bradford's Cuttiestone, carrying 6 stone, was second; J.H. Houldsworth's Bushey Park was third.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The House of Lords was filled to-day with members and visitors eager to hear the debate on the Home-Rule bill opened. Although the Conservative whips will not muster their fall force before the evening of the final division, the opposition had in attendance to-day five members to every one on the Liberal side.

With Figaro the only favorite to win the talent had a bad day's set-to with the bookmakers at Sheepshead Bay yesterday. The day at the tract was delightful, the track lightning fast, and the contests close and exciting. Tom Harding, from Jockey, Owner, and Trainer McCafferty's stable, captured the opening event, over the Futurity course, beating Chesspeake, the favorite, easily.

During the three days' holiday one noted visitor in New-York whose movements have been closely followed and eagerly chronicled took occasion to depart, and the whole city feels inclined to join in the message said to have been sent to a prominent railroad President some time ago: "Don't return and all will be forgiven." This was the premium on currency.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 5 -- The organization of the Lake Superior Consolidated Iron Mines, a corporation which will have much the same relation to the Bessemer iron ore trade of America that the Standard Oil has to their trade, was completed to-day.

-- An order from Col. Hain, Second Vice President and General Manager of the elevated railroad system in this city, restored to employment yesterday a large number of trainmen and shop hands who had been laid off early in the Summer. It la customary with the Manhattan company to discontinue some of its trains and to ran its repair shops on half force during the months of July and August.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The murders at Burlingham continue to be a mystery. Mrs. Halliday, suspected of killing the two women, has become so violent that handcuffs had to be applied. She tore her dress in strips and attempted to undress herself. Her talk is incoherent, and she is either insane or feigns insanity, as she did when in prison before.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Mr. Voorhees will call up to-morrow his resolution for daily meetings of the Senate at 11 o'clock. He is confident that there is a sufficient number of Senators in favor of the resolution to secure its adoption. The silver Senators are naturally opposed to it and will fight it. Their main dependence is in long-winded speeches, and the lengthening of the session each day would operate to their disadvantage.
CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 6 -- The popularity of harness racing in Chicago was well attested by the good crowd that turned out to see the trotters at Washington Park.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 5 -- The will of the late Col. Richard T. Auchmuty of New-York and Lenox, filed in the Probate Court to-day, contains no public bequests.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The first day's session of the convention of the New-York State Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association ended in a scene of disorder this evening. The fight over the Presidency between Morris Tekulsky, who wished to succeed himself, and B.K. Murphy, the present Financial Secretary, has become so hot that the delegates lost their heads, and pandemonium reigned in the convention.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 5 -- Iowa Prohibi- tionists to the actual number of 247, from fiftyfour different counties, came to Des Moines today with their war paint on. The convention was larger than it was expected to be by its enemies, and fully as large as its friends anticipated, A largo number of Republicans were in it, and so were the old-time third party Prohibitionists.

Louis V. Booraem of the law firm of Booraem, Hamilton, Beckett Ransom, 160 Broadway, was yesterday appointed receiver for the Moffett, Hodgkins Clarke Company, contractors, by Vice Chancellor Van Vleet, sitting in Jersey City. His bonds were fixed at $20,000.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 5 -- Judge Moon, in his charge to the Grand Jury yesterday, created a sensation by declaring that progressive euchre was gambling. He said: "Not only is gambling carried on in regular gambling resorts, but people of high standing and respectability gamble. They may not put down money, but they set an example for others in playing for prizes and awards.

The fates seem to have conspired, against the Eldorado Amusement Company. A receiver was yesterday appointed for the company by Vice Chancellor Van Fleet of New-Jersey, upon the application of creditors. The company wound up its affairs this season, as did its predecessor, the Palisade Amusement Company, in 1892, out of pocket and under the eagle eyes of a receiver.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Sept. 5 -- Coroner Meiners, assisted by Drs. Barry and Hinkson, held an autopsy upon the body of John Egan, the ten-year-old boy who was shot and killed yesterday by William Barrett, the infuriated Blissville dairy farmer. They found the boy's lungs, nasal cavity, and intestines had been perforated by the buckshot and veins and arteries inside his body torn, causing death by internal hemorrhage and shock.

Mr. H.N. Paul. President of the Pennsylvania Company for the Insurance of Lives and Granting Annuities, the Trustee of Reading's general and income mortgages, published a statement in the New-York and Philadelphia newspapers on June 16, in which he said, among other things:

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- The market opened strong and continued steady all day, closing strong and at about the highest. Atchison was held strongly, making a gain of 1 3 4. Boston and Montana Copper was strong, making a gain of 1 1 4. General Electric was also well held and sold at 47 1 2, closing at a plight concession from the highest.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- A New-York sailing party had a terrible experience off the coast here Sunday night. There were two women and four men in the party. For eight hours they clung to an overturned sailboat, which drifted about on the dark waters.

Benjamin Gambrill, forty-eight years old, said to have been a cotton broker, with an office at 18 Broadway, shot himself at his residence, 356 Mott Avenue, yesterday morning. He died after being taken to the Harlem Hospital.

Currency is finding its way back into the bank vaults with a celerity that surprises some of the bankers. There is no longer a premium on bills, and the money brokers in Wall Street admitted yesterday that there was no longer any profit in the handling of currency.

The committee of five which was appointed at Monday night's meeting of the depositors of the suspended Commercial Bank of Brooklyn called on Receiver William N. Dykmau yesterday and tried to find out something about the actual condition of the institution and the chances for resumption.
ROME, Sept. 5 -- The Pope will publish shortly a third edition of his Latin poems, entitled "Leonis PP XIII. Carmina et Inscriptiones." Two short poems not before published will appear in the volume.

Miss Bertha Welby is ordinarily the most amiable of women. About her only failings are a tendency to sarcasm and the ability to work herself into a high state of enthusiasm. Just at present she is both sarcastic and enthusiastic.

William Easton, managing director of Tattersalls. Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, has announced that there will be a great combination sale of thoroughbreds, trotters, and harness horses during the meeting of the Fair Association, beginning Oct. 2, when thoroughbreds from some of the largest breeding farms will be brought under the hammer.

Judging by the long lines at the ticket office and the slow-moving crowd that blocked the gates of the ticket takers at Niblo's last evening, all of German New-York, and a not inconsequential portion of the English element had decided to welcome hack the midget actors whose previous visits to the city earned for them a reputation many, if not most, of their bettergrown rivals have reason to envy.

To-day the first trial race will be sailed. The four big cutters that have been built to try to keep the famous old America's Cup in this country are to race together in order to determine which is the best all around boat, and which shall have th honor and responsibility of defending the cup against the Valkyrie.

Since David J. Mackey and his friends obtained control of the prosperous Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad a few months ago. there has been an earnest disposition manifested by certain Western stockholders to get the property out of Mr. MacKey's hands. The assertion has been broadly made that he has or is about to make use of the revenues of the Evansville and Terre Haute to help along other roads in which he is interested.

-- No more newspaper or hotel party excursions are to be run over the Western roads under a blanket rate covering the whole expenses of the trip. The conclusion was reached yesterday at a conference of the roads in Chicago, called to consider charges of rate cutting that were alleged to have been committed under cover of the blanket rate.

WASHINGTON, Sept 6. -- The President attended the performance of "The Isle of champagne" at the New National Theatre to-night. He was accompanied by Secretary Lament, and Dr. Bryant. The party occupied the first box at the right of the stage. Mr. Cleveland sat at the front of the box and the audience secured a good view of his profile.

Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy and his family arrived home from their visit to the World's Fair at 10 o'clock last night. They drove direct from the Grand Central Station, to the Mayor's residence at 7 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street.

After living to be eighty-three years old Mary Nagle, an unmarried Irishwoman, committed suicide some time Tuesday night by hanging herself with a leathern strap in her rooms, at 1,127 Second Avenue. The woman had been a domestic, and had saved enough money to yield her a sufficient income for her support. For several years she had lived alone in two squalid rooms in the rear on the third floor of the Second Avenue tenement.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 6. -- The Grand Army people will probably finish their business and leave for Home to-morrow evening. Already at the Union Station the jam of people leaving has began. The election of officers was brought up this afternoon and the three following were elected, practically, without opposition:

-- The "Select Few" Cyclers of Newark, N.J., will hold a century run to Turner's, N.Y., and return on Sunday, Sept. 24. The run will be a departure from the routes generally taken by "centuries." It is over the most picturesque roads within a handred miles of Newark, and leads through Sulfern, the fame Ramapo Volley, Tuxedo Park, and the finest part of Orange County.
Patrick Gleason, ex-Mayor of Long Island City, lain financial difficulties, according to his attorneys.
For Governor -- The Rev. LOUIS ALBERT BANKS of Boston.
-- Walter Brodie denies the charge of causing dissension in the ranks of the St. Louis Club.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 6-3:45 P.M.--Beet--Holders offer sparingly. Pork and Hams-Holders offer freely. Bacon-Holders offer moderately. Cheese -- Holders offer freely; American, finest white, easy, at 46a 6d; do colored, easy at 47s bid. Tallow -- Holders offer moderately; steady at 22s. Resin -- Holders offer moderately. Spirits of Turpentine -- Holders offer moderately. Lard-Spot-Holders offer moderately. Futures -- Holders ore not offering: prime Western, spot, dull at 42s.

-- A St. Louis physician is querying to know why marriage ceremonies should not be performed by doctors of medicine, instead of having the authority lodged in the hands of doctors of divinity and other ministers. He thinks it would be a good thing for this country if the doctors were given the power and exercised it properly.

RECENT DEATHS IN SOCIETY. -- The death at Charles H. Berryman at Newport on Tuesday has thrown into mourning a circle in society which has been unusually prominent for its brilliance. Miss Georgians, L. Borryman went everywhere in society in and out of town. At her home at 107 East seventeenth Street and at Newport she entertained a great deal. Mrs. Lorillard Spencer.

Francisco Gonzales, a Spaniard, thirty-three years old, of 50 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, was arrested last night on complaint of Mamie Carroll of 215 Pearl Street, who accuses him of threatening her life because she divulged the secret of his intended marriage with Mary Irene Davis of 1,109 Pacific Street.

The collapse of "King Solomon" at Eldorado has not introduced as much gloom into the entire Kiralfy family as one might suppose. These interesting people constitute what might be called, by him who seeks to be exact, two and one-half households. They are of the tribe of Imre on the one hand, of Bolossy on the other, with a solitary segment called Arnold wedged in between the two.

Nearly $60,000 was distributed among forty-five winning owners, trainers, and drivers as a result of Fleetwood's Grand Circuit harness races. Budd Doble's stable was the biggest winner, the three-year-old Margrave and Nancy Hanks accounting for the bulk of the money won by the Terre Haute trainer's horses. Monroe Salisbury owes most of his winnings to the great four-year-old Directum.

WASHINGTON, Sept 6. -- To the music of the Marine Band the delegates to the Pan-American Medical Congress, their wives and daughters and other female relatives to the number of 600, shook hands with the President this afternoon in the White House. The occasion was a reception tendered to the visiting physicians by the President, and it lasted from 5 o'clock until nearly 6.

METZ, Sept 6. -- Emperor William was entertained last evening at a banquet by the municipal authorities of Metz and the high officials of Lorraine. In his speech he thanked the people of Lorraine for the cordial welcome which they had given him and for the repeated demonstrations of loyalty which they had made dally during his sojourn at Urville.

-- Dr. Albert Shaw, editor of The American Review of Reviews, was married in Chriss Church, Reading, the cathedral church of the Episcopal Diccese of Central Pennsylvania, on Tuesday, to Miss Elizabeth L. Bacon, the ceremony being performed for the Rev. Dr. William P. Orrick, rector of the church. There were six bridesmaids, all attired in white and carrying pink roses, and two flower girls.

-- Three Irishmen sat in front of the clambake building and watched the crowd as it moved to and fro. Finally, one of the men who had been staring at the Roman notations on the New South Wales Building just across the way turned to his companions and said:
TROY, N.Y., Sept 6. -- Holmes Ide, one of the largest firms in the collar business, gave notice to-day that work will be resumed in their factory to-morrow.

BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 6. -- There was a peaceful invasion here to-day by 1,200 old fire fighters, who took complete possession of the village to this delight of nearly 10,000 spectators. It was the eighth annual tournament of the Suffolk County Volunteer Firemen's Association. Every town and village in the county that owns a fire engine had it here to be decked with gay ribbons, flowers, and with the metal work glittering in the sun.

A calm review of the work done by the First Naval Battalion during the week spent in Cold Spring Harbor leads to the conclusion that the time was excellently employed and that the efficiency of the organization was materially increased. The battalion as a whole received the benefit of eight days' experience in the routine of life aboard a man-of-war.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- Festival Hall has never been the scene of such a demonstration as broke forth, this afternoon during the progress of the Eisteddfod. For two hours the people of Cambria had been listening to contests in singing and the decisions of the literary critics.

After a very spirited game the Brooklyns won from the Browns at Eastern Part yesterday. Kennedy pitched a strong game for Brooklyn, while Breitenstein filled his position admirably for the visitors. The former won his game by scoring the winning run. "Tom" Daly made some timely hits, and Griffin figured to some extent in tallying runs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- The second day of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Philadelphia Driving Association was better attended than the opening day. The track was in grand condition for the last time and the weather was perfect.
The game is up. The veil of secrecy and misrepresentation is drawn aside. The depositors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn need wonder no longer where their money went.

BELFAST, Sept. 6. -- The Trades Unionist Congress passed to-day, by a vote of 137 to 97, a resolution "that labor candidates for Parliament who receive financial assistance from trades unions shall be required to pledge themselves to support the principles of collective ownership and State control of the means of production and distribution."

Prince Yorihito Komatsu ot Japan, a grandnephew of the present Emperor of Japan, is a guest at the Hotel Windsor. He is a Prince of the royal blood of the Japanese imperial family, and there are really only three lives between him and the imperial title of the Mikado. The present Emperor has only one son, a delicate youth of twelve years.

NEW-YORK, WEDNESDAY, Sept. 6 -- P.M. Somewhat of a check was given to-day to the upward movement in stocks. That such an advance as has taken place in the last week should be marked by a reaction, however, was entirely natural. As it turned out, few of the losses for the day were heavy, although a good many of the active shares appeared in the list of declines.
