-- M. Vlge of Tonlonse, France, who showed his collection of old French and Italian masters at Bonaventure's book shop, has taken his pictures to Chicago, where he hopes to find those buyers who failed to materialize in New-York daring the hot season.

Leonidas Merritt was seen yesterday in reference to the trust to be formed, with a capital of $30,000,000, among proprietors of iron mines in the Lake Superior district, announcement of which was made in The New-York Times yesterday. Mr. Merritt with his brothers in Duluth, are Trustees to represent the Mesala Range property.

There is a notable decline in the fervor of the talk among members of Congress as to the repeal of the tax on the notes of State banks. This is in part due, no doubt, to the fact that it is clear that the country has made up its mind to get the repeal bill through first, and put everything aside until that is done.
Dr. James Johnston of Jamaica, Went Indies, the well-known African explorer, arrived in this city yesterday, and la now at the Broadway Central Hotel.

The Grand Jury returned three Indictments against Emma Goldman yesterday for making speeches intended to incite to riot. Detective Jacobs, in whoso hands the requisition papers will be placed, will bring the prisoner from Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6. -- Local stocks have been buoyant. Metropolitan Traction advanced to 91 and Philadelphia to 80 1/2. Both stocks were in good demand. Baltimore Traction sold at 19 and People's Traction at 13. Money snows symptoms of easing up, and street-car lines, which, have always been, favorites, are being eagerly picked up.
An accidental shooting that came perilously near being fatal happened, yesterday morning in the police trial room in the Brooklyn Municipal Building.

MATAMORAS, Mexico, Sept. 6. -- It is learned here on good authority that the Mexican Government will make a strong and persistent effort to prove that the disputed island in the Rio Grande above here is Mexican soil. Col. Mainero and an engineering officer of the Mexican Army have returned from a visit to the camp of Major Keyes of the United States Army, where they spent some time conferring in retard to the trouble.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 6. -- Another big crowd attended the trotting meeting of the Northwestern Breeders' Association at Washington Park to-day, fully 6,000 persons witnessing the four races on the programme. While it will require several days' trotting to pack the track into perfect condition, some fast miles were made, and one of the events developed a very high class contest.

Morris Rivvo, a Russian pushcart peddler, thirty-five years old, who lived with his wife at 37 Broome Street, was run over and killed at the corner or Ridge and Rivington Streets yesterday by a wagon of the Bavarian Brewery of 240 West Eighteenth Street, driven by Louis Neufer.

One of the most conspicuous features of business down town yesterday was the appearance of lenders of time money in Wall Street after a lone dormant period. It is no longer difficult for business houses having good collateral to obtain accommodations at about the legal rates of interest.

Official notification of the chance in the anchorage regulations of the port of New-York, published yesterday in The New-York Times, was received from the Secretary of the Treasury yesterday by the United States Revenue Marine officers here having charge of the waters of New-York Harbor.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- At least 8,000 persons attended the big fair of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society at Waverly Park today.

The Giants only scored in one inning yesterday, and met defeat at the hands of the Cincinnati Reds. Chamberlain pitched one of those good games for which he is noted once in a while, and proved to be a complete enigma to the New-York batsmen. They only made four hits.

John I. Davenport, Chief Supervisor of Elections, who was ordered by Postmaster Dayton to vacate the rooms he had occupied in the Federal Building, asked Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court yesterday to grant an injunction restraining Mr. Dayton from interfering in any way with his occupancy of the apartments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Government receipts are still running low this month, the receipts from customs yesterday -- $79,000 -- being the lowest for any one day since war times. The total revenues for the six days of this month aggregate only $3,890,000, or about $650,000 a day, while the expenditures foot up $4,900,000, or more than $800,000 per day,

The east side banking and brokerage offices of B. Weinberger were still closed yesterday, and it is now believed that Mr. Weinberger will not return, at least not until the excitement of his many hundred customers has cooled down. Many of them stood in front of the main office, at 39 Essex Street, heaping dire curses upon his head, the wildest of which was the wish that he would get the black cholera.
To the Editor of the New-York Times: Permit me to say that the arrival of The New-York Times was eagerly awaited every day by the scientists at the meeting of the Fish Commission.

The new seven-story building at 47, 49, and 51 Pike Street was destroyed early yesterday morning by fire, which made rapid progress. When the fire was extinguished only parts of walls and a few twisted Iron columns were left standing, and these the firemen were busily engaged in the afternoon in tearing down.

SARATOGA, N. Y., Sept. 6. -- The work of the Department of Finance of the American Social Science Association Convention was began this morning with remarks by Frank J. Kingsbury on " Relative Value of Factors that Produce Wealth."

REMSEN R. HEGEMAN, a member of one of the oldest and wealthiest families of Flatbush, died at his home on Lott Street yesterday. Mr. Hegeman was fifty-three years old and the oldest son of Judge J. Hegeman. He was for twenty years an officer in the Supreme Court of Kings County. For eight years he was a Pinkerton detective. He served through the war.
The Commercial Cable Company yesterday sent out a message to all persons interested, which read:

Dr. A. Brodbeck of Hanover, Germany, who is known in Europe as the "apostle of idealism," has reached this city on his way to Chicago to attend the Religious Congress which will convene there next Monday.

NEWBUHG, N.Y., Sept 6. -- The women murdered by Mrs. Paul Haillday at Burlington, Sullivan County, were the wife and daughter of Thomas McQuilian of this city. He is a laboring man. His wife was a woman of fifty years and the daughter Sarah was past nineteen.

Mr. H.L. Ensign, President of the National Advertising Company, 114 Nassau Street, and a member of the New-York Athletic Club, returned from the Maine woods yesterday after enjoying one month's sport with the gun and rod. He brought with him the skins of a line bear and two wildcats, which he had shot after some exciting experiences, and a number of his fellow-clubmen have received hammers containing trout varying from one to four pounds each.

RUTLAND, Vt., Sept. 6. -- An attempt was made to wreck the New-York sleeper on the Bennington and Rutland Railroad near Wallingford early this morning. The nuts which fasten the needle teams to the tract cords on what is called the Childs Bridge were all removed, leaving nothing to support the bridge but the lateral rods.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6. -- A meeting of the National Commission was held to-day. It began with the reception, or Gov. Pattison and Lieut. Gov. Louis A. Watres of Pennsylvania. Gov. Pattison said he bad come with the Pennsylvania commissioners to celebrate their State day, and he was pleased to pay his respects to the National Commission.

Surprises were the order of the day at sheepshead Bay yesterday, and in some of the events the reversals of form shown were startling. Darfargilla was the first one to show that form sometimes does not count for much. She was the winner of the first race, and, with 15 to 1 quoted against her, beat a good field in the last time of 1:10 4-5.

Evidence are beginning to appear of a loosening of the purse strings as far as real estate loans are concerned. Several mortgages were made yesterday at 5 per cent. interest, and one loan of $20,000 for a year at 5 12 per cent. was made, after 6 per cent. had been demanded in valn. This is looked upon as a hopeful sign by operators.

The Paris, sailing yesterday, had among her passengers for Southampton Mr. and Mrs. H.H. Bradley, Mr. and Mrs. C. Hayden Coffin, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh R. Garden, Mr. and Mrs. James H. Reed, and Mr. and Mrs. George W. Sillcox.

LONDON, Sept. 6. -- The race for the St. Leger Stakes to-day at the Doncaster meeting attracted an enormons crowd. The royal family was represented by the Duke of Cambridge and Prince Francis of Teck. The peers present were numbered, by the score. The weather was warm and dull.

Bankers and capitalists generally are discussing with much interest the subject of currency legislation. The dispatches to The Times from Washington describing the desire of the Administration to find some practicable plan for increasing the volume of bank circulation without impairing the stability of our banking system have been widely read and the motive of the Administration is cordially approved.
SYRACUSE, Sept 6. -- Morris Tekulsky of New-York was re-elected this afternoon President of the State Wine, Beer and Liquor Dealers' Association by a vote of 192 to Murphy's 135.

RYDE, Sept. 6. -- The first one of the races for the International Gold Cup, given by the Royal Victoria Yacht Club, was sailed to-day. The contestants were the Prince of Wales's Britannia and Royal Phelps Carroll's Navahoe.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Sept. 6. -- James Pendergast, a livery stable keeper of Far Rockaway, was killed by an unmanageable horse at 1 o'clock this morning. The horse has a record as a runaway. He killed a former owner, and has run away with Pendergast repeatedly. The liveryman was a skillful driver, however, and declined to part with the animal.

Deep interest was manifested in financial circles yesterday in Mr. Isaac L. Rice's statement concerning the affairs of the Philadelphia and Heading Railroad which was published at length in The New-York Times. It was generally regarded as a clear and concise arraignment of the present management, and it was admitted with wonderful unanimity that unless the accusations it contained could be refuted the usefulness of the present administration had been destroyed.

The ladies of the Lenox Tennis Club finished their tournament contests yesterday afternoon on the club's courts, St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-third Street. Miss Elizabeth Goodchild from scratch carried off the honors, defeating Miss Wyeth (half thirty) in the final round, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Sept. 6. -- In the United States District Court here, Judge Ross, in the matter of Chum Shang Yuen, the Chinaman arrested under Section 6 of the Geary act, has given his decision, to the following effect:

Mayor David A. Boody of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon issued, in printed form, his patiently-awaited reply to the temperate article on the misgovernment of Brooklyn recently published in The Forum. The friends of the Mayor have for some time predicted that it was his Honor's purpose to dispose, to the best of his ability, of Mr. Edward M. Shepard's strictures on the public affairs of his municipality.
BOSTON, Sept. 6. -- The market opened irregular and continued dull during the morning. Several rallies were made, but the closing was generally lower, Atchison losing 1 point.

All of the cup defenders are now in the water. The Vigilant, Colonia, and Jubilee were last eight tugging at their anchor chains off the Atlantic Yacht Clubhouse at Bay Ridge, and the Pilgrim was bobbing up and down on the water off Stapleton. The Colonia was successfully launched yesterday morning from Downing Lawrence's yard. She was measured by Mr. Hyslop.

Every farmer knows how very tough may sometimes be the roots that spread in shallow soil, and the same phenomenon is to be observed in the minds of politicians. Senator CULLOM, for instance, cannot dislodge from his mind the notion that our present financial difficulties are largely due to the popularity of tariff reform in 1890 and 1892.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- The strong market of the last few days wound up to-day in a boom in local stocks. Metropolitan Traction, on urgent buying orders, rose to 95 1/2, Philadelphia Traction to 84 1/4 Baltimore Traction was steady at 19. United Gas Improment rose to 57. Lehigh Valley advanced 4 points, to 34, on the covering of snorts by an active trader, but there was a reaction at the close of 3 points.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The first keen anxiety on account of the cholera was noticeable here to-day. This afternoon it was reported that a charwoman employed in the House of Commons had died this morning of a disease with choleraic symptoms.

Groups of men who had deposited money in Bernard Weinberger's banking concern gathered yesterday in front of the three offices in Essex, Grand, and Houston Streets, as they had been told that the safes would be opened. Lawyer Jaworower, who represents several of the depositors and has secured an attachment upon the property in Weinberger's offices, said that the safes will be opened Saturday afternoon.

BOSTON, Sept. 7. -- The market opened quiet and generally steady. Boston and Maine and Fitchburg were the features, both being strong and advancing in price. The advance in Fitchburg is attributed by commission brokers to a meeting of investment orders. Toward the close the market became weak and closed fractionally lower.

WASHINGTON, Sept 7. -- All of the rumors about Assistant Secretary of State Quiney are set at rest. Mr. Quincy this afternoon sent his resignation to the President, and it was accepted. He will leave for Boston at once, and will devote his attention to the cause of the Democratic Party in that State.

The disclosures made in The Times yesterday relative to the Boston and Maine deal, particularly the publication of the terms of the contract between Mr. McLeod and Mr. Prince, created renewed interest in down-town circles. It was the discovery of that contract by the late Mr, Drexel which led to the forced retirement of Mr. McLeod from the Heading Company.
The yearly return to town has begun. The incoming trains are daily bringing hundreds back to the city, and the watering places and mountain resorts are the losers.
The renewed activity that has lately manifested itself in all branches of business makes a conspicuous showing in the rubber manufacturing industry.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The House of Lords was crowded this evening with people eager to hear the Earl of Rosebery, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, speak on the Home Rule bill. The scene was a brilliant one. Many Bishops and peeresses were present. In the diplomatic gallery sat several foreign Ambassadors. The space in front of the throne reserved for Privy Councilors was occupied by Arthur J. Balfour.

WASHINGTON, Sapt. 7. -- Col. Stump, Suprintendent of Immigration, Treasury Department, telegraphs that he has effected amicable arrangements with the Canadian Government, the steamship lines, and the railroads for the better protection of the United States from violations of the immigrant law. Superintendent Stump is now in Canada on this mission, which has been most successful, and only awaits the formal acquiescence of Secretary Carlisle before it is put into effect.

POET JERVIS, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Port Jervis was devastated to-night by a violent storm of wind and rain. It struct this village at 5:39 o'clock and lasted only about five minutes. The destruction wrought in this brief time was great.

About a dozen General Passenger Agents of Southern railroads assembled in one of the parlors of the Marlborough Hotel yesterday for the purpose of discussing a revision of the rules and regulations of the passenger department of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept 7. -- Patience is being nearly exhausted in Washington in contemplation of the slow work of the Senate with the repeal bill.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- The cruiser Columbia started, on her unofficial trial trip at 7:15 o'clock this morning, thoroughly to test her machinery. Her speed trial will take place on Saturday, and she will probably return to the Cramps' shipyard Sunday evening. The preliminary trial could have taken place a month ago, but the builders decided to await the return from Europe of Edwin S. Cramp, chief engineer of the company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Congressman Wilson, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House, has received a letter from Charles Stewart Smith, President of the New-York Chamber of Commerce, advocating the removal of the tariff tax on art. Mr Smith, who, by the way, is a Republican, says that, although a protectionist, he is of the opinion that the present tariff might be changed with advantage.

NEW-YORK. THURSDAY, Sept. 7 -- P.M. The stock market was weaker to-day, and prices generally suffered. The opening was below yesterday's close, but a little strength soon developed and caused small gains to what proved to be the best prices of the day.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Sept. 7. -- The Michael J. Donegan Association of the Eighteenth Ward, New-York, held their fourth annual outing and games to-day at Stanwell's Park. They arrived 1,000 strong on the steamboat Chancelor. Thomas Dooley officiated as Marshal. He had for aides William Savage and Frank J. Hughes. After disposing of a large breakfast, the party turned their attention to the schedule of athletic sports.

If the weather had been ordered it could not have been better for a test of the yachts in a race to windward. The wind was blowing strong from the south by east. It looked like a good club topsail breeze before the yachts stuck their noses outside the Hook, but when they neared the lightship it had freshened so that Capt. Haff lowered the Colonia's jack-yarder.

The New-York Baseball Club continued its down, ward career yesterday, when, with Rusie as pitcher, they lost a same to the Cincinnati men in seven innings. The visitors were superior both at the bat and in the field, as the following score shows:

There were very few yachtsmen around the New-York Yacht Club last night, many being kept from the club by the storm that came up. Many of those who were there, however, said that they thought that the race was a fair contest between the two vessels, but the universal regret was that the Jubilee and the Pilgrim were not in at the finish of the race.

There is peace in the Grand Old Party of this State, if its leaders are to be believed. They were led to say so yesterday, by the circulation of a report that Chairman Charles W. Hackett of the Republican Executive Committee had incurred the displeasure of Thomas C. Platt, and would consequently have to step down and out.
Ex-Senator Thomas J. Creamer has begun, a mysterious suit for $100,000 against Mrs. Fannie B. Fithian, one of the daughters of "Dick" Connolly, who was Tweed's Controller.

-- Among the deeds recorded in the Sullivan County Court at Laporte, Ponn., is one for four square miles of land, which a pious old farmer, Peter E. Armstrong, and his wife, conveyed to Almighty God and His heirs in Jesus Messiah." In consideration of His kind, protecting care in the past and present, and the exceeding great and precious promise of unending life.

-- Henry Irving sat through two boars of a play at the Chinese Theatre in San Fransisco without a smile. Being asked after ward about his impressions, He said that much of the noting was crude, as he had expected it would be, but there was some clever work in it, especially by a man who assumed the part of a woman and did it surprisingly well.

About the jolliest party to follow the racers over the course was made up of the guests of the New-York Yacht Club aboard the Iron Steamboat Taurus. Every member of the club had the privilege of inviting several guests, but there were comparatively few personal responses. The result was a party small enough to be thoroughly congenial.
Money on call loaned at from 2 @ 4 per cent. The last loan was made at 2 per cent.

EMMA M. CONVERSE of Providence, R.I., an astronomical writer of note, died of pneumonia at the Mountain View House. Whitefield, N.H., Wednesday. For more than forty years Miss Converse had been engaged in literacy pursuits, and in the early years of her toll was engaged in a wide range of educational work. For about sixteen years she had written monthly articles upon astronomical calculations, which have been widely reprinted in this country.

A closely-contested yacht race is never ended in the minds of the owners of defeated craft. There is nothing absolutely certain in yachting, and this uncertainty is half tee sport. The race between the Colonia and the Vigilant, like hundreds of other close races, will be disputed as long as yachtsmen "swap" views in all points save one.

-- The Bloomingdale Boat Club of West One Hundred and Second Street and the Hudson River celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the club last Sunday afternoon. A large number of visitors were present, and a varied programme of entertainment was very successfully carried out. A senior swimming race, three-quarters of a mile, was won by L.D. Urban, with George Segeritz second.

"JANE" AGAIN. -- "Jane" was put forward at the Standard Theatre last night. There was a fair house and a smooth performance. Charles Frohman will make no further use of "Fanny," but will keep "Jane" and Johnstone Bennett going at the Standard until "Charley's Aunt." which promises to be the funniest play of the year, is ready. Loie Fuller will do her snake dance at the Standard all next week.

There is trouble in the St. Augustine Protestant Episcopal Church (colored) of Brooklyn. When the rector, the Rev. William V. Tunnell, invited the Vestrymen forward to receive holy communion Sunday, the leading members refused. This caused comment at among the congregation.

A call for a meeting of the new Municipal Building Commission has been issued for noon next Tuesday. The 130 plans submitted by the architects who are competing for the opportunity of constructing the new building will then be formally opened. It will be only a constructive opening so far as the public is concerned, however.

The startling disclosures in The New-York Times showing how large sums of money were, advanced to the cashier and some of the Directors of the wrecked Commercial Bank of Brooklyn on their own discounted notes, some of which have already gone to protest, wore read by the depositors yesterday with profound surprise and interest.

It is natural that the experience of the Naniucket in the recent gale off Hatteras should have revived discussion upon the weathorly qualities of monitors. The reports indicate that she took great quantities of water down the hatches, through the hawse pipes, through seams in the deck, and between the deck and the turret, and that at one time it was coming in as fast as they could pump it out.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 7. -- The business outlook among the paper manufacturers is vastly improved over that of a few weeks ago. President Greenleaf of the Holyoke Paper Company says: "The manufacturers of Holyoke have been looking for better times, and their hopes are being realized. The Connecticut Mill which had been shut down for some time, has been started again.

Surrogate Rastus S. Ransom, whose term expires next January, announced yesterday that he is a candidate for renomination, and from the opinions expressed by bankers, business men, and prominent politicians of this city, both Tammany men and Republicans, little doubt is entertained that he will receive the unanimous vote of the convention.

CHICAGO, Sept 7. -- Two fast trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad crashed into each other this morning near Colenour, a small town close to the Indiana State line, and in an instant twelve lives were lost and nearly a score of other unfortunates were maimed and mangled. The dead are:
Warry S. Charles, Chinese interpreter at the Custom House, is under arrest on charges of blackmail.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 7 -- 8:45 P.M. -- Beet in fair demand; extra India mess steady at 75s, prime mess steady at 67s 6d. Fork in moderate demand. Hams and bacon in fair demand. Cheese in poor demand. Tallow and spirits of turpentine in moderate demand. Resin in poor demand. Lard -- Spot in moderate demand; futures in no demand; prime Western, spot, dull at 428 3d.

ROME, Sept. 7. -- The Brazilian Minister to Italy has Informed Premier Giolitti that the Brazilian squadron has revolted, and that the Government, although strong enough to preserve public order, will not be able to prevent the bombardment of Rio Janeiro.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Governor's Day dawned auspiciously, and with the early morning came the first stragglers of one of the biggest crowds Waverly has ever seen in the thirty-five years of State fairs. There were 30,000 persons and thousands of vehicles on the grounds. Around President E.B. Gaddis's tent there were local, State, and Federal officials of all grades.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7. -- Grey Dawn cut a tendon in the third heat of the 2:29 trot at Point Breeze today and fell an easy victim to sleepy Ned. The free-for-all race was called so late that but one heat could be trotted. The summaries:

Gennaro Bufaao, an Italian laborer, was killed yesterday morning at 8:45 o'clock at the little square near the Sixty-sixth Street station on the Ninth Avenue elevated railroad after he had tried to shoot two policemen and several citizens and had given Policeman William Bauer of the Twenty-fourth Precinct the option of being killed or of taking life.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The discovery on Monday last of two dead women at Burlingham, Sullivan County, buried in a foul grave beneath refuse in Paul Halliday's barn did not end the horrible crime for which his young gypsy wife stands charged. This morning Paul Halliday's body was dug up from beneath the floor of his own humble home at the foot of the Shawangunk Mountains.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7. -- James Messarie, an Italian, who lives on William Street, Belleville, died at St. Michael's Hospital this afternoon from the effects of toadstool poisoning. His wife, who is in the hospital, is said to be fatally ill from the same cause.

RYDE, Isle of Wight, Sept. 7. -- A strong northwest wind blew all this morning. The Channel was rough, and it was doubtful whether the second race for the International Gold Cup could be sailed to-day.
GARRISONS, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- Ex-Secretary of State Hamilton Fish dies early this morning at his country house, Glen Clyffe, Just outside of this village.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 7. -- Capt. John G.B. Adams, the new Commander in Chief of the Grand Army, was born in Groveland, Mass., Oct. 6. 1841, and spent his boyhood and youth in that locality.

A clever wagon thief for whom the police have been diligently searching for several days will be arraigned in the Tombs to-day. On Aug. 30 a truck with ten cases at cigars, valued at $5,500, was driven to the wharf of the Stonington Line, at Pier 36 North River. There was a long line of trucks on the wharf waiting to unload, and this truck was in the middle.

MONCLOVA, Mexico, Sept 7. -- The news has just reached here of the withdrawal of the Gubernatoral candidacy of Col. Jose Garzo Galam, the present Governor of the State of Coahuila, and there is much rejoicing over his action. It is reported that Miguel Cardenas, the opposition candidate, has also withdrawn from the race.

Why don't the Aldermen act finally upon the application of the Trustees of the Women's Hospital for permission to sell the present site at Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, Lexington and Fourth Avenues, and so permit the Trustees to build a new hospital further up town.

Hamilton Fish, who has been for many years one of the most honored citizens of New-York, was born in this city Aug. 3, 1808. He came of old and distinguished stock, his father, Col. Nicholas Fish, having been a colonial officer in the Revolutionary War, where he was a personal friend of Washington and the intimate and confidential associate of Alexander Hamilton, whose executor he became.

Expressions of surprise and incredulity were uttered in the offices of the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad in this city yesterday morning when a dispatch came from Terre Haute, Ind., announcing that Judge Brigge of the United States Circuit Court had sustained the appointment of G.J. Grammar as receiver of the property.

LOCKPORT, La., Sept. 7 -- A severe cyclone struck the pretty little town of Lockport, on Bayon La Fourche, at about 9 A. M. and left it a mass of ruins and desolation. Five persons were killed and many injured.

The State Civil Service Commission thinks the Board of Electrical Control should fellow civil service rules in making removals and appointments. The Board of Electrical Control does not think so, and for two rears has been dispensing its patronage without regard to civil service law.

A meeting of the New-York Cycle Dealers' Association was held at the Hotel Pomeroy on Wednesday evening to hear the final reports of the committees having in charge the arrangements for the dealers' race meet, which will be held on Manhattan Field to-morrow afternoon. Chairman Gilmour of Porter Gilmour, presided, and L.P. Browne, Jr., was Secretary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Secretary Hoke Smith has received the following telegram from Inspector Faison at Caddo, Indian Territory:

Bonnie Scotland was well represented at Jones's Wood and Washington Park yesterday afternoon. It was the thirty-seventh annual picnic and games of the New-York Caledonian Society, and every patriotic son and daughter of fair Scotland in this city was present.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Treasury Department has issued the following circular from the office of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Treasury Department has issued the following circular from the office of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue:

The American Protective Tariff League is instituting what it calls an industrial census. From his headquarters at 135 West Twentythird Street it is flooding the country with a circular, accompanied by printed blanks, in which it asks the co-operation of business men and others in what 18 evidently an effort to attribute the cause of the recent business depression to the present political Administration.

David J. Mackay, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad, left this city yesterday for Terre Haute, Ind., for the purpose of attending the bearing before Judge Briggs, in the United States Circuit Court next Monday, on the receivership question. He expressed the belief before departing that the appointment of G.J. Grammer as receiver would be canceled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- A dispatch sent from Washington yesterday about the proposal of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to impose a tax on certain certificates of deposit issued by banks and said to be passing as currency, caused some surprise and misunderstanding in parts of the country, and has caused Commissioner Miller to answer many questions to-day.
